I heard from my holy teacher, the Gaon, the Goodness of Hashem, Yehuda Aryeh Leibush, Av Beit Din of Vishnitz (author of "Ari D'Vei Ilai" zt"l), that a man asked our Holy Rabbi Elimelech zt"l, who said about one of those sitting in his Beit Midrash that he was a "Baal Gilluy Eliyahu" (one to whom Elijah is revealed).
He asked him: How is it possible that this is so? Does not the author of the Ibn Ezra not admit that there is currently a revelation of Elijah, as he wrote in his book? And presumably, he did not have a revelation of Elijah. And your honor also testifies that the author of the Ibn Ezra was a greater man than this man whom your honor says is a Baal Gilluy Eliyahu. So how is it possible that this is so?
Our Holy Rabbi Elimelech zt"l replied: The truth is indeed as I said. And I will preface for you a preface. Behold, Chazal said that Elijah is the Angel of the Covenant. And behold, Elijah flies across the world in four flights. And how is it possible that he is at every circumcision, for aren't all the circumcisions at one time after the time of prayer? And it is possible that at the time they are reciting the blessing on the circumcision here, they are reciting blessings all over the world also at this moment. And how can he be in two places at once?
Only, I say to you the matter, that Elijah, by bringing all of Israel back in repentance and saying "Hashem is G-d," merited a general soul of all Israel. And through this, at the time of the entry of children into the covenant of Avraham Avinu, then a part of Elijah's soul sparks and reveals itself in the child, and each one takes according to his value and root. And afterwards, when he grows up and walks in the good path, then that part of Elijah that he has is truly revealed to him.
And if so, this man sitting next to me, about whom I say he has a revelation of Elijah, in truth he has only a small part of Elijah. Therefore, according to the goodness of his deeds, he merited and the small part that was in him was revealed. But the author of the Ibn Ezra had a large part, and he did not have the power to rectify and clarify so that the magnitude of Elijah's part would be truly revealed in him. Therefore, he did not have a revelation of Elijah.
Source: "Sfat Emet" (Brezan) Parshat Matot, Page 118b

The "Ibn Ezra" wrote (Parshat Vayishlach) that there is a great virtue to the Land of Israel, that whoever has an important portion in it, it is like a portion in the World to Come.
And behold, all of Israel has a portion in the World to Come, as it is written "And Your people are all righteous." So too, all of Israel has a portion in the Land of Israel. However, just as for the World to Come one does not merit except according to the measure of good deeds, Torah, and Mitzvot which one acquires in this world, and "He who toiled on Sabbath eve will eat on Sabbath," so it is in the Land of Israel. For the Land of Israel to accept him and for him to have a portion in it, one needs to preface with Torah and Mitzvot.
And in the Shas, Berachot (5a), "Three good gifts the Holy One, Blessed be He, gave to Israel: Torah, and the Land of Israel, and the World to Come." And it seems that the Sages zt"l were particular about the order, and this supports this idea.
Source: "Shem MiShmuel" (Sochatchov) Kedoshim 5673, Page 287
Source: Yemei Habinyan

אַחֲרֵי חֲתֻנָּתוֹ יָשַׁב בְּוִילְנָא בְּבֵית חוֹתְנוֹ רַבִּי בִּנְיָמִין וָואלְף נֶכֶד הָרַמָ"א, פַּרְנַס הָעִיר. הוֹדוֹת לְחוֹתְנוֹ שֶׁדָּאַג לְסִפּוּק צְרָכָיו בְּהַרְחָבַת הַדַּעַת, זָכָה לְחַבֵּר אֶת חִבּוּר הָעֲנָק "שִׂפְתֵי כֹהֵן" עַל שׁוּ"עַ יוֹרֶ"ד וְהוּא בֶּן עֶשְׂרִים וְאַרְבַּע שָׁנָה.
בְּהַקְדָּמָתוֹ לְסִפְרוֹ זֶה הוּא כּוֹתֵב: בֶּאֱמֶת וּבְתָמִים טָרַחְתִּי טִרְחוֹת הַרְבֵּה וְכַמָּה יְגִיעוֹת יָגַעְתִּי, לֹא עָסַקְתִּי בְּשׁוּם עֵסֶק אַחֵר, לֹא נָתַתִּי שֵׁינָה לְעֵינַי וּתְנוּמָה לְעַפְעַפַּי שָׁנִים רַבּוֹת, עַד אֲשֶׁר הוֹצֵאתִי מִכֹּחַ אֶל הַפּוֹעַל מַחְשַׁבְתִּי. שְׁמוֹנָה עָשָׂר רַבָּנִים גְּדוֹלֵי הַדּוֹר, בֵּינֵיהֶם הַתּוֹי"ט וּמְחוּתָּנוֹ מַהַרְשַׁ"ק, הִסְכִּימוּ לְהַדְפָּסַת סִפְרוֹ זֶה.
בִּשְׁנַת תט"ו כְּשֶׁעָלוּ הַמּוּסְקוֹבִיטִים עַל הָעִיר וִוילְנָה וְעָרְכוּ טֶבַח רַב בִּיהוּדֶיהָ, עָזַב אֶת הָעִיר וְהִגִּיעַ לְלוּבְּלִין, בַּיּוֹם הָרִאשׁוֹן שֶׁל חַג הַסֻּכּוֹת הִגִּיעוּ הַקּוֹזָקִים לְלוּבְּלִין וְעָשׂוּ בָּהּ שַׁמּוֹת. הַשַּׁ"ךְ נָדַד מִמָּקוֹם לְמָקוֹם עַד שֶׁבָּא לְעִיר דְּרַזְנִיץ וְנִתְקַבֵּל בָּהּ לְרַב.
לְפִי הַמְלָצַת רַבּוֹ רַבִּי הֶשִׁיל מִקְרָאקָא נִתְקַבֵּל לְאַבַּ"ד בְּעִיר הַמּוֹרָאבִית הָלִישָׁה [הוֹלֶשׁוֹב] וְיָשַׁב בָּהּ עַד יוֹם פְּטִירָתוֹ. הַשַּׁ"ךְ לֹא הֶאֱרִיךְ יָמִים, אַרְבָּעִים וְאַחַת שָׁנָה הָיוּ יְמֵי חַיָּיו, מְעַטִּים וְרָעִים גַּם רָאָה בְּצָרַת עַמּוֹ בִּשְׁנַת תַּ"ח וְתַ"ט וְשָׁתָה בְּעַצְמוֹ מִכּוֹס הַתַּרְעֵלָה עַד תּוּמּוֹ, אוּלָם לְפִי מְעַט שְׁנוֹתָיו רַב מִקְנָתוֹ. בְּחִבּוּרָיו הַהִלְכָתִיִּים הֵאִיר נָתִיב לְמוֹרֵי הוֹרָאָה בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל.
נוֹסָף עַל סִפְרוֹ שִׂפְתֵי כֹּהֵן נִדְפְּסוּ "תָּקְפּוֹ כֹהֵן" עַל דִּינֵי תְּפִיסָה, עַל חִבּוּר זֶה כָּתַב רַבִּי יְהוֹנָתָן אַיְבְּשִׁיץ: הָכִי קָרָא שְׁמוֹ תָּקְפּוֹ כֹהֵן, כִּי בּוֹ הֶרְאָה עֹצֶם וְתֹקֶף חָכְמָתוֹ. בְּסִפְרוֹ "נְקֻדּוֹת הַכֶּסֶף" מַשִּׂיג עַל הַטַּ"ז, כֵּן נִדְפַּס "פּוֹעֵל צֶדֶק" קִצּוּר תַּרְיַ"ג מִצְוֹת לְפִי דַּעַת הָרַמְבַּ"ם. אֶת הַתְּלָאוֹת שֶׁעָבְרוּ עַל הַיְּהוּדִים בִּשְׁנוֹת הַטֶּבַח תַּ"ח וְתַ"ט מַעֲלֶה בְּסִפְרוֹ "מְגִלָּה עָפָה", גַּם סְלִיחוֹת וְקִינוֹת עַל הַגְּזֵרוֹת הָאֵלֶּה חִבֵּר, וּבִהְיוֹתוֹ בַּעַל עֵט סוֹפֵר מָהִיר, חָרַז שִׁיר מְיֻחָד לִכְבוֹד אָבִיו.
בִּרְבוֹת הַיָּמִים קָמוּ גְּדוֹלִים, מוֹרֵי הוֹרָאָה וּפֵרְשׁוּ אֶת דִּבְרֵי הַשַּׁ"ךְ. בֵּינֵיהֶם רַבִּי יוֹסֵף תְּאוֹמִים, בַּעַל "פְּרִי מְגָדִים", וְרַבִּי יַעֲקֹב מְלִיסָא בַּעַל "נְתִיבוֹת הַמִּשְׁפָּט".
נִסְתַּלֵּק א' אֲדָר א' תכ"ג. וּמְנוּ"כּ בְּהַעֶלִישׁוֹ.[הרב דוד הלחמי ז״ל, ״חכמי ישראל״ (ב״ב תשס״א) ע׳ פ״ח]

Thus writes the Chida in his book "Shem HaGedolim" (Part 2, System Shin, Letter 134): **"כְּבָר נוֹדַע שֶׁהָרַב זַ"ל קֹדֶם שֶׁחִבֵּר שַׁ"ךְ עַל שֻׁלְחָן עָרוּךְ יוֹרֶה דֵּעָה, עָשָׂה בֵּאוּר רָחָב עַל טוּר וּבֵית יוֹסֵף יוֹרֶה דֵּעָה, וְאַחַ"כּ חִבֵּר הַשַּׁ"ךְ, וְהוּא רוֹמֵז עָלָיו [=בְּשַׁ"ךְ לְשׁוּ"עַ] וְאוֹמֵר בְּסִפְרִי כָּתַבְתִּי..."** - "It is already known that the Rabbi zt"l, before he composed the Shach on Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah, made a broad explanation on the Tur and Beit Yosef Yoreh Deah, and afterwards composed the Shach, and he hints to it [in the Shach on the Shulchan Aruch] and says 'In my book I wrote...'"
The Chida adds further (there) to express his amazement that his delightful book "Takfo Kohen" on the laws of seizure, **"חִבְּרוֹ הָרַב זַ"ל בְּמֶשֶׁךְ חֹדֶשׁ אֶחָד בִּלְבַד...!"** - "The Rabbi zt"l composed it in the course of one month only...!"
The Chida summarizes his great astonishment at the great might of our Rabbi the Shach with a short sentence of great meaning: **"וְהוּא פֶּלֶא"** - "And he is a wonder..."
Actually, this is how his teacher and Rabbi, the famous Gaon Rabbi Heshel of Krakow, already expressed himself in his approbation to the Shach's composition on "Yoreh Deah", writing among other things: **"שַׁבְתִּי וְרָאִיתִי אֶת הַחִבּוּר הַגָּדוֹל שֶׁחִבֵּר הָאַלּוּף הַמֻּפְלָא, עוֹשֶׂה פֶּלֶא...!"** - "I returned (Shavti) and saw the great composition that the wondrous champion composed, doing wonders (Oseh Feleh)...!"
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Moshe Yaakov Kanner Shlita, "Tosefet HaModia", 5 Tevet 5768, Page 10

body_he: בְּעֶצֶם, הֲרֵי כָּךְ כְּבָר הִתְבַּטֵּא עַל רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ מוֹרוֹ וְרַבּוֹ הַגָּאוֹן הַנּוֹדָע הָרַבִּי ר' הֶעשִׁיל מִקְּרָאקָא, בְּהַסְכָּמָתוֹ לְחִבּוּר הַשַּׁ"ךְ לְ"יוֹרֶה דֵּעָה", בְּכָתְבוֹ בֵּין הַשְּׁאָר: "שַׁבְתִּי וְרָאִיתִי אֶת הַחִבּוּר הַגָּדוֹל שֶׁחִבֵּר הָאַלּוּף הַמֻּפְלָא, עוֹשֶׂה פֶּלֶא...!"[הרה״ג ר' משה יעקב קנר שליט״א, ״תוספת-המודיע״, ה׳ טבת תשס״ח, עמ׳ י']

It is told that in the years of Tach and Tat (1648-1649), when there were many decrees against the Jewish people, the Shach was forced to flee for his life from the fear of the wicked. Behold, the Shach's sister also fled from her father's house, and arrived at the house of a certain wealthy man who took her into his house and she became a servant to him. The Shach, upon coming to that city, also lodged in the house of that wealthy man.
The Shach settled down to study with diligence in a pleasant voice, as was his holy way. Behold, they heard the servant weeping in the other room. When asked the meaning of her weeping, she replied that in her father's house, her brother Rabbi Shabtai used to study with diligence in a pleasant voice, and since the voice of this diligent student resembles the voice of her brother, she remembered her brother Rabbi Shabtai, not knowing where he is and what became of his fate.
She told the wealthy man the name and identity of her brother, and finally it became known that indeed that diligent student in the house was her brother Rabbi Shabtai. The Shach blessed her at that hour that she should merit to see children and grandchildren engaging in Torah and Mitzvot and illuminating the world with their Torah.
Years later, she married the Gaon R' Yitzchak zt"l, and to them was born the Holy Gaon Rabbi Meir Eisenstadt zt"l, author of "She'eilot U'Teshuvot Panim Meirot".
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Natan Gestetner zt"l, Av Beit Din of Kiryat Agudat Yisrael Bnei Brak, "Chodesh BeChodsho", Tammuz 5766, Page 1

It happened with the Shach, when he was supported at the table of his father-in-law, who was great in Torah and exceedingly wealthy, that his father-in-law asked him that in a time of great need he should assist him in his business. He did so and succeeded greatly. Afterwards, when they asked again, he refused to engage further and interpreted the verse for him: **"אָמַר אוֹיֵב אֶרְדּוֹף אַשִּׂיג אֲחַלֵּק שָׁלָל תִּמְלָאֵמוֹ נַפְשִׁי אָרִיק חַרְבִּי תּוֹרִישֵׁמוֹ יָדִי"** - "The enemy said: I will pursue, I will overtake, I will divide the spoil; my lust shall be satisfied upon them; I will draw my sword, my hand shall dispossess them" (Exodus 15:9).
For the greatest enemy is the Yetzer Hara (Evil Inclination), as explained in *Chovot HaLevavot*. And behold, he knows that the Torah Scholar will not listen to him to neglect words of Torah simply. Therefore, he advises him that he will earn wealth and will not be so idle, and he will have his wealth for good deeds, in a way that his rectification is greater than his corruption. Indeed, eventually his intention is to draw him to his path little by little, and in the end, he will make him poor also, so that he will not be able to do good.
And this is "The enemy said: I will pursue, I will overtake," and in what way? "I will divide spoil, my lust shall be satisfied upon them, I will draw my sword," and afterwards "My hand shall dispossess him" - I will make him poor.
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Yehuda Segal Rosner Hy"d, Av Beit Din of Sekelhid, "Imrei Yehuda" (Brooklyn 5719) Page 74

The Gaon Rabbi Michel Yehuda Lefkowitz (Shlita) [zt"l] heard from our Rabbi [The Chazon Ish zt"l] who said about the composition of the Shach on the Shulchan Aruch, that we need to understand that the Holy One, Blessed be He, granted our Rabbi the Shach such Divine Assistance (Siyata Dishmaya) that He literally held his hand and told him: Write this word and write this word.
[See Tractate Niddah (73b): **"לְאוֹהֲבָיו מְשַׁגֵּר מִמַּה שֶּׁלְּפָנָיו"** - "To those He loves, He sends from what is before Him," and in Rashi there: **"כָּךְ חָכְמָה שֶׁהִיא לְאוֹהֲבָיו שֶׁל מָקוֹם, נְתָנָהּ לָהֶם מִפִּיו וְלֹא מֵאוֹצָר אַחֵר"** - "So is wisdom which is for the lovers of the Omnipresent, He gave it to them from His mouth and not from another treasury."]
Source: Rabbi Tzvi Yavrov Shlita, "Maaseh Ish" (Bnei Brak 5760) Part 2, Page 59

History holds a profound mystery: Why did the works of the young genius, the Shach (Rabbi Shabtai HaKohen), become the foundational text of Jewish Law found in every home, while the manuscripts of his legendary teacher, the great Rabbi Heshel of Cracow, were largely lost to time? The answer lies in a terrifying encounter between the living and the dead, a decree of death, and a sacrifice of honor.
It began with one of the most notoriously difficult sections of the Talmud: the Sugya of "Chavit" (The Barrel) in Tractate Bava Metzia. The challenge there is so immense that the Amora Rabbi Yochanan himself declared: "מַאן דִּמְתַרְגֵּם לִי חָבִית אַלִיבָּא דְּחַד תַּנָּא, מוֹבַלְנָא מָאנֵיהּ בַּתְרֵיהּ לְבֵי מַסּוּתָא" - "Whoever can interpret 'barrel' for me according to the view of a single Tanna [without contradiction], I will carry his clothes after him to the bathhouse."
Rabbi Yochanan was promising to serve such a scholar as a servant serves his master. For centuries, the greatest minds attempted to solve the riddle and failed.
But Rabbi Heshel, with his razor-sharp intellect, constructed a brilliant system that aligned the entire Sugya perfectly—or so it seemed. He presented this breakthrough to his elite students, and they were stunned by its apparent clarity. Flushed with the victory of his intellect, Rabbi Heshel prepared to deliver a public lecture to the city’s scholars. The night before, while reviewing his thesis, he exclaimed in a moment of dangerous confidence: "אִי ר' יוֹחָנָן" - "Woe, Rabbi Yochanan!"—implying that he, Rabbi Heshel, had finally bested the challenge that the great Sage thought was unsolvable.
At that exact moment, the candles in the study hall were extinguished by an invisible wind. Darkness fell.
The young Shach, then the junior student, was sent to fetch a light from the neighboring houses. He entered the first house he saw with a light in the window. Inside sat an old man, his face radiating an otherworldly awe and majesty, with a Gemara open before him to the very same page of "Chavit."
The old man looked up and spoke: "Know, my son, that I am Rabbi Yochanan. Your master believes he has solved the Sugya, but his words regarding me were heard in Heaven. Because of his slight against my honor, a decree of death has been issued against him. I extinguished the candles to bring you here, to give you a chance to save him."
The Shach stood frozen as the Sage continued. "I will show you the flaw in your master's logic—for he is mistaken. But to save him, you must do a terrible thing. Tomorrow, during his public lecture, when he reaches the pinnacle of his argument and the entire city is in awe of him, you must stand up and refute him. You must expose his error and humiliate him in public. The shame he feels will serve as his atonement and annul the death sentence."
Then Rabbi Yochanan made a promise that would shape Jewish history: "If you do this, I promise that your compositions will be published and accepted across the world for all eternity. But your master, who prided himself on his intellect, will lose his legacy—his writings will be lost, and his spiritual children will die."
The Shach returned to the study hall, shaken to his core, carrying the light and the heavy secret.
The next day, the great synagogue was packed. Rabbi Heshel ascended the podium and began to weave his brilliant tapestry of logic. The audience was captivated. He reached the climax, the solution to the riddle of "Chavit." Silence reigned—until the young Shach stood up.
With a trembling voice but iron logic, the Shach dismantled his master's entire thesis. He exposed the subtle error Rabbi Yochanan had revealed to him. The argument collapsed. Rabbi Heshel stood on the podium, his theory refuted, his brilliance dimmed before the eyes of the entire city.
But instead of anger, a look of shock and realization crossed Rabbi Heshel’s face. He listened to the refutation and whispered, "I swear by heaven and earth—this is not the human intellect of the young Shabtai speaking. These are the words of Rabbi Yochanan himself!"
And indeed, the decree was fulfilled. Rabbi Heshel lived, but his writings were lost to the winds of history. The Shach, who sacrificed his master's honor to save his life, merited that his works became the "Shach," the pillars of fire that illuminate the Torah world to this very day.
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Chaim Mordechai HaKohen Polov zt"l, "Likutim Sipurim" (Jerusalem 5762) Page 489

body_he: ר' יוֹחָנָן הֶרְאָה לוֹ מַה הָיְתָה טָעוּת הָרַרַ"ה, וְאָמַר לוֹ שֶׁעַתָּה לֹא יְסַפֵּר כְּלוּם וְיִתֵּן לְרַבּוֹ לְהַצִּיעַ אֶת הַשְּׁמוּעָה כִּדְבָרָיו, וְכֵן מָחָר יִתֵּן לוֹ לִגְמוֹר לִדְרוֹשׁ כֵּן בָּרַבִּים, וְאַחַ"כּ יַעֲלֶה הוּא (הַשַּׁ"ךְ) וְיֹאמַר שְׁרַבּוֹ טָעָה בַּדָּבָר זֶה וְיַסְבִּיר אֶת הַטָּעוּת. ר' יוֹחָנָן הִבְטִיחוֹ: בִּזְכוּת זֶה תִּזְכֶּה שֶׁחִבּוּרֶיךָ יִתְפַּרְסְמוּ בְּכָל הָעוֹלָם, וְאִילּוּ חִבּוּרֵי רַבְּךָ לֹא יִתְפַּרְסְמוּ (וְאָכֵן רֹב כִּתְבֵי חִדּוּשָׁיו שֶׁל הָרַרַ"ה אָבְדוּ בְּמֶשֶׁךְ הַשָּׁנִים, וְרַק מְעַט מֵהֶם נִדְפְּסוּ) וְזֶה יִהְיֶה חִלּוּף תַּחַת הַמִּיתָה, שֶׁיָּמוּתוּ יַלְדֵי רוּחוֹ. וְכֵן עָשָׂה הַשַּׁ"ךְ. אַחַר שֶׁדָּרַשׁ הָרַרַ"ה אֶת דְּבָרָיו בָּרַבִּים, עָלָה הַשַּׁ"ךְ וְהִסְבִּיר טָעוּת רַבּוֹ. כְּשֶׁשָּׁמַע הָרַרַ"ה זֹאת, אָמַר שֶׁיָּכוֹל לְהִישָּׁבַע שֶׁאֵין זֶה שֵׂכֶל אֱנוֹשִׁי שֶׁל בַּעַל הַשַּׁ"ךְ, אֶלָּא מֻכְרָח לִהְיוֹת שֶׁר' יוֹחָנָן בְּעַצְמוֹ אָמַר לוֹ זֹאת, כְּמוֹ שֶׁבֶּאֱמֶת הָיָה הַמַּעֲשֶׂה.[תולדות הרבי ר' העשיל במבוא הס' ״אוצר הרבי ר' העשיל״ שנד׳ בשנת תשמ״ם). ״נועם מגדים״ (ויזניץ) תולדות תשס״ג, עמ׳ ג']

The town of Kalish was in an uproar. The legendary genius, Rabbi Shabtai HaKohen—the "Shach"—had arrived. Though young in years, his fame had already spread across the Jewish world, and when he rose to speak in the local Beit Midrash, the hall was packed to capacity.
In the back of the room, hidden in the shadows of obscurity, sat a man whose external appearance betrayed nothing of his inner greatness: Rabbi Avraham Gombiner, the author of the 'Magen Avraham'. He listened continually to the Shach’s discourse, his mind dissecting every argument. He spotted a subtle difficulty in the Shach's logic, but his humility prevented him from standing up to challenge the guest publicly.
Instead, the Magen Avraham returned to his lodging and summoned one of his sharpest students. He briefed the young man like a general preparing a soldier for battle.
"Go to the Shach," he instructed, "and ask him this specific question. Now, listen closely: The Shach will undoubtedly answer you with this argument. When he does, you must counter with that argument. He will then likely pivot to a third proof—and when he does, you will trap him with this final question."
Armed with this intricate script, the student went to the Shach’s quarters. He presented the questions with fire and precision, parrying the Shach’s answers exactly as his master had predicted.
The Shach looked at the young student with piercing eyes. He sensed something was wrong. "Let us leave this topic for a moment," the Shach said. He began to quiz the student on other areas of Torah, only to find that the boy's genius was limited. The student stammered, unable to keep up with the Shach's lightning-fast mind outside of the prepared script.
The Shach smiled knowingly. "The sword is sharp," he said, "but the hand that wields it is not yours. tell me the truth—who sent you?"
Cornered, the student admitted, "I am an emissary of the Magen Avraham."
"If that is so," the Shach commanded, his voice filled with respect, "go back and tell your master that I do not want the messenger. I yearn to meet the source. Ask him to come to me."
When the Magen Avraham arrived, the atmosphere in the room shifted. As the two giants began to speak, the air seemed to crackle with electricity. It was no longer a conversation; it was a collision of mountains. They debated with a ferocity that only true scholars know, building towers of logic and dismantling them in seconds.
Suddenly, the door burst open. A man had been brought into the house for a Din Torah, a Torah judgement, but he was in a horrific state. His face was pale, his breathing shallow and rattling. He was clearly in the final moments of his life.
Panic rippled through the onlookers. "Rabbi!" they cried out to the Shach. "You are a Kohen! You must leave immediately! If this man dies, the house will become impure, and you are forbidden to be under the same roof!"
The Shach did not move. He did not run. He was deep in the fiery heart of a Torah argument with the Magen Avraham, and he refused to break the connection.
He rolled up his sleeve, his eyes blazing with a terrifying authority. He slammed his hand down on the table, shaking the room, and shouted in Yiddish:
"אִיךְ הֵייס וַוארְטְן!" – "Ich heiss warten!" ("I order [him] to wait!")
The room fell deathly silent as the Shach declared: "כָּל זְמַן שֶׁהִנְנִי פֹּה הוּא לֹא יָמוּת, מִמֵּילָא מֻתָּר לִי לְהִשָּׁאֵר כָּאן" – "As long as I am here, he will not die. Therefore, I am permitted to remain."
And the Angel of Death obeyed.
For as long as the Shach and the Magen Avraham continued their holy debate, the dying man’s chest continued to rise and fall, suspended in a miraculous state between worlds by the protective power of their Torah.
Only when the conversation concluded and the Shach finally stepped out the door did the man take his final breath, his soul departing the moment the pillar of Torah left the room.
Source: Rabbi Yitzchak Natan Kuperstock, "Sar HaTorah" (Jerusalem 5769) Page 33

**Or Tzadikim**
It was fluent in the mouth of our Rebbe [the holy Gaon, author of *Divrei Chaim* of Sanz, may his merit protect us]: A Chassid is only one who conducts himself according to the book *Or Tzadikim*. (Divrei Shalom).
Source: Otzar Hachaim - Minhagei Sanz (Jerusalem 5738), see references there

הָעִיר קָאלִישׁ כֻּלָּהּ רָעֲשָׁה וְגָעֲשָׁה. הַשְּׁמוּעָה עָשְׂתָה לָהּ כְּנָפַיִם: גְּאוֹן הַדּוֹר, הַשַּׁ"ךְ הַקָּדוֹשׁ (רַבִּי שַׁבְּתַי הַכֹּהֵן), הִגִּיעַ לָעִיר. עַל אַף גִּילוֹ הַצָּעִיר, שִׁמְעוֹ כְּבָר יָצָא בְּכָל תְּפוּצוֹת יִשְׂרָאֵל, וְכַאֲשֶׁר נֶעֱמַד לִדְרֹשׁ בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ הַמֶּרְכָּזִי, לֹא נוֹתַר בּוֹ מָקוֹם פָּנוּי אֲפִלּוּ לְסִיכָּה.
בְּפַאֲתֵי בֵּית הַמִּדְרָשׁ, חָבוּי בֵּין הַצְּלָלִים, יָשַׁב אָדָם שֶׁחָזוּתוֹ הַחִיצוֹנִית לֹא הֵעִידָה דָּבָר עַל גְּדֻלָּתוֹ הָעֲצוּמָה: הָיָה זֶה הַגָּאוֹן הַנִּסְתָּר רַבִּי אַבְרָהָם גּוֹמְבִּינֶר, בַּעַל הַ"מָּגֵן אַבְרָהָם". הוּא הֶאֱזִין בְּקֶשֶׁב רַב לְדִבְרֵי הַשַּׁ"ךְ, וּמוֹחוֹ הַחַד כְּתַעַר נִתֵּחַ כָּל מִלָּה. לְפֶתַע, הִבְחִין בְּקֻשְׁיָה דַּקָּה בְּמַהֲלָכוֹ שֶׁל הַדַּרְשָׁן, אַךְ עַנְוְתָנוּתוֹ לֹא אִפְשְׁרָה לוֹ לָקוּם וּלְהַקְשׁוֹת בִּפְנֵי קָהָל וְעֵדָה.
תַּחַת זֹאת, שָׁב הַ"מָּגֵן אַבְרָהָם" לְאַכְסַנְיָתוֹ וְקָרָא לְאֶחָד מִמֻּבְחֲרֵי תַּלְמִידָיו. הוּא תִּדְרֵךְ אֶת הַתַּלְמִיד כְּמַצְבִּיא הַשּׁוֹלֵחַ חַיָּל לַקְּרָב: "לֵךְ אֶל הַשַּׁ"ךְ," צִוָּה עָלָיו, "וּשְׁאַל אוֹתוֹ אֶת הַשְּׁאֵלָה הַזֹּאת. וְדַע לְךָ: הַשַּׁ"ךְ בְּוַדַּאי יָשִׁיב לְךָ כָּךְ וְכָךְ. כַּאֲשֶׁר יַעֲשֶׂה זֹאת – הַקְשֵׁה עָלָיו מִיָּד אֶת הַקֻּשְׁיָה הַזֹּאת. אוֹ אָז, הוּא יְנַסֶּה לְהָבִיא רְאָיָה מִמָּקוֹם אַחֵר, וְאַתָּה תִּסְתֹּר אֶת דְּבָרָיו בְּאֹפֶן זֶה..."
חָמוּשׁ בַּ"תַּסְרִיט" הַגְּאוֹנִי הַזֶּה, נִגַּשׁ הַתַּלְמִיד לְחַדְרוֹ שֶׁל הַשַּׁ"ךְ. הוּא הִצִּיג אֶת הַדְּבָרִים בְּאֵשׁ וְגָפְרִית, כְּשֶׁהוּא דּוֹחֶה אֶת תְּשׁוּבוֹתָיו שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן בְּדִיּוּק מַצְמְרֵר, מַמָּשׁ כְּפִי שֶׁחָזָה רַבּוֹ.
עֵינָיו הַיּוֹקְדוֹת שֶׁל הַשַּׁ"ךְ חָדְרוּ אֶת נֶפֶשׁ הַנַּעַר. הוּא חָשׁ שֶׁמַּשֶּׁהוּ אֵינוֹ כַּשּׁוּרָה. "הַנַּח לְנוֹשֵׂא זֶה לְרֶגַע," אָמַר הַשַּׁ"ךְ, וְהֵחֵל לִבְחֹן אֶת הַתַּלְמִיד בְּסֻגְיוֹת אֲחֵרוֹת. מְהֵרָה הִתְבָּרֵר כִּי בְּקִיאוּתוֹ שֶׁל הַנַּעַר מֻגְבֶּלֶת, וְהוּא הֵחֵל לְגַמְגֵּם מוּל מוֹחוֹ הַמַּבְרִיק שֶׁל הַשַּׁ"ךְ.
הַשַּׁ"ךְ חִיֵּךְ חִיּוּךְ מֵבִין וְאָמַר: "הַחֶרֶב אָכֵן חַדָּה, בְּנִי, אַךְ הַיָּד הָאוֹחֶזֶת בָּהּ – אֵינֶנָּה יָדְךָ. אֱמֹר לִי אֶת הָאֱמֶת – מִי שְׁלָחֲךָ?" דָּחוּק לַפִּנָּה, הוֹדָה הַתַּלְמִיד: "שְׁלִיחוֹ שֶׁל הַ'מָּגֵן אַבְרָהָם' אָנֹכִי." "אִם כָּךְ," פָּסַק הַשַּׁ"ךְ בְּקוֹל מָלֵא הַעֲרָכָה, "שׁוּב לְרַבְּךָ וֶאֱמֹר לוֹ: אֵינֶנִּי חָפֵץ בַּשָּׁלִיחַ. נַפְשִׁי כָּמְהָה לַמָּקוֹר עַצְמוֹ. בַּקֵּשׁ מִמֶּנּוּ שֶׁיָּבוֹא אֵלַי."
כַּאֲשֶׁר נִכְנַס הַ"מָּגֵן אַבְרָהָם" לַחֶדֶר, הָאֲוִירָה הִשְׁתַּנְּתָה מִן הַקָּצֶה אֶל הַקָּצֶה. לֹא הָיְתָה זוֹ שִׂיחַת רֵעִים, אֶלָּא הִתְנַגְּשׁוּת שֶׁל הָרֵי עֲנָק. שְׁנֵי הַמְּאוֹרוֹת הַגְּדוֹלִים צָלְלוּ לְעֻמְקָהּ שֶׁל הֲלָכָה בְּרִתְחָא דְּאוֹרַיְתָא, בּוֹנִים מִגְדָּלִים הַפּוֹרְחִים בָּאֲוִיר וְסוֹתְרִים אוֹתָם בְּהֶבְזֵק שֶׁל שְׁנִיָּה.
וְאָז, בְּשִׂיא הַוִּכּוּחַ, נִפְתְּחָה הַדֶּלֶת בְּבֶהָלָה. יְהוּדִי גּוֹסֵס הֻכְנַס לַבַּיִת בְּצֹרֶךְ דָּחוּף לְדִין תּוֹרָה. פָּנָיו הָיוּ חִוְּרִים כַּסִּיד, נְשִׁימָתוֹ כְּבֵדָה וּמְחַרְחֶרֶת – רְגָעָיו הָאַחֲרוֹנִים עֲלֵי אֲדָמוֹת. זַעֲקַת בֶּהָלָה עָבְרָה בַּנּוֹכְחִים: "רַבִּי! כְּבוֹד הָרַב הוּא כֹּהֵן! עָלֶיךָ לָצֵאת מִיָּד! אִם הָאִישׁ יָמוּת, הַבַּיִת יִטְמָא וְהָרַב יַעֲבֹר עַל אִסּוּר חָמוּר!"
אַךְ הַשַּׁ"ךְ לֹא זָע מִמְּקוֹמוֹ. הוּא הָיָה שָׁקוּעַ בְּלַבַּת הָאֵשׁ שֶׁל הַוִּכּוּחַ עִם הַ"מָּגֵן אַבְרָהָם", וְסֵרֵב לְנַתֵּק אֶת הַדְּבֵקוּת. הוּא הִפְשִׁיל אֶת שַׁרְווּלוֹ, עֵינָיו בָּעֲרוּ בְּאֵשׁ שֶׁל סַמְכוּת שְׁמֵימִית, וְהוּא הָלַם בְּאֶגְרוֹפוֹ עַל הַשֻּׁלְחָן בְּעָצְמָה שֶׁהִרְעִידָה אֶת אַמּוֹת הַסִּפִּים, כְּשֶׁהוּא שׁוֹאֵג בְּאִידִישׁ:
"אִיךְ הֵייס וַוארְטְן!" (אֲנִי מְצַוֶּה לְהַמְתִּין!)
הַשֶּׁקֶט הִשְׂתָּרֵר בַּחֶדֶר כַּאֲשֶׁר הַשַּׁ"ךְ הִכְרִיז: "כָּל זְמַן שֶׁהִנְנִי פֹּה – הוּא לֹא יָמוּת. מִמֵּילָא מֻתָּר לִי לְהִשָּׁאֵר כָּאן."
וּמַלְאַךְ הַמָּוֶת צִיֵּת.
כָּל אוֹתָהּ הָעֵת, בְּמֶשֶׁךְ שָׁעוֹת אֲרֻכּוֹת שֶׁבָּהֶן הִמְשִׁיכוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ וְהַ"מָּגֵן אַבְרָהָם" בְּמִלְחַמְתָּהּ שֶׁל תּוֹרָה, נִשְׁמָתוֹ שֶׁל הַחוֹלֶה נִשְׁאֲרָה תְּלוּיָה בֵּין שָׁמַיִם וָאָרֶץ, מֻחְזֶקֶת בְּכֹחַ הַהֲגָנָה הָרוּחָנִית שֶׁל לִמּוּדָם.
רַק כַּאֲשֶׁר תַּם הַוִּכּוּחַ, וְרַגְלוֹ שֶׁל הַשַּׁ"ךְ יָצְאָה אֶל מִחוּץ לְמִפְתַּן הַדֶּלֶת – רַק אָז יָצְאָה נִשְׁמָתוֹ שֶׁל הַיְּהוּדִי בְּאַחַת, בָּרֶגַע שֶׁבּוֹ עַמּוּד הָאֵשׁ שֶׁל הַתּוֹרָה עָזַב אֶת הַחֶדֶר.
[מְעֻבָּד עַל פִּי רבי יצחק נתן קופרשטוק, ״שר התורה״ (ירושלים תשס״ט) ע' 634]

I heard from my master, father, and teacher zt"l, the K"M, that the Holy Rabbi Shimshon of Ostropoli zt"l requested from the Shach during the decrees of Tach and Tat (1648-1649) that he accept upon himself to be killed for the Sanctification of the Name (Kiddush Hashem). The Shach answered him that he could not, because it was laid upon him to bring his composition to the light of the world.
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Yehuda Segal Rosner Hy"d, Av Beit Din of Sekelhid, "Imrei Yehuda" (Brooklyn 5719) Page 74

In the year 5724 (1964), when the Gaon R' Pinchas Hirschprung zt"l tested the students of the Satmar Yeshiva in Montreal on Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah, Laws of Mixtures (Taaruvot), and reached the end of Siman 110 where the Shach concludes his words: **"שָׁלוֹם רַב לְאוֹהֲבֵי תוֹרָתֶךָ וְאֵין לָמוֹ מִכְשׁוֹל"** - "Great peace to those who love Your Torah and they have no stumbling block."
He told us that he heard from his grandfather, the Gaon and Tzaddik R' David Tevel of Dukla zt"l, that the aforementioned conclusion was written by the Shach based on an incident that happened. Late one night, the Shach was pacing in his study, his mind burning with the fire of Torah. He was grappling with the final details of this difficult chapter. The physical walls around him ceased to exist; the floor beneath his feet was forgotten. There was only the argument, the logic, the truth of the Torah.
Pacing back and forth, he stepped out onto the balcony of his second-story apartment. He continued to pace, his eyes closed, his soul soaring in the upper worlds.
Inside the room, his wife, the Rebbetzin, froze in horror.
She watched as her husband reached the edge of the balcony. It had no railing. But the Shach did not stop. Driven by the momentum of his holy thoughts, he took another step—straight into the empty void of the night air.
But he did not fall.
To the Rebbetzin’s disbelief, her husband continued to pace, suspended in the air, supported by nothing but the holiness of his thoughts. He walked back and forth, turning in the air as if it were solid ground, mumbling the words of the Tur and the Beit Yosef.
She gasped, her hand flying to her mouth. Her instinct was to scream, to call out his name, to warn him. But she possessed a wisdom as deep as his learning. She realized that he was currently existing in a spiritual reality where the laws of nature—gravity, danger, death—did not apply. If she shouted, if she startled him and snapped him back to the physical world, gravity would instantly reclaim him, and he would plummet to his death.
So she held her breath. She stood silent, trembling, watching the miracle unfold, praying that his train of thought would lead him back to safety.
After a few terrifying minutes, the Shach turned and stepped back onto the stone floor of the balcony, and then back into the room. He sat down at his desk, picked up his quill, and prepared to write the conclusion of the chapter.
Only then did the Rebbetzin approach him. Gently, she told him what she had seen. She told him that for the last few minutes, he had not been walking on earth, but on the merit of his Torah.
The Shach listened, his face pale with the realization of the danger and the salvation. He dipped his quill into the inkwell and, with a trembling hand, added a final sentence to Siman 110 that remains printed to this day:
"שָׁלוֹם רַב לְאוֹהֲבֵי תוֹרָתֶךָ וְאֵין לָמוֹ מִכְשׁוֹל" "Great peace to those who love Your Torah, and for them, there is no stumbling block."
Source: Adapted from The Admor of Rachmastrivka Shlita, "Milin Kadishin" (Jerusalem 5766) Part 1, Page 134

בְּאַחַד הַלֵּילוֹת, בְּשָׁעָה מְאֻחֶרֶת, הִתְהַלֵּךְ הַשַּׁ"ךְ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בְּחַדְרוֹ, אָנָה וָאָנָה. מוֹחוֹ בָּעַר בְּאֵשׁ שֶׁל תּוֹרָה, נֶאֱבָק בַּפְּרָטִים הָאַחֲרוֹנִים וְהַדַּקִּים בְּיוֹתֵר שֶׁל הַסֻּגְיָה. הַקִּירוֹת הַגַּשְׁמִיִּים שֶׁסָּבִיב לוֹ חָדְלוּ מִלְּהִתְקַיֵּם בְּתּוֹדַעְתּוֹ; הָרִצְפָּה שֶׁמִּתַּחַת לְרַגְלָיו נִשְׁכְּחָה כָּלִיל. נוֹתְרוּ רַק הָאֱמֶת, הַסְּבָרָה וְהַתּוֹרָה הַצְּרוּפָה.
מִתּוֹךְ שִׁקּוּעוֹ הֶעָצוּם בְּמַחֲשָׁבָה, יָצָא הַשַּׁ"ךְ מֵהַחֶדֶר אֶל הַמִּרְפֶּסֶת הַפְּתוּחָה שֶׁבַּקּוֹמָה הַשְּׁנִיָּה. הוּא הִמְשִׁיךְ לִצְעֹד, עֵינָיו עֲצוּמוֹת, וְנִשְׁמָתוֹ מְרַחֶפֶת בָּעוֹלָמוֹת הָעֶלְיוֹנִים.
בְּתוֹךְ הַחֶדֶר, עָמְדָה אִשְׁתּוֹ, הָרַבָּנִית, וְקָפְאָה עַל מְקוֹמָהּ בְּאֵימָה.
הִיא רָאֲתָה אֶת בַּעֲלָהּ מַגִּיעַ לִקְצֵה הַמִּרְפֶּסֶת. לַמִּרְפֶּסֶת לֹא הָיָה מַעֲקֶה. אַךְ הַשַּׁ"ךְ לֹא עָצַר. מֻנָּע מִכּוֹחַ הַמַּחֲשָׁבָה הַקְּדוֹשָׁה, הוּא עָשָׂה צַעַד נוֹסָף – יָשָׁר אֶל תּוֹךְ הֶחָלָל הָרֵיק שֶׁל הַלַּיְלָה.
אַךְ הוּא לֹא נָפַל.
לְתַדְהֵמָתָהּ שֶׁל הָרַבָּנִית, הִמְשִׁיךְ בַּעֲלָהּ לְהִתְהַלֵּךְ, תָּלוּי בָּאֲוִיר, נִשְׁעָן עַל לֹא-כְלוּם מִלְּבַד קְדֻשַּׁת מַחְשְׁבוֹתָיו. הוּא צָעַד הָלוֹךְ וָשׁוֹב, מִסְתּוֹבֵב בָּאֲוִיר כְּאִילּוּ הָיָה זֶה קַרְקַע מוּצָקָה, מְמַלְמֵל אֶת דִּבְרֵי הַטּוּר וְהַבֵּית-יוֹסֵף.
הִיא הֵנִיחָה יָד עַל פִּיהָ בְּבֶהָלָה. הָאִינְסְטִינְקְט שֶׁלָּהּ צָרַח לִקְרֹא בִּשְׁמוֹ, לְהַזְהִיר אוֹתוֹ. אַךְ הִיא נִחֲנָה בְּחָכְמָה עֲמֻקָּה: הִיא הֵבִינָה שֶׁבְּרֶגַע זֶה מַמָּשׁ, הוּא מִתְקַיֵּם בִּמְצִיאוּת רוּחָנִית שֶׁבָּהּ חֻקֵּי הַטֶּבַע – הַכְּבִידָה, הַסַּכָּנָה, הַמָּוֶת – אֵינָם שׁוֹלְטִים. אִם הִיא תִּצְעַק, אִם הִיא תַּבְהִיל אוֹתוֹ וּתְנַתֵּק אוֹתוֹ מֵהַדְּבֵקוּת בַּחֲזָרָה אֶל הָעוֹלָם הַגַּשְׁמִי – הַגְּרָבִיטַצְיָה תִּתְפֹּס אוֹתוֹ מִיָּד, וְהוּא יִצְנַח אֱלֵי תְּהוֹם.
עַל כֵּן עָצְרָה אֶת נְשִׁימָתָהּ. הִיא עָמְדָה בִּדְמָמָה, רוֹעֶדֶת, צוֹפָה בַּנֵּס הַגָּלוּי, מִתְפַּלֶּלֶת שֶׁחוּט הַמַּחֲשָׁבָה שֶׁלּוֹ יוֹבִיל אוֹתוֹ בְּבִטְחָה חֲזָרָה.
לְאַחַר דַּקּוֹת שֶׁל מֶתַח מַחְרִיד, הִסְתּוֹבֵב הַשַּׁ"ךְ וְצָעַד חֲזָרָה אֶל רִצְפַּת הָאֶבֶן שֶׁל הַמִּרְפֶּסֶת, וּמִשָּׁם אֶל תּוֹךְ הַחֶדֶר. הוּא הִתְיַשֵּׁב לְצַד שֻׁלְחָנוֹ, נָטַל אֶת הַקּוּלְמוֹס, וְנִגַּשׁ לִכְתֹּב אֶת סִיּוּם הַסִּימָן.
רַק אָז נִגְּשָׁה אֵלָיו הָרַבָּנִית. בַּעֲדִינוּת סִפְּרָה לוֹ אֶת אֲשֶׁר רָאוּ עֵינֶיהָ. הִיא גִּלְּתָה לוֹ כִּי בַּדַּקּוֹת הָאַחֲרוֹנוֹת, לֹא הָלַךְ עַל הָאָרֶץ, אֶלָּא עַל כֹּחָהּ שֶׁל תּוֹרָה.
הַשַּׁ"ךְ הֶאֱזִין, פָּנָיו חָוְרוּ מֵהַהֲבָנָה שֶׁל גֹּדֶל הַסַּכָּנָה וְגֹדֶל הַהַצָּלָה. הוּא טָבַל אֶת הָעֵט בַּדְּיוֹ, וּבְיָד רוֹעֶדֶת הוֹסִיף אֶת הַמִּשְׁפָּט הַמְּסַיֵּם אֶת סִימָן ק"י, הַחָקוּק שָׁם עַד הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה:
"שָׁלוֹם רַב לְאוֹהֲבֵי תוֹרָתֶךָ וְאֵין לָמוֹ מִכְשׁוֹל"
body_en:
Regarding the toil and labor in Torah of our Rabbi the Shach zt"l, our Rabbi [The Chazon Ish zt"l] said that it is possible to think that the Shach, who composed at a young age such a comprehensive work on Yoreh Deah and Choshen Mishpat (besides other books he composed), surely did everything with wondrous speed... But it is not so.
For in a letter to his son, as brought in "Nekudos HaKesef" (on Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah Siman 34, Subsection 2), the Shach writes regarding a small detail in the laws of Treifot:
**"אֶתְמוֹל לָמַדְתִּי בַּמֶּה שֶׁהִקְשָׁה בְּנִי כְּמוֹ שָׁלוֹשׁ שָׁעוֹת בַּלַּיְלָה... אֲבָל עַכְשָׁיו קַמְתִּי בְּהַשְׁכָּמָה כִּשְׁנֵי שָׁעוֹת וְרָאִיתִי דְּלָא קָשֶׁה מִידֵי"**
"Yesterday I studied what my son asked for about three hours at night... but now I arose early for about two hours and saw that there is no difficulty at all"...
Behold, how much toil and labor the Shach invested in every detail!
Source: Rabbi Tzvi Yavrov Shlita, "Maaseh Ish" (Bnei Brak 5760) Part 3, Page 67

It is told that in the year 5408 (Tach - 1648), there was a great awakening and great expectation for the coming of our Righteous Messiah. There were knowers of hidden wisdom (Chen) who said that this year is hinted at in the verse in Daniel: **"בְּ'זֹאת' - בִּשְׁנַת תַּ"ח - יָבוֹא אַהֲרֹן אֶל הַקֹּדֶשׁ"** - "With 'Zot' (This) - in the year Tach - Aaron shall come into the Holy," a hint to the King Messiah. However, in the end, to the dismay of our hearts, it turned into the mourning of our dances; harsh troubles and terrible decrees passed over the People of Israel in the year Tach.
It is known that the Shach then published a proclamation, and in it he wrote: **"מֵאֵת ה' הָיְתָה זֹאת"** - "This was from Hashem," **"הִיא נִפְלָאת בְּעֵינֵינוּ"** - "It is wondrous in our eyes." In Heaven, they established the year "Zot" to be a year of miracles and wonders. However, **"זֶה הַיּוֹם עָשָׂה ה'"** - "This is the day Hashem made," as brought in Tractate Sanhedrin (98a) that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi asked the King Messiah: "When is the Master coming?" He answered him: "Today!" When the day passed and the Son of David did not come, Rabbi Yehoshua asked: "Did you not say - Today?" The King Messiah answered: "My intention was **'הַיּוֹם - אִם בְּקוֹלוֹ תִשְׁמָעוּן'** - 'Today - if you listen to His voice'."
And the Shach concluded: **"זֶה הַיּוֹם עָשָׂה ה'"** - "This is the day Hashem made" - if they fulfill the command of **"הַיּוֹם אִם בְּקוֹלוֹ תִשְׁמָעוּן"** - "Today if you listen to His voice" - **"אָזִי נָגִילָה וְנִשְׂמְחָה בוֹ"** - "Then we will rejoice and be glad in it."
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Grossman zt"l, "Lev Yisrael" (Jerusalem 5768) Page 209

body_he: וְיָדוּעַ כִּי הַשַּׁ"ךְ פִּרְסֵם אָז קוֹל קוֹרֵא, וּבוֹ כָּתַב: "מֵאֵת ה' הָיְתָה זֹאת" "הִיא נִפְלָאת בְּעֵינֵינוּ"; בַּשָּׁמַיִם קָבְעוּ אֶת שְׁנַת "זֹאת" לִהְיוֹת שְׁנַת נִיסִּים וְנִפְלָאוֹת. אָמְנָם "זֶה הַיּוֹם עָשָׂה ה'", כְּמוּבָא בְּמַסֶּכֶת סַנְהֶדְרִין (צח.) שֶׁרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי שָׁאַל אֶת מֶלֶךְ הַמָּשִׁיחַ אֵימָתַי אָתֵי מָר? עָנָה לוֹ הַיּוֹם! כְּשֶׁעָבַר הַיּוֹם וּבֶן דָּוִד לֹא בָּא שְׁאֵלוֹ רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ: הֲלֹא אָמַרְתָּ - הַיּוֹם? עָנָה מֶלֶךְ הַמָּשִׁיחַ: כַּוָּנָתִי הָיְתָה "הַיּוֹם - אִם בְּקוֹלוֹ תִשְׁמָעוּן", וְסִיֵּם הַשַּׁ"ךְ: "זֶה הַיּוֹם עָשָׂה ה'" - אִם יְקַיְּמוּ אֶת הַצִּוּוּי שֶׁל "הַיּוֹם אִם בְּקוֹלִי תִשְׁמָעוּן" - "אָזִי נָגִילָה וְנִשְׂמְחָה בוֹ".[הגאון רבי ישראל גרוסמן זצ״ל, ״לב ישראל״ (ירושלים תשס״ח) ע׳ ר״ט]
body_en:
The years 1648 and 1649 (Tach V'Tat) were years of fire and blood. The Cossack hordes swept through Eastern Europe, leaving devastation in their wake. Thousands of Jews fled westward, broken and destitute, seeking refuge in the communities of Moravia.
Among the stream of refugees arriving in the town of Holešov (Holleschau) was a young man in tattered clothes. He carried no possessions, only the clothes on his back and a mind that contained the entire Torah. He sat in the back of the local Beit Midrash, wishing to remain anonymous, refusing to derive any honor from the Torah he had mastered. This young refugee was none other than Rabbi Shabtai HaKohen—the Shach—whose commentary had already begun to revolutionize the Jewish world, though his face remained unknown.
One day, a complex Halachic dispute erupted in the Beit Midrash of the town's Rav, the elderly and revered Tzemach Tzedek (Rabbi Menachem Mendel Krochmal). The scholars of the town argued back and forth, but the solution remained elusive.
Finally, one of the scholars stood up and said, "I have seen a new sefer that was recently published called Siftei Kohen. The author discusses this very issue!" He proceeded to quote the Shach’s opinion.
The room buzzed with excitement as the scholars began to dissect the new commentary. "He means this!" argued one. "No, his logic dictates that!" countered another. The debate grew heated, with interpretations flying through the air—many of them missing the mark entirely.
In the back of the room, the young refugee listened painfully as his own intentions were misunderstood. Unable to restrain himself for the sake of the truth, he stepped forward from the shadows.
"Forgive me," the stranger said softly, his voice cutting through the noise. "But in my humble opinion, the author's intent is entirely different."
He then proceeded to dismantle the previous arguments and constructed a brilliant, crystal-clear explanation of the Siftei Kohen's true reasoning.
The Beit Midrash fell silent. The elderly Tzemach Tzedek sat motionless, listening to the young refugee's logic. His eyes widened in amazement. As the young man finished speaking, the Tzemach Tzedek reached up and grasped his own white beard—a sign of utmost seriousness.
"I swear!" the Tzemach Tzedek thundered, holding his beard. "I swear that this logic you have just spoken—I heard it from the author of the Siftei Kohen himself! It is impossible for anyone else to understand the depth of his mind so perfectly!"
He looked piercingly at the young man in rags. "You are him. You are the Shach."
The secret was out. The refugee could no longer hide. The author and his Torah had been reunited.
Source: HaGaon R' Kalman Yehoshua Babad Shlita, "Tiferet Meshulam" (Brooklyn 5761) Page 743

שְׁנוֹת תַּ"ח וְתַ"ט (1648-1649) הָיוּ שְׁנוֹת זַעַם וּבַלָּהוֹת. חַרְבָּם שֶׁל הַקּוֹזָקִים הִכְּתָה בְּאַכְזָרִיּוֹת בְּקָהִילּוֹת יִשְׂרָאֵל, וַאֲלָפִים נָסוּ עַל נַפְשָׁם, עוֹזְבִים מֵאֲחוֹרֵיהֶם בַּיִת וּרְכוּשׁ, נָעִים וְנָדִים בַּדְּרָכִים כִּפְלִיטִים חֲסְרֵי כֹּל.
בֵּין נַחְשׁוֹלֵי הַפְּלִיטִים שֶׁהִגִּיעוּ לָעִיר הָאלִישׁוֹי שֶׁבְּמוֹרַבְיָה, צָעַד אַבְרֵךְ צָעִיר, לָבוּשׁ בְּלוֹאִים, שֶׁפָּנָיו לֹא הִסְגִּירוּ אֶת הָאוֹצָר הַגָּנוּז בְּמוֹחוֹ. הָיָה זֶה רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ (רַבִּי שַׁבְּתַי הַכֹּהֵן). הוּא בָּחַר לָשֶׁבֶת בְּיַרְכְּתֵי בֵּית הַמִּדְרָשׁ, נֶחְבָּא אֶל הַכֵּלִים, מְסָרֵב לֵהָנוֹת מִכִּתְרָהּ שֶׁל תּוֹרָה, וּמְבַקֵּשׁ רַק מָקוֹם לְהָנִיחַ אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ.
בְּאוֹתָם יָמִים, כִּהֵן בָּעִיר הַגָּאוֹן הַיָּשִׁישׁ רַבִּי מְנַחֵם מֶנְדְּל קְרוֹכְמָל, בַּעַל הַ"צֶּמַח צֶדֶק". בֹּקֶר אֶחָד, הִתְעוֹרְרָה בְּבֵית מִדְרָשׁוֹ שְׁאֵלָה הִלְכָתִית סְבוּכָה. גְּדוֹלֵי הַלּוֹמְדִים הִתְנַצְּחוּ זֶה עִם זֶה, אַךְ הַהֲלָכָה נִשְׁאֲרָה רוֹפֶפֶת בְּיָדָם.
לְפֶתַע, קָם אֶחָד הַלּוֹמְדִים וְאָמַר: "רַבּוֹתַי! רָאִיתִי סֵפֶר חָדָשׁ שֶׁיָּצָא לָאוֹר זֶה עַתָּה, 'שִׂפְתֵי כֹּהֵן' שְׁמוֹ, וְשָׁם הוּא עוֹסֵק בְּדִיּוּק בְּעִנְיָן זֶה!" הוּא צִטֵּט אֶת דִּבְרֵי הַשַּׁ"ךְ, וּמִיָּד פָּרַץ וִכּוּחַ סוֹעֵר. כָּל לוֹמֵד נִסָּה לְפָרֵשׁ אֶת כַּוָּנַת הַמְּחַבֵּר בְּדֶרֶךְ שׁוֹנָה, מוֹשְׁכִים אֶת הַדְּבָרִים לְכָאן וּלְכָאן.
בַּפִּנָּה הָאֲחוֹרִית, הִתְכַּוֵּץ הַפָּלִיט הַצָּעִיר בִּמְקוֹמוֹ. הוּא שָׁמַע כֵּיצַד מְסַלְּפִים אֶת כַּוָּנָתוֹ, וְלִבּוֹ בָּעַר בְּקִרְבּוֹ. לְבַסּוֹף, לֹא יָכוֹל הָיָה לַעֲמֹד מִנֶּגֶד. הוּא נִגַּשׁ אֶל מֶרְכַּז הָאוּלָם.
"מְחִילָה מִכְּבוֹדְכֶם," אָמַר הַזָּר בְּקוֹל שָׁקֵט אַךְ תַּקִּיף, "אַךְ לַעֲנִיּוּת דַּעְתִּי, כַּוָּנַת הַמְּחַבֵּר הִיא אַחֶרֶת לְגַמְרֵי." בְּמִלִּים מְדֻדּוֹת וּבַהֲבָנָה מַעֲמִיקָה, הוּא בָּנָה מַהֲלָךְ מַבְרִיק שֶׁהֵאִיר אֶת דִּבְרֵי הַשַּׁ"ךְ בְּאוֹר חָדָשׁ וּבָהִיר. הַקֻּשְׁיוֹת נָפְלוּ אַחַת אַחַת, וְהַסֻּגְיָה הִתְיַשְּׁבָה כְּמִין חֹמֶר בְּיַד הַיּוֹצֵר.
הַ"צֶּמַח צֶדֶק" הַיָּשִׁישׁ הִבִּיט בַּזָּר הַצָּעִיר בְּהִשְׁתָּאוּת. כְּשֶׁסִּיֵּם הַשַּׁ"ךְ אֶת דְּבָרָיו, אָחַז הָרַב הַזָּקֵן בִּזְקָנוֹ הַלָּבָן בְּהִתְרַגְּשׁוּת וְקָרָא: "נִשְׁבָּע אֲנִי! סְבָרָה זוֹ שֶׁשָּׁמַעְנוּ עַתָּה – מִפִּיו שֶׁל בַּעַל הַ'שִּׂפְתֵי כֹּהֵן' בְּעַצְמוֹ יָצְאָה! אִי אֶפְשָׁר לְאִישׁ אַחֵר לְכַוֵּן לְדַעְתּוֹ בְּדִיּוּק מַחְרִיד שֶׁכָּזֶה!"
הוּא יָרַד מִמְּקוֹמוֹ וְחִבֵּק אֶת הַפָּלִיט. "אַתָּה הוּא," קָבַע הָרַב. "אַתָּה הוּא הַשַּׁ"ךְ." וְכָךְ, בְּתוֹךְ הֶמְיַת הַמִּלְחָמָה, נֶחְשַׂף מְאוֹרָן שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל.
[על פי הרה״ג ר' קלמן יהושע באב״ד שליט״א, ״תפארת משולם״ (ברוקלין תשס״א) ע׳ תשמ״ג]

It is told that the Shach zt"l had a large bowl full of red gold coins, and he would finger them with his hand while studying a difficult Sugya to expand his mind and for joy.
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Shlomo Zalman Ehrenreich Hy"d, Av Beit Din of Shamloi, "Drashot Lechem Shlomo" (Brooklyn 5739) Page 101

I heard from the Gaon and Tzaddik R' Yaakov HaLevi Sharer zt"l, that the Gaon, author of the Shach, used two holy names while writing his composition *Shach* on Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah and Choshen Mishpat. One was a name for swearing the quill, in order to write with speed the entire matter (perhaps also to direct the language well, and to be precise to a hairsbreadth in his pure language, and for this one needs Divine Assistance). And the second name was so that he would remember everything concerning that matter and the Sugya he was dealing with, and would not forget any Gemara or saying of Chazal that concerned the Sugya.
Source: Rabbi Mendel Gertner Shlita, "Mipihem U'Mipi Ketavam" (Brooklyn 5768) Part 2, Page 14

In the city of Vilna, the study hours of the renowned Shach (Rabbi Shabtai HaKohen) were sacred. During those fixed times, the door to his chamber remained shut. No matter the wealth or status of the visitor, the answer was always the same: "The Rabbi is learning. He cannot be disturbed." The silence of his room was heavy with the holiness of Torah, and the townspeople knew to wait with reverence until the session concluded.
One day, however, the impossible happened.
A simple stranger knocked at the door. To the astonishment of the students waiting outside, the door creaked open immediately. The Shach did not merely glance out; he stood to his full height, interrupting his profound studies. He welcomed the man warmly, exchanged a few quiet words, and then—breaking all precedent—walked the stranger all the way out to the street, escorting him with the dignity reserved for royalty.
The crowd of petitioners waiting in the antechamber exchanged hopeful glances. If the Rabbi has interrupted his learning for this man, they reasoned, surely the session is over. He will receive us now, too. They assumed the visitor must have been a hidden tzaddik (righteous man) or carrying a matter of life and death.
But as soon as he returned, the door was closed again. The Shach continued the learning  at his Gemara, and the silence of deep study resumed. He would see no one else.
One student, bolder than the rest, could not contain his curiosity. When the doors finally opened later that day, he approached the Shach trembling. "Rebbe," he asked, "forgive me, but we are confused. You broke your holy custom for that stranger. Why could you not receive the rest of us?"
The Shach’s face turned grave. His voice dropped to a whisper. "I did not interrupt my study for a living man," he revealed. "With that visitor, I was fulfilling the commandment of Halevayat HaMet—escorting the dead. I saw with clarity that he is destined to be murdered by bandits on the road. Heaven forbid, his time has come."
The student stood frozen, the blood draining from his face. Dead? But he just walked out! A desperate thought seized him: If I know this, perhaps I can change it.
Without asking permission, the student bolted from the house. He ran through the winding streets of Vilna, breath tearing at his lungs, scanning the road for the stranger. Finally, he spotted him walking toward the outskirts of the city.
"Stop! Stop!" the student cried, catching up to him, panting. "You must come back! It is dangerous!" He poured out everything the Shach had said, pleading with the man to return to the safety of the city walls.
Terrified by the prediction of the holy Rabbi, the stranger agreed. Together, they turned back toward the safety of the Jewish quarter.
They were walking past a military guard post, safe within the city limits. Suddenly—CRACK.
A rifle fired. A soldier, cleaning his weapon, had triggered it by mistake. The bullet went astray, striking the stranger in the chest. He collapsed and died on the spot.
The student stood over the body, horrified. He had tried to outrun fate, yet death had found the man exactly as predicted, only here, on a city street, instead of the forest road. Crushed by guilt, thinking his interference had somehow caused this, the student ran back to the Shach, tears streaming down his face.
"Rebbe!" he cried, recounting the tragedy. "I tried to save him, but he died anyway! Is his blood on my hands?"
The Shach looked at him with eyes that seemed to see across worlds. "You certainly require atonement for interfering," the Shach said gently but firmly. "You see, the decree was sealed. He was destined to die today. But had he continued on his way, he would have been killed by a band of ruthless murderers in the forest. The noise of that attack would have alerted the authorities, and those murderers would have been caught."
The Shach sighed, a sound full of pain. "Now that he has died here by accident, those murderers remain free in the forest. Heaven have mercy, but two more Jews will now have to perish before those bandits are finally captured and removed from the world."
Source: Rabbi Chaim Mordechai HaKohen Polov zt"l, "Likutim Sipurim" (Jerusalem 5762) Page 489

פַּעַם הִגִּיעַ אֵלָיו אֶחָד, וְהַשַּׁ"ךְ קָם מִיָּד מִלְּפָנָיו מְלֹא קוֹמָתוֹ וְהִפְסִיק מִלִּימוּדוֹ. הוּא דִּיבֵּר אִתּוֹ מַה שֶּׁדִּיבֵּר, וְלִיוּוָהוּ עַד מִחוּץ לְבֵיתוֹ. מִכֵּיוָן שֶׁכּוּלָּם יָדְעוּ אֶת דַּרְכּוֹ וּמִנְהָגוֹ שֶׁלֹּא הִפְסִיק מֵעוֹלָם מִלִּימוּדוֹ, סְבוּרִים הָיוּ שֶׁמִּכֵּיוָן שֶׁהַפַּעַם הִפְסִיק מִלִּימוּדוֹ, בְּוַדַּאי יְקַבֵּל גַּם אֶת כָּל אֵלֶּה שֶׁהִמְתִּינוּ לוֹ. גַּם לֹא הָיָה סָפֵק אֶצְלָם, כִּי מִי שֶׁבָּא אֵלָיו וְהִפְסִיק מִלִּימוּדוֹ בִּגְלָלוֹ, הוּא אָדָם גָּדוֹל וְצַדִּיק, אֲשֶׁר הָי' לוֹ עִנְיָן נָחוּץ מְאֹד - אֲבָל הַנָּחָתָם הִתְבַּדְּתָה; אַחֲרֵי שֶׁלִּיוּוָהוּ, חָזַר לְלִמּוּדוֹ וְלֹא קִיבֵּל אִישׁ עַד גְּמַר לִמּוּדוֹ, כְּמִנְהָגוֹ מִדֵּי יוֹם.
הָי' שָׁם אֶחָד שֶׁאָזַר אוֹמֶץ וְהִרְהִיב לִשְׁאוֹל אֶצְלוֹ: רַבֵּינוּ, כֵּיוָן שֶׁכְּבָר הִפְסַקְתֶּם מִלִּימוּדְכֶם לִכְבוֹד הָאִישׁ הַהוּא, הֱיִיתֶם יְכוֹלִים כְּבָר לְקַבֵּל אֶת כּוּלָּם! הֵשִׁיב לוֹ הַשַּׁ"ךְ: בְּאִישׁ זֶה קִיַּמְתִּי מִצְוַת הַלְוָיַת הַמֵּת, מִכֵּיוָן שֶׁעוֹמֵד לְהֵירָצַח בְּהִילּוּכוֹ ע"י רוֹצְחִים ר"ל. הַשּׁוֹאֵל הִתְפַּעֵל מְאֹד מֵהַדְּבָרִים, אַךְ פֶּלֶא הָיָה בְּעֵינָיו: מַדּוּעַ, אִם כֵּן, לֹא אָמַר לוֹ הַשַּׁ"ךְ שֶׁלֹּא לְהַמְשִׁיךְ לָלֶכֶת לְדַרְכּוֹ?
הֶחְלִיט הַשּׁוֹאֵל לָרוּץ אַחַר הָאִישׁ וּלְהַחֲזִירוֹ. לְאַחַר שֶׁחָקַר וְהִתְעַנְיֵין בְּאֵיזוֹ דֶּרֶךְ הָלַךְ - רָץ אַחֲרָיו עַד שֶׁהִשִּׂיגוֹ. הוּא סִיפֵּר לוֹ כָּל מַה שֶׁשָּׁמַע מִבַּעַל הַשַּׁ"ךְ אוֹדוֹתָיו, וְהַחֲזִירוֹ הָעִירָה.
וַיְהִי בְּהַלְכָם, עָבְרוּ בְּמָקוֹם שָׁם עָמְדוּ אַנְשֵׁי חַיִל עַל מִשְׁמַרְתָּם; אוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה נִפְלַט כַּדּוּר מִקְּנֵה-הָרוֹבֶה שֶׁל חַיָּל, שֶׁלֹּא בְּכַוָּנָה, וּפָגַע בְּאִישׁ זֶה שֶׁנֶּהֱרַג ר"ל בַּמָּקוֹם - - -
הָאִישׁ-הַשּׁוֹאֵל שֶׁהֶחֱזִירוֹ נִבְהַל מְאֹד, בְּחָשְׁבוֹ שֶׁאוּלַי הוּא מִתְחַיֵּב בְּדָמוֹ שֶׁל הָאִישׁ. הוּא מִהֵר חֲזָרָה אֶל הַשַּׁ"ךְ וְסִיפֵּר לוֹ מַה שֶׁקָּרָה. אָמַר לוֹ הַשַּׁ"ךְ: בְּוַדַּאי אַתָּה צָרִיךְ כַּפָּרָה; אָמְנָם הַנִּרְצָח הָיָה נֶהֱרָג גַּם בְּלָאו-הָכִי, אַךְ לֹא כָּאן אֶלָּא בְּמָקוֹם מְרוּחָק מִכָּאן, בְּאֶמְצַע הַיַּעַר, וְעַל יְדֵי הֲרִיגָתוֹ הָיוּ נִתְפָּסִים הָרוֹצְחִים הַנִּמְצָאִים שָׁם, וְכָעֵת יִצְטָרְכוּ לַהֲרֹג ר"ל עוֹד שְׁנֵי יְהוּדִים עַד שֶׁיִּתָּפְסוּ הָרוֹצְחִים וִיבַעֲרוּ אוֹתָם מִן הָעוֹלָם! (מַהַרְשַׁ"ג זַ"ל) (מִכָּאן רוֹאִים עַד כַּמָּה צָרִיךְ לְהִזָּהֵר; מִכֵּיוָן שֶׁהַשַּׁ"ךְ לֹא אָמַר לוֹ כְּלוּם, הָי' צָרִיךְ לְהָבִין שֶׁאִי אֶפְשָׁר הַדָּבָר בְּאֹפֶן אַחֵר! וְה' יִשְׁמֹר אֶת כָּל יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּכָל מָקוֹם שֶׁהֵם, אָמֵן).[הגה״ח רבי חיים מרדכי הכהן פולוב ז״ל, מחשובי חסידי חב״ד, ״לקוטי ספורים״ (ירושלים תשס״ב) ע׳ תפ״ט]
body_en:
The Holy Rabbi of Huniad zt"l was the son-in-law of the Holy Gaon Rabbi Zev Goldberger zt"l, Av Beit Din of Huniad. The Holy Rabbi Zev of Huniad was the son of the Holy Rabbi Baruch Goldberger zt"l of Manosh. The Holy Rabbi Baruch of Manosh was the son-in-law of the Holy Rabbi Michael of Manosh zt"l, brother of the Holy Rabbi Yosef zt"l. The two brothers were Chassidim of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zt"l, and were natives of the city "Holleschau". Their father, Rabbi Yaakov, was a descendant of the Shach, and he received as an inheritance the house where the Shach lived.
Once, the two aforementioned brothers arrived to visit their father, Rabbi Yaakov, in "Holleschau". The matter was on Sabbath eve, and when their father went to the Beit Midrash, he boasted before those present that he had important guests. Are they not his holy sons? However, he waited for them in vain, and they did not arrive at the Beit Midrash. After the prayer, their father went home ashamed and humiliated, after boasting of his guests and they did not arrive at the Beit Midrash. When he arrived home, he found his sons in his house, and they asked him immediately: In which room did the Shach sit and engage in Torah? He answered them that it was the room he gave them to lodge in. And he said that he does not use that room at all, and only for the honor of his important guests did he give them this room.
His sons answered and said to him, that they felt a wondrous light inside the room, to the point that they could not leave the room due to the great light that prevailed in it, and therefore they did not arrive at the Beit Midrash.
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Moshe Aryeh Freund zt"l, Av Beit Din of the Eda Haredit, "Pitgamin Kadishin", 25 Adar 5762, Page 17
Source: Lev Yisrael

body_he: פַּעַם הִגִּיעוּ שְׁנֵי הָאַחִים הַנִּזְכָּרִים לְבַקֵּר אֶת אֲבִיהֶם רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב בְּ"הֶעָלִישׁוֹי". הַדָּבָר הָיָה בְּעֶרֶב שַׁבָּת קֹדֶשׁ, וְכַאֲשֶׁר הָלַךְ אֲבִיהֶם לְבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ, הִתְפָּאֵר בִּפְנֵי הַנּוֹכְחִים שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ אוֹרְחִים חֲשׁוּבִים. הֲלֹא הֵם בָּנָיו הַקְּדוֹשִׁים. אוּלָם הוּא חִיכָּה עֲלֵיהֶם עַד בּוֹשׁ, וְהֵם לֹא הִגִּיעוּ לְבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ. אַחֲרֵי הַתְּפִילָה הָלַךְ אֲבִיהֶם לְבֵיתוֹ בּוֹשׁ וְנִכְלָם, אַחֲרֵי שֶׁהִתְפָּאֵר בְּאוֹרְחָיו, וְהֵם לֹא הִגִּיעוּ לְבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ. כַּאֲשֶׁר הִגִּיעַ לְבֵיתוֹ, מָצָא אֶת בָּנָיו בְּבֵיתוֹ, וְהֵם שְׁאָלוּהוּ מִיָּד, בְּאֵיזֶה חֶדֶר הָיָה הַשַּׁ"ךְ יוֹשֵׁב וְעוֹסֵק בַּתּוֹרָה. הוּא עָנָה לָהֶם, כִּי הוּא אוֹתוֹ הַחֶדֶר אֲשֶׁר מָסַר לָהֶם לְהִתְאַכְסֵן בּוֹ. וְאָמַר, שֶׁהוּא אֵינוֹ מִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ כְּלָל בַּחֶדֶר זֶה, וְרַק לִכְבוֹד אוֹרְחָיו הַחֲשׁוּבִים, מָסַר לָהֶם זֶה הַחֶדֶר. עָנוּ בָּנָיו וְאָמְרוּ לוֹ, שֶׁהֵם הִרְגִּישׁוּ אוֹר נִפְלָא מְאֹד בְּתוֹךְ הַחֶדֶר, עַד שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה אֶפְשָׁר לָהֶם לָצֵאת מִתּוֹךְ הַחֶדֶר, מֵחֲמַת הָאוֹר הָרַב אֲשֶׁר שָׁרַר בּוֹ, וְלָכֵן לֹא הִגִּיעוּ לְבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ.[הגה״צ רבי משה אריה פריינד זצ״ל, גאב״ד העדה החרדית, ״פתגמין קדישין״, כ״ה אדר תשס״ב, ע׳ י״ז]
body_en:
I sat in the house of my father-in-law, Maran HaGrish (Rabbi Yosef Shalom) Elyashiv Shlita, and I looked into the introduction of the Shach to his book on Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah, where the author describes how much toil he labored in this composition.
And so writes the Shach in his introduction there: **"אַף כִּי בֶּאֱמֶת וּבְתָמִים טָרַחְתִּי טִרְחוֹת הַרְבֵּה וְכַמָּה יְגִיעוֹת יָגַעְתִּי, לֹא עָסַקְתִּי בְּשׁוּם עֵסֶק אַחֵר, לֹא נָתַתִּי שֵׁינָה וּתְנוּמָה לְעַפְעַפַּי. שָׁנִים רַבּוֹת, עַד אֲשֶׁר הוֹצֵאתִי מִכֹּחַ אֶל הַפּוֹעַל מַחֲשַׁבְתִּי וּבֵרַרְתִּי וְשָׁקַלְתִּי הַכֹּל בְּכַף מֹאזְנַיִם, וְחָזַרְתִּי עַל כָּל צְדָדִים וְצִדְדֵי צְדָדִים לֹא פַּעַם וּשְׁתַּיִם כִּי אִם מֵאָה פְּעָמִים וְאֶחָד עִם חֲבֵרִים חֲשׁוּבִים אֲהוּבִים חֲבִיבִים וַעֲרֵבִים הַמַּקְשִׁיבִים לְקוֹלִי, וּמִי שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה אִתִּי בִּמְחִיצָתִי לֹא יַאֲמִין כִּי יְסוּפַר לוֹ מִגֹּדֶל הַתְּלָאָה שֶׁהָיְתָה עָלַי בְּחִפּוּשׂ בְּיַם הַתַּלְמוּד וְהַפּוֹסְקִים עַד כִּי הֶעֱמַדְתִּי הַכֹּל עַל בּוּרְיוֹ"** - "Although in truth and sincerity I toiled many toils and labored many labors, I did not engage in any other business, I did not give sleep or slumber to my eyelids. For many years, until I brought my thought from potential to actual, and I clarified and weighed everything in the scales, and I went over all sides and sides of sides not once or twice but a hundred and one times with important, beloved, dear, and pleasant colleagues who listened to my voice. And whoever was not with me in my presence would not believe if told of the magnitude of the weariness that was upon me in searching in the sea of the Talmud and Poskim until I established everything clearly." End quote.
And behold, when my father-in-law saw me looking into this introduction, he said that it is a tradition with him that during the period of the decrees of Tach and Tat (1648-1649), a decree of annihilation was decreed, Heaven forbid, upon the entire Jewish people. In exchange for this, it was decided in the Heavenly Court to take three of the giants of the generation from the world.
HaGrish Elyashiv said that according to the tradition in his hands, one of them was Rabbi Shimshon of Ostropoli. He did not detail the name of the second. And the third was the author of the Shach, except that in the end it was decided that the Shach could not be taken, because the world needs his Torah, and therefore they must leave him here in this world.
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Yitzchak Zilberstein Shlita, Av Beit Din of Ramat Elchanan, "Tuvcha Yabiu" (Bnei Brak 5761) Part 2, Page 197

body_he:
וְכָךְ כּוֹתֵב הַשַּׁ"ךְ בְּהַקְדָּמָתוֹ שָׁם: "אַף כִּי בֶּאֱמֶת וּבְתָמִים טָרַחְתִּי טִרְחוֹת רַבּוֹת וְכַמָּה יְגִיעוֹת יָגַעְתִּי, לֹא עָסַקְתִּי בְּשׁוּם עֵסֶק אַחֵר, לֹא נָתַתִּי שֵׁינָה וּתְנוּמָה לְעַפְעַפַּי. שָׁנִים רַבּוֹת, עַד אֲשֶׁר הוֹצֵאתִי מִכּוֹחַ אֶל הַפּוֹעַל מַחְשַׁבְתִּי וּבֵרַרְתִּי וְשָׁקַלְתִּי הַכֹּל בְּכַף מֹאזְנַיִם, וְחָזַרְתִּי עַל כָּל צְדָדִים וְצִדְדֵי צְדָדִים לֹא פַּעַם וּשְׁתַּיִם כִּי אִם מֵאָה פְּעָמִים וְאֶחָד עִם חֲבֵרִים חֲשׁוּבִים אֲהוּבִים חֲבִיבִים וַעֲרֵבִים הַמַּקְשִׁיבִים לְקוֹלִי, וּמִי שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה אִתִּי בִּמְחִיצָתִי לֹא יַאֲמִין כִּי יְסוּפַּר לוֹ מִגֹּדֶל הַתְּלָאָה שֶׁהָיְתָה עָלַי בְּחִיפּוּשׂ בְּיַם הַתַּלְמוּד וְהַפּוֹסְקִים עַד כִּי הֶעֱמַדְתִּי הַכֹּל עַל בּוּרְיוֹ", עַכָּ"ל.
וְהִנֵּה, כְּשֶׁרָאַנִי מוֹ"ח מְעַיֵּין בְּהַקְדָּמָה זוֹ אָמַר שֶׁמְּקוּבָל אֶצְלוֹ שֶׁבִּתְקוּפַת גְּזֵרוֹת תַּ"ח-תַּ"ט נִגְזְרָה גְּזֵרַת כְּלָיָּה רַחַ"ל עַל כָּל עַם יִשְׂרָאֵל, וּבִתְמוּרָה לְכָךְ הוּחְלַט בְּבֵית דִּין שֶׁל מַעְלָה לָקַחַת מֵהָעוֹלָם שְׁלוֹשָׁה מִגְּדוֹלֵי הַדּוֹר.
הַגְּרִי"שׁ אֶלְיָשִׁיב אָמַר שֶׁלְּפִי הַקַּבָּלָה שֶׁבְּיָדָיו אֶחָד מֵהֶם הָיָה רַבִּי שִׁמְשׁוֹן אוֹסְטְרוֹפּוֹלְיֶ'ר. אֶת שְׁמוֹ שֶׁל הַשֵּׁנִי לֹא פֵּירֵט, וְהַשְּׁלִישִׁי הָיָה בַּעַל הַשַּׁ"ךְ, אֶלָּא שֶׁלְּבַסּוֹף הֻכְרַע שֶׁאֶת הַשַּׁ"ךְ אִי אֶפְשָׁר לָקַחַת, כִּי הָעוֹלָם זָקוּק לְתוֹרָתוֹ, וְלָכֵן צְרִיכִים לְהַשְׁאִירוֹ כָּאן בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה.[הגאון רבי יצחק זילברשטיין שליט״א, אב״ד רמת-אלחנן, ״טובך יביעו״ (ב״ב תשס״א) ח״ב, ע׳ קצ״ז]
body_en:
Our Rabbi the Shach lived in Vilna. In those days, the decrees of the years Tach and Tat (1648-1649) occurred, and he was forced to flee and arrived in Lublin. But from there too he was forced to escape due to the Cossacks who came there and killed hundreds of thousands of Jews there, may Hashem avenge their blood.
[Regarding these pogroms, the Holy Yaavetz zt"l writes about his grandfather Rabbi Yaakov zt"l, father of his father the Holy Chacham Tzvi zt"l, that he too was among those whom the Cossacks pursued. They came to testify before the Holy Rabbi R' Heshel of Krakow zt"l that faithful witnesses testified they saw the Cossacks strike Rabbi Yaakov the aforementioned on his head and he fell wallowing in his blood. Therefore, Rabbi R' Heshel permitted his wife (as an Agunah). However, one night before the marriage, the "killed one" came on his feet. To their question of how he did not die from the blow of the sword that the Cossack struck on his head, he answered that the Cossack struck him by mistake only with the handle holding the sword, and he pretended as if he was dead. Afterwards, when they went on their way, he got up and came here. Since that incident, Rabbi R' Heshel did not want to rule on Halachot for practical application.]
Our Rabbi escaped from Lublin and fled to Czechia, where he passed away. To this day, his resting place is honored in the city of Holleschau, and the Shach's Beit Midrash still stands on its mound, and they renovated the tombstone recently.
Our Rabbi did not live long, to our sorrow, and passed away at the prime of his days, being only 41 years old. He printed his first book on Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah when he was only 24 years old. He writes in the introduction: **"לֹא נָתַתִּי שֵׁינָה וּתְנוּמָה לְעַפְעַפַּי שָׁנִים רַבּוֹת, עַד אֲשֶׁר הוֹצֵאתִי מִכֹּחַ אֶל הַפּוֹעַל מַחֲשַׁבְתִּי, וּבֵרַרְתִּי וְשָׁקַלְתִּי הַכֹּל בְּכַף מֹאזְנַיִם וְחָזַרְתִּי עַל כָּל צְדָדִים וְצִדְדֵי צְדָדִים לֹא פַּעַם אַחַת וּשְׁתַּיִם כִּי אִם מֵאָה פְּעָמִים וְכוּ' וּמִי שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה אִתִּי בִּמְחִיצָתִי לֹא יַאֲמִין כִּי יְסוּפַר לוֹ וְכוּ'"** - "I did not give sleep or slumber to my eyelids for many years, until I brought my thought from potential to actual, and I clarified and weighed everything in the scales, and I went over all sides and sides of sides not once or twice but a hundred times etc., and whoever was not with me in my presence would not believe if told etc." End quote.
And behold, when we make a simple calculation, we arrive at an amazing revelation. For behold, the book was printed when he was 24 years old. In those days, printing a book took several years, especially a large book like the Shach on Yoreh Deah with Shulchan Aruch; such a thing took at least 4 years. And according to his aforementioned words, until he wrote his composition, a hundred times passed over him. Thus, it turns out that he began editing the book when he was a boy of 17 years, and already then he was immensely expert in the books of the early and later authorities.
The Shach also composed a book called "Takfo Kohen" on the Sugya of "Takfo Kohen" in Tractate Bava Metzia regarding matters of doubts and presumptions (Chazakot). And the Rabbi Chida writes that the Shach composed the book in the course of one month only. And from the Holy Gaon Rabbi Yonatan Eybeschutz zt"l, there is a large Kuntres (pamphlet) in Siman 25 on this composition.
And the Rabbi Chida writes a wondrous thing, that our Rabbi the Shach had Holy Names and he used them when he sought a saying in the Shas or in the books of the early authorities. And seemingly, what is the greatness if they use Names? The answer is, that the greatness is that in order to merit Names - one needs to study Torah first, and the Shach, who received a Name from Heaven, learned and engaged in Torah even before that.
Source: Rabbi David HaLachmi zt"l, "Chachmei Yisrael" (Bnei Brak 5761) Page 88

[עַל פּוֹגְרוֹמִים אֵלּוּ כּוֹתֵב הַגָּהַ"ק הַיַּעֲבֵ"ץ זַצַ"ל עַל זְקִינוֹ רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב זַצַ"ל אֲבִי אָבִיו הַגָּהַ"ק הֶחָכָם צְבִי זַצַ"ל, שֶׁגַּם הוּא הָיָה מֵאֵלֶּה שֶׁהַקּוֹזָקִים רָדְפוּ אַחֲרֵיהֶם, וּבָאוּ לְהָעִיד לִפְנֵי הַגָּהַ"ק הָרַבִּי ר' הֶעשִׁיל מִקְּרָאקָא זַצַ"ל שֶׁעֵדִים נֶאֱמָנִים הֵעִידוּ שֶׁרָאוּ שֶׁהַקּוֹזָקִים הִיכּוּ אֶת רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב הַנַּ"ל בְּרֹאשׁוֹ וְנָפַל מִתְבּוֹסֵס בְּדָמוֹ. אֲשֶׁר עַל כֵּן, הָרַבִּי ר' הֶעשִׁיל הִתִּיר אֶת הָעֲגוּנָה. וְאוּלָם, לַיְלָה אֶחָד קוֹדֶם הַנִּשּׂוּאִין בָּא הָרוּג בְּרַגְלָיו, וּלְשֶׁאֱלָתָם אֵיךְ לֹא מֵת מִמַּכַּת הַחֶרֶב שֶׁהִכָּה הַקּוֹזָק עַל רֹאשׁוֹ, הֵשִׁיב שֶׁהַקּוֹזָק הִכָּה אוֹתוֹ בְּטָעוּת רַק עִם הַיָּדִית הַמַּחֲזֶקֶת אֶת הַחֶרֶב, וְעָשָׂה עַצְמוֹ כְּאִילּוּ שֶׁמֵּת, וְאַחַ"כּ כְּשֶׁהָלְכוּ לְדַרְכָּם קָם וּבָא לְכָאן. מֵאָז אוֹתוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה לֹא רָצָה הָרַבִּי ר' הֶעשִׁיל לִפְסֹק הֲלָכוֹת לְמַעֲשֶׂה.]
רַבֵּינוּ נִמְלַט מִלּוּבְּלִין וּבָרַח לְצֶ'כְיָה וְשָׁם נִפְטַר. עַד הַיּוֹם מְנוּחָתוֹ כָּבוֹד בְּעִיר הֶעָלִישׁוֹי, וְגַם בֵּית מִדְרָשׁוֹ שֶׁל הַשַּׁ"ךְ עֲדַיִין עוֹמֵד עַל תִּלּוֹ, וְחִידְּשׁוּ אֶת הַמַּצֵּבָה לָאַחֲרוֹנָה.
רַבֵּינוּ לֹא הֶאֱרִיךְ יָמִים, ל"ע, וְנִפְטַר בִּדְמֵי יָמָיו וְהוּא בֶּן מ"א שָׁנִים בִּלְבַד. אֶת סִפְרוֹ הָרִאשׁוֹן עַל שׁוּ"עַ יוֹ"ד הִדְפִּיס כְּשֶׁהוּא בֶּן כ"ד שָׁנִים בִּלְבַד, וְכוֹתֵב בַּהַקְדָּמָה וְזַ"ל: "לֹא נָתַתִּי שֵׁינָה וּתְנוּמָה לְעַפְעַפַּי שָׁנִים רַבּוֹת, עַד אֲשֶׁר הוֹצֵאתִי מִכֹּחַ אֶל הַפּוֹעַל מַחְשַׁבְתִּי, וּבֵרַרְתִּי וְשָׁקַלְתִּי הַכֹּל בְּכַף מֹאזְנַיִם וְחָזַרְתִּי עַל כָּל צְדָדִים וְצִדְדֵי צְדָדִים לֹא פַּעַם אַחַת וּשְׁתַּיִם כִּי אִם מֵאָה פְּעָמִים וְכוּ' וּמִי שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה אִתִּי בִּמְחִיצָתִי לֹא יַאֲמִין כִּי יְסוּפַּר לוֹ וְכוּ'". עַכָּ"ד.
וְהִנֵּה כְּשֶׁנַּעֲרוֹךְ חֶשְׁבּוֹן פָּשׁוּט נַגִּיעַ לְגִילּוּי מַדְהִים, דְּהִנֵּה הַסֵּפֶר הוּדְפַס בִּהְיוֹתוֹ בֶּן כ"ד שָׁנִים, וּבַיָּמִים הָהֵם הַדְפָּסַת הַסֵּפֶר אָרְכָה כַּמָּה שָׁנִים, וּבִפְרָט סֵפֶר גָּדוֹל כְּהַשַּׁ"ךְ עַל יוֹ"ד עִם שׁוּ"עַ, דָּבָר כָּזֶה לָקַח לוֹ לְפָחוֹת ד' שָׁנִים. וּכְפִי דְּבָרָיו הַנַּ"ל, עַד שֶׁכָּתַב אֶת חִבּוּרוֹ עָבַר עָלָיו מֵאָה פְּעָמִים, כָּךְ שֶׁנִּמְצָא שֶׁהִתְחִיל בַּעֲרִיכַת הַסֵּפֶר בִּהְיוֹתוֹ כְּבֶן י"ז שָׁנָה, וּכְבָר אָז הָיָה בָּקִי עָצוּם בְּסִפְרֵי הָרִאשׁוֹנִים וְהָאַחֲרוֹנִים.
עוֹד חִבֵּר הַשַּׁ"ךְ סֵפֶר בְּשֵׁם "תָּקְפּוֹ כֹהֵן" עַל סוּגְיַית תָּקְפּוֹ כֹּהֵן שֶׁבְּמַסֶּכֶת בָּבָא מְצִיעָא עַל עִנְיְנֵי סְפֵקוֹת וַחֲזָקוֹת. וְהָרַב חִידָ"א כּוֹתֵב שֶׁהַשַּׁ"ךְ חִבֵּר אֶת הַסֵּפֶר בְּמֶשֶׁךְ חֹדֶשׁ אֶחָד בִּלְבַד, וּמֵהַגָּהַ"ק הָרַבִּי ר' יְהוֹנָתָן אַיְיבְּשִׁיץ זַצַ"ל יֵשׁ קוּנְטְרֵס גָּדוֹל בְּסִימָן כ"ה עַל חִבּוּר זֶה.
וְכוֹתֵב הָרַב חִידָ"א דָּבָר פֶּלֶא, שֶׁלְּרַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ הָיָה שֵׁם מִשְּׁמוֹת הַקֹּדֶשׁ וּבוֹ הִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ כְּשֶׁבִּיקֵּשׁ לְחַפֵּשׂ מֵימְרָא בַּשַּׁ"ס אוֹ בְּסִפְרֵי הָרִאשׁוֹנִים. וְלִכְאוֹרָה, מַה הָרְבוּתָא אִם מִשְׁתַּמְּשִׁים בְּשֵׁמוֹת, וְהַתֵּירוּץ הוּא, שֶׁהָרְבוּתָא הוּא, שֶׁכְּדֵי לִזְכּוֹת לְשֵׁמוֹת - צְרִיכִים לִלְמֹד תּוֹרָה מִקּוֹדֶם, וְהַשַּׁ"ךְ שֶׁקִּבֵּל שֵׁם מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם לָמַד וְעָסַק בַּתּוֹרָה עוֹד לִפְנֵי כֵּן.
וּכְבָר הָיָה מַעֲשֶׂה אֵצֶל רַבֵּינוּ הַחֲתַ"ס זַצַ"ל, שֶׁאַבְרֵךְ אֶחָד הִגִּיעַ אֵלָיו וּבִקֵּשׁ מִמֶּנּוּ הֶיתֵּר הוֹרָאָה, וְהַחֲתַ"ס שָׁאַל אוֹתוֹ שְׁאֵלָה בְּהִלְכוֹת יוֹם טוֹב וְהַתֵּירוּץ לְכָךְ הָיָה כָּתוּב בְּמַהַרְשָׁ"א בְּמַס' בֵּיצָה. הָאַבְרֵךְ לֹא יָדַע מֵאוֹתוֹ מַהַרְשָׁ"א, אָז אָמַר לוֹ הַחֲתַ"ס, שֶׁהוּא עַצְמוֹ ג"כּ אֵינוֹ זוֹכֵר אֶת כָּל הַהֲלָכוֹת, אֲבָל הוּא לָמַד אֶת הַדְּבָרִים, וְאִם לוֹמְדִים - יוֹדְעִים לְכָל הַפָּחוֹת הֵיכָן לְחַפֵּשׂ, אֲבָל אִם לֹא לוֹמְדִים - לֹא יוֹדְעִים אֲפִי' הֵיכָן לְחַפֵּשׂ.[הגה״צ רבי נתן גשטטנר זצ״ל, גאב״ד קרית אגוד״י-ב״ב, ״הישיבה״, ניסן תשס״ו, ע׳ 30]

Few and evil were the days of the two lives [life span] of our Rabbi the Shach. At his passing, he had not yet completed 42 years, and during his few years, periods of suffering and great sorrow passed over him, both troubles of the general public and his personal burden. In his days, one of the hardest decrees that passed over the Jewish people during the days of exile poured out on the heads of the Jews, namely the infamous "Decree of Tach and Tat" (1648-1649).
In the year 5408 (Tach), cruel riots broke out in Ukraine against the Jews, which exacted a very high price in blood. The difficult events began with the uprising of the Cossack people, may their name be blotted out, and their rebellion against their enslavers, the Polish landowners, and against the praised King of Poland, Władysław, who died a short time after the beginning of the rebellion. [Regarding the positive personality of Władysław, King of Poland, our Rabbi the Shach writes (in his "Megillah Afah", see below): **"מֶלֶךְ כָּשֵׁר, רָאוּי לְמַנּוֹתוֹ בֵּין צַדִּיקִים, כִּי מֵעוֹלָם הֵטִיב חַסְדּוֹ עִם הַיְּהוּדִים, וְאֶת בְּרִיתוֹ אִתָּם הֵקִים"** - "A worthy king, fitting to count him among the righteous, for he always extended his kindness to the Jews and established his covenant with them."]
The death of King Władysław together with the rebellion of the Cossacks brought about absolute looseness in the power of the Polish royal house, and in its wake, the security situation turned very unstable. Lawlessness, robbery, looting, and terrible murders were daily occurrences. Anarchy ruled supreme, and it added strength and courage to the oppressor of the Jews, Bohdan Chmielnicki, may his name be blotted out [whose statue stands to this day in Kiev, the capital of Ukraine, as a figure of a hero].
Together with his bands of cruel murderers, Chmielnicki went out to conquer city after city throughout the state of Ukraine. And as in every place where the enemies of Israel raise their heads, so too in Ukraine, the Jewish people were the first and main victims of the Cossack rioters, who destroyed with terrible cruelty the majority of the Jewish communities. After they looted and robbed all they had, they also added beating, killing, and slaughtering them without mercy. The number of Jews killed in those bloody events reached hundreds of thousands, may Hashem avenge their blood.
As stated, the cruel pogroms began in the year Tach (1648), and their beginning was in the cities of Ukraine, and from there the rioters continued to rampage also during the following year, the year Tat (1649), also in the territories of Volhynia and Podolia. But compared to the Jews in the aforementioned countries, the Jews of the state of Lithuania, and among them the residents of the city of Vilna, the city of residence of our Rabbi the Shach (which was in those days under Russian rule), enjoyed relative quiet and tranquility in the meantime. Only after about seven years, in the years 5414-5415, did they too drink the cup of poison, being subjected also to slaughter and killing, to trampling, plunder, and looting, under the trampling and destroying Cossack boot without mercy.
The bad news of the Cossack riots against the Jews of Ukraine did not reach the Jews of Lithuania so quickly. Only when several weeks had passed from the beginning of the cruel massacres did the rumor reach the ears of our Rabbi the Shach, causing him immense shock. In its wake, the Jews of Vilna came to know a "Shach" of a different kind. The Jews of Vilna were accustomed that our Rabbi the Shach never went out even four cubits from Halacha, and all his hours and moments were given since always and constantly only to the business of Torah alone. But the troubles of Israel in Ukraine, which now rose beyond the head, brought him out of all his fences and boundaries.
Out of chastising pain and indescribable sorrow, our Rabbi the Shach began to take an interest and clarify how much the hand of Hashem touched every community in Ukraine. He sought to hear about the events of the cruel pogroms down to the smallest details. And all that he heard and verified, he wrote in blood of his heart on a scroll of a book. He called it "Megillah Afah" (The Flying Scroll / Scroll of Darkness). Thus came to the world an additional composition from the fruit of the pen of the author of the Shach, a composition of a completely different type, which shakes the heart of all its readers.
In this book, our Rabbi the Shach also calls the entire Jewish people to fasting and eulogy, and to mourn bitterly **"עַל בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל וְעַל עַם ה' כִּי נָפְלוּ בַּחֶרֶב..."** - "Over the House of Israel and over the people of Hashem for they fell by the sword..." [Although in its first edition (Amsterdam 5411), the composition was called "Megillah Afah", in subsequent editions the Megillah was printed under the name "Megillat Eifah" (Scroll of Eifah/Darkness), and the publisher (anonymously) of the Jerusalem 5765 edition writes that **"הַשֵּׁם הַזֶּה נִרְאֶה מַתְאִים יוֹתֵר לַכַּוָּנָה, כִּי 'עֵיפָה' פֵּירוּשׁוֹ חֹשֶׁךְ, כְּמוֹ לְשׁוֹן הַפָּסוּק 'עֹשֵׂה שַׁחַר עֵיפָה' (עמוס ד' י"ג)"** - "This name seems more fitting to the intention, for 'Eifah' means darkness, like the language of the verse 'He makes the dawn darkness' (Amos 4:13)."]
To remember those terrible troubles, our Rabbi the Shach took upon himself and his descendants for their generations to fast on the 20th day of the month of Sivan, every single year. In addition, our Rabbi the Shach also composed special "Selichot and Kinot" (Penitential Prayers and Lamentations), which were written in poetic language, to be recited on the day of the fast. His composition "Megillat Eifah" was also written in poetic language. Printed essentially as an introduction to those "Kinot and Selichot", upon which he writes: "And I composed these Selichot and Kinot with weeping and supplications, to say them on this day every year, a time and seasons." Our Rabbi the Shach also turns with a request to **"כָל אִישׁ אֲשֶׁר הֲרִיחוֹ ה' בְּיִרְאָתוֹ, וּבְשֵׁם יִשְׂרָאֵל יְכֻנֶּה, יָשִׂים עַל לִבּוֹ אֵלּוּ הַדְּבָרִים וְהָעִנְיָנִים, וְיִקְבַּע עַצְמוֹ יוֹם זֶה לְקוֹנֵן עָלָיו כְּעַל שְׁנֵי הַחוּרְבָּנִים [!], אוּלַי יַשְׁקִיף ה' וְיֵרָאֶה מִמְּעוֹנִים"** - "Every man whom Hashem has scented with His fear, and is called by the name Israel, should place these words and matters on his heart, and fix for himself this day to lament upon it as upon the two Destructions [of the Temples]!, perhaps Hashem will look down and see from His abodes."
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Natan Gestetner zt"l, Av Beit Din of Kiryat Agudat Yisrael Bnei Brak, "HaYeshiva", Nissan 5766, Page 30
