בִּשְׁנַת ה' אֲלָפִים תַּ"ח פָּרְצוּ בְּאוּקְרָאִינָה פְּרָעוֹת אַכְזָרִיּוֹת בַּיְּהוּדִים, שֶׁגָּבוּ מְחִיר דָּמִים גָּבוֹהַּ בְּיוֹתֵר. הַמְאֹרָעוֹת הַקָּשִׁים הֵחֵלּוּ עִם הִתְקוֹמְמוּתָם שֶׁל עַם הַקּוֹזָקִים ימ"ש, וּמְרִידָתָם בִּמְשַׁעְבְּדֵיהֶם בַּעֲלֵי הָאֲחֻזּוֹת הַפְּרִיצִים הַפּוֹלָנִיִּים, וּבְמֶלֶךְ פּוֹלִין הַמְהֻלָּל וְוֹלְדִיסְלָב, שֶׁמֵּת תּוֹךְ זְמַן קָצָר מִתְּחִלַּת הַמֶּרֶד [עַל אִישִׁיּוּתוֹ הַחִיּוּבִית שֶׁל וְוֹלְדִיסְלָב מֶלֶךְ פּוֹלִין כּוֹתֵב רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ (בְּ"מְגִלָּה עָפָה" שֶׁלּוֹ, רְאֵה לְהַלָּן): "מֶלֶךְ כָּשֵׁר, רָאוּי לְמַנּוֹתוֹ בֵּין צַדִּיקִים, כִּי מֵעוֹלָם הֵטִיב חַסְדּוֹ עִם הַיְּהוּדִים, וְאֶת בְּרִיתוֹ אִתָּם הֵקִים"].
מוֹתוֹ שֶׁל הַמֶּלֶךְ וְוֹלְדִיסְלָב יַחַד עִם הַמֶּרֶד שֶׁל הַקּוֹזָקִים הֵבִיאוּ לִידֵי הִתְרוֹפְפוּת מוּחְלֶטֶת בְּכוֹחָהּ שֶׁל בֵּית הַמְּלוּכָה הַפּוֹלָנִי, וּבְעִקְבוֹתֶיהָ הָפַךְ הַמַּצָּב הַבִּטְחוֹנִי לִהְיוֹת מְאֹד בִּלְתִּי יַצִּיב. הַהֶפְקֵרוּת, הַשּׁוֹד וְהַבִּיזָה, וְהָרְצִיחוֹת הָאֲיוּמוֹת הָיוּ מַעֲשִׂים שֶׁבְּכָל יוֹם, הָאֲנַרְכְיָה שָׁלְטָה בַּכִּיפָּה, וְהִיא שֶׁהוֹסִיפָה כֹּחַ וְאֹמֶץ לַצַּר הַצּוֹרֵר אֶת הַיְּהוּדִים בּוֹגְדָן חְמֶלְנִיצְקִי ימ"ש [מִי שֶׁפֶּסֶל דְּמוּתוֹ נִיצָּב עַד הַיּוֹם בְּקִיֶּיב בִּירַת אוּקְרָאִינָה, בְּתוֹר דְּמוּת שֶׁל גִּבּוֹר].
יַחַד עִם כְּנוּפִיּוֹתָיו הַמְרַצְּחִים הָאַכְזָרִיִּים, יָצָא חְמֶלְנִיצְקִי ימ"ש לִכְבֹּשׁ עִיר אַחַת אַחֲרֵי הַשְּׁנִיָּה בְּכָל מְדִינַת אוּקְרָאִינָה. וּכְמוֹ בְּכָל מָקוֹם שֶׁצּוֹרְרֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל נוֹשְׂאִים רֹאשׁ, כָּךְ גַּם בְּאוּקְרָאִינָה הָיוּ בְּנֵי הָעָם הַיְּהוּדִי לַקָּרְבָּנוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנִים וְהָעִקָּרִיִּים שֶׁל הַפּוֹרְעִים הַקּוֹזָקִים, שֶׁהֶחֱרִיבוּ בְּאַכְזָרִיּוּת נוֹרָאָה אֶת מַרְבִּית הַקְּהִלּוֹת הַיְּהוּדִיּוֹת, וּלְאַחַר שֶׁבָּזְזוּ וְשָׁדְדוּ אֶת כָּל אֲשֶׁר לָהֶם, הוֹסִיפוּ גַּם לְהַכּוֹת, לַהֲרֹג וְלִטְבּוֹחַ בָּהֶם לְלֹא חֶמְלָה, מִנְיַן הַהֲרוּגִים הַיְּהוּדִים בְּאוֹתָם מְאֹרָעוֹת דָּמִים הִגִּיעַ לְמֵאוֹת אֲלָפִים הַיָּ"ד.
כָּאָמוּר, הַפּוֹגְרוֹמִים הָאַכְזָרִיִּים הֵחֵלּוּ בִּשְׁנַת תַּ"ח, וּתְחִילָּתָן בְּעָרֵי אוּקְרָאִינָה, וּמִמֶּנָּה הִמְשִׁיכוּ הַפּוֹרְעִים לְהִשְׁתּוֹלֵל גַּם בְּמֶשֶׁךְ הַשָּׁנָה הַבָּאָה, שְׁנַת תַּ"ט, גַּם בִּתְחוּמֵי וָואהְלִין וּפוֹדוֹלְיָה. אֲבָל לְעֻמַּת הַיְּהוּדִים שֶׁבִּמְדִינוֹת הַנִּזְכָּרוֹת, הֲרֵי יְהוּדֵי מְדִינַת לִיטָא וּבְתוֹכָם בְּנֵי הָעִיר וִוילְנָא, עִיר מְגוּרָיו שֶׁל רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ, שֶׁהָיְתָה בְּאוֹתָם יָמִים תַּחַת שִׁלְטוֹן רוּסְיָה, נֶהֱנוּ בֵּינְתַיִים מִשֶּׁקֶט וְשַׁלְוָה יַחֲסִית. רַק לְאַחַר כְּשֶׁבַע שָׁנִים, בַּשָּׁנִים תִּי"ד-תט"ו, שָׁתוּ גַּם הֵם אֶת כּוֹס הַתַּרְעֵלָה, בִּהְיוֹתָם נְתוּנִים גַּם הֵם לְטֶבַח וּלְהֶרֶג, לְמִרְמָס לְשֹׁד וּלְבִיזָה, תַּחַת הַמַּגָּף הַקּוֹזָקִי הַדּוֹרֵס וְהוֹרֵס לְלֹא רַחֵם.
הַשְּׁמוּעוֹת הַלֹּא טוֹבוֹת מִפְּרָעוֹת הַקּוֹזָקִים בִּיהוּדֵי אוּקְרָאִינָה לֹא הִגִּיעוּ כֹּל כָּךְ מַהֵר אֶל יְהוּדֵי לִיטָא, רַק כַּאֲשֶׁר חָלְפוּ שָׁבוּעוֹת מִסְפָּר מִתְּחִלַּת הַשְּׁחִיטוֹת הָאַכְזָרִיּוֹת, הִגִּיעוּ שִׁמְעָן לְאָזְנֵי רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ, מַה שֶּׁגָּרַם לוֹ לְזַעֲזוּעַ עָצוּם, וּבְעִקְבוֹתָיו הִתְוַדְּעוּ יְהוּדֵי וִוילְנָא לְ"שַׁ"ךְ" מִסּוּג אַחֵר. רְגִילִים הָיוּ יְהוּדֵי וִוילְנָא שֶׁרַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ אֵינוֹ יוֹצֵא אַף פַּעַם מִד' אַמּוֹת שֶׁל הֲלָכָה, וְכָל שְׁעוֹתָיו וּרְגָעָיו נְתוּנִים מֵאָז וּמִתָּמִיד רַק לְעֵסֶק הַתּוֹרָה לְבַדָּהּ, אֶלָּא שֶׁצָּרוֹת יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּאוּקְרָאִינָה שֶׁעָלוּ כָּעֵת לְמַעְלָה רֹאשׁ, הוֹצִיאוּ אוֹתוֹ מִכָּל סְיָגָיו וּגְדָרָיו.
מִתּוֹךְ כְּאֵב מְיַסֵּר וְצַעַר בַּל יְתוֹאַר הֵחֵל רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ לְהִתְעַנְיֵין וּלְבָרֵר עַד כַּמָּה נָגְעָה יַד ה' בְּכָל קְהִלָּה וּקְהִלָּה בְּאוּקְרָאִינָה, הוּא בִּיקֵּשׁ לִשְׁמֹעַ עַל אֵירוּעֵי הַפּוֹגְרוֹמִים הָאַכְזָרִיִּים עַד לְפִרְטֵי פְּרָטִים. וְאֶת כָּל אֲשֶׁר שָׁמַע וְאִימֵּת, כָּתַב בְּדַם לְבָבוֹ עַל מְגִלַּת סֵפֶר. אוֹתָהּ קָרָא בְּשֵׁם "מְגִלָּה עָפָה". כָּךְ בָּא לָעוֹלָם חִבּוּר נוֹסָף מִפְּרִי עֵטוֹ שֶׁל בַּעַל הַשַּׁ"ךְ, חִבּוּר מִסּוּג שׁוֹנֶה לְגַמְרֵי, הַמְזַעְזֵעַ אֶת לֵב כָּל קוֹרְאָיו.
בְּסִפְרוֹ זֶה גַּם קוֹרֵא רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ לְעַם יִשְׂרָאֵל כּוּלּוֹ לְתַעֲנִית וּלְהֶסְפֵּד, וּלְהִתְאַבֵּל מָרָה "עַל בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל וְעַל עַם ה' כִּי נָפְלוּ בַּחֶרֶב..." [אִם כִּי בְּמַהֲדוּרָתוֹ הָרִאשׁוֹנָה (דְּפוּס אַמְסְטֶרְדָּם שְׁנַת תי"א) נִקְרָא הַחִבּוּר בְּשֵׁם "מְגִלָּה עָפָה", הֲרֵי בַּמַּהֲדוּרוֹת הַבָּאוֹת נִדְפְּסָה הַמְּגִלָּה תַּחַת הַשֵּׁם "מְגִלַּת עֵיפָה", וְהַמּוֹ"ל (בְּעִילּוּם שְׁמוֹ) שֶׁל מַהֲדוּרַת יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשס"ה כּוֹתֵב שֶׁ"הַשֵּׁם הַזֶּה נִרְאֶה מַתְאִים יוֹתֵר לַכַּוָּנָה, כִּי "עֵיפָה" פֵּירוּשׁוֹ חֹשֶׁךְ, כְּמוֹ לְשׁוֹן הַפָּסוּק "עֹשֵׂה שַׁחַר עֵיפָה" (עָמוֹס ד' י"ג)].
לְזֵכֶר אוֹתָן הַצָּרוֹת הַנּוֹרָאוֹת, קִיבֵּל רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ עָלָיו וְעַל זַרְעוֹ לְדוֹרוֹתֵיהֶם לְהִתְעַנּוֹת בְּיוֹם כ' לְחוֹדֶשׁ סִיוָן, בְּכָל שָׁנָה וְשָׁנָה. בְּנוֹסָף חִבֵּר גַּם רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ "סְלִיחוֹת וְקִינוֹת" מְיֻחָדוֹת, שֶׁנִּכְתְּבוּ בִּלְשׁוֹן פִּיּוּטִית, לְאָמְרָם בְּיוֹם הַתַּעֲנִית, וְחִבּוּרוֹ "מְגִלַּת עָפָה" שֶׁנִּכְתַּב גַּם הוּא בִּלְשׁוֹן פִּיּוּטִית. נִדְפַּס בְּעֶצֶם כְּהַקְדָּמָה לְאוֹתָן "קִינוֹת וּסְלִיחוֹת", עֲלֵיהֶן הוּא כּוֹתֵב: "וְחִבַּרְתִּי אֵלּוּ הַסְּלִיחוֹת וְהַקִּינוֹת בִּבְכִי וּבְתַחֲנוּנִים, לְאוֹמְרָם בְּיוֹם זֶה בְּכָל שָׁנָה וְשָׁנָה, עִידָּן וְעִדָּנִים". רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ גַּם פּוֹנֶה בְּבַקָּשָׁה לְ"כָל אִישׁ אֲשֶׁר הֲרִיחוֹ ה' בְּיִרְאָתוֹ, וּבְשֵׁם יִשְׂרָאֵל יְכֻנֶּה, יָשִׂים עַל לִבּוֹ אֵלּוּ הַדְּבָרִים וְהָעִנְיָנִים, וְיִקְבַּע עַצְמוֹ יוֹם זֶה לְקוֹנֵן עָלָיו כְּעַל שְׁנֵי הַחוּרְבָּנִים [!], אוּלַי יַשְׁקִיף ה' וְיֵרָאֶה מִמְּעוֹנִים".
הָיוּ לוֹ לְרַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ כַּמָּה טְעָמִים בִּקְבִיעוּת יוֹם הַתַּעֲנִית דַּוְקָא בְּיוֹם כ' סִיוָן: "יַעַן כִּי יוֹם זֶה הוּא תְּחִלָּה לַגְּזֵרוֹת וּמַכְאוֹבוֹת, וְחֳלָאִים רָעִים וְנֶאֱמָנִים" כִּי בְּיוֹם זֶה הָיְתָה הַשְּׁחִיטָה הַגְּדוֹלָה שֶׁל יְהוּדֵי קְהִלַּת נֶעמִירוֹב, אֵלֶיהָ נִמְלְטוּ מַרְבִּית הַיְּהוּדִים מִכָּל סְבִיבוֹתֶיהָ, וְהִיא שֶׁהָיְתָה הַקְּהִלָּה הָרִאשׁוֹנָה שֶׁבָּהּ בִּיצְּעוּ הַמְרַצְּחִים אֶת מְזִימָּתָם הַשְּׁפֵלָה, כִּלְשׁוֹנוֹ שֶׁל בַּעַל הַשַּׁ"ךְ: "הִנֵּה הַקְּהִלָּה הַקְּדוֹשָׁה נֶעמִירוֹב הָיְתָה רֹאשׁ לַגְּזֵרוֹת הַדַּקִּים... (בְּשֵׁם זֶה הוּא מְכַנֶּה אֶת הַמְרַצְּחִים, וּרְאֵה לְהַלָּן), הָאֱוִילִים וְטִפְּשִׁים, וּמִשָּׁם נָפוֹצוּ עַל פְּנֵי כָּל הָאָרֶץ וְהָיָה לְהַרְבֵּ"ה רָאשִׁים..." חֶשְׁבּוֹן הַהֲרוּגִים בְּעִיר נֶעמִירוֹב לְבַדָּהּ הָיָה: "כְּמוֹ שִׁשָּׁה אֲלָפִים נְפָשׁוֹת קְדוֹשִׁים, גְּאוֹנִים וְרַבָּנִים, חֲכָמִים וּנְבוֹנִים, זְקֵנִים וִישִׁישִׁים, בַּחוּרִים וּבְתוּלוֹת, חֲתָנִים וְכַלּוֹת, טַף וְנָשִׁים..."
טַעַם נוֹסָף הָיָה לְרַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ בִּקְבִיעוּת יוֹם כ' סִיוָן לְיוֹם צוֹם זֶה אֶבְחָרֵהוּ: "וְגַם כִּי בּוֹ הוּכְפְּלוּ הַצָּרוֹת וְקִלְקוּלִים, כִּי גַּם גְּזֵרַת תתקל"א הָיְתָה בַּיּוֹם הַהוּא..." [בְּהַזְכִּירוֹ אֶת גְּזֵרַת תתקל"א, הִתְכַּוֵּן רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ אֶל הַגְּזֵרָה הָאֲיוּמָה שֶׁהָיְתָה בְּצָרְפַת בַּמֵּאָה הָאַחֲרוֹנָה לָאֶלֶף הַחֲמִישִׁי לִבְרִיאַת עוֹלָם, בִּימֵי רַבּוֹתֵינוּ בַּעֲלֵי הַתּוֹסָפוֹת, שֶׁתְּחִילָּתָהּ בַּעֲלִילָה שְׁפֵלָה וּמְרוּשַּׁעַת עַל אֶחָד מִיהוּדֵי הָעִיר בְּלוֹיַאשׁ שֶׁבְּצָרְפַת, שֶׁכְּאִילּוּ הִטְבִּיעַ נַעַר נוֹצְרִי בַּנָּהָר, וְצִוָּה מוֹשֵׁל הָעִיר הַצּוֹרֵר לָקַחַת שְׁלוֹשָׁה מֵחַכְמֵי צָרְפַת, מִתַּלְמִידֵי רַבֵּינוּ תָּם וְהָרַשְׁבַּ"ם, וּלְהַשְׁלִיכָם חַיִּים לִמְדוּרַת אֵשׁ, וְיַחַד עִמָּם הָיוּ שְׁלוֹשִׁים וְאֶחָד יְהוּדִים, שֶׁהֶעֱמִידוּ אוֹתָם בִּפְנֵי הַבְּרֵירָה, אוֹ לְהָמִיר דָּתָם אוֹ לְהִשָּׂרֵף חַיִּים רח"ל, וְעָמְדוּ הַיְּהוּדִים בַּנִּסָּיוֹן הַקָּשֶׁה, וְקִידְּשׁוּ שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם בָּרַבִּים, בְּמָסְרָם נַפְשָׁם לִשְׂרִיפָה עַל קְדוּשַׁת שְׁמוֹ יִתְבָּרַךְ.
בְּסֵפֶר "עֵמֶק הַבָּכָא" לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵף הַכֹּהֵן מְסַפֵּר: שֶׁצִּוָּה הַצּוֹרֵר: "וַיִּקְשְׁרוּם בַּעֲבוֹתוֹת, וַיַּצִּיתוּ אֵשׁ בְּעֵצִים, וַיַּכּוּ אוֹתָם לְפִי חֶרֶב וַיַּשְׁלִיכוּם אֶל תּוֹךְ הָאֵשׁ, וְלֹא נִשְׂרְפוּ... וַתֵּצֵא נִשְׁמָתָם וַיָּמוּתוּ לִפְנֵי ה', שְׂרִיפַת נִשְׁמָתָם וְגוּף קַיָּים, וּמִתּוֹךְ שִׁירַת "עָלֵינוּ לְשַׁבֵּחַ" עָלְתָה נִשְׁמָתָם הַשָּׁמַיְמָה". הָיָה הַמְאֹרָע הַזֶּה בְּיוֹם כ' סִיוָן שְׁנַת ד' אֲלָפִים תתקל"א, וּלְזִכְרָהּ שֶׁל אוֹתָהּ גְּזֵרָה קָבְעוּ רַבֵּינוּ תָּם, רֹאשׁ חַכְמֵי צָרְפַת בַּיָּמִים הָהֵם, וְאִתּוֹ עַמּוּ הִסְכִּימוּ כָּל רַבּוֹתֵינוּ הַצָּרְפָתִים לִקְבּוֹעַ אֶת יוֹם כ' בְּסִיוָן לְיוֹם צוֹם וּמִסְפֵּד לַדּוֹרוֹת.] טַעַם שְׁלִישִׁי לִקְבִיעַת הַתַּעֲנִית בְּיוֹם כ' סִיוָן הָיָה, מִכֵּיוָן: "כִּי יוֹם זֶה לֹא יֶאֱרַע בְּשַׁבַּת קֹדֶשׁ בְּשׁוּם פָּנִים, עַל פִּי הַקְּבִיעוֹת וְהַלּוּחוֹת אֲשֶׁר בְּיָדֵינוּ מְתוּקָּנִים".
יֵשׁ לְהַפְלִיא וּלְהַדְגִּישׁ אֶת הָעוּבְדָה שֶׁרַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ, גְּאוֹן הַגְּאוֹנִים, שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה פּוֹסֵק מִתַּלְמוּדוֹ יוֹם וְלַיְלָה, וְכָל עִתּוֹתָיו וּרְגָעָיו הָיוּ קֹדֶשׁ לְעֵסֶק הַתּוֹרָה לְבַדָּהּ, הוּא שֶׁכָּל אוֹת הַכְּתוּבָה בְּפִסְקֵי הִלְכוֹתָיו, מְחֻשֶּׁבֶת וּמְדֻיֶּקֶת, וְכַאֲשֶׁר עַל תָּהָה צָרָה לְיַעֲקֹב, הוּא לֹא חָס עַל זְמַנּוֹ הַיָּקָר מִפָּז, וְאַף לֹא הֵטִיל אֶת מְלֶאכֶת אִיסּוּף פִּרְטֵי הַשְּׁחִיטוֹת וְהַהֲרִיגוֹת וְהַעֲלָאָתָם עֲלֵי סֵפֶר עַל הַ"סַפְרָא דְּדַיָּינָא" שֶׁלּוֹ, גַּם לֹא עַל אַף אֶחָד אַחֵר שֶׁיָּכוֹל הָיָה לְהִימָּנוֹת עַל כּוֹתְבֵי הָעִתִּים, אֶלָּא הוּא מָצָא לְנָכוֹן וְלַנָּחוּץ שֶׁדַּוְקָא הוּא בְּעַצְמוֹ יַעֲשֶׂה אֶת כָּל הַמְּלָאכָה הַנִּכְבָּדָה הַזֹּאת.
אֶת זְמַנּוֹ הַיָּקָר לְאֵין עֲרוֹךְ, שֶׁהָיָה יָכוֹל לְחַדֵּשׁ בּוֹ עוֹלָם מָלֵא שֶׁל חִידּוּשֵׁי תּוֹרָה נִפְלָאִים, הִקְדִּישׁ כָּעֵת רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ לְטִיפּוּל בְּחִבּוּרוֹ זֶה, מֵהַמַּסָּד וְעַד הַטְּפָחוֹת, הָחֵל מִקַּבָּלַת הָעֵדוּת לְפִרְטֵי פְּרָטִים עַל כָּל הַמְאֹרָעוֹת וְעַד לִכְתִיבַת תֵּיאוּר מְדֻיָּק שֶׁל כָּל הַתְּלָאָה, כּוֹלֵל גַּם אֶת גְּדוֹלֵי וִוילְנָא, בֵּינֵיהֶם אָבִיו זְקִינוֹ שֶׁלּוֹ עַצְמוֹ, הֲלֹא הוּא הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי אֶפְרַיִם כַּ"ץ מִוִּילְנָא בַּעַל "שַׁעַר אֶפְרַיִם" (שׁוּ"ת עַל אַרְבָּעָה טוּרִים וְעוֹד), כְּמוֹ גַּם הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל קְיְידָנוֹבֶר בַּעַל "בִּרְכַּת הַזֶּבַח" (הַגָּהוֹת בִּגְמָרָא רַשִּׁ"י וְתוֹס' בְּסֵדֶר קָדָשִׁים); הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי הִלֵּל אַשְׁכְּנַזִּי בַּעַל "בֵּית הִלֵּל" (עַל שׁוּ"עַ יוֹ"ד וְאֶהָ"ע); וְהַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי שַׁבְּתַי הַכֹּהֵן בַּעַל הַשַּׁ"ךְ. "כּוּלָּם הוּכְרְחוּ לָצֵאת מִן הָעִיר [=וִוילְנָא], וְהָלְכוּ בַּגּוֹלָה, וְנָפוֹצוּ בָּאָרֶץ לְהַרְבִּיץ תּוֹרָה בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל, וְהָיוּ לִמְאוֹרוֹת..."
מְנָת סֵבֶל גְּדוּשָׁה וְדַרְכֵי נוֹד רַבִּים עָבְרוּ עַל רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ בְּאוֹתָהּ שְׁעַת הַגְּזֵרָה. אֲבָל גַּם בִּשְׁעַת מְנוּסָתוֹ מֵעִיר לְעִיר, וּמִמְּדִינָה לִמְדִינָה, אָנוּ מוֹצְאִים אוֹתוֹ מַמְשִׁיךְ לְהִתְיַגֵּעַ בְּתוֹרָתוֹ וּלְחַדֵּשׁ בָּהּ חִדּוּשִׁים, וּבִהְיוֹתוֹ בֵּין הַמִּשְׁפָּתַיִם הוּא גַּם הִמְשִׁיךְ לִכְתּוֹב אֶת חִבּוּרוֹ לְשׁוּ"עַ "חוֹשֶׁן מִשְׁפָּט". וְכָךְ מָצָאנוּ בְּחִבּוּרוֹ זֶה (סִימָן ג' ס"ק א'), שֶׁלְּאַחַר שֶׁבָּא אֶל הַנַּחֲלָה וְאֶל הַמְּנוּחָה הוֹסִיף עַל מַה שֶּׁכָּתַב בְּעֵת נְדוּדָיו, אֶת הַדְּבָרִים הַבָּאִים;
"בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁכָּתַבְתִּי דִּבְרֵי הַנַּ"ל לֹא הָיָה לְפָנַי סֵפֶר "כֶּסֶף מִשְׁנֶה", כִּי זֶה לָמַדְתִּי בְּבָרְחִי מִן מִלְחֶמֶת הָרֵיקִים ימ"ש... וְעַתָּה עִיַּנְתִּי בְּסֵפֶר "כֶּסֶף מִשְׁנֶה", וְרָאִיתִי שֶׁהִרְגִּישׁ שָׁם בַּקּוּשְׁיָא שֶׁהִקְשֵׁיתִי לְעֵיל עַל הָרַמְבַּ"ם" - הֲרֵי לָנוּ שֶׁגַּם בִּשְׁעַת הִתְגַּבְּרוּת מִדַּת הַדִּין, בִּזְמַן שֶׁהָיָה הַשַּׁ"ךְ בְּמַצָּב שֶׁל פִּקּוּחַ נֶפֶשׁ מַמָּשׁ, וְהָיָה נִמְהָר לָנוּס עַל נַפְשׁוֹ, גַּם אָז הוּא הָיָה עָסוּק בִּכְתִיבַת חִידּוּשָׁיו בַּהֲלָכָה שֶׁל "שְׁנַיִם שֶׁדָּנוּ, דִּינֵיהֶם דִּין", וּבְשִׁיטַת הָרַמְבַּ"ם בָּזֶה. "לוּלֵי תוֹרָתְךָ שַׁעֲשֻׁעָי אָז אָבַדְתִּי בְעָנְיִי..."
מְעַנְיֵין, וּכְפִי שֶׁכְּבָר הִזְכַּרְנוּ לְעֵיל, רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ מְכַנֶּה אֶת הַקּוֹזָקִים (גַּם בְּ"מְגִלָּה עָפָה" שֶׁלּוֹ) בְּשֵׁם "רֵיקִים", כְּכֹל הַנִּרְאֶה הָיְתָה הַ"רֵיקָנוּת" נֶחְשֶׁבֶת אֶצְלוֹ לְדַרְגָּה הַפְּחוּתָה בְּיוֹתֵר, מַה שֶּׁנִּקְרָא בִּלְשׁוֹן הָעָם "לֵיידִיק-גֵּייעֶר" בְּלַעַ"ז [=הוֹלֵךְ בָּטֵל, אוֹ מְבַלֶּה-עוֹלָם], וְאוֹתָהּ "רֵיקָנוּת" הִצְמִיחָה פֵּירוֹת בְּאוּשִׁים מֵהַסּוּג הַגָּרוּעַ בְּיוֹתֵר... עַד לְבִיצּוּעַ רְצִיחוֹת וְכָל מִינֵי מַעֲשֵׂי אַכְזָרִיּוּת...
בִּתְחִילַּת מְנוּסָתוֹ (בְּשִׁלְהֵי חֹדֶשׁ תַּמּוּז תט"ו) הִגִּיעַ רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ לְעִיר לוּבְּלִין, אַךְ עַד מְהֵרָה הִגִּיעוּ הָרֵיקִים הַמְרַצְּחִים גַּם לְלוּבְּלִין (בְּיוֹם א' דְּחַג הַסֻּכּוֹת), וְעָשׂוּ בָּהּ שַׁמּוֹת. שׁוּב נֶאֱלַץ רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ לָנוּס עַל נַפְשׁוֹ, וּבְדַרְכֵי נְדוּדָיו הִגִּיעַ עַד לִמְדִינַת מוֹרַבְיָה (צֶ'כְיָה), שָׁם נָדַד מֵעִיר לְעִיר, בְּדֶרֶךְ הַמִּילוּט שֶׁלּוֹ עָבַר רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ גַּם דֶּרֶךְ הָעִיר פְּרָאג (שׁוּ"ת "שְׁבוּת יַעֲקֹב", לְהַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב רִישֶׁר מִפְּרָאג וְאַבַּ"ד מִיץ, ח"א סִימָן ל"ו), עַד בּוֹאוֹ אֶל הָעִיר דְּרֶזְנִיץ (שׁוּ"ת "חֲתַם סוֹפֵר", אוֹ"ח סִימָן פ"ט), שָׁם הִתְקַבֵּל לְרַב וְאַבַּ"ד. תְּקוּפָה קְצָרָה בִּלְבַד יָשַׁב רַבֵּינוּ עַל כֵּס הָרַבָּנוּת בִּדְרֶזְנִיץ, עַד שֶׁעַל פִּי הַמְלָצַת מוֹרוֹ וְרַבּוֹ הַגָּאוֹן הָרַבִּי ר' הֶעשִׁיל מִקְּרָאקָא נִקְרָא לְכַהֵן כְּמָרָא דְּאַתְרָא בְּעִיר הֶעָלִישׁוֹי, שָׁם אִוְּתָה נַפְשׁוֹ לָשֶׁבֶת עַל הַתּוֹרָה וְעַל הָעֲבוֹדָה, וְאָכֵן בָּהּ יָשַׁב בִּקְבִיעוּת עַד לְיוֹם פְּטִירָתוֹ.
בְּחַסְדֵי שָׁמַיִם, וּלְתוֹעֶלֶת כָּל הַדּוֹרוֹת הַבָּאִים עָלְתָה בְּיָדוֹ שֶׁל רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ לָקַחַת עִמּוֹ בְּכָל דַּרְכֵי גָּלוּתוֹ אֶת כִּתְבֵי יָדוֹ הַיְּקָרִים מִכָּל יָקָר, וְלִנְצוֹר עֲלֵיהֶם כְּבָבַת עֵינוֹ, וּבְכָל מָקוֹם שֶׁגָּלָה גָּלְתָה תּוֹרָתוֹ עִמּוֹ, וְהָיָה תַּלְמוּדוֹ בְּיָדוֹ, הֲלֹא הֵמָּה חִבּוּרָיו הָרַבִּים שֶׁעֲדַיִין הָיוּ בִּכְתַב יָד, וּבְתוֹכָם יְצִירָתוֹ הָעֲנָקִית, הֲלֹא הִיא חִבּוּרוֹ לְשֻׁלְחָן עָרוּךְ "חוֹשֶׁן מִשְׁפָּט". כַּנִּזְכָּר לְעֵיל כְּבָר הָיָה עִיקַּר חִבּוּרוֹ זֶה, בְּרוּבּוֹ הַגָּדוֹל, עָרוּךְ וּמוּכָן לִדְפוּס, וּמְעוּטָר בְּהַסְכָּמַת גְּדוֹלֵי הַדּוֹר, עוֹד בַּיָּמִים בָּהֶם הִתְגּוֹרֵר רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ בְּוִילְנָא רַבָּתִי, בְּטֶרֶם נִמְלַט מִמֶּנָּה מֵאֵימַת הַקּוֹזָקִים ימ"ש. אֲבָל גַּם בְּמֶשֶׁךְ תְּקוּפַת גָּלוּתוֹ וּנְדוּדָיו, וְגַם בְּעֵת בְּיָשְׁבוֹ בְּהֶעָלִישׁוֹי הִמְשִׁיךְ רַבֵּינוּ הַשַּׁ"ךְ לְשַׁכְלֵל אֶת חִבּוּרוֹ זֶה בְּהַשְׁלָמָה אַחַר הַשְׁלָמָה, עַד שֶׁהֶעֱמִידוֹ עַל מְכוֹנוֹ כָּרָאוּי.[הרה״ג ר׳ משה יעקב קנר שליט״א, "תוספת-המודיע״, י״ב טבת תשס״ח, ע׳ ט״ז]

I heard from the Rabbi R' Wolf Adler a"h, that his father had terrible persecutions in his city, and he feared that this would damage his mind. He mentioned himself before the Holy Rabbi, the author of "Or LaMeir" of Spikov, and the Holy Rabbi told him to study every day a page of Shach (on Choshen Mishpat), based on the verse **"כִּי שִׂפְתֵי כֹהֵן יִשְׁמְרוּ דַעַת"** - "For the lips of the priest (Siftei Kohen) shall guard knowledge." [From the mouth of the Gaon Rabbi Eliezer David Friedman Shlita].
Source: "Mipihem U'Mipi Ketavam" (Brooklyn 5767) Part 1, Page 277

How wondrous is the matter that the very study of the Torah of the Shach is considered also among the Segulot (spiritual remedies)... Thus we find in the "Sefer HaMiddot" from the Holy Rabbi Nachman of Breslov zt"l (Entry "Daat" - Knowledge), that several pieces of advice and Segulot are brought in it for **"מִי שֶׁמּוֹחוֹ מְבוּלְבָּל"** - "One whose mind is confused," meaning a person whose ideas are confused and he cannot think with clarity. One Segulah for this is to eat wheat. Another Segulah is to be accustomed to reciting the prayer of Habakkuk the Prophet ("A prayer of Habakkuk the prophet upon Shigionoth", Habakkuk Chapter 3).
And another Segulah is mentioned there: **"גַּם לִימוּד שַׁ"ךְ [שִׂפְתֵי כֹהֵן] סְגֻלָּה לָזֶה...!"** - "Also studying Shach [Siftei Kohen] is a Segulah for this...!" - The words of the Shach, besides being devoted to meditating on the Halachic ruling with absolute clarity, also organize the brain of a person, straighten his intellect, and purify his ideas...
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Moshe Yaakov Kanner Shlita, "Tosefet HaModia", 19 Tevet 5768, Page 18

The Taz (Turei Zahav), who was much older than the Shach, published comments on the words of the Shach. Nevertheless, the Shach, even though he was much younger than him, found [reason] to contradict the words of the Taz, and he even published a book of critiques called "Nekudos HaKesef" (Points of Silver). The Shach wanted to hint with this name that he considers our Rabbi David [HaLevi, the Taz], the elder, to be a greater scholar, just as gold is worth more than silver. So too, the book of the Taz called "Turei Zahav" (Rows of Gold) is worth more than his book "Nekudos HaKesef".
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Yechiel Michel Stern Shlita, "Gidulei HaDorot" (Jerusalem 5755) Part 1, Page 205

Our Rabbi [The Gaon of Tchebin zt"l] was a descendant of the author of the Shach. There was a tradition in his family from their ancestor the Shach, that whoever of his offspring would need salvation should come to his grave and plead for himself, and after he is answered, he should return and go up to his grave.
A story happened with the daughter of our Rabbi's sister who was not visited [with children], and they traveled to the city of Holleschau to pray at the resting place of the Shach. At the turn of the year, a son was born to her (this is the Gaon Rabbi Mendel Geldwerth). When she returned to his grave to give thanks for the salvation she merited, she met exactly at that place a woman who had been with her exactly the year before, and she understood that she too came to give thanks for a salvation.
Indeed, she entered into conversation with her, and she told that her daughter had strayed from the straight path and was about to marry a gentile officer. She came to pray at the marker of the Shach, and some time later, a short time before the wedding, the officer rode on his horse and fell from it and died. Her daughter returned in repentance and now stands to marry a Jew, and for this she came to give thanks. (From the mouth of Rabbi Lipa Geldwerth in the name of his father Rabbi Mendel. Rabbi Mendel was the great-grandson of the 'Kochav MiYaakov', son of his eldest daughter, wife of the Av Beit Din of Toust, Rabbi Yaakov Mendel Rubin. Rabbi Mendel was a wondrous Torah scholar and spread Torah in the Yeshiva 'Torat Emet' of Kamenitz in Brooklyn for dozens of years and raised many great students).
Source: "Sar HaTorah" (Jerusalem 5769) Page 634

The Shaarei Torah (the Gaon Rabbi Binyamin Wolf Low zt"l) was the Rabbi in the city of Verboy located in Slovakia, and there is his resting place of honor to this day. He had a great Yeshiva and raised many disciples. Among his great disciples was the holy Gaon Rabbi Chaim Sofer zt"l, author of *Machane Chaim*. In his youth, Rabbi Chaim Sofer studied in the Yeshiva of my grandfather, the Chatam Sofer zt"l. Upon arriving at the Yeshiva of the Chatam Sofer, he was only 11 years old, and the Chatam Sofer was very fond of him. Upon the passing of his teacher, the Chatam Sofer, he went to study under the greatest of the Chatam Sofer's disciples, the holy Gaon Maharam Ash zt"l.
Upon returning to his home in Pressburg, his father Rabbi Fishel Sofer zt"l, who was a teacher of small children for his livelihood, fell ill. They did not have a piece of bread in their house. His mother's relatives, who were wealthy merchants, proposed to him that he join them in their business and become rich. Seeing that he was about to enter a great trial, he decided to flee and exile himself to a place of Torah, to the Shaarei Torah in Verboy. But a great doubt nested in his heart whether he would succeed in studying in the Yeshiva, for the Shaarei Torah was known as extremely sharp, and it was forbidden to ask questions in the middle of the lesson [unlike the custom in the Yeshiva of his teacher, the Chatam Sofer, where they could ask in the middle of the lesson]. Rabbi Chaim Sofer used to debate a lot and did not know how he would integrate into the Yeshiva. But having no choice, he traveled to Verboy and arrived in the middle of the delivery of the lesson given by the Shaarei Torah. He sat in one of the corners and listened to the delivery of the lesson.
In the middle of the lesson, a difficulty arose for him, and he could not restrain himself and asked the Shaarei Torah in the middle of the lesson. Everyone was amazed to hear his question, for they were not accustomed to students asking in the middle of the lesson, especially since the questioner was a young man of 19 years. The Shaarei Torah was also very impressed by him. After the lesson, he called him, greeted him, asked for his name, invited him to his home, and showed him that the holy Gaon, author of the book *Baruch Taam* zt"l, had already stood upon this point [at the end of the book *Shaarei Torah* Part 1, Kuntres Acharon, he brings several notes, and in one of the notes he writes that this is from the *Baruch Taam*, and on the second note he writes that this is from a certain great one of our generation, without writing the identity of the commenter. But I saw in a manuscript and it seems very likely to me that this great one is the *Baruch Taam*, and I do not know why in the first instance he wrote his name and in the second he omitted his name].
While in Verboy, Rabbi Chaim Sofer searched for a place to eat, drink, and sleep, as was customary in those days that students would eat days at the homes of householders. He found no place anywhere and was forced against his will to lodge with a certain wagon driver who was destitute. He gave him a "respectable" place to sleep in the horse stable, placing a partition between him and the horses so he could sleep in peace on the straw. Rabbi Chaim Sofer was very fastidious and suffered greatly from this. He also had no arranged place to eat, until one day the matter became known to his teacher, the Shaarei Torah, who took him to his home, and he studied with him until the middle of the night.
Years later, Rabbi Chaim Sofer told his close ones that all these difficulties were trials for him, to see if he would follow his mother's relatives to engage in business and negotiation and neglect Torah study, for simply put, all the students found a place to eat and sleep, and specifically he did not find one; it was all trials, and he merited to withstand them all.
The son of Rabbi Chaim Sofer writes that after several years, when his father returned to live in Pressburg, his city of birth, the Shaarei Torah once traveled to a certain place for health needs. On his journey, he stopped in Pressburg to visit the home of his distinct disciple, Rabbi Chaim Sofer, and told him that the Shaarei Torah hoped very much that his name would be publicized through his merit. His son writes that when the Shaarei Torah saw the extent of the poverty prevailing in his student's home, he wanted to leave the house immediately because he did not want Rabbi Chaim to trouble himself for him to honor him and spend money on him. But he could not leave immediately so as not to insult Rabbi Chaim. Therefore, in the morning hours, when Rabbi Chaim went out for the Morning Prayer, the Shaarei Torah took the opportunity and left.
The poverty that prevailed in the home of Rabbi Chaim Sofer was beyond measure. He had one candlestick for Shabbat candles, and he would always pawn it for food needs. He himself carved out nut shells and made them like cups, and in them, he lit the candles.
In the course of time, his teacher, the Shaarei Torah, exerted himself on his behalf, and he was accepted to the rabbinate in the village of Yamring. There he came to rest and inheritance, and also had some livelihood from the rabbinate.
Source: "Chodesh BeChodsho", Adar 5767, p. 1
Source: Be'er Basadeh

body_he: מַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁהָיָה עִם בַּת אֲחוֹת רַבֵּינוּ שֶׁלֹּא נִפְקְדָה וְנָסְעוּ לְעִיר הוֹלְשׁוֹב, לְהִתְפַּלֵּל בִּמְקוֹם מְנוּחַת הַשַּׁ"ךְ, וְלִתְקוּפַת הַשָּׁנָה נוֹלַד לָהּ בֵּן (ה"ה הָרַהַ"ג רַבִּי מֶנְדְּל גֶעלְדְוֶוערְטֶה) כְּשֶׁשָּׁבָה לְקִבְרוֹ לְהוֹדוֹת עַל הַיְשׁוּעָה שֶׁזָּכְתָה, וּבְדִיּוּק פָּגְשָׁה בַּמָּקוֹם אִשָּׁה שֶׁהָיְתָה עִמָּהּ בְּדִיּוּק בַּשָּׁנָה שֶׁעָבְרָה וְהֵבִינָה שֶׁגַּם הִיא בָּאָה לְהוֹדוֹת עַל יְשׁוּעָה. וְאָכֵן נִכְנְסָה אִיתָהּ לְשִׂיחָה וְהִיא סִיפְּרָה שֶׁבִּתָּהּ סָרָה מִדֶּרֶךְ הַיָּשָׁר וְעָמְדָה לְהִינָּשֵׂא לְקָצִין גּוֹי, וּבָאָה לְהִתְפַּלֵּל עַל צִיּוּן הַשַּׁ"ךְ, וּזְמַן מָה לְאַחַר מִכֵּן, זְמַן קָצָר לִפְנֵי הַחֲתֻנָּה, נָסַע הַקָּצִין עַל סוּסוֹ וְנָפַל מִמֶּנּוּ וָמֵת. בִּתָּהּ שָׁבָה בִּתְשׁוּבָה וְעַתָּה עוֹמֶדֶת לְהִנָּשֵׂא לִיהוּדִי, וְעַל כָּךְ בָּאָה לְהוֹדוֹת. (מִפִּי רַבִּי לִיפָּא גֶעלְדְוֶוערְטֶה בְּשֵׁם אָבִיו רַבִּי מֶנְדְּל. רַבִּי מֶנְדְּל הָיָה נִינוֹ שֶׁל הַ'כּוֹכָב מִיַּעֲקֹב', בֶּן בִּתּוֹ הַגְּדוֹלָה אֵשֶׁת גַּאֲבַ"ד טָאוּסְט, רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב מֶנְדְּל רוּבִּין. רַבִּי מֶנְדְּל הָיָה תַּ"ח מֻפְלָג וְהִרְבִּיץ תּוֹרָה בִּישִׁיבַת 'תּוֹרַת אֱמֶת' דְּקַמְנִיץ בִּבְרוּקְלִין עֲשׂרוֹת בַּשָּׁנִים וְהֶעֱמִיד תַּלְמִידִים רַבִּים וּגְדוֹלִים).[״שר התורה״ (ירושלים תשס״ט) ע' 634]
body_en:
...And furthermore, this was his holiness and purity [of the Holy Gaon, author of "Avnei Nezer" of Sochatchov zt"l] regarding all of Israel in what we saw with him as a wonder: That even though he was not a Kohen but an Israelite, he was careful and strict not to enter the tent of a corpse, and even near the righteous. And no one knew the secret of his reason and rationale. And now that we have merited the holy book "Shem MiShmuel" by his son the Holy Gaon, the Admor HaEmtzai zt"l, I saw there in Parshat Emor from the year 5672 that he wrote regarding this, and this is his language:
**"וּלְפִי הָאָמוּר יֵשׁ לִיתֵּן טַעַם חָדָשׁ שֶׁכֹּהֲנִים מוּזְהָרִין עַל טוּמְאַת מֵת, שֶׁהַטּוּמְאָה זוֹ הִיפּוּךְ מַהוּתָם וּמְקַלְקֶלֶת מַעֲלָתָם (ע"ש), וּבְהִטַּמְאָם לַמֵּת מוֹשְׁכִין עֲלֵיהֶם טוּמְאָה זוֹ, וְאוּלַי עַי"ז שׁוּב יִהְיֶ' בִיכוֹלֶת כּוֹחוֹת הַחִיצוֹנִים לִשְׁלוֹט בָּהֶם בְּבוֹא פְּקֻדָּתָם בְּעוֹד נִשְׁמָתָם בְּקִרְבָּם, וּבָזֶה יוּבַן טַעַם אֲנָשִׁים רָמֵי הַמַּעֲלָה יִשְׂרְאֵלִים שֶׁמַּקְפִּידִין שֶׁלֹּא לִכְנוֹס בְּאוֹהֶל הַמֵּת, שֶׁתָּמִיד הָי' בְּעֵינֵי לְפֶלֶא כַּאֲשֶׁר רָאִיתִי אֶת כ"ק אָבִי אַדְמוֹ"ר זַצַלָּלָה"ה מַקְפִּיד עַ"ז, וּלְפִי הָאָמוּר הַדָּבָר מוּבָן. עַכְלַ"ק וְעַיֵּי"שׁ בַּאֲרִיכוּת."** - "And according to what is said, a new reason can be given why Kohanim are warned against impurity of the dead, for this impurity is the opposite of their essence and spoils their virtue (see there). And by becoming impure to the dead, they draw upon themselves this impurity, and perhaps through this, the external forces will again have the ability to rule over them when their time comes while their soul is still within them. And with this, the reason is understood why men of high stature, Israelites, are particular not to enter the tent of the dead. For it was always a wonder in my eyes when I saw my holy father, the Admor zt"l, being particular about this, and according to what is said, the matter is understood." End quote, see there at length.
And the Chassid R' Shmuel Yechiel zt"l of Sochatchov told me that he traveled with our Holy Rabbi zt"l when he was abroad to the city of Holleschau to prostrate himself on the grave of his ancestor, our great Rabbi the Shach zt"l. When they came to the city, he did not want to stay in the city at all, and immediately they traveled to the cemetery. No man was with him except him (R' Shmuel Yechiel). Our Holy Rabbi wrote for himself a *Kvitel* (note) in the manner given to Tzaddikim, and began to write in the text: "I am Ploni ben Ploni" and calculated the entire order of generations from him back to the Shach.
In his request at the end, he did not see [what he wrote]. When he came close to the grave of the Shach, he pulled his shoes off his feet and commanded him (R' Shmuel Yechiel) to distance himself from him and further until a place where it would no longer be possible for him to see him. Afterwards, he approached his grave with wondrous emotions and stayed there for a long time. When he returned afterwards to his attendant who was standing at a distance, his holy face was burning like torches, and there is no estimating the magnitude of the joy that was upon him. He said to our Holy Rabbi: "Since you merited to be here with me also at the holy grave, say there at least some Psalms." And he waited for him zt"l.
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Tzvi Yehuda Mamlak Hy"d, "Abir HaRoim" (Piotrkow 5695) Part 1, Page 78

body_he: וְסִיפֵּר לִי הָרַהַ"ח ר' שְׁמוּאֵל יְחִיאֵל זַ"ל מִסָּאכָאטְשָׁאב שֶׁהוּא נָסַע עִם רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּדוֹשׁ זַצַ"ל כְּשֶׁהָי' בְּמֶרְחָץ בְּחוּ"ל לְעִיר הָאֶלִישָׁאב לְהִשְׁתַּטֵּחַ עַצְמוֹ עַל קֶבֶר זְקִינוֹ רַבֵּינוּ הַגָּדוֹל הַשַּׁ"ךְ זַצַ"ל, וּכְשֶׁבָּאוּ הָעִירָה לֹא רָצָה לִשְׁהוֹת בְּהָעִיר כְּלָל וְתֵיכֶף נָסְעוּ לְהַבֵּית הַחַיִּים וְשׁוּם אָדָם לֹא הָי' עִמּוֹ זוּלָתוֹ, וְרָאָה שכ' רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּדוֹשׁ לְעַצְמוֹ קְוִויטֶעל כְּדֶרֶךְ שֶׁנּוֹתְנִים לְצַדִּיקִים, וְהִתְחִיל לִכְתּוֹב בְּנוֹסַח: אֲנִי פב"פ וְחִשֵּׁב כָּל סֵדֶר הַדּוֹרוֹת מִמֶּנּוּ עַד הַשַּׁ"ךְ וּבַקָּשָׁתוֹ לְבַסּוֹף לֹא רָאָה, וּכְשֶׁבָּא סָמוּךְ לְקֶבֶר הַשַּׁ"ךְ שָׁלַף מִנְעָלָיו מֵעַל רַגְלָיו וְצִוָּה עָלָיו שֶׁיַּרְחִיק עַצְמוֹ מִמֶּנּוּ וּלְהַלְאָה עַד מָקוֹם שֶׁלֹּא יִהְיֶ' בְּאֶפְשָׁר עוֹד לוֹ לִרְאוֹתוֹ, וְאַחַ"כּ נִגַּשׁ אֶל קִבְרוֹ בְּהַאֲנָפְּלָאוֹת וְשָׁהָה עַצְמוֹ שָׁם זְמַן רַב, וּכְשֶׁחָזַר אַחַ"כּ לִמְשַׁמְּשׁוֹ שֶׁהָי' עוֹמֵד מֵרָחוֹק הָיוּ פָּנָיו הַקְּדוֹשִׁים בּוֹעֲרוֹת כְּלַפִּידִים וְאֵין לְשַׁעֵר גּוֹדֶל הַשִּׂמְחָה שֶׁהָי' עָלָיו, וְאָמַר לְרַבֵּינוּ הַק' אֵלָיו כֵּיוָן שֶׁזָּכִיתָ לִהְיוֹת כָּאן עִמְּךָ גַּם אֶל הַקֶּבֶר הַקָּדוֹשׁ וְתֹאמַר שָׁם עַכָּ"פ אֵיזֶה מִזְמוֹרֵי תְּהִלִּים וְהוּא הִמְתִּין עָלָיו זִיעָ"א.[הגה״ח רבי צבי יהודה מאמלאק הי״ד, ״אביר הרועים״ (פיעטרקוב תרצ״ה) ח״א, ע׳ ע״ח]
body_en:
The wedding of my grandfather, the Baal "Binyan David" zt"l, was in Bobov. Since my grandfather, the Av Beit Din of Ohel zt"l, was no longer alive, he was still at the joy of his engagement but passed away in the meantime before the wedding, therefore they held the wedding in Bobov with the Holy Gaon Rabbi Shlomo of Bobov zt"l, who was the uncle from both sides.
At the time of the wedding, the Rabbi of Bobov zt"l said that the Holy Elder, Maran the "Divrei Chaim" zt"l, is certainly very happy with this match. For he once approached the bookcase and said: **"עִם כָּל הַצַּדִּיקִים יֵשׁ לָנוּ שַׁיָּכוּת שֶׁל קִירְבָא אוֹ מְחוּתָּנִים, לְבַד מֵהַשַּׁ"ךְ זַצַ"ל, וְכָעֵת שֶׁזּוֹכֶה לְהִשְׁתַּדֵּךְ עִם אֶחָד מִצֶּאֱצָאֵי הַשַּׁ"ךְ הֲרֵי שֶׁשִּׂמְחָתוֹ גְּדוֹלָה..."** - "With all the Tzaddikim we have a connection of closeness or in-laws, except for the Shach zt"l. And now that he merits to match with one of the descendants of the Shach, behold his joy is great..."
With Maran the "Divrei Chaim" zt"l, there was great importance to one of the descendants of the Shach. If one came to Sanz, Maran the "Divrei Chaim" zt"l would give him all the money that came in to him that week. Also his grandson, the Holy Gaon Rabbi Shlomo of Bobov zt"l, held to this, that he drew the descendants of the Shach very close...
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Yekutiel Yehuda Meislish Shlita, Av Beit Din of Sighet, "Betzila DeMehemnuta", Toldot 5770, Page 19

body_he:
אֵצֶל מָרָן הַדִּבְרֵי חַיִּים זִי"ע הָיָה חֲשִׁיבוּת גְּדוֹלָה לְאֶחָד מִצֶּאֱצָאֵי הַשַּׁ"ךְ, שֶׁאִם הָיָה בָּא לְצַאנְז אֶחָד מִנְּכָדָיו הָיָה מָרָן הַד"ח זִי"ע נוֹתֵן לוֹ כָּל הַכֶּסֶף שֶׁנִּכְנַס בְּאוֹתוֹ שָׁבוּעַ.
גַּם נֶכְדּוֹ הַגָּהַ"ק רַבִּי שְׁלֹמֹה מִבַּאבּוֹב זִי"ע הֶחֱזִיק בְּכָךְ שֶׁקֵּרֵב לִמְאוֹד לְנֶכְדֵי הַשַּׁ"ךְ...[הגה״צ רבי יקותיאל יהודה מייזליש שליט״א, אבד״ק סיגייט, ״בצילא דמהימנותא״, תולדות תש״ע, ע׳ י״ט]
body_en:
The 'Divrei Chaim' used to draw the descendants of the Shach close, saying that with all the great ones he was connected by family ties, and only with the Shach he found no family connection, and he wanted a connection with him, therefore he drew his descendants close.
Indeed, in Sanz there was one of the heads of the community, a respected Torah scholar and man of deeds, and the 'Divrei Chaim' was very close to him. Another Jew heard about this in the town, who was also a grandson of the Shach. However, this Jew was very simple and naively thought that the Rabbi would show him those same signs of affection that he showed to the first one. Indeed, the Rabbi of Sanz drew him close, but not like the first one.
When asked about this, he answered that there are two types of Shas (Talmud sets). There is a Shas from the Slavita press which is glorious in its printing, and there is a Shas from Dyhernfurth whose letters are broken, and it is hard to learn from it (From the mouth of Rabbi Ephraim Padua, Av Beit Din of London).
Source: The Gaon of Tchebin zt"l, "Sar HaTorah" (Jerusalem 5769) Page 640

The Holy Admor the Elder [Author of the Tanya zt"l] once ruled on a certain matter, a Halacha for practical application, not like the Shach. The Shach revealed himself to him and asked him to correct it and rule like him, and because of this, he would reveal an important matter to him.
And he revealed to him, that at the time when he [the Baal HaTanya] enters into *Dveikut* (cleaving to G-d) in "Echad" (so I heard in this language) - the Head Tefillin sometimes tilts to the side, and the angels laugh at him. And it is understood that the Rabbi corrected this. (Maharsha"g zt"l).
Source: Rabbi Chaim Mordechai HaKohen Perlow zt"l, "Likutim Sipurim" (Jerusalem 5762) Page 76

"Nekudos HaKesef" - Our Rabbi the Shach printed his book "Siftei Kohen" on the section of Yoreh Deah when he was only 24 years old. And on this book, 18 great sages of Israel wrote enthusiastic approbations. At that time, the Taz printed his book on Yoreh Deah. The Taz was already an eminent elder and the Shach was young as mentioned, and there were those who said there is no reason to rule like the Shach because the Taz is greater than him in wisdom and age.
The Shach published critiques on the book of the Taz called "Nekudos HaKesef" (Points of Silver), named after the verse (Song of Songs 1:11) "We will make you rows of gold with points of silver." And the Shach writes in his introduction to his book *Nekudos HaKesef* in this language: **"אָמַר הַמְחַבֵּר, אַל יַעֲלֶה עַל לֵב הַקּוֹרֵא בְּסִפְרִי זֶה שֶׁמִּפְּנֵי שֶׁהָיָה לִי ח"ו אֵיזֶה מַחֲלֹקֶת עַל בַּעַל הַטּוּרֵי זָהָב אוֹ יֵשׁ לִי בְּלִבִּי אֵיזוֹ טִינָא עָלָיו חִבַּרְתִּי הַהַשָּׂגוֹת עַל סִפְרוֹ, כִּי הֲלֹא נוֹדַע לַכֹּל כִּי נִתְקַיֵּם בָּנוּ אֶת וָהֵב בְּסוּפָה וְהַתּוֹרָה מְחַזֶּרֶת עַל אַכְסַנְיָא שֶׁלָּהּ, שֶׁנַּעֲשֵׂיתִי אַכְסַנְיָא לְהַבַּעַל טוּרֵי זָהָב וְהָיָה אֶצְלִי שְׁלֹשָׁה יָמִים וְכִבַּדְתִּיו כָּבוֹד גָּדוֹל אֲשֶׁר לֹא יְאֻמַּן כִּי יְסֻפַּר, וְגַם הוּא נִתְכַּבֵּד בִּי הַרְבֵּה עַד שֶׁנְּשָׁקַנִי עַל רֹאשִׁי וְשָׂמַח בִּי מַמָּשׁ כְּשִׂמְחַת בֵּית הַשּׁוֹאֵבָה"** - "The author said: Let it not arise on the heart of the reader in this book of mine that because I had, Heaven forbid, any dispute with the author of *Turei Zahav* or I have in my heart any grudge against him that I composed the critiques on his book. For is it not known to all that 'Et Vahev BeSufah' (Love at the end) was fulfilled in us, and the Torah returns to its host. For I became a host to the author of *Turei Zahav* and he was with me for three days, and I honored him with great honor which would not be believed if told. And he also was honored by me greatly until he kissed me on my head and rejoiced in me literally like the joy of Simchat Beit HaShoeivah." End quote.
[And his intention, that regarding the Joy of Simchat Beit HaShoeivah, the Tosafot wrote in Sukkah (50b s.v. Chad) in the name of the Yerushalmi, that from there they drew the Holy Spirit (Ruach HaKodesh). And automatically, when two giants of the generation, commentators of the Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah, met, certainly this was a joy of a Mitzvah, from which they draw the Holy Spirit, similar to the joy of Simchat Beit HaShoeivah.
Regarding this matter, we find in Tosafot Chagigah (15a s.v. Shuvu) in the name of the Yerushalmi regarding Rabbi Elisha ben Avuya [Acher] who went out to evil culture. And it is in the Yerushalmi that this happened because of an incident that occurred: Avuya his father was one of the greats of Jerusalem. On the day he came to circumcise him, he called all the greats of Jerusalem and seated them in one house, and Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua in another place. While they were eating and drinking, they began clapping and dancing. They (R' Eliezer and R' Yehoshua) said: While they are engaging in theirs, we will engage in ours. They sat and engaged in words of Torah. Fire came down from Heaven and surrounded them. Avuya said to them: My masters, did you come to burn my house? They said to him: Heaven forbid, rather we were sitting and repeating words of Torah from the Torah to the Prophets and from the Prophets to the Writings, and the words were joyful as when they were given from Sinai, they were not given with fire. End quote.
And so too with the Shach and the Taz, the words were joyful as when they were given from Sinai, and they were joyful like in the Joy of Simchat Beit HaShoeivah, from where they draw the Holy Spirit.]
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Natan Gestetner zt"l, Av Beit Din of Kiryat Agudat Yisrael Bnei Brak, "HaYeshiva", Nissan 5766, Page 22

הַשַּׁ"ךְ הוֹצִיא לָאוֹר הַשָּׂגוֹת עַל ס' הַטַּ"ז בְּשֵׁם "נְקֻדּוֹת הַכֶּסֶף", עַל שֵׁם הַפָּסוּק (שִׁיר הַשִּׁירִים א, יא) תּוֹרֵי זָהָב נַעֲשֶׂה לָּךְ עִם נְקֻדּוֹת הַכָּסֶף, וְכוֹתֵב הַשַּׁ"ךְ בְּהַקְדָּמָתוֹ לְחִבּוּרוֹ נְקֻדּוֹת הַכֶּסֶף בְּזֶהַ"ל: "אָמַר הַמְחַבֵּר, אַל יַעֲלֶה עַל לֵב הַקּוֹרֵא בְּסִפְרִי זֶה שֶׁמִּפְּנֵי שֶׁהָיָה לִי ח"ו אֵיזֶה מַחֲלֹקֶת עַל בַּעַל הַטּוּרֵי זָהָב אוֹ יֵשׁ לִי בְּלִבִּי אֵיזוֹ טִינָא עָלָיו חִבַּרְתִּי הַשָּׂגוֹת עַל סִפְרוֹ, כִּי הֲלֹא נוֹדַע לַכֹּל כִּי נִתְקַיֵּם בָּנוּ אֶת וָהֵב בְּסוּפָה וְהַתּוֹרָה מְחַזֶּרֶת עַל אַכְסַנְיָא שֶׁלָּהּ, שֶׁנַּעֲשֵׂיתִי אַכְסַנְיָא לְהַבַּעַל טוּרֵי זָהָב וְהָיָה אֶצְלִי שְׁלֹשָׁה יָמִים וְכִבַּדְתִּיו כָּבוֹד גָּדוֹל אֲשֶׁר לֹא יְאֻמַּן כִּי יְסֻפַּר, וְגַם הוּא נִתְכַּבֵּד בִּי הַרְבֵּה עַד שֶׁנְּשָׁקַנִי עַל רֹאשִׁי וְשָׂמַח בִּי מַמָּשׁ כְּשִׂמְחַת בֵּית הַשּׁוֹאֵבָה", עַכָּ"ד.
[וְכַוָּנָתוֹ, שֶׁבְּשִׂמְחַת בֵּית הַשּׁוֹאֵבָה כָּתְבוּ הַתּוֹס' בְּסֻכָּה (נ: ד"ה חַד) בְּשֵׁם יְרוּשַׁלְמִי, שֶׁמִּשָּׁם שָׁאֲבוּ רוּחַ הַקֹּדֶשׁ. וּמִמֵּילָא, כְּשֶׁנִּפְגְּשׁוּ בֵּינֵיהֶם שְׁנֵי גְּדוֹלֵי הַדּוֹר מְפָרְשֵׁי הַשּׁוּ"עַ יוֹ"ד, בְּוַדַּאי הָיְתָה זֹאת שִׂמְחָה שֶׁל מִצְוָה, שֶׁמִּשָּׁם שׁוֹאֲבִין רוּחַ הַקֹּדֶשׁ, דּוּגְמַת שִׂמְחַת בֵּית הַשּׁוֹאֵבָה.
בְּעִנְיָן זֶה מָצִינוּ בְּתוֹס' חֲגִיגָה (טו. ד"ה שׁוּבוּ) בְּשֵׁם יְרוּשַׁלְמִי בְּעִנְיַן רַבִּי אֱלִישָׁע בֶּן אֲבוּיָה [אַחֵר] שֶׁיָּצָא לְתַרְבּוּת רָעָה, וְאִיתָא בִּירוּשַׁלְמִי דְּזֹאת אֵירַע מִשּׁוּם מַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁהָיָה, שֶׁאֲבוּיָה אָבִיו הָיָה מִגְּדוֹלֵי יְרוּשָׁלַיִם וּבְיוֹם שֶׁבָּא לְמָהוֹלֵי קָרָא לְכָל גְּדוֹלֵי יְרוּשָׁלַיִם וְהוֹשִׁיבָן בְּבַיִת אֶחָד, וּלְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר וּלְרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בְּמָקוֹם אַחֵר, מִן דְּאָכְלִין וְשָׁתִין שַׁרְיוּ מְטַפְּחִין וּמְרַקְּדִים, אָמְרֵי עַד דְּאִלֵּין עָסְקִין בְּדִידְהוּ נַעֲסוֹק בְּדִידַן, יָשְׁבוּ וְנִתְעַסְּקוּ בְּדִבְרֵי תּוֹרָה יָרְדָה אֵשׁ מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם וְהִקִּיפָה אוֹתָן, אָמַר לוֹן אֲבוּיָה אַבָּא גַּבְרִין מָה בָּאתֶם לִשְׂרֹף בֵּיתִי, אָמְרוּ לוֹ חַ"ו אֶלָּא יוֹשְׁבִין הָיִינוּ וְחוֹזְרִין דִּבְרֵי תּוֹרָה מִתּוֹרָה לִנְבִיאִים וּמִנְּבִיאִים לִכְתוּבִים וְהָיוּ הַדְּבָרִים שְׂמֵחִים כִּנְתִינָתָן מִסִּינַי, לֹא בָּאֵשׁ נִתְּנוּ, עַכּ"ד.
וּכְמוֹ כֵּן אֵצֶל הַשַּׁ"ךְ וְהַטַּ"ז הָיוּ הַדְּבָרִים שְׂמֵחִים כִּנְתִינָתָם מִסִּינַי, וְהָיוּ שְׂמֵחִים כְּמוֹ בְּשִׂמְחַת בֵּית הַשּׁוֹאֵבָה, שֶׁמִּשָּׁם שׁוֹאֲבִין רוּחַ הַקֹּדֶשׁ.][הגה״צ רבי נתן גשטטנר זצ״ל, גאב״ד קרית אגוד״י-ב״ב, ״הישיבה״, ניסן תשס״ו, ע׳ 22]

Segulah for Fear of Heaven - In the collection "Kerem Shlomo" of Bobov (Year 4, Kuntres 6) it brings: The Admor Moharba"tz, Av Beit Din of Bobov zt"l Hy"d, was accustomed to say in the name of his holy grandfather, the Holy Gaon of Sanz zt"l, that it is very beneficial for Fear of Heaven that a young man should study Shach with Ketzot [HaChoshen].
Source: "Pi Tzaddik" (Brooklyn 5750) Page 65

"No secret is hidden from him" - Among the other things engraved on the holy tombstone of our Rabbi the Shach, this sentence is also found: **"כָּל רָז לֹא אָנִיס לֵיהּ...!"** - "No secret is hidden from him...!"
There is no need at all to believe in this [as mere exaggeration], for anyone who contemplates his compositions realizes on his own the endless control he had over the entire giant expanse of our Holy Torah, in all its subjects. We also find hints to his knowledge in the wisdom of the Hidden (Kabbalah) in his compositions. For example, in "Yoreh Deah" (Siman 277), our Rabbi the Shach brings in the name of **"חַכְמֵי הָאֱמֶת"** - "The Sages of Truth" (Kabbalists) that a person needs to ensure that when he rises from his study, he should not leave the book he studied in open: **"וְיָדוּעַ לְחַכְמֵי הָאֱמֶת שֶׁיֵּשׁ מַלְאָךְ אֶחָד שֶׁנִּקְרָא שֵׁ"ד, וְהוּא 'ש'וֹמֵר דַּ'פִּין' עַל מִי שֶׁמַּנִּיחַ סֵפֶר פָּתוּחַ וְיוֹצֵא, שֶׁמְּשַׁכֵּחַ לִמּוּדוֹ"** - "And it is known to the Sages of Truth that there is one angel called 'Shed' (Demon), and he is 'Shomer Dappin' (Guard of Pages - an acronym for SHED) over one who leaves a book open and goes out, that he causes him to forget his learning."
In "Shem HaGedolim" by Rabbi Chida (Part 2, System Shin, Letter 134), he brings: **"וְשָׁמַעְתִּי מֵרַב אֶחָד, שֶׁהָרַב שַׁ"ךְ הָיָה יוֹדֵעַ שֵׁם הַמְּצִיאָה, דְּהַיְינוּ שֵׁם קָדוֹשׁ לְכַוֵּן בּוֹ, וְלִמְצֹא הַבְּקִיאוּת שֶׁרוֹצֶה תֵּיכֶף וּמִיָּד...!"** - "And I heard from one Rabbi, that the Rabbi Shach knew the 'Name of Finding', meaning a Holy Name to meditate upon, and to find the expertise/knowledge he wanted immediately and at once...!"
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Moshe Yaakov Kanner Shlita, "Tosefet HaModia", 19 Tevet 5768, Page 19
Source: Nezer Hatorah
Source: Siach Zkenim
Source: Demuyot Hod

He was born in Ferrara in the year 5448 [1688] [to his father R' Avraham], and he was murdered there on Rosh Chodesh Adar in the year 5503 [1743]. He occupied himself with the wisdom of Kabbalah and conducted himself with piety and abstinence. In the year 5477 [1717], he was ordained for the rabbinate by Rabbi Hillel Ashkenazi and was appointed as the Rabbi of Gorizia.
Due to his desire to thoroughly understand the wisdom of Kabbalah, he left his position after about a year, ascended to the Land of Israel, and settled in Safed. There, he was ordained for the rabbinate a second time by Rabbi Chaim Abulafia, the Rabbi of Safed. After his daughter passed away in a plague, he left the Land in the year 5480 [1720] and returned to Italy, where he was appointed as the Rabbi of Florence, staying there for 21 years.
For the purpose of printing his book, he wandered from place to place; among others, he traveled to Izmir, Salonika, Constantinople, London, and Syria. In the year 5497 [1737], he arrived in Jerusalem. About three years later, he returned to Italy and continued his wanderings. During one of his journeys, when he was close to the city of Reggio, he was murdered [on Rosh Chodesh Adar 5503] by robbers, who buried him near the shore. Six days later, his body was found by Jews from Modena, who brought him to a Jewish grave in the city of Cento.
Source: Ateret Avot (Jerusalem 5775), Vol. 3, p. 517
---

The holy Gaon, Rabbi Immanuel Chai Riki, may his merit protect us—author of *Mishnat Chassidim*—was among the greatest Kabbalists of his generation. His important book, *Mishnat Chassidim*, is founded and based primarily on the writings of our master, the Arizal. Its interior is paved with love, containing short compilations of the intentions (Kavanot) of the Arizal and his holy cubs (disciples).
The holy Gaon, the *Divrei Chaim*, may his merit protect us, writes in praise of the book *Mishnat Chassidim* and calls it: **"סֹלת ְּברּוָרה ּונְ ִקּיָה"** - **"Clean and pure flour."** [The reason the Divrei Chaim writes that it is clean and pure flour is because in those days there were many manuscripts circulating where the source was doubtful regarding who truly wrote them. However, those writings that our master the author brings are truly the writings of the Arizal upon which one can rely.]
Additionally, our master authored the book *Maaseh Choshev* on the matters of the work of the Tabernacle and its vessels, and the book *Choshev Machashavot* on the laws of Mikvaot. All his books are arranged and written with extreme brevity, yet they are filled with endless depth, to the point that they require great study to understand and comprehend his innovations.
The Chida, may his merit protect us, writes about him in *Shem Hagedolim* in his entry, that for twenty-two years, he fasted every weekday and conducted himself with piety and holiness. He visited Safed and Jerusalem and passed away in the country of Italy. Some say he was killed for the Sanctification of the Name (Kiddush Hashem) in the year 5503 [1743] in Italy, due to the many decrees the Jews suffered there. To this day, there are members of the Riki family in Italy.
In addition to these books, he authored another book called **"הֹון ָעשיר"** - **"Hon Ashir"** on the six orders of Mishnah. At the beginning of Tractate Berachot, our master writes regarding the reason the Tanna opened specifically with the commandment of reading the Shema: because the first commandment with which one opens the night is the commandment of reading the Shema. Behold, the reading of the Shema is the acceptance of the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven, and the most fundamental principle is the acceptance of the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven.
In the books of the early sages (Rishonim), we find a dispute regarding whether the first utterance of the Ten Commandments, **"ָאנֹ ִכי ה' ֱא ֶֹלקיָך"** - **"I am the Lord your G-d,"** is considered a positive commandment or a negative one. The Rambam counted this in the number of the 613 commandments, whereas the Bahag and several Rishonim do not consider this within the category of a positive commandment. For behold, in the Mechilta, they said a parable: To what is this matter comparable? To a king who entered a city, and the people asked him to make decrees and laws for them. The king said to them: First, accept my sovereignty upon yourselves, and then I will give you laws. Therefore, the Rishonim disputed whether this constitutes a positive commandment.
The author adds that for this reason, the Mishnah mentions the matter of eating Terumah—from the time the Kohanim enter to eat their Terumah—because Terumah is the choicest part of the produce. Similarly, the reading of the Shema is the choicest commandment of all the 613 commandments, for it is the acceptance of the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven.
Source: Sichot Melaveh Malkah (Bnei Brak 5769), Vol. 3, p. 109
---

Regarding the attitude of the great righteous Kabbalists toward our master's book, *Mishnat Chassidim*, one can cite the words of the holy Gaon, the author of *Ateret Tzvi* of Zidichov, may his merit protect us. He writes in *Ateret Tzvi* (Zohar on Shemot, page 2b): "And the words of the *Mishnat Chassidim*, etc., are clean flour, etc., for he was a faithful copier." And in his book *Pri Kodesh Hillulim* (page 21), he writes: "And so is the custom, and one can rely on the Rabbi of *Mishnat Chassidim* even more, for he certainly saw all the pamphlets of the Arizal's disciples."
In the book *Amud HaTorah* by the holy Gaon of Razla, may his merit protect us (Letter Peh, 3), he writes: "Regarding our master, the *Mishnat Chassidim*, it is said of him, 'You shall listen to him,' and I have heard from speakers of truth that the Rebbe, the holy Gaon, Rabbi Shalom of Belz, of blessed memory, established a fixed time every day to study the holy book *Mishnat Chassidim* according to the *Maggid Mishneh*."
And in the Responsa *Divrei Chaim* (Even HaEzer, Part 1, end of section 101), he writes: "That the words of the *Mishnat Chassidim* according to the *Maggid* [referring to a commentary or interpretation style] show that his words are clean flour, and one cannot remove anything from it, etc., for the words of the *Mishnat Chassidim* are from the Arizal and his disciples or from the words of the great early Kabbalists, clearly and without error, and therefore one should not budge from his words."
Source: Beit Aharon V'Yisrael, Nissan 5772, p. 7
---

He was born in the village of Safrin, near Sambir in Galicia. His name was our master, Rabbi Yitzchak Isaac Eichenstein, of blessed memory (also called R' Yitzchak Safriner), son of the Rebbe R' Tzvi, son of the Rebbe R' Alexander, son of the Rebbe R' Tzvi, son-in-law of the Gaon, the author of the *Tosafot Yom Tov*, of blessed memory.
The descendants of our master from the Komarno dynasty signed their names with their family name 'Safrin', named after the village of 'Safrin' where their grandfather lived. The family name 'Safrin' passed to all the descendants of the Komarno house, while the rest of his family from Zidichov and Sambir continued with the name 'Eichenstein'. In the book *Asirit HaEifah*, we found the holy Rebbe Mahari"a of Komarno signing his name as 'Safrin'.
Our holy master was a disciple of the great and awesome man of G-d, the holy Rebbe R' Elimelech of Lizhensk, may his merit protect us... After the passing of his holy teacher from Lizhensk, our master traveled to his holy teacher, the Chozeh (Seer) of Lublin, may his merit protect us. He was his disciple and was considered one of his closest associates. The holy Chozeh showed him excessive affection and treated him with honor, just as he did for the great Tzaddikim, even though our master did not conduct himself as a Rebbe in his own home.
Once, on the holy Sabbath, the Chozeh took out his white robe, and with his own honor and by himself, he dressed our master in it. (Another version: The holy Chozeh removed the white robe he was wearing on the holy Sabbath and dressed our master in it. The Chozeh did not do this except for unique individuals of rare quality). From then on, wearing white on Shabbat became a statute for him and his descendants after him.
Our master wished to earn a living from the toil of his hands and distanced himself from the rabbinate, even though his livelihood was not always abundant. However, his home was open wide at all times. Our master held the lease on the village tavern, and also the road toll. When necessary, he also engaged in stone quarrying. And when someone had a complicated and twisted calculation that all the experts had given up on, our master would clarify and untangle the entire knot without any difficulty. However, his main occupation was Torah and good deeds, and all his livelihood pursuits were considered secondary to him.
Source: None
---

Once, a wealthy nobleman (a Polish squire) came before our master. He needed to perform very difficult calculations regarding his businesses and could not find anyone among the greatest mathematical minds who could perform this thoughtful work, except for our master. Hashem was with him, and he succeeded in his task, finishing everything in a short time, to the astonishment of all the clerks and servants of the nobleman. The nobleman saw that this was not natural; he handed over a large fortune to him and entrusted his businesses into his hands, and his name went out among the nobles as an honest and faithful man.
From then on, success smiled upon him, and his name grew great. His righteousness filled the land, and as his wealth increased, so did he increase his distribution of charity.
Our master's house was open to travelers and passersby. Our master was not satisfied with feeding the poor who came to him of their own accord at his table; rather, he brought in guests even against their will. For besides the tavern, he held the lease on the road toll. Since our master enjoyed the toil of his hands and did not want to accept the yoke of the rabbinate upon himself, and according to the law of the kingdom, every wagon harnessed to a horse or any animal passing through the village was required to stop before the window of his house and pay the fixed toll to his collector.
As was customary in those days, the road was blocked by a beam. After paying the toll to the collector standing at the window of the house—where one end of the beam rested on a latch—they would remove the barrier, and the traveler would then pass with his wagon and continue on his way.
That collector, a kosher and faithful Jew who sat and learned Mishnayot or recited Tehillim between one person and the next, was commanded and stood ready by our master: If a Jewish traveler arrived, he had no permission to accept the toll. Instead, he had to bring him inside the house so that he would pay the toll to [the Rebbe] himself. And when this traveler was a man who was not wealthy, not only did our master exempt him from the toll entirely, but he forced him to eat at his table for free, without money. Thus, poor people were found at his table at every time and hour.
Our master was not just a "hospitable man" like many village people of his generation who excelled in this virtue; rather, he was also great in Torah and good deeds. The six orders of Mishnah were fluent in his mouth by heart, as one reads "Ashrei yoshvei veitecha," and he was expert in the Shas and all four parts of the Shulchan Aruch, which he completed many times.
Our master was a great scholar, a "wondrous genius in seven wisdoms" (as phrased by his grandson, the Mahara"tz), and a hidden Tzaddik. He was known for the magnitude of his righteousness and fear of Heaven. Besides his holiness, he was a great Torah scholar and a very charitable man. To this day, there is a well in the forest in the village where our master immersed himself.
In his youth, our master was a scribe (bookkeeper) in the house of a wealthy man in Lemberg (Lvov). At that time, the Gaon, the *Ketzot HaChoshen*, was a tutor in the wealthy man's house. At night, our master would meet with the *Ketzot HaChoshen*, and they would delight in Torah together.
Since then, a friendship continued between them. Years later, when the *Ketzot HaChoshen* was appointed as Rabbi in the city of Stryi, near Komarno, our master continued to travel to him. When he had a difficult matter in Gemara, Rashi, and Tosafot, he would wrap the Gemara or the book in his bag, rise, and go up to the city of Stryi to present his doubts before him and debate the Halacha with him. Although Israel was not widowed of great Torah scholars—even in his own locale, where he could have sought Torah from their mouths—our master was accustomed to say that by walking to Stryi to that Gaon, he was fulfilling the commandment of the Torah: **"כִּי יִפָּלֵא מִמְּךָ דָבָר וגו'... וְקַמְתָּ וְעָלִיתָ אֶל הַמָּקוֹם אֲשֶׁר יִבְחַר ה' אֱלֹהֶיךָ בּוֹ. וּבָאתָ אֶל הַכֹּהֲנִים הַלְוִיִּם וְאֶל הַשֹּׁפֵט אֲשֶׁר יִהְיֶה בַּיָּמִים הָהֵם וְדָרַשְׁתָּ וְהִגִּידוּ לְךָ אֵת דְּבַר הַמִּשְׁפָּט"** - **"If a matter is too baffling for you... then you shall rise and go up to the place that the Lord your G-d shall choose. And you shall come to the Levitical priests and to the judge who will be in those days, and you shall inquire, and they will tell you the verdict"** (Deuteronomy 17:8-9). For that Gaon was the "Great Priest" of Israel and the teacher of Rabbis in his generation, and regarding a "Siftei Kohen" (Lips of the Priest) like him, it is said: **"יִשְׁמְרוּ דַעַת וְתוֹרָה יְבַקְשׁוּ מִפִּיהוּ"** - **"For the priest's lips should keep knowledge, and they should seek the law at his mouth"** (Malachi 2:7).
On Monday, the 1st of Rosh Chodesh Adar in the year 5560 [1800], our master arrived in the city of Stryi and passed away there. Apparently, this was his last journey to his friend and teacher, the author of *Ketzot HaChoshen*.
[Another version:] It is told that our master avoided traveling to the city of Stryi all his life because his mazal (fortune/intuition) foresaw that he would pass away there and be buried there. In the end, he was brought there in chains by policemen. And so the story happened: In the village of 'Safrin', where our master held the tavern, the district head (to whom the village belonged) forgot to collect taxes from the villagers for several years. The sum was large from many years, and the district minister demanded a large sum from the village master. The village master did not know how to make the calculation or how much to demand from each villager. Our master was famous as a great sage in the wisdom of mathematics; therefore, the village master asked him to make the calculation for him. Our master performed this calculation in a short time on a small piece of paper. With the essence of the calculation, the village master traveled to the district minister to pay the fixed tax.
Source: None
---

When he showed the calculation to the district minister in the city of 'Stryi', the minister was amazed by the calculation, and especially that it was on a small piece of paper. He asked him, "Who made this wondrous calculation for you? For even my greatest servants and employees were unable to do such a thing." The village master told him that a Jewish man who holds the tavern in his village made this entire calculation.
The district minister sent one of his servants to our master to come to him in the city of Stryi. At first, our master refused due to his fear, for all his days he was afraid to travel to the city of Stryi, and they did not know his reason. Then, due to the decree of the government, he was forced to travel there. When he arrived there, after a few hours, he passed away to the life of the World to Come. Then his intention became known, that he knew all his days that he was destined to be buried in the city of Stryi, may his merit protect us.
Source: Eser Kedushot, Shalshelet Hakodesh (Jerusalem 5767), p. 5
---

The Chassid Rabbi Yitzchak Isaac Safrin, of blessed memory, father of the holy Rebbe, the author of *Ateret Tzvi*, may his merit protect us, earned his living from the toil of his hands. He had a tavern from which he brought bread for the mouths of his children. Yet, despite this, he was a man elevated above the people and one of the Chassidim of the holy Rebbe, Rabbi Yaakov Yitzchak, the 'Chozeh' of Lublin, may his merit protect us. In revealed Torah (Nigleh), he debated much with the famous Gaon, Rabbi Aryeh Leib, author of the *Ketzot HaChoshen*, of blessed memory.
He had five sons, and all of them were known and famous as Tzaddikim and holy men. They are: The holy Rebbe R' Moshe of Sambir, author of *Tefillah L'Moshe*; the holy Rebbe R' Tzvi Hirsch of Zidichov, author of *Ateret Tzvi*; the holy Rebbe R' Berish of Zidichov (who continued the leadership of Chassidut after the passing of the *Ateret Tzvi*, regarding whom [the Ateret Tzvi] testified that he was greater than him in fear of Heaven, and he was the father of the holy Rebbe R' Yitzchak Isaac of Zidichov, may his merit protect us); the holy Rebbe R' Sender of Komarno (father of the holy Rebbe R' Yitzchak Isaac of Komarno); and the holy Rebbe R' Lipa of Sambir, may his merit protect us.
They said that their mother, peace be upon her, would wake up every night at midnight and weep and lament over the destruction of the Temple. She would also wake her children, who, out of being roused from sleep, would begin to cry as children do. Their crying would mingle with her crying over the honor of our House of Glory, and through her prayer and request that we soon merit its rebuilding.
The *Ateret Tzvi* counted three instructions and practices that his father insisted upon all his years:
1. He would not sit down to a meal unless a guest joined him to eat.
2. He never sat at a meal where words of Torah were not spoken.
3. All the days of his life, he never spoke about any person, neither for bad nor for praise. The holy Rebbe of Zidichov added: "That we should not speak ill of others—we too are capable of this. But to be careful not to speak even in praise of another person is very difficult for us to be careful about..."
Once, Rabbi Yitzchak Isaac complained and apologized to his wife in sorrow, after making a soul-accounting in the middle of the night, that he did not know how he could stand before the Heavenly Court after his days and years were full—with what merit would he come before them? His wife answered him wisely: **"בִּמְסִלָּה נַעֲלֶה"** - **"On the highway, we shall go up"** (Numbers 20:19). She hinted at the names of their sons with the acronym: **B**erish, **M**oshe, **S**ender, **L**ipa, **H**irsch... Witty interpreters add an acronym for the word "Na'aleh" (We shall go up): **N**ichnas **L**'Gan **E**den **H**akadosh (Enters the Holy Garden of Eden).
...The great Rabbi Yitzchak Isaac mentioned above [father of the holy Rebbe R' Tzvi Hirsch of Zidichov] did not conduct himself as a Rabbi all his days; rather, he earned his living from the toil of his hands. He was fluent by heart in the six orders of Mishnah and the four parts of the Shulchan Aruch. He was one of the Chassidim of our holy master from Lublin, Rabbi Yaakov Yitzchak, of blessed memory. When he came to his Rebbe, he too walked in white garments on Shabbat, just like all his holy disciples of blessed memory (so wrote the holy Gaon of Spinka to me, who heard this from his teacher, our master Rabbi Yitzchak Isaac of Zidichov).
And his son, our master, Rabbi Tzvi Hirsch of Zidichov, said about him: "I am vinegar son of wine compared to my father." He constantly praised his holy attributes, among them: that he never spoke about any person, and at every table, there had to be words of Torah. When his sons began to learn, he instituted that every day one of his sons would say some words of Torah at the meal. He always ate together with all the servants with love of Israel.
His grandson, my father-in-law and grandfather, the holy Gaon, our master Rabbi Yuda Tzvi of Razla, of blessed memory, said: In his childhood, he was at the Seder night of Pesach with his grandfather, the aforementioned Rabbi Yitzchak Isaac. He still remembers and feels the taste of the sweetness of the wondrous light from the holiness of his grandfather, of blessed memory.
Source: Eser Kedushot (Jerusalem 5761), p. 17
---

**And your seed shall possess**
Our master [the holy Rebbe R' Yitzchak Isaac of Kfar Safrin, may his merit protect us] once said that he had a tradition: When the angel said to our father Abraham at the time of the Binding of Isaac (Akeidah), **"אַל תִּשְׁלַח יָדְךָ אֶל הַנַּעַר"** - **"Do not stretch out your hand against the lad"** (Genesis 22:12), our father Abraham, peace be upon him, did not listen to him until he promised him that Rashi would descend from him.
His son, the holy Rebbe R' Moshe of Sambir, added that this is hinted at in the verse **"וְיִרַשׁ זַרְעֲךָ"** - **"And your seed shall possess"** (Genesis 22:17). The letters of **'וְיִרַשׁ'** (Veyarish) are the letters of **'וְרַשִׁ"י'** (V'Rashi - And Rashi). And words spoken fitly are sweet. (Ateret Zekeinim).
Source: Shalshelet Hakodesh (Jerusalem 5767), p. 14
---

He was born in the year 5536 [1776] to his father, the holy Rebbe R' Avraham Yehoshua Heschel of Apta, may the memory of the righteous be for a blessing, author of *Ohev Yisrael*. When he reached marriageable age, he married the Rebbetzin Mirel, daughter of the holy Rebbe R' Chaim Yaakov of Dukla, may the memory of the righteous be for a blessing (one of the disciples of the holy Rebbe R' Menachem Mendel of Rimanov, may the memory of the righteous be for a blessing).
With the passing of his holy father on the 5th of Nissan 5585 [1825], he filled his place in leading his holy congregation. He established his court in the city of Zinkov. He passed away on Rosh Chodesh Adar 5615 [1855] and is buried in Zinkov.
Source: Ba'alotz Tzaddikim (Shikun Skvira 5760), p. 23
---

I heard from the grandson of the holy Rebbe, the Chassid R' Moshe Zilberman [z"l] (today in Brooklyn), who was once present with the holy Rebbe [Mahara"a of Belz], may his merit protect us, in his holy chamber on the 2nd of [Rosh Chodesh] Adar, the night of the Hillula (anniversary of passing) of the holy Rebbe R' Yitzchak Meir of Zinkov, of blessed memory. The Rebbe spoke about his grandfather, the Tzaddik of Zinkov, and told the following:
The holy Rebbe of Apta, author of the *Ohev Yisrael*, may his merit protect us, once traveled to a certain city. On the way to the town, a large crowd came out to greet his holy face at a great distance from the city. This caused the holy Rebbe of Apta grief, and he was very distressed by the honor the Rabbi [himself] was receiving. As he approached closer to the city boundaries, multitudes more came out to greet him. And when he entered the town to reach his destination, additional crowds added to the throng, coming to seek him and welcome the face of the Tzaddik at the city gates.
This matter pained the holy Rebbe of Apta, may his merit protect us, and he was very distressed with great sorrow, bitter that "who is he and what is he" to merit such things.
Source: None
---

Behold, his son, the Tzaddik of Zinkov, Rabbi Yitshe Meir—"who was very clever!" as the Rebbe emphasized—wished to calm his holy father's mind. He said to him, essentially, that the crowd had come due to *his* [the son's] merit and for *his* honor! Indeed, his father's mind was put at ease, and he calmed down.
After the "Shalom taking" (greeting ceremony) from the entire huge crowd, the "Apta Rav" went to his lodging and turned to his holy son and asked him: "Indeed, the crowd did not come for my honor, but to call upon you! But tell me: Why, and for what reason, did you merit this?..."
The son answered him immediately: Because I am your son!!!
The holy Rebbe of Apta responded by interpreting the verse (Genesis 45:13): **"וְהִגַּדְתֶּם לְאָבִי אֶת כָּל כְּבוֹדִי בְּמִצְרַיִם וגו'"** - **"And you shall tell my father of all my glory in Egypt, etc."** He asked: How could Joseph the Tzaddik boast about himself? Rather, **"לְאָבִי"** - **"To my father"**! Meaning: All my glory that is in Egypt is **"לְאָבִי"** - meaning, because of my father!
[According to tradition, the understanding of the matter is: Because initially, the son said the crowd arrived for his own honor, thereby hurting his father's honor, he then retracted and said everything was due to the father's merit, not his own merit, thus restoring the honor to his father, etc. And this is the meaning of "To my father - all my glory."] (Heard from the aforementioned R' Moshe Zilberman [z"l], who was present at the holy chamber). It should be noted that the Rebbe repeated this story again when he paid a courtesy visit to the holy Rebbe of Kopyczynce, at the lodging of the holy Rebbe Mahara"a of Sadigura (as all three were grandsons of the Tzaddikim of Zinkov and Apta). The Rebbe told them this story in the exact words quoted below.
It is also important to bring here a slightly different version (in brief) that I heard the Rebbe tell—during that visit, a conversation of Tzaddikim—that once the holy Rebbe of Apta was traveling in a carriage, and he arrived at a place where they honored him greatly, and he became very pale. His son, Rabbi Yitshe Meir, noticed this immediately [- "A child is still a child!" the Rebbe noted -] and asked him: Father, what happened?... His father answered that he was afraid of the honor - - - ! The son said to him: "Tatte (Father), they don't mean you! They only mean me!..." His father calmed down and his mind was put at ease, and he said to him: "You have revived me!..." (= You have given me life, my son).
Afterward, Rabbi Yitshe Meir explained to his father: Why do they give him such honor? And he answered him: Because I am your son!!!
The Rebbe said: "The Tatte (Father), of blessed memory, used to say: The world says a 'Vort' (a saying), that 'because of the story', the Apta Rav interprets the verse: **'וְהִגַּדְתֶּם לְאָבִי אֶת כָּל כְּבוֹדִי בְּמִצְרַיִם'** - **'And you shall tell my father of all my glory in Egypt.'** That all the glory is: 'L'Avi'! Because of the honor of my father!!!"
Source: Beito Naveh Kodesh (Petach Tikva 5709), Nissan Part 1, p. 133
---

body_he: אֲנִי בִּנְעוּרַי סָבַלְתִּי עֲנִיּוּת וְגָלוּת, הַחֹמֶר שֶׁלִּי נֶחְלַשׁ עַד שֶׁיָּכֹלְתִּי לִסְבֹּל אַחֲרֵי כֵן אֶת כָּל הַכָּבוֹד הַזֶּה...וְאַתָּה מִנְּעוּרֶיךָ וְעַד הַיּוֹם לֹא סָבַלְתָּ דַּחְקוּת, מַה יִּהְיֶה בְּסוֹפְךָ אִם לֹא תְּסַגֵּף אֶת גּוּפְךָ...אָמְרוּ, דְּבָרָיו שֶׁל הָ"אוֹהֵב יִשְׂרָאֵל" נִתְקַבְּלוּ, וּבְנוֹ הַגָּדוֹל סָבַל אַחֲרֵי כֵן שָׁנִים הַרְבֵּה מִמַּחְסוֹר וְגָלוּת עַד אֲשֶׁר שְׁמוֹ נִתְפַּרְסֵם לַמֶּרְחַקִּים..."חֲסִידִים מְסַפְּרִים" (יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשל"ט) ח"ב, עמ' 112
body_en:
The holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak Meir of Zinkov married off his granddaughter to the holy Rebbe Rabbi Avraham Yehoshua Heschel, the eldest son of Rabbi Yitzchak of Skvira. On the Sabbath following the wedding, the in-law was late for prayer. He apologized, explaining that it was his family tradition to recite the entire Book of Psalms before prayer.
Rabbi Yitzchak Meir answered him that he also has a tradition from his ancestors—to fulfill what is hinted at by the acronym of **"תְּהִלִּים"** (Tehillim - Psalms): **"ֹל'א תִ ְ 'קּפֹץ יָ ְ 'דָך ֵמ'ָא ִחיָך ָה ֶ 'א ְביֹון..."** - **"You shall not shut your hand against your needy brother..."** (Deuteronomy 15:7). [The letters T-H-L-Y-M correspond to the first/key letters of the Hebrew phrase].
Source: Bitaon Ohev Yisrael, Adar 5760, p. 9
---

I heard in the name of the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak Meir [of Zinkov], may his merit protect us, that he said the following: The world says about me that I have a good heart. And the truth is indeed so. But what can I do with a good heart? Can I give my heart to a Jew? [But what can I do with a good heart? Can I give my heart to the poor? Can the poor man eat my heart?]
But what do I do? Does not the Merciful One desire the heart? So I make an exchange with Hashem, blessed be He. I give Him my heart, and in exchange, He writes to me: **"לִי הַכֶּסֶף וְלִי הַזָּהָב"** - **"Mine is the silver, and Mine is the gold"** (Haggai 2:8). And He provides me with enough so that I can grant the poor according to their needs.
Source: Kerem Beit Yisrael (Jerusalem 5762), p. 132
---

Our master [the Mahara"a of Belz], may his merit protect us, told in his room on the night of the Hillula, the 2nd of [Rosh Chodesh] Adar, praising the Tzaddik Rabbi Yitshe Meir of Zinkov, who was a man of charity and hospitality, and a lover of the poor.
A story happened once on the eve of Passover, in the middle of the day. They searched for him in all corners of the house and the surroundings. After all search efforts came up with nothing, they finally found him standing in the cellar, distributing wine to anyone in need (R' Moshe Zilberman [z"l] forgot the exact details at the time).
Continuing the above story, I heard that the Rebbe added and told that the holy Rebbe Rabbi Avraham Yehoshua Heschel of Apta, may his merit protect us, concluded regarding his holy son—Rabbi 'Yitzchak' Meir, may his merit protect us, of Zinkov—as follows: "...Although my name is 'Avraham' [associated with Chesed/Kindness], etc., but in you [referring to his son the Mahari"m] lies the attribute of Chesed!!!"
Source: Beito Naveh Kodesh (Petach Tikva 5709), Nissan Part 1, p. 136
---

Our master Rabbi Yitzchak Meir would distribute all his money to charity, and he never had money for household expenses. He was always in debt to shopkeepers. When he returned from towns he had visited, he returned without a single penny because he had distributed and scattered everything to the needy. His righteous daughter, Mrs. Rachel'e, would travel after him to the towns, hoping she might be able to save some of the large sums of money for the household expenses.
Source: Bitaon Ohev Yisrael, Adar 5760, p. 60
---

Once, the holy Rebbe of Ruzhin said: If I had eight more Tzaddikim like the holy Rebbe of Kapishnitz (Kopyczynce) and the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak Meir, son of the holy Rebbe of Apta, we could bring the Messiah.
Source: Mizkenim Etbonan (Jerusalem 5767), Vol. 2, p. 42
---
Source: Demuyot Hod
Source: She'arit Yisrael
Source: Imrei Nachum

During the days our master [the Chiddushei Harim], may his merit protect us, was in Ostila [at the great wedding there], he befriended the son of the holy Rebbe of Apta, the holy Rebbe R' Yitzchak Meir of Zinkov, may his merit protect us, greatly, for so his father the holy Rebbe commanded him, saying that he was a contemporary of his age.
In his later years, our master spoke several times of the aforementioned R' Yitzchak Meir. When our master [the Chiddushei Harim] began to say words of Torah every holy Sabbath immediately after the Maariv prayer, he said that the Rebbe R' Yitzchak Meir of Zinkov also used to do so.
Source: Meir Einei HaGolah, p. 25a, Section 164
---

It is told about the holy Rebbe Rabbi Avraham Yehoshua Heschel of Apta, may his merit protect us (author of *Ohev Yisrael*), that he promised that after his passing, he would shake worlds Above to hasten the redemption of Israel. After he passed away, a delegation of Chassidim came to his son, the holy Rebbe R' Yitzchak Meir of Zinkov, to ask: What about his father's promise?
R' Yitzchak Meir dozed off for a moment, and afterwards said to the Chassidim: "Father came to me just now and said to me: It is written in Psalms (48:10), **'דִּמִּינוּ אֱלֹהִים חַסְדֶּךָ בְּקֶרֶב הֵיכָלֶךָ'** - **'We have thought, O G-d, on Your lovingkindness, in the midst of Your temple.'** When we were in this world, we 'thought'—we imagined—'Elohim' (G-d representing Judgment), that all the events occurring to the Children of Israel are judgments and punishments (Elohim = Attribute of Justice). However, **'חַסְדֶּךָ בְּקֶרֶב הֵיכָלֶךָ'** - **'Your lovingkindness is in the midst of Your temple'**—when I ascended Above to Your temple in Heaven, I saw that everything is kindness (Chasadim). So how can I ask, Heaven forbid, to annul them?"
Source: Yagdil Torah (Jerusalem 5767), Vol. 2, p. 46
---

Rabbi Yitzchak Meir of Zinkov had letters of Maggidut (preaching authority) from a number of towns in Bessarabia, and the residents of the towns were obligated to consult with him before accepting a Rabbi, Shochet, or Chazan for their communities.
Rabbi Yitzchak Meir happened to be in Liova and realized that a new Rabbi had been accepted without his knowledge. The members of the congregation justified themselves before him: "We needed a Rabbi and also a Chazan. A Rabbi happened to come to us who has a pleasant voice, so we accepted him."
Rabbi Yitzchak Meir retorted to them: "You chose a Rabbi who knows how to pray before the *Teivah* (Amud/Lectern). I would have sent you a Rabbi who knows how to pray before the Holy One, Blessed be He..."
Source: Bitaon Ohev Yisrael, Adar 5760, p. 7
---

I heard several times from my master, my father, of blessed memory, in the name of the holy Rabbi, our master R' Yitzchak Meir, of blessed memory, Av Beit Din of Zinkov-Apta [son of the holy grandfather, the *Ohev Yisrael* of Apta, of blessed memory]:
Once, a villager came before him. The Tzaddik asked him: "Do you have a livelihood?" The villager replied: "If I work, then I will have it!" and went on his way. His intention was: If he performs some labor or works in the field, then he will earn his livelihood.
The aforementioned Tzaddik received the moral lesson from the villager's statement as a hint regarding the service of Hashem, as the Sages said: **"יָגַעְתִּי וּמָצָאתִי"** - **"I toiled and I found"** (Megillah 6b).
Some time later, at one of the gatherings, when he spoke words of the Living G-d before his listeners, he incorporated the saying: "If I work, then I will have it."
With this, he explained their saying: **"אֲפִלּוּ שִׂיחַת חֻלִּין שֶׁל תַּלְמִיד חָכָם צְרִיכָה לִמּוּד"** - **"Even the idle talk of a Torah scholar requires study"** (Avodah Zarah 19b; Sukkah 21b). Meaning: A Torah scholar who hears even idle talk from a simple man, that too requires study. Meaning: He should understand to derive a moral lesson from it. For certainly, this did not happen to him for no reason; rather, there is some hidden intelligence in it that one needs to understand. And intentionally, the narrator was sent to him. And understand this well.
Source: Imrei Elimelech (Brooklyn 5764), p. 51
---

I heard in the name of the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak Meir [of Zinkov], son of the holy Rebbe of Apta. Once he came to a certain city and did not stay at his usual lodging house, but at another house. The owner of the first lodging house did not come to greet him.
On that day that the Rabbi stayed in the city, the Chevra Kadisha of the city arranged a meal, and they sent to call the owner of the first lodging house to the meal as well. When the Rabbi saw him, he asked him: "Why did you not come until today to greet me?" He replied: "Because they didn't call me."
Rabbi Yitzchak Meir said in these words: "Gentlemen, I will ask you a question. The Gemara (Gittin 55b) tells of **'אַקַּמְצָא וּבַר קַמְצָא חָרִיב יְרוּשָׁלַיִם'** - **'Because of Kamtza and Bar Kamtza, Jerusalem was destroyed.'** Is there any difficulty? Was it destroyed because of Kamtza? Was it not destroyed only because of Bar Kamtza? And what is Kamtza guilty of, that the destruction is named after him as well?
"The answer is: You, Kamtza, behold you knew that you are a friend! Why did you wait for them to call you and not come on your own? Rather, because he waited for honor, he caused the destruction of Jerusalem. For this reason, one who considers himself a friend is obligated to come to his friend's joy and not wait for them to call him." (Writings of Chassidim).
Source: Bitaon Ohev Yisrael, Adar 5760, p. 7
---

The holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak Meir had letters of Maggidut (preaching rights) from many towns, and it was his custom to travel to these towns. There were places where he would come on Rosh Chodesh, and he would conduct a Rosh Chodesh meal. He also came to Mezhibuzh from time to time.
Once, he came to Mezhibuzh for Rosh Chodesh Sivan and conducted a Rosh Chodesh table there. He said during the meal: The name of Asher's daughter is **"שֶׂרַח"** (Serach), which is an acronym for **סְ'עוּדַת רֹ'אשׁ חֹ'דֶשׁ** (Seudat Rosh Chodesh - Meal of Rosh Chodesh).
There was a clever boy there, namely R' Simcha Bik, who later became the Av Beit Din of Mohilev. He said that this is also an acronym for **רֹ'אשׁ חֹ'דֶשׁ סִ'יוָן** (Rosh Chodesh Sivan).
The Ruzhiner Rebbe was impressed and said: "The world says 'Nit kein Ayin Hara' (No Evil Eye)."
Source: Bitaon Ohev Yisrael, Adar 5760, p. 9
---
Source: Orchot Aharon
Source: Nezer Hatorah

I heard in the name of the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak Meir of Zinkov, may his merit protect us, that once he blessed an innkeeper before his departure from there, that Hashem should help him so that in the coming year he would still be with him.
The aforementioned holy Rebbe said to him: "Hashem will help that you will be a Baal Teshuvah (penitent), and I will be a Tzaddik Gamur (perfectly righteous). Then I will not be able to be with you, for **'בְּמָקוֹם שֶׁבַּעֲלֵי תְּשׁוּבָה עוֹמְדִין אֵין צַדִּיקִים גְּמוּרִים יְכוֹלִים לַעֲמֹד'** - **'In the place where penitents stand, the perfectly righteous cannot stand'** (Berachot 34b)."
Source: Kerem Beit Yisrael (Jerusalem 5762), p. 132
---

Once, a man entered to see the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak Meir, son of the Apta Rav, may his merit protect us. The Rebbe looked at him and asked him why he had come to him.
He told him that he came to see the face of the Tzaddik, as it is known that this is very effective for the rectification of the soul.
The holy Rebbe said to him: "Behold, you are also a Tzaddik, as per the language of the verse: **'וְעַמֵּךְ כֻּלָּם צַדִּיקִים'** - **'And your people are all righteous'** (Isaiah 60:21). And when you contemplate well upon yourself how you look, it will be a great benefit for you from this..."
Source: Mizkenim Etbonan (Jerusalem 5767), Vol. 2, p. 284
---

I heard from my father, the Rebbe, may his merit protect us, wondrous things from the last days [of the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak Meir of Zinkov, may his merit protect us] before his passing.
