My father, the Rebbe, of blessed memory, was present at the time of his passing, close to his table. Until the last moment, his mind was clear and settled. He surrendered his soul to his Creator in holiness and purity, and died literally with a kiss on the 2nd day of Rosh Chodesh Adar in the year 5615 [1855]. The details are wondrous, but this is not the place to elaborate. May his soul be bound in the bundle of life. (Torat Avot, Monastritch).
Source: Bitaon Ohev Yisrael, Adar 5760, p. 7
---

**The iniquity of Israel shall be sought**
A Baal Teshuvah (penitent) sat in the Beit Midrash of Rabbi Yitzchak Meir of Zinkov, entirely sad, broken, and crushed with bitterness.
Rabbi Yitzchak Meir passed by and said to him: "Why are you in such low spirits? A time will come when they will search for your sins and will not find them. You too will search for them, and who knows if you will find them. My father, the *Ohev Yisrael*, already interpreted the verse in Jeremiah (50:20): **'וּבָעֵת הַהִיא נְאֻם ה' יְבֻקַּשׁ אֶת עֲוֹן יִשְׂרָאֵל וְאֵינֶנּוּ'** - **'In those days, and in that time, says the Lord, the iniquity of Israel shall be sought for, and there shall be none.'** Why will they seek the sin?
"He explains: What is a sin? Zero. If one purifies the sin, one places it *after* a number of substance. It turns the one into ten, the two into twenty. Where penitents stand, perfect Tzaddikim cannot stand.
"And in the future, in those days, they will seek the sin—they will want to place it as purified *after* the Mitzvot to multiply them—**'וְאֵינֶנּוּ'** - **'and there shall be none'**..."
Source: Chassidim Mesaprim (Jerusalem 5739), Vol. 2, p. 138
---

**Traveling to the Tzaddik**
The holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak Meir of Zinkov, may the memory of the righteous be for a blessing, once turned to those sitting at his holy table and asked them: What is the concept of traveling to a Tzaddik? Not a single one dared to answer.
He, of blessed memory, said as follows: "In every Jew, a good inner point is hidden. But—**'הַשָּׁמֵן לֵב הָעָם'** - **'Make the heart of this people fat'** (Isaiah 6:10)—the Evil Inclination, with its schemes, strives to prevent this point from awakening. However, when one comes to the Tzaddik, he blows upon and awakens this point."
Source: Maasei Avot (Jerusalem 5765), p. 22
---

**Rabbi honors the rich**
Our Sages, of blessed memory, said in Eruvin (86a): **"רַבִּי מְכַבֵּד עֲשִׁירִים"** - **"Rabbi [Yehudah HaNasi] would honor the rich."**
I heard from a certain man who heard from my grandfather, the holy Rebbe R' Yitzchak Meir of Zinkov, may his merit protect us, that he asked: Our holy Rebbe [Rabbi Yehudah HaNasi], who did not benefit from this world even with a small finger, honored the rich?
He, of blessed memory, said that the intention is that until our holy Rebbe's time, the rich stood truly at a low level, and wealth was rolling in the streets, and no man desired to deal with it. However, our holy Rebbe elevated wealth and showed that even with this acquisition, there is a high service to Hashem. And he who withstands this test is greater than the test of poverty. Therefore, he honored the rich of the generation for this [test] itself. There is a long story about this, but this is not the place for it.
Source: Erchei Yehoshua (Jerusalem 5756), p. 159
---

**More than a fifth**
**"הַמְבַזְבֵּז אַל יְבַזְבֵּז יוֹתֵר מֵחֹמֶשׁ"** - **"He who squanders [for charity] should not squander more than a fifth"** (Ketubot 50a).
I heard in the name of the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak Meir, of blessed memory, regarding the holy Rebbe of Apta, may his merit protect us, that he analyzed why the Sages used the language **"הַמְבַזְבֵּז"** - **"He who squanders"** and not **"הַנּוֹתֵן"** - **"He who gives"** charity, etc.
He said: **"הַמְבַזְבֵּז"** implies language of contempt (Bizayon). Meaning, only one who needs to force himself to give contemptuously [i.e., treating the money as if he despises it to let it go], *then* he should not give more than a fifth. But one whose heart lifts him to give all that he has—certainly, he has permission to give.
Source: Bitaon Ohev Yisrael, Adar 5760, p. 9
---

body_he: כַּאֲשֶׁר אאמו"ר זצ"ל הָי' נוֹסֵעַ בַּקַּיִץ לְהִנָּפֵשׁ אָמַר פַּעַם אַחַת לְתַלְמִידֵי הַיְשִׁיבָה חִשַּׁבְתִּי דְרָכָי וָאָשִׁיבָה רַגְלַי אֶל עֵדֹתֶיךָ (תְּהִלִּים קיט, נט) דְּרַגְלַי הוּא כִּנּוּי לְתַלְמִידִים הַקְּרוּיִים בָּנִים (סִפְרִי וָאֶתְחַנַּן ו, ז) עַ"ד שֶׁאָמְרוּ (עִי' עֵרוּבִין ע:) בְּרָא כַּרְעָא דַּאֲבוּהָ וְכַאֲשֶׁר חִשַּׁבְתִּי לֵילֵךְ בִּדְרָכַי לְצֹרֶךְ עַצְמִי, מִקֹּדֶם אָשִׁיבָה רַגְלַי דְּהַיְנוּ תַּלְמִידַי אֶל עֵדֹתֶיךָ לְהַזְהִירָם עַל לִמּוּד הַתּוֹרָה וְהִתְנַהֲגוּת יְשָׁרָה.כ"ק מרן אדמו"ר מפאפא זצוק"ל"קובץ ההקדמות" (ברוקלין תשד"מ) ע' ט"ז
body_en:
The Gaon and Tzaddik Rabbi Yitzchak Shlomo Ungar (Shlita) [zt"l], Av Beit Din of Chug Chatam Sofer, one of the great disciples of the holy Admor the "Vayaged Yaakov" (of Pupa) zt"l, related:
This was the custom with our Rebbe, the "Vayaged Yaakov" zt"l. When the days of Pesach arrived in the Yeshiva of "Pupa," since most of the Yeshiva students did not live in the city of Pupa, the Rebbe ensured that they prepared the Seder in the Beit Midrash and everything needed for the sake of conducting the Seder according to its laws.
The Seder was conducted in the Beit Midrash while most of the Yeshiva students sat at the tables of the Beit Midrash, enjoying the splendor of the Divine Presence as their faces were directed to see the holy service of the Seder night conducted by their admired Rabbi.
The conduct of the Seder continued with sublime fear, sign after sign: Maggid, Rachtzah, Motzi, Matzah, etc. After the meal, the Rebbe announced in a loud voice "Tzafun," while turning his head toward the pillows and covers to take the Matzah. But behold, it was not found. The Rebbe understood that someone among the students had acted according to Jewish custom and taken the Afikoman.
As was his holy way, he spoke very little, especially on this night whose holiness is beyond all comprehension. Without speech or words, he gestured with his hand a motion of questioning, and immediately everyone understood that he wished to ask where the Matzah was. I approached the Rebbe with the Afikoman in my hand, with a shy face. The Rebbe signaled that the Matzah should be returned to him.
I saw that it was a time of joy (*Idana d'chedvata*), and I refused to return the Afikoman before meriting a proper blessing from the Rebbe.
The Rebbe saw that he was obligated to break his silence, for he would not receive the Matzah until he promised something explicitly to his student. Having no choice, he opened his mouth and said: "What do you ask?" Immediately I answered: "Bless me, Rebbe, that I may merit to grow into a Talmid Chacham and a G-d-fearing man." The Rebbe lowered his head as if deepening his thoughts and seized by contemplation. After a number of moments, the Rebbe raised his head and said: "My student, my dear one! I have acted for you in Heaven, and they agree and are ready for you to grow in Torah and fear of Heaven. What remains is only the demand for agreement and readiness on your part. With toil and exertion, you will certainly come to this..." (Kuntres *HaBikur BeEretz HaKodesh* - 40 Hours in the Land of Israel).
Source: "Ohr Chadash", Nissan 5763, p. 42

He was the fifth son of our master, the holy Gaon, Rabbi Chaim, author of *Divrei Chaim* of Sanz, may his merit protect us. He was born around the year 5590 [1830] and was named after his grandfather, the Gaon, author of *Baruch Taam*, of blessed memory. His holy father testified great things about his soul, saying that for three hundred years, such a lofty soul had not descended to this world.
He was the son-in-law of the holy Gaon, the author of *Yitav Lev*, of blessed memory, from Sighet. Initially, he was the Av Beit Din of Rudnik, where his holy father had served in the rabbinate before being accepted as Av Beit Din of Sanz. Later, he was accepted as Av Beit Din of Gorlice.
He was a fervent zealot and did not show favoritism to any man. His holy service was hidden, concealed, and veiled. According to the testimony of the greats of his generation, he was also great in Torah, with sharpness and expertise. He passed away on the 1st of Rosh Chodesh Adar in the year 5666 [1906] and is buried in the city of Gorlice.
Source: Yalkut Mikach Tov (Brooklyn 5762), Vol. 5, p. 206
---

The holy grandfather, the author of *Divrei Chaim*, may his merit protect us, once said about his son, the holy grandfather of Gorlice, may his merit protect us: "My Baruch has a soul that has not been in this world for four hundred years. He is entirely Truth, and behold, the world is full of lies. Therefore, he cannot tolerate the world, and the world cannot tolerate him."
Source: Kuntres Shefa Chaim, Parshat Toldot 5743 - Antwerp, p. 27
---

There is a saying from the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us. Once, there was an incident where someone disturbed the holy Gaon, the author of *Divrei Chaim* of Sanz, may his merit protect us. His son, the holy Rebbe Rabbi Baruch of Gorlice, said about that man that he is wicked and it is a Mitzvah to bury him.
His holy father said to him that he has proof that there is no commandment to bury the wicked. For behold, regarding the Exodus from Egypt, it is written about the Children of Israel (Ezekiel 16:7): **"וְאַתְּ עֵרֹם וֶעֶרְיָה"** - **"And you were naked and bare,"** meaning they were without any commandments. Yet seemingly, during the three days of darkness, they buried the wicked [who died then]. As stated in the Sages (Targum Yonatan on Parshat Bo), if there were a commandment to bury the wicked, then they *did* have a commandment! Thus, this is proof that there is no commandment to bury the wicked.
His son, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, answered him: This is no proof. For after he is dead, truly there is no commandment to bury him. But while he is *alive*, it is a commandment to bury him.
Source: Kuntres Divrei Torah, Pekudei 5749, p. 5
---

An incident occurred with the holy Rebbe, the author of *Divrei Chaim*, may his merit protect us. The custom was that any food brought to his pure table on the holy Sabbath, even once, would be placed on his table every Sabbath in its turn. In his old age, there were many foods placed on his table that he did not eat from.
Once, the holy Rebbe was cleaving [to G-d] in his thoughts, and the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, who sat next to his table, saw a poor man whom he recognized had not put food in his mouth for a long time. He gave him some of the soup that was on the table to revive his starving soul—soup that his holy father had not eaten from for several years.
Immediately afterwards, the *Divrei Chaim* aroused from his thoughts and asked for the food that his son had granted to this poor man. The holy Rebbe of Gorlice trembled and did not know what to do. Afterwards, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, expressed himself saying: "The Creator of the World granted me wisdom." He called the poor man and asked him, "How was the soup?" The poor man answered and said, "It literally revived me." When the *Divrei Chaim* heard the poor man's words, he was pleased and fell silent.
Regarding this, and also regarding the strong bond of the holy Rebbe of Gorlice to his holy father, he expressed himself after his father's passing with these words: "If they had told me before my father's passing that if I let them cut off my ten fingers, my father's life would be extended even by only ten minutes, I would not have hesitated for a moment. Immediately and instantly, I would have placed my fingers on the table to be cut off." We have no comprehension of his attachment to his holy father...
Source: Divrei Torah, Shelach 5763, p. 2
---

I heard from my friend R' Aharon Sofer, of blessed memory, that he was once present on the holy Sabbath of Parshat Va'etchanan with my holy uncle, the holy Rebbe Rabbi Baruch, Av Beit Din of Gorlice, while he was in Tarnigrad.
When he came to arrange his pure table, he opened and said: Moses our Teacher said (Deuteronomy 9:24), **"מַמְרִים הֱיִיתֶם עִם ה' מִיּוֹם דַּעְתִּי אֶתְכֶם"** - **"You have been rebellious against the Lord from the day that I knew you."** Because he was extremely humble, he attributed all of Israel's deficiencies only to himself. Therefore, he said: "You are good; only the deficiency is that I am your Rebbe."
And he concluded with these pure words: **"מַמְרִים הֱיִיתֶם מִיּוֹם דַּעְתִּי אֶתְכֶם"** - "Since the day you knew me and I became your Rebbe, you have had such a face [of rebellion]!" He would say this with such great broken-heartedness that everyone shed tears.
Source: Pi Tzaddik (Brooklyn 5750), p. 204
---

I heard from my holy grandfather, my teacher and master (the Gaon Maharash Engel of Radomishla), of blessed memory, that when he was in Rudnik (after he fled from his rabbinical post in Bilgoray under Russian rule at that time), he was sitting with the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us. There was a case of Chalitzah. All night long, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice sat and studied with him and another old Posek (Halachic authority) all the matters of Chalitzah, both revealed (Nigleh) and hidden (Nistar).
The next day, after the Chalitzah, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice said to the judges: "The deceased was here and acknowledged the good deed for the rectification you performed for his soul through the Chalitzah."
Source: Kol Hakatuv L'Chaim (Jerusalem 5729), p. 172
---

Once, Rabbi Yeshaya of Praga saw that several of his Chassidim were talking during the Torah reading. He turned to them with humor and said:
"With us, it seems they love the Torah 'Zu-Lieb' (too much). When they take the Torah out of the Ark and carry it closed, everyone kisses it. But when they begin to read from it, they start talking idle chatter, because they love it only when it is 'Zu'—meaning closed."
Source: Gedolei HaTorah V'HaChassidut (Jerusalem 5728), Vol. 23, p. 22

Regarding the greatness of the holy Rebbe Rabbi Baruch of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, it is told that Chassidim from Congress Poland came to take shelter in his faithful shadow for the Holy Day (Yom Kippur).
It happened that on the Holy Day, a severe illness (plague) spread, Heaven forbid, in the city of Gorlice. By order of the government, a decree was issued that all guests were forced to leave the city immediately and instantly, to save them from danger. They also ordered the synagogue that all foreign citizens must go to the train, and wait for the railway train they prepared to come soon to take them to their cities.
When they told this to our master (the holy Rebbe of Gorlice) during the break, that the Chassidim were worried that they were forced to travel on the Holy Day, our master answered that they should not go. They did not understand our master's saying. They explained the matter to our master again, that there is a decree, etc. Again, our master replied: "Fahren vellen zey nisht" (Travel, they will not).
Our master's words were fulfilled in their entirety. Shortly before Gorlice, the train broke down, and it was impossible for another train to travel through there. Until they fixed the train, it was already after the holiday, and then they all traveled to their homes.
Source: Chemdat Hakerem (Bobov), Mishpatim 5764, p. 3
---

The holy grandfather of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, once said to a certain Tzaddik who asked his advice on whether to listen to the Chassidim who wanted to crown him as a leader.
He answered him with words of wisdom: "If you *want* to be a Rebbe, then you are not worthy of it. And if you do *not* want to be a Rebbe, then you can be a Rav."
Source: Divrei Torah USA 5761 - Issue 29, p. 5
---

An original story from the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us (which I did not read in a book but heard person to person—from the subject of the story). I heard this from my father, of blessed memory, who witnessed the story himself; meaning, the subject of the story told it to him.
In our town of Helmec, there was a Shochet, Rabbi Eliyahu, of blessed memory, who was a G-d fearing man, etc. (I did not know him, but he himself told this to my father, of blessed memory):
When he was a child, he traveled with his father for some matter to Gorlice. In the morning, he went to the Beit Midrash to pray. Before prayer, he took a book to learn. In Galicia, the sharp-minded boys used to study the book *Maharit Algazi*. He was about nine or ten years old. He took out the book *Maharit Algazi* from the bookcase and sat by the table, studying with pleasantness and desire.
Meanwhile, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice came down from his house to the Beit Midrash to pray. Outside stood a boy of about 14 or 15 years old who was playing with buttons with his peers. When the holy Rebbe of Gorlice saw this, it pained him greatly that here in the Beit Midrash sits a ten-year-old boy studying *Maharit Algazi* with pleasantness and desire, while that older boy sits and plays with buttons before prayer.
The holy Rebbe of Gorlice left the Beit Midrash and stood next to that boy to watch his game. That boy lost all the buttons he had in the game. The holy Rebbe of Gorlice answered him: "Nutah, do you let yourself lose in the game?" The boy said: "What can I do? I have already finished all the buttons I had..."
The holy Rebbe of Gorlice said to him: "But you have some!" He showed him that he should tear the buttons off his coat and continue playing. And so he did; he tore off the buttons and continued playing. But again he lost. Again the holy Rebbe of Gorlice challenged him: "Do you allow yourself to lose?" He showed him to tear the buttons off his vest. Again he lost. He showed him to tear them off his shirt. He lost that too, and remained half-naked.
The holy Rebbe of Gorlice grabbed him by the lapel of his garment, led him into the Beit Midrash, and said to him: "Look and observe! Here sits a ten-year-old boy studying *Maharit Algazi* with desire and pleasantness, and you, a young man of fifteen, play with buttons? This is what you deserve..."
Source: Betzila D'Mehemnuta, Naso 5766, p. 14
---

I am compelled to tell what I heard from someone who was present himself at the time of the incident. There was a certain Jew in Rudnik named R' Yamish (and I still remember him in his old age). He was a Torah scholar and a G-d fearing man. This R' Yamish used to walk in worn-out clothes, and I still remember how his handkerchief always peeked out of his pocket in the manner of the poor.
Also living in Rudnik was a Jew named R' Yosef Mintzer (whom I did not know, but I knew his son R' Itzhe Mintzer). He was the magnate of Rudnik. Although many residents of the city were wealthy Jews from the basket trade (Kishlech) which they made into an industry in the city, R' Yosef was a mighty magnate and was the head of the community. He paid the largest community taxes (Kultus Steier), and everything happened according to his word.
Once, the holy grandfather of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, who served as Rabbi in Rudnik, noticed how R' Yosef approached R' Yamish, turned to him, and said: "Yamish, give me a pinch of tobacco to smell." For R' Yosef, the magnate, it was a great importance that he was asking him for a pinch of tobacco. R' Yamish immediately took out his tobacco box and gave it to him with fear and reverence.
When the holy grandfather of Gorlice noticed this (and he noticed everything happening around him), he began to burn like a flame of fire. He ran immediately to R' Yosef the aforementioned, and before the entire congregation, he slapped him on his cheek until the sound was heard throughout the Beit Midrash. He began to rebuke him for his insolence and audacity to approach a Torah scholar and ask him for a pinch of tobacco, and he threw him out of the Beit Midrash.
As if Rabbis are no longer found in this generation! Indeed, one must also marvel at the conduct of R' Yosef the aforementioned, who did not flare his nostrils in anger. Rather, he left the Beit Midrash in submission, removed his shoes, and entered to appease R' Yamish.
Source: Divrei Torah USA 5765 - Issue 22, p. 14
---

The Rebbe (the holy master, the Admor of Toldot Aharon, of blessed memory) told a story that happened with the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, of blessed memory. Once, two young men entered to see him. One of them was G-d fearing from the masses, while his friend was an ignoramus and empty. The second young man wanted to test the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us. He told his first friend before entering the inner sanctum that he had committed a certain great sin, and bet him that the holy Rebbe would not sense the sin.
After this, the two of them entered. When the G-d fearing young man extended his hand to the holy Rebbe, he received him with a cheerful countenance, etc. But when the second young man extended his hand, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice screamed at him in a loud voice: "Sheigetz! How do you dare show your face to the Holy One, Blessed be He, etc."
Then everyone realized to know that the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, saw everything with his Holy Spirit.
Source: Zechor L'Avraham (Jerusalem 5763), Vol. 2, p. 262
---

I heard about the holy grandfather of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, that he needed to travel for Shabbat to Bardiov. One grandson asked to join him on the trip, but the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, did not want to take him. His mother came to ask that he take him, and he said to her: "I do not want to, but since you request it, I will take him."
On the holy Sabbath morning, he hurried through his prayers. After the prayer and the meal, he told the Gabbai that he was entering his room to sleep, and come what may, he should not be woken.
Meanwhile, thunder and lightning began, a great storm. In the middle, lightning flashed and struck the grandson who was sleeping there in the adjacent room, and he was killed, may Heaven save us. Then they understood his intention retroactively.
Source: Betzila D'Mehemnuta, Vayishlach 5770, p. 2
---

*   **צדקה תציל ממות**
They asked Rabbi Yeshaya of Praga: "It is written **צדקה תציל ממות** - 'Charity saves from death.' But aren't a man's years allotted from the start? How will charity help here?"
Rabbi Yeshaya answered: "A man who gives charity above his means has an opening of the mouth to come with pleas and ask the Creator: 'You too, give me years above the allotment...'"
Source: Chassidim Mesaprim (Jerusalem 5739), Vol. 1, p. 98

I heard from my uncle, the holy Rebbe R' Shalom of Niska, of blessed memory—who was a great Torah scholar, a Tzaddik, and a holy man, and in his first marriage was the son-in-law of my grandfather, the holy Gaon R' Moshe Yosef of Ohel, and was in great friendship with my holy father, may his merit protect us, and was younger than him.
He told that once, at the home of the holy grandfather of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, for a full year, every single day in the morning, a crow (called *varane* in our locale) would come to the window at the height of the house and peck with its beak on the window. The holy grandfather of Gorlice used to call the crow "My Dybbuk."
In his holy way of concealing his paths, he dismissed the matter by saying that the crow surely built its nest on the windowsill and was coming to the nest. Nevertheless, every day when the crow arrived, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice would say: "Here comes my crow again."
During that period, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice traveled to Krakow—where there were many Sanz Chassidim—and stayed with the magnate R' Michel Shermeret. One of the days during his stay in Krakow, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice entered the room of his son, R' Shalom, and said to him: "Shalom, please enter my room and I will show you something."
When he entered his room, he showed him at the window the crow that used to come to his house constantly. The holy Rebbe of Gorlice answered and said: "Look now, the crow has followed me to Krakow." (And it was recognizable that this was the same crow that came all year to his window, for that crow had a specific sign: its tail was docked. This too is a novelty, for it is a rare thing to find a crow with a docked tail).
Source: Betzila D'Mehemnuta, Vayishlach 5770, p. 2
---

The holy Rebbe (Rabbi Chana Halberstam), Av Beit Din of Koloshitz, of blessed memory, told me what the holy Rebbe of Cieszanow, of blessed memory, told him about the holy grandfather of Gorlice.
Once, he stood to pray near the window facing the street. His eyes were open to the street. The elder Chassidim already recognized in him when his eyes were open but he was not seeing.
Similarly, once he conducted his pure table with a meat meal. They served the food before him, and he ate and distributed leftovers (Shirayim). Two hours later, he asked the Gabbai to bring him coffee with milk. From this, it became known that he had fasted that day and made himself appear as if he were eating. In this too, the wondrous Chassidim followed him and recognized in him when he was not eating. For this was the entire service of the Tzaddikim: to conceal their deeds and their holy service.
However, regarding the matter of sight, this work is harder, since the eyes are not under a person's control (see Nedarim 32b). But the Tzaddikim, due to the greatness of their service, merited this level to sanctify their sight.
[In connection to this concealment of his deeds, one can cite what the holy Gaon Rabbi Avraham David Horowitz, Gaavad of Strasbourg, of blessed memory, wrote—cited in the introduction to the book *Ateret Chaim*, Part 1: Once, my teacher, the author of *Pitcah Zuta*, traveled to Rudnik for Purim. He arrived there at dawn. When the holy Rebbe of Gorlice saw him, he told him in fear that he had just seen his father, the holy Rebbe of Sanz, may his merit protect us (who had passed away many years prior), and spoke with him about matters he could not utter. Afterwards, the holy Rebbe regretted revealing this and repeated: "Yesterday at night we spoke much about Tzaddikim, so presumably that is why I imagined so."]
Source: Shefa Chaim (Union City 5743), Vol. 2, p. 198
---

The holy Rebbe Rabbi Mandel Baron, of blessed memory, from Yasla, was the brother of my grandmother, Mrs. Chaytsha, peace be upon her. In the family circle, they told that the name "Mandel" was given to him due to the circumstances of his birth.
His father, R' Eliezer Yeruchem, of blessed memory [son-in-law of the *Divrei Chaim* of Sanz, may his merit protect us], had been married for several years and had not yet been blessed with viable offspring. Once, on a Friday night during the meal, the *Divrei Chaim*, may his merit protect us, turned to him, took out a single almond from the soup plate, and handed it to him, saying: "Da hasti a Mandel" (Here you have an almond).
Afterwards, he was blessed with this son, and in memory of the event, he named him "Mandel" in Israel. I did not merit to know Rabbi Mandel personally, as for most of his days he was known to be sickly and weak, confined to bed, and almost never left his city of Yasla. He was a famous Tzaddik, and all the Rebbes and Tzaddikim of the House of Sanz used to visit him and fulfill the Mitzvah of visiting the sick.
Source: None
---

Once, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, walked in Vienna. There was a certain wheel there that revolved upwards, and people were sitting on it [a Ferris wheel].
The holy Rebbe commanded that everyone should get off it. There was one person who did not want to get off. A few moments later, the wheel fell, and that person fell and was killed, may Heaven save us.
Source: Betzila D'Mehemnuta, Vayishlach 5770, p. 2
---

The Admor, the holy Rebbe Mahari"a of Pshevorsk, of blessed memory, told: My uncle, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, once spent Shabbat in Bilgoray. There were many Chassidim and men of action there. He saw a book that had been published by a certain "Gadol" (prominent figure), and he looked into it at what he wrote there concerning Zimri son of Salu, justifying his action. He became angry and threw the book to the ground.
The Chassidim of that "Gadol" were enraged at this desecration. He apologized to them, saying: "Behold, I did as is written in that very book! For he writes that Zimri son of Salu chose the evil in its minority—choosing the sin itself rather than the thoughts of sin which are harder than the sin. Therefore, when I saw this book, I had thoughts of throwing it to the ground. So, in order not to stumble in thoughts of sin which are harder than the sin itself, I threw it to the ground in practice."
Source: Sichatan Shel Avdei Avot (Jerusalem 5766), Vol. 1, p. 205
---

When a person looked at the clock hours after finishing a meat meal to know when the six hours would end so he could eat dairy foods, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice called him: "Glutton and drunkard! For he has just finished eating, and he is already looking to know when he can eat again..." (I heard this from the holy Gaon of Koloshitz, of blessed memory).
Source: Yud Gimmel Orot (Brooklyn 5754), Vol. 1, p. 235
---

When the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Engel of Radomishla, of blessed memory, once met with the Gaon Rabbi Moshe Chaim Lau, Av Beit Din of Piotrkow, of blessed memory, and they spoke about the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Engel told him a story:
A wealthy man and Chassid, R' Meir Bretfeld, conducted his business in partnership with his son, R' Leibish. Once, an incident occurred where the two could not agree. They chose the holy Rebbe of Gorlice and his brother, the holy Rebbe Rabbi Aharon, Av Beit Din of Sanz, may his merit protect us, as arbitrators. They agreed between them that the third deciding judge would be the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yehoshua of Belz, may his merit protect us.
In the middle of the deliberations during that Torah judgment, a man arrived wishing to deliver a specific message to the holy Rebbe of Gorlice. He came on an urgent mission from one of the Gorlice Chassidim who was sitting in prison for the crime of forging a transit document from Austria to Russia. The lawyer he hired suggested he appeal the verdict. However, he decided to ask the advice of the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, beforehand whether to do so.
The holy Rebbe of Gorlice listened to the question and replied: "There is no need to appeal. Soon the defendant will receive a pardon and go free."
A week later, King Alexander II was killed in Russia in the month of Adar 5641 [1881]. His successor declared a general amnesty in the country.
When the holy Rebbe of Belz, may his merit protect us, heard of this (about what happened in Russia and the amnesty), he expressed himself and said in his humility: "We cannot compare ourselves to the Rabbi of Gorlice, who foresaw the change of government in Russia."
And the Gaon Maharash of Radomishla, Av Beit Din of Piotrkow, of blessed memory, added: "He was a silent Baal Shem Tov." [The holy Rebbe of Pshevorsk, may his merit protect us, heard this from the Rebbe R' Aharon, son of the holy Rebbe R' Elisha, who was the son of the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us].
Source: Rabbeinu Hakadosh MiSanz (Jerusalem 5740), Vol. 2, p. 335
---

**A Wise Man's Heart is at His Right**
**"לֵב חָכָם לִימִינוֹ וְלֵב כְּסִיל לִשְׂמֹאלוֹ"** - **"A wise man's heart is at his right hand; but a fool's heart at his left"** (Ecclesiastes 10:2).
One can explain: Behold, if a wise man studies any subject, whether one tractate or several tractates, he always looks to his right [at the pages he has already turned] to rejoice in what he has already learned. But the fool forever looks to his left [at the remaining pages] to see how many pages he still has left to learn. And understand this.
The holy Rebbe Rabbi Baruch of Gorlice, may his merit protect us.
From the manuscript of his son, the holy Rebbe Rabbi Sinai of Zhmigrod, of blessed memory.
Source: Chemdah Genuza (Brooklyn 5762), Vol. 2, p. 8
---

One year, on the night of Rosh Hashanah, our master the Admor, may his merit protect us, told that the holy grandfather of Gorlice spoke Torah at his table on the night of Rosh Hashanah on the verse (Psalms 132:4): **"אִם אֶתֵּן שְׁנַת לְעֵינָי לְעַפְעַפַּי תְּנוּמָה, עַד אֶמְצָא מָקוֹם לַה' מִשְׁכָּנוֹת לַאֲבִיר יַעֲקֹב"** - **"I will not give sleep to my eyes, or slumber to my eyelids, until I find a place for the Lord, a dwelling place for the Mighty One of Jacob."**
Behold, it is brought in holy books that all creatures require sleep, even the water. However, this is until a person reaches levels where he cleaves entirely to the Holy Shechinah, the Source of Life. Then he does not need to give slumber to his eyelids. And this is the intention: **"אִם אֶתֵּן שְׁנַת לְעֵינָי לְעַפְעַפַּי תְּנוּמָה"** - "If I give sleep..." this is only **"עַד אֶמְצָא מָקוֹם לַה'"** - "Until I find a place for the Lord," meaning only until one reaches adhesion (Dveikut) with the Holy Shechinah.
The Chassidim who were there did not understand the relevance of this Torah thought to Rosh Hashanah. They asked him about the "P'tach Zuta" (Small Opening/Introduction). He answered them: "What do you not understand? This is the secret of Rosh Hashanah: **'מַאן דְּדָמִיךְ בְּרֵישׁ שַׁתָּא'** - **'He who sleeps at the beginning of the year...'**"
Source: Betzila D'Mehemnuta, Ki Tavo 5764, p. 3
---

The "P'tach Zuta" told that the service of the holy Rebbe of Gorlice on the eve of the Holy Day (Yom Kippur) was terribly awesome and openly revealed, and the weeping was beyond imagination... [This service was also seen with the "P'tach Zuta" himself. As my father (the holy Gaon Rabbi Avraham David Horowitz, Gaavad of Strasbourg, of blessed memory) told, when he ate from the soup, they didn't know what was more in the plate—soup or tears...]
But after the holy Rebbe of Gorlice had already entered for "Kol Nidrei," they did not see upon him such dread and fear of the Day. As is known from what is written in *Yitav Lev*, that when one arrives at the Day of Judgment, one needs to be joyful.
The "P'tach Zuta" also told that after the prayer of the night of the Holy Day, they would bring a bed into the Beit Midrash. The holy Rebbe of Gorlice would lie down on it until the morning light. It seemed to everyone that he was sleeping. But when the morning light arrived, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice rose from the bed and approached the Amud (lectern) for prayer immediately, without washing his hands.
There was once a time when he rose in the middle of the night of the Holy Day and wanted to start praying immediately. When he noticed that the congregation was not there, he asked the "P'tach Zuta": "Where is the entire congregation?" He did not want to answer that they were sleeping, so he said that they were preparing themselves for prayer...
The holy Rebbe of Gorlice said that on the Holy Day, there is no need to prepare for prayer, because from its beginning to its end, it is all one.
Source: Betzila D'Mehemnuta, Ki Tavo 5764, p. 3
---

The holy Rebbe of Gorlice did not go to a "Shalom Zachar." They asked him the reason for this matter, since his father, the *Divrei Chaim*, did go.
He answered: "What is the concept of coming to a Shalom Zachar? That we come to comfort the baby who came from a world that is entirely light to this world, and he is very distressed by this. And with what can we comfort him? Through my father coming and showing the baby what a baby can grow into! Then the baby was comforted and filled with vitality. But if I go and he sees what grew from me, with what will the baby be comforted?..."
Thus he clothed his conduct in concealment.
Source: Halichot Kodesh, Elul 5765, p. 8
---

The holy grandfather of Gorlice once said to his brother, the holy Gaon of Shinova, may his merit protect us: "Tell me please, my brother. Did we not come out of one womb and have one father for both of us? And we walk on one path. Why then are our words contradictory, such that one always says the opposite of what the other says?
"But I will tell you the difference between us. You, when you see a mountain full of lies but inside it there is a tiny point of truth, then out of your great longing to reach the truth, you feel around and break the entire mountain just to attain the point of truth.
"Whereas I, when I find a mountain full of truth but inside it there is a tiny point of lies, I throw away the entire mountain (in his holy language: 'Schlag ich kapores mit dem ganzen barg' - I use the whole mountain for Kapores/discard it) because of the point of lies within it."
Indeed, anyone who knows and recognizes their holy paths will see in the words of this parable a general definition of their ways: Both of them sought the truth, but the holy Rebbe of Shinova loved the truth greatly, while the holy grandfather of Gorlice hated falsehood greatly. And these words are ancient (venerable).
Source: Kuntres Shefa Chaim, Parshat Toldot 5743 - Antwerp, p. 27
---

My grandfather (the holy Rebbe Rabbi Elimelech Horowitz), of blessed memory, said in the name of the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, of blessed memory, who said: Why is it the way of the world that a person loves his grandchildren very much?
He said in his language: "Weil mein soney's soney iz mir a guter freint" (Because my enemy's enemy is my good friend). [For the son is the "enemy" of the father, meaning that sometimes it is the nature of sons to deviate from the words of their fathers and be contrary to their spirit. And if so, the grandchildren (who deviate from the sons) again find favor in his eyes.]
Source: Zar'a Kadisha (Brooklyn 5767), p. 290
---

**Good Measure is Greater**
I heard them say in the name of the holy Rebbe Rabbi Uri of Sambir, may his merit protect us, who was known as a worker of salvations, that he said regarding the saying of the Sages (Pe'ah, Chapter 8, Mishnah 9): **"כָּל מִי שֶׁאֵינוֹ לֹא חִגֵּר וְלֹא סוּמָא וְלֹא פִסֵּחַ וְעוֹשֶׂה עַצְמוֹ כְּאֶחָד מֵהֶם, אֵינוֹ מֵת מִן הַזִּקְנָה עַד שֶׁיִּהְיֶה כְּאֶחָד מֵהֶם"** - **"Anyone who is not lame, blind, or halt, but makes himself out to be like one of them, will not die of old age until he becomes like one of them."**
He said: So too is the measure for the opposite [for good]. If one makes an effort to guard even his limbs that are not under his control [from sin], then he will not die of old age until those limbs are under his control. For the measure of good is greater than the measure of punishment.
The Gaon Rabbi Eliezer David Friedman, Shlita.
Source: Mipi Sefarim V'Sofrim (Bnei Brak 5758), Vol. 2, p. 314
---

Yesterday I told my grandson a story I heard from my grandfather, the holy Gaon, the author of *P'tach Zuta*, of blessed memory, who said he saw Ruach Hakodesh (Divine Inspiration) three times with the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us. I told them one of them.
My grandfather was extremely destitute. Once, a desire burned within him to travel to Gorlice for the days of Chanukah. Since he was poor and had no money for travel expenses, he decided to walk the way from his home in Lizhensk all the way to Gorlice.
On the way, he became exhausted from the hardships of the road and could not continue due to the cold that prevailed there. He laid himself down for a while near a wall by the side of the road. At that time, a certain gentile passed by and told him that it was dangerous to sit like that, but my grandfather did not have the strength to continue on the road.
Meanwhile, a certain squire (Poritz) passed by with a carriage and asked him where his face was headed. He replied that he wanted to reach Gorlice. The squire said to him: "Get up by the wagon and come with me." Indeed, the squire drove him to Gorlice, and when they arrived, he dropped him off in the center of the city. (And my grandfather, of blessed memory, said that this was no ordinary squire...).
In the evening, before the Maariv prayer, my grandfather arrived at the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us. After the prayer, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice answered and said: "Pinchas'l, hast zich geglist tzu kumen tzu unz, 'tzu fis', shoyn reinish l'schar avur hatzibbur." (Pinchas'l, you craved to come to us, 'on foot', give a Reinish [coin] as payment for the public).
My grandfather, who was destitute, did not have a Reinish in his possession, so he asked one of the people there to give it for him. Back then, there were no telephones or the like to inform of his arrival. Rather, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice sensed that he had come on foot... And two other times he saw open Ruach Hakodesh with him, but I do not remember them right now. He saw many revelations, but this one happened to him personally.
Source: Betzila D'Mehemnuta, Mishpatim 5767, p. 17
---

I heard a story from my holy master, my father and teacher, may his merit protect us. Once, a certain Rabbi, a Torah scholar and servant of G-d from the land of Hungary, arrived in Sanz. He was sitting and dozing in a room adjacent to the room of the holy grandfather [of Gorlice], may his merit protect us, waiting to enter the inner sanctum.
The holy grandfather of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, went and took a handful of soot from the furnace and smeared it on the face of the aforementioned Rabbi until he was completely blackened. When he finished his deed, he woke him from his sleep and told him that the Rebbe was calling him to his room. The man, who knew nothing of what had been done to him, rose in alarm and entered immediately with fear and reverence to greet the holy face of the holy grandfather.
Upon his entry, the holy grandfather called out to him: "What happened to you? Why is your face black?" The aforementioned Rabbi answered innocently and said: "I know that my face is black [spiritually], and for this reason, I came to the Rebbe, that he might instruct me in the way I should go to purify my dirty face."
The holy grandfather returned and said to him: "Before you know that your face is dirty with soot, please approach the water well and wash your face." The man cried out again and said: "Indeed, from where do we take purifying waters if not from the Rebbe? And for this, I came."
After a long give and take, the holy grandfather showed him clearly how his face was dirty with soot and that he should go wash himself with water.
It seems to me, in the depth of the holy intention of the holy grandfather of Gorlice, may his merit protect us—that it is clear he did not intend to make a joke, especially with a Rabbi and Torah scholar. Even he once said: "Anyone who raises his hand without intending a Unification (Yichud) with it is not in the category of a human being."
It appears that he saw harsh judgments and accusations in Heaven against the collective of Israel at that time. It is known that in those days, breaches broke out in the wall of religion by the Maskilim and Neologs of their kinds. He intended with this to advocate for the people of Israel who are innocent of crime, for they do not recognize their impurity. Even when they are told that their faces are black, they do not know how to accept rebuke, and they do not know how and with what to return. They transgress prohibitions of Karet and death penalties, yet they are "doing Tikkunim of Teshuvah" [thinking they are righteous]. And forgiveness was granted to the entire congregation of the Children of Israel because it was unintentional for all the people.
Source: Leket Shoshanim (Bnei Brak 5740), Pesach, p. 52
---

It is told that in his last year, when our master (the holy Rebbe Rabbi Baruch of Gorlice, may his merit protect us) was already lying in bed due to his weakness, the righteous Rebbetzin Chaya Fradel, peace be upon her, said to her husband, our master the Maharbatz (author of *Kedushat Tzion* of Bobov), of blessed memory: "I will go and visit my uncle." He said to her: "Go in peace."
When she took leave of him, she told him that she had only two daughters, and it had been a long time since she had given birth. Therefore, she wanted our master to bless her with a male child. Our master (the holy Rebbe of Gorlice) waited a moment and said to her: "Po'alt" (You have accomplished/It is done). And then a male child was born to her, who is our master, the Admor (Maharash of Bobov), of blessed memory.
Our master, our Rebbe (the Admor of Bobov), of blessed memory, told this story again with an addition: "My mother, my teacher, who knew my uncle our master (the holy Rebbe of Gorlice) well from Tarnow—where he used to visit the home of her father (the holy Rebbe R' Shalom Eliezer of Ratzfert, may G-d avenge his blood), who was the brother of our master—when she was still a girl, she asked our master: Since she has only two daughters and it has been six years since she gave birth, and she still has no son, our master should bless her with a male child.
"Our master (the holy Rebbe of Gorlice) answered her: 'If you give me ten [Ranish], then you will have a male child.' My mother did not have the money with her, so she borrowed the aforementioned ten and gave them to our master. Our master promised her that she would have a son, and within a year, I was born."
Source: Chemdat Hakerem (Bobov), Mishpatim 5764, p. 2
---

I heard in the name of the holy Rebbe of Klausenburg, of blessed memory: His grandfather, the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, was very weak in his old age. The doctors advised feeding him gravy with bone marrow from an animal. However, he had refrained for many years from eating any meat of an animal.
They were perplexed about the matter. His father, the Rabbi of Rudnik, of blessed memory, did not want to take upon himself to deceive his father. However, one of the family members took it upon himself, for the sake of saving his father's life, to put bone marrow into the meat gravy.
But when they placed the plate with the gravy before him, they sensed that it was impossible to deceive him. He stirred with the spoon many times until he himself said that it was impossible to deceive him. He rebuked the deceiver, even though he apologized that he did what he did for the sake of saving a life.
Source: Sichatan Shel Avdei Avot (Jerusalem 5766), Vol. 1, p. 203
---

The Tzaddikim of Truth saw in advance what would be in our generation at the End of Days. The holy grandfather of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, who all his days was in a joyful mood of holiness, could not tolerate the sound of laughter in his last year, even from a playing child.
He used to say: "If you saw what is coming upon you, you would not laugh." And sometimes he would say: "If you saw what I see, you would throw yourselves on the floor and weep from great sorrow." (Although it was not the holy Rebbe's way to speak of his own greatness).
My master, my father, may his merit protect us, used to repeat the words of the aforementioned holy grandfather. And in the years 5700-5705 (1939-1945), we saw clearly, due to our many sins, everything the earlier Tzaddikim had said.
Source: Yisrael Saba, Cheshvan 5733, p. 374-375
---

Our Holy Rabbi, Rabbi Elazar Mendel of Lelov Zy"a, used to say: In the King's palace, ministers of the kingdom and commanders circulate without attracting attention or consideration. So is the matter in the Land of Israel: lofty Tzaddikim circulate without crowds gathering around them and masses honoring them, for it is the King's Palace.
Source: Malchut Beit David

My grandfather (the holy Gaon, author of *Divrei Chaim* of Sanz), may his merit protect us, passed away on the 25th of Nissan 5636 [1876] and is buried in Sanz. Once, his sons sat together: my uncle, the holy Gaon of Gorlice; the holy Gaon Rabbi Aharon, Av Beit Din of Sanz; and his grandson, the holy Gaon of Bobov, may his merit protect us.
In a conversation of Torah scholars, they began to discuss why my holy grandfather, the *Divrei Chaim*, may his merit protect us, passed away in the month of Nissan. They decided that there are Tzaddikim who wish to depart from this world on days when, in any case, Tachanun is not recited. Since in the World of Truth, there is an accusation against a Tzaddik if Tachanun is not recited on the day of his Yahrtzeit, and this was the wish of their holy father, may his merit protect us.
And behold, it is a wondrous thing that all three of these aforementioned Tzaddikim passed away on days when Tachanun is not recited: The holy Gaon of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, passed away on Rosh Chodesh Adar; the holy Gaon Mahara"a of Sanz, may his merit protect us, passed away on Rosh Chodesh Menachem Av; and the holy Gaon of Bobov, may his merit protect us, passed away on Rosh Chodesh Tammuz, may his merit protect us and all of Israel, Amen.
Source: Ohel Kedoshim (Jerusalem 5740), p. 130
---

Our master the Rebbe (the holy Rebbe Admor Maharash of Bobov), of blessed memory, told that his holy father, our master the Maharbatz (author of *Kedushat Tzion*), of blessed memory, may G-d avenge his blood, was in the first year of mourning [for his father, the holy Rebbe Rabbi Shlomo of Bobov, may his merit protect us, who passed away on Rosh Chodesh Tammuz 5665/1905].
On that night, the eve of the 2nd day of Rosh Chodesh Adar [the day of the passing of the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us], he saw in his dream that he was walking in the markets of Jerusalem the Holy City, near the Dung Gate, together with the holy Gaon Rabbi Betzalel Dayan, of blessed memory. Many people were walking and gathering near the Dung Gate.
When he asked the holy Gaon Rabbi Betzalel, "Where are all these people going?" he answered and said, "They are going to the funeral of a great man who has passed away."
Again, a second time, he saw in his dream how he was standing near the bed of a certain deceased person, and his holy father, our master Maharash, of blessed memory, was standing and eulogizing the deceased with weeping. With this, he woke up.
He was very afraid, especially because his heart pounded over the repetition of this dream twice. He ran immediately to the Mikvah. He could not concentrate his thoughts properly for prayer and walked back and forth in his room. Among the Chassidim who had gathered in the Beit Midrash for the Rosh Chodesh prayer, they wondered why the holy Rebbe did not appear. Only due to the burden of the congregation did he gather strength, put on his belt, wrap his Tallis over his shoulder in his room, and begin reciting "Barchi Nafshi," etc.
In the middle of his recitation, a telegram arrived from Gorlice to him with the terrible news that the holy Rebbe of Gorlice had passed away. Immediately, the holy Rebbe looked at his watch and saw that there were still a few minutes to reach the train traveling to Gorlice. He removed the Tallis from his shoulder and said to those surrounding him: "I am traveling to Gorlice for the funeral of my uncle of Gorlice. Those who wish to participate in the funeral, join me."
They all went together and arrived still in time for the funeral.

**Acceptance of Leadership**
When the holy Gaon Rabbi Baruch of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, was accepted to be the Av Beit Din of Gorlice, a meal was held for him on Sunday of Parshat Ki Tisa. He said then:
**"כִּי תִשָּׂא אֶת רֹאשׁ בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל"** - **"When you take the head of the Children of Israel"** (Exodus 30:12). Meaning, when you desire to accept upon yourself some "headship" (leadership).
**"לִפְקֻדֵיהֶם"** - **"According to their numbers"** (literally: to their visitations/lacks). This is an expression of deficiency. Meaning, that they accept a head/leader so that he will tell them their deficiencies.
**"וְנָתְנוּ אִישׁ"** - **"Then shall they give every man..."** They should see to place upon themselves a man such that **"כֹּפֶר נַפְשׁוֹ"** - **"a ransom for his soul."** Meaning, one who knows in himself that he still needs atonement for his own soul and does not imagine himself to be perfect. Such a leader can lead the community with goodness.
**"וְלֹא יִהְיֶה בָהֶם נֶגֶף בִּפְקֹד אֹתָם"** - **"That there be no plague among them when he numbers them."** Meaning, that no destruction or breach should be heard in the conduct of the public, and he will stand guard to protect them from every evil thing with the help of Heaven.
[From the pamphlet *Divrei Baruch*, which is a manuscript left behind by the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yaakov Halberstam of Teshakava, of blessed memory, who copied it from the writings of his father, the holy Rebbe Rabbi Sinai, Av Beit Din of Zhmigrod, who was the son of the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, may his merit protect us.]
Source: Ateret Chaim (Brooklyn 5739), Vol. 1, p. 39

**The Wicked at the Entrance of Gehennom**
The holy grandfather of Gorlice, may his merit protect us, explained the saying of the Sages (Eruvin 19a): **"רְשָׁעִים אֲפִלּוּ עַל פִּתְחוֹ שֶׁל גֵּיהִנּוֹם אֵינָם חוֹזְרִין בִּתְשׁוּבָה"** - **"The wicked, even at the entrance of Gehennom, do not repent."**
He said this is wondrous. He explained based on what is known, that Tzaddikim, after their passing, go to elevate the souls of the wicked from Gehennom. It is also known about the Bach (Bayit Chadash) that forty days before his passing, they began to cool the fires of Gehennom so that he could pass through there. When he passed there after his passing, he took out all the souls that were there.
These wicked people, who in this world thought they were righteous, even when they are dead and being led to the entrance of Gehennom, their pride does not depart from them. They think they are being led there to elevate the souls of the wicked, just like the Tzaddikim.
Source: Kuntres Shefa Chaim, Parshat Toldot 5743 - Antwerp, p. 25

Chassid
Let it not be wondrous in his eyes that I wrote to him the title "Chassid." Look in Yoreh Deah, Laws of Torah Study, Siman 246, Seif 21. The Rama wrote: "Nevertheless, anyone who can sustain himself well from the work of his hands and engage in Torah, this is the attribute of Chassidut and is a gift of G-d, but it is not the attribute of every man," etc. And now, since the Blessed G-d granted your honor to spread Torah with students and to benefit from the toil of his hands—which in this lowly generation I have found one in a thousand—if so, the title "Chassid" is fitting and proper for him.
Source: "Choshen V'Ephod" - Hamodia, 26 Shevat 5759, p. 18

**Do Not Hate Your Brother**
I heard a witty interpretation from the holy Rabbi, famous for his wisdom, our master Baruch Halberstam, of blessed memory, Av Beit Din of Gorlice, on the verse: **"לֹא תִשְׂנָא אֶת אָחִיךָ בִּלְבָבֶךָ"** - **"You shall not hate your brother in your heart"** (Leviticus 19:17).
One might wonder: Does the verse not continue, **"וְאָהַבְתָּ לְרֵעֲךָ כָּמוֹךָ"** - **"And you shall love your neighbor as yourself"**? If so, all the more so one is obligated to love his brother, his own flesh and blood!
Rather, certainly, the situation is worse regarding relatives. Brothers together, from the rest of the Children of Israel, are often hateful to one another due to the inheritance of their fathers or jealousy of a brother who loves one more than the other, and similar issues. Relatives hate each other more than strangers.
Therefore, the holy Torah warned: **"לֹא תִשְׂנָא אֶת אָחִיךָ בִּלְבָבֶךָ"** - **"You shall not hate your brother in your heart."** Meaning, at the very least, if you do not love him properly as good and pleasant brothers should—at the very least, do not hate him.
And this is what it says: **"לֹא תִשְׂנָא אֶת אָחִיךָ"** - **"You shall not hate your brother,"** etc. This means at least passively (Shev V'al Ta'aseh) do not hate him as mentioned. Whereas regarding the rest of the Children of Israel, one can fulfill **"וְאָהַבְתָּ לְרֵעֲךָ כָּמוֹךָ"** - **"And you shall love your neighbor as yourself"**—meaning love in the heart and in action, and not just the negation of hatred as mentioned above.
Source: Divrei Torah (Munkacs), Vol. 9, Letter 26

**Mechutan (In-law)**
I heard from the Admor, the holy Rebbe Mahari"a of Pshevorsk, of blessed memory, and also from my in-law, the holy Gaon Maharash Schneebalg, of blessed memory, in the name of his grandfather, the author of *P'tach Zuta*, of blessed memory, who heard from the holy mouth of the holy Rebbe of Gorlice, of blessed memory:
In the world, they joke that it is easier to connect with a *Mechutan* (in-law) than with fathers and Rabbis. Therefore, one must be more careful and precise with whom one marries into.
The holy Gaon Rabbi Elchanan Heilprin, of blessed memory, Av Beit Din of Golders Green.
Source: Sichatan Shel Avdei Avot (Jerusalem 5766), Vol. 1, p. 204

He was born in the city of Lvov (Lemberg) on the 24th of Iyar, 5592 [1832], to his father, the Chassidic Rabbi and Kabbalist R' Efraim Tzvi (Hirsch) HaKohen, and to his mother, the righteous woman Beila. The Yalles (or Yalish) family is a distinguished family of priestly lineage (Kehunah) extending back to our master Yeshayah Kohen Tzedek, one of the later Tosafists (cited many times in *Shita Mekubetzet*).
The Chassid R' Efraim Tzvi was connected from his youth to his holy teacher, the holy Tzaddik Rabbi Uri of Strelisk, of blessed memory—known among the Tzaddikim of his generation as the "Saraf" (Fiery Angel) of Strelisk—until the day of his passing (23rd of Elul 5586 [1826]).
After the passing of his Rebbe, R' Efraim Tzvi did not want to lead a congregation of Chassidim, even though it was known among the Chassidim and disciples that his Rebbe, the Saraf, had embraced him in his arms and said to him: "Efraim Hersh meiner, ich veis az du bist a rechter Kohen mizaro shel Aharon" (My Efraim Hersh, I know that you are a true Kohen from the seed of Aaron).
He connected himself with bonds of love and awe to his friend and teacher, the holy Tzaddik Rabbi Yehuda Tzvi of Rozdol, of blessed memory, who filled the place of their Rebbe, the Saraf, in the city of Stretin (until his passing on 11th of Iyar 5604 [1844]).
From his youth, Rabbi Uri (affectionately called Uri'li) was diligent day and night in the study of Gemara and Shulchan Aruch. He prayed with immense enthusiasm according to the version of Strelisk-Stretin. He also engaged in collecting money for charity during his free time. When he was about five years old, his father R' Efraim Tzvi took him to Stretin, and the holy Tzaddik Rabbi Yehuda Tzvi spoke great and wondrous things about him. His diligence in the revealed Torah made an impression in his city of Lvov.
When he became Bar Mitzvah in the year 5605 [1845], he stood for examination before the Rabbi of the city, the Gaon of his generation, Rabbi Yosef Shaul HaLevi Nathanson, author of the Responsa *Shoel U'Meshiv*. The Gaon accepted him to study as a student in his Halacha classes among his great disciples, foremost among them the Gaon Rabbi Yitzchak Schmelkes, who later served as Av Beit Din in Lvov.
From time to time, Uri'li went to take shelter in the shadow of holiness in Belz, with his holy teacher, the Sar Shalom, of blessed memory.
In the year 5611 [1851], he married the daughter of the expert Rabbi, Rabbi Shimon Tana, a righteous teacher and preacher in the city of Komarno, a descendant of the Taz and the Bach. He sat in his house engaged in Torah and service of G-d.
...Although he began to lead a congregation of Chassidim, nevertheless, he did not want to accept "Petakaot" (Kvitelach/money) from his Chassidim, only money for charity. He said about himself that he was merely a charity collector (Gabbai Tzedakah) who receives a wage for his trouble, a small wage for the sustenance of his household.
Stories of wonders were already told about him, and people traveled to him from other towns to receive blessings from him. He distributed all the money to the poor and needy.
His other teacher, the holy Tzaddik Rabbi Avraham Itzi of Strelisk, of blessed memory, said about him: "His facial features resemble those of our Rebbe, the Saraf."
Even though he conducted his leadership immediately after the passing of his Rebbe, the Tzaddik of Strelisk, he traveled from time to time (from month to month) to Sadigura to take shelter in the shadow of the holy Admor, the *Abir Yaakov*, son of the holy Tzaddik of Ruzhin.
...According to the advice of the holy Admor, the *Abir Yaakov* of Sadigura, our master established his residence and Beit Midrash in the year 5638 [1878] in the city of Sambir. Thousands and tens of thousands of Jews from Galicia and Hungary took shelter in his holy shadow to receive his blessings, advice, and salvation.
His lavishness in giving charity and performing kindness for all the poor and needy, both in the country and in the Holy Land, was beyond human generosity and difficult to describe on paper. His preparations to welcome the holy Sabbath, both in Torah and service and in charity and kindness, were beyond human comprehension. Those who merited to see his holy face on Friday nights and Sabbath days saw clearly what the Sages said: "It is not similar, etc.," for his face shone with the radiance of the Shechinah.
All the days of his residence in Sambir (32 years), he did not travel from his court to another city for Shabbat, except when Shabbat fell on the 23rd of Elul. Then he would travel on Thursday with his family and all those accompanying him to spend Shabbat in the Beit Midrash of the Saraf and in the adjacent house.
Forty days before the Sabbath of Parshat Shekalim, on Rosh Chodesh Adar II, in the year 5670 [1910], he fell ill with a severe illness that the expert doctors could not diagnose. His digestion ceased, and he tasted nothing but a little water from the spring of Gisyevka. Nevertheless, his Torah study and service did not cease all those days and nights. His soul ascended to the hidden heights while his pure body was wrapped in a Tallis during the Musaf prayer of Shabbat Rosh Chodesh, Parshat Shekalim.
(From the words of his grandson, the Gaon Rabbi Efraim Eliezer Yalles, of blessed memory, formerly a Dayan in the city of Stryi, and later Av Beit Din of Philadelphia, in the introduction to his book Responsa *Divrei Efraim Eliezer*).
Source: Tiferet Meshulam (Brooklyn 5761), p. 111

The holy Tzaddik Rabbi Uri was born in Lvov on the 24th of Iyar 5592 [1832], to his holy father, the Kabbalist Rabbi Efraim Tzvi HaKohen Yalles, of priestly lineage and one of the greatest disciples of the "Saraf" of Strelisk.
In his youth, he was already famous as a prodigy (Illui). Rabbi Uri, together with his friend the Gaon Rabbi Yitzchak Schmelkes (author of Responsa *Beit Yitzchak*, Rabbi of Lvov), studied daily with the Gaon Rabbi Yosef Shaul Nathanson. He also studied together with the great Chassid Rabbi Mordechai Palil.
Despite the fact that his great teacher was among the opponents of Chassidut, Rabbi Uri did not refrain from traveling occasionally to our master, the Sar Shalom [of Belz, of blessed memory], to quench his soul's thirst for the ways of Chassidut and its conduct. He always dedicated himself to collecting funds to support the hidden poor.
In the year 5610 [1850], he was ordained for teaching (Hora'ah) by his teacher, Rabbi Yosef Shaul. At that time, he married and moved to live in Komarno.
...The Tzaddik Rabbi Uri of Sambir took shelter in the shadow of the holiness of our master, the Mahara"sh. He lived in the city of Komarno and was extremely poor, living in destitution. He sat constantly in the Beit Midrash engaged in Torah and service, and his wife supported the family by the toil of her hands: she sewed sacks for a certain merchant.
Once, when she finished her work, she took the sacks on her shoulders and carried them to the merchant's house. She was pregnant at the time. On the way, her foot slipped, she fell, and miscarried. They informed her husband of the matter. Rabbi Uri hurried home and found many women attending to her; one saying to give her a little wine to revive her soul, another saying to put a little jam in her mouth—but there was nothing in the house.
The women poured out their wrath upon Rabbi Uri, accusing him of casting the burden of livelihood upon his wretched wife while he spent all his days in the Beit Midrash like an idler. When they distressed him with their words, he left his house and went to his Rebbe to pour out his heart before him.
In the middle of the night, he arrived in the city of Lvov. He was very hungry and tired from the journey and did not know what to do, for all the people of the city were sleeping. Suddenly, he lifted his eyes and saw a man standing opposite him. The man asked him: "What do you seek?"
Rabbi Uri told him that he was a wayfarer and wanted to enter a house to rest from his journey, for he was very tired and also wished to revive his starving soul. The man took him and brought him to the synagogue. In the corner of the synagogue stood a cabinet. The man opened the door of the cabinet, took out a loaf of bread and a flask of brandy, gave them to Rabbi Uri, and immediately disappeared.
R' Uri washed his hands, ate and drank his fill, recited Grace After Meals, lay down on the bench, and slept. In the morning, when the Shamash (sexton) of the synagogue came and saw that the bread and brandy were missing from the cabinet, he immediately understood that this was the doing of the guest sleeping on the bench. The Shamash approached him, woke him from his sleep, and asked him: "Who ate the bread that was in the cabinet?"
He answered him: "A man gave me the bread to eat." The Shamash became very angry and struck him on his cheek two or three times. Immediately, the door opened, and that same man who had brought him the night before entered the synagogue. He raised his voice at the Shamash: "Stay your hand! Do not strike him! R' Uri of Komarno is not a thief, Heaven forbid! Only I myself gave him the bread to eat because he was very hungry, to the point of danger to life."
Only after hearing these words did the Shamash's anger subside. From there, Rabbi Uri went to his Rebbe and told him of all his distress and his bad situation. The Mahara"sh said to him: "You worry about livelihood—tradition is in our hands that a man to whom Elijah the Prophet appears has no worries about livelihood; you, who saw Elijah the Prophet twice, do not worry."
When the people who were in the Rebbe's house at that time heard the words of their holy Rebbe, they hurried and took Rabbi Uri and seated him on a chair of honor and gave him a livelihood in abundance. The Rebbe laid his hands upon him to be a Rabbi of Israel and sent him home, saying to him: "Go with this strength of yours and save Israel, and everything that comes out of your mouth shall be fulfilled."
Immediately, many people gathered to him and came before him with their requests, granting him silver and gold, and he was a worker of salvations. He distributed all the money they gave him to the poor and to Torah scholars. The Chassidim of Komarno envied him and distressed him greatly, so he decided to leave Komarno and settled in the city of Sambir, and from there his fame went out throughout the Galilee.
The Chassid R' Yisrael Klapholtz z"l
Source: Admorei Belza (Bnei Brak 5749), Vol. 1, p. 265

The Chassid R' Avraham Yosef Beckenroth told me that he heard from his father: It is known that the holy Rebbe R' Uri of Sambir, of blessed memory, was a Chassid of the holy Rebbe R' Avraham Yaakov of Sadigura, of blessed memory.
His father (the narrator's) remembered that every year on the 10th of Elul, one day before the Hillula (Yahrtzeit) of the holy Rebbe of Sadigura (which falls on the 11th of Elul), the Rebbe [R' Uri] would personally prepare a candle made of wax that was so large it reached from the floor to the ceiling, in honor of the soul of the holy Rebbe of Sadigura.
The Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Chaim Ashri, Shlita.
Source: Siach Zekeinim (Brooklyn 5762), Vol. 4, p. 336

His custom was to send the first *Kvitel* (prayer note) along with the *Pidyon* (redemption money) that was given to him on that day to the holy Rebbe Rabbi Avraham Yaakov of Sadigura, of blessed memory, every single day.
After his passing, he sent the first Kvitel with the Pidyon to his son who filled his place, the holy Rebbe R' Yisrael of Sadigura. The second Kvitel with the Pidyon he sent to the second son, the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak of Boyan, of blessed memory, author of *Pachad Yitzchak*.
When the Gabbaim (attendants) saw that he did not keep the first Pidyon for himself, they tried to prevent the first person entering with a Kvitel from being a wealthy man, so that he [R' Uri] would not lose a large Pidyon. However, the holy Rebbe of Sambir would stand at the door and choose who among the people would enter first.
The holy Rebbe Rabbi Meshulam Yissachar Ashkenazi, of blessed memory, of Stanislav-London.
Source: Tiferet Meshulam (Brooklyn 5761), p. 764

The Chassid R' Avraham Yosef Beckenroth told me: Due to a certain reason, my father, peace be upon him, needed to stand trial. My father lived in Schodnica and Drohobych (on Shabbat he was in Schodnica), and he had to come to the court in Drohobych, and also to the high court in Sambir.
On the designated day that my father had to stand trial in Sambir, he traveled early in the morning watch to Sambir to the holy Rebbe R' Uri of Sambir, of blessed memory, to mention himself before him. When he arrived at the Rebbe's house, he found him walking on the porch dressed in his outer coat (tillep) (the trial was in the winter) and reciting Tehillim with a candle in his hand.
My father asked him the meaning of this. The holy Rebbe said to him in these words: "Du veist garnisht vi gut s'iz tzu zagen a kapitel Tehillim ven gantz Sambir shlaft" (You know nothing of how good it is to say a chapter of Tehillim when all of Sambir sleeps).
When my father told the holy Rebbe about the trial, the Rebbe said to him: "I know the judge. He is a native of Ukraine and he is an evil man [er iz a paskudnyak]. Every morning at eight o'clock, the judge leaves his house for the courthouse. When he leaves his house at that hour, you should walk around there."
My father, who was a Chassid, did not ask any questions. The Rebbe's command protected his soul, and he went there at eight o'clock in the morning. On that day, there was snow and frost. When the judge left his house, a black dog suddenly attacked him and knocked him onto the ice, and he died immediately.
When my father saw that the judge had died, he returned to the holy Rebbe and told him about the downfall of the judge. The holy Rebbe did not react to this at all (for with the holy Rebbe, such a matter was not a big deal). Since this was so, the trial returned to Drohobych, and there my father had acquaintances, and after various efforts, he was released from the trial.
The Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Chaim Ashri, Shlita.
Source: Siach Zekeinim (Brooklyn 5762), Vol. 4, p. 335

The holy Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Freund, of blessed memory, son of the holy Gaon [Rabbi Avraham Yehoshua] of Nasaud and disciple of the *Kedushat Yom Tov* of Sighet, was the son-in-law of the holy Rebbe R' Zev Goldberger, of blessed memory, from Huniad.

My uncle, the holy Rabbi R' Uri of Stanislav, Shlita, told me that the Chassid R' Leibish Lampel, of blessed memory, told him that he was studying in the city of Altstadt at the time the holy Rebbe of Sambir passed away. All the young men went to the funeral, and thousands of men, women, and children gathered there. The wailing grew strong and ascended to the heavens.
He said that many people had tears streaming from their eyes, crying: "From now on, who will worry for us to provide our livelihood and send us [money] for the Holy Sabbath?" For it was his custom to pay the butchers and grocers on behalf of all the poor of his city. It was known that he scattered all his money, giving it to the needy until he left nothing for himself.
My aforementioned uncle also told a story in the name of the Chassid R' Leibish Kohen, peace be upon him, from Jerusalem, that there is a received tradition regarding a man named R' Kadish, who was one of the Chassidim of the holy Rebbe of Sambir and traveled to him frequently.
Once, it arose in his mind that since the Rebbe travels occasionally to the holy Rebbe of Sadigura, it would be right for him to travel there for Shabbat as well. However, he did not reveal his thought or reason to anyone, lest people be upset with him and react against him. He arose and traveled on Thursday from his home. Since the way to Sadigura passed through the city of Sambir, he was careful not to get off the wagon in Sambir so that his journey would not become known to anyone.
Suddenly, he heard someone calling his name: "R' Kadish! R' Kadish!" However, he thought to himself that presumably there was someone else whose name was like his name, so he paid no attention to it. But suddenly, he saw the attendant (Shamash) of the holy Rebbe of Sambir putting his head into the carriage and saying: "R' Kadish, behold I called you several times, why did you not answer?"
He answered him: "Since no one knows that I am traveling here, it did not occur to me that the intention was for me." And he asked him: "How did you know I was traveling here?"
The attendant replied that the holy Rebbe commanded him to take a flask of wine and deliver it to R' Kadish who is passing through this city on his way to Sadigura for the Holy Sabbath, and that he should place the wine for him on the pure table of the holy Rebbe of Sadigura.
R' Kadish stood amazed at the open Ruach Hakodesh (Divine Spirit) of his holy Rebbe.
The Gaon Rabbi Kalman Yehoshua, Av Beit Din, Shlita.
Source: Tiferet Meshulam (Brooklyn 5761), p. 785

The holy Rebbe R' Uri of Sambir, may his merit protect us, whose righteousness in distribution exceeded all bounds, would borrow from others in times of need and scatter it for charity. He used to say that charity must be given with self-sacrifice (Mesirut Nefesh). When one skimps on his own needs for charity, that is self-sacrifice of the body. However, when one borrows and gives to charity, that is "Mesirut Nefesh" (risking the soul)—for perhaps, Heaven forbid, he will be a "wicked borrower who does not repay."
The Chassid R' Yitzchak David Lieder, z"l.

The Chassid R' Avraham Yosef Beckenroth told me that his father told him that the holy Rebbe R' Uri of Sambir, of blessed memory, once fell ill with pneumonia, may Heaven save us. It is known that in those days, this was a very dangerous illness.
It was Erev Shabbat Mevarchim (Sabbath of Blessing the New Month), and the holy Rebbe wanted to go to the Mikvah. His sons would not let him under any circumstances. Since he wanted very much to go immerse in the Mikvah, the holy Rebbe said: "Ask the 'Alter Shochet' (Old Slaughterer)." (This was the father of R' Avrahamtshe Marzel, a Shochet in Srivnitza; he was a great Chassid of the holy Rebbe R' Uri).
They called the aforementioned 'Alter', and before he entered the holy Rebbe's room, his sons told him: "Heaven forbid you should agree to our father's wish to go to the Mikvah." He answered them: "Do you think I will tell the holy Rebbe that he should go immerse in the Mikvah when he is in such a condition?"
However, when the holy Rebbe of Sambir asked him if he should go to the Mikvah, he answered: "Does the Rebbe not go to the Mikvah?" (Since he was a fervent Chassid, he did not want to speak against the wish of the holy Rebbe of Sambir).
The holy Rebbe immersed in the Mikvah, and nothing happened to him.
The Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Chaim Ashri, Shlita.
Source: Siach Zekeinim (Brooklyn 5762), Vol. 4, p. 335

My uncle, the holy Gaon Maharatz of Stanislav, Shlita, told that he heard from his in-law, the holy Gaon of Pshevorsk, Shlita, that on the night of Yom Kippur, a doctor was present in the Beit Midrash of the holy Rebbe of Sambir. He, of blessed memory, would go around with the doctor to the weak people to check if they were permitted to fast.
He also heard from his in-law that the holy Rebbe of Sambir prolonged the Neilah prayer on Yom Kippur with wondrous service and enthusiasm until an hour or two hours after the stars came out.

He was accustomed to distributing food (Mezonot) to his congregation at the conclusion of the day [Yom Kippur]. However, when a concern arose that there were some among his followers who were delaying more than their strength allowed until the end of his prayer because they wished to break their fast on his food, he instituted the distribution of food *before* the Neilah prayer. My aforementioned uncle also told that the Chassid R' Meir Lemet (Shlita) [z"l] told him that he heard from the holy Rebbe Rabbi Avraham Yaakov of Sadigura, the *Abir Yaakov*, that when he was young, he saw the holy Rebbe of Sambir. He asked his father, the holy Rebbe R' Yisrael of Sadigura: "Who is this guest?" His father answered him that it is Rabbi Uri of Sambir. **The Breastplate shall not move**
I heard from the Chassid, the Rebbe's grandson, R' Baruch Moshe Parnas, peace be upon him, that at the beginning of the war [World War II], when everyone fled, he fled to the city of Sambir. There was a city ledger (Pinkas) there, and they showed him that it was written there that the holy Rebbe R' Uri of Sambir, of blessed memory, promised that for one hundred years, no mishap would occur to the city.
At that time, it was still within the hundred years, for a few months were lacking to complete the century. Afterward, the Germans, may their names be obliterated, entered the city for eleven days. During those days, nothing happened to any Jew, even though in other towns, as soon as they entered, they beat and murdered, etc.
After eleven days, the town was returned to the Russians, may their names be obliterated. And so, after some years [when the hundred years were up], the Germans, may their names be obliterated, entered and did as they did to all the communities of Israel, may G-d avenge their blood. But this was already after one hundred years from the promise of the aforementioned Tzaddik.
The Chassid R' Yehoshua Zev Lerner, Shlita.
My master, my father, of blessed memory, passed on to me the last "Torah" he heard from the holy mouth of his father and teacher, the Admor, the holy Tzaddik Rabbi Uri Kahana Rabba of Sambir, may his merit protect us, which he said on his deathbed on the holy Sabbath of Parshat Tetzaveh, year 5670 [1910] (he passed away on Shabbat, Parshat Pekudei, on Rosh Chodesh Adar II, year 5670).
**"וְיִרְכְּסוּ אֶת הַחֹשֶׁן מִטַּבְּעֹתָיו אֶל טַבְּעֹת הָאֵפוֹד... וְלֹא יִזַּח הַחֹשֶׁן מֵעַל הָאֵפוֹד"** - **"And they shall bind the breastplate by its rings to the rings of the ephod... so that the breastplate shall not move from the ephod"** (Exodus 28:28).
"The Breastplate (Choshen) is today the Torah scholars and Tzaddikim. The Ephod is the multitude of the people. One must bind oneself with the simple Jews, to be on the 'Band of the Ephod'. The simple Jew should think of the Torah scholar, and the Breastplate should not move from the Ephod—the Torah scholar should not separate himself from the simple Jew." [= The Choshen is the Torah scholar and Tzaddikim, the Ephod is the masses. We need to connect ourselves with the simple Jews, to be on the 'Band of the Ephod'—that the simple Jew should think of the Torah scholar, and the Choshen should not move from the Ephod, meaning the Torah scholar should not remove himself from the simple Jew.]
From a letter by the holy Gaon Rabbi Efraim Eliezer Yalles, of blessed memory, of Sambir-Philadelphia.
Source: Mashmia Yeshua (Brooklyn 5771), p. 55
