When the lad grew up (the holy Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Freund, of blessed memory, Av Beit Din of Huniad), his father sent him to receive *Hormanah* (Rabbinic Ordination) from the greats of the generation, and among them from the famous Gaon Mahari Greenwald, of blessed memory, who was the "Minister of Consenters" in his generation to grant ordination to anyone who had completed himself in Torah and instruction and was worthy of that mantle.
In that period, it was customary that when a Rabbi's son came to be tested, he would bring with him a letter from his fathers requesting to examine his character. Sometimes, even if he wasn't fully worthy, they would give him ordination out of respect for his fathers. However, the holy Rebbe of Huniad did not bring a letter from his father, the holy Rebbe of Nasaud. Therefore, the Gaon Mahari Greenwald suspected that he had come to be tested without his father's permission. Since this was so, he tested him strictly and thoroughly lest he fail.
However, the holy Rebbe of Huniad knew how to answer all his questions on the spot. Finally, he asked him if he could compare one matter to another (Milta L'Milta), and on this too, he answered with good taste and knowledge. Yet, even though he found no fault in him, he still feared lest he had come without his father's permission. Therefore, he told him to travel home, and he would send the ordination after him.
The Gaon Mahari Greenwald drew up a letter of ordination for him, writing in it that he had tested him and found in him the "taste of elders," and that he knew how to weigh logic and compare matters. However, he attached a letter to the ordination addressed to the holy Rebbe of Nasaud. In it, he wrote that since his son arrived to be tested without a letter from his father, he feared that perhaps his father did not wish for him to receive ordination out of respect for his ancestors, but only if he was truly worthy. Therefore, he did not send the letter [directly to the son]. But now that he succeeded in the examination, certainly the father would be happy and pleased that he is worthy of the Rabbinic mantle. [See also in the beginning of the book *Mikveh Yisrael*, for the holy Rebbe of Nasaud praised his son greatly, saying he was exceptional in instruction.]
The Rabbi Yitzchak Shimon Feder, Shlita.
Source: Mishpachot Rabbanim BeUngarn (Bnei Brak 5754), Vol. 1, p. 119

The Chassid R' Simcha Yissachar Ber Lefkovitz told me (his name is called after the holy Rebbe of Cieszanow, of blessed memory, and every time the holy Rebbe of Nasaud read his name in a Kvitel, he would ask if his name was Simcha Ber):
He heard from the holy Rebbe of Nasaud, of blessed memory, saying about his son, the holy Gaon R' Yisrael of Huniad, of blessed memory: "My Yisrael is a beautiful Torah scholar. He knows more than me. He has one fault: he cannot speak a 'Paradek' (sermon) on the Bimah."
I heard from our holy Rebbe [the Admor of Toldot Aharon], may his merit protect us, that he learned several matters of conduct from the holy Rebbe of Huniad, may his merit protect us.
On one hand, he conducted himself with the attribute of humility to the utmost extreme. For example, the Rebbe told that the house of the Rabbi of Huniad was near the Beit Midrash. In his house, there was a cabinet designated for Tallis and Tefillin. Anyone who wanted to leave their Tallis and Tefillin in the Rabbi's house would place them in that designated cabinet. Almost all the young men kept their Tefillin in the Rabbi's house. The Rabbi would trouble himself for every young man to give him the Tefillin, and afterwards to return them to the cabinet. He did not care at all about troubling himself to serve even a young boy.
However, if a matter touched upon the Honor of Heaven, he would overcome and roar like a lion to protest for the Honor of Heaven. He did not conduct himself with false humility. The holy ways of the Rabbi of Huniad illuminated for our holy Rebbe throughout his life: where one needs to conduct oneself with humility, and where one needs to scream and protest for the Honor of Heaven.
The Chassid R' Mordechai HaKohen Blum, Shlita.
Source: Shufrei D'Avraham (Jerusalem 5761), Vol. 1, p. 88

Our Rebbe (the holy Admor of Toldot Aharon), may his merit protect us, said in the name of our Elder Rebbe (the holy Rebbe Rabbi Aharon Roth, author of *Shomrei Emunim*), of blessed memory, that he said about the holy Gaon of Huniad, may his merit protect us, that a part of the world stands on his merit.
He further praised his humility, saying about him that he was so lowly of spirit that he did not know what pride was at all. (R' Chaim Roth heard this from our Rebbe, may his merit protect us).
The Chassid R' Yitzchak Isaac Zeligovitch, z"l.

The Chassid R' Eliezer Harfenes, peace be upon him, told me—and the Chassid R' Chaim Mordechai Sheinberg, peace be upon him, told me that he was present at the time of the incident:
When the holy Rebbe of Satmar, of blessed memory, came to Satmar, he fell ill with the "Rose" (erysipelas) on his leg. The holy Gaon R' Yisrael of Huniad, of blessed memory, who was then in Satmar, came to visit him.
When R' Yisrael walked out from the holy Rebbe of Satmar, he walked backwards [facing the Rebbe]. Every time, he bowed in honor of the holy Rebbe. The holy Rebbe could not tolerate this and said: "Nu, nu." But he continued to walk and bow.
The holy Rebbe got down from his bed and ran toward him so that he would hurry his exit and not humble himself so much.
When the holy Gaon R' Yisrael left, the Chassid R' Yaakov Hersh Friedman of Tarnow, peace be upon him (who was also there), said to the holy Rebbe: "The Rebbe is an expert (Mevin) regarding 'where he is' (wie gar nisht er iz bei zich - how he considers himself nothing)."
The holy Rebbe said to him: "And 'gar nisht' (nothing) is indeed 'bei zich' (with him/where he is)." [Meaning: He truly considers himself nothing].
The Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Chaim Ashri, Shlita.

**Honor and Shame Are Equal**
Our Rebbe [the holy Admor of Toldot Aharon, of blessed memory] merited to drink from the well of Torah of the holy Rebbe R' Yisrael Freund, of blessed memory, son of the holy Gaon of Nasaud, of blessed memory.

And there is no unrighteousness in Him
I told a while ago in the name of our Rabbi, the Baal Vayaged Yaakov zt"l, who interpreted the verse (Psalms 92:16): להגיד כי ישר ה' צורי ולא עולתה בו - "To declare that the L-rd is upright, my Rock, and there is no unrighteousness in Him."
"To declare" - meaning words of rebuke. One must think - "For the L-rd is upright, my Rock" - that the Holy One, Blessed be He, sees my form and stands before me. Then, with this intention, surely - "and there is no unrighteousness in Him" - that there will be no wrong, Heaven forbid, in my words.

**The Honor of Torah**
The elderly Chassid R' Yosef Pinkus told me that he saw with his own eyes: When the holy Rebbe R' Yeshayale of Kerestir was in the city of Klausenburg, they prepared his table on Friday night. Many young married men (Avreichim) sat there at the head of the table.
The Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Freund of Huniad, son of the Rabbi of Nasaud, of blessed memory, sat at the side of the table, because those "sons of holy ones" preceded him and pushed him there.
However, when the holy Rebbe R' Yeshayale entered the Tish (table), he noticed that the Rabbi of Huniad was sitting at the side. He went there, asked for a chair, and sat next to the Rabbi of Huniad specifically, in order to teach and show the virtue of the Honor of Torah.
The Gaon Rabbi Shimon Hirschler, Shlita.
Source: Gishmei Bracha (London 5771), p. 591

The son of the Av Beit Din of Nasaud, of blessed memory, was the holy Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Freund, Av Beit Din of Huniad, of blessed memory. He was the father of the holy Gaon Rabbi Moshe Aryeh Freund, of blessed memory, Gaavad of the Eda Haredit in Jerusalem, may it be built and established. He passed away a few years before the outbreak of the Second World War.
The holy Rebbe R' Yoel of Satmar said at his funeral: "There was a Jew here for whom honor and shame were equal to him, and now he too is gone."
Rabbi Yisrael was a very holy man and used to accept *Kvitelach* (prayer notes) (his father, the Av Beit Din of Nasaud, also accepted Kvitelach). I remember that once he came to our city, Hermannstadt, and stayed with my grandfather [my father's father], the Chassid our teacher Rabbi Mordechai Aryeh [Leib] Friedman, of blessed memory. On that day, I did not go to Cheder because I did not feel well, and I merited on that day to observe and look much at his holy face and follow his actions.
Once, he saw a man riding a 'bicycle' (Bicykel). Out of his great innocence, he asked what this thing was. They answered him—his attendants and close ones—that with this, a person can shorten his way, for a journey that takes twenty minutes on foot can be done with the bicycle in five minutes.
Rabbi Yisrael became enthusiastic and said: "If so, I would be happy to receive a bicycle too, and thus I will make the way to the Mikvah in five minutes instead of twenty minutes..." They had to explain to him that this is not respectful for a Rabbi and Rebbe like him to ride a bicycle.
The Gaon Rabbi Eliezer David Friedman, Shlita.
Source: Hagash"p Mipi Sefarim V'Sofrim (Bnei Brak 5769), p. 26

Once, our master the holy Rebbe [the *Divrei Yoel* of Satmar], may his merit protect us, came to Huniad for Shabbat. The Rabbi of Huniad ate the meal in his home. Our Rebbe (the holy Admor of Toldot Aharon) told what happened to him with his first teacher, the Av Beit Din of the holy community of Huniad, the holy Rebbe R' Yisrael Freund, of blessed memory, son of the holy Rebbe of Nasaud, of blessed memory.
Behold, our Rebbe, of blessed memory, was then a young man of age and wanted to travel to study in a Yeshiva. He went to receive a blessing of farewell from the aforementioned Av Beit Din. He arrived in the middle of the Shacharit prayer. After the prayer of Shmoneh Esrei, he approached him immediately due to the pressure of time, for the train had to leave in a very short time.
The aforementioned Rabbi was praying from the Siddur of the Arizal. He showed him what was written at the top of the page. He did not understand what he was showing him, and he was forced to wait helplessly until the end of the prayer.

The meaning is: After Shmoneh Esrei, the abundance descends that was achieved in the prayer. And whoever interrupts with speech in the middle, the abundance stops. Therefore, he did not want to interrupt until after 'Aleinu', which is the end of the prayer. (R' Shmuel Mordechai Schwartz).

Once, when our master, the holy Admor of Toldot Aharon, of blessed memory, stayed in Haifa during the summer days for a number of weeks, his son accompanied him. When our master needed to return to Jerusalem the Holy City, his son lost his hat and had nothing to wear on his head.
The son went and searched twenty-two times up and down in all places, and even asked the attendants to help him search. Everyone participated in the search and seeking abundantly. When he saw that he could not find the hat, he told the matter to his father, our master, may his merit protect us.
Our master asked him: "Where do you remember putting it?" He replied that he remembered placing it in the iron cabinet that was in our master's room. However, he had already searched, and all the attendants had searched, and it seemed to him that all the shelves there were empty.
Our master said: "Let us enter that room." Our master approached the iron cabinet, and immediately at its opening, he found the hat and gave it to his son.
His son was amazed at the sight of his eyes. Our master said: "I received this from the Rabbi of Huniad, of blessed memory. When they say the saying of the Sages, 'Rabbi Binyamin said, etc.', and believe in truth that everything is in the presumption of blindness until the Holy One, Blessed be He, illuminates their eyes—then the Holy One, Blessed be He, illuminates the eyes, and then one finds the lost object immediately. And I said it and believed it in truth, therefore immediately and instantly I found it."
The Chassid R' Mordechai HaKohen Blum, Shlita.

**Tikkun Chatzot**
My holy master, my father (the holy Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Freund, Av Beit Din of Huniad), of blessed memory, was accustomed to say the explanation in the Mishnah (Berachot 1:1): **"וְלָמָּה אָמְרוּ חֲכָמִים עַד חֲצוֹת? כְּדֵי לְהַרְחִיק אֶת הָאָדָם מִן הָעֲבֵרָה"** - **"And why did the Sages say until midnight? To distance a person from transgression."**
That Tikkun Chatzot (Midnight Rectification prayer) is the Segulah (remedy) to distance a person from transgression.
The holy Gaon Rabbi Moshe Aryeh Freund, of blessed memory, Gaavad of the Eda Haredit.
Source: Kitvei Kodesh - Ateret Yehoshua (Jerusalem 5758), p. 256

**Spared**
In Tractate Shabbat (29b), in the Mishnah: **"כָּחַס עַל הַנֵּר, כָּחַס עַל הַשֶּׁמֶן, כָּחַס עַל הַפְּתִילָה חַיָּב וכו'"** - **"If he spared the lamp, spared the oil, spared the wick, he is liable, etc."** The commentators asked why it needed to say "spared the lamp, spared the oil, etc." [repetition].
I heard from the holy Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Freund, of blessed memory, Av Beit Din of Huniad, that he said in the name of the Gra (Vilna Gaon), of blessed memory, based on what is brought in Tractate Beitzah (16a): That all of a person's expenses are fixed for him from Rosh Hashanah, except for the expenses of Shabbat and Yom Tov, etc. If he reduces [spending on Shabbat], they reduce for him [from Heaven], and if he adds, they add for him.
It turns out that if he believed with perfect faith in the words of the Sages, he would not "spare" the lamp, the oil, or the wick. And in truth, he gains nothing by skimping on Shabbat. Since if he reduces, they reduce for him as brought in the Gemara above.
Only in his smallness of faith does it *seem* to him that he is gaining by sparing the lamp, etc. And this is the language **"כָּחַס"** (Kachas - *As if* he spared). Meaning, it *seems* to him that he spared the lamp, etc., but in truth, there is no gain at all, since if he reduces, they reduce for him as mentioned above. And words spoken fitly are sweet.
From a holy letter of the holy Admor of Toldot Aharon, of blessed memory.
Source: Nezer HaTorah, Kislev 5765, p. 239

The Admor Rabbi Yosef Tzvi Kalish, of blessed memory, was one of the prominent figures among the remnants of the previous generation. As a grandson and continuator of the Vorka dynasty, he filled the place of his father, the Admor Rabbi Shimon [son of Rabbi Mendel of Vorka and grandson of the Old Admor Rabbi Yitzchak of Vorka, of blessed memory], of blessed memory, in leading the congregation of Skierniewice Chassidim.
He was born in the year 5666 [1906]. He was the son-in-law of the Admor R' Yaakov of Biala (author of *Divrei Binah*), of blessed memory. He served as a Rabbi in the city of Karczew. From there, he was called about twenty years ago, by the Skierniewice Chassidim headed by R' Yitzchak Gerstenkorn, founder of Bnei Brak, to serve in the rabbinate of the newly built and established Bnei Brak.
He was a great and beautiful blend of Rebbe-hood and Rav/Posek. He led his congregation of G-d fearers and the city of Bnei Brak while also being a Posek in Forbidden and Permitted matters and arbitrating monetary matters as per the Torah. His goodness was upon him, and he instilled an atmosphere of Chassidut and fear of Heaven around him.
While still abroad, he walked a long way in the path of "enjoying the toil of his hands." He always served Hashem with joy. In Bnei Brak, he did not establish a Minyan before himself in his home as is the way of Admorim; rather, he established his place of prayer in the synagogue of the city because of **"בְּרֹב עָם הַדְרַת מֶלֶךְ"** - **"In the multitude of people is the King's glory."**
His connection to public matters was always prominent. A few days before his passing, he asked forgiveness from the doctor, lest he had hurt his honor. His soul departed on the eve of the holy Sabbath, Parshat Terumah, Erev Rosh Chodesh Adar I, 5717 [1957], in Tel Aviv. He was brought the next day to his rest in Tiberias. May his soul be bound in the bundle of life.
Source: HaNe'eman, Nissan 5717, p. 47

**A Kosher Man**
The holy Rebbe Rabbi Yosef Kalish of Skierniewice, of blessed memory, Av Beit Din of Bnei Brak, said: It is written **"הֲיֵשׁ בָּהּ עֵץ אִם אַיִן"** - **"Whether there is wood (Etz) therein, or not (Ayin)"** (Numbers 13:20). Rashi explains: Is there a Kosher man there?
One needs to understand why it says **"אִם אַיִן"** - **"or not"** (literally: or nothing). It should have been enough to say "Is there a tree therein?"
It appears that **"אִם אַיִן"** means: Is there a man there who can say **"וְאִם אַיִן מְחֵנִי"** - **"And if not, blot me out"** (Exodus 32:32)? Meaning, that he has self-sacrifice for the sake of Israel.
The Chassid R' Noach Gad Weintraub, z"l.
Source: BiYeshishim Chochma (Jerusalem 5754), p. 161

He was born in Krakow in the year 5384 [1624] to his father, Rabbi Yehuda Leib Ashkenazi Katz. At the age of 13, he began to study Kabbalah. Because of this, his wealthy parents sent him to study from the sages of the secret wisdom in Jerusalem. He was a distinct disciple of Rabbi Yisrael Ashkenazi, author of *Heichal Hashem*, and Rabbi Yaakov Tzemach, the physician. He also studied with Rabbi Zerachiah Gota, a disciple of the Maharit and Rabbi Yisrael Binyamin HaLevi.
He married the daughter of (his teacher) Rabbi Azariah Ze'evi, and was the brother-in-law of Rabbi Natan Gota. He studied in the Yeshiva of the Kabbalists in Jerusalem.
He was among the most important Kabbalists, the cubs of the Arizal. He was called "The Cornerstone of the Wisdom of Truth that is with us today," because he arranged the writings of the Arizal that were recorded in their time as they were spoken: Pshat, Drush, and Kavanot, following in the footsteps of his teacher Mahari Tzemach who began this.
In the year 5406 [1646], he began to edit the writings in Jerusalem. His work continued for four years due to exile and wanderings. After the decrees of Tach V'Tat (1648-1649), he traveled to Poland to inquire about the welfare of his family. He spent eight days in Damascus, in the home of Rabbi Shmuel Vital, son of Rabbi Chaim [Vital]. He found a note from his father stating that he should distribute three books, and so he did: *Derech Etz Chaim* (which is the book *Etz Chaim* with a second edition), *Pri Etz Chaim*, and *Nof Etz Chaim*.
He stayed in Constantinople from Purim until Shavuot and continued editing there. Upon arriving in Krakow, he completed his work. He established disciples there, among them his relative Rabbi Yosef Darshan of Posen, author of *Yesod Yosef*.
Despite his young age, he was crowned with immense praises by the geniuses of the time. In the year 5414 [1654], he set his steps to return via Constantinople, and arrived in the Land [of Israel] in 5415 [1655], sick and crushed from the prolonged wanderings. In 5416 [1656], he signed a letter of mission for two emissaries to save the Ashkenazic settlement in Jerusalem. He passed away young, at age 38, on the 20th of Adar 5422 [1662], and was buried on the slope of the Mount of Olives.
He himself authored many books on Kabbalah, Drush, and Mussar. The Chida writes that he authored thirty-nine books, corresponding to the numerical value of **"טַ"ל"** (Tal - Dew) Orot (Lights). One book by this name, in the way of Pshat and Drush on the Torah in clear style, was printed in Warsaw 5671 [1911] from the treasures of the *Imrei Emet*. In every one of his books, the word "Or" (Light) is found, hinting at his name Meir. The collective name for his books is *Kochvei Or* (Stars of Light).
Among them known to us: *Meorei Or*, entries of appellations for the Arizal; *Shapit*, and on it a commentary *Meorot Natan* and *Yair Nativ* by his hands, R' Natan Spira and R' Yaakov son of R' Binyamin Wolf of Vilna; *Or Rav*, a long commentary on the Zohar; *Or Pnei Melech*, a summary of the intentions of prayers according to the Arizal, composed in Constantinople in 5414; *Or Zarua*, a commentary on the book *Etz Chaim*. Published in Jerusalem, Ahavat Shalom, 5766; *Or Shabbat*, on three hymns of the Arizal; *Azamer*, *Asader*, and *Bnei Heichala*; *Or Ner*, on the subject of reincarnations. Most of it was copied as *Midrash Talpiot* entry Gilgul. Without mentioning its author; *Or Tzadikim*, laws, customs, and words of ethics. Completed in Krakow. Printed in Hamburg 5450, and again in Warsaw 5649. R' Tzvi Hirsch of the Dayanim of Posen published it in Amsterdam 5459 under the name *Or HaYashar* to hint at his name Hirsch, with editorial changes and important approbations. It was printed again in 5527 and 5557. A magnificent edition by R' Chaim Yosef Waldman, Jerusalem 5741.
Mahari of Belz encouraged the printing of the Siddur *Or HaYashar* in which these customs are integrated, saying in the name of his father, the Sar [Shalom], that the beginning of his entry into fear of Heaven was through this Siddur. The book merited many editions; *Ilan HaGadol*, to ease the study of Kabbalah for his students abroad, Ostroh 5581, Warsaw 5624; *Mesilot Chochmah*, 32 rules in Kabbalah, Shklov 5565; *Or Tzach* on the subject of the evolution of the Sefirot, a summary of the book *Mevo Shearim*, with notes and references by Rabbi Eliyahu Tzion Sofer, Ahavat Shalom, 5744, pp. 41, 153.
From the same editor also: *Torah Or*, composed in the year 5420 [1660], on matters of Kabbalah in the commentary of the Ramban on the Torah, Jerusalem 5749, 248 pages. In the conclusion of his introduction: "The young one, son of Buzi, Meir HaKohen Ashkenazi."
The rest of his books remained in manuscript, among them: *Or HaAvukah* on the foundations of Kabbalah (apparently lost); *Or Bahir* on Sefer HaBahir (in the National Library), and glosses on Recanati.
Rabbi Meir Wunder, Shlita.
Source: Elef Margaliot (Jerusalem 5753), p. 723

Our teacher, Rabbi Meir Poppers, a man of Jerusalem, may it be rebuilt. A disciple of Rabbi Yisrael Ashkenazi and the Kabbalist Rabbi Yaakov Tzemach. He authored *Meorei Or*, entries of appellations according to the opinion of our master the Arizal, of blessed memory.
And I have seen in manuscript some of his compositions: *Or Zarua* on Etz Chaim, *Or Pnei Melech* - intentions of prayers, *Or Ner* on reincarnations, *Or Tzach* on the evolution [of worlds], *Matok HaOr* - commentary on Ein Yaakov according to the way of Truth (Kabbalah), *Or Rav* - commentary on the Zohar, wondrously large.
And I heard that he authored books [corresponding to the number of] "Tal Orot" (39 Lights). And his brother-in-law, Rabbi Natan Gota, wrote that his soul rested on the 20th of Adar 5422 [1662]. [Shem Hagedolim by the Chida, regarding him].
Source: Rabbanan Kadishei (Jerusalem 5759), p. 484

He was born in Izmir in the year 5487 [1727] to his father, Rabbi Yisrael Yaakov, Av Beit Din and Rosh Yeshiva in Jerusalem, one of the sharpest minds of his generation, great in Torah, possessing pilpul and logic.
He excelled in creating his composition, *Hilchot Yom Tov*, which includes innovations on the laws of Bechorot (Firstborns) and Challah for the Ramban, which he composed as a supplement to the book of the Rif. He became known in the scholarly world as "The Maharit Algazi" named after his pilpulistic and halachic book of great value. It was printed and reprinted a number of times and was greatly beloved by all the greats of the generation and those who frequent the Beit Midrash.
In addition to this composition, he authored the book *Simchat Yom Tov* and Responsa.
He passed away on the 2nd of Adar I, 5562 [1802], and is buried on the Mount of Olives in Jerusalem the Holy City.
Rabbi David Halachmi, z"l.
Source: Chachmei Yisrael (Bnei Brak 5761), p. 190

The Chida, may his merit protect us, writes about him: "Yom Tov Rishon D'Orayta" (The first Yom Tov of the Torah) [= Maharit - Yom Tov Algazi]. (Language of the Chida in *Shem Hagedolim*).
The Gaon Rabbi Yechiel Michel Stern, Shlita.
Source: Gedolei Hadorot (Jerusalem 5755), Vol. 1, p. 399

The holy Rebbe Rabbi Nechemiah Alter, of blessed memory, may G-d avenge his blood, brother of the Admor of Gur, of blessed memory, used to tell what he heard from a great elderly man:
The Maharit Algazi was the Av Beit Din and Rosh Yeshiva in the Holy City of Jerusalem in the year [55xx] and went on a mission of Mitzvah to Europe. He was in the city of Frankfurt am Main close to the year 5540 [1780]. The Gaon, author of *Chatam Sofer*, of blessed memory, writes about him: "I knew him in the past when he was an emissary of Zion in Frankfurt am Main close to the year 5540, and the land was illuminated by his glory. Yet he had not even reached half the honor due to him according to what is seen from his composition *Hilchot Yom Tov*, for he performed wonders, increased wisdom, etc."
While he was in Frankfurt, a young man came to him and told him that he had a relative in the city of Prague who was an Agunah (a chained woman). She was a young woman, and he wanted to marry her. He told him the manner in which she was an Agunah. At that time, the Rabbi in Prague was the Gaon, author of *Noda B'Yehuda*, of blessed memory. When he told him the manner of her being an Agunah, it arose in the mind of the Maharit Algazi, of blessed memory, that he could permit her, for he had grounds for this.
Due to his great compassion and the greatness of the Mitzvah to release her from being an Agunah, and also because there was a young man who wanted to marry her, he decided to travel to Prague to the Noda B'Yehuda, and they would permit the woman from her Agunah status.
The Maharit traveled with the young man to Prague. Immediately upon arriving there, the Maharit went to the Noda B'Yehuda. He spoke with him in words of Torah, and they engaged for three days in words of Torah. During the conversations, he remarked to him about the permission for the aforementioned Agunah. They spoke about this at length and debated this permission. The Maharit Algazi decided to permit the Agunah, and told them to prepare for the wedding, and he would be at the wedding.
The Gaon, author of *Noda B'Yehuda*, had great distress from this, for in his opinion there was no permit for her prohibition, and he had great weakness of mind from this. When the Noda B'Yehuda sat in his room in great sorrow, the young man who was the husband [to be] of the Agunah came to him. Then the Noda B'Yehuda immediately strengthened his mind and exerted himself to annul the permit of the Maharit Algazi. He prepared himself quickly to go to the Maharit Algazi to retract his permission since the husband was present with him.
When the Noda B'Yehuda came to the Maharit, they began to debate once more. Then the Maharit Algazi said to the Noda B'Yehuda: "You think that because the husband of the Agunah came to you, you hold your opinion not to permit her. Know for certain that the husband of the Agunah is no longer in this world; he has already passed away and died. Only because you have great distress and weakness of mind, therefore Heaven had mercy on you to send you the aforementioned husband, so that you would not have distress. But in truth, he has already passed away.
"And the proof to my words: Even though you told your son to lock the husband of the Agunah in the house so that he could not go out until they see him for me—and indeed it was so, that the son of the Noda B'Yehuda locked the husband so he could not go out—but you will see when you come home, he will not be there, for he passed away long ago."
And so it was. When the Noda B'Yehuda came to his house, the husband was not in his house. Then they performed the wedding according to the permit of the Maharit Algazi, and the Maharit Algazi was also at the wedding.
The holy Rebbe Rabbi Aryeh Mordechai Rabinowitz, z"l, Av Beit Din of Bnei Brak.
Source: Karnei Re'em (Bnei Brak 5755), Vol. 1, p. 127

Our master Yitzchak Alfasi [the Rif], known throughout the world for *Halachot Rav Alfas*, was the father of all Torah scholars. With the eye of his intellect, upon which the Holy Spirit rested, he saw to clarify, sift, and select fine flour from between the two Talmuds, the Babylonian and the Jerusalem, the judgments followed as Halacha for practice for generations. He established them forever, one statute for the House of Israel, all of them. The Halacha follows him, and in Heaven, he is considered highly. They announced regarding him in the firmament: "And Isaac sowed, and the man grew great and went on growing until he became very great."
After him arose the great lion from the dwelling of lions, our master Moshe ben Nachman [the Ramban], to complete and fill the Halachot upon which the sun of the Torah of Rav Alfas did not shine. He composed *Hilchot Bechorot*, *Challah*, and *Nedarim*, shining like the essence of the heavens for purity, and repeated his teaching exactly like the language of the Rif.
These Halachot, which were open and revealed to the eyes of our early masters, of blessed memory, the disciples of the Ramban—such as the Rashba and the Ra'ah, as seen from their compositions, and also to our master Asher—the Rosh, of blessed memory, who copied them and brought them verbatim in his Halachot for Tractates Bechorot and Challah, constant in their order—through him we merited a substantial portion of the Torah of Moshe.
For after this period, these Halachot were hidden and disappeared from every eye. Only unique individuals among the great later sages (Acharonim), such as our master Betzalel Ashkenazi and our master Tam ibn Yahya, author of *Ohalei Tam*, and the Gaon of our strength the Chida, of blessed memory, merited to see the holiness and become perfumed by his Torah. Thus, these Halachot remained hidden and stored away in archives.
Until, in the fullness of days, merit was revealed by the worthy one, the chosen of G-d, the Chassid, the mighty shepherd, head of the exile of Ariel, our master the King, our Rebbe Yom Tov Algazi, of blessed memory, Rabbi of Rabbis in the Holy City of Jerusalem, may it be rebuilt.
When he went out to circulate in the cities of Frankia (Europe) in the years 5530-5536 [1770-1776] on a mission of Mitzvah as an emissary of Zion to revive the hearts of the crushed and broken, and in that time many hardships and troubles passed over him, G-d showered upon him the dew of revival. Like cold water on a tired soul, a Mitzvah drags another Mitzvah along, and the Torah of Moshe—the two Tablets of the Covenant, *Hilchot Nedarim* and *Bechorot*—came into his hand (was not available to him?), and our master rejoiced over them like one finding great spoil.
His soul asked in prayer to Hashem: **"מִי יִתֵּן וְהָיָה זִכַּנִי ה' לְזַכּוֹת אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל מְגַלֶּה עֲמוּקוֹת לִפְנֵי כָּל יוֹדְעֵי דָת וָדִין"** - **"Oh that Hashem would grant me the merit to benefit Israel, revealing depths before all who know law and judgment."**
When our master returned at the end of his mission to the Holy Land, he sought to fulfill his vow to bring this hidden treasure to light for the world. He began to join himself to the holiness to make explanations and sources for it. He set his face first and foremost on Tractate Bechorot, for the right of the firstborn belonged to it.
In his great humility, our master [the Maharit Algazi, of blessed memory] describes his teaching before us as if it is unworthy to be joined to the holiness. He made it only for students of the Beit Rav, to find an opening and a faithful source for the words of the author of the Halachot.
And so he writes in his introduction: "And I know in my soul a tenth that I am destined to learn, small words adding a weekday to the holy. What will this give before the great ones whose little finger is thicker than my loins? However, regarding these, I desired two things according to their laws, and this and that is fulfilled for all there is time. A wise heart and strong power will hold the righteous to his path through the Tree of Life. And this is the Torah which Moshe placed, for this is a great general rule, a complete Torah. From his mouth we live and from their waters we drink. And to these men, the students of the Beit Rav, they will set their eyes to the hyssop that is in the wall to the sides, to find the opening where its place is."
However, from the day he arrived in Jerusalem, they surrounded him and encircled him: "The rivers of my sorrow, due to the pressure of the public, in your sorrow, Jerusalem did not restore his spirit days and nights; there is no day without its curse being abundant."
Despite this, he delivered his soul literally to bring it out to the world, as per his testimony in his introduction: "And little that I stole by day and stole by night, like one raking over coals, a matter and half a matter."
Our master did not manage to publish the two Halachot and recite the blessing over the finish, two according to their laws. For the time being, the one was revealed and seen, the beloved one.
And when it arose in favor before the Master of All, the printing of this book, Hashem arranged at our master's hand a faithful envoy who went on a mission of Mitzvah from the Holy City of Hebron. And he sent Yehuda before him, **"הֶחָכָם הַשָּׁלֵם וְהַכּוֹלֵל זֶה סִינַי כְּמוֹהֲרַ"ר יְהוּדָה לִיאוֹן"** - **"The complete and comprehensive sage, this Sinai, our master Rabbi Yehuda Leon."** He appointed him as an agent for this matter, to bring it to the magnificent printing house in the celebrated city of Livorno, for during our master's residence in our Holy City, a printing house had not yet been established there.
And so the envoy expresses himself in the introduction to this book:
"I was on the way, Hashem led me, and I passed through the land of Tunis, etc., and I spoke judgments with its kings and ministers. And they saw all the holy writings of the great one of our lords, our father, our shepherd, the head of the exile of Ariel, the great Rabbi, fortress and tower, the crown of our heads, our teacher and master Asher Or Lo (whose light is his) in Zion, the Holy City, Yom Tov Rishon D'Orayta, may his lamp shine. And they all answered Amen as one, with a whole heart and willing soul." And he signed his name: **"עֶבֶד נִרְצֶה לַעֲבוֹדַת מוֹ"ר עֲטֶ"ר מֶלֶךְ יְרוּשָׁלַיִם"** - **"A servant willing for the service of my master and teacher, the crown of my head, the King of Jerusalem."**
With the help of the magnificent magnates of the Shaul family and the Recanati family in Izmir, who waved a wave offering of gold, a huge sum, the printing of the book was made possible.
The prayer of our master [Maharit Algazi] to benefit the many with the Halachot of the Ramban and to reveal depths before all knowers of religion and law was accepted with favor. In the year 5554 [1794], at the going forth of the sun in its might, *Hilchot Bechorot* and *Challah* for the Ramban, of blessed memory, came out to the world with the commentary of our master, which they called by the name *Hilchot Yom Tov*.
This composition, described by our master as "a little explanation and a little discussion," and similarly he calls it in his other books "my small book," became famous quickly. It illuminated the entire world. In it, he showed his strength and might in Torah as one of the Rishonim, the greats of the world, the pillars of the earth. They were amazed by the depth of his immense intellect and his frightening scope. Our master, in the explanation of the Halachot and the ramifications, questions and disassembles, builds and contradicts in the sea of the Talmud and in all the books of the Rishonim, breaking mountains and shattering rocks, straightening paths and revealing depths.
The viewer will see that it is not "small" but a "great" book before us, wide of hands and open entirely. Explanations branching out and discussion extending long before us. For he goes out from his boundary and domain to every wind and side of the sides of the Torah like an angel of G-d, ascending and descending in the Bavli to the Yerushalmi and from the Tosefta to the Sifrei. And in general, the words of our masters the Rishonim and Acharonim until his time literally. And especially, he revealed the strength of his arm in the Torah of the Mishnah to the King, and the Camp of Efraim like a flowing stream from the source of their Beit Midrash. Until in the books of the Acharonim they called it **"הַסֵּפֶר הַנּוֹרָא"** - **"The Awesome Book"** and **"הַסֵּפֶר הַבָּהִיר"** - **"The Bright Book."** It merited to be accepted as one of the foundational books explaining the Torah of our masters, both in his innovations and in his rulings. From him is the corner, from him is the peg, for all the compositions that were authored from his time by the geniuses of the Land of Israel and the lands of the East, who discuss his Torah and delight in it with fear and honor as one of the early masters (Kama'ei).
And it came to pass at the end of forty years, in the year 5596 [1836], the printer in the city of Pressburg the Crowned arose and awakened. They began to raise upon the altar of the press the books of Rav Alfas anew with the addition of innovations. At that very time, G-d brought into the hands of our master, the author of *Chatam Sofer*, of blessed memory, the book of our master [Maharit Algazi] containing the composition of the Ramban on Hilchot Bechorot. He had been distressed all his days that he could not find them, and he searched in all the gates, countries, and towns, in markets openly and in inner chambers, until he heard G-d and listened to the voice of his prayer, and the book reached his hand via two of his students.
He said: "Who would grant that the books of the Rif be printed and the Halachot of the Ramban be attached to the Halachot of the Rif to fill the lack, and no book of Torah would be lacking a single letter." He gave them to the aforementioned printer, and the printer's face lit up to meet him. The matter came out executed magnificently and corrected.
The greats of the generation praised and lauded it in their approbations: our master the *Chatam Sofer* and the Gaon Rabbi Nachum Trebitsch, Av Beit Din of Nikolsburg.
When the first volume ascended upon the table of kings, the printer received letters of praise from the majority of all the exiles: our master Rabbi Akiva Eiger, of blessed memory, and from the luminary of the exile, the Gaon our master Moshe Teitelbaum, author of *Yismach Moshe*, of blessed memory. And also words of praise and laudation from those two brothers-in-law, the famous geniuses: Rabbi Yosef Shaul Nathanson and Rabbi Mordechai Zev Ettinga, of blessed memory, the masters of the *Mefarshei HaYam*.
From the approbations and letters, their amazement and astonishment at the great vision revealed to their eyes is reflected before us. And so our master the *Chatam Sofer*, of blessed memory, saw the matters:
"And around him a great storm raged, from a great and precious man, a world genius, Mahu' Yom Tov Algazi, of blessed memory. I knew him in the past when he was an emissary of Zion in Frankfurt am Main close to the year 5540 [1780], and the land was illuminated by his glory. Yet he had not even reached half the honor due to him according to what is seen from this composition called *Hilchot Yom Tov* on Bechorot and Challah, for he performed wonders, increased wisdom. From the day of the composition of the Mishnah, such a composition has not been seen for the King."
And our master Rabbi Akiva Eiger, of blessed memory, also praises in words and writes:
"A heavy and very wondrous commentary from the Gaon our master Yom Tov Algazi, of blessed memory."
A great and important correction was made in the Pressburg edition: to ease the study for those delving into it, they put signs in it and fixed in every Halacha from the words of the Ramban the place where the King, the Maharit, spoke, amended, elongated, and debated as a Sugya and a system on its own.
Similarly, in later editions in the Zhitomir press in 5621 [1861] and in the Warsaw press in 5623 [1863], they followed the form of the Pressburg edition. When they joined the books of Rav Alfas to every tractate in the Shas, they also added the Halachot of the Ramban for Bechorot and Challah with the commentary of our master for Tractate Bechorot. Since then, the dwelling of this composition was established in its entirety as an inseparable part of all editions of the Shas for generations of the world.
Also the editors of the Shas in Vilna in the year 5626 [1866] followed in the footsteps of their predecessors and increased the work when they joined their notes and glosses of two of the sages of Vilna: the Gaon Rabbi Eliyahu Bahag"mar Shmuel Strashun, of blessed memory, and the Rabbi R' Yosef Nachum Montkali.
And so our master merited what others did not merit: that his Torah is engraved between the staves of the Shas, in the format and character of our early masters, the commentators of the Halachot—Rabbeinu Yonah, the Ran, and the Nimukei Yosef...
This wisdom is hidden from us, except for this solitary tractate from this order, Tractate Bechorot, whose wisdom came to revelation thanks to the mighty man, a hero in the war of Torah, who established a yoke and brought its mysteries outside. The Maharit Algazi and Tractate Bechorot are one; his name is called upon it and it is called by his name. Its obscure Sugyas and complex Halachot are clarified by our master, the father of all graspers of this wisdom, to their depth and breadth. Before us are spread out like a dress the methods of the Bavli and Yerushalmi, the Rishonim and Acharonim.
Our master also deciphers hidden things for us, additions (Tosafot) external from the treasures of the author of *Shita Mekubetzet*, Rabbi Betzalel Ashkenazi, which were in manuscript and are illuminated with words rejoicing like their giving at Sinai.
The teaching of our master the Maharit was poured and kneaded with the creation of Bechorot, and it became the very essence of its existence. The engagement in the details of its Halachot and Sugyas obligates a robbery of depths in the Torah of our master. We have not found our hands and feet in the laws of the Firstborn and the Branching Out, were it not for his illuminating light guiding us in the paths of its pathways. Our master breathed a new spirit, pleasantness, and sweetness into the study of this tractate. He paved and conquered the King's highway to its hidden places and treasures, and merited us to enter this palace which was until then closed and sealed.
The Maharit Algazi on Bechorot is not just a commentary and explanation on the Halachot of the Ramban for this tractate, and it is not limited only to the laws branching out from this tractate. His great mind knows no boundaries, what they are, and the attribute of constriction does not grasp him at all. An overflowing spring whose waters do not fail. With a quiet spirit, he opens and explains the words of the Ramban, precise in every single tag and letter of his words, weighing his language in a balance of fine gold.
From here, our master descends to plunder the depths of the Sugya itself. He illuminates it with his crystal light and stamps upon every one of its corners the seal of his clarity. His wondrous precisions in the words of our masters Rashi and the Baalei Tosafot fertilize the entire Sugya.
With the boldness of holiness, he passes to the methods of the rest of the Rishonim, sharpens their words, and illuminates their methods on firm foundations from the Yerushalmi. He creates supports in his pilpul from the Sifra and Sifrei, uproots mountains and straightens the paths of the Sugyas. A king breaking a path for himself from Sugya to Sugya, clashing with damages and warning regarding seeds. And his heart is the heart of a lion full of purity. In the path of his walking, he settles difficulties in the Rambam that all his armor-bearers wearied to find the opening for. He investigates investigations and innovates wondrous novelties, removing a difficulty of the Mishnah for the King, and wondering at the innovation of the *Machaneh Efraim*. He extends the good hand of Hashem upon him, for is the land not wide in measure?
And after he dives into mighty waters and draws up a pearl in his hand, he returns to the beginning of his words. And on the way of his return, when his soul is calm from asking, clarifying an additional Sugya, and illuminating a new path in the explanation of a baffling Yerushalmi, after asking forgiveness from its commentators, the Rash Sirilio and the R"a Fulda.
"מַה נּוֹרָא הַמָּקוֹם הַזֶּה" - "How awesome is this place" (Genesis 28:17) when the entire Torah is folded beneath it in one tractate—Tractate Bechorot.
His gigantic creation in this book became the heritage of the Torah nation in all its dwellings in general, and for those who delve and study in particular. The knights of the shepherds and those sitting on judgment lean upon him in their rulings, as the viewer will see in the books of P'sak and Responsa of the greats of Israel to their dispersions. The heads of Yeshivas and their students pilpulize and curl [their logic] in his arrangements. The mighty ones of Torah and masters of shields (defenders/debaters) delve deeply into his investigations and drink his words with thirst, and the dwellers of the tent are astonished by his expertise.
His method of study acquired a resting place in the tents of the Yeshivas, for he is the opener of the gate to enter the palace of true learning and pilpul. Among the elite, there are those who established fixed times to delve deeply into the Torah of our master. The elders of the gate told us that in the Batei Midrash in Poland and Galicia, special groups banded together to engage in the Torah of the Maharit Algazi.
Many authors who discussed his Torah raised their comments and objections upon their books. Among them are the Rabbis and Poskim of the generations in their Responsa; among them are heads of Metivtas (Yeshivas) in their classes. Those who made special pamphlets (Kuntresim) increased to do so, going through our master's words in order, and recording their comments constantly in order, each one according to his way.
The Gaon, author of Chelkat Yoav, who made precious and wondrous comments. The Gaon Rabbi David Friedman of Karlin, author of She'ilat David, who despite rarely paying attention to the words of the Acharonim, saw fit to make his deep comments on the words of our master. And rising above them all is the Gaon Rabbi Abba Yaakov HaKohen Borochov, author of Chevel Yaakov, who in Part 3 of his book printed a special pamphlet on the composition of the Maharit Algazi.
The Gaon Rabbi Baruch, son of the Hagrashaz Auerbach, z"l.And the Gaon Rabbi Aharon Mordechai Shadmi, Shlita.
Source: Introduction to Hilchot Bechorot V'Challah (Jerusalem 5753), Vol. 1, p. 7

A terrible event occurred in his time, which demonstrated from Heaven the righteousness and greatness of the Maharit Algazi. It concerned a pregnant woman whose husband died without children, though he had a small brother. The woman gave birth to a son who died on the eighth day. There were those who permitted her to remarry without *Chalitzah* (the levirate separation ceremony), but our Master (in Responsa Simchat Yom Tov, Siman 11) forbade her to remarry without *Chalitzah*. Many disagreed with him, until he returned in his book (ibid, Siman 12) to prove she was forbidden, and he concluded there: "But this alone I say, that the Sage who is the father of the woman, who exerted all his efforts to permit his daughter—if he does this to act against the ruling of Maran the Beit Yosef and the Rama, I promise him that no good will come to him..."
And indeed, it happened that many who involved themselves on the side of the woman were punished by Heaven. Even that Rabbi and Gaon who disagreed with our Master fell ill and was close to death, until he sent to our Master to ask his forgiveness (cited in the book *Toldot Chachmei Yisrael*, Part 3, Chapter 3, regarding Rabbi Aryeh Leib Frumkin).
Source: "Gedolei HaDorot" (Jerusalem 5755), Part 1, p. 399

body_he: מַעֲשֶׂה נוֹרָא אֵירַע בִּזְמַנּוֹ, שֶׁהֶרְאוּ מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם אֶת צִדְקַת וּגְדֻלַּת מַהֲרִי"ט אַלְגָאזִי, וְהוּא בְּאִשָּׁה מְעֻבֶּרֶת שֶׁמֵּת בַּעְלָהּ בְּלֹא בָּנִים, וְלוֹ אָח קָטָן, וְיָלְדָה הָאִשָּׁה בֵּן שֶׁמֵּת בַּיּוֹם הַשְּׁמִינִי, וְהָיוּ כָּאֵלֶּה שֶׁהִתִּירוּ אוֹתָהּ לְלֹא חֲלִיצָה, אַךְ רַבֵּינוּ (בְּשׁוּ"ת שִׂמְחַת יוֹ"ט סִימָן י"א) אֲסָרָהּ לְלֹא חֲלִיצָה, וְרַבִּים חָלְקוּ עָלָיו, עַד שֶׁחָזַר בְּסִפְרוֹ שָׁם סִי' י"ב לְהוֹכִיחַ לְאוֹסְרָהּ וְסִיֵּם שָׁם: "אַךְ זֶה בִּלְבַד אֲנִי אוֹמֵר כִּי הֶחָכָם אֲבִי הָאִשָּׁה אֲשֶׁר הִשְׁתַּדֵּל בְּכָל מַאֲמַצֵּי כֹּחוֹ לְהַתִּיר אֶת בִּתּוֹ, אִם כֹּה יַעֲשֶׂה לַעֲשׂוֹת הֵיפֶךְ מָרָן הַבַּ"י וְהָרַמָ"א אֲנִי מַבְטִיחוֹ כִּי לֹא יַעֲלֶה לוֹ טוֹבָה..."וְאָכֵן קָרָה שֶׁרַבִּים שֶׁהִתְעַסְּקוּ לְצַד הָאִשָּׁה נֶעֶנְשׁוּ מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם, וְגַם אוֹתוֹ רַב וְגָאוֹן שֶׁחָלַק עַל רַבֵּינוּ חָלָה וְנָטָה לָמוּת עַד שֶׁשָּׁלַח לְרַבֵּינוּ לְבַקֵּשׁ מְחִילָתוֹ (הוּבָא בְּסֵפֶר תּוֹלְדוֹת חַכְמֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל ח"ג פ"ג לְרַבִּי אַרְיֵה לֵייבּ פְרוּמְקִין).הויה"ג ר' יחיאל מיכל שטרן שליט"א"גדולי הדורות" (ירושלים תשנ"ה) ח"א, ע' 399

**Biography**
The holy Rabbi Aharon Aryeh was the son of Rabbi Meir the Great of Premishlan. He was his disciple and the trustee of his house, the Baal Shem Tov.
He was a descendant of the Ari (Rabbi Yitzchak Luria) from Korbil, and one of the greats of Chassidut. He was a noble personality, an ascetic, and a recluse. He was a distinct disciple of the Maggid Rabbi Yechiel Michel of Zlotchov and Rabbi Elimelech of Lizhensk.
His son was the famous Tzaddik Rabbi Meir of Premishlan. His father said of him that he left a burning torch of fire.
Once he said to his teacher, Rabbi Elimelech of Lizhensk: "Although the Tzaddikim of the generation aspired to merit the revelation of Elijah, a true servant of G-d must refuse to merit the revelation of Elijah, for it contains an infringement upon human free will."
In addition to his son Rabbi Meir, he left behind sons who were great Tzaddikim: Rabbi Yitzchak Leifer of Kalish, Rabbi Dov of Brzezan, and Rabbi Michel of Komarna. He passed away on the 2nd of Adar (or 11th of Adar II) 5573 (1813) and is buried in Premishlan.
Source: "Chachmei Yisrael" (Bnei Brak 5761), p. 160

On the holy Shabbat when we bless the month of Elul, in the year 5755 (1995), I (and my pleasant grandson R' Yehoshua Heschel Shlita, son of my son Rabbi Shalom Yosef Shlita) were among those spending Shabbat with my relative, the holy Gaon and Admor of Bobov zt"l. We lodged at the home of Rabbi Shalom Kessler Shlita. I had with me the cup of my ancestor, the holy Rabbi Meir'l of Premishlan zt"l. The Rebbe zt"l made Kiddush on it with great holiness, and spoke words of holiness regarding the family of the holy Rabbi Meir'l zt"l.
In the course of conversation, he related that he heard from his father, the holy Gaon Rabbi Ben Zion of Bobov zt"l, that his ancestor, known as R' Meir the Great of Premishlan zt"l, was one of the disciples of the holy Baal Shem Tov, may his merit protect us. When his first two children were born, he saw them after the birth and expressed himself in a way that implied he did not intend for this specific child, but rather for souls higher than these, and they passed away, G-d forbid. When the Rebbetzin gave birth to a third son, she prevented her husband, R' Meir zt"l, from seeing the child, fearing that what happened to the first ones might happen to him. She insisted that the holy Baal Shem Tov come first and bless the child with long and good years.
About a year and a half passed until he could bring the holy Baal Shem Tov to his home. The Baal Shem Tov asked the child if he knew who he was. The child was already speaking a few words and answered him that he was Rabbi Yitzchak Luria!! Upon this, the Baal Shem Tov said: "So shall you live" (*Azoy zolstu leben*).
Afterward, when R' Meir the Great zt"l was permitted to see the son, he answered and said that he had already dismissed great souls from this world, but the blessing of the Baal Shem Tov protected this one, and he lived. According to assumption, this child was the holy Rabbi Aharon Aryeh of Premishlan zt"l, known as R' Aharon Leib zt"l.
Source: "Yafah Sichatan" (Brooklyn 5769), Part 2, p. 24

When Rabbi Aharon Leib of Premishlan made his way to Rimanov, to Rabbi Menachem Mendel, he ordered his wagon driver to switch places with him. He even took the wagon driver's hat and dressed the wagon driver in his own *Spodik* (fur hat)...
They approached the city, and behold, a large group of Rabbi Menachem Mendel's disciples came out to greet the wagon, for their Rebbe had sent them to welcome a Tzaddik.
The disciples rushed to the wagon driver wearing the "Spodik" and greeted him with trembling. However, Rabbi Naftali of Ropshitz immediately approached the "supposed wagon driver" and said: "Peace be upon you, our Master."
Rabbi Aharon Leib asked him: "From where did you discern the matter?"
He answered: "I saw with what humility he manages the horse, and I knew that he is the holy one..."
Source: "Chassidim Mesaprim" (Jerusalem 5739), Part 2, p. 121

body_he: הרה"ג ר' ידידיה ברנדסדורפר שליט"א"שנות ביכורים-מדות" (ת"א ס"א) ע' ר"כ
body_en:
I heard a story about the Admor, the Beis Yisrael *zt"l*, that while he was at a certain Simcha, they asked him to taste from a dish that was on the table so that it would become *Shirayim* (leftovers from a Tzaddik). He said in a clever way that since he looked at the food, it is *Shirayim*.
Source: HaGaon HaChassid Rabbi Zvi Yitzchak Abramowitz z"l, "Taam HaZvi" (Bnei Brak 5752) Part 2, p. 230

The holy Rabbi Aharon Leib zt"l, father of the holy Rabbi Meir of Premishlan zt"l—the holy Rabbi Mendel of Rimanov zt"l said of him that he is the Messiah of the generation. R' Aharon Leib answered that he is not the Messiah, but rather he is in the aspect of the verse: **אהבת צדק ותשנא רשע** - "**You have loved righteousness and hated wickedness**" (Psalms 45:8). The holy Rabbi of Rimanov said: "Look at the end of the verse, what is written? **על כן משחך** - '**Therefore G-d, your G-d, has anointed you**' (ibid), meaning he is in the aspect of Messiah."
He replied that he is not Messiah, for only this aspect applies to him: **והוא מחלל מפשעינו** - "**But he was pained because of our transgressions**" (Isaiah 53:5). For the Messiah suffers afflictions to atone for the sins of Israel, and since he does not suffer afflictions [he cannot be the Messiah].
Source: "Ashrei HaIsh" (Jerusalem 5771), p. 122

The holy Rabbi Aharon Leib of Premishlan zt"l was a disciple of the holy Maggid of Zlotchov. Once, when he arrived at his Rebbe, the holy Maggid, he found him lying on the ground with his hands and feet spread out. R' Aharon Leib asked him the meaning of this. The holy Maggid told him that a harsh decree was hovering over the people of Israel, and he was shaking worlds in vain. R' Aharon Leib said to him: "Why should our Rebbe sacrifice his soul so much for this matter alone? After all, I too, with my strength, can engage in this." The holy Maggid rose from the ground, and R' Aharon Leib lay himself down with spread hands and feet and shook the decree. When he rose from the ground, he said that he had already succeeded in annulling the decree, but they still needed to undergo some humiliation for this, and then everything would be sweetened.
And so it was. The next day, R' Aharon Leib and the Maggid of Zlotchov hired a wagon and traveled together to a nearby village. There, they stood by the house of a certain Jew and asked him to let them lodge there. He agreed. The two Tzaddikim stayed there all day and served G-d. After midday, the holy Maggid stood up to pray the Morning Prayer (*Shacharit*), as was his holy custom to pray at a late hour. When the owner of the inn saw this, he began to scream at him at the top of his lungs: "Is it possible to behave against the Shulchan Aruch and pray after midday?!" He made a great tumult and shamed him greatly. The holy Maggid of Zlotchov did not answer him at all. Rabbi Aharon Leib also stood by the side and answered nothing. But the man did not stop screaming, and amidst his shouting, the man became so enraged at the holy Maggid that he wanted to hit him. Then R' Aharon Leib stood against him and warned him not to dare strike him, for he knew the secret of the matter—that they were only to suffer humiliation and nothing more. When the holy Maggid finished his prayer, they traveled from there to their homes, and the decree was completely annulled.
Source: "Mipihem U'mipi Ketavam" (Kiryat Joel 5767), Part 1, p. 288

The holy Rabbi Aharon Leib of Premishlan zt"l once fell ill. At that time, a poor man arrived at his house and asked to enter to see him, but the Rebbetzin did not want to let him in. When the holy Rabbi Aharon Leib heard that she refused the one asking to enter, he rose from his bed and opened the door. When the poor man entered, he said that he was Elijah the Prophet and wanted to teach him all the secrets of the holy Torah.
The holy Rabbi Aharon Leib replied to him: "I wish to serve G-d according to my grasp. I desire to attain the revealed Torah through my toil and labor. As for the hidden Torah, I wish to hear it from the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed be He, in His Glory and Essence."
Some time passed, and the Rebbetzin of the holy Rabbi Aharon Leib fell ill. Rabbi Aharon Leib traveled to the holy Rabbi Yechiel Michel of Zlotchov zt"l and asked him to bless the Rebbetzin with recovery. The holy Rabbi of Zlotchov answered him that he should travel to the holy Rabbi Elimelech of Lizhensk zt"l, and from there the recovery would come to her.
The holy Rabbi Aharon Leib traveled to spend Shabbat in Lizhensk. On the way, he said to the Rebbetzin: "Know that the holy Rabbi Elimelech sees on a person's forehead everything he has done from the day of his birth. I am very afraid that the holy Rabbi Elimelech will send me away from his holy home, and we will have nowhere to be for the holy Shabbat. Therefore, prepare all our Shabbat needs in our lodging, for the Rebbe will not receive me."
When Rabbi Aharon Leib zt"l came to Lizhensk, the holy Rabbi R' Elimelech did not want to give him 'Shalom' (a greeting), saying that he saw on his forehead that he had transgressed the three cardinal sins: Idolatry, Incest, and Bloodshed.
The holy Rabbi Aharon Leib returned to his lodging brokenhearted, saying to the Rebbetzin: "I told you to prepare my Shabbat needs, for the Rebbe will not receive me."
On Shabbat eve, Rabbi Aharon Leib went to pray in the Beit Midrash of the holy Rabbi Elimelech, but he did not enter inside; rather, he stood outside so as not to disturb the holy R' Elimelech from his prayer. Suddenly, the holy R' Elimelech stopped his prayer and asked: "Where is there a young man here who does not let me pray?!"
They searched for the 'young man' and found the holy Rabbi Aharon Leib praying in the 'polish' (anteroom of the Beit Midrash). He was called to Rabbi Elimelech, who honored him and gave him a place at the eastern wall.
On Saturday night, Rabbi Aharon Leib entered the Rebbe's room with the Rebbetzin and asked for a recovery for her. Rabbi Elimelech took off the *Gartel* (belt) he was wearing, told the Rebbetzin to hold one end while he held the other, and asked the Rebbetzin: "Do you feel better yet?" When the Rebbetzin answered no, he asked a second time: "And now?" The Rebbetzin answered that indeed she felt better. He asked a third time, and then she answered that she was now completely healthy like any person.
The Rebbe asked her if it was true that she hadn't recovered the first time. The Rebbetzin answered that indeed she felt healed immediately, but she lied because she wanted to hold onto the holy R' Elimelech's *Gartel* a bit longer...
Afterward, Rabbi Aharon Leib asked Rabbi Elimelech what were the sins he saw on his forehead. Rabbi Elimelech reminded him that when he returned from immersing in the Mikvah on the day of his Bar Mitzvah, a couple passed before him and expressed: "If only we had a son like this!" These words introduced a bit of feelings of pride into his heart, and our Sages said (Sotah 4b): **כל אדם שיש בו גסות הרוח כאילו עובד ע"ז וכאילו בא על העריות** - "**Anyone who possesses arrogance of spirit is as if he worships idols and as if he commits incest.**" And behold, recently Elijah the Prophet came to him to teach him, and he rejected him and shamed him, and **וכל המלבין פני חברו ברבים כאילו שופך דמים** - "**Anyone who shames his neighbor in public is as if he spills blood**" (Bava Metzia 58b).
Source: "Sarfei Kodesh" (Bnei Brak 5768), p. 301

My grandfather, the holy Rabbi Aharon Leib, once sat at the Seder night and recited the Haggadah. When he reached the section "Pour out Your wrath," he ordered the door to be opened as is customary. When the door was opened, the holy Rabbi Aharon Leib said to Elijah the Prophet: "Blessed is he who comes, Rebbe!" They sat and spoke with each other, and from one topic to another, they spoke of those matters [meaning matters of Redemption]. Elijah stood up and said: "It is already late, I must go, for the Rebbe of Lublin has already opened the door."
My grandfather, the holy Rabbi R' Aharon Leib, was one of the great Tzaddikim who merited the revelation of Elijah whenever he wished.
Source: "Arba'ah Arazim" (Bnei Brak 5727), p. 108

The holy Admor of Bobov zt"l told me in the name of his father, the holy Gaon Rabbi Ben Zion of Bobov zt"l, that the holy Rabbi Aharon Leib of Premishlan zt"l was once in the city of Lemberg (Lvov). He went to visit the great Gaon Rabbi Yaakov Ornstein zt"l, the "Yeshuos Yaakov," with whom he had been connected since his youth when they studied together. In honor of the great guest, the heads of the community arranged a respectable meal. During the meal, they brought a bowl of soup before the holy Rabbi. The holy Rabbi stuck his spoon into the bowl for about a quarter of an hour and began to say to himself the verse: **יצא אדם לפעלו ולעבדתו עדי ערב** - "**Man goes forth to his work and to his labor until evening**" (Psalms 104:23). He repeated this for about half an hour. The "Yeshuos Yaakov," the heads of the community, and all those seated there did not begin to eat out of respect for the great guest, the holy Rabbi Aharon Leib zt"l, not knowing the meaning of his actions.
Meanwhile, as they were arranging the poultry meat prepared for the meal in the kitchen, they found a question regarding one of the bones. They brought it before the Rabbi, and he ruled it forbidden. Then they understood the reason for the delay, but they did not know the connection to the aforementioned verse. The Yeshuos Yaakov zt"l asked him about this, and he answered him: "King David, peace be upon him, says **יצא אדם לפעלו ולעבדתו עדי ערב** - '**Man goes forth to his work and to his labor until evening**' - meaning that every person must work on perfecting himself and doing good deeds. And after he has already fulfilled his duties, the work is still incumbent upon him **עדי ערב** - '**until evening**' - meaning to be a guarantor (*Arev*) also for others, and to guard them from stumbling blocks and prohibitions."
Source: "Yafah Sichatan" (Brooklyn 5769), Part 2, p. 25

R' Aharon Leib was a holy and awesome man, and all his words were spoken in wondrous unifications. Once he said: "When Messiah our Righteous One comes, it will become known that our family is the most beautiful and important family. And who will stand in the secret of the holy ones?"
Source: "Mipihem U'mipi Ketavam" (Kiryat Joel 5767), Part 1, p. 288

body_he: הָרַבִּי רַבִּי אֱלִימֶלֶךְ מִלִּיזֶענְסְק זי"ע הָיָה פַּעַם סַנְדָּק וְהֵבִיאוּ לוֹ כַּמָּה כָּרִים כְּדֵי לִישֵׁב עֲלֵיהֶם וְלֹא הוּטְבוּ בְּעֵינָיו, עַד שֶׁהֵבִיאוּ לוֹ הַכַּר שֶׁל רַבִּי אַרוֹן לֵייבּ אָבִיו שֶׁל הרה"ק רַבִּי מֵאִיר מִפְּרִימִישְׁלָאן זי"ע וְהוּטַב בְּעֵינָיו וְיָשַׁב עָלָיו.הרה"ק רבי מרדכי חיים מסלונים זצוק"ל"מאמר מרדכי" (ירושלים תשס"ה) ח"ג, ע' קי"ג

**Biography**
The Gaon Rabbi Binyamin Wolf Low, author of "Shaarei Torah" zt"l, was born in Wodzisław around the year 5537 (1777) to his father, the Gaon Rabbi Elazar, Av Beit Din of Santov, author of "Shemen Rokeach." He received most of his wisdom from his genius father and also studied under the Gaon Rabbi Aryeh Leib zt"l, Av Beit Din of Prostitz. He served in the rabbinate in the towns of Rospits, Amsha, Kelin, and Topolczan. In the year 5596 (1836), he ascended to serve as the glory of the famous city of Verboy. There he led a great Yeshiva, and among his disciples were the Geonim the author of "Kol Aryeh" zt"l and "Machane Chaim" zt"l. His books "Shaarei Torah" on complex topics in the Shas were printed, and many manuscripts remain to this day that have not yet seen the light of print. He passed away on Thursday, the 2nd of Adar II, in the year 5601 (1841).
Source: "Ohr Yisrael", Kislev 5756, p. 5
...Rabbi David [Deutsch], son of the "Goren David," who was head and shoulders above others in Torah and wisdom, brought the tremendous Gaon Rabbi Binyamin Wolf zt"l, author of "Shaarei Torah," from Topolczan to Verboy. The aforementioned Gaon was one of the unique greats of Hungary—and before his Torah power, greatness, and glory were recognized and revealed. A great son to his great father, the author of "Shemen Rokeach" zt"l. In the writ of appointment, the people of Verboy wrote to the author of Shaarei Torah: "Behold the sun and the moon and eleven stars bow down to him," meaning Verboy and Piestany, which then served as large and famous communities, are in the aspect of sun and moon—and eleven stars are the eleven districts—bowing to him. Indeed, with the power of his mighty Torah, this mighty Gaon led his congregation, and his words were heard afar. There in Verboy, the author of Shaarei Torah spread much Torah and fear of Heaven, and an elder sat in the Yeshiva which stood for glory, and from there Verboy went out to distances. The books "Shaarei Torah" are foundational books in understanding and scholarship, regarding strong evidence and more. Within the framework of the "Heritage of Hungarian Jewry Project" by the "Jerusalem Institute," two volumes on the Laws of Evidence appeared, and additional volumes from the author's own manuscripts are being prepared, containing his novellae on Shas and Shulchan Aruch. The author of "Shaarei Torah" was, in his first marriage, the son-in-law of our Master Rabbi Efraim Zalman Margolios zt"l of Brody.
The Gaon Rabbi David Wessely zt"l, the great Dayan of Pressburg, once told a story in praise of the author of Shaarei Torah. When the latter was a groom in the house of the Gaon Maran Rabbi Efraim Zalman zt"l of Brody—the sages of Brody honored him with a sermon in the Kloiz there. Rabbi Binyamin Wolf was still young in days, about sixteen years old. On Shabbat morning, the great father-in-law found his young son-in-law frightened and agitated from the fear of the congregation for the sermon. Our Master Rabbi Efraim Zalman appeased him by saying to him: "My son, it is possible that there is someone among the sages of Brody who knows more than you—but I am certain that there is no one who knows better than you." His explanation and way of study of the author of Shaarei Torah surpassed them all...
Source: "Verboy VeRabbaneha" (Jerusalem 5755), p. 12

body_he: ...רַבִּי דָּוִד בַּרַ"ג שֶׁהָיָה מִשִּׁכְמוֹ וּלְמַעְלָה בְּתוֹרָה וְחָכְמָה הֵבִיא מִטּוֹלְפוֹטְשְׁנִי לְוֶוערְבּוֹי אֶת הַגָּאוֹן הֶעָצוּם רַבִּי בִּנְיָמִין וָואלְף זי"ע בַּעַל "שַׁעֲרֵי תּוֹרָה". הַגָּאוֹן הַנַּ"ל הָיָה מִיחִידֵי גְּדוֹלֵי אוּנְגַרְן ־ וְטֶרֶם שֶׁהִכִּירוּ וְנִתְגַּלָּה אוֹר כֹּחַ תּוֹרָתוֹ, גְּדֻלָּתוֹ וְתִפְאַרְתּוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן הַזֶּה. בֵּן גָּדוֹל לְאָבִיו הַגָּדוֹל בַּעַל שֶׁמֶן רוֹקֵחַ זי"ע. בִּכְתַב הָרַבָּנוּת כָּתְבוּ אַנְשֵׁי וֶוערְבּוֹי לְבַעַל שַׁעֲרֵי תּוֹרָה "הִנֵּה הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ וְהַיָּרֵחַ וְאַחַד עָשָׂר כּוֹכָבִים מִשְׁתַּחֲוִים לוֹ", ר"ל וֶוערְבּוֹי וּפִישְׁטִיאַן שֶׁשִּׁמְשׁוּ אָז כִּקְהִלּוֹת גְּדוֹלוֹת וּמְפֻרְסָמוֹת הֵן בִּבְחִינוֹת שֶׁמֶשׁ וְיָרֵחַ ־ וְאַחַד עָשָׂר כּוֹכָבִים הֵן אַחַד עֶשְׂרֵה גְּלִילוֹת ־ מִשְׁתַּחֲוִים לוֹ. אָכֵן בְּכֹחַ תּוֹרָתוֹ הָעֲצוּמָה נִהֵל הַגָּאוֹן הָאַדִּיר הַזֶּה אֶת קְהַל מַרְעִיתוֹ וּדְבָרָיו נִשְׁמְעוּ לְמֵרָחוֹק. שָׁם בְּוֶוערְבּוֹי הִרְבִּיץ בַּעַל שַׁעֲרֵי תּוֹרָה הַרְבֵּה תּוֹרָה וְיִרְאָה, וְהָיָה זָקֵן שֶׁיּוֹשֵׁב בִּישִׁיבָה הָעוֹמֶדֶת לְתִפְאֶרֶת, וְשֵׁם וֶוערְבּוֹי יָצָא לְמֶרְחַקִּים. סִפְרֵי "שַׁעֲרֵי תּוֹרָה" הִינָם מִסִּפְרֵי הַיְסוֹד בַּהֲבָנָה וְלַמְדָנוּת, בְּעִנְיְנֵי עֵדוּת חֲזָקָה רֹב וְעוֹד, בְּמִסְגֶּרֶת "מִפְעַל מוֹרֶשֶׁת יַהֲדוּת הוּנְגַרְיָה" שע"י "מְכוֹן יְרוּשָׁלַיִם" הוֹפִיעוּ שְׁנֵי הַכְּרָכִים עַל הִלְכוֹת עֵדוּת, וּבַהֲכָנָה נִמְצָאִים כְּרָכִים נוֹסָפִים הַנֶּעֱרָכִים מֵעֶצֶם כת"י שֶׁל הַמְחַבֵּר, וּבָהֶם חִדּוּשָׁיו עַל הַשַּׁ"ס וְהַשּׁוּ"עַ. בַּעַל הַ"שַּׁעֲרֵי תּוֹרָה" הָיָה בְּזִוּוּג רִאשׁוֹן חֲתָנוֹ שֶׁל רַבֵּינוּ אֶפְרַיִם זַלְמָן מַרְגָּלִיּוֹת זצ"ל מִבְּרָאדִי.הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי דָּוִד וֶועסֶעלִי זצ"ל דַּיָּינָא רַבָּא דְּפְרֶסְבּוּרְג הַמְּעֻטִּירָה, סִפֵּר פַּעַם בְּשִׁבְחוֹ שֶׁל בַּעַל שַׁעֲרֵי תּוֹרָה. כְּשֶׁהָאַחֲרוֹן הָיָה חָתָן בְּבֵית הַגָּאוֹן מָרָן רַבִּי אֶפְרַיִם זַלְמָן ז"ל מִבְּרָאדִי ־ כִּבְּדוּהוּ חַכְמֵי בְּרָאדִי בִּדְרָשָׁה בַּקְלוֹיז שָׁם. רַבִּי בִּנְיָמִין וָואלְף הָיָה עוֹד צָעִיר לְיָמִים כְּבֶן שֵׁשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה. בְּשַׁבָּת בַּבֹּקֶר מָצְאוּ הַחוֹתֵן הַגָּדוֹל אֶת חֲתָנוֹ הַצָּעִיר נִבְהָל וְנִרְגָּשׁ מֵאֵימְתָא דְּצִבּוּרָא שֶׁל הַדְּרָשָׁה. פִיְּסוֹ רַבֵּינוּ אֶפְרַיִם זַלְמָן בְּאָמְרוֹ לוֹ: בְּנִי, יִתָּכֵן שֶׁיֵּשׁ בֵּין חַכְמֵי בְּרָאדִי מִישֶׁהוּ שֶׁיּוֹדֵעַ יוֹתֵר מִמְּךָ ־ אֲבָל בְּטוּחַנִי שֶׁאֵין מִישֶׁהוּ שֶׁיּוֹדֵעַ יוֹתֵר "טוֹב" מִמְּךָ, הַסְבָּרָתוֹ וְדֶרֶךְ לִמּוּדוֹ שֶׁל בַּעַל שַׁעֲרֵי תּוֹרָה עָלוּ עַל כֻּלָּם...הרב שמואל שבתי ווייס שליט"א"ווערבוי ורבניה" (ירושלים תשנ"ה) ע' י"ב
body_en:
Our Master [the "Kol Aryeh" zt"l] studied for a full year (Year 5600/1840) in the Yeshiva of Verboy. When he was about to leave the Yeshiva and return home, he was crowned with a letter of authorization and permission to teach (*Hormana* and *Heter Hora'ah*) from his great teacher, the author of Shaarei Torah, who described him with the title 'Moreh Moreinu' (Teacher of our Teachers). It happened that instead of writing "Native of Mad" (*Yelid Mad*) on it, the Gaon wrote by mistake "Av Beit Din of Mad" (*A.B.D. Mad*).
When our Master went out from his teacher's presence and looked into the letter, he noticed the error that had come from the ruler's hand. He returned to his teacher's room with a request that his teacher add his hand a second time to write and correct the mistake. However, when the Shaarei Torah saw what was written, he answered him with a smiling face: "If I have already written so, I will leave it as is and will not change it..."
Days later, when our Master was accepted as Av Beit Din of Mad, he told this in his first sermon, as a spirit of holiness that appeared in the Beit Midrash of his teacher in Verboy.
Source: "HaKol Aryeh" (Brooklyn 5767), Part 1, p. 42

...Among those agreeing to "Artzot HaChaim" [the book of the Gaon the "Malbim" zt"l] were: The "Chatam Sofer" zt"l of Pressburg, the Gaon Rabbi Binyamin Wolf zt"l, author of "Shaarei Torah" of Verboy...
In the archives of R' A. Segal Shisha from England, a copy of the book "Artzot HaChaim" from the first edition (Breslau 5597) is preserved, which the Malbim sent as a gift to the Rabbi of Verboy from Kelin with a dedication in his handwriting saying: "A gift sent to the friend of my soul, the great Gaon, the true one, the crown of Israel and its glory, the beauty of Jeshurun and its splendor, the knight of shepherds, the Prince of Torah, the Treasury of Science, N.Y. (Ner Yair - may his candle shine), P.H.H. (Peh Kadosh - holy mouth), righteous, pious and humble, like the honor of his Torah name, Binyamin Wolf, author of the book 'Shaarei Torah'. From his friend who cleaves to his love, Meir Leibush Malbim, residing here in the holy community of Kempen, the author."
Source: "BaSufah U'vaSa'arah" (Bnei Brak 5760), p. 26

Regarding the holiness of his teacher, the author of Shaarei Torah, [his student the "Kol Aryeh"] told awesome things. He was like an iron wall against anything new that is forbidden by the Torah. He related that his teacher was bitter before him that the Rabbis had become very bad, may G-d have mercy, such that they even say "Deutsch" (German sermon/modernity) over a corpse (eulogy).
Once, the head of the community (*Rosh HaKahal*) was there and was brazen to his face regarding a Chazzan whom he did not accept. The Rosh HaKahal said that a Rabbi like the author of Shaarei Torah could still be obtained and found from another place, but a Chazzan who could sing with a voice like that Chazzan was not to be found. The Shaarei Torah set his eyes upon the Rosh HaKahal, and may G-d have mercy, he fell ill with a critical illness until they had to transport him in a small wagon because he could not move his hands and feet, G-d forbid. He asked to be transported with the wagon opposite the window of the Shaarei Torah. Then he screamed: "Rebbe, forgive me!" The Shaarei Torah answered him: "Even from the lowest depths of Sheol I will not let you out."
When they told this to the Chatam Sofer zt"l, he said it is no novelty, for **רצון יראיו יעשה** - "**He fulfills the will of those who fear Him**" (Psalms 145:19). Nevertheless, those who fear G-d need to be careful that they have good will, for punishing a Tzaddik is also not good. But he [the "Shaarei Torah"] held that protecting the fence of the Torah is different.
Source: "HaKol Aryeh" (Brooklyn 5767), Part 2, p. 583

The Shaarei Torah was famous as a holy man and a wonder-worker, and everything that came out of his mouth was fulfilled. I have already told the story once that one of the *Maskilim* (Enlightened ones) entered his Beit Midrash on Yom Kippur dressed in his shoes (leather shoes, forbidden on Yom Kippur). The Shaarei Torah ordered him to leave immediately. The man was brazen and refused to leave. The Shaarei Torah said that in the coming year, he would no longer come to the Beit Midrash.
A year passed, and the Maskil appeared for the Kol Nidrei prayer, again with his shoes. They came and told the Shaarei Torah that he said he wouldn't come next year, yet here he is. The Shaarei Torah said: "There is still time." The next day, the Maskil fell down lifeless.
Several days later, close associates came and told the story to my grandfather, the Chatam Sofer zt"l. The Chatam Sofer said that it is no novelty that the Maskil died from the curse of the Shaarei Torah, for it is written: **רצון יראיו יעשה** - "**He fulfills the will of those who fear Him**" (Psalms 145:19). However, the Chatam Sofer said that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not desire that Tzaddikim should have such wishes.
But for Tzaddikim, there are different ways in this.
Source: "Chodesh BeChodsho", Adar 5767, p. 2

Once, our Master [the "Kol Aryeh" zt"l] went for a walk with his teacher [the "Shaarei Torah" zt"l]. His teacher had just finished the third part of his book *Shaarei Torah* on matters of credibility (*Ne'emanut*), one witness, etc. His teacher's opinion of it was favorable, and he said with evident satisfaction: "With this work, I will not need to be ashamed before the first ones."
Our Master, the disciple, replied to him: "May my Rebbe permit me to express my opinion. It seems to me that the first work, on matters of presumptions (*Chazakot*), is superior to it, and the right of the firstborn belongs to it."
His teacher did not agree with him and said: "It is not so with me, for in my opinion, this work surpasses its predecessors."
Years later, when our Master told this story, and he himself was already famous as a tremendous Gaon, he remarked: "But I stand by my opinion, that the first gate (*Shaar*) of the works of 'Shaarei Torah' is the most exalted."
Source: "HaKol Aryeh" (Brooklyn 5767), Part 1, p. 41

In the year 5581 (1821), our Master [the Gaon Rabbi Binyamin Wolf Low zt"l] published his first book "Shaarei Torah". From within the walls of the letters of the greats of the generation to his book, their esteem and the precious honor of our Master's Torah zt"l is evident.
The Gaon Rabbi Mordechai Banet zt"l writes in his words: "...In it is glorious wisdom, explaining in the sea of the Talmud and going out with remnants, with sharpness and proficiency and logic, like a flame bound to a coal, giving a way in the sea of the Talmud... rope by rope he ties and hair by hair he braids to the hair [of the topic], he has an arm with might, a lion in the group, joined by wise companions and his teaching is ordered, prepared and also investigated, he feeds us from the best of the best, reveals the arm and light falls..."
Also, the Gaon Rabbi Akiva Eiger zt"l writes in his words in his approbation: "...I saw and read his reading, this is his praise, his sharpness and his clarification with his straight intellect, he made the crooked straight, and behold his sayings flowed with milk and honey, pure sayings seven times refined. I saw that his hands are great in the war of Torah, fighting with a strong hand and an outstretched arm..." The Gaon Rabbi Akiva Eiger even mentions his words in "Shaarei Torah" in his glosses to Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah Siman 268.
The Gaon, author of *Chatam Sofer* zt"l, in his approbation, praises the sharpness and proficiency of our Master: "...The Rabbi, the great Gaon, the knight of knights, who has the teeth of lions and the jawbones of young lions... and I found it all beautiful, I saw no blemish in it but clear words, his hand is full of Shas and early and late Poskim, he gathered sheaves in the threshing floor, and his dough is mixed with sharpness and proficiency and gathering sayings..."
Also, the Gaon, author of "Baruch Taam", Rabbi Baruch Frankel Teomim zt"l, multiplies words of praise for our Master zt"l and his work "Shaarei Torah": "...My father-in-law, I saw that he strengthened his gates with wondrous proficiency and in every matter that came up generally and went out to be judged in a new matter, his hands were great in weighing his opinion from matter to matter in the topics of Shas and Poskim, early and late, he left almost nothing in this matter from their words that he did not bring into the crucible of his examination..."
Source: "Responsa Shaarei Torah HaChadashot" (Jerusalem 5765), p. 5

**Biography**
**Shaarei Torah**
The holy Gaon Rabbi Binyamin Wolf Low zt"l, author of *Shaarei Torah*, was the son of the holy Gaon Rabbi Eliezer Low zt"l, author of Responsa *Shemen Rokeach*. He lived in the days of our Master the Chatam Sofer zt"l. He was one of the greats of the generation in his days, and merited to be one, unique, and special in his brilliant books, in which he explains difficult topics with straight logic. Great depth can be found between the sections of his books. He merited to receive enthusiastic approbations from all the greats of the generation in those days.
First, he received from his father, the author of *Shemen Rokeach*; the holy Gaon Rabbi Mordechai Banet, Av Beit Din of Nikolsburg and Rabbi of the State; my grandfather our Master Rabbi Akiva Eiger; my grandfather our Master the Chatam Sofer; Rabbi Elazar Fleckeles, author of *Teshuva Me'Ahavah* and Dayan in Prague; Rabbi Shmuel Landau, son of the *Noda BiYehuda*; Rabbi Yaakov of Lissa, author of *Chavat Daat*; Rabbi Baruch Frankel, author of *Baruch Taam*; Rabbi Efraim Zalman Margolios, Av Beit Din of Brody; and several other Geonim.
