He also had a glorious lineage of ancestry to all the greats of the generation, descendants of the holy Gaon the Bach, the holy Gaon author of *Torat Chaim*, the holy Gaon Rabbi Heschel zt"l of Krakow, the holy Gaon author of *Magenei Shlomo*, and higher in holiness.
Source: "Chodesh BeChodsho", Adar 5767, p. 1
**Biography**
He was born in the year 5662 (1902) in Săsciori to his father, the holy Gaon Rabbi Moshe son of Amram zt"l, author of *Arugat HaBosem*. He acquired his Torah learning from his great father in Chust. Upon reaching the age of 18, he married the daughter of his uncle, the holy Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Menachem Braun zt"l, Av Beit Din of Brezivitz, and lived there near his father-in-law.
When he was 24 years old, several important communities urged him to sit on the rabbinical chair. In the year 5665 (1905), upon his great father's advice, his path in the rabbinate began in the holy community of Likov, where he served for seven years. Afterward, he was called to serve as the glory of the holy community of Tzehlem, filling the place of his great uncle, the holy Gaon Rabbi Eliezer David zt"l, author of *Keren LeDavid*. From the year 5684 (1924), he sat on the rabbinical chair in the town of Huniad until the year 5688 (1928). From 5688, he served in the rabbinate in the city and mother of Israel, the holy community of Pupa, where he spread Torah and pure fear of Heaven to thousands.
He took shelter greatly in the holy shadow of Maran the holy Rabbi Yissachar Dov of Belz zt"l. He passed away on the holy Shabbat, 2nd of Adar, 5701 (1941), and is buried in the city of Pupa. He left behind a blessing: his books *Vayaged Yaakov* on the Torah and Festivals, Responsa *Mishpatecha LeYaakov*, and other books.
Source: "Reshumim BeShimcha" (Ashdod 5766), p. 513
When my master, my father zt"l, traveled in the summer for rest, he once said to the Yeshiva students: **חשבתי דרכי ואשיבה רגלי אל עדתיך** - "**I considered my ways and turned my feet to Your testimonies**" (Psalms 119:59). "My feet" (*Raglai*) is a nickname for students, who are called children (Sifrei Va'etchanan 6:7), similar to what they said (Eruvin 70b): **ברא כרעא דאבוה** - "**A son is the leg of his father.**" And when I considered going on my ways for my own needs, beforehand "I turned my feet"—meaning my students—"to Your testimonies," to warn them about Torah study and upright conduct.
Source: "Kovetz HaHakdamot" (Brooklyn 5744), p. 16

I remembered a small remark from my master, my father zt"l, which rests in my memory from the days of my youth. Once, when I was still a young man, I looked into one of the books of Tzaddikim (I do not remember now which book it was) that speaks of the virtue of the attribute of joy, which is a great principle in the service of the Creator, blessed be He. He wrote that even in the days of distress (*Yemei HaMetzarim* - the Three Weeks), when we mourn the destruction of the Temple, we also need to be in joy (and perhaps it was written there even on Tisha B'Av). Being still a young man, I wondered about this, for I did not understand the meaning of the words.
My master, my father zt"l, passed before me and looked at the book in front of me. He grasped my thoughts regarding what I was wondering about and said to me: "Do not think that Chassidim do not fulfill what is written in the Shulchan Aruch regarding the laws of the Three Weeks. But the intention is, for example, when a Jew says in prayer the verse 'Let Israel rejoice in its Maker,' he needs to feel joy in all his limbs, and similarly whenever he says a word of holiness."
These words remained engraved in my memory to this day. This matter is known from the story that happened to the Yismach Moshe when he came to the holy Rebbe of Lublin zt"l. It was difficult for him: why are Chassidim always joyful? The holy Rebbe of Lublin grasped his thought and answered him with good reasoning (*B'tuv Taam*) according to a parable: A King was taken captive far away and stopped to rest with one of his lovers. When the lover saw him, he wept uncontrollably, yet with all this, he rejoiced that the King was lodging with him. The analogue is that the Divine Presence is, as it were, with us in exile. Understand this.
Source: "Kovetz HaHakdamot" (Brooklyn 5744), p. 16

In the introduction to the book *Vayaged Yaakov* by the holy Gaon Rabbi Yaakov Yechezkiya Greenwald of Pupa zt"l, his son, the author of *Vayechi Yosef* zt"l, brings a story that happened with his father. When he stayed at the place of the springs, on Friday night after the *Tish*, he went out in the company of some of his close ones for a walk. On their way, they reached those springs. One of them said that if they could drink from the spring water now, it would be good and upright. Since the lack of an Eruv prevented them from taking vessels for drinking, the "Vayaged Yaakov" stood and told the story brought by the holy Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik of Komarna zt"l in his book *Netiv Mitzvotecha* (Path of Unity, Path 3, Letter 1):
A story involving the Baal Shem Tov, who traveled with one of his disciples to a desolate wilderness. In the middle of the way, the disciple called out to his Rebbe that he was very thirsty and had no water in his possession. The Baal Shem Tov did not pay attention to him and said nothing. After some time, the disciple saw that his strength was failing. He cried out to his Rebbe in bitterness of soul to have mercy on him, for he had already reached a life-threatening situation.
The Baal Shem Tov asked him if he believed with perfect faith that when the Holy One, Blessed be He, created the world, He foresaw all the troubles that would occur throughout the days of the world, and already then prepared a remedy and salvation for all of them from their distress, and likewise prepared salvation for him to find water to quench his thirst? The disciple contemplated his Rebbe's words, and after some time, reached a recognition with perfect faith that he indeed believed in this. Upon seeing that he truly believed, the Baal Shem Tov promised him that he would be saved soon.
And it happened as they traveled from there, they saw a gentile carrying two jugs of water on his shoulder. He sold them water, and the disciple drank and was relieved. Afterward, the Baal Shem Tov asked the gentile for whom he was carrying the water. He replied: "Madness seized my master, who ordered me to bring him specifically water from a certain spring. I do not know if its waters are better than the waters of our village, and even I do not understand his purpose, and I have already been carrying the water for several miles."
Then the Baal Shem Tov turned to his disciple and said to him: "Now you see eye to eye that the Blessed G-d foresees and looks upon all His creatures to give them their needs. Already from the six days of Creation, it was prepared for you that at this time, the will of the landowner would be created to desire to drink specifically from the waters of the spring located far from him, and all this was to quench your thirst on the way."
When the "Vayaged Yaakov" finished telling the aforementioned story, a gentile from the local residents approached to drink from the spring waters. He even lent his vessel to the members of the group. When asked what his business was at such a late hour of the night at the springs, and if he was accustomed to this, he answered and said: "I have never done so, but just now, suddenly in the middle of the night, I desired the waters of the spring." And miraculously, the Holy One, Blessed be He, foresaw and gave counsel in the heart of that gentile to come and drink at a specific and precise hour so that his beloved children could quench their thirst.
Source: "Mipi Sefarim VeSofrim" (Bnei Brak 5768), Part 1, p. 6

One year, a strong desire awakened within me to travel to the city of Kaliv for the 7th of Adar, the day of the *Hillula* (Yahrtzeit) of the holy Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik of Kaliv zt"l, to prostrate myself on his holy grave. Since the day of the Yahrtzeit fell on Sunday, I decided to spend the preceding Shabbat with the holy Rabbi Shalom Eliezer'l of Ratzfert, may G-d avenge his blood, zt"l.
I remember entering to receive permission and a blessing for the journey from my teacher and Rabbi, the holy Gaon of Pupa zt"l. In those days, he was very weak and frail in his body. He did not sit as usual in his library but was lying helpless on his bed in the inner room of his house.
When the Rebbe heard my request, he answered with these words: "Du veist, az ich halt, az di shenste Chassidus, iz a blatt Gemara!" (You know that I hold that the most beautiful Chassidus is a page of Gemara!). [Meaning: You know my opinion is that the finest Chassidut is studying a page of Gemara!].
I understood from his words that he was not pleased with this journey. I accepted the judgment and turned my face back to leave the holy room. But as my feet stood on the threshold of the door, the Rebbe called out to me: "Ich vil nisht az talmidim zoln zogn az ich bin moneia fun Chassidus" (I do not want students to say that I prevent them from Chassidut). Therefore, go on your way in peace.
How many mighty lessons are to be heard from this. "The most beautiful Chassidus is a page of Gemara."
Source: "Reshumim BeShimcha" (Ashdod 5766), p. 290

My father's way was that when he heard a saying from a Tzaddik or something said in his name, he would innovate some matter in a verse or a saying of the Sages regarding it, adding to their words. When I was in my youth, he took me once to take shelter in the shadow of the holy Master, the Gaon Rabbi Yissachar Dov of Belz zt"l. He taught me and said to me that it is a *Segulah* (spiritual remedy) to hear words from a Tzaddik. There is no difference whether one understands what one hears, or if they are words of Torah, prayer, or liturgical poems. For words that come out in holiness have a *Segulah* to effect good action.
Source: "Kovetz HaHakdamot" (Brooklyn 5744), p. 29

A special chapter was occupied by [the Admor, author of "Vayaged Yaakov"] regarding his faith in Tzaddikim and his true Chassidut in complete self-nullification. His cleaving to the Admorim of the House of Belz zt"l and taking shelter in their shadow constitutes a special chapter in the tapestry of his life. What an impression his conversations and teachings left within him! Filled with holiness and purity upon his return from his visits to Belz, these words from every utterance he absorbed there, every good custom he saw, and the yearning for the holiness of the Tzaddikim he attained there were imprinted deep in his soul. He even changed several of his customs to match what he saw in Belz.
Correspondingly, he greatly honored other Tzaddikim and the children of holy ones. I recall the visit of the holy Admor Rabbi Shalom Eliezer Halberstam zt"l (may G-d avenge his blood) of Ratzfert, who visited Pupa on the holy Shabbat, Parashat Korach 5696 (1936), and lodged with the Chassid R' Yehoshua HaLevi Hoffman Hy"d. On Shabbat eve, when the Admor zt"l came from the Mikvah and I accompanied him, the holy Rabbi of Ratzfert entered his lodging. With what self-nullification and submission he [the Pupa Rebbe] received him! He asked him: "When will the Rebbe pray tomorrow?" The aforementioned holy Rabbi answered: "The holy Rebbe of Lublin said 9 o'clock is the time for prayer." On the holy Shabbat, the holy Admor [of Pupa] zt"l arranged a great Kiddush in honor of the guest, and he himself stood and warned about order, demonstrating his self-nullification and excessive submission in honor of the servants of G-d.
With this, he instilled in us faith in Tzaddikim and increased in us, his disciples, faith in him as well, as per his words in his holy book *Vayaged Yaakov*: **כערכך הכהן כן יהיה** - "**According to your valuation, O Priest, so shall it be**" (Leviticus 27:12). Just as you value the Tzaddik, so will be your power regarding receiving his influence. And in this conduct of his, where we saw how a great man who raised hundreds of disciples could completely nullify himself in fear of the honor of Tzaddikim, it was a lesson and a sign for us.
Source: "Sichot Kodesh" (Brooklyn 5763), p. 71

[The "Vayaged Yaakov" of Pupa zt"l] used to take shelter greatly with Maran the holy Gaon Rabbi Yissachar Dov of Belz zt"l and spoke with him about many matters. After he heard of his passing, my father demanded in the synagogue of the holy community of Huniad to deliver a great eulogy with much bitterness, like a son for his father. From then on, he would travel many times to Belz to his son, the holy Gaon Shlita (this is the holy Rabbi Aharon zt"l). Upon returning home, he recorded for himself the Torah teachings he heard from Maran Shlita. Lately, when he traveled, he did not let the young man traveling with him serve him along the way. Even regarding the ticket at the railway, he insisted on taking it himself with his own honor. His way was to be meticulous about every movement and every word of a Tzaddik.
Source: "Kovetz HaHakdamot" (Brooklyn 5744), p. 25

My friend, the Chassid R' Yisrael Meizner zt"l, who was one of the disciples of my teacher and Rabbi, the holy Gaon of Pupa, author of *Vayaged Yaakov* zt"l: When his time came to present himself to the army, being a healthy and sturdy young man, he did not know what counsel to take in his soul on how to be released from them and be saved from their hands.
What did he do? He went and came to our Rebbe and asked for his blessing for salvation and success. Our Rebbe answered him and wished him, according to his request, that he should succeed in being saved from the draft.
However, the young man Yisrael was not yet at ease with the blessing the Rebbe gave him, and his soul was not quieted. He stood and continued to ask and demand to hear an explicit "promise" coming from the Rebbe's mouth that he would not go out to the army and that nothing would happen to him, but rather he would be clean for his home.
Our Rebbe called me and whispered in my ear to go to the house of my relative, the seamstress of shrouds for the dead, and to bring from her house a piece of shroud cloth from the remnants in her possession. As commanded and done, I hastened to her house and brought the piece of shroud cloth to our Rebbe.
Our Rebbe secluded himself with the young man Yisrael in his holy room and stayed there with him alone for a certain time.
The next day, when the young man Yisrael presented himself before the draft board of the state army, suddenly his whole body broke out in red blisters, wounds, and fresh sores from the sole of his foot to his head. Needless to say, they released him on the spot, for no sick person presents himself for war.
The young man Yisrael returned and came to our Rebbe's house. He was full of those wounds and blisters. Again, he secluded himself with him for a certain time in the holy room while it was closed. When he came out of the holy room—behold, his flesh was restored, and he was completely healthy, until no trace whatsoever was recognizable of those frightening blisters that had inflamed his flesh just moments before.
Everyone asked to know what happened to him upon his arrival and departure, but our Rebbe warned him not to tell a word or half a word in anyone's ears of all that his eyes saw and all that passed over him within the walls of the room when they were closed inside. "But I," [said the narrator], "who was the messenger dealing with the matter of the shroud cloth, knew what I knew, that there is a connection between the things, and I kept the matters in my heart for a time to find."
After years passed, after our Rebbe was gathered to his people and ascended to the heights, I turned to R' Yisrael Meizner and said to him: "Now that our Rebbe's soul is bound in the bond of life and he dwells in Eden in the world that is all good, please reveal to my ear all that our Rebbe did with him when he secluded himself with him in his holy room."
R' Yisrael told me: "Our Rebbe took that piece of shroud cloth you brought from your relative and wrapped it around my fingers, and passed it over all the flesh of my body, round and round. The next day, when I presented myself before the army personnel, I had what I had, and they sent me free to my home. When I came to the Rebbe the second time, he again did for me as the first time, and passed that cloth over my whole body as in the beginning. And behold, wonder of wonders, all the plagues and wounds disappeared as if they had never been."
Source: "Reshumim BeShimcha" (Ashdod 5766), p. 303

When my master, my father zt"l, was Av Beit Din in the holy community of Tzehlem, they prayed in the synagogue with *Nusach Ashkenaz*, and likewise in the Yeshiva's Beit Midrash, from the days of the previous Rabbis there. When the students increased from towns that prayed *Nusach Sefard*, my master, my father zt"l, wanted to institute that they pray *Nusach Sefard* in the students' Beit Midrash. However, because on Shabbat and Festivals he prayed Shacharit in the students' Beit Midrash and some householders (*Baalebatim*) also prayed in his Minyan with the students, they complained about this and asked him not to change the Nusach.
He asked the advice of the holy Gaon [Rabbi Shmuel Rosenberg], Av Beit Din of Unsdorf zt"l. He answered him that although by law he is permitted to change it, since in his opinion it is a great benefit for the householders to pray with his Minyan as it will be effective for their fear of Heaven, therefore it is right not to change from the custom of before, so that the householders will not cease praying further in his Minyan.
When my master, my father zt"l, was at the spa in Luhacovice (in the country of Czechoslovakia), the holy Rebbe of Ratzfert zt"l, grandson of the *Tiferet Shlomo*, was there. Afterward, when my master, my father zt"l, happened to meet him, the aforementioned holy Gaon told his Chassidim who were with him great and wondrous things about my master, my father. He himself mentioned himself before him by his mother's name and asked him to pray for him and his household, and told his Chassidim that it was worthwhile for them to go receive a blessing from him.
Source: "Kovetz HaHakdamot" (Brooklyn 5744), p. 25

During the week, we heard his lessons (of the Admor, author of *Vayaged Yaakov* zt"l) in Gemara, Rashi, Tosafot, and Sugyot. On holy Shabbat nights, we merited his holy Tables (*Tish*). The order was: the students ate at the homes of householders, who were assigned by the Gabbaim who arranged this. After the meal, they gathered at the Beit Midrash for the conducting of the Table of our holy Rebbe.
Our Rebbe zt"l came to the meal late. According to our knowledge then, he studied Zohar HaKadosh, Midrash Rabbah, and holy books, primarily from the Baal Shem Tov zt"l. When the Rebbe arrived at the Beit Midrash and we saw his holy face aflame, in our simple eyes we saw upon him the greatness of the holiness of Shabbat, and the verse was already fulfilled in him: **באור פניך תבהיקם** - "**In the light of Your face, You make them shine**" (based on Psalm 89:16). We merited to hear from him how he receives the holy angels with "Shalom Aleichem." Everything went with great awakening. He began the prayer "Master of All Worlds" (*Ribon Kol HaOlamim*), and when he reached "To merit us to receive Shabbats," etc., they said it with a melody, and everything was with great awakening. At the end, he also said it with a melody, and the students with him.
When he reached Kiddush and the beginning of the meal, the Rebbe did not stop saying anything. We only saw his service in eating the holy Shabbat foods. After the meal, he began to sing "Kol Mekadesh Shevi'i," and everything was with a flame of fire, especially "Draw Your kindness to those who know You," etc. **באור פניך תבהיקם** - "**In the light of Your face, You make them shine.**" We felt that these prayers were on behalf of the students, that they should merit all this. After the Zemirot, the Rebbe said Torah, some of which is found in his holy book *Vayaged Yaakov*, and many times he integrated his words with the topics we learned during the week.
After Grace after Meals, they brought fruits. Then our Rebbe zt"l would tell stories and various customs of Tzaddikim. There were times when I wrote them down. In what manner he said this is impossible to record; at any rate, the words themselves were full of holiness and purity... His great merit of the holy Admor *Vayaged Yaakov* should protect us.
Source: "Sichot Kodesh" (Brooklyn 5763), p. 9

Once, a destitute poor man came before my teacher, the holy Gaon, author of Vayaged Yaakov of Pupa zt"l, in the middle of the Yom Kippur Katan prayer, asking that our Rebbe pray for his relative who was lying in his house in critical condition. My teacher, the author of Vayaged Yaakov, said to him: "In the prayer of Yom Kippur Katan, we say: 'If pushed away with the left, draw near with the right.' Behold, the left is wealth, the right is long life, as it is written: ארך ימים בימינה ובשמאלה עשר וכבוד - 'Length of days is in her right hand; in her left hand are riches and honor' (Proverbs 3:16). Since he was pushed away with the left (poverty), he should be drawn near with the right, meaning he will have long life." And so it was.
Source: "Mima'ayan HaMachane" (Bnei Brak 5764), p. 19

When my holy master, my father, resided in the holy community of Huniad, it happened that the frivolous ones gathered and arranged to hold dances called a "Ball." Knowing that my holy master, my father, would cry out against this, they did their deeds in secret so that it would not become known to him and he would not disturb them. The matter became known to him close to Shabbat, which was followed by Sunday, for which all preparations were already ready and the people had already bought entrance tickets. Even from the homes of the G-d-fearing, they prepared themselves at least to go and watch.
Then, on the holy Shabbat, he ascended before the Holy Ark and preached a great rebuke. Words as hard as sinews and words coming from the heart entered the hearts of hundreds of souls. They threw away the tickets and did not go even to watch. Those people who were not of high standing, who arranged the matter, remained in disgrace and shame.
Source: "Vayaged Yaakov" (Brooklyn 5739), Part 2, p. 34

...The greatness of the virtue of fixing times for Torah is that through this, one gains the receipt of reward even for the time one was engaged in worldly matters. But if one does not fix times for Torah, he loses much.
I heard from my holy master, my father (the "Vayaged Yaakov") zt"l, a parable regarding this matter (which he said in the name of a certain book): A Torah scholar and an ignoramus (Am Haaretz) entered for judgment and accounting in the World Above. The Torah scholar engaged most of the day in Torah and a little time in business matters. The ignoramus walked and wandered in the streets all day. Naturally, the Torah scholar entered first for judgment, and the ignoramus stood by his side and heard the accounting they made for the Torah scholar. They ruled there that for his Torah study, he deserved such and such Garden of Eden, and for engaging in livelihood, such and such Garden of Eden.
When the ignoramus observed that they apportioned reward for eating, drinking, and sleeping, he thought to himself that he need not worry about his judgment at all, for he had eaten and drunk plenty and more. When the judgment with the Torah scholar concluded, the ignoramus entered for judgment and accounting with joy and a glad heart. They ruled for him that for eating and drinking he deserved such and such Gehennom, and for sleeping such and such Gehennom, and for engaging in livelihood such and such Gehennom.
He began to scream: "Is it possible?! Is this what is called the World of Truth?! Did they not give that Torah scholar Garden of Eden for eating and drinking? Why is my inheritance diminished that they give me Gehennom? Is there favoritism in the matter?"
They answered him: "Fool of the world! That Torah scholar studied Torah all day, so automatically his eating and drinking were a preparation and qualification for the service of G-d. Therefore, he deserves Garden of Eden. Not so you, who walked in the streets all day and turned your heart to idleness, and transgressed ולא תתורו אחרי לבבכם ואחרי עיניכם - 'Do not explore after your heart and after your eyes' (Numbers 15:39). Automatically, the eating and drinking were a preparation and qualification for sins. Therefore, for this, you deserve Gehennom."
Source: "Vayaged Yaakov" (Brooklyn 5739), Part 2, p. 34

The Holy Rabbi, author of 'Imrei Chaim' of Vizhnitz zya, told in the name of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev that sometimes he would turn to a Chassid and say to him: "I took your soul out of you, I laundered it, and here I am returning it to you." Meaning, that he should keep it in purity from this day forward.
Source: MiPi Sefarim V'Sofrim (Bnei Brak 5768) Part 2, p. 192

The Holy Rabbi of Kalev interprets what we say in the Zemirot for Shabbat, in the Piyut "Ki Eshmera Shabbat" (Because I will keep Shabbat): "Al Ken Achabes Bo Libi B'Vorit" (Therefore I will wash my heart with it like soap). He was precise that it should have said "Achabes Bo Libi" (I will wash my heart with it), that *he* is the washer. And why did he say "B'Vorit" (with soap/lye)? The Holy Rabbi explains that the intention of the verse is that a person needs to wash his heart so much, until his heart becomes the soap itself which washes and whitens other things. Meaning, that his heart should be so clean that it will have the power to wash the rest of the hearts of the Children of Israel as well. And this explanation was said in books in the name of other Tzaddikim (words of Yechezkel, Parashat Devarim, in the name of Rabbi Tzvi of Rimanov). And indeed, the words are fitting for the one who said them, for the Holy Rabbi was known to have the power to wash and purify the heart of anyone who came to him. For whoever just looked at him was awakened to repentance.
And once, when he came to spend Shabbat in the city of Tokay, several light-minded youths who had thrown off the yoke [of Heaven], G-d forbid, came on Thursday before Shabbat to make fun and mock the Tzaddik. The Holy Rabbi greeted them, and they remained to sleep in his lodging on Thursday night. When they looked at the Holy Rabbi during his sleep, their hearts were greatly awakened to return in complete repentance. And they did not move from there again until they accepted upon themselves to leave their evil way. They remained to spend Shabbat in his shadow on the Holy Shabbat, and turned into G-d-fearing and whole Jews.
And with this great power, he acted to repair Judaism in the entire country of Hungary, and established religion on its mound there. He fixed matters of purity that had not succeeded for many Rabbis to fix before his arrival. For example, mixed dancing of men and women at wedding celebrations was very widespread in the country of Hungary, until he fixed in his city of Kalev and in all the surrounding districts that they would not conduct any weddings without him. And when he came to the weddings, he separated men from women there with his staff. He did not rest and was not quiet until he fixed the matter. And with this power, he succeeded in more Rabbis in the country fixing the matter in their towns.
And in every city and town where the Holy Rabbi of Kalev spent Shabbat there even once, they began to pray there in Nusach Sefard according to the custom of the Chassidim. For during his stay there for one Shabbat alone, he succeeded in inclining the hearts of the people of the city to him so much that they began to conduct themselves like him. For example, the city of Nyírmada was entirely populated by people from Oberland (Upper Province) who prayed in Nusach Ashkenaz. From the day the Holy Rabbi spent Shabbat there, they prayed even in the Great Synagogue in the city in Nusach Sefard. Thus, the Holy Rabbi merited to turn entire communities to the path of Torah and fear, according to the way of Chassidut.
Therefore, many geniuses and Tzaddikim turned to his discipline, even "Hanei D'Kadishei Minei" (those who were holy before him). There was a story with a woman in the districts of the city of Kalev who was an Agunah from her husband for several years. Witnesses testified that her husband died, but there was a question if it was possible to rely on their testimony. Several great Rabbis discussed and debated the matter, and in the end permitted her to marry. The head of the permitters was the Gaon of Mattersdorf zt"l, author of Responsa "Shemen Rokeach." But the Holy Rabbi of Kalev opposed and came out against this permission with force. One of the greats and holy ones of the generation zya who was in those days wrote a long letter to the Holy Rabbi of Kalev, that he should inform him of the reason why he opposes this permission and leaves the woman as an Agunah for nothing. And if he does not inform him of the reason for his prohibition, he will come out against him with his staff. The Holy Rabbi of Kalev did not answer a word to this, and stood by his opinion to forbid. In the end, the woman's husband came to his home alive. Then they understood retroactively the reason of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev, that he saw this with his Holy Spirit. And through this story, his name became more famous in all the countries (see Igrot Sofrim Part 2, Letter 40).
Source: Avodat Avodah (Canada 5769) Part 2, p. 173

At the end of one of the terms of study in the Yeshiva in Pupa, before I turned to travel home to our city of Kapuvar, I entered inside to the holy [room] to my teacher and Rabbi, the holy Gaon, the "Vayaged Yaakov" zt"l, to receive from him a blessing of peace and a blessing for the road. Since in those days there was great danger for any Jew to walk among the gentiles—as the uncircumcised soldiers would pick on anyone whose appearance testified that he was a Jew, and with great wickedness and cruelty would strike them with faithful blows, which not once brought about mortal danger, Heaven forbid—therefore I asked my Rabbi for advice, to know what I should do so as not to fall into their impure hands.
The Rebbe said to me with open Divine Inspiration (Ruach HaKodesh): "The train on which you will travel will have three cars, and each car has three classes. Enter the third class of the middle car, and the Good G-d will guard you and save you from all evil, and no harm will befall you!"
Source: "Petach Tov" (Brooklyn 5765), p. 276

Before the outbreak of the World War, the authorities in the country of Hungary sought to draft all the young men into the army. The draft decree also applied to many students of our holy Yeshiva in Pupa. These turned, of course, to our Rabbi, the holy Gaon "Vayaged Yaakov" zt"l, to receive a Tzaddik's blessing to be saved from the hands of the wicked and to evade the obligation of the draft.
I, too, was among them. At that gathering, I stood behind the Rebbe zt"l. Suddenly, the Rebbe turned his face to me, struck me with his holy fist, and said to me: "You too are here?! About you, I am not worried, for our Sages said (Avot 3:5): כל המקבל עליו עול תורה מעבירין ממנו עול מלכות ועול דרך ארץ - 'Anyone who accepts upon himself the yoke of Torah, the yoke of government and the yoke of worldly cares are removed from him!'"
And in every period that the matter rises in my memory, I feel the blow of the fist I received then from his holy hands.
Source: "Reshumim BeShimcha" (Ashdod 5766), p. 294

The Admor (the "Vayaged Yaakov" zt"l) was soft as a reed, overflowing with love and affection for every man, and forgiving beyond compare. Yet with all this, he was courageous in his method and unbending as a cedar in his conduct. During the time of decrees, people were awakened to travel from their places to hide from the wrath. The matter was impossible to execute in an organized manner; only individuals succeeded in it. Our Rabbi zt"l feared that these individuals would be lost in their wandering and assimilated in their places of dispersion. He came out to preach against this firmly, interpreting the verse (Exodus 14:13): התיצבו וראו את ישועת ה - "Stand firm and see the salvation of the L-rd."
He held onto this method despite the physical danger involved. The spiritual weight decided for him, as per the words of the holy Ohr HaChaim on the portion of Vayigash regarding the verse (Genesis 46:30): ויאמר ישראל אל יוסף אמותה הפעם אחרי ראותי את פניך - "And Israel said to Joseph: 'Now let me die, since I have seen your face.'" And he writes: "It is a known thing that Tzaddikim desire the absence of the son more than his being wicked," see there.
Source: "Sichot Kodesh" (Brooklyn 5763), p. 71

One of the wondrous attributes we saw in my master, my father (the "Vayaged Yaakov" zt"l), was that he guarded himself from anger. Once, while opening and closing a small snuff box in his hand, he told a story about the holy Rabbi of Ropshitz zt"l. He had a small silver snuff box, but they never saw him smell from it; he only opened it and closed it. They asked him what the box served if he didn't smell from it. He answered that many times a matter occurs for which he wants to get angry. Then he opens the box and places the matter inside and closes it, keeping it well inside for an hour or two. Afterward, when his wrath has subsided, he opens the box, looks, and contemplates the matter he placed inside—whether it is worth getting angry over.
I remember further in the holy community of Tzehlem, it happened once on Motzaei Shabbat during Havdalah. As the students were pushing themselves towards him, due to the pushing, the cup of Havdalah spilled from his hand, and also the hat of his Shtreimel was scorched by the Havdalah torch. They were very frightened, but he zt"l, instead of getting angry at them, made a joke about it.
A student who served him told that once, by mistake, he didn't see that our Rabbi zt"l was holding his hand in the place where the door closes. He opened the door and it struck his hand until his skin was wounded deeply and blood flowed. He did not get angry, but only said: "You see, I don't need so much honor" (for opening the door was for his honor so he wouldn't have to trouble himself). The next day, the student came with a broken spirit to ask forgiveness so he wouldn't bear a grudge against him. He answered him with humor: "On the contrary, behold our Sages said: אין אדם נוקף אצבעו מלמטה אלא אם כן מכריזין עליו מלמעלה - 'A person does not bruise his finger below unless it is proclaimed against him Above' (Chullin 7b). If not for this, they don't speak of me so much Above, but because of your hand, they spoke of me Above."
Once on a holy Shabbat before prayer, when he wanted to go pray, he did not find his Tallis. They searched for it and did not find it. A tumult arose that it was surely stolen. The holy Admor zt"l sat quietly, and no anger was recognizable on him at all, even though it was late to go pray. He said that it would surely be found. Afterward, the Tallis was found, and he went to pray. When he reached the door of his room, he stood and said: "Apparently, I would have needed to go to the Mikvah again to immerse because I was angry. But at least I will wash my hands in cleanliness." He returned to his room, washed his hands, and went to pray.
Source: "Tzeidah LaDerech" (Brooklyn 5769), p. 17

Once in difficult times, when there were many poor people in the city because the householders were called to forced labor (Angaria), my master, my father called a gathering for all the members of his community to establish support for the families of the poor. He ordered the Tur (Code of Law) on the Laws of Charity to be brought before him. He studied the Tur before the householders simply and nothing more. These words caused a great awakening in the hearts of the listeners until each and every one took upon himself to give a large sum. It was a great novelty.
Source: "Vayaged Yaakov" (Brooklyn 5739), Part 2, p. 29

In Hungary, they brought Etrogim from Greece, and they were very beautiful. I remember that one young man from the disciples of our Rabbi, the "Vayaged Yaakov" zt"l, brought a beautiful and majestic Etrog from Pest. The holy "Vayaged Yaakov" was very happy and gave him his belt (Avnet) as a gift. When he handed it to him, he said: "You know that the reason for a belt is so that his heart should not see the nakedness (Ervah). There is a great hint in this, for we find the word 'sees' (Ro'eh) regarding the opinion of existence for a certain thing [as in רואה אני את דברי אדמון - 'I see the words of Admon' (Ketubot 108b)]. Therefore, one must be careful that a person's heart should be in holiness and not, Heaven forbid, contemplate matters of nakedness and the like."
Source: "Sichot Kodesh" (Brooklyn 5763), p. 75

It is known that my holy grandfather left in his will: "That until ten generations, anyone who comes from his descendants to the marker of his grave, they should let them enter without disturbing them."
Source: Kol Menachem (Jerusalem 5765) Mo'adim, p. 355

A wondrous event occurred once in the Sukkah of my master, my father zt"l, in the holy community of Pupa. At a time when the enemies of Israel had already increased in the land and the fear of the wicked was cast upon our brethren, the Children of Israel, it happened that a group of wicked uncircumcised ones wanted to carry out pogroms and destruction on the night of the Sukkot festival in the Sukkah of my master, my father zt"l.
And it was, when they opened the door of the Sukkah to enter, they were terrified and hurried and fled immediately and ran away without a pursuer. The next day, they themselves told others that when they opened the door, they suddenly saw a great light which they could not bear, and they became confused and terrified and fled. So my mother, the righteous Rebbetzin zt"l, told me.
Source: "Vayaged Yaakov" (Brooklyn 5739), Introduction

She also told that when the wicked government, known as Nazi Germany, conquered the state of Austria, and my uncle, the Gaon and Av Beit Din of Tzehlem zt"l, was in exile in Vienna, my master, my father zt"l traveled from Hungary to Austria to the city of Vienna to see him. The journey was fraught with great danger for anyone of his stature, for the wicked ones there were accustomed to beating and tormenting without mercy anyone who was a Jew. All the friends begged my master, my father, and screamed at him not to go, but he did not listen to their voices.
And it was a miracle, for the verse was fulfilled in him: וראו כל עמי הארץ כי שם ה' נקרא עליך ויראו ממך - "And all the peoples of the earth shall see that the name of the L-rd is called upon you, and they shall be afraid of you" (Deuteronomy 28:10). For even the search that was customary to perform on everyone crossing the border, they did not do to him, and they were afraid to touch him.
Source: "Vayaged Yaakov" (Brooklyn 5739), Introduction, p. 17

Our holy Rebbe (the Admor of Bobov) Shlita told what he heard from a certain man when he went to comfort him upon the passing of his father, who toiled all his days with great exertion to bring prey to his household and conducted himself in his home with poverty and frugality.
...And it was one day, one of his acquaintances offered him a business deal that was forbidden according to the law of the land, but he stood to gain a large and respectable sum from it. Indeed, he refused the offer with all firmness, even though his children had already reached marriageable age and he did not have the necessary money to marry them off.
The man turned to his son and said: "Behold, you know that I studied thirteen 'terms' (Zmanim) with the holy Rabbi, the Baal Vayaged Yaakov of Pupa zt"l. And behold, if, Heaven forbid, it were revealed in public that I engaged in sour business, can you imagine what shame and disgrace I would cause to the revered and holy name of my Rebbe? For they would say, 'Look what kind of students he raised.' Therefore, I am ready to live a life of sorrow, for the main thing for me is that no disgrace should come out regarding my Rebbe."
Source: "Pri HaKerem", Menachem-Av 5765, p. 4

body_he: ...וַיְהִי הַיּוֹם הִצִּיעַ לוֹ אֶחָד מִידִידָיו מִסְחָר שֶׁהָיְתָה אֲסוּרָה לְפִי חֹק הַמְּדִינָה, אַךְ הָי' עוֹמֵד לְהַרְוִיחַ עַל יָדָהּ סְכוּם גָּדוֹל וְנִכְבָּד. אָמְנָם סֵרֵב בְּכָל תֹּקֶף לְקַבֵּל אֶת הַהַצָּעָה, עַל אַף שֶׁכְּבָר הִגִּיעוּ בָּנָיו לְפִרְקָם וְלֹא הָי' לוֹ הַכֶּסֶף הַנִּדְרָשׁ לְהַשִּׂיאָם. פָּנָה הָאִישׁ לִבְנוֹ וְאָמַר, "הֲרֵי יָדוּעַ לְךָ שֶׁלָּמַדְתִּי שְׁלֹשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה 'זְמַנִּים' אֵצֶל רַבִּי הַק' בַּעַל וַיַּגֵּד יַעֲקֹב מִפָּאפָּא זצ"ל. וְהִנֵּה אִם ח"ו יִתְגַּלֶּה בָּרַבִּים שֶׁעָסַקְתִּי בַּמִּסְחָר הֶחָמוּץ הַזֶּה, הַאִם אֶפְשָׁר לְשַׁעֵר אֵיזֶה בּוּשָׁה וּכְלִימָה שֶׁאֶגְרֹם בָּזֶה לִשְׁמוֹ הַנֶּעֱרָץ וְהַנִּקְדָּשׁ שֶׁל רַבִּי, כִּי יֹאמְרוּ הַבְּרִיּוֹת רְאוּ אֵיזֶה גִּדּוּלִים גִּדֵּל. עַל כֵּן הִנְנִי מוּכָן לִחְיוֹת חַיֵּי צַעַר, כִּי הָעִקָּר אֶצְלִי הוּא שֶׁלֹּא יֵצֵא עַל יְדֵי בִּזָּיוֹן לְרַבִּי"."פרי הכרם", מנחם-אב תשס"ה, עמ' ד'
body_en:
ושמעו אמרי כי נעמו, כמו פולח ובוקע בארץ - "They shall hear my words, for they are sweet; As when one cleaves and breaks up the earth" (Psalms 141:6-7).
I heard from my teacher and Rabbi, the holy Gaon of Pupa, author of Vayaged Yaakov zt"l, in a Shabbat HaGadol sermon, interpreting the connection of the verses in a witty manner: When people go to hear words of ethics (Musar) and awakening, and the intention of the listeners is only to enjoy a pleasant sermon, they turn all the effort of the preacher into vanity. The matter is like a woodchopper who needs to strike with the axe upon the tree to cut it, but in the end, he misses the tree and strikes and cleaves the earth, and it is useless.
This is what King David, peace be upon him, said: "They shall hear my words, for they are sweet" - if they come to hear my words only because of the pleasantness in them, then my work is compared to "As when one cleaves and breaks up the earth," which misses the main action as mentioned. The main thing is the words of guidance, ethics, and awakening.
Source: "Reshumim BeShimcha" (Ashdod 5766), p. 305

And I will fill their treasuries.
I heard from my teacher and Rabbi, the Baal Vayaged Yaakov zt"l, in the explanation of the Mishna in Tractate Uktzin (3:12): "The Holy One, Blessed be He, is destined to inherit to every righteous person 310 worlds, as it is said: להנחיל אהבי יש ואצרתיהם אמלא - 'To cause those who love Me to inherit substance (Yesh), and I will fill their treasuries' (Proverbs 8:21)."
For in this world, it will not be like in the World to Come where one wants to attain double and more. For truly, the essence of thirst [in this world] is given in this world so that one may desire more and more spirituality. But there [in the World to Come], "I will fill their treasuries," and they will not desire more.
Source: "Torat Ish" (Bnei Brak 5765), Part 1, p. 59

His Friend
He was in doubt whether a student fulfills the obligation of Mishloach Manot (sending portions on Purim) by sending to his Rabbi, since it is written: ומשלוח מנות איש לרעהו - "and sending portions one man to his friend" (Esther 9:19), etc.
In my humble opinion, this too is by way of jest. Touch upon yourself regarding that which is written: כי יגח שור איש את שור רעהו - "If a man's ox gores his neighbor's ox" (Exodus 21:35). Would we say that if a student's ox gored his Rabbi's ox, he would be exempt from paying, as we interpret "an ox of his friend (Re'ehu) and not an ox of Hekdesh (consecrated property)"? Also, regarding that which is written: ואהבת לרעך כמוך - "You shall love your neighbor as yourself" (Leviticus 19:18), would we say that this does not apply to a Rabbi and student? Rather, certainly, all of Israel is included in "his friend."
And I heard in the name of a certain Sage who was asked if one sends portions to an enemy, since it is written "a man to his friend." He answered him with an explicit verse written: וכי יהיה איש שנא לרעהו - "But if any man hates his neighbor" (Deuteronomy 19:11). At any rate, it is simple that all of Israel are generally "his friend"...
Source: "Choshen V'Ephod" - Hamodia, 26 Shevat 5759, p. 18

Setting Times for Torah
In the name of my teacher, the Baal Vayaged Yaakov zt"l, who said regarding those who set times for Torah: Even though this is negligible in the majority [of the day], nevertheless, the rule is established (Yoma 84b): כל קבוע כמחצה על מחצה דמי - "Anything fixed is considered as half and half." And on occasion, our Rabbi added: If so, one who fixes two hours is found to have studied the whole day—the two halves...
Source: "Ma'ayanot Ish", Menachem-Av 5764, p. 40

The Holy Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik of Kalev zya had a son named Meir. After the passing of his holy father, the Evil Inclination succeeded in trapping him in his net, and he joined a group of loafers and reckless people who spent their time playing cards in the tavern in their vicinity. The Holy Chevra Kadisha of his holy father spoke to his heart that he should return and sever his ties with these reckless people, since his source is from a holy quarry, and it is a shame for him to do these evil deeds. But it was in vain. The students decided to plead at the holy marker of their Rabbi that his son should return to the good path.
That night, the Holy Rabbi appeared to his son in a dream and said to him: "Know, my son, that I came to you now from my resting place in the Garden of Eden. I will not let you continue your daily order until you accept upon yourself to sever your ties with that group of loafers and return to the good path to join my students." In the morning, Meir woke up from his sleep completely confused, and did not know what to do in his soul, and remained silent in his house.
A few hours passed. His friends in the tavern noticed that he had not arrived as was his custom every day. Some of them turned aside to his house in order to inquire of his welfare. When they arrived, Meir clarified to them that he could no longer be in their company because his father z"l had commanded him so in a dream, and instructed him to improve his ways from now on.
His friends laughed and said: "Meir, you were never a man of intelligence. What has happened to you now? Do you believe in dreams? Do not set your heart to them and come with us now as is your custom every day." Meir accepted their words and joined them. In the card game, his friends cheated so that he would earn a lot of capital, so that he would want to remain in their company in the future. And indeed, when he returned to his home, he reflected to himself: "Behold, I earned much money through them; surely my company with them is good for me."
That night, his holy father appeared to him again and rebuked him: "Meir, yesterday you did not accept my words and returned to your stubbornness. Therefore, I troubled myself again to descend from my place in the Garden of Eden to this lowly world, despite the difficulty involved in this. My son, do not go on the way with them, withhold your foot from their path. Know that I will not let go of you until you accept my words and return in complete repentance."
The next day, the friends noticed that Meir was absent again from their company, and they understood that the dream still frightened him. They decided to visit his home all together this time. When they arrived, he told them that his father returned and revealed himself to him and warned him strongly to return in repentance, and if not, he would take his soul from him. His friends returned and laughed at him as on the previous day. Indeed, this time they did not succeed in convincing him with their laughter, and he did not want to join them anymore. His friends grabbed him by force and forced him to go with them, and so he spent time in their company on this day as well.
On the third night, his father appeared to him again and said: "This time I will go further and engrave a sign upon you that will leave its impression forever, and will remind you that I was indeed with you and warned you. You will say no more that dreams speak falsely." Inside his house stood a large iron stove of great weight, which even five men could not lift. The Holy Rabbi took this stove with his hands and cast it upon his son, breaking his leg, and said: "Now you will not be able to walk on your leg, and this will be a sign for you that the dream is true. Return from your perverse deeds."
When his friends returned on the third day and heard from his mouth the events of the night, and even saw his broken leg, they were very frightened and fled for their lives in great fear.
This Meir returned in complete repentance and joined the students of his holy father, and became a Chassid and servant of G-d like them. Many others were awakened and returned in repentance upon hearing that the Holy Rabbi of Kalev acted with tangible actions in a dream.
Source: Binyan Shlomo, Adar 5765, p. 7

Healing of the Soul
Regarding the custom of Chassidim and men of action to immerse before prayer even during the nine days [of Av] from Rosh Chodesh Av, my master, my father wrote in a responsum that this is not against Halacha. As explained in the Poskim (Shaarei Teshuva Siman 551), for health needs, it is permitted to wash, and the healing of the soul is no less than the healing of the body. Immersion for the healing of the soul, since one does not intend for pleasure, is permitted.
When Maran the Maharid of Belz zt"l was at the spa in Marienbad, my master, my father zt"l also traveled there. Maran of Belz zt"l asked him if he came for healing, and my master, my father answered: "For the healing of the soul and the healing of the body."
Source: "Vayaged Yaakov" (Brooklyn 5740), Introduction, p. 24

Biography
The righteous Rabbi Yisrael Zalman, son of Rabbi Avraham HaLevi Szalay-Wobski zt"l. In his youth, he became close to Maran the author of Yesod HaAvodah zt"l and cleaved to him with all his soul. Afterward, he was the attendant (Mashbak) and faithful man of his grandson, Maran the Admor Moharash [the "Divrei Shmuel"] zt"l, and his son after him, Maran the Admor Mohara (the "Beit Avraham") zt"l, who cherished him greatly.
In his old age, he ascended to the Holy Land and established his residence in the holy city of Jerusalem. He lived in the neighborhood of Maran the Ramach (Rabbi Mordechai Chaim of Slonim) zt"l, who also cherished and admired him with extraordinary esteem. He even established several study sessions with him during the day on the holy Zohar and more. He testified about him that he possessed the Image of G-d in perfection.
He passed away on the night of the holy Shabbat, 2nd of Adar II, 5708 (1948), and is buried on the Mount of Olives.
Source: "Mizkenim Etbonan" (Jerusalem 5767), Part 2, p. 302

I heard from Rabbi Yisrael Zalman zt"l that his father, the Chassid Rabbi Avraham zt"l, was a Chassid of Koidanov, and he was G-d-fearing and whole. Being a merchant, his way was to travel with several other merchants to Poltava in Russia, which was a metropolis for merchandise. Everyone would buy the merchandise he dealt with for his trade, and they would return and sell them in their places.
The other merchants who traveled with him, when they returned, would lodge every night at an inn and eat from what was served before them. Similarly, upon arriving on the holy Shabbat, they would rest at an inn on the main road and eat the Shabbat meals served by the innkeepers.
This journey lasted several weeks. However, Rabbi Avraham, the father of R' Yisrael Zalman, due to his concern regarding the Kashrut of the food, would eat only dry bread and salty fish that he brought with him from his home for the entire duration of the journey, and even on Shabbat. The other merchants traveling with him always thought he was a miser—a 'karger'—saving food from his mouth to avoid paying for good meals at inns.
On one of the journeys, when they were already on their way back with a wagon full of merchandise and their hearts were good with the merchandise that G-d had brought to their hands, when the holy Shabbat arrived, they decided that this time they would pay for Rabbi Avraham'l to eat the Shabbat meals with them. However, when they proposed this to him, he rejected them with both hands and refused to eat what was served to them at the inn.
On Shabbat morning, when the innkeeper served the Cholent, they saw that inside the stew was an old kishke stuffed with cheese. The merchants were stunned and asked him how he cooked such a thing, for this is meat and milk, Heaven forbid. The innkeeper, who appeared to be a kosher Jew in every respect, answered them that he was from the 'Karaites' who fulfill only what is written in the Torah simply—that it is forbidden to cook only a kid in its mother's milk, but ordinary meat and milk are permitted to cook, Heaven forbid.
And the merchants said: 'Avraham'l is not a karger'... [He is not a miser, not because he spares his money does he not eat at inns on the crossroads, but because he knows that it is possible to stumble in severe Torah prohibitions].
Source: "Mizkenim Etbonan" (Jerusalem 5767), Part 2, p. 303

When Maran the Admor Moharash [the "Divrei Shmuel"] zt"l asked Rabbi Yisrael Zalman to serve as his Gabbai, he said to him: "The world says that a Gabbai is not a Chassid, so is it right that I should become a Gabbai?" [For why should I be a Gabbai?]
The Maharash answered him: "I promise you that you will be an even greater Chassid."
And so it was. Not only did the position of Gabbai not blemish his Chassidut, but on the contrary, through it, the height of his majesty, holiness, and righteousness became known, and he became bound to him with all the days of his soul.
It was not for nothing that the Rebbe desired him to serve as Gabbai, for indeed he was a man of noble character traits and goodness of heart that were exceptional.
And so the Rebbe once expressed about him: "Rabbi Yisrael Zalman obligates attendants!"
Source: "Mizkenim Etbonan" (Jerusalem 5767), Part 2, p. 304

It is known that Maran the Admor the Maharash [the "Divrei Shmuel"] zt"l suffered greatly from diabetes, and due to the illness, he had severe sores on his legs. Rabbi Yisrael Zalman would change the bandages periodically. Once, R' Yisrael Zalman was not in his vicinity, and he needed to change the bandage. He asked his son, Maran the Admor the "Beit Avraham," to kindly change the bandage.
When he saw the sores, he groaned from great pain and could not bandage the dressing properly. The Divrei Shmuel answered him: "Where is Rabbi Yisrael Zalman?" The Beit Avraham said to him: "Why do you need him always? Is it impossible to manage without him?" He answered him: "If you search the whole world, will you find such a Yisrael Zalman?" [If they search the entire world, is there a man like Rabbi Yisrael Zalman to be found?]
[The Chassid Rabbi Yisrael Shimon Kastelnitz zt"l added that what was most amazing about him was that the R' Yisrael Zalman would tell this story himself, and it seemed as if he was speaking about someone else and not himself; so without any pride and without any excitement did he tell it.]
Source: "Mizkenim Etbonan" (Jerusalem 5767), Part 2, p. 306

After the passing of the holy Admor Mohara [the "Beit Avraham"] zt"l from Baranovich, Rabbi Yisrael Zalman entered to the Admor Moharash'd (Rabbi Shlomo David) zt"l and said: "Whether to travel to the Holy Land or not—I do not ask, for the Rebbe zt"l already commanded me to do so. But my question is whether I must travel immediately or if I can still stay here." Moharash'd answered him that in the meantime, he could stay in Baranovich.
Until once, the holy Admor Moharash'd zt"l needed to travel to a certain place and asked R' Yisrael Zalman to continue his established practice of serving the Tzaddikim even now, and prepared to pack his belongings into the suitcase. But the Rebbe refused the service of an old man like him and insisted that he pack his belongings into the suitcase himself, and R' Yisrael Zalman did not agree to this in any way. Until the Rebbe answered and said: "I see I have no choice but to send you to the Land of Israel..." R' Yisrael Zalman answered: "Ya, dos ya!" (Yes, to this I agree...).
R' Yisrael Zalman ascended here in his old age, a few years before the outbreak of the World War, leaving behind abroad his entire extensive family, which included sons, sons-in-law, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. With the outbreak of the terrible war, as the destroyer ascended upon the majority of the Jewish communities in the European exile on the day of G-d's wrath, his extensive family perished among them. R' Yisrael Zalman numbered about seventy souls of his descendants who all ascended on the altar, except for one single survivor—his grandson, the Chassid R' Eliyahu Binyamin Tennenhaus zt"l.
Much is told about the strength of spirit of R' Yisrael Zalman, who with superhuman strength strove to accept the judgment of Heaven upon himself with love, without allowing even a trace of complaint or grievance against Heaven, G-d forbid, to enter his heart.
A prolonged period passed until he merited to see his aforementioned grandson again, who arrived here alone, solitary and lonely from his entire family, among them the members of his household and his children who were separated from him on their way to death. It goes without saying that one cannot describe R' Yisrael Zalman's emotion upon meeting his only grandson, a lonely survivor from his entire extensive family, who hastened to announce his imminent arrival.
When he arrived, R' Yisrael Zalman stood in the middle of the Maariv prayer—during the blessings of Shema. Naturally, they hurried immediately to announce to R' Yisrael Zalman the news of the grandson's arrival, but R' Yisrael Zalman refused to stop in order to greet the grandson until he finished his prayer!
Here, R' Eliyahu zt"l built his house again, and at the turn of the year, a first son was born to them. This was on Tisha B'Av, and naturally, they hurried immediately to announce the good news to R' Yisrael Zalman.
R' Yisrael Zalman did not hesitate, and in the midst of the Kinot of Tisha B'Av, he jumped on the table like a young lad and blessed in a loud voice and with immense joy the blessing of 'Shehecheyanu' with G-d's Name and Kingship, to thank G-d for His good kindness.
Source: "Shivcho Shel Aharon" (Jerusalem 5769), p. 131

The remnants of that generation used to depict the features of R' Yisrael Zalman as a natural chunk of the landscape in the Shtiebel and at the Tables (Tish), indispensable. He is a kind of "Chazzan of the Assembly" without whom no prayer or song begins.
The Rebbe is not willing for R' Yisrael Zalman to serve him. "A vessel my father used..." he says, but R' Yisrael Zalman is his right hand and his ambassador in all the Shtiebels to disperse them. He is the one who brings out and brings in every public matter and private affairs. He collects money for Eretz Yisrael for the Rebbe, and also worries about the Rebbe's household expenses.
When the tragedy happened and the "Beit Avraham" zt"l passed away in the prime of his days, while he was in the city of Slonim, Rosh Chodesh Iyar 5693 (1933), the voice of R' Yisrael Zalman was heard during the purification (Taharah) reading with emotion the verses of Song of Songs: ראשו כתם פז - "His head is as the most fine gold" (5:11), ידיו גלילי זהב - "His hands are as rods of gold" (5:14). Hearts melted like water when they brought the holy Ark into the Beit Midrash and he stood and lamented over him the bitter lament "Men of faith are lost."
And at the end, when a Torah Scroll was buried, R' Yisrael Zalman did this with tears. When he held the holy body and engaged in his honor, he sobbed with terrible brokenness and said to his soul: "I am not capable... I am not... Did I not carry him in my arms when he was a baby..." Also when they put a little earth of Eretz Yisrael on him and the time came to close the grave, he burst out again in a bitter sigh and said to his heart: "I am not capable... I cannot... I am not... How can we cover with earth this beauty, whose appearance shines like the splendor of the face of the King..."
However, immediately after the closing of the grave, he put on a new face and girded himself with strength to strengthen broken hearts (and upon their return from the ancient cemetery in the city of Slonim, where the portion of the lawgiver is hidden, he stood and distributed "L'Chaim" to the Chassidim as is customary) and to unite the congregation and the holy society as those engaged in the mission of the holy Rebbe. Or-then he turned to all the Shtiebels with special letters containing words of comfort and practical matters to preserve the holy legacy, and to unite around the only son of the "Beit Avraham" zt"l—the young Admor, the Maharash'd Hy"d—whom he cherished like the apple of his eye.
In his connection to the young Admor, Rabbi Yisrael Zalman rose to the peak of spiritual heights. When the new Rebbe was crowned young in days, 21 years old, nevertheless, the elderly Chassid who managed to take shelter in the shadow of the grandfather of his grandfather (the author of Yesod HaAvodah) demonstrated complete self-nullification and conducted himself with him as a Chassid to his Rebbe in every matter.
The Rebbe, as is known, struggled terribly in his refusal to take upon himself the role of leadership, but R' Yisrael Zalman, with wisdom and intelligence, stood by his right hand in his first steps at the time of conducting the "Tables" and the like, to ease him in several open and hidden matters.
Even when he ascended afterward to the Land of Israel, he did not cease to take interest in what was happening in the presence of the young Admor, and his friends from Baranovich wrote to him periodically words of Torah they merited to hear from his holy mouth.
But not only this: Behold, the tribulations of the war of extermination by the Nazis, may their names be blotted out, approached and came upon the people of Israel. In this terrible Holocaust, more than fifty of his descendants perished for the Sanctification of the Name: sons and daughters, sons-in-law and daughters-in-law, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Only one single one of them (R' Eliyahu Binyamin Tennenhaus, may he be remembered for good) survived.
And it was, when the bad news reached the ears of R' Yisrael Zalman sitting in Jerusalem, the Tzaddik accepted upon himself the judgment of Heaven with love. He did not let even a slight sound escape his mouth, until... he was also told about the killing of the holy Admor Rabbi Shlomo David Yehoshua zt"l by the Nazis—at that moment a bitter sigh was torn from his heart: "Woe is me, the Rebbe too!" Even in the coming days, he refused to be comforted after him, saying that the tragedy of the killing of the holy Rebbe wounded his heart even more than his personal tragedy in the killing of dozens of his descendants! This wondrous connection between a Chassid and his Rebbe is sublimely beyond human grasp.
Before this, when the people of our community in Jerusalem undertook various actions in an attempt to save the Rebbe Hy"d, R' Yisrael Zalman arrived and asked to donate a very large sum of money for this need—beyond his means. The Chassidim who knew his situation refused to take it from him, but he stood firm on his wish, and finally they "compromised" with him to take only half, with a promise that if it turned out the money was not needed, they would return it to him. Typical of R' Yisrael Zalman is what he wrote then to a groom among his relatives on the day of his wedding, that he would remember him for good that... he might yet merit to hear good news from the Admor Shlita and the rest of our community, without placing any emphasis whatsoever on his own descendants and family members.
In the book Toldot Aharon (Masechet Chayei the Gaon Rabbi Aharon'le Roth zt"l of Beregsaz, author of Shomrei Emunim), Chapter 14, the words of this Tzaddik are brought, writing about Rabbi Yisrael Zalman zt"l in this language: "Some time ago, an elderly Jew, a holy man who still merited to serve the earlier Tzaddikim, entered my presence. His heart was bitter within him, for he had sixty descendants, all beloved and clear, and the rumor arrived that they were all killed for the Sanctification of G-d's Name in the Holocaust. I answered him with emotion: 'You should rejoice that you merited to sacrifice before Him, blessed be His Name, so many precious sacrifices, a thing our fathers and our fathers' fathers did not merit.' Since the old man heard these words, he began to weep from great joy and gladness, and hot tears flowed from his eyes, and he went out from my presence with great strengthening..."
Source: "BaSufah U'vaSa'arah" (Bnei Brak 5760), p. 26

Rabbi Yisrael Zalman ascended to the Land of Israel in his old age. The matter was in the winter of 5696 (1936). On Motzaei Shabbat after Chanukah, his son-in-law R' Yehoshua Kaiziel Hy"d arranged a great Melaveh Malkah meal in his honor, as a farewell party, in which the "Younger Rebbe" participated with a large group of Chassidim. The survivor who was present at that party related that great emotion was evident on the Rebbe regarding the journey of R' Yisrael Zalman.
It is told by the Chassidim that the "Beit Avraham" was the one who urged R' Yisrael Zalman to ascend to Jerusalem, and during his last visit to the Land of Israel in the year 5693 (1933), he told the Chassidim that he would send R' Yisrael Zalman to Jerusalem as a "reinforcement" for the renewed Shtiebel. In a letter to the people of our community in Jerusalem sent by the Admor Moharash'd for Pesach, after R' Yisrael Zalman had settled among them, he wrote: "You will be able to receive much from him, for he served Torah scholars much, and service is greater than study, and והוי מתאבק בעפר רגליהם - 'dust yourself in the dust of their feet' (Avot 1:4) is written, and this was certainly..."
Together with him ascended his righteous wife Zlata a"h, and they spent the remainder of their days in a Jerusalem apartment provided for their use by the philanthropist R' Yosef Weinberg a"h, from the Chassidim of Slonim, adjacent to the holy Rabbi Mordechai Chaim of Slonim zt"l, head of the community in the Land of Israel, who admired him greatly and praised him excessively, saying of him that he has the "Image of G-d" in perfection.
When they once asked on Lag BaOmer from R' Mottel (Mordechai Chaim) to pass before the Ark (lead the prayers), he said: "Better you send R' Yisrael Zalman, G-d loves him much more than me!" Even when the two of them turned in a special letter of strengthening to the community after the terrible news of the killing of the Admor Hy"d, the Ramach (R' Mottel) insisted that they publish R' Yisrael Zalman's signature before his signature for this reason. And when they came to ask him for a blessing for salvation, he would say: "Go to R' Yisrael Zalman that he should ask for you, because he is a 'simple' (Tamim) Jew (who fulfills in his soul תמים תהיה עם ה' אלקיך - 'You shall be wholehearted with the L-rd your G-d' - Deut 18:13), and 'with a simple one, Heaven does not play games' (un a tamim zagt men fun himmel nit op)."
Close to his dwelling, the Shtiebel of Slonim Chassidim in Jerusalem was established, and Rabbi Yisrael Zalman, despite his advanced age, was the living spirit among the group. His eye did not dim nor did his vigor abate. In that place, the Yeshiva "Beit Avraham" was founded in the year 5702 (1942), and he supported it in our days.
As one for whom Slonimer Chassidut was the essence of his entire life's existence, R' Yisrael Zalman found no comfort after the Holocaust except in the building of Slonimer Chassidut, as he wrote in those days in a letter to the community: "In this bitter hour when my heart is broken and torn to shreds from all that has passed over us due to our many sins, that all the holy and dear was taken from us into exile and we remain few from many, I have nothing to comfort myself with and to restore my aching and wounded soul except with the voice of Torah that bursts forth and rises to me from the lovely young men of our holy Yeshiva Beit Avraham, dear young men upon whom the fear of G-d hovers, who could be a model in the time of Maran the Yesod HaAvodah zt"l, in whose holy shadow I merited to take shelter. The voice of Torah rises to me into my tent from the lovely young men of the Yeshiva day and night, who kill themselves in the tent of Torah amidst pressure and poverty, and this is my only comfort after the hand of G-d touched me and I remained few from all my dear family and from all my brothers and friends and those dear to me abroad, until G-d has mercy on us and brings us out to great light speedily."
A fierce and wondrous love he loved the Rosh Yeshiva—who was the holy Admor the Maharash'n (Rabbi Shalom Noach Berezovsky) zt"l—and as one who stood by the creator-stones of Slonimer Chassidut, he transmitted to him much of these matters, and harbored wonderful trust in him, despite being nearly fifty years younger than him. When he still did not know that a survivor remained for him from all the dozens of descendants who were annihilated in the Holocaust, he said to the Rebbe zt"l: "You are like a son to me." And indeed, with this feeling he related to him. When it happened one day that the Rebbe did not come to the Yeshiva, R' Yisrael Zalman hurried and troubled himself to turn aside to his house to ask of his welfare...
One night at the end of the month of Adar I, in the year 5708 (1948), Rabbi Yisrael Zalman saw his Rebbe, the Admor the Maharash zt"l, in his dream. And behold, he called to him: "Yisrael Zalman, come with me!" He told the story of the dream with great anxiety to the Admor the "Netivot Shalom" zt"l, and told further that he saw himself in the dream sinking in many waters and not succeeding in getting out of them.
The Rebbe tried to distract his mind and calm him, but two weeks later, Rabbi Yisrael Zalman was indeed called to the World Above. Old and satisfied with days, he was gathered to his Rebbe in the Yeshiva on High. "And what he stands and serves here, he stands and serves there." His soul departed in purity, when he was eighty-five years old, at midnight on the holy Shabbat, 2nd of Adar II, 5708.
Source: "Tosefet Hamodia", 30 Adar I 5768, p. 25

body_he: הרה"ח רַבִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל זַלְמָן זצ"ל הָיָה עוֹד מֵרוֹאֵי פָּנָיו שֶׁל מָרָן בַּעַל "יְסוֹד הָעֲבוֹדָה" זי"ע, וְאַחַ"כּ שִׁמֵּשׁ כְּנֶאֱמַן בֵּיתָם וְיַד יְמִינָם שֶׁל רַבּוֹה"ק אַדְמוֹ"ר מוהר"ש וְאַדְמוֹ"ר מוהר"א [הַ"בֵּית אַבְרָהָם"] מִבַּרָאנוֹבִיץ זי"ע, וּבַעֲרוֹב יָמָיו עָלָה לְארה"ק ע"פ מִצְוַת מָרָן מוהר"א זי"ע, וְהִתְיַשֵּׁב בְּעיה"ק יְרוּשָׁלַיִם.כָּאן נָתַן עָלָיו עֵינוֹ הַטּוֹבָה אאמו"ר הרה"ח [הַנָּגִיד ר' יוֹסְ'ל] זַ"ל שֶׁהֶעֱמִיד לִרְשׁוּתוֹ דִּירָה בַּחֲצֵרוֹ, בְּצָמוּד לְדִירָתוֹ שֶׁל מָאטִיל [הרמ"ח זי"ע], וְכֹה שִׁמְּשׁוּ יַחַד שְׁנֵי צַנְתְּרוֹת הַזָּהָב, כְּתֵל תַּלְפִּיּוֹת שֶׁעֵינֵי קְהַל חֲסִידֵי סְלֹאנִים בְּכָל אֲתַר וַאֲתַר נְשׂוּאוֹת אֲלֵיהֶם, בִּמְיֻחָד בַּתְּקוּפָה הַקָּשָׁה שֶׁל שְׁקִיעַת הַמְּאוֹרוֹת וְחֻרְבַּן בֵּית רַבּוֹה"ק בַּגּוֹלָה בַּשּׁוֹאָה הָאֲיוּמָה לֹא תקפ"ץ...פָּרָשָׁה בִּפְנֵי עַצְמָהּ הִיא הָאַהֲבָה וְהַיְּדִידוּת הַמֻּפְלֶגֶת שֶׁשָּׂרַר בֵּין מָרָן הרמ"ח זי"ע לְבֵין שְׁכֵנוֹ וְרֵעוֹ הַקָּרוֹב הרה"ח רַבִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל זַלְמָן זצ"ל. תָּדִיר הָיְתָה דַּעְתּוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי מָאטִיל נְתוּנָה עַל רִי"ז לְסִפּוּק צְרָכָיו וְלִדְאֹג לְכָל מַחְסוֹרוֹ...כְּשֶׁהָיוּ מַפְצִירִים בְּרַבִּי מָאטִיל בִּתְקוּפַת הַ'פְּגָזִים' שֶׁנּוֹרוּ מֵחַיָּלֵי הַלִּגְיוֹן הַיַּרְדֵּנִי, שֶׁיֵּאוֹת לָרֶדֶת אֶל הַמִּקְלָט הָיָה אוֹמֵר: כָּל זְמַן 'דֶער אַלְטִיטְשְׁקֶער לֶערְנְט תּוֹרָה לִשְׁמָהּ' אֵין מָקוֹם לְפַחֵד, כְּשֶׁכַּוָּנָתוֹ עַל הרה"ח רַבִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל זַלְמָן ז"ל...רַבִּי מָאטִיל הָיָה לוֹ סֵדֶר קָבוּעַ בְּלִמּוּד גְּמָרָא בְּחַבְרוּתָא עִם רַבִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל זַלְמָן, כְּשֶׁרַבִּי מָאטִיל הָיָה כְּבָר לְאַחַר הַתְּפִלָּה וְאִילּוּ אֵצֶל רִי"ז הָיָה זֶה הֲכָנָה לִתְפִלָּה. בִּהְיוֹתָם דָּרִים בִּשְׁכֵנוּת, מִשֶּׁשָּׁמַע רַבִּי מָאטִיל אֶת רִי"ז כְּשֶׁהוּא נִסְחָב עִם הַ'פַּאנְטוֹפְל' הֵבִין שֶׁכְּבָר קָם מִשְּׁנָתוֹ וְהֵכִין עֲבוּרוֹ מַיִם חַמִּים לִשְׁתִיָּה, לַמְרוֹת שֶׁבַּיָּמִים הָהֵם הָיְתָה זוֹ עֲבוֹדָה רַבָּה ־ הֲכָנַת מַיִם חַמִּים...פַּעַם [בְּשָׁנִים שֶׁלְּאַחַר פְּטִירַת רַבִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל זַלְמָן ז"ל] בְּיוֹם ב' לְחֹדֶשׁ אֲדָר, עָבַר רַבִּי מָאטִיל בַּ'שְּׁטִיבְּל' וְהִבְחִין בִּמְסִבַּת מֵרֵעִים הַיּוֹשְׁבִים יַחַד בִּשְׁתִיַּית 'לְחַיִּים'. וְשָׁאַל ־ מַה יּוֹם מִיּוֹמִים וְלִכְבוֹד אֵיזֶה מְאֹרָע הוּבָא הַ'תִּיקּוּן'.מִשֶּׁהֱשִׁיבוּ הרה"ח ר' אֵלִיָּהוּ טֶנֶנְהוֹיְז ז"ל כִּי זֶהוּ לְרֶגֶל יוֹמָא דְּהִילּוּלָא שֶׁל זְקִינוֹ הרה"ח ר' יִשְׂרָאֵל זַלְמָן ז"ל, נַעֲנָה רַבִּי מָאטִיל וְאָמַר: "זָאל עֶר זַיין גֶעזוּנְט אוּן שְׁטַארְק, עֶר לֶעבְּט אַ טָאג" ־ ["שֶׁיִּהְיֶה בָּרִיא וְחָזָק, טוֹב לוֹ שָׁם"]...הרה"ח ר' מיכל אהרן וינברג ז"ל"שבחו של אהרן" (ירושלים תשס"ט) ע' ק"ל
body_en:
One of the residents of the Holy Land, while abroad with Maran the Admor the Maharash'd zt"l, entered into a marriage agreement (Shidduchin) with the granddaughter of Rabbi Yisrael Zalman. It was agreed that he would return to Israel, and within a short time return abroad and marry his spouse, and immediately ascend to live in Israel.
However, due to various reasons, he was delayed in Israel for a long time, and when he traveled abroad, the war broke out and the bride perished together with the entire family of R' Yisrael Zalman. When he built his house with one of my relatives, Rabbi Yisrael Zalman participated in the wedding and gave them a gift (Doron Derasha) with a good eye. He said to him: "Know that I have nothing in my heart against you, Heaven forbid, because you were delayed in Israel." He blessed them with all blessings from a willing heart and soul.
Source: "Mizkenim Etbonan" (Jerusalem 5767), Part 2, p. 307

The Rama [= the Chassid R' Michel Aharon Weinberg zt"l] was accustomed to describing the pleasantness of the heartfelt prayer of R' Yisrael Zalman, and his evening prayers before the Amud, according to the melody of the version accepted in the halls of our holy Rabbis in the exile. Especially, he would describe his emotional prayer on Rosh Hashanah, on which he also served as the caller for the Shofar blowing (Makri), and he would imitate with emotion his calling - "Ayyy Tekiah"...
Indeed, he would pray Musaf before the Amud on one of the two days—apparently the second day, while on the first day Rabbi Mottel [the Ramach] served as the Chazzan. The Rama was accustomed to saying that their prayers highlighted greatly the difference in their characters and manner of service: for Rabbi Mottel would shorten and ascend as was his way, whereas R' Yisrael Zalman would lengthen considerably with pleasantness, until on the day R' Yisrael Zalman prayed, the prayer would conclude a full hour later than the day of Rabbi Mottel's prayer...
Source: "Shivcho Shel Aharon" (Jerusalem 5769), p. 132

On the Shabbat after his passing [of Rabbi Yisrael Zalman], Maran the Ramach said that he wanted to speak before the congregation. When they gathered around him, he opened and said: "Since Rabbi Yisrael Zalman, who was the protector for all of us, has passed away from us to the world that is all good, he used to pray for all the people of our community for all their needs broadly. From this day onward, each and every one needs to worry and pray for himself, for we will lack his many prayers that he used to pray on our behalf constantly in their order."
Source: "Mizkenim Etbonan" (Jerusalem 5767), Part 2, p. 307

Biography
The Gaon Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz zt"l was born in the year 5651 (1891) in the town of Delyatitz in the Minsk district to his father, the Gaon Rabbi Aharon Aryeh Leib, who served in the rabbinate in the cities of Hanipoli in Barashi and Didkovitch (Volhynia district), and at the end of his days lived in Jerusalem.
In his youth, he studied in the Yeshiva in Tzehlem (Zvhil?), and afterward in the gathering of prodigies (Kibbutz HaIlluyim) in Eishishok under the Gaon Rabbi Zundel Hutner zt"l, with whom he studied together for about two years. He became famous then as a wondrous prodigy, and already as a small boy wrote several works (which remained in manuscript) that earned the approbation of the great Rabbis. His good reputation reached Slobodka, and a special messenger was sent to Eishishok in 5669 (1909) to persuade him to come study in "Knesset Yisrael" in Slobodka. There he merited extra appreciation from the Rosh Yeshiva, the Gaon Rabbi Moshe Mordechai Epstein zt"l, who expressed about his arrival that "A lion has ascended from Eishishok."
In the year 5673 (1913), he married the granddaughter of the Gaon Rabbi Avraham Moshe, Av Beit Din of Rakov, and in a second marriage, the granddaughter of the Gaon Rabbi Betzalel HaKohen of Vilna. Immediately upon his marriage, he was accepted as Rabbi of the town of Rakov. He was ordained for ruling by the Geonim Rabbi Refael Shapiro of Volozhin, Rabbi Eliyahu Baruch Kamai of Mir, the Rosh Yeshiva Gaon Rabbi Moshe Mordechai Epstein, and Rabbi Eliezer Rabinowitz of Minsk.
In the year 5676 (1916), he founded a Yeshiva in Rakov and spread Torah to students there. At the same time, he began to engage in public affairs in various roles, as a member of the committee of the Agudat HaRabbanim in Poland, a member of the secretariat of the Council of Torah Sages [together with the Geonim Rabbi Menachem Ziemba and Rabbi Yaakov Meir Biderman zt"l], and President of Agudat Yisrael in White Russia. He was also among the founders of the "Vaad HaYeshivot" in Vilna and the Kollel "Ateret Tzvi" in Vilna founded by the Gaon Rabbi Chaim Ozer Grodzinski zt"l [later the Kollel moved to Otwock], and was among those close to our Master the "Chafetz Chaim" and the Grah"a (Rabbi Chaim Ozer) zt"l.
In the year 5686 (1926), he was chosen as President of the Mir Yeshiva and traveled on its mission to the USA. There he succeeded in raising its difficult economic situation, and thanks to this, its development and the increase of its students from one hundred to five hundred became possible. In the year 5689 (1929), he was chosen as Rabbi of Tiktin in the Lomza district, and there too he founded a Yeshiva.
With the outbreak of World War II, he wandered with the Mir Yeshiva to Vilna, and from there he ascended by hand (escaped) to the USA. There he established and served as the living spirit in the "Vaad Hatzalah" (Rescue Committee), which saved thousands of Jews from the valley of killing, among them great transmitters of tradition and Admorim. Likewise, he took upon his neck the yoke and burden of the Mir Yeshiva throughout the war years, until he succeeded in bringing all its students to the USA. Then he established it anew and stood at its head until the day of his death. He also assisted through the Rosh Yeshiva, the Gaon Rabbi Eliezer Yehuda Finkel zt"l, to establish the Mir Yeshiva in the Land of Israel, and took upon himself the yoke of its maintenance in the first period of its existence.
Included in his mighty activities was the establishment of the network of Talmud Torahs and institutions for girls "Otzar HaTorah" in the land of Morocco, in which many thousands of students were educated in Torah and testimony. Through this, they were saved from the cursed network of Enlightenment spread by the heads of the "Alliance" at the feet of the Jews of France and Morocco, which was under French rule since World War I.
