The Gaon Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz passed away on the 2nd of Adar, 5724 (1964), and was brought to rest near the grave of his father in Jerusalem, the Holy City [in the cemetery in the Sanhedria neighborhood].
Source: "Igrot Maran RIZ HaLevi" (Jerusalem 5768), p. 408

My teacher, the Gaon Rabbi Mordechai Gifter zt"l, told me that the Gaon Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz zt"l once entered to the Gaon Rabbi Avraham Gordon zt"l, Rosh Yeshiva of Telz in Lithuania, and said to him in this language: "Rebbe, I dreamt at night a certain tremendous difficulty (Kushya)—in the middle of the night's sleep—" and R' Avraham told the difficulty to the Rosh Yeshiva. The Rosh Yeshiva said to his student that it was indeed a tremendous difficulty, but he added and said to him: "Here in Telz, we stopped getting excited about such a thing a long time ago, to dream of a difficulty in a Sugya of the Gemara. In Telz, the true sign for one who is immersed in learning is one who thinks also of the answer (Terutz)! [With us in the Yeshiva, they are so immersed in learning that we hope to hear from the Yeshiva students the answer to the difficulty as well]."
Source: "Ohel Moshe" (Brooklyn 5767), Part 1, p. 600

...All those years—even when he was immersed up to his neck in public affairs—Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz zt"l was tied to the world of Yeshivot with a love as strong as death. In the year 5686 (1926), he came to the rescue of the Mir Yeshiva, which was in a difficult financial crisis, and hundreds of its students stood before the disgrace of hunger. Rabbi Avraham could not stand by. On the mission of the Yeshiva, he went out to the United States, together with the Rosh Yeshiva, the Gaon Rabbi Eliezer Yehuda Finkel, to conduct campaigns among the wealthy of the Jewish communities. The radiating charm of their personalities won many hearts on the American continent. After they battered their feet across the United States, they succeeded in sending to Mir a sum of money that seemed imaginary. "Much of this success is due to the merit of Rabbi Avraham," expressed the heads of the Yeshiva. The special Divine Assistance (Siyata Dishmaya) with which he was blessed in all his activities—was already a byword.
Before his return to Poland, Rabbi Avraham succeeded in founding in the United States a permanent "Friends Circle" that would act for the sake of the Mir Yeshiva and ensure that contributions would be sent to it regularly.
His second rabbinical city was Tiktin, in the Brisk region. During his tenure there, he succeeded—according to the story—in saving its Jews from a pogrom. This was in the period close to the outbreak of World War II, when unceasing Nazi propaganda flowed from Berlin and greatly increased antisemitism in Poland. Dormant hatred of Israel awakened with full force, and gangs of antisemites surrounded the cities and threatened to wreak havoc on the Jews. When Rabbi Avraham learned of the pogrom these gangs were planning to conduct in his city, he hurried to the local governor and demanded with all force that he station an army battalion for the defense of the community. The governor acceded to him—and the rioters were forced to give up their plot in the presence of the armed soldiers. The personal price Rabbi Avraham "paid" for this was high: the leaders of the rioters decided to take revenge on him and tried to murder him through a staged "car accident." He was miraculously saved, but was forced to leave Tiktin out of fear for his life.
The volcano upon which Polish Jewry sat in that period of the eve of the Holocaust grew hotter day by day. In Elul 5699 (1939), the war broke out and brought the conflagration to its peak, a flood of blood threatening to drown the great Jewish centers in the world.
Rabbi Avraham succeeded in arriving with his family, through wandering paths saturated with dangers, to independent Vilna. Here, among thousands of Rabbis and Yeshiva students who crowded Vilna, he quickly integrated into the great activity of saving the Torah world...
Rabbi Avraham—the great lover of the Torah world—was the man sent by the Holy One, Blessed be He, as a pioneer before the camp, to be a support and sustenance for the Yeshiva students going out to the path of their rescue. From Heaven, he was rolled to the United States in time, in order to act from there tirelessly for the sake of their exit to freedom, for the sake of their economic existence, and for the sake of their rescue from the various dangers that abounded for them on that tortuous path. In the winter of 5700 (1940), he and his family merited to receive visas to the United States, and they left for there via Sweden—a short time before this escape route was closed.
"Chapter America" opened in the life of Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz—a gigantic chapter in action, in which his life's work soared and reached unknown heights. Past and present integrated in his personality in harmony. His roots, his Torah, and his vision he drew from the spirit-rich Jewry of Europe in which he grew. The ability to act, to establish his tremendous rescue enterprises—he drew from the wealthy and influential Jewry of the United States. To European Jewry, twitching in its death throes in those years, he mobilized tirelessly the help of the wealthy and complacent Jews of America.
The spiritual desert of the United States merited the dew of Torah life with the arrival of Rabbi Avraham. He established a branch of the Mir Yeshiva in New York and breathed into it that same spirit he had received far from here, from his teachers in Slobodka and Telz. An atmosphere of Torah for its own sake and aspiration for greatness in Torah without material purpose, title, or position—a new atmosphere in materialistic America, preparing the buds of a great revolution. A new American generation of Bnei Torah grew between the walls of "Mir America," in the shadow of Rabbi Avraham. While his nights were holy for Torah toil, his days were divided between delivering lessons to his students and nurturing the Yeshiva—and the world-embracing rescue activity. Throughout the years of the Yeshiva's wanderings in Japan and Shanghai—Rabbi Avraham was the man who fed and sustained it under difficult war conditions and in strange and alien lands at the ends of the earth, when without him, hundreds of Yeshiva students had no source of livelihood. He—he alone, with legendary self-sacrifice—was the single oxygen pipe flowing life into the arteries of the Yeshiva.
Immediately upon his arrival in the United States, he threw himself head and most of his body into the activities of the "Vaad Hatzalah" (Rescue Committee) which had been established only a short time before. Here came to him the cry for help from the heads of the Mir Yeshiva trapped in the Soviet trap in Vilna, pleading for its rescue. By miracles of Heaven, all the members of the Yeshiva merited Japanese visas and exit permits from the Soviet Union; but without the gigantic sums required for exit, all chances of rescue were liable to go down the drain. An almost imaginary sum of more than fifty thousand dollars was required to finance the travel tickets on "Intourist," the price of the voyage to Japan, and the rest of the travel expenses. The time allotted to them to purchase the tickets at "Intourist" was running out—and when the deadline passed, the validity of the exit permits would expire... Every moment of delay was liable to seal their fate for the rod, Heaven forbid!
The situation was literally life-threatening. The only hope of the Yeshiva was the "Vaad Hatzalah," and Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz at its head. At the height of the holy Shabbat, in the month of Tevet 5701 (1941), the heads of the Yeshiva sent an urgent telegram to Rabbi Avraham—a call of S.O.S., or saving souls. Until the coming Monday—two days later—they required the immense sum, otherwise they would miss the deadline... In forty-eight hours, the hourglass would stop.
Rabbi Avraham was the only man capable of "lifting" such a burden. The telegram arrived at his home on the morning of that Shabbat. He himself was absent from his home. He was staying in Manhattan, standing to speak there in a synagogue where wealthy people prayed, in order to raise donations for the "Vaad Hatzalah." His son, Rabbi Shraga Moshe, looked at the telegram and was shaken: the matter could not tolerate any delay. He succeeded, after much effort, in locating a Jew living near the synagogue and asked him to enter and call "Rabbi" Kalmanowitz to the phone...
In the middle of the sermon he was delivering, Rabbi Avraham hurried to the phone. He heard about the matter and mobilized for the soul-saving operation. An idea flashed in his mind on how to immediately raise the gigantic sum and transfer it to Vilna within the short time remaining (the operation of transferring funds under war conditions was accompanied by many bureaucratic obstacles and lasted a not-short time). He hurried to hire a taxi, joined by three wealthy and respected men known by name (among them the philanthropist Harry Fischel and the Matzah manufacturer Manischewitz), and traveled to the home of the head of the Joint Distribution Committee in New York. He knew that in his authority as the man to sign on the authorization to the Joint branch in Vilna and to instruct his people there to lend the necessary sum to the Mir Yeshiva.
The head of the Joint, stunned by the sight of the famous Rabbi bursting into his home from a taxi at the height of Shabbat—tried at first to evade. Rabbi Kalmanowitz did not give up. The responsibility for saving the Yeshiva rested on his shoulders. Stormy all over, he raised his voice in an uncompromising demand: "Do not stand idly by the blood of your neighbor!" He demanded from the head of the Joint to sign immediately on the approval of the loan to the Yeshiva for the full amount, against the guarantee of his three wealthy lenders. The man could not stand before the firm demand, which burst from the essence of Rabbi Avraham's heart blood. He signed the required approval. The "Rescue Telegram" went out immediately to the Joint branch in Vilna. Rabbi Avraham breathed a sigh of relief. True, he had just taken upon himself responsibility for the repayment of a loan of fifty thousand dollars—a huge sum by the value of those days—but is there a heavy burden in the world when it comes to taking the Yeshiva out of captivity?
With this, the expenses were not yet over. Additional requests for help flowed to Rabbi Avraham from a group of Rabbis in occupied Lithuania, and each one of them was a matter of life and death. Again he girded his loins, wandering from donor to donor and collecting the required sums. The bureaucratic obstacles stood in his way like stumbling blocks. Sending money to an occupied land was conditional on a license on behalf of the American Treasury Department and in the transfer mechanism of the Federal National Bank.
In Lithuania, the validity of the exit permits was about to expire, and the race against time was becoming impossible... Rabbi Avraham activated all his connections, brought into the picture several people of position who were numbered among his friends and faithful assistants (headed by the two Tennenbaum brothers), and succeeded in achieving the unbelievable: an immediate transfer of the money, while bypassing all administrative regulations, from which no one is exempt.
To the aid of the man, fighting like a lion for the rescue of his brothers, many of the influential and top people in the administration were mobilized—Jews and non-Jews alike. Their hearts followed his wondrous personality. Faced with Rabbi Avraham's self-sacrifice, it was impossible to remain indifferent. He acquired devoted friends—both among the leaders of American Jewry and among the heads of statesmen in Washington; among them were the Secretary of the Treasury, Mr. Morgenthau, and Mr. Pehle, head of the "War Refugee Board." Years later, at a thanksgiving party arranged in their honor by the Friends of Mir Yeshiva, Rabbi Avraham told with emotion about Mr. Pehle's personal part in the rescue efforts:
"In the month of Tevet 5701, we were forced to transfer immediately to Kovno in Lithuania a large sum in American dollars for travel money for the students of Mir Yeshiva and for another group of Rabbis, and according to the usual arrangement, it would have taken several days until they gave the license. If we had waited, they would have come to a bitter end, Heaven forbid and save. So we came to Mr. Pehle, and he arranged the matter immediately via telephone. And through this, hundreds of Torah greats found in Shanghai (until now) were saved, and several hundred more found in the Land of Israel and other countries."
His rescue efforts embraced all the occupied countries of Europe. In the year 5703 (1943)—after the majority of Polish and Lithuanian Jewry had perished—the cup of poison reached the Jewry of Slovakia. In Pressburg, Slovakia, sat then the holy Gaon and Tzaddik Rabbi Michael Dov Weissmandl zt"l, who acted feverishly in daring attempts to delay the death trains to Auschwitz. Among other things, he succeeded in maintaining contacts with senior officials of the Nazi regime in Slovakia, whose lust for money did not fall short of their hatred for Jews, and spoke with them about the possibility of a "deal": delaying the death trains in exchange for "ransom money" in huge sums. He hurried to send to Switzerland—through underground ways he succeeded in creating—appeals to the representatives of the "Vaad Hatzalah," and his soul was in his request: Send money immediately! Every moment means: the lives of Jewish souls!
Rabbi Avraham entered immediately into the thick of the beam. Also in this case, the telegram arrived at the height of the holy Shabbat. He refused to lose precious minutes. Accompanied by one of his close associates—the Gaon Rabbi Gedalia Schorr—he traveled with lightning speed to the "Synagogue of the Wealthy," which belonged to the Reform community in New York. Upon arriving there, he asked to meet immediately with the "Rabbi" and expressed in his ears his request: to deliver a sermon, on a most urgent matter, before the congregants!
The "Rabbi" reacted with impatience: Such a thing must be arranged in advance, there are fixed rules, it is impossible to allow everyone to speak "just like that"—there must be order... "Perhaps you will return in the middle of the week and we will talk about a time for your sermon," he suggested politely.
"But every day the danger of death hovers over multitudes of Jews in Slovakia," intervened Rabbi Gedalia Schorr in the conversation, "and the waiting of a few days means..."
"I understand," answered the Rabbi, without hiding his shortness of spirit: "But order is order! Our 'Synagogue' has rules, and we cannot deviate from them!"
He turned to return to his place, but Rabbi Avraham—stormy to the depths of his soul—ran after him and his whole being said plea: "Allow me to say to the congregation just one word... I ask this of you in the name of the entire Jewish people!!!"
"One word only—as you said!", the Rabbi finally acceded to him: "Remember—no more than a word..."
At the conclusion of the prayer, the Rabbi accompanied him to the Bimah and remained standing by his side, to supervise lest he violate the condition...
The entire congregation fixed curious and tense eyes upon him: What does the "Orthodox" Rabbi intend—whose beard and clothing seemed stranger here than ever—to say to them?
Rabbi Avraham straightened to his full height, began to tremble all over his body in a spasm of terrible emotion. Suddenly, a single, unique scream burst from his throat, shaking hearts: "SAVE!!"
And he collapsed to the floor and fainted...
The congregation was shaken and alarmed, doctors were summoned and labored for about ten minutes to restore his consciousness. When he finally woke up, pale and weak, the worried Rabbi asked him how he felt.
"How do I feel?" Rabbi Avraham burst into bitter weeping: "I feel fine, but it is not about me that we speak... We speak of multitudes of our brothers being murdered and slaughtered in these moments!!!"
"Gentlemen!", he cried from the depths of his soul; "When we see a Jew fainting, immediately everyone runs to help him... But in Europe... In Europe, our brothers and sisters are falling slain, in hundreds and thousands, and here no one lifts a finger... Is it possible?! Have we gone mad, dear Jews? How can we stand in tranquility over the blood of our brothers?!"
At this stage, the Rabbi surrendered. He noticed the strong impression the "cheeky" Orthodox Rabbi made on the congregants. They looked at him as a holy man who came to them from "other spheres," and again the Rabbi did not prevent him from preaching in their ears and conducting an appeal for the rescue of the Jews of Slovakia. The appeal succeeded above and beyond. Even among the Reform Jews, whose world was as far from his as east is from west and who were not faithful like him to "All Israel are responsible for one another"—Rabbi Avraham's personality vibrated the deepest strings of the soul.
His rescue operations were amazing in their scope and daring. He operated on every plane that had a shred of a chance to save a Jew, even just one. In his book on the areas of activity of the "Vaad Hatzalah" which he headed, he writes:
"In the beginning, the Rescue Committee was founded specifically to save the Yeshivot, the Torah scholars, and the spiritual leaders. Afterward, time passed, we expanded the rescue to all layers of our people, to anyone for whom there was only some possibility to save him, even a remote possibility—through ways known as actual self-sacrifice, such as smuggling borders; hiding in pits, ditches, and caves; forging passports; paying ransom money to the hands of murderers, and with the help of G-d, we merited to save at least a small part..."
Throughout all the years of the Holocaust, Rabbi Avraham lived with all his 248 limbs the subject of rescue. He ate, slept, and breathed rescue.
One of his devoted assistants in those days describes his rare daring:
"Nothing stood in his way in that period. When he came to save, he denied all boundaries of the world. There are no kings, no ministers, no dignitaries, no rich men, and no important people, the laws of the state do not exist. Not once did he violate actual criminal laws for the sake of saving a Jewish soul. Before his eyes was engraved the verse: 'Who are you that you should be afraid of a man that shall die, and of the son of man which shall be made as grass,' and strange in his eyes were all those who made many calculations."
He himself did not calculate any calculations. "Slim chance of success," "zero chances," and "low probability" did not impress him. Even on a doubt of a doubt of a chance, he was ready to give his soul and work until the exhaustion of forces.
No obstacle stopped him. Not once did he express his wonder at the "calculators of calculations": "If it were a matter of saving yourself, there would be no action that was too hard, or too expensive, or repulsive... Regarding saving yourself, the concept 'illegal' does not exist... That is exactly our obligation in the rescue of every single one of Israel!"
To this goal, he operated with superhuman powers. Twice he succeeded in meeting with Roosevelt, President of the United States, in his honor and person. In an interview with him, he laid out his grievance against the harsh immigration laws preventing many Jews from being saved from the gas chambers, and pleaded for the easing of restrictions and increasing the quota of immigrants.
Also regarding the famous Rescue Train, which carried Jews from Bergen-Belsen to a safe place in Switzerland, Rabbi Avraham had an active part (among the survivors on that train was the Admor of Satmar, Rabbi Yoel Teitelbaum zt"l, who until the end of his days recognized the good to Rabbi Avraham and felt he owed him his life). He activated all his strong connections with his acquaintances in the administration for this subject, and especially with the people of the "War Refugee Board" in the President's office. After the exhausting negotiations with the Germans finally concluded, the train arrived safely at its destination in Switzerland...
The few feelings of happiness Rabbi Avraham experienced when receiving this good news, like additional news of successes in saving Jews—were in his eyes the most wonderful compensation for his efforts which had no measure or limit. Every soul of Israel snatched from the valley of killing was a full world, literally as it implies, and his joy over the rescue knew no bounds.
His devotion to the individual did not fall short of the devotion to the collective. When the Leitner brothers and Rabbi Binyamin Zev Steinfeld—students of Mir—arrived in San Francisco in 5707 (1947), they were detained by the authorities because their passports had expired, since there was no Czech consul in Shanghai to extend the validity of the passports. The matter was brought to the attention of the Gaon Rabbi Kalmanowitz zt"l. He traveled immediately to Philadelphia, to the center of immigration of the United States, and did not rest or be quiet until he achieved entry permits for them to the United States; and on the second day of their detention, a telegram arrived from the central immigration office to allow their entry to the United States.
Also at the end of the Holocaust, when the Jewish people mourned their many victims and licked their bleeding wounds—Rabbi Avraham knew no rest. Like a faithful soldier, he stood on his watch, as he had from the day he stood on his own opinion, and gave his soul for the many tasks awaiting him at such a time. Finding countries of refuge for the survivors of the remnant whose homes and communities were destroyed; their rehabilitation as brands plucked from the fire; caring for their material and spiritual needs; establishing and basing anew the Torah centers that were annihilated; extensive educational activity for the children of the Eastern communities, uprooted in those days from their lands and roots and arriving in their multitudes to countries where severe dangers of assimilation lurked for them.
Each one of these life-projects, wondrous and tremendous in dimensions, is worthy of being described on its own. However, when speaking of the activities of Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz, the canvas is too short to contain even a small part of them. The tapestry of his life is rich and broad, too much to be confined within the boundaries of pen and paper...
Source: "HaZricha BeFa'atei Kedem" (Bnei Brak 5761), Part 3, p. 197

I remember that when he arrived in the Holy Land—after the war—the great Gaon, the master of rescue operations, the Honored Holiness of our Teacher Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz, Rosh Yeshiva of Mir in the USA zt"l (and he lodged at the Babad Hotel in Jerusalem), the greats of Israel and the heads of Yeshivot came to greet him, and arranged a kind of reception in honor of his Torah. In the Torah discussion, he mentioned the following idea: On the verse (Genesis 8:21) ויישר אך נח וגו' - "And Noah remained only" (Wait, the verse cited in the text is Gen 7:23 וישאר אך נח), Rashi explains (and it is from Midrash Aggadah, Bereishit Rabbah): "He was groaning and coughing blood from the trouble of the cattle and beasts." And some say that he was late in feeding the lion and it bit him, etc. The question is asked: Why did the lion burst out and rage at the delay in giving his food more than the rest of the animals? After all, as our Sages said (in Tanchuma ibid) that neither Noah nor his sons tasted the taste of sleep for all those twelve months, and as our Sages said in Sanhedrin (108b) regarding the great trouble Noah had in caring for the animals and beasts and every creeping thing that the Holy One, Blessed be He, made to sustain and feed everyone in whom there was a spirit of life in the Ark. There are those whose food is by day and those whose food is by night. How much he toiled until he knew what the food of this one and that creature was! Once he peeled an apple and a worm fell out of it, and a chameleon wanted it and swallowed the worm, and he knew from then on that this was its food.
After all this, what is the claim of the lion and his anger that Noah was late once in giving him food? But the answer is that the lion knew that he is a privileged one (Yachsan), for he was the lion, the only one (he and the lioness) in the whole world who remained alive among the rest of the animals that remained alive after the Flood...
And the Rosh Yeshiva of Mir cried out with weeping from the walls of his heart: "Gentlemen, the world of Torah in Europe has been destroyed! Terrible and awful to imagine is the shocking destruction that happened to the holy people. The voice of Torah that burst forth and rose from Europe day and night has been silenced. Synagogues and study halls have been silenced, shattered, and destroyed to the foundation, Heaven forbid. Millions of our brothers and sisters went up in fire and flames in the four deaths of the court. There are no words and no expressions for the magnitude of the pain and suffering of the scattered sheep of Israel. May G-d avenge their blood speedily, and save us and comfort us and gladden us.
"And behold, every soul of Israel, and every Ben Torah who remains in the world, all the remnant that is left—he is a privileged one, he is a lion! He who remains after the flood of fire and sulfur that surrounded the chosen of the people of Israel—he is precious to us and the delight of our eyes. We must guard him like the apple of the eye of Judaism, to nurture him and establish him, to sustain him to keep him and care for him, to return the crown of the glory of Torah to its former state. Heads of Yeshivot, be careful please with the precious deposit in your hands, to sustain him and lead him with kindness and mercy, with consideration and caution, in order to magnify Torah and glorify it, to fill the empty void, the chaos and void that remains after the destruction, and the world is desolate, may the Merciful One save us.
"Happy are you that your lot has fallen in pleasant places to guard this deposit. Let us all know together the magnitude of the value of the holiness of the task around every Ben Torah who remains alive. And let us pray to the Blessed G-d that He be our help to fulfill our obligations in our world towards the coming of the great and awesome day and towards the coming of Messiah our Righteous One, may he come and gladden us, speedily in our days, Amen."
Source: "Mordechai Avraham" (Jerusalem 5758), Part 1, p. 28

...And in that period, a light appeared in the storm, when the Gaon R' Avraham Kalmanowitz zt"l, Av Beit Din of Rakov and one of the great rescuers of the Holocaust, visited Morocco. He was one of the establishers of the yoke of Torah in that period when he was Rosh Yeshiva of Mir and its President in the United States. He was not satisfied with that but searched further in the lands of exile in North Africa and other places to save the children of Israel and bring them under the wings of the Divine Presence. Then the Gaon R' Refael Abbo zt"l appeared in Morocco and brought him from Tiberias, from the Cheder of Jerusalem. They called him "The Angel Refael." They established the Otzar HaTorah Yeshivot throughout Morocco.
Then we studied all the Sugyot in depth with Rashi and Tosafot, and everything was fluent by heart. Thus we could recite whole chapters of the Talmud by heart with the explanation of Rashi and Tosafot. Afterward, the Gaon Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz zt"l conceived the idea to transfer the select students from Otzar HaTorah in Morocco to the Mir Yeshiva in America. Fourteen students were chosen from all over the land of Morocco—from Marrakech, Casablanca, Meknes, and more—and I was counted among them.
I was the youngest of them all, about 14 years old. When we arrived in the USA, the Gaon Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz zt"l brought us excellent lecturers (Maggidei Shiur) who said a lesson in Gemara every single day. Specifically, I have to point out the first in holiness, the Gaon and Tzaddik R' Eliezer Dessler zt"l, author of Michtav MeEliyahu. From him, we received not only a Musar lesson—as is known, he was a great Gaon in the Torah of Musar—but mainly a Gemara lesson on the page with Rashi and Tosafot. It is interesting that his way of study was not far from the way of Sephardic depth (Iyun) that we were accustomed to until then. He did not engage in Pilpulim (casuistry) but strove to understand the Sugya with in-depth plain meaning and to get to its depth. He was very true in his learning. And I will not elaborate (v'ein kan makom l'ha'arich) in his praise regarding his righteousness and tremendous influence.
After him came the famous Gaon R' Chaim Kreiswirth (Shlita) [zt"l], known as "The Illuy of Krakow," who taught in a different way and said lessons in pilpul of Torah (Pilpula d'Orayta) with sharpness and tremendous proficiency in Bavli and Yerushalmi. The Gaon Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz zt"l took care of all matters, and even afterward, he was connected all his days with the students of that time. I received the last letter of his life from him, in which he took great interest in the situation of the Yeshiva, Yeshivat HaRambam U'Beit Yosef, which I headed, etc., with great affection, as his long letter to me testifies...
Source: "Eshel Avraham" (Petach Tikva 5760), Part 1, p. 23

There is a verse (Isaiah 29:13): ותהי יראתם אותי מצות אנשים מלמדה - "And their fear of Me is a commandment of men learned by rote." There is a tremendous claim in this, which is why there is the severe punishment (ibid, verse 14): הנני יוסף להפליא את העם הזה הפלא ופלא ואבדה חכמת חכמיו - "Therefore, behold, I will proceed to do a marvelous work among this people, even a marvelous work and a wonder: for the wisdom of their wise men shall perish," and other severe punishments.
I once heard from Rabbi Avraham Kalmanowitz that he explained what "a commandment of men learned by rote" is: When a person today is like yesterday, and tomorrow is like today, and he is not better tomorrow than today—he does not ascend and stands in the same place—this is "a commandment of men learned by rote."
Source: "Amrei Yaakov" (Brooklyn 5766), p. 4

Biography
The Admor Rabbi Yisrael Alter of Gur zt"l was born in the year 5655 (1895) to his father, Rabbi Avraham Mordechai of Gur, author of Imrei Emet, son of the Sfat Emet and grandson of the Chiddushei HaRim. In the house of his great father, he received education for a life of Torah and holiness and to loathe worldly pleasures.
He married the daughter of his uncle, Rabbi Yaakov Meir Biderman, and settled in Warsaw. Like the way of his ancestors, he withdrew from leading others and engaged in business casually, dedicating the main part of his time to ascent in Torah and fear of Heaven. Already then, he showed signs of a leader with supreme grace. He founded groups (Chaburot) of young men engaged in Torah and Chassidut. With his wondrous mind, he knew every single one of the thousands of lovely young men in Warsaw who belonged to Gur Chassidut.
With the outbreak of World War II, he was tested with all the tribulations of the time. His wife and children perished in the Holocaust, and he escaped together with his father and arrived in the Land of Israel broken and crushed over the bereavement of his family and over the people of G-d who fell before the enemy. He stood at the right hand of his great father, who was then already ill and weak, and guided the Chassidim—especially the young ones—to Torah and service.
On the holiday of Shavuot 5708 (1948), his father passed away, and the yoke of leadership fell upon his shoulders. With his appointment as Admor of Gur, he was recognized as one of the great leaders of Haredi Jewry. With his wisdom and understanding, he knew how to follow the spirit of each and every one. Quickly, his Beit Midrash became a mound of mouths (Tel Talpiot - a center of attraction), and from all circles and all strata of the people, they knocked on the doors of his house to receive advice, guidance, encouragement, and strengthening. His patience knew no bounds, especially for the brokenhearted and the Holocaust survivors, of whom he was like a father and mother to many.
The Rebbe demanded constant ascent from his Chassidim. He loathed superficiality and placed great emphasis on matters of holiness and persistence in Torah for all layers of the people, from Yeshiva students to householders burdened with livelihood and economy. With his understanding and broad horizons, he expanded the boundaries of holiness by establishing Batei Midrash and educational institutions in many cities in the Land of Israel and in the Diaspora.
For twenty-nine years, he led the "Beit Yisrael" Chassidim from his court in Jerusalem, the Holy City, and merited to see generations of Bnei Torah, Chassidim, and men of action emerging from his institutions on the same line and path as in former years, before the destruction of Europe.
He returned his soul to his Creator on the 2nd of Adar, 5737 (1977) (and is buried on the Mount of Olives). He did not merit to leave behind enduring offspring, and the leadership of Gur Chassidut passed to his brother, the Admor Rabbi Simcha Bunim, the "Lev Simcha" zt"l.
Source: "BeMa'alot Kedoshim U'Tehorim" (Brooklyn 5760), p. 136

body_he: הרה"ק הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" מִגּוּר זצ"ל הָיָה דַּרְכּוֹ בְּדִבּוּרִים קָשִׁים, אַךְ לִבּוֹ הָיָה רַךְ כַּקָּנֶה, וּכְשֶׁהָיָה בָּא אֶצְלוֹ "קְוִויטֶעל" שֶׁל אֵיזֶה דָּבָר לֹא טוֹב וכדו', הָיוּ עֵינָיו זוֹלְגוֹת דְּמָעוֹת.כ"ק מרן אדמו"ר מלעלוב זצוק"למלוה-מלכה פר' משפטים תשס"א"דברות קודש" (רמת לעלוב ב"ב) משפטים תשס"ב, עמ' ג'
body_en:
In order to instill in us the love of Torah, my father (the Gaon Rabbi Moshe Aharon Stern zt"l - Mashgiach of Kamenitz Yeshiva) used to take us towards morning to the Beit Midrash of Gur. He showed us how people study Torah before prayer and explained to us the virtue of the owner of the "Beit Yisrael" zt"l, who instilled this conduct. He explained to us that the "Beit Yisrael" loved the Torah and those who study it, and instilled this love in his Chassidim.
He also corrected this: Torah study at every free moment. The Shtiebels are full of Torah students in the morning hours before the Shacharit prayer. When everything is still pure and quiet, when the bustling of daily life has not yet arisen, the Batei Midrash are already filling with Torah study. For so the Rebbe demanded: Torah... Torah... Torah... For the Torah is the spiritual basis for every Jewish heart. He demanded Torah study in holiness and purity, with a heart free from the vanities of this world. And Torah study is the central basis in the life of the flock that the Rebbe led.
Source: "HaMashgiach D'Kamenitz" (Jerusalem 5758), p. 190

body_he: הגה"ח רבי צבי יצחק אברומוביץ ז"ל"טעם הצבי" (ב"ב תשנ"ב) ח"ב, ע' ר"ל
body_en:
I will relate as an eyewitness, that once I was invited on a holy Shabbat for the "Great Kiddush" by our Rebbe [the "Beis Yisrael" of Ger] *zy"a*. There were several guests from the Chassidic community, and among them was the famous composer R' Yaakov Talmud *zt"l*. On the table stood all kinds of strong drinks, but R' Yaakov was a sickly man and his doctors warned him to avoid drinking liquor, so naturally, he did not dare approach the drinks at all. And behold, my ears heard how the Rebbe *zy"a* turned to him and said in this language: "R' Yankel, by me you can drink from all the drinks, I guarantee that it won't harm you at all, on my responsibility... However, if you drink outside my house, I cannot guarantee for you..." And of course, R' Yankel tasted from all the bottles...
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Natan Einfeld Shlita, "Minchat Natan" (Bnei Brak 5767) Part 1, p. 119

body_he: כְּדֵי לְהַשְׁרִישׁ בָּנוּ אַהֲבַת תּוֹרָה, הָיָה אָבִי (הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה אַהֲרֹן שְׁטֶערְן זצ"ל ־ מַשְׁגִּיחַ דִּישִׁיבַת קַמְנִיץ) לוֹקֵחַ אוֹתָנוּ לִפְנוֹת בֹּקֶר לְבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ שֶׁל גּוּר, וְהֶרְאָה אֵיךְ אֲנָשִׁים לוֹמְדִים תּוֹרָה לִפְנֵי הַתְּפִלָּה, וְהִסְבִּיר עַל מַעֲלַת בַּעַל "בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" זצ"ל, שֶׁהִשְׁרִישׁ הַנְהָגָה זוֹ. וְהִסְבִּיר לָנוּ כִּי הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" אָהַב אֶת הַתּוֹרָה וְלוֹמְדֶיהָ וְהֶחְדִּיר בַּחֲסִידָיו אַהֲבָה זוֹ. גַּם זֹאת תִּיקֵּן, לִמּוּד תּוֹרָה בְּכָל זְמַן פָּנוּי. הַשְּׁטִיבְּלַאךְ מְלֵאִים בְּלוֹמְדֵי תּוֹרָה בִּשְׁעוֹת הַבֹּקֶר הַמּוּקְדָּמוֹת קוֹדֶם תְּפִלַּת שַׁחֲרִית. כַּאֲשֶׁר הַכֹּל עֲדַיִן זַךְ וְשֶׁקֶט, כְּשֶׁעֲדַיִן לֹא קָם הַכְּרָךְ לְחַיֵּי הַיּוֹם יוֹם, כְּבָר מְמַלְּאִים אֶת בָּתֵּי הַמִּדְרָשׁ בְּלִימוּד תּוֹרָה. כִּי כָּךְ תָּבַע הָרַבִּי, תּוֹרָה... תּוֹרָה... תּוֹרָה... כִּי הַתּוֹרָה הִיא הַבָּסִיס הָרוּחָנִי לְכָל לֵב יְהוּדִי. הוּא תָּבַע לִמּוּד תּוֹרָה בִּקְדֻשָּׁה וּבְטָהֳרָה. בְּלֵב פָּנוּי מֵהַבְלֵי הָעוֹהַ"ז. וְלִמּוּד הַתּוֹרָה הוּא הַבָּסִיס הַמֶּרְכָּזִי בְּחַיֵּי הַצֹּאן שֶׁהִנְהִיג הָרַבִּי.הרה"ג ר' יחיאל מיכל שטרן שליט"ארב דשכונת "עזרת תורה""המשגיח דקמניץ" (ירושלים תשנ"ח) ע' 190
body_en:
I have a personal story. In the year 5717 (1957), the Rebbe the Beit Yisrael zt"l stayed in Safed. I traveled there and did not find lodging for myself. I was hungry from the trouble of the road. The attendant (Mashbak) R' A.R. brought me a full meal from the Rebbe's house: Challah, fish, etc. I did not want to accept it, and I said to him: "Do not steal" is said also in the Rebbe's house. Who gave you permission to give?
He said to me: "If so, I am obligated to reveal to you. The Rebbe told me once: 'Know that the matter of hospitality (Hachnasat Orchim) is not so simple—to take a full meal prepared for you and for the household members and serve it to a stranger who came by chance completely under your roof... The advice for this is: And so it is with me in the house. I declare everything ownerless (Hefker) for the sake of guests. Any Jew who comes is permitted to take from the kitchen food and drink that he finds, and to give to anyone he wants... Everything is for the sake of the poor and the guests. It is ownerless like the house of Joab son of Zeruiah (see Sanhedrin 49a: מה מדבר הפקר לכל אף ביתו של יואב מופקר לכל - "Just as the desert is ownerless to all, so too the house of Joab was ownerless to all"). I declare it ownerless, and you can distribute everything to guests.' And he added: 'If you accustom yourself in my house to bring in guests, you will be able afterward in your house to bring in guests properly.'"
[The narrator continues:]
Years ago, while still in the lifetime of the holy Maran my master, my father [the Admor of Toldot Aharon] zt"l, I had an interesting story. I was walking in the street in Meah Shearim on the way to the Beit Midrash. A Jew driving in his car met me, stopped me, and said to me: "Presumably you are going to Toldot Aharon. Come, get in, and travel with me to the Beit Midrash." (This was a novelty to me, for usually one needs to ask someone to stop, and it is rare that someone offers on his own).
I asked him: "How is it that you do this? After all, this is not so common..."
He told me that he bought the car 12 years ago. He entered the "Beit Yisrael" of Gur zt"l before this to ask if he should buy it, because he was afraid of accidents and the like. The "Beit Yisrael" said to him: "Accept upon yourself not to go to sleep without doing a favor for a Jew with your car." And 12 years have already passed since then, and thank G-d, not once has any damage happened to me. Today, this is his last trip of the day, and he still hadn't found how to do a favor with his car. Exactly then he saw me and understood that I wanted to get to the Beit Midrash, and he wanted to take me.
Source: "BaChatzer HaKodesh", Vayechi 5762, p. 3

The custom of the holy Admor, the "Beit Yisrael" of Gur zt"l, was that every Purim he was seen to be very tense. Especially during the conducting of his pure Table, it was possible to feel the fear and Divine awe that prevailed there. In contrast to this, on the eve of Yom Kippur, during the conducting of his pure Table, signs of special joy were recognizable on him.
Once, one of his close associates asked him: "Seemingly, the matter is exactly the opposite. On Purim, which is a day of joy and gladness, he is tense. And on the eve of Yom Kippur, when everyone is trembling and afraid, he is happy?"
He answered him a terrible answer that descends and pierces the chambers of the belly: "On the eve of Yom Kippur, when everyone is found in an atmosphere of fear of sin and fear and dread of sinning, I can be calm and happy. But in contrast to this, on Purim, when the street is stormy and bustling to our sorrow, and many people who are not of high standing circulate then in the street to ambush the young of the flock—holy sheep—and cause them to sin, Heaven forbid... behold, the heart bursts from pain and worry that, Heaven forbid, no Jew should be damaged in his Judaism. If so, how can I be happy?"
Source: "Otzar HaChassidut", Adar 5758, p. 15

body_he: כ"ק הָאַדְמוֹ"ר הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" מִגּוּר זי"ע מִנְהָגוֹ בַּקֹּדֶשׁ הָיָה שֶׁכָּל פּוּרִים רָאוּ עָלָיו וְהָיָה נִכָּר בַּעֲלִיל שֶׁהוּא מָתוּחַ מְאֹד, וּבִפְרָט בְּשַׁעַת עֲרִיכַת שֻׁלְחָנוֹ הַטָּהוֹר הָיָה אֶפְשָׁר לְמַשֵּׁשׁ אֶת הַפַּחַד וְהַיִּרְאָה הָאֱלוֹקִית שֶׁשָּׁרַר שָׁם, וּלְעֻמַּת זֹאת בְּעֶרֶב יוֹם כִּיפּוּר בְּשַׁעַת עֲרִיכַת שֻׁלְחָנוֹ הַטָּהוֹר הָיָה נִכָּר עָלָיו אוֹתוֹת שֶׁל שִׂמְחָה מְיֻחָדִים. פַּעַם שְׁאָלוֹ אֶחָד מִמְּקֹרָבָיו דְּלִכְאוֹרָה הַדָּבָר מַמָּשׁ לְהִיפּוּךְ בְּפוּרִים שֶׁזֶּה יוֹם שִׂמְחָה וְחֶדְוָה, הוּא מָתוּחַ, וּבְעֶרֶב יוֹם כִּיפּוּר כְּשֶׁכֻּלָּם חֲרֵדִים וּפוֹחֲדִים הוּא שָׂמֵחַ, עָנָה לוֹ תְּשׁוּבָה נוֹרָאָה שֶׁיּוֹרֶדֶת וְנוֹקֶבֶת חַדְרֵי בֶּטֶן, בְּעֶרֶב יוֹם כְּפוֹר כְּשֶׁכֻּלָּם מְצוּיִים בְּאַטְמוֹסְפֵירָה שֶׁל יִרְאַת חֵטְא וּפַחַד וּמוֹרָא מִלַּחְטֹא, אֲנִי יָכוֹל לִהְיוֹת רָגוּעַ וְשָׂמֵחַ, אֲבָל לְעֻמַּת זֹאת בְּפוּרִים שֶׁלְּצַעֲרֵנוּ הָרְחוֹב סוֹעֵר וְגוֹעֵשׁ וְהַרְבֵּה אִינְשֵׁי דְּלָא מְעַלּוּ מִסְתּוֹבְבִים אָז בָּרְחוֹב לֶאֱרֹב לְצְעִירֵי הַצֹּאן צֹאן קָדָשִׁים וּלְהַחְטִיאָם ח"ו, הֲרֵי הַלֵּב מִתְפַּלֵּץ מִצַּעַר וּדְאָגָה שֶׁח"ו לֹא יוּזַק שׁוּם אִישׁ יְהוּדִי בְּיַהֲדוּתוֹ, אִם כֵּן אֵיךְ אֲנִי יָכוֹל לִהְיוֹת בְּשִׂמְחָה.הרה"ג ר' אהרן טויסיג שליט"א"אוצר החסידות", אדר תשנ"ח, ע' ט"ו
body_en:
...And regarding this matter of delay (Shehiya) and insulation (Hatmana), I studied it in its time in depth with the holy Admor Rabbi Yisrael Alter of Gur zt"l with the Tur Shulchan Aruch and Poskim. His opinion was as I wrote, that strictly speaking, there is no need to be stringent like the Chazon Ish zt"l not to use a swept shovel (Garufa) for Shabbat, for according to us, the ruling is established like Chananiah, and as explained in the Rama, there is no concern that one needs only a recognition (Heker) and it is sufficient with a shovel. He added reasons to this.
Incidentally, I will write a great principle that the Admor zt"l revealed to me then regarding the stringencies he imposes on himself. Even though he asked me to keep the matters secret, nevertheless, now after his passing, there is no longer a need to hide the matter. He revealed that in essence, he yearns greatly to be stringent on himself regarding all opinions and methods and concerns, and he is ready and prepared for this. Only since it is common that his customs are revealed to his Chassidim even if he tries to hide them, and many conduct themselves so after him, therefore he weighs always whether it is worthwhile for him to be stringent even for himself. Since if he is stringent, it is possible that a portion of the Chassidim will not conduct themselves like him, imagining that it is difficult. He feared that they would again not follow the customs he instituted for the many, even the important ones, imagining that he is overly stringent.
He suggested as an example the use of electricity on Shabbat, regarding which the Chazon Ish zt"l is stringent. He estimates that a portion of his Chassidim in the cities of the land will not conduct themselves so, and again they will not want to conduct themselves according to his customs even regarding important customs, imagining that he is overly stringent. Thus, his gain would be cancelled by his loss when he is stringent even for himself. (And he concluded then that he chose for himself a great rule: that the main stringencies and fences in the generation of Messiah are the rectification of the attribute of Yesod (moral purity). In this, he is specifically very stringent, and in this, he does not care even if a significant portion cannot stand it, for this is the main thing in this generation. And he said that even in this, surely he is stringent only for the future and not regarding rectifications of repentance for the past. But regarding other stringencies, the main thing is to keep according to the law of the Shulchan Aruch. And one who is stringent on himself to exit all concerns—blessing will come upon him, but without noise and in privacy specifically; this is the gist of his words).
Source: "Moadim U'Zmanim" (Bnei Brak 5741), Part 7, Siman 153, p. 3

Our Rebbe, the Beit Yisrael zt"l, taught us this thing: If the members of one's household are not pleased with his deeds, perforce he should know from this that in Heaven they are not pleased with his deeds. Let him not go in imaginations hovering on the wings of elevation, [thinking] that if only he were elevated according to the will of Heaven, the members of his household would be pleased with him.
Source: "Shnot Bikurim-Midot" (Tel Aviv 5761), p. 409

I heard from the Chassid R' Menachem Eliezer Moses Shlita: On Rosh Hashanah 5718 (1957), his father, the Chassid R' Shlomo Zalman Moses zt"l, secretary of the Action Committee of Agudat Yisrael and of the Council of Torah Sages, was in his house due to a heart attack he suffered then. He was forbidden to leave his house. On the night of Rosh Hashanah, it bothered him greatly that he could not go to the holy Maran the Admor of Gur, the "Beit Yisrael" zt"l, to bless and be blessed. The Rebbe apparently sensed this. On the day of Rosh Hashanah at six in the morning, the holy Admor of Gur arrived at his house, entered, and said to him: "R' Shlomo Zalman, יהב ליה ידיה ואוקמיה - 'He gave him his hand and raised him' (Berachot 5b). You could not come to me to say 'A Gut Yohr' (A Good Year), so I came to you to bless you with 'A Gut Gebentsht Yohr' (A Good Blessed Year)." This visit literally revived him.
R' Shlomo Hersh Weiss stood there. After R' Shlomo Zalman Moses zt"l passed away, R' Shlomo Hersh Weiss would arrive every year on the Yahrtzeit of R' Shlomo Zalman, saying that this is the Yahrtzeit of a Jew to whom the Rebbe, the Beit Yisrael, arrived an hour before the prayer on Rosh Hashanah, so this indicates his greatness.
Source: "Kochavei Ohr", Ki Tavo 5766, p. 3

He also told that his uncle, Rabbi Refael Horowitz zt"l, used to travel many times a year on a "Nesiya" (journey) to the holy Maran the Admor, the "Beit Yisrael" zt"l, and would lodge with his brother-in-law, Rabbi Shlomo Zalman Moses zt"l. On Shabbat Chanukah 5724 (1963), he was still with him. R' Shlomo Zalman passed away on the 11th of Tevet 5724. Therefore, when he wanted to travel for Shabbat Mevarchim Shevat, he wanted to change lodgings because of the question of Yichud (seclusion with the widow), for behold, they travel to the Rebbe for a "Nesiya" without their wives.
Therefore, he entered the Rebbe of Gur and asked if he should change lodgings to the house of his relative, Rabbi Elimelech Luksenburg. The Rebbe of Gur said to him: "It is enough that she received one blow (meaning the passing of her husband). Do you want to give her another blow (by stopping to lodge with her)? You can come to me for the 'Nesiya' with your wife—her sister—and Heaven forbid you should change lodgings."
Source: "Kochavei Ohr", Ki Tavo 5766, p. 3

I heard several times from the holy Maran, the holy Admor of Gur zt"l, at the time I gave him my books as a gift. He said: "Regarding books, [the verse] 'He who hates gifts shall live' (Proverbs 15:27) does not apply." But he did not say the reason.
Source: "Responsa Shraga HaMeir", Part 3, Siman 90

body_he: הגאון רבי נתן איינפלד שליט"א"מנחת נתן" (ב"ב תשס"ז) ח"א, ע' קי"ט
body_en:
The Rebbe, the "Beis Yisrael", would visit Hadassah Hospital a number of times a year to fulfill the Mitzvah of visiting the sick among his relatives, Chassidim, or public and Torah figures. Before every visit, the Rebbe would drive to my house and pick me up in his car to conduct the visit together with me! All my pleas before him not to trouble himself, and all my explanations that I could reach the hospital on my own, did not help at all. "I need you," said the Rebbe, "and therefore I must come to you!" The truth is, that when the Admor of Ger wants to visit the hospital, he doesn't exactly need the Rabbi's help... but his wish was to honor me, 'so that the hospital knows the Rebbe needs the Rav'!... And indeed, you can imagine for yourself the excitement and commotion that was felt in the entire neighborhood when the Rebbe and his entourage arrived. Also, when he walked around the hospital, like an electric current passed through the corridors; everyone stopped their work and stood to gaze at his holy figure.
One time, as I accompanied him in the corridor, we saw two of the senior professors at that time – Halperin and Rachmilevitz. When they noticed the Rebbe, they fell silent and signaled to me that they wished to meet him. The Rebbe asked me who they were, and when I answered, he reacted – if these are they, I must meet them. Professor Halperin said to the Rebbe – I am the grandson of the "Oneg Yom Tov". Immediately the Rebbe asked – And what connection do you have to him? The professor answered – His picture hangs on my wall everywhere I work... The Rebbe's reaction-demand was – "And for the sake of his soul, what are you doing?! Do you walk in his ways?!" Rachmilevitz also had to say something, and therefore he said to the Rebbe - In my name, there is the word *Rachamim* (Mercy). Nu, remarked the Rebbe, Halperin spoke simply, you are already speaking *Pshettlech* (convoluted explanations)...
I also merited to be at the terrible event of the departure of his pure soul on the first day, 2nd of Adar 5737 (1977), after he was hospitalized for a full day at Hadassah Hospital. I also tried, as the "small one," to assist the senior medical team that labored with all its might for the Rebbe's recovery, but the decree was sealed and the "Beis Yisrael" returned his soul to its Creator.
Source: HaRav HaGaon R' Yaakov Man Rakovsky zt"l (From the notes of HaRav HaChassid R' Yisrael Pinchas Tirnauer Hy"u), "Olam HaChassidut", Nissan 5766, p. 12

I merited to be present at the time of the baking of Matzot of our Rabbi, the "Beit Yisrael" of Gur zt"l (in the exquisite bakery of R' Leibel Slonim zt"l in the Beit Yisrael neighborhood of Jerusalem), together with many more Chassidim from our people who flocked to participate in this event. Our Rabbi zt"l walked back and forth, his face aflame, and his open eye was upon all the workers and their actions, ensuring everything would be with surplus Kashrut and beauty.
Behold, I saw him approach the first man who kneads the flour and water into dough. The man extended his palms towards him to show they were clean perfectly. However, our Rabbi zt"l, after checking the hands, added and asked him in these words: "Do you also have a clean heart?! Do you also have clean eyes?!" Upon hearing the piercing question, the simple man turned pale and was very frightened. However, our Rabbi did not wait for his answer and in the blink of an eye moved away from him and onwards, only his question continued to echo in the space of the air.
Source: "Minchat Natan" (Bnei Brak 5767), Part 1, p. 119

Indeed, such caution our Rabbi instituted in the baking of his Matzot: it is not enough to wash the hands; one must also contain a pure heart and pure eyes...
Source: "Minchat Natan" (Bnei Brak 5767), Part 1, p. 119

Once I was on Purim with my teacher and Rabbi, the Gaon (Rabbi Shmuel Ehrenfeld), the Mattersdorfer Rav zt"l. He himself told me that he was once in the Land of Israel in the month of Elul and wanted to return abroad for the High Holy Days. He had swelling in his leg, may we be spared, and could not walk. They did not allow him to walk, and he remained in the Holy Land for Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur. Also on Sukkot, he was in his house and could not enter the Sukkah.
When Hoshana Rabba arrived, the "Beit Yisrael" of Gur arrived to visit him. Immediately when he entered, he said to him: "Mattersdorfer Rav, get down from your bed!" He answered: "Gerer Rebbe, I cannot, and I am forbidden to move..."
The "Beit Yisrael" said to him again: "Mattersdorfer Rav, get down from your bed: It is stated (Sukkah 47a) שמיני עצרת רגל בפני עצמו - 'Shemini Atzeret is a festival (Regel) unto itself!'" [A play on words: Regel means festival, but also leg. Meaning: The leg stands on its own].
"I got up and went down from the bed, and I even fulfilled the Mitzvah of Sukkah."
Source: "BaChatzer HaKodesh", Emor 5762, p. 1

My Rebbe was truly the Rebbe, the "Beit Yisrael." Many things passed through his way. He was once by me to visit because the doctors worried me that I needed to lie down and not get out of bed, and they spoke about heart problems, Heaven forbid.
When he came here in the house, in this room, he grabbed my hand and said to me strongly: "Tolner Rebbe, doctors say worrying things. In Heaven, they know better than them, and there they say you have nothing in your heart! You have a good and healthy heart, and there is nothing to worry about!"
The things were said with such confidence, as if words "In Heaven they know better and say there," he revealed that he knows what is in Heaven. Naturally, I immediately recovered and did not listen to the voice of the doctors, and I got out of bed.
Source: "Ki Chaim Hem LeMotza'eihem" (Jerusalem 5761), p. 78

Rabbi Zvi Yitzchak Abramowitz *zt"l* told me about a Jew, a Talmid Chacham who was close to the Beis Yisrael *zy"a*, whose wife became very ill and nearly lost her mind. He had already decided to divorce her and marry another, as they could not establish a Jewish home together. This caused the Rebbe *zy"a* great pain. Since Rabbi Abramowitz *zt"l* was on close friendly terms with that Jew, when he once entered the inner sanctum, the Beis Yisrael *zy"a* said to him with great pain on his face: "Don't you know that they are already holding before a *Get* (divorce)..."
The Rabbi told me that he gathered courage and said aloud: "Can't the Rebbe work on this? As per the language of Tosafot in Yevamot, **כי רחמי ש-ד-י מרובים** - 'For the mercies of the Almighty are abundant'..." At that moment, a great change occurred in the face of the Rebbe *zy"a*, and he said to him: "I know which Tosafot you are referring to" (see Yevamot 65b, Tosafot *s.v.* Ki Ha, at the end of the entry, where they wrote in the name of the Ritzba's responsum regarding a specific trouble ending in marriage matters, "that she should not rush to destroy her building [home], for the mercies of the Almighty are abundant").
The Rebbe repeated this phrase several times: "For the mercies of the Almighty are abundant," and dismissed him in peace. The Rabbi *zt"l* concluded and said to me: "Understand for yourself, that by the merit of that Tzaddik's prayer, that woman began to heal immediately after that, until she completely emerged from all her illness, and she and her husband established a complete family."
The Rabbi *zt"l* told me that it seemed to him the reason the Ritzba specifically used this Holy Name, the name *Shaddai* (Almighty), is because this name is conducive for fruitfulness and multiplication, as is found in the Baal HaTurim on the verse: **אני אל ש-ד-י פרה ורבה** - "I am G-d Almighty, be fruitful and multiply" (Genesis 35:11; Exodus 6:3). And I added that in the Sugya there (Yevamot 65b), this verse is indeed brought to derive that the man is commanded regarding fruitfulness and multiplication. [Years later I found in the books of the Maggid of Kozhnitz *zy"a* in two places (Remzei Yisrael, beginning of Hagahot to Etz Chaim; Ner Yisrael Likutim Rav Hai Gaon letter 49) that he brought the language of the aforementioned Tosafot, and wrote that they specifically used this name because of the story brought there in their words, and as is found in Rashi on the portion of Vayechi (49:25) on the verse **ברכות שדים ורחם** - "Blessings of the breast and womb," which hints at this matter. And this is sufficient for the understanding.]
Source: From the notes of HaRav HaGaon R' Michael Aryeh Rand Shlita, "HaModia-Tosefet", 12 Shevat 5769, p. 18

וְאָמַר לִי הָרַב זַצַ"ל כִּי נִרְאֶה לוֹ שֶׁהַטַּעַם שֶׁנָּקַט הָרִיצְבָּ"א בִּלְשׁוֹנוֹ דַּוְקָא שֵׁם קָדוֹשׁ זֶה, שֵׁם שַׁ-דַּ-י, כִּי שֵׁם זֶה מְסֻגָּל לְפוּ"ר [לְפִרְיָה וּרְבִיָּה], כְּדְאִיתָא בְּבַעַל הַטּוּרִים עַל הַפָּסוּק אֲנִי אֵל שַׁ-דַּ-י פְּרֵה וּרְבֵה (בראשית לה, יא; שמות ו, ג). וְהוֹסַפְתִּי שֶׁבַּסּוּגְיָא שָׁם (יבמות סה, ב) הוּבָא בֶּאֱמֶת פָּסוּק זֶה לֵילַף מִמֶּנּוּ שֶׁהָאִישׁ מְצֻוֶּה עַל פְּרִיָּה וּרְבִיָּה [אַחַר שָׁנִים מָצָאתִי בְּסִפְרֵי הַמַּגִּיד מִקּוֹזְ'נִיץ זִי"עַ בְּב' מְקוֹמוֹת (רמזי ישראל ריש ההגה' לפע"ח; נר ישראל ליקוטי רב האי גאון אות מט) שֶׁהֵבִיא לְשׁוֹן הַתּוֹס' הָאָמוּר, וְכָתַב שֶׁנָּקְטוּ דַּוְקָא שֵׁם זֶה מִפְּנֵי הַמַּעֲשֶׂה שֶׁהוּבָא שָׁם בְּדִבְרֵיהֶם, וּכְדְאִיתָא בְּרַשִׁ"י פָּרָשַׁת וַיְחִי (מט, כה) עַל הַפָּסוּק בִּרְכוֹת "שָׁדַיִם" וָרַחַם שֶׁרוֹמֵז עַל עִנְיָן זֶה. וְאכ"מ].
מרשימות הרה"ג ר' מיכאל אריה ראנד שליט"א"המודיע-תוספת", י"ב שבט תשס"ט, ע' י"ח
body_en:
We saw the Ruach HaKodesh (Divine Inspiration) that appeared in his Beis Medrash (of the Rebbe, the "Beis Yisrael" of Ger *zt"l*) at every step and turn. Miracles rolled under his table, but the Rebbe of Kotzk *zy"a* said that the greatest miracle is to instill *Yirat Shamayim* (Fear of Heaven) in the heart of a Jew, and this is what the Rebbe *zt"l* did—he instilled *Yirat Shamayim* in thousands of hearts.
The Rebbe knew what was happening with everyone. I testify upon myself by Heaven and Earth that I clearly saw many times that he recognized everyone's deeds. He always hid this knowledge and conduct under some fact or mask, but we knew the truth. I remember once, someone entered with his hat tilted back on his forehead. The Rebbe *zt"l* said to him: "Even when the hat is on the forehead, I recognize on you what you are doing..."
Many things were not understood at the time of his actions, and only after many years passed were the results seen. He used to say in the name of the Rama of Pano on the verse: **ותמונת ה' יביט** - "And he beholds the image of the L-rd" (Numbers 12:8), that Moshe Rabbeinu, peace be upon him, had "a *himeldige blick*" (a Heavenly view/gaze). "The simplicity of Moshe is in every generation." This was his conduct, and in a special way, he drew many people close—even those who were not Chassidim and not Torah scholars—and afterwards, fruits were seen, when their children were already good. This was his work for the youth, that they should be drawn to the way of Torah, Chassidut, and good character traits, a matter about which he spoke much, that one cannot do enough to educate for good character traits.
Source: Faithful of his house, HaRav HaChassid R' Chanina Schiff z"l, "Rava D'Amieh" (Jerusalem 5762) p. 54

הָרַבִּי יָדַע מַה נַּעֲשָׂה אֵצֶל כָּל אֶחָד. וּמֵעִיד אֲנִי עָלַי שָׁמַיִם וָאָרֶץ שֶׁרָאִיתִי בַּעֲלִיל הַרְבֵּה פְּעָמִים שֶׁהִכִּיר עַל כָּל אֶחָד מַעֲשָׂיו. תָּמִיד הִסְתִּיר יְדִיעָתוֹ וְהַנְהָגָתוֹ זוֹ תַּחַת אֵיזוֹ עֻבְדָּה אוֹ מַסְוֶה, אֲבָל יָדַעְנוּ הָאֱמֶת. זְכוּרַנִי, פַּעַם נִכְנַס אֵלָיו אֶחָד עִם כּוֹבָעוֹ שָׁמוּט עַל מִצְחוֹ, אָמַר לוֹ הָרַבִּי זַצַ"ל: "גַּם כְּשֶׁכּוֹבַע עַל הַמֵּצַח אֲנִי מַכִּיר עָלֶיךָ מַה שֶּׁאַתָּה עוֹשֶׂה"...
בְּהַרְבֵּה דְּבָרִים לֹא הֵבִינוּ אֶת מַעֲשָׂיו וְרַק אַחֲרֵי עֲבוֹר שָׁנִים הַרְבֵּה רָאוּ הַתּוֹצָאוֹת. הָיָה אוֹמֵר מִשְּׁמוֹ שֶׁל הָרַמַ"ע מִפָּאנוֹ עה"פ: "וּתְמוּנַת ה' יַבִּיט", שֶׁמֹּשֶׁה רַבֵּנוּ ע"ה הָיָה לוֹ "אַ הִימֶלְדִיגֶע בְּלִיק", רְאִיָּה שְׁמֵימִית. "אִתְפַּשְׁטוּתָא דְּמֹשֶׁה בְּכָל דָּרָא וְדָרָא". זוֹ הָיְתָה הַנְהָגָתוֹ, וּבְאֹפֶן מְיֻחָד קֵרֵב הַרְבֵּה אֲנָשִׁים גַּם לֹא חֲסִידִים וְלֹא תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים וְאַחַ"כּ נִרְאוּ פֵּרוֹת, כַּאֲשֶׁר יַלְדֵיהֶם כְּבָר הָיוּ טוֹבִים. זוֹ הָיְתָה עֲבוֹדָתוֹ בַּעֲבוּר הַצְּעִירִים שֶׁיִּמָּשְׁכוּ לְדֶרֶךְ הַתּוֹרָה וְהַחֲסִידוּת וּמִדּוֹת טוֹבוֹת, דָּבָר עָלָיו דִּבֵּר הַרְבֵּה שֶׁאֵין עוֹשִׂים דַּי לְחַנֵּךְ לְמִדּוֹת טוֹבוֹת.
נאמן ביתו הרה"ח ר' חנינא שיף ז"ל"רבא דעמיה" (ירושלים תשס"ב) ע' נ"ד

The Gaon Rabbi Baruch Sorotzkin *zt"l* had [the terrible illness, and lived with it] for seventeen years. Gur Chassidim relate that the Admor, the Beis Yisrael *zy"a*, met with the Gaon Rabbi Zalman Sorotzkin *zt"l*, who was the chairman of the Council of Torah Sages, and he told the Admor about the health condition of his son, Rabbi Baruch mentioned above. The Admor, who usually spoke in Yiddish, said to Rabbi Zalman in Hebrew using the spoken tongue: "Yihyeh Tov!" (It will be good!). It was a wonder what the Admor saw to speak in such a style, but after seventeen years, the aforementioned understood that the Admor meant that it would be "Tov" (Good), which in Gematria equals 17!
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Natan Einfeld Shlita, "Minchat Natan" (Bnei Brak 5767) Part 1, p. 80

On the day of the "Shiva" [for the passing of the "Beis Yisrael" *zy"a*], when [HaRav HaChassid Rabbi Zvi Yitzchak Abramowitz *zt"l*] entered among the comforters, his brother, who filled his place, the Rebbe the Lev Simcha *zy"a*, said to him: "Zei mechazek alle, m'hat unz ginumen a korban far alle, Yosef HaTzaddik" (Be strong everyone, they have taken a sacrifice from us for everyone, Yosef HaTzaddik).
Source: Rabbi Yisrael Rubinstein Hy"u, "HaModia", 12 Shevat 5769, p. 12

The following story was told to the editors of the book ["HaGaon HaChassid"] by HaRav HaChassid R' Meir Heine *shlita*:
"In the month of Elul 5740 (1980), I met HaRav HaChassid R' Yisrael Chaim Ginzburg *zt"l* in the street, and he told me with great emotion that he was returning from the house of the Rebbe, the 'Beis Yisrael'. I noticed that R' Yisrael Chaim was very agitated and asked him if this was the first time he had entered the Rebbe's room. Then he told me a terrible story:
'Last night I saw in my dream that my time had come to depart from the world, and they were bringing me up before the Heavenly Court for judgment. Suddenly, I saw in my dream that my Rebbe, the author of the 'Beis Yisrael' of Ger *zt"l*, arrived—who was then, of course, among the living [in the context of the story's timeline]—and requested from the Heavenly Court that they give him another half year to live. With this, the terrible dream ended.
This morning, when R' Yisrael Chaim woke up agitated from his dream, he rushed to pray Shacharit in the Rebbe's Beis Medrash, and after the prayer, he passed before the Rebbe, who said to him – 'Yishar Koach' (Strength to you)!
The Rebbe, it seemed, understood and returned a smile; no one else knew what had occurred behind the scenes.'
R' Yisrael Chaim *zt"l* passed away about half a year later, on the 17th of Adar 5710 (1950)."
Source: "HaGaon HaChassid" (Jerusalem 5771) p. 352

'בְּלֵיל אֶמֶשׁ רָאָה בַּחֲלוֹמוֹ שֶׁמַּגִּיעַ זְמַנּוֹ לְהִפָּטֵר מֵהָעוֹלָם וּמַעֲלִים אוֹתוֹ לִפְנֵי בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל מַעְלָה, לְדוּנוֹ. לְפֶתַע רָאָה בַּחֲלוֹמוֹ, שֶׁמַּגִּיעַ רַבּוֹ, בַּעַל הַ'בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל' מִגּוּר זַצַ"ל, שֶׁהָיָה אָז כַּמּוּבָן בֵּין הַחַיִּים, וּבִקֵּשׁ מִבֵּית הַדִּין שֶׁל מַעְלָה שֶׁיִּתְּנוּ לוֹ עוֹד חֲצִי שָׁנָה לִחְיוֹת. בָּזֶה נִסְתַּיֵּם הַחֲלוֹם הַנּוֹרָא.
הַבֹּקֶר כְּשֶׁקָּם ר' יִשְׂרָאֵל-חַיִּים נִסְעָר מֵחֲלוֹמוֹ, אָץ לְהִתְפַּלֵּל שַׁחֲרִית בְּבֵית מִדְרָשׁוֹ שֶׁל הָרַבִּי, וְאַחַר הַתְּפִילָה עָבַר לִפְנֵי הָרַבִּי וְאָמַר לוֹ – 'יִישַׁר כּוֹחַ'!
הָרַבִּי, נִרְאָה שֶׁהֵבִין וְהֵשִׁיב חִיּוּךְ, אִישׁ זוּלָתָם לֹא יָדַע מַה הִתְרַחֵשׁ מֵאֲחוֹרֵי הַדְּבָרִים'."ר' יִשְׂרָאֵל-חַיִּים זַ"ל נִפְטַר כַּחֲצִי שָׁנָה לְאַחַר מִכֵּן, בְּי"ז בַּאֲדָר תַּשַׁ"י.
"הגאון החסיד" (ירושלים תשע"א) ע' 352

...In those blessed years, [HaRav HaChassid Rabbi Zvi Yitzchak Abramowitz *zt"l*, the Rav of Chatzor] merited to spend much time in the shadow of his Rebbe [the "Beis Yisrael" of Ger *zy"a*], at the holy Friday night meals and at the great Kiddush, at his table and in personal conversations. These experiences melted into his being like good oil, and in times of favor, he would recount them with full description of every detail regarding the love of the holy. Here is one of them as heard from his mouth:
A female relative of my mother, may she live (from the side of R' Mendel Kaminer, and thus also a relative of the Rebbe), passed away. That woman did not walk in the way of Torah all her days, as happened to many in that era, to the sorrow of the heart. At that time, I arranged a "travel" to the Rebbe. During a break on Friday night, I was called to his room, and the Rebbe began to investigate and ask about that deceased woman. The first questions were understandable, but after them came questions that had no explanation (such as what floor she lived on). I sensed that the Rebbe was aiming for something specific, and therefore when the Rebbe fell silent for a moment, I utilized the pause and said on my own initiative that in her last years she had improved her ways. Or then, the Rebbe shook himself and said to me: You have nothing to worry about, everything will be fine, and he dismissed me in peace. Then I realized that the purpose of the conversation was for me to speak well of her, and thus the Rebbe could work to rectify her soul. I gave thanks to Hashem Yitbarach, who granted me the wisdom to say what was required.
Source: "Zvi Tiferet" (Jerusalem 5771) p. 181

קְרוֹבַת מִשְׁפָּחָה שֶׁל אִמִּי תִּחְיֶה, (מִצַּד ר' מֶענְדְל קָמִינֶר, וּמִמֵּילָא גַּם קְרוֹבָה שֶׁל הָרַבִּי) הָלְכָה לְעוֹלָמָהּ. אוֹתָהּ אִשָּׁה לֹא הָלְכָה כָּל יָמֶיהָ בְּדֶרֶךְ הַתּוֹרָה, כְּפִי שֶׁאֵרַע לְרַבִּים בְּאוֹתָהּ תְּקוּפָה לְדַאֲבוֹן הַלֵּב. בְּאוֹתוֹ זְמַן עָרַכְתִּי "נְסִיעָה" אֶל הָרַבִּי. בְּהַפְסָקָה בְּלֵיל שַׁבָּת נִקְרֵאתִי אֵלָיו לְחַדְרוֹ, וְהָרַבִּי הֵחֵל לַחְקֹר וְלִשְׁאוֹל אוֹדוֹת אוֹתָהּ נִפְטֶרֶת. הַשְּׁאֵלוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנוֹת הָיוּ מוּבָנוֹת, אַךְ אַחֲרֵיהֶן בָּאוּ שְׁאֵלוֹת שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה לָהֶן שׁוּם הֶסְבֵּר (כְּגוֹן בְּאֵיזוֹ קוֹמָה הִיא גָּרָה). חַשְׁתִּי כִּי הָרַבִּי חוֹתֵר לְמַשֶּׁהוּ מְסֻיָּם, וְלָכֵן כַּאֲשֶׁר הָרַבִּי הֶחֱרִישׁ לְרֶגַע, נִצַּלְתִּי אֶת הָאֶתְנַחְתָּא וְאָמַרְתִּי בְּיָזְמָתִי, שֶׁבִּשְׁנוֹתֶיהָ הָאַחֲרוֹנוֹת הֵיטִיבָה אֶת דְּרָכֶיהָ. אוֹ אָז נִנְעַר הָרַבִּי וְאָמַר לִי: אֵין לְךָ מַה לִּדְאֹג, הַכֹּל יִהְיֶה בְּסֵדֶר, וּפְטָר אוֹתִי לְשָׁלוֹם. אָז נוֹכַחְתִּי לָדַעַת כִּי מַטְּרַת הַשִּׂיחָה הָיְתָה כְּדֵי שֶׁאַמְלִיץ טוֹב בַּעֲדָהּ, וְכָךְ יוּכַל הָרַבִּי לִפְעֹל לְתִקּוּן נִשְׁמָתָהּ. נָתַתִּי תּוֹדָה לַהֲשִׁי"ת, שֶׁחָנַן אוֹתִי בִּינָה לוֹמַר אֶת הַמִּתְבַּקֵּשׁ.
"צבי תפארת" (ירושלים תשע"א) ע' קפ"א
body_en:
It is fitting to mention some of the things that [the Admor, the "Beis Yisrael" of Ger *zt"l*] would say to the *bochurim* (young men) who came to him to seek Hashem, and all his words almost held the majority. There is what he said to *bochurim*, and especially to those learning, he said: "One who says a teaching must have the owner of the teaching standing before him, as it is said: **אך בצלם יתהלך איש** - 'Only in an image does a man walk' (Psalms 39:7)." This should be understood to mean that not every young man will see the form of the Tanna or Amora whose teaching is being said in their name, but rather one must pay attention and believe that the holiness of the owner of the teaching shines upon us at this hour when we are learning his teaching. And certainly, this matter must awaken a feeling of Fear of Heaven, as he sometimes concluded: "From when one opens the Gemara until one closes it - one must not speak a single word; how can one chat when Abaye and Rava are standing before us? (From the moment one opens the Gemara until closing it, it is forbidden to speak a single word; how is it possible to speak when Abaye and Rava are standing before us?)"
From another *bochur*, I heard that he said to him: "One must serve the One Above with joy (one needs to serve G-d with joy), for **מלא כל הארץ כבודו** - 'The whole earth is full of His glory' (Isaiah 6:3)," and this was a simple *bochur* with no great intellect and not excelling in Chassidut. And I remember how that *bochur* described with excitement his special gesture of the Admor *zt"l* and his shining face when he said these words to him...
I heard from HaRav HaChassid R' Shmuel Lukever *zt"l* that once in his youth, the Admor *zt"l* said to him: "King Solomon walked around day and night, and asked **להטות לבבנו אליו** - 'To incline our hearts to Him' (I Kings 8:58)." And those who seek Hashem will understand the taste of this request.
Source: HaRav HaChassid R' Mordechai Mayrenz Shlita, "Al Mishkenot HaRo'im" (Bnei Brak 5759) p. 40

body_he:
מִפִּי בָּחוּר אַחֵר שָׁמַעְתִּי שֶׁאָמַר לוֹ: "מֶען דַּארְף דִּינֶען דֶּעם אֵייבֶּערְשְׁטֶען בְּשִׂמְחָה (צָרִיךְ לַעֲבֹד אֶת ד' בְּשִׂמְחָה) כִּי מְלוֹא כָל הָאָרֶץ כְּבוֹדוֹ", וְזֶה הָיָה בָּחוּר פָּשׁוּט לֹא בַּעַל מֹחַ וְלֹא הִצְטַיֵּן בַּחֲסִידוּת. וְזוֹכְרַנִי כֵּיצַד תֵּאֵר הַבָּחוּר הַלָּז בְּהִתְפַּעֲלוּת אֶת תְּנוּעָתוֹ הַמְיֻחֶדֶת שֶׁל מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר זַצַ"ל וְאֶת פָּנָיו הַמְּאִירִים בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁאָמַר לוֹ מִלִּים אֵלֶּה...
שָׁמַעְתִּי מִפִּי הרה"ח ר' שְׁמוּאֵל לוּקֶעוֶוער זַ"ל שֶׁפַּעַם בְּבַחֲרוּתוֹ אָמַר לוֹ אַדְמוֹ"ר זַצַ"ל: "שְׁלֹמֹה הַמֶּלֶךְ אִיז אַרוּם גֶעגַאנְגֶען טָאג אוּן נַאכְט, אוּן הָאט גֶעבֶּעטְן 'לְהַטּוֹת לְבָבֵינוּ אֵלָיו'" (שְׁלֹמֹה הַמֶּלֶךְ הִתְהַלֵּךְ יוֹמָם וָלַיְלָה וּבִקֵּשׁ 'לְהַטּוֹת לְבָבֵינוּ אֵלָיו'). וּמְבַקְשֵׁי ה' יָבִינוּ טַעַם בַּקָּשָׁה זוֹ.
הרה"ח ר' מרדכי מיירנץ שליט"א"על משכנות הרועים" (ב"ב תשנ"ט) עמ' מ'
body_en:
We saw a great deal with the Admor, the Beis Yisrael *zt"l*, when we merited to learn in the Kollel for outstanding scholars that he maintained in his Beis Medrash. He demanded daily lists of time-keeping with precision to the minute, and he would supervise day by day personally or through his attendant. Also afterwards, when I merited to establish the Kollel in 5731 (1971) on his mission, he would follow the strictness of time-keeping, and sometimes he surprised us with his presence near the entrance of the Kollel at the designated hour for the start of the *Seder* (learning session), holding his watch in his hand to rebuke the *Avreichim* who were a few minutes late.
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Nachum Rotstein Shlita, Rosh Yeshivat "Nezer HaTorah", "Avnei Zikaron" (Jerusalem 5752) Part 2, p. 216

body_he: הגאון רבי נחום רוטשטיין שליט"אראש ישיבת "נזר התורה""אבני זכרון" (ירושלים תשנ"ב) ח"ב, ע' רט"ז
body_en:
A Yeshiva student from the USA wrote to his friend who was studying in the Mir Yeshiva in Jerusalem, saying that lately thoughts of heresy were troubling him, and doubts in faith were undermining his peace of mind, and he did not know how to rid himself of this. The friend entered the Beis Yisrael to ask for advice (this was in Shevat 5737/1977, the last month of the Beis Yisrael's life). The Rebbe told him to write to his friend that he should say "Amen Yehei Shmei Rabba" in a loud voice, for they said in the Gemara: **כל העונה אמן יהא שמיה רבא בכל כוחו אפילו יש בו שמץ של עבודה זרה מוחלין לו** - "Anyone who answers 'Amen, May His Great Name be blessed' with all his strength, even if he has a trace of idolatry in him, he is forgiven" (Shabbat 119b). And if this is effective even for one who has a trace of idolatry in him, it will certainly be effective for him. The Rebbe added that he should write to his friend to publicize this also to his friends.
The matter was a wonder, for it is known that the Rebbe's way was to hide his words, and especially regarding miracles and the like, he was very careful not to reveal anything. Yet here, he commanded him to publicize this.
However, when the letter arrived in the USA, the Beis Yisrael was no longer in the world. Then they understood why he commanded him to publicize this, so that it would be effective even after he was no longer here, *zy"a*...
After the passing of the Beis Yisrael *zt"l*, his brother, the Pnei Menachem *zt"l*, asked me if I knew his brother, the Rebbe. I answered that I knew him a little. He said to me: It seems to you that you knew him... I will tell you one detail about him, and you will understand everything. I followed every movement of his and saw wonderful things. However, during prayer, I could not observe because I had to pray. Therefore, for a certain period, I used to pray early so that I could observe him during the time of prayer. Sometimes, when they said *Ish"r* [Amen Yehei Shmei Rabba], they saw him wrapping himself in his Tallit and turning around in a storm towards the children who were crowded behind him, calling out to them aloud "Amen Yehei Shmei Rabba". The world thought his intention was to awaken them and urge them to answer *Ish"r* loudly, but with my own eyes, I saw that the reason was completely different. When he reached the answering of "Amen Yehei Shmei Rabba", he was entirely burning like a flame of fire, as is known in the holy Zohar regarding the magnitude of the virtue of answering *Ish"r*. In order that those standing around him would not notice the storm of his soul, he would turn around in a sharp turn backwards, and used these movements to blur and hide his enthusiasm.
Source: HaRav HaChassid R' Moshe Ludmir Shlita, "Yagdil Torah" (Jerusalem 5768) Part 1, p. 11

body_he:
הַדָּבָר הָיָה לְפֶלֶא, שֶׁהֲרֵי יָדוּעַ שֶׁדַּרְכּוֹ שֶׁל הָרַבִּי הָיְתָה לְהַסְתִּיר דְּבָרָיו, וּבְעִיקָּר מוֹפְתִים וְכַדּוֹמֶה הָיָה מַזְהִיר מְאֹד שֶׁלֹּא לְגַלּוֹת, וְכָאן עוֹד צִוָּהוּ לְפַרְסֵם זֹאת.
אוּלָם כַּאֲשֶׁר הִגִּיעַ הַמִּכְתָּב לְארה"ב כְּבָר לֹא הָיָה הַבֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל בָּעוֹלָם, אָז הֵבִינוּ מַדּוּעַ צִוָּהוּ לְפַרְסֵם זֹאת, שֶׁיּוֹעִיל גַּם לְאַחַר שֶׁלֹּא יִהְיֶה כָּאן, זִיעַ"א...
אַחַר פְּטִירָתוֹ שֶׁל מָרָן הַבֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל זַצַ"ל שְׁאָלַנִי אָחִיו כ"ק הַפְּנֵי מְנַחֵם זַצַ"ל אִם הִכַּרְתִּי אֶת אָחִיו הָרַבִּי? עָנִיתִי הִכַּרְתִּיו קְצָת. אָמַר לִי: נִדְמֶה לְךָ שֶׁהִכַּרְתָּ אוֹתוֹ... אֲסַפֵּר לְךָ פְּרָט אֶחָד מִמֶּנּוּ תָּבִין עַל הַכֹּל. עָקַבְתִּי אַחַר כָּל תְּנוּעָה שֶׁלּוֹ וְרָאִיתִי דְּבָרִים נִפְלָאִים, בְּרַם, בִּשְׁעַת הַתְּפִילָה לֹא יָכֹלְתִּי לְהִתְבּוֹנֵן שֶׁהֲרֵי צָרִיךְ הָיִיתִי לְהִתְפַּלֵּל. לָכֵן, בִּתְקוּפָה מְסֻיֶּמֶת נָהַגְתִּי לְהִתְפַּלֵּל בְּהַשְׁכָּמָה כְּדֵי שֶׁאוּכַל בִּשְׁעַת הַתְּפִילָה לְהִתְבּוֹנֵן בִּתְפִילָתוֹ. פְּעָמִים בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁאָמְרוּ אִישַׁ"ר [אָמֵן יְהֵא שְׁמֵיהּ רַבָּא] רָאוּ אוֹתוֹ מִתְעַטֵּף בְּטַלִּיתוֹ וּמִסְתּוֹבֵב בִּסְעָרָה לְעֵבֶר הַיְלָדִים שֶׁהִצְטוֹפְפוּ מֵאֲחוֹרָיו כְּשֶׁהוּא קוֹרֵא לְעֶבְרָם בְּקוֹל "אָמֵן יְהֵא שְׁמֵיהּ רַבָּא", הָעוֹלָם הָיוּ סְבוּרִים שֶׁכַּוָּנָתוֹ לְעוֹרְרָם וּלְזָרְזָם שֶׁיַּעֲנוּ אִישַׁ"ר בְּקוֹל רָם, אַךְ בְּעֵינַי רָאִיתִי שֶׁהַסִּבָּה הָיְתָה אַחֶרֶת לְגַמְרֵי. כְּשֶׁהִגִּיעַ לַעֲנִיַּית אָמֵן יְהֵא שְׁמֵיהּ רַבָּא הָיָה כֻּלּוֹ בּוֹעֵר כְּאֵשׁ לֶהָבָה, כַּיָּדוּעַ בְּזוֹהַ"ק גּוֹדֶל מַעֲלַת עֲנִיַּית אִישַׁ"ר, וּכְדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יַבְחִינוּ הָעוֹמְדִים סְבִיבוֹ בְּסַעֲרַת נַפְשׁוֹ, הָיָה מִסְתּוֹבֵב בְּסִיבוּב חַד לְאָחוֹר, וְהִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ בִּתְנוּעוֹת אֵלּוּ לְטַשְׁטֵשׁ וּלְהַסְווֹת אֶת הִתְלַהֲבוּתוֹ.
הרה"ח ר' משה לודמיר שליט"א"יגדיל תורה" (ירושלים תשס"ח) ח"א, ע' י"א
body_en:
I heard once from the veteran Mashgiach, the Chassid Rabbi Mendel Weissblum [*zt"l*] (Shlita), that if our Rebbe, the "Beis Yisrael" *zt"l*, urges and enthuses and warns so much about eating in holiness, then this is the first thing we must instill in the youth.
Source: HaRav HaGaon R' Yedidya Brandsdorfer Shlita, "Shnot Bikurim-Middot" (Tel Aviv 5761) p. 220

בְּאַחַת הַפְּעָמִים כְּשֶׁלִּוִּיתִיו בַּמִּסְדְּרוֹן רָאִינוּ שְׁנַיִם מִבְּכִירֵי הַפְּרוֹפֶסוֹרִים בְּאוֹתָהּ עֵת – הַלְפֶּרִין וְרַחְמִילֶבִיץ'. כְּשֶׁהִבְחִינוּ בָּרַבִּי הֵם הִשְׁתַּתְּקוּ וְרָמְזוּ לִי שֶׁבִּרְצוֹנָם לְהִיפָּגֵשׁ עִמּוֹ. הָרַבִּי שְׁאָלַנִי מִי הֵם, וּכְשֶׁעָנִיתִי, הֵגִיב – אִם אֵלּוּ הֵם, עָלַי לְפָגְשָׁם. פְּרוֹפֶסוֹר הַלְפֶּרִין אָמַר לָרַבִּי – אֲנִי נֶכְדּוֹ שֶׁל הָ"עוֹנֶג יוֹם טוֹב", מִיָּד שָׁאַל הָרַבִּי – וּמַה שַׁיָּכוּת יֵשׁ לְךָ אִיתוֹ? עָנָה הַפְּרוֹפֶסוֹר – תְּמוּנָתוֹ תְּלוּיָה לְיָדִי בְּכָל מָקוֹם בּוֹ אֲנִי עוֹבֵד... תְּגוּבַת-תְּבִיעַת הָרַבִּי הָיְתָה – "וּלְמַעַן נִשְׁמָתוֹ מָה הִנְּךָ עוֹשֶׂה?! הַאִם אַתָּה הוֹלֵךְ בִּדְרָכָיו?!" רַחְמִילֶבִיץ' הָיָה צָרִיךְ גַּם הוּא לוֹמַר מַשֶּׁהוּ, וְעַל כֵּן אָמַר לָרַבִּי - בִּשְׁמִי יֵשׁ אֶת הַמִּלָּה רַחֲמִים. נוּ, הִפְטִיר הָרַבִּי, הַלְפֶּרִין דִּבֵּר פָּשׁוּט, אַתָּה כְּבָר אוֹמֵר פְּשֶׁעטְלִיךְ...
זָכִיתִי גַּם לִהְיוֹת בַּמַּעֲמָד הַנּוֹרָא שֶׁל יְצִיאַת נִשְׁמָתוֹ הַטְּהוֹרָה בְּיוֹם רִאשׁוֹן ב' אֲדָר תשל"ז, לְאַחַר שֶׁאֻשְׁפַּז לִימָמָה שְׁלֵמָה בְּבֵית הַחוֹלִים הֲדַסָּה. נִסִּיתִי לְסַיֵּעַ גַּם אֲנִי הַקָּטָן לַצֶּוֶות הָרְפוּאִי הַבָּכִיר שֶׁעָמַל בְּכָל כּוֹחוֹ עַל רְפוּאַת הָרַבִּי, אוּלָם נִגְזְרָה הַגְּזֵרָה וְהַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" הֵשִׁיב אֶת נִשְׁמָתוֹ לְיוֹצְרָהּ.
הרה"ג ר' יעקב מן רקובסקי זצ"ל(מרשימות הרה"ח ר' ישראל פנחס טירנואר הי"ו)"עולם החסידות", ניסן תשס"ו, ע' 12
body_en:
For his last trip (of HaRav HaChassid R' Yaakov Yitzchak Piek *zt"l* from Los Angeles) to the Rebbe, the "Beis Yisrael", Rabbi Yaakov Yitzchak arrived thirty years ago. It was the holy Shabbat of Parshat Emor - 13 Iyar 5731 (1971). I also arrived in Jerusalem for a "trip" for this holy Shabbat. The "Riy" (R' Yaakov Yitzchak) was invited to dine at the holy Shabbat table of the Rebbe, the "Beis Yisrael".
At the end of the holy Shabbat meal, the Rebbe *zt"l* asked the Riy what he wanted to drink. Cold or hot? And to this, he replied - I want everything! The Rebbe asked him, is it possible, and is everything permitted for a Jew? The Riy replied: Here (meaning in the Rebbe's house) everything is permitted to me.
In response, R' Yaakov Yitzchak was asked again by the Rebbe: - But it is written: **קדש עצמך במותר לך** - "Sanctify yourself in what is permitted to you"?
R' Yaakov Yitzchak did not hesitate and replied: Here everything is holiness (meaning by the Rebbe)!
The Rebbe *zt"l* smiled and said: It is written in the books that all year round, the body pushes away the soul, because it wants to eat. The soul, in contrast, does not need food, whereas the soul is interested only in holiness and spirituality. On Erev Yom Kippur, when it is a Mitzvah to eat, the soul and the body together both want to eat. And so is the face of things also when eating by the Tzaddik; the soul and the body want to eat. "It's a 'steiger' (a way/manner) as you say, here everything is holiness"! (This is like you said, that here everything is holiness).
Source: HaRav HaChassid R' Menachem Raflowitz z"l, "Yechi Reuven" (Jerusalem 5763) p. 217
