בְּתֹם סְעוּדַת שַׁבָּת קֹדֶשׁ שָׁאַל מָרָן זַצַ"ל אֶת רִי"י מַה בִּרְצוֹנוֹ לִשְׁתּוֹת. קַר אוֹ חַם? וְעַל זֶה הֵשִׁיב - אֲנִי רוֹצֶה הַכֹּל! מָרָן שְׁאָלוֹ, הֲיִיתָכֵן וְכִי לִיהוּדִי מֻתָּר הַכֹּל? הֵשִׁיב רִי"י כָּאן (הַכַּוָּנָה לְבֵית מָרָן) מֻתָּר לִי הַכֹּל.
בִּתְגוּבָה נִשְׁאַל ר' יַעֲקֹב יִצְחָק שׁוּב ע"י הָרַבִּי: - הֲרֵי כְּתִיב "קַדֵּשׁ עַצְמְךָ בְּמֻתָּר לָךְ"?ר' יַעֲקֹב יִצְחָק לֹא הִסֵּס וְהֵשִׁיב: כָּאן הַכֹּל קְדֻשָּׁה (הַכַּוָּנָה אֵצֶל הָרַבִּי)!
מָרָן זַצַ"ל חִיֵּךְ וְאָמַר: כָּתוּב בַּסְּפָרִים שֶׁבְּכָל הַשָּׁנָה, הַגּוּף דּוֹחֶה אֶת הַנְּשָׁמָה, כִּי הוּא רוֹצֶה לֶאֱכוֹל. הַנְּשָׁמָה לְעֻמָּתוֹ אֵינֶנָּה זְקוּקָה לְאוֹכֶל, וְאִלּוּ הַנְּשָׁמָה מְעֻנְיֶנֶת רַק בִּקְדֻשָּׁה וְרוּחָנִיּוּת. בְּעֶרֶב יוֹהַכָּ"פּ כַּאֲשֶׁר מִצְוָה לֶאֱכוֹל, הַנְּשָׁמָה וְהַגּוּף יַחַד שְׁנֵיהֶם רוֹצִים לֶאֱכוֹל. וְכָךְ פְּנֵי הַדְּבָרִים גַּם כַּאֲשֶׁר אוֹכְלִים אֵצֶל הַצַּדִּיק, הַנְּשָׁמָה וְהַגּוּף רוֹצִים לֶאֱכוֹל, "ס'אִיז אַ שְׁטַיְיגֶער וִוי דִי אַא זָאגְסְט, דָּא אִיז אַלְץ קְדֻשָּׁה"! (זֶה כְּעֵין שֶׁאָמַרְתָּ, שֶׁכָּאן הַכֹּל קְדֻשָּׁה).
הרה"ח ר' מנחם רפלוביץ ז"ל"יחי ראובן" (ירושלים תשס"ג) ע' 217
body_en:
In the month of Kislev 5746 (1985), my grandfather, the Admor of Tolna *zt"l*, said: I once had a wondrous Ruach HaKodesh (Divine Inspiration) with my teacher and Rebbe, the author of the "Beis Yisrael" *zy"a* of Ger. When I had a matter of faintness of heart and it was not revealed from the heart to the mouth - to any born of woman, the Rebbe *zt"l* suddenly called me and brought me into his private room. He sat calmly and commanded me also to sit, honored me with a drink as was his way, opened his mouth in wisdom, and told me the story at length and with deliberation:
A parable of a village boy, an ignoramus, for whom they hired a tutor for much money to teach him the form of the letters and the pronunciation. When his father arrived to see the tutor's success, the tutor apologized that, thank G-d, he succeeded with all the letters except the letter 'Hey', which the boy is not willing to say in any way or form what is under the 'Hey'. His father was amazed and commanded his son to say the letters, and behold his son, thank G-d, knows well. He reaches the letter 'Hey' and refuses to say it! The father got angry and said to him: If you don't say it, I will beat you! The boy cried and said: Father, do you want me to say it? Truly, do you want it? Didn't you warn me not to say it?! And they didn't understand his intent. He explained that his father stole a small lamb from the neighbor and hid it under the hay in the yard and warned his son not to reveal what is hidden under the hay. And the boy in his innocence thought that the letter 'Hey' was the spoken hay (in Yiddish, hay is called 'Hey'), and therefore he did not want to reveal it.
All this is explained on the verse in the Tochecha (Admonition): **תחת אשר לא עבדת את ה' אלקיך בשמחה ובטוב לבב מרב כל** - "Because you did not serve the L-rd your G-d with joy and gladness of heart for the abundance of everything" (Deuteronomy 28:47). All the commentators ask why such heavy punishments are deserved for a lack of joy? And the Rebbe R' Chanoch of Alexander answered regarding this, that the intent is not just the lack of joy, but that a Jew who is not happy has something worse underneath this. And for this, he deserves a heavy punishment, since a Jew needs to be in joy, and if not, he will fall from his level and reach very far into sins, and this is "Underneath that you did not serve with joy" - there is something worse hidden here, like the stolen lamb. And words of wisdom.
My grandfather added and said: This was not the Parsha connected to the verse! This was not the Yahrtzeit of the Rebbe of Alexander! Rather, this was Ruach HaKodesh that I needed now to hear how important the attribute of joy is!
Source: From the notes of HaRav HaChassid R' Moshe David Mordechai Weinberg Shlita, "Ki Chaim Hem L'Motza'eihem" (Jerusalem 5761) p. 21

כָּל זֶה מוּסְבָּר עַל הַפָּסוּק בַּתּוֹכֵחָה "תַּחַת אֲשֶׁר לֹא עָבַדְתָּ אֶת ה' אֱלֹקֶיךָ בְּשִׂמְחָה וּבְטוּב לֵבָב מֵרֹב כֹּל", שֶׁכָּל הַמְפָרְשִׁים שׁוֹאֲלִים מַדּוּעַ מַגִּיעַ עַל אִי שִׂמְחָה עוֹנָשִׁים כֹּה כְּבֵדִים? וְהָרַבִּי ר' הֶענִיךְ מֵאֲלֶכְּסַנְדֶּר עָנָה עַל כָּךְ שֶׁאֵין הַכַּוָּנָה רַק לְאִי הַשִּׂמְחָה, אֶלָּא שֶׁיְּהוּדִי שֶׁאֵינוֹ שָׂמֵחַ יֵשׁ מַשֶּׁהוּ גָּרוּעַ יוֹתֵר מִתַּחַת זֶה וְעַל זֶה מַגִּיעַ עוֹנֶשׁ כָּבֵד, מִכֵּיוָן שֶׁיְּהוּדִי צָרִיךְ לִהְיוֹת בְּשִׂמְחָה, וְאִם לֹא, יִפּוֹל מִמַּדְרֵגָתוֹ וְיַגִּיעַ רָחוֹק מְאוֹד בַּעֲבֵירוֹת, וְזֶה תַּחַת אֲשֶׁר לֹא עָבַדְתָּ בְּשִׂמְחָה יֵשׁ כָּאן מַשֶּׁהוּ מוּחְבָּא גָּרוּעַ יוֹתֵר כְּמוֹ הַטָּלֶה הַגָּנוּב ודפח"ח.
הוֹסִיף זְקִינִי וְאָמַר: לֹא הָיָה זֶה הַפָּרָשָׁה הַקְּשׁוּרָה לַפָּסוּק! לֹא הָיָה זֶה יוֹמָא דְּהִילּוּלָא שֶׁל הרה"ק מֵאֲלֶכְּסַנְדֶּר! אֶלָּא הָיָה זֶה רוּחַ הַקֹּדֶשׁ שֶׁאֲנִי צָרִיךְ עַכְשָׁיו לִשְׁמֹעַ כַּמָּה חֲשׁוּבָה מִדַּת הַשִּׂמְחָה!
מרשימות הרה"ח ר' משה דוד מרדכי וינברג שליט"א"כי חיים הם למוצאיהם" (ירושלים תשס"א) ע' כ"א

...So it was with [HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yisrael Aryeh Zalmanowitz *zt"l*], who was also connected to the Admor, the author of the "Beis Yisrael" of Ger *zt"l*. He would travel to him to spend Shabbat Bereishit with him, and so too he was with him at Simchas. The Rebbe of Ger returned a relationship of demonstrated friendship to him, and several times when he stayed in Haifa, he entered to visit him in his rabbinical city of Acre.
He also told a miracle story about himself, that once when the Rav (HaGaon R' Yisrael Aryeh Zalmanowitz) *zt"l* was suffering an attack of pain from an ulcer he suffered from greatly, the doctors told him he needed surgery because they found the ulcer was bleeding. The Rav was very troubled by this. Behold, the Admor, the author of the "Beis Yisrael" *zt"l*, entered to visit him and saw him very troubled. At that hour, his book "Chayei Nefesh", which he had just published, was on the table. The "Beis Yisrael" used to encourage him to print his novellae. During that visit, he pointed to the book "Chayei Nefesh" and said with his wit: "Oib ihr vet eire sefarim druken, vet men eich nisht druken" (If you print [press] your books, you won't be pressed [suffering]). And so it was, that on that very day he was released to his home, and since then his suffering was eased.
Source: Rabbi Yechezkel Solomon Shlita, "Sanz", Tishrei 5764, p. 124

...In those days when the new systems of the State were forming, it was natural that HaRav HaChassid Rabbi Shammai Ginzburg *zt"l*, who was a partner in the defense systems of the Holy City, would be offered a respectable position. The rumor reached far; they wanted R' Shammai to integrate into the senior staff, specifically in the Rabbinical Court system in the State. His answer was short and decisive: "I do not lift my eyes to this position." His resolute opposition to making a living from words of Torah was sweeping. He also did not agree to make a living from the Rabbinical Court system.
The activists who handled the matter were very surprised. For R' Shammai did not hide his request to find a source of livelihood. His goal was also known: to do everything in his power to contribute in those systems for the sake of the People of Israel. They pleaded with him again and again. R' Shammai answered them that as long as he does not have an explicit instruction from the mouth of the "Beis Yisrael", he does not consider integrating into the said system.
"Did you enter the Rebbe to ask for instruction on the matter?" he was asked.
R' Shammai answered: "I am accustomed with the Admor, the 'Beis Yisrael', from days of old; I do not present questions at all. And I receive the answer even before I ask. If this was the Rebbe's opinion, I would have certainly heard about it already. If no instruction was given to me on this matter, it is nothing but that this is not my place."
In this question, the essence of the connection between R' Shammai and his Rebbe, the "Beis Yisrael", was revealed. The Rebbe, whose Ruach HaKodesh was palpable in his room, and R' Shammai, who was so close - it was in the aspect of "Before they call, I will answer." regarding every question that arose for R' Shammai, he merited to be called to the Rebbe and receive instruction before he laid it out in practice.
R' Shammai rubbed his mind, how could he do for his home and contribute his part according to the command of the hour. He merited to receive approval from the Rebbe for these thoughts, when he received a respectable position in the absorption system of the Jewish Agency. At every step and turn of his, he did only what his Rebbe instructed him. Among the pages of the book "HaGaon HaChassid", many stories are embedded about this...
Source: "HaGaon HaChassid" (Jerusalem 5771) p. 347

body_he:
הִתְפַּלְּאוּ עַל כָּךְ עַד מְאֹד הָעַסְקָנִים אֲשֶׁר טִפְּלוּ בָּעִנְיָין. שֶׁכֵּן, ר' שַׁמַּאי לֹא הִסְתִּיר אֶת מְבֻקָּשׁוֹ לִמְצֹא מְקוֹר פַּרְנָסָה. גַּם יְדוּעָה הָיְתָה מְגַמָּתוֹ. לַעֲשׂוֹת כָּל שֶׁבִּיכוֹלְתּוֹ כְּדֵי לִתְרֹם בְּאוֹתָן מַעֲרָכוֹת לְמַעַן עַם יִשְׂרָאֵל. הִפְצִירוּ בּוֹ שׁוּב וָשׁוּב, עָנָה עַל כָּךְ ר' שַׁמַּאי, כִּי כָּל עוֹד אֵין בְּיָדוֹ הוֹרָאָה מְפֹרֶשֶׁת בַּנּוֹשֵׂא מִפִּי כ"ק הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל", הֲרֵי אֵין הוּא מַעֲלֶה עַל דַּעְתּוֹ הִשְׁתַּלְּבוּת בַּמַּעֲרֶכֶת הָאֲמוּרָה."הַאִם נִכְנַסְתָּ לָרַבִּי לְבַקֵּשׁ הוֹרָאָה בָּעִנְיָין?" נִשְׁאַל.עָנָה ר' שַׁמַּאי: "נוֹהֵג אֲנִי אֵצֶל הָאַדְמוֹ"ר הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" מִיָּמִים יָמִימָה, אֵינִי מַצִּיג שְׁאֵלוֹת כְּלָל. וַאֲנִי מְקַבֵּל תְּשׁוּבָה עוֹד בְּטֶרֶם אֶשְׁאַל. אִם זוֹ הָיְתָה דַּעְתּוֹ שֶׁל הָרַבִּי, וַוּדַאי כְּבָר הָיִיתִי שׁוֹמֵעַ עַל כָּךְ. אִם לֹא נִיתְּנָה לִי כָּל הוֹרָאָה בַּנִּדּוֹן, אֵין זֹאת אֶלָּא, שֶׁאֵין זֶה מְקוֹמִי".
בִּשְׁאֵלָה זוֹ נֶחְשַׂף תַּמְצִית הַקֶּשֶׁר שֶׁל ר' שַׁמַּאי לְרַבּוֹ מָרָן הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל". הָרַבִּי, שֶׁרוּחַ הַקֹּדֶשׁ הָיְתָה מוּרְגֶּשֶׁת בְּחַדְרוֹ, וְר' שַׁמַּאי, שֶׁהָיָה כֹּה מְקֹרָב - הָיָה בִּבְחִינַת "טֶרֶם יִקְרָאוּ וַאֲנִי אֶעֱנֶה".בְּכָל שְׁאֵלָה שֶׁהִתְעוֹרְרָה אֵצֶל ר' שַׁמַּאי, זָכָה לְהִיקָּרֵא אֵצֶל הָרַבִּי וּלְקַבֵּל הוֹרָאָה, בְּטֶרֶם שָׁטַח אוֹתָהּ בְּפוֹעַל.
ר' שַׁמַּאי חִכֵּךְ בְּדַעְתּוֹ, אֵיךְ יוּכַל לַעֲשׂוֹת לְבֵיתוֹ וְלִתְרוֹם אֶת תְּרוּמָתוֹ עַל פִּי צַו הַשָּׁעָה. הוּא זָכָה לְקַבֵּל מֵהָרַבִּי אִישּׁוּר לְמַחְשְׁבוֹתָיו אֵלּוּ, כְּשֶׁקִּיבֵּל תַּפְקִיד נִכְבָּד בְּמַעֲרֶכֶת קְלִיטַת הָעֲלִיָּיה שֶׁל הַסּוֹכְנוּת הַיְּהוּדִית.בְּכָל צַעַד וָשַׁעַל שֶׁלּוֹ, עָשָׂה רַק מַה שֶּׁרַבּוֹ הוֹרָה לוֹ. בֵּין דַּפֵּי הַסֵּפֶר "הַגָּאוֹן הֶחָסִיד" מְשֻׁבָּצִים סִפּוּרִים רַבִּים עַל כָּךְ...
"הגאון החסיד" (ירושלים תשע"א) ע' 347
body_en:
...A chapter unto itself is the closeness of my father-in-law (HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yissachar Dov Goldstein *zt"l*) to the Admor, the Beis Yisrael of Ger *zt"l*. He would visit him every Erev Rosh Chodesh, and at times of festivals and holidays. Once, when he arrived to greet him on one of the Erev Rosh Chodesh days... when he returned once from an eye doctor, he entered the Admor. Upon his entry, the Rebbe opened: "Certainly you know the Gemara **יראה יראה כדרך שבא לראות כך בא ליראות** - 'He shall appear, he shall appear; just as he came to see, so he came to be seen' (with two eyes, etc.) (Chagigah 2a). With G-d's help, you will see good." It was a wonder, because he had not mentioned or told the Admor about his eye health.
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Naftali Hertzka Frankel zt"l, Member of the Badatz Edah HaChareidis (From the notes of HaRav HaChassid R' Yisrael Pinchas Tirnauer Hy"u), "Olam HaChassidut", Tishrei 5770, p. 21

body_he: הגה"צ רבי נפתלי הירצקא פרנקל זצ"לחבר בד"צ העדה החרדית(מרשימות הרה"ח ר' ישראל פינחס טירנואר הי"ו)"עולם החסידות", תשרי תש"ע, ע' 21
body_en:
One of the attendants of the Rebbe, the "Beis Yisrael" *zt"l*, told that at the beginning of his work in the holy service, he happened to stand at the door sometimes while the Admor received the public seeking Hashem.
And behold, on one occasion, after the last of the people left the place, the Rebbe turned to him with a question: According to what "order" do those coming enter here? He answered: According to their arrival. Whoever arrives stands "in line", and when his turn comes, he enters. He added to ask: And if a respected person comes, does he wait like everyone else? The attendant said: In such a case, those standing waive their right and allow him to enter immediately. And when a Rav arrives, does he wait for his turn? He answered: A respected Rav, everyone honors him. But if it is a young Rav, he generally waits in line. The "Beis Yisrael" showed a gesture of disapproval and said: Any Rav who arrives - you must bring him in immediately. And furthermore, also a Rosh Yeshiva, or a Mashgiach, and even a Melamed in a Talmud Torah should enter without waiting. There is reason to spare his time, and also so that his congregation or students see that he is honored, for the honor of the Torah.
Source: From the notes of HaRav HaChassid Bnash"k R' Menachem Alter Shlita

body_he: מרשימות הרה"ח בנש"ק ר' מנחם אלתר שליט"א
body_en:
It is written (Parshat Yitro, Ex 18:3) that Moshe Rabbeinu called the name of his first son Gershom **כי גר הייתי וגו'** - "For I was a stranger etc.", and the second he called Eliezer **כי אלהי אבי בעזרי ויצילני מחרב פרעה** - "For the G-d of my father was my help and delivered me from the sword of Pharaoh." The Sforno asks that his rescue from the sword of Pharaoh was before he was a stranger in a foreign land, so why did he name the second son for his rescue? (See there and in the Or HaChaim what they answer).
The Beis Yisrael (of Ger *zy"a*) said an answer by way of a parable regarding a Holocaust survivor groom who came before him. At the time of the Simcha, our Rebbe was saved from the sword of Pharaoh, but from the perspective of his rescue, he saw no reason to rejoice as long as his brothers were found in their distress under the servitude of Egypt. Only now that it became known to him that the reason for his rescue was so that he would redeem Israel, then he saw a reason to rejoice. And he said to the groom: So too you, at the time you left the valley of killing, it was impossible for you to have joy from this, due to your knowledge that all your family was killed. But now that you are about to establish a family, and it becomes known to you that the reason for your rescue is so that through you there will be a continuation for your glorious family, now you see a reason to rejoice.
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Chaim Shaul Kaufman zt"l, Rosh Yeshivat Gateshead, "Yikra D'Chayei" (Jerusalem 5767) p. 329

body_he: הגאון רבי חיים שאול קויפמן זצ"לראש ישיבת גייטסהד"יקרא דחיים" (ירושלים תשס"ז) ע' שכ"ט
body_en:
The Holy Rebbe, the "Beis Yisrael" [of Ger] *zy"a*, once said jokingly that behold, the expression "Oif geroymt" (in high spirits/uplifted) has a double meaning. This expression is said about a person who is uplifted and happy, and also about a place that is clean from all waste. And the two are one, for with the power of joy, a person purifies himself, and can overcome the tests of the Yetzer (Evil Inclination) to be saved from the trap he set.
Source: Maran Admor of Vizhnitz Shlita, Leil Sh"k Parshat Terumah 5765, "Da'ach", Terumah 5773, p. 7

body_he: מרן אדמו"ר מויז'ניץ שליט"אליל ש"ק פר' תרומה תשס"ה"דא"ח", תרומה תשע"ג, עמ' ז'
body_en:
HaRav HaChassid Rabbi Avraham Mordechai *zt"l*, son of HaRav HaTzaddik R' Moshe Betzalel Alter *Hy"d*, made the Sheva Brachot for his grandson (R' Shaul Borzykowski *Hy"v*). In the middle of the meal, our Rebbe, the Beis Yisrael, turned to R' Avraham Mordechai and said to him: "Look now, Motil, der Tatte iz da, der Zeide iz da" (Look, Motil, your father R' Moshe Betzalel is here, and also the grandfather, the Sfas Emes, is here).
Source: HaRav HaChassid Rabbi Moshe Ludmir Shlita, "Yagdil Torah - Nisuin" (Jerusalem 5773) p. 32

body_he: הרה"ח רבי משה לודמיר שליט"א"יגדיל תורה - נשואין" (ירושלים תשע"ג) ע' ל"ב
body_en:
A Jew told me in the name of HaRav HaChassid R' Yisrael Horowitz, who was accustomed to go to the pure table (Tish) of the Beis Yisrael *zy"a*. Once he thought to himself that since, due to the large crowd, he cannot see and cannot hear anything, he would not come to the Tish anymore. After the *Tish*, the Beis Yisrael was circulating among the crowd and stopped next to him. The Beis Yisrael said to him: "I think it is a pity that you came here to the Tish; surely in this time you could have learned a few pages of Gemara. It is a pity on your precious time..." When R' Yisrael saw that the Rebbe grasped his thought, he never missed coming to the *Tish* again.
HaRav HaChassid R' Moshe Aharon Segal *zt"l* once went to the table of the Beis Yisrael together with his son, HaRav HaChassid R' Avraham Yitzchak... And when the Beis Yisrael circulated before the Tish, he stopped next to them and said to R' Moshe Aharon: "You enter the Tish." And to his son R' Avraham Yitzchak, whom he recognized as a great *Masmid* (diligent student), he said: "It is a pity on your precious time, surely in this time you could manage a few pages of Gemara - for the Beis Yisrael would circulate until the early hours of the morning in the streets of Jerusalem, and he knew who wakes up early in the morning..."
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Shalom Eisenberger Shlita, Dom"tz Kiryat Sanz - Jerusalem, "Ma'ayanot HaChaim", Nissan 5773, p. 62

body_he:
הרה"ח ר' מֹשֶׁה אַהֲרֹן סג"ל זַ"ל הָלַךְ פַּעַם אֶל שֻׁלְחָנוֹ שֶׁל הַבֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל יַחַד עִם בְּנוֹ הרה"ח ר' אַבְרָהָם יִצְחָק... וּכְשֶׁהִסְתּוֹבֵב שָׁם הַבֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל קוֹדֶם הַטִּישׁ נֶעֱצַר לְיָדָם וְאָמַר ל' מֹשֶׁה אַהֲרֹן אַתָּה תִּיכָּנֵס אֶל הַטִּישׁ וְלִבְנוֹ ר' אַבְרָהָם יִצְחָק, שֶׁהִכִּיר בּוֹ שֶׁהוּא מַתְמִיד גָּדוֹל, אָמַר, חֲבָל עַל זְמַנְּךָ הַיָּקָר הֲרֵי אַתָּה יָכוֹל בִּזְמַן זֶה לְהַסְפִּיק כַּמָּה דַּפֵּי גְּמָרָא - שֶׁהֲרֵי הַבֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל הָיָה מִסְתּוֹבֵב לִפְנוֹת בֹּקֶר בִּרְחוֹבוֹת יְרוּשָׁלַיִם וְיָדַע מִי מַשְׁכִּים בַּבֹּקֶר...
הגאון רבי שלום אייזנברגר שליט"אדומ"ץ קרית צאנז - ירושלים"מעיינות החיים", ניסן תשע"ג, ע' ס"ב
body_en:
The Admor, the "Beis Yisrael" of Ger *zt"l*, during one of his visits to Hatzor HaGlilit, where the Kiryat Chassidei Gur was established for glory. The Gaon R' Asher Neihauz, Rosh Yeshivat "Sifsei Tzaddik" of Gur Chassidim in Hatzor, told that the Admor waved his hands towards the borders of Syria, Lebanon, and Jordan, and those close to him heard him say: "Go away from here!"...
Since then and until today, recounted HaGaon R' Asher Neihauz, Hatzor HaGlilit has not known terrorists and evil occurrences. They seemed to distance themselves from there, a bowshot away, to fulfill the command of a Tzaddik.
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Yitzchak Zilberstein Shlita, "Tuvcha Yabiu" (Bnei Brak 5761) Part 2, p. 256

body_he: הגאון רבי יצחק זילברשטיין שליט"א"טובך יביעו" (ב"ב תשס"א) ח"ב, ע' רנ"ו
body_en:
Once a meeting was held by the Gedolei Yisrael in the offices of Chinuch Atzmai on David Yellin Street in Jerusalem. It was a difficult meeting that lasted almost a full day without exaggeration. The "Beis Yisrael", for whom this was not his way - and I know and witness that he did not participate in any fundraising except for Chinuch Atzmai and 'HaModia' - sat for a long time on the chaotic seat in that meeting for the sake of Heaven.
The topic spoken of at the gathering was the proposal to reduce the salaries of teachers and educators in order to ease the burden of Chinuch Atzmai.
The "Beis Yisrael" said to me then: "I am ready to go from morning until evening for the sake of Chinuch Atzmai, provided that they do not touch the teachers' salaries..."
Source: HaRav HaChassid R' Shmuel Mordechai Mintz Shlita, "Niv HaMoreh", Menachem Av 5768, p. 17

body_he:
הַמְדֻבָּר בְּכִינוּס הָיְתָה הַהַצָּעָה לְהַפְחִית בִּשְׂכַר הַמּוֹרִים וְהַמְחַנְּכִים בִּכְדֵי לְהָקֵל עַל שֶׁבֶר הַחִינּוּךְ הָעַצְמָאִי. הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" אָמַר לִי אָז: "הִנְנִי מוּכָן לָלֶכֶת מִבֹּקֶר וְעַד עֶרֶב לְמַעַן הַחִינּוּךְ הָעַצְמָאִי, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יִגְּעוּ בִּשְׂכַר הַמּוֹרִים..."
הרה"ח ר' שמואל מרדכי מינץ שליט"א"ניב המורה", מנ"א תשס"ח, ע' 17
body_en:
The 'Beis Yisrael' once called Saba [HaRav HaChassid Rabbi Chaim Yitzchak Schwartz] *zt"l* and said to him: 'Ich hab gizehen a sheine zach vas iz gut far dir...' [I saw a beautiful thing that is good for you]: Imagine for yourself the tribulations of Yaakov Avinu, after fourteen years of learning at Shem and Ever, not sleeping at all at night, arriving at a place of danger where there are wild beasts, and he had nowhere to sleep, only on stones, and that was not enough, but the stones quarreled among themselves... [Upon me let the Tzaddik rest his head...]
I know, I knew - concluded Saba *zt"l* - if the 'Beis Yisrael' says to me 'This is good for you', apparently there is a specific instruction here for me, and I kept the matter in my heart. Forty years later, when I was a Gabbai of the Chassidic Shtiebel in Tel Aviv, there was a certain 'Parsha' (disturbance) in the Shtiebel. Or then I understood the intention of the 'Beis Yisrael', that one should not be impressed by any disturbance, but rather continue with the holy work!
Source: "Siach HaParsha" (Jerusalem 5772) Vayetze, p. 1

body_he:
יָדוּעַ יָדַעְתִּי - סִיֵּם סַבָּא זַ"ל - אִם הַ'בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל' אוֹמֵר לִי 'זֶה טוֹב בִּשְׁבִילְךָ', כַּנִּרְאֶה יֵשׁ כָּאן הוֹרָאָה מְיֻחֶדֶת בִּשְׁבִילִי, וְשָׁמַרְתִּי הַדָּבָר בְּלִבִּי. לְאַחַר אַרְבָּעִים שָׁנָה בִּהְיוֹתִי גַּבַּאי שֶׁל בֵּית הַחֲסִידִים בְּתֵל אָבִיב, הָיְתָה אֵיזוֹ פָּרָשִׁיָּה, בַּשְּׁטִיבְּל, אוֹ אָז הֵבַנְתִּי אֶת כַּוָּנַת הַ'בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל', שֶׁאֵין לְהִתְפַּעֵל מִשּׁוּם הַפְרָעָה, אֶלָּא לְהַמְשִׁיךְ בַּעֲבוֹדַת הַקֹּדֶשׁ!
"שיח הפרשה" (ירושלים תשע"ב) ויצא, עמ' א'
body_en:
One who was close to our Rebbe, the 'Beis Yisrael' *zy"a*, told me that once during Kiddush on Pesach, the Beis Yisrael asked him about a certain person if he was a relative of so-and-so. He answered "A veiter karov" (A distant relative). The Beis Yisrael remarked jokingly that this is an oxymoron, "A veiter oder a karov" (A distant one or a close one). He added a story that during the 'Knessiah HaGedolah', the author of the 'Chafetz Chaim' asked Maran the 'Imrei Emet' regarding what is written in the verse: **אחרי ה' אלקיכם תלכו** - "After the L-rd your G-d shall you walk" (Deuteronomy 13:5). But isn't "Acharei" (After) a term of distance? (Bereishit Rabbah 44:6). And what is the language of "Muflag" (distant/distinguished) here? The Imrei Emet answered him: "Ich vel eich zogen a chassidishe terutz" (I will tell you a Chassidic answer): According to how much a person holds himself distant and removed from Hashem Yitbarach, so is he truly close to Hashem Yitbarach...
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Daniel Chaim Alter Shlita, "Davar Echad" (Jerusalem 5766) p. 112

body_he: הגאון רבי דניאל חיים אלתר שליט"א"דבר אחד" (ירושלים תשס"ו) ע' קי"ב
body_en:
In the year 5713 (1953), when he prayed (the "Beis Yisrael" of Ger *zy"a*) still in the Yeshiva of Sfas Emes, once on a holy Shabbat after the prayer, when he returned to his home, he approached a *bochur* who stood nearby and asked him: "Did you speak in the middle of Davening?" "Do not enter my house for two weeks." The *bochur* answered: Someone spoke to me and I didn't answer him. The Beis Yisrael said to him: "If so, do not enter for 4 weeks!" Immediately he approached another and asked him: "Did you speak today in the middle of Davening? Do not enter my house for two weeks." The *bochur* answered: "I regret it and promise that I will not speak again in the middle of Davening!" The Beis Yisrael said to him: "If so, I invite you to Kiddush today!!!" Thus he taught and educated: Excuses and justifications are the act of the "Baal Davar" - the Evil Inclination! Regret! Repentance! And accepting for the future, this is the act of the Good Inclination! (And he mentioned the Midrash Rabbah Parshat Balak... whoever says 'I have sinned', no angel or creature can touch him) And on the contrary! In the place where penitents stand, complete righteous men cannot stand!
Source: From the notes of HaRav HaChassid R' Moshe Ludmir Shlita

body_he: מרשימות הרה"ח ר' משה לודמיר שליט"א
body_en:
During the years of the illness of Maran (the "Imrei Chaim" of Vizhnitz *zt"l*), there were times when his condition was very difficult. And K"k Maran Admor of Vizhnitz *shlita* visited the courts of the Tzaddikim of the generation to mention our Rebbe before them and ask them to pray for his complete recovery. While he was with the Rebbe (the "Beis Yisrael" *zy"a*) of Ger, the holy Rebbe advised him to take upon himself extra activity in leading the congregation of Vizhnitz, as a Segulah for extending the years of our Rebbe. In light of the saying of Chazal: **עד שלא השקיע שמשו של משה הזריח שמשו של יהושע** - "Before the sun of Moshe set, the sun of Yehoshua rose" (Bereishit Rabbah 58:2). And if so, perhaps his time to reign has arrived, and due to this, it is liable to remove his holy father from the world. Therefore, the advice is that he should begin to conduct authority, and automatically, through this, our Rebbe's years will be lengthened.
Maran (K"k Maran Admor the "Imrei Chaim" of Vizhnitz *zy"a*) once expressed in the ears of R' Moshe Ernster *n"y*: "The Rebbe (the "Beis Yisrael") of Ger credited me with a number of years of life!" - Some interpreted his holy words according to the following story: For the holy Rebbe (the "Beis Yisrael" *zy"a*), during one of his visits to our Rebbe - while he was ill - extended his hand, saying: **יהב ליה ידיה ואוקמיה** - "He gave him his hand and raised him up" (Berachot 5b). And indeed, afterwards, the condition of our Rebbe improved - it is possible that Maran referred to this blessing of the holy Rebbe.
Source: "Ma'ayan HaBracha", Sivan 5766, p. 30

body_he:
מָרָן (כ"ק מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר הָ"אִמְרֵי חַיִּים" מִוִּיזְ'נִיץ זִי"עַ) הִתְבַּטֵּא פַּעַם בְּאָזְנֵי ר' מֹשֶׁה אִירְנְשְׁטֵיין נ"י: "הָרַבִּי (הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל") מִגּוּר זִכַּנִי בְּמִסְפַּר שְׁנוֹת חַיִּים!" - יֵשׁ שֶׁפֵּרְשׁוּ דִּבְרֵי קָדְשׁוֹ עַל פִּי הַמַּעֲשֶׂה דִּלְקַמָּן, כִּי הרה"ק (הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" זִי"עַ) בְּאֶחָד מִבִּיקּוּרָיו אֵצֶל רַבֵּינוּ - בִּהְיוֹתוֹ חוֹלֶה - הוֹשִׁיט יָדוֹ, בְּאוֹמְרוֹ: "יְהַב לֵיהּ יְדֵיהּ וְאוֹקְמֵיהּ" (ברכות ה' ע"ב), וְאָמְנָם לְאַחַר מִכֵּן הוּטַב מַצָּבוֹ שֶׁל רַבֵּינוּ - יִתָּכֵן שֶׁעַל בִּרְכָתוֹ זוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק הִתְכַּוֵּן מָרָן.
גָּדוֹל עַד מְאֹד הָיָה צַעֲרוֹ שֶׁל הָאַדְמוֹ"ר מִגּוּר זִי"עַ בְּהִוָּדַע לוֹ הַבְּשׂוֹרָה הַמָּרָה עַל הִסְתַּלְּקוּת רַבֵּינוּ (הָ"אִמְרֵי חַיִּים" זִי"עַ). הֱיוֹת שֶׁהַלְּוָיָה הִתְקַיְּמָה בְּעֶרֶב שַׁבָּת, וְהָאַדְמוֹ"ר מִגּוּר לֹא הָיָה נוֹהֵג לִנְסוֹעַ בְּיוֹם שִׁשִּׁי, לָכֵן עָרַךְ "הַתָּרַת נְדָרִים" כְּדֵי שֶׁיּוּכַל לִנְסוֹעַ. בְּמֶשֶׁךְ שָׁעָה אֲרוּכָה הִשְׁתַּתֵּף בִּשְׁלַבֵּי הַהֲכָנָה לַלְּוָיָה. בְּעֵת הַהַלְבָּשָׁה - לְאַחַר הַטָּהֳרָה בַּמִּקְוֶה - נָכַח גַּם הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל".
בְּעֵת הַ"קְּרִיעָה" לִבְנֵי רַבֵּינוּ - בְּחַדְרוֹ שֶׁל מָרָן - גָּעוּ כֻּלָּם בִּבְכִיָּה עֲצוּמָה. הֵעִיר הָרַבִּי מִגּוּר שֶׁנָּכַח שָׁם: "בְּכוּ! בְּכוּ! כָּל כְּלַל יִשְׂרָאֵל צָרִיךְ לִבְכּוֹת!"
הרה"ח ר' נתן אלי' רוט ז"ל"מאיר החיים" (ב"ב תשנ"ב) ח"ב, ע' תל"ט
body_en:
Great was the sorrow of the Admor of Ger *zy"a* when the bitter news of the passing of our Rebbe (the "Imrei Chaim" *zy"a*) became known to him. Since the funeral took place on Erev Shabbat, and the Admor of Ger was not accustomed to travel on Friday, he therefore performed "Hatarat Nedarim" (Annulment of Vows) so that he could travel. For a long hour, he participated in the stages of preparation for the funeral. At the time of the dressing - after the purification in the Mikvah - the "Beis Yisrael" was also present.
At the time of the "Keriah" (tearing of clothes) for the sons of our Rebbe - in the room of Maran - everyone burst into intense weeping. The Rebbe of Ger, who was present there, remarked: "Weep! Weep! All of Klal Yisrael needs to weep!"
Source: HaRav HaChassid R' Natan Eli' Roth z"l, "Meir HaChaim" (Bnei Brak 5752) Part 2, p. 439

body_he:
וְסִפֵּר ר' דָּוִד זַ"ל, כִּי בִּגְמַר שִׂיחָתָם כְּשֶׁעָמְדוּ לְהִפָּרֵד מִמֶּנּוּ, אִיחֵל לוֹ הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" בִּרְכַּת רְפוּאָה שְׁלֵימָה. וּכְשֶׁיָּצְאוּ מִלְּפָנָיו הוֹסִיף הָרַבִּי וְהִפְטִיר אַחֲרֵיהֶם בְּקוֹל "וּבֵרַכְתֶּם גַּם אוֹתִי", וְנִפְטְרוּ מִמֶּנּוּ לְשָׁלוֹם.
כָּאָמוּר הָיָה זֶה בְּיוֹם שֵׁנִי הָאַחֲרוֹן שֶׁל הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל", וְאִישׁ לֹא הֶעֱלָה אָז עַל דַּעְתּוֹ, שֶׁיָּמָיו שֶׁל הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" סְפוּרִים עֲלֵי אֲדָמוֹת. אָמְנָם רָאָה מש"ב רַשִׁ"י בַּפָּסוּק זֶה (שמות י"ב ל"ב) שֶׁפֵּרֵשׁ עה"פ "וּבֵרַכְתֶּם גַּם אֹתִי". וְזַ"ל: "הִתְפַּלְּלוּ עָלַי שֶׁלֹּא אָמוּת", וְאָכֵן לֹא לְחִנָּם זָעַק אַחֲרֵיהֶם בְּקוֹל גָּדוֹל וְלֹא יָסַף: "וּבֵרַכְתֶּם גַּם אֹתִי".
[הרה"ח ר' אַבְרָהָם יוֹסֵף הַנַּ"ל אָמַר לִי, כִּי בַּשְּׁבוּעַיִם הָאַחֲרוֹנִים שֶׁלּוֹ, הָיוּ עוֹד כַּמָּה מִקְרִים שֶׁפָּטַר אֶת הַהוֹלְכִים מִלְּפָנָיו וְאָמַר לָהֶם "וּבֵרַכְתֶּם גַּם אֹתִי" וְאַף אֶחָד לֹא שָׂם לֵב לְמַה שֶׁרָמוּז בְּפֵירוּשׁ רַשִׁ"י לְפָסוּק זֶה - וְאַגַּב אֲצַיֵּן כִּי ר' דָּוִד זַ"ל הָיָה הַ"הַזְכָּרָה" הָאַחֲרוֹנָה שֶׁל הַבֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל. כִּי ר' דָּוִד נָסַע מִיָּד בְּאוֹתוֹ יוֹם שֵׁנִי בַּבֹּקֶר לִשְׁוַויְּיץ וְעָשָׂה הַנִּיתּוּחַ, וּבְכָל יוֹם הָיָה המשב"ק מִתְעַנְיֵין אֵצֶל הַמִּשְׁפָּחָה בְּשֵׁם הָרַבִּי לָדַעַת מַה שְׁלוֹם ר' דָּוִד. בְּיוֹם שב"ק הָאַחֲרוֹן פָּרָשַׁת שְׁקָלִים, קוֹדֶם שֶׁנִּכְנַס הַבֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל לביהכנ"ס לִתְפִילַּת שַׁחֲרִית שֶׁל שַׁבָּת, הִתְעַנְיֵין שׁוּב עַל ר' דָּוִד, וְהִתְפַּלֵּא שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה נִשְׁמָע שׁוּם חֲדָשׁוֹת מִלִּפְנֵי שַׁבָּת. הַבֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל הִתְפַּלֵּל אָז שַׁחֲרִית שֶׁל שַׁבָּת בְּבֵיהמ"ד יַחַד עִם הַצִּיבּוּר וְלִפְנֵי אֲמִירַת הַלֵּל יָצָא מִבֵּיהמ"ד נִכְנַס לְחַדְרוֹ וּלְמָחֳרָתוֹ עָלְתָה נִשְׁמָתוֹ בִּסְעָרָה הַשָּׁמַיְמָה - אַחַ"כּ בִּימֵי הַשִּׁבְעָה אָמְרוּ הַמְקוֹרָבִים שֶׁהַ"הַזְכָּרָה" הָאַחֲרוֹנָה אֵצֶל הַבֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל הָיָה ר' דָּוִד פְרֶנְקְל].
הרב יצחק פרנקל שליט"א"זכור לדוד" (ירושלים תש"ס) ע' רמ"ו
body_en:
HaRav HaGaon R' David Frenkel *zt"l* (a close associate of the "Chazon Ish" *zt"l*) told that when it became known to him - in the month of Shevat 5737 (1977) - that he had to undergo surgery, R' David said that regarding this surgery, one must consult specifically with the "Beis Yisrael". He asked through the attendant to set a time for him, and the Beis Yisrael said he should come to him at dawn. This was on the second to last day of the life of the "Beis Yisrael". At dawn, R' David came, together with his brother-in-law, the Gaon Rabbi Rafael HaLevi Soloveitchik *zt"l*. The "Beis Yisrael" stood then by the bars in the courtyard of the Beis Medrash together with an *Avreich* (HaRav HaChassid R' Avraham Yosef Irnenstein *shlita*, who told me this). And when he saw them approaching and coming, he said to that *Avreich*, "Di tzvay Yiden kumen aher" (These two Jews are coming here), and immediately entered his room and waited for them.
And R' David *zt"l* told that at the end of their conversation, when they stood to part from him, the "Beis Yisrael" wished him a blessing for a complete recovery. And when they went out from before him, the Rebbe added and called out after them in a loud voice: "And bless me also," and they departed from him in peace.
As mentioned, this was the second to last day of the "Beis Yisrael", and no one imagined then that the days of the "Beis Yisrael" were numbered upon the earth. Indeed, he saw what Rashi writes on this verse: **וברכתם גם אותי** - "And bless me also" (Exodus 12:32). And his language is: "Pray for me that I do not die." And indeed, not for nothing did he cry out after them in a great voice and did not cease: "And bless me also."
[HaRav HaChassid R' Avraham Yosef mentioned above told me that in his last two weeks, there were several more instances where he dismissed those walking before him and said to them "And bless me also," and no one paid attention to what was hinted in Rashi's commentary on this verse - and by the way, I will note that R' David *zt"l* was the last "Hazkarah" (Kvitel) of the Beis Yisrael. For R' David traveled immediately that Monday morning to Switzerland and had the surgery, and every day the Mashbak (attendant) would inquire with the family in the name of the Rebbe to know R' David's welfare. On the last holy Shabbat, Parshat Shekalim, before the Beis Yisrael entered the synagogue for the Shacharit prayer of Shabbat, he inquired again about R' David, and wondered that no news was heard from before Shabbat. The Beis Yisrael then prayed Shacharit of Shabbat with the congregation, and before the recitation of Hallel, he went out from the Beis Medrash, entered his room, and the next day his soul ascended in a storm to Heaven - afterwards, during the days of Shiva, the close ones said that the last "Hazkarah" with the Beis Yisrael was R' David Frenkel.]
Source: Rabbi Yitzchak Frenkel Shlita, "Zechor L'David" (Jerusalem 5760) p. 246

After the passing of the Beis Yisrael of Ger *zy"a*, our Rebbe (K"k Maran Admor Mahari"m of Rachmastrivka *zt"l*) told that he once heard from a Litvish Jew who said to him that he could testify about the Rebbe of Ger that he instilled *Yirat Shamayim* (Fear of Heaven) even at the end of the world.
Source: "Ma'ayan HaBracha", Sivan 5766, p. 30

body_he: הגאון ר' נחום רוטשטיין שליט"אראש ישיבת "נזר התורה""ברכת אברהם" (ירושלים תשס"ח) ע' ק"נ
body_en:
I heard from K"k Maran Admor, the Beis Yisrael *zt"l*, on the verse: **שחת לו לא בניו מומם וגו'** - "Corruption is his, not His children's is the blemish, etc." (Deuteronomy 32:5). **בינו שנות דור ודור** - "Consider the years of generation and generation." For if one corrupted and spoiled for himself alone, he can still return in repentance and be accepted. But "His children - their blemish," what his children saw and became corrupted by, this blemish remains, for it is impossible to fix this. And therefore it is said, "Consider the years of generation and generation," to remember this. Thus are his holy words.
Source: HaGaon R' Nachum Rotstein Shlita, Rosh Yeshivat "Nezer HaTorah", "Birkat Avraham" (Jerusalem 5768) p. 150

body_he:
הגה"ק ר' יַעֲקֹבְ'לֶה זַצַ"ל אַדְמוֹ"ר מִפְּשֶׁעווָארְסְק, אִם כִּי לֹא הָיָה רָגִיל לְהַבִּיט בְּסִפְרֵי צַדִּיקֵי חֲדַר קָאצְק, אָמְנָם אָמַר שֶׁהַסֵּפֶר בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל שׁוֹנֶה וְהָי' מְעַיֵּין בּוֹ, בַּאֲשֶׁר הוּא מָלֵא מִסִּפְרֵי הַנֹּעַם אֱלִימֶלֶךְ קְדֻשַּׁת לֵוִי וְהַחוֹזֶה מִלּוּבְּלִין וְעוֹד זִי"עַ.
הגה"צ רבי אלחנן היילפרין זצ"לאבד"ק גולדרס-גרין"יפה שיחתן" (ברוקלין תשס"ה) ח"ב, ע' קנ"ח
body_en:
My son-in-law, the Rav of Makova *shlita*, had a wondrous thing regarding a Torah thought (in Seder Bereishit) in the holy book "Beis Yisrael" of the Rebbe of Ger *zt"l*, which the proofreaders wanted to omit. The Beis Yisrael *zt"l* appeared to him in a dream to warn him about the matter, saying to him that he should know that this is "Torah".
The Holy Gaon R' Yaakov'ele *zt"l*, Admor of Pshevorsk, although he was not accustomed to look into the books of the Tzaddikim of the Cheder of Kotzk, nevertheless said that the book "Beis Yisrael" is different and he would study it, inasmuch as it is full of the books "Noam Elimelech", "Kedushat Levi", and the "Chozeh of Lublin" and others *zy"a*.
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Elchanan Halperin zt"l, Av Beit Din Golders Green, "Yafah Sichatan" (Brooklyn 5765) Part 2, p. 158

body_he:
--- פֹּה הָיָה אֵפֶר, אֶת דְּבָרָיו שָׁמַעְתָּ מִתּוֹךְ כִּבְשַׁן הָאֵשׁ מִטְּרַבְּלִינְקָה... עֵדָה חֲרֵבָה... עָפָר שֶׁחָזַר לִהְיוֹת לְבֵנָה. הָאֲנָשִׁים הַמְבֻגָּרִים זוֹכְרִים זֹאת. אֵלֶּה שֶׁעָבְרוּ וְנִשְׁטְפוּ מֵעַל רֹאשָׁם בַּחֻרְבָּן, זוֹכְרִים הֵם אֶת הָרֶמֶץ מִתּוֹךְ הָאֵשׁ, אֶת אוֹתוֹ אֵפֶר, אֵפֶר כִּירָה מוּכָן הוּא, הָאֵפֶר שֶׁהָיָה מוּכָן לְקַבֵּל עָלָיו עֹל מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם, אוֹתוֹ אֵפֶר הַנִּשְׂרָפִין שֶׁמִּמֶּנּוּ נִבְנָה דּוֹר עִם כּ"כ הַרְבֵּה קְדֻשָּׁה. כְּיִרְמְיָ' בִּשְׁעָתוֹ שֶׁלִּיקֵּט אֵבָרִים, הָרַבִּי לִיקֵּט אֵבָרִים וּפְדָרִים שֶׁפָּקְעוּ מֵע"ג הַמִּזְבֵּחַ בְּאוֹשְׁוִויץ... עוֹדְדָם, חִיזְּקָם... "עַם שְׂרִידֵי חֶרֶב הָלוֹךְ לְהַרְגִּיעוֹ יִשְׂרָאֵל".
כ"ק מרן אדמו"ר ה"פני מנחם" מגור זצוק"לבאבן הפינה לישיבת חידושי הרי"ם - ב' ניסן תשל"ז"רבא דעמיה" (ירושלים תשס"ב) ע' כ"ב
body_en:
My father (the "Imrei Emet") *zt"l* wrote in his will, after the entire will he wrote, as is known, and in which he asked the congregation to strengthen themselves, he wrote further: "Since new faces have come, I hereby hand over the leadership to my son M' Yisrael *sheyichyeh*." What is the meaning of: "New faces" (Panim Chadashot)? Tosafot says ashes of forbidden items are permitted. Why? Because "new faces have come."
--- Here there were ashes, you heard his words from within the fiery furnace of Treblinka... A destroyed congregation... Dust that returned to be a brick. The older people remember this. Those who passed and were swept away over our heads in the destruction, they remember the embers from within the fire, that ash, ash that is ready for the stove, the ash that was ready to accept upon itself the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven, those burnt ashes from which a generation was built with so much holiness. Like Yirmiyah in his time who gathered limbs, the Rebbe gathered limbs and scattered pieces that burst from upon the altar in Auschwitz... encouraged them, strengthened them... "With the remnants of the sword, Israel goes to find rest."
Source: K"k Maran Admor the "Pnei Menachem" of Ger zt"l, At the cornerstone laying for Yeshivat Chiddushei HaRim - 2 Nissan 5737, "Rava D'Amieh" (Jerusalem 5762) p. 22

In the massive spiritual "Yesh" (substance) that the "Beis Yisrael" left behind, our Rebbe (K"k Maran Admor the "Lev Simcha" *zt"l*) saw the only comfort for the vast void that opened with his passing. In a note in the handwriting of our Rebbe (the "Lev Simcha") which was found in his room during the week of the "Shiva", it was found written:
"Strengthening in Torah and pure Fear of Heaven, the precious treasure that the deceased and our fathers worked for: Holy Yeshivot, holy youth, holy Kollels, holy and pure homes. This is his comfort, our comfort, and your comfort!"
Source: "Rava D'Amieh" (Jerusalem 5762) p. 10

[HaRav HaChassid Rabbi Zvi Yitzchak Abramowitz *zt"l*, the Rav of Chatzor] told that on one of his travels [to the 'Beis Yisrael' *zy"a*] he heard the Rebbe quoting the words of the Gemara (Berachot 12b): "Anyone who commits a transgression and is ashamed of it, is forgiven for all his sins immediately." And he wondered to himself, for in the Gemara the word "immediately" is not mentioned, but he kept the matter in faith wondering. How great was his joy when he saw some time later that in Tosafot at the end of the chapter "Ein Omdin" (Page 34b, s.v. Kisui), the article is brought with the addition of the word "immediately".
Source: "Zvi Tiferet" (Jerusalem 5771) p. 179

The Holy Admor, the *Be'er Yaakov* of Nadvorna Zt"l, saved me once from surgery. Several doctors told me that surgery on the vocal cords was mandatory. He sent me then to a certain doctor, and when I arrived at him, he already knew all the details and did what was necessary. Blessed be G-d, I did not need surgery.
Source: Halichot Kodesh

body_he:
וְאָמַר הַפְּנֵי מְנַחֵם שֶׁמּוּנָח בָּזֶה עִנְיָן עָמוֹק, לֹא רַק לְגַבֵּי אֲמִירַת הַקַּדִּישׁ וּבָרְכוּ, אֶלָּא שֶׁלְּאַחַר פְּטִירַת הַצַּדִּיק יֵשׁ לְהַרְבּוֹת קְדֻשָּׁה אֵצֶל כָּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד.
הגה"ח רבי יעקב מאיר אלתר שליט"אבן כ"ק מרן ה"פני מנחם" מגור זצוק"ל"אדר וארבע פרשיות" (ברוקלין תש"ע) עמ' 3
body_en:
I remember on 2nd Adar 5756 (1996), which was the last day in the life of my master, father, and teacher, the Pnei Menachem *zy"a*, he said after the Mincha prayer, that in the year 5708 (1948), after they rose from the "Shiva" of the Imrei Emet *zy"a*, the Pnei Menachem wanted to pray together in the Minyan of Maran the Beis Yisrael *zy"a*. And the Beis Yisrael told him to pray in another place, because when a Tzaddik passes away, much holiness departs from the world, and one needs to increase holiness, and who can estimate the magnitude of the holiness that is missing with the passing of Father *zt"l*, therefore it is better that he also prays before the Ark (leads the prayers).
And the Pnei Menachem said that a deep matter lies in this, not only regarding the saying of Kaddish and Barchu, but that after the passing of the Tzaddik, one must increase holiness with each and every one.
Source: HaRav HaChassid Rabbi Yaakov Meir Alter Shlita, son of K"k Maran the "Pnei Menachem" of Ger zt"l, "Adar V'Arba Parshiot" (Brooklyn 5770) p. 3

body_he: הרב אליהו נאה שליט"א"חכו ממתקים" (ירושלים תשס"ח) ח"א, ע' רכ"א
body_en:
Once while walking in the settlement of Emmanuel, our Rebbe [HaGaon Rabbi Shlomo Zalman Auerbach *zt"l*] asked me to accompany him to the name of the street we were walking on. I answered him: "Beis Yisrael" - named after the Rebbe of Ger *zt"l*. Immediately our Rebbe said an explanation in the name of the Beis Yisrael:
It is written: **בית ישראל ברכו את ה' בית אהרן ברכו את ה' בית הלוי ברכו את ה' יראי ה' ברכו את ה'** - "House of Israel, bless the L-rd; House of Aaron, bless the L-rd; House of Levi, bless the L-rd; You who fear the L-rd, bless the L-rd" (Psalms 135:19-20).
Why by "You who fear the L-rd" is "House" not written, like in all the rest? Rather, the house of those who fear the L-rd is the Beis HaMedrash. (I heard from HaRav HaGaon Rabbi Chaim Kornberg *zt"l*).
Source: Rabbi Eliyahu Na'eh Shlita, "Chaku Mamtakim" (Jerusalem 5768) Part 1, p. 221

body_he: הגה"ח רבי צבי יצחק אברומוביץ ז"ל"טעם הצבי" (ב"ב תשנ"ב) ח"ב, עמ' ע'
body_en:
K"k Maran Admor the Beis Yisrael *zt"l* said that Chassidim used to say in explanation of the name Amalek - "A mahl leigt er mich avek, a mahl leig ich ihm avek" (Sometimes he defeats me and sometimes I defeat him), and the main thing is who strikes the last blow, to here are his holy words.
Source: HaGaon HaChassid Rabbi Zvi Yitzchak Abramowitz z"l, "Taam HaZvi" (Bnei Brak 5752) Part 2, p. 70

body_he: הרה"ח ר' מרדכי מיירנץ שליט"א"על משכנות הרועים" (ב"ב תשנ"ט) ע' ק"ג
body_en:
The Admor, the "Beis Yisrael" *zt"l* - even before his presidency. He would "enter the thickness of the beam" to supervise the *bochurim* in all their ways. Once at a "Chabura" meal for Rosh Chodesh Adar, suddenly the Admor *zt"l* entered (already then they related to him with awe of majesty, and his appearance by itself aroused excitement). And he said in the name of the "Sfas Emes" (brought in Sfas Emes Likutim): "Mishenichnas Adar" (From when Adar enters) - they did not say "Misheba Adar" (From when Adar comes), meaning that the holiness of Adar needs to enter into the body of the person (there is a version "Es darf't trenin di adern" - one needs to tear the veins and arteries).
Source: HaRav HaChassid R' Mordechai Mayrenz Shlita, "Al Mishkenot HaRo'im" (Bnei Brak 5759) p. 103

body_he: הגה"צ רבי חנוך דב פדווא מלונדון זצ"ל(מרשימות הגאון רבי אברהם יונה שווארץ שליט"א)"הליכות חנוך" (ברוקלין תשע"א) ע' מ"ד
body_en:
In the name of K"k Admor the Beis Yisrael of Ger *zt"l*, the reason for the one who says "Hav'arah l'lav yatzat" (Burning was singled out for a prohibition) (Shabbat 70a), for seemingly it requires explanation why burning is different that it is lighter than all other primary labors. And he said the reason for this is that behold it is said: **וינח ביום השביעי** - "And He rested on the seventh day" (Exodus 20:11). That the Holy One, Blessed be He, as if it were, rested on Shabbat from all the labors He did during the whole week before Shabbat, and all the labors that were prohibited are a remembrance of the labors that the Holy One, Blessed be He, rested from on Shabbat. But the labor of fire, behold it was created on Motzaei Shabbat (see Pesachim 54a). It turns out that regarding the labor of fire, the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not rest on Shabbat Bereishit, therefore it is not so severe, and his words are pure.
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Chanoch Dov Padwa of London zt"l (From the notes of HaGaon Rabbi Avraham Yonah Schwartz Shlita), "Halichot Chanoch" (Brooklyn 5771) p. 44

body_he: הגאון רבי משה שטרנבוך שליט"א"מועדים וזמנים" (ב"ב תשמ"א) ח"ח, לקוטי הערות פ' ל"ו
body_en:
I will note here a new thing in the laws of Tzedakah, which K"k Admor Rabbi Yisrael Alter *zt"l* of Ger *zy"a* innovated, and the root of his words is that behold in Tzedakah there is an obligation to give to every needy person sufficient for his lack, and even a horse to ride upon and a servant to run before him, as is explained in Rambam, Chapter 7 of Matnot Aniyim, and its source is from Ketubot 67b: that this is included in the Mitzvah of Tzedakah, and it seems that this is from the obligations of Tzedakah specifically. But from Maaser (tithe) money, it is impossible to give this, for Maaser money is a special enactment to give to the poor literally for necessary needs, not like today where they are accustomed to give from Maaser money for rent and household needs if they are not necessary. For although this is included in the Mitzvah of Tzedakah, but it is not explained that this is included in the rectification of Maaser, which needs to be designated for the poor literally as implied. And in his opinion, it is fitting to designate Maaser money separately from Tzedakah money, and to distribute only for necessary needs to the poor literally, for in this alone does the rectification of Maaser go out, etc. But he decided not to publicize the matter, and apparently he feared lest publishing this would be a beginning to strictness and its end to leniency, that they would not give, Heaven forbid, Maaser money, out of fear that they would not give in the proper place, therefore we brought his words here as a note and not for practical ruling.
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Moshe Sternbuch Shlita, "Moadim U'Zmanim" (Bnei Brak 5741) Part 8, Likutim He'arot Parshat 36

body_he: מרשימות הרה"ג ר' מיכאל אריה ראנד שליט"א"המודיע-תוספת", י"ב שבט תשס"ט, ע' י"ח
body_en:
The Rabbi [HaGaon HaChassid Rabbi Zvi Yitzchak Abramowitz] *zt"l* told me that he was with the Beis Yisrael *zy"a* comforting mourners at the home of HaGaon Rabbi Shlomo Attik *zt"l* when he sat Shiva for his mother. Maran *zy"a* said then that King David, peace be upon him, said (Psalms 35:14) **כאבל אם קדר שחותי** - "I bowed down heavily, as one that mourneth for his mother." And why did he mention mourning for a mother specifically, and not mourning for a father? And he answered by way of what is brought in the Radak on the verse (Psalms 8:4) **כי אראה שמיך מעשה אצבעתיך ירח וכוכבים אשר כוננתה** - "When I behold Your heavens, the work of Your fingers, the moon and the stars, which You have established." Why did King David, peace be upon him, not mention the sun as well? And he explains there according to the simple meaning "For at night he said this psalm when he was looking at the moon and stars and understanding the wonders of the Creator." And similarly, one can say that David said this verse after his mother passed away and he mourned for her before his father passed away. And Maran *zy"a* added further and said: Behold it is brought (Bereishit Rabbah 96:4) that Yishai lived four hundred years, and if so, King David, peace be upon him, passed away before him, and did not mourn for him at all. Thus are his holy words.
Source: From the notes of HaRav HaGaon R' Michael Aryeh Rand Shlita, "HaModia-Tosefet", 12 Shevat 5769, p. 18

body_he:
מִתּוֹלְדוֹתָיונוֹסָף עַל כְּהוּנָתוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי חַיִּים [הַגְּרָ"ח מִבְּרִיסְק] כְּאַבָּ"ד וְרַ"מ בְּרִיסְק, הִרְבִּיץ תּוֹרָה לַאֲלָפִים, אִם כִּי לְאַחַר שֶׁעָבַר לִבְרִיסְק לֹא הָיְתָה לוֹ יְשִׁיבָה רִשְׁמִית עִם כָּל הַסַּמְמָנִים שֶׁל מוֹסָד. בְּנוֹ רַבִּי יִצְחָק זְאֵב, שֶׁרָאשֵׁי וּפַרְנְסֵי קְהִילַּת בְּרִיסְק הֵטִילוּ עָלָיו אֶת הָעֲטָרָה לְאַחַר פְּטִירַת אָבִיו, הִמְשִׁיךְ אֶת שַׁרְשֶׁרֶת הַקֹּדֶשׁ, וּכְמוֹ אָבִיו לֹא הָיְתָה לוֹ יְשִׁיבָה, אִם כִּי בַּשָּׁנִים הַבָּאוֹת רוֹוַח מִנְהָג חָדָשׁ בִּישִׁיבוֹת לִיטָא לִשְׁלוֹחַ אֶת טוֹבֵי הַתַּלְמִידִים לִבְרִיסְק, לִלְמֹד פֶּרֶק זְמַן מְסֻיָּם, חֳדָשִׁים וּלְעִתִּים גַּם שָׁנָה שְׁלֵימָה וָמַעְלָה, כְּדֵי לְהִתְבַּשֵּׂם מִתּוֹרָתוֹ שֶׁל הַגְּרִי"ז.
בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁהַגְּרִי"ז נִתְבַּקֵּשׁ לִישִׁיבָה שֶׁל מַעְלָה בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם, לִפְנֵי הִתְקַדֵּשׁ יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים, תַּשׁ"ךְ, נִמְנְתָה קְהִילַּת בְּרִיסְק בֵּין קְהִילּוֹת הַקֹּדֶשׁ שֶׁנֶּחְרְבוּ בַּשּׁוֹאָה שֶׁפָּגְעָה בְּבֵית יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּאֵירוֹפָּה. רָאשֶׁיהָ וּפַרְנָסֶיהָ כְּמוֹ כָּל בְּנֵי הַקְּהִילָּה שֶׁקִּדְּשׁוּ אֶת ה' בְּחַיֵּיהֶם, נִסְפּוּ בַּשּׁוֹאָה עַל קִדּוּשׁ הַשֵּׁם. לֹא הָיָה מִי שֶׁיַּטִּיל עַל בְּנוֹ אֶת אִיצְטְלַת הָרַבָּנוּת, אַךְ הָעֲטָרָה הוּטְלָה עַל בְּכוֹר הַבָּנִים רַבִּי יוֹסֵף דֹּב, גַּם לְלֹא גִּינוּנִים פּוֹרְמָלִיִּים אוֹ רִשְׁמִיִּים, וְהוּא הוֹסִיף חוּלְיָה רְבִיעִית בְּשַׁלְשֶׁלֶת בְּרִיסְק הַמְעַטִּירָה לְשֵׁם וּלְתִפְאֶרֶת.
בְּרִיסְק כְּבֵית מִדְרָשׁ, כְּמוֹ סוּרָא וּפוּמְבְּדִיתָא לְפָנִים, כְּמוֹ לוּבְּלִין פְּרֶשְׁבּוּרְג וְטְשֶׁעבִּין בַּדּוֹר הָאַחֲרוֹן, הָפְכוּ לִהְיוֹת מוּשָׂגִים בְּעוֹלַם הַתּוֹרָה יוֹתֵר מֵאֲשֶׁר מְצִיאוּת בָּעוֹלָם הַגַּשְׁמִי, וְלָכֵן הֵם מוֹסִיפִים לְהִתְקַיֵּים גַּם בְּסַעֲרוֹת הַיָּמִים. אִם בְּרִיסְק הַקְּהִילָּה הַיְּהוּדִית עָלְתָה בְּלֶהָבוֹת וְהָפְכָה לְעִיֵי חֳרָבוֹת, הֲרֵי בְּרִיסְק כְּמוּשָׂג חִידְּשָׁה נְעוּרֶיהָ מִבְּחִינָה רוּחָנִית, וּכְבִיכוֹל הוּעְתְּקָה לִירוּשָׁלַיִם עִיר הַקֹּדֶשׁ, רוּחָהּ שֶׁל אוֹתָהּ קְהִילָּה שׁוֹרָה בְּאָהֳלֵי תּוֹרָה הֲלֹא הֵם בָּתֵּי הַמִּדְרָשׁ אֲשֶׁר בִּשְׁכוּנַת אַחֲוָה וְהַסִּמְטָאוֹת הַמּוֹבִילוֹת אֲלֵיהֶם, וּכְמוֹ בַּיָּמִים שֶׁלִּפְנֵי הַשּׁוֹאָה מַקְרִינָה בְּרִיסְק אֶת אוֹרָהּ לְמֶרְחַקִּים, וּמִבְּחִינָה כַּמּוּתִית אַף הוּרְחֲבוּ גְּבוּלוֹתֶיהָ...
אִם נִיתָּן לְהַגְדִּיר אֶת אִישִׁיּוּתָם שֶׁל הַגְּאוֹנִים לְבֵית בְּרִיסְק, נִיתָּן לְהַגְדִּיר אֶת רַבִּי יוֹסֵף דֹּב, שֶׁזָּכִינוּ לִרְאוֹתוֹ בְּאַרְבָּעִים שְׁנוֹתָיו הָאַחֲרוֹנוֹת בְּעִיר הַקֹּדֶשׁ, כְּמַמְשִׁיךְ נֶאֱמָן שֶׁל אָבִיו הַגָּדוֹל בְּכָל פְּרָט וּפְרָט, כַּאֲשֶׁר הִשְׁמִיעַ בְּאָזְנֵי תַּלְמִידָיו אֶת תּוֹרָתוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו הַגְּרִי"ז, אִם מִשֶּׁלּוֹ וְאִם שֶׁל זְקֵנוֹ רַבִּי חַיִּים לֹא הָיְתָה זֹאת חֲזָרָה בְּעָלְמָא אֶלָּא מַמָּשׁ חַי אוֹתָהּ מֵחָדָשׁ. הוּא לֹא הֶחְסִיר אֲפִילּוּ אֶת הַהַרְגָּשָׁה וְהַהַדְגָּשָׁה הַקַּלָּה בְּיוֹתֵר, וְלֹא נֶעֶדְרָה מִמֶּנּוּ הַנִּימָה הַקַּלָּה בְּיוֹתֵר, כְּפִי שֶׁשָּׁמַע אֶת הַדְּבָרִים מִפִּי אָבִיו. לֹא הָיְתָה זֹאת תּוֹצָאָה שֶׁל זִכְרוֹנוֹ הַפֶנוֹמֶנָלִי, וְאָמְרוּ עָלָיו, כִּי כָּל מַה שֶּׁלָּמַד אִי פַּעַם לֹא שָׁכַח מֵעוֹלָם, אֶלָּא הָיְתָה זֹאת דֶּרֶךְ הַהֲבָנָה הַיְּשָׁרָה, הָאָב וְהַבֵּן הָיוּ זֵהִים בְּדַרְכֵי מַחֲשַׁבְתָּם, וְלֹא הָיוּ יְכוֹלִים לְהַעֲלוֹת עַל דַּעְתָּם עִיקּוּם כָּל שֶׁהוּא בְּדֶרֶךְ הֲבָנַת הַתּוֹרָה. עוֹד בִּשְׁנוֹת נְעוּרָיו לֹא זָזָה יָדוֹ מִתּוֹךְ יָדוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו הַגָּדוֹל. בְּכִשְׁרוֹנוֹתָיו הָעֲצוּמִים זָכָה לְהַעֲרָכַת בְּנֵי הַתּוֹרָה שֶׁנָּשְׂאוּ נַפְשָׁם לְהִתְקָרֵב אֵלָיו אוּלָם הוּא הִשְׁתַּדֵּל לֹא לְהִתְבַּלֵּט, וְתָמִיד עָמַד, כִּבְיָכוֹל, בְּצִילּוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו. כִּשְׁרוֹנוֹתָיו הָעֲצוּמִים לֹא פָּגְעוּ בְּשַׁקְדָנוּתוֹ וְלֹא רָצָה לְהִיבָּטֵל מִלִּימּוּדוֹ אֲפִילּוּ שָׁעָה קַלָּה, אוּלָם בִּשְׁעַת הַצּוֹרֶךְ כַּאֲשֶׁר אַבָּא הֵטִיל עָלָיו שְׁלִיחֻיּוֹת צִבּוּרִיּוֹת מִלֵּא אוֹתָם בִּמְסִירוּת וּבְנֶאֱמָנוּת מוּפְלָאָה, אוּלָם מִיָּד עִם מִילּוּי הַשְּׁלִיחוּת חָזַר לְלִימּוּד הַתּוֹרָה, כִּבְיָכוֹל לְהַשְׁלִים אֶת הַזְּמַן שֶׁעָסַק בִּשְׁלִיחוּת אַחֶרֶת.
לְכוֹתֵב הַטּוּרִים נִמְסַר, כִּי עוֹד לִפְנֵי מִלְחֶמֶת הָעוֹלָם הַשְּׁנִיָּה הוּעְלְתָה הַצָּעָה לַעֲלִיָּיתוֹ שֶׁל הַגְּרִי"ז לִירוּשָׁלַיִם, וְאָז הִצְבִּיעַ עַל בְּנוֹ הַבְּכוֹר הַגְּרִי"ד כְּמוּכְשָׁר לְמַלֵּא מְקוֹמוֹ כְּרַב וְאַבָּ"ד בְּרִיסְק.
כַּאֲשֶׁר בָּנָה אֶת בֵּיתוֹ עִם רַעְיָתוֹ הָרַבָּנִית ע"ה בִּתּוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי יִצְחָק וַיְינְשְׁטֵיין זַצַ"ל רַבָּהּ שֶׁל וִוישְׁנָאבָה, שִׁיגֵּר מָרָן בַּעַל הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" בְּרָכָה לְבָבִית "לְמַזָּל טוֹב וּלְאֹשֶׁר נֶצַח לִבְנוֹת בַּיִת נֶאֱמָן לְבֵית הַלֵּוִי, לְשִׂמְחַת לֵב וּלְנַחַת הוֹרִים".
בִּשְׁנַת תש"י הֵטִיל עָלָיו אָבִיו הַגְּרִי"ז לְהַשְׁמִיעַ שִׁיעוּרִים בִּפְנֵי בְּנֵי הַחֲבוּרוֹת שֶׁהָיוּ בָּאִים לִשְׁמֹעַ תּוֹרָה מִפִּי אָבִיו, וּבְמֶשֶׁךְ עֶשֶׂר הַשָּׁנִים תש"י-תש"ך שִׁמֵּשׁ הַגְּרִי"ד בְּחָסוּת אָבִיו כְּרֹאשׁ יְשִׁיבַת בְּרִיסְק בְּפוֹעַל, וְעאכ"ו לְאַחַר שֶׁשָּׁקְעָה הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ בַּצָּהֳרַיִם וְהַגְּרִי"ז נִסְתַּלֵּק לְבֵית עוֹלָמוֹ הִרְגִּישׁ אֶת גּוֹדֶל הָאַחְרָיוּת שֶׁהוּטְלָה עָלָיו לְהַמְשִׁיךְ בְּשַׁרְשֶׁרֶת מַרְבִּיצֵי הַתּוֹרָה. אָמְנָם הַתַּלְמִידִים שֶׁהָיוּ נוֹהֲרִים לְבֵית מִדְרָשׁוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו בִּרְחוֹב פְּרַס, הוֹסִיפוּ לִנְהוֹר אֵלָיו, אֶל חַדְרוֹ הַצַּר בִּרְחוֹב מְנַחֵם, וְשָׁם הִסְתּוֹפְפוּ בְּצִלּוֹ בִּשְׁאִיפָתָם לִשְׁתּוֹת מִבְּאֵר הַמַּיִם הַחַיִּים.
בְּשִׁיעוּרָיו, אִם עַל מַסֶּכְתּוֹת סֵדֶר קָדָשִׁים, אִם עַל סֵדֶר זְרָעִים וּטְהָרוֹת, וְאִם בְּחִדּוּשָׁיו שֶׁל פָּרָשַׁת הַשָּׁבוּעַ בְּמוֹצָ"שׁ שֶׁשֻּׁלְּבוּ בָּהֶם הֲלָכוֹת חַיִּים וְהַשְׁקָפוֹת תּוֹרָנִיּוֹת, הָיָה מְשַׁלֵּב בְּתוֹךְ חִדּוּשָׁיו הוּא אֶת חִדּוּשֵׁי זְקֵנוֹ הַגְּרָ"ח וְאָבִיו הַגְּרִי"ז, בְּנֹסַח בֵּית מִדְרָשָׁהּ שֶׁל בְּרִיסְק, וְהַתַּלְמִידִים הָיוּ מְרוּתָּקִים לְמוֹצָא פִּיו. אֵין אֵיפוֹא כָּל פֶּלֶא שֶׁמֶּרְחֲקֵי אֲרָצוֹת וּמֵעֵבֶר לַיָּם הָיוּ מֵאוֹת נוֹהֲרִים לְהִצְטָרֵף לְתַלְמִידֵי יְשִׁיבָתוֹ, וְשָׂח לִי אָחִי וָרֹאשׁ זַצַ"ל, כִּי עוֹד לִפְנֵי אַרְבָּעִים שָׁנָה שָׁמַע מִפִּי הַגְּרִי"ז מִבְּרִיסְק, בְּהַצְבִּיעוֹ עַל בְּכוֹר בָּנָיו: "עוֹד יְהֵא רֹאשׁ יְשִׁיבָה גָּדוֹל".
הַגְּרִי"ד הָיָה מַשְׁמִיעַ אֶת שִׁיעוּרָיו לְעִתִּים בְּבֵית מִדְרָשׁוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו, אוּלָם מִידֵי יוֹם בְּיוֹמוֹ בַּדִּירָה הַצָּרָה בִּרְחוֹב מְנַחֵם, וְהַחֶדֶר הָיָה צַר מֵהָכִיל אֶת עֲשָׂרוֹת הַתַּלְמִידִים בַּחוּרִים וְאַבְרֵכִים גַּם יַחַד, וְעַל כֵּן הָיוּ מְקַיְּמִים אֶת הַשִּׁיעוּרִים בְּמִשְׁמָרוֹת, וְהוּא הָיָה מַשְׁמִיעַ כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה שִׁיעוּרִים מִידֵי יוֹם בְּיוֹמוֹ.
מַמְשִׁיךְ נֶאֱמָן הָיָה לְאָבִיו בִּשְׁמִירָה עַל דֶּרֶךְ הַמְיֻחֶדֶת הַדֶּרֶךְ הָאֵיתָנָה, הַבְּנוּיָה עַל חֹסֶר פְּשָׁרָה עַל הָרַעְיוֹן הַיְסוֹדִי לְהַמְשִׁיךְ הָלְאָה אֶת מְסוֹרֶת הַיַּהֲדוּת לְלֹא שִׁנּוּי קַל בְּיוֹתֵר בְּכָל תְּחוּמֵי הַחַיִּים, אִם בְּסִדְרֵי הַיְשִׁיבָה הַחִיצוֹנִיִּים כִּפְנִימִיִּים, וְאִם בַּהֲלִיכוֹת הַצִּבּוּר, וְגַם כָּאן שָׁמַר הַגְּרִי"ד מִכָּל מִשְׁמָר וְתָבַע נֶאֱמָנוּת לְדֶרֶךְ אָבִיו הַגָּדוֹל.
לֹא הָיָה בִּנְיָן קָבוּעַ, לֹא מִשְׂרָד וְלֹא פְּנִימִיָּה לִישִׁיבַת בְּרִיסְק. סָפֵק אִם אֵי פַּעַם יָצָא מִתַּחַת יָדוֹ מִכְתַּב תּוֹדָה לְאֵלֶּה שֶׁהֶעֱבִירוּ אֵלָיו תְּרוּמוֹתֵיהֶם הַנְּדִיבוֹת, כְּדֵי שֶׁעֲשָׂרוֹת הָאַבְרֵכִים וְהַצְּעִירִים הַמִּסְתּוֹפְפִים בִּישִׁיבַת בְּרִיסְק יְקַבְּלוּ אֶת הַתְּמִיכָה הַמְצֻמְצֶמֶת הַדְּרוּשָׁה לָהֶם, כְּדֵי שֶׁיּוּכַל לְהִסְתּוֹפֵף בְּאָהֳלָהּ שֶׁל תּוֹרָה. קִבְּלוּ הֵימֶנּוּ וּמִיָּדוֹ אֶת הַסְּכוּמִים הַמַּתְאִימִים לְכַלְכָּלַת בֵּיתָם, כָּל אֶחָד לְפִי צְרָכָיו, וְגַם אִם הַדַּלּוּת זָעֲקָה מִקִּירוֹת בֵּיתוֹ, הֲרֵי לְגַבֵּי בְּנֵי תּוֹרָה, אִם תַּלְמִידָיו הוּא וְאִם תַּלְמִידֵי יְשִׁיבוֹת אֲחֵרוֹת, הִתְיַיחֵס בְּרוֹחַב לֵב, וְהִשְׁתַּדֵּל שֶׁיּוּכְלוּ לִלְמֹד תּוֹרָה מִתּוֹךְ הַרְחָבַת הַדַּעַת כְּכָל הָאֶפְשָׁר. גְּאוֹנוּתוֹ בְּחֶסֶד כְּמוֹ בַּתּוֹרָה הִיא פָּרָשָׁה בִּפְנֵי עַצְמָהּ, וְהוּא הֵדִין מְצוּדָתוֹ הַפְּרוּסָה לְמֶרְחַקִּים, וְכָךְ לְמָשָׁל נוֹדַע לְכוֹתֵב הַטּוּרִים, דֶּרֶךְ אַגַּב, עַל תְּמִיכָתוֹ בְּתַלְמוּד תּוֹרָה הַקַּיָּים עַל טָהֳרַת הַקֹּדֶשׁ, בְּחֵיפָה. הוֹצָאוֹת אֵלּוּ, עִם רִיבּוּי הַסַּפְסָלִים בְּבָתֵּי הַמִּדְרָשׁ בַּשָּׁנִים הָאַחֲרוֹנוֹת הִסְתַּכְּמוּ בְּאַלְפֵי דּוֹלָרִים מִדֵּי חֹדֶשׁ בְּחָדְשׁוֹ. מִתּוֹךְ עִקְבִיּוּת וְנֶאֱמָנוּת לְדֶרֶךְ אָבִיו לֹא הָיָה נָכוֹן לְקַבֵּל הִשְׁתַּתְּפוּת מִגּוֹרְמִים כָּל שֶׁהֵם, וְהִקְפִּיד לְקַבֵּל תְּרוּמוֹת רַק מִידֵי יְחִידִים שֶׁזָּכוּ לִיטּוֹל חֶלְקָם בְּהַחְזָקַת הַתּוֹרָה. נִיתָּן לְהָבִין אֵיפוֹא שֶׁמַּעֲמָסָה כַּסְפִּית עֲצוּמָה רָבְצָה עַל שִׁכְמוֹ. אוּלָם בְּבִטְחוֹנוֹ הַגָּדוֹל בַּה', הָיָה סָמוּךְ וּבָטוּחַ שֶׁיּוּכַל לְמַלֵּא אֶת הַהִתְחַיְּיבוּיוֹת שֶׁקִּיבֵּל עָלָיו, וְאָמְנָם בְּס"ד עָלְתָה בְּיָדוֹ לִשְׁמוֹר עַל עֶקְרוֹנוֹתָיו.
מֵאָז הוּנְחוּ הַיְסוֹדוֹת לְשַׁרְשֶׁרֶת הַמְפוֹאֶרֶת בְּווֹלָאזִ'ין, חָלוּ בְּעוֹלָם הַגָּדוֹל חֲלִיפוֹת וּתְמוּרוֹת מִבְּחִינָה מְדִינִית וְגֵיאוֹגְרַפִית. שִׁידּוּד הַמַּעֲרָכוֹת הָיָה גַּם בְּקֶרֶב הָעָם הַיְּהוּדִי, אוּלָם מוֹרֶשֶׁת בְּרִיסְק נִשְׁאֲרָה כְּמַתְכּוּנְתָּהּ וּכְצִבְיוֹנָהּ הַמְּקוֹרִי, מִבְצַר עֹז לַתּוֹרָה וְלַתְּעוּדָה שֶׁשָּׁמַר עַל הַחוֹמָה הַמַּקִּיפָה אֶת בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל, לְבַל יַחְדְּרוּ אֵלֶיהָ רוּחוֹת הַכְּפִירָה הַחִילּוֹנִיּוֹת, מַמְשִׁיכֵי הַשַּׁלְשֶׁלֶת שֶׁל בְּרִיסְק לֹא חִכּוּ עַד אֲשֶׁר הָאוֹיֵב הַחִילּוֹנִי יָבוֹא בִּגְבוּלָם, אֶלָּא יָצְאוּ לַמַּעֲרָכָה לְקַדֵּם פָּנָיו, וְאֶת הֲפָצַת הַתּוֹרָה בָּרַבִּים רָאוּ כְּאֶחָד מִכְּלֵי הַנֶּשֶׁק בַּמִּלְחָמָה.
"גַּם אַחֲרֵי אֲשֶׁר הוּרְמָה הָעֲטָרָה בעוה"ר, אוֹר תּוֹרָתוֹ וּשְׁמוֹ עַד הַיּוֹם זוֹרֵחַ בְּאָהֳלֵי תּוֹרָה, בַּשְּׁעָרִים הַמְּצוּיָּנִים בַּהֲלָכָה" - כּוֹתֵב הַגְּרִי"ז בַּהַקְדָּמָה לְסֵפֶר אָבִיו "חִדּוּשֵׁי רַבֵּינוּ חַיִּים הַלֵּוִי", בְּהַדְגִּישׁוֹ "כִּי דְּבָרָיו הַמְּאִירִים וּשְׂמֵחִים נִתְפַּשְּׁטוּ בְּכָל הָעוֹלָם כֻּלּוֹ ע"י תַּלְמִידָיו וְתַלְמִידֵי תַּלְמִידָיו וְשִׁיטַת לִימּוּדוֹ נִתְפַּשְּׁטָה בְּכָל הַיְשִׁיבוֹת וּמְקוֹמוֹת הַתּוֹרָה, כֻּלָּם לְאוֹר תּוֹרָתוֹ יְהַלֵּכוּן, וּמִבְּאֵר חָכְמָתוֹ יִשְׁאֲבוּ!" וְהַדְּבָרִים נִיתָּנִים לְהֵיאָמֵר גַּם לְגַבֵּי מַמְשִׁיךְ הַשַּׁרְשֶׁרֶת הַגְּרִי"ד, אֲשֶׁר מִשַּׁעֲרֵי צִיּוֹן הַמְּצוּיָּנִים בַּהֲלָכָה הִקְרִין אוֹרוֹ לְמֶרְחַקִּים. נִסְתַּלֵּק ב' אֲדָר א' תשמ"א.
הרב בצלאל לנדוי ז"ל"ישורון" (ירושלים תשס"א) ח"ט, ע' קל"ג

**BIOGRAPHY**
**HaGaon Rabbi Yosef Dov son of the Griz of Brisk *zt"l***
**Yoma DeHillula - 2nd of Adar [1]**
**His History**
In addition to the tenure of Rabbi Chaim [the Griz's father] as Av Beit Din and Rosh Yeshiva in Brisk, he disseminated Torah to thousands, although after he moved to Brisk he did not have an official Yeshiva with all the trappings of an institution. His son Rabbi Yitzchak Zev, upon whom the heads and leaders of the Brisk community cast the crown after his father's passing, continued the holy chain, and like his father, he did not have a Yeshiva, although in the coming years a new custom became prevalent in Lithuanian Yeshivot to send the best students to Brisk, to learn for a specific period of time, months and sometimes a full year and more, to become perfumed with the Torah of the Griz.
When the Griz was asked to the Yeshiva on High in Jerusalem, before the sanctification of Yom Kippur, 5720 (1959), the community of Brisk was counted among the holy communities that were destroyed in the Holocaust that struck the House of Israel in Europe. Its heads and leaders, like all the children of the community who sanctified Hashem in their lives, perished in the Holocaust for the Sanctification of the Name. There was no one to cast the mantle of Rabbinate upon his son, the eldest of the sons, Rabbi Yosef Dov, even without formal or official ceremonies, and he added a fourth link in the glorious chain of Brisk.
Brisk as a Beis Medrash, like Sura and Pumbedita of old, like Lublin, Pressburg, and Tchebin in the last generation, became concepts in the world of Torah more than a reality in the physical world, and therefore they continue to exist even in the storms of the times. If in Brisk the Jewish community went up in flames and turned into heaps of ruins, behold in Brisk as a concept, its youth was renewed spiritually, and as if it were copied to Jerusalem the Holy City, the spirit of that community rests in the tents of Torah, which are the Batei Medrash in the Achva neighborhood and the alleyways leading to them, and just as before the Holocaust it radiated its light from Brisk to distances, quantitatively its borders were even expanded...
If it is possible to define the personality of the Geonim of the House of Brisk, it is possible to define Rabbi Yosef Dov, whom we merited to see in his last forty years in the Holy City, as a faithful continuer of his great father in every single detail. When he sounded in the ears of his students the Torah of his father the Griz, whether his own or that of his grandfather Rabbi Chaim, this was not a mere repetition, but he literally lived it anew. He did not omit even the feeling and the slightest emphasis, nor was the slightest nuance missing from him, as he heard the things from his father. This was not a result of his phenomenal memory, and they said of him that everything he ever learned he never forgot, but rather this was the way of straight understanding; the father and son were identical in their ways of thinking, and could not conceive of any distortion whatsoever in the way of understanding Torah. Even in the years of his youth, his hand did not move from within the hand of his great father. With his immense talents, he merited the appreciation of the Torah scholars who looked up to him, but he tried not to stand out, and always stood, as it were, in the shadow of his father.
His immense talents did not harm his diligence, and he did not want to be idle from his study even for a slight hour. However, in time of need, when "Abba" cast public missions upon him, he fulfilled them with devotion and wondrous faithfulness, but immediately upon completing the mission he returned to Torah study, as if to make up the time he was occupied with another mission.
The writer of these lines was informed that even before the Second World War, the proposal of the Griz's immigration to Jerusalem was raised, and then he pointed to his eldest son, the Griz, as fit to fill his place as Rav and Av Beit Din in Brisk.
When he built his house with his wife *a"h*, the daughter of the Gaon Rabbi Yitzchak Weinstein *zt"l*, the Rav of Vishnaba, Maran the "Chazon Ish" sent a blessing to the house "For Mazal Tov and eternal happiness to build a faithful house for the House of Levi, for the joy of heart and parental pleasure."
In the year 5710 (1950), his father the Griz tasked him with delivering Shiurim before the members of the groups who came to hear Torah from his father, and for ten years 5710-5760, the Griz served under his father's auspices as the de facto Rosh Yeshiva of Brisk. All the more so after the sun set at noon and the Griz passed away to his eternal home, he felt the magnitude of the responsibility cast upon him to continue the chain of Torah disseminators. Although the students who flocked to his father's Beis Medrash on Press Street continued to flow to him, to his narrow room on Menachem Street, and there they gathered in his shadow with their aspiration to drink from the well of living waters.
In his Shiurim, whether on the tractates of Seder Kodshim, Zeraim, or Taharot, and whether in his novellae on the weekly Parsha on Motzaei Shabbat which incorporated laws of life and Torah outlooks, he would integrate within his novellae the novellae of his grandfather the Griz and his father the Griz, in the style of the Beis Medrash of Brisk, and the students were thirsty for his utterances. It is therefore no wonder that from distant lands and across the sea, hundreds flocked to join the students of his Yeshiva, and my brother and Rosh [Yeshiva] *zt"l* told me that forty years ago he heard from the Griz of Brisk, pointing to his eldest son: "He will yet be a great Rosh Yeshiva."
The Griz would deliver his Shiurim sometimes in his father's Beis Medrash, but daily in the narrow apartment on Menachem Street, and the room was too narrow to contain the dozens of students, *bochurim* and *avreichim* together, and therefore they held the Shiurim in shifts, and he would deliver many Shiurim daily.
He was a faithful continuer of his father in guarding the special path, the firm path built on lack of compromise on the fundamental idea to continue the tradition of Judaism without the slightest change in all areas of life, whether in the order of the Yeshiva externally or internally, or in public conduct, and here too the Griz kept guard and demanded loyalty to the path of his great father.
There was no permanent building, no office, and no dormitory for the Brisk Yeshiva. It is doubtful if a letter of thanks ever issued from his hand to those who transferred their generous donations to him, so that the dozens of *avreichim* and young men gathering in the Brisk Yeshiva would receive the meager support for them, so they could gather in the tent of Torah. They received from him and from his hand the sums suitable for their household sustenance, each according to his needs, and even if poverty cried out from the walls of his house, regarding the Bnei Torah, whether his students or students of other Yeshivot, he related with a broad heart, and tried to enable them to learn Torah with expansion of mind as much as possible. His genius in Chessed (kindness) as in Torah is a chapter unto itself, and the same applies to his net spread far and wide. Thus, for example, it became known to the writer of these lines, by the way, about his support for the Talmud Torah on the purity of holiness in Haifa. These expenses, with the increase of benches in the Batei Medrash in recent years, amounted to thousands of dollars monthly. Out of consistency and loyalty to his father's path, he was not willing to accept participation from any bodies whatsoever, and insisted on receiving donations only from individuals who merited to take their share in supporting Torah. It can be understood, therefore, that a heavy financial burden lay on his shoulders. However, in his great trust in Hashem, he was confident that he could fulfill the obligations he took upon himself, and indeed, with Heaven's help, he succeeded in keeping his principles.
Since the foundations for the glorious chain were laid in Volozhin, changes and transformations have occurred in the great world politically and geographically. A realignment of systems also occurred among the Jewish people, but the legacy of Brisk remained in its format and original character, a fortress of strength for Torah and testimony that guarded the wall surrounding the House of Israel, lest the winds of heresy and secularism penetrate it. The continuers of the chain of Brisk did not wait until the secular enemy came to their border, but went out to the campaign to meet him, and they saw the dissemination of Torah to the masses as one of the weapons in the war.
"Also after the crown was lifted due to our many sins, the light of his Torah and his name shine until today in the tents of Torah, in the gates of those excellent in Halacha" - writes the Griz in the introduction to his father's book "Chiddushei Rabbeinu Chaim HaLevi", emphasizing "For his enlightening words and happy ones spread throughout the entire world by his students and his students' students, and his method of study spread in all Yeshivot and places of Torah, all walk by the light of his Torah, and draw from the well of his wisdom!" And these words can be said also regarding the continuer of the chain, the Griz, whose light radiated to distances from the gates of Zion excellent in Halacha. He passed away on 2 Adar I 5741 (1981).
Source: Rabbi Betzalel Landau z"l, "Yeshurun" (Jerusalem 5761) Vol. 9, p. 133

שָׁבוּעַ אַחֲרֵי כֵּן הָיִיתִי אֵצֶל הָרֹאשׁ יְשִׁיבָה שֶׁלִּי, ר' יוֹשֵׁע בֶּער זַצַ"ל [הַגְּרִי"ד מִבְּרִיסְק], וְגַם הוּא הִתְעַנְיֵין: "שָׁמַעְתִּי שֶׁהָיְתָה לְךָ תְּאוּנָה, מַה קָּרָה שָׁם בְּדִיּוּק"? נִסִּיתִי לְתָאֵר לוֹ אֵיךְ אֵירְעָה הַתְּאוּנָה, וְאָז בָּאָה הַתְּגוּבָה שֶׁאֵינֶנִּי יָכוֹל לִשְׁכּוֹחַ אוֹתָהּ: "אוֹי, הָיִיתָ יָכוֹל לַהֲרוֹג בֶּן אָדָם"!
אַתֶּם מְבִינִים? הַשּׁוֹטֵר, שֶׁתַּפְקִידוֹ בְּעֶצֶם לִשְׁמֹר עַל חַיֵּי הָאֲנָשִׁים, כְּשֶׁאָמַרְתִּי לוֹ שֶׁהָרוּחַ הֵעִיפָה אֶת הָרֶכֶב, מִיָּד נָחָה דַּעְתּוֹ וְאָמַר: 'אָה, בְּסֵדֶר'. אֲבָל רֹאשׁ הַיְשִׁיבָה לֹא אָמַר לִי 'הָיִיתָ יָכוֹל לְהֵיהָרֵג', הוּא אָמַר: 'הָיִיתָ יָכוֹל לַהֲרוֹג מִישֶׁהוּ'! הוּא הִסְתַּכֵּל עָלַי כְּמוֹ עַל מְשׁוּגָּע. אֵיךְ יִתָּכֵן שֶׁיְּהוּדִי יַגִּיעַ לְמַצָּב שֶׁבּוֹ הוּא עָלוּל לַהֲרוֹג מִישֶׁהוּ! כָּךְ יְהוּדִים מִסְתַּכְּלִים.
הגאון רבי שמשון פינקוס זצ"ל"תפארת שמשון" (ירושלים תשס"ט) ח"א, ע' שס"ז

**BIOGRAPHY**
**Ha"Levush" *zy"a***
**Yoma DeHillula - 3rd of Adar [20]**
**His History**
Our Rebbe Mordechai Yaffe *zy"a* was born in Prague to his father Rabbi Avraham, in the year 5290 (1530). In his youth, he traveled to Poland and received Torah from the mouths of his teachers, the holy Maharshal and the Rema *zy"a*, and the Torah of the Hidden (Kabbalah) he received from the mouth of his Rebbe "A man of faith, from the greatest of the later Kabbalists, his name is known in the gates," Rabbi Mattityahu son of R' Shlomo Delakrut *zy"a* (see his introduction to his book 'Levushei Or Yekarot').
Upon his return to Prague, he founded a Yeshiva and stood at its head, disseminating Torah to multitudes of students, until the year 5321 (1561), when "wrath went out from before Hashem in the decree of expulsion (of the Emperor Ferdinand) in the land of my birth, the state of Bohemia, and the first preventer moved me, blessed be He, and I was exiled at the head of exiles from the holy community of Prague... and I went to the land of Italy, I came to the holy community of Venice..." (from his introduction to 'Levush Malchut'). In Italy, his soul desired "to learn mathematical and natural sciences".
In the year 5352 (1592), he was appointed as Rav and Av Beit Din in the holy community of Grodno in Lithuania, in place of the Gaon Rabbi Natan son of R' Shimon Spira *zt"l*, author of 'Mevo Shearim' on the book 'Shaarei Dura'. There he built a great synagogue which was named after him, as was engraved on the eastern wall: "The Small Sanctuary established and founded by the Gaon the 'Levush' (5378) Malchut to the minor count".
In the year 5368 (1608), he was called to disseminate Torah and stand at the head of the Yeshiva in Lublin, in place of the Maharram of Lublin - who moved to Krakow. From there he moved to serve as Av Beit Din in Kremenets in the state of Volhynia, and after a short period, in the month of Iyar 5352 (1592), he returned to his birth city Prague, to fill the place of the Maharal as Rav of Prague - who moved to Posen. In the year 5359 (1599), the crowns were switched, and the Maharal returned to serve in Prague, and our Rebbe was called to sit on a high chair and was elevated to the holy community of Posen - there he sat until his last day on earth, on Tuesday, 3rd of the month of Adar II, year 5372 (1612), and there is his resting place in honor.
During the period of his tenure in Posen, he stood at the head of the "Council of Four Lands" (which at his time was only the Council of "Three Lands"), and from there his net was spread over the entire land. And thus he is described by his contemporary, the Gaon Rabbi David Ganz *zt"l*, author of "Tzemach David": "Rabbi Mordechai Yaffe is the great Rav, distinguished in wisdom and age, the standard-bearer of the camp of Israel etc., and he is the one who established many students, and he is the head and main of the Gedolei Roshei Yeshivot and Dayanim of the Three Lands..."
Also in his last days, when he lay on his deathbed, he continued in this, as our eyes will see his lofty responsum in the Responsa of Maharram of Lublin (see siman 122 and 125) which he signed his name: "And behold I am now cast upon a bed of sickness, G-d forbid, and hanging on the judgment of the King, King of Kings, blessed be He, that He should support me to send healing and cure from this illness..." And it is also noted there: "Since the aforementioned Gaon (our Rebbe the Levush) is cast upon a bed of sickness, his arm is weak, and the hands of the Gaon Kamahar"r Mordechai are heavy, and almost no impression is recognizable, he asked of us to confirm and fulfill his signature that it is his handwriting literally, and everyone here is holy, words of a wise mouth find favor. Therefore we confirmed him and fulfilled him: Mordechai son of Har"r Yosef Sofer and Shamash of the holy community of Posen, and signed Yosef Sofer son of my master father Shlomo HaLevi zlh"h". The day of the signature is on Rosh Chodesh Adar II 5372 (1612), meaning two days before his passing.
Source: "Alim LeTerufah", Pekudei 5768, p. 3

מִתּוֹלְדוֹתָיורַבֵּינוּ מָרְדְּכַי יָפֶה זִי"עַ נוֹלַד בִּפְרַאג לְאָבִיו רַבִּי אַבְרָהָם, בִּשְׁנַת ר"צ, בִּנְעוּרָיו נָסַע לְפוֹלִין וְקִיבֵּל תּוֹרָה מִפִּי רַבּוֹתָיו הַקְּדוֹשִׁים הַמַּהַרְשַׁ"ל וְהָרַמָ"א, זִי"עַ, וְאֶת תּוֹרַת הַנִּסְתָּר קִיבֵּל מִפִּי רַבּוֹ "אִישׁ אֱמוּנִים, מִגְּדוֹלֵי מְקֻבָּלִים הָאַחֲרוֹנִים, שְׁמוֹ בַּשְּׁעָרִים נוֹדָע" רַבִּי מַתִּתְיָהוּ בּ"ר שְׁלֹמֹה דֶלוֹקְרַאט זִי"עַ (רְאֵה הַקְדָּמָתוֹ לְסִפְרוֹ 'לְבוּשֵׁי אוֹר יְקָרוֹת').
בְּשׁוּבוֹ לִפְרַאג יָסַד יְשִׁיבָה וְעָמַד בְּרֹאשָׁהּ, כְּשֶׁהוּא מַרְבִּיץ תּוֹרָה לַהֲמוֹנֵי תַּלְמִידִים, עַד שְׁנַת שכ"א, עֵת אֲשֶׁר "יָצָא הַקֶּצֶף מִלִּפְנֵי ה' בִּגְזֵירַת גֵּירוּשׁ (-שֶׁל הַקֵּיסָר פֶערְדִינַאנְד) בְּאֶרֶץ מוֹלַדְתִּי מְדִינַת פִּיהֶם, וְהֵנִיעַנִי הַמֵּנִיעַ הָרִאשׁוֹן יִתְבָּרַךְ וְהִגְלָה הִגְלֵיתִי בְּרֹאשׁ גּוֹלִים מִק"ק פְּרַאג... וְהָלַכְתִּי לְאֶרֶץ אִיטַלְיִי"א בָּאתִי לְק"ק וִינִיצְיָא"ה..." (מִתּוֹךְ הַקְדָּמָתוֹ לַ'לְּבוּשׁ מַלְכוּת'). בְּאִיטַלְיָא אִיוְּותָה נַפְשׁוֹ "לִלְמֹד חָכְמוֹת לִימוּדִיּוֹת וְטִבְעִיּוֹת".
בִּשְׁנַת של"ב נִתְמַנָּה לְרַב וְאַבָּ"ד בְּק"ק הוֹרָאדְנָא שֶׁבְּלִיטָא, עַל מְקוֹמוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי נָתָן בּ"ר שִׁמְעוֹן שַׁפִּירָא זַצַ"ל, בַּעַל 'מְבוֹא שְׁעָרִים' עַל הַסֵּפֶר 'שַׁעֲרֵי דוּרָא', שָׁם בָּנָה, בֵּית כְּנֶסֶת גָּדוֹל אֲשֶׁר נִקְרָא עַל שְׁמוֹ, וּכְפִי שֶׁנֶּחֱרַת עַל כּוֹתֶל הַמִּזְרָח: "הַבַּיִת מִקְדָּשׁ הַמְעַט כּוֹנְנָה וְיִסְּדָה הַגָּאוֹן הַ'לְּבוּשׁ' (-של"ח) מַלְכוּת לפ"ג".
בִּשְׁנַת שס"ח, נִקְרָא לְהַרְבִּיץ תּוֹרָה וְלַעֲמֹד בְּרֹאשׁ הַיְשִׁיבָה שֶׁבְּלוּבְּלִין, עַל מְקוֹמוֹ שֶׁל הַמַּהַרַ"ם מִלּוּבְּלִין - שֶׁעָבַר לִקְרָאקָא. מִשָּׁם עָבַר לְכַהֵן כְּאַבָּ"ד בִּקְרֶעמְנִיץ שֶׁבִּמְדִינַת וָואהלִין, וְכַעֲבוֹר תְּקוּפָה קְצָרָה, בְּחֹדֶשׁ אִיָּיר שְׁנַת שנ"ב, חָזַר לְעִיר מוֹלַדְתּוֹ פְּרַאג, לְמַלֵּא מְקוֹם הַמַּהֲרַ"ל כְּרַבָּהּ שֶׁל פְּרַאג - שֶׁעָבַר לְפוֹזְנָא. בִּשְׁנַת שנ"ט נִתְחַלְּפוּ הָעֲטָרוֹת, וְהַמַּהֲרַ"ל שָׁב לְכַהֵן בִּפְרַאג, וְרַבֵּינוּ נִקְרָא לָשֶׁבֶת עַל כִּסֵּא רָם וְנִשָּׂא דִּק"ק פּוֹזְנָא - שָׁם יָשַׁב עַד יוֹמוֹ הָאַחֲרוֹן עֲלֵי אֲדָמוֹת, בְּיוֹם ג' לְחֹדֶשׁ אֲדָר שֵׁנִי שְׁנַת שע"ב לפ"ק, וְשָׁם מְנוּחָתוֹ כָּבוֹד.
בִּתְקוּפַת כְּהוּנָתוֹ בְּפוֹזְנָא עָמַד בְּרֹאשׁ "וַעַד אַרְבַּע אֲרָצוֹת" (שֶׁעֲדַיִין הָיְתָה בְּשַׁעְתּוֹ רַק וַעַד שֶׁל "שָׁלֹשׁ אֲרָצוֹת"), וּמִשָּׁם הָיְתָה מְצוּדָתוֹ פְּרוּסָה עַל כָּל הָאָרֶץ. וְכָךְ מְתָאֲרוֹ, בֶּן דּוֹרוֹ, הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי דָּוִד גָּאנְז זַצַ"ל בַּעַל "צֶמַח דָּוִד": "רַבִּי מָרְדְּכַי יָפֶה הוּא הָרַב הַגָּדוֹל הַמּוּפְלָג בְּחָכְמָה וְזִקְנָה הַנּוֹשֵׂא דֶּגֶל מַחֲנֵה יִשְׂרָאֵל וְכוּ', וְהוּא אֲשֶׁר הֶעֱמִיד תַּלְמִידִים הַרְבֵּה, וְהוּא רֹאשׁ וְעִיקַּר מִגְּדוֹלֵי רָאשֵׁי יְשִׁיבוֹת וְדַיָּינֵי דְּשָׁלֹשׁ אֲרָצוֹת..."
גַּם בְּיָמָיו הָאַחֲרוֹנִים, כְּשֶׁשָּׁכַב עַל עֶרֶשׂ דְּוַי, הִמְשִׁיךְ בְּכָךְ, וּכְפִי אֲשֶׁר תֶּחֱזֶינָה עֵינֵינוּ תְּשׁוּבָתוֹ הָרָמָתָה בְּשׁוּ"ת מַהֲרַ"ם מִלּוּבְּלִין (עַיֵּי"שׁ סִי' קכ"ב וְסִי' קכ"ה) שֶׁחָתַם שְׁמוֹ: "וַהֲרֵי אֲנִי עַכְשָׁיו מוּטָל עַל עֶרֶשׂ דְּוַי ל"ע וְתוֹלֶה בְּדִין מֶלֶךְ מַלְכֵי הַמְּלָכִים יִתְבָּרַךְ שֶׁהוּא יִסְעָדֵנִי לִשְׁלוֹחַ תְּרוּפָה וּרְפוּאָה מֵחֳלִי זֶה..." וְכֵן מְצוּיָּין שָׁם: "בִּהְיוֹת שֶׁהַגָּאוֹן הַנִּזְכָּר (-רַבֵּינוּ הַלְּבוּשׁ) מוּטָל עַל עֶרֶשׂ דְּוַי, קָלַנוּ מִזְּרוֹעוֹ, וִידֵי הַגָּאוֹן כַּמָּהֲרַ"ר מָרְדְּכַי כְּבֵדִים, וְכִמְעַט שֶׁאֵין רִישּׁוּמוֹ נִיכָּר, בִּיקֵּשׁ מֵאִתָּנוּ לְאַשֵּׁר וּלְקַיֵּים חֲתִימָתוֹ שֶׁהוּא כְּתַב יָדוֹ מַמָּשׁ וְכוּלָּם פֶּה קָדוֹשׁ דִּבְרֵי פִּי חָכָם חֵן. בְּכֵן אִשַּׁרְנוּהוּ וְקִיַּמְנוּהוּ: מָרְדְּכַי בְּהָרַ"ר יוֹסֵף סוֹפֵר וְשַׁמָּשׁ דְּק"ק פּוֹזְנָא, וּנְאֻם יוֹסֵף סוֹפֵר בְּלֹא"א שְׁלֹמֹה הַלֵּוִי זלה"ה". יוֹם הַחֲתִימָה הוּא בְּיוֹם ר"ח אֲדָר שֵׁנִי שע"ב, דְּהַיְינוּ יוֹמַיִים קוֹדֶם פְּטִירָתוֹ.
"עלים לתרופה", פקודי תשס"ח, עמ' ג'

My father, my teacher (HaGaon Rabbi Yeshaya HaLevi Horowitz *zt"l*, one of the important Chabad Chassidim) writes in his book "Eden Tzion" (page 113, note 9) as follows: "I heard in my youth that the reason the Gaon R' Mordechai Yaffe *zt"l* called his books by ten names of 'Levushim' (Garments), is because of a trial he had. Once he strayed and wandered to an impure place, and when he saw and understood that he was in great danger, Heaven forbid, he told them that he was ready for this (what they asked of him there to commit a sin), but he needed the bathroom to relieve himself. There he pushed himself into the sewer which was wide and large, and extended to the outside of the city on the river bank. At the time when he was in great danger of dying there, he was dressed in ten garments and soiled them all. He vowed then that if Hashem Yitbarach would save him and he would remain alive, he would compose ten books with names of ten 'Levushim'" (End quote from the book "Eden Tzion"). And he also prayed then for the future generations that in order not to come to a test, they should not have a handsome appearance.
And Rabbi Levi Yitzchak Bender from Anash told that when he was in the Makova Yeshiva in Poland, he knew a certain *bochur* there named Rabbi Yitzchak Otwock-er, who drew many *bochurim* close to Breslov. When the First World War broke out, the father of the aforementioned Rabbi Yitzchak came to the Yeshiva to return him home. Then they saw that Rabbi Yitzchak *zt"l* was a man of very handsome appearance, and his father was the complete opposite. Rabbi Levi Yitzchak asked him how this could be, and he told him: That his father is the fifteenth generation from the author of the "Levushim", who requested 'what' after the trial he had - that for fifteen generations his descendants should be of repulsive appearance. And he is already the new generation, from him begins a new beginning [and see in the notes of HaRav HaChassid R' Yehuda Leib Levin *zt"l* (in the book "Beis Yisrael" Vorka, Mossad HaRim Levin 5752 p. 207-208) who brings the aforementioned story in the name of the Admor Rabbi Simcha Bunim of Otwock *zy"a* and adds that after the Levush stood the test, the Levush *zy"a* prayed that his seed and his seed's seed would be from now on 'ugly', lest their appearance be beautiful and lest they also be forced to stand in tests, and his prayer was accepted and since then all his descendants are ugly, see there. And the matter is known that the Admorim of Vorka were ugly].
Source: "Amirah Yafah" (Jerusalem 5764) p. 38
