כַּאֲשֶׁר הִגִּיעַ זְמַן הַפֵּרָעוֹן, נִזְדַּמֵּן לַחֲנוּתוֹ שֶׁל הָאַבְרֵךְ פָּרִיץ אֶחָד אֲשֶׁר בָּא לִקְנוֹת בְּשָׂמִים, וּבְצֵאתוֹ שָׁכַח שָׁם אַרְנָק יָקָר שֶׁל עוֹר הַנִּקְרָא "רִימוֹן", וּבוֹ סְכוּם כֶּסֶף, כַּאֲשֶׁר הָאַבְרֵךְ רָאָה אֶת הָאַרְנָק הַנֶּאֱבָד, הִנִּיחוֹ לְמִשְׁמֶרֶת עַד שֶׁיַּחְזֹר הַפָּרִיץ לִיקַּח אֶת אֲבֵידָתוֹ.
כַּעֲבוֹר זְמַן מָה, רָאָה הָאַבְרֵךְ אֶת רַבִּי לֵייבּ שָׂרָה'ס עוֹבֵר בַּשּׁוּק לִפְנֵי חֲנוּתוֹ, רָץ אַחֲרָיו וְאָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי, כְּבָר הִגִּיעַ זְמַן פֵּרָעוֹן הַחוֹב, אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי לֵייבּ, הַאִם לֹא קִבַּלְתָּ עֲדַיִין הַמָּעוֹת. הֵשִׁיב, לֹא. אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי לֵייבּ, הַאִם לֹא שָׁכַח פָּרִיץ רִימוֹן בַּחֲנוּתְךָ, הֵבִין הָאַבְרֵךְ, כִּי הַפָּרִיץ הָיָה שְׁלִיחוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי לֵייבּ שֶׁבָּא לְשַׁלֵּם הַחוֹב. הוֹסִיף הָאַבְרֵךְ וּבִיקֵּשׁ אֶת רַבִּי לֵייבּ שֶׁיְּזַכֵּהוּ לִרְאוֹת אֶת אֶחָד מִל"ו צַדִּיקִים הַנִּסְתָּרִים, אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי לֵייבּ הִקְשֵׁיתָ לִשְׁאוֹל, אֲבָל אִם תִּצְטָרֵף אֵלַי בִּנְסִיעוֹתַי, בַּדְּרָכִים, אוּלַי אוּכַל לְמַלֵּא בַּקָּשָׁתְךָ.
הִסְכִּים הָאַבְרֵךְ לְהִצְטָרֵף אֶל רַבִּי לֵייבּ בְּמַסְּעוֹתָיו, אַחַר כַּמָּה יָמִים הִגִּיעוּ אֶל קְצֵה כְּפָר אֶחָד, וְעָמַד רַבִּי לֵייבּ שָׁם לִפְנֵי בַּיִת קָטָן, וְאָמַר אֶל הָאַבְרֵךְ שֶׁיִּכָּנֵס לִפְנִים, וְשָׁם יִרְאֶה חַיָּיט שֶׁהוּא מִל"ו צַדִּיקִים, נִכְנַס הָאַבְרֵךְ, וְאָמַר לְהַחַיָּיט שֶׁבָּא כְּדֵי שֶׁיְּתַקֵּן לוֹ בֶּגֶד קָרוּעַ, וְנָתַן לוֹ אֶחָד מִבְּגָדָיו שֶׁנִּקְרְעוּ לוֹ לְתַקְּנוֹ, כְּדֵי שֶׁיּוּכַל לִשְׁהוֹת זְמַן מָה בִּמְחִיצַת הַצַּדִּיק. כַּאֲשֶׁר גָּמַר הַחַיָּיט תִּיקּוּן הַבֶּגֶד, בִּיקֵּשׁ שְׂכַר הַמְּלָאכָה כַּמָּה מַטְבְּעוֹת קְטַנּוֹת (גְּרַייצֶער), וְלֹא הָיָה לוֹ לְהָאַבְרֵךְ כִּי אִם מַטְבֵּעַ גָּדוֹל, וּבִיקֵּשׁ מֵהַחַיָּיט שֶׁיְּקַבֵּל מִמֶּנּוּ אֶת הַמַּטְבֵּעַ הַגָּדוֹל, כִּי רָצָה לְהַנְהוֹת אֶת הַצַּדִּיק מֵהוֹנוֹ, אֲבָל הַחַיָּיט לֹא הִסְכִּים לָזֶה, וְאָמַר לוֹ שֶׁיֵּלֵךְ לְהַחֲלִיפוֹ לְמַטְבְּעוֹת קְטַנּוֹת. נִכְנַס הָאַבְרֵךְ לְחֶדֶר סָמוּךְ בְּאוֹתוֹ בַּיִת, לִרְאוֹת אִם יֵשׁ שָׁם מִי שֶׁיּוּכַל לְהַחֲלִיפוֹ, וְרָאָה שֶׁאֵיזֶה רַבִּי יוֹשֵׁב שָׁם, וְהִכִּיר כִּי זֶהוּ צוּרָה שֶׁל צַדִּיק וְקָדוֹשׁ, אֲבָל לֹא יָדַע מִי הוּא, הֶחֱלִיף הַמַּטְבֵּעַ וְחָזַר אֶל הַחַיָּיט לְשַׁלֵּם לוֹ. אַחַר כָּךְ יָצָא מִשָּׁם וְחָזַר אֶל רַבִּי לֵייבּ שָׂרָה'ס אֲשֶׁר הִמְתִּין עָלָיו בַּחוּץ, וְשָׁאַל אֶת רַבִּי לֵייבּ, מִי הוּא הַצַּדִּיק אֲשֶׁר רָאִיתִי יוֹשֵׁב בַּחֶדֶר הַסָּמוּךְ. אָמַר לוֹ רַבִּי לֵייבּ, הַצַּדִּיק הַזֶּה הוּא הָרַבִּי רַבִּי מָרְדְּכַי מִטְּשֶׁערְנָאבִּיל, אֲשֶׁר גַּם הוּא עוֹסֵק לְפַרְנֵס אֶת הַל"ו צַדִּיקִים, מֵאָז וְאֵילָךְ הִתְחִיל הָאַבְרֵךְ לִנְסוֹעַ אֶל הרה"ק מִטְּשֶׁערְנָאבִּיל, וְנִתְקָרֵב אֵלָיו וְנִמְנָה בֵּין תַּלְמִידָיו.
כ"ק מרן אדמו"ר מטאהש זצוק"ל"עבודת עבודה" (קאנאדא תשס"ט) ח"ב, ע' רס"ה

I heard from Hrh"ch R' Moshe Cohen shlita who received from the elders of the Chassidim a story that happened with the students and Chassidim of Hrh"k R' Leib Sarah's zy"a. Once, on a certain night when the Chassidim sat in the Beis Medrash, drinks and Tikun (refreshments) were brought before them by one of the Chassidim who had a Yahrtzeit that night. The Chassidim drank from the drink and tasted from the Tikun, and sat and told stories of Tzaddikim. Thus they delved more and more into matters of Tzaddikim and their service.
The man bringing the Tikun saw and noticed how the Chassidim were elevated and entered another world, and did not want them to disconnect from this state. Therefore, he quickly ran and brought more drink and more Tikun. The Chassidim, in their part, tasted from the Tikun and delved more and more into the stories and Fear of Heaven they learned from those stories. They did not notice at all how hour after hour passed and soon the night had passed. Thus they sat and conversed until dawn, when from great fatigue a deep sleep fell upon them and they all remained sleeping there in the Beis Medrash, some on the floor and some on the bench.
It was the way of Hrh"k R' Leib Sarah's zy"a to pray early. And behold, in that morning when he entered the Beis Medrash, he saw a thing he was not accustomed to seeing until this day: how all the Chassidim were all sleeping specifically in the Beis Medrash. Hrh"k R' Leib zy"a waited in his wonder, until one Chassid woke up from his sleep and saw how the Rebbe was standing here in the Beis Medrash and waiting for them. Trembling and shaking seized him and also great shame surrounded him.
He approached the Rebbe and began to apologize that the story was such: yesterday at night a Chassid brought drink and Tikun, and they drank much drink because they sat for a long time and conversed about matters of stories of Tzaddikim and Fear of Heaven, until at dawn a great sleep fell upon them. When the Rebbe heard what had passed over them, he commanded that they call the owner of the Yahrtzeit to come before him.
And it was when he approached, the Rebbe said: Behold, I have a great claim against you. Know that because of your drink, you merited to bring the Shechinah out of Exile for one night, for it is known that the Shechinah is in Exile, and if so, why did you let Her return afterwards to Her Exile? Until here is the story. And the words are awesome to understand, that through a sitting of those who love [Hashem] together, they merit such a great thing to bring the Shechinah out of Her Exile, and to remove the sorrow of the Shechinah for that time.
Source: HaRah"g R' Moshe Menachem Taubenfeld Shlita, "B'Pikudecha Asicha" (Shikun Skver 5764) p. 91

הָאִישׁ הַמֵּבִיא אֶת הַתִּיקּוּן רָאָה וְהִבְחִין הָאֵיךְ הַחֲסִידִים נִתְעַלּוּ וְנִכְנְסוּ לְעוֹלָם אַחֵר, וְלֹא רָצָה שֶׁיִּתְנַתְּקוּ מִמַּצָּב הַזֹּאת, לָכֵן חִישׁ מַהֵר רָץ וְהֵבִיא עוֹד מַשְׁקֶה וְעוֹד תִּיקּוּן, וְהַחֲסִידִים הֵמָּה בְּשֶׁלָּהֶם טָעֲמוּ מֵהַתִּיקּוּן וְהִתְעַמְּקוּ יוֹתֵר וְיוֹתֵר בְּהַסִּפּוּרִים וּבְיִרְאַת שָׁמַיִם שֶׁלָּמְדוּ מֵהַסִּפּוּרִים הָהֵם, הֵם לֹא הִבְחִינוּ כְּלָל הָאֵיךְ שֶׁעוֹבֵר שָׁעָה אַחַר שָׁעָה וְעוֹד מְעַט וּכְבָר עָבְרָה הַלַּיְלָה, כָּכָה יָשְׁבוּ וְשׂוֹחֲחוּ עַד לִפְנוֹת בֹּקֶר שֶׁמֵּרוֹב הָעֲיֵיפוּת נָפְלָה תַּרְדֵּמָה גְּדוֹלָה עֲלֵיהֶם וְכוּלָּם נִשְׁאֲרוּ לִישַׁן שָׁמָּה בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ מִי מֵהֶם עַל הָרִצְפָּה וּמִי מֵהֶם עַל הַסַּפְסָל.
דַּרְכּוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק ר' לֵייבּ שָׂרָה'ס זִיעָ"א הָיְתָה לְהִתְפַּלֵּל בְּהַשְׁכָּמָה, וְהִנֵּה בַּבֹּקֶר הַהוּא כַּאֲשֶׁר נִכְנַס לְבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ, רָאָה דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא הוּרְגַּל לִרְאוֹת עַד הַיּוֹם, אֵיךְ שֶׁכָּל הַחֲסִידִים כּוּלָּם יְשֵׁנִים דַּיְיקָא בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ. הרה"ק ר' לֵייבּ זִיעָ"א הִמְתִּין בִּתְמִיהָתוֹ, עַד שֶׁחָסִיד אֶחָד הֵקִיץ מִשְּׁנָתוֹ וְרָאָה הָאֵיךְ הָרַבִּי עוֹמֵד כָּאן בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ וּמַמְתִּין עֲלֵיהֶם, חִיל וּרְעָדָה אֲחָזַתּוּ וְגַם בּוּשָׁה גְּדוֹלָה סִיבֵּב אוֹתוֹ.
הוּא הִתְקָרֵב אֵצֶל הָרַבִּי וְהִתְחִיל לְהִתְנַצֵּל כִּי מַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁהָיָה כָּךְ הָיָה, אֶתְמוֹל בַּלַּיְלָה הֵבִיא חָסִיד אֶחָד מַשְׁקֶה וְתִיקּוּן, וְשָׁתוּ הַרְבֵּה מַשְׁקֶה כִּי יָשְׁבוּ זְמַן הַרְבֵּה וְשׂוֹחֲחוּ עִנְיְנֵי סִפּוּרֵי צַדִּיקִים וְיִרְאַת שָׁמַיִם, עַד שֶׁלִּפְנוֹת בֹּקֶר נָפְלָה תַּרְדֵּמָה גְּדוֹלָה עֲלֵיהֶם. כְּשֶׁמּוֹעַ הָרַבִּי אֶת מַה שֶּׁעָבַר עֲלֵיהֶם צִוָּה שֶׁיִּקְרְאוּ אֶת בַּעַל הַיָאהרְצַיְיט שֶׁיָּבוֹא לְפָנָיו.
וַיְהִי כַּאֲשֶׁר קָרַב, אָמַר לוֹ הָרַבִּי הִנֵּה טַעֲנָה גְּדוֹלָה יֵשׁ לִי עָלֶיךָ, תֵּדַע שֶׁבִּשְׁבִיל מַשְׁקֶה שֶׁלְּךָ זָכִיתָ לְהוֹצִיא אֶת הַשְּׁכִינָה לְלַיְלָה אַחַת מִן הַגָּלוּת כִּי כַּיָּדוּעַ כִּי שְׁכִינְתָּא בְּגָלוּתָא, וְאִם כֵּן לָמָּה הִנַּחְתָּ לָהּ לַחְזֹר אַחֲרֵי כֵן לְגָלוּתָהּ. עַד כָּאן הַמַּעֲשֶׂה. וְהַדְּבָרִים נוֹרָאִים לַמֵּבִין כִּי עַל יְדֵי יְשִׁיבָה שֶׁל אוֹהֲבִים בְּיַחַד, זוֹכִים לְדָבָר גָּדוֹל כָּזֶה לְהוֹצִיא אֶת הַשְּׁכִינָה מִגָּלוּתָהּ, וּלְהָסִיר צַעַר הַשְּׁכִינָה עַל אוֹתוֹ הַזְּמַן.
הרה"ג ר' משה מנחם טויבנפלד שליט"א"בפיקודיך אשיחה" (שיכון-סקווירא תשס"ד) ע' צ"א

Hrh"k Rabbi Yaakov Shimshon of Shepetivka once asked Hrh"k Rabbi Leib Sarah's to say what news was heard in the matters of the Kingdom. Hrh"k said that the great ones of the Kingdom gathered to decree decrees upon Israel. One of the ministers answered - What is this that it is always known to Israel the decree that we are standing to decree upon them even before they go out into action, even though we do this in great secret? And who informs them? One of them answered that the verse speaks fully (Ecclesiastes 10:20): עוף השמים יוליך את הקול - "A bird of the heavens shall carry the voice," and from this the decrees become known to them and they pray and ask for mercy and annul the decree. And they settled among themselves that they would not speak any word anymore among themselves, but rather everything would be done in writing, and no voice would issue from their mouths.
The soul of Hrh"k of Shepetivka was aggrieved and he said - If so, what can we do so that the decree will become known to us so we can ask for mercy and annul the evil decrees from Israel? Hrh"k Rabbi Leib said to him that they erred in their counsel, for he lowered to the end of the verse: ובעל כנפים יגיד דבר - "And that which hath wings shall tell the matter," and this is even without the utterance of any speech and voice.
Source: Hrh"k Rabbi Mordechai Chaim of Slonim zt"l, "Maamar Mordechai" (Jerusalem 5762) Part 2, p. 67

It is told of the holy Rabbi, our teacher and master Leib Sarah's, may his merit protect us, that in his days there reigned a certain Emperor in the country of Austria [Joseph II] who constantly wanted to decree decrees of apostasy and heresy. He said that he would not rest nor be quiet until the Rabbi ate with the priest—to distinguish between the holy and the profane—from one bowl.
The holy Rabbi would come to him every Sabbath eve and enter straight into his palace; he was seeing but not seen, and only the Emperor saw him. He began to shout and scold his servants for allowing this man to enter, but they thought he was a madman who had lost his mind.
The holy Rabbi began to strike him with vigorous blows until he tore up the decrees. These matters are also known in the history books of the nations, where documents regarding this were found.
Source: Divrei Torah, Ki Tisa 5749, p. 4

**Biography**
He was born in the year 5554 (1794) in Tertzal to his father, Rabbi Yehuda Aryeh, from the family of HaGaon Rav Yoel Gottlieb, Av Beis Din of Galanta. His parents settled in the city of Nagykálló (Kaliv) and he was sent to study in the government school. However, afterwards, a spirit from above hovered over him, and he dedicated all his time to Torah and Divine service.
He studied under Maran the Chatam Sofer in Pressburg and connected himself to the holy Rabbi, the Mahari"a of Kaliv. In the year 5573 (1813), he married Mrs. Breindel, the daughter of the philanthropist our teacher Meir Lichtenstein of Tertzal, a descendant of HaGaon Rav Yitzchak Chayut, author of *Zera Yitzchak*. After her passing, he married her sister, M. Yitel.
He sat in his home for several years engaged in Torah and service, and his name went out as a giant in Torah and a sublime Tzaddik. During the years he lived in his father-in-law's house, he became close to his teacher, the holy Gaon Rabbi Yechezkel Panet, Av Beis Din of Karlsburg, author of *Mareh Yechezkel*, who loved him dearly and tasked him with teaching his sons and attentive students.
Under the influence of his aforementioned teacher, he also traveled to the holy Rabbi of Rimanov. After his teacher moved his residence to the land of Siebenbürgen (Transylvania), HaGaon Rav Chaim Yosef was appointed as Av Beis Din of Tertzal in his place. In later days, he was accepted as Av Beis Din of Stropkov.
He passed away on the 4th of Adar II, 5627 (1867), and is buried in the village of Tisinec, near Stropkov.
Source: Mareh Yechezkel (Bnei Brak 5768), p. 137

**Biography**
He was born in the year 5601 (1841) to his father, Rabbi Avraham Shmuel. He was the Rosh Yeshiva of Telz and one of the greatest Rosh Yeshivas in Lithuania. He was a giant in Torah, sharp-minded, and possessed sublime character traits. He expanded the Mussar movement founded by Rabbi Yisrael Salanter, glorifying and perfecting it.
Initially, he served as a Rosh Yeshiva in the Yeshiva of Rabbi Yisrael Salanter in Kovno. From there, he went to Slabodka to serve as Av Beis Din. In the year 5634 (1874), he was appointed Av Beis Din in the community of Kelm, the main fortress of the Mussar movement, where he spread Torah for ten years.
When he was appointed Rosh Yeshiva of Telz, he dedicated himself entirely to spreading Torah according to the method of logic (Higayon) and penetrating the depth of the subject matter. He based his method of study on the words of the Rishonim (early commentators), delving into them until the system and the Sugya (topic) were understood without any doubt or uncertainty.
He instituted the study of Mussar as one of the fundamental studies in the Yeshiva. He did his best to integrate the understanding of the Gemara with the method of Mussar. Although in his time there were those who opposed the study of Mussar in Yeshivas, he stood firm on his watch and did not cancel the study of Mussar in his Yeshiva; on the contrary, he invested great efforts to turn the Telz Yeshiva into a center of Mussar.
He spent most of his time in Torah, innovating new insights and showing many the path of Torah and Mussar. Alongside this, he also engaged in community matters (Tikkun Olam) and was revealed as a public activist with great talent.
He saw the organization of religious Jewry as a remedy against the spread of the Enlightenment (Haskalah). For this purpose, he placed himself at the head of the Chareidi organization "Knesset Yisrael." To establish the organization, he intended to publish a daily Chareidi newspaper, but this did not succeed.
In the year 5669 (1909), he participated in a meeting of the greats of Poland, Lithuania, and Germany held in Bad Homburg. In the year 5670 (1910), he went to London to conduct a fundraising campaign for the Telz Yeshiva, which was in a difficult financial situation at the time. With his great personality, he succeeded in capturing Jewish London for his great Yeshiva, but he never returned to his beloved Telz.
In distant London, he passed away on the 4th of Adar I, 5670 (1910), and went to his eternal rest. His place as Av Beis Din and Rosh Mesivta in Telz was filled by Rabbi Yosef Bloch, who continued his father-in-law's path.
Thousands of students emerged from the Beis Midrash of Rabbi Eliezer Gordon of Telz, great in Torah and fear of Heaven, among them Rabbis and community leaders.
His sons-in-law: The Gaon Rabbi Zalman Sorotzkin, Av Beis Din of Lutsk, and the Gaon Rabbi Yitzchak Aizik Hirshowitz, Av Beis Din of Telsen, author of the book *Meitav HaHigayon* (who perished in the Holocaust), and the aforementioned Rabbi Yosef Leib Bloch. Among his students were famous Rosh Yeshivas: The known Geonim Rav Elchanan Wasserman, Rabbi A.Y. Finkel (Rosh Yeshiva of Mir), Rabbi Yosef Kahaneman of Ponevezh, and Rabbi Yechezkel Sarna (Rosh Yeshiva in Hebron).
Source: Chachmei Yisrael (Bnei Brak 5761), p. 364

Regarding the extraordinary love of Torah of the Rosh Yeshiva and Gaon Av Beis Din of Telz, HaGaon Rabbi Eliezer Gordon zt"l, the Gaon Rabbi Mordechai Gifter zt"l related:
When our master, HaGaon Rav Chaim of Brisk, married off his son Rabbi Moshe zt"l, Rav Chaim refrained from inviting Rav Eliezer to the wedding because he did not want to trouble him to come at his advanced age. However, before the Chuppah was held, Rav Leizer Gordon appeared unexpectedly. Rav Chaim honored him with *Siddur Kiddushin* (officiating the marriage) and even explained the matter by saying:
"Rav Leizer has such a love of Torah that he would be ready to give me his rabbinate..."
This was [referring to] when Rav Eliezer Gordon asked HaGaon Rav Chaim zt"l to come to Telz and serve as Rosh Yeshiva there. To show the strength of his desire in the matter, Rav Eliezer said to Rav Chaim: "If you wish, I am ready to give you the rabbinate of Telz as well."
Characteristically, when the Telzer Rav was asked why he troubled himself to attend the wedding despite his weakness, he replied to his questioner: "I knew that at this joy, the 'craftsman and the smith'—the fine flour and oil of Lithuanian Jewry—would participate. Since I am perplexed and struggling for a long time with a tremendous difficulty [in learning] for which I have no resolution, I thought that at this wedding I would make my distress known to the many, and surely, with the help of Heaven, I would merit to hear an answer to my difficulty as well."
Source: Shimush Chachamim (Jerusalem 5761), p. 141

The love of Torah and diligence of HaGaon Rabbi Eliezer of Telz zt"l knew no bounds. When he walked from the Yeshiva building to his home, or when he walked outside for his affairs or to take a walk, his lips would murmur words of Torah the entire time. He would innovate Torah insights while walking, and it was recognizable on his face that beams of light were shining from the joy he took in his innovations.
He was so immersed in his thoughts of Torah that it seemed to him he was debating with someone. He would make gestures of argumentation with his fingers and his whole body, like someone arguing with his friend and seeking to set him straight on the truth.
Source: Gedolei HaDorot (Jerusalem 5756), Vol. 3, p. 910

HaGaon Rabbi Betzalel Rakow zt"l, Ra'avad of Gateshead, told of the visit of the Gaon of Israel, the Ponevezher Rav zt"l, to the city of Gateshead. He entered the Ponevezher Rav's room to speak with him. The Ponevezher Rav asked him if he had ever studied under HaGaon Rav Eliezer Gordon. Then the Ponevezher Rav gave him his hand, telling him to feel a specific spot. Rav Rakow felt a broken bone there.
Then the Ponevezher Rav told him: "When I studied in the Telz Yeshiva, I sat next to HaGaon Rav Eliezer Gordon zt"l while he delivered the lecture. Once, Rav Eliezer was so 'cooked' [fired up] in learning that he gestured with his hand back and forth, and he grabbed my hand and twisted it and twisted it until it broke a bone. It was such pain! Later, when the Rosh Yeshiva heard about this, he felt bad and asked my forgiveness. I told him: 'Rebbe! Do not worry, it will be a souvenir for me that I learned Torah from the Rebbe!'"
[He was so seized by his learning that he grabbed my hand and turned it and turned it until he broke a bone, and there was great pain. Afterwards, when the Rosh Yeshiva heard of this, he sent for me to ask my forgiveness. I said to him: 'Rebbe, do not worry, this will be a sign of remembrance for me that I learned Torah from my Rebbe!']
[The Ponevezher Rav also said that we discussed then whether this is considered a blemish (Mum) that would disqualify one from the service of the Priesthood (Kehunah), for the Ponevezher Rav was a Kohen (I do not remember exactly if Rav Rakow discussed this with the Ponevezher Rav, or if he discussed it himself).]
Source: B'Tzel HaKodesh (Jerusalem 5767), p. 123

The elderly Rabbi Rosh Yeshiva Gefen (a scion of the rabbinic Traub family from the city of Keidan), who studied in his youth under Rabbi Eliezer in Telz, once related to the writer of these lines:
When Rabbi Eliezer taught a class to students, the table in his room did not stand in one place. Rather, it would "travel" across the room back and forth, because when Rabbi Eliezer became enthusiastic, he would shake it forcefully without realizing... Sometimes, when his hands encountered not the table but one of the students, he would also grab him forcefully and shake him back and forth in the heat of the debate without realizing what he was doing.
He also told me that once he was present in Rabbi Eliezer's room when he ate breakfast on Friday. They placed before him on the table a slice of Challah and a plate of butter. Rabbi Eliezer was mashing with a spoon on the slice for a long hour as if spreading butter, spreading without end, without realizing that he had not touched the butter at all, since he was contemplating and immersed the entire time in thoughts of Torah.
Source: Marbitzei Torah U'Mussar (Brooklyn 5737), Vol. 1, p. 228

In the winter of 5634 (1874), the great scholar Rabbi Avraham Yitzchak Naviazki zt"l passed away. The deceased, after being blessed with Torah and greatness, did not benefit from the community funds and served for many years as a Posek (decisor) in Kovno without receiving a salary. After his passing, his son-in-law, HaGaon Rav Eliezer Gordon zt"l (that great Gaon who was later Av Beis Din and Rosh Mesivta in Telz), filled his place. However, for the son-in-law, the community had already allocated a salary, and the "Naviazki Kloiz" also participated in the salary with six rubles a week, so that he would have a livelihood with ease, and he would also deliver a lecture in the aforementioned Kloiz.
Whenever I speak of the aforementioned HaGaon Rav Leizer, I am reminded of an incident that testifies to the wisdom of his Torah, and this is the matter:
In the year 5631 (1871), a "distinguished guest" visited Kovno—a Colonel (Polkovnik) from Austria. He was accompanied by his son, a Captain. According to their words, they boasted that they were traveling on a mission from the righteous minister Sir Moses Montefiore zt"l to Petersburg, to lobby for equal rights for Jews and to awaken the government regarding the pogroms by the Greeks in Odessa in the year 5630 (1870). They claimed the nobles of the Diaspora set their eyes on him to choose him to be a delegate because he had the talent to stand before a king and ministers. He acceded to their pleas to accept this mission.
This Polkovnik was a great orator and wonderful speaker, decorated with many medals of honor from the Austrian Kingdom. However, the only Hebrew letters of recommendation he had in his hand were from the righteous Rabbi David ben Shimon zt"l, Rabbi of the Westerners (North Africans) in the Holy Land. This "Minister" attracted the entire intelligentsia of Kovno: doctors, pharmacists, lawyers, etc. He revealed a little of his secrets to them, and secretly they collected a few hundred rubles for him to support his travel expenses and the expenses of the operations, etc. They further showered him with words of apology and appeasement for not being able to support him more.
This "Minister," even though he prided himself on his genius and his official uniform jewelry, conversed only with the intelligentsia. Nevertheless, the desire of HaGaon Rav Leizer zt"l succeeded in being honored to be received for an interview with him as well. The Gaon, with his great sharpness and penetrating gaze, recognized immediately that he was a fraud! Therefore, he entered into words and interrogations with him until he recognized that the "Colonel" realized his conscience was exposed before this Gaon.
The imposter hastened to leave the city the next morning without receiving a "farewell blessing" even from his supporters. Indeed, it was revealed by this Gaon that he was a crook and a man of deceit, but they still did not want to believe it until a few weeks later when it was published in the newspaper *HaMaggid* (Krasnystaw correspondence from another city) that a "Colonel" imposter passed there and was caught in his trickery.
Behold, the intelligentsia who mock the G-d-fearing saw this time that only the "clever ones" were trapped in the snare. Do the Sages of Torah have eyes in their heads to distinguish between truth and falsehood, while they, of little faith, strayed in vain to give trust to a man of deceit disguised in the uniform of a Colonel?
Source: Zichron Yaakov (Jerusalem 5728), Vol. 2, p. 172

In Kelm, HaGaon Rabbi Eliezer Gordon zt"l founded a "Kibbutz" of excellent young men and studied with them. Once, two young men from the Kibbutz were taken to the army, and a large sum was needed to redeem them from there. As was the custom in those days, respected householders went around to the doors of donors to collect money for this purpose, but they did not succeed in collecting the full amount.
So, he took the silver crowns of the Torah scrolls from the synagogue, pawned them, and with the money he received for them, he redeemed the young men. When the gabbaim (wardens) of the synagogue complained about the matter, he called them and told them that the most beautiful crown for the Torah scrolls is the Torah study of the released young men.
Source: Gedolei HaDorot (Jerusalem 5756), Vol. 3, p. 910

The following story is brought in the book *Moreshet Avot*, and it took place during the period when the government in Russia forbade the operation of holy Yeshivas and issued a decree for their absolute closure.
Rabbi Eliezer of Telz, like other greats of Israel at that time, did not heed the warnings and continued to maintain the Yeshiva, which numbered hundreds of young men who sat and diligently studied Torah day and night. The matter was brought to the attention of the government through informers, and they hastened to send one of their officials to Telz to stand closely over the situation and report whether studies were truly taking place in the Yeshiva.
The official arrived at the Yeshiva hall, which was bustling with life, and the sound of Torah was heard in a great noise. The Rosh Yeshiva was busy at that time with his head and majority [of his being] in clarifying the topic being studied, and he did not notice the government official who approached him.
"How many students are in the Yeshiva?" asked the official. Rabbi Eliezer did not reply. The study partner who learned with the Rosh Yeshiva drew his attention to the fact that a government official was standing next to him, but the Rosh Yeshiva signaled with his hands that he had no possibility to speak now until he finished his study.
With no choice, the official waited at the back of the hall until the Rosh Yeshiva finished his study. In the meantime, Rabbi Eliezer signaled the students to leave the hall, and only twenty should remain.
Afterwards, he approached the official and received him with a welcoming face, apologizing that he was unable to speak with him earlier. The official presented before him the government order forbidding the existence of a Yeshiva. "And how is it possible that I see here no less than four hundred young men sitting and learning?" said the official.
As in all generations, the Rosh Yeshiva of Telz knew that in such a case one must prepare three things: a gift (bribe), prayer, and war. After he shoved a not insignificant sum of money into the official's hand, he turned and said to him:
"How do you say there are four hundred young men here? Did you count them one by one, or did you rely on a visual estimate? Go now and count the number of young men sitting and learning, and you will see that we are not talking about a Yeshiva but about a few individuals who came to learn here..."
The official understood the hint, and since the coins placed in his pocket were more important to him than a truthful report to his superiors, he agreed to report to the government only on twenty young men who sat and learned in the hall. Thus, all the denunciations against the Yeshiva were founded on lies.
After a short period, another denunciation arrived, and now a more senior official who was in charge of the entire district was sent to the Yeshiva. He arrived at the Yeshiva, and like his predecessor, approached Rav Eliezer of Telz, holding the order forbidding the existence of the Yeshiva.
When the Rosh Yeshiva saw that the 'gift' would no longer be effective in this case, he turned to the inspector and said to him with great firmness: "Know that even if you exile me to Siberia as punishment for operating the Yeshiva, I will continue to learn there too. Nothing will help you. Although you are interested in bringing the students of the holy Yeshivas to a state where they stop learning, know for yourselves that such a thing will not arise and will not be. We will continue to learn as long as our breath is in our noses."
"But," the Rosh Yeshiva waved his hand toward the inspector, "if the Yeshiva stops operating, I am not at all sure that you will continue to serve in your high position."
The words had barely left the ruler's mouth, and after a number of days, it became known that this inspector was removed from his position as supervisor of the district.
Source: Tuvcha Yabiu (Jerusalem 5761), Vol. 2, p. 415

The Rabbi of the Chassidim in Moscow, HaGaon Rav Yeshaya Zusha Shuvaks zt"l, known as "The Boyder Rav," was admired by HaGaon HaChassid Rav Zalman Leib Estolin zt"l, who praised him all his days as being expert in the entire Shas with Tosafot by heart.
Rav Shuvaks told Rav Zalman Leib that in his youth he studied under Rabbi Eliezer of Telz, known as 'Rav Leizer Telzer'. Rav Leizer was a tremendous genius, to the point that the great of the generation, the *Sdei Chemed*, called him "The Mighty Gaon."
Rav Shuvaks was close to this teacher and was considered among the important students. Being so close, Rav Leizer did not hide from him what he hid from others: many times he saw his teacher studying in secret the *Likutei Torah* and *Torah Ohr* of the Alter Rebbe [of Chabad]. When anyone from the householders (Baalebatim) would enter, Rabbi Eliezer would immediately hide the book so as not to arouse their wonder, for in the Lithuanian circle where he served as Rosh Yeshiva, the study of Chassidut was not accepted.
Rav Shuvaks told Rav Zalman Leib another story that testifies to the Chassidic approach of Rav Leizer Telzer:
"When I was a young man, I remained in the Yeshiva for Simchat Torah and decided to approach and participate in the Minyan of the householders. There I hoped to receive an Aliyah to the Torah as is customary in the Diaspora of Israel. However, the householders were quite coarse and did not pay attention to the students among them, so I remained after the Torah reading without an Aliyah. I was broken inside, and I entered the Rosh Yeshiva's room weeping.
When he saw my fallen face and tearing eyes, he asked me for the meaning of the matter, for today is Simchat Torah. I poured out my heart before him.
The Rosh Yeshiva dismissed my feelings with a wave of his hand: 'Nu, householders are what they are (meaning, you shouldn't take the behavior of householders to heart. They are worth what they are).' Then he poured me a large glass of vodka and instructed me to empty the glass. I did as he commanded, and then he said to me: 'Nu, so this was your rectification (Tikkun) instead of the Aliyah to the Torah...'"
Source: Gaon V'Chassid (Jerusalem 5767), p. 46

Rabbi Eliezer Gordon, Rosh Yeshiva of Telz, lived and breathed Torah, and even passed away for the sake of Torah. His Yeshiva was the desire of his life and soul. There was nothing that could threaten to stop his enterprise, even though his path was paved with obstacles and difficulties.
In the year 5668 (1908), a severe fire broke out in Telz and consumed all the wooden houses in the city at once, including the Yeshiva building. Nothing remained of everything considered the source of his vitality, the place of Torah study. However, he did not turn to mourning. All his desires were set on rebuilding the ruins. Simultaneously, he toiled greatly and worked for the residents of the town until not a single family was left without a roof over their heads. The Yeshiva returned from its exile in the nearby town of Plungian to its resting place and inheritance, Telz.
It is understood that from all this, a heavy burden of debt fell upon his shoulders. He had no escape but to take—at seventy years of age—the wanderer's staff. In the winter of 5670 (1910), he set his face toward England accompanied by his son-in-law, Rabbi Aharon Walkin, Av Beis Din of Shad.
Under the conditions of that time, such a journey was a real danger for him. Doctors absolutely forbade it due to a heart attack he had suffered four years prior, and even warned him that the prevailing English weather in winter constituted a mortal danger.
Rabbi Eliezer did not heed their warnings, and his entire being was focused on one thing only—saving the Torah that was dearer to him than anything.
Rabbi Eliezer hung many hopes on the wealthy Jews of England. Upon arriving in London, he immediately organized a mass gathering for them. He stood before them, visibly emotional, demanding with tremendous enthusiasm, raising vivid and burning descriptions before them about the Yeshiva and the story of the miserable fire that turned everything into heaps of ruins. He elaborated on the hardships of the Yeshiva after the disaster and what he had to sacrifice to rebuild the place anew.
While he was still speaking with visible effort, he sensed how the distinguished Englishmen were not overly moved by his words. From their cold reaction, he understood that he had not achieved his request at all. Intense anguish was caused to him, and that very night he suffered a severe heart attack which severed the thread of his life. Thus, he ascended in a storm to Heaven upon the altar of Torah.
Source: Tal Orot (Jerusalem 5755), p. 148

*   **Gen 40:15**
*   **Gen 40:15**
*   **Gen 40:15**
The Gaon [Rabbi Eliezer Gordon], Rosh Yeshiva [of Telz] zt"l, traveled in his final days to the capital city, London, to solicit donations for the maintenance of the holy Yeshiva, as was customary. He was not very successful in his mission because several members of the community there obstructed his path and piled many difficulties before him, until finally, he fell ill and passed away there in London, where his honorable resting place is.
A wondrous event occurred: When he was appointed as Rabbi of Telz, the Av Beis Din there had a grievance against him, thinking the rabbinical position was rightfully his. In his jealousy, the Av Beis Din could not remain living in the city, so he traveled to the capital, London, where he was accepted as the Chief Rabbi of the city.
Another incident occurred with the Rosh Yeshiva zt"l there. At the beginning of his steps as Rabbi of the city [Telz], he asked the ritual slaughterers (Shochtim) to bring their knives before him for inspection, as is the custom of old in Israel to show the knives to the Rabbi. The head of the Shochtim there, who was a great expert in his craft, felt offended by this invitation, thinking the Rabbi did not rely on his expertise. He refused to come before the Rabbi to show his knife, and he too left the city and traveled to the capital, London. There he entered into large business ventures found there and succeeded greatly in his affairs, making a fortune.
From these two men, Rabbi Gordon zt"l had the opportunity to ask their forgiveness while he was in London before his passing.
At his massive funeral held in London, a Rabbi from the city of Leeds arrived to eulogize him. In his speech, he paraphrased the verse in Parashat Miketz, and these were his words:
**כי גנב גנבתי** - "For I was stolen away" - the burden of the debts of the holy Yeshiva stole my peace of mind, and I was forced to travel to distant places. **וגם פה לא עשיתי מאומה** - "And here also have I done nothing" - [meaning] here in London I did not succeed in covering these debts at all. And not only that, but even this: **כי שמו אתי בבור** - "That they should put me into the dungeon" - that they are putting my body into the grave.
Source: Milei D'Orayta (Jerusalem 5769), p. 158

**Proof from the Torah**
My father-in-law [HaGaon Rabbi Eliezer Gordon of Telz] zt"l was a great man, extremely sharp, like the sharp scholars of Pumbedita.
Once, my father-in-law was occupied with an important mission to establish a Chareidi newspaper that would stand in the breach against the newspapers of the Maskilim (Enlighteners) which introduced the poison of heresy into Jewish homes. On this path, he happened upon the home of a wealthy man who was a former student of his. When he asked for his help for the purpose for which he traveled, the rich man answered that he would help only a little, for he already supported another monthly journal, *HaShiloach*, which centered around itself substantial writers who knew their craft well.
My father-in-law zt"l said to him: "And from where do you know that the Chareidi newspaper won't also stand at a literary level?"
The rich man answered with arrogant impudence that it is presumed of the "Chareidi idlers" that they lack literary talent.
Rabbi Eliezer Gordon became very emotional and said to the rich man: "But isn't every booklet of theirs full of heresy!" Immediately, he took one booklet from the pile lying on the rich man's table, leafed through it, and found a famous narrated article about the Exodus from Egypt. The author wrote that although the story is full of miracles and wonders, one cannot dismiss it entirely, but rather one must distinguish between these stories and the historical material which should be accepted willingly as material for the history of Israel. Of primary importance stands the statistical side of it, in which there is no doubt, since the numbers are very precise and show how many of our ancestors were there when they left Egypt. However, the rest of the Torah stories, its laws and judgments—that is a matter for believers, and every man is free in his opinions, provided he does not cut history and statistics...
"Except," [said Rav Eliezer], "that within the speech, this 'wise-to-do-evil' man struggles with the matter of statistics as well, for there are 'miracles' in it too. Namely, that Yaakov and his sons when they went down to Egypt were only **ויהי כל נפש... שבעים נפש** - 'And all the souls... were seventy souls.' And in Parashat Vayigash there is an old 'statistic' explicitly stating that there is no doubt in it, according to Rashi's calculation of the ages of Kehat, Amram, and Moshe. There is a statistical law that natural increase of any nation is one percent per year roughly every fifty years. Consequently, a nation of Israel numbering seventy souls upon its descent to Egypt would grow, according to this, after fifty years to 140 souls, and according to that calculation until the year of their redemption (210 years) - to about 1,300 - 1,400 souls.
"So how does the statistics of the Redemption come and say that the men of the army in Israel alone numbered six hundred thousand? And if we add the young men up to age 20 and the elderly from age sixty, as well as the women—it turns out that those leaving Egypt numbered at least two million four hundred thousand, instead of the small number that should have been according to natural increase.
"If so, the heretical writer wonders—is there not a miracle of miracles here? And his answer is: that here too one must divide and distinguish between numbers and miracle stories. Meaning: truly 600,000 men of the army left Egypt, and together with the children and women—they truly numbered two million four hundred thousand. But how is this increase possible? This is simple: in Egypt there were tens of thousands of slaves who, following the Jews, rebelled against their masters and left together with the Children of Israel, and consequently this large number emerged..." (End of the Maskil's words).
My father-in-law zt"l began to prove to the rich man how ridiculous and stupid the words of this writer were. He brought him proofs and evidences from the Torah, and proved to him also from reality that it is impossible for such a small number of Jews to dominate such a large and vast number of tens of thousands of slaves. According to this, it would turn out that even in the lands of exile, where there is only a tiny minority of Jews, these could dominate the entire population of the country—is such a thing possible?
But the rich man stood his ground, insisted, sometimes denied, sometimes said one cannot demand of writers to believe in "six at one birth," until a brilliant idea sparked in my father-in-law's mind, and he said to the rich man:
"And what will you give me if I bring you proof from the statistics itself, which no man would dare challenge, that the daughters of Israel gave birth in Egypt to six at one birth—what will you give me then?"
The rich man answered with a smile on his lips: "Let us hear!!"
"The usual average of a family," said my father-in-law, "is five souls: father and mother and three sons or daughters. In every family, there is one who was born first: a firstborn male or female. According to this, if we count a city that has a thousand souls, we know there are 200 firstborns, according to the calculation of one for every five. According to this, even if we want to know how many firstborns (male or female) are in the nation, we must divide the souls in it by five, and then we find the number of firstborns, which is the fifth part.
"According to this, the nation that left Egypt and numbered two million four hundred thousand souls—how many firstborns should have been in it? If we divide this number by five, we get 480,000 in each part, meaning close to half a million male or female firstborns. Let us assume half were born male firstborns and half female firstborns; it turns out there should have been 240,000 male firstborns.
"However, in the Book of Numbers, it is said that they counted the firstborns in the second year of their exodus from Egypt, and behold, how great is the wonder that they found only **ויהי כל בכור זכר... שנים ועשרים אלף שלשה ושבעים ומאתים** - 'And all the firstborn males... were twenty-two thousand two hundred and seventy-three!' Did you hear anything? Instead of 240,000—only a tenth part is found?
"And how can we explain the matter that instead of a ratio of 5:1, it was approximately 53:1? Since the Merciful One made the firstborn dependent on the 'opening of the womb' (Peter Rechem), we are forced to say that every woman who gave birth to one firstborn subsequently gave birth to 52 simple children.
"This matter is terrifying to the mind, since in the days of Moshe the years were already shortened, as stated in the prayer of Moshe: **ימי שנותינו בהם שבעים שנה** - 'The days of our years are threescore years and ten.' If so, it is impossible for a woman to give birth naturally only 8-9 times. And if every woman had more than fifty children then, we are perforce compelled to say that they gave birth to 6 at one birth!!!"
Source: Mipihem Shel Raboseinu (Bnei Brak 5768), Vol. 1, p. 375

...After the passing of the holy Maggid [of Mezeritch], our Rebbe [the holy Rabbi Zev Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra zt"l] traveled to the holy Rabbi Meshulam Feivish of Zbarazh, author of *Yosher Divrei Emet*. They were bound to each other with bonds of love in wondrous adhesion.
It is told that once, when our Rebbe returned from the city of Zbarazh to the city of Tcharne-Ostra, the holy Rabbi Feivish escorted him a distance outside the city. Afterwards, our Rebbe sat on the wagon of the holy Rabbi Feivish to escort him back into the city. And so it happened several times, that one escorted the other outside the city and into the city. All this was due to the affection and great love that prevailed between them.
This was also the reason that despite our Rebbe's intense desire to ascend to the Land of Israel and favor its dust, he refrained from bringing his thought into action, for their love and adhesion together was so great that he literally could not part from him...
Source: Ohr Yekarot (Jerusalem 5758), Vol. 1, p. 18

**Biography**
The holy Rabbi Zev Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra zt"l, one of the members of the Holy Palace—students of the holy Rabbi, the Great Maggid, our teacher Dov Ber of Mezeritch—was born to his father Rabbi Naftali Tzvi zt"l. Even when he was tender in years, special talents were recognizable in him; his diligence and devotion to Torah study were wondrous.
He basked in the shadow of the Maggid of Mezeritch even in his childhood, as the Maggid drew him close with extra affection. After the passing of the Maggid, he cleaved to the holy Rabbi Meshulam Feivish of Zbarazh, author of *Yosher Divrei Emet*, and was a student-colleague to him.
When the holy Rabbi of Tcharne-Ostra began to lead a congregation, the geniuses and holy ones of the land cleaved to him, headed by our teacher the "Ahavat Shalom" of Kosov, Rabbi David Shlomo Eibschutz, Av Beis Din of Soroka, author of *Arvei Nachal*; Rabbi Yitzchak of Kasiyev-Yagelnitsa; Rabbi Zalman Leib (son of the daughter of the Gaon author of *Noda B'Yehuda* zt"l) who even ascended with him to Tiberias; and others.
With the passing of the holy Rabbi of Zbarazh, he ascended to dwell in the Land of Israel [in the year 5558/1798] and established his residence in Tiberias. Over the years, he stood at the head of the Chassidic community in Tiberias and worked greatly for the sake of the settlement in the Holy Land. Abroad, his place was filled by his great student, our teacher the "Ahavat Shalom." From Tiberias, the holy Rabbi Zev sent him a special letter in which he blessed him regarding the continuation of the leadership, that it should not depart from his seed forever.
On the 5th of Adar 5583 (1823), the holy Rabbi returned his soul to its Creator, and his honorable resting place is in the old cemetery in Tiberias.
Source: Sarfei Kodesh (Bnei Brak 5768), p. 289

Great affection and admiration prevailed between our Rebbe [HaRah"k Rabbi Zev Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra zt"l] and his in-law, the holy Rabbi Meshulam Zusha of Anipoli zt"l. It is told—the cities of Tcharne-Ostra and Anipoli are close to each other—that one day a certain informer (Moser) appeared who informed on all the residents of the villages in that area and caused them to lose their livelihood, until they almost despaired of their lives.
Several times they gave a *Kvittel* (note) to our Rebbe and to the holy Rabbi Zusha to remove this wicked man, but to no avail. The informer continued his activity to the grief of the hearts of all the residents. Once, they complained before him with weeping that their strength had failed because of that wicked man. Our Rebbe promised them that G-d would be their help. But this too did not help.
Once, a Minyan of Jews traveled before Rosh Hashanah to the holy Rabbi Zusha and wept greatly before him. After the holiday, that wicked informer fell ill with a sudden death and died, and the Children of Israel were saved from their troubles.
The Chassidim of our Rebbe said the miracle was their Rebbe's, and the Chassidim of Rabbi Zusha said it was their Rebbe's work.
In the month of Cheshvan afterwards, Rabbi Zusha was hosted by his in-law, our Rebbe, in Tcharne-Ostra. They dined together, and the Chassidim stood around them. In the middle of the meal, Rabbi Zusha answered his in-law, our Rebbe, and asked him: "How did you lose that informer?"
Our Rebbe said: "I had no counsel against him. The story was thus: On Yom Kippur, I prayed the Ne'ilah prayer before the Amud (lectern) and prolonged my prayer until they had already finished in the synagogue of the city, and everyone had already left. Anyone who left the synagogue stood behind the wall of my Beis Midrash to hear my prayer. The informer was also there behind the wall. *Demolt hab ich ihm derlangt a hirhur teshuvah, iz er shoin geven meiner, hab ich ihm gekent beikumen* [At that moment I handed him a thought of repentance; once he was mine, I was able to overcome him]. For initially, he was so far from holiness that I had no connection or relevance to him."
Then it became known to all that this was the handiwork of our Rebbe, Rabbi Zev zt"l.
Source: Kol Emunim, Terumah 5771, p. 3

When the holy Rabbi Zev Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra ascended to the Land of Israel, he sent one of the members of the group on his way to travel to Kosov, to his student the holy Rabbi Menachem Mendel, to tell him in his name that he ordains him as a Rebbe and leader in Israel.
Rabbi Mendel was very poor at the time and lived in terrible poverty. His wife sold slaked lime [they would heat bricks and extinguish them in cold water, and the stones would melt and become lime], and from this she supported her household with great frugality.
When the messenger arrived at his house, he saw the Rebbetzin standing in the yard with the lime. Her children, who were playing in the yard, accidentally overturned the barrels with the lime during their running. Everything spilled onto the ground, and all her labor went down the drain.
She entered her husband, the holy Rabbi, who was sitting and learning, and complained to him out of grief: "Look, please, what your children have done."
He replied to her with calmness: "*Az s'iz shoin gar shlecht, vert gut...*" [When the situation is already very bad, it will become good].
While this was happening, the messenger entered and said to him: "The Rebbe sent me to tell you *az ihr megt shoin vern Rebbe*..." [that you may now become a Rebbe].
As soon as the messenger left his house, a "German" Jew approached him and asked where the Rebbe lived. He showed him the holy Rabbi's house. He entered and gave him a *Kvittel* and ten Rhenish coins for a redemption.
When the holy Rabbi Zev Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra arrived in the Holy Land, he wrote a letter from there to his student, the holy Rabbi of Kosov, in these words:
"Today, Sunday, when yesterday we blessed the month of Sivan, 'May his kingdom be renewed both now and upon the souls of his house, that it shall not move from him and from his children and his children's children from now and forever'..."
Source: Maamar Mordechai (Slonim), Vol. 2, p. 146

A great blessing was granted to our Rebbe (the "Ahavat Shalom" of Kosov zt"l) from his teacher (the holy Rabbi Zev Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra zt"l):
That whenever he would need a sum of money, whether large or small, for the sake of a Mitzvah or charity, he should extend his hand into the "Shiplad" (drawer) and say this phrase: "In the merit of Rabbi Velvel, save please!"
And surely, the salvation would come immediately. According to the luck of the receiver, so he would find the money in the drawer, whether little or much—to know that everything comes by Divine Providence.
Source: Keter Malchut (Bnei Brak 5756), p. 57

The journey of our Rebbe (the holy Rabbi Zev Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra zt"l) to the Land of Israel was accompanied by Chassidim and men of action... It should be noted that this Aliyah of our Rebbe was the fourth Chassidic Aliyah.
The first was in the year 5528 (1768), in which students of our Rebbe the Baal Shem Tov zt"l ascended, among them the holy Rabbi Nachman of Horodenka and the holy Rabbi Menachem Mendel of Premishlan zt"l and others.
In the year 5537 (1777) was the mass Aliyah led by the students of the Great Maggid of Mezeritch zt"l: the holy Rabbi Menachem Mendel of Vitebsk and the holy Rabbi Avraham HaKohen of Kalisk zt"l and others.
In the year 5555 (1795) there was an additional Aliyah—the third in number—led by the holy Rabbi Yaakov Shimshon of Shepetovka zt"l.
Thus, our Rebbe's Aliyah, accompanied by "other distinguished men," is the fourth Aliyah of the standard-bearers of Chassidut, whose souls were bound to the Desirable Land. Without looking at the danger of the roads and wars, our Rebbe left behind his important rabbinate and the large public of his Chassidim and admirers abroad, and gave his soul to ascend in holiness.
The Holy One of Israel, [Rabbi Yisrael] of Ruzhin zt"l, already testified about our Rebbe: "Only one who feels its sublime taste like the Tzaddik Rabbi Velvel'e is worthy of traveling to the Land of Israel."
Our Rebbe established his residence in the holy city of Tiberias. More than eighty years after his passing, the Rabbi of Tiberias, the holy Gaon Rabbi Moshe Kliers zt"l, notes in his book *Tabor HaAretz* (56, 2): "The holy Rabbi Zev Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra zt"l sat in Tiberias, and his house where he sat is still found here" (see also at the end of the book there).
Source: Ohr Yekarot (Jerusalem 5758), Vol. 1, p. 18

They asked Rabbi Yeshaya of Praga: "People give the Master money so that he may benefit from it, so why does he distribute it all to charity? Did he receive the money for this purpose?"
Rabbi Yeshaya answered: "They give to me so that I may enjoy it, and I enjoy giving charity."
Source: Chassidim Mesaprim (Jerusalem 5739), Vol. 1, p. 68

During all the eleven years that the holy Rabbi Avraham of Kalisk was together with the holy Rabbi Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra in the holy city of Tiberias, Rabbi Wolf would come to him every Seudah Shlishit (Third Meal), and the holy Rabbi of Kalisk would go to him every Rosh Chodesh...
The holy Rabbi Zev of Tcharne-Ostra once came to the home of the holy Rabbi of Kalisk. The holy Rabbi of Kalisk honored him to say a word of Torah. Then, the aspect of the mind of the holy Rabbi Pinchas of Koritz opened up to him, and he said deep words for several hours until he felt that the mind of the holy Rabbi of Kalisk became weak, and he stopped... And from then on, he never said Torah again all his days.
Source: Maamar Mordechai (Slonim), Vol. 2, p. 80

When he was in the Holy Land, sitting in the holy city of Tiberias, they came to mention a request before him. He answered and said:
"Previously, when I was abroad, I would effect such a thing with a wave of the hand—but here, in the King's Palace, one needs Derech Eretz (proper respect/manners)!"
Source: Maamar Mordechai (Slonim), Vol. 2, p. 88

Once, the Chassidim grabbed the Etrog of the righteous Rabbi Velvel Tchinoster when he was in Tiberias. At the moment they grabbed the Etrog, the aforementioned Tzaddik fainted. When they woke him, he shouted: "My heart! My heart!"
They saw that the fainting came because they grabbed the Etrog, which is called "the Heart" according to the holy Zohar, even though the Etrog was lying in another room.
Source: Kovetz Eliyahu (Jerusalem 5743), p. 30

Rabbi Zalman Barzel zt"l was once with his teacher, the holy Rabbi of Tcharne-Ostra. The Rabbi gave him some food. He apologized that it was difficult for him to eat because he suffered from stomach issues.
The holy Rabbi ordered that "Kashe" (buckwheat porridge) be served to him, and he was forced to eat it and was healed, even though it is known that Kashe is very harmful to the stomach.
Source: Maamar Mordechai (Slonim), Vol. 3, p. 43

The holy "Ahavat Shalom" of Kosov zy"a was a student of several of the Tzaddikim of his generation, and one of his teachers was the holy Rabbi Zev of Tcharne-Ostra zy"a.
The story is known that before the wedding of the holy Rabbi David of Tolna zy"a, who was the son-in-law of the holy Rabbi Yisrael Avraham son of Rabbi Zusha, and Rav Yisrael Avraham was the son-in-law of the holy Rabbi Zev Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra...
Rabbi Wolf had already traveled to the Land of Israel, and the holy Rabbi Yisrael Avraham was no longer in this world. The Rebbetzin traveled with her daughter, the bride, to collect money for the wedding needs and dowry, which she had taken upon herself, as she had no money.
She arrived at the student of her father, the "Ahavat Shalom." When she arrived, the holy Rabbi asked her what sum she needed. She said she needed five hundred gold coins. The holy Rabbi opened a drawer in his table and gave her the entire sum she requested.
He answered that her father—the holy Rabbi Wolf—had told him before he traveled to the Land of Israel that if he ever needed money, he should open the "Shiplad" and find his request. Until that day, he did not want to use this, but if the Rebbe's daughter arrives and asks in such a way, "I use this."
He added that since he could not participate in the wedding, he therefore invited them to a meal he would hold in their honor in his city, Kosov. They brought musical instruments, and he danced with the bride a Mitzvah dance.
Source: Milin Kadishin (Jerusalem 5766), Vol. 1, p. 20

A certain simple man was once tested with a very difficult temptation, but he overcame himself and did not stumble. He was given a gift from Heaven as his reward: whenever he would come to mention the Holy Name, he would feel in his soul how far things reached...
From then on, whenever he prayed or blessed and came to mention the name of Heaven, his whole body began to tremble and his limbs shook from fear. This man, who was very simple and did not understand what this was, came to complain about this before the holy Rabbi of Tcharne-Ostra (in another version: the holy Rabbi, the Ohr HaMeir of Zhitomir) that he did not know what happened to him and he could not bear it anymore.
The holy Rabbi said to him: "You merited and were given a thing that others request and toil for all the days of their lives! And you give up on this with a wave of a hand?..."
The holy Rabbi taught him understanding and taught him how to live with this sublime level.
Source: Maamar Mordechai (Slonim), Vol. 2, p. 88

...Behold, when brothers sit together, those who fear G-d speak one to another about the true Tzaddikim, their words, and their deeds. Thus we have received from the mouths of our holy Rabbis, men of truth, that the holy Tzaddik Rabbi Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra, in the days of his old age, had his residence in Tiberias with the [Rabbi of] Kalisk zy"a.
His way was that his eyes were always open forever; even during sleep, they were not closed. He was with his great students there. During the days of his illness, one of his students entered and found him lying with his eyes closed. He was very frightened, etc.
He opened his eyes and said to him: "Why are you crying so much?"
He answered him: "Because I saw you with closed eyes, something that never happened before."
He said to him: "Know that I peeked to see the later generations, etc., and I saw that even servants of Hashem like you will need great mercy to be saved from thoughts, etc."
The student wept even more: "What will become of us?"
He said to him: "Your advice is *Redin fun unz* (speak of us), and through connection to Tzaddikim you will escape, and a Tzaddik shall live by his faith."
Source: Torat Avot (Slonim), p. 268

*   **חייב אדם לברך על הרעה כשם שמברך על הטובה**
I heard in the name of HaGaon HaTzaddik Rav Yeshaya zt"l of Praga, that he eulogized his only son, the Gaon zt"l who was Av Beis Din of Bialobrzegi, and said the words of our Sages (Berachot 54a): **חייב אדם לברך על הרעה כשם שמברך על הטובה** - "A man is obligated to bless for the bad just as he blesses for the good."
Please note the language: **חייב** (Chayav - obligated). This implies that for the rest of the people, they are "Chayav" [like debtors/guilty], because who can say "I have merited my heart" to such an extent that he accepts a terrible tragedy upon himself, Heaven forbid, with great joy just like good things? And even though he forces his heart to be in this aspect, strictly speaking, in his heart, he is a "Chayav" (debtor/lacking).
Source: Shaar Yissachar (Jerusalem 5728), Vol. 1, p. 42

body_he: בִּמְרוּצַת הַשָּׁנִים קִבֵּל רַבֵּינוּ (הָ"אַהֲבַת שָׁלוֹם" מִקָּאסוֹב זי"ע) מֵרַבּוֹ (הרה"ק רַבִּי זְאֵב וָואלְף מִטְּשַׁארְנִיאוֹסְטְרָהָא זי"ע) שְׁנֵי חֲלוּקִים לְבָנִים - "חַלָאטִין", אֲשֶׁר הָיוּ יְקָרִים מְאֹד בְּעֵינָיו. אֶל הַמִּשְׁלוֹחַ הָיָה מְצֹרָף מִכְתָּב, בּוֹ כָּתַב לוֹ רַבּוֹ, שֶׁיַּחֲזִיק אֶת הַחֲלוּקִים בַּחֲשִׁיבוּת גְּדוֹלָה, יַעַן כִּי הֵמָּה מַלְבּוּשָׁיו מַמָּשׁ, שֶׁלְּבָשָׁם לְאַחַר שֶׁטָּבַל בִּנְהַר דִּינוֹר.רַבֵּינוּ נָתַן אַחַר כָּךְ חַאלַט אֶחָד לִבְנוֹ הרה"ק בַּעַל "תּוֹרַת חַיִּים" זי"ע, וְצִוָּהוּ שֶׁלֹּא יְשַׁנֶּה סֵדֶר הַתְּפִירוֹת, כִּי קַבָּלָה בְּיָדוֹ, שֶׁהַחַיָּט בְּעֵת שֶׁתָּפַר אוֹתוֹ הָיָה מְיַחֵד יִחוּדִים בְּכָל תְּפִירָה וּתְפִירָה.גַּם לְאַחַר שֶׁחָלְפוּ מֵעַל לְמֵאָה שָׁנָה מֵעֵת קַבָּלַת הַחֲלוּקִים, הָיוּ אֵלֶּה שְׁלֵמִים וְטוֹבִים.וְסִפֵּר הרה"ג ר' יוֹסֵף אַרְיֵה כַּהֲנָא זַ"ל מִסִּיגֶט (חֲתַן הרה"ק בַּעַל "מַרְאֵה יְחֶזְקֵאל" מִדֶּעשׁ), כִּי פַּעַם בִּהְיוֹתוֹ בְּקָאסוֹב לְהִסְתּוֹפֵף בְּצֵל רַבּוֹ הַ"תּוֹרַת חַיִּים" בְּחַג הַפֶּסַח, לִפְנֵי הֶחָג עָזַר לְרַבּוֹ בִּבְדִיקַת הֶחָמֵץ, וּבֵין הַיֶּתֶר צִוָּהוּ הרה"ק שֶׁיִּבְדֹּק גַּם אֶת הַמְּגֵרָה שֶׁלּוֹ מֵחָמֵץ. בַּמְּגֵרָה הָיָה מוּנָח תַּכְרִיךְ כְּתָבִים חֲשׁוּבִים, שֶׁשָּׁמַר עֲלֵיהֶם הַ"תּוֹרַת חַיִּים" מִכֹּל מִשְׁמָר, וְהִקְפִּיד הָרַבִּי מְאֹד - בְּעֵת שֶׁהִפְרִידָם זֶה מִזֶּה לְבָדְקָם מֵחָמֵץ - שֶׁלֹּא יַבִּיטוּ בָּהֶם, וּבִפְרָט עַל אֶחָד מֵהֶם. הַדָּבָר עוֹרֵר סַקְרָנוּתוֹ שֶׁל ר' יוֹסֵף אַרְיֵה, וְכַאֲשֶׁר הרה"ק נִכְנַס לְחֶדֶר אַחֵר, הֵצִיץ בּוֹ אוֹתוֹ חָסִיד, וְרָאָה כִּי זֶהוּ מִכְתָּבוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק מִטְּשַׁארְנִי־אוֹסְטְרָהָא אֶל רַבֵּינוּ, בְּעֵת מִשְׁלוֹחַ הַחַלָאטִין (אֶבֶן שְׁתִיָּה עַמ' כז).[הַ"תּוֹרַת חַיִּים" נָתַן אֶת הַ"חַלַאט" לִבְנוֹ הרה"ק בַּעַל "צֶמַח צַדִּיק" זי"ע, וּכְעַבוֹר זְמַן זֶה עָבַר בִּירֻשָּׁה לְבִתּוֹ הָרַבָּנִית שָׂרָה ע"ה מִסְּקָאהל, וְהִיא נָתְנָה אוֹתוֹ בְּמַתָּנָה לַחֲתָנָהּ הרה"צ ר' פִּנְחָס מִבָּארְשָׁא זצ"ל. הַ"חַלַאט" הַשֵּׁנִי הָיָה בְּבֵית גְּנָזָיו שֶׁל הרה"ק ר' מֹשֶׁה מִקָּאסוֹב זצ"ל - הוּא וְכֵן הַ"צֶמַח צַדִּיק" הָיוּ לוֹבְשִׁים אוֹתָם רַק בְּרֹאשׁ הַשָּׁנָה וּבְיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים בְּשַׁעַת הַתְּפִלָּה.]"כֶּתֶר מַלְכוּת" (ב"ב תשנ"ו) עַמ' ס"ב
body_en:
Over the years, our Rebbe (the "Ahavat Shalom" of Kosov zy"a) received from his teacher (the holy Rabbi Zev Wolf of Tcharne-Ostra zy"a) two white robes—"Chalatin"—which were very precious in his eyes. Attached to the shipment was a letter in which his teacher wrote to him that he should hold the robes in great importance, for they were literally his garments, which he wore after immersing in the Dnieper River.
Our Rebbe later gave one *Chalat* to his son, the holy Rabbi author of *Torat Chaim* zy"a, and commanded him not to change the order of the stitches, for he had a tradition that the tailor, at the time he sewed it, unified unifications (Yichudim) with every single stitch.
Even after more than a hundred years had passed since the receiving of the robes, they were whole and good.
HaGaon Rav Yosef Aryeh Kahana zt"l of Sighet (son-in-law of the holy Rabbi author of *Mareh Yechezkel* of Deesh) related that once, when he was in Kosov basking in the shadow of his teacher the *Torat Chaim* during the festival of Passover, before the holiday he helped his teacher with the search for Chametz. Among other things, the holy Rabbi commanded him to check his drawer for Chametz as well.
In the drawer lay a bundle of important papers which the *Torat Chaim* guarded more than anything. The Rebbe was very strict—when separating them to check them for Chametz—that they should not look at them, and especially at one of them.
This matter aroused the curiosity of Rav Yosef Aryeh. When the holy Rabbi entered another room, that Chassid peeked at it and saw that it was the letter of the holy Rabbi of Tcharne-Ostra to our Rebbe, at the time of sending the Chalatin.
[The *Torat Chaim* gave the *Chalat* to his son, the holy Rabbi author of *Tzemach Tzaddik* zy"a. After some time, this passed by inheritance to his daughter, the Rebbetzin Sarah a"h of Skole, and she gave it as a gift to her son-in-law, the holy Rabbi Pinchas of Borsha zt"l. The second *Chalat* was in the treasury of the holy Rabbi Moshe of Kosov zt"l—he and the *Tzemach Tzaddik* would wear them only on Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur during prayer.]
Source: Keter Malchut (Bnei Brak 5756), p. 62

**Biography**
The holy Rabbi Shmuel Avraham Abba zy"a was born in the year 5547 (1787) to his father, the holy Rabbi Moshe Shapira of Slavita, son of the holy Rabbi Pinchas of Koritz zy"a. When he reached maturity, he married Mrs. Sheindel, the daughter of the holy Rabbi Aryeh Leib of Chmelnik, the only son of the holy Rabbi Chananya Lipa of Chmelnik, and son-in-law of Rabbi Vishel of Tsheshilnik, the fourth generation from the Sem"a.
He basked in the shadow of the Rebbe Rav Zusha and the holy Rabbi Baruch of Medzhybizh.
He worked in the famous printing press of 'Slavita' with his holy father. He was captured with him in the year 5596 (1836). When they were exiled to Siberia with his brother, the holy Rabbi Pinchas, they were detained for seven years in Moscow and brought close the Cantonists.
When they were released in the year 5617 (1857), our Rebbe returned to Slavita and was crowned as Admor. Many visited his holy abode to be saved through words of salvation and mercy, and he became famous as a Tzaddik, a foundation of the world.
During the time of Dodi (my uncle), when his son the holy Rabbi Aryeh Leib became engaged to the daughter of the holy Rabbi the 'Tzemach Tzaddik' of Vizhnitz, when his son the author of *Imrei Baruch* was taken after the wedding, our Rebbe traveled to Vizhnitz and stayed for a number of weeks with his offspring. On his way back, he returned his soul to its Creator on the 5th of Adar I, 5624 (1864), being old and satisfied with days, at the age of eighty years.
Source: Zechut Avot (Bnei Brak 5772), Vol. 6, p. 262

I heard that the wife of my uncle, the holy Rabbi Moshe, Av Beis Din of Slavita, was once having difficulty giving birth. Her husband went before his father, the holy Rabbi Pinchas of Koritz zt"l, to pray for her to give birth easily.
His father answered him that his wife was having difficulty giving birth because the fetus did not want to descend to this lowly world, because he was a great soul. In Heaven, they were leading the aforementioned soul from chamber to chamber, and now they were leading him into the Chamber of Music. The music was very pleasing in his eyes, and he accepted upon himself to go out into the air of the world for this.
He said to his son, the Rabbi Rav Moshe: "Mazal Tov." He also told him that the child would be a great musician.
And so was the newborn, the holy Rabbi Shmuel Avraham zt"l, who is called by everyone "Rabbi Shmuel Abba of Slavita."
Source: Luach Maagal HaShana (Skver 5766), p. 166

On the holy Sabbath of Parashat Shemot 5728, our Rebbe [the Imrei Chaim of Vizhnitz zt"l] related:
Rabbi Shmuel Abba and his brother Rabbi Pinchas, grandsons of the holy Rabbi Pinchas of Koritz zy"a, sat in prison for twenty years. In the final year of their stay there, Rabbi Shmuel Abba said:
"I am confident that this year we will be released from prison, because on Yom Kippur they sent the guard of the prison house, who was a Jew, to pray before the Amud for the Ne'ilah prayer with the Minyan of prisoners. Before Kaddish, he turned to Hashem Yitbarach and said:
'What should I ask for? Should I ask for money? For what?! Health? For what?! I serve the masters?! Children? For what? Who will guide them?!' (Meaning: What will I ask for, that I should have money? For what purpose?! Health? For what purpose?! That I may be able to serve the Czar?! Children? For what purpose?! Who will guide them?!)
And so he counted several more matters. Finally, he said: 'Therefore, I ask only that Your Great Name be magnified and sanctified,' and he continued with the Kaddish."
Source: Bit'on Vizhnitz, Elul 5765, p. 10

"מֻבְטָחַנִי שֶׁבַּשָּׁנָה הַזֹּאת נְשֻׁחְרַר מִבֵּית הַסֹּהַר, כִּי בְּיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים שִׁלְּחוּ מִנְיַן הַמִּתְפַּלְּלִים בְּבֵית הַסֹּהַר אֶת שׁוֹמֵר בֵּית הַסֹּהַר, שֶׁהָיָה יְהוּדִי, לְהִתְפַּלֵּל לִפְנֵי הָעַמּוּד תְּפִלַּת נְעִילָה, וְלִפְנֵי קַדִּישׁ פָּנָה הַלָּה לְהַשֵּׁי"ת וְאָמַר:
'וָואס זָאל אִיךְ בֶּעטְן, אִיךְ זָאל הָאבְּן גֶּעלְט? צוּ וָואס?! גֶּעזוּנְט? צוּ וָואס? אִיךְ זָאל קֶענֶען דִּינֶען פַּאנְיֶען?! קִינְדֶער? צוּ וָואס? וֶוער וֶועט זֵיי מַדְרִיךְ זַיין?! (=מַה אֲבַקֵּשׁ, שֶׁיִּהְיֶה לִי כֶּסֶף? לְשֵׁם מַה?! בְּרִיאוּת? לְשֵׁם מַה?! שֶׁאוּכַל לְשָׁרֵת אֶת הַצַּאר הָרוּסִי?! יְלָדִים? לְשֵׁם מַה?! מִי יַדְרִיךְ אוֹתָם?!) וְכָךְ מָנָה עוֹד כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה עִנְיָנִים. לְבַסּוֹף אָמַר: 'לָכֵן, אֵינֶנִּי מְבַקֵּשׁ אֶלָּא כִּי יִתְגַּדַּל וְיִתְקַדַּשׁ שְׁמֵיהּ רַבָּא', וְהִמְשִׁיךְ הַקַּדִּישׁ".הָרַב שְׁמוּאֵל אֲבִישַׁי שְׁטוֹקְהָמֶר שליט"א"בִּטְאוֹן וִיזְנִיץ", אֱלוּל תשס"ה, עַמ' י'
