*   **מלך זקן וכסיל**
I heard that when the beloved and pleasant brothers, the holy Rabbi Shmuel Avraham Abba Shapira zt"l and his second, similar to him, the holy Rabbi Pinchas zt"l of Slavita, sat in prison, the prison warden came and said that according to their severe sentence, they needed to sit in a dark room and not in a room where light prevails. The spirit of the holy Rabbi Shmuel Abba zt"l fell.
His brother, the holy Rabbi Pinchas zt"l, said to him: "Why is the Evil Inclination called **מלך זקן וכסיל** - 'an old and foolish king' (Ecclesiastes 4:13)? Is he not wise? He only makes others foolish.
"Indeed, the truth is that the Evil Inclination is an old and foolish king, for we sit in prison because it is the decree of a king. However, what is the Evil Inclination doing in prison, and who brought him to sit in prison?!"
Then Rabbi Shmuel Abba zt"l understood that the words were directed at him, that this was from the counsel of the Evil Inclination that he should have a fall of spirit (depression) from the words of the prison warden. And his mind was set at ease.
Source: Imrei Pinchas (Bnei Brak 5763), Vol. 2, p. 172

*   **אשריך עולם שהקב"ה מלך בך**
At the time when Hashem Yitbarach had mercy on the two holy brothers and brought them out from darkness to light after they sat in prison for 22 years due to a false accusation, Heaven forbid—as is known, when they came to their home, there were many people from the entire area who came to greet their holy faces. Everyone yearned greatly to speak with them, whether relatives or other people.
Immediately when they entered their home and sat on the chairs, they did not speak with any man, even with their household members. The beginning of their words was when the holy Rabbi Shmuel Abba zt"l said to his brother, the holy Rabbi Pinchas zt"l:
"Behold, for 22 years we have not been in our home. Perhaps, Heaven forbid, our Torah has been forgotten from us."
He thought for a few moments and said: "Behold, in the days of my youth, I was fluent in the book *Maavar Yabbok* by heart, and it seems to me that the conclusion of this book is in this language: **אשריך עולם שהקב"ה מלך בך** - 'Happy are you, O world, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, is King in you.'"
He ordered that this book be taken from the bookcase in his home. He looked into it and saw that it was indeed written so. He rejoiced and enjoyed it greatly, saying: "Thank G-d, blessed be He, that I have not forgotten, Heaven forbid."
So great was their righteousness and holiness that after such a long time—twenty-two years that they had not seen the members of their household and their relatives—they did not begin with any conversation with them. Only the beginning of their words was words of Torah and fear, lest Heaven forbid they had forgotten some matter of Torah. It was clearly seen how this entire world was trivial in their eyes, and the main thing was only to think constantly of the Eternal World. Furthermore, in the days of his youth, he was fluent by heart in the holy book *Maavar Yabbok*, and it is known that this book deals only with those matters [death and the afterlife], may their merit protect us.
It is further told that when the holy brothers returned to their home, a large and vast crowd waited for them. They sang and danced, surrounded them, and showered them with great love, preventing them from entering their holy home. One of them turned to his brother and said to him:
"It seems that from Heaven, a few more minutes of exile have been decreed upon us, and we have not yet completed them. Therefore, they prevent us from returning to our homes..."
Source: Tiferet Avot-Vizhnitz (Bnei Brak 5753), p. 641

*   **ומח שמו וזכרו**
*   **ונמח זכורו**
*   **מלהזכירו בזיכרון קדוש**
*   **זכר**
*   **עלינו**
The holy Rabbi Shmuel Abba of Slavita zt"l explained the hymn we say in the Yotzer for Parashat Zachor: **ומח שמו וזכרו, ונמח זכורו מלהזכירו בזיכרון קדוש** - "And blot out his name and his memory, and let his mention be blotted out from mentioning him in a holy remembrance."
Grammatical difficulties abound here. Since we ask "blot out his name and his memory," why do we go back and say "and let his mention be blotted out"? Also, the words "from mentioning him in a holy remembrance" have no explanation or relevance.
He said that this is the interpretation: First, we ask that his name and all his influence be blotted out, as it is known that **זכר** (Zecher - memory/mention) indicates influence. Then, certainly, it will be good, as mentioned in the **עלינו** prayer: "And idols will be utterly cut off"—to rectify the world in the Kingdom of the Almighty. That is, when his name and all his influence are blotted out, then the rectification will be complete, that the Name will be whole and the Throne whole, and the Redemption will be complete...
But if, Heaven forbid, the time has not yet arrived, we ask that at the very least "let his mention be blotted out from mentioning him in a holy remembrance." Meaning: let his influence be blotted out from influencing at the time when the influence of holiness flows, and at the time when the influence of holiness flows, let it not be mixed, Heaven forbid, with the influence of the Klipah (husk/evil), may the Merciful One save us. Understand this well.
Source: Zechut Avot-Vizhnitz (Bnei Brak 5753), p. 541

**Biography**
He was born in the year 5563 (1803) to his father, Rabbi Yaakov Moshe zt"l. He was the son-in-law of the holy Rabbi Yitzchak of Radvil zy"a. He was counted among the great students of the holy Maggid of Kozhnitz and his son, the holy Rabbi Moshe of Kozhnitz zy"a.
He served in the rabbinate of Shidlovtza and afterwards in Praga [a suburb of Warsaw]. Many basked in his shadow, and the greats of the generation admired him. He was a friend of the holy Rabbi, author of *Chiddushei HaRim* zt"l of Gur.
He passed away on the 5th of Adar 5628 (1868) and is buried in Warsaw. He left behind his works: *Harei Besamim*, *Atzei Besamim*, and *Rashei Besamim*.
Source: Sarfei Kodesh (Bnei Brak 5768), p. 291

The Gaon and Tzaddik Rabbi Yeshaya Mushkat of Praga (a suburb of Warsaw), author of *Atzei Besamim* on Mishnayot and other books, was a native of Warsaw. His father, Rabbi Yaakov Moshe, was one of the Chassidim of the Maggid Rabbi Yisrael of Kozhnitz and was the son-in-law of the Gaon and famous Tzaddik Rabbi Yitzchak of Radvil, author of *Ohr Yitzchak* on the Torah, son of the famous Tzaddik Rabbi Yechiel Michel of Zlotchov, one of the students of the Great Maggid of Mezeritch.
Rabbi Yeshaya served first as Rabbi in Shidlovtza, and afterwards, from the year 5600 (1840) onwards until his passing in 5628 (1868), he served as Rabbi and Admor in Praga, a suburb of Warsaw. His activity and influence on the Jews of Warsaw and Praga were great during these years, 5600-5628.
Rabbi Yeshaya was close friends with the Gaon author of *Chiddushei HaRim* of Gur, who lived in Warsaw until the year 5619 (1859), and also with the Gaon Rabbi Natke Spiegelglass, author of *Meorot Natan*, who was a student of the Gaon author of *Chemdat Shlomo* and a Kozhnitzer Chassid, and was a Dayan and Posek in Warsaw for fifty-two years from 5581 to 5633. The three of them together succeeded in influencing the Jews of Warsaw and making it a Chassidic community.
Rabbi Yeshaya worked in unison with the Rabbi HaGaon Rav Chaim Davidsohn, who was Av Beis Din in Warsaw from 5600-5614, and afterwards with the Rabbi HaGaon Rav Berish Meisels, who was Av Beis Din in Warsaw from 5614-5630. During this period, Rabbi Yeshaya signed various proclamations together with the other Rabbis of Warsaw.
Besides being a Tzaddik and leader of a Chassidic congregation, Rabbi Yeshaya Mushkat excelled as a giant in Torah, as seen from his books *Atzei Besamim* on Mishnayot and others. He maintained correspondence with the greats of his generation. He excelled in his cleverness and wit, and interesting stories and sayings circulate about him regarding his replies to the Maskilim of his generation.
Source: Gedolei HaTorah V'HaChassidut (Jerusalem 5728), Vol. 23, p. 7

They asked Rabbi Yeshaya of Praga: "What is the reason they said: For prayer in public, six worshipers are sufficient, but for Grace After Meals (Birkat HaMazon) in public [Zimmun with Hashem's name], seven eaters are needed?"
Rabbi Yeshaya answered: "I do not understand the question. Who cares if another Jew eats..."
Source: Chassidim Mesaprim (Jerusalem 5739), Vol. 1, p. 68

[The holy Admor, the *Imrei Chaim* of Vizhnitz zt"l, related:]
In the city of the Gaon Rabbi Yeshaya, the Prager Rav, there lived a blind pauper who sold bagels in the market.
Once, policemen caught him and took the bagels from him because he did not have a license to sell. However, since he had no other livelihood, with no choice, he stood the next day as well to sell bagels. When HaGaon Rav Yeshaya saw him, he hurried and bought all the bagels from him before he could be caught by the policemen. He did this day after day.
Once, his students asked him: "Teach us, our Rebbe, what does it matter to you if the bagels remain with the pauper? Pay him the money, and let the bagels remain with him, for surely our Rebbe has no need for bagels?"
Rabbi Yeshaya answered them: "If I buy all the bagels from him, and he comes home with an empty basket, the mistress of the house says to him: 'What a successful merchant you are—you sold all the bagels so quickly!' And then they honor him in his home. But if I give him the money and the bagels remain with him, it will not be pleasant for him, for he received money of charity (Chessed), and why should I take the pleasure and honor from him?"
Our Rebbe [the *Imrei Chaim*] concluded: "That is called a *Bar Daat* (a man of understanding)!"
Source: Sarfei Kodesh (Bnei Brak 5768), p. 292

*   **הרוצה לנסך יין על גבי המזבח ימלא גרונם של תלמידי חכמים יין**
*   **בעקבותא דמשיחא הגפן תתן פריה ויין ביוקר**
*   **בעקבותא דמשיחא חוצפא יסגא**
Once, on a festive day, Rabbi Yeshaya of Praga sat at his table with a congregation of Chassidim around him. He was eating a Seudah of Mitzvah and speaking at length in words of Torah. Many people became enthusiastic.
One old man said: "Let us send to buy wine."
The Tzaddik stopped him and said: "We have learned: 'Morning sleep and midday wine remove a man from the world.'"
The Chassidim did not let up. They had an argument in their mouths, for our Sages have already said: **הרוצה לנסך יין על גבי המזבח ימלא גרונם של תלמידי חכמים יין** - "He who wishes to pour wine on the altar should fill the throats of Torah scholars with wine..."
The Rabbi answered them: "I never understood the words of our Sages (Sotah 49b): **בעקבותא דמשיחא הגפן תתן פריה ויין ביוקר** - 'In the footsteps of the Messiah, the vine will give its fruit, yet wine will be expensive.' If the vine gives its fruit, why will the price of wine rise?
"Now your words explain it to me. Is it not true that **בעקבותא דמשיחא חוצפא יסגא** - 'In the footsteps of the Messiah, impudence will increase,' and everyone will consider that his Rebbe is a Torah scholar, and he will buy much wine so that he can fill his throat. Thus, wine will be expensive..."
Source: Chassidim Mesaprim (Jerusalem 5739), Vol. 2, p. 16

[The holy Rabbi Avraham of Porisov zt"l] used to praise the words of HaGaon Rav Yeshayale of Praga, author of *Rashei Besamim* zt"l, who used to say:
Why is the law regarding one who falls into "waters that have no end" (waters where the shore cannot be seen from all sides) that his wife is forbidden [to remarry] (Yevamot 121a)? After all, the majority of people drown when they are not seen coming up, and in all cases we follow the majority!
But the matter is thus: If the law were that his wife is permitted because we assume he drowned, there would not be a single one of those who fall into the water who would survive, for the law would cut off his life. But since saving a life is stricter than the issue of Agunah, the Sages forbade his wife. Consequently, he is able to be saved, for there is no concern that she will remarry [improperly].
Source: Gedolei HaTorah V'HaChassidut (Jerusalem 5728), Vol. 23, p. 7

*   **וכל הנשים**
*   **וכל הנשים יתנו יקר לבעליהן**
*   **וכל הנשים העמדות**
It is told about the wife of Rav Yeshaya of Praga: She was a G-d-fearing woman, but she disobeyed his mouth, and her one argument was that she was busy with Mitzvos. When he asked something of her, she stood in prayer or was busy with [religious] stations.
Once her husband said to her: "Why do you not do my will and are always busy?"
She answered him: "Behold, you see that I am busy with Mitzvos always!"
He said to her: "In the Torah it is written **וכל הנשים** - 'And all the women whose heart stirred them up in wisdom spun the goats' (Exodus 35:26). The Baal HaTurim says: 'Three times the words **וכל הנשים** - "And all the women" are mentioned in the Tanach: Here; and later **וכל הנשים יתנו יקר לבעליהן** - "And all the women shall give honor to their husbands" (Esther 1:20); and furthermore **וכל הנשים העמדות** - "And all the women that stood" (Jeremiah 44:15).
"Those women who engaged in the work of Heaven [spinning goats for the Tabernacle] gave honor. But those cursed ones who burned incense to the host of heaven caused exile and became a byword and a taunt.' Up to here is the language of the Baal HaTurim.
"You see," said Rav Yeshaya to his wife the Rebbetzin, "that even women who engage in holy work for the Tabernacle are obligated to give honor to their husbands and listen to their voice."
Source: Gedolei HaTorah V'HaChassidut (Jerusalem 5728), Vol. 23, p. 15

The community leaders of Praga, near Warsaw, entered Rabbi Yeshayahu and said:
"The community asks that his honor explain: great is the sorrow and great is the disgrace from his conduct. Every lowlife, drunkard, or thief finds shelter in his Beis Midrash and enjoys his hospitality. Is this the Mitzvah of Hachnasat Orchim (welcoming guests)?"
Rabbi Yeshayahu replied to them:
"In the evening of my days, I have concluded saying: I promise my share in the World to Come."
"How so?" asked the leaders.
"The matter is simple," answered the Rabbi. "I will come to the World of Truth, and they will ask me: 'What is your occupation?' I will say: 'What difference does it make what my occupation is? If I am a drunkard or a scoundrel, a thief or a swindler—I am a guest, and you must receive me with a cheerful face.' They will ask me: 'And did you also not test and investigate your guests?' I will answer: 'Certainly! Ask the leaders of Praga and they will tell you...' With no choice, they will accept me..."
"And you," concluded Rabbi Yeshaya, "listen to my voice like me. Instead of promising my house from drunkards, promise your homes for the future..."
Source: Chassidim Mesaprim (Jerusalem 5739), Vol. 3, p. 233

הַקָּהָל בִּקֵּשׁ שֶׁנַּסְבִּיר לִכְבוֹדוֹ, מַה רַב הַצַּעַר וְגָדוֹל הַבִּזָּיוֹן מֵהִתְנַהֲגוּתוֹ. כָּל חֲדַל־אִישִׁים, שִׁכּוֹר אוֹ גַּנָּב מוֹצֵא לוֹ מַחֲסֶה בְּבֵית מִדְרָשׁוֹ וְנֶהֱנֶה מֵאֲרוּחוֹתָיו. כְּלוּם זֹאת הִיא מִצְוַת הַכְנָסַת אוֹרְחִים?הֶחְזִיר לָהֶם רַבִּי יְשַׁעְיָהוּ:
בַּעֲרוֹב יָמַי גָּמַרְתִּי אוֹמֵר: אַבְטִיחַ חֶלְקִי לְעוֹלָם הַבָּא.
הָא כֵּיצַד? - שָׁאֲלוּ הַפַּרְנָסִים.
הַדָּבָר פָּשׁוּט - עָנָה הָרַבִּי - אָבוֹא לְעוֹלָם הָאֱמֶת, יִשְׁאָלוּנִי: מַה מַּעֲשֶׂיךָ? אַגִּיד: מַאי נַפְקָא מִינָּה מַה מַּעֲשַׂי, אִם אֲנִי שִׁכּוֹר אוֹ בֶּן בְּלִיַּעַל, גַּנָּב אוֹ רַמַּאי - אוֹרֵחַ אֲנִי וְיֵשׁ לְקַבְּלֵנִי בְּסֵבֶר פָּנִים יָפוֹת. יִשְׁאָלוּנִי: וְאַתָּה גַּם כֵּן לֹא בָּחַנְתָּ וְלֹא חָקַרְתָּ אֶת אוֹרְחֶיךָ? אָשִׁיב: בְּוַדַּאי, שַׁאֲלוּ אֶת פַּרְנְסֵי פְּרַאגָא וְיַגִּידוּ לָכֶם... בְּלֵית בְּרֵירָה יְקַבְּלוּ אוֹתִי...
וְאַתֶּם מְסַיֵּם רַבִּי יְשַׁעְיָה - שִׁמְעוּ לְקוֹלִי כָּמוֹנִי, בִּמְקוֹם לְהַבְטִיחַ אֶת בֵּיתִי מִשִּׁכּוֹרִים, תַּבְטִיחוּ אֶת בֵּיתְכֶם לֶעָתִיד...הרה"ח ר' יְהוּדָה לֵייבּ לֵוִין ז"ל"חֲסִידִים מְסַפְּרִים" (יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשל"ט) ח"ג, עַמ' 233

*   **הקורא את שמע צריך שיכון את לבו שנאמר שמע ישראל**
*   **שבת כהלכתו**
HaGaon HaKadosh Rav Yeshayali of Praga, author of *Harei Besamim*, may his memory be for a blessing in the World to Come, was very strict that a white tablecloth be placed on the table on the holy Sabbath.
He used to say: Just as the crimson thread turned white on Yom Kippur, for white hints at forgiveness of sins (Shabbat 86a), so too on the holy Sabbath a white tablecloth must be placed, to hint that even if one worships idols, etc., they forgive him if he keeps **שבת כהלכתו** - "Shabbat according to its law" (Shabbat 118b), just like on Yom Kippur.
Source: Karnei Re'em (Bnei Brak 5755), p. 120

Rabbi Yeshaya of Praga explained the expression used for a miser: "He is a mouse lying on a Dinar."
Because when a mouse enters a sack of flour, he finds double benefit in it: he has food to eat, and also a soft bed to lie upon. But when he enters a pile of wheat, he finds an advantage and a disadvantage: he has food to eat, but the lying is hard, for the wheat pricks. However, when he enters a sack of money—it is bad for him from here and from there: he has no food to eat, and the lying is hard.
So it is with most miserly rich men. They spare every food item that comes to their mouth, they spare every penny, and they have no pleasure from their money: and from much worry over their money, their sleep is not sleep.
Source: Raayonot LaDrush (Jerusalem 5766), p. 362

They asked Rabbi Yeshaya of Praga: "If suffering is a good thing, why didn't they institute a blessing over it?"
Rabbi Yeshaya answered: "Certainly they instituted one: 'Who has provided me with all my needs' (She'asah Li Kol Tzorki)."
Source: Chassidim Mesaprim (Jerusalem 5739), Vol. 1, p. 167

*   **האומנין קורין בראש האילן ובראש הנדבך מה שאינן רשאין לעשות כן בתפילה**
*   **הקורא את שמע צריך שיכון את לבו שנאמר שמע ישראל**
Once, the *Chiddushei HaRim* [Rabbi Yitzchak Meir of Gur] asked Rabbi Yeshaya of Praga:
"Why does the Mishnah say (Berachot 16a): **האומנין קורין בראש האילן ובראש הנדבך מה שאינן רשאין לעשות כן בתפילה** - 'Laborers may recite [Shema] at the top of a tree or at the top of a course of stones, something they are not permitted to do for prayer [Amidah].'
"Does not the Reading of Shema require more intent (Kavanah) than prayer, as the Gemara says (ibid): **הקורא את שמע צריך שיכון את לבו שנאמר שמע ישראל** - 'One who reads the Shema must direct his heart, as it is said: Hear O Israel.' So why is it permitted to say the Shema at the top of a tree, while the Amidah prayer is forbidden?"
Rabbi Yeshaya answered him: "Prayer is forbidden to be prayed in a place of danger, even a doubtful danger to life, as is told (Berachot 3) in the story of Rabbi Yossi with Elijah the Prophet in the ruin. Therefore, it is forbidden to pray at the top of a tree. But regarding the Reading of Shema, one needs to say it with self-sacrifice (Mesirat Nefesh). And if so, what does it matter that he says it at the top of a tree? Lest he fall? Is one not obligated to give up his life for the Reading of Shema anyway?"
Source: Gedolei HaTorah V'HaChassidut (Jerusalem 5728), Vol. 23, p. 26

They asked Rabbi Yeshaya of Praga: "Why did they permit a Torah scholar an eighth of an eighth of pride (Sotah 5a)? Is not even a crumb of pride despicable?"
Rabbi Yeshaya answered: "They permitted it to him so that he could fulfill 'Sanctify yourself in what is permitted to you'..."
Source: Chassidim Mesaprim (Jerusalem 5739), Vol. 2, p. 100

*   **הלואי אותי עזבו ותורתי שמרו**
Rabbi Yeshayahu of Praga asked:
"Our Sages told us that the Holy One, Blessed be He, says to the Jews: **הלואי אותי עזבו ותורתי שמרו** - 'Would that they had forsaken Me but kept My Torah.' How is it possible to forsake the Holy One, Blessed be He, and with that, keep the Torah?"
And Rabbi Yeshayahu answered:
"'Forsaken Me' refers to the investigations about Me. 'Kept My Torah' refers to the Mitzvos, the simplicity..."
Source: Chassidim Mesaprim (Jerusalem 5739), Vol. 3, p. 93
