סִפְּרוּ לָנוּ חֲזַ"ל, אוֹמֵר הַקַּבָּ"ה לַיְּהוּדִים: "הַלְוַאי אוֹתִי עָזְבוּ וְתוֹרָתִי שָׁמָרוּ", אֵיךְ יִתָּכֵן לַעֲזֹב לְהַקַּבָּ"ה וְעִם זֶה לִשְׁמֹר אֶת הַתּוֹרָה?וּמְתָרֵץ רַבִּי יְשַׁעְיָהוּ:
אוֹתִי עָזְבוּ - הַחֲקִירוֹת סְבִיבִי, תּוֹרָתִי שָׁמָרוּ - אֶת הַמִּצְווֹת, אֶת הַפַּשְׁטוּת...הרה"ח ר' יְהוּדָה לֵייבּ לֵוִין ז"ל"חֲסִידִים מְסַפְּרִים" (יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשל"ט) ח"ג, עַמ' 93
body_en:
**Biography**
He was born in the year 5569 (1809) to his father, Rabbi Raphael zt"l Dobrinsky, who was one of the hidden Tzaddikim of his generation and a descendant of a long line of hidden Tzaddikim. Rabbi Raphael maintained an inn in a small village near Prentziv in Poland for his livelihood, and there his son Rabbi Avraham was born.
His father, who recognized from the time of his birth that he was created for greatness, dedicated him entirely to Heaven. When no teacher fitting his stature was found in Prentziv, the city of his residence, he took him to Plotzk, which was full of sages and scribes. In a short time, the boy grew and adopted for himself all the treasures of Torah and the 48 acquisitions. For some time, he acquired wisdom and knowledge from the Rabbi of the city, the famous Gaon Rabbi Leibush Charif zy"a. But he acquired the essence of his Torah by himself through toil and self-study.
In the year 5585 (1825), a new chapter began in his life when the Chassidic philanthropist Rabbi Dan Landau zt"l took him as a groom for his daughter. Our Rebbe zy"a was supported at the table of Rabbi Dan for many years. Without the burdens of the yoke of livelihood, he turned nights into days with immense diligence and toil in Torah study. Our Rebbe even changed his family name in those days to the name Landau, like his father-in-law's family name.
Many communities sent distinguished delegations pleading before him to take upon himself the yoke of the rabbinate. Finally, our Rebbe acceded to the request of the leaders of the city of Tchechenov to come and be their Rabbi and guide. With his unique qualities and the great love of Israel that pulsed within him, our Rebbe quickly became beloved by the people of his city. He soon became famous by name and praise for his Torah and holiness, and for the righteousness of his distribution to every poor and destitute person.
He even opened a large Yeshiva in Tchechenov which quickly became a creator of many of the greats of the coming generation. From between its walls, it sprouted many leaders of the generation, men of renown.
Alongside being known as a man of Halacha who did not move a hairsbreadth from the minutiae of the law, he paved a unique path for himself in the service of G-d. Among other things (differing from the Tzaddikim of his generation who cleaved to the path of our Rebbe the Baal Shem Tov zy"a), our Rebbe selected for himself the version of prayer according to the Ashkenaz rite (Nusach Ashkenaz), from which he did not deviate in the slightest. He was strict about every jot and tittle of custom and order of prayer.
Our Rebbe zy"a had his own way of leadership as well. He refused to conduct himself as a Rebbe like the other Tzaddikim of the generation. He did not permit his Chassidim to flock to his shadow until after the passing of the Seraph of Kotzk and the holy Rabbi author of *Chiddushei HaRim* of Gur zy"a. Only then did he accept the decree and no longer pushed away those coming to bask in his shadow.
The Tzaddikim of his generation admired him and related to him with awe of holiness. Even in the mouths of the masses, his fame went out as a wondrous man, a master of the Holy Spirit, whose blessings bore fruit and whose word did not return empty. To the point that even people who were not members of the covenant (non-Jews) would come to seek his face.
In the last years of his life, his main study and the majority of his innovations were in the orders of Kodshim and Taharot. However, he did not want to commit his Torah innovations to writing. Even regarding Halachic responsa, he refused to reply to his many questioners for reasons hidden with him. He would only reply orally.
He passed away from the world on the 5th of Adar I, 5635 (1875), in the 86th year of his life. He left behind offspring blessed by G-d. Among them: his son Rabbi Zev Wolf of Strykov zy"a; his son Rabbi Berish of Biala zy"a; his son-in-law Rabbi Shmuel of Shinova zy"a, known for his work *Ramatayim Tzofim*; and others. From his Torah innovations, the books *Zechuta D'Avraham*, *Beit Avraham*, *Chessed L'Avraham*, *Tzelota D'Avraham*, *Ahavat Chessed*, and others were published.
Source: Nezer HaTorah, Elul 5762, p. 30

When our Rebbe, HaGaon HaKadosh Rabbi Avraham zy"a of Tchechenov, was a toddler lying in his cradle, one day he grabbed his head with his two hands. His parents took his hands off his head, and he began to cry. Immediately, they understood that he did not want to go without a head covering, so they sewed a hat for him.
(I heard this from Rabbi Raphael Friedman zt"l, who heard it from his grandson, Rabbi Fishel Dan Landau zt"l).
Source: B'Yishishim Chochmah (Jerusalem 5754), p. 35

...And regarding what you demanded of me, to inform you when my grandfather our Rebbe (HaGaon Rabbi Avraham of Tchechenov) zt"l began to be a Rebbe of Chassidim?
In the days of his youth, he basked in the shadow of the holy Rabbi, the famous Rav Fishel zt"l of Strykov. He was also twice by the holy Rabbi Rav Simcha Bunim zt"l of Pshischa. He conducted himself in the ways of the Chassidim and their customs in prayer. Afterwards, he changed his path in this and prayed and conducted himself in everything according to the custom of Ashkenaz and the prayer of Vatikin (sunrise).
Source: Rabbi Zev Lipschutz (Lodz 5694), p. 17

*   **כלי שני אינו מבשל**
I know a story: Our Rebbe, my grandfather the Tzaddik (HaGaon of Tchechenov zy"a), was accustomed to drinking very hot coffee, to the point that the hand would recoil from it (Yad Soledet Bo), something impossible for anyone else.
Once, when he was dining with his son, the Admor Rabbi Zev Wolf of Strykov, they served them two cups of very hot coffee. The Tzaddik immediately began to drink and signaled his son to drink as well.
"The coffee is boiling (*kocht*) and it is impossible," said his son, Rabbi Zev.
His father, the Tzaddik, scolded him: "How could you bring out of your mouth a thing that is not in accordance with the opinion of our Sages? **כלי שני אינו מבשל** - 'A secondary vessel does not cook'!"
When the Admor Maharz"v later traveled to Kotzk, and the Rebbe of Kotzk asked him, as was his holy custom, to tell him some new insight from his righteous father, he told him this remark of his father.
"Who can compare to such a man whose every limb is Torah!" said the Rebbe of Kotzk in great amazement.
Source: Zechuta D'Avraham (Tel Aviv 5730), p. 33

*   **תני בר קפרא**
*   **כל שאור וכל דבש לא תקטירו ממנו אשה לה**
*   **עבירה גוררת עבירה**
Once, a group of Chassidim came to the Admor Rabbi Avraham of Tchechenov and asked him to come out against the conduct in Kotzk, where they pray late and prolong the preparations for prayer.
The Rebbe answered them that we find in the Baraita: **תני בר קפרא** - "Bar Kappara taught: If one put a kortov of honey into it [the incense], no man could stand because of its scent. And why do they not mix honey into it? Because the Torah said: **כל שאור וכל דבש לא תקטירו ממנו אשה לה** - 'For any leaven and any honey, you shall not burn from it a fire offering to the L-rd.'"
The question is asked: What does the Baraita add? Is this not what is stated in the verse itself?
He said: The Torah comes to say that although it is possible to make it better—for if honey were mixed in, it would be superb and sublime—nevertheless, one thing interests us: "The Torah said."
"This is the same matter in our case. It is possible that through many preparations the prayer is more improved. But only one thing interests us: what 'The Torah said.' And in the Shulchan Aruch, it is written to pray on time."
The Rebbe added and said: "In any case, I will not come out against them, for we have a rule: **עבירה גוררת עבירה** - 'A sin drags a sin along.' Since I do not see the 'sins' that are dragged after this sin, therefore I will not come out against this."
(From the mouth of Rabbi Yeshayahu Frankel, as he heard from his in-law, the Admor Rabbi Avraham Landau of Strykov).
Source: Sar HaTorah (Jerusalem 5769), p. 664

*   **תשב אנוש עד דכא ותאמר שובו בני אדם**
An old man told that he wanted to know the holy Gaon Rabbi Avraham of Tchechenov zy"a. He entered his Beis Midrash, but did not know who the Rabbi was. Suddenly, he saw an old man approaching the Mezuzah, and with a great cry, he said: **תשב אנוש עד דכא ותאמר שובו בני אדם** - "You turn man to contrition, and say: Return, ye children of men" (Psalms 90:3).
Trembling seized him from fear. And he no longer needed to ask who the Rabbi was, for he immediately understood who he was.
(I heard this from Rabbi Yechiel Weil, who heard it from the old man, the master of the story).
Source: B'Yishishim Chochmah (Jerusalem 5754), p. 36

At the time of the decree on clothing in Poland, the opinion of the holy Rabbi Avraham of Tchechenov zt"l was that one must oppose this and go with actual self-sacrifice. He wanted to travel to the *Chiddushei HaRim* to speak with him about this matter. However, due to his weakness, his household members did not let him travel all the way to Warsaw, which was too far.
He said to them: "I am not going there *tzu zitzen* (to sit/stay)." (Meaning, he is not going to stay there).
In the end, when he traveled, he did not want to sit on a chair at all, so as not to change from his word, despite the fact that this was not his intention [literally]. He stood the entire time!
Source: Zichron Devarim (Jerusalem 5767), p. 16

Once, the Admor of Strykov zt"l related about his grandfather, the Gaon of Tchechenov zy"a, that a match had already been concluded for one of his offspring. The in-law, who was a respected man, asked to postpone the conclusion of the match until after the Nine Days.
The Gaon of Tchechenov zy"a instructed to cancel the match, saying that he does not wish to pair up with a man who tries to be cleverer than what is ruled in the Shulchan Aruch (Orach Chayim 551:2), which states: "But to betroth without a meal is permitted, and even on the Ninth of Av itself it is permitted, lest another precede him."
Source: Divrot Kodesh (Strykov), Chukat 5769, p. 3

I recall: When the Admor of Slonim zt"l, author of *Birkat Avraham*, was recounting the praises of the sages of the generations, as soon as he reached Rabbi Avraham'li of Tchechenov, he opened and told of the Admor author of *Divrei Shmuel* zt"l.
In the days of his youth, the *Divrei Shmuel* traveled from Slonim to Tchechenov to observe his ways and stayed within his presence for about six weeks. In this short period of time, the *Divrei Shmuel* immersed himself entirely in the toil of Torah according to the Tchechenov style, in discussion and debate. He managed to learn the entire Shas Bavli from beginning to end with fine, thorough scrutiny, until he was amazed at himself and said:
"This is nothing but from the power of the Torah of Rabbi Avraham'li that flows around him!"
And he further said: "I felt a light then. Only one other time did I feel such a light of *D'orayta* (Torah)—when I was in the Land of Israel!"
Source: Marbitzei Torah MeOlam HaChassidut (Bnei Brak 5746), Vol. 1, p. 116

A story of a Jew who turned to the holy Gaon zt"l of Tchechenov with a complaint that he was a solitary Jew living in the village of Munkatov.
Our Rebbe zt"l said to him: "Is there such a thing as a solitary Jew? Does he not have Abaye and Rava?!..."
And regarding his question of which Mussar book he should learn, he answered him: "*Reishit Chochmah* or the *Shelah*."
(I heard from the Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reizman zt"l, who heard from his father—the master of the story—Rabbi Natanel HaLevi zt"l).
Source: B'Yishishim Chochmah (Jerusalem 5754), p. 35

When I came to live in Manchester, I met an old man here who still knew the holy Rabbi Avraham of Tchechenov zt"l. He told me that in his youth he was an eyewitness to a certain incident, and the Tchechenover Rav called him to come to him so he could hear from him what he saw.
This man was from a very simple family. When he entered before the Tchechenover Rav, he entered with his hands in his pockets. Immediately, the Tchechenover Rav said to him:
"You are a *Nogea* (interested party) in the matter, and an interested party is disqualified for testimony."
And he did not want to hear from him or speak with him anymore.
Source: Maadanei Yosef (Jerusalem 5763), p. 132

This was the story of Rabbi Shmuel Grudka, one of the trustworthy residents of Ostrowa in the early seventh century [5600s]:
"I was released from 12 years of service in the Russian army. I returned to my home and my wife, and I didn't have a penny in my hand. On my wife's advice, I went to Tchechenov, to the Tzaddik Rabbi Avraham, to ask for his blessing. The Rebbe blessed me with the blessing of success when I go out to do business.
"'With what shall I go out?' I asked him.
"'With my blessing,' he answered me. I believed his words with all my heart.
"I went out from Tchechenov to the market of Ostrowa, and I had nothing in my hand. I wandered among the peasants and peddlers, my soul depressed. Behold, I saw a peasant standing next to a wagon loaded with grain.
"'Buy, *Starozakonny* (Old Testament believer),' he said.
"'But I have no money,' I answered.
"'Then I will lend to you. Sell and profit and pay me back.'
"I did not refuse. I brought the grain into my yard, sold it at a good price, with a decent profit within two or three days.
"A week passed. When the fair was held again in Ostrowa, I went out to the market. Behold, I see a group of peasants, and among them one peasant shouting loudly, wailing and tearing his hair. I approached out of curiosity, and behold, it was the peasant who sold me the grain. He was bitter, blaming himself that he behaved like a fool, coming with his grain a week ago to the market and selling it on trust to a Jew completely unknown to him. And now—his produce is gone, the money is gone, and the Jew is gone...
"I approached him, took him aside, and said to him: 'Here I am, the one who bought the grain from you. I came to look for you and pay you what is due to you. Here is your money in my bag; I will count it out to the last penny.'
"I handed the money to the peasant, and his eyes lit up. In an instant, he changed; he rejoiced with great joy, hugged me, and patted me on the shoulder repeatedly. 'There is no trustworthy Jew like you in the whole world,' he mumbled incessantly. 'And from now on, I will do business only with you,' he stated.
"From that day on," related Rabbi Shmuel, "I became the trustee of this peasant and all the people of his village and the neighboring villages. They brought me all their produce on trust, and I sold and served them faithfully. Thus, Rabbi Shmuel became rich, believing with all his heart that his livelihood and wealth came to him through the merit of the Tzaddik.
"The peasants remained faithful to him until his last day. After his passing, they kept faith with his sons and heirs, continuing his trade until the Holocaust broke out, telling at every opportunity of the blessing of the Tzaddik from Tchechenov that stood for them."
Source: Ostrowa Mazowiecka (Jerusalem 5726), p. 112

**Matchmaking**
The holy Gaon of Tchechenov zt"l zy"a wrote that the matter of matchmaking (Shidduchim) is among the things covered by the Ancient of Days. Indeed, I think that for him zt"l, the level of things he said was always clear to him in all worlds, and therefore regarding the matter of Shidduchim, he said that it was covered from him—meaning, from his level of vision.
However, regarding what we decide and say in all questions, it is only according to what Hashem Yitbarach grants us to clarify according to the opinion of the holy Torah. And this, I think, needs to be said regarding a Shidduch as well.
Source: Igrot HaRav (Jerusalem 5753), p. 161

HaGaon our teacher Rabbi Avraham zt"l, Av Beis Din of Tchechenov, gave an order to his genius sons zt"l that they should not dare to come to him before he writes to them to come.
He conducted himself this way whenever he wanted to see one of his sons; he would write a special letter for him to come. His reason was that during the time his sons are not in his house and his city, they are not fulfilling the commandment of Honoring One's Father. Therefore, he commanded that they should not come to him unless called. Thus, during the entire time they lived in another city, they would fulfill the honor of their father and his command not to come to their father's house except when their holy father desired them and called them to come to his holy courts.
Source: Otzar Sichot Tzaddikim (London 5753), p. 293

My friend, HaGaon Rabbi Tzvi Yechezkel Michelson, Av Beis Din of Płońsk, wrote to me, and this is his language:
I heard from my friend, Rabbi Moshe Tzvi N.Y., a Dayan and Posek here, that he knew the man—a Chassid and wealthy man in the city of Tchechenov—who spoke some bad words against our Rebbe, the Gaon author of *Noda B'Yehuda*, Av Beis Din of Prague zt"l, regarding what he wrote in his book concerning the recitation of "L'Shem Yichud" and Chassidim, etc. (see *Noda B'Yehuda*, Mahadura Kama, Yoreh Deah, Siman 93).
The matter reached the Rabbi, HaGaon HaKadosh Rabbi Avraham zt"l, who was then the Rabbi in Tchechenov. He commanded to excommunicate and ban the slanderer until he traveled to the city of Prague and asked forgiveness at a gathering of a Minyan of ten men at the grave of that Tzaddik.
And so it was, for all the people of the city of Tchechenov separated from him and did not stand within his four cubits. He was forced to wander from his city for about a year until he returned from Prague, and then he released him from the ban. Despite all this, that rich man became impoverished and poor, and was in need of people's [charity] until he passed away to his eternal home a short time later, may we be spared.
Source: Meshareitav Esh Lohet (Bnei Brak 5760), Vol. 1, p. 11

They tell of HaGaon HaKadosh Rabbi Avraham of Tchechenov zt"l that he had a certain friend, a genius and holy man, who once asked him:
"Are we not both great in Torah together? I have increased Torah like you, and I also have good deeds like you. Why do they shout 'Rebbe' about you, but not about me?!"
The Gaon of Tchechenov answered him: "Tell me, my friend, did you ever have a great joy the likes of which you cannot describe?"
He said: "Yes, once I earned ten thousand rubles at one time."
"If so," answered the Gaon of Tchechenov, "indeed, you had great joy!" And he repeated his words several times: "Joy that you cannot describe more! Now, know, my friend and beloved companion, that when I stretch out my hand to put on Tefillin and I am still only preparing myself to fulfill the command of my Creator, I have a joy thousands of thousands of times greater than what you had when you earned the ten thousand rubles."
Immediately, that Tzaddik burst into great weeping and said: "If so, the world is not mistaken in you, and you are worthy to be called Rebbe." From that day on, he went and read himself "Rebbe" [referring to the Tchechenover] and basked in his shadow as one of his students.
Source: B'Yishishim Chochmah (Jerusalem 5754), p. 35

The holy Rabbi Avraham of Porisov zt"l told that a certain Sage from the Holy City of Jerusalem, may it be rebuilt, was abroad visiting the holy Gaon, the Rabbi and Av Beis Din of Tchechenov, of blessed memory.
The aforementioned Gaon asked him: "I heard that they say about you that you are among the Sages in our Holy Land. I have a question to ask you: Why do the people of the Land of Israel, when they have a request, go to the graves of Tzaddikim to pray, whereas with us abroad, for everything that happens, we go before the Rebbe to mention it [submit a Kvittel]?"
The Sage answered him: "I am forced to tell a reason according to Halacha. For we find regarding the spies: Joshua went to his teacher, Moses our Teacher, peace be upon him, and he blessed him: 'May G-d save you from the counsel of the spies.' If so, his method was to go to the Rebbe to mention it before him. But Caleb went to prostrate himself on the graves of the Patriarchs to pray there.
"If so, then the Rebbe was Moses our Teacher, peace be upon him, and he was definitely a Rebbe. And the graves of the Patriarchs are definitely graves of Tzaddikim. Therefore, each one acted according to his method: this one to the Rebbe and that one to the graves of Tzaddikim.
"However, now the people of the Land of Israel hold that the matter of a 'Rebbe' is doubtful [whether there is a true Rebbe like Moses], whereas the graves of Tzaddikim are certain. And since 'doubt does not remove certainty,' therefore they go specifically to the graves of Tzaddikim which are certain."
The aforementioned holy Gaon praised his clever words. Several times he would say jokingly to a famous Rebbe who was with him that he heard from the Sage from the Land of Israel that the matter of a Rebbe is a doubt, and it is a "doubt regarding a Rabbinic matter" [which we rule leniently/dismissively].
Source: Karnei Re'em (Bnei Brak 5755), Vol. 1, p. 174

The holy Admor (of Strykov) zt"l told several times about the greatness of the acts of charity of his grandfather, the holy Gaon Rabbi Avraham of Tchechenov zy"a. In his later years, he would distribute vast amounts of money to charity, to the point that they would send him money from all over the world. Everything passed through his hand, and he did not want to benefit or touch this charity money.
He said that the world tells of one of the important men in Kotzk whose name was the Chassid Rabbi Abba, who served as a Shochet, etc., that he was the trustee for charity matters for the Gaon of Tchechenov zy"a. He appointed him to manage all the charity affairs.
The holy Rabbi of Kotzk zy"a would always ask the aforementioned Rabbi Abba, when he came to him in Kotzk, to tell him about the conduct and speech of the Gaon of Tchechenov zy"a.
Source: Divrot Kodesh (Strykov), Chukkat 5769, p. 3

*   **הלומד תורה לשמה זוכה לדברים הרבה**
Our Rebbe, the holy Gaon of Tchechenov zy"a, said: **הלומד תורה לשמה זוכה לדברים הרבה** - "He who learns Torah for its own sake merits many things" (Avot 6:1).
Even what he did not do, they say about him and attribute to his name.
(I heard this from his grandson, the holy Rabbi Pinchas Zelig Landau zt"l).
Source: B'Yishishim Chochmah (Jerusalem 5754), p. 36

When the son of the Admor Maharash"d [of Klausenburg-USA] Shlita was born, he honored [the holy Admor of Klausenburg zt"l] with the Sandeka'ut the Admor of Boyan, Rabbi Mordechai Shlomo zt"l.
[Regarding the admiration our Rebbe (the Admor of Klausenburg zy"a) harbored for him, it is told, among other things, that once when he visited the Admor of Boyan zt"l in his palace, when he left, he said to HaGaon Rav Shmuel Krasno in this language:]
"He sits tucked within his four cubits and shakes the entire world and its fullness."
Source: Lapid HaEsh (Bnei Brak 5763), Vol. 2, p. 457

A few weeks before the liquidation of the holy community of Tchechenov during the decree of annihilation of 5703 (1943), it became known to the people of the city that the impure Nazis were plotting specifically against the grave of the Tzaddik (HaGaon of Tchechenov) zt"l. They resolved to uproot it from its place and plow the ground so that no remnant would remain there.
Immediately, the heads of the Chevra Kadisha gathered: Rabbi Yisrael Yaakov Student Hy"d, a great Torah scholar, lecturer to the masses, and devoted activist of Agudath Israel; Rabbi Binyamin Melina, one of the faces of the city and its important figures, an activist for public needs with faithfulness; Rabbi Avraham Friedman, an enthusiastic activist in his city; and joined by Rabbi Berish Klenitz, one of the respected men of Tchechenov.
Together they resolved to thwart the plot of the wicked ones at any price, even if the greatest punishment would come upon them. The honor of the holiness of the Tzaddik's memory was dearer to them than anything.
At night, they put their lives in their hands and went out to the cemetery. They dug and opened the grave of the Tzaddik zt"l. When they reached the Golel (covering stone), they were surprised and amazed at the sight of their eyes—the bones of the Tzaddik were lying there for sixty-seven years, and the state of the body was still as if it had been buried not long ago; even the shrouds had not decayed.
With awe and fear and trembling of holiness, they took out the body of the Tzaddik inside a Tallit. They went out and dug a grave for him in the new cemetery in Tchechenov, between two trees that they marked, and there they buried his holy remains...
Source: Zechuta D'Avraham (Tel Aviv 5730), p. 96

*   **אמונה ובטחון**
The holy Gaon Rabbi Avraham of Tchechenov zy"a said:
"The entire world stands on Faith (Emunah) and Trust (Bitachon). Therefore, the first letters of the Aleph-Bet are an acronym for **אמונה ובטחון** (Emunah u'Bitachon). And with this, one merits everything."
(I heard this from Rabbi Bunim Fogel of Rawa).
Source: B'Yishishim Chochmah (Jerusalem 5754), p. 37

*   **אלה**
*   **תשובה**
I recall a word I heard from the late Gaon Rabbi Yoav Yehoshua zt"l of Kintzk (author of *Chelkat Yoav*) in the name of the holy Gaon of Tchechenov zt"l, which he heard from him on Rosh Hashanah.
He asked a question on the verse in Parashat Korach regarding Moses our Teacher, peace be upon him, who made a test: "If these men die the common death of all men... then the L-rd has not sent me."
He asked: What is the proof? Perhaps they contemplated repentance (Teshuvah) like the sons of Korach? How could Moses our Teacher place his entire mission in doubt?
He answered: Because of this, he was precise in saying **אלה** ("These")—meaning, these specific people as they are now. But a **תשובה** (Baal Teshuvah/Penitent) is a different person entirely, since he changes his deeds.
[He relied on what the Rambam zt"l wrote in Chapter 2 of Laws of Repentance, that a Baal Teshuvah who changes his deeds is as if he is another man.]
Source: Mikra Meforash (Piotrkow 5696), p. 64b

From my father-in-law, the Gaon (author of *Avnei Nezer*) of Sochatchov zt"l, I heard in the name of the holy Gaon of Tchechenov zt"l:
Regarding Kaddish for a father and mother—since they instituted it, one who cancels it is considered to be disrespecting his father and mother, which is a Torah prohibition, even after death.
Source: Shut Eretz Tzvi (Bnei Brak 5750), Vol. 1, p. 158

*   **עמלק**
The Gaon Rabbi Meir Shapiro zt"l, Rosh Yeshiva of Chachmei Lublin, told during the Purim meal of 5693 (1933) that the holy Gaon Rabbi Avraham of Tchechenov zt"l would write the name **עמלק** (Amalek) every day and erase it, to fulfill the commandment of blotting out Amalek.
(I heard this from Rabbi Moshe Rotenberg who heard it from his mouth).
Source: B'Yishishim Chochmah (Jerusalem 5754), p. 36

*   **היינו כחולמים**
The holy Gaon of Tchechenov zt"l explained (Psalms 126:1): **היינו כחולמים** - "When the L-rd returns the captivity of Zion, we were like dreamers."
The truth is that this world is a passing world, "like a dream it will fly away," and a man should not worry about this world at all. However, right now, due to the multitude of sins, a person does not feel this, and this world seems to him to be the main thing.
But at the time when G-d returns the captivity of Zion, then we will see eye to eye that all the troubles of the exile were only like a dream.
Source: Devar Tzvi-Shabbat (Brooklyn 5769), p. 111

*   **אתה תקום תרחם ציון כי עת לחננה כי בא מועד**
*   **עת לחננה**
I heard—when I was a youth—from the honorable Rabbi, the Gaon Av Beis Din of Sochovola zt"l, in the name of the holy Gaon, our master Rabbi Avraham'le of Tchechenov zt"l, interpreting what is written: **אתה תקום תרחם ציון כי עת לחננה כי בא מועד** - "You will arise and have mercy on Zion; for it is time to favor her, for the appointed time has come" (Psalms 102:14).
Based on what our Sages said (Sanhedrin 98): "If they merit, I will hasten it; if they do not merit, in its time." It is explained from this that even if they do not merit, Heaven forbid, nevertheless the Redemption will be in its time and season.
This is what we advocate in our prayers before the Master of the Worlds, Blessed be He: that He should hasten to send our Righteous Messiah even before the time, even without "merit," Heaven forbid. For by this, the whole world will know that He is good and beneficent, merciful and gracious, even to those who are not worthy.
However, if He extracts the depth of judgment, Heaven forbid, to wait with our Redemption and the redemption of our souls until its precise time—because of the fact that it is in the category of "did not merit," Heaven forbid—then surely perforce He will come in His time. Then there will no longer be any recognition of the attribute of His goodness and His grace upon us.
And this is what is written: "You will arise and have mercy on Zion," meaning from the aspect that **עת לחננה** - "it is time to favor her" (now is the time to be gracious). To be called Merciful and Gracious, He must come quickly and the appointed time will arrive. Then perforce He will come.
Source: Yad Yosef (Jerusalem 5751), p. 57

Our Master, Rabbi Elazar Menachem Mendel of Lelov Zy"a, used to command people who came to him for matters of health, salvation, success, etc., to eat *Pas Shacharis* (morning bread) for forty days without interruption.
It is told that once, a man stopped eating *Pas Shacharis* a few days before finishing the forty days because he already felt well. Afterward, he returned to his weakness. The Rebbe Zy"a commanded him to start the forty days anew.
Source: Minhagei Nisuin Lelov

**Biography**
The holy Rabbi Mordechai Shlomo Friedman of Boyan-New York was the son of the holy Rabbi Yitzchak of Boyan. He was born in the year 5651 (1891) in Boyan and was the youngest of his sons. With the passing of his father in the year 5677 (1917), he filled his place together with his holy brothers in Vienna.
In the year 5687 (1927), he immigrated to the United States upon the recommendation of his brother, the Rabbi of Tchernowitz, and his uncle, the holy Rabbi Yisrael of Chortkov. He was a sublime holy man and Tzaddik who merited great appreciation among the greats of Torah and Chassidut. He was one of the heads of the Council of Torah Sages and its great leaders of Agudath Israel and outlined its path.
He was famous for his noble character traits, his humility, and his wisdom. He visited the Holy Land a number of times and initiated the establishment of the Ruzhin Yeshivas in Jerusalem and Bnei Brak, where Admorim of the House of Ruzhin joined him. He dedicated himself to strengthening and establishing them.
Despite his severe health weakness in the last years of his life, he did not cease to worry and act for the sake of the public, until his passing on the 5th of Adar 5731 (1971). He was brought to rest on the Mount of Olives in Jerusalem, opposite the place of the Temple. His place is filled by his grandson, the holy Admor of Boyan Shlita, who lives in Jerusalem.
Source: Abir HaMalchut (Jerusalem 5764), Vol. 1, p. 377

My grandfather zt"l was the youngest of the sons of his father, the holy [Pachad Yitzchak] of Boyan, a child of old age. His name was called Mordechai Shlomo, and in his childhood, they called him "Matinyu," meaning a gift.
This is because my grandmother, his mother the Rebbetzin, daughter of the holy Rabbi Yochanan of Rachmastrivka zy"a, acted through her request from her father that another son be born to her. And indeed, for the general public of Israel as well, my grandfather zt"l was a gift in this generation.
Source: Imrei Kodesh (Tishrei 5769), p. 17

Regarding the extraordinary diligence of the holy Admor [of Boyan] zy"a, it is told that already in his youth, close to his Bar Mitzvah, he would shut himself up for many consecutive hours in his room and engage in Torah with a diligence that amazed all those around him.
Until his mother, the righteous Rebbetzin Mrs. Malka a"h, became slightly alarmed in her concern that this was not in accordance with his physical strength. She entered her husband, the holy Admor the *Pachad Yitzchak* zy"a, and expressed her concern about his excessive diligence.
Maran zy"a answered her: "But I told you that he is a *Chiddush* (novelty/wonder)." [It is known that his father expressed at the time of his birth that he was a *Chiddush*, a matter understood among the greats of Chassidim that his intention was regarding his holy soul, which was in the category of a *Chiddush* in the world].
Also, throughout the coming years, they spoke much of his great diligence. It is told that when he was in the East Side in the USA, he would shutter the windows of the house and sit for hours upon hours consecutively engaging in Torah by the light of a candle. [The matter of shuttering the windows was once explained: that his holy desire was to learn Torah by the refined light of the candle and not by the coarse atmosphere of the USA].
It is also told that when he was in the Holy Land and spent the Sabbath in the city of Tel Aviv, after the Kabbalat Shabbat prayer, the Gabbaim announced that due to his weakness which attacked him, the Admor zy"a would not come out to conduct his pure Table (Tish) in the company of the many Chassidim who had come up specifically for the Sabbath to bask in the shadow of his holiness.
How surprised the Chassidim were that during all hours of the night until the wee hours of the holy Sabbath night, he sat in his holy room and engaged in Torah, and no sign of weakness was recognizable on him at all (from the mouth of HaGaon Rav Yechiel Michel Rabinowitz Shlita).
Regarding this matter, one of the attendants in the holy chamber told that in the evening of his days, the holy Admor zy"a groaned and said that while his strength was still with him, "We did not know what sleep was on the night of the holy Sabbath. How could I fall asleep sometimes while sitting by the Gemara."
Source: Marbeh Torah (Boyan), Shavuot 5766, p. 6

During one of the visits of the holy Admor (HaRah"k Rabbi Mordechai Shlomo) zy"a of Boyan to the Holy Land, when I entered for a private audience, he stood over his study session in a certain tractate.
"I am currently engaged in..." etc.
In his holy words to me, he elaborated with greatness and wonders regarding the order of study in depth (Iyun), that one needs to exert oneself with all powers to study with the depth of the brain and intellect, and that one should choose initially the difficult tractates that require much depth.
Source: Marbeh Chaim (Jerusalem 5766), Vol. 2, p. 243

*   **מורא רבך כמורא שמים**
My grandfather (the holy Admor of Tolna zt"l) once told me:
"I traveled in my youth to all the Tzaddikim of the generation in America. This was not strictly as a Chassid, but rather as a friend and relative to most of them. Once, I was for the holy Sabbath with the Tzaddik of Boyan zt"l. On Sunday, I hurried to catch the train leaving for my city. I came for a farewell blessing to the Rebbe of Boyan, and they told me that he was currently closed in his room studying with the Tefillin of Rabbeinu Tam, and he does not allow anyone to enter!
"I felt like a good enough friend and permitted myself to enter his room to tell him that I was in a hurry to travel, and I knew he would have aggravation if I didn't say goodbye to him or if I missed the train.
"When I opened the door and he lifted his holy eyes in wonder to see who was disturbing him against his will, I felt for the first time the meaning of the Gemara: **מורא רבך כמורא שמים** - 'The fear of your teacher is as the fear of Heaven.' I felt how, without a mask on his face, he casts terror and fear of G-d on all his surroundings.
"He zt"l, the moment he saw me, immediately changed his form and smiled with all his heart and parted with endless blessings, and he had no grievance. But for me, that second of opening the door was enough to truly feel what awe of his Master was, and I accepted him upon myself as my teacher and distinct Rebbe."
Source: Ki Chaim Hem L'Motzaehem (Jerusalem 5761), p. 98

I merited once to be called to the holy Admor [of Boyan] zy"a, while he was in the Holy Land, at the yearning hour close to the time of lighting the Sabbath candles.
When I arrived at his lodging according to his instruction, and I opened the door of his holy room, a vision fell upon my eyes of his pure majestic form radiating awe from the holiness of the Sabbath (and he was still dressed in a weekday hat). His entire being said: "Sabbath is approaching and coming."
Out of great fear, I was struck silent. I was not capable of continuing to enter his four cubits. Had he not lifted his pure eyes and signaled me to approach him, I would have fled out of great fear.
[In that chosen occasion, the holy Admor revealed a handbreadth of the holiness of the hour and said thus: "Also by my father the holy one (Admor HaRah"k Pachad Yitzchak zy"a), he permitted only individuals to enter him at this great hour close to Sabbath."]
Source: Kovetz Tiferet Yisrael, Tammuz 5765, p. 34

At the time of my Bris, the holy Admor of Boyan zy"a was staying in Jerusalem during that period and arrived to participate in the joy. My holy uncle (the Klausenburger Rebbe) zy"a honored him with the Sandeka'ut.
He did not want to accept, claiming that the holy uncle should serve as Sandek. But when the entreaties overcame him, he tried to excuse himself by claiming that he had not been to the Mikvah that day.
However, my holy uncle did not let go of him, saying that he does not need a Mikvah. And indeed, he was the Sandek.
Source: Milin Kadishin (Jerusalem 5766), Vol. 1, p. 148

I merited to see the service of the High Priest, the holy Admor zy"a [Rabbi Mordechai Shlomo of Boyan zy"a] at his pure tables. How with every tasting and sip of drink, they saw with their senses how "he is elevated and the world itself is elevated with him."
In supernal holiness, he ascended and was elevated, instilling elevation and ascent upon his surroundings. When we saw his holy service, we came to the understanding of what is in the words of the *Mesillat Yesharim* [Chapter 26, explaining the attribute of Holiness]: that the food of the Tzaddik is like a sacrifice, and it is as if it is sacrificed upon the altar literally, and he is brought close to them as if sacrificed upon the altar.
Truly they said that it was worth the trouble to swallow thousands of miles in order to see his holy service at the time of conducting the Tish. Even just to see him putting one spoon of soup into his holy mouth. There was in this such a great lesson that all the trouble was worth it for this alone. One spoon full of incense for a pleasant fragrance to Hashem.
Source: Marbeh Chaim (Jerusalem 5766), Vol. 1, p. 55

The conducting of his holy Table (of the holy Admor of Boyan zt"l) was like the table of Admorim in ancient years.
For is it not known that the Admorim of the House of Ruzhin are always secluded and separated from people? The time of fitness when they appear before the public is at the time of conducting the Table. At that time, *gibben zey zich op in gantzen* [they give themselves over completely] with the Chassidim to elevate them and raise them to themselves.
On the other hand, the Chassidim also want to receive at that time influences in full handfuls, in materiality and spirituality. They are connected then with all their mind and soul to the Rebbe. It is a matter of the upper one coming to the lower one, and the lower one elevating himself with all his strength to ascend to the upper one and to meet at least for a moment, to connect to the Rebbe, to be with him at one stage on the ladder set earthward whose head reaches the heavens, where he ascends degree after degree without limit.
In the preparation itself, one could discern how the Chassidim waited with longing eyes for the coming of the Rebbe, and their eyes were turned to the door from which the Rebbe would exit. Everyone grabbed a place for himself that would be close to the Rebbe.
And behold, the Rebbe enters. Then you feel *vi es kumt arein a Yid fun an ander velt in gantzen, in gantzen oisgeton mehavayos olam hazeh* [how a Jew enters from another world entirely, completely stripped of the existences of this world], only cleaving constantly to Hashem Yitbarach, and always living in the air of the Garden of Eden here in this world.
And where are you? Only the great love from the Rebbe to the Chassidim, and from the Chassidim to the Rebbe, and between the Chassidim to each other—only this strengthens one not to fall to the ground.
It can be said that one who did not see and hear the *Birkat HaNehenin* (Blessing on Enjoyment) from the Admor of Boyan never heard a blessing in his life. The Gemara that wonders about the tractate of Berachot, that one should go to a Sage to learn blessings, can be understood only if you were by the Admor of Boyan at the time of his blessing the *Birkat HaNehenin*. To see how the Rebbe blessed the *Birkat HaNehenin*, you would understand what the Tanna wanted, and how he reasoned and spoke.
And so too regarding *Birkat HaZimmun* (Invitation to Grace). All my days it was difficult for me regarding all the details of the laws in the chapter "Three who ate" (Berachot Chapter 7), and why all the discussions there are about the few words that "my masters, we want to bless (bentsch)" until "that we have eaten of His," which are spoken so much.
But after I heard the blessings of the Zimmun from the Rebbe, I already recognized the essence and quality of the holiness of the Zimmun, and the matters standing at the height of the world. And how within this is included all their consciousness and thanksgiving, the depths of their holy heart, and the gratitude to Hashem. Then one understands the majority of the importance of the blessing of Zimmun.
By the Rebbe, I heard the "Baruch" with all the interpretations, and especially I heard the "Atah Hashem" - what it is. And so too all the *Birkat HaNehenin*.
It is known that the holy words of the Admorim of the House of Ruzhin in general, and the Admorim of Boyan in particular, are intermingled and included from everything—revealed and hidden. Only one who is well versed in Gemara, Poskim, and books of Chassidut, and in addition to this has the sweetness of Torah and the life of the world planted within us and the great love absorbed in his heart—only he can reach the edge of understanding in their Torahs which come in extreme brevity, fine flour of fine flour, sifted with 13 sieves. But how great is the quality included in this, and how many sheets could be filled just to explain one Torah.
It is known that from the days of our Sages, they were accustomed to bless one another with the blessing of "L'Chaim" (To Life), as is brought in Tractate Shabbat. And the matter was renewed again in the days of the Baal Shem Tov, that the inner life was renewed for every Jew, until the coming of the Messiah.
And this was renewed principally by the Tzaddik blessing each and every one "L'Chaim" (To Life)—new life, inner life, Jewish life. *Tzu a nai lebn tzum lebn* [to a new life, to life] and he lives in them. "Remember us for life," *tzu zain lebedig* [to be alive/lively].
And it is known that one of the main matters in the conducting of the Rebbe's Table is the saying of "L'Chaim" to the Rebbe. Here you saw what a true "Blessing of L'Chaim" is. While with others the blessing of L'Chaim is in honor of the holy Sabbath, in honor of a holiday, in honor of a specific event, or in honor of a family joy—here you saw that the blessing of L'Chaim is a thing high above high. It touches generations of generations, sons and sons of sons. It touches their entire essence. *Demolt bet men far alles in der velt!* [Then one asks for everything in the world!]
And the seeing of the Tzaddik specifically to the requester, and how many times with the extending of his holy hand, one sees how the upper and lower literally met. The upper blesses the lower, and hands over to him unlimited powers.
It is known how it was among the Chassidim, the manner and matter of their adhesion (Devekut) of the Tzaddikim of the House of Ruzhin. Here you saw *an offen oisgegosener devekut* [an openly poured out adhesion] in all his 248 limbs, and it was revealed and visible to every man of understanding. The adhesion at the time of conducting the Table cast extra awe.
The "Yichus Niggun" which the Rebbe himself played on the night of the holy Sabbath—and with others at other times, and some say it is from the Great Maggid of Mezeritch—behold, the melody is essentially Holy of Holies. When the Rebbe played this melody, it was a melody full of taste and grace. Then he elevated all the Chassidim to a world that is all good, where there are only kindnesses and no judgments dwell there at all; to a world that is all song, above the intellect of his Torahs. It is not within his power to describe the feeling one feels at the hour the Rebbe plays...
At this Table of Chanukah in the year 5712 (1951), I was with several of my friends, and we were amazed and astonished to know if such a holy Table could exist at all in this world, or perhaps it is nothing but an imagination in the world? *Mir hobn nisht gevust oif vos a velt mir zainen* [We didn't know what world we were in]. On the way back to our home, when we entered the subway in the USA, we could not see where we were...
Source: Kovetz Tiferet Yisrael, Tevet 5761, p. 26

In those days of the Six Day War, we spoke many times by telephone with the Rebbe of Boyan. He asked that we report to him all the time on every piece of news arriving from Jerusalem or from Washington. We would call the Rebbetzin a"h, the attendant, or the children frequently to know if it was possible to speak with him. But before they could answer, he would already pick up the phone in his room and inquire and ask what the news was.
He asked to know what we were doing, with whom we spoke in Washington, what they were saying in the State Department, what the Senators were saying—and perhaps it is possible to do something more? He simply trembled from the very thought that perhaps we were not fulfilling our obligation, perhaps we were not doing enough...
From the heart of each of us, a heavy stone was rolled away in those days when the first news of the Jews' victories against their enemies began to arrive. But it is literally difficult to describe the great joy with which the Rebbe of Boyan received this good tiding. Even through the telephone instrument, it was possible to pick up how his weak heart beat from great joy. One could even see how his pale face lit up and shone.
And simultaneously, it was possible to feel his deep pain over the victims. "How do you think, are the Jews telling the truth about the number of victims, or perhaps they are hiding them?" he asked with sadness. But immediately he added: "Indeed, it is forbidden to ask this, for even one Jew is a great heartache."
Several times he repeated the words: "One Jew"—and we could sense how his heart was literally torn for every Jew, for every Jewish soul that was cut down to the magnitude of the sorrow.
Source: B'Shnei Einayim (Brooklyn 5748), p. 364

In Boyan, and also in the courts of his holy ancestors, it was not customary to honor his holy ancestors with honors at weddings and other joyous occasions, even at the joyous occasions of his offspring (although they were present sometimes at joyous occasions during the Chuppah, due to the holiness of the occasion as is known).
However, over the years, my grandfather, the holy Admor zy"a, agreed to be honored with blessings at weddings. When he noticed sometimes that other Admorim arrived, he would ask the owner of the joy to honor them, while leaving him alone.
Once, at one of the weddings, my grandfather the Admor zy"a noticed that one of the Admorim arrived. He too came to the Chuppah. He called our Rebbe to the owner of the joy and asked him to honor the aforementioned Admor with his honor.
After the Chuppah, the aforementioned Admor approached my grandfather zy"a and said to him with a sort of complaint: "Although regarding his own honor he could forgive, but how did he forgive the honor of his holy ancestors?"
My grandfather zy"a was silent and did not answer him a word. A slight smile arose on his holy face, which was understood by those around him as if to say: "I, with my holy ancestors, can already work it out. Lest they think, Heaven forbid, that my grandfather scorned the honor of his ancestors—on the contrary! In Boyan, everyone knew *az di greste Chassidim funem Tatten zenen geven di eigine kinder, di fir kinder* [that the greatest Chassidim of the Father were his own children, the four children] (who were his holy sons).
When my grandfather would speak of his father, he would always say "*Der Heiliger Tatte*" (The Holy Father). But, my grandfather zt"l knew well how to distinguish between imaginary honor and true honor.
Source: Kovetz Tiferet Yisrael, Shevat 5766, p. 20

In New York, there was a Jew who was a great man of kindness (Baal Chessed) for many years. At the time of his old age, he began to feel weakness and wanted to stop this activity.
But before he made a decision, he entered the Admor of Boyan and asked him if it was proper for him to do so, because his strength had weakened and he was no longer as he was yesterday and the day before.
The Admor answered him on the spot: "Heaven forbid! Not only should you not stop, but you should continue to engage in acts of kindness with greater vigor and greater strength."
The Admor of Boyan emphasized his answer to him with a story about one of the Tzaddikim who lived a very long life. When they asked him, "With what did you prolong your days?", he answered that in his youth he took upon himself that he would always enter from one Mitzvah into another. Even before he finished one Mitzvah, he would immediately begin another Mitzvah, so that he would have no interruptions between Mitzvah and Mitzvah.
Thanks to this, he has a ready answer for the Angel of Death. The moment he comes to him, he answers him: "Do I live for myself? Do I not live for the sake of the Mitzvah!..."
Source: Haggadat Reb Shalom (Jerusalem 5765), p. 32

In the days of our Master, the Holy Rabbi R' Elazar Mendel of Lelov Zy"a, the vision of multiplying titles for every Rabbi, more or less famous, was already widespread. As a sort of protest against this custom, his way was to nickname the Evil Inclination (*Yetzer Hara*) with the name "Rashkbahag" (Head of all the Children of the Diaspora), because he hunts and rules over the entire universe in his heart.
Source: Malchut Beit David

When he reached maturity, the Chassid Rabbi Yisrael Kuflivitz zt"l was taken as a groom for the daughter of the famous Chassid Rabbi Eli' Neigarten zt"l. Rabbi Eli', who was a Chassidic figure from previous generations, was among the first to frequent the home of the holy Admor [of Boyan] zt"l in New York.
Rabbi Eli' was a young man when Maran (the Admor of Boyan) zy"a arrived in New York. Immediately upon his arrival, Rabbi Eli' connected himself to him, and from then on did not move from the house of Maran zy"a. Rabbi Eli', who was considered one of the heads and important figures of the Chassidim in New York, found for himself a groom after his own heart: Rabbi Yisrael, a Chassidic young man and a scholar, considered the choice of the young men, who basked in the shadow of Maran zy"a in Torah.
A wondrous story in which the clarity of Maran (the Admor of Boyan) zy"a was seen occurred with Rabbi Eli' and his son-in-law Rabbi Yisrael.
One day, Rabbi Eli' entered the inner sanctum to Maran zy"a, who took an interest in the situation of Rabbi Eli'. Rabbi Eli' was then teaching schoolchildren, and Maran zy"a asked him what he was learning with the children. Rabbi Eli' answered that they were currently engaged in Tractate Kiddushin.
Maran zy"a asked: "Why is Tractate Gittin learned before Kiddushin?"
Rabbi Eli' waited, and Maran zy"a answered in the language of the commentators: "Because at the time of Kiddushin (betrothal), the one betrothing needs to see if the woman was already betrothed and divorced, if the Get (divorce bill) was done properly."
Rabbi Eli' went out wondering from the room of Maran zy"a: why did his holy words hint at this?
The next day, for the occasion of the Hillula (celebration), the Chassidim gathered for a Seudah of Mitzvah in the Kloiz. At the meal, his son-in-law, Rabbi Yisrael, related that last night he accompanied his teacher, HaGaon Rav Moshe Feinstein, on his way to arrange a Kiddushin. Before the Chuppah, it was suddenly revealed that the bride had been previously betrothed, and a question arose regarding the validity of the Get from her previous husband. The Get was brought before HaGaon Rav Moshe Feinstein, who invalidated it and ordered a new Get to be prepared.
"At what time did the incident occur?" asked Rabbi Eli' to his son-in-law Rabbi Yisrael.
When he answered, Rabbi Eli' answered with emotion that this was exactly the hour he was by Maran zy"a, and he spoke with him about exactly that topic!
Source: Kovetz Tiferet Yisrael, Tammuz 5765, p. 81

*   **מבשרי אחזה אלוה**
It is told of my grandfather zt"l, that once when he was on the way to the Land of Israel, and when he passed over the high mountains in the lands of Europe, the attendant sitting next to him said: "Let the Rebbe please look and see the wonders of the Creator."
My grandfather zt"l lifted his holy hand and answered and said: **מבשרי אחזה אלוה** - "From my flesh I shall see G-d" (Job 19:26).
Source: Imrei Kodesh (Tishrei 5769), p. 38

The Chassid Rabbi Noach Friznd, may he live, relates:
After his engagement, he traveled to Tel Aviv to visit his father and his father-in-law, Rabbi Amram Blau zt"l, at the "Kupat" [charity fund] to the holy Admor zy"a [of Boyan - New York, who was visiting the Land of Israel then]. He was hosted then in Tel Aviv by his brother-in-law, the holy Rabbi of Pshedborz-Tel Aviv zt"l.
And it was, when he arrived at his dwelling - on the 16th of Tevet 5718 (1958) - exactly at the hour that the Admor of Pshedborz-Tel Aviv zy"a, the "Abir Yaakov," left the room of our Rebbe zy"a. The holy Admor zy"a went out to escort him.
It is known how great the love and wondrous affection that prevailed between these two Tzaddikim was; it was unique in its kind. In the middle of the way, the Abir Yaakov zy"a stopped and said to our Rebbe zy"a: "*Genug*" [Enough].
But our Rebbe zy"a continued to escort him. Afterwards, he stopped again once and said: "Boyaner Rebbe, *Genug*." But our Rebbe zy"a continued to escort him until the Abir Yaakov zy"a stopped again and said to our Rebbe zy"a: "A person's will is his honor." Then our Rebbe zy"a stopped and did not continue to escort him, according to his holy will.
[And when they were by our Rebbe zy"a in his holy room, his father-in-law Rabbi Amram spoke before him about the worry of his heart regarding these days of marrying off the offspring, that the expenses are great and there is no money, etc.
Our Rebbe zy"a answered him and said to him: "Behold, it is brought that the salvation of G-d is like the blink of an eye. And how many blinks of an eye are there still until the wedding?"
Rabbi Amram would always tell that he saw with his senses how the holy words of the Admor of Boyan were fulfilled. For within a few days, a full bag of work was brought before him [he was an authorized appraiser, and a company brought him a bag with many items that needed appraisal], and from that bag, he married off his daughter.]
Source: Gilyon Kehal Adat Chassidei Boyan, Miketz 5767, p. 4

My grandfather, the holy Admor of Tolna zt"l, told about the holy Admor of Boyan zt"l, that he was in America in those days. At one of the celebrations, they served him ice cream for dessert. When he lingered a little, they told him that he needed to eat it quickly, otherwise it would melt.
The Rebbe pushed away the plate and said: "I will never taste from this food."
And to the wonder of those around him, he said: "From my youth, they taught me to eat everything with composure (Yishuv HaDaat) and slowness. A food item that is entirely speed is not a thing for me!"
Source: Ki Chaim Hem L'Motzaehem (Jerusalem 5761), p. 40

I heard a story about the custom of the holy Rabbi of Boyan zy"a, whose way in holiness was that after the Mussaf prayer of Shabbat, he would approach the groom and ask him: "Who are you?"
Once, someone asked him about this strange custom: "Does the Rebbe not know the grooms?"
The holy Rabbi of Boyan zy"a answered and said that he intended to inform the groom that he should know that after the prayer in which he was called up to the Torah, he is not the same groom he was before. Rather, now he has received a very sublime different form. Therefore, to illustrate the matter, he would ask the groom "Who are you?", as if he did not know him at all.
Source: Gilyon Kehal Adat Chassidei Boyan, Vayakhel 5760, p. 4

In the meetings of Agudath Israel, he [the holy Admor of Boyan zt"l] was more of a friend (Chaver) than a Rebbe, and specifically here it was possible to learn from him in a tangible way.
He, for whom hundreds of people listened with unusual awe and respect to every word coming out of his mouth, would himself sit and listen with Derech Eretz and attention to whatever the smallest of the small said. He would ask permission to speak from the chairman with submission, and then he would address everyone as "Chaver" (Friend).
"Yes, that Chaver, please forgive me that I forgot his name... he said... but it is difficult for me to agree with him. It seems to us that it is possible to say otherwise..."
And so, with Derech Eretz, he would refute, but he never said "Accept my opinion," even though his opinion, presumably, was the correct one. He did not even demand that they obey him immediately. On the contrary, he specifically wanted to hear... "How do you reason?"—he would ask and turn to the right and to the left, as if everyone was equal and as if everyone's opinion was equal to his.
Source: B'Shnei Einayim (Brooklyn 5748), p. 365

My grandfather, the C"K Maran Admor of Boyan zt"l, said by way of allegory: We find (Beitzah 16a) that Shabbat is called a "Good Gift" that the Holy One, Blessed be He, gave to Israel. And it is a "gift on condition to return." Meaning, through the Holy Shabbat, it is possible to return in Teshuva. He said this on Shabbat Shuva, and added that Shabbat is an acronym for 'Shabbat Bo Tashuv' (On Shabbat, you shall return [in repentance]), meaning that through the "Good Gift," it is possible to return in Teshuva.
Source: Betzila D'Mehemnuta, Bo 5765, p. 6

He was born on the night of the Holy Shabbat, 18 Adar II 5624 (1864), to his father, our teacher Rabbi David z"l, in the village of Tzelemanka near Holeschau in the state of Moravia. Before reaching the age of Mitzvot, he went into exile to a place of Torah, to the holy Gaon, the author of "Chatan Sofer," and did not move his hand from his hand. Afterwards, he was a student-colleague to his son and successor, the holy Gaon Rabbi Simcha Bunim Ehrenfeld. Upon reaching his maturity in the year 5648 (1888), he was taken with honor as a groom to the brother-in-law of his Rabbi, the Gaon Rabbi Shalom Dov Stern. In the year 5650 (1890), he was called to Vienna to assist the Mara D'Atra (local Rabbi), the Gaon Rabbi Zalman Spitzer, and to serve as Rosh Mesivta in the Beit Midrash of the "Shas Society" [where he delivered classes on Shas for over forty years]. Within a few years, his teachers crowned him with permission to serve as Head of the Beit Din for the Schiffschul communities. He was unique as an expert and distinguished in Halachic ruling, out of a trembling fear of holiness. Likewise, he accomplished great and mighty things for the sake of the general public and individuals, out of modesty, as his entire aim was to increase the Honor of Heaven.
Besides being a genius and Posek, he was known as a Tzaddik, a Foundation of the World. The Gaon Rabbi Yaakov Teitelbaum told that when our Rebbe (the Gaon Rabbi Meir Arik zt"l) arrived in Vienna, he walked with him in the street of the city. Suddenly, our Rebbe noticed the figure of the Dayan, Rav Yosef. His crystal-clear eyes picked up the expression of his face which testified to righteousness and holiness, even though he had not yet met him then and did not know who he was. He asked his student, the Gaon Rabbi Yaakov, about him: "Who is this - mit dem reinem lichtigen ponim (with the pure, luminous face)?" After his passing, parts of his Torah teachings were gathered and printed in the book 'Pardes Yosef' (newly published with many additions, Brooklyn 5763). It is relevant to mention the words of the Gaon Rav Shmuel Wosner zt"l in his approbation to the book: "I merit to testify that they were said in holiness and purity, fear and love, simple fear and charming humility that wrapped that Tzaddik and great man. To his credit, one can attribute all the spiritual ascents of my native city Vienna, which in his days, when the most famous geniuses of Israel were there, was a lodging for Torah. And I never saw such power of prayer, such pouring out of the soul with pure tears, as that Tzaddik had, pouring out his pure heart..." He passed away on the 6th of Adar, 5693 (1933), and was brought to rest near the tombstone of his Rabbi in Mattersdorf.
Source: HaMeir LaOlam (Antwerp 5767) p. 17

Before our Rebbe [the holy Admor of Boyan zt"l] traveled to the Land of Israel on one of the occasions, when one of the Anash (men of our community) living in the Holy Land entered him, our Rebbe clarified with him how it was possible to transfer money to the Land of Israel, for he did not want in any way to transfer money not according to the law.
And behold, in the middle of the words, the aforementioned Chassid heard about certain huge sums of money that he intended to distribute for the needs of the poor of the Land of Israel. He was amazed to hear this, especially knowing the poverty that prevailed in his house. He could not restrain himself and asked in amazement: "Did they not say 'He who spends should not spend more than a fifth'?"
Our Rebbe answered him: "The reason stated for this is so that he should not come to need [the help of] creatures. And since I am anyway in need of creatures [dependent on support], for me this is not applicable."
And even while he was in the Land of Israel, when much more money was gathered to him from the revenues, he distributed it all to charity.
One of the attendants who stood by the door while he was in Tel Aviv saw the revenues and those leaving our Rebbe's room zy"a, and knew that very large sums were piling up on his table. He was very amazed that when our Rebbe was about to return abroad, he called to the Anash in charge of the Gemach (Free Loan Fund) named after his brother, the holy Rabbi of Leipzig zy"a, and asked them for a loan of a thousand dollars so that he could travel back to the USA, because he did not have money for travel expenses with him.
He promised them that when he arrived there, he would send the money back to the Gemach. He was unable to understand this: that after such large sums passed through his hands, not even money for travel remained with him, because he distributed everything to charity!
Source: Gilyon Kehal Adat Chassidei Boyan, Vayakhel 5760, p. 4

It was a gem in the mouth of our Rebbe (the Gaon Rabbi Chaim Brim zt"l) to tell that when the C"K Maran Admor [the Holy Rabbi Mordechai Shlomo] zya visited from Boyan in the Holy Land in the year 5702 (1942) and stayed in the Holy City of Jerusalem for the holiday of Shavuot, Anash (men of our community) came up from all over the Holy Land to stay in his holy shadow for the holiday. On the eve of Shavuot, guests from outside Jerusalem entered to greet him, and among them were Chassidim from the city of Tel Aviv. After greeting him, they asked the Admor zya that on the Shabbat following Shavuot [Shabbat Nach Shavuot], he would accede to their request to travel and spend Shabbat in Tel Aviv. The Admor zya answered them with this phrase: "Yetzt fahrt men tzum barg Sinai" [Now we are traveling to Mount Sinai], and it is impossible to think about another journey right now [and indeed, after Shavuot, when they took leave with a Kvitel and asked again, he acceded to them and agreed].
Our Rebbe (the Gaon Rabbi Chaim Brim) zt"l further told that it is known that on the night of Shavuot, the Admor [of Boyan] zya would enter for Kiddush only at midnight [because he began counting Sefirat HaOmer on the second night of Pesach (abroad) after the Seder was conducted—and in order for there to be seven complete weeks until the Kiddush of Shavuot, he would enter for Kiddush only at midnight on the night of the Shavuot holiday, and the Chassidim had enough time to prepare properly]. Our Rebbe went to say Tikkun in one of the study halls in his neighborhood, and towards midnight, he got up to go towards the holy dwelling of the Admor zya to witness the conducting of the Pure Table (Tish). Before he left the synagogue, our Rebbe approached one of the greatest geniuses of Jerusalem who was sitting and learning then in the aforementioned Beit Midrash, and whispered in his ear that if he wishes to witness sights of the hosts, a sight that does not occur every day, he should come with him now. Indeed, the man responded, closed the Gemara, and came with him to hear the Kiddush of the Admor zya. Afterwards, the Gaon answered our Rebbe that it was indeed worth closing the Gemara to witness this holy sight.
The C"K Maran Admor Shlita of Boyan told that he heard from our Rebbe (the Gaon Rabbi Chaim Brim) zt"l that at the time the Admor zya recited Megillat Ruth on the holiday of Shavuot, he peeked through the crack in the door of his holy room and saw how tears flowed from the eyes of the Admor zya incessantly during the recitation of Megillat Ruth. The Admor Shlita added and noted the words of the Taz (Orach Chaim Siman 588) regarding crying on Shabbat, like Rabbi Akiva who cried during the recitation of Shir HaShirim because he knew how far the matters reached. The same applies to Megillat Ruth, in which the entire foundation of the Kingdom of the House of David is hinted. The Admor zya, who knew how far the matters reached to awaken the merit of David son of Yishai and the King Messiah, that he should come and redeem us speedily in our days, Amen, therefore his tears flowed without ceasing, end of his holy words.
In the year 5760 (2000), forty years later, our Rebbe (the Gaon Rabbi Chaim Brim zt"l) expressed to one of his acquaintances and said: "A person does not fully grasp the mind of his teacher until forty years" (see Avodah Zarah 5b), and now I have understood why his tears flowed, and it is based on the statement of the Gemara: **בכה רבי יש קונה עולמו בשעה אחת** - "Rabbi cried: There is one who acquires his world in one hour" (Avodah Zarah 10b). And Ruth the Moabite acquired her world, the entire Kingdom of the House of David, in one hour when she said: **עמך עמי ואלהיך אלהי** - "Your people shall be my people, and your G-d my G-d" (Ruth 1:16). In that one moment, she acquired her entire world. And for this, [my Rebbe] the Admor zya cried during the recitation of Megillat Ruth: How great is the value of one moment!
Source: Marbeh Chaim (Jerusalem 5764) p. 75

עוֹד סִפֵּר רַבֵּינוּ (הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי חַיִּים בְּרִים) זצוק"ל כַּיָּדוּעַ שֶׁבְּלֵיל שָׁבוּעוֹת הָיָה אַדְמוֹ"ר [מִבָּאיָאן] זִי"עַ נִכְנָס לְקִדּוּשׁ רַק בַּחֲצוֹת לַיְלָה [מִשּׁוּם שֶׁהִתְחִיל לִסְפֹּר סְפִירַת הָעוֹמֶר בְּלֵיל שֵׁנִי שֶׁל פֶּסַח (בְּחוּ"ל) אַחַר עֲרִיכַת הַסֵּדֶר - וּכְדֵי שֶׁיִּהְיוּ שֶׁבַע שַׁבָּתוֹת תְּמִימוֹת עַד קִדּוּשׁ שֶׁל שָׁבוּעוֹת הָיָה נִכְנָס לְקִדּוּשׁ רַק בַּחֲצוֹת לֵיל חַג הַשָּׁבוּעוֹת, וְהָיָה סִפֵּק בִּידֵי הַחֲסִידִים לְהִתְכּוֹנֵן כָּרָאוּי]. רַבֵּינוּ הָלַךְ לוֹמַר תִּקּוּן בְּאֶחָד מִבָּתֵּי הַמִּדְרָשִׁים בִּשְׁכוּנָתוֹ, וְלִקְרַאת חֲצוֹת לֵיל קָם לֵילֵךְ לְעֵבֶר מְעוֹן קָדְשׁוֹ שֶׁל אַדְמוֹ"ר זִי"עַ לַחֲזוֹת בַּעֲרִיכַת הַשֻּׁלְחָן הַטָּ', וְלִפְנֵי שֶׁיָּצָא מִבֵּית הַכְּנֶסֶת נִגַּשׁ רַבֵּינוּ לְאֶחָד מִגְּדוֹלֵי גְּאוֹנֵי יְרוּשָׁלַיִם שֶׁיָּשַׁב וְלָמַד אָז בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ הַנַּ"ל וְלָחַשׁ עַל אָזְנוֹ שֶׁאִם יֵשׁ אֶת נַפְשׁוֹ לַחֲזוֹת בְּמַרְאוֹת הַצּוֹבְאוֹת מַחֲזֶה שֶׁלֹּא בְּכָל יוֹם מִזְדַּמֵּן כְּמוֹהוּ, יָבוֹא אִתּוֹ כָּעֵת, וְאָכֵן הַלָּה נַעֲנָה וְסָגַר אֶת הַגְּמָרָא וּבָא אִתּוֹ לִשְׁמֹעַ אֶת הַקִּדּוּשׁ שֶׁל אַדְמוֹ"ר זִי"עַ, אַחַר כָּךְ נַעֲנָה הַגָּאוֹן לְרַבֵּינוּ שֶׁאָכֵן הָיָה כְּדַאי לִסְגֹּר אֶת הַגְּמָרָא כְּדֵי לַחֲזוֹת בְּמַרְאֵה קוֹדֶשׁ זֶה.
סִפֵּר כ"ק מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר שְׁלִיטָ"א מִבָּאיָאן שֶׁשָּׁמַע מֵרַבֵּינוּ (הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי חַיִּים בְּרִים) זצוק"ל שֶׁבְּשָׁעָה שֶׁאַדְמוֹ"ר זִי"עַ אָמַר מְגִלַּת רוּת בְּחַג הַשָּׁבוּעוֹת, הֵצִיץ דֶּרֶךְ חֶרֶךְ בְּדֶלֶת חַדְרוֹ הַקָּ' וְרָאָה אֵיךְ שֶׁמֵּעֵינֵי אַדְמוֹ"ר זִי"עַ זוֹלְגוֹת דְּמָעוֹת לְלֹא הֶרֶף בְּשַׁעַת אֲמִירַת מְגִלַּת רוּת, וְהוֹסִיף אַדְ"שׁ וְצִיֵּן לְדִבְרֵי הַטַּ"ז אוֹרַח חַיִּים סִי' רפח בְּעִנְיַן בְּכִיָּה בְּשַׁבָּת, כְּרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא שֶׁבָּכָה בְּעֵת אֲמִירַת שִׁיר הַשִּׁירִים מִפְּנֵי שֶׁיָּדַע עַד הֵיכָן הַדְּבָרִים מַגִּיעִים, וְהוּא הַדִּין בִּמְגִלַּת רוּת בָּהּ מְרֻמָּז כָּל יְסוֹד מַלְכוּת בֵּית דָּוִד, וְאַדְמוֹ"ר זִי"עַ שֶׁיָּדַע עַד הֵיכָן הַדְּבָרִים מַגִּיעִים לְעוֹרֵר זְכוּת דָּוִד בֶּן יִשַׁי וּמַלְכָּא מְשִׁיחָא שֶׁיָּבוֹא וְיִגְאָלֵנוּ בִּמְהֵרָה בְּיָמֵינוּ אָמֵן, עַל כֵּן זָלְגוּ עֵינָיו דְּמָעוֹת לְלֹא הֲפוּגוֹת, עכתד"ק.
בִּשְׁנַת תש"ס אַרְבָּעִים שָׁנָה לְאַחַר מִכֵּן, הִתְבַּטֵּא רַבֵּינוּ (הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי חַיִּים בְּרִים זַצַ"ל) לְאֶחָד מִמְיֻדָּעָיו וְאָמַר, אֵין אָדָם עוֹמֵד עַל דַּעַת רַבּוֹ עַד אַרְבָּעִים שָׁנָה (רְאֵה ע"ז ה:) וְעַתָּה הֵבַנְתִּי עַל מָה זָלְגוּ עֵינָיו דְּמָעוֹת, וְהוּא עַל פִּי מַאֲמַר הַגְּמָרָא (ע"ז י:) בָּכָה רַבִּי יֵשׁ קוֹנֶה עוֹלָמוֹ בְּשָׁעָה אַחַת, וְרוּת הַמּוֹאֲבִיָּה קָנְתָה אֶת עוֹלָמָהּ אֶת כָּל מַלְכוּת בֵּית דָּוִד בְּשָׁעָה אַחַת כְּשֶׁאָמְרָה "עַמֵּךְ עַמִּי וֵאלֹהַיִךְ אֱלֹהָי" בְּרֶגַע אֶחָד זֶה קָנְתָה אֶת כָּל עוֹלָמָהּ, וְעַל זֶה בָּכָה [רַבִּי] אַדְמוֹ"ר זִי"עַ בַּאֲמִירַת מְגִלַּת רוּת, מַה רַב עֶרְכּוֹ שֶׁל רֶגַע אֶחָד!"מַרְבֶּה חַיִּים" (יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשס"ד) עַמּוּד ע"ה

[The C"K Maran Admor of Boyan zt"l] said to a group in the Ruzhin Yeshiva in Jerusalem: "Sadness? We do not speak of that, for among Chassidim, this is forbidden even a little bit. But to be in [uncontrolled] joy is also forbidden. For one can distinguish how 'Da'at' (knowledge/mind) is connected to joy: When a baby is born, he immediately cries. When he grows a little and receives Da'at, he begins to laugh."
Source: Kovetz Tiferet Yisrael, Tammuz 5769, p. 10

[The description of the visit of our Holy Rebbe (C"K Maran Admor of Boyan zt"l, during his visit to the Holy Land in the year 5713/1953) to the home of the "Chazon Ish," I heard from the mouth of his household member, Rav David Frankel z"l, who was present during the visit. Also present during the visit was the Chassid Rav Mordechai Horinstein z"l.]
While our Holy Rebbe was in Tel Aviv, he traveled one day to Bnei Brak and visited the home of the "Chazon Ish." Upon our Holy Rebbe's arrival at the home of the "Chazon Ish," Rav David Frankel z"l, a member of the Chazon Ish's household, entered to inform him that our Holy Rebbe had arrived to visit him. The "Chazon Ish" was sitting by the window as was his custom, and immediately approached his table and ordered the table to be set and the books lying on it to be taken down. He went out to receive the face of our Holy Rebbe. After greeting each other, our Holy Rebbe spoke about visiting that day the pure Mikvah that had been inaugurated at that time on Bar Kochba Street in Tel Aviv, which was made with great splendor and the utmost Kashrut and beauty, and for which the "Chazon Ish" had worked greatly to establish. Our Holy Rebbe added humorously: "For this Mikvah does not fall short in the level of beauty and splendor from the Mikvaot in America." The "Chazon Ish" expressed his satisfaction with our Holy Rebbe's impression.
In the midst of this, our Holy Rebbe and the "Chazon Ish" opened a lengthy Halachic discussion, which lasted twenty minutes, regarding the laws of Mikvaot, drawn water, and the laws dependent on them. Rav David Frankel added to describe that the close associates of the "Chazon Ish" understood and saw that the "Chazon Ish" was in excessive excitement; when he checked his pulse, it was boiling and throbbing from great excitement. Indeed, while our Holy Rebbe and the "Chazon Ish" spoke in the laws of Mikvaot, he spoke with boiling fervor all that time, and they recognized upon the "Chazon Ish" the magnitude of his excitement and enthusiasm.
When our Holy Rebbe left, the "Chazon Ish" escorted him to the car parked across the road, and the face of the "Chazon Ish" expressed admiration for the majesty of our Holy Rebbe. When the "Chazon Ish" returned to his home, Rav David Frankel asked him: "Since a short time ago, a great and very famous man visited the 'Chazon Ish,' is the Rebbe of Boyan also on that level?" The "Chazon Ish" reacted and answered in praise of our Holy Rebbe: "Ay, ay, surely the Rebbe of Boyan is a 'Yesod ShebeYesod' (A Foundation within a Foundation)." The Chazon Ish expressed to his close associates that it would have been proper to return the visit to the Rebbe of Boyan, who is great in Torah, but since a short time ago a certain "great one" visited here, and I did not return a visit to him due to my weakness at that time, and this matter could be interpreted as an insult to his honor, therefore he refrained now as well from returning a reciprocal visit to the Rebbe of Boyan.
Upon entering the car, our Holy Rebbe expressed to the Chassidim the magnitude of his admiration for the "Chazon Ish," saying that the grace of Torah rests upon him (from the mouth of the Chassid Rav Yonah Zeller z"l who was present then in the car).
After our Holy Rebbe's visit, the "Chazon Ish" sent, via the Gaon Rav Chaim Yaakov Goldvicht z"l (one of the Chassidim of Anash and close to the Chazon Ish), his book "Chazon Ish" on the laws of Mikvaot as a gift to our Holy Rebbe. In the dedication on the book, the "Chazon Ish" wrote "In honor of the Hadrat Geono Shlita"; this title was one the "Chazon Ish" wrote only for unique individuals among the Torah giants of his generation.
(I heard from the Gaon Rav Chaim Yaakov Goldvicht z"l that our Holy Rebbe expressed before the heads of the Chassidim that he wished to see the Chazon Ish. And he [Rav Goldvicht] suggested to the "Chazon Ish" our Holy Rebbe's desire to visit him).
Source: Kovetz Tiferet Yisrael, Tishrei 5767, p. 70
