בִּשְׁהוּת רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' בְּתֵל אָבִיב, נָסַע בְּאֶחָד הַיָּמִים לִבְנֵי בְּרַק וּבִקֵּר בְּבֵית הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ", בְּהַגִּיעַ רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' לְבֵית הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ", נִכְנַס הָרַב דָּוִד פְרַנְקְל זַ"ל אִישׁ בֵּיתוֹ שֶׁל הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ", לְהוֹדִיעוֹ כִּי רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' הִגִּיעַ לְבַקְּרוֹ. הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" יָשַׁב כְּמִנְהָגוֹ עַל יַד הַחַלּוֹן וּמִיָּד נִגַּשׁ לְשֻׁלְחָנוֹ וְצִוָּה לַעֲרֹךְ אֶת הַשֻּׁלְחָן וּלְהוֹרִיד אֶת הַסְּפָרִים הַמּוּנָחִים עָלָיו, וְיָצָא לְקַבֵּל אֶת פְּנֵי רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ'. לְאַחַר קַבָּלַת שָׁלוֹם שָׂח רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' שֶׁבִּקֵּר בְּאוֹתוֹ יוֹם בַּמִּקְוֶה הַטָּהֳרָה שֶׁנֶּחְנְכָה בְּאוֹתָהּ הָעֵת בִּרְחוֹב בַּר כּוֹכְבָא בְּתֵל אָבִיב, שֶׁנַּעֲשָׂה בְּרֹב פְּאֵר וְתַכְלִית הַכַּשְׁרוּת וְהַהִדּוּר וַאֲשֶׁר הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" פָּעַל רַבּוֹת בַּהֲקָמַת אוֹתָהּ הַמִּקְוֶה. רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' הוֹסִיף בְּצַחוּת: כִּי מִקְוֶה זוֹ לֹא נוֹפֶלֶת בְּרָמַת הַיֹּפִי וְהַפְּאֵר מֵהַמִּקְוָאוֹת שֶׁבְּאָמֵרִיקָה. הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" הִבִּיעַ אֶת קוֹרַת רוּחוֹ מֵהִתְרַשְּׁמוּת רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ'.
בְּתוֹךְ כָּךְ פָּתְחוּ רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' וְהַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" בְּדִיּוּן הִלְכָתִי אָרֹךְ, שֶׁנִּמְשַׁךְ עֶשְׂרִים דַּקּוֹת בְּהִלְכוֹת מִקְוָאוֹת וּמַיִם שְׁאוּבִים וְהַדִּינִים הַתְּלוּיִים בָּהֶם. הָרַב דָּוִד פְרַנְקְל הוֹסִיף לְתָאֵר, כִּי מְקֹרְבֵי הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" הֵבִינוּ וְרָאוּ עֵת הָיָה הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" בְּהִתְרַגְּשׁוּת יְתֵירָה, כַּאֲשֶׁר הַגִּיד עַל יְדֵי אָזְנוֹ הָיָה רוֹתֵחַ וְרוֹתֵת מֵרֹב הִתְרַגְּשׁוּת. אָכֵן עֵת נִדְבְּרוּ רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' וְהַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" בְּהִלְכוֹת מִקְוָאוֹת, רָתַח וְרָתַת הַגִּיד כָּל אוֹתוֹ הַזְּמַן וְהִכִּירוּ עַל הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" אֶת רֹב הִתְרַגְּשׁוּתוֹ וְהִתְפַּעֲלוּתוֹ.
כַּאֲשֶׁר יָצָא רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' לִוָּה אוֹתוֹ הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" עַד הַמְּכוֹנִית שֶׁחָנְתָה מֵעֵבֶר לַכְּבִישׁ, וּפְנֵי הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" הִבִּיעוּ הִתְפַּעֲלוּת מֵהוֹד רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ', כְּשֶׁחָזַר הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" לְבֵיתוֹ, שָׁאַל אוֹתוֹ הָרַב דָּוִד פְרַנְקְל, כִּי לִפְנֵי זְמַן מָה בִּקֵּר אֵצֶל הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" אָדָם גָּדוֹל וּמְפֻרְסָם מְאֹד, הַאִם גַּם הָרַבִּי מִבָּאיָאן בְּאוֹתָהּ דַּרְגָּה, הֵגִיב הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" וְנַעֲנָה בְּהַפְלָגַת רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ': אַי, אַי, הֲלֹא הָרַבִּי מִבָּאיָאן הוּא "יְסוֹד שֶׁבִּיסוֹד". הַחֲזוֹ"א הִתְבַּטֵּא לִפְנֵי מְקֹרְבָיו, כִּי הָיָה מִן הָרָאוּי לְהַחֲזִיר בִּקּוּר לָרַבִּי מִבָּאיָאן הַגָּדוֹל בַּתּוֹרָה, אֶלָּא הֱיוֹת וְלִפְנֵי זְמַן לֹא רַב בִּקֵּר כָּאן גָּדוֹל אֶחָד, וְלֹא הֶחֱזַרְתִּי לוֹ בִּקּוּר עֵקֶב חֻלְשָׁתִי בָּעֵת הַהִיא, וְיוּכַל הַדָּבָר לְהִתְפָּרֵשׁ כִּפְגִיעָה בִּכְבוֹדוֹ, לָכֵן נִמְנַע הוּא גַּם עַכְשָׁיו לְהַחֲזִיר בִּקּוּר גּוֹמְלִין לָרַבִּי מִבָּאיָאן.
בְּהִכָּנֵס רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' אֶל הַמְּכוֹנִית בִּטֵּא לִפְנֵי הַחֲסִידִים אֶת גֹּדֶל הִתְפַּעֲלוּתוֹ מֵהַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" בְּאָמְרוֹ, כִּי חֵן הַתּוֹרָה שׁוֹרָה עָלָיו (מִפִּי הרה"ח מו"ה יוֹנָה צֶלֶר זַ"ל שֶׁנּוֹכַח אָז בַּמְּכוֹנִית).
אַחַר בִּקּוּר רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' שָׁלַח הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" בִּידֵי הרה"ג רַבִּי חַיִּים יַעֲקֹב גוֹלְדְוִויכְט זַ"ל מֵחֲסִידֵי אַנַ"שׁ וּמִמְקֹרְבֵי הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ", אֶת סִפְרוֹ "חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" עַל הִלְ' מִקְוָאוֹת, כִּתְשׁוּרָה לְרַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ'. בַּהַקְדָּשָׁה עַל הַסֵּפֶר כָּתַב הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" לִכְבוֹד הַדְרַת גְּאוֹנוֹ שְׁלִיטָ"א, תֹּאַר זֶה הָיָה כּוֹתֵב הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ" רַק לִיחִידֵי סְגֻלָּה מִגְּדוֹלֵי הַתּוֹרָה בְּדוֹרוֹ.(שָׁמַעְתִּי מִפִּי הרה"ג רַבִּי חַיִּים יַעֲקֹב גוֹלְדְוִויכְט זַ"ל, כִּי רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' הִבִּיעַ לִפְנֵי רָאשֵׁי הַחֲסִידִים, כִּי רוֹצֶה הוּא לְהִתְרָאוֹת עִם הַחֲזוֹ"א. וְהוּא הֵצִיעַ לִפְנֵי הַ"חֲזוֹן אִישׁ", אֶת רְצוֹן רַבֵּינוּ הַקָּ' לְבַקְּרוֹ).הרה"ח ר' דֹּב בֶּער רַבִּינוֹבִיץ שְׁלִיטָ"א מַשְׁבָּ"ק כ"ק מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר מִבָּאיָאן שְׁלִיטָ"א"קוֹבֵץ תִּפְאֶרֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל", תִּשְׁרֵי תשס"ז, עַמּוּד 70
body_en:
I remember when the C"K Maran Admor [Rabbi Mordechai Shlomo] zya of Boyan was in the Holy Land, he was attacked by terrible pains, G-d forbid, which caused him to be unable to sleep or rest. For entire nights, they saw him walking around his room with a Gemara in his hand. Due to his extraordinary caution regarding the pain of others and disturbing them, he feared lest the members of the household wake up from his walking back and forth. He removed his shoes and thus walked around his holy room in socks alone. They checked after him and found that over the course of several nights, he went through several tractates from cover to cover. Even while wrapped in terrible suffering, he found no cure for his pains except through the toil of Torah.
Source: Marbeh Chaim (Jerusalem 5766) Part 1, p. 201

After [the C"K Maran Admor of Boyan zt"l] was discharged from the hospital following a severe attack where he was in danger, he asked one of his close associates to bring Tractate Yoma. He recited by heart the entire lengthy Tosafot on page 34b, beginning with the words "Hanei Mili B'Issura D'Oraita," and asked him to check inside if he had forgotten anything, for he feared his memory might have weakened due to the illness. He repeated all the words of the Tosafot, but in the middle, he skipped one proof brought in the Tosafot. The aforementioned relative did not want to trouble him and ignored it. However, upon finishing the Tosafot, our Rebbe said to him: "I believe I forgot the aforementioned proof... It is told that a certain Torah scholar once recited the Maharit Algazi on Bechorot by heart..."
Source: Gilyon "Kahal Adat Chassidei Boyan", Mishpatim 5758, p. 3

When the C"K Maran Admor [of Boyan] zya returned from one of his visits to the Holy Land, he said to the C"K Admor of Skver zt"l: "Dem Tatten's Yidden [The Father's Jews/Chassidim] are very loyal. They bring 'Dem Tatten's A Kind' [The Father's child/son] so close." And it was a wonder, the level of his humility (see Kovetz Torat Chesed 25, Iyar 5755 New York, page 38, note 3, in the name of the C"K Admor of Rachmastrivka-Boro Park Shlita).
Source: Kovetz Tiferet Yisrael, Shevat 5766, p. 20

...My grandfather, the C"K Admor of Tolna zt"l, left the city of Arad (on the 15th of Tammuz 5753) straight for Jerusalem, the Holy City, to the Mount of Olives. He troubled himself to travel first thing to the grave of the holy "Ohr HaChaim" in honor of his Hillula (Yahrzeit). He said that he heard from the Rebbe zt"l of Boyan that if there is no screen separating the sight of the eye, it is considered as if one is literally in the place one sees. The Rebbe of Boyan used this regarding his ascent to a grave, as he did not want to enter the cemetery, but wanted to be at the grave of a Tzaddik. He traveled until he was close to the place and looked towards the grave until he narrowed his vision and saw the grave, and that sufficed for him. "So," said my grandfather, the C"K Admor of Tolna zt"l, "I do after I saw a great deed. And we gain by this that we do not enter the cemetery and require a Mikvah before and after, and at my age, the matter is not easy."
Source: Tanchumecha Yeshashu Nafshi (Jerusalem 5764) p. 665

In his final year, [the C"K Maran Admor of Boyan zt"l] said to me: "Az s'kumt on a zach a shtarke teshuka - darf men zich aynhalten" [When a very strong desire for something comes upon a person, one must restrain oneself].
Source: Kovetz Tiferet Yisrael, Tammuz 5769, p. 10

body_he: מִלְּבַד הֱיוֹתוֹ גָּאוֹן וּפוֹסֵק, נוֹדַע כְּצַדִּיק יְסוֹד עוֹלָם. הג"ר יַעֲקֹב טַיְיטֶלְבּוֹים, סִפֵּר כִּי בְּהַגִּיעַ רַבֵּינוּ (הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי מֵאִיר אָרִיק זַצַ"ל) לְוִינָא, הָלַךְ עִמּוֹ בִּרְחוֹבָהּ שֶׁל עִיר, לְפֶתַע הִבְחִין רַבֵּינוּ בִּדְמוּתוֹ שֶׁל הַדַּיָּן ר' יוֹסֵף, וּבְעֵינֵי הַבְּדֹלַח שֶׁלּוֹ קָלַט אֶת הַכָּרַת פָּנָיו שֶׁעָנְתָה צִדְקוּת וּקְדֻשָּׁה, לַמְרוֹת שֶׁטֶּרֶם הִכִּירוֹ אָז, וְלֹא יָדַע מִי הוּא. וְשָׁאַל אֶת תַּלְמִידוֹ הג"ר יַעֲקֹב אוֹדוֹתָיו: "מִי הוּא זֶה - מִיט דֶּעם רַיינֶעם לִיכְטִיגֶען פָּנִים". לְאַחַר פְּטִירָתוֹ נִתְקַבְּצוּ חֵלֶק מִדִּבְרֵי תּוֹרָתוֹ וְנִדְפְּסוּ בְּסֵפֶר 'פַּרְדֵּס יוֹסֵף' (הַנִּדְמָ"ח בְּתוֹסֶפֶת מְרֻבָּה, בְּרוּקְלִין תשס"ג), מִן הָעִנְיָן לְצַיֵּן אֶת דִּבְרֵי הַגָּאוֹן ר' שְׁמוּאֵל וָואזְנֶר זַצַ"ל בְּהַסְכָּמָתוֹ לַסֵּפֶר: "וְזוֹכֶה אֲנִי לְהָעִיד כִּי נֶאֶמְרוּ בִּקְדֻשָּׁה וְטָהֳרָה דְּחִילָא וּרְחִימָא, יִרְאָה פְּשׁוּטָה וַעֲנוּת חֵן שֶׁהָיוּ עוֹטְפִים אוֹתוֹ צַדִּיק וְגַבְרָא רַבָּא, אֲשֶׁר לִזְכוּתוֹ יֵשׁ לִזְקֹף כָּל הָעֲלִיּוֹת הָרוּחָנִיּוֹת שֶׁל עִיר מוֹלַדְתִּי וִינָא, אֲשֶׁר בְּיָמָיו שֶׁהָיוּ בִּימֵי גְּאוֹנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל הֲכִי מְפֻרְסָמִים הָיְתָה אַכְסַנְיָה שֶׁל תּוֹרָה. וּמֵעוֹלָם לֹא רָאִיתִי אוֹתוֹ כֹּחַ הַתְּפִלָּה, אוֹתוֹ הִשְׁתַּפְּכוּת הַנֶּפֶשׁ בְּאוֹתָם דְּמָעוֹת טְהוֹרוֹת, שֶׁהָיָה אוֹתוֹ צַדִּיק שׁוֹפֵךְ מִקִּירוֹת לֵב הַטָּהוֹר...". נלב"ע בְּיוֹם ו' אֲדָר שְׁנַת תרצ"ג לִפְרָט קָטָן, וְהוּבַל לִמְנוּחוֹת בְּסָמוּךְ לְמַצֶּבֶת רַבּוֹ בְּמַאטֶרְסְדָארְף."הַמֵּאִיר לָעוֹלָם" (אַנְטְוֶורְפֶּען תשס"ז) עַמּוּד י"ז
body_en:
The Chassid Rav Beril Weiss told me that he heard from his father, the Chassid Rav Shlomo a.h., who heard from the Gaon Rav Yosef Baumgarten zt"l, who said: "Ich hab mich gevikt unter'n Tallit funem Chatan Sofer" (I rocked myself/was wrapped under the Tallit of the Chatan Sofer) [meaning: I took shelter in the shadow of the Chatan Sofer's Tallit].
The aforementioned also told me that he heard from his father z"l: Once they told the Holy Rabbi, the Maharid of Belz zt"l, about a breach in the city of Vienna. The Holy Rabbi said: "Reb Yossele (referring to the Gaon Rav Yosef Baumgarten), veist dervun (knows about it), iz yadi mesuleket (so my hand is removed/I don't need to intervene)."
Source: Siach Zekenim (Brooklyn 5772) Part 8, p. 345

"Greater is the one who causes others to do than the doer" (Bava Batra 9a). It is brought from the Holy Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik of Zidichov zya that he asked about the double language "Gadol" (Great) the one who causes others to do "Yoter" (More) than the doer. Seemingly, the double language is superfluous, and it should have said "Greater is the one who causes others to do than the doer" and nothing more. Rather, the Holy Rabbi of Zidichov zya explained: "Gadol HaMa'aseh" - meaning, the one who causes others to give charity is great. "Yoter Min HaOseh" - the meaning of "Yoter" (more) is that he is great specifically when he is *also* "Min HaOseh" (from the doer) - when the one who causes and warns others to give charity is himself also a doer, meaning he also gives charity from his own. Then his value and reward are very great.
And so they tell of my grandfather zt"l, that when people would enter him to ask him to influence certain people to donate to a specific charitable need, he would first take out a sum of money from his own funds and give it to the requesters. And when they asked him: "We did not come to our Rebbe to ask him to give from his own money, but rather to influence so-and-so to give," he would answer: "In order for me to be able to influence others to give, I must first give myself, and then I will be able to influence them to give as well."
Source: Sichat Kodesh - Or l'16 Adar 5758 - New York

body_he: וְכֵן מְסַפְּרִים עַל זְקִינִי זַצַ"ל שֶׁכַּאֲשֶׁר הָיוּ נִכְנָסִים אֵלָיו לְבַקְּשׁוֹ שֶׁיַּשְׁפִּיעַ עַל אֲנָשִׁים מְסֻיָּמִים שֶׁיִּתְרְמוּ לְאֵיזֶה צֹרֶךְ צְדָקָה מְסֻיֶּמֶת, אֲזַי הָיָה מִקּוֹדֶם מוֹצִיא סְכוּם כֶּסֶף מִמָּמוֹנוֹ וְנָתַן לַמְבַקְּשִׁים. וְכַאֲשֶׁר הָיוּ שׁוֹאֲלִים אוֹתוֹ הֲרֵי לֹא לְזֶה בָּאנוּ אֶל רַבֵּינוּ לְבַקְּשׁוֹ שֶׁיִּתֵּן מִמָּמוֹנוֹ אֶלָּא כְּדֵי שֶׁיַּשְׁפִּיעַ עַל פְּלוֹנִי לָתֵת. הָיָה עוֹנֶה, כִּי כְּדֵי שֶׁאוּכַל לְהַשְׁפִּיעַ עַל אֲחֵרִים שֶׁיִּתְּנוּ צְדָקָה מֻכְרָח אֲנִי מִקּוֹדֶם בְּעַצְמִי לָתֵת וַאֲזַי אוּכַל לְהַשְׁפִּיעַ גַּם עֲלֵיהֶם שֶׁיִּתְּנוּ.כ"ק מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר מִבָּאיָאן שְׁלִיטָ"אבְּשִׂיחַת קָדְשׁוֹ - אוֹר לְט"ז אֲדָר תשנ"ח - נְיוּ יָארְק
body_en:
The C"K Maran Admor Rabbi Mordechai Shlomo of Boyan zt"l said in one of his talks regarding the importance of Yeshivot today: "In the past, they did not need this, and even though there were those who murmured that in places where there were no Yeshivot they could not learn, the truth slaps them in the face. For from the Kloiz'n (small study halls) and Batei Midrashot came forth Torah giants and famous Poskim, more than from the countries where there were Yeshivot. They were faithful proof that to know how to learn, there is no need to integrate into an organized Yeshiva framework. However, today, with the weakening of the pillars of Torah and fear of Heaven, not only for study do we need the framework of Yeshivot, but even for the instilling and strengthening of Chassidut, we need this."
Source: Yisrael B'Tifarto (Jerusalem 5763) p. 61

In the Blessing of the New Month, we say: "A life of wealth and honor." It is difficult: how do we pray and ask for honor, which is a despicable trait, and Chazal spoke extensively in its negation? And why do we not ask for wealth alone and honor alone, but "a life of wealth and honor"? One can say that the Holy One, Blessed be He, tested the Patriarchs with trials as is known. He tested Avraham our Father with wealth, Yitzchak our Father with suffering, and Yaakov our Father with poverty, G-d forbid. And what is the hardest trial of all? The trial of Avraham our Father a.h., to be wealthy, honored, and great, and despite all that to remain on a high level of believing in G-d and walking in His ways. And this is what is said: **ואברם כבד מאד** - "And Avram was very heavy [rich]" (Genesis 13:2), meaning that his trial with wealth was very difficult for him.
And this is what we pray and ask from G-d on Shabbat Mevarchim: "Give us, Master of the World, a life of wealth that we can use the money for the sake of the Honor of Heaven, and not, G-d forbid, for blindness and for imaginary physical honor, which would result, G-d forbid, in a stumbling block." Therefore, they linked together in the prayer "May it be the will... a life of wealth and honor," that the wealth should be for the sake of Heaven, and for the honor of G-d, honored.
Source: Kovetz Tiferet Yisrael, Tammuz 5769, p. 9

My grandfather zt"l said: **כבולעו כך פולטו** - "As it absorbs, so it emits" (Pesachim 30b). The more a person increases in swallowing the good into himself, the more he emits the bad from within him.
Source: Imrei Kodesh, Kislev 5768, p. 107

It was a gem in the mouth of the C"K Maran Admor [the Holy Rabbi Mordechai Shlomo] zya of Boyan regarding the phrase established by the Men of the Great Assembly in the Shabbat prayer: **עם מקדשי שביעי כלם ישבעו ויתענגו מטובך** - "The people who sanctify the seventh day, all of them shall be satiated and delighted from Your goodness." He said that it is human nature regarding physical pleasures that as long as the feeling of hunger has not ceased, one delights in it. However, immediately when one comes to satiety, one no longer has any pleasure in them. This is not so regarding spiritual pleasures. Anyone who merits to taste the flavor of spirituality in Torah and Mitzvot, even if he increases in his pleasures, no amount of satiety will diminish his pleasures. Even after he comes to satiety, he still has delight and desire to increase in his pleasures. End of his holy words.
Source: Marbeh Chaim (Jerusalem 5766) Part 2, p. 21

My grandfather zt"l once said regarding the matter of setting times [for Torah]: A Jew, being busy and preoccupied all day with his livelihood needs, the small amount of time he engages in Torah is nullified by the work of the entire day. However, if he sets times for Torah and his study is by way of permanence (Keviut), behold, "Anything fixed is considered as half on half" (Ketubot 15a), and it is not nullified.
Source: Imrei Kodesh, Tishrei 5769, p. 169

My holy uncle, the Admor Rabbi Mordechai Shlomo of Boyan zya, used to say that we must always remember the saying of Chazal (Sukkah 11b-12a): **תעשה ולא מן העשוי** - "You shall make it, and not from that which is already made." Meaning, we should not be satisfied and content "from what is already made" until now, but rather "Ta'aseh" (You shall make/do) - that we must always continue further and ascend higher and higher.
Source: Shevet MiYisrael (Jerusalem 5767) p. 22

body_he: עוֹד סִפֵּר לִי הַנַּ"ל, שֶׁשָּׁמַע מֵאָבִיו זַ"ל: שֶׁפַּעַם סִפְּרוּ לְהַרְהַ"ק מַהֲרִי"ד מִבֶּעלְזָא זַצַ"ל אוֹדוֹת פִּרְצָה בְּעִיר וִין, אָמַר הרה"ק: ר' יָאסֶעלֶע (כָּךְ קָרָא לְהַגָּאוֹן ר' יוֹסֵף בּוֹימְגַארְטֶן) וַוייסְט דֶּערְפוּן, אִיז יָדִי מְסֻלֶּקֶת.הרה"ג ר' יִשְׂרָאֵל חַיִּים אַשְׁרִי שְׁלִיטָ"א"שִׂיחַ זְקֵנִים" (בְּרוּקְלִין תשע"ב) חֵלֶק ח', עַמּוּד שמ"ה
body_en:
[The Gaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Shlomo Baumgarten zt"l] told about his father, the Gaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yosef zt"l, that once the Holy Rabbi, the Maharid of Belz zt"l, arrived in his city. He walked with a group of Chassidim in the street and saw him. This was before he knew him. He asked the people around him: "Ver iz der Yid vos zein tzurah sheint em?" (Who is this Jew whose face shines?).
Another time, when the Holy Rabbi, the Maharid of Belz zt"l, arrived in his city, his lodging was one floor above their home. On Wednesday, he conducted a 'Tish'. His father, the Gaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yosef zt"l, was busy then with ruling on questions regarding poultry and the like. The Maharid zya sent a messenger downstairs to call him to come to the Tish. His father apologized that he could not come right now because he was busy ruling on questions. When the Maharid zya heard this, he went down to him to his apartment to visit him.
Source: Rabeinu HaGadol Amru (Jerusalem 5776) p. 209

...After the passing of the Gaon Rabbi Zalman Spitzer, the Gaon Rabbi Yeshaya Furst zt"l, author of the book "Chazon Yeshaya," was accepted as Rav of the community. He was one of the remnants of the Great Assembly from the last disciples of the Ktav Sofer zya. He was one of the greatest leaders of Israel in the period between the two World Wars and stood at the head of G-d's battles in all matters. When they wanted to introduce certain changes to the Christian calendar (the plan was to arrange a calendar with equal months and one day a year would not be counted in the number of days of the month and week, but would be a special day named 'World Day' to be considered a national holiday in all countries of the world; this day would not have a name like Sunday or Monday, only the day following it would begin from the day before it, meaning if World Day would be on Tuesday, it would not be considered Tuesday, only the day following it would appear on the calendar as Tuesday. Understandably, this was a breach in the observance of the Holy Shabbat, and therefore the leaders of Haredi Judaism worked to annul the decree). And there was a danger looming over the observance of the Holy Shabbat. HaGaon Rav Y. Furst traveled at the head of a delegation of Agudath Israel and appeared before the League of Nations in Geneva and worked to annul the idea. Rabbi Yeshaya Furst merited to be saved from the claws of the wicked Nazis and arrived in London, where he passed away on the 4th of Adar 5703 (1943).
As a Dayan of the community served the Gaon Rabbi Yosef Baumgarten zt"l, author of the book 'Pardes Yosef', who was a pillar of fire walking before the camp. He drew close the young flock who were in Vienna in spiritual danger, lest they be swept away by the turbulent waters in the big city. His good heart and nobility of soul drew the masses of Vienna's Jews to him like magic cords, even those who were not counted under the flag of the Schiffschul. He was also a fervent zealot according to the path he saw with his teachers. On the day the Hebrew University opened in Jerusalem, he preached before the congregation with copious tears and said that a fast should be decreed for this...
Source: Edi Marom (Brooklyn 5774) p. 408

When we learned the Gemara Shabbat (23a): **אמר אביי מריש הוי מהדר מר אמשחא דשומשמי אמר האי משך נהורי טפי** - "Abaye said: At first, the Master used to seek sesame oil, saying: This one draws its light more [burns longer]." Rashi explains that it does not hurry to burn out like olive oil. Behold, there is a Hiddur (enhancement) in this, that it does not hurry to burn out and burns for a long time. Regarding this, [the Gaon Rabbi Shlomo Baumgarten zt"l] said that it became clear to him what his father, Rabbi Yosef zt"l, used to be very happy about on Chanukah when his candles burned for a long time. There were those who wondered about this joy, what does it accomplish? But in the words of the Gemara, we found a faithful source for his joy.
Source: Siach Yisrael (Jerusalem 5772) p. 132

The Chassid Rav Meir Yuda Wosner told me that in the Skverer housing project, there was a great fire on the 10th of Nissan, 5726 (1966). The entire Beit Midrash burned down, G-d forbid, but the room of the Holy Rebbe of Skver zt"l did not burn, and even smoke did not enter his room. I heard then from the Holy Rebbe of Skver that he said about this: "Da hat men nisht geredt beim davenen" (Here, they did not speak during prayer).
So too it was in our city, the city of Vienna, where there were two synagogues called "Schiffschul." In the courtyard stood the Great Schiffschul, where the Gaon Rabbi Yeshaya Furst zt"l served as Rav, and they prayed in that Beit Midrash with about seven hundred people. But among them were also people who were "modern." Upstairs was the Rav, the Gaon HaTzaddik Rav Yosef Baumgarten zt"l, who was a Tzaddik. The Holy Rabbi Avraham Yehoshua Heschel of Kapishnitz zt"l used to come every year on the holiday of Shavuot to our Beit Midrash to hear the recitation of Akdamut by Rav Yosef. In this Beit Midrash, they did not speak not only during prayer, but when they entered the Beit Midrash even before prayer, they did not speak there. Two hundred people prayed there, and anyone who entered the Beit Midrash approached the Holy Ark and said "Va'ani B'Rov Chasdecha etc. B'Yiratecha," kissed the Parochet, and returned to his place. This Beit Midrash was not destroyed on Kristallnacht.
Source: Siach Zekenim (Brooklyn 5772) Part 9, p. 174

[The Gaon Rabbi Shlomo Baumgarten zt"l] said in the name of his father zt"l regarding our custom that the Mohel sings the song on the day of the Brit Milah, and begins from "V'Chrot Imo HaBrit": In the beginning of the song **אז ישיר** - "Then [Moshe] sang" (Exodus 15:1), there is a hint to Milah (circumcision), for "Az" (Aleph-Zayin, 1+7=8) in Gematria is 8, hinting to Milah on the eighth day.
Source: Siach Yisrael (Jerusalem 5772) p. 132

He was born in the city of Malenitz on the 7th of Kislev, 5631 (1870), to his father the Chassid Rav Pinchas Yaakov HaKohen Levin. When he reached maturity, he married the daughter of the Gaon HaTzaddik our Teacher Rabbi Yehuda Aryeh Leib Alter of Gur, the author of "Sfat Emet" zt"l, and settled in the city of Gur. In the year 5680 (1920), he was accepted as Av Beit Din in the holy community of Bendin. The book "Yechahen Pe'er" was printed from him, containing novellae and sermons, and on the Torah and Festivals. He passed away on the 6th of Adar I, 5695 (1935).
Source: Kerem Shlomo (Bobov) Iyar 5746, p. 23

My father-in-law, the Admor the "Sfat Emet" zt"l, told me when I was young that I should learn much in the Order of Kodshim, since I am a Kohen.
Source: Introduction to "Yechahen Pe'er"

The sons and sons-in-law of the Admor of Gur, the author of "Sfat Emet" zt"l, were all giants of spirit, without exception. Men of stature who illuminated the skies of Chassidic Poland. His eldest son, the Admor RA"M [Rabbi Avraham Mordechai], head of the exile of Ariel and Rabbi of all the children of the exile. The second, the Holy Gaon Rabbi Moshe Betzalel Hy"d, became a symbol of pure and supreme fear of Heaven, holy and pure, head and shoulders above all the people. Their brother-in-law, the Holy Gaon Rabbi Yaakov Meir Biderman zt"l, one of the heads of the Rabbis of Warsaw, did not leave the four cubits of Torah all his days. A wondrous diligent scholar who stayed in the tent of Torah all the years of his life, always sitting and meditating on his studies. The two younger sons of the Admor were wondrous in their deeds and stature: Rabbi Nechemiah the wholesome Tzaddik who resembled a wholesome burnt offering, who never left the four cubits of Torah and Chassidut all his days; and Rabbi Menachem Mendel, the Gaon and Kabbalist and wondrous wise man, a giant of spirit, one of the unique individuals of his generation. A unique chapter in its own right was the Holy Gaon Rabbi Chanoch Tzvi, their brother-in-law.
A genius in revealed and hidden Torah, a supreme holy man and a true lover of Israel who walked his own unique path while remaining loyal without restriction to the method of Gur and the Torah of his teachers and ancestors. His preparations for prayers lasted long hours during the holidays, and sometimes he did not manage to eat at all, the prayers themselves were already not particularly long. He was a man of emotion and many gestures. In the Beit Midrash of the Admor of Gur, they are not accustomed to such things, but for Rabbi Chanoch Tzvi, no one remarked and no one said a thing. On the contrary, they related to his deeds with open admiration.
Source: Rav Pe'er (Jerusalem 5724) p. 48

body_he: גָּאוֹן בְּנִגְלֶה וּבְנִסְתָּר, קָדוֹשׁ עֶלְיוֹן וְאוֹהֵב יִשְׂרָאֵל אֲמִתִּי אֲשֶׁר פָּסַע לוֹ בְּדַרְכּוֹ הַמְיֻחֶדֶת בְּמִינָהּ תּוֹךְ נֶאֱמָנוּת לְלֹא סְיָג לְשִׁיטַת גּוּר וּלְתוֹרַת מוֹרָיו-אֲבוֹתָיו. הֲכָנוֹתָיו לִתְפִלּוֹת נִמְשָׁכוֹת שָׁעוֹת אֲרוּכוֹת בִּימֵי הֶחָג וּלְעִתִּים אֵינוֹ מַסְפִּיק לִסְעֹד בִּכְלָל, הַתְּפִלּוֹת עַצְמָן כְּבָר אֵינָן אֲרוּכוֹת בִּמְיֻחָד.הוּא בַּעַל רֶגֶשׁ וּבַעַל תְּנוּעוֹת רַבּוֹת, בְּבֵית מִדְרָשׁוֹ שֶׁל הָאַדְמוֹ"ר מִגּוּר אֵינָם רְגִילִים בְּכְגוֹן דָּא, אֲבָל לְרַבִּי חֲנוֹךְ צְבִי אִישׁ אֵינוֹ מֵעִיר וְאִישׁ אֵינוֹ אוֹמֵר דָּבָר, לְהֵיפֶךְ, בְּהַעֲרָצָה גְּלוּיָה מִתְיַחֲסִים לְמַעֲשָׂיו.הרה"ח ר' יְהוּדָה לֵיבּ לֵוִין זַ"ל"רַב פְּאֵר" (יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשכ"ד) עַמּוּד מ"ח
body_en:
In the year 5681 (1921), he was called to serve in glory as the Rabbi of Bendin. Before his election, the city was a rock of division and skirmishes between the religious factions and the secularists. The election campaign was conducted in a storm and tempest. After Rabbi Tzvi Chanoch achieved victory in the elections and was chosen as Rav, his opponents, who had slandered him greatly during the election days, came to his house for a courtesy visit. He was very happy to greet them and honored them very nicely. He opened and said:
*   There is a story about a wise man who happened upon a forest, and beasts of prey emerged towards him and plotted to eat him alive. He had no weapons in his hand to fight them, and even if he had weapons, he would not have known how to use them. What did he do? He decided in his heart to start loving these beasts. But how does one love beasts of prey? He meditated deeply and reflected that they are G-d's creatures, and everything He created, He created for His honor, until a strong and faithful love awakened in his heart. Since he did so, the beasts also began to feel love for him, for **כמים הפנים לפנים** - "As water reflects the face to the face" (Proverbs 27:19), and they did not touch him for harm!
"I too," the Rav of Bendin concluded with a tone of victory, "decided beforehand to love all of you, and that is why I succeeded in the elections!..."
Source: Demuyot Hod (Jerusalem 5738) Part 3, p. 42

body_he: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּחָכָם אֶחָד שֶׁנִּקְלַע לְיַעַר וְחַיּוֹת טֶרֶף הֵגִיחוּ לְעֻמָּתוֹ וְזָמְמוּ לְאָכְלוֹ חַיִּים. כְּלֵי זַיִן לֹא הָיוּ בְּיָדוֹ לְהִילָּחֵם בָּהֶם, וְאַף אִלְמָלֵי הָיוּ לוֹ כְּלֵי זַיִן לֹא הָיה יוֹדֵעַ כֵּיצַד מִשְׁתַּמְּשִׁים בָּהֶם. מָה עָשָׂה? הֶחְלִיט בְּלִבּוֹ שֶׁיַּתְחִיל לֶאֱהֹב אֶת הַחַיּוֹת הַלָּלוּ. אַךְ כֵּיצַד אוֹהֲבִים חַיּוֹת טֶרֶף? הָיָה מִתְעַמֵּק וּמַפְלִיג בַּהִרְהוּרִים, שֶׁהֵם יְצוּרֵי ה', וְכָל מַה שֶּׁבָּרָא לִכְבוֹדוֹ בָּרָא, עַד שֶׁהִתְעוֹרְרָה בְּלִבּוֹ אַהֲבָה עַזָּה וְנֶאֱמָנָה. מִכֵּיוָן שֶׁכָּךְ הֵחֵלּוּ גַּם הַחַיּוֹת לִרְחֹשׁ לוֹ אַהֲבָה, כִּי "כַּמַּיִם הַפָּנִים לַפָּנִים" וְלֹא נָגְעוּ בּוֹ לְרָעָה!אַף אֲנִי כֵּן - הִפְטִיר רַבָּהּ שֶׁל בֶּנְדִין בְּנִימַת נִצָּחוֹן - עוֹד מִקּוֹדֶם הֶחְלַטְתִּי לֶאֱהֹב אֶת כֻּלְּכֶם, וְלָכֵן הִצְלַחְתִּי בַּבְּחִירוֹת!...הָרַב אַהֲרֹן סוֹרְסְקִי שְׁלִיטָ"א"דְּמוּיוֹת הוֹד" (יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשל"ח) חֵלֶק ג', עַמּוּד מ"ב
body_en:
The Holy Gaon of Bendin (Rav Chanoch HaKohen Levin) zt"l said to one of his students at the time he was appointed as Rav of the city: "He should know that the Rav of the city is like the town clock, which all the people of the city look at and conduct themselves by. Indeed, one cannot hang it in a low place, where every passerby can move it according to his will. Also, it should not be too high where it is difficult to look at, but rather in the middle of the tower of the city. The metaphor is that he should not hear and incline his ear to do for everyone who surrounds him. Also, he should not be superior and separated from them too much, for then they will say that he is haughty and does not descend to understand anything of their needs, but rather in a middle way."
Source: Sichatan Shel Avdei Avot (Jerusalem 5768) Part 2, p. 230

When the 'Imrei Emet' zya established the 'Agudath Israel' party, the Holy Rabbi Yissachar Dov of Belz zya was not counted among its supporters. The 'Imrei Emet' sent an important delegation to him, which included four great men: his brother-in-law the Gaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Chanoch Tzvi HaKohen of Bendin, the Holy Rabbi Yitzchak Zelig of Sokolov, the Gaon Rabbi Meir Shapiro zt"l, and another great man whose name I do not recall. Throughout their conversation, the Ga'avad of Bendin spoke with submission in the name of his brother-in-law the Admor, saying: "Thus said my brother-in-law the Admor." When he spoke excessively in this manner, the Holy Rabbi of Belz answered him: "You do not need to mention the Rebbe so much, for your opinion is also important and precious to me..." And in the name of the close associates of the Maharid, I heard that after their visit, he said he was impressed most of all by the Ga'avad of Bendin.
Source: HaGaSha"P MiPi Sefarim V'Sofrim (Bnei Brak 5769) p. 156

It is told that once the "Imrei Emet" sent a delegation regarding matters of Agudath Israel to the Admor Rabbi Yissachar Dov of Belz. At the head of the speakers was his brother-in-law, the Rav of Bendin. The Admor of Belz was amazed by his world-embracing personality in Torah, in holiness, and in high levels, of his guest, who was also the son-in-law of the "Sfat Emet" and the grandson of the Rebbe Reb Henich of Alexander. He expressed his wonder aloud:
*   "With us in Galicia, it is customary that sons of Admorim lead a congregation. Why does a man of high stature like him not lead a congregation himself, alongside the leadership of his brother-in-law, the 'Imrei Emet'? And what need did he see to bind himself to the Admor?"
The Rav of Bendin answered, and emphasized the path of absolute nullification of the greats of the world before the Holy Admor in Gur:
*   "In order to get a concept of the level of our Rebbe, it is fitting to first observe the ways of his holy brother. I have a brother-in-law, the brother of the Admor, and his name is Rabbi Moshe Betzalel. That which every Jew is obligated to raise upon his heart during the acceptance of the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven during the Reading of Shema - he thinks about all day long, without distracting his mind for a moment... And even he, when he wishes to enter to his brother, makes preparations, steps ten times back and forth, until he dares to cross his threshold into the inner sanctum..."
Source: Or Zarua LaTzaddik (Jerusalem 5761) Part 1, p. 177

The C"K my father-in-law (the "Sfat Emet") zt"l asked me once on Shavuot at the Holy Table regarding the text of the Piyut "V'Ata Banim Shiru LaMelech" (And now children sing to the King). It should have said "Children sing to the Father." And it seems to me based on what is brought in the Ramban, that Love and Fear cannot exist at once except in the service of G-d alone. Therefore, it fits well "And now children sing to the King," for the two of them are one. And from this, he concludes "In glorious splendor," that from the two of them together, the attribute of Tiferet (Splendor) is made, as is known.
Source: Yechahen Pe'er (Jerusalem 5725) p. 130, 15a

body_he:
אֶצְלֵנוּ בְּגָלִיצְיָה, נָהוּג שֶׁבְּנֵי אַדְמוֹ"רִים מַנְהִיגִים עֵדָה. מַדּוּעַ אִישׁ רָם מַעֲלָה כְּמוֹהוּ, לֹא יַנְהִיג בְּעַצְמוֹ עֵדָה, לְצַד הַנְהָגָתוֹ שֶׁל גִּיסוֹ, הָ"אִמְרֵי אֱמֶת", וּמָה רָאָה צֹרֶךְ לְהִתְקַשֵּׁר לָאַדְמוֹ"ר? נַעֲנָה הָרַב מִבֶּענְדִין, וְהִטְעִים אֶת דֶּרֶךְ הַבִּיטּוּל הַמּוּחְלָט שֶׁל גְּדוֹלֵי עוֹלָם, בִּפְנֵי הָאַדְמוֹ"ר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בְּגוּר:
כְּדֵי לְקַבֵּל מֻשָּׂג עַל מַעֲלָתוֹ שֶׁל הָרַבִּי שֶׁלָּנוּ, רָאוּי לְהִתְבּוֹנֵן תְּחִלָּה בְּדַרְכֵי אָחִיו הַקָּדוֹשׁ. גִּיס יֵשׁ לִי, אָחִיו שֶׁל הָאַדְמוֹ"ר, וּשְׁמוֹ רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה בְּצַלְאֵל. אֶת אֲשֶׁר כָּל יְהוּדִי חַיָּב לְהַעֲלוֹת עַל לִבּוֹ, בְּשַׁעַת קַבָּלַת עֹל מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם בִּקְרִיאַת שְׁמַע - הוּא חוֹשֵׁב כָּל הַיּוֹם כֻּלּוֹ, מִבְּלִי לְהַסִּיחַ דַּעַת לְרֶגַע - - - וְאַף הוּא, בְּבַקְּשׁוֹ לְהִכָּנֵס אֶל אָחִיו, עוֹרֵךְ הֲכָנוֹת, פּוֹסֵעַ עֶשֶׂר פְּעָמִים הָלוֹךְ וָשׁוֹב, עַד שֶׁמֵּעֵז לַעֲבֹר מִפְתָּנוֹ אֶל הַקֹּדֶשׁ פְּנִימָה - - -"אוֹר זָרוּעַ לַצַּדִּיק" (יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשס"א) חֵלֶק א', עַמּוּד קע"ז
body_en:
His brother-in-law, the Elder Admor Rabbi Avraham Mordechai of Gur, when teaching his sons and grandsons the Mishna in Avot: **והוי מקבל את כל האדם בסבר פנים יפות** - "And receive every person with a pleasant countenance" (Avot 1:15), used to add an explanation like this:
*   With a pleasant countenance, like the Rav of Bendin...
Source: Demuyot Hod (Jerusalem 5738) Part 3, p. 28

body_he: בְּסֵבֶר פָּנִים יָפוֹת, כְּמוֹ הָרַב מִבֶּענְדִין...הָרַב אַהֲרֹן סוֹרְסְקִי שְׁלִיטָ"א"דְּמוּיוֹת הוֹד" (יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשל"ח) חֵלֶק ג', עַמּוּד כ"ח
body_en:
I visited Warsaw for the first time. In the aristocratic home of Baumeister, I merited to participate in a meal presided over by the Admor of Gur zt"l. I also met there the in-law of the Admor of Gur, the Av Beit Din of Bendin zt"l, the father of the RIM Levin and Rav Pinchas Levin. He too was one of the most prominent figures I met in that period, a living embodiment of Ahavat Yisrael (Love of Israel) that encompassed with his intense love every soul in Israel, great and small alike. He did not know how to hate a man.
Source: Zichronot (Bnei Brak 5739) p. 183

They tell of the Gaon HaTzaddik Rav Tzvi Chanoch Levin, the Rav of Bendin zt"l, that he would welcome every person of Israel with love and affection, and it was literally evident in him that his soul went out to every Jewish child. It happened that during his illness, a young man slept at his place, to be ready to serve him if he needed him. When he needed to wake him, he would stand over him trembling and say with great emotion: "Behold, I come to awaken from his sleep a son of the Blessed G-d..."
Source: Al Mishkenot HaRo'im (Jerusalem 5742) p. 23

Once, when my father (Rabbi Yaakov Mordechai) z"l happened to be in the city of Bendin, he entered to visit the home of the Rav, who was the son-in-law of his uncle the Sfat Emet. The Rav invited him to wash his hands for a meal in which other important guests participated. The Bendiner Rav, who was known for his good eye and love of Israel, wanted to honor everyone. Therefore, after Birkat HaMazon, he apologized to him that he could not honor him properly. Therefore, he 'invented' a new honor and honored our grandfather Rav Yaakov Mordechai to drink first from the 'Cup of Blessing' after the one who recited the blessing, before the host...
Source: Siach HaParasha, Terumah 5771, p. 6

...A delegation of the greats of Israel arrived in the Land of Israel, leaders of Haredi Jewry who stood at the head of Agudath Israel in Poland. The members of the delegation were the C"K owner of the "Imrei Emet," the Admor of Gur zt"l, the Admor of Sokolov zt"l, and the Ga'avad of Bendin, HaGaon Rabbi Chanoch Tzvi Levin zt"l, with the goal of making peace between the sides [= HaGaon Rav Yosef Chaim Sonnenfeld and Rav Kook zt"l]. The tension was great during the delegation's stay in the land. Its members met with all those involved in the subject, studied the problems and the bone of contention and the differences of opinion. Much has been written about this delegation.
...I will tell here a characteristic and instructive curio: As mentioned, among the members of the delegation was also the Ga'avad of Bendin, the Gaon Rabbi Chanoch Tzvi Levin zt"l, the father of Rav Yitzchak Meir Levin z"l and Rav Pinchas Levin z"l. Rav Moshe Blau zt"l told me that during the stay of the delegation members, he entered to visit the Ga'avad of Bendin zt"l. He [the Rav] stroked the hands of Rav Blau z"l with extraordinary affection, saying incessantly: "How are you, mein teyerer (my dear) beloved Rabbi Moshe'le, you cannot imagine how dear you are to me."
Rav Blau z"l said that in those turbulent and tense days, when the incitement against him was so great, behold, he saw great encouragement in this attitude of the Ga'avad of Bendin zt"l towards him. Rav Blau z"l continued to tell that literally while he was sitting in the company of the Ga'avad of Bendin who was hugging and embracing him, the head of his opponents entered, Rav Shmuel Aharon Weber z"l, who was the head of those fighting against the elders of the Rabbis, HaGaon Rav Y. Diskin zt"l and HaGaon Rav Y.C. Sonnenfeld zt"l, and who attacked Agudath Israel incessantly, and especially Rav Blau z"l.
How surprised Rav Blau z"l was to see how the Ga'avad of Bendin zt"l hugged Rav Weber, embracing him and speaking to him in exactly the same language: "How are you, Rav Shmuel Aharon'le, mein teyerer (my dear), my beloved, you cannot imagine how dear you are to me..." Upon telling me these things, Rav Moshe Blau zt"l added and said: "Can you imagine my feeling..."
Behold, as a lover of Israel, the Ga'avad of Bendin zt"l honored both of them. It is known that during the visit of the Ga'avad of Bendin zt"l, he gave great encouragement to Agudath Israel...
Source: Sharsheret HaDorot (Jerusalem 5761) Part 3, p. 267

...Sosnowiec, our city, was close to Bendin. In Bendin lived the brother-in-law of the Rebbe, the Bendiner Rav. "Er iz geven a Kli" (He was a vessel/instrument). When the Bendiner Rav made a match with Rav Meir, the Rebbe's [son of the "Imrei Emet" zya], Rav Meir was the son-in-law of the Rav of Bendin. Everyone walked on foot on Shabbat for the Shabbat of Blessings (Aufruf); it wasn't far, they could walk. The Bendiner Rav had ten sons, all "Kelim" (vessels/capable men). The father of the Bendiner Rav was Rav Pinchas Yaakov. Rav Pinchas Yaakov approached the Sfat Emet and said he wanted to make a match with the Rebbe. The Rebbe said to him: "Mein Feigele iz doch a shvache" (My Feigele is weak). He asked if she could have children. The Sfat Emet said to him: "Kinder, gute kinder" (Children, good children). Indeed, she had good children.
They called the Bendiner Rav "The Lover of Israel." He called every Jew by the name "Tzaddik." The people of Jerusalem said at the time when the Imrei Emet arrived for a journey to the Land of Israel with the Rav of Bendin, and everyone entered to "Shalom nemen" (greet) both of them, they said: Anyone who leaves the Bendiner Rav leaves "Tzubrochen" (broken), and anyone who leaves the Rebbe [the Imrei Emet] leaves happy. Because the Bendiner Rav says to everyone "Tzaddik." An important Jew enters, hears he is a Tzaddik, indeed thinks this fits him. But he is amazed that after him enters a shoemaker, a tailor, and everyone receives the title "Tzaddik." So he leaves broken, for they did not mean him specifically. But the Rebbe says nothing to anyone; he doesn't make a business out of him, nor does he make a business out of the other...
Source: She'al Avicha, Shavuot 5758, p. 9

He drew people close, relatives and distant ones, and never hurt a person, even with a slight gesture. Therefore, his house was always bustling with many people. There were bothersome people who would torment him with lengthy words which they spread out before him, and the Holy Gaon Rabbi Chanoch Tzvi never revealed shortness of breath or bitterness of spirit. He welcomed every person with immense joy, with enthusiasm, extending "Shalom" to him with both hands.
Once, when he was already serving as the Rav of Bendin, in the harsh winter days, a man entered to him, and he rejoiced with him with great joy. "How good that you came," "How good that you came," he said aloud out of joy. He seated the man in an honorable place and asked for refreshments to be brought for him. "Such a precious guest," he said.
The Rebbetzin did not recognize this guest. The man left, and the Rebbetzin entered to her husband and asked:
*   "Who was this honored guest?"
*   "I don't know, I don't know him, a Jew..." - he answered innocently.
So it was when he stayed in Gur or Warsaw, and afterwards in Bendin. Never did a person say "The place is too narrow for me" in the Rav's house. Never did a person feel superfluous in this house. Every guest or passerby was received with extraordinary cordiality, with open joy, and therefore, people were drawn to the home of the Holy Gaon, and visited him often.
Source: Rav Pe'er (Jerusalem 5724) p. 49

body_he:
מִי הָיָה זֶה הָאוֹרֵחַ הַמְכֻבָּד הַזֶּה?
אֵינֶנִּי יוֹדֵעַ, אֵינֶנִּי מַכִּירוֹ, יְהוּדִי... - עָנָה בִּתְמִימוּת.כָּךְ זֶה הָיָה בְּעֵת שִׁבְתּוֹ בְּגוּר אוֹ בְּוַוארְשָׁא וְאַחֲרֵי כֵן בְּבֶנְדִין. לְעוֹלָם לֹא אָמַר אָדָם צַר לִי הַמָּקוֹם בְּבֵיתוֹ שֶׁל הָרַב, מֵעוֹלָם לֹא הִרְגִּישׁ אָדָם עַצְמוֹ מְיֻתָּר בְּבֵית הַזֶּה, כָּל אוֹרֵחַ אוֹ עוֹבֵר דֶּרֶךְ נִתְקַבֵּל בִּלְבָבִיּוּת יוֹצֵאת מֵהַכְּלָל, בְּשִׂמְחָה גְּלוּיָה, וְלָכֵן, נִמְשְׁכוּ אֲנָשִׁים לְבֵיתוֹ שֶׁל הגה"ק, הִרְבּוּ לְבַקֵּר אֶצְלוֹ.הרה"ח ר' יְהוּדָה לֵיבּ לֵוִין זַ"ל"רַב פְּאֵר" (יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשכ"ד) עַמּוּד מ"ט
body_en:
He did not make calculations of profit and loss in his conversation and dealings with people. He toiled to fulfill every request, every wish of small and great alike. He never recoiled from difficulties or complications. Especially, he toiled to make peace between partners or between a man and his wife. He was a pursuer of peace with all his heart and soul, and as was his way, with enthusiasm and redoubled energy...
Throughout Poland, thousands of poor people walked with letters of recommendation from the Holy Gaon Rabbi Chanoch Tzvi in their pockets. He himself helped every seeker and requester, and also demanded of others to help every seeker and requester. He never checked the character of the requester, in the aspect of: "We do not check regarding food..."
And as was his way, he was awake to every public and holy matter. With the founding of the organized Haredi movement named "Agudath Israel," he joined its ranks with holy fervor. He participated in its gatherings and conferences and was elected to the Council of Torah Sages, in which he was one of the leading speakers. In Agudath Israel, he saw a holy and sublime aspiration, an obligation of the generation. Therefore, he agreed with all his heart to grant his blessing to his eldest son, Rav Yitzchak Meir Levin Shlita [zt"l], to serve as its leader...
And until his last day, he was awake to every holy matter, to every public matter. He contributed greatly to fortifying the walls of Agudath Israel and expanding its framework among Chassidic and Torah circles that stood far from it. For his influence was great upon people and Torah giants and Chassidut in his generation. In steadfast friendship and sincere love, he was with all the Admorim and Torah giants, and everyone saw in him one of the greats of Israel, a true lover of Israel and a supreme holy man, one of the unique individuals of his generation.
He was especially awake to Haredi Torah education. In his conduct, in his deeds, he resembled one of the greats of Israel from past generations, a primordial genius, yet with all that, he understood the needs of the new generations. He knew how to distinguish between the main thing and the secondary, in his toil to fortify the wall of pure Judaism.
Source: Rav Pe'er (Jerusalem 5724) p. 49

...And further regarding Agudath Israel. Our Rebbe (the Gaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Shaul Brach zt"l, Av Beit Din of Kashau) was in the year 5694 (1934) in the resort place of Karlsbad in 'Czechia'. At that same time, the C"K Admor of Gur (the "Imrei Emet") zt"l was there with his entourage, his sons, his sons-in-law, his brother-in-law the Gaon of Bendin, and others, in the resort place of Marienbad, not far from Karlsbad. One day, a special messenger came from the C"K Admor of Gur to our Rebbe in Karlsbad and asked him in the name of the Admor. Since the Admor wants to meet with the Rav of Kashau, but he is in Marienbad with about thirty people who all want to see the Rav of Kashau, therefore he asks that the Rav of Kashau forgive his trouble and turn aside to them in Marienbad. The next day, our Rebbe traveled to the C"K Admor of Gur in Karlsbad [our Rebbe's grandson, the Chassid Rav Avraham Yitzchak Brody, lived in Jerusalem and was with our Rebbe then and traveled as well].
When our Rebbe returned to his home in Kashau, he told us about this meeting with the Rebbe of Gur. And these were his words approximately: "Know, that the Rebbe of Gur does not have one moment in a twenty-four hour period that he is not cleaving to the Holy One, Blessed be He. My visit with him lasted about three minutes. The Admor told me that my book is difficult, and I answered him, and with that, the visit ended and I left. Understandably, we did not speak any politics. After I left the Rebbe's room, the Gaon of Bendin zt"l, the Admor's brother-in-law, asked me to enter his room. There we stayed for four consecutive hours. He was interested in the situation of Jewish matters in our country. The Gaon of Bendin agreed with me completely. He also told me that they know for certain that in communities like ours, there is no need at all to found an Agudah. And do they know that we stand in all matters concerning the observance of religion against destroyers? And especially Zionist movements, in a higher and stronger degree than in their country and everywhere else, despite the fact that they founded the Agudath Israel society. However, despite all this, he has a great request of me:
'Behold, the Rav of Kashau' - he said - 'although he is not an Agudist, but he also never came out against the Agudah, not with a voice of bravery and not even with a weak voice. And even today we are not asking the Rav of Kashau to join Agudath Israel. But despite this, there are many places in most locations in Europe where it is very necessary to found the Agudath Israel society. And in many places, they refrain from this, saying that there are greats of Israel whose opinion is not comfortable with this. And behold, if we come to such places to found Agudath Israel there, they will ask the advice of the greats of Israel, and the Rav of Kashau will surely be among those asked. And we ask for the Rav's help, that in those places where the Agudath Israel society is very necessary to strengthen religion and save the youth from the claws of the inciters, there surely the Rav of Kashau also agrees that it is necessary to found Agudath Israel. May this spirit return to his questioners and strengthen them, and his words will be heard.'
Our Rebbe said about the Gaon of Bendin zt"l that he is unique in his generation in his love of Israel, and that he is ready to serve every Jew and kiss the hem of his cloak out of his great love for him. 'I have never seen in my life a broken and humble Jew in his own eyes like this Gaon,' our Rebbe concluded his words about the Rav of Bendin."
Source: Shaul Bechir Hashem (Netanya 5736) p. 119

Partial list from the sources of one journey (with the C"K Maran Admor the "Pnei Menachem" of Gur zt"l) from Monday, 18 Adar II 5755 [mostly in free translation], as recorded at the time of the event...
...He began to speak of his holy uncle, the Rav of Bendin, son-in-law of the Sfat Emet zt"l. And he told among other things: "I was once in Otwock in my childhood, with my father the holy 'Imrei Emet' zya, and we were supposed to return to Gur for a Shabbat of a family Simcha. But suddenly I fell ill with angina, and there was no possibility to take me to Gur. It was decided to leave me in Otwock. Before they left, my father calmed me and told me that the Rav of Bendin was also staying in Otwock and he would watch over me and immediately after Shabbat he would return.
The Rav of Bendin, who heard that my father said this to me, rejoiced over this like one finding great spoil. Indeed, the entire Shabbat he cared for me faithfully and told me stories, etc. I will never forget that Shabbat. I remember, when my father returned, I asked him if it is permitted to speak in the middle of the Shemoneh Esrei prayer. My father answered me: 'Certainly not!' I wanted to be sure, and asked him again: 'So it is forbidden to speak in the middle of the Shemoneh Esrei prayer in any way?' And again he answered: 'Certainly not, and why do you ask?' And I answered: 'Because on Shabbat I stood during prayers next to my holy uncle, the Rav of Bendin, and I heard him speaking in the middle of the Shemoneh Esrei prayer.'
The 'Imrei Emet' was surprised and asked: 'What did you hear?' I answered: 'I heard him saying "Tatte Zisser, Tatte Zisser" [Sweet Father, Sweet Father]!' My father the Imrei Emet smiled and said: 'The Rav of Bendin is entirely holy, a very great man. He is not, G-d forbid, just speaking. "Tatte Zisser" - certainly his intention is to the Holy Shechinah, and one who is close to G-d is permitted to say so.'
Since then," concluded our Rebbe (the "Pnei Menachem") zya, "I knew to look at the Bendiner Rav in a different way - that he is entirely spiritual. Nevertheless, with my holy father, I never heard such a thing, even though his enthusiasm in prayer was 'gewaldig' [immense]. It seems that restraint is a higher level, as they say about Hillel the Elder, who was the teacher of Yonatan ben Uziel, that for him [Hillel], a bird flying overhead during his study was not burned, because he held back the fire of enthusiasm inside himself..."
Source: Nafshi Ta'arog (Jerusalem 5761) Part 2, p. 17

The Yetzer (Evil Inclination) has many faces. Sometimes he appears as a zealot and sometimes as a compromiser. My father, the Gaon HaTzaddik (Av Beit Din of Bendin) zt"l, said that this is why they established the prayer "Remove Satan from before us and from behind us." From before us - this represents the face of a zealot. And from behind us - this represents the compromiser...
Source: HaModia, 10 Menachem Av 5756

When the final moments of Rabbi Tzvi Chanoch of Bendin arrived, on the night of the Holy Shabbat, after the meal, the 6th of Adar 5695 (1935), they heard him call out:
*   "Abba Rechima (Beloved Father), if this is Your will, please let it be as You wish..."
With these words, his soul flew to the heights (I heard from his son, Rabbi Yitzchak Meir Levin).
Source: MiMa'ayanot HaNetzach (Bnei Brak 5739) Avot, p. 68

body_he: אַבָּא רְחִימָא, אִם זֶה רְצוֹנְךָ, אָנָּא שֶׁיִּהְיֶה כְּמוֹ שֶׁאַתָּה רוֹצֶה...בַּמִּלִּים הָאֵלּוּ פָּרְחָה נִשְׁמָתוֹ לַמָּרוֹם (שָׁמַעְתִּי מִבְּנוֹ רַבִּי יִצְחָק מֵאִיר לֵוִין).הָרַב אַהֲרֹן סוֹרְסְקִי שְׁלִיטָ"א"מִמַּעְיְנוֹת הַנֶּצַח" (בְּנֵי בְּרַק תשל"ט) אָבוֹת, עַמּוּד ס"ח

...And since due to our sins, many have been missed from us within thirty days, missing among the holy ones were three great men, I am hereby reading a eulogy for them... Behold they are: A priest at the head, the Gaon, the famous Tzaddik, our Teacher Rabbi Chanoch Tzvi HaKohen Levin zt"l, who was the Av Beit Din of the community of Bendin. Great in Torah, he left several compositions in his holy handwriting, and one which was already printed...
Source: Yechahen Pe'er (Jerusalem 5725) p. 130, 17b

I called the name of the book "Yechahen Pe'er" because hinted in its letters is the name of my father-in-law, C"K Admor our Teacher Rabbi Yehuda Aryeh zt"l (author of "Sfat Emet"), son of the Admor Rabbi Avraham Mordechai zt"l, son of the C"K Maran Admor the "Chiddushei HaRim" zt"l. Also hinted in it is the name of my father, my teacher, HaRav Rabbi Pinchas Yaakov HaKohen zt"l, son of HaRav Rabbi Yechiel Efraim Fischel zt"l of Malenitz, son of the C"K my grandfather Admor Chanoch Henich HaKohen zt"l of Alexander. Also my mother's father, my teacher, the Admor Rabbi Hirsch Tomashovver zt"l. Also my grandfather, HaRav Rabbi Hirsch of Malenitz and Przysucha zt"l, son-in-law of the daughter of Rabbi Fischel of Strykov zt"l. Also my father-in-law's father, HaRav Rabbi Yehuda HaLevi zt"l. Also hinted in it is the name of my late son, HaRav Rabbi Yechiel Efraim Fischel zt"l. Also because the subject of the book is regarding Kodshim (Holy Things) and the service of the Kohanim.
Source: Introduction to "Yechahen Pe'er"

He (the Chassid Rabbi Yaakov Yitzchak Pik z"l) used to say in the name of the Ga'avad of Bendin, Rabbi Tzvi Chanoch HaKohen Levin zt"l, who interpreted the words of the Gemara (Megillah 10b): **מסורת היא מאבותינו אמוץ ואמציה אחים היו** - "It is a tradition from our fathers that Amotz and Amatzia were brothers." "Amotz" refers to the person strengthening himself. And through the person strengthening himself, the Holy One, Blessed be He, also strengthens him and pours strength into him, and this is "Amatzia." These two go together - "They were brothers."
This saying, which encapsulates sublime ideas of great significance, was used by Rabbi Yaakov Yitzchak to strengthen others and illuminate their eyes to the fact that the first strengthening must be taken by the person himself, to strengthen himself. Behold, a person is in a time of trouble and does not see the way out of it. First of all, he must be "Amotz" and strengthen himself in his spirit with his own powers, and afterwards - **לאל גומר עלי** - "To G-d who completes for me" (Psalms 57:3), the Holy One, Blessed be He, adopts his powers ("Amatzia") and increases strength for him.
[We recorded these words heard from the Chassid Rav Pinchas Yaakov HaKohen Levin z"l, son of the Ga'avad of Bendin zt"l, from the mouth of his close associate, Rabbi Yaakov Yitzchak, the Chassid Rav Mordechai Leib Lebkovitch Hy"v (Community of Gur, Beit Shemesh)].
Source: Esh Tamid (Jerusalem 5761) p. 166

It is written (Micah 7:15): **כימי צאתך מארץ מצרים אראנו נפלאות** - "As in the days of your coming out of the land of Egypt, I will show him wonders." I heard from the Chassid Rav Yitzchak Meir Levin z"l in the name of his father who was the Av Beit Din of Bendin, that seemingly one should be precise: why did it say "I will show him wonders" and not "I will do wonders"? Rather, the matter is that every single day the Blessed G-d performs miracles and wonders with us at every time and moment - "For Your miracles that are with us every day." But they are hidden and we do not see them with our eyes. However, in the future to come, the Blessed G-d will show us all those miracles and wonders that He did with us always, and this is "I will show him wonders" specifically.
Source: Divrot Kodesh (Ramat-Lelov Bnei Brak) Shemot 5763, p. 3

Tehillim (Psalms) is advice to be saved from sadness and pride, for all of Tehillim is about joy and humility. And this is like what our Rebbe of Kotzk zt"l said about himself, that he is a Jew wrapped in Tehillim. And I said before the Holy Gaon of Sochatchov zt"l that this is the explanation in the Midrash regarding the story of the peddler etc., and he showed him a wrapped Tehillim etc., and it found favor in his eyes.
Source: Yechahen Pe'er (Jerusalem 5724) HaBen Yakir Li Efraim, p. 7

I said regarding what is in the Gemara, a dispute whether the Son of David comes in a generation that is entirely guilty or entirely innocent. And behold, these and these are the words of the Living G-d. And for this, in this generation, one can say that both are true. That from small to great, there is no one who will not be guilty, who could be and needs to be better and innocent. And also from small to great, according to the changes and descent of the generation, G-d forbid, and according to the troubles, G-d forbid, he could be more guilty. And despite all this, he is innocent. It is found that in truth, now these and these are the words of the Living G-d. And for this, may it be the will that the Messiah our Righteous One should come in truth to redeem us speedily, Amen Selah.
Source: Yechahen Pe'er (Jerusalem 5724) p. 107, 15a

There are for Jerusalem 20 names. Yirah (Fear), Shalom (Peace). And as I defined in Jerusalem, that it is brought that it is called Jerusalem because Avraham our Father called it Yirah, and Shem called it Shalem. And the Rebbe Rav Ber zt"l asks: Why is it not called Shalem-Yirah? And they also ask that it should have said Yirah-Shalem, why Yerushalayim? And it appears that this is to teach us that even though peace is good from every place, one needs to precede it with fear before peace.
Source: Yechahen Pe'er (Jerusalem 5725) Drashot, p. 49, 15b

The Gaon Rabbi Yehoshua David Povarsky zt"l was born on the 10th of Shevat 5662 (1902) in the city of Lyuban near Slutsk. Being a lad of about 12, he was accepted as a regular student in the Yeshiva of Slutsk. There he was diligent in his studies with immense perseverance. In time, he ascended to the Holy Land together with the family of the Rav of Brisk. In the year 5705 (1945), he was appointed to serve as Rosh Yeshiva in the Ponevezh Yeshiva in Bnei Brak, and served there until the day of his passing on the 6th of Adar 5759 (1999).
Source: Maran HaRav Shach (Bnei Brak 5766) Part 1, p. 143

The C"K Admor of Pshevorsk zt"l told that in Galicia it was known that there is a young man in Lithuania who knows the four parts of Shulchan Aruch by heart, and his name is our great Rebbe, David Povarsky zt"l.
Source: Kol HaTorah, Nissan 5760, p. 76

My father, Rav David Hershovitz z"l, told that HaGaon Rav David Povarsky zt"l learned after his wedding in the Kollel of HaGaon Rav Elchanan Wasserman z"l in Baranovich. Once my father z"l entered HaGaon Rav David's place and saw that he was learning by the light of a 10-watt bulb. My father went and bought a 25-watt bulb and wanted to install it in the lamp in the home of HaGaon Rav David z"l. HaGaon Rav David z"l did not agree in any way. His reason was with him: because the electricity bill was a shared account with the landlord, and the landlord rented the apartment to him with the understanding that he would use a 10-watt bulb. Therefore, he cannot change this and take more electricity than what was agreed upon initially. Especially since it is impossible to know exactly how much electricity he uses, and the landlord will always suspect him of using more electricity than enough.
Source: Kol HaTorah, Nissan 5760, p. 72

Once, the Holy Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik of Kalev zya heard a cantor singing with an especially pleasant and sweet voice (it is possible that at that time he was already sheltering in the shadow of the holiness of Rabbi Shmelke zya). The Holy Rabbi responded and said: "Master of the Universe, if I had such a pleasant voice, I could serve You and even draw others under the wings of Your Shechinah." Immediately, that cantor was silenced from his singing, for his pleasant voice was taken from him and given to the Holy Rabbi in his stead.
Source: Binyan Shlomo, Adar 5765, p. 7

A story that happened: Many years ago, I came on a Thursday and found him [the Gaon Rabbi David Povarsky zt"l] sick with bronchitis, with fever and coughing, and it was difficult for him to speak. I asked him what would be at night, would he go to the Yeshiva as was his way? He answered me: "Obviously." I asked him: "Is it possible in such a condition? Behold, it is dangerous!" He did not answer me. I repeated my question twice and three times, and he did not answer. Finally, I said to him: "It is Torah, and I must learn."
After about a quarter of an hour, he told me that he would tell me a story about a certain Rebbetzin who was sick and was in danger. Towards Yom Kippur, the doctor said she was forbidden to fast, but she did not want to hear under any circumstances, for all her days she fasted on Yom Kippur, and how could she eat in her old age? The household members worried greatly and invited the great professor. For if he would order her, it is possible she would listen to him. The professor arrived, and after a few minutes told the sick woman that she could fast on Yom Kippur. The household members were astonished and asked him: "Is she not in danger?" He answered them: "Certainly she is in danger, and if she fasts, she is in literal mortal danger. However, if she eats, she will be in *more* danger than if she fasts."
"And I understood immediately that this was the answer to my question. Certainly, it is forbidden for him to go to the Yeshiva and this will harm his health. But if he does not go to the Yeshiva, it will harm him even more. And behold, the Torah is his physical sustenance, and without Torah, it will harm his bodily health."
Source: Kol Nehi Ariema (Bnei Brak 5759) p. 25

...From his unique and sublime behaviors of my master, my father zt"l, who walked among us like an angel of G-d, a ladder set on the ground and its head reaching the heavens. It was a gem in his mouth, the saying of the Gemara: "They sent from there: Who is a 'Ben Olam HaBa' (Son of the World to Come) etc." And indeed, all that is said there was fulfilled in him. He would interpret with the sweetness of his lips "Ben Olam HaBa" in Yiddish: "Er iz a dortiker" (He is a 'there-nik' / one from there). Meaning, he does not live in this world at all, but his entire existence is the World to Come. And those close to my father zt"l, seeing his way of life, saw with their senses how this matter was fulfilled in him with sublime perfection. He had no taste in food, and in all the pleasures of this world. Rather, he was alive in the World of Truth. All this our eyes saw...
Source: Kol HaTorah, Nissan 5760, p. 11

מֵעִיקְּרֵי הַיְסוֹדוֹת אֲשֶׁר הָי' מְשַׁנֵּן בְּכָל עֵת, הִיא יְסוֹד הַחֵרוּת וְהַהִשְׁתַּחְרְרוּת הַמֻּחְלֶטֶת מִכָּל שִׁעְבּוּדֵי הַגּוּף וְטִרְדּוֹתָיו, וְלִהְיוֹת הַנֶּפֶשׁ בִּמְנוּחָה שְׁלֵמָה לַתּוֹרָה וְלַעֲבוֹדַת הַשֵּׁי"ת, וְהוּא עִנְיַן וַיַּרְא מְנוּחָה כִּי טוֹב וְאֶת הָאָרֶץ כִּי נָעֵמָה וַיֵּט שִׁכְמוֹ לִסְבֹּל, וְעַל יְדֵי עֲמַל הַתּוֹרָה וְלִימוּד הַמּוּסָר בְּכָל עֵת נַעֲשָׂה בֶּן חוֹרִין גָּמוּר, וְכָל נִפְתּוּלֵי הַחַיִּים וּתְלָאוֹת הַגּוּף כְּבָר אֵין נוֹגְעִים אֵלָיו כְּלָל, וְלִבּוֹ וְרוּחוֹ פְּנוּיִים לִדְבֵיקוּתָם בְּהַשֵּׁי"ת וּבְתוֹרָתוֹ. אַשְׁרֵי הַזּוֹכֶה לְכָךְ, אאמו"ר זצ"ל זָכָה לְזֹאת וְהָי' לְאוֹת וּלְמוֹפֵת בְּעִנְיָן זֶה, וְאַף כְּשֶׁהִקִּיפוּהוּ מַחֲלוֹת קָשׁוֹת, וְהָי' לוֹ דַּלֶּקֶת רֵיאוֹת בִּשְׁתֵּי רֵיאוֹתָיו וְצִוָּה הָרוֹפֵא לְהַבְהִילוֹ לְבֵית הַחוֹלִים, וְהוּא עָלָה לַיְשִׁיבָה לַאֲמִירַת הַשִּׁיעוּר כָּרָגִיל, הַנִּשְׁמָע כַּדָּבָר הַזֶּה, אֵין זֶה אֶלָּא כִּי אֵינוֹ מֵעָלְמָא הַדֵּין אֶלָּא בֶּן עוֹלָם הַבָּא כְּמַאֲמָרוֹ, וְכָךְ הָי' כָּל יָמָיו בִּבְחִי' עוֹלָם הַבָּא וּמִתְעַנֵּג מִזִּיו הַשְּׁכִינָה. גַּם הָי' לאאמו"ר זצ"ל נְקִיּוּת הַדַּעַת נִשְׂגָּבָה, וְהָי' מַפְלִיא הַדָּבָר עַד מְאֹד לִרְאוֹת אֵיךְ הוּא מְשֻׁחְרָר לַחֲלוּטִין מִכָּל נְגִיעוֹת אִישִׁיּוֹת בְּכָל דֶּרֶךְ חַיָּיו, וְלָכֵן גַּם שִׁיקּוּל דַּעְתּוֹ הָי' טָהוֹר וְנָקִי, וְהָיוּ הַכֹּל נֶהֱנִין מִמֶּנּוּ עֵצָה וְתוּשִׁי', בְּבִטָּחוֹן גָּמוּר, כִּי דַּעְתּוֹ צְרוּפָה וּמְזֻכֶּכֶת עַל דֶּרֶךְ הָאֱמֶת וְהַצֶּדֶק הַמּוּחְלָט בְּכָל עִנְיָן, בְּכָל עֵת וּבְכָל שָׁעָה.
סְפָרָיו "יְשׁוּעַת דָּוִד" עַל כָּל חֶלְקֵי הַשַּׁ"ס אֲשֶׁר עָמַל הַרְבֵּה בְּמֶשֶׁךְ יְמֵי חַיָּיו לְהוֹצִיאָם לָאוֹר, הָיוּ לְנַחֲלָה וְלִבְרָכָה, וְגַם הִשְׂכִּיל מְאֹד בִּצְנִיעוּת מֻפְלֶגֶת כְּדַרְכּוֹ בַּקֹּדֶשׁ לְהַסְתִּיר וּלְהַצְנִיעַ אֶת חִדּוּשָׁיו, כַּאֲשֶׁר הִבְלִיעַ בֵּין הַשִּׁיטִין וּבְצוּרָה מֻצְנַעַת אֶת חִדּוּשֵׁי תּוֹרָתוֹ הַיְקָרִים, וְזָכָה לְהַעֲמִיד תַּלְמִידִים הַרְבֵּה אֲשֶׁר הָיוּ לִמְאוֹרוֹת. גַּם סִפְרֵי הַיִּרְאָה "מוּסָר וְדַעַת" וְהֵם דִּבְרוֹת קָדְשׁוֹ וְשִׂיחוֹת הַמּוּסָר אֲשֶׁר נִרְשְׁמוּ ע"י תַּלְמִידָיו, הָיוּ לְנַחֲלָה וְלִבְרָכָה לְעַם קוֹדֶשׁ, וּשְׂפָתָיו דּוֹבְבוֹת בַּקֶּבֶר לְחַיֵּי נֶצַח.מֵעִיקְּרֵי דְּרָכָיו וְהַנְהָגוֹתָיו בַּקֹּדֶשׁ הָיְתָה הַתְּדִירוּת הַמּוּחְלֶטֶת בַּעֲמָלוֹ בַּתּוֹרָה וּבַעֲבוֹדַת הַקֹּדֶשׁ - בְּסִדְרֵי תַּלְמוּדוֹ, וּבְהַרְבָּצַת תּוֹרָה וְיִרְאָה לַעֲדָרִים, מִבְּלִי הֶפְסֵק וְהֶסַּח הַדַּעַת כְּלָל, וְהָי' זֶה מֻפְלָא בְּיוֹתֵר. וְהִנֵּה יְסוֹד עִנְיָן זֶה בְּהִתְבּוֹנְנוּת הוּא מִסּוֹד הַנֶּצַח וְחַיֵּי עוֹלָם הַבָּא, וְהוּא סוֹד עִנְיָן לְמַעְלָה מִן הַזְּמַן, כִּי מֻשַּׂג הַזְּמַן הוּא מִן הַבְּרִיאָה וְהוּא מוּרְכָּב מֵחֲלָקִים, אֲבָל עוֹלָם הַבָּא שֶׁהוּא עוֹלָם הַנֶּצַח, הֲרֵי הוּא בִּמְצִיאוּתוֹ מִקְשָׁה אַחַת מִבְּלִי גְּבוּלוֹת וּזְמַנִּים כְּלָל וְהוּא סוֹד הַנֶּצַח, וּכְבָר אֵין בּוֹ עִנְיַן הֶפְסֵק כְּלָל. אאמו"ר זַצַ"ל אֲשֶׁר הָי' "כְּמַאֲמָרוֹ" בֶּן עוֹלָם הַבָּא, כְּבָר מְשֻׁחְרָר מֵעִנְיַן הַהֶפְסֵק וְהַפְּרָקִים, וְזֶה הָי' סוֹד כֹּחוֹ בְּקִיּוּם הַדָּבָר בְּאֹפֶן מֻשְׁלָם, וְכָל יְמֵי חַיָּיו הָי' תָּדִיר, תָּדִיר בְּתוֹרָתוֹ, תָּדִיר בִּתְפִלָּתוֹ, תָּדִיר בַּעֲבוֹדָתוֹ עֲבוֹדַת הַקּוֹדֶשׁ, וּבְכָל הֲלִיכוֹתָיו בַּקֹּדֶשׁ.הרה"ג ר' בָּרוּךְ דֹּב פּוֹבַרְסְקִי שְׁלִיטָ"ארֹאשׁ יְשִׁיבַת פּוֹנִיבֶז'"קוֹל הַתּוֹרָה", נִיסָן תש"ס, עַמּוּד י"א

We also merited to see and learn from him the essence of a true disciple. Being all his days attached to his distinguished Rabbi, our grandfather the Mashgiach Rabbi Yerucham zt"l, whose image was always before his eyes. We would wonder to hear from him at all times the phrase: "He would do this now," "He would say this about that." And this is a power and a wondrous virtue, which not every person merits. Only a true disciple properly, who connects to his Rabbi with heart and soul, merits that the ways of his Rabbi's thoughts are already grasped and attached to him and his soul. Until even after the passing of his Rabbi, he merits that his heart feels and directs to the truth of his Rabbi's mind in every matter, to be a light for him in all his ways.
Source: Kol HaTorah, Nissan 5760, p. 11

Regarding the virtue of diligence, we can learn from the conduct of the Rosh Yeshiva of Ponevezh, the Gaon Rabbi David Povarsky zt"l:
The sound of soft footsteps echoed in the slumbering street. The paving stones of the street already knew the walker, Rav David Povarsky zt"l, who made his way night after night, exactly at the same hour, up the hill. The learners, those who stayed late at night, who toiled over their studies in the hall of Ponevezh, knew that when the creaking of the opening doors was heard, it was a sign that the time was three-thirty after midnight. There is no need to glance at the clock; the sound of the door creaking is more accurate than any clock in the world. So it was for decades - every night. But there was one night when the doors of the hall opened earlier, five minutes earlier exactly! The diligent students of the Yeshiva who glanced at their watches looked at each other in disbelief. For the first time in many years, the Yeshiva door opened at three twenty-five! So contrary to the character of the great Rosh Yeshiva, to the way of the Kelm Yeshiva which he held onto and did not deviate from all the days of his life.
A stormy, rainy winter night. A piercing cold wind froze bones blowing outside. Not a living soul dared to go out to the dark street. In the modest house on Werner Street lay Rabbi David on his bed, wrapped in blankets. Hard coughs burst from his throat, and strong shivers shook his weak body. The Rebbetzin stood by his bed, and on her face were signs of worry. He was no longer young, the Rav, and she was so anxious for his health. The hands of the clock moving towards the hour of three after midnight disturbed her rest. She knew well that she would never succeed in stopping the Rav from going to the Beit Midrash to learn his regular session. Not bad weather, nor a shaky health condition, nor his advanced age would prevent him from going out to the Yeshiva. She knew that learning was the source of his vitality, without it he had no life. And yet, she feared.
When the hour approached three, Rabbi David rose from his bed. As every night, he washed his hands and recited the Blessings of the Torah. The Rebbetzin tried to say that perhaps he would learn at home today, but she knew in advance that at three-fifteen exactly, the Rav would go out on his way to the Yeshiva hall as every night. When the door closed, the Rebbetzin glanced at the clock. To her great amazement, the time was three-five. The Rav had advanced his departure from the house by five full minutes! For decades she did not remember such a "deviation." What happened this time? She wondered to herself.
A distance of a few houses away stood Rav Berel Povarsky Shlita, the son of Rabbi David, by the window of his house. On this night, he did not succeed in falling asleep. With great anxiety, he listened to the storm raging outside. The lightning flashed and the rain tapped on the windows now. He knew that his father was sick and had a cold, and he was very worried. He knew well that no power in the world would prevent him from his study in the Yeshiva. "It is literally Pikuach Nefesh (saving a life)..." his lips murmured in worry.
"I must go!" he thought. "At three-fifteen, I will present myself at my parents' house and suggest to Father to learn with him in chavrusa at home, provided he does not go out into the stormy night!"
Rav Berel donned his coat and went out to the street, bowing his head before the lashes of the rain, struggling with the stormy wind that threatened to blow the umbrella from his hands. A glance at the luminous digits of his watch revealed to him that he did not need to hurry; before three-fifteen, Father does not leave the house. At three-fifteen exactly, the devoted son presented himself, dripping water, shivering from cold, at the door of the house. "Father already left!" the mother informed with worried face. Rav Berel still managed to see his father's bent figure receding into the night on the way up to the Yeshiva. He looked at his mother, the Rebbetzin; a look of understanding flashed in her eyes. She understood the mother, and the son understood too why Rabbi David advanced his departure from the house... Rabbi David feared that his worried son would try to persuade him to stay home. And how could he cancel a whole night of study in the Yeshiva? How is it possible to be disconnected for a whole night from the source of life? He hurried and advanced his departure from the house before the son could arrive...
Only when the story became known was the mystery solved. Now the students understood why and for what reason the Rosh Yeshiva appeared for study five minutes before the time for the first time in twenty years.
Source: Or Daniel (Bnei Brak 5764) Part 4, p. 484

לֵיל חֹרֶף גָּשׁוּם וְסוֹעֵר, רוּחַ צוֹלֶפֶת קָרָה, מַקְפִּיאַת עֲצָמוֹת נָשְׁבָה בַּחוּץ, נֶפֶשׁ חַיָּה לֹא הֵעֵזָה לָצֵאת לָרְחוֹב הַחֲשׁוּךְ. בַּבַּיִת הַצָּנוּעַ שֶׁבִּרְחוֹב וַסֶּרְמַן שׁוֹכֵב רַבִּי דָּוִד עַל מִטָּתוֹ, מְעֻטָּף בִּשְׂמִיכוֹת, שִׁיעוּלִים קָשִׁים בּוֹקְעִים מִגְּרוֹנוֹ, וּצְמַרְמוֹרוֹת עַזּוֹת מַרְעִידוֹת אֶת גּוּפוֹ הֶחָלוּשׁ. הָרַבָּנִית נִצְּבָה לְיַד מִטָּתוֹ וְעַל פָּנֶיהָ אוֹתוֹת דְּאָגָה, כְּבָר לֹא צָעִיר הוּא הָרַב וְהִיא כֹּה חֲרֵדָה לִבְרִיאוּתוֹ. מְחוֹגֵי הַשָּׁעוֹן שֶׁנָּעוּ לְעֵבֶר הַשָּׁעָה שָׁלוֹשׁ אַחַר חֲצוֹת הִדְרִיכוּ אֶת מְנוּחָתָהּ, יָדְעָה הִיא הֵיטֵב שֶׁלְּעוֹלָם לֹא תַּצְלִיחַ לַעֲצֹר אֶת הָרַב מִלָּלֶכֶת לְבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ לִלְמֹד אֶת שִׁעוּרוֹ הַקָּבוּעַ, לֹא מֶזֶג אֲוִיר גָּרוּעַ וְלֹא מַצָּב בְּרִיאוּתִי מְעֻרְעָר, גַּם לֹא גִּילוֹ הַמִּתְקַדֵּם, יִמְנָעוּהוּ מִלָּצֵאת אֶל הַיְשִׁיבָה, הֵן יוֹדַעַת הִיא כִּי הַלִּמּוּד הוּא מְקוֹר חִיּוּתוֹ שֶׁל הָרַב, בִּלְעָדָיו אֵין לוֹ חַיִּים, וּבְכָל זֹאת, כֹּה חוֹשֶׁשֶׁת הִיא.
כְּשֶׁהִתְקָרְבָה הַשָּׁעָה שָׁלוֹשׁ, קָם רַבִּי דָּוִד מִמִּטָּתוֹ, כִּבְכָל לַיְלָה נָטַל יָדָיו וּבֵרַךְ אֶת בִּרְכוֹת הַתּוֹרָה, הָרַבָּנִית נִסְּתָה לוֹמַר כִּי אוּלַי יִלְמַד הַיּוֹם בְּבֵיתוֹ, אַךְ יָדְעָה מֵרֹאשׁ שֶׁבְּשָׁלוֹשׁ וַעֲשָׂרָה בְּדִיּוּק יֵצֵא הָרַב בְּדַרְכּוֹ לְהֵיכַל הַיְשִׁיבָה כְּמוֹ בְּכָל לַיְלָה. כְּשֶׁנִּסְגְּרָה הַדֶּלֶת, הֵעִיפָה הָרַבָּנִית מַבָּט בַּשָּׁעוֹן, לְגֹדֶל פְּלִיאָתָהּ הָיְתָה הַשָּׁעָה שָׁלוֹשׁ וַחֲמִשָּׁה, הָרַב הִקְדִּים אֶת צֵאתוֹ מִן הַבַּיִת בְּחָמֵשׁ דַּקּוֹת תְּמִימוֹת! כְּבָר עֲשָׂרוֹת שָׁנִים אֵינֶנָּה זוֹכֶרֶת "חֲרִיגָה" כָּזֹאת, מָה אֵרַע הַפַּעַם? תָּמְהָה לְנַפְשָׁהּ.
בְּמֶרְחָק שֶׁל כַּמָּה בָּתִּים נִצָּב לְיַד חַלּוֹן בֵּיתוֹ הָרַב דֹּב פּוֹבַרְסְקִי שְׁלִיטָ"א, בְּנוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי דָּוִד. בַּלַּיְלָה זֶה לֹא הִצְלִיחַ לְהֵרָדֵם, בַּחֲרָדָה רַבָּה הֶאֱזִין לַסְּעָרָה הַמִּשְׁתּוֹלֶלֶת בַּחוּץ, הַבְּרָקִים הִבְזִיקוּ וְהַגֶּשֶׁם הִקִּישׁ כָּעֵת עַל הַחַלּוֹנוֹת, יָדַע הוּא שֶׁאַבָּא חוֹלֶה וּמְצֻנָּן, וְהָיָה מֻדְאָג מְאֹד, יָדַע הֵיטֵב שֶׁאֵין כֹּחַ בָּעוֹלָם שֶׁיִּמְנַע מִמֶּנּוּ לְבַטֵּל אֶת לִמּוּדוֹ בַּיְשִׁיבָה, "מַמָּשׁ פִּקּוּחַ נֶפֶשׁ..." - מִלְמְלוּ שְׂפָתָיו בִּדְאָגָה."עָלַי לָלֶכֶת!" - חָשַׁב - "בְּשָׁלוֹשׁ וַעֲשָׂרָה אֶתְיַצֵּב בְּבֵית הַהוֹרִים וְאַצִּיעַ לְאַבָּא לִלְמֹד עִמּוֹ בְּחַבְרוּתָא בַּבַּיִת וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יֵצֵא אֶל הַלַּיְלָה הַסּוֹעֵר!"עָטָה רַבִּי בָּרוּךְ דֹּב אֶת מְעִילוֹ וְיָצָא אֶל הָרְחוֹב, מַרְכִּין אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ מִפְּנֵי צְלִיפוֹתָיו שֶׁל הַגֶּשֶׁם, נֶאֱבָק בָּרוּחַ הַסּוֹעֶרֶת שֶׁאִיְּמָה לְהָעִיף מִיָּדָיו אֶת מִטְרִיָּתוֹ, צָעַד לְכִוּוּן רְחוֹב וַסֶּרְמַן, הֲצָצָה בַּסְּפָרוֹת הַזַּרְחָנִיּוֹת שֶׁל שְׁעוֹנוֹ גִּלְּתָה לוֹ שֶׁאֵינֶנּוּ צָרִיךְ לְמַהֵר לִפְנֵי שָׁלוֹשׁ וַעֲשָׂרָה אַבָּא אֵינֶנּוּ עוֹזֵב אֶת הַבַּיִת. בְּשָׁעָה שָׁלוֹשׁ וַעֲשָׂרָה בְּדִיּוּק הִתְיַצֵּב הַבֵּן הַמָּסוּר נוֹטֵף מַיִם, רוֹעֵד מִקֹּר, בְּפֶתַח הַבַּיִת. "אַבָּא כְּבָר יָצָא!" - הוֹדִיעָה אִמּוֹ הָרַבָּנִית בְּפָנִים דּוֹאֲגוֹת, רַבִּי בָּרוּךְ דֹּב עוֹד הִסְפִּיק לִרְאוֹת אֶת דְּמוּתוֹ הַשְּׁפוּפָה שֶׁל אָבִיו מִתְרַחֶקֶת אֶל תּוֹךְ הַלַּיְלָה בַּדֶּרֶךְ הָעוֹלָה לַיְשִׁיבָה, הוּא הִבִּיט בְּאִמּוֹ הָרַבָּנִית, מַבָּט שֶׁל הֲבָנָה הִבְזִיק בְּעֵינֶיהָ, הֵבִינָה הָאֵם וְהֵבִין גַּם הַבֵּן מַדּוּעַ הִקְדִּים רַבִּי דָּוִד צֵאתוֹ מִן הַבַּיִת... חָשַׁשׁ רַבִּי דָּוִד כִּי בְּנוֹ הַדּוֹאֵג לוֹ יְנַסֶּה לְשַׁכְנְעוֹ לְהִשָּׁאֵר בַּבַּיִת, וְכֵיצַד יוּכַל לְבַטֵּל לַיְלָה שָׁלֵם שֶׁל לִמּוּד בַּיְשִׁיבָה? אֵיךְ אֶפְשָׁר לְהִינָּתֵק לְלַיְלָה שָׁלֵם מִמְּקוֹר הַחַיִּים? מִהֵר וְהִקְדִּים אֶת יְצִיאָתוֹ מִן הַבַּיִת לִפְנֵי שֶׁיַּסְפִּיק הַבֵּן לְהַגִּיעַ...רַק כְּשֶׁנּוֹדַע הַסִּפּוּר, נִפְתְּרָה הַתַּעֲלוּמָה, עַתָּה הֵבִינוּ הַבַּחוּרִים עַל מַה וְלָמָּה הוֹפִיעַ רֹאשׁ הַיְשִׁיבָה לְלִמּוּד חָמֵשׁ דַּקּוֹת קוֹדֶם הַזְּמַן בַּפַּעַם הָרִאשׁוֹנָה מִזֶּה עֶשְׂרִים שָׁנִים.הרה"ג ר' דָּנִיֵּאל אוֹחְיוֹן שְׁלִיטָ"א"אוֹר דָּנִיֵּאל" (בְּנֵי בְּרַק תשס"ד) חֵלֶק ד', עַמּוּד תפ"ד

I heard from my teacher [the Gaon Rabbi David Povarsky] zt"l on several occasions that he had a bit of a grievance regarding the fact that people are accustomed to calling his Mussar words "Shmuessen" (Talks). He told me that these are not "Sichot" (Conversations) but "Shiurim" (Lessons) - lessons on how to think thoughts, lessons on how to understand the words of Chazal.
Source: Kol Nehi Ariema (Bnei Brak 5759) p. 51

The close associates of our Rebbe [the Gaon Rabbi David Povarsky] zt"l told how much he sacrificed his soul for the observance of his Sedarim (schedules), in the study preceding prayer and the delivery of Shiurim in the Yeshiva, and the orders of prayer and Mussar in the Yeshiva. They told that when he was invited to officiate at a wedding, he would do so even though he complained about the burden falling upon him, but he sacrificed his soul for the joy of his students, the children of the Yeshiva. He requested that they arrange matters in a way that he could return for the beginning of the Mussar Seder in the Yeshiva. For to "fall in" for Maariv without preceding it with Mussar study, he could not do. And to enter in the middle of the Seder to the Yeshiva, he certainly could not do. Therefore, he requested greatly that they see to it that he could return for the beginning of the Mussar Seder. And so, with consistent vigilance, we saw him always persisting in prayers and Mussar in the Yeshiva.
A story happened with Maran HaGaon Rav David Povarsky zt"l, Rosh Yeshiva of Ponevezh, that he was attacked by illness and fell bedridden. Expert doctors who were summoned to his bedside determined that he must take certain medications. The household members were very worried when they realized that even after he fulfilled the doctors' words and took the medications, his condition went and worsened.
Suddenly, the Rosh Yeshiva turned to the doctor standing by his side and asked if he could take a Gemara and look into it, for then he would certainly feel better. The doctor answered in the negative and explained that the exertion would harm his health. However, when HaGaon Rav David felt that the illness continued to worsen, he did not heed the doctor's warnings and entered his library room and began to learn as was his habit from days of yore.
Within a short time, his head and most of him were immersed in the Sugya. The doctor left the house while warning those present that the actions of the patient were liable to cause further deterioration in the situation. But what could be done; after half an hour in which the Rosh Yeshiva was immersed in study, his condition improved immeasurably.
He himself explained afterwards to his household members: "A Jew who is accustomed almost from the day of his birth to sit by the books, since you took away this pleasure from him, you cut him off from the thread of his life..."
Source: Aleinu LeShabeach (Bnei Brak 5764) Part 1, p. 46
