I met an Avreich (young married man), one of the Yeshiva students, and he told me that in his youth, a story happened: When his eldest daughter was born, the Rosh Yeshiva [the Gaon Rabbi David Povarsky zt"l] sent him a sum of money for household expenses (as is known, the Rosh Yeshiva used to care for Avreichim to ease their household burden in an honorable way). The Avreich did not feel comfortable receiving financial support, so he went up to the Rosh Yeshiva's house. The Rosh Yeshiva opened the door for him and asked him the purpose of his coming. The Avreich said to him regarding what the Rosh Yeshiva sent... The Rosh Yeshiva said to him: "It's okay, it's okay..." and closed the door.
Some time later, on Erev Yom Kippur, when that Avreich approached the Rosh Yeshiva to wish him a Good Year, the Rosh Yeshiva asked him for forgiveness for the fact that when he was at his house, perhaps he did not treat him with enough honor because he immediately closed the door. What gentleness and what feeling lies in this story! This Avreich felt uncomfortable and barely arrived at the Rosh Yeshiva's house, and certainly there was no insult to his honor when the Rosh Yeshiva dismissed him immediately. Yet, the Rosh Yeshiva felt a need to apologize, and this was after a period of time had passed; the feeling of lack of respect for another was still engraved in his heart.
That Avreich tells me: Some years later, at the birth of one of the children, the Rosh Yeshiva sent him a sum of money. Then he met the Rosh Yeshiva in the street and approached him and said to him that it seems to him that he has no need for this support. Then the Rosh Yeshiva answered him with the sweetness of his tongue: "How many children do you have? How much does your wife earn?" and other such questions. "How can you say that you have enough, for your children it is not enough..." The Rosh Yeshiva, who hovered in high worlds with other concepts, yet when it came to others, behold he entered into details and details of details out of an objective approach.
Source: Kol Nehi Ariema (Bnei Brak 5759) p. 55

body_he: מְסַפֵּר לִי אוֹתוֹ אַבְרֵךְ, לְאַחַר כַּמָּה שָׁנִים בְּלֵידַת א' הַיְלָדִים שָׁלַח לוֹ הָרֹאשׁ יְשִׁיבָה סְכוּם כֶּסֶף, וְאָז פָּגַשׁ אֶת הָרֹאשׁ יְשִׁיבָה בָּרְחוֹב וְנִגַּשׁ אֵלָיו וְאָמַר לוֹ שֶׁנִּרְאֶה לוֹ שֶׁאֵין לוֹ צֹרֶךְ בַּתְּמִיכָה הַזּוֹ, וְאָז עָנָה לוֹ הָרֹאשׁ יְשִׁיבָה בְּמֶתֶק לְשׁוֹנוֹ: כַּמָּה יְלָדִים יֵשׁ לְךָ, כַּמָּה אִשְׁתְּךָ מַרְוִיחָה, וְעוֹד שְׁאֵלוֹת כַּיּוֹצֵא בָּאֵלּוּ, אֵיךְ הִנְּךָ יָכוֹל לוֹמַר שֶׁיֵּשׁ לְךָ דַּי, לִילָדִים שֶׁלְּךָ אֵין מַסְפִּיק... הָרֹאשׁ יְשִׁיבָה שֶׁמְּרַחֵף בְּעוֹלָמוֹת גְּבוֹהִים, עִם מֻשָּׂגִים אֲחֵרִים, אַךְ מַה שֶּׁנּוֹגֵעַ לַאֲחֵרִים הֲרֵי הוּא נִכְנַס לִפְרָטִים וּפְרָטֵי פְּרָטִים מִתּוֹךְ גִּישָׁה מְצִיאוּתִית.הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי צְבִי יְהוּדָה אֶדֶלְשְׁטֵיין שְׁלִיטָ"א"קוֹל נְהִי אֲרִימָה" (בְּנֵי בְּרַק תשנ"ט) עַמּוּד נ"ה
body_en:
I once spoke with the Gaon Rav David Povarsky zt"l about a young man who moved from Yeshiva to Yeshiva because he was not satisfied with the first place, and afterwards also there he was not satisfied, etc. The reaction of the HaGaon Rav David to this was that there is a certain bird in the cities of the sea with a very developed sense of smell, and it always seems to it that there is some bad smell in this place, and it wanders to another place, and so on forever. And it did not know that the bad smell came from itself... And understand this well.
Source: Kol HaTorah, Nissan 5760, p. 72

I heard that when he [the Gaon Rav Avraham David Yaakovzon zt"l] was sitting Shiva, the great Rosh Yeshiva, the Gaon Rav David Povarsky zt"l, arrived and said to them: "Listen, they are no longer here. For what did the Holy One, Blessed be He, institute Shiva? We always think maybe we could have saved, maybe we could have done more. There are always these feelings, most of which are unjustified. And if so, why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, make Shiva? Because every father has his uniqueness, his character traits, what can be learned from him. And so, in the flow of life, there is no time for this. They gave him seven days to contemplate. They exempted him from everything, forbade him even to learn, only the difficult things. Come concentrate on the father, come learn from him. The Evil Inclination is afraid of these moments. It does everything it can to distract the mind. Then he will give regret, and he will give more things, and he will do everything. The main thing is: do not take the main thing, go concentrate on the father..."
Source: Adir BaMarom (Bnei Brak 5764) p. 38

I remember what I heard from my teacher and Rabbi, Rabbi David Povarsky zt"l, on the verse: **כרחם אב על בנים רחם ה' על יראיו** - "As a father has mercy on children, so does the L-rd have mercy on those who fear Him" (Psalms 103:13). And he asked: Behold, the mercy of the mother on the children is greater than that of the father, as is known. And he told that when his son, HaGaon Rav Berel Povarsky, had to report to the Russian army (where it is known "None that go unto her return" - either spiritually or physically), he ordered him to fast for three days so that at the time of his examination for his fitness to serve, they would send him away on the spot due to his weakness. And behold, on the second day of his fast, when HaGaon Rav Berel was writhing in hunger, his mother approached him and said to him in a whisper: "Berel'e of mine, please come with me in secret and I will give you something so that father won't see." Even though she was a great woman.
And then he said that he understood the intention of the verse "As a father has mercy on children" specifically. That the Holy One, Blessed be He, has the mercy of the father to do for the person what is good for him, even if in the place where the emotion is, there is cruelty here. And it is actually intellectual mercy and perfect mercy.
Source: Zichron Moshe (Jerusalem 5769) p. 90

He was born in the year 5511 (1751) in the village of Szerencs. He was orphaned from his father, Rabbi Moshe Yechezkel, while still a lad of about 8 years old. Therefore, he was forced to shepherd his father's sheep and thereby support his widowed mother. The Holy Rabbi, Rav Leib Sarah's zya, recognized the greatness of his soul. He traveled to that village and paid his widowed mother so she would give him the lad to raise him. Rav Leib took him and brought him to the Holy Rabbi, Rav Shmelke of Nikolsburg zya, and there he grew into a great tree. [The compiler said: See below in story number "MiPi Sefarim V'Sofrim" for a different version of this].
In the year 5541 (1781), he stayed for some time in the city of Kalev (Nagykálló) and lodged in the home of my grandfather, Rav Yaakov Fisch zt"l. Even though at that time he was still hiding among the vessels (hidden), Rav Yaakov saw wondrous things in him. The Holy Rabbi stayed in the city of Kalev for 11 weeks. When he wanted to travel from there, Rav Yaakov asked that he remain in the city and the people of the city would accept him as Av Beit Din, and he would be their Rav and guide. The Holy Rabbi did not agree. Rav Yaakov said to him: "If so, I demand that you pay for the food and lodging you received in my house for the duration of the 11 weeks." He pressed him so much until he agreed and accepted upon himself the Rabbinate. Then the Holy Rabbi became famous, and the city of Kalev became a mound of mounds (a center of attraction), and he established many disciples there, righteous men and servants of G-d.
On the 7th of Adar, the day of the passing of Moshe Rabbeinu, the Man of G-d passed away in the year 5581 (1821). That year was a leap year, and he passed away in Adar II.
He commanded to engrave on his tombstone this language: "He could learn a page [of Gemara] and was an 'Erlicher Yid' (Honest Jew)." It is told that the reason he commanded to engrave "And was an Erlicher Yid" is that when he lodged in the house of my grandfather Rav Yaakov zt"l, Rav Yaakov asked him to merit to see Elijah the Prophet ZL"T. The Holy Rabbi promised him. Once, when they were walking together on the road, a certain gentile came towards them riding on a horse and spoke with the Holy Rabbi. In the end, he said to him in the Hungarian language "Braver Yid" and went on his way. Then the Holy Rabbi said to Rav Yaakov: "You saw Elijah the Prophet." And because he said to him "Braver Yid," he commanded to engrave on his tombstone "And was an Erlicher Yid." [So it is told, and I do not know if the words are reliable].
The Holy Rabbi, the Baal Divrei Chaim of Sanz zya, said that even after the passing of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev, holiness still rests in the city of Kalev, and he yearned to be the Av Beit Din there, but it did not work out. He was accustomed to speak much of the greatness of his holiness.
His Hillula day was in the country of Hungary like the Hillula of Rav Elimelech of Lizhensk zya in the country of Poland. From all ends of the country, they came to visit his holy marker, and all the Tzaddikim, the luminaries of each generation, came there on the day of the Hillula. Also, throughout the days of the year, they increased in coming and sending Kvitelach (notes) there.
Source: Avodat Avodah (Canada 5754) Part 1, p. 155-161

Our Rebbe, the Holy Baal Shem Tov zya, upon his return from the journey to our Holy Land (may it be built and established speedily in our days), a journey which he did not succeed in completing as is known, passed through the land of Hungary. He was in the city of Szerencs, Zemplén County [and it was then a market day]. At night, he delivered a sermon, and within his words, the Holy One said that there are wise men among the people, and they go to the market and do business there. Afterwards, they go to eat and drink, to hear musical instruments, and to delight in pleasures. However, the fools go in the opposite way: while still on their way to the market, before they have done any business, they already go to the musical instruments and lose there their capital and money on eating and drinking and the rest of the vain pleasures, remaining empty vessels without a penny to a penny. It turns out they lose the market as well. Thus he illustrated his parable by way of moral instruction regarding those who lose the Eternal World, the life of the World to Come, for the sake of the fleeting pleasures of this world.
And behold, during his stay in Szerencs, he lodged in the home of the Nagid, the officer Rav Moshe Yechezkel zt"l, who was a hospitable man and drew him very close. Before the Holy Baal Shem Tov continued on his way, he opened with honor for the host, to express his thanks and blessing for the good they had bestowed upon him. He asked them what was their request and petition. They answered and said that they were childless, G-d forbid, and their request and petition was to be visited with the matter of salvation and mercy with living and enduring offspring. He answered them that if they agreed to lose their wealth there, then they would be saved with the help of G-d with enduring offspring. Both of them agreed to the matter. Afterwards, he added and said to them that a son would be born to them who would illuminate the entire world.
So it was, and in the year 5511 (1751), Rav Moshe Yechezkel and his wife Mrs. Rizel were visited with a male son whom they named Yitzchak Eizik. However, a short time after the child was born, the father passed away. In the meantime, the wheel turned on him as well, and he lost his assets. When the child grew up, he helped support his poor mother through his work in shepherding sheep.
Source: Abir HaRo'im (Brooklyn 5755) p. 54

body_he: כָּךְ הֲוָה, וּבִשְׁנַת תקי"א לפ"ק נִפְקְדוּ ר' מֹשֶׁה יְחֶזְקֵאל וְאִשְׁתּוֹ מָרַת רִיזְל בְּבֵן זָכָר שֶׁקָּרְאוּ שְׁמוֹ יִצְחָק אַיְיזִיק. אוּלָם זְמַן קָצָר לְאַחַר שֶׁנּוֹלַד הַיֶּלֶד נִפְטַר הָאָב, אֲשֶׁר בֵּינְתַיִם גַּם נֶהְפַּךְ עָלָיו הַגַּלְגַּל וְיָרַד מִנְּכָסָיו, וּכְשֶׁגָּדַל הַיֶּלֶד הָיָה עוֹזֵר לְפַרְנָסַת אִמּוֹ הָעֲנִיָּה ע"י עֲבוֹדָתוֹ בְּמִרְעֵה הַצֹּאן.מִכְתְּבֵי הרה"ק רַבִּי מְנַחֵם שְׁלֹמֹה טוֹיְבּ מִקָּאלִיב זַצַ"ל"אַבִּיר הָרוֹעִים" (בְּרוּקְלִין תשנ"ה) עַמּוּד נ"ד
body_en:
It is worth noting the story of the approach of the Holy Rabbi, Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik of Kalev zya, to the light of Chassidut. Behold, it is accepted by the world that the Holy Rabbi of Kalev, when he was a young lad, was orphaned from his father and became a shepherd. With his flute, he would play well over the field for hours and days, until he met the Holy Rabbi, Rabbi Leib Sarah's zya, and he brought him to Nikolsburg to the Rabbi, Rav Shmelke zya. But there are many doubts regarding this version, for the Holy Rabbi of Kalev was not an orphan in his youth, and his father even merited to marry him off. Also, already in his infancy, a light shining within him was recognizable, and there are proofs for this. Furthermore, the versions of the story vary here. As I heard another version from my father, my teacher z"l, which was a tradition with him and is more acceptable, and this is its content:
The Holy Rabbi Moshe Leib of Sassov zya (who was also one of the disciples of the Holy Rabbi of Nikolsburg zya) happened once to be in the city of Szerencs, the place of residence of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev in those days. Before the Mincha prayer, the Holy Rabbi Moshe Leib walked, seized in his thoughts, while murmuring from the verses of the sacrifices: **את הכבש אחד תעשה בבקר ואת הכבש השני תעשה בין הערבים** - "The one lamb you shall offer in the morning, and the other lamb you shall offer at dusk" (Numbers 28:4). Like a flame of fire, he repeated the verse again and again, for indeed it is so that these two lambs are not a simple matter. The Holy Rabbi of Kalev was still young then, but when he noticed the conduct, he understood that there were things within. He gathered strength and approached Rabbi Moshe Leib and asked him: "Where does one take such lambs?" meaning, from where is this service, and who is the one teaching to say the sacrifices in this manner? Rabbi Moshe Leib took him to his Rabbi in Nikolsburg and showed him a source of living water to draw from for his soul. Indeed, for many years, the Holy Rabbi of Kalev drank with thirst the words of the Rabbi, Rav Shmelke, before his wedding and after. When he traveled to return to his home in Hungary after the wedding, in the blessing of parting, his Rabbi laid his hands upon him and blessed him. At the conclusion, he began to read the verses at the beginning of the Torah: "In the beginning G-d created etc." until "And G-d said, Let there be light, and there was light."
Regarding the Rabbinate he took upon his shoulders in the city of Kalev, it is told that one of the dignitaries and leaders of that city, the Gaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yaakov Fisch zt"l [whom the Holy Rabbi, Rabbi Chaim of Sanz zya, used to call "Der Heiliger Rabbi Yaakov Fisch"], worried for the sustenance of the household of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev all the days he stayed in the shadow of his Rabbi in Nikolsburg. For indeed, the Holy Rabbi of Kalev, during his stay with listening friends there, saw shining faces. In his ascent to the heights of the levels, he almost did not give his heart and mind to the needs of his home. But these were many and burdened Rabbi Yaakov the aforementioned on his shoulders. Upon his return to Kalev, Rabbi Yaakov asked him to accept upon himself the mantle of the Rabbinate in the city of Kalev and its districts. When he began to refuse, Rabbi Yaakov opened his mouth with wisdom and said: "Do you not know that the members of your household were sustained with all their needs all the days of your being in Nikolsburg by my hand? And behold, if you do not agree to the Rabbinate, then I will demand all my expenses. Only in this will I concede: if you wrap yourself in the cloak of the Rabbis to instruct the Children of Israel in our city." With no choice, he acceded to his urging. Indeed, he conducted his presidency with high standards to serve Israel for forty years [and see the Ran, Nedarim 33b, s.v. Gezeira, who brought in the name of the Rashba that one who supports his friend without specifying, returns and collects, that he did not support him except as a loan. If so, here too Rabbi Yaakov could have demanded his debt. And see further Tosafot Ketubot 108a s.v. Ha].
Source: Avodat Avodah (Canada 5754) Part 1, p. 155-161

body_he: אוֹדוֹת הָרַבָּנוּת שֶׁנָּטַל עַל שִׁכְמוֹ בְּעִיר קָאלִיב מְסֻפָּר, שֶׁאֶחָד מִיַּקִּירֵי וִישִׁישֵׁי הָעִיר הַזֹּאת, הרה"צ רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב פִישׁ זַצַ"ל [שֶׁהַרְהַ"ק רַבִּי חַיִּים מִצָּאנְז זִי"עַ הָיָה רָגִיל לְכַנּוֹתוֹ "דֶּער הֵיילִיגֶער רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב פִישׁ"] דָּאַג לְכַלְכָּלַת בֵּית הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב כָּל יְמֵי שִׁבְתּוֹ בְּצֵל רַבּוֹ בְּנִיקְלְשְׁבּוּרְג, כִּי אָמְנָם הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב בְּשִׁבְתּוֹ עִם חֲבֵרִים מַקְשִׁיבִים שָׁם, רָאָה פָּנִים מְאִירִים, וּבְהַעְפִּילוֹ בְּרוּם הַמַּדְרֵגוֹת כִּמְעַט שֶׁלֹּא נָתַן לִבּוֹ וְדַעְתּוֹ לְצָרְכֵי בֵּיתוֹ, אַךְ אֵלּוּ מְרֻבִּים הָיוּ וְהֶעֱמִיסָם רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב הַנַּ"ל עַל שִׁכְמוֹ, בְּשׁוּבוֹ לְקָאלִיב בִּקֵּשׁ מִמֶּנּוּ רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב שֶׁיְּקַבֵּל עַל עַצְמוֹ אֶת אַדֶּרֶת הָרַבָּנוּת בְּעִיר קָאלִיב וּבִגְלִילוֹתֶיהָ, וּכְשֶׁהִתְחִיל לְסָרֵב פָּתַח רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב פִּיו בְּחָכְמָה וְאָמַר: "הֲלֹא תֵּדַע כִּי בְּנֵי בֵּיתְךָ נִזּוֹנוּ כָּל צָרְכָּם כָּל יְמֵי הֱיוֹתְךָ בְּנִיקְלְשְׁבּוּרְג עַל יָדִי, וְהִנֵּה אִם לֹא תַּסְכִּים אֶל הָרַבָּנוּת אֲזַי אֶתְבַּע כָּל הוֹצָאוֹתַי, וְאַךְ בְּזֹאת אֲוַתֵּר אִם תִּתְעַטֵּף בְּאִיצְטְלָא דְּרַבָּנַן לְהוֹרוֹת אֶת בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּעִירֵנוּ", וּבְלֵית בְּרֵירָה נֶעְתַּר לְהַפְצָרָתוֹ, וְאָכֵן נָהַג נְשִׂיאוּתוֹ בְּרָמָה לְשָׁרֵת אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל כְּאַרְבָּעִים שָׁנָה [וְעַיֵּין רַ"ן נְדָרִים לג: ד"ה גְּזֵירָה, שֶׁהֵבִיא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּהָרַשְׁבָּ"א שֶׁהַמְּפַרְנֵס אֶת חֲבֵרוֹ בִּסְתָם חוֹזֵר וְגוֹבֶה שֶׁלֹּא פִרְנֵס אֶלָּא לְשֵׁם הַלְוָאָה, וְאִ"כּ ה"נ הָיָה יָכוֹל רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב לִתְבֹּעַ אֶת חוֹבוֹ. וְעַ"ע תּוֹס' כְּתוּבּוֹת קח. ד"ה הָא].הגה"ח רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר דָּוִד פְרִידְמָן שְׁלִיטָ"א"מִפִּי סְפָרִים וְסוֹפְרִים" (בְּנֵי בְּרַק תשס"ח) חֵלֶק ב', עַמּוּד י"ז
body_en:
The Holy Rabbi, Rav Yitzchak Eizik of Kalev, became a son-in-law to a great innkeeper. Rav Eizik asked that he give him a separate room inside the inn so he could learn and pray and serve G-d in quiet and tranquility. He also asked his father-in-law not to disturb him in the aforementioned matters and not to open the door of the room when he was there. In time, the Holy Rabbi, Rav Moshe Leib of Sassov zya, arrived at the inn there. There were nine men together with him, and they wanted to pray the Mincha prayer and looked for a tenth for the minyan. The innkeeper thought to himself that now, with no choice, he would disturb his son-in-law even in the middle of study due to the honor of the Holy Rabbi, Rav Moshe Leib.
And so it was that they joined the Holy Rabbi, Rav Eizik'l, to the minyan. When Rabbi Moshe Leib said the portion of the sacrifices - **את הכבש אחד תעשה בבקר ואת הכבש השני תעשה בין הערבים** - "The one lamb you shall offer in the morning, and the other lamb you shall offer at dusk" (Numbers 28:4) - Rabbi Eizik was very moved. After the prayer, he asked the Holy Rabbi, Rabbi Moshe Leib: "Vu nemt men azelche shefelech?" (Where does one get such lambs?). He answered him: "By the Rabbi, Rav Shmelke of Nikolsburg." Then the Holy Rabbi, Rav Eizik of Kalev, traveled to the Rabbi, Rav Shmelke of Nikolsburg, and there he drew close to the path of Chassidut.
Source: Malchut Beit David (Ramat-Lelov Bnei Brak) Tammuz 5765, p. 67

The Holy Gaon of Kalev zya (who, besides his great righteousness famous to all, was also a Genius of Geniuses, and two hundred and eighty communities belonged to his Rabbinical district and were under his authority; he was a disciple of the Holy Gaon, Rav Shmelke zya, and in the Responsa "Keter Kehuna" there is a response to him describing him with wondrous titles) suffered terrible afflictions. Living worms swarmed under his skin, and his whole body was full of wounds and boils, until he could not bear clothes upon himself. They had to make for him clothes light as paper. Sometimes the suffering overcame him until he was forced to take off even these clothes. Except for Shabbat and Yom Tov, on which he was like any other man, for he made a condition upon accepting the suffering that on Shabbat and Yom Tov he would have rest. After lighting the candles, he would wear Shabbat clothes, and immediately after Havdalah, he already had to take them off due to the magnitude of the suffering.
He said in his holy humility: "Behold, the Messiah is pierced for our transgressions and suffers for the iniquities of Israel (as explained in Sanhedrin 98a). And I do not want the Messiah to suffer for my sins, therefore I accepted the suffering upon myself." End of his holy words. And to the understanding person, it is easy [to understand] that for the sins of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev, the Messiah does not suffer. Rather, through his suffering, he eased the burden of the King Messiah who is pierced for our transgressions. And who knows what part of the world he protected with his suffering.
Source: Divrei Torah, Tetzaveh 5749, p. 8

I heard this story from my father, the Av Beit Din of 'Neveh Achiezer' zt"l, who heard it from his grandfather, the Holy Rabbi, author of 'Midrash Aharon' of Benedekowitz zt"l. When the people of the city of Kalev desired to take for themselves the Holy Rabbi, Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik zya, to serve in glory as the Rav of their city "Kalev" and its districts, they turned to him, and with them was a 'Letter of Rabbinate' in his honor. Signed upon it were all the heads, dignitaries, and leaders of the city. Even from the districts of the city "Szabolcs," they signed the letter. All of them as one agreed to crown our Rebbe with the crown of Rabbinate in this entire region of the land. Except for one remote village in the districts of the city, where the majority of its inhabitants were ignorant people of low standing. The residents of this village did not want to sign the Letter of Rabbinate, and their argument was in their mouths: "What do we have to do with the Rav of the big city? It is far from us. Surely the important Rav will not trouble himself among the mountains and hills to pound his feet to us. Questions that happen to us in Halacha, it is enough for us if we ask the mouth of the Shochet who happens into the village occasionally. Even at weddings, marriages, and eulogies, we will not merit to see him. If so, what do we have to do with this Rav?!"...
The dignitaries of the city brought the letter before our Rebbe, and they desired to receive his agreement to be crowned with the crown of Rabbinate. But our Rebbe, noticing that the residents of this village did not sign the letter, desired to know the meaning of the matter. They laid out before him the argument of the villagers. When our Rebbe heard these grievances, our Rebbe obligated himself with a full mouth that with the help of G-d, he would always come to participate and adorn the celebrations that they would conduct in this village. After this obligation, even the people of this village agreed to sign the 'Letter of Rabbinate'. Now our Rebbe's title was complete, and our Rebbe agreed - to the joy of heart and satisfaction of all of them - to accept upon himself the yoke of the Rabbinate in the city of 'Kalev' and its districts.
And it was the day, and that day was the eve of Chanukah. Behold, one of the men of that village appeared before our Rebbe and invited him with honor and splendor to participate in the celebration of the engagement of his offspring which would take place with the help of G-d inside the village. The cold was great, and the frost even glazed the ground. The travels of the road to this village were hard and exhausting. But our Rebbe - faithful to his promise - began making his way to that village to participate in the engagement celebration. Our Rebbe arrived at the village, and behold, he found himself in the company of villagers and simple folk, poor in understanding and lacking in stature, far a great distance from his regular surroundings - the congregation of his Chassidim and students. There our Rebbe lit the Chanukah candles. Understandably, he had anguish of the soul - for what and why did he need this travel. But understandably - he would not change his word, and according to all that came out of his mouth, he would do.
The joy and excitement among the residents of the village were great, for they merited that our Rebbe would participate in the engagement meal. When the engagement meal arrived, all the men of the village came in their multitudes to the celebration. Our Rebbe sat at the head of the table and began arranging the 'Tena'im' (conditions of engagement) document as is customary.
They reached the place of the witnesses' signature. He began looking for two valid witnesses to sign this document. But quickly it became clear to him that the residents of the village did not know at all how to read and write in the Holy Tongue, and they could not sign their names except in the vernacular. Understandably, our Rebbe did not desire this. What did our Rebbe do? He began investigating and inquiring after the names of the Jewish residents, until he reached one Jew named Levi. Our Rebbe thought to himself: 'If so, I will be one witness, and this Jew named Levi, I will teach him to sign his name. After all, it is a short and easy name to grasp, and he will be the second witness'...
Our Rebbe began to teach this Jew the letters of writing the name 'Levi': "Listen and hear, all you have to do is write a long line, and that is 'Lamed'. Afterwards, you will write a shorter line, and that is the letter 'Vav'. Afterwards, you will make a small line, and that is the letter 'Yud'."
How great was the joy of this Jew, for from now on he would be the only one among the Jews of the village who knows how to sign his name in the Holy Tongue. He would be the 'Talmid Chacham' of the village. But one thing he did not know: that in the Holy Tongue - unlike all foreign languages - one writes from right to left, and not from left to right. The villager began to scribble with enthusiasm as requested - a long line, a medium one, and a short one.
But when our Rebbe looked at his signature, behold the Jew did not write "Levi" but "Yavan" (Greece - Yud, Vav, Nun sofit) from left to right as was his habit... Our Rebbe almost despaired from this. But suddenly his face took on enthusiasm, his eyes flashed lightning, and he called out in a loud voice:
"Now I know what the war of the Hasmoneans against the Greeks was! For the Hasmoneans are the opposite of the Greeks. Look and see, behold on this page the Jew wrote 'Yavan' (Greece). However, when we turn the page to its other side, we will find the name 'Levi'. Here we have it, that the Levites - the chosen tribe - are the tribe of the Hasmoneans, they are the opposite of the Greeks..."
Source: Avodat Avodah (Canada 5769) Part 2, p. 173

אֶת הַכְּתָב, הֵבִיאוּ טוֹבֵי הָעִיר לִפְנֵי רַבֵּינוּ, וְחָפְצוּ לְקַבֵּל אֶת הַסְכָּמָתוֹ לְהִתְעַטֵּר בְּכֶתֶר הָרַבָּנוּת. אַךְ רַבֵּינוּ, בְּהַבְחִינוֹ כִּי תּוֹשְׁבֵי הַכְּפָר הַלָּזֶה לֹא חָתְמוּ עַל הַכְּתָב, חָפֵץ לָדַעַת אֶת פֵּשֶׁר הַדָּבָר, כַּאֲשֶׁר שָׁטְחוּ לְפָנָיו אֶת טַעֲנָתָם שֶׁל אַנְשֵׁי הַכְּפָר. כַּאֲשֶׁר שָׁמַע רַבֵּינוּ טְרוּנְיוֹת אֵלּוּ, הִתְחַיֵּב רַבֵּינוּ בְּפֶה מָלֵא, כִּי בְּעֶזְרַת הַשֵּׁם יָבוֹא תָּמִיד לְהִשְׁתַּתֵּף וּלְפָאֵר אֶת הַשְּׂמָחוֹת אֲשֶׁר יַעַרְכוּ בִּכְפָר זֶה, אַחַר הִתְחַיְּבוּת זוֹ נֵאוֹתוּ אַף אַנְשֵׁי כְּפָר זֶה לַחְתֹּם עַל 'כְּתָב הָרַבָּנוּת', עַתָּה הָיְתָה הַכְתָּרָתוֹ שֶׁל רַבֵּינוּ שְׁלֵמָה, וְנֵאוֹת רַבֵּינוּ - לְשִׂמְחַת לֵב וּשְׂבִיעוּת רָצוֹן כֻּלָּם - לְקַבֵּל עַל עַצְמוֹ אֶת עֹל הָרַבָּנוּת בְּעִיר 'קָאלִיב' וּגְלִילוֹתֶיהָ.
וַיְהִי הַיּוֹם, וְאוֹתוֹ יוֹם עֶרֶב חֲנֻכָּה הָיָה, וְהִנֵּה אֶחָד מֵאַנְשֵׁי הַכְּפָר הַהוּא, מוֹפִיעַ לִפְנֵי רַבֵּינוּ וּמַזְמִינוּ בְּכָבוֹד וּבְהָדָר לְהִשְׁתַּתֵּף בְּשִׂמְחַת אֵירוּסֵי צֶאֱצָאָיו אֲשֶׁר יְקַיֵּם בְּעֶזְרַת הַשֵּׁם בְּתוֹכְכִי הַכְּפָר. הַקֹּר הָיָה גָּדוֹל, וְהַכְּפוֹר אַף הוּא הִגְלִיד עַל הָאָרֶץ. טִלְטוּלֵי הַדֶּרֶךְ לִכְפָר זֶה הָיוּ קָשִׁים וּמַתִּישִׁים, אַךְ רַבֵּינוּ - נֶאֱמָן לְהַבְטָחָתוֹ - הֵחֵל עוֹשֶׂה אֶת דַּרְכּוֹ, אֶל אוֹתוֹ כְּפָר, לְהִשְׁתַּתֵּף בְּשִׂמְחַת הָאֵירוּסִין. רַבֵּינוּ הִגִּיעַ לַכְּפָר, וְהִנֵּה מוֹצֵא הוּא אֶת עַצְמוֹ בִּסְבִיבַת אֲנָשִׁים כַּפְרִיִּים וּפְשׁוּטֵי עָם, דַּלֵּי הַשָּׂגָה וּמְעוּטֵי מַעֲלָה, רָחוֹק מֶרְחָק רַב מִסּוֹבְבָיו הַתְּמִידִיִּים - קְהַל חֲסִידָיו וְתַלְמִידָיו, שָׁם הִדְלִיק רַבֵּינוּ אֶת נֵרוֹת הַחֲנֻכָּה, וְכַמּוּבָן כִּי עָגְמַת נֶפֶשׁ הָיְתָה לוֹ - עַל מַה וְלָמָּה הוּצְרַךְ לְטִלְטוּל זֶה. אַךְ כַּמּוּבָן - שֶׁאֶת דְּבָרוֹ לֹא יְשַׁנֶּה, וּכְכָל הַיּוֹצֵא מִפִּיו יַעֲשֶׂה.
הַשִּׂמְחָה וְהַהִתְרַגְּשׁוּת בֵּין תּוֹשְׁבֵי הַכְּפָר גְּדוֹלָה הָיְתָה, עַל כִּי זָכוּ לְכָךְ שֶׁרַבֵּינוּ יִשְׁתַּתֵּף בִּסְעוּדַת הָאֵירוּסִין. בְּהַגִּיעַ סְעוּדַת הָאֵירוּסִין, בָּאוּ כָּל אַנְשֵׁי הַכְּפָר בַּהֲמוֹנֵיהֶם אֶל הַשִּׂמְחָה, רַבֵּינוּ יָשַׁב בְּרֹאשׁ הַשֻּׁלְחָן, וְהֵחֵל מְסַדֵּר אֶת 'שְׁטַר הַתְּנָאִים' כַּנָּהוּג.הִגִּיעוּ לִמְקוֹם חֲתִימַת הָעֵדִים, הִתְחִיל מְבַקֵּשׁ אַחַר שְׁנֵי עֵדִים כְּשֵׁרִים לַחְתֹּם עַל כְּתָב זֶה, אַךְ עַד מְהֵרָה הִתְבָּרֵר לוֹ, כִּי תּוֹשְׁבֵי הַכְּפָר, אֵינָם יוֹדְעִים כְּלָל קְרוֹא וּכְתוֹב בִּלְשׁוֹן הַקּוֹדֶשׁ, וְאֵינָם יְכוֹלִים לַחְתֹּם אֶת שְׁמָם אֶלָּא בְּלוֹעֲזִית, וְכַמּוּבָן כִּי בְּכָךְ לֹא חָפֵץ רַבֵּינוּ. מָה עָשָׂה רַבֵּינוּ, הִתְחִיל חוֹקֵר וְדוֹרֵשׁ אַחַר שְׁמוֹתֵיהֶם הַיְּהוּדִים שֶׁל הַתּוֹשָׁבִים, עַד שֶׁהִגִּיעַ לִיהוּדִי אֶחָד בְּשֵׁם לֵוִי, סָבַר רַבֵּינוּ לְעַצְמוֹ: 'אִם כָּךְ, אֶהְיֶה אֲנִי עֵד אֶחָד, וִיהוּדִי זֶה הַמְּכוּנֶה לֵוִי, אֲלַמְּדוֹ לַחְתֹּם אֶת שְׁמוֹ, הֲרֵי שֵׁם קָצָר וְקַל לִקְלִיטָה הוּא, וְהוּא יִהְיֶה עֵד הַשֵּׁנִי'... הֵחֵל רַבֵּינוּ לְלַמֵּד אֶת יְהוּדִי זֶה אֶת אוֹתִיּוֹת כְּתִיבַת הַשֵּׁם 'לֵוִי': הַסְכֵּת וּשְׁמַע, כָּל שֶׁעָלֶיךָ לַעֲשׂוֹת הוּא לִכְתֹּב קַו אָרֹךְ, וְזֶהוּ 'ל', וְאַחַ"כּ תִּכְתֹּב קַו קָצָר יוֹתֵר וְזֶה הָאוֹת 'ו', וְאַחַר תַּעֲשֶׂה קַו קָטָן וְזֶהוּ הָאוֹת 'י'.
מַה רַבָּה הָיְתָה שִׂמְחָתוֹ שֶׁל יְהוּדִי זֶה, כִּי מֵעַתָּה יְהֵא הַיְּחִידִי בֵּין יְהוּדֵי הַכְּפָר הַיּוֹדֵעַ לַחְתֹּם אֶת שְׁמוֹ בִּלְשׁוֹן הַקּוֹדֶשׁ, הוּא יִהְיֶה הַ'תַּלְמִיד חָכָם' שֶׁל הַכְּפָר, אַךְ דָּבָר אֶחָד לֹא יָדַע, כִּי בִּלְשׁוֹן הַקּוֹדֶשׁ - בְּנִגּוּד לְכָל הַשָּׂפוֹת הַלּוֹעֲזִיּוֹת - כּוֹתְבִים מִיָּמִין לִשְׂמֹאל, וְלֹא מִשְּׂמֹאל לְיָמִין, הִתְחִיל הַכַּפְרִי מְשַׁרְבֵּט בְּהִתְלַהֲבוּת כְּפִי שֶׁהִתְבַּקֵּשׁ - קַו אָרֹךְ, בֵּינוֹנִי וְקָצָר.אַךְ כַּאֲשֶׁר הִבִּיט רַבֵּינוּ בַּחֲתִימָתוֹ, וְהִנֵּה הַיְּהוּדִי לֹא כָּתַב "לֵוִי" אֶלָּא "יוּן" מִשְּׂמֹאל לְיָמִין כְּהֶרְגֵּלוֹ... כִּמְעַט וּכְבָר הִתְיָאֵשׁ רַבֵּינוּ מִכָּךְ, אַךְ לְפֶתַע לָבְשׁוּ פָנָיו הִתְלַהֲבוּת, עֵינָיו יָרְקוּ בְּרָקִים וְקָרָא בְּקוֹל:"עַתָּה יָדַעְתִּי מַה הָיְתָה מִלְחַמְתָּם שֶׁל הַחַשְׁמוֹנָאִים בַּיְּוָנִים, כִּי הַחַשְׁמוֹנָאִים, הִיפּוּכָם שֶׁל הַיְּוָנִים הֵם. הַבִּיטוּ וּרְאוּ, הִנֵּה עַל דַּף זֶה כָּתַב הַיְּהוּדִי "יוּן" אוּלָם כַּאֲשֶׁר נַהֲפֹךְ אֶת הַדַּף לְצִדּוֹ הָאַחֵר נִמְצָא אֶת הַשֵּׁם "לֵוִי", הֲרֵי לָנוּ, כִּי הַלְּוִיִּים - הַשֵּׁבֶט הַנִּבְחָר - שִׁבְטָם שֶׁל הַחַשְׁמוֹנָאִים - הִיפּוּכָם שֶׁל הַיְּוָנִים הֵם"...הגה"צ רַבִּי דָּוִד מֵאִיר וַוייס שְׁלִיטָ"א(מֵרְשִׁימוֹת הָרַב יְהוֹשֻׁעַ הֶעשִׁיל קָטִינָא שְׁלִיטָ"א)"עוֹלָם הַחֲסִידוּת", אֲדָר-ב תשס"ח, עַמּוּד 20

Regarding the holiness of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev and his levels, I heard from the C"K Admor the Holy Rabbi of Bobov Hy"d, that once the Holy Rabbi of Kalev sat with his group, and during one of the conversations he said: "If I would give one sigh in truth, we would already merit the Redemption!..." The students did not dare to ask for this, only hinted to him: "Please..." meaning, why is it not honorable for him to sigh? The Rabbi answered them and said: "But what can I do that I cannot sigh..." And the Holy Rabbi of Bobov concluded: In this, one sees the greatness of the level of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev in accepting suffering with love. For behold, he suffered all his days from a severe skin disease in his flesh, and all his days he was crushed with great suffering from this, until he could not wear anything but a thin tunic of silk. And with all this, he apologized that he did not know what a sigh was...
Source: Pi Tzaddik (Brooklyn 5750) p. 251

It was [the Holy Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik of Kalev zya], a master of great service who elevated all the people of his surroundings. He was a master of great suffering - he suffered severely in his skin. When a doctor visited him, the doctor asked him how a human born of woman could be capable of bearing such suffering. He answered him that it is brought that suffering cleanses the sins of a person. If so, their value is very sublime. And automatically, the suffering that has already passed over me is for me a very great pleasure, for behold they 'cleanse' and I am happy that I merited these sufferings. And the pleasure that I have from the cleansing of sins that passed over me, this itself gives me the strength to suffer and accept upon myself more suffering for the next moment.
Source: Milin Kadishin (Jerusalem 5767) Part 3, p. 263

Rabbi Eizik of Kalev was accustomed to suffering from his youth until his old age. A doctor asked him: "How can a person bear suffering always?"
Rabbi Eizik answered: "The suffering that is in the past does not hurt. The suffering that is in the future - who worries about future pain? There remains the suffering that is in the present - suffering of a moment. And who cannot bear suffering for a moment?..."
Source: Chassidim Mesaprim (Jerusalem 5739) Part 1, p. 137

The Holy Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik of Kalev used to come to immerse every Holy Sabbath eve in the Mikvah of the Holy Ari in the Holy City of Safed. Once he took with him his attendant, Rabbi Yaakov Fisch, but forgot to bring him back. When Rabbi Yaakov left the Mikvah, he saw Jews wearing white clothes according to the custom of the Land of Israel. He was very surprised and asked where he was. They told him that he was in the city of Safed. He was very terrified: how did he get to Safed? At the conclusion of Shabbat, he went outside the city and found the Holy Rabbi of Kalev. He said to him: "I forgot you, come with me back." And he returned him to his city and his home.
Source: Ma'amar Mordechai (Jerusalem 5762) Part 2, p. 171

וּבְכֹחוֹ הַגָּדוֹל הַזֶּה פָּעַל לְתַקֵּן הַיַּהֲדוּת בְּכָל מְדִינַת אוּנְגַארִין, וְהֶעֱמִיד בָּהּ הַדָּת עַל תִּלָּהּ, וְתִיקֵּן שָׁם עִנְיְנֵי דְּמָתָא, מַה שֶּׁלֹּא עָלְתָה לְהַרְבֵּה רַבָּנִים לְתַקֵּן טֶרֶם בּוֹאוֹ, כְּגוֹן רִקּוּדֵי תַּעֲרוֹבוֹת אֲנָשִׁים וְנָשִׁים בְּשִׂמְחַת נִשּׂוּאִין, הָיָה נָפוֹץ מְאֹד בִּמְדִינַת אוּנְגַארִין, עַד שֶׁהוּא תִּיקֵּן בְּעִירוֹ קָאלִיב וּבְכָל הַגְּלִילוֹת סָבִיב, שֶׁלֹּא יַעַרְכוּ שׁוּם חֲתֻנּוֹת בִּלְעָדָיו, וְכַאֲשֶׁר בָּא אֶל הַחֲתֻנּוֹת, הִפְרִיד שָׁם עִם מַקְלוֹ בֵּין אֲנָשִׁים לְנָשִׁים, וְלֹא נָח וְלֹא שָׁקַט עַד שֶׁתִּיקֵּן הַדָּבָר, וּבְכֹחַ זֶה הִצְלִיחוּ עוֹד רַבָּנִים שֶׁבַּמְּדִינָה לְתַקֵּן הַדָּבָר בְּעַיְירוֹת שֶׁלָּהֶם.
וּבְכָל עִיר וָעִיר אֲשֶׁר הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב שָׁבַת שָׁם אֲפִילּוּ רַק פַּעַם אַחַת, הִתְחִילוּ לְהִתְפַּלֵּל שָׁם בְּנֻסַּח סְפָרַד כְּמִנְהַג הַחֲסִידִים, כִּי בְּשִׁבְתּוֹ שָׁם בְּשַׁבָּת אַחַת לְבַד, הִצְלִיחַ לְהַטּוֹת כָּל כָּךְ אֶת לְבָבוֹת בְּנֵי הָעִיר אֵלָיו, עַד שֶׁהִתְחִילוּ לְהִתְנַהֵג כְּמוֹהוּ. וּכְגוֹן עִיר נִיר-מַאדֶע, הָיְתָה מְיוּשֶּׁבֶת כֻּלָּהּ בַּאֲנָשִׁים מִבְּנֵי גְּלִיל הָעֶלְיוֹן (אוֹיבֶּערְלַאנְד), אֲשֶׁר הִתְפַּלְּלוּ בְּנֻסַּח אַשְׁכְּנַז, וּמִיּוֹם שֶׁשָּׁבַת שָׁם הרה"ק, הִתְפַּלְּלוּ אַף בְּבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת הַגָּדוֹל שֶׁבָּעִיר בְּנֻסַּח סְפָרַד, וְכָךְ זָכָה הרה"ק לַהֲפֹךְ קְהִלּוֹת שְׁלֵמוֹת לְדֶרֶךְ הַתּוֹרָה וְהַיִּרְאָה, עַל פִּי דֶּרֶךְ הַחֲסִידוּת.
וְלָכֵן סָרוּ לְמִשְׁמַעְתּוֹ הַרְבֵּה גְּאוֹנִים וְצַדִּיקִים, אַף הָנֵי דְּקַדִּישֵׁי מִינֵיהּ. וְהָיָה מַעֲשֶׂה בְּאִשָּׁה אַחַת בִּגְלִילוֹת הָעִיר קָאלִיב, אֲשֶׁר הָיְתָה עֲגוּנָה מִבַּעְלָהּ כַּמָּה שָׁנִים, וְעֵדִים הֵעִידוּ שֶׁבַּעְלָהּ מֵת, אֲבָל הָיְתָה שְׁאֵלָה אִם אֶפְשָׁר לִסְמֹךְ עַל עֵדוּתָם, וְכַמָּה גְּדוֹלִים נָשְׂאוּ וְנָתְנוּ בַּדָּבָר, וּלְבַסּוֹף הִתִּירוּהָ לְהִנָּשֵׂא, וְרֹאשׁ הַמַּתִּירִים הָיָה הַגָּאוֹן מִטְּרִישְׁט זַ"ל בַּעַל שׁוּ"ת שֶׁמֶן רוֹקֵחַ, אֲבָל הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב הִתְנַגֵּד וְיָצָא נֶגֶד הַהֶתֵּר זֶה בְּתֹקֶף. וְאֶחָד מִגְּדוֹלֵי וּקְדוֹשֵׁי הַדּוֹר זִי"עַ שֶׁבַּיָּמִים הָהֵם, עָרַךְ מִכְתָּב אָרֹךְ אֶל הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב, שֶׁיּוֹדִיעַ לוֹ הַטַּעַם לָמָּה הוּא מִתְנַגֵּד לְהֶתֵּר זֶה, וּמְעַגֵּן אֶת הָאִשָּׁה בְּחִנָּם, וְאִם לֹא יוֹדִיעַ לוֹ טַעַם אִיסּוּרוֹ, יֵצֵא נֶגְדּוֹ בְּמַקְלוֹ. הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב לֹא עָנָה עַל זֶה דָּבָר, וְעָמַד בְּדַעְתּוֹ לֶאֱסֹר. לְבַסּוֹף בָּא בַּעְלָהּ שֶׁל הָאִשָּׁה לְבֵיתוֹ חַי, וְאָז הֵבִינוּ לְמַפְרֵעַ טַעְמוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב, שֶׁרָאָה זֹאת בְּרוּחַ קָדְשׁוֹ, וְעַל יְדֵי מַעֲשֶׂה זֶה נִתְפַּרְסֵם שְׁמוֹ בְּיוֹתֵר בְּכָל הַמְּדִינוֹת (עַיֵּן אִגְּרוֹת סוֹפְרִים חֵלֶק ב' מִכְתָּב מ').כ"ק מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר מִטַּאהֶעשׁ זצוק"ל"עֲבוֹדַת עֲבוֹדָה" (קַאנַאדַא תשס"ט) חֵלֶק ב', עַמּוּד קע"ג

It is known about the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya that in the middle of prayer, he would place his hands on the flesh of his holy heart [and it is known that he suffered terrible afflictions from an illness where worms swarmed under his skin, and one of the Tzaddikim said about him that he was on the level of Adam the First before the sin]. For due to the great purification of his body, the matter of impurity due to touching covered places was not applicable to him. Since all his flesh turned to be holy like an angel. And like that which is brought in the holy book "Orach LaTzaddik" (Parashat Tazria), that he heard several times from his holy father, our Rebbe the Rabbi Rav Elimelech zya, who said: "Would that a person have a pure soul, refined like my body."
Source: Divrei Torah, Chukat 5748, p. 4

The Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya sent the "Mar'eh Yechezkel" to serve as Rav in Karlsburg. But he answered that there is already a Rav serving there. Nevertheless, the Holy Rabbi of Kalev said that he should travel there. Indeed, by the time the "Mar'eh Yechezkel" zya arrived in Karlsburg, the Rav who was serving had already passed away.
Source: Betzila D'Mehemnuta, Shelach 5767, p. 2

Rabbi Yaakov Rosenfeld a.h. was the father of Rabbi Shmuel Rosenfeld zt"l, known as Rav Shmuel Teglasher, one of the founders of the settlement in Teglash. His origin was from Galicia, and he sheltered in the holy shadow of the C"K Holy Gaon Rabbi Menachem Mendel of Rimanov zya, who lived in those days in the city of Frysztak. Likewise, he sheltered with other holy Tzaddikim of the towns there, until he went into exile from the city of his residence.
Regarding the reason for his emigration from his place of residence, it is accepted among the family members that once a quarrel broke out between two gentiles near the courtyard of Rav Yaakov's house. One of them killed his friend and threw him into his courtyard. Rabbi Yaakov feared greatly from the threat of the neighbors and the gentiles and from the fear of the authorities. Immediately, he fled from his place of residence to the lands of Hungary and settled in the city of Kalev, in his desire to shelter in the holy shadow of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya, and he cleaved to him as a Chassid to his Rebbe.
Regarding the manner of his attachment and his coming to the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya, it is told that in that period, the Holy Rabbi, the Maggid of Kozhnitz zya, was in the lands of Hungary. It was his desire to go visit the Holy Rabbi of Kalev. Rav Yaakov z"l joined him on his way, and they traveled together to greet the Holy Rabbi of Kalev. In order to reach Kalev, they had to pass through the city of H. Mad. There was a crossroads there, and one of them led to Kalev. Since they did not know which was the correct path, the Holy Rabbi of Kozhnitz zya used the sense of smell (which, as is known, his Rebbe the Holy Rabbi Rav Elimelech zya granted him as an inheritance - the sense of smell). When the Maggid of Kozhnitz zya smelled the paths, he said: "Here, this is the path that leads to the city of Kalev."
When the Holy Rabbi of Kozhnitz zya arrived at the home of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya, he took Rav Yaakov z"l to accompany him to the room of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev. When they opened the door of the room of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev, they found him circling from corner to corner in his holy room, walking in dveykut (cleaving to G-d), saying with enthusiasm the verse: **את הכבש אחד תעשה בבקר ואת הכבש השני תעשה בין הערבים** - "The one lamb you shall offer in the morning, and the other lamb you shall offer at dusk" (Numbers 28:4), asking himself: "Vi nemt men di zvei shefelech" (Where does one get the two lambs?). Afterwards, the Holy Rabbi of Kalev turned his face to them and received them with love and affection, extending his holy hand to them in greeting.
As mentioned, since then Rav Yaakov moved his residence to the city of Kalev. There he married in a second marriage his wife Mrs. Rachel a.h. and remained living there until the day of his passing.
In the year 5559 (1799), a son was born to him, Rav Shmuel, who in time was one of the founders of the settlement in Teglash. He passed away on the 26th of Sivan 5565 (1805) and was buried in the old cemetery in the city of Kalev, next to the place of his tent which the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya designated for his burial place.
Being a boy of six years, Rav Shmuel was orphaned from his father Rav Yaakov. However, despite his young age, he was accustomed to arrive at the Beit Midrash of that Tzaddik. Indeed, at a young age, Rav Shmuel already merited to be blessed by the holy mouth of the Tzaddik of Kalev zya. The way of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev was to hear the Morning Blessings from the mouths of the school children and to answer Amen after their blessings. Once, when the children passed before him, and Rav Shmuel was also among them, and he heard the Morning Blessings from his mouth, he raised his holy hands and with pleasant speech called out and said: "G-d shall be gracious to you, my son. Your future is to serve as a worthy Chazzan (Cantor) who with your pleasant voice will ask for mercy on behalf of the Congregation of the Assembly of Jeshurun." This blessing stood for him as a safeguard for many days, when in the fullness of days he served as a Chazzan during the Days of Awe in the presence of the Tzaddik of Tzehlim zt"l...
Rabbi Shmuel continued to shelter in the holy shadow of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya, and became perfumed from the radiance of his Torah and holiness until the day of his passing.
Rabbi Shmuel z"l used to tell his offspring a wondrous thing that happened to him with the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya. When he traveled once to shelter in the holy shadow of one of the Admorim, and on his return via Kalev, [the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya] told him words of Torah on the verse (Exodus 23:20-21): **הנה אנכי שלח מלאך לפניך לשמרך בדרך ולהביאך אל המקום אשר הכנתי. השמר מפניו ושמע בקלו אל תמר בו כי לא ישא לפשעכם כי שמי בקרבו** - "Behold, I send an Angel before you, to keep you in the way, and to bring you into the place which I have prepared. Beware of him, and obey his voice, provoke him not; for he will not pardon your transgressions: for My name is in him." And the content of his holy words: That the Tzaddik is the angel who guards the souls of his Chassidim on their way in all their desires and matters. And the verse warns you: "Beware of him and obey his voice, provoke him not" - that a person needs to beware of the Holy Tzaddik, and to listen to his voice. "Provoke him not" - that thoughts should not arise in your mind to exchange the Tzaddik for another Tzaddik. "For he will not pardon your transgressions for My name is in him." And the Holy Rabbi of Kalev even added for him a Gematria with a small number and a large number, how his name and the name of his Rabbi are hinted in this verse.
Being that Rabbi Shmuel was a "Ben K"V" (acronym for Kol Bo - meaning he contained everything/was a disciple), his Rabbi the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya passed away.
Source: V'Yigmol Shekedim (Ashdod 5768) p. 62

עַל אֹפֶן הִתְדַּבְּקוּתוֹ וּבוֹאוֹ לְהַרְה"ק מִקָּאלִיב זִי"עַ מְסֻפָּר, שֶׁבְּאוֹתָהּ תְּקוּפָה הָיָה הרה"ק הַמַּגִּיד מִקָּאזְנִיץ זִי"עַ בִּמְדִינוֹת הוּנְגַרְיָה, וְהָיָה בִּרְצוֹנוּ לָלֶכֶת לְבַקֵּר אֶת הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב, ר' יַעֲקֹב זַ"ל נִלְוָה אֵלָיו בְּדַרְכּוֹ וְנָסְעוּ יַחְדָּיו לַחֲלוֹת אֶת פְּנֵי הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב. בִּכְדֵי לְהַגִּיעַ לְקָאלִיב הָיָה עֲלֵיהֶם לַעֲבֹר דֶּרֶךְ הָעִיר ה' מַאדֶע, שָׁם הָיְתָה פָּרָשַׁת דְּרָכִים, שֶׁאַחַת מֵהֶן הוֹבִילָה לְקָאלִיב, מִכֵּיוָן שֶׁלֹּא יָדְעוּ מַהִי הַדֶּרֶךְ הַנְּכוֹנָה, הִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ הרה"ק מִקָּאזְנִיץ זִי"עַ בְּחוּשׁ הָרֵיחַ (- שֶׁכַּיָּדוּעַ הֶעֱנִיק לוֹ רַבּוֹ הרה"ק רַבִּי אֱלִימֶלֶךְ זִי"עַ כִּירוּשָׁה אֶת חוּשׁ הָרֵיחַ), וּכְשֶׁהֵרִיחַ הַמַּגִּיד מִקָּאזְנִיץ זִי"עַ אֶת הַדְּרָכִים, אָמַר הִנֵּה כִּי כֵן זוֹ הִיא הַדֶּרֶךְ הַמּוֹבִילָה לְעִיר קָאלִיב.
כַּאֲשֶׁר הִגִּיעַ הרה"ק מִקָּאזְנִיץ זִי"עַ לְבֵיתוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב זִי"עַ, לָקַח אֶת ר' יַעֲקֹב זַ"ל שֶׁיְּלַוֵּהוּ לְחַדְרוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב, וּבְפָתְחָם אֶת דֶּלֶת חַדְרוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב מְצָאוּהוּ מִסְתּוֹבֵב מִפִּנָּה לְפִנָּה בְּחַדְרוֹ הַקָּ', וּמִתְהַלֵּךְ בִּדְבֵיקוּת בְּאָמְרוֹ בְּהִתְלַהֲבוּת אֶת הַפָּסוּק "אֶת הַכֶּבֶשׂ אֶחָד תַּעֲשֶׂה בַבֹּקֶר וְאֵת הַכֶּבֶשׂ הַשֵּׁנִי תַּעֲשֶׂה בֵּין הָעַרְבָּיִם", בְּשָׁאֲלוֹ לְעַצְמוֹ "וִוי נֶעמֶעט מֶען דִּי צְוֵוי שֶׁעפֶעלֶעךְ", וּלְאַחַר מִכֵּן הֵסֵב הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב אֶת פָּנָיו אֲלֵיהֶם וְקִבְּלָם בְּאַהֲבָה וּבְחִיבָּה, בְּהוֹשִׁיטוֹ לָהֶם אֶת יָדוֹ הַקָּ' לְשָׁלוֹם.כָּאָמוּר, מֵאָז הֶעְתִּיק ר' יַעֲקֹב אֶת מוֹשָׁבוֹ לְעִיר קָאלִיב, שָׁם נָשָׂא בְּזִוּוּג שֵׁנִי אֶת זוּגָתוֹ מָרַת רָחֵל ע"ה וְנִשְׁאַר לָגוּר שָׁם עַד יוֹם פְּטִירָתוֹ.בִּשְׁנַת תקנ"ט, נוֹלַד לוֹ בְּנוֹ ר' שְׁמוּאֵל, שֶׁלְּיָמִים הָיָה מִמְּקִימֵי הַיִּשּׁוּב בְּטֶעגְלַאשׁ. נלב"ע בְּיוֹם כ"ו סִיוָן שְׁנַת תקס"ה לפ"ק, וְנִטְמַן בְּבֵית הַחַיִּים הַיָּשָׁן בְּעִיר קָאלִיב, לְיַד מָקוֹם אָהֳלוֹ שֶׁיִּעֵד הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב זִי"עַ לִמְקוֹם קְבוּרָתוֹ.
בִּהְיוֹתוֹ בֶּן שֵׁשׁ שָׁנִים נִתְיַתֵּם ר' שְׁמוּאֵל מֵאָבִיו ר' יַעֲקֹב, אוּלָם לַמְרוֹת גִּילוֹ הַצָּעִיר נָהַג לְהַגִּיעַ לְבֵית מִדְרָשׁוֹ שֶׁל אוֹתוֹ צַדִּיק וְאָכֵן בְּגִיל צָעִיר זָכָה כְּבָר ר' שְׁמוּאֵל לְהִתְבָּרֵךְ מִפִּי קָדְשׁוֹ שֶׁל הַצַּדִּיק מִקָּאלִיב זִי"עַ. דַּרְכּוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב הָיְתָה לִשְׁמֹעַ אֶת בִּרְכוֹת הַשַּׁחַר מִפִּיהֶם שֶׁל יַלְדֵי תַּשְׁבָּ"ר וְלַעֲנוֹת אָמֵן אַחַר בִּרְכוֹתֵיהֶם, פַּעַם אַחַת כְּשֶׁעָבְרוּ לְפָנָיו הַיְלָדִים שֶׁגַּם ר' שְׁמוּאֵל הָיָה בֵּינֵיהֶם וְשָׁמַע אֶת בִּרְכוֹת הַשַּׁחַר מִפִּיו, הֵרִים אֶת יָדָיו הַקָּ' וּבְנֹעַם שִׂיחַ קָרָא וְאָמַר אֱלֹקִים יְחָנֵךְ בְּנִי וַעֲתִידְךָ לְשַׁמֵּשׁ כִּשְׁלִיחַ צִבּוּר הָגוּן אֲשֶׁר בְּקוֹלְךָ הֶעָרֵב תְּבַקֵּשׁ רַחֲמִים בְּעַד קְהַל עֲדַת יְשׁוּרוּן. בְּרָכָה זוֹ עָמְדָה לוֹ לְמִשְׁמֶרֶת לְיָמִים רַבִּים, כַּאֲשֶׁר בִּרְבוֹת הַיָּמִים שִׁמֵּשׁ כְּשַׁ"ץ בַּיָּמִים הַנּוֹרָאִים בִּמְחִצַּת הַצַּדִּיק מִטַּאהֶעשׁ זַ"ל...רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל הִמְשִׁיךְ לְהִסְתּוֹפֵף בְּצֵל קָדְשׁוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב זִי"עַ, וְהִתְבַּשֵּׂם מִזִּיו תּוֹרָתוֹ וּקְדֻשָּׁתוֹ עַד לְיוֹם פְּטִירָתוֹ.רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל זַ"ל הָיָה מְסַפֵּר לְיוֹצְאֵי חֲלָצָיו דָּבָר נִפְלָא שֶׁאֵרַע לוֹ עִם הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב זִי"עַ, כַּאֲשֶׁר נָסַע פַּעַם לְהִסְתּוֹפֵף בְּצֵל קָדְשׁוֹ שֶׁל אֶחָד הָאַדְמוֹ"רִים, וּבַחֲזָרָתוֹ דֶּרֶךְ קָאלִיב, אָמַר לוֹ [הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב זִי"עַ] דִּבְרֵי תּוֹרָה עַל הַפָּסוּק (שמות כג, כ-כא): "הִנֵּה אָנֹכִי שֹׁלֵחַ מַלְאָךְ לְפָנֶיךָ לִשְׁמָרְךָ בַּדֶּרֶךְ וְלַהֲבִיאֲךָ אֶל הַמָּקוֹם אֲשֶׁר הֲכִינֹתִי. הִשָּׁמֶר מִפָּנָיו וּשְׁמַע בְּקֹלוֹ אַל תַּמֵּר בּוֹ כִּי לֹא יִשָּׂא לְפִשְׁעֲכֶם כִּי שְׁמִי בְּקִרְבּוֹ". וְתֹכֶן דִּבְרֵי קָדְשׁוֹ: שֶׁהַצַּדִּיק הוּא הַמַּלְאָךְ הַשּׁוֹמֵר נַפְשׁוֹת חֲסִידָיו בְּדַרְכָּם בְּכָל חֶפְצֵיהֶם וְעִנְיְנֵיהֶם, וְהַפָּסוּק מַזְהִירְךָ: 'הִשָּׁמֶר מִפָּנָיו וּשְׁמַע בְּקֹלוֹ אַל תַּמֵּר בּוֹ', שֶׁצָּרִיךְ הָאָדָם לְהִשָּׁמֵר מִפְּנֵי הַצַּדִּיק הַקָּ', וְלִשְׁמֹעַ בְּקוֹלוֹ, 'אַל תַּמֵּר בּוֹ', שֶׁלֹּא יַעֲלֶה בְּמַחְשַׁבְתְּךָ לְהָמִיר אֶת הַצַּדִּיק בְּצַדִּיק אַחֵר, 'כִּי לֹא יִשָּׂא לְפִשְׁעֲכֶם כִּי שְׁמִי בְּקִרְבּוֹ', והגה"ק מִקָּאלִיב אַף הוֹסִיף לוֹ גִּימַטְרִיָּא בְּמִסְפָּר קָטָן וּבְמִסְפָּר גָּדוֹל אֵיךְ מְרֻמָּז שְׁמוֹ וְשֵׁם רַבּוֹ בְּפָסוּק זֶה.בִּהְיוֹת רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בֶּן כ"ב, נלב"ע רַבּוֹ הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב זִי"עַ."וְיִגְמֹל שְׁקֵדִים" (אַשְׁדּוֹד תשס"ח) עַמּוּד ס"ב
body_en:
The Holy Rabbi, the Baal Divrei Chaim zya, once said that the songs and melodies of the Rav of Kalev are Holy of Holies. He also taught himself to pronounce the letter "Resh" with the Hungarian accent in order to be able to sing the song "Szol a Kakas Mar" (The Rooster Calls) without changes.
Source: Abir HaRo'im (Brooklyn 5755) p. 78

It is known from the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya that when he would sing in the Hungarian language, and my grandfather from Sanz when he would sing the melody "Szol a Kakas," the table was wet with tears. And it is also known that the Chozeh of Lublin zya would count after the Seder the Sedarim of all the Tzaddikim of the generation and detail their praises, how they shone in the heavens. And once he said that he did not see the Seder of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev. Afterwards, it became known that in this year, the Holy Rabbi of Kalev conducted the entire Seder in Hungarian. And it is clear that if the Holy Rabbi of Lublin did not see the Seder, then also many angels and seraphim did not see it. And this was the way of the service of the Holy Baal Shem Tov and his disciples, the Holy Society, to hide everything until they reached under the Throne of Glory, and only the Blessed G-d knew of it.
Source: Divrei Torah, Beha'alotcha 5749, p. 2

Regarding the wondrous Dveykut (cleaving to G-d) of Maran the Divrei Chaim zt"l, our Rebbe (C"K Maran Admor the "Divrei Yoel" of Satmar) zt"l told that his father-in-law/uncle, the Holy Rabbi of Razo-Vlodava zt"l, was once in Sanz for one of the Holy Shabbats. On the night of the Holy Shabbat, when the Holy Rabbi of Sanz took the cup in his hand for Kiddush, he began to sing with wondrous Dveykut the words "Shabbat Kodesh" with the melody of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya on the word "Galut Galut" etc. And so Maran the Divrei Chaim zt"l stood and sang with wondrous Dveykut for long hours until the candles went out and the day almost dawned. When Maran the Divrei Chaim zt"l woke up [from his trance], he said in wonder: "Did I not think that only one minute had passed?"
Source: Moshian Shel Yisrael (Satmar) Part 2, p. 182

Generally, on the Shabbat before the Hillula (of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya - 7 Adar), they would sing songs composed by the Holy Rabbi of Kalev - in the Holy Tongue and in the Hungarian language. However, also during the year, from time to time, they would honor [someone] to sing the song "Sirnak Rinak" (The sheep are bleating/humming, the holy flock). Maran the Baal "Imrei Chaim" of Vizhnitz zt"l would sob with weeping while singing these songs...
On the Holy Shabbat, Parashat Vayeira, year 5717 (1956), three days before the outbreak of the Sinai War, there was very great tension in the Land of Israel, out of fear of what was to come, Heaven forbid. Our Rebbe ordered to sing "Sirnak Rinak." When they sang the words "Until I become its shepherd, let none be missing from his flock...", he pointed to himself. And indeed, with the help of Heaven, not a man was missing from the Chassidim of Vizhnitz who were mobilized in the war, and among them were also those in dangerous places at the front of the battles.
Source: Meir HaChaim (Bnei Brak 5752) Part 2, p. 314

Regarding the complete Redemption, [the Holy Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik of Kalev zya] stormed worlds all the days of his life in several ways. It is known that once on the night of Pesach, he delayed for many hours and did not want to begin the Seder unless the Redemption would be on that night, just as at the time of our exodus from Egypt. Until they sent to him the Seven Shepherds from the Upper World, and they pleaded with him not to be stubborn about this, for the time for grace had not yet arrived.
And once, he fell asleep on the first day of the holiday of Shavuot, and his household members recognized that this was not ordinary sleep, but an ascent of the soul. Therefore, they did not dare to wake him. But on the second day of the holiday, when they saw that he still had not awakened from his Dveykut, they were alarmed by this and woke him. After the holiday, when they told the matters before his in-law, the Holy Rabbi, Baal "Ateret Tzvi" of Zidichov zya, he said: "Pity, pity that they woke him on the second day from his Dveykut. For he ascended then to the Upper Worlds and stormed for the Redemption. And he had already arrived close to the Palace of the Messiah. And had they not woken him, he would have acted to bring the complete Redemption."
Source: Avodat Avodah (Canada 5769) Part 2, p. 175

The Holy Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik of Kalev zya said before his passing: "After Shabbat, there is no Isru Chag" [meaning, after he (Shabbat) is gone, there is no binding to the holiday/no continuation]. And indeed, after the passing of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev, there was not a single one who filled his place.
Source: Otzar Yisrael (Jerusalem 5755) p. 164

It is known what the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zya said before his passing to his students who asked him to whom they should travel after him. He answered them: "To the one who has the power to take out a dirty soul of Israel and purify it, similar to how one washes a dirty shirt and returns it afterwards clean." End of his holy words.
Source: Divrei Torah, Chukat 5748, p. 4

בְּאוֹתוֹ לַיְלָה נִתְגַּלָּה הרה"ק לִבְנוֹ בַּחֲלוֹם וְאָמַר לוֹ: "דַּע לְךָ בְּנִי שֶׁבָּאתִי אֵלֶיךָ עַתָּה מִמְּקוֹם מְנוּחָתִי בְּגַן עֵדֶן, וְלֹא אֶתֵּן לְךָ לְהַמְשִׁיךְ אֶת סֵדֶר יוֹמְךָ עַד שֶׁתְּקַבֵּל עַל עַצְמְךָ לְנַתֵּק קְשָׁרֶיךָ עִם אוֹתָהּ חֲבוּרַת רֵיקִים, וְתַחֲזֹר לַמּוּטָב לְהִתְחַבֵּר עִם תַּלְמִידַי". לְעֵת בֹּקֶר הִתְעוֹרֵר מֵאִיר מִשְּׁנָתוֹ מְבֻלְבָּל לְגַמְרֵי, וְלֹא יָדַע לָשִׁית עֵצוֹת בְּנַפְשׁוֹ מַה לַעֲשׂוֹת, וְנִשְׁאַר דּוֹמֵם בְּבֵיתוֹ.שָׁעוֹת אֲחָדוֹת עָבְרוּ, חֲבֵרָיו בְּבֵית הַמַּרְזֵחַ הִבְחִינוּ שֶׁעֲדַיִין לֹא הִגִּיעַ כְּמִנְהָגוֹ בְּכָל יוֹם. סָרוּ אֲחָדִים מֵהֶם לְבֵיתוֹ ע"מ לִדְרֹשׁ בִּשְׁלוֹמוֹ. כְּשֶׁהִגִּיעוּ, הִבְהִיר לָהֶם מֵאִיר שֶׁשּׁוּב לֹא יוּכַל לִשְׁהוֹת בִּמְחִיצָתָם כִּי כָּךְ צִוָּהוּ אָבִיו זַ"ל בַּחֲלוֹם, וְהוֹרָה לוֹ לְהֵיטִיב דְּרָכָיו מֵעַתָּה.שָׂחֲקוּ חֲבֵרָיו וְאָמְרוּ: "מֵאִיר, הֲלֹא מֵעוֹלָם בַּר שֵׂכֶל הָיִיתָ, מָה אֵירַע לְךָ עַתָּה, וְכִי מַאֲמִין אַתָּה בַּחֲלוֹמוֹת, אַל תִּתֵּן לִבְּךָ אֲלֵיהֶם וּבוֹא עִמָּנוּ עַתָּה כְּמִנְהָגְךָ בְּכָל יוֹם". קִיבֵּל מֵאִיר אֶת דִּבְרֵיהֶם וְהִצְטָרֵף אֲלֵיהֶם. בְּמִשְׂחַק הַקָּארְטִין הֶעֱרִימוּ חֲבֵרָיו שֶׁיַּרְוִיחַ הוֹן רַב, כְּדֵי שֶׁיִּרְצֶה לְהִשָּׁאֵר בְּחֶבְרָתָם בֶּעָתִיד. וְאָכֵן כְּשֶׁחָזַר לְבֵיתוֹ הִרְהֵר לְעַצְמוֹ הִנֵּה הִרְוַחְתִּי כֶּסֶף רַב עַל יָדָם, הֲרֵי שֶׁחֶבְרָתִי עִמָּם טוֹבָה עֲבוּרִי.
בַּלַּיְלָה זֶה נִתְרָאָה אֵלָיו אָבִיו הַקָּדוֹשׁ שׁוּב, וְהוֹכִיחוֹ: "מֵאִיר, בְּיוֹם הֶעָבָר לֹא קִבַּלְתָּ דְּבָרַי וְחָזַרְתָּ לְסוּרְךָ, וְעַל כֵּן הִטְרַחְתִּי עַצְמִי שׁוּב לֵירֵד מִמְּקוֹמִי בְּגַן עֵדֶן לְעוֹלָם שָׁפָל זֶה, עַל אַף הַקּוֹשִׁי שֶׁיֵּשׁ בְּכָךְ - בְּנִי אַל תֵּלֵךְ בַּדֶּרֶךְ אִתָּם, אֶת רַגְלְךָ מְנַע מִנְּתִיבוֹתָם, דַּע כִּי לֹא אַרְפֶּה מִמְּךָ עַד שֶׁתְּקַבֵּל דְּבָרַי וְתַחֲזֹר בִּתְשׁוּבָה שְׁלֵמָה".לְמָחֳרָת הִבְחִינוּ הַחֲבֵרִים שֶׁמֵּאִיר נֶעְדָּר שׁוּב מֵחֶבְרָתָם, וְהֵבִינוּ שֶׁהַחֲלוֹם מַפְחִידוֹ עֲדַיִין. הֶחְלִיטוּ לָסוּר הַפַּעַם כֻּלָּם יַחַד לְבֵיתוֹ. כְּשֶׁהִגִּיעוּ, אָמַר לָהֶם שֶׁאָבִיו חָזַר וְנִגְלָה אֵלָיו וְהִזְהִירוֹ בְּתֹקֶף שֶׁיָּשׁוּב בִּתְשׁוּבָה, וְאִם לָאו, יִטֹּל נִשְׁמָתוֹ מִמֶּנּוּ. שָׁבוּ חֲבֵרָיו וְשָׂחֲקוּ עָלָיו כִּבְיוֹם הָאֶתְמוֹל. אָכֵן בַּפַּעַם הַזֹּאת לֹא הִצְלִיחוּ לְשַׁכְנְעוֹ בִּצְחוֹקָם, וְלֹא אָבָה לְהִצְטָרֵף אֲלֵיהֶם עוֹד. תְּפָסוּהוּ חֲבֵרָיו בְּכֹחַ וְהִכְרִיחוּהוּ לֵילֵךְ עִמָּהֶם, וְכָךְ בִּילָה בְּחֶבְרָתָם אַף בְּיוֹם זֶה.
בַּלַּיְלָה הַשְּׁלִישִׁי נִתְגַּלָּה אֵלָיו אָבִיו שׁוּב וְאָמַר: "בַּפַּעַם הַזֹּאת אֶרְחִיק לֶכֶת וְאֶחְקֹק סִימָן עָלֶיךָ שֶׁיַּשְׁאִיר רִשּׁוּמוֹ לְתָמִיד, וְיַזְכִּירְךָ שֶׁאָכֵן הָיִיתִי אֶצְלְךָ וְהִזְהַרְתִּיךָ, וְלֹא תֹּאמַר עוֹד שֶׁחֲלוֹמוֹת שָׁוְא יְדַבֵּרוּ" - בְּתוֹךְ בֵּיתוֹ עָמַד תַּנּוּר גָּדוֹל עָשׂוּי בַּרְזֶל שֶׁמִּשְׁקָלוֹ רַב, עַד שֶׁאֲפִי' חֲמִשָּׁה בְּנֵי אָדָם לֹא יָכְלוּ לַהֲרִימוֹ - נָטַל הרה"ק תַּנּוּר זֶה בְּיָדָיו וְהֵטִילוֹ עַל בְּנוֹ וְנִשְׁבְּרָה רַגְלוֹ, וְאָמַר: "עַתָּה לֹא תוּכַל לְהַלֵּךְ עַל רַגְלְךָ, וְזֶה יִהְיֶה לְךָ לְאוֹת שֶׁהַחֲלוֹם אֱמֶת, וַחֲזֹר בְּךָ מִמַּעֲשֶׂיךָ הַנְּלוֹזִים".כְּשֶׁשָּׁבוּ חֲבֵרָיו בַּיּוֹם הַשְּׁלִישִׁי וְשָׁמְעוּ מִפִּיו אֶת קוֹרוֹת הַלַּיְלָה, וְאַף אֶת רַגְלוֹ הַשְּׁבוּרָה רָאוּ, נִבְהֲלוּ מְאֹד וּבָרְחוּ לְנַפְשָׁם בְּפַחַד גָּדוֹל.מֵאִיר זֶה חָזַר בִּתְשׁוּבָה שְׁלֵמָה וְהִתְחַבֵּר לְתַלְמִידֵי אָבִיו הַקָּדוֹשׁ, וְנַעֲשָׂה חָסִיד וְעוֹבֵד הַשֵּׁם כְּמוֹתָם, רַבִּים נוֹסָפִים הִתְעוֹרְרוּ וְחָזְרוּ בִּתְשׁוּבָה בְּשָׁמְעָם שֶׁהרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב פָּעַל פְּעֻלּוֹת מַמָּשִׁיּוֹת בַּחֲלוֹם.כ"ק מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר מהר"ש מִבָּאבּוֹב זצוק"ל"בִּנְיַן שְׁלֹמֹה", אֲדָר תשס"ה, עַמּוּד ז'

In the book "Michtavei Kodesh" page 146, it is brought in the name of the C"K Admor of Bobov (Shlita) [zt"l] that his father, the C"K Maharavtz of Bobov zt"l Hy"d, wanted to make the wedding of his daughter on the 7th of Adar. When this became known to his in-law, the Holy Rabbi, Rabbi Shalom Eliezer, he asked him in a letter to change the time of the wedding to another day. This was because he had a strong yearning to be at the marker of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev on the day of the 7th of Adar. And if they did not change the time of the wedding, he would travel to Kalev and not come to the wedding, so much did his soul desire to be there on the day of the Hillula. And so it was that the wedding took place on the 4th of Adar.
Source: Abir HaRo'im - Kalev (Brooklyn 5755) p. 128

On the 7th of Adar - the day of the Hillula of the Holy Rabbi, Rav Yitzchak Eizik zt"l of Kalev - masses of Israel were accustomed to travel to his city to prostrate themselves on his grave. The "Saba Kadisha" (Author of "Ahavat Yisrael" of Vizhnitz zya) came once (in the year 5694/1934) to there a day before, and immediately went to pray on the holy marker.
While he was there in the Beit Midrash, the "Saba Kadisha" asked about the place where the Holy Rabbi of Kalev zt"l stood during his prayers. When they showed him, he positioned himself there while praying Mincha, and they saw him rejoicing greatly that he merited to pray in that holy place. He also asked Rav Baruch Fisch - the grandson of Rav Yaakov Fisch, who was the head of the community in the time of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev - to show him the letter in which the Holy Rabbi asked the leaders of the community for a raise in his salary. In the letter, the Holy Rabbi reasoned his request by writing: "Do not think that I want to live a better and more comfortable life, but rather because I need to marry off two orphans. Although they asked me to move to live in another city, and I could receive an addition to my salary there, yet it is not my desire to wander from here."
His request was accepted and they added for him. Upon seeing the letter, our Rebbe kissed it. Also his sons: the Holy Gaon Moharam'm of Vishay and the C"K Admor the "Imrei Chaim" zt"l were with him [and see further in the book "Meir HaChaim", Part 2, page 314, that also his son, the C"K Maran author of "Imrei Chaim" zt"l, visited several times at the marker in Kalev on the day of the Hillula, once with his father the "Saba Kadisha" zya as mentioned above, and it is known that he visited there in the years 5701 and 5704, and there are those who say he was there additional times].
Source: Kadosh Yisrael (Bnei Brak 5745) p. 538

What my holy and pure grandfather wrote in his famous song: "Szol a kakas mar, majd meg virrad mar," which translates to "The rooster calls, soon there will be light." And the Holy Rabbi gives a reason for the rooster calling in the middle of the night: Because then the Holy One, Blessed be He, descends to the World of Action to see what is happening down here. And at that moment, the rooster gets warm because "So too under His wings" until he begins to shout. And through his shouting, human beings wake up and rise from their sleep for the service of the Creator. "And if you have any greater light than this," this is "The rooster calls, soon there will be light."
And this is what King David, peace be upon him, said: **אחסה בסתר כנפיך** - "I will trust in the covert of Your wings" (Psalms 61:5). For behold, the purpose of "the covert of Your wings" is that through this we will arrive at "I will reveal the glory of Your Kingdom." And I also want to take shelter in that study that comes out from the covert of Your wings, so that I can also reveal and publicize "The glory of Your Kingdom," like this rooster who shouts and announces with loud voices so that guests will hurry to rise for the service of G-d.
Source: Kol Menachem (Jerusalem 5755) Mo'adim, p. 362

body_he: וְזֶהוּ שֶׁאָמַר דהמע"ה "אֶחְסֶה בְסֵתֶר כְּנָפֶיךָ" דְּהִנֵּה הַתַּכְלִית מִ"סֵּתֶר כְּנָפֶיךָ" הוּא שֶׁנַּגִּיעַ עַל יְדֵי זֶה לְ"גַלֵּה כְּבוֹד מַלְכוּתֶךָ", וַאֲנִי גַּם רוֹצֶה לַחְסוֹת בְּאוֹתוֹ הַלִּמּוּד הַיּוֹצֵא מִסֵּתֶר כְּנָפֶיךָ, שֶׁאוּכַל גַּם אֲנִי לְגַלּוֹת וּלְפַרְסֵם אֶת "כְּבוֹד מַלְכוּתֶךָ", כַּתַּרְנְגוֹל הַזֶּה שֶׁצּוֹעֵק וּמַכְרִיז בְּקוֹלֵי קוֹלוֹת כְּדֵי שֶׁאוֹרְחִים יִזְדָּרְזוּ לָקוּם לַעֲבוֹדַת ה'.כ"ק מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר מִקָּאלִיב שְׁלִיטָ"א"קוֹל מְנַחֵם" (יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשנ"ה) מוֹעֲדִים, עַמּוּד שס"ב טו"ב
body_en:
Not for nothing was his Hillula day a day of gathering for all the Tzaddikim, and from all the countries they came to Kalev on the 7th of Adar to prostrate themselves on his holy marker. For the power of his influence grew so much, until all the greats and all the Tzaddikim from all the towns felt that they had a connection and bond to him.
And during my studies for several years in the city of Kalev, in the Yeshiva of my uncle, our teacher Rabbi Menachem Brody zt"l, Av Beit Din of the holy community of Kalev, I merited to prostrate myself many times on his holy marker of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev. And every year on the 7th of Adar, I merited to see and know there many Tzaddikim who gathered there, together with thousands of the Children of Israel who aroused great mercy there. And many Children of Israel were saved there with great salvation on that day by the power of that Elder.
For just as in his lifetime, the Holy Rabbi gave his soul to sweeten judgments from the Children of Israel, and all his days he suffered terrible afflictions for the general public of Israel, until due to his weakness he could not wear regular clothes but rather clothes made of paper, so too certainly even after his passing, he works hard in the Heavens above to sweeten judgments from the Children of Israel.
Source: Avodat Avodah (Canada 5769) Part 2, p. 174

וּבְלָמְדִי כַּמָּה שָׁנִים בְּעִיר קָאלִיב, בִּישִׁיבַת דּוֹדִי מוֹ"ר רַבִּי מְנַחֵם בְּרָאדִי זַצַ"ל אבדק"ק קָאלִיב, זָכִיתִי לְהִשְׁתַּטֵּחַ פְּעָמִים רַבּוֹת עַל צִיּוֹן קָדְשׁוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב, וּבְכָל שָׁנָה בְּיוֹם ז' אֲדָר זָכִיתִי לִרְאוֹת וּלְהַכִּיר שָׁם הַרְבֵּה צַדִּיקִים שֶׁהִתְכַּנְּסוּ לְשָׁם, יַחַד עִם אַלְפֵי בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁעוֹרְרוּ שָׁם רַחֲמִים מְרֻבִּים, וְהַרְבֵּה בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל נוֹשְׁעוּ שָׁם בִּישׁוּעָה רַבָּה בַּיּוֹם הַהוּא בְּכֹחוֹ שֶׁל אוֹתוֹ זָקֵן.
כִּי כְּשֵׁם שֶׁבְּחַיִּים חִיּוּתוֹ מָסַר הרה"ק נַפְשׁוֹ לְהַמְתִּיק דִּינִים מִבְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל, וְכָל יָמָיו סָבַל יִסּוּרִים נוֹרָאִים בְּעַד כְּלַל יִשְׂרָאֵל, עַד שֶׁמֵּרֹב חֻלְשָׁתוֹ לֹא הָיָה יָכוֹל לִלְבֹּשׁ בְּגָדִים רְגִילִים כִּי אִם בְּגָדִים הָעֲשׂוּיִים מִנְּיָר, כֵּן וַדַּאי גַּם אַחַר פְּטִירָתוֹ עוֹבֵד קָשׁוֹת בַּשְּׁמֵי מַעַל לְהַמְתִּיק דִּינִים מִבְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל.כ"ק מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר מִטַּאהֶעשׁ זצוק"ל"עֲבוֹדַת עֲבוֹדָה" (קַאנַאדַא) תשס"ט חֵלֶק ב', עַמּוּד קע"ד
body_en:
7th of Adar - On His Holy Marker
In the land of Hungary, there was a mass streaming to the marker of the Holy Rabbi, Rav Yitzchak Eizik of Kalev zya, to the same extent that in the country of Poland they streamed to the marker of the Holy Rabbi, Rav Elimelech.
A Jew who was in Hungary in the year 5704 (1944), before the oppressors arrived there, told that thousands of the Children of Israel ascended to the marker of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev to plead in prayer on his marker with terrible, heart-rending weeping.
When the Holy Rabbi, the Maharid of Belz, was at the marker of the Holy Rabbi of Kalev on his Hillula day, the 7th of Adar, the entire crowd pushed around the marker. The Holy Rabbi of Belz responded and said in wonder: "Why do you push? Do you not see that the Holy Rabbi of Kalev is above everyone and blessing all those who come to his marker that they should achieve all good?" ("L'Akik Un B'Ranfin" - To eyes and with faces [visible to all]).
Source: L'Akik V'L'Branfin (Jerusalem 5767) p. 3

HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Lipman David Shuvaks zt"l was born in the year 5590 (1830) approximately, to his father the Chassid HaTzaddik Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak zt"l. Rabbi Dudtze was known as a genius in Halachic ruling while still in his youth in Poland, and he taught while the Elder Admor of Kotzk was still alive. He ascended to Jerusalem in the year 5658 (1898). After a short period, he returned abroad on a mission for the building of the "Batei Varsha" neighborhood in Jerusalem. In the year 5661 (1901), he returned, and the author of "Torat Chesed" imposed upon him to serve as Ra'avad (Head of the Beit Din) for the Chassidic community in Jerusalem... Old and satisfied with days, he passed away on the 7th of Adar II, year 5684 (1924).
Source: Mara D'Ar'a D'Yisrael (Jerusalem 5763) Part 2, p. 287

body_he: כַּאֲשֶׁר הָיָה הרה"ק מַהֲרִי"ד מִבֶּעלְזָא עַל הַצִּיּוֹן שֶׁל הרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב, בְּיוֹמָא דְּהִילּוּלָא שֶׁלּוֹ בְּיוֹם ז' אֲדָר, נִדְחֲפוּ כָּל הַקָּהָל סְבִיב הַצִּיּוֹן, נַעֲנָה הרה"ק מִבֶּעלְזָא וְאָמַר בִּפְלִיאָה, לָמָּה תִּדְחֲפוּ, וְכִי אֵינְכֶם רוֹאִים שֶׁהרה"ק מִקָּאלִיב נִמְצָא מֵעַל כֻּלָּם וּמְבָרֵךְ אֶת כָּל הַבָּאִים עַל צִיּוֹנוֹ שֶׁיִּפְעֲלוּ כָּל טוֹב ("לֶעקִיךְ אוּן בְּרָאנְפִין" בְּעִיר בּוּדַאפֶּעסְט אוֹר לְיוֹם ג' פָּרָשַׁת וַיֵּרָא).כ"ק מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר מִדַּארָאג שְׁלִיטָ"אאוֹר לְיוֹם ג' וַיֵּרָא תשס"ז"יַשְׁקוּ הָעֲדָרִים", וַיֵּרָא תשס"ז עַמּוּד ג'
body_en:
At the age of four, he was orphaned from his mother. His father was diligent to guide him in the path of Torah and tradition. He distributed from his bread and gave him into the hands of capable teachers. Even in his virtues, the lad Lipman David was recognized, and as he was called by a nickname of affection until the end of his days, "Dudtze." Already then, signs of his righteousness were seen in him. When he was four years old and received a slice of bread and also a penny to buy something to accompany his bread, he used to give the penny to a poor person, and he would eat the bread without seasoning it.
In his wondrous diligence, he ascended in the levels of Torah. Already from his childhood years, the Holy Admor Rabbi Menachem Mendel of Kotzk recognized him, and from then on he merited special closeness from him. In the home of the Rebbe of Kotzk grew the daughter of his sister, Mrs. Chava Leah, who was orphaned in her youth from her father. The Rebbe of Kotzk set his eyes upon Rabbi Dudtze. When he reached the age of fourteen, the "Tena'im" (engagement conditions) were written in the home of the Rebbe, who stood on the side of the bride. When he reached fourteen years, they entered the Chuppah in a good and successful hour.
A few years after the marriage, he was close to the table of the Admor of Kotzk, who would repeat before the young Dudtze the Pilpul (complex Torah analysis) that he would deliver before his students every Shabbat.
After the Chuppah, he told her, Rabbi Dudtze, that during the Chuppah, the image of her father's face appeared before him. This was already several years after he was in the World of Truth, and he had never seen him since he passed away before his [Dudtze's] ascent [to the family]. However, when Rabbi Dudtze described the image of his face to her, she was surprised, for indeed he described him accurately, as if he was standing before them.
Rabbi Shneur Zalman of Lublin, author of "Torat Chesed," granted them his blessing. According to the story, the young woman entered to be blessed and asked him to be visited with a male son. The Rav of Lublin acceded to her request. When she told this to her husband, Rabbi Dudtze, he argued: "Why did you ask for a male son? You should have asked for children." The Rebbetzin answered that from the sight of the shining face of the author of "Torat Chesed," fear fell upon her and she did not dare to ask for more. Indeed, at the turn of the year, she bore a son to Rabbi Dudtze. In the interim period, the author of "Torat Chesed" passed away to his eternal home, and the child was named after him, Shneur Zalman, and after the grandfather, Yaakov Yisrael.
The writing of a Sefer Torah was completed with the Redemption of the Firstborn (Pidyon HaBen). During the Pidyon, Rabbi Dudtze cried. To the question of the Hahra"tz Rabbi David Biederman, Rabbi Dudtze expressed his wish that he should merit to bring the newborn son to the Chuppah. Indeed, he was blessed by Rabbi David, and Rabbi Dudtze merited to lead his son to the Chuppah...
Source: Introduction to "Chiddushei HaGarad" (Jerusalem 5748) p. 1-15

בְּשַׁקְדָנוּתוֹ הַמֻּפְלָאָה הִתְעַלָּה בְּמַעֲלוֹת הַתּוֹרָה וּכְבָר מִשְּׁנוֹת יַלְדוּתוֹ הִכִּיר בּוֹ הָאַדְמוֹ"ר הַקָּדוֹשׁ רַבִּי מְנַחֵם מֶנְדִּיל מִקָּאצְק, וּמֵאָז זָכָה הֵימֶנּוּ לְקִירְבָה מְיֻחֶדֶת. בְּבֵיתוֹ שֶׁל הָרַבִּי מִקָּאצְק גָּדְלָה בַּת אֲחוֹתוֹ מָרַת חַוָּה לֵאָה, שֶׁנִּתְיַתְּמָה בִּנְעוּרֶיהָ מֵאָבִיהָ. הָרַבִּי מִקּוֹצְק נָתַן בְּרַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע אֶת עֵינוֹ. וּבִמְלֹאת לוֹ שְׁלוֹשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה שָׁנָה נִכְתְּבוּ "הַתְּנָאִים" בְּבֵיתוֹ שֶׁל הָרַבִּי שֶׁהָיָה הָעוֹמֵד מִצַּד הַכַּלָּה. כְּשֶׁמָּלְאוּ לוֹ י"ד שָׁנִים נִכְנְסוּ לְחֻפָּה בְּשָׁעָה טוֹבָה וּמוּצְלַחַת.שָׁנִים מִסְפָּר לְאַחַר הַנִּשּׂוּאִין הָיָה סָמוּךְ עַל שֻׁלְחָנוֹ שֶׁל הָאַדְמוֹ"ר מִקָּאצְק, שֶׁהָיָה חוֹזֵר בִּפְנֵי הַצָּעִיר דּוֹדְצֶ'ע אֶת הַפִּלְפּוּל שֶׁהָיָה מַשְׁמִיעַ לִפְנֵי תַּלְמִידָיו, מִדֵּי שַׁבָּת בְּשַׁבַּתּוֹ.
בִּמְלֹאת לוֹ לַצָּעִיר רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע, הַמֻּפְלָג בְּכִשְׁרוֹנוֹת, שֵׁשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה שָׁנָה. כְּבָר הָיָה בָּקִי מֻפְלָא בְּאַרְבַּעַת חֶלְקֵי שׁוּ"עַ, הֶעֱנִיק לוֹ הָאַדְמוֹ"ר סְמִיכַת חֲכָמִים, רוֹשְׁמֵי הַקּוֹרוֹת מְצַיְּנִים שֶׁהָיְתָה זֹאת פַּעַם יְחִידָה שֶׁהָאַדְמוֹ"ר מִקָּאצְק הֶעֱנִיק סְמִיכַת חֲכָמִים, רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע אַף נִתְמַנָּה עַל יָדוֹ כְּמוֹ"צ בִּקְהִילַּת קָאצְק. וְהוּא אָז עֲדַיִין צָעִיר לְיָמִים.בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁהָאַדְמוֹ"ר הֶעֱנִיק לוֹ אֶת הַסְּמִיכָה הוֹסִיף לוֹ אֶת בִּרְכָתוֹ שֶׁלֹּא יִיכָּשֵׁל בִּדְבַר הֲלָכָה, בִּהְיוֹתוֹ מִירְאֵי הוֹרָאָה נָהַג רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע לוֹמַר כָּל יוֹם אֶת סֵפֶר הַתְּהִלִּים, וּמִתְפַּלֵּל שֶׁלֹּא תֵּצֵא תַּקָּלָה מִתַּחַת יָדוֹ, וְהוּא הַדִּין בְּיוֹם שֶׁהָיָה מְסַדֵּר גֵּט כְּרִיתוּת, הָיָה שׁוֹהֶה בְּתַעֲנִית וּבִתְפִלָּה.
בַּשָּׁנִים הָהֵם הָיוּ לוֹ שִׁעוּרִים קְבוּעִים עִם שְׁאֵר בְּשָׂרוֹ רַבִּי אַבְרָהָם מִסּוֹכַטְשׁוֹב בַּעַל "אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר". בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁבַּעַל חִדּוּשֵׁי הָרִי"מ הָיָה מַשְׁמִיעַ אֶת שִׁעוּרוֹ לִפְנֵי בְּנֵי עֲלִיָּה, נִמְנָה רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע בֵּין שׁוֹמְעֵי לִקְחוֹ.רַבִּי אַבְרָהָם מִסּוֹכַטְשׁוֹב בַּעַל "אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" נוֹדַע כְּגָאוֹן מֻפְלָא, וּכְבָר בַּיָּמִים הָהֵם הִצְטַיֵּן בְּדֶרֶךְ לִמּוּדוֹ. בְּחַבְרוּתָא עִם רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע, עָלוּ אֵיפוֹא, הַשָּׁנִים וְהִתְעַלּוּ בְּמַעֲלוֹת הַתּוֹרָה.בַּעַל "אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" הִרְגִּישׁ בְּכִשְׁרוֹנוֹ הַמֻּפְלָא שֶׁל רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע כִּכְלִי מֻכְשָׁר לְקַבֵּל וְלִקְלֹט אֶת שִׁיטָתוֹ הַמְיֻחֶדֶת, וְנִיתַּן לְהַמְלִיץ כִּי מָצָא הַפַּטִּישׁ אֶת סַדָּנוֹ. רַבִּי אַבְרָהָם הִכְנִיס אוֹתוֹ לְפַרְדֵּס שֶׁל לוֹמְדוּת, הִדְרִיכוֹ וְכִיוּוּן אֶת דַּרְכּוֹ לָלֶכֶת מֵישָׁרִים בְּפִלְפּוּל וּבִסְבָרָא...בְּנִגּוּד לְלוֹמְדִים צְעִירִים בְּיָמָיו, שֶׁהָיוּ לְהוּטִים אַחַר הַחִידּוּד וְהַפִּלְפּוּל, שָׁקַד רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע הַצָּעִיר בְּדֶרֶךְ הַלִּמּוּד שֶׁל הָרַבִּי מִקּוֹצְק וַחֲתָנוֹ בַּעַל הָ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר", לְהַעֲמִיק בְּכָל סוּגְיָה וּלְהֲבִינָהּ עַל בּוּרְיָהּ, וְלֹא לְחַפֵּשׂ חִדּוּשִׁים אֶלָּא לְאַחַר שֶׁיַּעַמְדוּ עַל יְסוֹדוֹתֶיהָ שֶׁל הַסּוּגְיָה, לְהָבִין וְלָדַעַת אֲמִתָּהּ שֶׁל תּוֹרָה, וְהִיא שֶׁעָמְדָה לוֹ בְּלִמּוּדוֹ בְּכָל שְׁנוֹת חַיָּיו.
כַּחֲצִי יוֹבֵל שָׁנִים שִׁמֵּשׁ רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע כְּמוֹ"צ בְּקָאצְק וְרָכַשׁ לוֹ נִסָּיוֹן רַב בְּהוֹרָאָה עַד שֶׁהַקְּהִילָּה הַמְפֹאָרֶת לְעַעֶרְטוֹב פָּנְתָה אֵלָיו בְּבַקָּשָׁה לְכַהֵן בָּהּ כְּבוֹד כְּאַבָ"ד, וּכְשָׁלוֹשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה שָׁנָה כִּהֵן בִּקְהִילָּה מַעְטִירָה זֹאת.בְּכָל אוֹתָן הַשָּׁנִים שָׁקַד רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע עַל הַתּוֹרָה, כְּשֶׁהוּא מִתְעַלֵּם לַחֲלוּטִין מִכָּל הַבְלֵי הָעוֹלָם הַזֶּה, מִתּוֹךְ צַעַר וְדוֹחַק וּבְיִחוּד סָבַל צַעַר גִּדּוּל בָּנִים. שְׁלוֹשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה יְלָדִים נוֹלְדוּ לוֹ מֵאֵשֶׁת נְעוּרָיו, וְכֻלָּם לֹא הֶאֱרִיכוּ יָמִים וְנִפְטְרוּ עַל פָּנָיו. כַּמָּה מֵהֶם אַף בָּנוּ אֶת בָּתֵּיהֶם וְנִישְּׂאוּ, הוֹלִידוּ יְלָדִים, אוּלָם אַף הֵם נִפְטְרוּ בְּקוֹצֶר יָמִים וְהִשְׁאִירוּ אַחֲרֵיהֶם יְתוֹמִים רַכִּים. בְּאֶחָד הַיָּמִים, כַּאֲשֶׁר נַפְשׁוֹ הָיְתָה מָרָה עָלָיו, שָׁפַךְ אֶת לִבּוֹ לִפְנֵי רַבּוֹ הָאַדְמוֹ"ר שְׁאֵר בְּשָׂרוֹ הרה"ק רַבִּי דָּוִד מִקָּאצְק וְהַלָּה יָעַץ לוֹ לַעֲקֹר מִבֵּיתוֹ וְלַעֲלוֹת לְאֶרֶץ הַקּוֹדֶשׁ. אַף הֶעֱנִיק לוֹ אֶת בִּרְכָתוֹ.
בִּשְׁנַת תרנ"ח בְּקֵירוּב עָזַב רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע אֶת בֵּיתוֹ וְיָצָא בְּדַרְכּוֹ לְאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל, תְּנָאֵי הַנְּסִיעָה לְאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל בַּיָּמִים הָהֵם הָיוּ קָשִׁים בְּיוֹתֵר, אַף הַכְּנִיסָה לָאָרֶץ לֹא הָיְתָה קַלָּה בִּגְלַל הַהַגְבָּלוֹת שֶׁהֵטִילוּ הַשִּׁלְטוֹנוֹת הַתּוּרְכִּיִּים, הָאֳנִיָּה בָּהּ נָסַע רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע עָגְנָה אֵיפוֹא בְּאֶחָד מִנִּמְלֵי סוּרְיָה, הַנָּמֵל הַהוּא לֹא הָיָה מְתֻקָּן לַעֲגִינַת אֳנִיּוֹת כְּגוֹן אֵלּוּ, וְהַסַּפָּנִים הֶעֱלוּ אוֹתוֹ לַחוֹף בְּעֶזְרַת חֲבָלִים, מִכָּאן יָצָא רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע, וְנִלְווּ אֵלָיו רַעְיָתוֹ וּשְׁנֵי נְכָדָיו הַיְתוֹמִים, עַל גַּבֵּי חֲמוֹרִים דֶּרֶךְ הַמִּדְבָּר, תּוֹךְ יְגִיעוֹת וּתְלָאוֹת רַבּוֹת, כַּמָּה פְּעָמִים אִיְּמוּ עֲלֵיהֶם שׁוֹדְדִים וְגַזְלָנִים, וְהֵם נֶאֶלְצוּ לִמְצֹא מַחְסֶה עַד שֶׁהִגִּיעוּ בְּחַסְדֵי ה' לְאֶרֶץ הַקּוֹדֶשׁ, וְאֶת יְרוּשָׁלַיִם עיה"ק אִוָּה לְמוֹשָׁב לוֹ.
כְּבֶן שִׁשִּׁים בְּקֵירוּב הָיָה רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע בִּשְׁנַת תרנ"ח, כַּאֲשֶׁר הִגִּיעַ לְאֶרֶץ הַקּוֹדֶשׁ, יַחַד עִם רַעְיָתוֹ וּשְׁנַיִם מִנְּכָדָיו, מִיָּד עִם עֲלִיָּתוֹ נִתְקַבֵּל בְּכָבוֹד עָצוּם ע"י גְּדוֹלֵי יְרוּשָׁלַיִם, חֲסִידִים וּפְרוּשִׁים גַּם יַחַד, שֶׁהִבִּיעוּ אֶת קוֹרַת רוּחָם עַל הָאֲרִי שֶׁעָלָה מִבָּבֶל וְקָבַע אֶת מוֹשָׁבוֹ בעיה"ק.לְפִי מָסֹרֶת שֶׁבְּעַל פֶּה נוֹעַד שָׁנִים אֲחָדוֹת לִפְנֵי כֵן עִם הַגָּאוֹן הָאַדִּיר רַשְׁכְּבָהַ"ג רַבִּי שְׁנֵיאוֹר זַלְמָן מִלּוּבְּלִין בַּעַל "תּוֹרַת חֶסֶד" וְהֵם הִמְתִּיקוּ סוֹד בֵּינֵיהֶם לַעֲלוֹת בְּיַחַד לְאֶרֶץ הַקּוֹדֶשׁ. בֵּינְתַיִם הִלְשִׁינוּ עַל בַּעַל "תּוֹרַת חֶסֶד" וְהָיָה צָפוּי לְמַעֲצָר ע"י הַשִּׁלְטוֹנוֹת הַפּוֹלָנִיִּים וְלָכֵן נֶאֱלַץ לְהַקְדִּים אֶת עֲלִיָּתוֹ לִירוּשָׁלַיִם, הוּא שָׂמַח אֵיפוֹא בְּיוֹתֵר, כַּאֲשֶׁר רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע עָלָה לִירוּשָׁלַיִם. לְיָמִים אַף הֵטִיל עָלָיו אֶת כְּהוּנַת הָרַאֲבַ"ד בְּבַדָּ"צ חֲסִידִים שֶׁהוּקַם עַל יָדוֹ בעיה"ק.
בַּיָּמִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים לַעֲלִיָּתוֹ נִכְנַס לְקַבֵּל אֶת פְּנֵי מָרָא דְּאַתְרָא רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל סָלַנְט וְתוֹךְ שִׂיחָתָם בְּדִבְרֵי תּוֹרָה הִבְחִין רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בִּגְדֻלָּתוֹ וְהִתְרַגֵּשׁ בְּיוֹתֵר מִנִּסְיוֹנוֹ בְּהוֹרָאָה. בְּצֵאת הָאוֹרֵחַ מִבֵּיתוֹ, הִפְטִיר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל "נִפְתְּרָה אַחַת הַבְּעָיוֹת שֶׁהֵעִיקוּ עַל יְרוּשָׁלַיִם נִיתַּן כְּבָר לְהָקִים בַּדָּ"צ חֲסִידִים", נִיבָּא וְיָדַע מַה נִיבָּא, שֶׁכֵּן בַּשָּׁנִים הַקְּרוֹבוֹת נִבְחַר רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע לְכַהֵן כְּרַאֲבַ"ד לַעֲדַת הַחֲסִידִים.הָיָה זֶה שָׁנָה שְׁנָתַיִם לְאַחַר עֲלִיָּתוֹ, בַּעַל "תּוֹרַת חֶסֶד", שֶׁהֵחֵל בַּהֲכָנוֹת לְיַיסֵּד בַּדָּ"צ לַעֲדַת הַחֲסִידִים, הֵצִיעַ לִפְנֵי רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע אֶת כְּהוּנַת הָרַאֲב"ד בְּבֵית הַדִּין. בְּרִאשׁוֹנָה סֵירַב רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע לְכַהֵן כְּרַאֲבַ"ד וְהִצִּיעַ לְפָנָיו מוּעֲמָדִים אֲחֵרִים, אוּלָם בַּעַל "תּוֹרַת חֶסֶד" טָעַן אִתּוֹ: "חָזֵי דְּעַלָּךְ קָא סְמִיכְנָא, אִם לֹא תֵיעָנֶה לְהַצָּעָתִי לְכַהֵן כְּרַאֲבַ"ד, לֹא יוּקַם בֵּית הַדִּין".לְשֵׁמַע דְּבָרָיו הַנִּמְרָצִים שֶׁל בַּעַל "תּוֹרַת חֶסֶד" הִרְכִּין רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ וְנַעֲנָה לַתְּבִיעָה, וּבְמֶשֶׁךְ שְׁלוֹשִׁים הַשָּׁנִים הַבָּאוֹת שִׁמֵּשׁ כְּמַנְהִיגָהּ הָרוּחָנִי שֶׁל הָעֵדָה הַחֲסִידִית בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם.
בְּמַעֲמָדוֹ כְּרַאֲבַ"ד בַּדָּ"ץ דַּחֲסִידִים נִמְנָה בֵּין רָאשֵׁי וּמַנְהִיגֵי הַיַּהֲדוּת הַנֶּאֱמָנָה בְּעִיר הַקּוֹדֶשׁ וְהִתְיַצֵּב בְּרֹאשׁ הַמַּעֲרָכוֹת עַל קְדֻשַּׁת יְרוּשָׁלַיִם וְאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל. זֹאת וְעוֹד, רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע הָיָה אֶחָד הָאִישִׁים הַבּוֹדְדִים שֶׁיָּכְלוּ לְרַכֵּז סְבִיבָם אֶת כָּל חוּגֵי הַיַּהֲדוּת הַנֶּאֱמָנָה, לַמְרוֹת חִילּוּקֵי הַדֵּעוֹת וְהַהַשְׁקָפוֹת בֵּינֵיהֶם. הָיָה זֶה סִמְלִי כִּי בִּבְרִית הַמִּילָה אֵצֶל נֶכְדּוֹ שֶׁנֶּעֱרַךְ כְּחָדְשַׁיִם סְפוּרִים לִפְנֵי פְּטִירָתוֹ, שִׁימֵּשׁ רַבִּי חַיִּים זוֹנֶנְפֶלְד כְּמוֹהֵל וְאִילּוּ הָרַב קוּק נִתְכַּבֵּד בְּסַנְדְּקָאוּת, וּבְפִי זִקְנֵי יְרוּשָׁלַיִם סוֹבְבִים חִדּוּשֵׁי הַתּוֹרָה שֶׁהוּשְׁמְעוּ בְּמַעֲמָד זֶה.
כָּאָמוּר נִפְטְרוּ עָלָיו כָּל יוֹצְאֵי חֲלָצָיו בְּחַיָּיו, וְאַחַת מִמַּטְּרוֹתָיו שֶׁל רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע בַּעֲלִיָּתוֹ לְאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל הָיְתָה לְהִבָּנוֹת וְכוּ', לְאַחַר פְּטִירַת אֵשֶׁת נְעוּרָיו מָרַת חַוָּה לֵאָה ע"ה, בְּיוֹם ב' אֲדָר תר"ס, הִצִּיעוּ לְפָנָיו לִבְנוֹת אֶת בֵּיתוֹ עִם הָאִשָּׁה הַצְּנוּעָה מָרַת תָּמָר, בִּתּוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ג רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב יִשְׂרָאֵל שׁוֹאֵל בהרה"ג רַבִּי מָרְדְּכַי בְּנוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן הָאַדִּיר רַשְׁכְּבָהַ"ג רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב מִלִּיסָא זַצַ"ל בַּעַל הַ"נְּתִיבוֹת" וְהַ"חַוַּת דַּעַת".
לְאַחַר הַחֻפָּה סִפֵּר לָהּ רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע שֶׁבִּשְׁעַת הַחֻפָּה נִרְאֲתָה לְפָנָיו דְּמוּת דְּיוֹקְנוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיהָ, שֶׁהָיָה כְּבָר זֶה כַּמָּה שָׁנִים בְּעָלְמָא דִּקְשׁוֹט, מֵעוֹלָם לֹא רָאָה אוֹתוֹ שֶׁכֵּן נִפְטַר לִפְנֵי עֲלִיָּתוֹ אוּלָם כַּאֲשֶׁר תֵּאֵר רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע בְּפָנֶיהָ אֶת דְּמוּת דְּיוֹקְנוֹ, הוּפְתְּעָה בְּיוֹתֵר שֶׁכֵּן תֵּאֵר אוֹתוֹ בִּמְדֻיָּק, כְּאִילּוּ הוּא עוֹמֵד לִפְנֵיהֶם.
רַבִּי שְׁנֵיאוֹר זַלְמָן מִלּוּבְּלִין בַּעַל "תּוֹרַת חֶסֶד" הֶעֱנִיק לָהֶם אֶת בִּרְכָתוֹ, לְפִי הַמְסֻפָּר נִכְנְסָה הָאִשָּׁה הַצְּעִירָה לְהִתְבָּרֵךְ וּבִקְּשָׁה מִמֶּנּוּ לְהִיפָּקֵד בְּבֵן זָכָר. הָרַב מִלּוּבְּלִין נַעֲנָה לְבַקָּשָׁתָהּ. כַּאֲשֶׁר סִפְּרָה עַל כָּךְ לְבַעְלָהּ רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע טָעַן אַתָּה "לָמָּה בִּקַּשְׁתְּ בֵּן זָכָר, הָיִית צְרִיכָה לְבַקֵּשׁ בָּנִים". הָרַבָּנִית עָנְתָה כִּי לְמַרְאֵה פָּנִים הַזּוֹהֲרִים שֶׁל בַּעַל "תּוֹרַת חֶסֶד" נָפַל פַּחַד עָלֶיהָ וְלֹא הֵעִיזָה לְבַקֵּשׁ יוֹתֵר, וְאָמְנָם לִתְקוּפַת הַשָּׁנָה יָלְדָה בֵּן לְרַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע, בִּתְקוּפַת הַבֵּינַיִם נִפְטַר בַּעַל "תּוֹרַת חֶסֶד" לְבֵית עוֹלָמוֹ, וְהַיֶּלֶד נִקְרָא עַל שְׁמוֹ שְׁנֵיאוֹר זַלְמָן, וְעַל שֵׁם הַסַּבָּא יַעֲקֹב יִשְׂרָאֵל.
כְּתִיבָתָהּ שֶׁל סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה הוּשְׁלְמָה עִם פִּדְיוֹן הַבֵּן. בְּשַׁעַת הַפִּדְיוֹן בָּכָה רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע, לִשְׁאֵלָתוֹ שֶׁל הרה"צ רַבִּי דָּוִד בִּידֶרְמָן הִבִּיעַ רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע אֶת מִשְׁאֲלָתוֹ שֶׁיִּזְכֶּה לְהַכְנִיס אֶת הַבֵּן הַיִּלּוֹד לְחֻפָּה, וְאָמְנָם נִתְבָּרֵךְ ע"י רַבִּי דָּוִד, וְזָכָה רַבִּי דּוֹדְצֶ'ע לְהוֹלִיךְ לְחֻפָּה אֶת בְּנוֹ הַנַּ"ל...
