When I studied under the Gaon Rabbi Tzvi Kinstlicher Zt"l, a certain Admor lived there near the Yeshiva. There were young men who desired to play a prank. When the Admor entered to pray and took off his outer coat and his gold cane, the young men took them and dressed one of the group members in them. They stood him next to the Admor so that when he finished the Amidah prayer, he would see him standing there dressed in his clothes. Indeed, when the Admor saw the young man, the matter disturbed him, and he went to tell the story as it happened to the Rosh Yeshiva, HaGaon Rabbi Tzvi Kinstlicher.
The Rabbi was very shaken by the deed his students had done. In the next class, before he began to say the lesson, he said: "Our Sages said: **זכה נעשית לו סם חיים לא זכה נעשים לו סם מות** - 'If he merits, it becomes for him a potion of life; if he does not merit, it becomes for him a potion of death.' And one who makes a mockery of a Jew, and all the more so of the son of holy ones, certainly does not merit the potion of life through the Torah." With this, he closed the Gemara that was before him and declared: "I do not wish to bequeath the potion of death to you..." and he left without saying the lesson. His words, which were spoken with truth and a broken heart over the pain of a Jew, still echo in my ears.
Source: Mipi Sefarim VeSofrim

At the outbreak of the Second World War by the oppressive Germans, may their names be obliterated, people spoke in terror about the pogroms and atrocities committed by the wicked ones. They passed news and rumors that reached them about the destruction of the House of Israel from mouth to ear. Sometimes, even during the time of prayer, groups of men stood outside the synagogue discussing the sensational news, and consequently, some of the congregants were drawn into the conversation.
So it was in our city, Hermannstadt. The Rabbi of the city, our teacher HaGaon Rabbi Tzvi Kinstlicher Zt"l, sought to awaken the people regarding the severity of talking during prayer and the reading of the Torah, especially since because of this they missed answering Amen, Kaddish, Kedusha, and Barchu. Therefore, he preached and said with eloquent language the following words:
It is told that a priest asked the Holy Gaon Rabbi Yonasan Eybeschutz Zt"l why in houses of prayer, the gentiles stand with respect and awe, whereas in synagogues and study halls, there are sometimes people who are inattentive and talk. Rabbi Yonasan answered him wisely to defend the Children of Israel by way of a parable: Behold, a servant, upon coming before his king, will certainly stand in fear and trembling, for the fear of his master is upon his head. So too, the nations of the world are likened to servants, and therefore they stand in houses of prayer in fear and dread. Not so is the one who enters his father's presence. For in whatever state a son enters to his father, he does not fear him. And behold, the Children of Israel are the children of the Lord G-d, as it is written: **בנים אתם לה' אלקיכם** - "You are children to the L-rd your G-d." Because of this, it is found that they talk in synagogues.
Based on this, the Gaon Rabbi Tzvi Kinstlicher preached as follows and said to interpret the verse (Devarim 14:1) with a witticism: Indeed, **בנים אתם לה' אלקיכם** - "You are children to the L-rd your G-d," and because of this, you do not fear so much to speak before Him. However, our Sages have already interpreted (Yevamot 13b) the continuation of the verse **לא תתגדדו** - "You shall not cut yourselves" as **לא תעשו אגודות אגודות** - "Do not form separate factions." Meaning, let there not be conversation in groups of people and in public. Know your sin before the Omnipresent, for the severity of the iniquity in this is great. Although there is a defense for the speakers here, certainly one must prevent and be careful of idle chatter during prayer, for its evil is great.
Source: Mipi Sefarim VeSofrim

כֵּן הָיָה בְּעִירֵנוּ הֶעְרְמַנְשְׁטָאדְט וְרַב הָעִיר מוֹ"ר הַגְּ"ר צְבִי קִינְסְטְלִיכֶר זַצַ"ל בִּקֵּשׁ לְעוֹרֵר אֶת הָעָם עַל חֹמֶר הַדִּבּוּר בְּשַׁעַת הַתְּפִלָּה וּקְרִיאַת הַתּוֹרָה, וּבִפְרָט שֶׁעַל יְדֵי זֶה הִפְסִידוּ עֲנִיַּת אָמֵן וְקַדִּישׁ וּקְדֻשָּׁה וּבָרְכוּ, וְעַל כֵּן דָּרַשׁ וְהִגִּיד בְּצַחוּת לָשׁוֹן, אֶת הַדְּבָרִים דִּלְהַלָּן:
מְסַפְּרִים שֶׁכֹּמֶר אֶחָד שָׁאַל אֶת הַגָּה"ק רַבִּי יְהוֹנָתָן אַיְיבְּשִׁיץ זִי"עַ מַדּוּעַ בְּבָתֵּי הַתִּפְלָה עוֹמְדִים הַגּוֹיִם בְּדֶרֶךְ אֶרֶץ וּבְאֵימָה וְאִילּוּ בְּבָתֵּי כְּנֵסִיּוֹת וּמִדְרָשׁוֹת יֵשׁ לְעִתִּים אֲנָשִׁים שֶׁאֵינָם מַשְׁגִּיחִים וּמְדַבְּרִים, עָנָהוּ הָרַבִּי ר' יְהוֹנָתָן בְּחָכְמָה לְהַמְלִיץ טוֹב עַל בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּדֶרֶךְ מָשָׁל, דְּהִנֵּה עֶבֶד בְּבוֹאוֹ לִפְנֵי מַלְכּוֹ וַדַּאי יִתְיַצֵּב בְּפַחַד וּרְעָדָה כִּי מוֹרָא אֲדוֹנוֹ עַל רֹאשׁוֹ, וְכֵן נַמִּי אֻמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם נִמְשְׁלוּ לַעֲבָדִים וּלְפִיכָךְ עוֹמְדִים הֵם בְּבָתֵּי תִּפְלָה בְּמוֹרָא וּבְפַחַד, לֹא כֵן הַנִּכְנָס לְאָבִיו, שֶׁבֵּן בְּאֵיזֶה מַצָּב שֶׁהוּא עָיֵיל לְגַבֵּיהּ אָבִיו וְלָא דָּחִיל מִינֵּיהּ, וַהֲרֵי בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל הֵם בְּנֵי הָאָדוֹן ה' כִּדְכְתִיב "בָּנִים אַתֶּם לַה' אֱלֹקֵיכֶם" וּמִשּׁוּם הָכִי הִמָּצֵא תִּמְצָא שֶׁמְּדַבְּרִים בְּבָתֵּי כְּנֵסִיּוֹת.
עַל פִּי זֶה דָּרַשׁ כְּחֹמֶר הַגְּרַ"צ קִינְסְטְלִיכֶר וְאָמַר לְפָרֵשׁ בִּמְלִיצָה הַפָּסוּק (דְּבָרִים י"ד, א') הֵן אָמְנָם "בָּנִים אַתֶּם לַה' אֱלֹקֵיכֶם" וּבְגִין כָּךְ אֵינְכֶם יְרֵאִים כָּל כָּךְ מִלְּדַבֵּר לְפָנָיו, אַךְ כְּבָר דָּרְשׁוּ חֲזַ"ל (יְבָמוֹת יג:) עַל הֶמְשֵׁךְ הַפָּסוּק "לֹא תִתְגֹּדְדוּ - לֹא תַּעֲשׂוּ אֲגֻדּוֹת אֲגֻדּוֹת" הַיְנוּ שֶׁלֹּא תִּהְיֶה הַשִּׁיחָה בַּאֲגֻדּוֹת אֲנָשִׁים וּבָרַבִּים, וּדְעוּ חַטַּאתְכֶם לִפְנֵי הַמָּקוֹם כִּי חֹמֶר הֶעָווֹן בָּזֶה גָּדוֹל הוּא, וְהַגַּם שֶׁלִּמּוּד זְכוּת יֵשׁ כָּאן עַל הַמְּדַבְּרִים, וַדַּאי שֶׁיֵּשׁ לִמְנֹעַ וּלְהִזָּהֵר מִשִּׁיחָה בְּטֵלָה בְּשַׁעַת הַתְּפִלָּה כִּי רַבָּה רָעָתָהּ.הגה"ח רבי אליעזר דוד פרידמן שליט"א"מפי ספרים וסופרים" (ב"ב תשס"ח) ח"ב, ע' תכ"ב

When I studied Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah Part 1 with my teacher and Rabbi, the Gaon and Chassid Rabbi Meir Maggid Zt"l (died 21 Tammuz 1983), in order to be tested and crowned with Rabbinic ordination, the Rebbe [the Holy Admor, the *Yeshuot Moshe* of Vizhnitz] Zt"l guided me to review the words of the *Mechaber* (Author of Shulchan Aruch) and the *Rema*, as well as the words of the *Noda BiYehuda* and the *Shach*, by heart. The Rebbe also tested me several times on the language of the *Mechaber* and *Rema* by heart. This guidance was very helpful to me. For when the elderly Gaon Rabbi Tzvi Kinstlicher, Av Beis Din of Sibiu Zt"l [author of *Be'er Tzvi*], tested me for three consecutive days, the Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah Part 1 lay closed on his table. Yet, with all that, he tested me on every single page without missing a page.
This is how they studied in previous generations. They also knew by heart all the sections of *Nekudos HaKesef*, *Dagul Mervava*, *Chatam Sofer*, *Be'er Heitev*, and also included all the *Pri Megadim* from beginning to end.
Source: Otzar Efraim

The Gaon Rabbi Tzvi Kinstlicher was a very great man, and I merited his closeness. I was in his presence often. His service in holiness was with immense enthusiasm. Already during the recitation of "Barchi Nafshi," while wrapping himself in the Tallis, he would shout and become inflamed with great intensity. The Holy Rabbi Yehuda of Dzikov Zt"l would come to stand next to him during prayer because he wanted to listen to his prayers. With his eloquent tongue, he would ask about his Mincha and Maariv prayers, if they were Yom Kippur prayers, for he prayed with such adhesion and outpouring of the soul that regular people pray on the Holy Day.
Source: Mipi Sefarim VeSofrim

In the period before the Second World War, a great man named HaGaon Rabbi Tzvi Kinstlicher Zt"l, Av Beis Din of Hermannstadt-Sibiu, lived in Romania [after the war he lived in Jerusalem and was very close to HaGaon Rabbi Yosef Tzvi Dushinsky Zt"l, and the Holy Rabbi Yehuda Horowitz of Dzikov Zt"l basked in his shadow]. One year, in the month of Nissan, he felt terrible pains in his stomach. He traveled to the city of Klausenburg to seek expert doctors who could find a cure for his illness. Indeed, what he feared came upon him, for after repeated examinations, they informed him that a severe illness was nesting in his body, and they had to operate to uproot and cure the disease.
When the Gaon received the hard news, he said, "I could not agree to this, to be in the hospital during the days of the holiday, and I trusted in G-d that I would not transgress 'Bal Te'acher' (do not delay), and I came to my home." Lacking a choice, the doctors agreed to postpone the surgery but warned him strictly not to eat anything except milk, eggs, and orange juice, and certainly not to eat bread.
He conducted the Seder night as was his way, with uplifted spirit and enthusiasm of the soul, with joy and gladness. At the time of eating the Matzah, he decided to transgress the doctors' words and ate an olive's bulk (Kazayis) of Matzah soaked in milk on both nights. "And by the mercies of G-d, they did not end, for on the second night after the Seder, the pains completely departed, as if they never were, and I felt no pain, thank G-d."
On the Shabbos after Pesach, he went up to the Bimah and informed the public of his distress, that he had to undergo a dangerous surgery, and that they should pray for him and ask for mercy on his behalf. He delivered parting words to them with shedding tears, fearing he might not merit, Heaven forbid, to rise from his sickbed, for who knows what the Blessed Name would decree upon him.
After a few days, he traveled back to Klausenburg to the doctor, who examined him with repeat tests before the surgery. But at that hour, he was amazed and astounded by the sight: the illness had completely disappeared, and he found no bad thing in the place of the stomach. He was sure in his mind that in the meantime, he had visited an expert doctor who had cured his illness completely. Out of great excitement, he asked him to reveal who was the doctor who succeeded in healing him completely. The Gaon replied that he had not been to any doctor, only that on the Seder night he ate the Kazayis of Matzah from the "Food of Healing," and through this, he merited a complete recovery. "And [the doctor] answered and said that a great miracle was done for me, and he admitted that the knowledge and wisdom of medicine is as nothing against the will of the Creator, Blessed be His Name."
The owner of the story himself wrote the entire sequence of events to his friend and in-law, the Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Welz Zt"l, and concludes there: "Please deliver the content of the letter to my son, may he live, so that he too may know to give thanks and praise to His Name, may He be blessed, for all the kindness He has bestowed upon me, and let him bless the blessing 'Who performed miracles for our fathers'" (The letter was printed in full in *Be'er Tzvi*, section of letters, letter 32). Also, witnesses who heard it recounted with longing how the Gaon described to them how he felt that the Matzahs worked to remove all his pains from him.
Source: Hagash"p Be'er HaChaim

body_he: בְּשַׁבָּת אַחֲרֵי פֶּסַח עָלָה לַבִּימָה, וְהוֹדִיעַ אֶת צַעֲרוֹ לָרַבִּים, שֶׁעָלָיו לַעֲבֹר נִתּוּחַ מְסֻכָּן וְשֶׁיִּתְפַּלְּלוּ בַּעֲדוֹ וִיבַקְּשׁוּ עָלָיו רַחֲמִים. וּמָסַר לִפְנֵיהֶם דִּבְרֵי פְּרֵידָה בְּדִמְעוֹת שָׁלִישׁ שֶׁמָּא לֹא יִזְכֶּה חָלִילָה לָקוּם מִמִּטַּת חָלְיוֹ, כִּי מִי יוֹדֵעַ מַה יִּגְזֹר עָלָיו הַשֵּׁי"ת. לְאַחַר כַּמָּה יָמִים נָסַע שׁוּב לִקְלוֹיזְנְבּוּרְג אֶל הָרוֹפֵא, שֶׁבָּדַק אוֹתוֹ בִּבְדִיקוֹת חוֹזְרוֹת טֶרֶם הַנִּתּוּחַ, אַךְ בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה נִדְהַם וְנִשְׁתּוֹמֵם מִן הַמַּחֲזֶה שֶׁהַמַּחֲלָה נֶעֶלְמָה כָּלִיל, וְלֹא מָצָא שׁוּם רֵעוּתָא בִּמְקוֹם הַקֵּבָה, וְהָיָה בָּטוּחַ בְּדַעְתּוֹ שֶׁבֵּינְתַיִם בִּקֵּר אֵצֶל רוֹפֵא מֻמְחֶה שֶׁרִפֵּא אֶת מַחֲלָתוֹ, וּמֵרֹב הִתְפַּעֲלוּת בִּקֵּשׁ שֶׁיְּגַלֶּה לוֹ מִי הוּא הָרוֹפֵא שֶׁהִצְלִיחַ לִרְפָאוֹתוֹ רְפוּאָה שְׁלֵימָה, וְהֵשִׁיב הַגְּרַ"צ שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה אֵצֶל שׁוּם רוֹפֵא, רַק אָכַל בְּלֵיל הַסֵּדֶר אֶת הַכְּזַיִת מַצָּה מֵיכְלָא דְּאָסְוָותָא, וְעַל יְדֵי כָּךְ זָכָה לִרְפוּאָה שְׁלֵימָה, "וְעָנָה [הָרוֹפֵא] וְאָמַר, שֶׁנֵּס גָּדוֹל נַעֲשָׂה לִי, וְהוֹדָה שֶׁיְּדִיעַת וְחָכְמַת הָרְפוּאָה הוּא כְּאַיִן נֶגֶד רְצוֹן הַבּוֹרֵא יִתְ"שׁ". בַּעַל הַמַּעֲשֶׂה עַצְמוֹ כּוֹתֵב אֶת כָּל הִשְׁתַּלְשְׁלוּת הַדְּבָרִים אֶל יְדִידוֹ וּמְחֻתָּנוֹ הַגָּה"צ רַבִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל וֶועלְץ זַצַ"ל, וּמְסַיֵּם שָׁם: "נָא לִמְסֹר תֹּכֶן הַמִּכְתָּב לִבְנִי שֶׁיִּחְיֶה, שֶׁיֵּדַע גַּם הוּא לְהוֹדוֹת וּלְהַלֵּל לִשְׁמוֹ יִתְבָּרֵךְ עַל כָּל הַחֶסֶד אֲשֶׁר גְּמָלַנִי, וִיבָרֵךְ בִּרְכַּת שֶׁעָשָׂה נִסִּים לַאֲבוֹתֵינוּ" (הַמִּכְתָּב הֻדְפַּס בִּמְלוֹאוֹ בְּ'בְּאֵר צְבִי' חֵלֶק הָאִגְּרוֹת, מִכְתָּב לב), וְגַם עֵדֵי שְׁמִיעָה הָיוּ מְסַפְּרִים בְּעֶרְגָּה, אֵיךְ הָיָה הַגְּרַ"צ מְתָאֵר לָהֶם אֵיךְ הִרְגִּישׁ שֶׁהַמַּצּוֹת פָּעֲלוּ לְהָסִיר מִמֶּנּוּ אֶת כָּל מַכְאוֹבָיו.הגה"צ רבי אלימלך בידרמן שליט"א"הגש"פ באר החיים" (ירושלים תשע"ד) ע' ס"א

**Biography**
He was born in Jerusalem, the Holy City, on the 1st of Adar, 1889, to his father, the Gaon and Tzaddik Rabbi Nesanel HaLevi Zt"l, who merited to serve in holiness near the author of *Chidushei HaRim*, and was among the great Chassidim of the author of *Sfas Emes*, and among those who frequented the homes of the Gaon of Lublin, author of *Toras Chesed*, Rabbi A. of Mszczonow, and Rabbi Yeshayale of Praga.
After the passing of the *Chidushei HaRim*, Rabbi Nesanel's wife became very ill. His Rebbe, the *Sfas Emes*, instructed him that the path to her recovery lay in their immigration to the Land of Israel. This was an open miracle, as there was no chance by way of nature that she would survive the hardships of the journey. Indeed, they ascended to the Holy Land, and she lived for many days.
One day, Rabbi Nesanel decided to travel to his Rebbe, the *Sfas Emes*, in Poland—a journey that lasted a full year. He and his wife were already elderly, and he did not think at all that he would be built up further (have more children). Upon arriving before the *Sfas Emes*, the Rebbe said to him: "Expecting a male son!" Rabbi Nesanel sat and wrote a letter to his friend, Rabbi Avrumtshe Mintzberg in Jerusalem, containing precise instructions regarding the Bris—what name to give the newborn, who would be the Sandak, etc. When he returned to Jerusalem, his friend asked him, "How did you know at all that a son was about to be born to you?" Rabbi Nesanel replied, "What is the question? The Rebbe said so!" This son was my grandfather, Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak, who was born in his father's old age.
Source: Pe'er Yisrael

..."The truth is that when he [=his brother, the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Auerbach *zt"l*] got married, I was only a child of ten. Besides that, it has been about sixty years that I am in the category of a 'villager' and far from my father's house in Jerusalem, so I do not have much to add and innovate in my poverty."
"I remember as a small child how he was always diligent in his studies in the Breslov *Shtiebel* in Shaarei Chesed. In his time, it was a shack with tin and not a building like today. The order then in the Talmud Torah 'Etz Chaim' was that the first grades of the Talmud Torah were branches in all the neighborhoods, and afterward, they moved to the center in Machane Yehuda. I was a small child in the branch of Shaarei Chesed, and I would play outside near the synagogue. To this day, his wondrous image stands before my eyes as he sits there for hours upon hours and studies day and night with tremendous diligence. I remember this as a small child. When he was about a lad of seventeen, I saw him studying Tractate Avodah Zarah with wondrous diligence. I remember that I did not understand then why he was not studying Bava Kamma and Bava Metzia like everyone else... Already then, he had high and lofty attainments more than everyone."
"He indeed studied in the Etz Chaim Yeshiva, where he studied in *Chavrusa* with his friends, the wondrous Gaon Rabbi Efraim Zalaznik *zt"l* and the mighty Gaon Rabbi Meir Soloveitchik *zt"l* and others. However, the form of the Yeshiva then was not similar to today. When over the years a complete 'Shulchan Aruch' (set structure) was formed regarding the form of a Yeshiva and a Yeshiva student and the schedules of the Yeshiva... back then in Etz Chaim, it was more of a style that each one does what his heart desires. Therefore, at times, he studied alone in other places without a framework, and there he rose and ascended with all his might."
"He had tremendous and special talents, but he was hidden and did not stand out in anything. He was hidden. By nature, he was silent. When he established the Yeshiva, Grandmother Ruchamkin *a"h* wondered: 'How can R' Shmuel be a Rosh Yeshiva? After all, he doesn't know how to open his mouth, and how will he say Shiurim...' But in the end, we saw how he shook and turned the whole world over."
"I remember his engagement party (*Tna'im*). At the end of the year 5711 (1951), his father-in-law was from the family of Karliner Chassidim from the houses of Hungary. There is a picture that lies very strongly in my head: back then, they used to make the *Tna'im* in the bride's apartment, and everything was full of people, students, neighbors, etc. He sat next to HaGaon R' Shmuel Zalaznik *zt"l*, who was one of the heads of the Etz Chaim Yeshiva. Representing the Yeshiva, my brother *zt"l* preached words of Torah as is customary. As is accepted, the public interrupted him with singing, but he paid no attention to this and continued to preach for a long hour the entire time in words of Torah despite the singing. To this day, the picture stands before my eyes of how everyone is singing and he overcomes the singing and continues with his sermon, and HaGaon R' Shmuel Zalaznik *zt"l* inclines his ears and exerts himself with all his strength to hear his words. Then, as a child, I already noticed the trait of my brother *zt"l* that he does not reckon with anything..."
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Mordechai Auerbach Shlita (from the notes of HaRav Yaakov Grossnas Shlita), "Musaf Zikaron", Adar 5778, p. 41

לְאַחַר הִסְתַּלְּקוּת הַחִידָ"ה חָלְתָה מְאוֹד זוּגָתוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי נְתַנְאֵל, רַבּוֹ הַ"שְׂפַת אֱמֶת" הוֹרָה לוֹ שֶׁהַדֶּרֶךְ לִרְפוּאָתָהּ טְמוּנָה בַּעֲלִיָּתָם לְאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל. הָיָה בְּכָךְ מוֹפֵת גָּלוּי שֶׁכֵּן לֹא הָיָה סִכּוּי עַל פִּי דֶּרֶךְ הַטֶּבַע שֶׁהִיא תִּשְׂרֹד אֶת טִלְטוּלֵי הַדֶּרֶךְ. וְאָכֵן הֵם עָלוּ לַארה"ק וְהִיא הֶאֱרִיכָה יָמִים.
בְּאֶחָד הַיָּמִים הֶחְלִיט רַבִּי נְתַנְאֵל לִנְסֹעַ אֶל רַבּוֹ הַ"שְׂפַת אֱמֶת" בְּפוֹלִין - נְסִיעָה שֶׁאָרְכָה שָׁנָה שְׁלֵימָה. הוּא וְזוּגָתוֹ כְּבָר הָיוּ בָּאִים בַּיָּמִים וּכְלָל לֹא חָשַׁב שֶׁיִּבָּנֶה עוֹד. בְּבוֹאוֹ לִפְנֵי הַ"שְׂפַת אֱמֶת" אָמַר לוֹ הָרַבִּי - "מְצַפֶּה אַתָּה לְבֵן זָכָר!" יָשַׁב רַבִּי נְתַנְאֵל וְכָתַב אִגֶּרֶת לִידִידוֹ רַבִּי אַבְרוּמְטְשֶׁע מִינְצְבֶּרְג בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם, וּבָהּ הוֹרָאוֹת מְדֻיָּקוֹת לְגַבֵּי הַבְּרִית - אֵיזֶה שֵׁם לָתֵת לָרַךְ הַנּוֹלָד, מִי יִהְיֶה הַסַּנְדָּק וְכוּ'. כְּשֶׁשָּׁב לִירוּשָׁלַיִם שְׁאָלוֹ יְדִידוֹ, וְכִי מִנַּיִן יָדַעְתָּ בִּכְלָל שֶׁעוֹמֵד לְהִוָּלֵד לְךָ בֵּן, הֵשִׁיב רַבִּי נְתַנְאֵל - 'מָה הַשְּׁאֵלָה, הֲרֵי הָרַבִּי אָמַר!' בֵּן זֶה הוּא זְקֵנִי רַבִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל יִצְחָק שֶׁנּוֹלַד לְעֵת זִקְנוּתוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו.
body_en:
He merited a special and strict upbringing. His father would wake him in the middle of the night for his studies. As he testified about himself, from the day he turned twelve, he did not sleep more than four hours, and sometimes he sufficed with three hours in a twenty-four-hour period. Until his old age, he slept less than an hour in a twenty-four-hour period! This holy service was multiplied on Thursday nights and Shabbos Kodesh and Motzaei Shabbos, when he would not go up to his bed at all and sat occupied with Torah all night.
Upon reaching the age of Bar Mitzvah, he was fluent in three tractates of the Talmud: Bava Kamma, Bava Metzia, and Bava Batra, in addition to Tractate Beitzah, which he was accustomed to knowing by heart.
He merited extra affection from the great and righteous men of Jerusalem, such as the Holy Rebbe of Barnov Zt"l, with whom he spent much time. He became very close to the Holy Rebbe R' Dovid'l Biderman Zt"l of Lelov, who showed him signs of great affection. Once, when his belt (Gartel) fell, the Rebbe of Lelov bent down to pick it up and girded him, expressing, "I have rolled a living Torah scroll!" So greatly did his estimation of him grow! Similarly, the Holy Rebbe R' Simcha Bunim of Otwock Zt"l, grandson of the Holy Rebbe of Warka Zt"l, valued him greatly.
Also in his youth, he read, studied, and served the great Torah scholars in the Holy Land, such as the Gaon, author of *Toras Chesed* of Lublin Zt"l, who liked and cherished him greatly. Especially, he appreciated the immense effort he exerted in understanding matters to their depth. He spent much time in the presence of the "Holy Grandfather," the Holy Rebbe R' Shlomo Eliezer Alfandari Zy"a. His distinct teacher in the hidden Torah (Kabbalah) was the Kabbalist, the Divine Rabbi Chaim Shaul Dweck Zt"l. He studied Kabbalah with him for six consecutive years from midnight until the Shacharis prayer. Indeed, all his days, he occupied himself greatly with the hidden Torah, as I saw myself many times. He even edited the precise proofreading for the holy book *Netiv Mitzvotecha* by the Holy Gaon Mahari of Komarno Zy"a on Sha'ar HaYichudim.
The greats and Rabbis of Jerusalem saw in him a rising light that was destined to illuminate the skies of the land with his Torah. He also merited to visit a number of times in the presence of the Rashkabahag (Leader of the Generation), the Maharil Diskin Zt"l, and the Rabbi of Jerusalem, the Gaon Rabbi Yosef Chaim Sonnenfeld Zt"l, who imparted his spirit upon him and spoke with him much in words of Torah, and literally did not move his hand from his hand.
Source: Pe'er Yisrael

הוּא זָכָה לְחִבָּה יְתֵירָה אֵצֶל גְּדוֹלֵי וְצַדִּיקֵי יְרוּשָׁלַיִם, כְּמוֹ הרה"ק מִבַּארְנוּב זַצַ"ל שֶׁהִרְבָּה לִשְׁהוֹת בִּמְחִצָּתוֹ. הִתְקָרֵב מְאוֹד לְהרה"ק ר' דּוּדִיל בִּידֶרְמַאן זַצַ"ל מִלֶּעלוֹב, אֲשֶׁר הֶרְאָה לוֹ אוֹתוֹת שֶׁל חִבָּה לָרֹב. פַּעַם בְּעֵת שֶׁנָּפַל אַבְנֵטוֹ הִרְכִּין הרה"ק מִלֶּעלוֹב אֶת עַצְמוֹ לַהֲרִימָהּ, וַחֲגָרוֹ כְּשֶׁהוּא מִתְבַּטֵּא 'גָּלַלְתִּי סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה חַי'! עַד כְּדֵי כָּךְ גָּבְרָה הַעֲרָכָתוֹ אֵלָיו! כֵּן הֶעֱרִיכוֹ מְאֹד הרה"ק ר' שִׂמְחָה בּוּנִים מֵאטְווֹצְק זַצַ"ל נֶכֶד הרה"ק מִוּוֹרְקָא זַצַ"ל.עוֹד בִּצְעִירוּתוֹ הוּא קָרָא וְשָׁנָה וְשִׁמֵּשׁ אֶת גְּדוֹלֵי תַּלְמִידֵי הַחֲכָמִים בַּארה"ק כְּהַגָּה"ק בַּעַל "תּוֹרַת חֶסֶד" מִלּוּבְּלִין זַצַ"ל, אֲשֶׁר חִבְּבוֹ וְהוֹקִירוֹ מְאֹד. וּבִפְרָט הֶעֱרִיךְ אֶת הַיְגִיעָה הָעֲצוּמָה שֶׁמִּתְיַגֵּעַ בַּהֲבָנַת הַדְּבָרִים לְעֻמְקָן. הוּא הִסְתּוֹפֵף רַבּוֹת בִּמְחִצָּתוֹ שֶׁל הַסַּבָּא קַדִּישָׁא הרה"ק ר' שְׁלֹמֹה אֱלִיעֶזֶר אַלְפַאנְדְּרִי זִי"עַ, רַבּוֹ הַמֻּבְהָק בְּתוֹרַת הַנִּסְתָּר הָיָה הַמְקֻבָּל הָאֱלֹקִי רַבִּי חַיִּים שָׁאוּל דְּוֵויק זַצַ"ל, אֶצְלוֹ לָמַד קַבָּלָה בְּמֶשֶׁךְ 6 שָׁנִים רְצוּפוֹת מֵחֲצוֹת לַיְלָה וְעַד תְּפִלַּת שַׁחֲרִית, וְאָכֵן כָּל יָמָיו עָסַק רַבּוֹת בְּתוֹרַת הַנִּסְתָּר כְּפִי שֶׁרָאִיתִי בְּעַצְמִי פְּעָמִים רַבּוֹת. וְהוּא אַף עָרַךְ הַגָּהָה הַמְדֻקְדֶּקֶת לַסּה"ק "נְתִיב מִצְווֹתֶיךָ" לְהַגָּה"ק מַהֲרִי"א מִקָּאמַרְנָא זִי"עַ עַל שַׁעַר הַיִּחוּדִים.
גְּדוֹלֶיהָ וְרַבָּנֶיהָ שֶׁל יְרוּשָׁלַיִם רָאוּ בּוֹ אוֹר עוֹלֶה שֶׁעוֹד עָתִיד לְהָאִיר שְׁמֵי אֶרֶץ בְּתוֹרָתוֹ. כֵּן זָכָה לְבַקֵּר פְּעָמִים מִסְפָּר בִּמְחִצָּתוֹ שֶׁל רַשְׁכְּבָהַ"ג מַהֲרִי"ל דִּיסְקִין זַצַ"ל, וְרַבָּהּ שֶׁל יְרוּשָׁלַיִם הַגָּה"ק רי"ח זוֹנֶנְפֶלְד זַצַ"ל שֶׁהֶאֱצִיל מֵרוּחוֹ עָלָיו וְהִרְבָּה לְהִשְׁתַּעֲשֵׁעַ עִמּוֹ בְּדִבְרֵי תוֹרָה, וּמַמָּשׁ לֹא זָזָה יָדוֹ מִתּוֹךְ יָדוֹ.
עוֹד בִּהְיוֹתוֹ צָעִיר לְיָמִים בִּקֵּשׁ מִמֶּנּוּ מְאֹד לְהִצְטָרֵף כְּחָבֵר הַבַּדַ"ץ. אֲבָל אִמּוֹ בִּקְּשָׁה מִמֶּנּוּ שֶׁלֹּא יְשַׁמֵּשׁ כְּדַיָּן - וְנִמּוּקָהּ בְּפִיהָ - בְּאוֹתָם הַיָּמִים כְּשֶׁנִּפְטַר אָדָם, הָיוּ הַמְמֻנִּים מוֹצִיאִים אֶת הָאַלְמָנָה מִבֵּיתָהּ וּמְשַׁכְּנִים אוֹתָהּ בְּחַדְרוֹן כָּלְשֶׁהוּ. אִמּוֹ טָעֲנָה 'וְכִי תִּהְיֶה דַּיָּן וְתִצְטָרֵךְ לָתֵת יָד לְעַוְלָה שֶׁכָּזוֹ?!' וְאָכֵן בְּמֶשֶׁךְ שָׁנִים אֲרֻכּוֹת הוּא סֵרֵב לִהְיוֹת דַּיָּן, עַד שֶׁעָלָה לִירוּשָׁלַיִם מַהֲרִי"ץ דּוּשִׁינְסְקִיָא זַצַ"ל שֶׁהִפְצִיר בּוֹ רַבּוֹת לְקַבֵּל עָלָיו אֶת הַמִּנּוּי, וְלַמְרוֹת טַעֲנָתוֹ שֶׁל רַבֵּינוּ כִּי לֹא יוּכַל עוֹד לְשַׁמֵּשׁ כְּגַבַּאי צְדָקָה, הִתִּיר לוֹ מַהֲרִי"ץ לְשַׁמֵּשׁ בִּשְׁנֵי הַתַּפְקִידִים יַחַד.בְּט"ז בְּכִסְלֵו תש"ב, קִבֵּל מִכְתַּב הַתְמַנּוּת מִמַּנְהִיגֵי יְרוּשָׁלַיִם לִהְיוֹת דַּיָּן וּמוֹרֶה צֶדֶק בְּבֵית דִּין שֶׁל הָעֵדָה הַחֲרֵדִית, וּמִנִּי אָז יָצָא שְׁמוֹ לִתְהִלָּה עַל פְּנֵי כָּל קַצְוֵוי תֵּבֵל, וְעַל פִּתְחֵי בֵּיתוֹ הִתְדַּפְּקוּ לִשְׁמֹעַ מוֹצָא פִּיו. בְּאוֹתָם יָמִים הָיוּ שְׁנֵי בָּתֵּי דִּין, הָאֶחָד שֶׁל "פְּרוּשִׁים" וְהַשֵּׁנִי שֶׁל "חֲסִידִים", זְקֵנִי שִׁמֵּשׁ כְּרַאֲבַ"ד בַּדַ"ץ חֲסִידִים. בִּתְקוּפָה מְאֻחֶרֶת יוֹתֵר הִתְאַחֲדוּ שְׁנֵי בָּתֵּי הַדִּין. כְּחָבֵר הַבַּדַ"ץ הוּא הָיָה מְמֻנֶּה עַל שְׁנֵי תַּפְקִידִים כִּבְדֵי מִשְׁקָל - כַּשְׁרוּת הַמִּקְוָואוֹת, וּסְמִיכַת חֲכָמִים.
פַּעַם הִבִּיעַ בְּצַחוּת לְשׁוֹנוֹ שֶׁאִילּוּ הָיָה מְלַמֵּד פָּשׁוּט הָיָה יוֹתֵר שָׂמֵחַ בְּחֶלְקוֹ, בְּצַיְּנוֹ כִּי שְׁלוֹשִׁים שָׁנָה עָסַק בְּמֶלְמְדוּת וּשְׁלוֹשִׁים שָׁנָה בְּדַיָּנוּת, וְכַוָּנָתוֹ הָיְתָה כַּאֲשֶׁר כִּהֵן שָׁנִים מִסְפָּר כְּרֹאשׁ יְשִׁיבַת "תּוֹרַת חַיִּים", וְגֹדֶל הָאַחֲרָיוּת הַמֻּטֶּלֶת עַל כְּתֵפוֹ שֶׁל רַב וְדַיָּן הִיא גְּדוֹלָה לִמְאֹד, שֶׁלֹּא יַטֶּה אֶת הַדִּין.
בַּעֲרוֹב יָמָיו בְּעֵת מַחֲלָתוֹ הָאַחֲרוֹנָה חִשֵּׁב בְּעַצְמוֹ בְּאָמְרוֹ, עַל מַה שֶׁאָמְרוּ חֲזַ"ל שֶׁהַקַּבָּ"ה מְמַלֵּא שְׁנוֹתֵיהֶם שֶׁל צַדִּיקִים כְּמֹשֶׁה רַבֵּינוּ ע"ה שֶׁנּוֹלַד בְּז' בַּאֲדָר וְנִסְתַּלֵּק בְּאוֹתוֹ יוֹם, וַהֲרֵי לִכְאוֹרָה אֵיךְ יֵחָשְׁבוּ שְׁמוֹנַת הַיָּמִים שֶׁלִּפְנֵי הַמִּילָה בְּתוֹךְ הַשָּׁנִים הַלָּלוּ? 'אֶלָּא', תֵּרֵץ זְקֵנִי, 'הֲרֵי בְּמֹשֶׁה אִיתָא שֶׁנּוֹלַד מָהוּל!' וְאָכֵן הִתְקַיְּמוּ הַדְּבָרִים אֶצְלוֹ כַּאֲשֶׁר הִסְתַּלֵּק בְּיוֹם ז' בַּאֲדָר אֲשֶׁר הָיָה הַיּוֹם בּוֹ נִמּוֹל!וּפֶלֶא גָּדוֹל הָיָה כְּשֶׁשָּׁכַב עַל עֶרֶשׂ דְּוַי, וּבַעֲרוֹב יוֹם ו' בַּאֲדָר שָׁאַל פְּעָמִים רַבּוֹת הַאִם כְּבָר ז' אֲדָר, וּמִיָּד לְאַחַר צֵאת הַכּוֹכָבִים שֶׁל לֵיל ז' בַּאֲדָר תשכ"ט הֵשִׁיב אֶת נִשְׁמָתוֹ הַטְּהוֹרָה לְיוֹצְרָהּ. בְּצַוָּאָתוֹ בִּקֵּשׁ שֶׁלֹּא לְהַסְפִּידוֹ.כ"ק מרן אדמו"ר מקאמארנא-ירושלים שליט"א(מרשימות הרה"ח ר' ישראל פינחס טירנואר הי"ו)"עולם החסידות", אדר תשס"ט, ע' י"ג

When I was once with the Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l, one of the Dayanim of the Beis Din of the Edah HaChareidis in Jerusalem, he told me that his father Zt"l prepared a study schedule for him before prayer, early in the hours of the night: A Parsha of Chumash with Rashi, a chapter of Mishnayot, a page of Gemara with Rashi and Tosafot, a page of Shulchan Aruch, and a page of the Holy Zohar, and more. He said that because the world is clumsy and the mind is crooked, one therefore needs to straighten it with Torah study immediately upon rising from sleep.
Source: Yefe Sichatan

When my grandfather (HaGaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l) reached maturity and entered the covenant of marriage, the Holy Rebbe of Lelov Zy"a commanded him to wear white socks (*veise zaken*) and to walk in the street with a cane so as not to stumble by walking between two women. He also commanded him that he, in his own honor and by himself, should go to buy all the household needs so that his wife could sit in her home to fulfill the verse of David HaMelech.
For six years, he prayed Shacharis in the Minyan of the head of the Kabbalists, Rabbi Dweck, where they prayed at length according to the intentions (Kavanot) of the Rashash. I always saw him before a Mitzvah or a lofty time, like lighting Chanukah candles, Seder night, or even a "plain" weekday prayer, examining *Sha'ar HaKavanot* of the Maharhu, while remarking with a smile of humility: "Anyway, we don't understand anything, at least let's turn the pages..." But besides this, he had regular classes in the hidden Torah. He also had customs based on Kabbalah, such as white clothes on Shabbos and more.
His holy way was to come home after the Maariv prayer, taste a little something, and lie down immediately to sleep until midnight. At midnight, he would rise like a lion and begin engaging in his studies until the Shacharis prayer. This was his fixed daily schedule all his years.
In the years of his youth, he would go every night to the house of his friend and colleague, the Gaon and Tzaddik, the Kabbalist Rabbi A.Z. Margaliyot Zt"l, to conduct "Tikkun Chatzot" with him. They wore sackcloth and ashes, and with terrible weeping, they would recite the Tikkun, mourning the pain of the Shechinah and the exile of Israel.
His diligence was beyond all imagination. Throughout the entire day, he was occupied with his studies and lessons in revealed and hidden Torah, and his mouth never ceased from study, repeating his learning countless times.
Once I saw him studying Tractate Menachot. When he noticed me, he said to me: "I am studying the Daf Yomi even before they enacted it." Of course, he had his own schedule, but this was a schedule of a page a day besides his other fixed schedules.
Source: Pe'er Yisrael

בְּמֶשֶׁךְ שֵׁשׁ שָׁנִים הִתְפַּלֵּל שַׁחֲרִית בְּמִנְיָנוֹ שֶׁל רֹאשׁ הַמְקֻבָּלִים הָרַב דְּוֵויק, שָׁם הָיוּ מִתְפַּלְּלִים בַּאֲרִיכוּת עַל פִּי כַּוָּנוֹת הָרַשַׁ"שׁ. תָּמִיד רְאִיתִיו לִפְנֵי מִצְוָה אוֹ זְמַן גָּבוֹהַּ, כְּמוֹ הַדְלָקַת נֵרוֹת חֲנֻכָּה, לֵיל הַסֵּדֶר, אוֹ אֲפִילּוּ 'סְתָם' תְּפִלָּה שֶׁל יוֹם חֹל, מְעַיֵּן בְּשַׁעַר הַכַּוָּנוֹת לַמַּהַרְחַ"ו, כְּשֶׁהוּא מַפְטִיר בְּחִיּוּךְ עַנְוְתָנוּתוֹ - 'מִמֵּילָא לֹא מְבִינִים כְּלוּם, לְפָחוֹת נְדַפְדֵּף...' אֲבָל מִלְּבַד זֹאת הָיוּ לוֹ שִׁעוּרִים קְבוּעִים בְּתוֹרַת הַחֵ"ן. הָיוּ לוֹ גַּם הַנְהָגוֹת עַל פִּי קַבָּלָה כְּמוֹ בִּגְדֵי לָבָן בְּשַׁבָּת וְעוֹד.
דַּרְכּוֹ בַּקֹּדֶשׁ הָיְתָה לָבוֹא לְבֵיתוֹ לְאַחַר תְּפִלַּת עַרְבִית, אָז טָעַם קִימְעָה וְשָׁכַב מִיָּד לִישֹׁן עַד חֲצוֹת. בַּחֲצוֹת הַלַּיְלָה הִתְגַּבֵּר כָּאֲרִ"י וְהֵחֵל לַעֲסֹק בְּשִׁעוּרָיו עַד לִתְפִלַּת שַׁחֲרִית. זֶה הָיָה סֵדֶר יוֹמוֹ הַקָּבוּעַ כָּל שְׁנוֹתָיו. בִּשְׁנוֹת נְעוּרָיו הָיָה הוֹלֵךְ בְּכָל לַיְלָה אֶל בֵּית רֵעוֹ וַעֲמִיתוֹ הַגָּאוֹן הַצַּדִּיק הַמְקֻבָּל הרא"ז מַרְגָּלִיּוֹת זַצַ"ל לַעֲרֹךְ אִתּוֹ עִמּוֹ "תִּקּוּן חֲצוֹת", וְהָיוּ לוֹבְשִׁין שַׂק וָאֵפֶר, וּבִבְכִיּוֹת נוֹרָאוֹת הָיוּ אוֹמְרִים אֶת הַתִּקּוּן בְּהִתְאַבְּלָם עַל צַעַר הַשְּׁכִינָה וְגָלוּת יִשְׂרָאֵל.
הַתְמָדָתוֹ הָיְתָה מֵעֵבֶר לְכָל דִּמְיוֹן, בְּמֶשֶׁךְ כָּל הַיּוֹם הוּא עָסַק בְּלִמּוּדָיו וְשִׁעוּרָיו בְּתוֹרַת הַנִּגְלֶה וְהַנִּסְתָּר, וְלֹא פָּסַק פּוּמֵיהּ מִגִּירְסָא בְּחוֹזְרוֹ עַל לִמּוּדוֹ פְּעָמִים אֵין מִסְפָּר.פַּעַם רְאִיתִיו לוֹמֵד מַסֶּכֶת מְנָחוֹת, כְּשֶׁהִבְחִין בִּי אָמַר לִי - לוֹמֵד אֲנִי דַּף הַיּוֹמִי עוֹד מִלִּפְנֵי שֶׁתִּקְּנוּהוּ. כַּמּוּבָן שֶׁהָיָה לוֹ סֵדֶר מִשֶּׁלּוֹ, אֲבָל הָיָה זֶה סֵדֶר שֶׁל דַּף לְיוֹם מִלְּבַד שְׁאָר סְדָרָיו הַקְּבוּעִים.
מְקוֹם מְגוּרָיו הָיָה בֵּין בָּתֶּיהָ שֶׁל שְׁכוּנַת בָּתֵּי וַוארְשָׁא, אַךְ אֶת עִקַּר מוֹשָׁבוֹ קָבַע בְּבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת חֲסִידִים שָׁם, כַּאֲשֶׁר בֵּית כְּנֶסֶת זֶה מְשַׁמֵּשׁ עֲבוּרוֹ כְּבַיִת מִשְׁנִי, בּוֹ שָׁקַע לֵילוֹת שְׁלֵימִים בְּעֵסֶק הַתּוֹרָה. וְשִׁמֵּשׁ כְּרַב וּמוֹרֵה דֶּרֶךְ, וּבְעֵת שֶׁשִּׁמֵּשׁ מָקוֹם זֶה אַכְסַנְיָה לִגְדוֹלֵי עוֹלָם שֶׁעָרְכוּ שָׁם אֶת תְּפִלּוֹתֵיהֶם וְאֶת שֻׁלְחָנוֹתֵיהֶם הַטְּהוֹרִים, לֹא רָאָה בָּזֶה פְּחִיתוּת כָּבוֹד לְהִשְׁתַּתֵּף עִמָּהֶם וּלְכַבְּדָם בְּנוֹכְחוּתוֹ כְּאֶחָד מִן הַשָּׁוִים, וְגַם בְּעֵת הֵאָסֵף הַקָּהָל בְּלֵילוֹת שַׁבָּת, הָיָה נוֹטֵל חֵלֶק בַּאֲסִיפַת הַמְּרֵעִים.כ"ק מרן אדמו"ר מקאמארנא-ירושלים שליט"א(מרשימות הרה"ח ר' ישראל פינחס טירנואר הי"ו)"עולם החסידות", אדר תשס"ט, ע' י"ג
body_en:
Every month, the Chassidic Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l (of the Edah HaChareidis Badatz) [his father Rabbi Nesanel Zt"l basked in the shadow of the *Chidushei HaRim* Zy"a] was accustomed to greeting the Rebbe [the *Beis Yisrael* of Gur Zt"l] on Rosh Chodesh. Together with him came the man of the book, the elderly Rabbi Yosef Hoffman Zt"l. Regularly, the Rebbe Zy"a would give them a respectable sum of money for charity needs.
Once, elections for the Knesset in the Holy Land were about to be held on the 3rd of Elul (1961), and the days were days of polemic in Jerusalem the Holy City regarding whether to participate in the elections or abstain. Rosh Chodesh arrived, and HaGaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman did not come. Our Rebbe worried that perhaps there was something behind it, and he sent someone to clarify with him the meaning of his absence. Rabbi Reisman told the messenger that he did not come simply because he had a cold and was not leaving his house. The messenger returned and told our Rebbe things as they were.
However, the Rebbe's mind was still not at ease with this explanation. He went out himself with the messenger to the home of Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak, who lived in the "Batei Varsha" neighborhood, to hear from his mouth the reason why he did not come that day. "Perhaps someone offended him, Heaven forbid?" he asked.
Rabbi Reisman was very surprised and pointed to the messenger apologetically: "Did I not already tell him the reason..." However, the *Beis Yisrael* explained to him that he feared they were hiding the truth from him because of the polemic, and he was trembling in his heart lest someone had treated him improperly, Heaven forbid, and harmed the honor of the Torah.
Source: Pe'er Yisrael

body_he: פַּעַם אַחַת עָמְדוּ לְהִיעָרֵךְ הַבְּחִירוֹת לַכְּנֶסֶת בַּארה"ק בְּיוֹם ג' אֱלוּל (שְׁנַת תשכ"א), וְהַיָּמִים יְמֵי פּוּלְמוּס בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם עִיר הַקֹּדֶשׁ, אִם לְהִשְׁתַּתֵּף בַּבְּחִירוֹת אוֹ לְהִימָּנַע. הִגִּיעַ רֹאשׁ חֹדֶשׁ, וְהַגְרִי"י רַייזְמַאן לֹא בָּא. חָשַׁשׁ רַבֵּינוּ אוּלַי יֵשׁ דְּבָרִים בְּגוֹ, וְשָׁלַח לְבָרֵר אֶצְלוֹ אֶת פֵּשֶׁר הֵעָדְרוֹ. אָמַר הַגְרִי"י לַשָּׁלִיחַ, כִּי לֹא בָּא הַפַּעַם מִפְּנֵי סִבָּה פְּשׁוּטָה, מֵחֲמַת שֶׁהִצְטַנֵּן וְאֵינוֹ יוֹצֵא מִבֵּיתוֹ. חָזַר הַשָּׁלִיחַ וְסָח לִפְנֵי רַבֵּינוּ דְּבָרִים כַּהֲוָיָתָם.אוּלָם עֲדַיִן לֹא נִתְקָרְרָה דַּעְתּוֹ בְּהֶסְבֵּר זֶה. יָצָא אֵיפוֹא בְּעַצְמוֹ עִם הַשָּׁלִיחַ לְבֵיתוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל יִצְחָק, הַמִּתְגּוֹרֵר בְּ"בָתֵּי וַוארְשָׁא", כְּדֵי לִשְׁמֹעַ מִפִּיו אֶת הַסִּבָּה מַדּוּעַ לֹא בָּא הַיּוֹם. "אוּלַי מִישֶׁהוּ פָּגַע בּוֹ חָלִילָה?" שָׁאַל.הִתְפַּלֵּא מְאֹד הַגְרִי"י וְהִצְבִּיעַ לְעֵבֶר הַשָּׁלִיחַ כְּמִתְנַצֵּל: "הֲלֹא כְּבָר אָמַרְתִּי לוֹ אֶת טַעַם הַדָּבָר..." אוּלָם הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" הִסְבִּיר לוֹ, שֶׁחָשַׁשׁ פֶּן הֶעְלִימוּ מִמֶּנּוּ אֶת הָאֱמֶת בִּגְלַל הַפּוּלְמוּס, וְהָיָה חָרֵד בְּלִבּוֹ שֶׁמָּא חַס וְשָׁלוֹם נָהַג בּוֹ אֵי מִי שֶׁלֹּא כַּשּׁוּרָה, וּפָגְעוּ בִּכְבוֹד הַתּוֹרָה. (מֵעֵדוּת הַשָּׁלִיחַ ר' חַיִּים נַיְיהוֹז)"פאר ישראל" (ירושלים תשנ"ח) ח"א, ע' תקי"ט
body_en:
My grandfather (HaGaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l) was a Chassid with all his 248 limbs and 365 sinews. His entire being was soaked in pure Chassidus that he imbibed from his father and his teachers. A Chassidic saying or custom was precious and dear in his eyes like finding great spoil. Needless to say, he was strict about all Chassidic practices, such as Mikvah every day and the like.
When the *Imrei Emes* visited Jerusalem, my grandfather came before him, accompanied by a number of important Jews from Poland, and asked him to found a Chassidic Yeshiva in Jerusalem, as there was none until then. The *Imrei Emes* agreed to the request and asked how they would call the Yeshiva. My grandfather replied: "Sfas Emes." The *Imrei Emes* reacted: "I thought to give a more general name, but if you have already proposed this name, so let it be."
The first meeting of the Yeshiva also took place in his home, and the administration of the Yeshiva was also conducted in his home when the Yeshiva was at the beginning of its path in the Batei Varsha Chassidic Beis Medrash.
When the Holy Rebbe of Belz lived in Batei Varsha, my grandfather was among those who sat at his table and among those who cared with all their might for his well-being and benefit. Since his father-in-law (who was not my father Zt"l) was a grandson of Rabbi Elazar, the firstborn son of the *Sar Shalom* of Belz, the Holy Rebbe of Belz considered him a "Mechutan" (in-law) and called him such! When my brother was born, the Holy Rebbe arrived at our home to wish Mazel Tov to the mother.
His closeness to the Admor, the *Beis Yisrael* of Gur, was special in its kind. My grandfather sat regularly at the pure table conducted by the Admor on Friday nights and was accustomed to coming to him every Rosh Chodesh (together with Rabbi Yosef Hoffman Zt"l), and the *Beis Yisrael* would also give a respectable sum of money into their hands for charity.
The *Beis Yisrael* also respected my grandfather very much and visited him at least once every two weeks. Dozens of times, if not more, I was present at these visits, and I also accompanied my grandfather when he visited the *Beis Yisrael*. They would converse in words of Torah and Chassidus and raise memories from the destroyed Poland and the Jerusalem of old.
My grandfather greatly respected the Holy Rebbe of Satmar Zy"a. Back in the year 1932, when the Holy Rebbe visited Jerusalem, my grandfather spent much time in his shadow. On Shabbos Kodesh, at the time of Mincha, he was honored in his Beis Medrash with the Aliyah of Levi, but according to the custom of the Holy Rebbe, he read from the Torah after the stars came out. The next day, one of the Rabbis in Jerusalem met him and told him that he heard he went up to the Torah at night in the Minyan of the Rabbi of Krali, and how did he not fear ascending to the Torah at night?! My grandfather answered him: "When the Holy Gaon of Krali is among us, behold every single day is in the aspect of 'Simchat Torah,' and on Simchat Torah, we go up to the Torah when the evening shadows have already fallen..."
Source: Olam HaChassidut

body_he:
בְּעֵת שֶׁבִּקֵּר הָ"אִמְרֵי אֱמֶת" בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם, בָּאוּ לְפָנָיו זְקֵנִי וְעִמּוֹ מִסְפַּר יְהוּדִים חֲשׁוּבִים מִיּוֹצְאֵי פּוֹלִין, וּבִקְּשׁוּ מִמֶּנּוּ לְיַסֵּד יְשִׁיבָה חֲסִידִית בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם, בַּאֲשֶׁר עַד אָז לֹא הָיְתָה כָּזוֹ. הָ"אִמְרֵי אֱמֶת" הִסְכִּים לַבַּקָּשָׁה וְשָׁאַל כֵּיצַד יִקְרְאוּ לַיְשִׁיבָה - הֵשִׁיב זְקֵנִי - "שְׂפַת אֱמֶת". הֵגִיב הָ"אִמְרֵי אֱמֶת" - 'אֲנִי חָשַׁבְתִּי לָתֵת שֵׁם כְּלָלִי יוֹתֵר, אֲבָל אִם כְּבָר הִצַּעְתֶּם אֶת הַשֵּׁם הַזֶּה, כָּךְ יִהְיֶה'.
גַּם הָאֲסִיפָה הָרִאשׁוֹנָה שֶׁל הַיְשִׁיבָה הִתְקַיְּמָה בְּבֵיתוֹ, וְגַם נִהוּל הַיְשִׁיבָה הִתְנַהֵל בְּבֵיתוֹ כַּאֲשֶׁר הַיְשִׁיבָה הָיְתָה אָז בִּתְחִלַּת דַּרְכָּהּ בְּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ בָּתֵּי וַוארְשָׁא דַּחֲסִידִים.
כְּשֶׁהרה"ק מִבֶּעֶלְזָא הִתְגּוֹרֵר בְּבָתֵּי וַוארְשָׁא הָיָה זְקֵנִי מִיּוֹשְׁבֵי שֻׁלְחָנוֹ וּמֵאֵלּוּ שֶׁדָּאֲגוּ בְּכָל כּוֹחָם לְמַעַן שְׁלוֹמוֹ וְטוֹבָתוֹ. מִכֵּיוָן שֶׁחֲתָנוֹ הֲלֹא הוּא אָבִי זַצַ"ל הָיָה נֶכְדּוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּנוֹ בְּכוֹרוֹ שֶׁל הַשַּׂר שָׁלוֹם מִבֶּעֶלְזָא, הֶחֱשִׁיבוֹ הרה"ק מִבֶּעֶלְזָא לְ'מְחֻתָּן' וְכָךְ כִּנָּהוּ! כְּשֶׁאֲחִי נוֹלָד הִגִּיעַ הרה"ק לְבֵיתֵנוּ כְּדֵי לְאַחֵל מַזָּ"ט לַיּוֹלֶדֶת.
מְיֻחֶדֶת בְּמִינָהּ הָיְתָה קִרְבָתוֹ לָאַדְמוֹ"ר הַ"בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל" מִגּוּר. זְקֵנִי הֵסֵב דֶּרֶךְ קֶבַע לַשֻּׁלְחָן הַטָּהוֹר שֶׁעָרַךְ הָאַדְמוֹ"ר בְּלֵיל שַׁבָּת, וְנָהַג לָבוֹא אֵלָיו בְּכָל רֹאשׁ חֹדֶשׁ (יַחַד עִם רַבִּי יוֹסֵף הוֹפְמַן זַצַ"ל), וְהַבֵּ"י גַּם הָיָה נוֹתֵן בְּיָדָם סְכוּם כֶּסֶף נִכְבָּד לִצְדָקָה.הַבֵּ"י אַף הוּא הֶעֱרִיךְ אֶת זְקֵנִי עַד לִמְאֹד וּבִקֵּר אֶצְלוֹ לְפָחוֹת אַחַת לִשְׁבוּעַיִם. עֲשָׂרוֹת פְּעָמִים, אִם לֹא יוֹתֵר, נָכַחְתִּי בְּבִקּוּרִים אֵלּוּ וְכֵן הִתְלַוֵּיתִי לִזְקֵנִי כְּשֶׁבִּקֵּר אֵצֶל הַבֵּ"י. הֵם הָיוּ מְשׂוֹחֲחִים בְּדִבְרֵי תּוֹרָה וַחֲסִידוּת וּמַעֲלִים זִכְרוֹנוֹת מִפּוֹלִין הַחֲרֵבָה וִירוּשָׁלַיִם שֶׁל מַעְלָה.
זְקֵנִי הֶחֱשִׁיב מְאֹד אֶת הרה"ק מִסָּאטְמַאר זִיעַ"א, עוֹד בִּשְׁנַת תרצ"ב כְּשֶׁהרה"ק בִּקֵּר בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם הִסְתּוֹפֵף זְקֵנִי רַבּוֹת בְּצֵל קוֹרָתוֹ, וּבְשַׁבַּת קֹדֶשׁ לְעֵת הַמִּנְחָה הִתְכַּבֵּד בְּבֵית מִדְרָשׁוֹ בַּעֲלִיַּת לֵוִי, אֶלָּא שֶׁכְּמִנְהָגוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק קְרָאוֹ בַּתּוֹרָה לְאַחַר צֵאת הַכּוֹכָבִים. לְמָחֳרָת מְצָאוֹ אֶחָד מֵהָרַבָּנִים בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם וְאָמַר לוֹ שֶׁשָּׁמַע שֶׁהוּא עָלָה לַתּוֹרָה בַּלַּיְלָה בְּמִנְיַן הָרַב מִקְרָאלִי, וְאֵיךְ לֹא עָלָה חֲשָׁשׁ לַעֲלוֹת לַתּוֹרָה בְּעֵת הַלַּיְלָה?! עָנָה לוֹ זְקֵנִי - כְּשֶׁהַגָּה"ק מִקְּרָאלִי נִמְצָא בֵּינֵינוּ הֲרֵי כָּל יוֹם וָיוֹם הוּא בִּבְחִינַת "שִׂמְחַת תּוֹרָה", וּבְשִׂמְחַת תּוֹרָה עוֹלִים לַתּוֹרָה כַּאֲשֶׁר כְּבָר יִנְטוּ צִלְלֵי עֶרֶב...כ"ק מרן אדמו"ר מקאמארנא-ירושלים שליט"א(מרשימות הרה"ח ר' ישראל פינחס טירנואר הי"ו)"עולם החסידות", אדר תשס"ט, ע' י"ד
body_en:
I heard that the Holy Rebbe, the *Beis Yisrael* of Gur Zt"l, had a holy custom to visit HaGaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l while it was still dark at night, for he was awake from midnight onwards with his studies, as is known. A neighbor of the Riy"tz (Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak) became jealous of this honor and demanded of the Rebbe of Gur that he come to visit him as well. The Rebbe of Gur arrived while it was still night and knocked on the door. The man woke up from the sound of knocking and opened with a scream and a cry of "Thief!" and the like, thinking some thief was bothering him. The Rebbe of Gur knocked a fourth and fifth time until the man opened the door and was frightened by the sight of his eyes, that the Rebbe of Gur himself was knocking. The *Beis Yisrael* said to him: "Did I have to be called a thief just to hear you? And sufficient to the wise (VeDal)." For the Tzaddik knew who was the man who turns nights into days with Torah and service.
Source: Yefe Sichatan

There was a fairly long period when my grandfather (HaGaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l) was almost the only Posek of stature in Jerusalem! Every day, dozens if not hundreds of questions reached his table. I never saw him doubt any question; he always ruled immediately with clarity and speed, and the matters were clear as a dress. He also did not cause excessive stringencies, and the path of strictness was far from him. Today, this path is not practiced... One can say that since the Arizal says that in the future the Halacha will be according to Beis Shammai, it is possible that there are those who already want to prepare the way for this and be stringent like Beis Shammai...
The greats of the generation greatly praised his integrity in the way of ruling, his genius and cleverness, and his effort to seek out the truth. As HaGaon Rabbi Z.R. Bengis Zt"l expressed: "R' Yisrael Yitzchak'l surpasses many greats and Rabbis in the generation." The Holy Rebbe R' M. of Amshinov Zt"l did not rely on the kashrut of the Matzahs except only after the instruction and certification of our Rebbe.
The Holy Rebbe, the Mahara of Belz, respected him greatly and sent questions to him. In one case, someone came before the Holy Rebbe of Belz and asked him whether to name his son after his father, whose fate from the time of the Holocaust was unknown. The Holy Rebbe sent him to ask my grandfather's opinion, who ruled not to name after the father since his mother was still alive, and there was a concern that they might come to call the name to frighten her!
Also, when he was young, he was asked to join as a member of the Badatz (Rabbinical Court). But his mother asked him not to serve as a Dayan—and her reasoning was explicit: "In those days, when a person died, the officials would remove the widow from her home and house her in some small room. His mother argued, 'Will you be a Dayan and have to lend a hand to such injustice?!'" Indeed, for many long years, he refused to be a Dayan, until Rabbi Yosef Tzvi Dushinsky Zt"l urged him greatly to accept the appointment upon himself. Despite our Rebbe's argument that he would no longer be able to serve as a charity treasurer, Rabbi Dushinsky permitted him to serve in both roles together.
On the 16th of Kislev, 1941, he received a letter of appointment from the leaders of Jerusalem to be a Dayan and Moreh Tzedek in the Beis Din of the Edah HaChareidis. From then on, his name went out for praise to all ends of the world, and people knocked on his doors to hear the utterance of his mouth.
In those days, there were two Batei Din: one of the "Perushim" and the second of the "Chassidim." My grandfather served as the Av Beis Din of the Badatz of Chassidim. In a later period, the two Batei Din united. As a member of the Badatz, he was appointed over two weighty tasks: the kashrut of the Mikvaot and the ordination of sages.
Once, he expressed with his sharp tongue that if he were a simple teacher, he would be happier with his lot. He noted that he had engaged in teaching for thirty years and in Dayanut for thirty years, and his intention was that when he served for years as the head of Yeshivat "Toras Chaim," the magnitude of the responsibility placed on the shoulders of a Rabbi and Dayan is very great, lest he pervert justice.
In his old age, during his final illness, he calculated to himself, saying regarding what Chazal said that the Holy One, Blessed be He, completes the years of the righteous like Moses our Teacher, peace be upon him, who was born on the 7th of Adar and passed away on that day: "But seemingly, how are the eight days before circumcision counted within these years? 'Rather,'" my grandfather answered, "'regarding Moses, it is said he was born circumcised!'" And indeed, these words were fulfilled in him when he passed away on the 7th of Adar, which was the day he was circumcised!
And it was a great wonder when he lay on his deathbed, and on the evening of the 6th of Adar, he asked many times if it was already the 7th of Adar. Immediately after the stars came out on the night of the 7th of Adar, 1969, he returned his pure soul to its Creator. In his will, he requested not to be eulogized.
Source: Olam HaChassidut

גְּדוֹלֵי הַדּוֹר הִפְלִיאוּ מְאֹד אֶת יַשְׁרוּתוֹ בְּדֶרֶךְ הַפְּסָק, בִּגְאוֹנוּתוֹ וּבְפִקְחוּתוֹ, וְטִרְחָתוֹ לָתוּר אַחֲרֵי הָאֱמֶת, כְּמוֹ שֶׁהִתְבַּטֵּא הַגְרָזַ"ר בֶּענְגִיס זַצַ"ל - 'ר' יִשְׂרָאֵל יִצְחָקְ'ל שֶׁלִּי עוֹלֶה עַל הַרְבֵּה גְּדוֹלִים וְרַבָּנִים בַּדּוֹר'. הרה"ק ר"מ מֵאַמְשִׁינוֹב זַצַ"ל, לֹא סָמַךְ עַל כַּשְׁרוּת הַמַּצּוֹת אֶלָּא רַק לְאַחַר הוֹרָאָתוֹ וְכַשְׁרוּתוֹ שֶׁל רַבֵּינוּ.
הרה"ק מַהֲרַ"א מִבֶּעֶלְזָא כִּבְּדוֹ מְאֹד וְשָׁלַח אֵלָיו שְׁאֵלוֹת. בְּאֶחָד הַמִּקְרִים בָּא אֶחָד לִפְנֵי הרה"ק מִבֶּעֶלְזָא וְשָׁאַל בְּפִיו - הַאִם לָתֵת שֵׁם לִבְנוֹ עַל שֵׁם אָבִיו שֶׁלֹּא נוֹדַע גּוֹרָלוֹ מִזְּמַן הַשּׁוֹאָה. שְׁלָחוֹ הרה"ק לִשְׁאֹל אֶת דַּעַת זְקֵנִי, שֶׁפָּסַק שֶׁלֹּא יִקְרָא עַל שֵׁם אָבִיו הֱיוֹת שֶׁאִמּוֹ עֲדַיִן חַיָּה וְיֵשׁ חֲשָׁשׁ בַּדָּבָר שֶׁמָּא יָבוֹאוּ מֵחֲמַת קְרִיאַת הַשֵּׁם לְהַתִּירָהּ לְאַחֵר!כֵּן נִשְׁאַל בִּשְׁלִיחוּת ר' הִלֵּל וִינְד זַ"ל, הַאִם מֻתָּר לִתְלוֹת תַּפּוּחִים בַּסֻּכָּה כְּמִנְהַג בֶּעֶלְזָא בִּשְׁנַת הַשְּׁמִיטָה, וְהוֹרָה לוֹ הֶתֵּר בִּשְׁנֵי תַּפּוּחִים וְלֹא יוֹתֵר, וְהָיָה לְפֶלֶא.כ"ק מרן אדמו"ר מקאמארנא-ירושלים שליט"א(מרשימות הרה"ח ר' ישראל פינחס טירנואר הי"ו)"עולם החסידות", אדר תשס"ט, ע' י"ג

Our grandfather (HaGaon Rabbi Pinchas Yehuda Liberman Zt"l) established his place of prayer in the Beis Medrash "Kahal Yereim" - Chassidim in Mea Shearim, known by its nickname "Die Marmarisher Shul" (today the Beis Medrash Mishkenot HaRo'im). There, the fine and choice of the pure-minded of Jerusalem prayed, headed by Chassidim and men of action known for their Torah and righteousness. Our grandfather Zt"l became very friendly with them, and despite being relatively young compared to them—in his standing years—he was already considered there among the important congregants and one of the admired figures among them. He was of the "faces" and of those who sat first in the row of important figures in the Beis Medrash.
One of the glories of the Beis Medrash was none other than HaGaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l, member of the Badatz, and our grandfather Zt"l was also close to him. HaGaon Rabbi Reisman Zt"l would deliver regular classes there in the hours between afternoon and evening, a daily matter. It is also told that HaGaon Rabbi Reisman Zt"l, in his great humility and simplicity, would conduct the Melave Malka meal in the Beis Medrash. He would even organize and arrange the meal and the "salads." Not only that, but after Melave Malka, he would insist that he, and no other, wash the dishes and arrange them. No amount of pleading and explanations helped, among them from our grandfather Zt"l, that he could not bear to see the elderly Gaon serving the public like a simple waiter. But HaGaon Rabbi Reisman did not give up in any way on his claim and right to conduct the Melave Malka and arrange everything himself.
Source: Chacham Lev

body_he: אֶחָד מִפְּאֵרֵי בֵּיהַמַּ"ד הֲלֹא הָיָה הַגָּה"צ רַבִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל יִצְחָק רַייזְמַאן זְצוּקַ"ל חָבֵר הַבַּדַ"ץ, וְאַף אֵלָיו הָיָה זְקִינֵנוּ זַצַ"ל מְקֹרָב. הַגְרִי"י זַצַ"ל הָיָה מוֹסֵר שָׁם שִׁעוּרִים תְּמִידִים כְּסִדְרָן בַּשָּׁעוֹת בֵּין הָעַרְבַּיִם בֵּין מִנְחָה לְמַעֲרִיב דְּבַר יוֹם בְּיוֹמוֹ, וְכֵן מְסֻפָּר שֶׁהַגְרִי"י זַצַ"ל בְּגֹדֶל עַנְוְתָנוּתוֹ וּפַשְׁטוּתוֹ הַמֻּפְלֶגֶת הָיָה עוֹרֵךְ אֶת סְעוּדַת הַמְּלַוֶּה מַלְכָּה בְּבֵיהַמַּ"ד, כַּאֲשֶׁר הוּא הָיָה אֲפִילּוּ הַמְאָרְגֵן וְהַמְסַדֵּר אֶת הַסְּעוּדָה וְהַ"סָּלָטִים", וְלֹא זוֹ בִּלְבַד אֶלָּא שֶׁלְּאַחַר מְלַוֶּה מַלְכָּה הָיָה מִתְעַקֵּשׁ שֶׁהוּא וְלֹא אַחֵר יִשְׁטֹף אֶת הַכֵּלִים וִיסַדְּרֵם, וְלֹא עָזְרוּ כָּל מִינֵי תַּחֲנוּנִים וְהֶסְבֵּרִים, בֵּינֵיהֶם מִזְּקִינֵנוּ זַצַ"ל שֶׁלֹּא יָכוֹל הָיָה לִרְאוֹת אֶת הַגָּה"צ הַיָּשִׁישׁ מְשַׁמֵּשׁ אֶת הַצִּבּוּר כִּמְשָׁרֵת פָּשׁוּט, אַךְ הַגְרִי"י לֹא וִיתֵּר בְּשׁוּם אֹפֶן עַל הַחֲזָקָה וְהַזְּכוּת שֶׁלּוֹ לְקַיֵּם אֶת הַמְּלַוֶּה מַלְכָּה וּלְסַדֵּר אֶת הַכֹּל בְּעַצְמוֹ."חכם לב" (ירושלים תשס"ז) ע' נ"ח
body_en:
My grandfather (HaGaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l) pounded his feet knocking on the doors of donors for charity matters. He acted for them as a faithful charity treasurer. For long years, he collected donations for the poor and needy of the Holy City, supporting them and feeding them with modesty and secrecy. With his cleverness and wisdom, he knew how to find the families whose sustenance was failing and to care for their livelihood in an honorable way. Many times, he even borrowed money for charity needs.
The greats and righteous of the generation relied on him, transferring large sums to his hands for distribution. After he began to serve as a member of the Badatz, he stopped these activities openly and mostly worked only in secret. The reason for this was not due to concern for dignity, but because of the fear of bribery, lest he incline judgment in favor of the giver, etc.
But in his own home, poverty reigned constantly. Sometimes they even hungered for bread, literally. Even for Shabbos, sometimes the penny was not found...
Every Friday eve, he would go around the houses of Jerusalem with food supplies sufficient for three meals for poor families, as his father had done before him. Even on the day of his wedding, which, according to Jerusalem custom, was held on Friday eve, amidst the great preparation for the sublime time, he distributed the food portions to the needy on that day by his father's command, as he did every Friday. "The poor do not need to suffer because you are getting married," his father told him.
Even when he lay on his deathbed close to his passing, he whispered with his remaining strength into the ear of his son-in-law, his only one who was dear to him like a son, the Holy Rebbe Rabbi Shalom of Komarno Zt"l, not to forget to come to the aid of a certain Torah scholar who was in distress and hardship!
Once, he met by chance the famous philanthropist R' Yosef Weinberg Zt"l from the Beis Yisrael neighborhood, who was rushing for medical treatment. He urged him to assist him in a charity matter he was involved in at that time, naming a sum of 3 pounds (Lirot)—a quite significant sum in those days. Without a second thought, R' Yosef found that the sum matched exactly the expenses of the medical treatment, and he gave him the money. Indeed, he was saved immediately on that day without the need for any treatment at all!
It was a known thing in Jerusalem that with Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak, one could find a cure and remedy for every heartache, and a healing for every difficult matter brought to him, whether through advice and resourcefulness, or through a decent donation or a blessing, and it would be for salvation.
My grandfather also received *Kvitelach* (prayer notes) regularly, and he wrought many salvations in the land. I remember one case among many when a couple came before him who supported Torah institutions in Jerusalem extensively but had not been blessed with children for many years. My grandfather gave them a handful of almonds and said, "Take fruits." Within a year, the two embraced a male son. When they told the miracle before him, he dismissed the words as was his way.
Source: Olam HaChassidut

גְּדוֹלִי וְצַדִּיקֵי הַדּוֹר הָיוּ סוֹמְכִים עָלָיו בְּהַעֲבִירָם סְכוּמִים גְּדוֹלִים לְיָדָיו לְחַלּוּקָה. לְאַחַר שֶׁהֵחֵל לְכַהֵן כְּחָבֵר הַבַּדַ"ץ, הִפְסִיק בְּגָלוּי עִם הַפְּעֻלּוֹת הָאֵלּוּ, וּלְרֹב פָּעַל רַק בְּהַצְנֵעַ. הַסִּבָּה לְכָךְ לֹא הָיְתָה מֵחֲמַת חֲשָׁשׁ וּפְחִיתוּת כָּבוֹד, אֶלָּא מִפְּנֵי חֲשַׁשׁ שֹׁחַד, שֶׁמָּא יַטֶּה אֶת הַדִּין לְטוֹבַת הַנּוֹתֵן וְכַדּוֹ'.אֲבָל בְּבֵיתוֹ שֶׁלּוֹ עַצְמוֹ שָׁרַר תָּדִיר מַחְסוֹר וְלִפְעָמִים אַף רָעֲבוּ לְלֶחֶם כִּפְשׁוּטוֹ, גַּם לְשַׁבָּת פְּעָמִים לֹא הָיְתָה הַפְּרוּטָה מְצוּיָה...
מִידֵי עֶרֶב שַׁבַּת קֹדֶשׁ הָיָה סוֹבֵב אֶת בָּתֵּי יְרוּשָׁלַיִם, עִם מִצְרְכֵי מָזוֹן כְּדֵי שָׁלֹשׁ סְעוּדוֹת לְמִשְׁפָּחוֹת עֲנִיּוֹת, כְּפִי שֶׁנָּהַג אָבִיו לְפָנָיו. אֲפִילּוּ בְּיוֹם חֻפָּתוֹ, שֶׁכְּמִנְהַג יְרוּשָׁלַיִם נֶעֶרְכָה בְּעֶרֶב שַׁבָּ"ק, תּוֹךְ כְּדֵי הֲכָנָה רַבָּתִי לִזְמַן הַנִּשְׂגָּב, חִלֵּק בּוֹ בַּיּוֹם בִּפְקֻדַּת אָבִיו אֶת מְנוֹת הָאֹכֶל לַנִּצְרָכִים כְּמִדֵּי עֶרֶב שַׁבָּת. 'הָעֲנִיִּים אֵינָם צְרִיכִים לִסְבֹּל מִכָּךְ שֶׁהִנְּךָ מִתְחַתֵּן', אָמַר לוֹ אָבִיו.
אֲפִילּוּ כַּאֲשֶׁר שָׁכַב עַל עֶרֶשׂ דְּוַי סָמוּךְ לִפְטִירָתוֹ, לָחַשׁ בִּשְׁאֵרִית כּוֹחוֹתָיו לְאֹזֶן חֲתָנוֹ יְחִידוֹ הֶחָבִיב לוֹ כִּבְנוֹ כ"ק אָבִי הָאַדְמוֹ"ר רַבִּי שָׁלוֹם מִקָּאמַרְנָא זְצוּקַ"ל, שֶׁלֹּא יִשְׁכַּח לָבוֹא לְעֶזְרַת תַּלְמִיד חָכָם מְסֻיָּם הַמָּצוּי בְּצַעַר וּבְמָצוֹק!
בְּפוֹגְשׁוֹ פַּעַם בְּדֶרֶךְ אַרְעַי אֶת הַנָּגִיד הַמְפֻרְסָם ר' יוֹסֵף וַויינְבֶּערְג זַ"ל מִשְּׁכוּנַת בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל, אֲשֶׁר מִהֵר לְטִפּוּל רְפוּאִי, הִפְצִיר בּוֹ לְסַיְּעוֹ בְּמַעֲשֵׂה הַצְּדָקָה שֶׁעָסַק בּוֹ בְּאוֹתָהּ עֵת, בְּנָקְבוֹ בִּסְכוּם שֶׁל 3 פוּנְט (לִירוֹת) - סְכוּם דֵּי נִכְבָּד בַּיָּמִים הָהֵם. לְלֹא מַחְשָׁבָה שְׁנִיָּה מָצָא ר' יוֹסֵף שֶׁהַסְּכוּם תּוֹאֵם בְּדִיּוּק נִפְלָא לְהוֹצָאוֹת הָרְפוּאָה, וּמָסַר לוֹ אֶת הַכֶּסֶף, וְאָכֵן נוֹשַׁע מִיָּד בְּאוֹתוֹ הַיּוֹם לְלֹא צֹרֶךְ בְּטִפּוּל כְּלָל!
מְפֻרְסָם הָיָה הַדָּבָר בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם כִּי אֵצֶל רַבִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל יִצְחָק אֶפְשָׁר לִמְצֹא מָזוֹר וּתְרוּפָה, לְכָל מָרֵי לֵב, וּמַעֲלֶה אֲרוּכָה לְכָל דָּבָר הַקָּשֶׁה אֲשֶׁר יְבִיאוּן אֵלָיו, אִם בְּעֵצָה וְתוּשִׁיָּה, אוֹ בִּתְרוּמָה הֲגוּנָה אוֹ בִּבְרָכָה, וִיהִי לְתוּשִׁיָּה.גַּם זְקֵנִי קִבֵּל קְוִויטֶעלַאךְ בְּדֶרֶךְ קֶבַע, וִישׁוּעוֹת רַבּוֹת פָּעַל בְּקֶרֶב הָאָרֶץ. זְכוּרַנִי מִקְרֶה אֶחָד מִנִּי רַבִּים כְּשֶׁבָּאוּ לְפָנָיו זוּג שֶׁתָּמְכוּ רַבּוֹת בְּמוֹסְדוֹת הַתּוֹרָה בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם וְשָׁנִים רַבּוֹת לֹא נִפְקְדוּ בְּזֶרַע שֶׁל קַיָּמָא. זְקֵנִי נָתַן לָהֶם חֹפֶן שְׁקֵדִים וְאָמַר - 'קְחוּ פֵּרוֹת', תּוֹךְ שָׁנָה חִבְּקוּ הַשְּׁנַיִם בֵּן זָכָר. כְּשֶׁסִּפְּרוּ בְּפָנָיו אוֹדוֹת הַמּוֹפֵת, בִּטֵּל אֶת הַדְּבָרִים כְּדַרְכּוֹ.כ"ק מרן אדמו"ר מקאמארנא-ירושלים שליט"א(מרשימות הרה"ח ר' ישראל פינחס טירנואר הי"ו)"עולם החסידות", אדר תשס"ט, ע' ט"ו

Some years ago, I suffered strong pain in my knees. I was advised to travel to Sodom to bathe in its waters as a proven cure. At the time of my arrival in the Holy City of Jerusalem, may it be built and established, I heard that there were proclamations opposing the use of the bathing waters there due to reasons of immodesty. I entered to HaGaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l (and with me was one of the students of the Holy Yeshiva of Tshebin, he is HaGaon Rabbi Shlomo Ben-Zion Herbst Shlita, currently Av Beis Din of Flatbush), and I asked his pure opinion. He confirmed to me that the aforementioned warnings were on behalf of the Badatz, and when a Rabbi from abroad acts against this, then Heaven forbid, the entire negotiation of the Badatz with the city officials regarding going there would go to waste.
Of course, I accepted his pure opinion in truth and justice. However, I asked his advice on what to do for my pains. He said to me: "Is not the main thing the power of the salt in the water? Take one or two liters of salt and cast them into the water of a private bathtub in the house, and you will be healed as if in the waters of Sodom!" And so I did, and the pain disappeared after the first bath.
"And the [doctor] answered and said that a great miracle was done for me, and he admitted that the knowledge and wisdom of medicine is as nothing against the will of the Creator, Blessed be His Name."
The owner of the story himself wrote the entire sequence of events to his friend and in-law, the Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Welz Zt"l, and concludes there: "Please deliver the content of the letter to my son, may he live, so that he too may know to give thanks and praise to His Name, may He be blessed, for all the kindness He has bestowed upon me, and let him bless the blessing 'Who performed miracles for our fathers'" (The letter was printed in full in *Be'er Tzvi*, section of letters, letter 32). Also, witnesses who heard it recounted with longing how the Gaon described to them how he felt that the Matzahs worked to remove all his pains from him.
Source: Yefe Sichatan

My grandfather (HaGaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l) was absolutely a great zealot and distanced himself with all his might from the wicked and their budgets. With all his simplicity and pure virtues that shone from afar, he did not restrain himself regarding any breach in Judaism and protested with a great noise. It happened once that he was invited to a Bris Milah where a Rabbi was also invited whose opinions the Rabbis of Jerusalem were not comfortable with. My grandfather did not react at all, but the moment a proper opportunity arose, he simply disappeared from the place...
When he served as Rosh Mesivta in the Yeshiva of Toras Chaim in the Old City, he refused adamantly to allow students with long forelocks to enter his classes. But all this was in matters concerning the public. When it came to himself, he honored and prolonged his time with everyone who came under his roof, small and great alike, with his conduct in splendor and glory, as the radiance of his face shone from afar.
Source: Olam HaChassidut

I heard from my in-law, HaGaon Rabbi Yudel Greenfeld (Shlita) [Zt"l], Dayan of the Belz Chassidim in Antwerp, that a young man came before the Holy Gaon Rabbi Yaakov Yisrael Kanievsky Zt"l, the Steipler, with a request to pray for him regarding various unfortunate family events where he had not succeeded after his marriage. The Steipler replied that he saw upon him an accusation regarding a Torah scholar, Heaven forbid.
The young man reflected on the matter a great deal until he remembered that once, he was among a group of young men who behaved wildly with their singing in the neighborhood of HaGaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l. The Rabbi would wake up early to sleep so he could rise at midnight as was his holy custom, and he asked the young men not to disturb him with their voices. The aforementioned young man was the head of the thugs who were insolent toward him. He mentioned this before the Steipler Zt"l, who commanded him to take ten men to go to his grave and appease him. He did so, and the judgments were sweetened from him, and he was saved with eternal salvation.
Source: Yefe Sichatan

My grandfather (HaGaon Rabbi Yisrael Yitzchak Reisman Zt"l) lived in proximity to the home of the Holy Gaon, author of *Toras Chesed* of Lublin Zt"l. The author of *Toras Chesed* Zt"l had a wondrous sense of hearing and would hear the voice of my grandfather's study every night. Once he said to him: "I envy you that you still toil in Torah study. For me, I have nothing to toil over because everything I learned in my youth is fluent in my mouth." He then told him: "I do not know if I receive a reward for my Torah study today, for it does not come with exertion."
All the days of my grandfather's life, he lived with the author of *Toras Chesed* Zt"l. His holy teachings and Chabad stories that he heard from his mouth were fluent in his mouth. My grandfather was so attached to him that he requested in his will that upon his passing, they should pass by his Rebbe's grave to inform him of his passing.
Source: Olam HaChassidut

**Biography**
At the conclusion of the last day of Pesach, 1930, the sun of that Tzaddik, the Holy Admor Rabbi Yaakov Yissachar Ber Zt"l of Nadvorna, shone in the town of Seret in Romania. He was born to his father, the Holy Admor Rabbi Chaim Mordechai Zt"l of Nadvorna, and to his mother, the Rebbetzin, daughter of the Holy Rabbi Eliezer Zev Zt"l of Kretshnif. Years later, he told a wondrous story that occurred before his birth:
On the eve of the Pesach holiday, the time of his birth arrived. His holy father asked the Rebbetzin to agree to wait until the end of the holiday so that he would not be disturbed from his meticulous stringencies regarding Kashrut on Pesach. When she refused, he raised his eyes to Heaven and said: "Master of the World, for my part, I would be willing to fast for the duration of all the days of the holiday, but behold, You commanded us in Your Holy Torah to eat and rejoice on the holiday. I ask of You that the matter be postponed until after the days of Pesach, and I promise You, my Father in Heaven, that the child born will be entirely holy to G-d."
And indeed, so it was. On Motzaei Yom Tov, the last day of Pesach, the sun of our Rebbe shone.
From the dawn of his youth, he basked in the shadow of his holy ancestors and clung to their ways, with manners of holiness and Chassidus and toil in Torah with self-sacrifice. They too imparted their holy spirit upon him as they opened their good treasury before him and guided him toward his great future in leading the congregation of G-d. Indeed, our Rebbe stood out while still tender in years with a wondrous combination of manners of sublime holiness alongside rare cleverness. So much so that his friend from youth, the Holy Admor of Seret-Vizhnitz Zt"l, testified that already when our Rebbe was about seven years old, the Jews of Seret would turn to him and ask for his blessings, and he would grant them blessings from the depth of his heart.
The days of goodness did not last long. At the end of the year 1939, the World War broke out, and the order of the world collapsed. On the 25th of Sivan, 1941, the people of Seret and our Rebbe among them were expelled, exile after exile, to the district of Transnistria, where they stayed until the 2nd of Sivan, 1944.
Many hardships passed over him in the years of fury. Despite his young age, he was rescued with great cleverness and resourcefulness to extend a helping hand to his brothers groaning in their suffering. Even in those days, our Rebbe did not abandon any of the shields of holiness special to him, while utilizing every possible moment to diligently study Torah, in conditions that were no conditions.
With the end of the war, when Romania was conquered by the Russian army, the exiles were permitted to return to their homes. The situation in the city of Seret was unclear, and our Rebbe's father decided to travel to the home of his father, the Holy Admor Rabbi Itamar Zt"l, in Czernowitz, which the war had completely passed over. They sat there for close to a year until they returned to Seret, aspiring to ascend and grace the soil of the Holy Land. The arrangement of immigration permits took a long time. Our Rebbe, whose soul yearned to ascend to Jerusalem, pleaded with his father to allow him to ascend alone, as his soul desired to study Torah in the Yeshiva of the Gaon Rabbi Yosef Tzvi Dushinsky Zt"l in Jerusalem. The day after the Pesach holiday in 1946, our Rebbe sailed on an illegal immigrant ship, which was captured by the British. All passengers were sent to the detention camp in Atlit, where they stayed for a few months. Only at the end of the month of Elul did our Rebbe manage to go free and ascend to Jerusalem, to diligently study Torah and service as was the desire of his pure soul.
In the year 1948, his holy father ascended to the Land and settled in the Batei Ungarin neighborhood in Jerusalem. In those days, a war broke out, and many fell in the neighborhood from enemy shells, until his holy father was forced to move with his family to the city of Jaffa. Our Rebbe continued his studies in the Dushinsky Yeshiva in Jerusalem until the year 1950, when his holy father established the "Maamar Mordechai - Nadvorna" Yeshiva in Jaffa. Then he moved to study in his father's Yeshiva, standing at his right hand in establishing the Yeshiva and its conduct, being a model for many as a son of ascent raised above the people. Already then, many good people were drawn after him to gaze upon the radiance of his holiness and to be perfumed by the pleasantness of his conversations in matters of Torah and service of G-d. Even after his marriage, he continued to live in his holy father's presence while assisting him in the holy work. In the year 1960, when his holy father moved to live in Bnei Brak where he established anew the holy court and institutions of Nadvorna, our Rebbe also moved there.
With the passing of his holy father on the 15th of Tevet, 1978, when our Rebbe ascended to fill his place in holiness as a man over the congregation, his power was revealed with greater strength. Quickly, he became famous as a wise man of the Jews, a lover of Israel without limits who gives his soul to help all who turn to him, whose prayers pierce the heavens. Quickly, his house became a destination for many. He was famous for the clarity of his decisive answers; Urim VeTumim was for those who sought his door.
For over 24 years, he led the holy congregation with compassion, laboring incessantly to elevate them and instill in them solid and faithful foundations of love of Torah and fear of Heaven in the way of Chassidus. In his Torah words, which he delivered regularly, he would speak much, demanding from his congregation perfection in the acquisitions of Torah and fear. He followed in detail the ascent and growth of each and every one of the members of his congregation, guiding them to ascend the steps leading to the House of G-d.
On the 7th of Adar, 2012, the day of the passing of Moses our Teacher, the Faithful Shepherd, his soul ascended to Heaven, and the Holy Ark was hidden in the tent of his holy ancestors in the heights of the Mount of Olives.
Source: Nezer HaTorah

מִשַּׁחַר יְמֵי נְעוּרָיו מִסְתּוֹפֵף הָיָה בְּצִלָּם שֶׁל אֲבוֹתָיו הק' וּמִתְדַּבֵּק בְּאָרְחוֹתֵיהֶם, בְּגִינוּנֵי קְדֻשָּׁה וַחֲסִידוּת וּבִיגִיעַת הַתּוֹרָה בִּמְסִי"נ. אַף הֵם הֶאֱצִילוּ עָלָיו מֵרוּחָם הק' כְּשֶׁהֵם פּוֹתְחִים בְּפָנָיו אֶת אוֹצָרָם הַטּוֹב וּמַדְרִיכִים אוֹתוֹ לִקְרַאת עֲתִידוֹ הַגָּדוֹל בְּהַנְהָגַת עֲדַת ה'. וְאָכֵן, נִתְבַּלֵּט רַבֵּינוּ בְּעוֹדוֹ רַךְ בְּשָׁנִים בְּשִׁלּוּב מֻפְלָא שֶׁל גִּינוּנֵי קְדֻשָּׁה עִילָאִית לְצַד פִּקְּחוּת נְדִירָה, עַד כִּי הֵעִיד יְדִיד נְעוּרָיו כ"ק אַדְמוֹ"ר מִסֶּערֶעט וִיזְ'נִיץ (שְׁלִיטָ"א) [זְצוּקַ"ל] כִּי כְּבָר בִּהְיוֹת רַבֵּינוּ כְּבֶן שֶׁבַע הָיוּ יְהוּדֵי סֶערֶעט פּוֹנִים אֵלָיו וּמְבַקְּשִׁים אֶת בִּרְכוֹתָיו, וְהוּא הָיָה מַעֲנִיק לָהֶם בְּרָכוֹת מֵעֹמֶק הַלֵּב.
לֹא אָרְכוּ יְמֵי הַטּוֹבָה, בְּשִׁלְהֵי שְׁנַת תרצ"ט פָּרְצָה מִלְחֶמֶת הָעוֹלָם וּמָטוּ סִדְרֵי תֵּבֵל. בְּיוֹם כ"ה סִיוָן תש"א גֹּרְשׁוּ אַנְשֵׁי סֶערֶעט וְרַבֵּינוּ בְּתוֹכָם גּוֹלָה אַחַר גּוֹלָה לִמְחוֹז טְרַנְסְנִיסְטְרִיָּה, שָׁם שָׁהוּ עַד יוֹם ב' בְּסִיוָן תש"ד. תְּלָאוֹת רַבּוֹת עָבְרוּ עָלָיו בִּשְׁנוֹת הַזַּעַם, כְּשֶׁלַּמְרוֹת גִּילוֹ הַצָּעִיר נֶחְלָץ הוּא בְּרֹב פִּקְּחוּתוֹ וְתוּשִׁיָּתוֹ לְהוֹשִׁיט יָד מְסַיַּעַת לְאֶחָיו הַנֶּאֱנָקִים בְּסִבְלָם. גַּם בְּאוֹתָם יָמִים לֹא זָנַח רַבֵּינוּ מְאוּמָה מִגִּינוּנֵי הַקְּדֻשָּׁה הַמְּיֻחָדִים לוֹ, תּוֹךְ שֶׁהוּא מְנַצֵּל כָּל רֶגַע אֶפְשָׁרִי לִשְׁקֹד עַל הַתּוֹרָה, בִּתְנָאִים לֹא תְּנָאִים.
עִם תֹּם הַמִּלְחָמָה, מִשֶּׁנִּכְבְּשָׁה רוֹמַנְיָה ע"י הַצָּבָא הָרוּסִי, הֻרְשׁוּ הַגּוֹלִים לַחְזֹר לְבָתֵּיהֶם. הַמַּצָּב בְּעִיר סֶערֶעט לֹא הָיָה בָּרוּר וְאָבִיו שֶׁל רַבֵּינוּ הֶחְלִיט לִנְסֹעַ לְבֵית אָבִיו כ"ק אַדְמוֹ"ר רַבִּי אִיתָמָר זצוקלה"ה בְּטְשֶׁערְנוֹבִיץ, עָלֶיהָ פָּסְחָה הַמִּלְחָמָה כָּלִיל. קָרוֹב לְשָׁנָה יָשְׁבוּ שָׁם עַד שֶׁשָּׁבוּ לְסֶערֶעט, תּוֹךְ שְׁאִיפָה לַעֲלוֹת וּלְחוֹנֵן אֶת אַדְמַת ארה"ק. סִדּוּר רִשְׁיוֹנוֹת הָעֲלִיָּה נִתְמַשֵּׁךְ זְמַן רַב וְרַבֵּינוּ אֲשֶׁר כָּלְתָה נַפְשׁוֹ לַעֲלוֹת יְרוּשָׁלַיְמָה הִפְצִיר בְּאָבִיו כִּי יַרְשֵׁהוּ לַעֲלוֹת בְּגַפּוֹ, בַּאֲשֶׁר חָשְׁקָה נַפְשׁוֹ לִלְמֹד תּוֹרָה בִּישִׁיבָתוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן הַנּוֹדָע רַבִּי יוֹסֵף צְבִי דּוּשִׁינְסְקִיָא זַצַ"ל בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם. לְמָחֳרָת חַג הַפֶּסַח תש"ו הִפְלִיג רַבֵּינוּ בִּסְפִינַת מַעְפִּילִים, אֲשֶׁר נִלְכְּדָה ע"י הַבְּרִיטִים וְכָל בָּאֶיהָ נִשְׁלְחוּ לְמַחֲנֵה הַהֶסְגֵּר בְּעַתְלִית, שָׁם שָׁהוּ חֳדָשִׁים אֲחָדִים. רַק בְּשִׁלְהֵי חֹדֶשׁ אֱלוּל עָלָה בִּידֵי רַבֵּינוּ לָצֵאת לְחָפְשִׁי וְלַעֲלוֹת יְרוּשָׁלַיְמָה, לִשְׁקֹד עַל הַתּוֹרָה וְהָעֲבוֹדָה כְּמַשְּׂאַת נַפְשׁוֹ הַטְּהוֹרָה.
בִּשְׁנַת תש"ח עָלָה אַרְצָה אָבִיו הק' שֶׁל רַבֵּינוּ וְהִתְיַשֵּׁב בְּבָתֵּי אוּנְגָּרִין שֶׁבִּירוּשָׁלַיִם, בְּאוֹתָם הַיָּמִים פָּרְצָה מִלְחָמָה וַחֲלָלִים רַבִּים נָפְלוּ בַּשְּׁכוּנָה מִפְּגָזֵי הָאוֹיֵב, עַד שֶׁנֶּאֱלַץ אָבִיו הק' לַעֲקֹר עִם בְּנֵי מִשְׁפַּחְתּוֹ לְעִיר יָפוֹ. רַבֵּינוּ הִמְשִׁיךְ בְּלִמּוּדָיו בִּישִׁיבַת דּוּשִׁינְסְקִיָא בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם עַד שְׁנַת תש"י, עֵת הֵקִים אָבִיו הק' אֶת יְשִׁיבַת "מַאֲמַר מָרְדְּכַי - נַדְבוֹרְנָה" בְּיָפוֹ. אָז עָבַר לִלְמֹד בִּישִׁיבַת אָבִיו, כְּשֶׁהוּא מִתְיַצֵּב לִימִינוֹ בְּכִנּוּן הַיְשִׁיבָה וְהַנְהָגָתָהּ, בִּהְיוֹתוֹ מוֹפֵת לָרַבִּים כְּבֵן עֲלִיָּה מוּרָם מֵעָם. כְּבָר אָז הָיוּ רַבִּים וְטוֹבִים נוֹהִים אַחֲרָיו לָזוּן עֵינֵיהֶם בְּזִיו קְדֻשָּׁתוֹ וּלְהִתְבַּשֵּׂם מִנֹּעַם שִׂיחוֹתָיו בְּעִנְיְנֵי תּוֹרָה וַעֲבוֹדַת ה'. גַּם אַחַר נִשּׂוּאָיו הִמְשִׁיךְ לְהִתְגּוֹרֵר בִּמְחִצַּת אָבִיו הק' כְּשֶׁהוּא מְסַיֵּעַ לוֹ בַּעֲבוֹדַת הַקֹּדֶשׁ, וּבִשְׁנַת תש"כ מִשֶּׁעָבַר אָבִיו הק' לְהִתְגּוֹרֵר בִּבְנֵי בְּרַק בָּהּ כּוֹנֵן מֵחָדָשׁ אֶת חֲצַר הַקֹּדֶשׁ וּמוֹסְדוֹת נַדְבוֹרְנָה עָבַר גַּם רַבֵּינוּ לְשָׁם.
עִם הִסְתַּלְּקוּת אָבִיו הק' בְּיוֹם ט"ו בְּטֵבֵת תשל"ח. מִשֶּׁעָלָה רַבֵּינוּ לְמַלֵּא אֶת מְקוֹמוֹ בַּקֹּדֶשׁ כְּאִישׁ עַל הָעֵדָה נִתְגַּלָּה כּוֹחוֹ בְּיֶתֶר שְׂאֵת. עַד מְהֵרָה נִתְפַּרְסֵם כְּחַכִּימָא דִיהוּדָאֵי. אוֹהֵב יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּלִי מְצָרִים הַמּוֹסֵר נַפְשׁוֹ לְסַיֵּעַ לְכָל הַפּוֹנִים אֵלָיו, אֲשֶׁר תְּפִלּוֹתָיו מַבְקִיעוֹת רְקִיעִים. עַד מְהֵרָה הָיָה בֵּיתוֹ לְתֵל תַּלְפִּיּוֹת לָרַבִּים. מְפֻרְסָם הָיָה בִּבְהִירוּת תְּשׁוּבוֹתָיו הַחוֹתְכוֹת, כְּאוּרִים וְתֻמִּים הָיָה לַמְשַׁחֲרִים לְפִתְחוֹ.
בְּמֶשֶׁךְ לְמַעְלָה מִכ"ד שָׁנָה נִיהֵג בִּרְחִימָאִיוּת אֶת עֲדַת הַקֹּדֶשׁ, כְּשֶׁהוּא עָמֵל לְלֹא הֶרֶף לְרוֹמְמָם וּלְהַחְדִּיר בָּהֶם יְסוֹדוֹת אֵיתָנִים וְנֶאֱמָנִים שֶׁל אַהֲבַת תּוֹרָה וְיִרְאַת שָׁמַיִם בְּדֶרֶךְ הַחֲסִידוּת. בְּדִבְרֵי תּוֹרָתוֹ אֲשֶׁר נוֹשֵׂא הָיָה תְּמִידִין כְּסִדְרָן מַרְבֶּה הָיָה לִדְרֹשׁ מִקְּהַל עֲדָתוֹ שְׁלֵימוּת בְּקִנְיְנֵי תּוֹרָה וְיִרְאָה. כְּשֶׁהוּא עוֹקֵב בְּאֹפֶן פַּרְטָנִי אַחֲרֵי עֲלִיָּתוֹ וּצְמִיחָתוֹ שֶׁל כָּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד מִבְּנֵי עֲדָתוֹ, וּמַדְרִיכָם לַעֲלוֹת בַּמַּעֲלוֹת הָעוֹלוֹת בֵּית אֵ-ל.
בְּיוֹם ז' בַּאֲדָר תשע"ב, יוֹם פְּטִירַת מֹשֶׁה רַעְיָא מְהֵימְנָא, עָלְתָה נִשְׁמָתוֹ הַשָּׁמַיְמָה וְנִגְנַז אֲרוֹן הַקֹּדֶשׁ בְּאֹהֶל אֲבוֹתָיו הק' בִּמְרוֹמֵי הַר הַזֵּיתִים."נזר התורה", תמוז תשע"ב, ע' מ"ו

My father, our Master and Teacher of blessed memory, told me once that in his childhood (around the age of Bar Mitzvah), after the war, he found out that there was a border at the river, and Jews were fleeing through there from the Russians. He said that he wanted to have a part in the Mitzvah, so he went out from his house at 9:00 PM and began walking by the river, thinking perhaps he would encounter some Jew and be able to help him and save him. And so it was. After about half an hour, a Jew suddenly emerged from the water after a gentile had transported him with a boat. The man saw a boy with two sidelocks and understood he was a Jew. He approached him to ask if he knew where people go, for he had just fled from there and paid a gentile to smuggle him to the other side of the river, but from here on he had to manage on his own. My father asked him if he had more people with him. He said that indeed his wife and children still needed to cross. My father told him to go bring them and he would wait for him there, only that he should hurry before dawn rose. Indeed, he brought his wife and children. In the meantime, my father summoned a gentile with a wagon and brought them to his father the Rebbe Zt"l's house, where they stayed for six weeks until they got settled... Already in his childhood, it was his nature to seek to help others.
Source: Halichot Kodesh

With the Admor of Nadvorna Zt"l, the Rebbe [the Holy Admor the Maharash of Lelov Zt"l] had a special friendship from the days of their youth. They were good friends in their youth. On the day of the Rebbe's wedding, he was secluded in a hidden place with the Rebbe of Nadvorna until a late hour, and he studied with him for long hours. When the Rebbe of Nadvorna got married, the Rebbe gave him a book as a gift and wrote there: "To my friend, a servant of G-d from his youth." In the Kesubah of the Holy Rebbe Zt"l, the name of the Admor of Nadvorna is signed, who was then still a bachelor.
Source: Ohel Moed

Chassidim and men of action danced, righteous men rejoiced in gladness, and the groom [the Holy Admor, the *Be'er Yaakov* of Nadvorna Zt"l, on his wedding day] was immersed in spiritual worlds. No one sensed that the groom of the day, who naturally fasted according to the law of the day, had barely managed to drink, and in the heat of the day, he almost fainted. The groom himself, although he was immersed in the palaces of inner joy, was overcome by physical weakness and felt that in just a little while, he might faint from great thirst. It would have been simple to reach out to one of the bottles standing on the table and pour a glass of cold water to revive his soul. But the wondrous groom had taken upon himself a good resolution, for reasons of abstinence, not to take food or drink for himself, but to taste only from what was served to him. Even on his great day, and perhaps specifically on this day, he decided not to transgress the custom of self-denial he practiced—come what may.
At the very last moment, the thought arose in the mind of the one who was the Gabai at his side on the wedding day, one of the greats of the congregation, my father and teacher, the Chassidic Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Tzvi Kobalski Zt"l, that perhaps the groom was thirsty. He poured him a glass of water. The groom sipped and revived his soul. Afterward, he whispered to my father Zt"l: "Know that I was in a state of thirst to the point of expiration of the soul... I was not capable of holding on much longer... You saved me! I will be grateful to you for this in the future..."
Then my father reconstructed to himself and understood in retrospect that indeed, this was the Rebbe's custom in the days of his youth, out of manners of abstinence and self-control, not to be enslaved to matter, not to ask a person for food. His close ones knew that if they did not serve him—he could wait hours upon hours when food did not enter his mouth.
He learned the secret of his distancing from the physical connection to eating from my teacher, the Chassidic Gaon Zt"l, who was very close to our Rebbe in the days of his youth. Our Rebbe, whose entire days and nights were absorbed in the service of his Creator, had no time to enter the kitchen in his home. Once, a guest happened to come to our Rebbe's abode, and no one from the household was there. Our Rebbe deviated from his custom and entered the kitchen to prepare a drink for him. But he found himself perplexed, for he did not know where the dairy vessels and the meat vessels were located...
During the Shiva, the righteous Rebbetzin testified that once, when she was weak, the Rebbe asked to help her and prepare a hot drink for her. To perform the task, he asked her: "How do you set up a kettle..." And she answered and said: "No, this is my job"... To such an extent was he removed even from simple daily material activities, and to such an extent was her standing at his right hand for his holiness, to enable him to be separated and distinct from all matters of matter.
Source: Tal Talpiyot

בְּרֶגַע הָאַחֲרוֹן מַמָּשׁ, עָלָה בְּדַעְתּוֹ שֶׁל מִי שֶׁהָיָה הַגַּבַּאי לְצִדּוֹ בְּיוֹם הָאַפִּירְיוֹן, אֶחָד מִגְּדוֹלֵי הָעֵדָה, אַבָּא מָארִי, הַגָּאוֹן הֶחָסִיד רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל צְבִי קוֹבַלְסְקִי זַצַ"ל, שֶׁמָּא הֶחָתָן צָמֵא. מָזַג לוֹ כּוֹס שֶׁל מַיִם. הֶחָתָן לָגַם וְהֵשִׁיב נַפְשׁוֹ. אַחַר, לָחַשׁ לְאַבָּא זַצַ"ל:"דַּע, כִּי הָיִיתִי בְּמַצָּב שֶׁל צִמָּאוֹן עַד כְּלוֹת הַנֶּפֶשׁ... לֹא הָיִיתִי מְסֻגָּל לְהַחְזִיק יוֹתֵר מַעֲמָד... הִצַּלְתָּנִי! עַל חַסְדְּךָ אַכִּיר לְךָ טוֹבָה בָּזֶה וּבַבָּא"...
אָז שִׁחְזֵר אַבָּא לְעַצְמוֹ, וְהֵבִין לְמַפְרֵעַ, כִּי אָכֵן, זֶה מִנְהָגוֹ שֶׁל רַבֵּינוּ בִּימֵי צְעִירוּתוֹ, מִתּוֹךְ גִּינוּנֵי פְּרִישׁוּת וּשְׁלִיטָה עַצְמִית, שֶׁלֹּא לְהִשְׁתַּעְבֵּד לַחֹמֶר, שֶׁלֹּא לְבַקֵּשׁ מֵאָדָם אֹכֶל כְּלָל. מְקֹרָבָיו יָדְעוּ, כִּי אִם לֹא הִגִּישׁוּ לְפָנָיו - הָיָה יָכוֹל לְהַמְתִּין שָׁעוֹת עַל גַּבֵּי שָׁעוֹת, כְּשֶׁאֹכֶל לֹא נִכְנָס לְפִיו.
אֶת סוֹד הִתְרַחֲקוּתוֹ מִקֶּשֶׁר גַּשְׁמִי אֶל הָאֲכִילָה, לָמַד אָבִי מוֹרִי הַגָּאוֹן הֶחָסִיד זַצַ"ל, שֶׁהָיָה מְקֹרָב בִּמְאוֹד לְרַבֵּינוּ בִּימֵי חָרְפּוֹ. רַבֵּינוּ, שֶׁכָּל יָמָיו וְלֵילוֹתָיו סָפוּן הָיָה בַּעֲבוֹדַת קוֹנוֹ, אֵין לוֹ פְּנַאי לְהִיכָּנֵס לַמִּטְבָּח שֶׁבְּבֵיתוֹ.פַּעַם, נִקְלַע אוֹרֵחַ לִמְעוֹן רַבֵּינוּ, וְאִישׁ מִבְּנֵי הַבַּיִת לֹא הָיָה שָׁם. שִׁנָּה רַבֵּינוּ מִמִּנְהָגוֹ לִכְבוֹד הָאוֹרֵחַ וְנִכְנַס לַמִּטְבָּח לְהָכִין לוֹ מַשְׁקֶה. אֶלָּא שֶׁמָּצָא עַצְמוֹ נָבוֹךְ, כִּי אֵין הוּא יוֹדֵעַ הֵיכָן מִיקוּם הַכֵּלִים הַחֲלָבִיִּים וְהַכֵּלִים הַבְּשָׂרִיִּים...
בִּימֵי הַשִּׁבְעָה, הֵעִידָה הָרַבָּנִית הַצַּדְקָנִית, כִּי פַּעַם, בְּעֵת שֶׁנֶּחֶלְשָׁה, בִּקֵּשׁ הָרַבִּי לְסַיֵּעַ לָהּ וּלְהָכִין עֲבוּרָהּ מַשְׁקֶה חַם. כְּדֵי לְבַצֵּעַ אֶת הַמְּשִׂימָה, שָׁאַל אוֹתָהּ: "כֵּיצַד מַעֲמִידִים מֵיחַם..." וְהִיא נַעֲנְתָה וְאָמְרָה: "לֹא, זֶה תַּפְקִיד שֶׁלִּי"... עַד כְּדֵי כָּךְ הָיָה מְרֻחָק אֲפִילּוּ מֵהַפְּעֻלּוֹת הַחָמְרִיּוֹת הַיּוֹמְיוֹמִיּוֹת הַפְּשׁוּטוֹת, וְעַד כְּדֵי כָּךְ הָיְתָה עֲמִידָתָהּ לִימִין קָדְשׁוֹ, לְאַפְשֵׁר לוֹ לִהְיוֹת מֻבְדָּל וּמֻפְרָשׁ מִכָּל עִנְיְנֵי הַחֹמֶר.הרה"ג ר' חיים דוד קובלסקי שליט"א"תל תלפיות", אדר תשע"ג, עמ' ד'
