**Material in Holiness**
The Holy Rebbe, our Teacher R' Asher Meir Zt"l Halberstam, the Rabbi of Bochnia, said once at the conclusion of Tractate Chagiga: "Hadran Alach Chomer Bakodesh" (We will return to you, material in holiness). Meaning, those meticulous Tzaddikim who turn their materialism into holiness, and elevate it to Him. When such people pass from the world, then it is "Tractate Chagiga" (Celebration)—then there is great joy in all the worlds.
Source: Mashmia Yeshua

**Biography**
The Holy Gaon Rabbi Shlomo Zalman of Volozhin Zt"l, or as he was affectionately called: Rabbi Zelmele, was born to his father, the great "Whole and upright, fearing G-d and turning from evil," Rabbi Yitzchak, the Parnas of Volozhin, and to his mother, the righteous Mrs. Rivka, peace be upon her (who was the daughter of the Gaon Rabbi Yisrael HaKohen Rappaport Zt"l of Pinsk, brother of the famous Gaon Rabbi Chaim HaKohen Rappaport Zt"l of Lvov), on the 26th of Sivan, 1756.
Together with his older brother, the Holy Gaon Rabbi Chaim of Volozhin Zt"l, author of *Nefesh HaChaim*, he basked in the home of the Divine Gaon, the Chassid Rabbi Eliyahu of Vilna Zt"l, where he was sanctified and elevated to be high above high (their eldest brother was the Gaon Rabbi Simcha Zt"l).
To teach of his great magnitude and the intensity of his holiness, it is sufficient to note that his older brother, Rabbi Chaim Zt"l, described him on his tombstone and attributed to him the following: "My brother, head of the thousands of Israel, the Gaon and Tzaddik, resembling a son of G-d (angel), holy shall be said of him, the Honor of the Holiness of our Teacher Shlomo Zalman, peace be upon him."
On the 9th of Adar, 1808, he returned his pure soul to the Heights, to the sorrow of the heart of the entire House of Israel [and is buried in Vilna].
Few and short were his days upon the earth, thirty-two years. But it has already been said that what he accomplished in Torah with his great wisdom, the intensity of his genius, and the magnitude of his holiness, even Methuselah did not have enough time for!
Awesome things and wondrous stories beyond human understanding are told about this Gaon and holy man from very reliable sources. Especially from the writing of his disciple and household member, the Gaon Rabbi Yechezkel Feivel Zt"l, Maggid Meisharim and Moreh Tzedek of Vilna, who raised his pure memory upon the book *Toldot Adam* (printed for the first time about two hundred years ago, in Dyhernfurth, in the year 1801, when the Rabbis and Geonim of Vilna gave their testimony upon it. In it, the author tells of "the awesome and wondrous things my eyes saw in this terrible man over the course of many times that I merited to delight with him in love..."). The author of the book succeeded in combining the biographical portion and the tractate of his life—precious notes and pleasant introductions, and brings much of the Torah of his Holy Rebbe, his pilpulim and novellae, from the dawn of his childhood until the end of his days.
Source: Alim LiTerufah

יַחַד עִם אָחִיו הַגָּדוֹל, הַגָּה"ק רַבִּי חַיִּים מִוּוֹלָאזִ'ין זִי"עַ בַּעַל 'נֶפֶשׁ הַחַיִּים', הִסְתּוֹפֵף בְּבֵית אֱלֹקִי הַגָּאוֹן הֶחָסִיד רַבִּי אֵלִיָּהוּ מִוּוִילְנָא זִי"עַ, שָׁם נִתְקַדֵּשׁ וְנִתְעַלָּה לִהְיוֹת גָּבוֹהַּ מֵעַל גָּבוֹהַּ (אֲחִיהֶם הַבְּכוֹר הָיָה הַגְּ"ר שִׂמְחָה זַצַ"ל).
לְלַמֵּד עַל רֹב גָּדְלוֹ וְעֹצֶם קְדֻשָּׁתוֹ, דַּי לְצַיֵּן שֶׁאֶת אָחִיו הַגָּדוֹל, רַבִּי חַיִּים זַצַ"ל, תֵּאֲרוּ עַל מַצַּבְתּוֹ וְיִחֲסוּהוּ אַחַר אָחִיו הַקָּטָן מִמֶּנּוּ בְּזוֹ הַלָּשׁוֹן: "אֲחִי רֹאשׁ אַלְפֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל הַגָּאוֹן וְצַדִּיק דָּמֵי לְבַר אֱלָהִין, קָדוֹשׁ יֵאָמֵר לוֹ כקש"ת מו"ה שְׁלֹמֹה זַלְמָן נ"ע".
בְּיוֹם ט' אֲדָר שְׁנַת תקס"ח הֵשִׁיב נִשְׁמָתוֹ הַטְּהוֹרָה לַמָּרוֹם לִמְגִנַּת לֵב כָּל בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל [וּמְנוּ"כּ בְּוִוילְנָא]. מְעַטִּים וּקְצָרִים הָיוּ יָמָיו עֲלֵי חֶלֶד שְׁלוֹשִׁים וּשְׁתַּיִם שָׁנָה, אַךְ כְּבָר אָמְרוּ כִּי מַה שֶּׁהִסְפִּיק בַּתּוֹרָה בְּרֹב חָכְמָתוֹ, עֹצֶם גְּאוֹנוּתוֹ וְגֹדֶל קְדֻשָּׁתוֹ, גַּם חַיֵּי מְתוּשֶׁלַח לֹא הָיוּ מַסְפִּיקִים לְכָךְ!
דְּבָרִים נוֹרָאִים וְסִפּוּרִים מֻפְלָאִים מִדַּעַת אָדָם מְסֻפָּרִים עַל הַאי גָּאוֹן וְקָדוֹשׁ מִמְּקוֹרוֹת נֶאֱמָנִים בְּיוֹתֵר, בִּמְיֻחָד מִפִּי כְּתָבוֹ שֶׁל תַּלְמִידוֹ וּבֶן בֵּיתוֹ הַגְּ"ר יְחֶזְקֵאל פַיְיוִויל זַצַ"ל, מַגִּיד מֵישָׁרִים וּמוֹ"ץ דְּקַּ"ק וִוילְנָא, אֲשֶׁר הֶעֱלָה זִכְרוֹ טָהוֹר עֲלֵי סֵפֶר 'תּוֹלְדוֹת אָדָם' (נִדְפַּס לָרִאשׁוֹנָה לִפְנֵי כְּמָאתַיִם שָׁנָה, בְּדִיְהֶרְנְפוּרְט, בִּשְׁנַת תקס"א, כְּשֶׁרַבָּנֵי וּגְאוֹנֵי וִוילְנָא נָתְנוּ עָלָיו עֵדֵיהֶם, בּוֹ מְסַפֵּר הַמְחַבֵּר אֶת "הַנּוֹרָאוֹת וְהַנִּפְלָאוֹת אֲשֶׁר עֵינַי רָאוּ בָּאִישׁ הַנּוֹרָא הַלָּזֶה בְּהֶמְשֵׁךְ זְמַנִּים רַבִּים אֲשֶׁר זָכִיתִי לְהִתְעַלֵּס עִמּוֹ בָּאֲהָבִים..."). מְחַבֵּר הַסֵּפֶר הִשְׂכִּיל לְשַׁלֵּב בֵּין פָּרָשַׁת הַתּוֹלְדוֹת וּמַסֶּכֶת חַיָּיו - הֶעָרוֹת יְקָרוֹת וְהַקְדָּמוֹת נֶחְמָדוֹת, וּמַרְבֶּה לְהָבִיא מִדִּבְרֵי תּוֹרָתוֹ שֶׁל רַבּוֹ הק', פִּלְפּוּלָיו וְחִדּוּשָׁיו, מִשַּׁחַר יַלְדוּתוֹ וְעַד אַחֲרִית יָמָיו."עלים לתרופה", ויקרא תשס"ה, עמ' ג'

My teacher, HaGaon Rabbi M.D. HaLevi Soloveitchik Shlita, told:
Once, the great disciples of the Gaon Rabbi Chaim of Volozhin Zt"l sat before him: R' David Tevel of Minsk, R' Berel Turetz'er, and others. They spoke about the saying of Chazal: **כל פרנס המתגאה על הצבור שלא לשם שמים אינו זוכה לבן תלמיד חכם** - "Any leader who prides himself over the community not for the sake of Heaven does not merit a son who is a Torah scholar."
R' Chaim Zt"l said then: "By inference, you hear the positive. If so, it emerges that 'Any leader who prides himself over the community *for the sake of Heaven*, merits a son who is a Torah scholar'!!!"
The Gaon Rabbi Chaim of Volozhin Zt"l added and said: "My father was a Parnas in Volozhin, and all his work was for the sake of Heaven. Therefore, he merited a son like my brother, Rabbi Zalman, who had the entire Torah clear to him by heart: Shas Bavli and Yerushalmi, Sifra, Sifrei, Mechilta, Tosefta, Midrashim, Zohar, Tikkunim, and Etz Chaim [it did not cross his mind to refer to himself]."
Rabbi Chaim Zt"l continued and said: "Even if my brother R' Zalman lived in the time of the Tannaim and Amoraim, he would also be considered a Torah scholar." When the students heard this, trembling seized them. One of the students answered and said: "If so, then what was the Gaon of Vilna Zt"l?" R' Chaim Zt"l answered them: "Even if my brother R' Zalman lived a thousand years twice over, he would not reach the ankles of the Gra Zt"l."
He explained his intent: "With R' Zalman, the entire Torah was clear by heart just as every Jew knows how to say **אשרי יושבי ביתך** - 'Happy are those who dwell in Your house' by heart. But if a person is asked which word is written before **חנון ורחום ה'** - 'Gracious and merciful is the L-rd,' he will have to repeat the verse that precedes it, and through that, he will know. He cannot say immediately the words that are before it. And if he is asked to say **עלינו לשבח** - 'It is our duty to praise' backwards, to say a word before, he will have to start from the beginning of 'Aleinu LeShabeach' or he will need to look in the Siddur."
The Gaon Rabbi Chaim of Volozhin Zt"l concluded: "My brother R' Zalman's knowledge of the entire Torah was like every man knows 'Ashrei,' and certainly this is considered a Torah scholar even in the time of the Tannaim and Amoraim. Indeed, the Gra Zt"l knew the entire Torah in a way that he could say it also from the end to the beginning."
Source: Uvdot VeHanhagot LeBeit Brisk

וְהוֹסִיף הַגְּרַ"ח מוּוָאלָאזִ'ין זַצַ"ל וְאָמַר, אַבָּא שֶׁלִּי הָיָה פַּרְנָס בְּווֹאלָאזִ'ין וְכָל עֲבוֹדָתוֹ הָיְתָה לְשֵׁם שָׁמַיִם, וְלָכֵן זָכָה לְבֵן כְּאָחִי רַבִּי זַלְמָן שֶׁהָיָה אֶצְלוֹ בָּרוּר בְּעַ"פּ כָּל הַתּוֹרָה שַׁ"ס בַּבְלִי וִירוּשַׁלְמִי, סִפְרָא, סִפְרֵי, מְכִילְתָּא, תּוֹסֶפְתָּא, מִדְרָשִׁים, זוֹהַר, תִּקּוּנִים וְעֵץ חַיִּים [עַל עַצְמוֹ בִּכְלָל לֹא עָלָה בְּדַעְתּוֹ].
וְהִמְשִׁיךְ רַבִּי חַיִּים זַצַ"ל וְאָמַר, דַּאֲפִילּוּ אִם אָחִי ר' זַלְמָן הָיָה חַי בִּזְמַן הַתַּנָּאִים וְהָאֱמוֹרָאִים גַּ"כּ הָיָה נֶחְשָׁב לְתַלְמִיד חָכָם. הַתַּלְמִידִים כְּשֶׁשָּׁמְעוּ כָּךְ אֲחָזָתַם רְעָדָה. נַעֲנָה אֶחָד מִבֵּין הַתַּלְמִידִים וְאָמַר, א"כ אָז מַה כְּבָר הָיָה הַגָּאוֹן מִוִּילְנָא זַצַ"ל? עָנָה לָהֶם ר' חַיִּים דַּאֲפִילּוּ אִם אָחִי ר' זַלְמָן הָיָה חַי אֶלֶף שָׁנִים פַּעֲמַיִם, לֹא הָיָה מַגִּיעַ לְקַרְסוֹלָיו שֶׁל הַגְּרַ"א זַצַ"ל.
וּבֵאֵר אֶת כַּוָּנָתוֹ, דְּאֵצֶל ר' זַלְמָן הָיָה בָּרוּר בְּעַ"פּ כָּל הַתּוֹרָה כְּמוֹ שֶׁכָּל יְהוּדִי יוֹדֵעַ לוֹמַר "אַשְׁרֵי יוֹשְׁבֵי בֵיתֶךָ" בְּעַל פֶּה. אַךְ אִם נִשְׁאַל אָדָם אֵיזוֹ מִילָה כְּתוּבָה לִפְנֵי "חַנּוּן וְרַחוּם ה'", יִצְטָרֵךְ לַחְזֹר הַפָּסוּק שֶׁלִּפְנֵי כֵן, וְעַי"ז יֵדַע, וְלֹא יוּכַל לוֹמַר מִיָּד הַמִּלִּים שֶׁלְּפַנֶּ"כּ. וְאִם נִשְׁאַל אוֹתוֹ בְּ"עָלֵינוּ לְשַׁבֵּחַ", לוֹמַר מִילָה קֹדֶם, יִצְטָרֵךְ לְשֵׁם כָּךְ לְהַתְחִיל מִתְּחִלַּת "עָלֵינוּ לְשַׁבֵּחַ" אוֹ שֶׁיִּצְטָרֵךְ לְהִסְתַּכֵּל בַּסִּדּוּר.
סִיֵּם הַגְּרַ"ח מוּוָאלָאזִ'ין זַצַ"ל: "יְדִיעַת אָחִי ר' זַלְמָן הָיְתָה בְּכָל הַתּוֹרָה כְּמוֹ שֶׁכָּל אָדָם יוֹדֵעַ "אַשְׁרֵי", וּבְוַדַּאי שֶׁזֶּה נֶחְשָׁב לְתַלְמִיד חָכָם אַף בִּזְמַן הַתַּנָּאִים וְהָאֱמוֹרָאִים. אָכֵן הַגְּרַ"א זַצַ"ל יָדַע אֶת כָּל הַתּוֹרָה בְּאֹפֶן שֶׁיָּכוֹל לוֹמַר גַּם מֵהַסּוֹף לַהַתְחָלָה.הרב שמעון יוסף מלר שליט"א"עובדות והנהגות לבית בריסק" (ירושלים תשנ"ט) ח"א, ע' קפ"ג
body_en:
The Chafetz Chaim brings in his book: Once, while they were on the road, the famous disciples of the Gaon of Vilna, the brothers R' Chaim and R' Zalman of Volozhin, happened upon an inn. The owner, thinking they were ordinary guests, shamed and insulted them greatly and drove them out without giving them a place to sleep in his inn. They were forced, therefore, to continue their way in the dead of night. To his surprise, the Gaon R' Chaim sensed that the Tzaddik R' Zalman was crying. He asked him:
"Why do you cry, my dear brother? Why do you take to heart the insults of the foolish? Believe me that I didn't even listen to them and didn't pay attention to them!"
"No, my dear brother," answered the Tzaddik amidst weeping, "I am not crying over the insults the innkeeper insulted me with. Specifically regarding that, I don't care. But the fact pains me that at the time of the incident, when this man raised his voice against us, I felt a certain feeling of sorrow deep in my heart. From this, I learn that I have not yet reached the level of **הנעלבים ואינם עולבים** - 'Those who are insulted but do not insult,' and for this I weep!"
Source: HaChafetz Chaim - Chayav U'Po'alo

Rabbi Zalman of Volozhin was among the first in rank and most important [of the disciples of the Gra of Vilna Zt"l]. Once, the Gra commanded his attendant to bring Tractate Nazir before him so he could examine the language of a Baraita. However, the attendant was delayed on his way. Rabbi Zalman, who was then with his Rebbe and was asked to say it by heart, answered immediately and repeated the matter from beginning to end by heart, without dropping a word of the Gemara's language. The Gra enjoyed this immensely and expressed some of his praise to his face: "My son, regarding you the verse says (Yeshayahu 51:7): **עם תורתי בלבם** - 'The people in whose heart is My law'." The Gra would also say: **אם יתן איש את כל הון ביתו באהבה** - "If a man would give all the substance of his house for love" that R' Zalman has for my Torah, "he would be utterly contemned."
Source: HaGaon HaChasid MiVilna

The mighty Gaon, author of *Shaagas Aryeh* Zt"l, told that he heard two boys talking to each other. The older one was about 14 years old—this was the mighty Gaon, our Teacher R' Chaim Zt"l of Volozhin. The second was about seven years old—this was his brother, the Gaon and Tzaddik, our Teacher R' Shlomo Zalman Zt"l. The older boy asked his younger brother a difficulty: How can it be that among the Children of Israel there are people who are not fit, or are not masters of Torah? After all, our fathers Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob were the pillars of the world, and it would have been fitting for the Torah to return from itself to their seed and their seed's seed forever.
His young brother answered him with a decisive answer: Does not the Gemara (Bava Metzia 85a) say that from here on **התורה מחזרת על אכסניא שלה** - "The Torah returns to its lodging"? It is sufficient that the children and children's children are called a "lodging" for the Torah. And he admitted to his words.
Source: Karnei Re'em

My teacher, HaGaon Rabbi M.D. HaLevi Soloveitchik Shlita, told:
Once, the Gaon Rabbi Chaim of Volozhin Zt"l traveled with his brother R' Zelmele Zt"l in a wagon. The wagon overturned, and both of them fell to the ground. R' Chaim fainted, and R' Zelmele Zt"l cried. The people thought that R' Chaim fainted because he received a stronger blow, and that is why he fainted, and R' Zelmele Zt"l was crying because of the blow he received.
But afterward, they saw that this was not the case. When R' Chaim woke up, he asked immediately: "How are you, R' Zelmele?"... And R' Zelmele Zt"l answered him: "Perhaps you diverted your mind from your study for a moment... and we learned: One who walks on the road and interrupts his study and says **מה נאה אילן זה מה נאה ניר זה הרי זה מתחייב בנפשו** - 'How beautiful is this tree, how beautiful is this plowed field... he bears guilt for his soul'..." And the people understood that R' Chaim fainted because he feared for the safety of R' Zelmele Zt"l, and R' Zelmele Zt"l cried because of the fear of "Behold he bears guilt for his soul"... [I heard from my teacher, HaGaon Rabbi M.D. HaLevi Soloveitchik Shlita].
Source: Uvdot VeHanhagot LeBeit Brisk

R' Dovid Spitz from Vienna, who lives in the USA, relates: When he was in Belz in the year 5690 (1930), Maran (the holy Rebbe R' Aharon of Belz *ztzuk"l*) asked him in which Yeshiva he studied. He answered: In Nitra. Maran said to him: "The Rav of Nitra is 'an *Ehrlicher Yid*' (an honest/upright Jew). My father (the Maharid of Belz) *z"l* told me about him that he is an *Ehrlicher Yid*."
Source: HaRav HaChassid R' Yisrael Klapholtz z"l, "Admorei Belz" (Bnei Brak 5750), Vol. 5, p. 347

body_he: אֲבָל אַחַ"כּ רָאוּ שֶׁלֹּא כֵן הַדָּבָר. שֶׁכְּשֶׁר' חַיִּים הִתְעוֹרֵר, שָׁאַל מִיָּד: "מַה שְׁלוֹמְךָ ר' זַעלְמֶעלֶה"... וְר' זַעלְמֶעלֶה זַצַ"ל עָנָה לוֹ: "שֶׁמָּא הִסַּחְתָּ הַדַּעַת מִלִּמּוּדְךָ לְרֶגַע אֶחָד... וּתְנַן כָּל הַהוֹלֵךְ בַּדֶּרֶךְ וּמַפְסִיק מִלִּמּוּדוֹ וְאוֹמֵר מַה נָּאֶה אִילָן זֶה, מַה נָּאֶה נִיר זֶה, הֲרֵי זֶה מִתְחַיֵּב בְּנַפְשׁוֹ"... וְהֵבִינוּ הָאֲנָשִׁים שֶׁר' חַיִּים הִתְעַלֵּף בִּגְלַל שֶׁחָשַׁשׁ לִשְׁלוֹמוֹ שֶׁל ר' זַעלְמֶעלֶה זַצַ"ל, וְר' זַעלְמֶעלֶה זַצַ"ל בָּכָה בִּגְלַל שֶׁחָשַׁשׁ מֵהָא דְּ"הֲרֵי זֶה מִתְחַיֵּב בְּנַפְשׁוֹ"... [שָׁמַעְתִּי מִמּוֹ"ר הַגְּרַמַּ"ד הַלֵּוִי סָאלָאוֵוייצִיק שְׁלִיטָ"א]הרב שמעון יוסף מלר שליט"א"עובדות והנהגות לבית בריסק" (ירושלים תשנ"ט) ח"א, ע' קי"ג
body_en:
Rabbi Zalman of Volozhin once studied a single Mishna for an entire day. A man urged him to know how many times he studied the Mishna. He told him that he studied it 400 times, for he so loved the words and letters that he could not part from them.
Source: Yeinah Shel Torah

I heard from the honor of my father, my teacher Zt"l, about our great Rebbe, the Holy Gaon Rabbi Zelmele of Volozhin Zt"l. Once, he invited a worthy guest to his home, fed him, gave him drink, and fulfilled the Mitzvah of hospitality. When the guest turned to sleep, he heard the host studying and repeating Chapter 4 of Terumot and repeating it about three hundred times. The next morning, the guest approached him and asked him: "Forgive me, our Rebbe, and explain the meaning of the matter to me. In the Gemara we find (Chagigah 9b): **אינו דומה שונה פרקו מאה פעמים לשונה פרקו מאה ואחד** - 'One who reviews his chapter a hundred times is not comparable to one who reviews his chapter a hundred and one times.' But so many times, like 300, from where do we derive this?"
The Gaon Rabbi Zelmele Zt"l answered him: "To remember what we learned, indeed 101 times is enough. But one who has a love of Torah—how can he move from the chapter he is engaged in? For he loves it very, very much, and parting from it is difficult for him."
Source: Bishishim Chochma

It is told of R' Zelmele of Volozhin Zt"l that once he sat in the Beis Medrash in Vilna and studied with a study partner. They had difficulty with the words of the Tur. They asked R' Zalman, and he began walking back and forth in the Beis Medrash, immersed in study. He recited the entire language of the Tur by heart and stated the explanation of his words, and their difficulty was rejected. While he walked back and forth immersed in his study, he stepped on a nail that struck his foot. Blood flowed from him, and he did not feel it at all until they woke him to it... And once, R' Zelmele Zt"l sat near the stove immersed in his study, and his clothes began to burn, and he did not feel it...
Source: Uvdot VeHanhagot LeBeit Brisk

Upon hearing [The Gaon Rabbi Zalman of Volozhin Zt"l] from the mouth of the Gra regarding his concerns in connection with the custom of the world regarding Pidyon HaBen (Redemption of the Firstborn), R' Zalman hurried to take off his coat and gave it to a Kohen who was there. For years earlier, a firstborn son had been born to him who passed away after a few days. He feared that at the time, he had not fulfilled the Mitzvah of Pidyon HaBen according to its Halacha, according to the opinion of the Gra. Therefore, he hurried to repeat and fulfill it with all its stringencies.
Source: HaGaon HaChasid MiVilna

They tell of the Gaon Rabbi Shlomo Zalman of Volozhin Zt"l that he once came from Vilna to Volozhin to participate in the joy of his brother, the Gaon Rabbi Chaim, who was bringing his son to the Chuppah. R' Chaim wanted to gladden his brother who came to his celebration. He said to him: "My brother, behold you came for a celebration of a Mitzvah. I will send for the 'Klei Zemer' (musicians) to come and play before you and gladden you."
The musicians entered the room of Rabbi Shlomo Zalman and found him sitting on his chair with no book before him. They thought he was sitting and waiting for them. Immediately, they began their playing, striking instruments of song, drums, and cymbals to raise favor before him. And Rabbi Shlomo Zalman sat all that time, his lips whispering Torah... The musicians finished their playing, went out, and went their way.
Afterward, Rabbi Chaim entered to his brother.
"Chaim, my brother," Rabbi Shlomo Zalman asked him, "And where are those 'Klei Zemer' you promised to send me?..."
What became clear? That Rabbi Shlomo Zalman, in his adhesion to Torah, did not sense or feel at all anything that happened and was heard around him, as was his way always, that he would forget the world and its fullness when he was immersed in his study.
Source: Yeinah Shel Torah

body_he:
נִכְנְסוּ הַמְנַגְּנִים לְחַדְרוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי שְׁלֹמֹה זַלְמָן וּמְצָאוּהוּ יוֹשֵׁב עַל כִּסְאוֹ וְאֵין כָּל סֵפֶר לְפָנָיו. הָיוּ סְבוּרִים שֶׁהוּא יוֹשֵׁב וּמְחַכֶּה לָהֶם. מִיָּד פָּתְחוּ בִּנְגִינָתָם, הִכּוּ בִּכְלֵי-שִׁיר, בְּתֹף וּבִמְצִילְתַּיִם כְּדֵי לְהַעֲלוֹת רָצוֹן מִלְּפָנָיו. וְרַבִּי שְׁלֹמֹה זַלְמָן יוֹשֵׁב כָּל אוֹתוֹ הַזְּמַן וְשִׂפְתוֹתָיו מְרַחֲשׁוֹת תּוֹרָה... סִיְּמוּ הַמְנַגְּנִים אֶת נְגִינָתָם, יָצְאוּ וְהָלְכוּ לָהֶם. לְאַחַר מִכֵּן נִכְנַס רַבִּי חַיִּים אֵצֶל אָחִיו.
חַיִּים, אָחִי - שׁוֹאֵל אוֹתוֹ רַבִּי שְׁלֹמֹה זַלְמָן - וְהֵיכָן הֵם אוֹתָם "כְּלֵי-זֶמֶר" שֶׁהִבְטַחְתָּ לִשְׁלֹחַ לִי?...
מַה נִּתְבָּרֵר? שֶׁרַבִּי שְׁלֹמֹה זַלְמָן, בִּדְבֵקוּתוֹ בַּתּוֹרָה, לֹא חָשׁ וְלֹא הִרְגִּישׁ כְּלָל בְּכָל מַה שֶּׁהִתְרַחֵשׁ וְנִשְׁמַע מִסָּבִיב לוֹ, כְּדַרְכּוֹ תָּמִיד, שֶׁהָיָה שׁוֹכֵחַ עוֹלָם וּמְלוֹאוֹ בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁהָיָה שָׁקוּעַ בְּלִמּוּדוֹ.הגאון רבי בנימין אדלר שליט"א"יינה של תורה-אמת" (ירושלים תשנ"ג) ע' רי"ד
body_en:
My teacher, HaGaon Rabbi M.D. HaLevi Soloveitchik Shlita, told:
Once a Jew came to the Beis Medrash in Vilna and said he had a "Chiddush" (novel explanation) of "Pshat" in a Mishna in Demai. His words did not find favor in the eyes of the learners there. The aforementioned man was from Lithuania and pronounced "Shin" (left dot) as "Shin" (right dot). When he entered, he said he had a new "Perot" (cows - mispronouncing *Perush*/explanation). R' Zelmele [of Volozhin] Zt"l also sat there and said to him, "Your cows are Demai cows"... (And this was according to what the man said "Perush," it sounded like "Perot"). However, immediately and on the spot, R' Zelmele Zt"l regretted what he said. For what was that man guilty of, that he says "Shin" (left) instead of "Shin" (right)? He was very distressed by this, that he had shamed a Jew, and he went to search for him in the whole city but did not find him.
And R' Zelmele Zt"l became literally sick from this and fell into bed. The father-in-law of R' Zelmele Zt"l sought advice and found a man who resembled the description of the man who said the aforementioned Chiddush. He asked him to come before R' Zelmele Zt"l and tell him that he is the man who said the Chiddush in the Beis Medrash some time ago on the Mishna in Demai. But R' Zelmele Zt"l grasped that this was not that man. He urged him greatly to reveal the truth, until he admitted that it was not him. Only his father-in-law had sent him to him.
R' Zelmele Zt"l decided that he would go to all the synagogues in the city and ask forgiveness in public from Ploni whom he had shamed. When the Gra Zt"l heard of the story, he called R' Zelmele Zt"l and showed him in the Gemara Sukkah [52b]: "**צופה רשע לצדיק ומבקש להמיתו** - 'The wicked watches the righteous, and seeks to slay him,' **ואלמלא הקב"ה שעוזר לו אינו יכול לו** - 'and were it not for the Holy One, Blessed be He, who helps him, he could not overcome him,' as it is said, 'The L-rd will not leave him in his hand,' etc." The Gra asked: Granted, on the beginning of the verse Chazal expounded a great Chiddush, that "Rasha" (wicked) refers to the Evil Inclination. But what they said, "And were it not for the Holy One, Blessed be He, who helps him," behold this matter is explicit in the verse! What did they add here?
The Gra Zt"l said that the simple meaning is that a person does not have the power to stand against the Evil Inclination. But he must do all that he can. Only when he reaches a state of "he cannot overcome him," then the Holy One, Blessed be He, "helps him." And the Gra said to him: "Behold, you did all that you could, and more than that you do not need to do..."
And so it is explained in *Chovot HaLevavot* [Gate of Repentance, Chapter 10]: "If repentance is withheld from a person for some reason, then when he accepts upon himself the boundaries of repentance with all conditions that are in his power and ability, the Creator lightens his repentance for him. And if he harmed his fellow in his body or his money, the Creator will put will and love in his heart [of the victim], until he forgives him for what he sinned against him." See there. [I heard from my teacher and Rabbi, HaGaon Rabbi M.D. HaLevi Soloveitchik Shlita].
Source: Uvdot VeHanhagot LeBeit Brisk

A story involving the holy Gaon, R' Chaim of Volozhin, a disciple of the Gra, who had a brother named R' Zalman. He, too, was a tremendous Torah scholar and a Rav in a certain community. Once, one of the townspeople from R' Zalman's city came to his brother, R' Chaim, and told him that his brother, R' Zalman, had lost his mind.
R' Chaim asked him why he thought so. The Jew related that on the previous Friday night, he saw him running through the city streets without a head covering, holding a lit lamp in his hand. When R' Chaim heard this, he arose and traveled to his brother R' Zalman, worried for his well-being. When he arrived at his home, he found him sitting and studying Torah as usual. R' Chaim was amazed and asked his brother: "Is the matter I heard about you true?" And he told him what he had heard.
R' Zalman laughed and said to him: "I will tell you the story as it happened. On that Friday night, a man came to ask me about lighting a candle for a woman having difficulty in childbirth. When I heard his question, I immediately ruled that it was permitted. However, I saw that the man was still hesitating whether to desecrate the Shabbos. Since this was the case, and it was a matter of *Pikuach Nefesh* (saving a life), I grabbed the lamp that was sitting on my table and began to run to the woman's house. During my run, my Yarmulke fell from my head, but I continued running to save a life. For this reason, they encountered me in such a state... This is true fear of G-d, without personal interests or biases of any kind."
Source: HaRav Shimon Yosef Meller Shlita, "Uvdot VeHanhagot L'Beit Brisk" (Jerusalem 5759), Vol. 1, p. 112

Rabbi Zalman [of Volozhin] passed away on the 9th of Adar, 5548 (1788). During the days when the Gra (Vilna Gaon) was imprisoned in jail during his first arrest, in order not to distress him, they did not reveal the matter to him. Later, he rebuked them for this. All his days, the Gra remained loyal to his memory. Once, when he presented a *Chiddush* (novel Torah insight) to R' Shaul Katzenellenbogen, and the latter repeated the *Chiddush* two or three times out of great enjoyment, the Gra wept and said: "Where is R' Zalman?" He added and told that R' Zalman would repeat every *Chiddush* one hundred and one times.
Source: HaRav HaChassid R' Betzalel Landau z"l, "HaGaon HaChassid MiVilna" (Jerusalem 5738), p. 271

**Biography**
The Gaon and Tzaddik Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke Klein *zt"l*, author of "Tzror HaChaim," was born in the year 5565 (1805) to his father, Rabbi Yosef, in the district of Szilágy in Transylvania. At the age of Bar Mitzvah, he studied in nearby Vowshvar, close to Satmar. Afterward, he wandered with two young men to search for a new Yeshiva and arrived at the Yeshiva of Rabbi Shalom Charif Ullman in Lackenbach. In this Yeshiva, it was customary that only students who had studied there for a number of years received "days" (arranged meals) at the homes of the householders. The new students were forced to go around among the Jewish villagers to collect various food items for their sustenance for a week. Thus, Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke would go out every Thursday and collect food for his sustenance for the duration of a week.
In the year 5593 (1833), he was accepted as the Rav of Balkany, where he sat for about thirteen years. After his arrival there, he established a Yeshiva for himself. He was accustomed to studying his Gemara lessons with the addition of *Rishonim* and *Acharonim*, for in his opinion, "One who does not see the *Acharonim* will find it difficult to understand the *Rishonim*." At the end of this study, he would add words of wit and *Pilpul* (dialectics) of his own. On every page of Gemara, he would innovate two or three new insights. From Balkany, he was accepted as the Rav of Chust and led a Yeshiva there where about one hundred students studied.
In the year 5625 (1865), he was chosen as the Rav of Selish. There, he was able to expand his Yeshiva, as he was not as occupied with community needs as he was in Chust. It seems this was the reason for his decision to move to the community of Selish, which was a smaller community than that of Chust.
Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke was a Mohel and an excellent *Baal Tefillah* (prayer leader). He himself composed a number of melodies that are preserved to this day in various circles, and they sing them during the Hallel prayer and during the smelling of spices on Motzaei Shabbos. He tried to draw every Jew close, and with pleasant sayings, he demanded distancing from the spirit of the Enlightenment (*Haskalah*). When it became known to him that there were parents who wanted to teach their children the French language, he said jokingly: "What is so special about learning French? After all, in France, the child of every simple farmer speaks French."
Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke also became famous as a worker of salvations, but all his salvations were connected to Torah study. When they came before him to ask him to pray for the recovery of a specific sick person, he would say: "The *Chiddush* that we innovated now (during the study in the Yeshiva), we give to the sick person, *Ploni* son of *Ploni*, and in this merit, may he have a complete recovery." Sometimes he would say his prayer in a slightly different version: "In the merit of the Holy Torah that we studied now, may the sick person, *Ploni* son of *Ploni*, have a complete recovery."
The Yeshiva of Selish was recognized, along with thirty-one other Yeshivas, as one of the preparatory institutions for studies at the Pressburg Yeshiva. As is known, Pressburg itself had the rights of a rabbinical seminary, and based on this, the students were exempt from military service.
Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke maintained Responsa correspondence with the greats of his generation, with the Chasam Sofer, with the Ksav Sofer, with the author of "Divrei Chaim," and others. Together with the great Rabbis, he signed the "Kol Korei" (Proclamation) against the decisions of the Congress of 1869, which led to the split in the communities of Hungary.
His thoughts and words were always directed toward Heaven. When he asked a student to light his pipe for him to smoke, he used to say to him: "Light the vessel of smoke (the pipe) for me, so that we may burn the external forces (*Chitzonim*)." Until his last days, he studied with his students, and he passed away on the 9th of Adar II, 5635 (1875) (and his resting place is in honor in Selish).
Source: Rabbi Avraham Fuchs z"l, "Yeshivot Hungaria" (Jerusalem 5739), Vol. 1, p. 715

In the generation following the 'Chasam Sofer', there lived in Hungary one of the mighty figures of Torah and fear of Heaven, a giant in Torah named the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke, Av Beis Din of the holy community of Selish *zt"l*, author of the Sefer 'Tzror HaChaim'. He was a disciple of the holy Gaon Rabbi Shalom Charif *zt"l*, author of 'Divrei Rash'. This story was known and accepted among us:
In those days, the Yeshiva students were very poor. They would mortify themselves in the tent of Torah all week long. Only on Thursday towards evening would they travel to nearby towns to ask merchants for food to restore their souls. At night, they would stay in these towns, and the next day, Friday, they would return to the Yeshiva.
On one of these Thursday nights, when Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke of Selish was a young man, he began to delve deeply into the words of 'Sha'ar HaMelech'. In the middle of the night, he suddenly rose from his sleep while still engrossed in his thoughts on the words of 'Sha'ar HaMelech'. He did not notice that the day had not yet dawned, and thus he began to return to the Yeshiva.
As he passed through the forest, he suddenly encountered a pack of wolves, six in number, who were about to devour him in an instant. Then, suddenly, an old Jew appeared to him, approached him, and said: "Behold, a noise has been made in Heaven—how is it possible that a young man walking to sleep while engrossed in the words of 'Sha'ar HaMelech' should be prey for the teeth of wolves? Therefore, they sent me from Heaven—I am the author of the book 'Sha'ar HaMelech'—to save you from them..."
Thus, the two returned on the way back to the city in the dead of night, and they walked until the light of morning. Then they met his teacher, Rabbi Shalom Charif, who was traveling for a *Sandaka'us*. Upon seeing his student walking accompanied by an unknown old man, he clarified the matter. He realized what had happened the previous night, and from then on, he took care of all the needs of this student.
Source: HaRav HaChassid R' Yisrael Zilberschlag z"l, "Mekor Yisrael" (Bnei Brak 5768), p. 23

My father and teacher *z"l* told me that he heard from our teacher R' Yosef Shlomo Eckstein *z"l*, a disciple of Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke, that once in the middle of a fierce winter, his Rebbe told him that he wished to go out and immerse in the river, and he wanted him to accompany him. R' Yosef Shlomo agreed to this.
On the way, a thought arose in his mind: Now, on his way to the Mikveh, the clothes the Rabbi is wearing are keeping him warm. But on his way back from the frozen river, the clothes will certainly not succeed in warming him... When they reached the river, it did not even occur to R' Yosef Shlomo [who was a young man] to enter the cold river and immerse, for it was not relevant to withstand such a thing. However, Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke stripped off his clothes and quickly jumped into the water. When he came up from the river and began to dress in his clothes, a carriage stopped near them. It was a magnificent, well-heated carriage. The passenger inside called for them to enter and return them to their homes.
When they got off and began to wonder who this was and who that passenger in the carriage was, and from where she had suddenly appeared to them, Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke said to him: "Did you not realize that it is forbidden to be lazy..." With this, he hinted to him that if one wants to go to the Mikveh, then first of all, one must go and perform an action and trust in G-d that He will certainly come to his aid.
Source: HaGaon HaChassid Rabbi Eliezer Dovid Friedman Shlita, "Mipi Sefarim VeSofrim" (Bnei Brak 5768), Vol. 3, p. 167

He also told me in the name of his student, Rabbi Yosef Shlomo Eckstein, that his Rebbe, R' Shmuel Shmelke, used to smoke a *Lulka* [pipe]. When he wanted to light the *Lulka*, he would call a young man and say to him: "Behold, you have not yet sinned [based on the saying (Eruvin 21b): **בחורי ישראל שלא טעמו טעם חטא** - **'Young men of Israel who have not tasted the taste of sin'**], and if so, light the *Lulka* for me and intend to burn all the *Klippos* (impure shells)..."
Source: HaGaon HaChassid Rabbi Eliezer Dovid Friedman Shlita, "Mipi Sefarim VeSofrim" (Bnei Brak 5768), Vol. 3, p. 167

Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke was very sharp. Just from his *Pilpulim* (dialectics) alone, they printed a thick volume, aside from the rest of his books. However, regarding the precise inferences he made on Rashi, they did not print them, because in those days they loved *Pilpul* and wit more than the path of simple explanation and precision. When the 'Ksav Sofer' saw this book, he responded and said that it was a pity they did not print the precise inferences he made in Rashi from it.
Source: HaGaon HaChassid Rabbi Eliezer Dovid Friedman Shlita, "Mipi Sefarim VeSofrim" (Bnei Brak 5768), Vol. 3, p. 167

In his youth, Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke had a study partner (*Chavrusa*) who surpassed him in sharpness. In time, the two agreed to go together to Pressburg to study under the 'Chasam Sofer'. First, that sharp young man entered to the 'Chasam Sofer' to be tested and to ask to study in his Yeshiva. To his surprise, he rejected him with all sorts of excuses. When Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke heard this, he made a *Kal VaChomer* (a fortiori argument) for himself: If they did not admit his sharp friend to the Yeshiva, all the more so they would not accept him.
He thought to himself that since he was already in Pressburg, he would go in to the 'Chasam Sofer' to say hello. When he entered, he received him with a cheerful countenance and asked him to stay and study in his Yeshiva. However, Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke, despite wanting this with all his might, did not accept the offer, arguing that he could not stay to study because his friend was not staying either. The 'Chasam Sofer' answered him: "Der niks chaver" [-He is not a friend for you]. But Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke, who was young in years, refused to enter this Yeshiva without his friend. Therefore, he went with him to study in the Yeshiva of Rabbi Shalom Charif, mentioned above. Not many days passed before they expelled that young man from the Yeshiva because a flaw was found in his conduct. All his days, Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke regretted that he did not stay to study in the shadow of the 'Chasam Sofer'.
When this story happened, someone asked the 'Chasam Sofer' why he did not admit Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke's friend to his Yeshiva. The 'Chasam Sofer' answered him: "On his way entering to me to be tested, I noticed through the window that he trampled with his feet on the *Lulavim* with which I had covered my Sukkah, and in doing so, he trampled on the honor of the Mitzvah. Not so Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke; when he arrived there on his way to me, he moved the *Sechach* to the side and was careful not to step on them..."
Source: HaGaon HaChassid Rabbi Eliezer Dovid Friedman Shlita, "Mipi Sefarim VeSofrim" (Bnei Brak 5768), Vol. 3, p. 167

The Gaon and Tzaddik R' Shmuel Lichtenstein Shlita told me that he heard from his father-in-law, the Gaon and Tzaddik of Krasna *zt"l*, that once a man sick with lung disease (*lungen entzundung*) came to the holy Rebbe R' Hersh of Rimanov *zt"l*. The Rebbe told him to travel to the Gaon R' Shmuel Shmelke of Selish *zt"l*. The sick man traveled from Rimanov. On his way, he passed through the city of Mischkolcz and lodged at the house of a certain man. He asked him to let him lie on the oven (because he did not want to disturb the household members with his coughing).
The next day, the innkeeper asked him where his face was set. He answered that he was traveling to Selish and told him that he was sick with lung disease and that Rebbe R' Hersh of Rimanov had sent him to the Gaon R' Shmuel Shmelke *zt"l*. The innkeeper wondered greatly at this, that the Rebbe of Rimanov sent him to Selish. He asked him that when he returned from Selish, he should pass through his city and tell him what happened to him in Selish.
When the sick man told the Gaon R' Shmuel Shmelke that Rebbe R' Hersh had sent him to him, the Rav of Selish said: "How is it in my power to help you, and what does Rebbe R' Hersh want from me? But nevertheless, since you have arrived here, be present at the lesson I will deliver in the Yeshiva." The man did so. The Gaon delivered the lesson in the way of *Pilpul*, as is known, and resolved a contradiction in Tosafos with a specific *Chiddush*.
After he finished the lesson, he said: "I hereby give the merit from the answer to the Tosafos to *Ploni* the man who needs salvation." [Yiddish: "Dem zchus fun dem teretz oif Tosafos geb ich avek far dem Yid vus darf a yeshuah"]. Immediately when he left there, the man was healed from his illness. On his way back to his home, he passed through Mischkolcz again and told the innkeeper that he had been healed in Selish.
Source: HaRav HaGaon R' Yisrael Chaim Ashri Shlita, "Siach Zekeinim" (Brooklyn 5767), Vol. 6, p. 178

The aforementioned also told me that he heard from his father-in-law, the Gaon and Tzaddik of Krasna *zt"l*, that the Gaon R' Shmuel Shmelke of Selish *zt"l* was initially a Rav in the city of Balkany. The people of the city were destitute paupers, and close to the Rav's apartment was a cow shed. During the winter days, which were very cold, he would study in his bed under covers. Since he did not have enough for his livelihood to afford tallow candles, he would study by the light of a sulfur candle, which had a very bad smell. Thus, he studied Torah amidst hardship.
Source: HaRav HaGaon R' Yisrael Chaim Ashri Shlita, "Siach Zekeinim" (Brooklyn 5767), Vol. 6, p. 178

The Gaon and Tzaddik Rabbi Eliezer Dovid Friedman Shlita told: I heard from the Gaon and Tzaddik of Krasna *zt"l*, who was known and famous in the world, that by the sermon of the Gaon and Tzaddik R' Shmuel Shmelke of Selish *zt"l* during *Selichos*, before the refrain "Shema Koleinu," the awakening was so great that it was impossible to restrain oneself from weeping.
There was a certain Chassid, named R' Yitzchak Simcha, who was traveling for Rosh Hashanah to his Rebbes (from Ziditshov). He was forced to stop in Selish for *Selichos*, he and his friend. Since they heard that the Gaon and Tzaddik, author of "Tzror HaChaim" of Selish, speaks before the saying of "Shema Koleinu" and everyone weeps, they did not believe this. They resolved to strengthen themselves together and restrain themselves from weeping.
And so they did. The two of them stood together in one place in the Beis Medrash. The Gaon and Tzaddik began his sermon, and immediately the congregation began to weep. They strengthened themselves together and restrained themselves from weeping until suddenly they burst into very great weeping. It was very difficult to calm them, for their weeping was harder than the rest of the congregants there, because they had restrained themselves beforehand.
Source: HaRav HaChassid R' Chaim Shmuel Glickman Shlita, "Mipihem U'Mipi Ksavam" (Kiryas Joel 5768), Vol. 2, p. 85

The Gaon and Tzaddik Rabbi Yonasan Binyamin HaKohen, Dayan of the holy community of Selish *zt"l*, brought in his book 'Nefesh Yonasan' (Parashas Devarim) a story that happened in the Beis Din of the holy Rebbe Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke, Av Beis Din of Selish *zy"a*, author of 'Tzror HaChaim'. Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke used to make many compromises for litigants who came before him.
Once, two litigants came before him. One claimed that his friend borrowed a certain sum of money from him, and the other denied it, claiming that such things never happened. Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke suggested as a compromise that the defendant pay half the sum. When one of the judges heard the verdict, he argued insolently to Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke that this was certainly a false judgment. For logically, if he borrowed from him, he is obligated to pay everything, and if not, he is exempt from everything—so why should he pay half?
Rabbi Shmuel Shmelke replied to him that behold it is written: **אלקים נצב בעדת אל** - **"G-d stands in the congregation of G-d"** (Psalms 82:1). This means that the Holy One, Blessed be He, stands over the judges and checks that a verdict that is not correct, Heaven forbid, does not issue from their hands. Even though in the eyes of man the verdict seems like a lie, nevertheless, in the depth of the law, it is truth and correct. For sometimes the defendant owed the plaintiff money from a previous incarnation (*Gilgul*), and now he came to return it to him (and see there where he explains several verses in Parashas Devarim according to this, regarding Moses our Teacher rebuking the Children of Israel).
Source: HaGaon HaChassid Rabbi Eliezer Dovid Friedman Shlita, "Mipi Sefarim VeSofrim" (Bnei Brak 5772), Avot Vol. 1, p. 138

**Biography**
He was born in the year 5646 (1886) in Pish-tian, Slovakia, to his father Rabbi Yosef Moshe HaLevi Ungar, Av Beis Din of Pish-tian. Already in his years of infancy, Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar excelled in rare spiritual qualities.
In the days of his youth, he studied with great diligence in the Yeshiva of R' Noach Baruch Fischer in Prešov, and afterward in the Yeshiva in Unsdorf under the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Rosenberg *zt"l*.
He entered into the covenant of marriage with the Rebbetzin Mrs. Miriam Leah, the daughter of his teacher and uncle, Rav Noach Baruch Fischer, the Rav of Prešov.
The young prodigy Rabbi Shmuel Dovid had just turned twenty-one when he was chosen to be the Rav of the small community of Krompach in Slovakia.
After he completed five years of his tenure in the rabbinate of Krompach, the rabbinical seat in the community of Tirnau became vacant. This was an ancient community and the city of Rabbi Eizik, author of the "Minhagim." For fifteen years, Rabbi Shmuel Dovid sat in Tirnau and led this holy community.
In the year 5691 (1931), when the community of Nitra was orphaned of its Rav, the famous Gaon Rabbi Avraham Aharon Katz, they brought a letter of appointment to Rabbi Shmuel Dovid, urging him to move to them while promising to support his Yeshiva at their expense and even to expand its boundaries.
The move of Rabbi Shmuel Dovid HaLevi Ungar to Nitra gave him new wings. He expanded the scope of his activities, harnessed himself more to the yoke of public problems, expanded his actions in the field of spreading Torah, and his fame went far and wide as one of the leaders of the generation.
The main aspiration of his soul was invested in the holy Yeshiva he led. It was the joy of his life, and for it, he gave the essence of his vitality. A stream of students flowed to the Yeshiva in Nitra, from near and far, growing until the city became a metropolis of Torah.
He was great in educating the youth for Torah, and during the thirty-nine years he engaged in spreading Torah, he established a generation of thousands of Bnei Torah whose fear of Heaven preceded their wisdom.
In those terrible years of the Holocaust, Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar rose to become one of the unknown leaders in self-sacrifice for the salvation of Israel and the preservation of the ember of faith.
After the gates of the Yeshiva were locked, Rabbi Shmuel Dovid succeeded, accompanied by his son, Rabbi Shalom Moshe (today, 5736, Rav of Kiryat Yeshivas Nitra in Mount Kisco), in escaping the trap the oppressors had set for him at the last moment. He hid together with his son and also his student, Rav Meir Eisler, in the Zobor mountains and forests adjacent to Nitra, which were then under the rule of the Slovak partisans, while moving from place to place in utter destitution.
The last half-year of the life of the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar was wondrous, wrapped in majesty and heroism, and a whole book could be written about it. These were days of dedication and elevation of the soul to the highest degree.
He passed away on the 9th of Adar, 5705 (1945), a few weeks before the end of World War II. He returned his soul to the Above in the forest where he was hiding from the hands of the Nazi murderers. His grave was dug temporarily in the forest, and after the end of the war, his remains were transferred to Pish-tian, where they were interred next to the grave of his ancestors.
Source: "Rashei Golas Ariel" (Brooklyn 5736), Vol. 1, pp. 490-513

It is told that when my grandfather from Nitra was a small child of about four years old, the holy Rebbe R' Yehoshua'le of Belz *zy"a* saw him standing and praying. He praised his prayer greatly and said that a great man would grow from him.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Sanz-Klausenburg Shlita, "Rishuma D'Kedusha", Vayera 5762, p. 5

It happened once on the first night of the festival of Sukkos that it rained, and according to Halacha, one is exempt from sleeping in the Sukkah when it rains. My master, my father, made Kiddush and ate in the Sukkah, but he did not go into the house to sleep. Instead, all night long, he stood near the Sukkah, perhaps the rain would stop falling and allow him to sleep for a short time. Only towards morning did the rain stop... He was very happy and said: "The Eternal One has granted in the multitude of His kindnesses that one could sit in the Sukkah, eat in the Sukkah, and also sleep in the Sukkah."
Source: From the notes of HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Shalom Moshe Ungar zt"l, Ga'avad of Nitra, "BeChatzrot HaChaim", Adar 5763, p. 80

I meet many times with Nitra students. When I tell them that I am named after my grandfather, the Nitra Rav, they immediately fill with longing: "Ha! You are a grandson of the Nitra Rav? I learned by Zeide!" I have already met many Jews like this, and one almost never sees such a thing. After all, there were many great Torah disseminators before the war, but that students should speak of their Rebbe with such love and connection, with tears in their eyes—one does not see this. I have already seen this with dozens of his students, that immediately when they begin to speak of their Rebbe, the "Nitra Rav," of his pure prayers, and of his tremendous weeping like a son pleading before his father, of his fierce love for every single student—such a type of attachment, such a type of love from students—certainly, "as water reflects the face to the face," so indeed he granted great love to every student. Even after sixty and seventy years, this love is still engraved in their hearts...
My master, my father, would always praise the fact that the Yeshiva in Nitra remained the last place of Torah in all of Europe. My master, my father, used to say about the Nitra Rav: "He returned the key of Torah in Europe to the Holy One, Blessed be He." Since there was no longer any place of Torah to be found in all of Europe, he had the merit that until the very last minute, they let him continue with his Yeshiva [for in the last period, they literally let him continue his Yeshiva].
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Sanz-Klausenburg Shlita, "Rishuma D'Kedusha", Vayera 5763, p. 7

Once, one of the great Rabbis came to visit his son who was studying in Nitra. He went to pray early, and afterward came to the Beis Medrash. My master, my father, of blessed memory, was holding at "Ahavah Rabbah." Is it not meant to be heard by the ear? Our soul pined for how he said "Ahavah Rabbah" for twenty minutes with tremendous weeping. The aforementioned Rav asked: "What is different today from other days that I hear our Rebbe crying so much?" To his wonder, they answered him that every day he conducts such a prayer with such weeping...
Source: His son, HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Shalom Moshe Ungar zt"l, Av Beis Din of Nitra, "Rishuma D'Kedusha", Vayera 5763, p. 6

My father-in-law (HaGaon Rabbi Shmuel Unsdorfer) *zt"l* was a disciple of the holy elder [HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar of Nitra *zt"l*]. He told me once that when he first arrived to him, it was after the holiday of Pesach. He stood then to pray the Maariv prayer, and after the Shemoneh Esrei prayer, he read the Counting of the Omer, of course with tremendous service as was his way. My father-in-law told me that not a single Counting passed over him that he counted without remembering *that* Counting he heard from him, which was with such great enthusiasm and with flames of fire.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Sanz Shlita in his holy talk - 9 Adar 5769, "Betzila D'Mehemnuta", Tetzaveh 5769, p. 17

When I asked my teacher and master, HaGaon Rabbi Shmuel Wosner Shlita (in the month of Sivan 5766), to give me an approbation for the biography book of the Gaon HaTzaddik, author of "Neos Deshe" of Nitra *zt"l*, he told me that he still remembers when he entered to study under him in the year 5687 (1927) in Tirnau. He was with him for the first time during the Maariv prayer on a simple weekday, and he was very impressed by his service of prayer, which was literally like the Maariv prayer of the night of "Kol Nidrei." To this day, he is unable to forget this impression.
He also told me that the "Neos Deshe" passed away while in exile in the forests in Banská Bystrica and was buried there, as is known. After the war, when they wanted to evacuate him, there was a discussion whether to evacuate him to the Holy Land (after they saw the terrible destruction in the state of Slovakia) or to evacuate him to the graves of his ancestors in Pish-tian. My teacher and master, HaGaon Rabbi Wosner, was already in the Holy Land then, and they wrote to him to ask about this. The letter is still kept in his hand and lies in his archives. He ruled that since his father lies in Pish-tian and it is a place that is not so far away, it is better to evacuate him there. Afterward, they asked this question before HaGaon Rabbi Yosef Tzvi Dushinsky, the Ga'avad of the Holy City (Jerusalem) *t"v*, and he also ruled so.
He also told that when he traveled to the Holy Land before the war, his Rebbe from Tirnau wrote to him that he should try to be in the vicinity of his friend (of HaGaon Rabbi Shmuel Dovid), namely the Gaon Maharitz Dushinsky, and through this, he merited extra closeness from the Gaon Maharitz.
Source: HaRah"g R' Shimon Hirshler Shlita, "Gishmei Bracha" (London 5771), p. 692

In the city of Nitra, decades ago, young men from several countries in Europe, and even from the USA, studied in the Yeshiva. Many were drawn and came to be educated in Nitra, for our great Rebbe, the Av Beis Din of Nitra *zt"l*, educated and guided his students on how to pray and how to conduct themselves as Kosher, G-d-fearing Jews.
They tell that in a certain city in Hungary, the town Rav once approached a young married man (*Avreich*) and asked him: "Are you a Nitra student?" The *Avreich* replied: "Yes, I am a Nitra student, but it is a wonder in my eyes—how did the honorable Rav know this?" The Rav replied: "I saw the manner of your prayer, and I understood from this that you studied in Nitra, for this is what they taught in Nitra..."

Once I merited to walk with him, for Maran *zt"l* showed me a little closeness because I was already older. The conversation turned to the time of prayer, early or late. He told that he asked a certain young man when he arrived today for prayer. He answered that he came early and arrived at *Pesukei D'Zimra*. Maran *zt"l* said about this: "Is this called early? I am not so *Frum* (pious), yet once I came to prayer in the middle of *Birkas HaShachar*, and for the entire day, I could not find peace of mind over this."
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yonah Forst z"l, "Divrei Yonah" (Monsey 5762), Vol. 1, p. 83, 15a [ibid p. 348, 15a]

The Rabbi and Gaon R' Shmuel Dovid Ungar *z"l* was the son of the Rabbi and Gaon R' Yosef Moshe Ungar *z"l*, Rav in the town of Pish-tian, author of the Sefer "Sifsei Yosef," and son-in-law of the Gaon Rabbi Baruch Fischer *z"l*, Rav of Prešov. The members of his community loved the Gaon R' Shmuel Dovid for his lofty qualities, to such an extent that they did not want to "give him up." When he was about to move from Tirnau to Nitra, a dispute broke out to the heart of the heavens between the two communities, until a Beis Din of Rabbis decided in favor of Nitra.
Nitra was a distinctly Ashkenazic community, and Rabbi Ungar also conducted himself according to the customs of the *Misnagdim* of Oberland (Upper Hungary). However, among the students of his Yeshiva, there were groups of young men who had an inclination toward Chassidism. Once, a portion of the students surprised their Rebbe and bought him a "Streimel" as "Mishloach Manos" for Purim. The Rav decided to wear the "Streimel" on Shabbos and Holidays only at home, but not in public... With the help of his community members, he succeeded in building a gigantic Beis Medrash for his Yeshiva, which contained about three hundred students. Among his students, who admired him, stories and legends circulated about his virtues and his traits in Torah and service of G-d.
Source: HaRah"g R' Asher Anshel Yehuda Miller z"l, "Olamo Shel Abba" (Jerusalem 5744), p. 200

He [=his father-in-law, the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Alexander Unsdorfer *zt"l*] told me a story that happened with the Gaon Rabbi Michoel Dov Weissmandl *zt"l*. He was a tremendous prodigy (*Illui*) and a sharp mind, as is known. They wanted to crown him with the crown of the rabbinate in a certain city. He traveled to this city for Shabbos to deliver the customary trial sermon. He arrived there only late Friday night. Due to exhaustion, he went to rest. On Friday, the heads of the community and the activists came to speak with him, and thus the entire day passed. He imagined that on Friday night (Shabbos Kodesh), he would prepare the sermon to say the next day.
In the end, on Friday night, he was very tired and did not have the strength to prepare. He left it for the next day before the prayer. However, in the end, it did not work out, and he had no time at all to prepare the sermon. He said the sermon before the Reading of the Torah with sharpness, as was his way. They came to tell his father-in-law, the holy Gaon (Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar) of Nitra *ztzuk"l*, that the sermon was wondrous, and all the listeners enjoyed it, etc.
Afterward, when he returned to his father-in-law, his father-in-law expressed wonder hearing about his wondrous sermon. He told his father-in-law the truth, that he had miracles with the sermon, for he had no time to prepare himself. His father-in-law said to him in anger: "What? How does one presume to speak before a congregation before preparing himself beforehand..."
So I heard from my father-in-law *zt"l*, that Rabbi Michoel Ber *zt"l* himself told him. The truth is that there is a source for this in the Midrash (Shemos Rabbah 40:1) on the verse "He prepared it and also searched it" (**הכינה וגם חקרה**) - see there at length.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Sanz Shlita, "Betzila D'Mehemnuta", Emor 5762, p. 8

Our eyes saw his tremendous toil in the Holy Torah (of the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar of Nitra *zt"l*). It will be told to the generation that although he taught in public with dozens of students for years, nevertheless, he never went to teach in public—even the study of Chumash Rashi—without studying the material for himself beforehand. He would weigh what to say in public and what not to say.
I remember that once he studied the *Sugya* (topic) being learned for himself, together with some students, and I was also among them. During his study, wonderful *Chiddushim* (insights) occurred to him. Afterward, I was there when he taught the *Sugya* to the householders (*Baalebatim*), and he refrained from mentioning even a trace of these wonderful *Chiddushim*, because he understood that this was not relevant to his study with the householders.
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yonah Forst z"l, "Divrei Yonah" (Monsey 5762), Vol. 1, p. 84, 15a

I heard from the distinct students of my father-in-law (of Nitra) *zt"l*, and from truthful narrators who knew him closely: My father-in-law *zt"l* was of the disciples of Aaron—loving peace and pursuing peace, loving people and bringing them close to Torah. To bring close and not to distance, Heaven forbid.
Important students told me regarding his conduct in managing the large Yeshiva, that he did not allow distancing any student from within the walls of the Beis Medrash. He would say: "What profit is there if we distance him from the tent of Torah? For then, Heaven forbid, he will deteriorate from bad to worse. Rather, he should be brought close to Torah, and the light within it will return him to the good." I brought proof then to his words from our Rabbis of the early generations.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Sanz-Klausenburg Ztzuk"l, "Yisrael Saba", Issue 42 ["BeChatzrot HaChaim", Adar 5763, p. 81]

The Rabbi and Chassid R' Simcha Bunim Gewirtz *ny"i* told me: When I studied in Tirnau under the Gaon R' Shmuel Dovid of Nitra *zt"l*, it happened once that a certain student spoke against the holy Rebbe, author of "Minchas Elazar" of Munkacs *zt"l*. The Gaon R' Shmuel Dovid heard what he said, jumped from his place, and said to him with a rebuke: "You are speaking against the anointed of G-d! Go immediately to your home! I do not need you!" [Yiddish: "Du redst oif Meshichei Hashem, fahr shoin aheim! Ich ken dich da nisht broichen" - You speak against G-d's anointed, go home already! I can't use you here].
The young man said to him: "I will travel in the middle of the term?" The Gaon of Nitra said to him: "I cannot help you at all. You are forced to travel from here. You are speaking against the anointed of G-d and the Tzaddikim of the generation." In the end, he compromised that he would leave the Yeshiva for only eight days.
Source: HaRah"g R' Yisrael Chaim Ashri Shlita, "Siach Zekeinim" (Brooklyn 5762), Vol. 4, p. 347

Once I heard that the holy Rebbe of Munkacs arrived in the city of Pest. I traveled to him. When I entered, he gave me "Shalom." He recognized me, that I had been by him two weeks prior. He asked me: "Where do you study?" I did not want to answer that I studied under the Gaon of Nitra, who was the vice-president of the Agudah. He asked me again: "Nu, tell me where you study." I answered that I study in Tirnau. He said to me: "Er iz a'in ehrlicher Yid, megst lernen bei im" (He is an honest/upright Jew; you may study with him).
Source: HaRah"g R' Yisrael Chaim Ashri Shlita, "Siach Zekeinim" (Brooklyn 5762), Vol. 4, p. 347

I know a story from our Rebbe (the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar of Nitra) *zt"l*. At the time I studied there in the Yeshiva, there was a certain *Avreich* (young married man) who lived in the neighborhood of the Yeshiva, from the capital city of Vienna, who would occasionally enter the Beis Medrash and study among the students. After a few weeks passed, rumors were heard about him regarding severe desecration of Shabbos, Heaven forbid.
The students who were called by the name "Gabba'im of the Yeshiva" plotted advice on what to do, for our Rebbe *zt"l* was not at home then, as he had traveled out of the city. I was counted among the Gabba'im. It was simple for us to judge the *Avreich* to expel him from the walls of the Beis Medrash, and the verdict had already issued from us.
In the meantime, our Rebbe *zt"l* returned. It became known to him what had happened, and he called us to his home, the abode of holiness. We told him with clear testimony of the deed he had done, Heaven forbid, and therefore it was simple that we needed to reject him with both hands.
To this, our holy Rebbe *zt"l* answered us with great strictness in this language: "Who gave you permission to judge capital cases?" Behold, a great danger hovers over him that he will be distanced from the walls of the Yeshiva, and who knows what will be with him in the end? He was very, very angry and said in his holy humility: "Behold, as long as he enters the Beis Medrash occasionally, there is still hope that he will return and contemplate that there is childishness in him."
And there were several other reasons that this was not for you to judge at all, and Heaven forbid to reject him; on the contrary, one must speak to his heart. He added and said [which I heard several times from his mouth]: Our Sages said, "If this repulsive one (the *Yetzer Hara*) meets you, drag him to the Beis Medrash." He said: What does the *Yetzer Hara* care about the Beis Medrash? Rather, the *Yetzer Hara* in the Beis Medrash is not like the *Yetzer Hara* in the streets. As long as the *Yetzer Hara* is in the Beis Medrash, there is hope that the light within it—the light of Torah that shines in the Beis Medrash—[will reform him]. Even though the *Yetzer Hara* still pursues there, ultimately, if he is stone, he will melt. Therefore, we must search for all ways to bring him back in complete repentance. My hope is that in this way, we will succeed more than by distancing him and pushing him completely from under the wings of the Shechinah, Heaven forbid. (HaGaon HaTzaddik R' Shmuel Alexander Unsdorfer *zt"l*, Nesiv Nitra, Issue 2).
Source: "BeChatzrot HaChaim", Adar 5763, p. 81

Once, the holy elder, the Rav of Nitra *zt"l*, stayed in Vienna, the capital, for a Shabbos gathering for the students of the Nitra Yeshiva. At 4:00 PM on Shabbos afternoon, the Rav of Nitra was designated to deliver his speech. When the appointed hour arrived, the Rav of Nitra did not arrive. After twenty minutes passed, they understood that some incident had occurred, since my grandfather *zt"l* was very punctual. Several students went out to search until they reached a certain park, where they found him standing.
The students approached him to say that the entire audience was waiting for him and asked why he was delaying in coming. The Gaon *zt"l* showed them a certain bag lying on the ground and said that he was obligated to stay there to guard this until the end of Shabbos. He did not want to go with them until one of them obligated himself to stand there until Motzaei Shabbos.
To explain the matter, he told them that he had gone out for a walk on Shabbos afternoon, and a Jewish woman passed by with a bag in her hand. When she saw the form of a Jew with a beard, she said to him: "Shalom, Herr Rabbiner." Upon seeing this, he said to her: "Do you not know that the Sabbath of Israel forbids walking with a bag on Shabbos?" She answered and said that she did not know, but now she would go home to put it down. He told her that this was also forbidden and that she was obligated to leave it here. When she said she feared it would be stolen, he answered that he would guard it until Motzaei Shabbos.
From this, one sees his greatness—that he was willing to forgo the sermon and the *Seudah Shlishis* together with his students because he obligated himself to the woman to guard her belongings.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Sanz Shlita in his holy talk - 26 Nissan 5769, "Betzila D'Mehemnuta", Tazria-Metzora 5769, p. 19

My in-law, the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel (Unsdorfer) *zt"l*, told me that once the "Binyan Dovid" delivered a sermon in the Yeshiva of Nitra. In the midst of his words, he said that he was always amazed: How does it arise in the hand of the Rav of Nitra to establish outstanding students, filled with fear of Heaven? He thought to himself that presumably, he tells them many ethical talks (*Mussar*) and the like. However, now it became known that the Rav of Nitra is like a furnace standing at the edge of the Beis Medrash. Through putting many logs of wood into it, it influences warmth throughout the entire Beis Medrash. So too, the Rav of Nitra brings so much fear of Heaven into his own midst, and automatically, this influences everyone.
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yekusiel Yehuda Meisels Shlita, Av Beis Din of Sea Gate, "Betzila D'Mehemnuta", Ki Tisa 5771, p. 18

(HaRav HaChassid R' Yedidya Look *z"l*) told me that he studied in the Yeshiva under the holy elder of Nitra *zy"a*. At that time, about two hundred and fifty students studied in the Yeshiva. It was the way of the holy elder to test all the students every Friday. Once, for the purpose of the exam, he was awake all Thursday night in order to study. On Friday night (Shabbos Kodesh), he was tired and went to sleep. He did not go to the Pure Table (*Tish*) conducted by the Gaon of Nitra *zy"a*. He thought to himself that once, he was permitted to miss the *Tish*.
The next day, in the morning, when he passed by to say "Gut Shabbos," the holy elder said to him: "If I knew in which place you were conducting a *Tish*, I would have come to you..."
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Sanz Shlita, "Betzila D'Mehemnuta", Metzora 5763, p. 7

Once, a certain Rav and great Tzaddik, who was a disciple of the Rav of Unsdorf, came to Nitra. My master, my father, of blessed memory, conducted *Tikkun Chatzos* (Midnight Lamentation) with the students at midday during the three weeks [between the 17th of Tammuz and the 9th of Av]. He (the aforementioned Rav) said that it looked literally as if a telegram had just arrived now that the Beis HaMikdash had been destroyed...
Source: His son, HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Shalom Moshe Ungar zt"l, Av Beis Din of Nitra, "Rishuma D'Kedusha", Vayera 5763, p. 6

Regarding monetary matters, they saw wonders in him (in the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar *zt"l*). Even though, as the *Mara D'Asra* (local authority) in a large city, he had many burdens upon him, nevertheless, he supervised with a watchful eye every small detail of the several hundred students, and regarding the law of every penny as if it were a hundred.
I remember that once it became known to him that one of the Gabba'im of the "Food Society"—students appointed then to supervise food matters, who received no wage for this but did it as a matter of honor and responsibility—had neglected a sack of carrots [Yiddish: *mehren*] once, leaving it in an unguarded place until they spoiled. Maran *zt"l* said that he had the status of a negligent guardian (*Poshia*) and needed to pay. That is how exacting he was with every detail.
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yonah Forst z"l, "Divrei Yonah" (Monsey 5762), Vol. 1, p. 84, 15b

My father-in-law, the Gaon (Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar of Nitra) *zt"l*, had a unique merit in its kind: he merited to lead the famous Nitra Yeshiva even at such a late time when the lights of Torah had already been extinguished in all the Torah centers of Europe due to the Holocaust brought by the oppressor, may his name be blotted out, upon all the holy communities on that continent. My father-in-law *zt"l* was the last one still leading a Yeshiva in the year 5705 (1945) with literal self-sacrifice. This was the entire goal of his life: only to teach Torah and fear of Heaven to the young men of Israel.
As I heard from an important Jew who lived in Vienna before the war: Once, when my father-in-law *zt"l* visited him in Vienna, he complained to him about the difficult financial situation of the Yeshiva in Nitra. The interlocutor suggested to him that if he would spend Shabbos in Vienna, he promised him a very large income for the benefit of the Yeshiva.
My father-in-law *zt"l* replied that it was impossible for him to accept his offer because on Thursday evening he was compelled to be back to teach a lesson in Chumash and Rashi to the Yeshiva students. The aforementioned Jew replied in astonishment: "But if the money is so necessary for the benefit of the Yeshiva, then forgo one lesson!" To this, my father-in-law *zt"l* replied: "Is it not for the sake of studying with the students that I am interested in the money for the Yeshiva? If I cancel a lesson and do not teach, why do I need the money at all?"
This incident well describes his wondrous dedication to teaching Torah and fear of Heaven with the Yeshiva students.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Sanz-Klausenburg Ztzuk"l, "Nesiv Nitra", Tevet 5724, p. 7

I remember being by Maran (the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar) *zt"l* in Nitra when the days of wrath began, Heaven forbid. Every single day, more people were missing, and everyone knew they were being taken to death, Heaven forbid. Despite this, Maran *zt"l* began to teach us difficult topics in the laws of *Hatmanah* (insulating food on Shabbos). If students did not come on time, he would demand and require it, and he would also test the students with all his might.
At the time, I wondered about this: In such turbulent times, what is he demanding from the students with such firmness? But Maran *zt"l* knew the truth—that specifically in such a time of wrath, we have nothing to lean on and it is impossible to strengthen ourselves to stand before the waves of troubles, Heaven forbid, except through absolute grasping of the Torah.
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yonah Forst z"l, "Divrei Yonah" (Monsey 5762), Vol. 1, p. 111, 15b

Our grandfather, the holy Rebbe Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar of Nitra *zy"a*, was here in the Land of Israel for a visit in the year 5695 (1935). Since he returned, he would speak with longing and affection about the Land of Israel. From then on, they would send him an Esrog from the Land of Israel, and he cherished it very much.
I heard from my father (the Gaon Rabbi Shalom Moshe Ungar of Nitra) *zt"l* that back then, they brought him a white *Chalat* (robe) from the clothing of the Land of Israel. On Rosh Hashanah, he would wear it under his *Kittel*. Every item from the Land of Israel had great importance to him.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Nitra Shlita in conversation with C.K. Maran Admor M'Sanz Shlita, 20 Tevet 5767, "Betzila D'Mehemnuta", Va'era 5767, p. 3

In his Aggadic writings included in the fifth part of his book "Devar Yehoshua," the Gaon Rabbi Yehoshua Mendel Ehrenberg *zt"l* mentions favorably the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar *zt"l* of Nitra, as one through whose efforts thousands of Jews were saved: "And he merited to save even more than a thousand souls from Poland, and I too, the lowly one, am among them with my household, may they live."
Source: Rabbi Aharon Sorosky Shlita, "Marbitzei Torah MeOlam HaChassidut" (Bnei Brak 5749), Vol. 8, p. 164

Behold, I merited to know many greats of Israel when I was in Poland, and afterward in Vienna, and also by the *Knessiah Gedolah*. However, afterward, when I arrived at Maran (the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar) *zt"l* in Nitra, I was very impressed to see that in all his movements and the order of his life, he was literally a prepared table (*Shulchan Aruch*). Many matters regarding which I had learned the Halacha inside [the books], I realized afterward upon seeing Maran *zt"l* that everything was literally measured by the line of Halacha.
I remember once a question arose on Pesach—it was on the seventh or last day of Pesach—and Maran *zt"l* turned white as the lime of the Temple out of fear of a suspicion of something *Chametz*. I can tell you that afterward, I was in the concentration camps, and I saw several times the trembling of people facing death, Heaven forbid. But it was not like that trembling I saw then by Maran *zt"l* out of suspicion of something *Chametz*.
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yonah Forst z"l, "Divrei Yonah" (Monsey 5762), Vol. 1, p. 82, 15b

In the year 5702 (1942), before Pesach, the terrible decree was issued in the state of Slovakia by the cursed wicked ones to kidnap the virgins of Israel from the age of sixteen and up and transport them to a land of decree, to an unknown place. To this day, it is not known what was done with thousands of pure souls of Israel that they transported there—may G-d avenge our vengeance from them speedily.
There was great panic then in the camp of Israel. I know a story of one man who wanted to save his young daughters so they would not fall into the evil trap. The aforementioned attempted to cross the border with his daughters. It was then *Chol HaMoed* Pesach, and he promised his wife that he would send a telegraph message from across the border that he and the children had arrived safely at their desired destination. The mother sat in her house with longing eyes, watching for the time the pleasant news would come that they had crossed the border in peace and arrived at a safe place.
But the story was that they caught the father with his daughters even before they crossed the border. They led them to the city near the border and put them in prison. They sat there in the prison house all of *Chol HaMoed* and also the last days of Pesach. They were in great danger of being sent immediately to the land of decree, for such was the law with them regarding punishment for escape: whoever makes an escape and is caught is sent to the land of decree in an even more cruel manner than the rest of those sent there.
In the meantime, the matter became known to his wife and the mother of the girls. We can estimate the bitter feeling that seized their mother. The joy of the escape turned into grief, and the Holiday turned into mourning, Heaven preserve us, over her husband and her daughters. She sat weeping throughout the Holiday without respite. The world literally went dark for her, and there is no describing in words her sad situation from the hour the event became known to her regarding her husband and daughters, for she knew what awaited them.
However, remember for good that man, the Gaon and Tzaddik, the servant of G-d with literal self-sacrifice—especially in that time of distress when he cast his soul aside in danger to himself—namely, the Chassidic Gaon, our teacher R' Shmuel Dovid Ungar Shlita [ztzuk"l], Av Beis Din of Nitra. He did not rest and was not quiet until he redeemed those three captives with much money. They went out to freedom and liberty and were able to return to their homes in peace without any stumbling block.
This was on the last day of Pesach. They informed of this immediately by telephone message to the hard-spirited woman, that her husband and daughters had gone out to freedom. The next day, *Isru Chag*, they would return to their home in peace without stumbling. There is no need to tell of the effect this good news had on the soul of that wretched woman—that her husband and daughters had escaped from the teeth of the lions in peace.
From that moment, she waited with longing eyes for the time of the return of the father with the daughters to her home. The next day, she could not summon the strength to wait for them in her house; she sat only at the entrance of the courtyard, and with watching eyes, she waited for the moment of their arrival. The moment they came and she saw them, a voice burst forth in her weeping, pouring out all the emotion of her heart to a wondrous degree. She could not utter any words of thanks to the Holy One, Blessed be He, for the magnitude of the miracle that was done for her and them, due to the overflow of feelings in her heart.
Anyone who did not see the moment of the meeting, when a mother met and saw again her daughters after their return from such terrible captivity, and the weeping of the mother at the hour she saw the daughters return to their border, and the joy of the mother with the children—a joy at that hour—has never seen a feeling of joy in his days. Therefore, what I knew from the aforementioned event that happened in our days, so I imagine and describe before myself the joy of our Mother, the Land of Israel, at the hour when we all return to her bosom after such terrible captivity that has passed over us in these times. And regarding this wondrous joy that the Mother will rejoice with the children, Heaven preserve us, the Land of Israel with us and we with her...
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Yissachar Shlita Teichtal Hy"d, "Eim HaBanim Semeichah" (Budapest 5703), p. 36

The Rabbi R' Shlomo Pollack, who studied in the Yeshiva of the Gaon of Nitra during the war, told me: In those days when the wicked ones sent the Jews of the city of Nitra to the camps, the Nitra Rav *zt"l* was weeping incessantly over the people of his community who were sent to the unknown. He did not have the strength to speak. Therefore, he asked his son-in-law, HaGaon R' Michoel Ber Weissmandl *zt"l*, to teach the lesson in *Pirkei Avos* in his place, for he had no strength to speak. And so he did.
At the time HaGaon R' Michoel Ber lectured on the study of the chapter, he began to cry out toward Heaven: "Master of the World! Why do You do this to Your servants? Terrible decrees and slaughters like these..." and other expressions like this.
When they told the Gaon of Nitra the words of his son-in-law, he said: "Had I known that he would say so, I would not have sent him to say the lesson in my place. Rather, I would have exerted myself and studied on my own. For when one speaks before the public, one does not give *Mussar* (rebuke) to the Holy One, Blessed be He; rather, one must awaken the congregation to strengthen themselves in repentance."
Source: HaRah"g R' Shimon Hirshler Shlita, "Gishmei Bracha" (London 5771), p. 692

I remember a terrible matter that occurred during the time of the Destruction (*Churban*), Heaven preserve us, while we were still in Nitra. Indeed, every day they were taking people, and everyone knew they were going to death, Heaven preserve us. Suddenly, it became known that there was a piece of advice: that through taking a document from the priest stating they had converted, Heaven preserve us, they could be saved from killing. A great confusion of the mind was created by this, for nothing was required for this—they did not need, Heaven forbid, to go to the church or change anything. It was merely an external matter of taking a document from the priest, Heaven preserve us, and then "no more from my hands" [meaning, no further persecution], and through this, they could remain alive with their whole family.
Maran of Nitra *zt"l* called the entire congregation to the Beis Medrash and preached before them. Thus he said and explained to them: "Behold, we are in a difficult time where they take everything from us. From moment to moment, they were taking with a strong hand from the Jew all his possessions, his property, his house, and everything he had. They could do nothing. However, one thing remains for us that is impossible to take from us, and that is the pure faith in the Blessed Hashem. Now, due to our many sins, the decree has gone out to take even this from us, through their taking the document from the priest in order to remain alive.
