Therefore, one must awaken and strengthen oneself that *this* is what we were commanded in the Torah: 'And with all your soul'—even if he takes your soul. Therefore, come now, let us accept the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven completely (*b'poel*), to be ready for self-sacrifice in practice and not to seek salvation through such a document."
We read together "Shema Yisrael" to accept upon ourselves the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven in practice. After the sermon of our Rebbe *zt"l*, the entire people read together aloud the first verse of the Reading of the Shema, and the scene was one of trembling before G-d.
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yonah Forst z"l, "Divrei Yonah" (Monsey 5762), Vol. 1, p. 191, 15b

My grandfather, the Gaon of Nitra *zt"l*, during the years of wrath in World War II, was forced to flee and hide in the forests. It was then the winter season when a great cold prevailed outside. Since he had left his home in the month of Elul before the Holiday, he was dressed thinly on his body. Thus he wore [these clothes] until his passing in the coming month of Adar. In the fierce cold, there was a great danger to walk outside virtually naked and lacking everything.
Nevertheless, since he did not have special clothes in his hand to change for Shabbos, he acted according to the words of the Gemara (Shabbos 113b): "One who does not have special clothes for Shabbos should let his clothes hang down" by way of importance. He surrendered his soul [to the cold], for on weekdays he would lift the upper garment and fold it up, and for the honor of the Holy Shabbos, he rolled the clothes down. This is a great lesson: self-sacrifice at such a time for such a matter.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Sanz Shlita in "Sichat HaYom Yom S"K Tetzaveh 5768", "Betzila D'Mehemnuta", Tetzaveh 5768, p. 9

The righteous Rav of Nitra *zt"l*, who passed away in the forest during the days of the Holocaust while hiding there in a bunker, said before his passing: "Yidden redt nisht in di shulen" (Jews, do not talk in the Shuls/Synagogues), for this is a great cause for evil decrees, may the Merciful One save us.
Source: HaRah"g Rabbi Efraim Fishel Sendrovitz z"l, "Divrei Efraim" (Bnei Brak 5770), p. 293

I heard, I believe, from the mouth of C.K. Admor HaGaon R' Shmuel Dovid HaLevi Ungar *Hy"d*, Av Beis Din of Nitra, that he cried out and screamed in the bitterness of his heart and soul during the days of the terrible Holocaust that passed over us, the words of the *Paytan* in the prayer of *Yom Kippur Katan*: "If with the left hand You have pushed it away, bring it near with the right." Based on the verse in Proverbs (3:16): **ארך ימים בימינה בשמאלה עשר וכבוד** - **"Length of days is in her right hand; in her left hand are riches and honor."**
"Master of the World! If You have already pushed away what is written in the left hand—the riches that the enemies robbed and plundered from us, and the honor that they humbled us down to the dust—at least bring us near with what is written in the right hand: 'Length of days.' Leave us simple life!" Thus were his holy words. The words are trembling and descend to the innermost parts of the belly.
Source: (HaGri"d Singer zt"l, Ziv HaMinhagim p. 13) "Amirah Yafah" (Jerusalem 5764), p. 202

Regarding the love of Hashem, the Gaon of Nitra *zt"l* used to say: It is written **ואהבת את ה' אלקיך בכל לבבך** - **"And you shall love Hashem your G-d with all your heart."** There are two types of love. If there is a thing that is truly good, then the father wants his son to also love that thing. But if there is a thing that is good only for him and not for others—like smoking and the like—then the father does not want the son to become accustomed to it. And this is what the verse says: **ואהבת את ה' אלקיך** - **"And you shall love Hashem your G-d"**—in such a way that **ושננתם לבניך** - **"And you shall teach them diligently to your children."**
Source: HaRah"g R' Asher Anshel Yehuda Miller z"l, "Olamo Shel Abba" (Jerusalem 5744), p. 201

My master, my father (the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Dovid Ungar) *zy"a* said once, at the time he finished the sermon in a time of trouble (he was accustomed to preach every Shabbos Chanukah in the synagogue) regarding the prayer "A new light will shine upon Zion": This will certainly come, for Hashem has already promised to redeem us. But what we pray and ask for is "And may we *all* merit speedily to His light"—that we too should merit this in our lives and in our days, that our eyes may see and our hearts rejoice and our souls exult in Your salvation in truth.
Source: From a letter by his son, HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Shalom Moshe Ungar zt"l, Av Beis Din of Nitra, "Neos Deshe-Chanukah" (Mount Kisco 5746), p. 3

His student (of the Gaon of Nitra *zt"l*), my father-in-law R' Yaakov Shalom Goldstein *Hy"d*, told me that his Rebbe, the righteous Gaon, taught his students that one must precede the study of Torah with the fear of Hashem. Before he gave the lesson in Talmud to the Yeshiva students, he gave a *Mussar* lecture and spoke about the love of Hashem and fear of Heaven with such great enthusiasm that at the end of his words, he always burst into tears.
He used to say thus: "The Talmud, the Commentators, Shas, and Poskim are called 'Wisdom' (*Chochmah*). And wisdom on its own has no value and does not endure, as we say every day in the morning prayer: '...and the wise are as if without knowledge... for all is vanity.' Therefore, wisdom is like the number 'zero.' But if we place a specific number before the zero, the two numbers together receive value. And this is what they said in Pirkei Avos: 'Anyone whose fear of sin precedes his wisdom, his wisdom endures.'"
Source: HaRah"g R' Asher Anshel Yehuda Miller z"l, "Olamo Shel Abba" (Jerusalem 5744), p. 200

**Biography**
The sun of the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Auerbach *ztzuk"l* rose on Yom Kippur, 5692 (1931), as the firstborn son to his father, the Gaon of Israel, the Poskek of the generation, Rabbi Shlomo Zalman Auerbach *ztzuk"l*, in the neighborhood of 'Shaarei Chesed' in Jerusalem. The neighborhood was then full of the greats of the world, and their neighbor was Maran HaGaon Rabbi Dov Berish Weidenfeld *ztzuk"l*, the Gaon of Tchebin.
Thus, from a young age, he would go out and come in and was very close in the hall of the Rav of Tchebin. From a young age, he studied in the "Etz Chaim" Yeshiva in Jerusalem. From his youth, he was tremendously diligent, the glory of the students in the "Etz Chaim" Yeshiva. In his childhood, while everyone played, he was diligent in his studies, and nothing interested him except Torah study. His diligence, which had no peer, caused amazement. He was immersed in his studies and forgot the world and its fullness. They told about him that he would sit to study on Motzaei Shabbos and meditate on his Torah all that night until they found him in the morning of Sunday, wearing his *Streimel* and still studying and studying.
From a young age, he was bound up in Torah study and Halacha with his great father, Maran HaGaon Rabbi Shlomo Zalman Auerbach *ztzuk"l*. He would study Torah with him and receive from his mouth "service of Torah scholars" (*Shimush Talmidei Chachamim*) at a level unsurpassed. This, being his firstborn son, his right hand, and the one closest to him for many good years. "Give to a wise man, and he will be yet wiser"—he aspired to add more Torah and wisdom incessantly, and he drew from the Torah of the greats of the world in those generations.
Thus, even in the days of his youth, he basked in the shadow of the holy ones of the previous generation, among them our Masters: the "Chazon Ish" *ztzuk"l*, the Gaon of Brisk *ztzuk"l*, Rabbi Isser Zalman Meltzer *ztzuk"l*, and later the Gaon Rabbi Elazar Menachem Shach *ztzuk"l* and the Gaon Rabbi Yosef Shalom Elyashiv *ztzuk"l*. He discussed Torah and Halacha with them, and they were amazed to see the son of Rabbi Shlomo Zalman, that he grants warmth with his spiritual stature and constitutes a glorious vessel in his own right, absorbed in Torah and meticulous about its every tittle. He had a special connection with the Admorim of Gur throughout their generations, who appreciated and honored him greatly, a connection that existed even with his great father.
The greats of Israel testified about him that he was expert in all areas of Torah; no secret was hidden from him in the revealed (*Nigleh*) and the hidden (*Nistar*). Because of this, his stature grew to such an extent that his great father used to say about himself: "I am Abu d'Shmuel" (I am the father of Shmuel), like the great and holy Amora, the father of the Amora Shmuel, whose nickname in the expanses of the Talmud is "Abu d'Shmuel."
When he reached his maturity, he established his home with the great Rebbetzin Mrs. Rachel *a"h*, daughter of the Chassidic Rav Rabbi Pinchas Eliezer Paksher *zt"l*, of the Chassidim of Stolin-Karlin. The righteous Rebbetzin stood at his right hand with boundless devotion so that he could meditate on his Torah and engage in spreading Torah without disturbance.
The Gaon Rabbi Shmuel *zt"l* immersed himself entirely in the tent of Torah and fear of G-d. He had nothing in his world but these. He was known for his conduct in holiness and purity and with all the manners of Chassidut, a man in whom was spirit, and the fear of G-d hovered over him and illuminated all his surroundings. His students and those close to him were influenced by his ways and by the fear of G-d that beat within him, and they instilled this also in their offspring and students.
After his marriage, he continued diligently to study and persevere in the Yeshiva of the Kabbalists, Kollel "Sha'ar HaShamayim," which his grandfather, the Gaon and Kabbalist Rabbi Chaim Yehuda Leib Auerbach *ztzuk"l*, founded. In the halls of the high Yeshiva, the gates of the world of Kabbalah study opened before him more and more. He became known in the gates as great in the Torah of the hidden, alongside his being wondrous in the Torah of the revealed. His service in holiness as a Chassid and a recluse surely opened gates of light before him, preserved for those who know grace (*Chein*).
While still young in years, decades ago, he was appointed to serve as Rosh Yeshiva of "Shem Olam" of the Chassidim of Amshinov. He gave his soul to spread Torah among his students. One of the greatest among his admirers is may he be separated for life, C.K. Maran Admor of Amshinov Shlita, who throughout the years expresses his deep appreciation for the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel, saying that he sees him as his Rebbe who taught him Torah.
The Gaon Rabbi Shmuel *zt"l* was immersed in Torah study out of pure fear of Heaven and out of clear and deep contemplation of it. He bequeathed the path of Torah study to his students, and they recognized the good of the great Rav who illuminated for them the paths of the Talmud and set them up in a corner of light for all the days of their lives. So it was in all the places where he spread Torah until his last day.
Years later, he was called by the Gaon Rabbi Mordechai Elefant *zt"l*, who founded the "Itri" Yeshiva and stood at its head, to spread Torah there. Those days are remembered among the Yeshiva students as days of great light and the power of love of Torah and its diligence, which continued until the year 5737 (1977). For a significant period, he spread Torah in the "Kol Torah" Yeshiva in the Bayit Vegan neighborhood in Jerusalem, where his great father served as Rosh Yeshiva, and Rabbi Shmuel headed the "Kibbutz" of the older students. The Gaon Rabbi Shmuel headed "Kollel Shem" of the Moussaieff family, which is in the Bucharim neighborhood, and spread Torah to those who listened to his lessons in its hall.
On Rosh Chodesh Iyar of the year 5742 (1982), towards the summer term, he established the Yeshiva "Maalot HaTorah" in the "Shaarei Chesed" neighborhood in Jerusalem. The famous philanthropist R' Eliyahu Reichmann, the eldest of the brothers of the Reichmann family from Toronto, built the Yeshiva building, which became a fountain of spreading Torah and fear of G-d. An apartment was also built in the building for the Rosh Yeshiva, and he lived there until his last days in order to supervise closely the conduct of the Yeshiva and its guidance. In the year 5753 (1993), he established the Yeshiva for young men "Noam HaTalmud" in the "Shaarei Chesed" neighborhood.
In the month of Tevet 5750 (1990), the Rebbetzin Mrs. Rachel *a"h* passed away, and in her name, they established institutions of education and kindness.
The words he said in a eulogy for one of the Roshei Yeshiva are fitting for him: "Happy is his old age that did not shame his youth. The Rosh Yeshiva established many students. All his deeds were literally for the sake of Heaven. He merited the crown of Torah, and at his passing, the honor of the Torah was exiled. All his days he engaged in Torah study without calculations, and thus he merited the 'Crown of Torah'. It is difficult to eulogize, but one must strengthen the students; the Torah needs great strengthening. Let us all be strengthened, for we have nothing left but this Torah, and we will merit soon the Resurrection of the Dead."
Although he did not merit offspring of his own, he was always happy with every Jew in his joy, and especially with his students. He cared with all his heart for every one of the thousands of students, rejoiced in his joy, participated, and eased his pain. He carried his students on his heart; he guided and educated them and helped them establish homes in Israel. He spared no effort to participate in the celebrations of students, and even in the last week, after undergoing catheterization in his heart and pneumonia, he did not spare his strength and went out to participate in the joy of a student.
His profound books, "Darchei Shmuel" on Tractate Ohalos, became known in the gates. It opens gates to understanding and knowing the complex and intricate laws of purity and impurity. He printed it after the passing of the Rebbetzin *a"h* and for the elevation of her soul. Likewise, the series of books "Ohel Rachel," published by his students, rises on the table of kings. It includes ethical talks he delivered before his listeners regarding Holidays and festivals and current affairs. He also left very many writings on all subjects of Torah.
A special chapter in his conduct was his prayer, which rose from the depth of the heart. He poured out a whisper of prayer before his Creator, not only for himself but also for his students and for the entire House of Israel. Therefore, his prayer was prolonged greatly. The Shemoneh Esrei prayer of a regular day was about twenty minutes long; so too in Shacharis, so too in Mincha, and so too again in Maariv. On the Days of Awe, the prayer began at *Vasikin* (sunrise) and continued until the afternoon hours.
His great heart was compassionate and sensitive to the distress of widows and orphans. On Shabbos and holidays, widows and orphans and those having a hard day would dine at his table, and he shone his face upon them. Likewise, he headed charitable and kindness organizations, and in his merit, many contributed to easing the distress of Israel.
All his days, his heart burned and was sensitive to stand on the guard of the holies of Israel. He stood at the right hand of the generations of the past in these struggles and continued to stand on guard also at this time, especially in the last decades, until his last day. Whenever there were decrees against the holies of Israel, they broke his spirit and pained him greatly. He called from the depths of his heart to guard the Holy Shabbos and the purity of the education of the Yeshiva students and the halls of pure Charedi education. Likewise, he stood on the guard of the holy Yeshivas and their ways and pained over the attempts led by enemies of religion in cooperation with the High Court to try to narrow their steps.
He fought with immense pain against the ravages of technology and used to say: "The internet and the invalid devices have terrible prohibitions in them, and it requires great strengthening always." He called to act against the breach with a multitude of people. Words hewn from flames were heard in his speeches throughout the years on the guard of education, as it is said, "For I have known him, that he will command his children and his household after him." This is not a breach, but the heart of Judaism literally. "That they should tell us opinions on education? If they try to intervene and tell us not to study on Erev Pesach, this is something one must be killed for rather than transgress. It is like the counsel of Haman who sought to uproot everything, all the more so regarding the studies themselves. And upon each and every one, it is incumbent to stand on his watch."
On the night of Shabbos Kodesh, Parashas Tetzaveh 5778 (2018), close to midnight, he felt unwell, which turned out to be cardiac arrest. Rescue forces were summoned and tried to treat him, and he was rushed to Shaare Zedek Hospital. There, he returned his great and pure soul to the Creator of the Heart amidst the cries of "Shema Yisrael" of those present at midnight on Shabbos Kodesh. (And his resting place is in honor on Har HaMenuchos).
Source: "HaModia", 10 Adar 5778, p. 1

Regarding the connection [of his brother, the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Auerbach *zt"l*] with Maran the Chazon Ish *zt"l*, I heard from my uncle, HaRav Gershon Karlenstein Shlita, who told that my brother *zt"l* was found often by Maran the Chazon Ish *zt"l*. Every so often, he would come for periods to Bnei Brak to speak with him in learning and would lodge in their house. Generally, this was during *Bein HaZmanim* (intercession), although in Etz Chaim, they studied even during *Bein HaZmanim*.
There was one time when he prolonged the conversation with the Chazon Ish greatly, and when they finished, the hour was late. The Chazon Ish wanted him to sleep with him in his house and had already begun to prepare the bed for him. But my brother *zt"l* insisted on returning to sleep at the Karlenstein family's house so they would not worry about him. The aforementioned told me that when Maran the Chazon Ish *zt"l* entered from his room to the Beis Medrash for the Mincha prayer and saw that my brother HaGaon R' Shmuel *zt"l* was there, a light was spilled over his face; they literally saw a great smile on him.
"Also by Maran the Brisker Rav (HaGri"z) *zt"l*, he was considered literally a member of the household. He would always return and tell things from there. And this is aside from what he knew of his Torah from the mouth of his friend, the mighty Gaon Rabbi Meir HaLevi *zt"l*, son of the Rav *zt"l*. I also remember times when he prayed by him during the Rosh Hashanah prayers."
"I think that much of the reality of my brother HaGaon R' Shmuel *zt"l*—the meticulousness in Mitzvos, and all the 'bren' (fire/enthusiasm) in fear of Heaven, the warmth for everything in holiness, and how he was entirely a holy fire to Hashem and His Torah—he sucked from the stay in the presence of Maran the Brisker Rav *zt"l*, in which it was possible to sense fear of G-d."
"Also his special connections with Maran the Gaon of Tchebin *zt"l* are well known. They lived literally as neighbors. My brother the Rosh Yeshiva *zt"l* lived after his marriage on HaGaonim Street, and the Rav of Tchebin lived in Even Shaprut at the corner of Chasam Sofer. Thus, a special connection was formed that went and deepened over the years. In truth, at the time, we did not know so much about the connection that was between them, but afterward, over the years, we heard how he would speak of him with such great admiration."
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Mordechai Auerbach Shlita, "Musaf Zikaron", Adar 5778, p. 61

HaRav HaGaon R' Yaakov Aronovosky Shlita told: On Purim about more than ten years ago, we came as was our custom with my master, my father, HaRav HaGaon R' Avraham Dovid Yaakovzon Shlita: "It was a few days before the holiday of Shavuot during the third Seder (night session) in the Yeshiva. There was a wedding of relatives of our Rebbe Maran [HaGaon Rabbi Shmuel Auerbach] *zy"a*, and our Rebbe knew that I was also going there. The wedding was at the Central Hotel, a walking distance of about a quarter of an hour from the Yeshiva. Our Rebbe was busy studying the *Sugya*.
He went out of the Beis Medrash and said to me: 'There is a wedding tonight, one needs to go, but...' and he returned to his study. After a quarter of an hour, he got up again and said to me: 'The widow [the mother of the bride] came several times to invite me, but what shall I do? I didn't learn anything today; all day there were people. What shall I do...' And again he returned to his study. Again he went out and said: 'What shall I do? One needs to go, but...' And he was in great distress until finally, he decided there was no choice and one must go.
So we walked the whole way on foot to the Central Hotel. The whole way, he repeated the words of the *Baal HaMaor* and *Ramban*, Rabbi Yosi and the Rabbis. Regarding the damaged object to distance, regarding the damager to distance. Again mustard and bees, until we arrived at the hall. He sat for a few minutes, and on the way back, he dove again into the depth of the *Sugyas*!"
Source: "Romemut", Vayakhel-Pekudei 5778, p. 3

One of the students Shlita related: The terrible immersion of our Rebbe Maran [HaGaon R' Shmuel Auerbach] *zy"a* is well known. I heard that decades ago, when the Rebbetzin was still alive, a certain man arrived and wanted to enter to our Rebbe to speak with him. The Rebbetzin said to him: "If you come to speak with him in learning, you can enter. But if you come to speak with him about other matters, I take precedence! It has been two weeks that he is preoccupied and busy with the severe *Sugyas* in the chapter 'Kirah' (Shabbos), and he speaks to me almost nothing... Only if you want to speak with him in Torah, enter!"
Source: "Romemut", Vayakhel-Pekudei 5778, p. 8

HaRav HaGaon R' Avraham Dovid Yaakovzon Shlita told: This was about 30 years ago when they were dealing in the Yeshiva with a very deep *Sugya* with many "Ktzos" and "Nesivos." One of the best students of the Yeshiva, in Or HaChaim in Jerusalem, became engaged. Our Rebbe Maran [HaGaon R' Shmuel Auerbach] *zy"a* asked me to accompany him. The entire way, our Rebbe was deep, deep in the *Sugya* of "Ktzos" and "Nesivos," etc. When our Rebbe entered the hall and had to speak, I thought to myself: What will our Rebbe speak about now? After all, he is entirely in the depth of the *Sugya*...
Then I hear that our Rebbe Maran *zy"a* stood up and said: "We are at the engagement celebration of an important groom (*Chasan*), a 'Chasan Torah'! By a 'Chasan Torah,' one needs to speak words of Torah... Gentlemen! There are three 'Nesivos' in three places..." And so he continued and spoke in the study of a complete array in the *Sugya* they were dealing with in the Yeshiva...
Source: "Romemut", Vayakhel-Pekudei 5778, p. 4

Another of the students Shlita related: At another time, it happened that I accompanied our Rebbe, the Rosh Yeshiva [HaGaon Rabbi Shmuel Auerbach] *ztzuk"l*, who needed to go to a certain celebration. This was during one of the very stormy hours from a public perspective. And what were his words along the entire way? Only "Opening a handbreadth," "Compressed impurity," "End of impurity to exit," "Rambam," "Gaon"...
And always, this was his entire discourse and conversation. The whole world was noisy, and our Rebbe, the Rosh Yeshiva, was immersed in *Taharos* (Laws of Purity). Everyone would see, concludes that student of our Rebbe the Rosh Yeshiva *ztzuk"l*, "For they could enter at the most complicated times when all of Klal Yisrael was on the scale, worlds were storming, and in the whole world they were noting: 'R' Shmuel says this' and 'R' Shmuel says to do that.' But when coming to our Rebbe himself, he is found entirely, completely, deep, deep in the depth of Halacha and the examination of *Sugyas* in Zeraim or Bava Metzia..."
So too, the great Gaon Rabbi Baruch Shmuel HaKohen Deutsch Shlita related a wondrous story, that he was accustomed to return and tell about another hour, in which he stood and was amazed in the presence of the wondrous greatness of our Rebbe, the Rosh Yeshiva *ztzuk"l*, and his cleaving to the study of the Holy Torah. This was years ago when a severe decision stood at his door in fateful moments touching upon serious public matters. Our Rebbe *zy"a* waited for a great expert in his field and G-d-fearing man, to hear his professional opinion regarding the appropriate conduct in that severe affair, and how to manage the next steps. That expert, who was one of the loyalists of our Rebbe the Rosh Yeshiva *ztzuk"l*, called and said that he encountered a complete unavoidable accident (*Ones*) and was forced to be forty minutes late to the meeting.
The great Gaon Rabbi Baruch Shmuel HaKohen Deutsch Shlita, may he be separated for long life, tells how he stood in amazement and wonder at how our Rebbe Maran the Rosh Yeshiva *ztzuk"l* did not dedicate even a moment to superfluous engagement in that stormy public affair. Rather, immediately he began a discussion and debate in the depth of the analysis of *Sugyas* with sharpness and brilliance, like one swimming in the sea of living waters literally. It was not recognizable on him at all for a moment as if he was troubled so much by that public matter; rather, he was immersed entirely in the existence of the *Sugyas*. Until that expert arrived, and Maran *zy"a* turned out of necessity to deal with that matter. However, until that very moment, despite the great burden, our Rebbe the Rosh Yeshiva *ztzuk"l* did not dedicate time to superfluous engagement, but turned his heart and thought to engage in words of Torah in depth.
Source: "Musaf Zikaron", Adar 5778, p. 44

HaRav HaGaon Yaakov Leiner Shlita related: When I entered to our Rebbe Maran [HaGaon R' Shmuel Auerbach] *zy"a* about a year ago, and I mentioned before him his language with precision in what he writes in his book "Darchei Shmuel"—Ohalos regarding our Rebbe, the author of the 'Or Sameach' *zy"a*: "And also very surprising is what our Rebbe the Gaon *z"l* sits and expounds a verse to obligate death by the hands of Heaven where we do not find this in Chazal."
He smiled, and immediately reacted and said to me regarding what he wrote thirty years ago: "This text was already written by Rabbi Chaim HaKohen Rapoport on 'Pnei Yehoshua'... I searched and found it in the Responsa of Rabbi Chaim HaKohen Rapoport, Even HaEzer Siman 6 in the gloss..."
"I searched for it! I searched!" And I found this in the Responsa of Rabbi Chaim HaKohen Rapoport, Even HaEzer Siman 6 in the gloss...
Source: "Romemut", Vayakhel-Pekudei 5778, p. 9

It was fluent in the mouth of the holy Rav, our teacher R' Yosef *zt"l* of the community of Ir Chadash (son of the Gaon and holy author of "Maor VaShemesh" *zt"l*): "Master of the World! If, Heaven forbid, You do not grant me my requests of prayer for those who come to seek my prayer and my advice and to receive my blessings, I will not be able to be a leader of the Children of Israel anymore. And behold, I will do what is good in Your eyes, that I will lay down my watch." Until here were his holy words.
Source: The Holy Rebbe, Author of "Darchei Teshuva" of Munkacs Ztzuk"l, "Tiferet Banim" (Jerusalem 5760), Vol. 1, p. 395, 15b

HaRav HaGaon Menachem Novogrotsky Shlita related: Our Rebbe Maran [HaGaon R' Shmuel Auerbach] *zy"a* always taught us that the way to receive taste in prayer and to find renewal in every prayer and prayer is by making the prayer [one of] mercy and supplications, and to flee from "fixity" (*Keva*) in prayer. Meaning, from confining the prayer to a fixed and limited time, and praying out of pressure.
Our Rebbe Maran *zy"a* was of the opinion that *Lechatchila* (initially), it is fitting to be particular about the Reading of the Shema at the first time of the *Magen Avraham*, even though it is obvious to him that the Halacha was decided like the Gra. Indeed, he used to conduct himself [according to] Halacha L'Maaseh in his holy Yeshiva to exert effort to start so that he would finish it with the time of the Magen Avraham.
But on Shabbos and Holidays, when this would cause pressure and confusion and disturb the peace of mind required for prayer, behold he would forgo this enhancement. He did not feel a need at all to finish at this time, even when the gap was a few minutes. And this was one of the principles with him, that the prayer should be without pressure and without a time by which one needs to finish. For it is not only that this falls under the category of 'his prayer is fixed' (*Keva*), but this is the way and this is the measure to experience the closeness of G-d that exists in prayer. "To strip your body from upon your soul" in the language of the Nefesh HaChaim, but a tense feeling cannot possibly feel so. And it is impossible to exit from a feeling of "fulfilling one's obligation" (*Yotzei Zein*) and "to be after."
Source: "Romemut", Vayakhel-Pekudei 5778, p. 4

...Many people entered to Maran HaGaon Rabbi Shmuel Auerbach *zt"l* to ask for help, and every one of them felt loved, close, and dear. Beggars and paupers would knock on the door of the house, as if people were tossing a shekel or two toward them from a distance. The wretched of life and soul, who had one and only friend in the world, "Tell R' Shmuel that I arrived," they would ask of me when I opened the door for them. "We know each other." And what a delightful acquaintance they had.
The Rosh Yeshiva would honor them with a suitable gift, a respectable giving as is fitting for friends like them. And they would sit and converse... The Rosh Yeshiva had a special drawer in his vast memory for the collection of troubles and hardships of life specific to that certain beggar. He would inquire with friendliness, with warmth, with love, and with patience about the developments that occurred in the life of his friend since their last meeting until now... There was not one who did not leave him with an upright stature.
Students would ask to enter to him to receive encouragement and advice. I never heard what he spoke with them; no one from the household members was permitted to listen to what they conversed with him inside. But just to look at how they left from there with sparkling eyes, literally a new creation. Not once and not twice did we see this. He poured a spirit of life into them, and he did this with such joy, with such love, out of the loftiness of "And you shall walk in His ways"—that his good desire was to do good.
I want to add something else. The Rosh Yeshiva was a very independent man. The household members had no control over who to let inside and who not; everything had to pass under his exclusive decision. Every time we approached to ask if it was possible to let someone in. And it is impossible to forget how, when we approached to ask him to let in a certain Rosh Yeshiva, or a certain important activist who asks to consult with him. In every such instance, we felt that we were literally cutting into his living flesh. He would look at us with such a wretched look, as if saying: "What do you want from me? I want to learn?"
We stood in a very delicate situation. On one hand, we wanted to help the people knocking on the door of the house. On the other hand, it was painfully difficult for us regarding the Rosh Yeshiva, to disconnect him from study. There were times he answered in the affirmative, and there were times he pushed it off. We never stood on his considerations. But one thing we saw, consistent and clear: If the one knocking on the door was needy, wretched, or even a student who needed strengthening—the answer was always positive. He never answered in the negative when the matter was about doing good to someone.
"He loaded upon himself the yoke of life of people whom life had embittered for them; he loaded it in practice. Everyone knows from hearsay the stories of glory. How he cared for a widow and orphans, how he hosted at his table. Stories of wonders are always sterile and graceful, but in reality, he suffered on his shoulder great sorrow inside for every matter and issue. On Holidays and Shabbos, the Rosh Yeshiva was in higher realms; one could see with the senses that he was not that man. He was immersed in a completely different atmosphere. On Friday night, he could sit for three hours in tremendous cleaving (*Dveikus*). When he made Kiddush, those seated at the table did not open their mouths; they were unable to move.
Seder night, a burning fire! Holy of Holies! And into this elevated atmosphere, orphan children burst in, mischievous, pulling at the fringes of his clothes, performing somersaults, and pouring juice drinks on the table. And the Rosh Yeshiva rejoices and dances with them, endears himself to them, seeks to draw their hearts. People from the side would watch with bated breath at times; the contrast between his tremendous loftiness and the quarrels of the children around the table was literally depressing. How much is possible? But the Rosh Yeshiva did not think otherwise for a moment; these are his children!
And he continued to invite them holiday after holiday, again and again, with love. With patience, how much joy he would spread around him.
Some years after the passing of one of his students, his family still lived in Shaarei Chesed. Every Shabbos after the prayer, when he finished the study following the prayer, he would march in the streets of Shaarei Chesed. He marched with a relaxed Shabbos walk. He knocks on the door of the family, and after two knocks, opens and enters inside. He has not yet entered a single step, and already all the children jump to greet him: 'R' Shmuel! The Rosh Yeshiva has arrived! What's new?' And the Rosh Yeshiva scatters rays of light around him; the festive 'Gut Shabbos' fills the house with a special melody.
Afterward, he would sit and converse with all the children and ask about their welfare, inquiring also about the welfare of the widow while entirely light and joy. After he blessed everyone again with a festive Gut Shabbos, he turned to leave the house. He was the father of orphans and widows. He would sit and discuss with the widows the details of details, regarding matters of education and questions of life. I know a widow, that since her husband passed away, for over fifteen years he would call her every Friday and Holiday eve. He never missed a single time. His blessings flowed over the receiver: 'A Gut Shabbos,' 'A Lichtige Shabbos,' etc. And the widow returns a bundle of blessings of her own to him. So it was for seventeen years. When he did kindness, it was never temporary. Generally, people recoil from ongoing 'projects'; temporary kindness is enough for them, short-term. But he lived doing good for a Jew, day after day, year after year, with terrible perfection.
In the Rosh Yeshiva, we saw the embodiment of the words of the Rambam in Laws of Megillah (2:17): 'For there is no greater and more glorious joy than to gladden the hearts of the poor, the orphans, the widows, and the strangers, for one who gladdens the hearts of these unfortunate ones is like the Shechinah.'"
Source: HaRah"g R' Avraham Yechiel Una Shlita, "Musaf Zikaron", Adar 5778, p. 96

A certain widow who lived in proximity to the house of one of the Admorim entered before him one day and poured out her trouble before him: that she stands to marry off her son and has not a penny in her hand for her purse. When the Admor investigated and checked her situation, he asked her how she married off her previous son. The woman answered: "Even then I had nothing, and they told me to go to Rabbi Shmuel Auerbach, and he would give money in my hand for the wedding expenses. And indeed I went to him, and when he heard about my very pressed situation and checked that indeed such were the face of things, he said to me that from Heaven I arrived on a 'Good Day'... because that very day he sold the apartment he had for key money on Gesher HaChaim Street and gave me the sum of money so that I would have it for the wedding expenses..."
Source: "Musaf Zikaron", Adar 5778, p. 92

Anyone who knew our Rebbe Maran [HaGaon R' Shmuel Auerbach] *zy"a* knew that he did not sleep in his bed at all. How awesome was the sight to see him diligent in his studies in the hall of the Yeshiva; "day and night he shall not cease" meant literally. The students testify that for many years he would remain to meditate on Torah in the hall of the Yeshiva at night. Even when everyone left the hall to gather strength for the next day, until the last of them left in the small hours of the night, he was still entirely immersed in the existence of the Gemara. In the morning, the 'early risers' still found him leaning over his Talmud. In between, he would doze a little bit to gather strength to continue in the business of Torah.
In a eulogy delivered by the Gaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yitzchak Yerucham Borodiansky Shlita, brother-in-law of our Rebbe *zy"a*, he told in the name of one of those close to him that one day our Rebbe *zy"a* turned to him with a request to bring him 'Negel Vasser' [water to wash hands]. To the student's wonder, he asked him what is different today, for he did not recall our Rebbe ever asking him for 'Negel Vasser'. With charming humility, our Rebbe *zy"a* replied to him that indeed for several years... he does not go up to sleep on his bed [except on Shabbos and Holidays]. Rather, he dozes little by little. But now he felt weakness, and therefore he asks this request of him.
Source: "Romemut", Vayakhel-Pekudei 5778, p. 4

...My brother [the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Auerbach] *zt"l* was indeed the greatest 'Misnaged', and all his life he engaged and delved into the Torah of the Gra *zy"a*. However, on the other hand, he was also the greatest Chassid. His reality was a "Pillar of Fire." Everything burned within him: Torah study, fear of Hashem, love of Hashem, fulfillment of Mitzvos—everything was at the peak of enthusiasm.
Among the comforters was a certain Admor from a famous Chassidic group. I told him that my brother *zt"l* was boiling on Shabbos much more than you... I do not know when the entire process of Shabbos began with him, but there is no doubt they saw upon him on Shabbos a sublime and exalted conduct, with all the lofty words about Shabbos. He had control without boundaries in all areas. He was also expert straight and backward in all the Torah of Chassidut, of all the Chassidic groups.
In his time, he engaged for a specific period in the study of the Torah of the Hidden (*Nistar*) with the Gaon Rabbi Moshe Luria *zt"l*. May the Gaon Rabbi Michel Zilber Shlita be separated for good life—they were of the Slonimer Chassidim. As is known, the first Admor of Slonim, author of "Yesod HaAvodah," composed a book on Kabbalah named 'Chesed L'Avraham'. HaGaon R' M. Luria *zt"l* said that when he studied with my brother *zt"l*, my brother would quote him things from the aforementioned book of the Admor of Slonim that he himself did not know of. Of course, all this is only the 'withered leaves of wisdom' (*Novlos Chochmah*); his main toil all the days of his life was in the bodies of Torah.
Source: HaGaon Rabbi Mordechai Auerbach Shlita, "Musaf Zikaron", Adar 5778, p. 71

HaRav HaGaon Yaakov Aronovosky Shlita related: On Purim day, more than ten years ago, we came as was our custom with my master, my father, HaRav HaGaon R' Avraham Dovid Yaakovzon Shlita, to our Rebbe Maran [HaGaon R' Shmuel Auerbach] *zy"a*, and he blessed us, etc. My master, my father Shlita, replied with a blessing that the Rosh Yeshiva should lengthen days over his kingdom and continue to lead the generation... Our Rebbe smiled and told in his humility:
"On Purim in the Volozhin Yeshiva, Marana the Netziv *zy"a* was like a 'Purim Rav' and blessed the students according to their request. One student asked him to bless him that he should be the *Rishon LeTzion* (Chief Rabbi/Leader). Marana the Netziv refused to bless him with this. That student pleaded again and again. Then, with no choice, the Netziv said to him: 'I can bless you, but I cannot curse the generation...'"
Source: "Romemut", Vayakhel-Pekudei 5778, p. 6

**Biography**
Rabbi Yosef Baruch HaLevi Epstein from Ir Chadash (Neustadt) was one of the known Tzaddikim of the generation. He was the son of Rabbi Kalonymus Kalman, author of the "Maor VaShemesh" of Krakow. He was known in the Chassidic world by the name "The Guter Yid (Good Jew) of Neustadt." Thousands of Chassidim basked in his shadow. He visited the courts of Tzaddikim often. He traveled to the Admor of Sanz and was counted among the distinct disciples of the Tiferes Shlomo of Radomsk. He excelled in the love of Israel.
In his conduct, which was full of humility and simplicity, he succeeded in drawing multitudes to him. The Tiferes Shlomo honored him greatly. During R' Yosef Baruch's visits to Radomsk, Rabbi Shlomo would pass before the ark (lead the prayers) in order to give pleasure to the Tzaddik of Neustadt with his prayer. In one of his letters, Rabbi Shlomo invites him to participate in the wedding of his son, Rav Tzvi Meir Rabinowitz, who was the Av Beis Din in Radomsk. From the titles, we learn how much Rabbi Shlomo valued Rabbi Yosef. Thus he describes him: "Rav of peace from the Creator of Worlds, to the honor of the friend of my soul, the Rav, the great luminary, lamp of Israel and its holy one, glory of the generation, head of all the children of the Diaspora, the holy lamp (*Botzina Kadisha*), etc., the right pillar, the strong hammer, son of holy ones, a leafy olive tree, the honor of the holiness of his glory, our teacher R' Yosef Baruch HaLevi *n"y*, may he appear forever."
In his youth, he visited with his father by Rabbi Mendele of Rimanov. He also visited the Tzaddik Rabbi Meir of Premishlan, who called him to go up to the Torah as a Levi, saying: "You are a true Levi."
He left a famous righteous son, Rabbi Kalonymus Kalman HaLevi, who filled his father's place in Neustadt.
He was the brother of the known Tzaddik Rabbi Aharon of Krakow. The Tzaddikim of the generation said about him: "A coffin carrying its bearer." Although his great father, author of "Maor VaShemesh," did not lead a congregation and did not even have his own Beis Medrash (but prayed in the synagogue of the Rema), his sons were counted among the great Admorim, and thousands of Chassidim basked in their shadow.
He passed away on the 10th of Adar I, 5627 (1867), and his resting place is in honor in Neustadt.
Source: Rabbi Dovid Halachmi z"l, "Chachmei Yisrael" (Bnei Brak 5761), p. 305

In the days of his youth, the "Guter Yid" traveled regularly to the holy Chozeh (Seer) of Lublin. It is brought in the book of wondrous stories of the greats of Israel (p. 141) that while he was a young man in the Beis Medrash of the Chozeh, it happened that the Rebbe (the Chozeh) entered suddenly from his room to the Beis Medrash. His face was flaming like fire, and he walked the length of the Beis Medrash back and forth. Finally, he stood next to the place of Rabbi Yosef Baruch and said: "Come with me, son of R' Kalmish'l. Is it not you I am seeking? Come, and I will teach you a path in the service of G-d." The Rebbe led him with him to his room, and the two of them stayed there together for a long time. Many of the disciples of the Chozeh who remembered this were accustomed to travel later, from time to time, to Rabbi Yosef Baruch.
Source: HaRah"ch R' Yosef Dovid Weisberg z"l, "Rabbeinu HaKadosh M'Sanz" (Jerusalem 5738), Vol. 3, p. 47

At the beginning of his matter, the "Good Jew" disguised himself in the image of a simple farmer. He would walk in the markets and fairs, ostensibly trading in geese and chickens. He would raise birds and horses in his courtyard, feeding and watering them himself, while pretending to the people surrounding him as if this was his entire conversation and concept in this world. Only regarding one prominent trait was it impossible for him to conceal: his good heart and his burning love for every Jew, a love unto the consumption of the soul. Because of this trait, presumably, he was nicknamed by all "The Good Jew" (*Der Guter Yid*).
However, the hearts of the Children of Israel, sons of prophets, did not follow the mask he put on his face. They felt clearly that a city and a holy one were here. A large crowd of thousands flowed to bask in his shadow, until he was forced to come out of his enclosure and open his gates before all who were hungry. He became famous as a wonder-worker, one of the unique ones of the generation. His advice was as if a man inquired of the word of G-d. Men of ascent and every seeker of G-d cleaved to him to become wise from his ways in Torah and service.
Source: Rabbi Aharon Sorosky Shlita, "BeLabat Eish" (Bnei Brak 5745), Vol. 1, p. 206

The Gaon and Tzaddik Mahara, Av Beis Din of Sanz (son of the "Divrei Chaim" *zy"a*) *z"l*, told me that the Rebbe and Tzaddik Mahari of Neustadt *z"l* asked his father, the Rebbe and author of "Maor VaShemesh," before his passing, to which Tzaddik he should cleave. He answered him that he should travel to the Gaon and Tzaddik of Ropshitz, for he is a Tzaddik of Truth.
And so he did; he traveled for Shabbos Kodesh to Ropshitz. On Friday night after the prayer, the Gaon *zt"l* (of Ropshitz) quarreled with his gentile servant about why he did not supervise his courtyard properly, and the like. When he finished his words of quarreling, he put on the Tallis and said "Shalom Aleichem," etc. When the Rebbe Mahari *zt"l* saw this, he was very frightened, for he had never heard such a thing from his father the Rebbe *zt"l*, because he would speak on Shabbos Kodesh only in the Holy Tongue, and even that very little. Although he believed that the Gaon *zt"l* certainly performs wondrous unifications (*Yichudim*) with this, nevertheless, he could not tolerate such a path. Consequently, he felt no taste of holiness in the words of the Gaon *zt"l*. He stood by his table throughout the duration of his sitting at his Pure Table, but his heart was far from there.
Afterward, when the reclining guests left, the Rebbe Mahari *zt"l* remained in the Beis Medrash. He took out from his bag the holy writings from his father the Rebbe *zt"l* and studied them, and he wept greatly over the fact that he did not find such a Tzaddik to whom he could cleave. Amidst the weeping, sleep fell upon him and he slept. He saw his father the Rebbe *zt"l* in his dream and told him what had happened to him. His father said to him that the Rebbe of Ropshitz is a Tzaddik of Truth, and he should not move from him, and he should cleave to him. "And when you rise from your sleep by the light of morning, go to the house of the Gaon *zt"l*, and you will find him sleeping, and you will see that he is a Tzaddik of Truth."
When he woke from his sleep, he went to the house of the Gaon *zt"l* and found him sleeping, and he saw that it was so [end of quote]. He asked the Gaon Mahara *zt"l* what he saw, but he did not want to tell him. From this, it is understood how high the words of the Gaon of Ropshitz were.
Source: The Holy Rebbe Rabbi Yitzchak Eizik of Spinka Ztzuk"l in his introduction to the holy book "Imrei Yosef", Essay 3, Letter 7

Many of the righteous of his generation traveled to the "Guter Yid." Once, when the Tiferes Shlomo, the holy Rebbe R' Elazar of Kozhnitz *z"l*, and the holy Rebbe R' Nassan Dovid of Shidlovtza *z"l* were with him, he traveled with them to stroll across the field. On the way, a Jew came out from a certain village and wept and pleaded before him that his master wants to dismiss him from his place for no wrong in his hands—him, his children, and his children's children with him. He does not know where to put his soul; grief is in his heart day and night. Where will he turn? His enemy rises against him, and where will he go with the tender children? Thus he screamed and wept incessantly.
The "Guter Yid" turned to the Tzaddikim who were with him and said: "Please, Rabbis, do a favor for this Jew." The holy Rebbe of Kozhnitz said: "I am not a Rebbe. I am a simple Jew." And so they all evaded him with excuses. The "Guter Yid" said: "Behold, I recall that by the Rebbe of Radoshitz, someone came and apologized for a gentile who was distressing him. The Rebbe took his cane in his hand in such a manner (and he showed them how) and pulled it like a rifle, and shouted in a voice: 'Pui! But who is like him and who equals him!'"
The Jew was still standing and weeping for the Rebbe to have mercy on him. The Tiferes Shlomo said to him: "Fool, go to your house, for surely you have already been saved." He went to his house, and upon his arrival, he heard that the master had fired a bullet of death with his rifle at his own head and died a few moments before. And it was a wonder. (Sefer Sippurei Niflaos MiGedolei Yisrael, Siman 146).
Source: "Yad HaMaor VeHaShemesh" (Brooklyn 5737), p. 374

The Chassidic Rabbi R' Yosef Baruch Glickman *z"l* told me: When I was together with the holy Rebbe R' Shmaly of Lichov in Krakow, he had a Gemara Sukkah, Vilna Shas. He wrote his *Chiddushim* (insights) on the margins. I was studying in that Gemara then. He told me that I should guard the Gemara not to erase and not to tear, because he wrote on the margins. He was strict not to use his books [carelessly].
I told him that my grandfather, the "Guter Yid," also had a cabinet with books, and he was strict that no one should take a book from the cabinet. I heard from my grandfather, the holy Rebbe R' Yoshua Heschel of Chenstchin, that once someone waited to enter the "Guter Yid." In the meantime, he took a book and looked into it. When my grandfather, the "Guter Yid," sensed the matter, he asked him: "Why did you take a book? Do you not know that I am strict?" He answered: "I wanted to learn." My grandfather said with simplicity, as was his holy way: "To learn?! You have reviewed the Gemara [meaning: can you repeat the Gemara] borrowed without knowledge of a robber, asking without knowledge of a robber?" And he said this with the melody of the Gemara. When I told the aforementioned to R' Shmaly, he enjoyed the story.
Source: HaRah"ch R' Yisrael Chaim Ashri Shlita, "Siach Zekeinim" (Brooklyn 5758), Vol. 2, p. 17

The holy Rebbe called "Der Guter Yid" of Neustadt was the Rebbe Rabbi Yosef Baruch, son of the holy Rebbe, author of "Maor VaShemesh" *zt"l*. His way in holiness was that when he said Torah at the Pure Table, he would say it even with mistakes, and in this were secrets of secrets.
Until once he said on the verse (Exodus 18:11) **עתה ידעתי כי גדול ה'** - **"Now I know that the L-rd is great,"** that the holy Rashi wrote: "That he did not leave idolatry (*Avodah Zarah*) that he did not worship." He said: "That he did not leave this world that he did not worship." For it was written as an acronym (*Roshei Teivos* - A.Z. = Avodah Zarah / Olam Zeh). They asked him: "Rebbe, is it not brought [in the sources] 'Avodah Zarah'?" He replied to them: "Because Avodah Zarah and This World are one and the same," and sufficient for the wise.
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Aryeh Mordechai Rabinowitz zt"l, Av Beis Din of Bnei Brak, "Karnei Re'em" (Bnei Brak 5755), Vol. 1, p. 104

Once, R' Yosef of Neustadt *zy"a* had a monetary dispute with someone, and he wanted to take him to court (*Din Torah*). He traveled to Sanz to the holy Gaon, the "Divrei Chaim," to compromise on the matter. The holy and pure eyes of the "Divrei Chaim" immediately recognized the nature of this man. He testified that this R' Yossele does not utter mundane speech from his mouth, for everything he speaks contains hidden holy intentions and unifications (from the mouth of C.K. Maran Admor of Pshevorsk *ztzuk"l*).
R' Yossele remained for Shabbos Kodesh in Sanz. He stood next to the "Divrei Chaim" and was bent over, his hands hanging down. The "Divrei Chaim" asked him why he was so immersed in thought. He answered him: "**מאי בכך, הלא שבת היום לה'** - **'What of it? Is it not Shabbos today for the L-rd?'**" And his mouth uttered with simplicity that one must not distract one's mind from the holiness of a Jew on Shabbos.
After Shabbos, they parted from one another with great love and affection. R' Yossele said then: "Since I see that the Rebbe of Sanz has a healthy body and a healthy soul, I will cleave to him and take him for myself as a Rebbe" (from the mouth of my sharp and expert friend, R' Mordechai Dovid Ungar *n"y*).
Source: HaRah"g R' Chaim Dovid Bakan Shlita, "Yad HaMaor VeHaShemesh" (Brooklyn 5737), p. 348

After the passing of the Rebbe of Ropshitz, he (the "Guter Yid") traveled to the holy Rebbe of Radoshitz, and afterward, he traveled often to Sanz. Our Rebbe (the "Divrei Chaim") would praise and extol his wondrous personality and his simple conduct, full of mystery. Once he said: "In Heaven, they enjoy his recitation of Psalms more than my completion of Shas."
It is brought in the book "Devarim Areivim," p. 165, that when the righteous Rabbi Meshulam Feish of Tosh began to draw close to Chassidut, he traveled first to Rabbi Meir of Dzikov. He sent him away from his presence and said: "A Rebbe is the Sanzer Rav." R' Meshulam Feish continued his way to Sanz. While standing in line among those coming to receive "Shalom," our Rebbe (the "Divrei Chaim") grabbed him by his hand and commanded him to enter his room after him. R' Meshulam Feish entered and stood at the door. Our Rebbe turned to him: "Ihr vilst a Rebbe? Bald vet areinkumen a Rebbe!" (You want a Rebbe? Soon a Rebbe will come in!). After a short time, Rabbi Yosef Baruch entered the room, and our Rebbe rose to greet him. Then the Tzaddik of Tosh understood that the intention was him.
In the book "Sippurei Niflaos MiGedolei Yisrael," p. 145, it is brought what his attendant R' Yechiel Dovid told: When he [the Guter Yid] was in Sanz on Shabbos, our Rebbe (the "Divrei Chaim") seated him next to him and whispered secrets with him. It happened once on Friday night at the end of the *Tish* (Table), that our Rebbe accompanied him to his lodging and prolonged the conversation with him. The "Guter Yid" answered: "Sanzer Rav, you are an angel, a Seraph, and you do not need eating or drinking or sleep. However, I am a simple householder (*Baal HaBayis*), and I wish to lie down to sleep so that I may rise tomorrow with a clear mind for the service of G-d!"
Our Rebbe blessed him with "Gut Shabbos" and turned away from him. The "Guter Yid" began preparations to say *Krias Shema* on the bed. While he was preparing himself, the door opened, and our Rebbe [the "Divrei Chaim"] stood in the doorway and said: "How good that you are not sleeping yet..." and continued to converse with him with great affection out of inner longing. Finally, the "Guter Yid" answered again: "Sanzer Rav! His Honor is an angel and a Seraph; three days and nights without sleep will not harm him at all. But I am flesh and blood, simple, and it is impossible for me to exist without sleep!" Immediately, our Rebbe left the room.
The "Guter Yid" asked his attendant to close the door well, for the Rav of Sanz does not tire or weary, and he will certainly come again, "and I truly need some rest." Not a few moments passed, and our Rebbe knocked again on the door. But seeing that it was closed, he turned and walked away, saying to his men: "How is it possible to separate even for a moment from such a holy Jew!"
Source: Rabbi Yosef Dovid Weisberg z"l, "Rabbeinu HaKadosh M'Sanz" (Jerusalem 5738), Vol. 3, p. 45

(HaRah"ch R' Chaim Shmuel Walhendler *n"y*) told me that he heard from the Tchakava Rav *z"l* that he met a man in Russia who told him that his grandfather had no children for many years after his wedding. He and his wife went to the holy Rebbe of Sanz to bless them with children. The woman pleaded greatly with the holy Rebbe. The holy Rebbe told her to come every morning to remind him of the matter. The woman did so, and every morning she came to ask that the holy Rebbe promise her she would be saved.
Once, she had a quarrel with her neighbor. The neighbor told her: "Even if you go for another ten years to the holy Rebbe, you will not be saved." When the woman heard this, her heart broke within her, and she went to the holy Rebbe with a bitter heart and told the holy Rebbe what her neighbor had said to her.
When the holy Rebbe of Sanz heard what she told, he commanded that they call the holy Rebbe, the "Guter Yid," who was then in Sanz, to his room. When the "Guter Yid" entered, the holy Rebbe of Sanz *zt"l* told him: "This woman is still not saved with children, and I wanted to do her a favor. I told her to come here every morning to remind about the matter. Her neighbor told her that if she goes for another ten years, she will not be saved." Thus the holy Rebbe of Sanz told the "Guter Yid" three times.
The woman went from the holy Rebbe to her home and said to her husband that it seems they can be saved through the "Guter Yid." "Therefore, I ask of you to go to the 'Guter Yid' and remind yourself." The man, who was attached to the holy Rebbe of Sanz, did not want to go to another Rebbe. However, he could not withstand his wife's urging, and he went to the "Guter Yid." The "Guter Yid" took a paper and wrote an amulet (*Kamea*) for him. Afterward, they were saved with a male child. He was the grandfather of the man who told the story to the Tchakava Rav. He showed him the amulet, and it was written in it: "Yosef Baruch son of Malka Ratil" (and nothing more).
Source: HaRah"g R' Yisrael Chaim Ashri Shlita, "Siach Zekeinim" (Brooklyn 5758), Vol. 2, p. 16

Once, the holy Rebbe of Sanz was in Neustadt. The "Guter Yid" asked him: "In-law (*Mechutan*), I ask of you not as a Rebbe, but only as a Rav: Do we have a guarantee (*Arvus*) for the transgressors of Israel?"
The holy Rebbe of Sanz placed his head on the table. After a few minutes, he said: "**איך האב א דורך געווארפן** - **'I have reviewed'** [I have gone through] everything relevant to this matter, and we do not have a guarantee for them."
The "Guter Yid" then presented 18 reasons why [we should have a guarantee] for the sake of this honor.
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yissachar Ber Rotenberg zt"l, Av Beis Din of Wodislaw, "Siach Zekeinim" (Brooklyn 5754), Vol. 1, p. 210

I heard from my master, my father (the holy Rebbe Rabbi Tzvi Hirsch of Rudnik *zy"a*), that he heard from the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yosef of Neustadt *zt"l* (son of the "Maor VaShemesh," who was still by the holy Rebbe of Lublin and in his old age basked in the shadow of the holy Rebbe of Sanz). He said that in Lublin, there were four hundred residents of the villages who possessed the Holy Spirit (*Ruach HaKodesh*). One of the listeners asked: "If so, how is it possible that such a holy gathering did not bring the Messiah?"
The Rabbi (R' Yosef) answered him: "This is because they did not feel the urgency of the matter, for the lack was not felt there at all." All the listeners were astonished to hear this.
To explain the matter, it seems to me: Behold, it is clear that such Tzaddikim, in whose eyes all trappings of authority and desire for wealth and honor were mockery and derision, did not intend in their request for Redemption for material goals, Heaven forbid. Rather, they saw that due to the yoke of the nations and the exiles and the increase of impurity, a Jew has obstacles and trials that are difficult to withstand, and it is difficult to conduct oneself as a Jew. But when the Messiah comes, it will be "In order that glory may sing praise to You and not be silent," etc., and they will be able to serve G-d out of rest and tranquility. Because of this, they longed so much for his coming.
As our Sages said (Berachos 34b): **אין בין העולם הזה לימות המשיח אלא שעבוד מלכיות בלבד** - **"There is no difference between this world and the days of the Messiah except for subjugation to kingdoms alone."** And so the Rambam explains explicitly (Kings 12:4): **לא נתאוו החכמים והנביאים ימות המשיח לא כדי שישלטו על כל העולם ולא כדי שירדו בעכו"ם ולא כדי שינשאו אותם העמים ולא כדי לאכול ולשתות ולשמוח אלא כדי שיהיו פנויין בתורה ובחכמתה ולא יהיה להם נוגש ומבטל כדי שיזכו לחיי העולם הבא כמו שבארנו בהלכות תשובה** - **"The Sages and Prophets did not desire the days of the Messiah, not so that they would rule over the whole world, nor so that they would dominate the heathens, nor so that the nations would exalt them, nor to eat and drink and rejoice. Rather, so that they would be free for Torah and its wisdom, and there would be no oppressor or negator for them, so that they would merit the life of the World to Come, as we explained in the Laws of Repentance."**
However, there in Lublin, there was such a revelation that even four hundred villagers merited the Holy Spirit. And all the more so the Holy Fellowship, and the holy Elder of Sanz testified that in Lublin, when they danced, the walls literally shook. It was possible to recognize this on a cup of water. The holiness shone there like the sun at noon. And as soon as they longed "For the light of Your face upon us You lifted," they merited it immediately. Therefore, it is no wonder that they did not feel to what extent it is necessary to hasten the coming of the Messiah.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Sanz-Klausenburg Ztzuk"l, "Ra'ava D'Ra'avin", Tetzaveh 5741, "Divrei Torah", Gilyon 448, p. 2

The "Guter Yid" of Neustadt wanted to travel to Eretz Yisrael. The Chassidim pleaded with him not to travel, but they could not influence him. They spoke with the holy Rebbe of Sanz that he should speak with him and influence him.
The holy Rebbe of Sanz said to him: "Such dear Chassidim, dear children, and you leave them?"
The "Guter Yid" said to him: "Did not the Rebbe [the holy Rebbe R' Moshe'le of Lelov] also travel in his old age to Eretz Yisrael?"
The holy Rebbe of Sanz said: "Ho ho, R' Moshe'le Lelover! Who can compare himself to R' Moshe'le? Three years before he traveled, he was already not in this world."
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yissachar Ber Rotenberg zt"l, Av Beis Din of Wodislaw, "Siach Zekeinim" (Brooklyn 5754), Vol. 1, p. 210

The Chassidic Rabbi R' Chaim Shmuel Walhendler *n"y* told me: The holy Rebbe of Chenstchin was very angry when he heard people saying that his grandfather, the "Guter Yid," could not learn. He told that once the holy Rebbe of Sanz was in Neustadt with his son-in-law, the Gaon and Tzaddik R' Yodel of Kaminka *zt"l*. They argued in the Beis Medrash regarding the understanding of the *Pshat* (simple meaning) in a certain Tosafos.
In the midst of the discussion, the "Guter Yid" entered and saw that they were debating words of Torah. He said to them: "There is a time for Torah separately, and a time for prayer separately." The holy Rebbe of Sanz said to him: "We do not pray except from a decided Halacha" [and since he does not know the *Pshat*, he cannot stand and pray].
The "Guter Yid" said to him: "Nu, explain to me where it is difficult." He showed him the Tosafos. The "Guter Yid" said: "With us (*Unz*), we learn first Gemara, and then Rashi, and then Tosafos." [Meaning: We study first Gemara, then Rashi, then Tosafos]. He began to study the Gemara (the holy Rebbe of Chenstchin showed how his grandfather placed his fingers on the Gemara, and thus he studied as he moved his fingers on the lines). Afterward the Rashi. In the middle of his study of the Rashi, the holy Rebbe of Sanz jumped up [and said] that the Tosafos was already clear to him.
Afterward, when the holy Rebbe of Sanz left there, his son-in-law R' Yodel asked him: "Why did you ask the 'Guter Yid'? After all, he could have remained in the middle of the matter without the possibility of continuing the matter." The holy Rebbe of Sanz said to him: "It is brought that Torah and Prayer without fear and love do not fly upward. **ווי ווער לערענט היינט תורה לשמה** - **'Where is there one who studies Torah today for its own sake?'** [Meaning: Where is there one who studies Torah today *Lishma*?] Therefore, just as all the prayers come to the 'Guter Yid' that he should elevate them, for he is the Tzaddik of the generation, so too all the Torahs come to him that he should elevate them. And he elevates them level by level." (Consequently, he is great in Torah).
Source: HaRah"g R' Yisrael Chaim Ashri Shlita, "Siach Zekeinim" (Brooklyn 5758), Vol. 2, p. 14

I heard that the holy Gaon, Light of the Diaspora, Rabbi Meir Yechiel of Ostrovtza *zy"a*, told a story from the holy Gaon Rabbi Chaim of Sanz *ztzuk"l*. Once, he made a *Siyum HaShas* (completion of the Talmud), but he could not perform the *Siyum* in any way because one Tosafos in a certain place was very difficult for him. It arose in his mind that he should travel to the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yosele of Neustadt *zy"a*, known as "Der Guter Yid fun Neustadt," and there he would make the *Siyum*, for he was sure that the holy Rebbe of Neustadt would tell him the explanation of the words of Tosafos.
Even though he was not considered a scholar (*Lamdan*) and Gaon, but rather a Tzaddik and holy man—and even on Shabbos he would not say any Torah, only take into his hands the book "Maor VaShemesh" from his holy father *zt"l* and read in it, etc.—nevertheless, when the holy Rebbe, author of "Divrei Chaim" *zy"a*, came there and received "Shalom," he told him immediately that he came here to make a *Siyum HaShas*, because one Tosafos was difficult for him, and "Your Honor should answer it for me."
The holy Rebbe R' Yosele aforementioned said to him that he does not understand at all how it is possible to study the entire Shas, even for the greatest scholar. He told the Rebbe of Neustadt that even to finish the Book of Psalms is very difficult for him, and with all his strenuous efforts, he finishes all the Psalms in a full month or more. Because of this, he does not know how a person can finish the entire Shas.
The holy Rebbe, author of "Divrei Chaim" *zy"a*, said to him: "Perhaps Your Honor wants to exchange with me? I will give him the reward of all the study of the Shas, and Your Honor will give me the reward of the completion of all the Psalms of his that he finished once." He was silent and did not answer him at all. I understood from this that he had no desire at all to exchange with me, for as it seems, in his eyes, his completion of Psalms was greater than my completion of the entire Shas.
After this, they sat together to study the Gemara with the aforementioned Tosafos. Immediately when the holy Rebbe of Neustadt *zy"a* studied the Gemara and afterward the Tosafos, he stopped in the middle of the matter of the Tosafos and finished the matter of the Tosafos in the middle. Afterward, he began to study further. Automatically, the words of Tosafos were settled with simplicity.
The holy Rebbe R' Chaim *zt"l* was frightened and amazed. For according to how the holy Rebbe of Neustadt studied the Tosafos, that here he finished the previous matter and here he began another matter, everything was settled. We can learn a great moral lesson from this: Our Rebbe Chaim of Sanz *zt"l* was truly a very great Gaon, and also holy and a famous Tzaddik in the whole world. Nevertheless, he did not understand the intention of the Tosafos until the "Guter Yid of Neustadt" came and studied the true explanation of the Tosafos immediately. Look and see how far things reach. And a greater wonder is that our Rebbe the holy Gaon Rabbi Chaim *zt"l* knew beforehand that he would answer everything for him, even though he was not a scholar and Gaon like him. He only understood that the holy Rebbe R' Chaim *zt"l*, due to the magnitude of his righteousness, would learn the Tosafos correctly immediately, and so it was.
Source: HaGaon HaChassid Rabbi Gershon Emanuel Stashevsky z"l, "Gedulat HaTzaddikim" (Bnei Brak 5758), p. 26, Letter Aleph

The Chassidic Rabbi R' Chaim Shmuel Walhendler *n"y* told me that he heard from the holy Rebbe of Chenstchin *zt"l* that the holy Rebbe of Sanz was in Neustadt three times. He said that the "Guter Yid" did not give a *Kvitel* (note of request) to the holy Rebbe of Sanz, even though he was a Chassid of his. This was because after the passing of the holy Rebbe, the Chozeh [of Lublin], he did not want to give a *Kvitel* to any Tzaddik.
However, the holy Rebbe of Sanz gave a *Kvitel* to the "Guter Yid" when he came to Neustadt. The Rebbe of Chenstchin told a novelty: Before the "Guter Yid" took the *Kvitel* to read, he took his holy pipe in his mouth. The holy Rebbe of Sanz bent himself down to light the pipe. The "Guter Yid" did not react at all; he was only occupied with his service.
Source: HaRah"g R' Yisrael Chaim Ashri Shlita, "Siach Zekeinim" (Brooklyn 5758), Vol. 2, p. 15

C.K. my grandfather (the holy Rebbe, author of "Divrei Chaim" of Sanz *zy"a*) said to the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yossele of Neustadt *zt"l*: "My Chassidim are patient; they accept my sufferings with love."
R' Yossele said afterward to the Chassidim who went to accompany him to his lodging (for this conversation was in the village near Sanz where my grandfather stayed then, and R' Yossele's lodging was in an attic, and they were forced to go up there by a ladder because there were no stairs. He said he enjoyed it very much there because my grandfather did not have the strength to go to accompany him to the lodging, for in the city he walked with him to the lodging). R' Yossele rebuked them that this was an injustice on their part, that they do not pierce the heavens for the sake of our Rebbe [=the "Divrei Chaim"], for we have no one else like him in the world today.
The Chassidim answered the Rebbe (R' Yossele). He replied to them: "This is not so. Who am I? When I was a young man, they obeyed me (in Heaven). But nevertheless, if our Rebbe wanted, he would not have suffering. My intention is simply that if he does not strike (with his foot), he will not have the suffering. But it is possible that he is not to blame for this; he forgets that it hurts him."
The Chassidim answered that my grandfather eats little due to the suffering of his leg. R' Yossele said: "It became known to you today that he cannot eat, but I have already known this for about four or five years."
When I parted from him then, and it was seventeen days before Tammuz, he warned me not to fast the next day due to the trouble of the way. I asked him: "But I see that the Rebbe fasts a lot?" He replied to me: "If the food were good for me, I would not fast any fast except for Yom Kippur. **נאר וואס זאל איך טוהן אז איך קען שוין נישט שמעקן ציא קיין שום מאכל** - **'But what shall I do if I can no longer stand the smell of any food?'** (But what shall I do that I cannot tolerate any food)."
When my grandfather returned to his health, he made a meal of thanksgiving. R' Yossele of Neustadt said that he wanted to complain against our Rebbe for not sending to inform him that he was making the meal, for he would have hurried to come. The Chassidim began to tell him that it was a large meal and the crowd wore *Streimels* and closed the shops, etc. R' Yossele said: "That is not our intention. Rather, we heard that it was very beautiful in Heaven." (HaRav MiGrabowitz).
Source: The Holy Rebbe Rabbi Sinai of Zhmigrod Zy"a, "Chemdah Genuzah" (Brooklyn 5758), p. 131

Our Rebbe (the "Divrei Chaim" of Sanz) and the "Guter Yid" of Neustadt traveled together in a wagon. A beam protruded from the wagon, and the children jumped on it. One child jumped on it then. Our Rebbe (the "Divrei Chaim") asked the "Guter Yid" to pray that this child would have sons. Many years later, they understood his intention, for many adventures passed over him until he was blessed with viable offspring. (I heard from the mouth of my father-in-law *zt"l*).
Source: C.K. Maran Admor M'Pshevorsk Ztzuk"l, "Yud Gimmel Oros" (Brooklyn 5754), Vol. 1, p. 71

The "Guter Yid" was once in Sanz. On Friday night (Shabbos Kodesh), a long time passed until the holy Rebbe came to the Table. The Rabbis conversed among themselves: Why does the holy Rebbe of Sanz make such a fuss over the "Guter Yid," for he was not famous as a scholar (*Lamdan*). Within the time of speech, the holy Rebbe entered together with the "Guter Yid." The "Guter Yid" said to the holy Rebbe: "In-law (*Mechutan*) [his grandson, the holy Rebbe of Chenstchin, was the son-in-law of the holy Rebbe R' Yosha the son of the 'Baruch Taam'], I want to ask you: Why do they make such a fuss about the fish? For example, they ask: 'Do you already have fish for the honor of Shabbos Kodesh?' and the like."
The holy Rebbe of Sanz did not answer anything, for he understood that he wanted to continue. The "Guter Yid" concluded: "Only I think it is because they never tasted [sin]."
Source: HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yissachar Ber Rotenberg zt"l, Av Beis Din of Wodislaw, "Siach Zekeinim" (Brooklyn 5754), Vol. 1, p. 210

The Admor of Chenstchin once visited the home of the holy Rebbe Rabbi Yeshaya of Tchechoyv *ztzuk"l*, and the two of them amused themselves together for some time. Upon leaving, the Admor spoke to his intimates: Our Rebbe, the "Divrei Chaim," sought to learn the secret of the conduct of simplicity from my holy grandfather, the "Guter Yid" of Neustadt, and stayed with him together for a few days for this purpose.
On Thursday, they went out together to buy chickens for the honor of Shabbos. My grandfather, the "Guter Yid," lingered by each and every bird to examine it from all its sides, while our Rebbe, the "Divrei Chaim," stood and observed his actions and his inner intentions. Finally, my grandfather turned to him and said: "Rav of Sanz! Do not the greats of Hungary rise early to open [their doors]? This path is not suitable for you!"
The "Divrei Chaim" replied to him: "If so, then I will leave this conduct to my seed." The Admor of Chenstchin concluded that it seems the Rav of Sanz intended in his words to Rabbi Yeshaya, for indeed he is the one who conducts himself with simplicity in the ways of his life.
Source: Rabbi Yosef Dovid Weisberg z"l, "Rabbeinu HaKadosh M'Sanz" (Jerusalem 5740), Vol. 2, p. 410

He (the holy Rebbe of Neustadt *zy"a*) sought at the end of his years to ascend to Eretz Yisrael. He had already set out on his way and arrived in the city of Krakow, where he prostrated himself on the grave of his father, the "Maor VaShemesh." Surprisingly, he decided at that gathering to return on his tracks. Afterward, it became known that the ship on which he was supposed to sail to Eretz Yisrael sank in the sea with its people. And it was a miracle.
Source: Rabbi Aharon Sorosky Shlita, "BeLabat Eish" (Bnei Brak 5745), Vol. 1, p. 206

**Biography**
My grandfather *ztzuk"l* of Zvolin told in the name of the holy Rebbe R' Yossele of Neustadt *ztzuk"l* that it is a puzzling matter: What is the idea of this feast that the Holy One, Blessed be He, is destined to make for the righteous in the future to come, from the Wild Ox (*Shor HaBar*) and the Leviathan and the Preserved Wine? How is it possible that physical things like these are for the future to come, which is entirely spiritual?
He said: The explanation is that for the World to Come, the righteous could say: "Who knows? Perhaps the enjoyment of this world was also good like the World to Come? For we never tasted nor had the opportunity like the mighty rich ones of the world who delighted in the delicacies of the material world." Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, is destined to make a feast for the righteous in the future to come, first, before the World to Come, a feast of the materiality of this world—the Wild Ox which grazes on a thousand mountains, and the Leviathan, and the Wine preserved in its grapes from the six days of Creation. Afterward, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will give them from the abundance of good hidden for the World to Come, which is in the Garden of Eden, from all the spirituality and the attainment of the radiance of the Shechinah. Then they will recognize and know to distinguish between the holy and the profane, that material pleasure is like withering grass and grass that fades, while the delight of the soul is spirituality cleaving to the Life of Eternity. And each one will say: "This is fitting for me," and point with his finger: "This is my G-d and I will glorify Him," etc.
Source: "Imrei Shaul" (Modzitz), Shavuot, p. 119b

**Biography**
The holy Rebbe Rabbi Avraham Zerach Aryeh Yehuda Leib Halperin of Brezhan *zy"a* was born in the year 5608 (1848) to his father Rabbi Meshulam Shraga Feivish, and to his mother Mrs. Chana, the only daughter of Rabbi Asher Yeshaya of Ropshitz. In the year 5630 (1870), he married Mrs. Shlamtzi, daughter of Rabbi Yoel of Shatz, grandson of Rabbi Yechiel Michel the Maggid of Zlotchov, and son-in-law of Rabbi Meir of Premishlan. He was a disciple of our Rebbe [the "Divrei Chaim" of Sanz *zy"a*] and basked in his shadow for many years. In his book ["Imrei Yehuda"], p. 99, he testifies that he heard from him constantly saying: "There is no thought that can grasp Him at all," and he would say this quietly almost every single moment.
When his father passed away in the year 5634 (1874), he did not accede to the entreaties of the Chassidim to become Admor in his place. He agreed later only on the condition that he would serve them by bringing their *Kvitelach* (notes) to Sanz to our Rebbe. On his first trip to Sanz after his father's passing, they conversed about this, and our Rebbe [the "Divrei Chaim"] said to him: "When your father was alive, he was the Rebbe, and now we two will be Rebbes." As he said this, he embraced R' Aryeh Yehuda Leibish. But he was not impressed and asked him: "But how is it possible to do a favor for a Jew if someone comes to me with some request?" Our Rebbe replied to him: "When one feels his friend's trouble as if it were literally his own, one can do a favor by oneself." (See in his book, p. 93b, where he wrote in this version: "You should pray for him out of compassion that you will have for him, and through this, you will be able to arouse the mercies of Heaven for the man who asks.")
When Rabbi Leibish returned and said that together with our Rebbe he could accept upon himself, our Rebbe wondered at him and said to him: "Why do you speak so? After all, you will be, with G-d's help, a worker of salvations." Our Rebbe's wife listened to this conversation and hurried to write a *Kvitel* and hand it to R' Leibish. But he refused to accept it, claiming that in the house of the teacher of Israel, he does not accept *Kvitelach*. Upon his return to his home, he found the *Kvitel* there, which she had sent to him by express mail. In the attached letter, she wrote that although she had already heard several times how our Rebbe ordains, a semicha like his she had not yet heard.
Also, the Rebbe of Shinova once told the Rebbetzin that he heard from his father about R' Leibish that he was a great man, at the time he conversed about the intention of the writings of the Arizal regarding the knot of the head Tefillin.
During the period of his residence in Brezhan, the rabbinate of the city was not held by the family. However, when the Maharsham served there, he conducted himself in several matters as if the presumption of the rabbinate belonged to the Halperin family, and he did nothing regarding matters of ritual slaughter (*Shochatim*) and the Mikveh without receiving the consent of R' Leibish. When the Maharsham passed away, Rabbi Shraga Feivish Halperin, Av Beis Din of Zavia, was accepted in his place as Rav over the face of his father, the Admor R' Leibish.
