Towards Rosh Hashanah of the year 5619 (1859), the Rabbi of Biala (father of the holy Gaon, author of *Avnei Nezer* zt"l) traveled to Kotzk to take shelter in the shadow of the *Saraph* (Fiery Angel), as was his custom from days of yore. On the eve of Rosh Hashanah, Rabbi Zev Nachum entered the room of the Rebbe to wish him peace. Within the conversation, the Rebbe began to speak about the high level of the *Chiddushei HaRim*, and said that it is a great pity for a Jew like him who has so much merchandise to sell and has no one to sell it to (Ohr Pnei Yitzchak p. 23, letter 16, in the name of Hrh"ch R' Elyakim Getzel HaLevi Frankl zt"l, of Bendin).
A few months later, on the 22nd of Shevat, the *Saraph* passed away to the High Heavens. The *Chiddushei HaRim* began to lead a congregation then, and the Rabbi of Biala accepted his authority upon himself, as did his son the *Avnei Nezer*, and as did most of the important Chassidim of Kotzk. Rabbi Zev Nachum was very close to the Rebbe of Gur, who valued him greatly.
For seven years, the Rebbe of Gur led the congregation—"The Seven Years of Plenty" as they were called by the Chassidim—until the 23rd of Adar in the year 5626 (1866). With his passing, Rabbi R' Chanoch Henoch, "The High Priest from Alexander," filled his place.
The *Agudat Ezov*, who did not know him intimately from before, wrote a letter to his son who was then serving in the Rabbinate of Kroshnovitz, asking him if he knew the Rebbe R' Henoch. Since he surely heard in Kotzk that one who is not expert in the four parts of Shulchan Aruch cannot lead a congregation, [he asked] if indeed the new Rebbe was great in Torah as well. The *Avnei Nezer* replied in a letter to his father that indeed, he is a very great man and an outstanding Torah scholar, and that he was already traveling to him as a Chassid.
When Rabbi Zev Nachum received his son's letter, he too traveled to Alexander, and from then on, he was counted among the Chassidim of the Rebbe R' Henoch (Abir HaRo'im Part 2, Siman 321). But the days of the reign of the Rebbe of Alexander were not long, and on the 18th of Adar II, 5630 (1870), he passed away to his eternal home.
A select portion of the Chassidim who were still considered "Lions of the Group" in Kotzk turned to the son-in-law of the *Saraph*, who was serving at that time as the Rabbi of Kroshnovitz, and asked him to agree to accept the leadership of Chassidim upon himself. At first, the *Avnei Nezer* refused, but after some time, he agreed to accept upon himself the leadership of a small and select congregation of "Bnei Aliyah" (men of high spiritual standing), for whom there was nothing in their world but the four cubits of Halacha. Indeed, the matter succeeded in his hand, and he paved for himself an original path in leadership, which was indeed rooted in the paths of Kotzk, but he refined it and smelted it according to his own way.
A Chassidic leadership in a new style came into the world then: A path of serving Hashem through Torah study with exertion, with the fire of the soul, enthusiasm, and joy, out of holiness and purity. As the famous words of the *Avnei Nezer* in the introduction to his book *Eglei Tal*: "That the main part of Torah study is to be rejoicing and happy in his study, and then the words of Torah are absorbed in his blood."
In Kroshnovitz, a group of outstanding scholars, Chassidim, and men of action gathered, who were immersed in Torah all day long. Even when they traveled as Chassidim to their Rebbe, they sheltered in the tent of Torah, and the Beit Midrash resembled a Yeshiva to a great extent. Indeed, the *Avnei Nezer* continued simultaneously to lead his famous Yeshiva, where he disseminated Torah to the prodigies among the youth of Poland, according to his unique method of study known in the Torah world as "The Sochatchov Method of Study."

מִשֶּׁקִּבֵּל רַבִּי זְאֵב נַחוּם אֶת אִגֶּרֶת בְּנוֹ, נָסַע אַף הוּא לַאֲלֶכְּסַנְדֶּר וּמֵאָז הוּא נִמְנָה עַל חֲסִידָיו שֶׁל הָרַבִּי ר' הֶענִיךְ (אֲבִיר הָרוֹעִים ח"ב, סִי' שכ"א) אַךְ לֹא אָרְכוּ יְמֵי מַמְלַכְתּוֹ שֶׁל הָרַבִּי מֵאֲלֶכְּסַנְדֶּר, וּבְחַ"י אד"ש שְׁנַת תר"ל הוּא נִסְתַּלֵּק לְבֵית עוֹלָמוֹ.חֵלֶק מֻבְחָר שֶׁל הַחֲסִידִים שֶׁנֶּחְשְׁבוּ עוֹד בְּקוֹצְק לַאֲרָיוֹת שֶׁבַּחֲבוּרָה, פָּנוּ אֶל חֲתָנוֹ שֶׁל הַשָּׂרָף שֶׁשִּׁמֵּשׁ אוֹתָהּ עֵת כְּרַבָּהּ שֶׁל קְרוֹשְׁנוֹבִיץ, וּבִקְשׁוּהוּ שֶׁיֵּאוֹת לְקַבֵּל עָלָיו עֹל הַנְהָגַת חֲסִידִים. מִתְּחִלָּה סֵרֵב הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר", אַךְ לְאַחַר זְמַן מַה נֵאוֹת לְקַבֵּל עָלָיו הַנְהָגַת עֵדָה קְטַנָּה וּמֻבְחֶרֶת שֶׁל בְּנֵי עֲלִיָּה, אֲשֶׁר אֵין לָהֶם בְּעוֹלָמָם אֶלָּא ד' אַמּוֹת שֶׁל הֲלָכָה בִּלְבַד. וְאָמְנָם הַדָּבָר עָלָה בְּיָדוֹ, וְהוּא פִּלֵּס לוֹ נָתִיב מְקוֹרִי בַּהַנְהָגָה, אֲשֶׁר שָׁרְשׁוֹ נָעוּץ אָמְנָם בִּנְתִיבוֹתֶי' שֶׁל קוֹצְק, אַךְ הוּא שִׁכְלְלוֹ וּצְרָפוֹ ע"פ דַּרְכּוֹ.
הַנְהָגָה חֲסִידִית בְּנֹסַח חָדָשׁ בָּאָה אָז לָעוֹלָם, דֶּרֶךְ שֶׁל עֲבוֹדַת ה' ע"י לִמּוּד הַתּוֹרָה בִּיגִיעָה, בְּלַהַט הַנֶּפֶשׁ, הִתְלַהֲבוּת וְשִׂמְחָה מִתּוֹךְ קְדֻשָּׁה וְטָהֳרָה, כִּדְבָרָיו הַמְפֻרְסָמִים שֶׁל הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" בְּהַקְדָּמַת סִפְרוֹ "אֶגְלֵי טַל": "שֶׁעִקַּר לִמּוּד הַתּוֹרָה לִהְיוֹת שָׂשׂ וְשָׂמֵחַ בְּלִמּוּדוֹ, וְאָז דִּבְרֵי תּוֹרָה נִבְלָעִים בְּדָמוֹ". בִּקְרוֹשְׁנוֹבִיץ נִתְקַבְּצָה חֲבוּרָה שֶׁל לַמְדָנִים מֻפְלָגִים, חֲסִידִים וְאַנְשֵׁי מַעֲשֶׂה, שֶׁהָיוּ שְׁקוּעִים בְּמֶשֶׁךְ כָּל הַיּוֹם בַּתּוֹרָה. גַּם כַּאֲשֶׁר נָסְעוּ כַּחֲסִידִים אֶל רַבָּם הִסְתּוֹפְפוּ בְּאָהֳלָהּ שֶׁל תּוֹרָה, וּבֵית הַמִּדְרָשׁ דָּמָה בְּמִדָּה רַבָּה לִישִׁיבָה. וְאָמְנָם הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" הִמְשִׁיךְ בַּד בְּבַד לְנַהֵל אֶת יְשִׁיבָתוֹ הַמְפֹרֶסֶת בָּהּ הִרְבִּיץ תּוֹרָה לְעִלּוּיִים שֶׁבֵּין צְעִירֵי פּוֹלִין, עפ"י שִׁיטַת לִמּוּדוֹ הַמְיֻחֶדֶת הַיְּדוּעָה בָּעוֹלָם הַתּוֹרָנִי כְּ"שִׁיטַת הַלִּמּוּד הַסּוֹכַטְשׁוֹבִית".
גַּם אָבִיו הָרַב מִבִּיאַלֶה שֶׁדֶּרֶךְ זוֹ הָיְתָה דַּרְכּוֹ מֵאָז, קִבֵּל עָלָיו אֶת מָרוּת בְּנוֹ וְנָסַע אֵלָיו כְּחָסִיד לְכָל דָּבָר. חֲסִידִים שֶׁבְּאוֹתוֹ הַדּוֹר אָמְרוּ שֶׁקָּשֶׁה לְתָאֵר אֶת גֹּדֶל הַהַכְנָעָה שֶׁהָיְתָה לוֹ לְרַב מִבִּיאַלֶה בִּפְנֵי בְּנוֹ, וּבְאֵיזֶה בִּטּוּל הָי' יוֹשֵׁב לְפָנָיו בְּשֻׁלְחָנוֹ הַטָּהוֹר (שָׁם סִי' שכ"ב). כַּמָּה מַאֲלֵף הַדָּבָר שֶׁהַ"אֲגֻדַּת אֵזוֹב" שֶׁהָי' בְּעַצְמוֹ מִגְּדוֹלֵי הַדּוֹר, יִתְבַּטֵּל בְּצוּרָה שֶׁכָּזוֹ בִּפְנֵי הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" שֶׁהָי' בְּנוֹ וְגַם תַּלְמִידוֹ הַמֻּבְהָק! מֵאִידָךְ גִּיסָא גַּם הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" שֶׁהֶעֱרִיךְ מְאֹד אֶת אָבִיו, אֶת גְּדֻלָּתוֹ בַּתּוֹרָה וְאֶת קְדֻשָּׁתוֹ וְצִדְקָתוֹ, הָי' מְכַבְּדוֹ מְאֹד. בַּפַּעַם הָרִאשׁוֹנָה שֶׁבָּא הָרַב מִבִּיאַלֶה לְשֻׁלְחַן בְּנוֹ, סֵרֵב הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" לָשֶׁבֶת בְּרֹאשׁ הַשֻּׁלְחָן וְרָצָה לְפַנּוֹת אֶת מְקוֹמוֹ לְאָבִיו. אַךְ רַבִּי זְאֵב נַחוּם סֵרֵב וּבְסוֹפוֹ שֶׁל דָּבָר הִצִּיבוּ שְׁתֵּי כִּסְאוֹת בְּרֹאשׁ הַשֻּׁלְחָן וּשְׁנֵיהֶם יָשְׁבוּ בָּרֹאשׁ [מִפִּי מוֹהֲרַ"ר אַהֲרֹן יִשְׂרָאֵל בּוֹרְנְשְׁטֵין (שליט"א) [ז"ל] שֶׁשָּׁמַע מֵהַגָּהַ"ח מוֹהֲרַ"ר יִצְחָק מְנַחֵם בּוֹרְנְשְׁטֵין זַצַ"ל מִשֶּׁדְלִיץ]. וְעוֹד זֹאת, כַּאֲשֶׁר הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" הָי' שׁוֹמֵעַ שֶׁאָבִיו עוֹמֵד לָבוֹא אֵלָיו לְבַקְּרוֹ, הָי' נוֹסֵעַ מֶרְחָק שֶׁל עֲשֶׂרֶת ק"מ מִחוּץ לָעִיר, בִּכְדֵי לְקַבֵּל אֶת פָּנָיו (אֵלֶּה תּוֹלְדוֹת לְהַרַה"ח ר' יִצְחָק יַעֲקֹב אֶרְלִיךְ זַ"ל, ח"א עמ' 22). גַּם הַתּוֹאָרִים בָּהֶם מַכְתִּיר הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" אֶת אָבִיו, אֵין כִּמְעַט בְּדוֹמֶה לָהֶם אֶצְלוֹ, וְיָדוּעַ עַד כַּמָּה מְדַקְדֵּק הָי' בְּכָל תֹּאַר. הוּא כּוֹתֵב אֵלָיו "הָרַב הַגָּאוֹן הַגָּדוֹל" "הֶחָסִיד הַמְפֻרְסָם" "נֵר יִשְׂרָאֵל" "עַמּוּד הַיְמִינִי" "פְּאֵר הַדּוֹר" "הַמָּאוֹר הַגָּדוֹל" "סִינַי וְעוֹקֵר הָרִים" "הֶחָרִיף וְהַבָּקִי" "כְּבוֹד קְדֻשַּׁת" וְכַיּוֹ"ב [אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר אוֹ"ח ב' סִי' תנ"ג, תפ"ד, חוּ"מ סִי' נה, קל"א וְעוֹד]. הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" הָיָה גַּם פּוֹנֶה אֵלָיו לְעִתִּים קְרוֹבוֹת לְקַבֵּל מִמֶּנּוּ חַוּוֹת דַּעְתּוֹ בְּעִנְיְנֵי הֲלָכָה.
כְּחָסִיד אֲמִתִּי נִמְנַע הָרַב מִבִּיאַלֶה מִלּוֹמַר לִבְנוֹ אֶת דַּעְתּוֹ בְּעִנְיָנִים שׁוֹנִים, אַף שֶׁלְּעִתִּים מָצָא לְנָכוֹן לַעֲשׂוֹת כֵּן. וּמַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁהִצִּיעוּ לִפְנֵי הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" אֶת רַבָּנוּת נַאשֶׁלְסְק בְּעֵת שֶׁכִּהֵן כְּרַב בִּקְרוֹשְׁנוֹבִיץ וְדַעְתּוֹ נָטְתָה לְקַבֵּל אֶת הַהַצָּעָה. דַּעַת הַ"אֲגֻדַּת אֵזוֹב" לֹא הָיְתָה נוֹחָה מִכָּךְ, אַךְ הוּא לֹא רָצָה לְלוֹמַר מְאוּמָה. אָמְנָם זֹאת עָשָׂה, הוּא נָסַע לַגָּאוֹן הַמְפֻרְסָם רַבִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל יְהוֹשֻׁעַ מִקּוּטְנָא, וּבִקְשׁוֹ שֶׁיִּרְאֶה לִפְעֹל אֵצֶל בְּנוֹ לְבַל יַעֲזֹב אֶת קְרוֹשְׁנוֹבִיץ. אַךְ הַגָּאוֹן מִקּוּטְנָא עָנָה לוֹ שֶׁגַּם הוּא מְעֻנְיָן שֶׁהַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" יִשָּׁאֵר בִּקְרוֹשְׁנוֹבִיץ שֶׁהָיְתָה סְמוּכָה לְקוּטְנָא, וְכָךְ יְכוֹלִים הֵם לְבַקֵּר אִישׁ אֶת רֵעֵהוּ לְעִתִּים קְרוֹבוֹת, אַךְ מֵכִּירָן שֶׁדַּעְתּוֹ שֶׁל הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" הִיא דַּעַת תּוֹרָה, אִם נוֹטֶה הוּא לְקַבֵּל אֶת רַבָּנוּת נַאשֶׁלְסְק אֵין הוּא יָכוֹל לַהֲנִיאוֹ מִכָּךְ, וְאָמְנָם הוּא נִתְקַבֵּל אָז לְרַבָּנוּת נַאשֶׁלְסְק (אֲבִיר הָרוֹעִים ח"א, סִי' ק"פ).הגה"ח רבי צבי יהודה מאמלאק הי"ד"אביר הרועים" (פיערטקוב תרצ"ו) ח"א, אות קל"ג

Rabbi Zev Nachum used to praise his son greatly and would exaggerate his greatness. He once said about him that he is a lion. And not just an ordinary lion, but a great lion. And not [just] a lion, but a "Lion of the Academy" (Ari D'bei Ilai).
"We do not understand at all what he says, and only in study with great depth and Heavenly assistance is it perhaps possible to understand his deep words." (Siach Sarfei Kodesh, Part 5, p. 102, Letter 35, in the name of the Gaon Mohar"r Chanoch Henoch Orner zt"l, Av Beit Din of Laskorov).
Source: Haga"tz Rabbi Reuven Menachem Bornstein zt"l, "Ka'erez U'cha'ezov" (Jerusalem 5754) p. 15

It was fluent in his mouth (of the Gaon Rabbi Shlomo Kalish zt"l) in the name of the *Avnei Nezer*: "When a person sits to learn, behold, before he has managed to learn three or four hours, the pipes of understanding have not yet opened for him... Only afterwards do the gates of understanding open... It turns out that one who learns three or four hours and... stops from his study is likened to a person knocking on the door for a long time, and when they finally open for him, he has already slipped away and is gone..."
He also used to say frequently in the name of his Rebbe, the *Avnei Nezer*: "A person who does not study the Tur with the Beit Yosef in depth does not know what the sweet taste of the Holy Torah is."
In the evening of his days, Rabbi Shlomo would reconstruct alive the sublime scene when the students sat in awe before the *Avnei Nezer* and listened to the flowing Torah novellae from his mouth, illuminating and joyful as if given from Sinai: "The Rebbe never removed the 'Spodik' from his head during study. And at the end of the summer, when it was very hot, if he wanted to remove the 'Spodik' a little and rest a bit—he first closed the Gemara."
"The Rebbe never touched the Gemara during study," Rabbi Shlomo told further, "Just as one is careful with a Sefer Torah." Even the students did not put their hands on the table and the open book, except when they reached the end of the page and needed to turn the pages.
Source: Rabbi Aharon Sorasky shlit"a, "Sefer HaZikaron - Zichron Shlomo" (Jerusalem 5754) p. 454

בַּעֲרוֹב יָמָיו הָיָה רַבִּי שְׁלֹמֹה מְשַׁחְזֵר חַי אֶת הַמַּעֲמָד הַנִּשְׂגָּב עֵת יָשְׁבוּ הַתַּלְמִידִים בְּאֵימָה וְיִרְאָה לִפְנֵי הָ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" וְהִקְשִׁיבוּ לְחִדּוּשֵׁי תּוֹרָה הַקּוֹלְחִים מִפִּיו מְאִירִים וּשְׂמֵחִים כִּנְתִינָתָן מִסִּינַי: "הָרַבִּי מֵעוֹלָם לֹא הֵסִיר מֵעַל רֹאשׁוֹ אֶת הַ"סְפּוֹדִיק" בְּעֵת הַלִּמּוּד, וּבְשִׁלְהֵי דְּקַיְטָא בְּעֵת שֶׁהָיָה חַם מְאֹד, אִם רָצָה לְהוֹרִיד מְעַט אֶת הַ"סְפּוֹדִיק" וְלָפוּשׁ קִמְעָא - סָגַר תְּחִלָּה אֶת הַגְּמָרָא".
"הָרַבִּי מֵעוֹלָם לֹא נָגַע בַּגְּמָרָא בְּעֵת הַלִּמּוּד" סִפֵּר עוֹד רַבִּי שְׁלֹמֹה "כְּדֶרֶךְ שֶׁנִּזְהָרִין בְּסֵפֶר תּוֹרָה". אַף הַתַּלְמִידִים לֹא שָׂמוּ אֶת יְדֵיהֶם עַל גַּבֵּי הַשֻּׁלְחָן וְהַסֵּפֶר הַפָּתוּחַ, מִלְּבַד כְּשֶׁהִגִּיעוּ לְסוֹף הָעַמּוּד, וְהוּצְרְכוּ לַהֲפֹךְ הַדַּפִּים.הרב אהרן סורסקי שליט"א"ספר הזכרון - זכרון שלמה" (ירושלים תשנ"ד) ע' תנ"ד
body_en:
My relative, the Rabbi and Gaon R' Yaakov Rotenberg shlit"a, told me that he heard from our grandfather, the Gaon and Tzaddik of Wodislaw zt"l, who heard from Rabbi Hilman, who told him that the Gaon R' Eliezer Gordon, Av Beit Din of Telz zt"l, once happened to be in the city of Sochatchov. Since he heard of the greatness of the *Avnei Nezer*, he calculated in his mind that now that he was in his city, he would enter to see him. And so he did.
When he entered the holy Rabbi's presence, he asked him: "Where are you from?"
He answered: "From Telz."
And immediately he asked him: "Where are you holding?" Meaning, in which Sugya (topic) are you engaged now?
He answered: "Berara" (Selection/Clarification). That is, the Sugya of Berara.
Because he knew this Sugya thoroughly.
When he heard what the holy Rabbi answered, he made a motion as if wiping his forehead and shouted: "Ah! Berara!" (When R' Eliezer told the story, he interrupted his speech in the pronunciation of the people of Poland). "I haven't learned this Sugya for twenty years!"
And he began to debate the Sugya. In the middle, he shouted and called for Shmuel ("Ruft arein Shmuel'n"), meaning his son, the holy Rabbi, the *Shem MiShmuel*. And so he continued to debate.
R' Eliezer concluded to Rabbi Hilman: "You know that Berara is *my* Sugya. In the beginning, I still understood what he was saying. When he reached the middle of the Pilpul, I already understood nothing."
Source: Hrh"g R' Yisrael Chaim Ashri shlit"a, "Siach Zekenim" (Brooklyn 5758) Part 2, p. 347

I know a story about a certain son of fathers who was once for a Shabbat stay with the C.K. Admor, the Rabbi, the holy Gaon, man of G-d, Mohar"a zt"l of Sochatchov, while he was in Otwock. He stood by his table during the Friday night meal and intended and prayed: "If only this Tzaddik would be my help to come to purity of character traits."
While he was standing thus, immersed in his thought, the holy Admor zt"l opened his holy mouth and said in these words exactly: "Vos hat etz zich farleygt oif mir, lernt un davent vet mimeila dos shlechts avek gein." [=Why do you rely on me? Learn and pray, and automatically the bad will go away.]
And I know that person; upon hearing these words, he was greatly frightened and his hair literally stood on end, for he saw that the Admor zt"l intended with his holy spirit towards him. For they were not accustomed to hearing such words from him. And I write these words of truth for the honor of the Torah.
[The son of the author, the publisher of the new edition (Rabbi Yitzchak HaKohen Feigenbaum zt"l), said: Since the incident was about a hundred years ago, I permit myself to reveal now, for I heard from the mouth of my father zt"l, that this story happened with my father, my teacher (Hrh"g R' Yisrael Isser HaKohen Feigenbaum Hy"d), the author of this book himself, zt"l.]
Source: "Ohr Pnei Yitzchak" (Jerusalem 5752) p. 117

body_he: [אָמַר בֶּן הַמְחַבֵּר, הַמּוֹ"ל מֵחָדָשׁ (הָרַב יִצְחָק הַכֹּהֵן פַיְיגֶנְבּוֹיְם זַ"ל), כַּאֲשֶׁר עֻבְדָּא זוֹ הָיְתָה בְּעֵרֶךְ לִפְנֵי כְּמֵאָה שָׁנָה, מַתִּיר אֲנִי לְעַצְמִי לְגַלּוֹת עַכְשָׁיו, כִּי שָׁמַעְתִּי מִפֶּה אָבִי זַ"ל, שֶׁהַמַּעֲשֶׂה הַזֶּה הָיָה עִם אָבִי מוֹרִי (הַרַהַ"ג ר' יִשְׂרָאֵל אִיסֶר הַכֹּהֵן פַיְיגֶנְבּוֹיְם הִי"ד) מְחַבֵּר הַסֵּפֶר הַזֶּה עַצְמוֹ, זי"ע.]"אור פני יצחק" (ירושלים תשנ"ב) ע' קי"ז
body_en:
Once, when I was a Rabbi in Wieruszow, I received a letter that C.K. Maran Admor (the *Avnei Nezer*) zt"l traveled to the Reinitz spa in the country of Ashkenaz (Germany). I traveled there immediately and was with him zt"l also on the holy Shabbat. He spoke with me then a lot about the conduct of the Rabbi of Kotzk zt"l. Afterwards, he said to me: "Know that I agreed to accept the Rabbinate because I thought that only a few hundred outstanding Torah scholars who have a connection with me would travel to me. If it were so, it would have been a great benefit for them materially and spiritually, and for me too, it would not have been such a disturbance. But did you not know that the way of Chassidim is to magnify their Rebbe and tell wonders about him? Through this, simple people, even craftsmen who have no connection with me at all, came to me. It was very difficult for me to hear their words and their requests, but I could not cast them away due to compassion. Through this, I had a great disturbance, for their main desire was only for material things—livelihood and health and the like—and this is no light matter.
Indeed, to make myself free from this army is an easy thing for me. When I study Gemara, and I ask a question and it is answered, *muz er freia veren* (he must become free). If the refutation did not arise in my heart to contradict the answer. And I will reveal to you that this is the secret of the words of the Gemara in Sanhedrin (30b): 'Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak had a strictness... and said: Throw a palm tree at him...' And he raised him up because by answering the words of the Gemara, he threw the palm tree that was casting him down to the ground, etc. etc.
But to heal a sick person where there is danger is a difficult thing, and this depends much on the character of the sick man. Once I received a telegram from Warsaw to bless a certain Torah scholar whom I know, who is dangerously ill. I was forced to take the Book of Psalms and I said some Psalms, and I knew immediately that he would be healed, and so it was. But for simple people with whom I have no connection, it is very difficult to save them, for I need to nullify myself for them," end of his holy words.
Source: Letter from Haga"tz Rabbi Shaul Moshe Zilberman zt"l, Av Beit Din of Wieruszow, printed in "Abir HaRo'im", at the beginning of Part 2

וְאָמְנָם שֶׁלַּעֲשׂוֹת חָפְשִׁי מִן הַצָּבָא זֶה דָּבָר קַל אֶצְלִי כַּאֲשֶׁר אֲנִי לוֹמֵד גְּמָ', וַאֲנִי מַקְשֶׁה קֻשְׁיָא וּמִתָּרְצָה אָזַי מוּז עֶר פְרַייא וֶוערֶען אִם לֹא עָלָה בְּלִבִּי לִסְתֹּר הַתֵּרוּץ, וַאֲגַלֶּה לְךָ שֶׁזֶּה סוֹד דִּבְרֵי הַגְּמָ' בְּסַנְהֶדְרִין (דַּף ל' ע"ב) דְּרַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק הָיָה לוֹ הַקְפָּדָה וְאָמַר דְּרָמֵי דִּיקְלָא וּזְקִיפְתּוֹ לְהוּ כִּי ע"י שֶׁהָיָה מְתָרֵץ דִּבְרֵי הַגְּמָ', הָיָה רָמֵי דִּיקְלָא שֶׁהָיָה מַשְׁלִיךְ לְהוּ אַרְצָה שֶׁלֹּא יוּכְלוּ לְהָרַע וְכוּ' וְכוּ'.
אֲבָל לְרַפְּאוֹת חוֹלֶה שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ סַכָּנָה הוּא דָּבָר קָשֶׁה וְזֶה תָּלוּי הַרְבֵּה בְּמִדּוֹת אִישׁ הַחוֹלֶה וּפַעַם אַחַת קִבַּלְתִּי ט"ג דּוֹלֵג רַב [=טֶלֶגְרָם] מִוָּוארְשָׁא שֶׁאַבְרֵךְ אֶחָד בֶּן תּוֹרָה שֶׁאֲנִי מַכִּירוֹ הוּא חוֹלֶה מְסֻכָּן וְלֹא הָיָה לִי עֵצָה עֲבוּרוֹ עַד שֶׁהֻכְרַחְתִּי לִקַּח סֵפֶר תְּהִלִּים וְאָמַרְתִּי אֵיזֶה מִזְמוֹרֵי תְּהִלִּים וְיָדַעְתִּי תֵּיכֶף שֶׁיִּתְרַפֵּא וְכֵן הָיָה, אֲבָל לַאֲנָשִׁים פְּשׁוּטִים שֶׁאֵין לָהֶם שַׁיָּכוּת אֵלַי קָשֶׁה מְאֹד לְהוֹשִׁיעָם כִּי נִצְרָךְ לִי לְבַטֵּל עַצְמִי לָהֶם עכד"ק.ממכתב הגה"צ רבי שאול משה זילברמן זצ"לאבד"ק וויערשובנדפס ב"אביר הרועים", בהתחלת חלק שני
body_en:
The holy Rabbi, author of *Avnei Nezer* zt"l, did very much in efforts to release young Torah scholars so they would not be drafted into the army. He used to say to them the words of this Mishna: "Anyone who accepts upon himself the yoke of Torah, the yoke of government and the yoke of worldly cares are removed from him."
[The holy Rabbi R' Chaim of Ottynia zt"l expressed himself saying: "I am a specialist in matters of judgments" (that if a Jew has difficulties in court, let him come to save him), whereas the holy Rabbi of Sochatchov is a specialist in matters of release from the army...]
Once a Jew came before him and asked him for his blessing that his son would not be accepted into the army. He added that he is a young scholar (Avreich), a Torah scholar, and innovates novellae. While doing so, he took out a notebook with Torah novellae that he had written in it.
The *Avnei Nezer* looked in the notebook and said: "An Avreich who can say such a 'Shtikel Torah' (piece of Torah) will not be a soldier..."
Needless to note that as his words were, so it was, and they did not accept him.
Source: Haga"ch Rabbi Eliezer David Friedman shlit"a, "Mipi Sefarim VeSofrim" (Bnei Brak 5768) Part 1, p. 485

Once, during the Friday night meal, the Gaon and Chassid Rabbi Shlomo Kalish zt"l sat at the pure table of C.K. Maran Admor Rabbi Chanoch Henoch of Sochatchov zt"l in Bayit Vegan. Amidst the conversation, the Admor turned to Rabbi Shlomo and said:
"I remember that they used to say in Sochatchov that the *Avnei Nezer* zt"l said that the world mistakenly thinks that it is possible to effect salvations according to Kabbalah, but in truth, it is possible to effect salvations according to *Nigleh* (Revealed Torah). Do you know anything about this matter?"
Rabbi Shlomo smiled a broad smile and said: "I personally had an incident. Once I entered the *Avnei Nezer* with my father-in-law, the author of *Chelkat Yoav* zt"l. The *Avnei Nezer* turned to my father-in-law and told him: 'You must already begin accepting *Kvitelach* (petitions),' meaning to be an Admor.
The *Chelkat Yoav* was shaken and said: 'Rebbe, how can I do this? And what will I do if a Jew comes to me and asks me to effect that he will have a male son? After all, to be a Rebbe, one needs to know this.'
The *Avnei Nezer* answered him and said: 'Ay, do you not know Yevamot?'
The *Chelkat Yoav* said: 'If the Rebbe's intention is the commentary of the Rashba?'
The *Avnei Nezer* replied: 'If so, then you do know!'"
(Rabbi Shabtai Rappaport shlit"a, grandson of the author of *Shem MiShmuel* zt"l, commented that perhaps the intention is to Tosafot Yevamot 65a, s.v. *Shebeino Leveinah*, who wrote in the name of Rabbeinu Tam: "Or like Per' [perhaps referring to a specific custom or interpretation] of Rosh Chodesh, that they should make a meal and be appeased." And "Dapchach" [acronym for words of praise]. And I found support for this in *Abir HaRo'im* Part 2, Letter 238, see there).
And the *Avnei Nezer* added saying: "The world thinks that it is possible to effect salvations only according to the Hidden (Kabbalah), but I said that everything is possible also according to the Revealed. And I know, for example, *Nimukei Yosef* in Tractate Bava Kamma, that it is possible to visit barren women through it."
He closed [the subject] and did not explain. Immediately when we left the holy presence, my father-in-law did not delay and sat down to study all the *Nimukei Yosef* on Bava Kamma, but he did not find its place anywhere. But he [the *Avnei Nezer*] indeed knew it. End quote.
(Look well in *Abir HaRo'im* page 36, Letter 55). [And look in *Bnei Yissaschar*, Ma'amarei Chodesh Sivan, end of Ma'amar 6, that 13 Attributes were handed down to the Torah, which is expounded through them to awaken upon them the 13 Attributes of Mercy. It is possible via *Kal Vachomer* (a fortiori argument), and as the Maggid of Mezeritch zt"l said, that Moses our Teacher a"h prayed for Miriam: "**אל נא רפא נא וגו'**" - "**Please, God, heal her now, etc.**" He wanted to awaken the attribute of mercy of G-d. And the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him: "**ואביה ירק ירק וגו'**" - "**If her father had but spit, etc.**" From which they learned a *Kal Vachomer*, meaning He hinted to him to awaken mercy via *Kal Vachomer*, for he effected it through the Revealed Torah.]
Source: Hagaon Rabbi Shalom Mordechai HaKohen Schwadron zt"l, "Sha'al Avicha Veyagdecha" (Jerusalem 5746) Part 1, p. 360

The author of *Chelkat Yoav* told that once, while studying together with his teacher, the author of *Avnei Nezer*, the son of the *Shem MiShmuel* fell ill. He was then a child of nine years old, in a critical condition, literally humanly impossible. And behold, in the middle of the study, the Rebbetzin entered with a scream: "The child is dying, and you sit and learn and do nothing for the sake of the sick child!..."
The author of *Avnei Nezer* rose from his place, approached the sickbed, placed his hand on the child's face, and returned to the study table. Within a short time, the sick child began to sweat, and his condition improved.
The *Avnei Nezer* then said: "The truth is, the child's condition was improving while I sat and learned. Even without me doing any action for it. But since the Rebbetzin started screaming and interrupted me from study for a moment, I was already forced to get up and perform some action to save him, because there was already a moment of *Bitul Torah* (neglect of Torah)!"
Source: Hagaon Rabbi Shalom Mordechai HaKohen Schwadron zt"l, "Sha'al Avicha Veyagdecha" (Jerusalem 5746) Part 1, p. 360

body_he: קָם בַּעַל הָ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" מִמְּקוֹמוֹ, נִגַּשׁ לְמִיטַת הַחוֹלֶה, שָׁם אֶת יָדוֹ עַל פְּנֵי הַיֶּלֶד וְחָזַר לְשֻׁלְחַן הַלִּמּוּד, כְּשֶׁתּוֹךְ כְּדֵי כָּךְ הִתְחִיל הַיֶּלֶד הַחוֹלֶה לְהָזִיעַ וּמַצָּבוֹ הוּטַב.אָמַר אָז הָ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר": הָאֱמֶת הִיא, כִּי מַצַּב הַיֶּלֶד הָיָה מִשְׁתַּפֵּר בַּזְּמַן שֶׁיָּשַׁבְתִּי וְלָמַדְתִּי, גַּם בְּלִי שֶׁאֶעֱשֶׂה כָּל פְּעֻלָּה לְכָךְ, אֲבָל מִכֵּיוָן שֶׁהָרַבָּנִית הִתְחִילָה לִצְעֹק וְהִפְסִיקָה אוֹתִי מִן הַלִּמּוּד לְרֶגַע, כְּבָר הָיִיתִי מֻכְרָח לָקוּם וְלַעֲשׂוֹת אֵיזוֹ פְּעֻלָּה לְהַצָּלָתוֹ, כִּי הָיָה כְּבָר רֶגַע שֶׁל בִּיטוּל תּוֹרָה!הגאון רבי שלום מרדכי הכהן שבדרון זצ"ל"שאל אביך ויגדך" (ירושלים תשמ"ו) ח"א, ע' ש"ס
body_en:
A wondrous matter and a great story is what is known to me from C.K. Maran Admor zt"l of Sochatchov. Once, the Gaon and Chassid, Moreinu HaRav Feivel zt"l, the Av Beit Din of Nowy Dwor, became very ill with an infection in his hand. There was a discussion and debate among the doctors regarding his illness, and some of them said that if they did not cut off his hand, he was in danger.
The aforementioned Rabbi said that it is impossible to cut his hand until he first asks C.K. Maran Admor zt"l of Sochatchov (who was then Av Beit Din in the city of Nasielsk) to hear his opinion. He asked him to come visit him (for he was his friend and companion while he was in Kotzk).
When the Admor came there, he said that he would not give an answer, only that it was his will to convene a Beit Din (Rabbinical Court), and as they would say, so it would be established. He sent a special messenger and a carriage after C.K. my father-in-law (the Gaon Rabbi Yitzchak Feigenbaum, Av Beit Din of Warsaw) zt"l to come immediately to the city of Nowy Dwor.
There was also the famous Gaon, Rabbi Yoav Yehoshua zt"l, Av Beit Din of Kinsk (who was then a Moreh Tzedek in Nasielsk). C.K. Maran Admor zt"l seated them with him as if they were sitting for a Din Torah, negotiating in the laws of *Treifot* (fatal defects) regarding this matter. The doctors who wanted to perform the surgery sat in the second room and waited for their decision.
After a negotiation in this Halacha that lasted about some hours, a ruling came out that one should not cut his hand from him, and he could return to his health through dealing with other medicines. And so it was, that they did not cut his hand, and he recovered and rose from his illness.
I remember that once after this, I traveled with C.K. my father-in-law zt"l on the railway on the way up to the village of Jablonna (where C.K. my father-in-law sat during the summer time to breathe fresh air). On that journey, the honor of the aforementioned Gaon Rabbi from Nowy Dwor was also traveling. When he saw C.K. my father-in-law zt"l, he rejoiced with him with great joy and thanked C.K. my father-in-law zt"l for siding greatly in the session of that Beit Din not to cut his hand from him. (For in truth, so I heard from C.K. my father-in-law zt"l, who said that he innovated much and sided that there is no need to cut his hand). And all this I write for the honor of the Torah.
Source: Haga"h R' Yisrael Isser HaKohen Feigenbaum Hy"d, "Ohr Pnei Yitzchak" (Jerusalem 5752) p. 150, Letter 10

body_he: וּדְכִירְנָא שֶׁפַּ"א לְאַחַ"ז נָסַעְתִּי עִם כ"ק אָאָמוּר זַצַ"ל בִּמְסִילַּת הַבַּרְזֶל בַּדֶּרֶךְ הָעוֹלָה לִכְפַר יַאבְּלָאנַע (שֶׁשָּׁם יָשַׁב כ"ק אָאָמוּר בִּזְמַן הַקַּיִץ לִשְׁאֹף אֲוִיר צַח) וּבְאוֹתוֹ מַסָּע נָסַע כְּבוֹד הָרַב הַגָּאוֹן הַנַּ"ל מִנַּאוְודְאוֹוָאר וּכְשֶׁרָאָה אֶת כ"ק אָאָמוּר זַצַ"ל הָיָה שָׂמֵחַ עִמּוֹ שִׂמְחָה גְּדוֹלָה וְהוֹדָה לְכ"ק אָאָמוּר זַצַ"ל עַל מַה שֶּׁצִּדֵּד הַרְבֵּה בִּישִׁיבַת ב"ד זוֹ שֶׁלֹּא יַחְתְּכוּ מִמֶּנּוּ יָדוֹ (שֶׁבֶּאֱמֶת כֵּן שָׁמַעְתִּי מִכ"ק אָאָמוּר זַצַ"ל שֶׁאָמַר שֶׁהוּא חִדֵּשׁ הַרְבֵּה וְצִדֵּד שֶׁאֵין מִן הַנָּחוּץ לַחְתֹּךְ מִמֶּנּוּ יָדוֹ), וְכ"ז הִנְנִי כּוֹתֵב לִכְבוֹד הַתּוֹרָה.הרה"ג ר' ישראל איסר פייגנבוים הי"ד"אור פני יצחק" (ירושלים תשנ"ב) ע' ק"נ, אות י'
body_en:
This was his excessive holiness and purity over all Israel in what we saw as a wonder with him: Even though he (the *Avnei Nezer* zt"l) was not a Kohen but an Israelite, he was careful and very strict not to enter the tent of a corpse, even of Tzaddikim. No one knew the secret of his reason and reasoning.
Now that we have merited the holy book *Shem MiShmuel* by his son, the holy Gaon and Admor the Middle One zt"l, I saw there in Parashat Emor from the year 5672 (1912) that he wrote regarding this, and these are his words:
"And according to what is said, there is a new reason to give why Kohanim are warned against the impurity of the dead: Because this impurity is the opposite of their essence and spoils their level (see there). And by becoming impure to a dead person, they draw upon themselves this impurity. Perhaps through this, the external forces will again have the ability to rule over them when the day of their visitation comes, while their soul is within them. And with this, the reason is understood why men of high stature, Israelites who are strict not to enter the tent of a corpse—which was always a wonder in my eyes when I saw C.K. my father, the Admor zt"l, being strict about this. And according to what is said, the matter is understood." End quote, and see there at length.
However, at times, he would change his holy conduct with the holy ones of the Most High, the outstanding ones among the remnants whom G-d calls...
Source: Haga"ch Rabbi Tzvi Yehuda Mamlak Hy"d, "Abir HaRo'im" (Piotrkow 5696) Part 1, Letter 133

The Admor Rabbi David of Sochatchov zt"l told me that when he was a young married man (Avreich) after his wedding, he lived in the apartment of his grandfather, the *Avnei Nezer*. He designated the living quarters for him at the edge of the apartment.
Once, on the night of Hoshana Rabbah, the *Avnei Nezer* entered his apartment and asked him if he felt anything that night. He answered him that indeed, he felt there was an accusation against the entirety of Israel, and that the matter was nullified.
The *Avnei Nezer* told him that he felt correctly, for there was an accusation against the entirety of Israel. And because of this, he labored to resolve a Rif that was difficult for him. "With this, I crushed the feet of the accuser." (And he said in Yiddish: "Mit dem hab ich dem mekatreig tzehakt die fiss" - With this I chopped off the accuser's feet).
And these words were printed in Responsa *Avnei Nezer* Orach Chaim Siman 512.
Source: Haga"tz Rabbi Menachem Zev Kupa zt"l, Av Beit Din of Mlawa (Heard from Hrh"g R' Shmuel Laznowski zt"l)

The love of Torah of the *Avnei Nezer* zt"l was very wondrous. Out of love for the Torah, he commanded his attendants that any Yeshiva student be given permission to enter his presence at any time he desires—whether by day or by night, and even during eating or sleeping. The door was always open before him, since a young man sitting and studying Torah was, in his eyes, a treasure more precious than anything.
But if a Chassid from among his followers came who was not a Torah scholar and did not engage in Torah, he was liable to wait outside for even six hours until permission was granted for him to enter the inner sanctum.
Source: His student Haga"ch R' Shlomo Kalish zt"l [From the notes of Hrh"g R' Yisrael Haze zt"l]

...And with this I will go out and praise the One who bestows benefits upon the guilty, that we merited to clarify and whiten the explanation of the labor of Whitening (*Melachet Melaben*). And He will purify and whiten our souls from all filth and impurity through the remnant with the water of knowledge, and grant us the merit to return in complete repentance before Him. And we shall merit to purify our bodies into coats of skin (*Kotnot Or*) into coats of light (*Kotnot Ohr*), as the *Yenuka* said (in the Zohar): "This body that does not ascend, the light of the soul does not rest upon it." And may this serpent's skin be removed from us. May it be His will, Amen.
Source: "Responsa Avnei Nezer" Orach Chaim, Siman 169 - Letter 6

body_he: ...וּבָזֶה אֵצֵא וַאֲשַׁבֵּחַ לְהַגּוֹמֵל לְחַיָּבִים טוֹבוֹת, שֶׁזָּכִינוּ לְבָרֵר וּלְלַבֵּן בֵּאוּר מְלֶאכֶת מְלַבֵּן, וְהוּא יְטַהֵר וִילַבֵּן נַפְשׁוֹתֵינוּ מִכָּל לִכְלוּךְ וְטֻמְאָה ע"י שָׁרֵי' בְּמֵי הַדַּעַת וִיזַכֵּנוּ לָשׁוּב בִּתְשׁוּבָה שְׁלֵימָה לְפָנָיו, וְנִזְכֶּה לְטַהֵר אֶת גּוּפֵינוּ כָּתְנוֹת עוֹר בְּכִסְכּוּסֵי כְּמַאֲמַר הַיְּנוּקָא (בזה"ק) הַאי גּוּפָא דְּלָא סָלִיק בֵּי' נְהוֹרָא דְּנִשְׁמָתָא מְבַטְשִׁין לֵי', וְיָסוּר מֵאִתָּנוּ הַאי מַשְׁכָּא דְּחִוְיָא, כֵּן יְהִי רָצוֹן אָמֵן."שו"ת אבני נזר" או"ח, סי' קס"ט - אות ו'
body_en:
**Study in the Order of Kodshim**
I heard from C.K. my father, the Admor zt"l, who said in the name of my grandfather zt"l of Kotzk, that study in the Order of *Kodshim* purifies thoughts. And in the name of the Admor, the *Rim* of Gur zt"l, he said that for study of the Order of *Kodshim*, one needs pure thoughts.
And he decided between them: That in proportion to a person studying with pure thoughts, to that extent the study purifies the thoughts. And it becomes easier for him to purify the thought each time more. End of his words.
Source: "Shem MiShmuel" (Sochatchov) Miketz 5672, p. 136

body_he: שָׁמַעְתִּי מִכ"ק אָבִי אַדְמוֹ"ר זצללה"ה שֶׁאָמַר בְּשֵׁם זְקִינִי זצללה"ה מִקָּאצְק, שֶׁהַלִּמּוּד בְּסֵדֶר קָדָשִׁים מְטַהֵר אֶת הַמַּחֲשָׁבוֹת, וּבְשֵׁם אַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִי"ם מִגּוּר זצללה"ה אָמַר שֶׁלְּלִמּוּד סֵדֶר קָדָשִׁים צְרִיכִין מַחֲשָׁבוֹת טְהוֹרוֹת, וְהוּא הִכְרִיעַ בֵּינֵיהֶם שֶׁלְּעֻמַּת שֶׁאָדָם לוֹמֵד בְּמַחֲשָׁבוֹת טְהוֹרוֹת בָּהּ בְּמִדָּה הַלִּמּוּד מְטַהֵר אֶת הַמַּחֲשָׁבוֹת, וְנָקֵל לוֹ טָהֳרַת הַמַּחֲשָׁבָה בְּכָל פַּעַם יוֹתֵר. עכת"ד."שם משמואל" (סוכטשוב) מקץ תרע"ב, ע' קל"ו
body_en:
The Admor (author of *Avnei Nezer*) zt"l said before his passing that if they study his books, it will be a shield and a help even after his passing, literally as in his lifetime.
Source: "Eretz Tzvi" on the Torah (Kozhiglov) 11 Adar I 5687, p. 242

body_he: הִגִּיד אַדְמוֹ"ר (בַּעַל "אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר") זצוקללה"ה קֹדֶם פְּטִירָתוֹ, שֶׁאִם יִלְמְדוּ בַּסְּפָרִים שֶׁלּוֹ יִהְיֶה לְמָגֵן וּלְעֵזֶר גַּם אַחַר פְּטִירָתוֹ מַמָּשׁ כְּמוֹ בַּחַיִּים עכדה"ק."ארץ צבי" עה"ת (קוז'יגלוב) י"א אדר א' תרפ"ז, ע' רמ"ב
body_en:
C.K. my father, the Admor zt"l, told me that a man whose passion is Torah and Mitzvot—it is impossible for him to descend to Gehennom. And even if he descends, I guarantee for him that he will hurry and fly from there like an arrow from a bow.
Source: "Shem MiShmuel" (Sochatchov) Korach 5677, p. 289 [Ki Tisa - p. 219, Shem HaGashap - p. 112]

Rabbi Yashe Dinaburger [the author of *Tzafnat Paneach* zt"l] was in Lublin near the *Torat Chesed*. He presented a bench for him and said: "Sit, my son, sit." ("Shev bni shev").
Afterwards, he asked him: "How many times is this phrase found in the Shas?"
He answered immediately: "Seven times, corresponding to the number of 'Shev' (Sit/Seven)." (In the translation language [Yiddish], "Shev" is "Shiva" [Seven]).
Source: Haga"ch R' Yosef Patzanovski zt"l Hy"d, "Gan Yosef" (Bnei Brak 5758) p. 109, Letter 478

body_he: הִגִּיד לִי כ"ק אָבִי אַדְמוֹ"ר זצלה"ה שֶׁאִישׁ אֲשֶׁר הַתְּשׁוּקָה שֶׁלּוֹ הוּא תּוֹרָה וּמִצְווֹת אִי אֶפְשָׁר שֶׁיֵּרֵד לַגֵּיהִנֹּם, וַאֲפִילּוּ אִם יֵרֵד הִנְנִי עָרֵב בַּעֲדוֹ שֶׁיְּמַהֵר וְיָעוּף מִשָּׁם כְּחֵץ מִקֶּשֶׁת עכלה"ק."שם משמואל" (סוכטשוב) קרח תרע"ז, ע' רפ"ט[שם תשא - ע' רי"ט, שם הגש"פ - ע' קי"ב]
body_en:
"**והיא שעמדה לאבותינו ולנו**" - "**And it is that which stood for our fathers and for us.**" (Haggadah).
I heard from Hrh"g Ben-Zhak (son of holy seed) R' Simcha Rubin shlit"a from Risha, who heard from C.K. Admor R' Yechiel Yehoshua zt"l of Biala. While he was in the years of the war (WWII) in exile in Siberia, he said in the name of the holy Rabbi, the *Avnei Nezer* zt"l:
What do we say "Vehi She'amda" etc.? "**והיא**" (And it/she) refers to the Cup [of wine], which we lift. And this is according to the opinion in the Gemara (Shabbat 17b): "**גזרו על יינן משום בנותיהן**" - "**They decreed against their wine because of their daughters**" etc. The decree against ordinary wine was a fence for the Children of Israel so they would not worship idols, Heaven forbid, and assimilate among the nations.
And this is "**והיא**" - the decree that our Rabbis zt"l decreed upon the wine not to drink their wine—**it is that which stood for our fathers and for us**, that we remained one nation in the land, "A garden locked is my sister, my bride," etc. And sufficient for the wise.
Source: Notes of Hrh"ch R' Yehoshua Zev Lerner shlit"a, "Nitzutzei Orot", Shemini 5764, p. 4

body_he: וְהִיא שֶׁעָמְדָה לַאֲבוֹתֵינוּ וְלָנוּ (הגש"פ). שָׁמַעְתִּי מֵהַרְהַ"ג בנש"ק ר' שִׂמְחָה רוּבִין שְׁלִיטָ"א מֵרַיְישָׁא, שֶׁשָּׁמַע מִכ"ק אַדְמוֹ"ר ר' יְחִיאֵל יְהוֹשֻׁעַ זצוק"ל מִבִּיאַלָא, בְּעֵת הֱיוֹתוֹ בִּשְׁנוֹת הַמִּלְחָמָה (מַלְחֶמֶת הָעוֹלָם הַשֵּׁנִי') בְּגָלוּת "סִיבִּיר", שֶׁאָמַר בְּשֵׁם הָרַה"ק הָ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" זַ"ל מַה שֶּׁאוֹמְרִים וְהִיא שֶׁעָמְדָה וְכוּ', "וְהִיא" קָאֵי עַל הַכּוֹס, שֶׁמַּגְבִּיהִין, וְהוּא עפ"ד מַ"ד בַּגְּמָרָא (שַׁבָּת יז:) גָּזְרוּ עַל יֵינָן מִשּׁוּם בְּנוֹתֵיהֶן וְכוּ', דִּגְזֵרַת סְתָם יֵינָם הָי' גֶּדֶר לִבְנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁלֹּא יַעַבְדוּ ע"ז ח"ו וְיִטָּמְעוּ בֵּין הַגּוֹיִם. וְזֶהוּ וְהִיא, הַגְּזֵרָה שֶׁגָּזְרוּ רַבּוֹתֵינוּ זַ"ל עַל הַיַּיִן שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁתּוֹת מֵינָם, הִיא שֶׁעָמְדָה לַאֲבוֹתֵינוּ וְלָנוּ, שֶׁנִּשְׁאַרְנוּ גּוֹי אֶחָד בָּאָרֶץ, גַּן נָעוּל אֲחוֹתִי כַלָּה וְכוּ', ודפח"ח.מרשימות הרה"ח ר' יהושע זאב לערנער שליט"א"ניצוצי אורות", שמיני תשס"ד, עמ' ד'
body_en:
It is brought in *Tikkunei HaZohar* that a Jew needs to always have two signs upon him: On weekdays, the sign of Circumcision and the sign of Tefillin; and on Shabbat, the sign of Circumcision and the sign of Shabbat.
I heard from C.K. my father, the Admor, may he rest in peace, the reason: Because a person in this world is like a lost object, as it is written (Psalms 119:176): "**תעיתי כשה אבד וגו'**" - "**I have gone astray like a lost sheep...**" And a lost object is returned to its owners by means of signs. And two signs are a definitive proof that is Biblical.
Therefore, by means of two signs that are two marks, a person who seeks to find his lost object—meaning himself, from being lost any longer—can do so. End of his words.
Source: "Shem MiShmuel" (Sochatchov) Vayakhel 5670, p. 265

body_he: אִיתָא בְּתִקּוּנֵי הַזֹּהַר שֶׁצָּרִיךְ כ"א מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁיִּהְיוּ בּוֹ תָּמִיד שְׁנֵי אוֹתוֹת, בְּחוֹל אוֹת בְּרִית מִילָה וְאוֹת תְּפִילִּין, וּבְשַׁבָּת אוֹת בְּרִית מִילָה וְאוֹת שַׁבָּת. וְשָׁמַעְתִּי מִכ"ק אָבִי אַדְמוֹ"ר הַכ"מ הַטַּעַם מִשּׁוּם דְּאָדָם בְּעוֹהַ"ז הוּא כַּאֲבֵדָה כמאָה"כּ (תְּהִלִּים קי"ט קע"ו) תָּעִיתִי כְּשֶׂה אֹבֵד וְגוֹ', וַאֲבֵדָה מַחֲזִירִין לַבְּעָלֶי' בְּסִימָנִים, וּשְׁנֵי סִימָנִים הָווּ כְּסִימָן מֻבְהָק דְּהוּא דְּאוֹרַיְיתָא, וְע"כ ע"י שְׁנֵי אוֹתוֹת שֶׁהֵם שְׁנֵי סִימָנִים יָכוֹל אָדָם הַמְּבַקֵּשׁ לִמְצֹא אֲבֵדָתוֹ, הַיְנוּ אֶת עַצְמוֹ מִהְיוֹת עוֹד נֶאֱבָד, עכת"ד."שם משמואל" (סוכטשוב) ויקהל תר"ע, ע' רס"ה
body_en:
When the holy Gaon of Sochatchov zt"l, author of *Avnei Nezer*, foresaw with his holy spirit a number of years in advance that it was impossible to stop the people from settling in the Land with the help and spirit of the Zionist movement, Hashem awakened his spirit. He clarified and ruled Halachically that the commandment of settling the Land of Israel—in the essence of settlement, agriculture, acquisition, commerce, etc.—applies in this time as well, even before the coming of the Messiah (*Avnei Nezer* Yoreh Deah 454).
And since the day the Temple was destroyed, the Holy One, Blessed be He, has nothing but the four cubits of Halacha. Meaning, that the Halacha determines reality.
With this, the holy Gaon, author of *Avnei Nezer*, drove a faithful stake into the settlement of the Holy Land several years before the settlement began in the spirit of secular nationalism. Were it not that he preceded with the clarification of the early opinions and ruled this Halacha—that in our settling in the Land we are fulfilling a Mitzvah—we would not have found a place to settle here in the atmosphere of sin mixed with heretical methods.
Source: Haga"tz Rabbi Binyamin Mendelson zt"l, Av Beit Din of Komemiyut, "Igrot HaRav" (Jerusalem 5753) p. 252

body_he: כַּאֲשֶׁר הַגָּאוֹן הַקָּדוֹשׁ מִסּוֹכַטְשׁוֹב זי"ע בַּעַל הַ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" חָזָה בְּרוּהַ"ק מִסְפַּר שָׁנִים מִקּוֹדֶם שֶׁא"א לַעֲצֹר אֶת הָעָם מֵהִתְיַשְּׁבוּת בָּאָרֶץ בְּעֶזְרָתָהּ וּבְרוּחָהּ שֶׁל הַתְּנוּעָה הַצִּיּוֹנִית, וְהֵעִיר הַשֵּׁ"י אֶת רוּחוֹ וּבֵרֵר וּפָסַק לַהֲלָכָה שֶׁמִּצְוַת יִשּׁוּב אֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּעֶצֶם הַיִּשּׁוּב, בְּחַקְלָאוּת וְקִנְיָן וּמִסְחָר וְכַדּוֹ' נוֹהֵג בִּזְמַהַ"ז גַּם קֹדֶם בִּיאַת הַמָּשִׁיחַ (אַבְנֵ"ז חיו"ד תנ"ד), וּמִיּוֹם שֶׁחָרַב בֵּיהַמ"ק אֵין לוֹ לְהַקַּבָּ"ה אֶלָּא ד' אַמּוֹת שֶׁל הֲלָכָה בִּלְבַד, פֵּי' שֶׁהַהֲלָכָה קוֹבַעַת בָּעוֹלָם, וּבָזֶה קָבַע הַגָּהַ"ק בַּעַל הָאַבְנֵ"ז יָתֵד נֶאֱמָן בְּיִשּׁוּב ארה"ק כַּמָּה שָׁנִים לִפְנֵי שֶׁהִתְחִיל הַיִּשּׁוּב בְּרוּחַ הַלְּאֻמִּיּוּת הַחִלּוֹנִית. וְאִילּוּ לֹא הִקְדִּים בְּבֵרוּר שִׁיטוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנִים וּפָסַק הַהֲלָכָה הַזּוֹ, שֶׁבְּהִתְיַשְּׁבוּתֵנוּ בָּאָרֶץ הִנְנוּ מְקַיְּמִים מִצְוָה לֹא הָיִינוּ מוֹצְאִים מָקוֹם לְהִתְיַשֵּׁב פֹּה בַּאֲוִירָא שֶׁל חֵטְא הַמְעֹרָב עִם שִׁיטוֹת אֶפִּיקוֹרְסִיּוֹת.הגה"צ רבי בנימין מנדלזון זצ"לאב"ד קוממיות"אגרות הרב" (ירושלים תשנ"ג) ע' רנ"ב
body_en:
C.K. my father, the Admor zt"l, said that he saw famous people who, in the end, were not as worthy. This was because they grasped onto great things while they performed their deeds, but they had no connection to those great things.
Source: "Shem MiShmuel" (Sochatchov) Purim 5671, p. 167

body_he: אָמַר כ"ק אָבִי אַדְמוֹ"ר זצללה"ה שֶׁרָאָה אֲנָשִׁים מְפֻרְסָמִים אֲשֶׁר בְּסוֹפָם לֹא הָיָה כָּרָאוּי מֵחֲמַת שֶׁאָחֲזוּ בִּדְבָרִים גְּדוֹלִים בְּעוֹד שֶׁעָשׂוּ מַעֲשֵׂיהֶם וְלֹא הָיְתָה לָהֶם שַׁיָּכוּת לְאֵלֶּה הַדְּבָרִים הַגְּדוֹלִים."שם משמואל" (סוכטשוב) פורים תרע"א, ע' קס"ז
body_en:
Regarding the matter of prayer, C.K. my father, the Admor zt"l, said that it is called a "Keshet" (Bow) [= "With my sword and with my bow" - translated as "With my prayer and with my supplication"]. For it ascends upward according to the mass that the person places upon his heart and with the will of the heart. If he presses his heart and with complete will, it ascends higher, similar to an arrow from a bow that goes far according to the mass of the tension of the bowstring.
Source: "Shem MiShmuel" (Sochatchov) Bo 5679, p. 159

We saw love of Torah by my holy father and teacher ZY"A, whose mouth did not cease from recitation. It was fluent in the mouth of my father and teacher the holy one ZY"A, the words of the holy "Or HaChaim" (beginning of Parshat Tetzaveh) that the future Redemption depends on the merit of Moshe the Faithful Shepherd. And as long as Israel are not occupied with Torah, Moshe does not desire to redeem a people who are idlers from Torah. However, by increasing the power of Torah, we will hasten the Redemption of Israel.
Source: Funem Rebbe'ns Hoif

**His History**
He was born in Rogatchov in the year 5618 (1858) to his father, the Rabbi and Chassid, Mohar"a Efraim Fishel Rosen. When he was about 13 years old, he traveled to Slutsk and studied with the Gaon Rabbi Yosef Dov Soloveitchik, the Av Beit Din there. From there, he traveled to Shklov to the Yeshiva of the Gaon Rabbi Yehoshua Leib Diskin. He was famous as a wondrous prodigy (Illui).
After his marriage, he settled in Warsaw and lived there for several years. In the year 5649 (1889), he was accepted as the Rabbi for the Chassidic congregation. After the war, he returned to the city of Dvinsk.
He was a mighty and wondrous Gaon, unique in his kind with a wondrous memory. One who examines his books and letters will see that the Babylonian Talmud, Yerushalmi, Tosefta, Sifra, Sifrei, Mechilta, etc., and all the words of the Rishonim, and especially the language of the Rambam, were literally engraved upon the tablet of his heart.
From all ends of the earth, Rabbis, Roshei Yeshiva, Torah scholars, and precious young men wrote to him daily. He answered all of them on the same day he received their letter, and everything was in extreme brevity. It is a wonder that in his books, he does not mention any book other than the Rishonim, or even the Shulchan Aruch, except in rare places.
It is worthwhile to copy here what he wrote in one of his responsa (printed in Responsa *Tzafnat Paneach* published in Dvinsk, Part 2, Siman 8) regarding the recitation of Hallel on Passover night after the Maariv prayer. After bringing many sources for this custom, he concluded with these words:
"But what can I write to an opponent like you? For (even) if you were a Chassid like me, I would reveal to you secrets from the interpreters of hints and interpreters of difficult passages regarding this. But to an opponent like you, this is enough... Therefore, I will be brief and stop." End quote.
His book *Tzafnat Paneach* on the Rambam and on several tractates, Responsa *Tzafnat Paneach* in several parts, *Tzafnat Paneach* on the Torah, and more were printed. Much remains from him in manuscript.
He passed away on the 11th of Adar, 5696 (1936), and is buried in Dvinsk.
Source: "Kerem Shlomo" (Bobov) Tammuz 5740, p. 23

עִנְיַן תְּפִלָּה הִגִּיד כ"ק אָבִי אַדְמוֹ"ר זצללה"ה שֶׁנִּקְרֵאת קֶשֶׁת [=בְּחַרְבִּי וּבְקַשְׁתִּי - בְּתַרְגּוּם "בִּצְלוֹתִי וּבְבָעוּתִי"] שֶׁהִיא עוֹלָה לְמַעְלָה כְּפִי מַסַּת שֶׁהָאָדָם שָׂם עַל לִבּוֹ וּבִרְעוּתָא דְּלִבָּא, וְאִם הוּא דָּחִיק לִיבָּא וּבִרְעוּתָא שְׁלִים הִיא עוֹלָה לְמַעְלָה בְּיוֹתֵר כְּדִמְיוֹן חֵץ מִקֶּשֶׁת שֶׁהוֹלֵךְ לְמֵרָחוֹק כְּפִי מַסַּת מְתִיחַת הַמֵּיתָר שֶׁל הַקֶּשֶׁת."שם משמואל" (סוכטשוב) בא תרע"ט, ע' קנ"ט
נוֹלַד בְּרָאגַאטְשָׁאוּו בִּשְׁנַת תרי"ח לְאָבִיו הָרַה"ח מוֹ"ה אֶפְרַיִם פִישְׁל רָאזִין, בִּהְיוֹתוֹ בֶּן י"ג בְּעֵרֶךְ נָסַע לְסְלוּצְק וְלָמַד אֵצֶל הַג"ר יוֹסֵף דֹּב סָאלָאוֵוייצִיק אַבַּ"ד דְּשָׁם, וּמִשָּׁם נָסַע לִשְׁקְלָאוּו לִישִׁיבַת הַג"ר יְהוֹשֻׁעַ לֵיבּ דִּיסְקִין, וְהָיָה מְפֻרְסָם כְּעִלּוּי נִפְלָא.אַחַר חֲתֻנָּתוֹ הִתְיַשֵּׁב בְּוַוארְשָׁא וְדָר שָׁם כַּמָּה שָׁנִים. בִּשְׁנַת תרמ"ט נִתְקַבֵּל לְרַב לַעֲדַת הַחֲסִידִים, וְאַחַר הַמִּלְחָמָה שָׁב לְעִיר דְּוִוינְסְק. הָיָה גָּאוֹן אַדִּיר וְנִפְלָא, יָחִיד בְּמִינוֹ בְּזִכְרוֹנוֹ הַנִּפְלָא, הַמְעַיֵּן בִּסְפָרָיו וּבְמִכְתָּבָיו, יִרְאֶה כִּי שַׁ"ס בַּבְלִי וִירוּשַׁלְמִי תּוֹסֶפְתָּא סִפְרָא סִפְרֵי מְכִילְתָּא וְכוּ' וְכָל דִּבְרֵי הָרִאשׁוֹנִים וּבִפְרָט לְשׁוֹנוֹת הָרַמְבַּ"ם חֲרוּתִים מַמָּשׁ עַל לוּחַ לִבּוֹ. מִכָּל קַצְוֵי תֵּבֵל כָּתְבוּ אֵלָיו יוֹם יוֹם רַבָּנִים וְרָאשֵׁי יְשִׁיבוֹת, תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים וּבַחוּרֵי חֶמֶד, וּלְכֻלָּם הֵשִׁיב בְּאוֹתוֹ יוֹם שֶׁקִּבֵּל מִכְתָּבָם, וְהַכֹּל בְּקִצּוּר נִמְרָץ. לְפֶלֶא כִּי בִּסְפָרָיו אֵינוֹ מַזְכִּיר שׁוּם סֵפֶר זוּלַת מֵהָרִאשׁוֹנִים, אֲפִי' הַשֻּׁלְחָן עָרוּךְ, כִּי אִם בִּמְקוֹמוֹת אֲחָדִים.
כְּדַאי לְהַעְתִּיק בָּזֶה מַה שֶּׁכָּתַב בְּא' מִתְּשׁוּבוֹתָיו (נִדְפַּס בְּשׁוּ"ת צָפְנַת פַּעְנֵחַ שֶׁיָּצָא לָאוֹר בִּדְוִוינְסְק בְּח"ב סִי' ח') אוֹדוֹת אֲמִירַת הַלֵּל בְּלֵיל פֶּסַח אַחַר תְּפִלַּת עַרְבִית, אַחַר שֶׁהֵבִיא הַרְבֵּה מְקוֹרוֹת לְמִנְהָג זֶה, סִיֵּם בָּזֶה"ל: אַךְ מַה אֲנִי יוּכַל לִכְתֹּב לְמִתְנַגֵּד כָּמוֹךָ, כִּי (גַּם) [אִם] אַתָּה הָיִיתָ חָסִיד כָּמוֹנִי, הָיִיתִי מְגַלֶּה לְךָ בָּזֶה רָזִין מִדּוֹרְשֵׁי רְשׁוּמוֹת וְדוֹרְשֵׁי חֲמוּרוֹת, אַךְ לְמִתְנַגֵּד כָּמוֹךָ, דַּי בָּזֶה... לָכֵן אֲנִי מְקַצֵּר וּבָא, עכ"ל - נִדְפְּסוּ מִמֶּנּוּ סֵפֶר צָפְנַת פַּעְנֵחַ עַל הָרַמְבַּ"ם וְעַל כַּמָּה מַסֶּכְתּוֹת, שׁוּ"ת צָ"פ כַּמָּה חֲלָקִים, וְצָפְנַת פַּעְנֵחַ עה"ת, וְעוֹד. גַּם נִשְׁאַר מִמֶּנּוּ הַרְבֵּה בִּכְתַ"י
נִפְטַר בְּיוֹם י"א אֲדָר שְׁנַת תרצ"ו לִפְּ"ק, וּמְנוּ"כּ בִּדְוִוינְסְק."כרם שלמה" (באבוב) תמוז תש"מ, ע' כ"ג
body_en:
My father a"h lived far from 770, about half an hour's walk, yet he walked back and forth even on Friday night and on Shabbat day. On the seventh day of Passover 5709 (1949), the Previous Rebbe (the Rayatz zt"l) did not come out for the *Farbrengen* (gathering) due to health reasons, but my father, who did not know this, came to the *Farbrengen*.
The Rebbe [C.K. Maran Admor of Lubavitch zt"l] said: "Since R' Mordechai Groner came, it is a pity for his time; we must do something for his time." The Rebbe then stood for more than half an hour or an hour and told several stories he heard from the Previous Rebbe.
One of the stories was that the Rogatchover Gaon once entered with his father to the *Tzemach Tzedek*. The *Tzemach Tzedek* said to him: "Be a Lamdan (scholar) and study Tractate Nazir."
He was then about five or six years old. When he left the *Tzemach Tzedek*, he asked his father what the connection was between being a Lamdan and studying Tractate Nazir specifically. After all, "Lamdan" means to study the entire Torah, not specifically Tractate Nazir?!
His father did not know what to answer him. The small child, the Rogatchover, who was 'five or six years old' (that was the Rebbe's language), said to his father: "I do understand this. The Rebbe wants me to be a Nazir. If I become a Nazir, then the Rebbe's blessing that I be a Lamdan will be fulfilled in me. But if I tell [others] about my hair [being uncut], I won't be a Lamdan."
From then on, when he was five or six, he did not allow his hair to be cut. From then on, he was a Nazir.
Source: Hrh"ch R' Yehuda Leib Groner shlit"a, "Kfar Chabad", 11 Nissan 5760, p. 86

body_he: אַחַד הַסִּפּוּרִים הָיוּ שֶׁהַגָּאוֹן הָרוֹגַצ'וֹבִי נִכְנַס פַּעַם עִם אָבִיו לְצֶמַח צֶדֶק, וְהַצֶּמַח צֶדֶק אָמַר לוֹ: "תִּהְיֶה לַמְדָן וְתִלְמַד מַסֶּכֶת נָזִיר". הוּא הָיָה אָז כְּבֵן חָמֵשׁ אוֹ שֵׁשׁ שָׁנִים, וּכְשֶׁיָּצָא מֵהַצֶּמַח צֶדֶק שָׁאַל אֶת אָבִיו מַה הַקֶּשֶׁר בֵּין לִהְיוֹת לַמְדָן לְבֵין לִמּוּד מַסֶּכֶת נָזִיר דַּוְקָא, הֲרֵי לַמְדָן פֵּרוּשׁוֹ לִלְמֹד אֶת כָּל הַתּוֹרָה כֻּלָּהּ וְלֹא דַּוְקָא מַסֶּכֶת נָזִיר?! אָבִיו לֹא יָדַע מַה לַּעֲנוֹת לוֹ, וְהַיֶּלֶד הַקָּטָן, הָרוֹגַצ'וֹבִי, שֶׁהָיָה 'בֶּן חָמֵשׁ אוֹ שֵׁשׁ' (כָּךְ הָיָה הַלָּשׁוֹן שֶׁל הָרַבִּי), אָמַר לְאָבִיו: "אֲנִי כֵּן מֵבִין אֶת זֶה. הָרַבִּי רוֹצֶה שֶׁאֲנִי אֶהְיֶה נָזִיר, בְּאִם אֶהְיֶה נָזִיר אֲזַי תְּקֻיַּים בִּי הַבְּרָכָה שֶׁל הָרַבִּי שֶׁאֶהְיֶה לַמְדָן, אַךְ אִם אֲסַפֵּר אֶת שַׂעֲרוֹתַי לֹא אֶהְיֶה לַמְדָן". וּמֵאָז, כְּשֶׁהָיָה בֶּן חָמֵשׁ אוֹ שֵׁשׁ, לֹא הִרְשָׁה שֶׁיְּסַפְּרוּ אֶת שַׂעֲרוֹתָיו. מֵאָז הוּא הָיָה נָזִיר.הרה"ח ר' יהודה ליב גרונער שליט"א"כפר חב"ד", י"א ניסן תש"ס, ע' 86
body_en:
The Gaon of Rogatchov zt"l used to call the Rambam "Our Rabbi zt"l" or "Our Great Rabbi." When he said "Stam" (unspecified), the intention was the Rambam zt"l.
His custom was that after prayer every morning, before he began to study, he would say: "Good morning, Rebbe!" And before he went to sleep, he would say: "Good night, Rebbe!" His intention was to his quintessential teacher, the Rambam zt"l... (From oral tradition).
Source: Rabbi Menachem Mendel Tenenbaum shlit"a, "Kfar Chabad", 11 Adar II 5757, p. 42

The Gaon Rabbi Yosef, author of *Tzafnat Paneach* zt"l, was busy with his Torah study as usual before his Chuppah (wedding ceremony). He was looking into the Rambam. When they told him that he needed to go to his Chuppah, he made a crease in the [page of the] Rambam, closed it, and went to his Chuppah.
Source: Hrh"g R' Yissachar Tamar zt"l, "Alei Tamar" (Tel Aviv 5739) Part 1, p. 7

The famous Gaon of Rogatchov zt"l suffered greatly from headaches. He said that he does not see any neglect of Torah (Bitul Torah) that could be attributed to these headaches. He said that presumably, it is the resentment of the Rishonim (Early Authorities) and Acharonim (Later Authorities) who disagree with the Rambam. Since he justifies the words of the Rambam at all times, perhaps he hurt their honor through this. But he said that despite this, it is all worth it so that the Rambam should be right.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor the "Berach Moshe" of Satmar zt"l, "Pri Temarim", Terumah 5760, p. 19

The Gaon Rabbi Isser Zalman Meltzer zt"l told: Once I visited the Rogatchover when he was sick. When he was lying on his sickbed, I found him in a state of great worry, his eyes tearing.
I asked, "What happened?"
He answered me that he was worried lest he be caught disrespecting the honor of the Ra'avad. For in those days, he was engaged in clarifying a certain Halacha and was inclined to decide according to the opinion of the Rambam and not like the Ra'avad.
I said to him: "Torah is not in Heaven, and permission is granted..."
After some time, when he rose from his illness and we met again, I asked him: "What happened in the end with the discussion? Is it like the Rambam or like the Ra'avad?"
The Rogatchover hurried and replied: "Just as then, so too now, my heart inclines to decide according to the words of the Rambam. What can I do? His opinion seems correct to me. Is it possible to decide otherwise?!"
Source: Rabbi Aharon Sorasky shlit"a, "Marbitzei Torah MeOlam HaChassidut", Part 4, p. 105

It is known that after one of the researchers and thinkers of the free [secular] world visited, *lehavdil*, the Gaon Rogatchover zt"l, author of *Tzafnat Paneach*, that man left his house in great excitement and said that from the brain of the Rogatchover, it is possible to carve out two brains like Einstein's.
In that man's imagination, he could not find a greater expression than "two brains of Einstein." But in truth, even if we multiplied Einstein's brain by a thousand, they still would not have said a fraction of his praise.
And with my own ears, I heard from the holy mouth of the holy Gaon of Ostrovtza that the Gaon Rabbi Yosef the Rogatchover was expert in the Babylonian Talmud and Yerushalmi with the books of the Rambam by heart, more than any Jew in the world knows the chapter "Ashrei Yoshvei Veitecha."
This fact is known to every infant of his Rabbi's house: That his knowledge of the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmud, with the commentaries of Rashi and Tosafot on their tongues, is not of human intellect, and is nothing but G-dly wisdom, for the spirit of G-d was within him.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor of Sanz-Klausenburg zt"l, "Yahadut", Shevat 5734, p. 6, 15a [And see "Responsa Divrei Yatziv", Choshen Mishpat, Siman 87]

The Rogatchover Gaon zt"l used to call the Rambam by the name "Our Rabbi zt"l" or "Our Great Rabbi." This was the praise of the Gaon zt"l: "Stam" (unspecified) meant the Rambam zt"l.
And this was his custom: After prayer every morning, before he began to study, he said: "Good morning, Rebbe!" And before he went to sleep, he said: "Good night, Rebbe!" His intention was to his quintessential teacher, the Rambam zt"l...
(From oral tradition).
Source: Rabbi Menachem Mendel Tenenbaum shlit"a, "Kfar Chabad", 11 Adar II 5757, p. 42

There was a story with Rabbi Menachem Ziemba Hy"d of Praga, the last of the Geonim of Poland. He sat in a gathering with young Chassidim and spoke with excitement about the greatness of the Rogatchover, saying that even in earlier generations, one like him was not found.
One of the small members of the group, who knew only a little of great men outside the limited circle in which he grew up, opened up and asked: "And what is there to tell about his piety and fear of Heaven?"
Rabbi Menachem gave the questioner a look full of pity and answered him with a forgiving smile: "Did you ever hear about the wealthy man R' Yeshaya Priwes? (One of the greatest wealthy Jews in Poland). Well, this R' Yeshaya conducted huge businesses that amounted to many millions annually. How much do you think was the size of his profits? No more than a quarter to half a percent! In contrast, how much does a simple Jewish woman selling vegetables in the market earn? Go and check: Often her profit ranges between one hundred to two hundred percent! Nu, and with whom, in your opinion, did more profits accumulate during the year? With R' Yeshaya Priwes or with the vegetable seller in the market?"
"Up to here is the parable," concluded Rabbi Menachem. And as his face lit up toward the young questioner, he added and explained the moral to him:
"From the luminary that is in his Torah, the Torah of the Rogatchover, a sea of holiness and fear of Heaven flows to him, which generally cannot be compared with drops and drops of fear of Heaven that the common 'Ben Torah' merits, even if he engages for days and whole days in service and Chassidut..."
Source: Rabbi Aharon Sorasky shlit"a, "Marbitzei Torah MeOlam HaChassidut", Part 4, p. 3

body_he: "עַד כָּאן הַמָּשָׁל" הִפְטִיר רַבִּי מְנַחֵם, וּבְהָאִירוֹ פָּנָיו אֶל הַצָּעִיר הַשּׁוֹאֵל, הוֹסִיף וְהִסְבִּיר לוֹ גַּם אֶת הַנִּמְשָׁל: "מִן הַמָּאוֹר שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה שֶׁלּוֹ, תּוֹרַת הָרוֹגַאצ'וֹבִי, שׁוֹפֵעַ אֵלָיו יָם שֶׁל קְדֻשָּׁה וְיִרְאַת שָׁמַיִם, שֶׁבִּכְלָל אֵין לְהַשְׁוֹתוֹ עִם טִיפֵי טִיפִין שֶׁל יִרְאַת שָׁמַיִם שֶׁזּוֹכֶה לָהֶם בֶּן תּוֹרָה מִן הַמָּצוּי, אֲפִילּוּ עוֹסֵק יָמִים שְׁלֵמִים בַּעֲבוֹדָה וּבַחֲסִידוּת...הרב אהרן סורסקי שליט"א"מרביצי תורה מעולם החסידות", ח"ד, עמ' 3
body_en:
The Gaon R' Pinchas Teitz zt"l, Av Beit Din of Elizabeth and one of the heads of "Vaad Tzafnat Paneach," who was a member of the household of the Gaon of Rogatchov in his youth, testifies that he saw with his own eyes that within the span of one hour and sixteen minutes, the Gaon managed to answer 22 responses on 6 double postcards and 16 letters...
"His mouth literally did not stop from reciting," writes the Gaon Rashi Zevin zt"l. "And things are literal, not by way of metaphor. They say about him that because of this, he did not cut the hair of his head and grew it wild, so that he would not have to sit for that hour with his head uncovered and stop from words of Torah..."
Source: "Kerem Shlomo" (Bobov) Tammuz 5740, p. 23

body_he: בִּנְסִיעָתוֹ מִדְּוִוינְסְק לְרוֹגַאצ'וֹב הָיָה גּוֹמֵר בִּקְרוֹן הָרַכֶּבֶת חֲצִי הַשַּׁ"ס בְּעַל פֶּה, כָּךְ הוּא אָמַר בְּעַצְמוֹ פַּעַם בְּרוֹגַאטְשׁוֹב, וְהוֹסִיף, שֶׁבַּחֲזִירָתוֹ יְסַיֵּם אִי"ה אֶת הַמַּחֲצִית הַשְּׁנִיָּה...""מאורי ישראל" (ירושלים תשנ"ד) ע' 231-236
body_en:
On his journey from Dvinsk to Rogatchov, he would finish half of the Shas by heart in the train car. So he himself said once in Rogatchov, and added: "On my return, I will finish, with G-d's help, the second half..."
Source: "Meorei Yisrael" (Jerusalem 5754) p. 231-236

The Rosh Yeshiva of Lakewood, HaGaon Rabbi Aharon Kotler *zt"l*, used to tell this story on Purim:
When he was a young married man (Avreich), after the completion of his *Sheva Brachos*, he traveled on the train and met the Gaon of Rogatchov *zt"l* there. When he approached him, he asked him: "What is your occupation?" Rabbi Aharon answered: "I am a *Baal Habayis* (layman/homeowner)." The Gaon said to him: "Say some word of Torah." Rabbi Aharon began to lecture before him a complete array on the matters of *Zikah* (levirate bonds), which he had said during the course of the seven days of feasting, but to the Rogatchover, he said it all in less than an hour. When he finished, the Gaon said to him: "Nu, for a *Baal Habayis* you know quite well." And Rabbi Aharon testified about himself that these were his best classes...
Source: "She'al Avicha Veyagedcha" (Jerusalem 5739), Part 3, p. 20

body_he:
הָרַב זַצַ"ל סִפֵּר, שֶׁהָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער הָיָה הָרִאשׁוֹן מִגְּדוֹלֵי הַדּוֹר שֶׁזָּכָה לְהַכִּיר, וְהוּא עָשָׂה עָלָיו רֹשֶׁם אַדִּיר וְנִדְמָה הָיָה לוֹ כִּפְנֵי מַלְאַךְ אֱלֹקִים [כִּלְשׁוֹנוֹ]. לָוָה סְכוּם כֶּסֶף מֵאֶחָד מִידִידָיו וּבִקֵּשׁ שֶׁיּוֹדִיעַ לְהוֹרָיו הִי"ד שֶׁהוּא מִתְעַכֵּב. וְהָרַב זַצַ"ל הוֹסִיף שֶׁעַד הַיּוֹם לֹא מָצָא דֶּרֶךְ לְהָשִׁיב אֶת הַהַלְוָאָה כֵּיוָן שֶׁאוֹתוֹ בָּחוּר נֶהֱרַג בַּשּׁוֹאָה הִי"ד.
מַה שֶּׁזָּכַר בִּמְיֻחָד, הוּא הַשִּׁעוּר שֶׁנָּתַן אָז (הַגָּאוֹן מֵרָאגַאטְשָׁאוּו) בָּרַמְבַּ"ם הִלְכוֹת עֲבָדִים. כַּיָּדוּעַ, לְעוֹלָם לֹא פָּסַק פֻּומֵיהּ מִגִּירְסָא, הִרְצָה אֶת דְּבָרָיו בְּכָזוֹ בְּהִירוּת, הִסְבִּיר כָּל הֲלָכָה לְעֻמְקָהּ וּלְרָחְבָּהּ, בְּשָׂפָה בְּרוּרָה וּבְהַסְבָּרָה נִפְלָאָה, וּבְסַבְלָנוּת אֵין קֵץ, כְּמוֹ מְלַמֵּד דַּרְדְּקֵי, הָרַב שָׁתָה אָז בְּצָמָא אֶת אִמְרוֹתָיו, שֶׁעָרְבוּ לוֹ, מִנֹּפֶת צוּף וְכָל טַעַם. זֹאת בְּנִגּוּד לַשְּׁמוּעוֹת שֶׁרָוְחוּ, שֶׁכִּמְעַט אֵין לְהָבִין אֶת שִׂיחוֹתָיו, בְּשֶׁל הַהֶקֵּף, הַמְּהִירוּת וְהַקִּיצוּר, בּוֹ הוּא מַקִּיף כָּל נוֹשֵׂא וְעִנְיָן.
תּוֹךְ כְּדֵי לִמּוּד צִטֵּט הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער אֶת דִּבְרֵי הָרַמְבַּ"ם בְּהִלְכוֹת מְלָכִים (פ"ד ה"ד) לְגַבֵּי פִּילֶגֶשׁ שֶׁמֻּתֶּרֶת לְיִשְׂרָאֵל רַק בְּ"יִעוּד", וְאָז שָׁאַל הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער הֲרֵי מַשְׁמַע בַּגְּמָרָא לְהֶדְיָא שֶׁיִּעוּד זֶה לֹא פִּילֶגֶשׁ. הַגְּמָרָא בְּמַסֶּכֶת קִדּוּשִׁין דָּנָה אִם יִעוּד עוֹשֶׂה אֵירוּסִין אוֹ נִשּׂוּאִין וְעוֹד אֲבָל וַדַּאי שֶׁלֹּא עָלְתָה עַל דַּעַת הַגְּמָרָא שֶׁיִּעוּד זֶה פִּילֶגֶשׁ, קֻשְׁיָא מְפֻרְסֶמֶת.מוֹרֵנוּ הָרַב סִפֵּר, שֶׁמְּלַוָּיו שֶׁל הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער פָּחֲדוּ לִפְתֹּחַ אֶת הַפֶּה מִתּוֹךְ יִרְאַת הַכָּבוֹד אַךְ הוּא, כְּלוֹמַר רַבֵּינוּ, הָיָה אָז צָעִיר וְיַלְדוּת הָיְתָה בּוֹ וְהֵעִיז לְדַבֵּר לִפְנֵי הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער. כְּשֶׁשָּׁמַע הַקֻּשְׁיָא יוֹצֵאת מִפִּי כֹּהֵן גָּדוֹל, אָמַר מוֹרֵנוּ שֶׁאוּלַי מְקוֹר הָרַמְבַּ"ם בִּירוּשַׁלְמִי כְּתֻבּוֹת, שָׁם יֶשְׁנָהּ דֵּעָה שֶׁיִּעוּד זֶה כְּפִילֶגֶשׁ. הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער הֵגִיב וְכִי הָרַמְבַּ"ם הִנִּיחַ סוּגְיוֹת שְׁלֵימוֹת בְּשַׁ"ס בַּבְלִי לִדְחוֹת אֶת כֻּלָּם בִּגְלַל הַיְרוּשַׁלְמִי? אָמְנָם הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער זַצַ"ל לֹא קִבֵּל אֶת דְּבָרָיו, אַךְ בֵּרְכוֹ בְּבִרְכוֹת חַמּוֹת וּלְבָבִיּוֹת.
בְּהֶמְשֵׁךְ הַדֶּרֶךְ הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער שָׁאַל מַה הַפְּשָׁט בָּרַמְבַּ"ם (הִלְכוֹת עֲרָכִין פ"ז הֵי"א): "אֵין פּוֹדִין אֶת הַהֶקְדֵּשׁ אַכְסַרָה (בְּעֵרֶךְ) אֶלָּא בַּחֲקִירַת דָּמִים, וְאִם פָּדָה יַד הַקֹּדֶשׁ עַל הָעֶלְיוֹנָה (...) וְלוֹקְחִין אוֹתָהּ הַגִּזְבָּרִים וְשׁוֹתְקִין", וְשָׁאַל מַה כַּוָּנַת הָרַמְבַּ"ם וְשׁוֹתְקִין? שְׁתִיקָה זוֹ לְשֵׁם מַה בָּאָה? הַגָּאוֹן הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער הִסְבִּיר אֶת הַדָּבָר בְּעַצְמוֹ. פָּתַח וְאָמַר, עפ"י הַיְרוּשַׁלְמִי מַסֶּכֶת מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי (פ"ד ה"ב) "הֶקְדֵּשׁ שֶׁפְּדָאוֹ יוֹתֵר מִדָּמָיו תּוֹפֵס אֶת הַכֹּל. מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁפְּדָאוֹ יוֹתֵר מִדָּמָיו לֹא תָּפַס אֶת הַכֹּל. מַה בֵּין מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי לְהֶקְדֵּשׁ? אָמַר רַב אֵימִי שֶׁכֵּן אָדָם מָצוּי לִהְיוֹת מַרְבֶּה בְּהֶקְדֵּשׁ (וְאָמְרִינַן שֶׁמִּדַּעְתּוֹ הוֹסִיף) בְּעֵי רַב זְעִירָא נִבְדֹּק אוֹתוֹ הָאִישׁ וְאֹמַר לֹא לְכָךְ נִתְכַּוַּנְתִּי (הַיְנוּ, מַה יִּהְיֶה אִם בֶּאֱמֶת נִבְדֹּק וְיַגִּיד שֶׁלֹּא הִתְכַּוֵּן) לִכְשֶׁיִּבְדֹּק (הַיְנוּ שֶׁאִם בְּדָקוּהוּ הוֹלְכִים אַחַר דְּבָרָיו אֲבָל כָּל זְמַן שֶׁלֹּא נִבְדַּק אָמְרִינַן בִּסְתָמָא שֶׁלְּכָךְ הִתְכַּוֵּן). סִיֵּם הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער: זֶה הַפְּשָׁט וְשׁוֹתְקִין. נוֹטְלִים וְהוֹלְכִים בִּשְׁתִיקָה. לְלֹא בְּדִיקָה.
לֹא אֶשְׁכַּח אֶת הַהִתְלַהֲבוּת שֶׁאָחֲזָה בּוֹ (בְּהַגְרַ"ח קְרַייזְוִוירְט) כַּאֲשֶׁר דִּבֵּר עַל כְּבוֹד הַתּוֹרָה שֶׁחָפַף עַל הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער. הַכָּבוֹד שֶׁעָשׂוּ לוֹ בְּבוֹאוֹ לְוַוארְשָׁא הָיָה יוֹצֵא דֹּפֶן עַד שֶׁזִּקְנֵי וַוארְשָׁא אָמְרוּ אָז שֶׁמִּתְּקוּפַת הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אֵיגֶר שֶׁבִּקֵּר בְּוַוארְשָׁא לֹא הָיָה כָּזֶה כְּבוֹד הַתּוֹרָה. שְׁטִיחִים נִפְרְסוּ מִתַּחֲנַת הָרַכֶּבֶת עַד הָאַכְסַנְיָא הָאֲרָעִית שֶׁלּוֹ בָּעִיר. כָּל גְּדוֹלֵי הָעִיר בָּאוּ לִקְרָאתוֹ, וְרַבֵּינוּ פֵּרַט לִפְרָטֵי פְּרָטִים, עֲשׂוֹרוֹת שָׁנִים לְאַחַר מִכֵּן, אֶת שְׁמוֹת גְּדוֹלֵי הַתּוֹרָה שֶׁבָּאוּ אִישִׁית לְתַחֲנַת הָרַכֶּבֶת בְּוַורְשָׁא לְקַבֵּל פָּנָיו: רַבִּי מְנַחֵם זֶמְבָּא, רַבִּי אַבְרָהָם וַיְנְבֶּרְג הַ"רֵאשִׁית בִּיכּוּרִים" (תַּלְמִיד הָ"אַבְנֵי נֵזֶר" מִסּוֹכַטְשׁוֹב), רַבִּי מָרְדְּכַי קָאלִינֶע (שֶׁהָיָה מְפֻרְסָם בִּידִיעָתוֹ בְּכָל חֶלְקֵי הַתּוֹרָה בְּבַבְלִי וִירוּשַׁלְמִי. לְמַעֲשֶׂה, הֲרֵי רַבִּי מָרְדְּכַי קָאלִינֶע חִבֵּר אֶת הַסֵּפֶר "מִכְתְּבֵי תּוֹרָה", סֵפֶר שֶׁל מַשָּׂא וּמַתָּן בְּדִבְרֵי תּוֹרָה עִם הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער).הרב חיים רוזנבערג שליט"א"תוספת-המודיע", י"ב שבט תשס"ב, ע' י"ח

The Gaon Rabbi Neta Freund shlit"a told me that the Gaon R' Isser Zalman Meltzer zt"l told him that a certain wealthy man left his estate to be distributed to Yeshivot, and appointed the Gaon R' Chaim Ozer zt"l and the Gaon R' Yosef Rosen of Rogatchov zt"l as guardians (apotropos). R' Chaim Ozer sent R' Isser Zalman to travel to the Gaon of Rogatchov to discuss with him regarding the distribution of the estate.
And R' Isser Zalman said: "Before I entered to him, I prepared myself well in the Sugya of Apotropos." And he added: "The Ridbaz of Slutsk said about me that I have a quick grasp."
"When I entered the Gaon of Rogatchov, he spoke with me for two hours on the Sugya of Apotropos. And R' Isser Zalman said in these words: 'It poured out of him—Bavli, Yerushalmi, Sifra, Sifrei, Tosefta, with all the learning where the word Apotropos is mentioned.' And when he finished speaking, I had nothing to add to his words."
The aforementioned also told me that he heard further from the Gaon R' Isser Zalman Meltzer zt"l, that when the Rebbetzin of the Gaon of Rogatchov fell ill, she traveled for healing to the city of Vienna and passed away there. The Rogatchover traveled for the funeral. For him, it was *Bitul Torah* (neglect of Torah), a matter of *Pikuach Nefesh* (saving a life). During the entire time of his journey on the train, he spoke in Torah and delved into words of Torah so much that he completely forgot the reason for his journey to the city of Vienna.
When the train arrived in the city of Vienna, they told the Gaon that they had arrived in Vienna and that his wife had passed away, and that is why he traveled to Vienna. The Gaon said: "It is brought in the Gemara: 'Women, by what do they merit? etc. And they wait for their husbands until they come from the house of the Rabbis.' And he concluded that his wife should wait until he finishes the Pilpul."
Source: Hrh"g R' Yisrael Chaim Ashri shlit"a, "Siach Zekenim" (Brooklyn 5760) Part 3, p. 407

וְאָמַר ר' אִיסֶר זַלְמָן, קֹדֶם שֶׁנִּכְנַסְתִּי אֵלָיו, הֲכִינוֹתִי עַצְמִי הֵיטֵב בְּסוּגְיָא דְּאַפּוֹטְרוֹפּוֹס, וְהוֹסִיף, הָרִידְבַּ"ז מִסְּלוּצְק אָמַר עָלַי שֶׁיֵּשׁ לִי תְּפִיסָה מְהִירָה [אִיךְ הָאבּ אַ גִיכֶע תְּפִיסָה]. כְּשֶׁנִּכְנַסְתִּי אֶל הַגָּאוֹן מֵרָאגַאטְשָׁאוּו דִּבֵּר אִתִּי מֶשֶׁךְ שְׁעָתַיִם בְּסוּגְיָא דְּאַפּוֹטְרוֹפּוֹס, וְאָמַר רָא"ז בָּזֶה"ל, סְ'הָאט זִיךְ גֶעשָׁאטְן פוּן אִים בַּבְלִי, יְרוּשַׁלְמִי, סִפְרָא, סִפְרֵי, תּוֹסֶפְתָּא, מִיט אַלֶע לוֹמְדוּת, וָואוּ סְ'וֶוערְט דֶערְמָאנְט דָאס וָוארְט אַפּוֹטְרוֹפּוֹס [נִשְׁפַּךְ מִמֶּנּוּ בַּבְלִי יְרוּשַׁלְמִי סִפְרָא סִפְרֵי תּוֹסֶפְתָּא, עִם כָּל הַלּוֹמְדוּת אֵיפוֹא שֶׁרַק מֻזְכָּר הַמִּילָה "אַפּוֹטְרוֹפּוֹס"], וּכְשֶׁגָּמַר לְדַבֵּר, לֹא הָי' לִי לְהוֹסִיף עַל דְּבָרָיו.
עוֹד סִפֵּר לִי הַנַּ"ל, שֶׁשָּׁמַע עוֹד מֵהַגָּאוֹן ר' אִיסֶר זַלְמָן מֶעלְצֶר זַצַ"ל, שֶׁכְּשֶׁנֶּחֶלְתָה הָרַבָּנִית שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן מֵרָאגַאטְשָׁאוּו נָסְעָה לִרְפוּאָה לָעִיר וִוין וְנִפְטְרָה שָׁם. הָרָאגַאטְשָׁאוֶוער נָסַע לַהַלְוָיָ' וְאֶצְלוֹ הָי' בִּיטוּל תּוֹרָה עִנְיָן שֶׁל פִּקּוּחַ נֶפֶשׁ. בְּכָל עֵת נְסִיעָתוֹ עַל הָרַכֶּבֶת דִּבֵּר בַּתּוֹרָה, וְהִתְעַמֵּק בְּדִבְרֵי תּוֹרָה כָּל כָּךְ שֶׁשָּׁכַח לְגַמְרֵי סִבַּת נְסִיעָתוֹ לָעִיר וִוין.כְּשֶׁהִגִּיעָה הָרַכֶּבֶת לָעִיר וִוין, אָמְרוּ לַגָּאוֹן שֶׁהִגִּיעוּ לְוִוין וְשֶׁאִשְׁתּוֹ נִפְטְרָה וְשֶׁעַל כֵּן נָסַע לְוִוין. אָמַר הַגָּאוֹן, אִיתָא בַּגְּמָרָא, נָשִׁים בְּמַאי קָא זָכְיָין וְכוּ' וְנַטְרִין לְגַבְרַיְיהוּ עַד דְּאָתוּ מִבֵּי רַבָּנָן, וְסִיֵּם שֶׁתְּחַכֶּה זוּגָתוֹ עַד שֶׁיִּגְמֹר אֶת הַפִּלְפּוּל [זָאל זִי וַוארְטְן בִּיז אִיךְ עֶנְדִיג דֶעם פִּלְפּוּל].הרה"ג ר' ישראל חיים אשרי שליט"א"שיח זקנים" (ברוקלין תש"ס) ח"ג, ע' ת"ז

I saw in the book *Yalkut HaChe"k* (Tel Aviv-Jaffa, page 19) that the wondrous Gaon of our generation, Rabbi Yosef of Dvinsk zt"l, when his wife died, was discussing Torah while walking behind her bier. When they asked him about this, he replied to them: "I have already handed her over to the Chevra Kadisha..."
And indeed, no proof is brought from the Gaon zt"l, who was a living Torah scroll and a living Talmud, and the fountains of his wisdom were flowing and passing like a river that does not stop, and like a spring that strengthens without cease. And I heard that during his days of mourning, he engaged in Torah even though he had no connection to the laws of mourning. And certainly, his source was the Yerushalmi Moed Katan 3:5, that if one is eager for words of Torah, it is permitted. And who was eager for words of Torah like our great Rabbi zt"l?
And the trustee of his house, his attendant, R' Yosef Friher a"h, told me that when he [the Rogatchover Gaon] was staying in Petersburg, he engaged in Torah even on Tisha B'Av. And when they remarked to him about this, he replied with humor: "And how pleasant it is to receive lashes for the business of Torah..." It seems he relied on this Yerushalmi.
Source: Hrh"g R' Yissachar Tamar zt"l, "Alei Tamar" (Tel Aviv 5739) Part 1, p. 96 [And see further p. 113, 15b]

How great is the goodness stored with us, that a precious conversation has come into our hands, between the Geonim of the land from days of yore: The holy Gaon C.K. Maran Admor (author of *Kedushat Tzion* of Bobov) zt"l Hy"d, who, while in the city of Krynica, met the mighty Gaon Mohar"r Yosef Rosen zt"l of Dvinsk, famous by the name "The Gaon of Rogatchov."
And the story happened like this: On Friday, Parashat Beshalach, when Maran Maharbat"z zt"l was sitting on the porch in his lodging and reviewing the weekly portion "Shnayim Mikra VeEchad Targum," the aforementioned Gaon passed by there. When he was seen from a distance, our Rabbi zt"l rose from his seat and went to greet the Gaon, and he also came towards our Rabbi.
Our Rabbi zt"l opened with a question: "Did you know my grandfather, the author of the composition *LeTaharah*?" Seeing that our Rabbi was not recognized by the name of his book, he added and said: "Am I not the grandson of the holy Rabbi Mohar"r Mordechai Dov of Hornosteipel zt"l?" The Gaon replied: "Is not R' Mordechai Ber'nyu the only one among the Chassidim who knew well how to study with understanding and intelligence?"
Our Rabbi zt"l showed before him the verse in Parashat Beshalach (Exodus 16:23): "**שבתון שבת קדש לה' מחר את אשר תאפו אפו ואת אשר תבשלו בשלו**" - "**A solemn rest, a holy Sabbath to the Lord is tomorrow; bake what you will bake, and boil what you will boil.**" And the Sages zt"l hinted in it (Beitzah 15b): "From here is the source for Eruv Tavshilin from the Torah."
And the words are wondrous, for from where did they hint in this verse about the matter of Yom Tov falling on Friday?
But he said before him in the name of his grandfather, the holy Gaon Mohar"r Mordechai Dov of Hornosteipel zt"l, that behold we find in the verse (Deuteronomy 32:10): "**יצרנהו כאישון עינו**" - "**He kept him as the apple of His eye.**" The Rishonim explained (see Rabbeinu Bachya there) the reason why the pupil of a person's eye is called by the name "Ishon" (Little Man). Because there is a form of a man in it, and the word "Ishon" is based on "Ish" (Man). Therefore, the letter Nun was added at the end of the word to hint that it diminishes the thing. And similarly, one should interpret every addition of Nun at the end of a word.
The Gaon of Dvinsk interrupted the words of our Rabbi zt"l and said: "Are these words not already brought in the book *Tanya*?"
Our Rabbi zt"l continued that with this, the words of the Sages zt"l are understood. For it is written in the Torah "**שבתון**" (Shabbaton), and it is a hint to Good Days (Yom Tov), for the "On" (Vav-Nun) diminishes the word. And is not Shabbat higher in holiness than Yom Tov? Therefore, when the scripture diminished the Shabbat, its intention was for a matter of Yom Tov.
And this is its explanation: "**שבתון**" - when a Yom Tov occurs, "**שבת קדש לה' מחר**" - meaning, and the next day will be a holy Shabbat. Then: "**את אשר תאפו אפו ואת אשר תבשלו בשלו**" - "**bake what you will bake, and boil what you will boil**" - even on the Yom Tov that falls on Friday.
The aforementioned Gaon answered: "This novelty is written in the book *HaYashar* by Rabbeinu Tam zt"l."
In that gathering, our Rabbi zt"l said before him what he said in explanation of the language of the Paytan: "The Sambatyon River, which runs and rushes every day, proves on it [Shabbat] by resting." (See his words in the holy book *Kedushat Tzion* Part 2 in matters of Shabbat Kodesh). And with this, they parted in peace.
C.K. Maran zt"l was alarmed and astonished by the magnitude of the Gaon's sharpness, who for every word found a proving witness in the ancient books. Our Rabbi zt"l wanted to see the words written in the margins, so he searched and found in the book *HaYashar* that he wrote on the aforementioned Drush of the Sages zt"l: "And this is correct (Zal"k), it seems in my eyes that from the beginning it is derived from the verse," end quote.
And with great excitement, our Rabbi zt"l showed his close ones: "In truth, see the greatness of the sharpness of an Illui who knew to clarify the intention of Rabbeinu Tam, in the depth of his wisdom and the secret of his understanding, that the essence of his intention is indeed the words said above."
About a year passed since the meeting. Our Rabbi zt"l called several precious young men who were basking in his shadow and said to them: "Come and see how far the depth of the sharpness of the Illui, the Gaon of Rogatchov, reaches. For since I spoke with him, I have already looked three times in the entire book of *Tanya*, and I did not find a hint to his words, that he said that this is the intention of the author of the *Tanya* to say that the letters Vav-Nun hint to diminution. But now, after a full year, I labored and found in his words, what he writes in *Iggeret HaKodesh* Siman 17, and this is his language: 'That the illumination and revelation in the Garden of Eden is in the aspect of filling all worlds, that it is in the aspect of evolution from level to level through immense contractions... And it is the aspect of Supernal Wisdom called Eden HaElyon... But the revelation of the illumination that will be at the Resurrection of the Dead will be in the aspect of surrounding all worlds, which is not in the aspect of contraction and measure and limit etc.,' end quote.
"You see from the clarity of his language that the Hall which is in the level of smallness with immense contractions, is called 'Eden HaElyon' (The Upper Eden), and not the level above it in holiness which has no contraction at all. And the Gaon, immediately upon learning his golden language, to understand and be enlightened by the reason for calling the name 'Eden HaElyon', [understood] that perhaps they drag it [the name] to hint at the contracted Hall."
"Shloma Shel Malchut" (Bobov) Av 5762, p. 81

וּמַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁהָי' כָּךְ הָי': בְּעַשַּׁ"ק פָּרָשַׁת בְּשַׁלַּח, כַּאֲשֶׁר יָשַׁב מָרָן מַהַרְבַּ"צ זַצַ"ל עַל הַמִּרְפֶּסֶת בְּאַכְסַנְיָתוֹ, וְהָי' מַעֲבִיר הַסִּדְרָה שְׁמוֹ"ת, עָבַר דֶּרֶךְ שָׁם הַגָּאוֹן הַנַּ"ל, וְכַאֲשֶׁר נִרְאָה מֵרָחוֹק, קָם רַבֵּינוּ זַצַ"ל מִמּוֹשָׁבוֹ וַיֵּלֶךְ לְקַבֵּל פְּנֵי הַגָּאוֹן, וְגַם הוּא בָּא לִקְרַאת רַבֵּינוּ זֶה בָּזֶה.רַבֵּינוּ זַצַ"ל פָּתַח בִּשְׁאֵלָה, הֲיָדַעְתֶּם אֶת זְקִינִי בַּעַל חִבּוּר לְטָהֳרָה. וּבִרְאוֹת רַבֵּינוּ שֶׁלֹּא הִכִּירוֹ עַל שֵׁם סִפְרוֹ, הוֹסִיף וְאָמַר, הֲלֹא אֲנִי נֶכֶד הָרַה"ק מוֹהֲרַ"ר מָרְדְּכַי דֹּב מֵהָארְנָאסְטֵייפְּל זי"ע. הֵשִׁיב הַגָּאוֹן, הֲלֹא ר' מָרְדְּכַי בֶּערְ'נְיוּ הָי' הַיָּחִיד בֵּין הַחֲסִידִים אֲשֶׁר יָדַע הֵיטֵב לִלְמֹד בְּבִינָה וּבְהַשְׂכֵּל.
רַבֵּינוּ זַצַ"ל הֶרְאָה לְפָנָיו אֶת הַפָּסוּק בְּפָרָשַׁת בְּשַׁלַּח (שְׁמוֹת ט"ז כ"ג) "שַׁבָּתוֹן שַׁבַּת קֹדֶשׁ לַה' מָחָר, אֵת אֲשֶׁר תֹּאפוּ אֵפוּ וְאֵת אֲשֶׁר תְּבַשְּׁלוּ בַּשֵּׁלוּ", וְרָמְזוּ בָּהּ חֲזַ"ל (בֵּיצָה טו:) מִכָּאן לְעֵירוּב תַּבְשִׁילִין מֵה"ת, וּפְלוּאִין הַדְּבָרִים כִּי מֵאַיִן רָמְזוּ בַּפָּסוּק הַזֶּה מֵעִנְיַן יוֹ"ט שֶׁחָל לִהְיוֹת בְּע"ש. אַךְ אָמַר לְפָנָיו בְּשֵׁם זְקִינוֹ הַגָּהַ"ק מוֹהֲרַ"ר מָרְדְּכַי דֹּב מֵהָארְנָאסְטֵייפְּל זצוק"ל, כִּי הִנֵּה מָצִינוּ בְּפֵ' הַפָּסוּק (דְּבָרִים ל"ב י') "יִצְרֶנְהוּ כְּאִישׁוֹן עֵינוֹ", אֲשֶׁר פֵּרְשׁוּ הָרִאשׁוֹנִים (עיי"ש בְּרַבֵּינוּ בַּחְיֵי) הַטַּעַם שֶׁנִּקְרָא בָּבַת עֵינוֹ שֶׁל אָדָם בְּשֵׁם אִישׁוֹן, כִּי יֵשׁ בָּהּ צוּרַת אִישׁ, וּלְשׁוֹן אִישׁוֹן הוּא ע"ש קַטְנוּת הַצּוּרָה כִּי לְכָךְ הוֹסִיף ו"ן בְּסוֹף הַתֵּבָה לִרְמֹז שֶׁמַּקְטִין הַדָּבָר, וְכֵן יֵשׁ לְפָרֵשׁ בְּכָל הוֹסָפַת ו"ן בְּסוֹף הַתֵּבָה.
הַגָּאוֹן מִדְּוִוינְסְק, הִפְסִיק אֶת דִּבְרֵי רַבֵּינוּ זַצַ"ל וְאָמַר, הֲלֹא דְּבָרִים הָאֵלּוּ מוּבָאִים כְּבָר בְּסֵפֶר הַתַּנְיָא.הִמְשִׁיךְ רַבֵּינוּ זַצַ"ל כִּי בָּזֶה מוּבָנִים דִּבְרֵי חֲזַ"ל, כִּי כָּתוּב בַּתּוֹרָה שַׁבָּתוֹן, וְהוּא רֶמֶז לְיָמִים טוֹבִים, כִּי הו"ן מַקְטִין הַתֵּבָה, וַהֲלֹא שַׁבָּת הוּא לְמַעְלָה בְּקֹדֶשׁ מִיּוֹם טוֹב, לָכֵן כַּאֲשֶׁר הִקְטִין הַכָּתוּב אֶת הַשַּׁבָּת, כַּוָּנָתָהּ לְדָבָר מֵעִנְיַן יו"ט. וְזֶה פֵּרוּשָׁהּ, שַׁבְּתוֹ"ן, כְּשֶׁאֵירַע יו"ט, שַׁבַּת קֹדֶשׁ לַה' מָחָר, ר"ל וּלְמָחֳרַת יוֹ"ם יִהְיֶ' שַׁבַּת קֹדֶשׁ, אֲזַי, אֵת אֲשֶׁר תֹּאפוּ אֵפוּ וְאֵת אֲשֶׁר תְּבַשְּׁלוּ בַּשֵּׁלוּ, אֲפִי' בְּיו"ט שֶׁחָל לִהְיוֹת בְּעֶרֶ"שׁ.נַעֲנָה הַגָּאוֹן הַנַּ"ל, חִדּוּשׁ זֶה כָּתוּב בְּסֵפֶר הַיָּשָׁר לְרַבֵּינוּ תָּם זַ"ל.
בְּאוֹתוֹ מַעֲמָד אָמַר לְפָנָיו רַבֵּינוּ זַצַ"ל מַה שֶּׁאָמַר בְּבֵאוּר לְשׁוֹן הַפַּיְּטָן סַמְבַּטְיוֹן הַנָּהָר, שֶׁבְּכָל יוֹם רָץ וְנִמְהָר, יוֹכִיחַ בּוֹ מָנוֹחַ (עי' דְּבָרָיו בַּסְּפָהַ"ק קְדֻשַּׁת צִיּוֹן ח"ב בְּעִנְיְנֵי שַׁבַּת קֹדֶשׁ). וּבָזֶה נִפְרְדוּ לְשָׁלוֹם.
כ"ק מָרָן זצוק"ל נִבְהַל וְנִשְׁתּוֹמֵם מִגֹּדֶל חֲרִיפוּת הַגָּאוֹן, אֲשֶׁר עַל כָּל דִּבּוּר מָצָא לוֹ עֵד מוֹכִיחַ בִּסְפָרִים קַדְמוֹנִים, וְרָצָה רַבֵּינוּ זַצַ"ל לִרְאוֹת הַדְּבָרִים כְּתוּבִין עֲלֵי גִּלָּיוֹן, וְחִפֵּשׂ וּמָצָא בְּסֵפֶר הַיָּשָׁר אֲשֶׁר כָּתַב עַל דְּרָשַׁת חֲזַ"ל הַנַּ"ל, וְזַל"ק, נִרְאֶה בְּעֵינִי דְּמֵרֵישָׁא דִּקְרָא נָפְקָא, ע"כ. וּבְרֹב הִתְפַּעֲלוּת הֶרְאָה רַבֵּינוּ זַצַ"ל לִמְקֹרָבָיו, בֶּאֱמֶת, רְאוּ גַּדְלוּת חֲרִיפוּת שֶׁל עִלּוּי אֲשֶׁר יָדַע לְבָרֵר בְּכַוָּנַת הָר"ת, בְּעֹמֶק חָכְמָתוֹ וְסוֹד בִּינָתוֹ, אֲשֶׁר עִקַּר כַּוָּנָתוֹ הֵן הֵן הַדְּבָרִים הָאֲמוּרִים לְעֵיל.
כַּעֲבֹר לְעֵרֶךְ שָׁנָה מֵהַפְּגִישָׁה, קָרָא רַבֵּינוּ זַצַ"ל לְכַמָּה בַּחוּרֵי חֶמֶד הַמִּסְתּוֹפְפִים בְּצִלּוֹ, וְאָמַר לָהֶם, בּוֹאוּ וּרְאוּ עַד הֵיכָן מַגִּיעַ עֹמֶק חֲרִיפוּתוֹ שֶׁל הָעִלּוּי הַגָּאוֹן מֵרָאגַאטְשָׁאוּו, כִּי מֵאָז דִּבַּרְתִּי אִתּוֹ עִיַּנְתִּי כְּבָר שָׁלוֹשׁ פְּעָמִים בְּכָל סֵפֶר הַתַּנְיָא, וְלֹא מָצָאתִי רֶמֶז לִדְבָרָיו, אֲשֶׁר אָמַר כִּי הוּא זֶה כַּוָּנַת בַּעַל הַתַּנְיָא לוֹמַר שֶׁאוֹתִיּוֹת ו"ן מְרַמְּזִים עַל הַקַּטְנוּת. אַךְ עַתָּה בַּעֲבוּר שָׁנָה תְּמִימָה יָגַעְתִּי וּמָצָאתִי בִּדְבָרָיו, אֲשֶׁר כּוֹתֵב בְּאִגֶּרֶת הַקֹּדֶשׁ סִימָן י"ז, וְזַל"ק, שֶׁהַהֶאָרָה וְהַגִּילּוּי שֶׁבְּגַ"ע הִיא בְּחִינַת מְמַלֵּא כָּל עָלְמִין שֶׁהוּא בְּחִינַת הִשְׁתַּלְשְׁלוּת מִמַּדְרֵגָה לְמַדְרֵגָה ע"י צִמְצוּמִים עֲצוּמִים... וְהִיא בְּחִינַת חָכְמָה עִילָּאָה הַנִּקְרָא עֵדֶן הָעֶלְיוֹן... אֲבָל גִּילּוּי הַהֶאָרָה שֶׁבִּתְחִיַּת הַמֵּתִים יִהְיֶ', מִבְּחִינַת סוֹבֵב כָּל עָלְמִין שֶׁאֵינָהּ בְּחִינַת צִמְצוּם וְשִׁעוּר וּגְבוּל וְכוּ', עכלה"ק. הִנְּךָ רוֹאֶה מִצַּחוּת לְשׁוֹנוֹ שֶׁהַהֵיכָל אֲשֶׁר הִיא בְּדַרְגַּת הַקַּטְנוּת בְּצִמְצוּמִים עֲצוּמִים, הִיא נִקְרֵאת עֵדֶן הָעֶלְיוֹ"ן, וְלֹא הַמַּדְרֵגָה שֶׁלְּמַעְלָה הֵימֶנּוּ בַּקֹּדֶשׁ שֶׁאֵין בָּהּ צִמְצוּם כְּלָל. וְהַגָּאוֹן, תֵּיכֶף בְּלָמְדוֹ לְשׁוֹנוֹ הַזָּהָב שֶׁל בַּעַל הַתַּנְיָא, לְהָבִין וּלְהַשְׂכִּיל בְּטַעַם קְרִיאַת שֵׁם עֵדֶן הָעֶלְיוֹ"ן, כִּי שֶׁמָּא גָּרִים לָהּ לִרְמֹז עַל הֵיכַל הַמְצֻמְצָם."שלומה של מלכות" (באבוב) אב תשס"ב, ע' פ"א
