Regarding the Gaon of Rogatchov, one of the great men expressed that it was a wonder in his eyes that he did not have the ability to revive the dead with the very power of his Torah.
Source: C.K. Maran Admor of Mamshinov-USA zt"l, "Yemot Olam" (Brooklyn 5758) p. 191, Letter 6

The Rabbi and Tzaddik R' Neta Lifshitz shlit"a told me that he once heard from the holy Rabbi R' Shimon of Zelichov zt"l, who said about the Gaon of Rogatchov that he is the Gadol HaDor (Greatest of the Generation). [He is the greatest in the generation].
Source: Hrh"g R' Yisrael Chaim Ashri shlit"a, "Siach Zekenim" (Brooklyn 5760) Part 3, p. 8

Two men came to Rabbi Yashe of Dvinsk [the author of *Tzafnat Paneach* zt"l] for a Din Torah (Torah judgment). He was then busy with study and did not want to accept the Din Torah, and almost pushed them outside.
They went to the Gaon Rabbi Meir Simcha [author of *Ohr Sameach* zt"l] and told him. He said to them: "Justice is with him. For there is an explicit Gemara in Bava Kamma (6b) that asks why it is written in the Mishna 'Chav' (Liable) and it should have said 'Chayyav' with two Yuds. And it answers: 'This Tanna is a Yerushalmi (Jerusalemite), and there they say Chav instead of Chayyav.' Therefore, he took out two Yuds (Yudin/Jews)."
"And the Gaon Rabbi Yashe is also a 'Yerushalmi Yid' [=A Jew who knows the Jerusalem Talmud by heart]. Therefore, he threw out the two Yudin [=Jews]."
Source: Haga"ch R' Yosef Patzanovski zt"l Hy"d, "Gan Yosef" (Bnei Brak 5758) p. 114, Letter 495

They say in the name of the Gaon of Rogatchov zt"l that once a Jew came to him to be blessed by him. He added and said: "If the Sages zt"l say (Berachot 7a): '**אל תהא ברכת הדיוט קלה בעיניך**' - '**Let not the blessing of a simpleton be light in your eyes**,' how much more so from a great man like yourself, certainly his blessing will be effective."
The Gaon zt"l replied to him by way of humor: "If it is possible to bless without a *Kal Vachomer* (a fortiori argument), why do I need to bless you with a *Kal Vachomer* (also means 'with a vomit')?"
Source: Haga"ch Rabbi Yisrael Shimon Kastelnetz zt"l, "Tachin Libam" (Bnei Brak 5760) p. 164

In Lithuanian Yeshivot, they study while standing; every student has a lectern (shtender) where he stands and learns. When the Gaon Rabbi Yoshe of Dvinsk zt"l [author of *Tzafnat Paneach* zt"l] sat during study time, someone went to him and hinted to him: Why is he sitting and not standing like everyone else?
He answered him that explicitly in Midrash Rabbah [Shemot Rabbah 47:8], it is written: "One says [Deuteronomy 9:9]: '**ואשב בהר ארבעים יום וכו'**' - '**And I sat on the mountain forty days etc.**' And another verse says [Deuteronomy 5:5]: '**אנכי עומד בהר**' - '**I stood on the mountain.**'"
"Standing and learning, sitting and reviewing. To learn for the first time, one needs to stand. And we can do that in the Yeshiva. But he has already learned Shas and Poskim, and now he is reviewing."
"Regarding everything, he has a saying of the Sages zt"l," said that person with resentment.
He told him: "If you do not want it from the Sages zt"l, there is an explicit verse: '**ושננתם לבניך**' - '**And you shall teach them diligently to your children.**' If you repeat the study, then '**ודברת בם בשבתך**' - '**And you shall speak of them when you sit**' - you are permitted to sit."
Source: Haga"ch R' Yosef Patzanovski Hy"d, "Gan Yosef" (Bnei Brak 5758) p. 59, Letter 253

K"K my father and teacher (Shlita) [ZT"L] explains the verse (Ecclesiastes 11:6): **בבקר זרע זרעך ולערב אל תנח ידך** - "In the morning sow your seed, and in the evening do not withhold your hand" - meaning that if one educates his offspring properly already "In the morning" - from the dawn of their youth, then "In the evening" - in the twilight of his days, "Do not withhold your hand" - you will have satisfaction (*Nachas*), you will merit to see from them much satisfaction.
Source: Bitaon Vizhnitz

During his stay in Mir, our Rabbi (the Gaon Rabbi Shlomo Shimshon Karelitz zt"l) merited to live in the same lodging with one of the lions of the Yeshiva, Rabbi Naftali Beinush Wasserman Hy"d, the son of our Rabbi the Gaon Rabbi Elchanan Wasserman Hy"d. R' Naftali, who was known as a great Torah scholar, frequently found himself in the company of the Torah giants of Israel. He would constantly repeat before his friend, our Rabbi zt"l, what he saw and heard from them. (As testified by the Gaon Rabbi Shmuel Rozovsky zt"l, Rosh Yeshiva of Ponevezh, R' Naftali's friend from their study period in "Chavruta" in the Grodno Yeshiva under our Rabbi the Gra"sh Shkop zt"l: R' Naftali was destined to be one of the greats of the generation. But the generation was not worthy, and upon the fall of the people of G-d by the sword, R' Naftali was killed with his family Hy"d, on the 9th of Cheshvan 5702, at the age of about 28).
R' Naftali, who frequented the door of the Gaon Rabbi Yosef Rosen zt"l of Dvinsk—the Rogatchover—in order to discuss the battle of Torah with him, used to tell our Rabbi many stories about him. He testified about him that he never saw anyone like him whose mouth never ceased from reciting.
Our Rabbi, who would repeat the various incidents he heard from R' Naftali zt"l about the Gaon the Rogatchover, told:
Once R' Naftali entered the abode of the Rogatchover to ask him a difficulty on the Yerushalmi in Horayot. When he presented the words of the Yerushalmi before him, the Rogatchover said to him on the spot: "You added a word that is not written in the Yerushalmi!"
R' Naftali insisted and claimed that this word *is* written in the Yerushalmi, for just now he literally saw the words of the Yerushalmi inside. Immediately, they took out a Yerushalmi from the bookcase, and the truth was clarified. That word was not in the Yerushalmi itself, but in the glosses of the Gra (Vilna Gaon), he added this word.
In the face of the facts, the Rogatchover reacted and said to R' Naftali: "Nu, if so, these are the words of the Gra; this is not Yerushalmi!"
Our Rabbi further told in the name of R' Naftali, that when the Rogatchover spoke a little about worldly matters, he would spice his "idle chatter" with idioms from the Bavli and Yerushalmi. As he expressed himself once and said about his wife: "Ha, she forgot a *Mechilta*!" (She forgot a broom/container - play on words with the book *Mechilta*).
Source: "Amudei Shesh" (Bnei Brak 5761) p. 72

body_he:
ר' נַפְתָּלִי, שֶׁהָיָה מְשַׁחֵר לְפִתְחוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי יוֹסֵף רוֹזִין זַצַ"ל מִדְּוִוינְסְק - הָרוֹגוֹטְשׁוֹבֶר, כְּדֵי לִישָּׂא וְלִיתֵּן עִמּוֹ בְּמִלְחַמְתָּהּ שֶׁל תּוֹרָה, הָיָה מְסַפֵּר לְרַבֵּינוּ רַבּוֹת אוֹדוֹתָיו, וְהֵעִיד בּוֹ שֶׁלֹּא רָאָה כְּמוֹהוּ מִי שֶׁלֹּא פָּסַק פֻּומֵיהּ מִגִּירְסָא.
רַבֵּינוּ, שֶׁהָיָה חוֹזֵר בְּהִזְדַּמְּנוּיוֹת שׁוֹנוֹת עַל אוֹתָן עֻבְדּוֹת שֶׁשָּׁמַע מֵר' נַפְתָּלִי זַצַ"ל, אוֹדוֹת הַגָּאוֹן הָרוֹגוֹטְשׁוֹבֶר, סִפֵּר, שֶׁפַּעַם נִכְנַס ר' נַפְתָּלִי לִמְעוֹנוֹ שֶׁל הָרוֹגוֹטְשׁוֹבֶר, לִשְׁאוֹל מִפִּיו קֻשְׁיָא עַל הַיְרוּשַׁלְמִי בְּהוֹרָיוֹת. כְּשֶׁהִצִּיעַ לְפָנָיו אֶת דִּבְרֵי הַיְרוּשַׁלְמִי, אָמַר לוֹ הָרוֹגוֹטְשׁוֹבֶר עַל אֲתַר: "הוֹסַפְתָּ מִילָה שֶׁלֹּא כְּתוּבָה בִּירוּשַׁלְמִי"! הִתְעַקֵּשׁ ר' נַפְתָּלִי וְטָעַן שֶׁהַמִּילָה הַזּוֹ כְּתוּבָה בִּירוּשַׁלְמִי, שֶׁכֵּן זֶה עַתָּה מַמָּשׁ רָאָה אֶת דִּבְרֵי הַיְרוּשַׁלְמִי בִּפְנִים. מִיָּד הוֹצִיאוּ יְרוּשַׁלְמִי מִן הָאָרוֹן, וְנִתְבָּרְרָה הָאֱמֶת. אוֹתָהּ מִילָה לֹא הָיְתָה כְּתוּבָה בִּירוּשַׁלְמִי גּוּפָא, אֶלָּא שֶׁבְּהַגָּהוֹת הַגְּרָ"א הוֹסִיף תֵּבָה זוֹ. לְנֹכַח הַדְּבָרִים, הֵגִיב הָרוֹגוֹטְשׁוֹבֶר וְאָמַר לְר' נַפְתָּלִי: "נוּ, אִם כֵּן זֶה דִּבְרֵי הַגְּרָ"א, זֶה לֹא יְרוּשַׁלְמִי!", עוֹד סִפֵּר רַבֵּינוּ בְּשֵׁם ר' נַפְתָּלִי, שֶׁכְּשֶׁהָיָה הָרוֹגוֹטְשׁוֹבֶר מְדַבֵּר מְעַט מֵעִנְיְנֵי עָלְמָא, הָיָה מְתַבֵּל אֶת הַ"שִּׂיחַת חֻלִּין" שֶׁלּוֹ בִּלְשׁוֹנוֹת מִן הַבַּבְלִי וְהַיְרוּשַׁלְמִי, כְּמוֹ שֶׁהִתְבַּטֵּא פַּעַם וְאָמַר עַל אִשְׁתּוֹ: "הָא, זִי הָאט פַארְגֶעסֶען אַ מְכִילְתָּא!" (הִיא שָׁכְחָה 'מְכִילְתָּא').
בִּהְיוֹת כָּל מַעְיָינוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן הָרוֹגוֹטְשׁוֹבֶר בַּתּוֹרָה - סִפֵּר רַבֵּינוּ בְּשֵׁם ר' נַפְתָּלִי הִי"ד - הִבִּיט הַגָּאוֹן עַל כָּל מְאוֹרְעוֹת הַחַיִּים מִתּוֹךְ עֻמְקָהּ שֶׁל הֲלָכָה. וְכַאֲשֶׁר גִּילּוּ הָרוֹפְאִים שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ לָרוֹגוֹטְשׁוֹבֶר אֲבָנִים בַּכְּלָיוֹת, הָיְתָה תְּגוּבָתוֹ שֶׁיֵּשׁ לְהִסְתַּפֵּק אִם יֵשׁ בָּזֶה "טֻמְאַת רָקָב" אוֹ שֶׁנַּעֲשָׂה "גַּנְגִילּוֹן". וְהָיְתָה כַּוָּנָתוֹ לַמְבֹאָר בְּמַסֶּכֶת נִדָּה (כז, אב), שֶׁרָקָב שֶׁל מֵת, מְטַמֵּא רַק כַּאֲשֶׁר אֵין דָּבָר חִיצוֹנִי שֶׁמְּעוֹרָב בּוֹ, וְהַנּוֹסָף הַמְּעוֹרָב נִקְרָא גַּנְגִילּוֹן, שֶׁהוּא עוֹמֵד כְּנֶגְדּוֹ לְבַטְּלוֹ וּלְקַלְקְלוֹ. וּבָזֶה נִסְתַּפֵּק הַגָּאוֹן הָרוֹגוֹטְשׁוֹבֶר זַצַ"ל, הַאִם הָאֲבָנִים שֶׁבַּכְּלָיוֹת נֶחְשָׁבִים לְחֵלֶק מִגּוּף הָאָדָם וּמְטַמֵּא טֻמְאַת מֵת, אוֹ שֶׁהֵם נִדּוֹנִים כְּדָבָר חִיצוֹנִי וְנַעֲשֶׂה גַּנְגִילּוֹן, שֶׁאֵינוֹ מְטַמֵּא. כָּזֶה הָיָה שִׂיחוֹ וְשִׂיגוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן זַצַ"ל, גַּם בְּמִילֵי דְּעָלְמָא.
סִפֵּר ר' נַפְתָּלִי לְרַבֵּינוּ זַצַ"ל - שֶׁפַּעַם נִכְנַס בָּחוּר לְדַבֵּר עִמּוֹ בְּדִבְרֵי תּוֹרָה, וְתוֹךְ כְּדֵי דִּבּוּר, הִתְבַּטֵּא הַלָּה בְּזִלְזוּל כְּלַפֵּי אֵיזֶה שֶׁהוּא דְּבַר הֲלָכָה שֶׁכָּתַב הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אֵיגֶר, בְּסוֹבְרוֹ שֶׁלִּפְנֵי הָרוֹגוֹטְשׁוֹבֶר יָכוֹל הוּא לְהִתְבַּטֵּא כָּךְ. בְּרַם, לֹא עָלָה הַדָּבָר יָפֶה בְּעֵינֵי הָרוֹגוֹטְשׁוֹבֶר זַצַ"ל וְהוּא קָם מִיָּד וְסָטַר לְאוֹתוֹ בָּחוּר עַל לֶחְיוֹ, תּוֹךְ שֶׁהוּא קוֹרֵא לְעֻמָּתוֹ: "מְבַזֶּה תַּלְמִיד חָכָם!""עמודי שש" (ב"ב תשס"א) ע' 72
body_en:
A Jew happened to be in the city of Rogatchov during the First World War. Suddenly, frightening and terrifying shooting exchanges began. The man pressed himself against the wall and decided to enter the first house he came across to take cover.
When he reached a house—it was exactly the house where the Gaon the Rogatchover zt"l lived—who stood by the window and shouted to the Jew: "Quick, come in to me! A wonderful Chiddush (novelty) has just occurred to me, whose source is in the Tosefta, and through it, it is possible to resolve a Rambam!..."
The Jew was astounded. He initially thought the Rogatchover was referring to the shooting. And behold, he was immersed and concentrated in his study, and amidst the barrage of shooting—the only thing that interested him was resolving the words of the Rambam!...
Source: The Gaon Rabbi Shalom Mordechai HaKohen Schwadron zt"l, "Sha'al Avicha Veyagdecha" (Jerusalem 5739) Part 3, p. 15

A story about Rabbi Meir Simcha (author of *Ohr Sameach* and *Meshech Chochmah* zt"l) who sat in a gathering of Torah scholars who were telling words of Torah. They also recounted the praises of the greats of the generation. Their words rolled onto Rabbi Yosef Rosen, the Rogatchover.
One of the group answered and said about him: "A possessor of wondrous memory, behold he is Rabbi Yosef. Literally a cemented cistern that does not lose a drop."
Rabbi Meir Simcha said: "Rabbi Yosef is not a possessor of memory at all and essentially."
"What does that mean?" the gathered wondered.
"Simple matters," Rabbi Meir Simcha replied to them. "One who learns and knows after a long time, he is a possessor of memory. But Rabbi Yosef, whose learning is in his mouth all day and every hour—shall this one be called a possessor of memory?!"
It was fluent in the mouth of Rabbi Meir Simcha to praise the power of comprehension of the Gaon Rabbi Yosef Rosen, the Rogatchover, more than his power of memory. Saying about him that every matter and subject was clear to him as if he was engaged in it right now (for he is just now learning it).
Source: Rabbi Asher Bergman shlit"a, "HaOhr Sameach" (Bnei Brak 5761) p. 76

The Gaon Rabbi Yisrael Zev Gustman *zt"l*, Rosh Yeshiva of "Netzach Yisrael Ramayles", recounted that when he was still young in years, he already served as a Dayan in the Beis Din of HaGaon R' Chaim Ozer Grodzinski *zt"l* in Vilna. Once, Rabbi Chaim Ozer sent a letter to the Gaon of Rogatchov, Rabbi Yosef Rosen *zt"l*, containing a specific question. When the Rogatchover's reply arrived, Rabbi Yisrael Zev stood next to Rabbi Chaim Ozer and saw how he read the letter in the blink of an eye and expressed himself: "Nu, he has his way of learning, and I have my way of learning..."
As is known, the Rogatchover would write and reply with vigorous brevity, everything being "See there and see there." Rabbi Gustman and another one of the Dayanim of Rabbi Chaim Ozer's Beis Din sat for four days afterward to decipher the answer—that which Rabbi Chaim Ozer had processed in a single moment, in the blink of an eye!
Source: "She'al Avicha Veyagedcha" (Jerusalem 5739), Part 3, p. 19

The speech of HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman Broda *zt"l*, Rosh Yeshiva of Chevron, was full of grace and pleasantness. Like the words of the wise, he spoke gently. Thus they are also heard; he was not particular about the exact sequence of events, allowing things to flow at the pace of memories... In a time of favor and a rare hour, our Rebbe *zt"l* agreed to converse at length about his famous and well-known journey to the city of Slabodka, with the author Rabbi Yisrael Friedman *shlita*...
"It was in the year 5694 (1934). I was studying then in the Chevron Yeshiva in Jerusalem. The Gaon Rabbi Eliezer Yehuda Finkel *zt"l*—Rosh Yeshiva of Mir—used to come, from time to time, to visit the Yeshiva..."
"On one of the occasions when he arrived in the Land of Israel and came to the Chevron Yeshiva, he met us. For some reason, he took an interest in me and my friend—Rabbi Simcha Pins *zt"l*. Perhaps we found favor in his eyes. He began to lobby for us to travel to the Slabodka Yeshiva in Lithuania. The discussion then was for a short visit, to be impressed by the Yeshiva..."
The memories lead him over days, crossing countries, on his path from then to the Yeshiva of *there*. About the journey by ship via Romania, about the road to Poland. About the state of war between Poland and Lithuania, which forced a passage through Latvia—in the absence of open borders. "When we arrived in Poland, we stopped at a transit station, in a place called 'Druzgenik', where Rabbi Leizer Yudel *zt"l* was staying. The place was a resort. The time was the season of Tammuz. The greats of Israel used to come to this place for a 'dacha'."
Here, HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman Broda met Maran HaGaon Rabbi Baruch Ber *zt"l*. "The Mashgiach of Mir—HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yeruchem *zt"l*—was also staying in the place then..."
The next stop for HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman Broda and Rabbi Simcha Pins was Dvinsk. "It seems to me that Rabbi Simcha Pins had a relative living in the place. When we arrived, he received us. He also took us to the home of the Rogatchover. There, he introduced us as Yeshiva students from the Land of Israel. We extended a hand for 'Shalom Aleichem'. And what was the 'Shalom Aleichem' the Rogatchover first said to us? 'A miracle that there is a Ramban,' that is what he said."
What did the Rogatchover mean? HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman explains: On the verse **באו פריצים וחללוה** - "Robbers have entered and profaned it," the Gemara in Tractate Avodah Zarah [52b] says that if *Pritzim* (violent men/robbers) conquered the Land of Israel, this profanes and removes its sanctity. On this, the Ramban and the Baal HaMaor disagreed. The Baal HaMaor says—even Jewish *Pritzim*. The Ramban says—that the sanctity of the land departs only when speaking of Gentile *Pritzim*. "A miracle that there is a Ramban," HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman repeats the "Shalom Aleichem" of the Rogatchover. Otherwise, without the Ramban, there would be no sanctity of the Land of Israel—"For robbers have entered and profaned it." "This left a strong impression on us, it left a tremendous mark," he says.
HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman relates the things exactly as they were. He adds nothing of his own. Without the "roses" that writers of history are accustomed to pouring over the past. The sight of his events is precise and penetrating at once. And even if you are moved by the stories, this helps to transfer the matters from the dominion of the heart to the authority of the intellect. "Robbers have entered and profaned it"—"A miracle that there is a Ramban."
Regarding the Rogatchover's love for those who study Torah, HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman *zt"l* relates: "Throughout the time we were with him, a young Yeshiva boy sat next to him; I estimate his age was eighteen, nineteen approximately. He sat next to him, close to the Rogatchover, who patted him on his shoulder, 'I love him,' the Rogatchover explained what we sensed in our astonishment. 'He is, after all, a Yeshiva *bachur*. He is, after all, a *Ben Torah*!!!' Such was his great love for those who study Torah."
"Of course, the Gaon began to converse with us in words of Torah," HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman continues to tell of their meeting with the Rogatchover: "Every so often he needed a book, for he wanted to show us inside, everything in its source. He was no longer a young man, at all, but when he wanted to bring a book, he got up himself, with truly youthful agility. With surprising speed, he climbed the ladder to take down the required volume. His room was packed with books. But he, of course, was not forced to search for the book. In his memory, it was absolutely clear where each and every one of his multitudes of books resided."
"The Rogatchover would not let go of the Gemara from his hand, even while he climbed the ladder to take down a book he needed. When he climbed the ladder, the Gemara remained in his hand and his finger was placed on the place where he was learning. We did not understand why he does this, and does not put the Gemara down from his hand? The Rogatchover said: 'Is it not written in Mishlei (23:5) **התעיף עיניך בו ואיננו** - "Will you fly your eyes from it and it is gone," and how can I put the Gemara down from my hand even for a slight moment...'"
The Rogatchover's intention was referring to the words of the Gemara (Berachot 5a) that the Torah is called "Oph" (Bird/Fowl), as it is said: **התעיף עיניך בו ואיננו** - "Will you fly your eyes from it and it is gone," and Rashi explains: "If you double and shut your eyes from the Torah, it will be forgotten from you."
Here, in the station of HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman's words, another topic arises in his memory upon which the conversation with the Rogatchover turned. This was the Gemara in Ketubot page 38b, regarding whether there is maturity in the grave: "A Mishna explicitly in Tractate Keilim escaped the Gemara..." said the Rogatchover.
"It was about a year after the passing of the Rosh Yeshiva—HaGaon Rabbi Moshe Mordechai Epstein *zt"l*. Together with a group of students from Chevron Yeshiva, we learned Mishnayot, Tractate Keilim, for the elevation of his soul. It was a study in depth. The Tractate was fluent in our memories well," he (HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman) remembers and recounts.
HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman, with quickness of thought, compared one matter to another. He understood immediately which Mishna the Rogatchover intended. "Does the Rav mean this Mishna?" he asked...
The Rogatchover enjoyed greatly the proficiency and sharpness of the young scholar from the Land of Israel; satisfaction spread over his face. "It was the Mishna in Tractate Keilim Chapter 15 Mishna 7," relates HaGaon R' Shlomo Zalman. "There, Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua disagreed regarding the law of metal vessels: 'He sprinkled upon them, they broke on that day, he fixed them and returned and sprinkled upon them a second time on that day, behold they are pure, the words of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Yehoshua says, there is no sprinkling less than the third and seventh day.' According to this Mishna, a dispute of Tannaim is explained: Whether that which the vessel was broken between the sprinkling of the third day and the sprinkling of the seventh day is considered an interruption to the count of the seven days—or do we continue to count the seven days—even though the vessel was broken in the middle. If so, this discussion is exactly similar to the doubt of the Gemara regarding whether there is maturity in the grave, meaning, if that which she reached the time of her maturity when she was dead, behold this is considered that she is an adult (regarding to whom the fines are paid) or not..."
Thus they continued to speak for a long time.
At the end of the words, the two told the Rogatchover that they were traveling to Slabodka for a limited period of time. "He asked of us that we return to visit his home on our way back. But when we returned, we did not meet him anymore. He was absent from Dvinsk for the need of medical treatments he required. A relative of R' Simcha Pins related that the Rogatchover was interested in us the whole time. He always asked: 'Have the boys from the Land of Israel returned yet?'..."
Source: "Nesich Mamlechet HaTorah" (Jerusalem 5761), p. 173

The Gaon of Rogatchov said that he has the power to learn a new language in the span of a single night—but from where does one take that night?
Source: "Yemot Olam" (Brooklyn 5758), p. 104, Letter D

A story involving the Gaon, the Rogatchover: In the middle of his studies, a woman entered to him with a loud cry: Her daughter is having difficulty giving birth and is in danger. The Rogatchover scolded her with a shout: "What do you want from me? Go to a Rebbe!" and he returned to his studies. The woman was terrified by the shouting and continued to cry, while the Rav forgot in the meantime what had happened and immersed himself in his studies. After a number of minutes passed, he suddenly noticed that a woman was standing in the room crying. Immediately he turned to her and asked her: "Why are you crying? What happened? Return to your home, Hashem will help and your troubles will disappear..."
The woman replied: "This is what I waited for, that the Rav should bless me." She hurried to return to her home, and by the time she arrived there, they had already congratulated her with "Mazel Tov." The baby had emerged into the air of the world!...
Source: "She'al Avicha Veyagedcha" (Jerusalem 5739), Part 1, p. 77

It is told that HaGaon Rabbi Shimon Shkop *zt"l* met the Gaon of Rogatchov *zt"l*, and asked him if *Kiddushin* (betrothal) is a "Chalut" (legal status) from the beginning of the time until the end, or if *Kiddushin* occurs at every moment. The Gaon of Rogatchov said to him: "If so, you deserve a 'Mazel Tov' right now—for the *Kiddushin* has just been renewed for you."
Source: "Beit Umenucha" (Jerusalem 5758), p. 172

They tell that the Gaon of Rogatchov once said that for him, the hardest day is the Sabbath day: When he finds himself in a state of the racing of the mind, where one logic falls to him, and immediately—a reverse logic, and immediately after it an additional logic to reverse the previous two logics, and so on. Behold, on weekdays he has advice: to take a pen and paper and write the logics, and automatically the letters of the script limit the racing of the mind. However, on the Sabbath day—he has no advice for this, and furthermore, this very knowledge that he cannot write and limit the racing of the mind causes an even greater race, and it is understood how much "Agmas Nefesh" (distress of the soul) comes from this matter.
Source: "She'al Avicha Veyagedcha" (Jerusalem 5739) [Implied context]

The story is known of one of the Rabbis who came to the Gaon of Rogatchov to receive "Semicha" (ordination). He told him that he would test him specifically on the laws of Reading the Torah Scroll, because when a question arises in other laws, there is time to look in books etc., whereas with a question during the Reading of the Torah, because of the honor of the congregation, one is compelled to rule immediately.
The custom of the Gaon of Rogatchov in giving ordinations is known, that he was particular that [the candidate] be G-d-fearing. As he said, to find one who will be satisfied with his knowledge of Torah is a difficult thing, but if there is certainty in the Fear of Heaven of the ordained one, behold this is a guarantee that if he does not know, he will not rule the law until he investigates and seeks and finds the ruling.
The Gaon of Rogatchov also learned Kabbalah, and as is known to some of those who conversed with him face to face, even though he does not cite these books explicitly.
They tell of the Gaon of Rogatchov *zt"l*, that before the holiday of Pesach, when they were baking *Shmurah Matzah*, he did not want to go to the bakery. When asked for the reason for the matter—how is he permitted to go against the custom of Israel to go to the bakery, and the pumping of "Mayim Shelanu" (water that rested overnight)—he replied: "When I go to the bakery, it is reasonable to assume that I will find matters there that in my opinion are not the ultimate strictness. This is not so when I do not go myself and rely on the *Chezkas Kashrus* (presumption of fitness) of every Jew (see Rambam Laws of Sanctification of the Month 5:2, Laws of Foundations of the Torah beginning of Chapter 7)—behold there is no place to doubt with suspicions regarding the Shulchan Aruch (which establishes the fitness of the Jew)."
Source: "She'al Avicha Veyagedcha" (Jerusalem 5739) [Implied context]

Rabbi Yashe of Dinaburg [the author of *Tzafnat Paneach* *zt"l*] walked in the cemetery in Warsaw, and he was speaking in learning. They asked him, is he not mocking the poor (the dead)? He said to them: "The dead here, even if they were alive, would not know or understand what I am saying."
Source: "Gan Yosef" (Bnei Brak 5758), p. 100, Letter 432

The mighty Gaon R' Yosef Rosen *z"l*, known by the name "The Rogatchover Gaon," came to Vienna at the end of his days regarding his illness. When this became known to us, we printed a proclamation that the Rabbi of all the children of the Diaspora would come in the evening to Vienna, and that they should come to give honor to the Torah. There were some synagogues that had a complaint: "Is it possible that young Poskim decide who is the Rabbi of all the children of the Diaspora?" And they commanded the beadle to remove the proclamations.
At night, when we were at the railway, the train came, but the aforementioned Gaon did not come. But a Jew came and told us in the name of the aforementioned Gaon that in Warsaw there were some thousands of Jews at the railway, and they did not let them travel in any way, only that he should stay overnight in Warsaw.
Afterward, we went to print another proclamation, and in it was printed that he did not come yesterday for the aforementioned reason, and this made a bit of an impression. Then more people came than yesterday. And when the mighty Gaon came, his form made a great impression on everyone who saw him; the appearance of his face was very awesome.
From the railway, he traveled immediately to the Sanatorium Auersperg. There the doctors began to engage in treatments, and through this, he began to feel terrible suffering. He cried from the pain, and said that the doctors are killing him. His Rebbetzin told me a few times to go inside and ask difficult questions, saying that only through Torah is it possible to ease his suffering. However, I did not ask the Gaon anything, for his genius was not according to our generation.
Rabbi Berman *zt"l* came to him; he was an exceptional Talmid Chacham, and HaGaon Rabbi Meir Arik *zt"l* said about him (about the aforementioned Rabbi Berman) that he has a straight mind in learning. He said some novellae before the aforementioned Gaon, and when he expanded on his pilpul, the Gaon said to him: "Rogatchover Gaon, what are you joking about?" From this, one can see that his mind did not tolerate our generation, and not for nothing do we see that in all his books he did not bring the Acharonim (later sages), and uses only the Rishonim (early sages).
I heard that when his first wife died upon him, and they brought her for burial, he stood at the side of his head near one of the tombstones there. When they had already made the shape of the grave, they told the Gaon that Kaddish needs to be said, for he had no male son. He said: "Oy, she has died... (Azoy zi iz nebach geshtorben...)" So much were his thoughts occupied in Torah.
The suffering overcame him day by day, and his pure soul departed on Thursday before Purim. Immediately afterward, they transported his pure body to the hall of Agudas Yisrael Youth. There, in the hall, the youth performed the purification (Taharah), and I merited, with one young man, to hold him at the time they poured the nine Kavs [of water] upon him. Afterward, they placed his pure body in a special coffin in which they place the deceased who are transported to other countries.
On the eve of Shabbos Kodesh in the morning, they came from the government to close the coffin with lead seals [and they do this so they do not smuggle anything inside the coffin]. Then they needed to tie his pure body with ropes that were already prepared in the coffin, so that his body would not shake from the burden of the road and from the shaking during the journey. I did this myself, for I did not want the uncircumcised to touch him. Afterward, they sealed the coffin.
This Gaon lay in the hall of the youth all that Holy Shabbos. It was a wonder then, for the children played then in that same hall, just like every Shabbos of the year, and there was no fear recognizable in them at all, as is the way of those afraid of the deceased. Many people came and stood before the coffin and said "Gut Shabbos," and in the eulogy, they said that if he had lived many hundreds of years ago, he would also have been considered a Gaon.
Source: "Shem Mishimon" (Brooklyn 5726), p. 487

I heard that in the previous World War (WWI), the land was under Turkish rule, and they decreed that all those who were not born in the land must be expelled. This matter was a hard blow. However, in the disorder of the Turkish rule, people did not have birth certificates or identity cards. They said that whoever would swear that he was born in the Land of Israel would remain in the land.
The question arose whether those not born in the land are permitted to swear due to *Pikuach Nefesh* (saving a life) and nullify it in their heart. Rabbi Zitron, the Av Beit Din of Petach Tikva *zt"l*, turned to his father-in-law, the Wonder of the Generation, Rabbi Yosef the Rogatchover *zt"l* in 5677. He replied by telegram: "See Ketubot 75a."
He intended the Gemara there which says: **ולציון יאמר איש ואיש יולד בה** - "And of Zion it shall be said, this man and that man was born in her" (Psalms 87:5) - one who looks forward to seeing her is considered one of her children, as if he was born in her.
Source: "Alei Tamar" (Tel Aviv 5739), Part 1, p. 89

The critical sense of the Rogatchover is interesting. A Rabbi sent him the "Yerushalmi on Kodshim," which immediately upon its appearance had challengers (in our days it has been clarified absolutely that it is a forgery). He replied: "Last night I took some time to look at the volume, and behold I am very perplexed, for in my opinion it is silver covered in dross etc... and almost on every page it is visible to the eye that strangers have ruled over it... and when the post office is open I will send it back, for there is a concern of 'Do not keep [unrighteousness] in your tent' etc." (Responsa Tzafnat Paneach Siman 114).
And as a sign that follows it (Siman 115): "Today I sent back the volume, and behold it is only compiled from the Yerushalmi and the Rishonim, and there are things in it which were not given to be written... and regarding printing against the terrible [forgery], certainly it is proper to publicize so that they are not dragged after it."
He brings several examples of forgery from "the terrible volume." Let us note one: In Bechorot, beginning of Chapter 7, he brought the Baraita that is in the Tosefta of R' Akiva: "Maaser Behemah (Animal Tithe) is tithed from the Mishna upon its fellow." In truth—says the Gaon—it is a scribal error in the Tosefta, and it should be in the words of R' Akiva: **אין מעשרין** - "One does *not* tithe." He proves the truth of the version **אין מעשרין**. If the Yerushalmi were authentic, the version would be like the scribal error in our Tosefta.
Source: "Ishim VeShitot" (Jerusalem 5718), p. 135

The Gaon of Rogatchov *zt"l* once explained why one of the traits of fools is to laugh: Since the Rambam *zt"l*, mainly in the book "Moreh Nevuchim," calls wise men "Masters of Laughter" (Baalei HaSchok), his intention is that only one who is wise can laugh, whereas fools and idiots who do not understand cannot laugh. Therefore, explained the Gaon *zt"l*, fools laugh to say that they are not idiots, and the proof is that they know how to laugh... (Heard orally).
Source: "Keter Chabad", 11th of Adar II 5757, p. 42

This was in the year 5692 (1932). On one of the first days of the month of Iyar, I was traveling from Riga to Vilna. At the Dinaburg station, I interrupted the journey in order to stay overnight in Dinaburg and visit the Gaon of Rogatchov *zt"l*. I entered the city at about six o'clock, and after leaving my suitcase in one of the hotels, I walked to the Gaon's house. I was at the gate of his courtyard at about seven.
At the entrance to the courtyard, I met a man (according to his clothes and appearance: a Rav) as he was leaving the courtyard.
*   "Does the Gaon of Rogatchov live here?" I ask.
*   "Yes. But his honor will not be able to visit him now."
*   "Why?"
*   "Because he is not in good health. The doctor is in the house now."
*   "And when will it be possible for me to enter to him?"
*   "Maybe tomorrow, at nine."
*   "But, surely I came to Dinaburg specifically to see him, and the second train leaves from here to Vilna at the morning watch. And what shall I do for him, now is impossible. Maybe I will be able to visit him at night? Let's say at nine in the evening."
*   "No."
I did not know the man, I did not ask his name, and he did not ask my name, but from his decisive rulings, I recognized that he came now from the Gaon's house and that he feels a responsibility for the Gaon's rest.
I let him pass, and I remained standing at the threshold of the gate. Should I enter or not enter? Not to enter and travel at the morning watch with the train and not know the Gaon, or not to enter and be delayed here another full day in a place where I have no acquaintance and at six in the morning have an urgent matter for Vilna.
I will enter, and whatever happens happens: If I am accepted by the Gaon, good; and if not, what have I lost if I stay another day in Dinaburg, I will be able to afterwards. I entered. I came up to the door of the Gaon's house. The door was open. Inside there was a little movement. That one was right. A man dressed in European clothes is seen inside, apparently, this is the doctor. I hesitate a little and knock on the door. "Arein" (Enter) - and I am already in the outer room. The Rebbetzin comes from the inner room. She sets her eyes on me, intending apparently to show me the door, but suddenly the voice of the Gaon is heard from the inner room asking: "Wer iz?" (Who is there?). The Rebbetzin turns toward the room and says "Eppes a Rav" (Some Rav), and immediately the command comes: "Yikanes" (Let him enter). I advance my steps toward the middle door, I apologize, maybe it is impossible. Maybe another time. But the Rebbetzin replies: "Nu, since the Rav said enter, you have to enter." I enter. Before me is the Gaon with his face inspiring terror and in his frightening image, with his hair standing up and with the splendor of his appearance which all says honor and majesty.
*   "Shalom Aleichem, from where?"
*   "From Jerusalem, my name is Moshe Blau."
*   "Moshe Blau, I know the name. R' David Potash wrote to me also about his journey, sit down."
*   "But, surely the doctor is here, maybe I am burdening, maybe I will come another time."
*   "No, the doctor is idle matters, he will go immediately, the Rebbetzin invited the doctor, she is particular about the doctors' orders too much. Let it be so, in a little while he will go. Sit a little, and we will hear only what the doctor decrees on me, afterwards we will converse a little." I sit in the corner of the house. The doctor gives instructions, the Rebbetzin checks him with tests and inquiries, and he went his way. The Gaon takes a chair for himself and sits opposite me.
*   "Nu, and so I said nothing, the doctor is already gone. He says to gargle, good, if he decrees. Nu, and what is heard in Jerusalem?" I lecture before him on the purpose of my journey. He shows great interest. I ask him his Torah opinion and also his advice. His advice he gives me, but regarding the Torah opinion, he says to me: "Surely my way is known, I reply only to a question in writing, propose your question before me in writing and I promise to reply with a Torah opinion." (Note: I traveled then abroad on a mission for the Chareidi Edah to negotiate with the greats of Israel regarding the position of the Rabbinate of the Chareidi Edah in Jerusalem which arose then with the passing of the Garich"z zy"a, and the Rabbis of the Rabbinate office sent a telegram then to the Gaon R' Chaim Ozer *shlita* and to other greats of Israel that according to Torah law it is forbidden to appoint a Rav for the Chareidi Edah because of trespassing on the boundary of Rabbi Kook *zt"l*. In that matter, I traveled then from Riga to Vilna, and as said, I stopped also at the Gaon of Dinaburg to hear his opinion and receive advice from him by the way on the candidates).
He touched on the question of the Zionists in the Land of Israel, and said to me: "Surely he knows that I was specifically from the sharpest opponents, and I did not prevent myself from writing my opinion openly also about the holders of them, but lately I prevent myself from this, because after I wrote the known letter, I received a letter from my daughter in Petach Tikva, that the matter touches her soul and if I continue to write such things they will cut off her livelihood. And within speaking these words, he jumps from his place, takes out a Gemara from the crate, opens it and shows me Rashi (I did not note the place, and I forgot) that from this it emerges that according to law he had to refrain because of fear of danger to his daughter, that cutting off livelihood is with her the danger of life, since she has no other source."
And as these words he said to me: "Surely they (the Zionists) are suspected of everything, they are suspected also of bloodshed..."
He passed afterwards to ask about the welfare of the Gaon R' M.M. Epstein *zt"l* and ybl"ch the Gaon R' A.Z. Meltzer (*shlita*) [*zt"l*] etc. When we spoke about the questions of the communities, he told me that when the Chareidi Edah opened its Shechitah (in 5686), he received a letter from the Rabbis of the Rabbinate office with a demand that he issue a ruling that it is forbidden to open a special Shechitah, and he replied to them that they are speaking words of nonsense and there is no substance in the words (apparently they turned to all the greats of Israel and they all replied apparently the same answer).
"Does his honor not think to ascend to the Land of Israel?" I ask.
*   "And livelihood?"
*   "The Land of Israel will worry about that."
*   "I do not like this."
*   "I know a public institution that would be happy to bear the yoke of all his needs, if his honor would only agree to put his name on it."
*   "No, this too is not a goal to be in the last days a Gabbai of Tzedakah."
*   "And again," he said to me, "Did I not tell him that I am not patient, to see and be silent I cannot, to see and speak I am afraid, for with me they are suspected of everything and according to law it is forbidden to endanger oneself."
The Gaon brings his chair closer to me, and begins to explain to me a matter of Halacha, regarding "First Holiness" (Kedusha Rishona) - did it sanctify for the future to come, and explains an inquiry if the sanctity continues from the first or is renewed, and dives into mighty waters, in the Yerushalmi and Rambam, and while speaking he is very enthusiastic, and I absorb slaps on the knee and on the shoulder and for every comment on my part a pat on the shoulder, and if the comment finds favor in his eyes, the pat goes up and up, beautiful, and I feel at this hour the aspect of sufferings of love, it hurts more - more pleasure and more delight, I enjoy and am proud at once: The Gaon of Rogatchov beats me.
The deepening in the matter of Halacha continues and I want it not to stop but it stops, and I part from the Gaon of Rogatchov and write in my diary: An hour of spiritual satisfaction (Adar 5695).
Source: "Kitvei Rabbi Moshe Blau" (Jerusalem 5743), p. 64

**Pride**
They asked Rabbi Shlomo of Sasov: What is the reason that the arrogant person is worse than any other sinner, specifically that with him the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not want to dwell in one domain? Why?
The Rebbe replied: In a place where purity reigns, there is no memory of impurity. Wickedness flees from righteousness and licentiousness from fear. However, pride pushes itself into every place and penetrates every hole. It sticks to the wicked and does not let go of the righteous. It dwells in impurity and does not leave the pure. You are never rid of it. There is no other advice but to declare a ban (Cherem) upon it. To say: "It is either I or you..."
Source: "Chassidim Mesaprim" (Jerusalem 5739), Part 2, p. 12

**His History**
My father, the Admor Rabbi Chananya Yom Tov Lipa of Sasov *zt"l*, was a righteous man and elevated above the people, a tremendous Talmid Chacham, a servant of G-d and possessor of lofty character traits. In the various and varied stations of his life across the globe, he did much for Torah and testimony and established legions of soldiers for G-d and His Torah.
My father *zt"l* was born in the year 5665 (1905) to his father Rabbi Chanoch Henich of Sasov *zt"l*, son of the Admor Rabbi Yosef David of Sasov *zt"l*, son of the Admor Rabbi Shlomo of Sasov *zt"l*, son of the Admor Rabbi Chanoch Henich of Alesk *zt"l*, son-in-law of the Rebbe the "Sar Shalom" of Belz *zt"l* and higher in holiness.
My father *zt"l* married in the year 5684 (1924) in a first marriage his cousin, the Rebbetzin Chaya Roiza a"h, daughter of the K"K Admor Rabbi Yoel Teitelbaum of Satmar *zt"l* (who was the uncle of my father *zt"l*). From then on, he merited to be the right hand of his great father-in-law in important communities and served as Rosh Yeshiva. At first in Orshiva, and afterward in Karaly, and around the year 5692 (1932) the Admor moved with his son-in-law *zt"l* to serve in the city of Satmar the glorious.
My father *zt"l* educated the students of the Yeshiva in the paved path, and delivered classes that were engraved forever in the hearts of the students. Many Satmar Chassidim were counted among his students, and his image accompanied them in the paths of their lives. Later, my father *zt"l* was accepted to be the Rav in the city of Semihaly, and he would return to his home which was in Satmar for Shabbos. There he also served as Head of the Beis Din.
The wisdom of my father *zt"l* was famous. He once told of an interesting and very complex case that came to his door. My father *zt"l* in his wisdom discerned the deception of the litigants, and thus was saved from a great stumbling block when he gave the ruling of the Beis Din.

My father *zt"l* had a special mission during the Holocaust—he worked greatly to save Jewish souls and to assist refugees who arrived from Poland to Hungary.
Between the years 5699-5704 (1939-1944), Hungary was relatively quiet, while in most European countries the war machine operated at full force. Hungary was already a partner in the Reich alliance and Jews were drafted to the army—but the decree of expulsion had not yet applied to the Jewish people in Hungary.
Many Jews fled from Poland to Hungary and endangered themselves greatly in doing so; whoever was caught was sent back to the land of his origin. My father *zt"l* mobilized to help refugees who succeeded in infiltrating Hungary, found them hiding places, and worried for their needs.
My grandfather, the Admor Rabbi Henich *zt"l*, my father's father, lived in the city of Sasov near Lemberg in Galicia until WWI. Sasov was close to the border with Russia, and therefore the family members fled. They suffered many troubles and the shame of hunger, and moved to Lemberg. Since then they did not return to Sasov the destroyed.
My grandfather the Admor *zt"l* became Rav in the city of Keretzky in Czechoslovakia. In 5699 (1939), the oppressor (may his name be obliterated) conquered Czechoslovakia—granting a part of it to Hungary.
A great danger hovered now over the head of my grandfather. Originally, he was a Polish subject, and the Hungarians sent back all citizens of Poland. My grandfather *zt"l* and his family took up the wanderer's staff again and moved to Satmar, which was a large city and it was possible to hide there more easily. They lived in the house of my father *zt"l* between the years 5700-5703, and there my grandfather conducted his holy court. My grandfather the Admor *zt"l* passed away in Satmar during WWII, on the 7th of Cheshvan 5703, and in Satmar is his resting place in honor.
On the 24th of Adar 5704 (1944), Hungary was conquered in a lightning operation and a storm of murder. A few weeks later the Germans began sending transports of Jews one after another to the death camps in Poland.
To flee!!!—my father *zt"l* decided. This was about the first weeks of the occupation, before they closed the ghettos hermetically. Escape was still possible, and my father *zt"l*, his wife, and her sister who was a girl of seven and a half at the time—(later the Rebbetzin Matil Zacks of the United States, widow of HaGaon HaTzaddik R' Gershon Zacks *zt"l*, grandson of the Chofetz Chaim *zt"l*)—escaped by train from Satmar to Klausenburg disguised as Gentiles.
In Klausenburg lived a Satmar Chassid named R' Yirmiyah Tessler, and the fugitives arrived at his house. R' Yirmiyah knew border smugglers and directed them to a suitable smuggler. With the help of the smuggler, the three arrived in Temesvar, Romania.
The city of Temesvar was relatively safe, but danger still hovered over their heads, for the authorities were always searching for refugees who had infiltrated. My father *zt"l* continued his flight to Bucharest, and when he felt in danger there—he decided to board an illegal immigrant ship to the Holy Land.
This was in the year 5704. Three ships sailed at that time towards the Land of Israel. Two of them were sunk by the English at the gates of the Land of Israel, and only the ship that my father *zt"l* was on remained as a remnant.
My father *zt"l*, his wife the Rebbetzin, and her sister the girl were sent to Cyprus, and from there moved to Atlit. Finally, they arrived in Jerusalem the Holy City.
In Yoel Street in Jerusalem stands the synagogue of Satmar Chassidim. It was built in the year 5693 by the Chassidim, after the Admor Rabbi Yoel of Satmar *zt"l* visited the Land of Israel. When my father *zt"l* arrived there, he was appointed as Rav of the community of Satmar Chassidim in Jerusalem, he even founded the Yeshiva "Yitav Lev" with the Chassidim, and was crowned as Rosh Yeshiva.
After the Holocaust, at the end of 5705 (1945), the Satmar Rebbe *zt"l* ascended to the Land of Israel and lived there for about a year, after which he traveled to the United States. My father *zt"l* remained living in Jerusalem and managed the Yeshiva and the Beis Midrash in the Holy City.
In the year 5708 (1948), the Land of Israel stormed. The War of Independence and the rest of the events swept the residents into a whirlpool of worry and danger. The Satmar Rebbe sent a telegram to his son-in-law—my father *zt"l* and his daughter the Rebbetzin Chaya Roiza a"h, and asked them to come to America and be saved from the terror of the war.
Again my father *zt"l* took up the wanderer's staff, and this time to the United States. He moved with the Rebbetzin and her sister to America, settled in Manhattan, and founded a Beis Midrash for Sasov Chassidim. There he lived until the year 5714 (1954). In that year he became a widower from his wife the righteous Rebbetzin Mrs. Chaya Roiza a"h.
This was at the end of thirty years of their marriage. They did not merit children.
My father *zt"l* remained lonely and solitary, arose and traveled to the Holy Land, to breathe its air and find comfort in it...
My father *zt"l* was then fifty years old. He desired to marry a "Bat Banim" (woman of good lineage), and when my mother—the young widow of HaGaon Rabbi Mordechai Pogromansky—was proposed to him, he replied positively, and thus the match arose and was.
After their meeting, my mother spoke to the matchmaker with joy, for she found before her an exceptional Talmid Chacham and possessor of special qualities, dressed in Rabbinic garb and his whole appearance like an Admor. She felt that she received her request and the wish of her heart was fulfilled.
Only a slight fear beat in my mother, and she revealed the conscience of her heart to her friend: "It is possible that he will ask me to cover the wig (Sheitel). After all, I am not used to that..."
"He didn't ask, and therefore—don't worry"—the friend calmed her.
In Elul of 5715 (1955) the wedding took place.
Not much time passed and my father *zt"l* asked that my mother wear a covering over her wig. She acceded to the request easily and willingly. With time, my father *zt"l* encouraged her to add more covering, and she agreed to this too with a whole heart. Years later she told us: "Dear children, I was so impressed by your father *zt"l*, that I only wanted him to be satisfied... I thought to myself: If I merited such an important husband, and he asks me a request—how can I refuse such a personality?!"
My father *zt"l* also appreciated his wife greatly for her righteousness and talents. My mother was exceptionally learned, had a genius mind, and the love of learning beat within her. Among other things, she learned Mishnayot and Chumash with Rashi. All the members of her family who perished for Kiddush Hashem were talented.
My mother also excelled in knowing languages and wrote wonderfully. Everywhere that she happened to be in the circumstances of her life, she succeeded in absorbing the language. Thus she mastered six languages: Lashon HaKodesh, Yiddish, Polish, German, English, and French. In addition to this, she had knowledge of Russian and Italian.
My father *zt"l* worried for my mother and honored her greatly. They lived in Manhattan in a building of three levels, and my mother would go up and down from floor to floor many times a day. My father spared her strength and would watch and supervise her, lest she hurry and exert herself.
My mother aspired to continue living in the Land of Israel even after the marriage. Satiated with hardships in the seven levels of hell, she wanted to find rest for the sole of her foot in the land where the eyes of G-d are upon it.
But my father's Beis Midrash was located in Manhattan. He asked her to come live in America, calming her: "These are temporary dwellings; I promise you that we will return. I myself want to return to the Holy Land, for the purpose of Jews is in the Land of Israel. But meanwhile, there is my Beis Midrash—and after a time we will return."
A year passed from the marriage and my mother was graced with the mercies of Hashem with her firstborn son. My brother, the K"K Admor of Sasov *shlita*—from Kiryat "Yismach Moshe" in the Holy Land—was born. After his birth, my father *zt"l* promised: "We will conduct his *Chalakah* (first haircut) in Meron."
But the kindness of G-d overcame them, and until my brother *shlita* reached the age of three, two additional sons were born, and the Aliyah with three toddlers to the Holy Land was too difficult. But my father *zt"l* promised, and therefore he calculated the sum of the trip to the Holy Land, and sent the money to the poor of the Land of Israel.
All the time my parents did not abandon their dream to return to the Land of Israel. In the year 5718 (1958), three years after the marriage, my father *zt"l* began his journeys to the Holy Land. He would search and scout for land upon which he could settle. He surveyed many places, and finally—in the year 5722 (1962)—he found an area near Bnei Brak, and founded there the glorious neighborhood "Yismach Moshe".
The first residents entered to live in the neighborhood in the beginning of 5725 (1965), even before the roads were paved, and there was still no arranged transportation or communication.
The five children who should live were born one after another, and in the meantime my father *zt"l* was conducting his journeys to the Land of Israel and establishing his vision—Kiryat "Yismach Moshe". My mother remained alone with the children and enabled him to dedicate himself to his life's mission. She did this with a sense of lofty mission.
In the summer of 5724 (1964), my father *zt"l* stayed in the Holy Land and engaged in his great enterprise. We remained in America with our devoted mother who cared for us warmly. Beside her, a babysitter assisted her, a student of Beis Yaakov, G-d fearing.
Thus matters proceeded, until that bitter day - - -
In Elul 5724, my father *zt"l* held a press conference in Kiryat Yismach Moshe, reporting on what was being done in the field and what was still required to be done. Suddenly, without prior warning—he lost his speech and fell silent.
A few minutes of strange silence passed, and behold the speech returned to him. But very quickly my father *zt"l* got stuck again and remained voiceless. From there my father *zt"l* hurried to the doctor, and he determined: "The problem stems from the brain! You must go to the hospital."
My father *zt"l* was hospitalized, where the sorrowful and bitter fact was revealed: My father *zt"l* had a tumor in the brain r"l, and he must be operated on urgently.
At the time of the surgery, my mother stayed in America, packing and organizing for the trip to the Holy Land, to her husband's bedside. We remained alone, five small and tender children, in the hands of the babysitter. It was the summer vacation period, and she could dedicate herself to caring for us. But after a few weeks, during which my mother stayed by my father *zt"l*, the vacation ended and the babysitter was forced to return to her home and studies.
My mother organized for us, via telephone and letters, a place to stay. We moved to be in the house of my father's brother *zt"l*, Rabbi Mikirlhaz *zt"l* in Crown Heights. We were hosted there in the middle of the month of Elul until after Rosh Hashanah.
In the Ten Days of Repentance we got up, the five small children, and traveled to the Land of Israel. We arrived after a hard period and an exhausting flight, hoping to unite with Abba and Imma. But no home awaited us. The houses in "Yismach Moshe" were not yet ready, my father *zt"l* was in Hadassah Hospital for treatment, and in between in a hotel in Jerusalem—and my mother was devoted to him and stayed by his side.
My mother, who was obligated to be confined to my father's bedside, divided us among families of dear Jews: The three "big" sons (the oldest was less than eight): Yosef David, Henich, and Moshe, she sent to the home of Hrh"ch R' Yehuda Yoel Miller (*shlita*) [*zt"l*] in Jerusalem, a student of my father *zt"l* in Satmar. During my stay there I learned in Cheder Vizhnitz in Jerusalem.
The two baby girls—Shlomoh'le and Esther—were received in the home of the Stern family in Givat Shaul.
My mother continued to stay by my father's bedside in the hospital or hotel.
In the winter of 5725, the building of the first building in Kiryat Yismach Moshe was completed. Finally we had a home! How happy we were, the children, when we united with our dear parents. My father *zt"l* returned home from the hospital sitting in a wheelchair and the left side of his body paralyzed—but we had a father. We were happy to be in the presence of our parents.
Now began a new and difficult period in our lives. Every week my mother accompanied my father *zt"l* for radiation and treatments at Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem. At times my father *zt"l* was hospitalized for a few days, and my mother was always attached to him. She hired a Chareidi caregiver who lived in our house and worried for us.
The treatments did not heal my father *zt"l*, but they slowed the progress of the disease.
At the beginning of Kislev 5726, the situation deteriorated. My mother was with my father *zt"l* in the hospital in Jerusalem, and we were in Kiryat Yismach Moshe given over to the care of the caregiver and longing greatly for our parents.
On the 11th of Adar 5726, my righteous father *zt"l* passed away to his eternal home, and he was only 16 [years in the rabbinate/leadership? Text says "Ben 16" which usually means 16 years old, but context makes that impossible. Perhaps 16 years in America? Or 61? Born 1905, died 1966 = 61. Yes, likely a typo in source or OCR for 61 (ס"א vs ט"ז). Or 16 years of leadership in Israel/US? Let's stick to translation]. [And he is buried in Tiberias].
Source: "Maalot Mitachat LeEfes" (Jerusalem 5773), p. 302

כָּאן גָּר הַגָּאוֹן מֵרוֹגַאטְשׁוֹב? - אֲנִי שׁוֹאֵל. - כֵּן. אֲבָל כְּבוֹדוֹ לֹא יִהְיֶה יָכוֹל לְבַקֵּר אוֹתוֹ עַכְשָׁיו.
מַדּוּעַ? - מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא אֵינוֹ בְּקַו הַבְּרִיאוּת. הָרוֹפֵא נִמְצָא עַכְשָׁיו בַּבַּיִת.
וּמָתַי יִהְיֶה בִּיכוֹלְתִּי לְהִכָּנֵס אֵלָיו? - אוּלַי לְמָחָר, בְּתֵשַׁע.
אֲבָל, הֲלֹא אָנֹכִי בָּאתִי לְדִינָבּוּרְג בְּיִחוּד לִרְאוֹתוֹ, וְהָרַכֶּבֶת הַשְּׁנִיָּה, יוֹצֵאת מִכָּאן לְוִילְנָא, בְּאַשְׁמוֹרֶת הַבֹּקֶר. - וּמָה אֶעֱשֶׂה לוֹ, עַתָּה אִי אֶפְשָׁר. - אוּלַי אֶהְיֶה יָכוֹל לְבַקְּרוֹ בַּלַּיְלָה? נַגִּיד בְּתֵשַׁע בָּעֶרֶב. - לֹא.לֹא הִכַּרְתִּי אֶת הָאִישׁ לֹא שָׁאַלְתִּי לִשְׁמוֹ וְגַם הוּא לֹא שָׁאַל לִשְׁמִי, אֲבָל מִתּוֹךְ הַהֲלָכוֹת הַפְּסוּקוֹת שֶׁלּוֹ הִכַּרְתִּי שֶׁהוּא בָּא עַתָּה מִבֵּית הַגָּאוֹן וְשֶׁהוּא מַרְגִּישׁ בְּעַצְמוֹ אַחְרָיוּת בְּעַד מְנוּחָתוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן. אֲנִי נוֹתֵן לוֹ לַעֲבֹר, וַאֲנִי נִשְׁאָר עַל עָמְדִי עַל סַף הַשַּׁעַר. אֶכָּנֵס אוֹ לֹא אֶכָּנֵס? לֹא לְהִכָּנֵס וְלִנְסֹעַ בְּאַשְׁמוֹרֶת עִם הָרַכֶּבֶת וְלֹא לְהַכִּיר אֶת הַגָּאוֹן, אוֹ לֹא אֶכָּנֵס וְאֶתְעַכֵּב כָּאן עוֹד יוֹם תָּמִים בְּמָקוֹם שֶׁאֵין לִי שׁוּם מַכִּיר וּבְשָׁעָה שֵׁשׁ בַּבֹּקֶר דָּבָר דָּחוּף לִי לְוִילְנָא.אֶכָּנֵס וּמִמַּנָ"פ: אֶתְקַבֵּל אֵצֶל הַגָּאוֹן הֲרֵי טוֹב, וְאִם לָאו מַה הִפְסַדְתִּי, לְהַחְלִיט אִם לְהִשָּׁאֵר עוֹד יוֹם בְּדִינָבּוּרְג אוּכַל אַחַ"כּ. נִכְנַסְתִּי. בָּאתִי עַד לִפְנֵי דֶּלֶת בֵּיתוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן. הַדֶּלֶת פְּתוּחָה. בִּפְנִים קְצָת תְּנוּעָה. צָדַק הַלָּז. אָדָם לָבוּשׁ אֵירוֹפֵּאִי נִרְאֶה בִּפְנִים, כַּנִּרְאֶה שֶׁזֶּה הַדּוֹקְטוֹר. אֲנִי מְהַסֵּס קְצָת וְדוֹפֵק עַל הַדֶּלֶת. "אַרַיין" - וַאֲנִי כְּבָר בַּחֶדֶר הַחִיצוֹנִי. הָרַבָּנִית בָּאָה מֵהַחֶדֶר הַפְּנִימִי. נוֹתֶנֶת עֵינֶיהָ בִּי, מִתְכַּוֶּונֶת כַּנִּרְאֶה לְהַרְאוֹת לִי אֶת הַדֶּלֶת, אֲבָל פִּתְאוֹם נִשְׁמַע קוֹלוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן מֵהַחֶדֶר הַפְּנִימִי בִּשְׁאֵלָה: "וֶוער אִיז" (מִי שָׁמָּה). הָרַבָּנִית פּוֹנָה אֶל עֵבֶר הַחֶדֶר וְאוֹמֶרֶת "עֶפֶּעס אַ רַב", וְתֵיכֶף בָּא הַפְּקֻדָּה: "יִכָּנֵס". אֲנִי מְקַדֵּם אֶת פְּסִיעוֹתַי כְּלַפֵּי הַדֶּלֶת הָאֶמְצָעִית, אֲנִי מִתְנַצֵּל, אוּלַי אִי אֶפְשָׁר. אוּלַי בְּפַעַם אַחֶרֶת. אֲבָל הָרַבָּנִית מְשִׁיבָה: נוּ, כֵּיוָן שֶׁהָרַב אָמַר יִכָּנֵס יֵשׁ לוֹ לְהִכָּנֵס. אֲנִי נִכְנָס. לְפָנַי הַגָּאוֹן בְּפָנָיו הַמְּפִיקִים אֵימוֹת וּבִתְמוּנָתוֹ הַמַּבְהִילָה, בְּשַׂעֲרוֹתָיו הַזְּקוּפוֹת וּבְזִיו מַרְאֵהוּ שֶׁכּוּלּוֹ אוֹמֵר כָּבוֹד וָהוֹד.
שָׁלוֹם עֲלֵיכֶם, מֵאַיִן? - מִירוּשָׁלַיִם, שְׁמִי מֹשֶׁה בְּלוֹי. - מֹשֶׁה בְּלוֹי, אֶת שְׁמוֹ אֲנִי יוֹדֵעַ. ר' דָּוִד פּוֹטַשׁ כָּתַב לִי גַּם אוֹדוֹת נְסִיעָתוֹ, יֵשֵׁב. - אֲבָל, הֲלֹא הָרוֹפֵא הוּא כָּאן, אוּלַי אֲנִי מַכְבִּיד, אוּלַי אָבוֹא בִּזְמַן אַחֵר. - לֹא, הָרוֹפֵא דְּבָרִים בְּטֵלִים, הוּא יֵלֵךְ תֵּיכֶף, הָרַבָּנִית הִזְמִינָה אֶת הָרוֹפֵא, הִיא מְדַקְדֶּקֶת בְּמִצְוַת רוֹפְאִים יוֹתֵר מִדַּי. יְהִי כֵן, עוֹד מְעַט יֵלֵךְ לוֹ. יָשַׁב קְצָת, וְנִשְׁמַע רַק מַה שֶׁהָרוֹפֵא יִגְזֹר עָלַי, אַחַ"כּ נְשׂוֹחַח קְצָת. אֲנִי יוֹשֵׁב בְּפִינַת הַבַּיִת. הָרוֹפֵא נוֹתֵן הוֹרָאוֹת, הָרַבָּנִית בּוֹדֶקֶת אוֹתוֹ בִּבְדִיקוֹת וַחֲקִירוֹת וְהוּא הָלַךְ לוֹ. הַגָּאוֹן לוֹקֵחַ לוֹ כִּסֵּא וְיוֹשֵׁב מוּלִי. - נוּ, וּבְכֵן אָמַרְתִּי לֹא כְּלוּם, הָרוֹפֵא כְּבָר הָלַךְ. הוּא אוֹמֵר לְגַרְגֵּר, טוֹב, אִם הוּא גּוֹזֵר, נוּ, וּמַה נִּשְׁמַע בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם? אֲנִי מַרְצֶה לְפָנָיו עַל מַטְּרַת נְסִיעָתִי. הוּא מַרְאֶה בְּהִתְעַנְיְינוּת גְּדוֹלָה. אֲנִי שׁוֹאֵל מִמֶּנּוּ חַוַּות דַּעַת תּוֹרָתוֹ וְגַם אֶת עֲצָתוֹ. אֶת עֲצָתוֹ הוּא נוֹתֵן לִי, אֲבָל בְּנוֹגֵעַ לְחַוַּות דַּעַת תּוֹרָה, הוּא אוֹמֵר לִי: הֲלֹא דַּרְכִּי יָדוּעַ, אֲנִי מֵשִׁיב רַק עַל שְׁאֵלָה בִּכְתָב, יַצִּיעַ לְפָנַי אֶת שְׁאֵלָתוֹ בִּכְתָב וַאֲנִי מַבְטִיחוֹ לְהָשִׁיב לוֹ דַּעַת תּוֹרָה. (הֶעָרָה: אֲנִי נָסַעְתִּי אָז לְחוּ"ל בִּשְׁלִיחוּת הָעֵדָה הַחֲרֵדִית לָבוֹא בִּדְבָרִים עִם גְּדוֹלֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל בִּדְבַר מִשְׂרַת הָרַבָּנוּת שֶׁל הָעֵדָה הַחֲרֵדִית בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם שֶׁנִּתְעוֹרְרָה אָז עִם הִסְתַּלְּקוּתוֹ שֶׁל הַגְּרִיחָ"ז זיע"א, וְרַבָּנֵי מִשְׂרַד הָרַבָּנוּת שָׁלְחוּ אָז טֶלֶגְרָמָה לְהַגְרַחַעַ"ז שְׁלִיטָ"א וּלְעוֹד גְּדוֹלֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁעַפִּ"י דַּ"ת אָסוּר לְמַנּוֹת רַב לָעֵדָה הַחֲרֵדִית מִפְּנֵי הַסָּגַת גְּבוּל שֶׁל הָרַב קוּק זַ"ל. בְּאוֹתוֹ עִנְיָן נָסַעְתִּי אָז מֵרִיגָא לְוִילְנָא, וּכְאָמוּר סַרְתִּי גַּם אֵצֶל הַגָּאוֹן מִדִּינָבּוּרְג לִשְׁמֹעַ דַּעְתּוֹ וּלְקַבֵּל מִמֶּנּוּ בְּדֶרֶךְ אַגַּב עֵצָה עַל הַמּוֹעֲמָדִים).הוּא נָגַע בִּשְׁאֵלַת הַצִּיּוֹנִים, בְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל, וְאָמַר לִי: הֲלֹא הוּא יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁאָנֹכִי הָיִיתִי דַּוְקָא מֵהַמִּתְנַגְּדִים הֲכִי חֲרִיפִים, וְלֹא מָנַעְתִּי אֶת עַצְמִי מִלִּכְתֹּב דַּעְתִּי בְּגָלוּי גַּם עַל הַמַּחֲזִיקִים בָּהֶם, אֲבָל בַּזְּמַן הָאַחֲרוֹן אֲנִי מוֹנֵעַ אֶת עַצְמִי מִזֶּה, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁאַחַר שֶׁכָּתַבְתִּי אֶת הַמִּכְתָּב הַיָּדוּעַ, קִבַּלְתִּי מִכְתָּב מִבִּתִּי בְּפֶתַח תִּקְוָה, שֶׁהַדָּבָר נוֹגֵעַ לְנַפְשָׁהּ וְכִי אִם אוֹסִיף לִכְתֹּב בִּדְבָרִים כָּאֵלֶּה יְקַפְּחוּ אֶת פַּרְנָסָתָהּ.וְתוֹךְ כְּדֵי דְּבָרָיו אֵלֶּה, קוֹפֵץ הוּא מִמְּקוֹמוֹ, מוֹצִיא גְּמָרָא מֵהָאַרְגָּז פּוֹתְחָהּ וּמַרְאֶה לִי רַשִׁ"י (לֹא רָשַׁמְתִּי לִי אֶת הַמָּקוֹם, וְשָׁכַחְתִּי) שֶׁמִּתּוֹךְ זֶה יוֹצֵא שֶׁעַפִּ"י דִּין הָיָה לוֹ לְהִמָּנַע מִפְּנֵי חֲשַׁשׁ סַכָּנָה שֶׁל בִּתּוֹ, שֶׁקִּפּוּחַ פַּרְנָסָה הוּא אֶצְלָהּ סַכָּנַת נְפָשׁוֹת, מֵאַחַר שֶׁאֵין לָהּ מָקוֹר אַחֵר.וּכְדַבְרִים הָאֵלֶּה אָמַר לִי: הֲלֹא הֵם (הַצִּיּוֹנִים) חֲשׁוּדִים עַל הַכֹּל, הֵם חֲשׁוּדִים גַּם עַל שְׁפִיכוּת דָּמִים...הוּא עָבַר אַחַ"כּ לִשְׁאוֹל לִשְׁלוֹם שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן רַמַ"מ עֶפְּשְׁטֵיין זַצַ"ל וְיִבָּלַחַ"ט הַגָּאוֹן רַא"ז מֶלְצֶר (שְׁלִיטָ"א) [זַצַ"ל] וְכו'. כַּאֲשֶׁר דִּיבַּרְנוּ עַל שְׁאֵלוֹת הַקְּהִילּוֹת, סִיפֵּר לִי שֶׁכַּאֲשֶׁר הָעֵדָה הַחֲרֵדִית פָּתְחָה אֶת הַשְּׁחִיטָה שֶׁלָּהּ (בִּשְׁנַת תרפ"ו) קִיבֵּל הוּא מִכְתָּב מֵאֵת רַבָּנֵי מִשְׂרַד הָרַבָּנוּת בִּדְרִישָׁה שֶׁהוּא יוֹצִיא פְּסָק שֶׁאָסוּר לִפְתֹּחַ שְׁחִיטָה מְיֻחֶדֶת, וְהֵשִׁיב לָהֶם שֶׁהֵם מְדַבְּרִים דִּבְרֵי שְׁטוּת וְאֵין בַּדְּבָרִים מַמָּשׁ (כַּנִּרְאֶה שֶׁהֵם פָּנוּ אֶל כָּל גְּדוֹלֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְכוּלָּם הֵשִׁיבוּ כַּנִּרְאֶה אוֹתָהּ הַתְּשׁוּבָה).הַאִם אֵינוֹ חוֹשֵׁב כַּתַּ"ר לַעֲלוֹת לְאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל, שׁוֹאֵל אֲנִי. - וּפַרְנָסָה. - אֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל תִּדְאַג לְכָךְ. - אֶת זֶה אֵינִי אוֹהֵב. - אֲנִי יוֹדֵעַ מִמּוֹסָד צִיבּוּרִי שֶׁהָיָה מְאֻשָּׁר לָשֵׂאת בְּעוֹל כָּל סִיפּוּקוֹ, אִם כַּתַּ"ר יַסְכִּים רַק לָשׂוּם אֶת שְׁמוֹ עָלָיו. - לֹא, גַּם זוֹ אֵינָהּ מַטָּרָה לִהְיוֹת בַּיָּמִים הָאַחֲרוֹנִים גַּבַּאי שֶׁל צְדָקָה. - וְשׁוּב, אָמַר לִי, הֲלֹא אָמַרְתִּי לוֹ שֶׁאֲנִי אֵינֶנִּי סַבְלָן, לִרְאוֹת וְלִשְׁתּוֹק אֵינִי יָכוֹל, לִרְאוֹת וּלְדַבֵּר אֲנִי מִתְיָרֵא, כִּי אֶצְלִי חֲשׁוּדִים הֵם עַל הַכֹּל וְעַפִּ"י דִּין אָסוּר לְהַכְנִיס א"ע לְסַכָּנָה.הַגָּאוֹן מְקָרֵב אֶת כִּסְאוֹ יוֹתֵר אֵלַי, וּמַתְחִיל לְבָאֵר לִי דְּבַר הֲלָכָה, בְּעִנְיַן קְדֻשָּׁה רִאשׁוֹנָה קִדְּשָׁה לֶעָתִיד לָבוֹא, וּמְבָאֵר חֲקִירָה אִם הַקְּדֻשָּׁה נִמְשֶׁכֶת מֵהָרִאשׁוֹנָה אוֹ מִתְחַדֶּשֶׁת, וְצוֹלֵל בְּמַיִם אַדִּירִים, בַּהַיְרוּשַׁלְמִי וּבָרַמְבַּ"ם, וּבְדַבְּרוֹ מִתְלַהֵב הוּא מְאֹד, וַאֲנִי סוֹפֵג סְטִירוֹת בַּיָּרֵךְ וּבַכָּתֵף וְעַל כָּל הֶעָרָה מִצִּדִּי חֲבִיטָה בַּכָּתֵף, וְאִם הַהֶעָרָה מוֹצְאָה חֵן בְּעֵינָיו, הַחֲבִיטָה עוֹלָה עוֹלָה, יָפָה, וַאֲנִי מַרְגִּישׁ בְּשָׁעָה זוֹ אֶת הַבְּחִינָה שֶׁל יִסּוּרִים שֶׁל אַהֲבָה, יוֹתֵר כּוֹאֵב - יוֹתֵר הֲנָאָה וְיוֹתֵר תַּעֲנוּג, אֲנִי נֶהֱנֶה וּמִתְגָּאֶה כְּאֶחָד: הַגָּאוֹן מֵרוֹגַאטְשׁוֹב חוֹבֵט אוֹתִי.הַהִתְעַמְּקוּת בִּדְבַר הֲלָכָה נִמְשֶׁכֶת וַאֲנִי רוֹצֶה שֶׁלֹּא תִּפָּסֵק אֲבָל הִיא נִפְסֶקֶת, וַאֲנִי נִפְרָד מֵהַגָּאוֹן מֵרוֹגַאטְשׁוֹב וְרוֹשֵׁם בְּיוֹמָנִי: שָׁעָה שֶׁל קוֹרַת רוּחַ נַפְשִׁית (אֲדָר תרצ"ה).מֵרְשִׁימוֹת הָרַב מֹשֶׁה בְּלוֹי זַ"ל"כִּתְבֵי רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה בְּלוֹי" (יְרוּשָׁלַיִם תשמ"ג) ע' 64

**His History**
HaRahatz R' Menachem David Chodorov *zt"l* was born in Vizhnitz in the year 5647 (1887) to his father HaRahatz Rabbi Mordechai of Tolna-Vizhnitz zy"a, grandson of the Holy Rabbi David of Tolna zy"a and son-in-law of the "Imrei Baruch" of Vizhnitz zy"a. He married in 5665 (1905) the Rebbetzin Henyele, daughter of his uncle the Holy Rabbi Shmuel Abba of Horodenka, the "Sifsei Tzaddik" zy"a.
In the years 5674-5680 (1914-1920) he served as a Moreh Tzedek (Halachic Judge) in Kolomyia and Chernowitz. He was considered one of the dignitaries of the Rabbis and Admorim in the United States; he was important both in the circles of the world of scholars and among the world of Chassidim.
In the year "Sim Shalom" (5726/1966), the HaRahatz published the book "Imrei Baruch" in a second edition, together with the "Sifsei Tzaddik", from his father-in-law. In this edition, "15 Essays" were added to the book, which R' Menachem David Chodorov *zt"l* said and preached on various occasions. He passed away on 11th Adar 5760.
**Story:**
My soul friend, Rabbi Menachem David Chodorov (*shlita*) [*zt"l*], student of my grandfather [HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Yehuda Yoel Deutsch *zt"l* Av Beit Din of Hanusovce], married the Rebbetzin Henyele, daughter of his uncle Rabbi Shmuel Avraham Abba Hager, the Admor of Horodenka. Rabbi Mendely told me that he traveled to Stanislav, to the Gaon Rabbi Leibish Horowitz, to ask him for "Semicha". He did not reveal to him who he was, but asked him to test him. The author of "Harei Besamim" agreed to this, and for long hours at night he tested him in ruling. The next day the certificate of Semicha was in his hand, and only then did he reveal to him the source of his quarry.
The Rav was amazed at a young man, from the descendants of the greats of Chassidut, who was also great in Halacha... He served as a Moreh Tzedek in Kolomyia and Chernowitz (5674-5680), but he did not have money to purchase an apartment in Chernowitz. At that time, he participated as a delegate to the Agudas Yisrael conference in Pressburg. The conference decided to send a "delegation" to the USA and to join him to it. He agreed to this, for he thought that in America he would succeed in raising the sum needed for him to buy an apartment. However, he did not succeed in this and remained in the USA. This was in the year 5680. Now he worried to bring his parents and his family. Indeed, in the year 5681 they arrived in the USA, and the joy of the father and son was boundless. HaRahatz Rabbi Mordechai, who was educated in the house of his grandfather R' Dudel in Tolna, founded the Union of Admorim in the USA and stood at its head. He had Chassidim and admirers. His son, Rabbi Menachem David (*shlita*) [*zt"l*], exceeded him in doing, in his greatness in Torah, in his wisdom and his deeds for the benefit of the general public and the individual. An activist and one of the heads of Agudas Yisrael, the Union of Rabbis, the organization of students of Hungarian Yeshivas, and more...
Source: "HaGaon HaKadosh MiVishniva" (Bnei Brak 5769), Part 2, p. 396

**His History**
The Gaon Rabbi Mordechai Weitzel of Oshmina was born in the year 5597 (1837) to his father R' Avraham Menachem, who was a respected merchant in the city of Antipolya. In his childhood, his diligence and intense perseverance in Torah were already recognizable. In his youth, he received Torah from R' Yitzchak Hirsch, who was later Rav in Semiatitch. Being about 14 years old, he entered into the covenant of marriage with the daughter of one of the dignitaries of the city of Antipolya, the Rebbetzin Chaya *zt"l*, who was known for her righteousness. She would wash with her own hands the clothes of the sick in the city and would care for them with devotion, and she helped her husband to be diligent in Torah and Divine service. In his year 19, he came to Pinsk and would enter the home of R' Mordechai Zakheim *zt"l*, the Av Beit Din there, and was ordained by him for ruling. Afterward, he returned to Antipolya and helped Rabbi Pinchas Michael, the Av Beit Din there, in matters of religion and law, and they also learned together.
R' Pinchas Michael was one of the famous Tzaddikim, and many would rise early to open [their doors] to pray for them. His biography has already been written by the author Ben Ezra.
In the year 5626 (1866), he was accepted as Rav in the city of Boten, near Slonim. And when people came to R' Pinchas Michael, he would say: "Go to R' Mordechai. And he would say to go to him for he is a great Tzaddik and a wonderful Chacham."
And in the year 5647 (1887), he was accepted as Rav in Karlitz. He sat there for about four years and his name was publicized for praise, and they came to hear his advice and receive his blessing. He founded many societies there for acts of charity and kindness. He sat there until the year 5651. Afterward, he was accepted as Rav in Oshmina which is in the Vilna district. There too he instituted orders in all institutions of charity and kindness. And in the year 5665 (1905), he was accepted as Rav in the city of Slonim, where distinguished scholars sat, the most famous of whom was R' Moshe, author of "Chelkat Mechokek". There he accomplished much, and mainly in the Slonim Yeshiva "Etz Chaim" where more than 400 students learned. Everyone rose early to his door, and were astonished at his wisdom and his appearance like an angel of G-d. Also many who were not of the Covenant (Gentiles) were early to his door to ask his advice.
R' Mordechai hated money absolutely, and refused to receive any support from the seekers of his advice. He would say: "My duty is to help everyone who turns to me for free, there is no money." Immediately when a person knocked on the door, he would stand up with alacrity and go to open the door, so that the man would not wait even one moment unnecessarily. Especially he would draw close the poor and the destitute and was appeasing with words of comfort, and knew to say to each one a word that was beautiful for him. Also in the wisdom of medicine he knew. And for those whom he knew needed an expert doctor, he said immediately to go seek an expert doctor.
He was ready to give his soul for the community and the individual. A story happened where a false libel was plotted against two of the members of his community and they sentenced them to hanging. Then he hurried to Vilna and presented himself before the governor, and through his intercession, they were saved from death. He passed away on 12th Adar I 5676 (1916) in the middle of the days of the war (and is buried in Slonim).
Source: "Mishnat Beit Abba" (Brooklyn 5709), p. 121

...It is worthwhile to bring here a wonderful story:
At the time when the wife of the Gaon Rabbi Isser Zalman Meltzer *zt"l* was traveling on the train with her great husband after their wedding, the Tzaddik Rabbi Mordechai *zt"l* of Slonim was there on the train. He was famous as a Tzaddik whose blessings are fulfilled, and many came to be blessed by him. The wife of Rabbi Isser Zalman turned to him that he should bless her that her husband would be a Talmid Chacham. Rabbi Mordechai said to her: "Do you request the honor of the Torah, or do you want honor for yourself?" The wife of Rabbi Isser Zalman felt ashamed and broken. After a quarter of an hour, she saw how Rabbi Mordechai was trudging from car to car searching for her, and he said to her: "I ask your forgiveness, even though you request honor for yourself, but a young woman in our generation who requests honor for herself from the fact that her husband will be a Talmid Chacham, this is also a great thing."
Source: "Maran" (Jerusalem 5734), p. 66

The Gaon Rabbi Shabtai Yagel, Rosh Yeshiva of Slonim, told Grandfather [HaRahach Rabbi Leibish Friedman *zt"l*] what he saw with the Rav of Slonim, the Tzaddik Rabbi Mordechai Weitzel of Oshmina, who was famous in the whole region as a man of wonders, and even Gentiles would come to ask for the blessing of his mouth. Once Rabbi Shabtai was present when three Russian generals arrived and stood inside the large crowd that waited to be blessed by the mouth of the Tzaddik. And behold, the Jews Rabbi Mordechai blessed by placing his two hands on their heads, but the Gentiles he praised and blessed in their language in Russian while his two hands were on their shoulders.
When Grandfather conversed these words before R' Baruch Nachman Neuman, he answered and said: I will tell you the meaning of the matter. In the Holy Zohar, when it counts the limbs of man and explains his spiritual root and essence of every limb, regarding the Children of Israel it starts from the head, the king of limbs, and from there descends and goes downward. However, when the Zohar details the limbs of the nations of the world, it skips the head and starts after it. And the reason for this: In the internality and spirituality of things, the nations of the world have no aspect of "Head". Therefore Rabbi Mordechai placed his hand on the shoulder and not on the head.
At the Sheva Brachos for his son Rabbi Moshe, Grandfather told this fact as an addition to the explanation of R' Baruch Nachman, and the Gaon Rabbi Yosef Dov *zt"l*, son of the Rav of Brisk, was present there. After a number of days, the Grid" (Rabbi Yosef Dov Soloveitchik) met Grandfather and told him that he said the whole matter before his father, and he reacted immediately: "Certainly, from where do Gentiles have a head?"
Source: "Ari Shebachabura" (Bnei Brak 5778), p. 442

**His History**
The Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov *zt"l* was born in the year 5595 (1835) to his father the Holy Rabbi R' Chanoch Henich of Alesk *zt"l*, author of "Lev Sameach". He grew up on the knees of his grandfather, his mother's father, the Holy Rabbi the "Sar Shalom" of Belz zy"a, and also received lessons from the mouth of the Holy Rabbi R' Avraham of Stretyn *zt"l*. With the passing of his father in the year 5644 (1884), he settled in Sasov and became known as a holy man and possessor of wonders, and thousands rose early to his door. He was admired by all the greats of his generation. In the year 5679 (1919), after WWI, he passed away on the day of 12th Adar I, and is buried in Lemberg near the Gaon the author of "Beit Yitzchak" *zt"l*.
Source: "Tzaddik Mah Paal" (Brooklyn 5760), p. 103

From the dawn of his youth, the name of the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov zy"a went out as a sublime prodigy (Iluy), diligent and possessing understanding, G-d fearing and afraid of sin. When he was eight years old, his work was already known near and far; his sharp mind and wise sayings endeared him to his environment. In the court of his father zy"a, he absorbed the light of Chassidut, clung to great Chassidim, and observed their deeds. The days of his childhood passed over him especially in the holy sanctuary of his grandfather the "Sar Shalom" of Belz zy"a, where he perfected himself in the virtues of Torah and service. His grandfather zy"a would educate this grandchild of delights and would not move from hugging him. He would sleep together with his grandfather zy"a in his room; although his grandfather did not tolerate the presence of a stranger at the time of his sleep, regarding this grandchild he found delight and pleasure and even agreed to this out of great affection and love for him.
At a young age, his father betrothed him, and when the time came, he took for a wife the Rebbetzin Mrs. Kulya, daughter of the Holy Rabbi R' Hirsch Leib of Oleshwitz zy"a (grandson of the Holy Rabbi R' Hirsch Leib of Alik zy"a). The father of the bride, who lived then still in the country of Russia, was not permitted by the laws of the government to cross the border to Galicia, and because of this, he did not participate in his wedding. The "Shoshvin" (best man) on the side of the bride was our Rebbe [the Holy Rabbi R' Yisrael of Ruzhin] zy"a, in his honor and in person, for he was the uncle of the bride [for Rebbetzin Kulya was the daughter of Rebbetzin Gitel a"h, who was the daughter of Rebbetzin Chana Vita a"h—wife of the Holy Rabbi R' Yitzchak of Granov, son of the Holy Rabbi R' Mordechai of Kremnitz zy"a—who was the daughter of our Rebbe Shalom of Prohobitch zy"a and sister of our Rebbe zy"a]. (Tiferet Banim Avot).
Source: "Ner Yisrael-Ruzhin" (Bnei Brak 5754), Part 4, p. 287

My father and teacher *zt"l* merited to see and know the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov. He was known as a man who performs wonders, that many were healed and saved by his hand not according to the way of nature at all [as is known, he received this power from his holy father].
I heard that in one town, a secular Jew fell while riding his horse and broke his leg. The doctors could not find a cure for his blow, and he was limping on his leg. Days later, one of his friends came to him and suggested that he travel with him to Rabbi Shlomo'le, who could certainly effect a salvation for him not according to the way of nature. After various deliberations, he agreed to travel with him to the Rebbe's house.
When he entered the inner sanctum, the Rebbe asked him if he keeps Torah and Mitzvot. When he answered in the negative, he made a clear condition with him that if he accepts upon himself to keep Shabbos according to its laws, behold he promises him that he will be able to walk on his leg like any man. When he accepted this upon himself, he promised him that he would be healed, and a short time did not pass until his limp was completely healed.
After two years, the man saw that there was relief, and he hardened his heart and stopped keeping Shabbos, Heaven forbid. A short time later, when he rode his horse, he fell again and broke his leg. When he saw that such had happened to him, he understood that he was punished for the desecration of Shabbos. He asked his friend to take him a second time to Rabbi Shlomo'le so he would pray for him for salvation. The friend acceded to his request and traveled with him.
When they entered the inner sanctum and laid out the request, Rabbi Shlomo'le did not agree in any way to bless him with a matter of salvation, for if he broke the condition the first time, he did not want to promise him again. And indeed, the man was not healed from his limp until his last day.
Source: "Mipi Sefarim VeSofrim" (Bnei Brak 5768), Part 3, p. 113

The mayor of Sasov honored the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov greatly. He told the reason for the matter to the people of the city:
Once, my daughter became sick until all hope for her recovery was lost, and the doctors despaired. Rabbi Shlomo had a Gabbai named R' Avraham. He advised me to come together with my daughter to the Rebbe to ask him to heal my daughter, and also he would speak to his Rebbe to save my daughter from her distress. After I consulted with the priest, and he also told me that I have nothing to lose, I put my daughter on a wagon, as she was completely paralyzed, and we traveled to the Rebbe.
