When we arrived at the Rebbe and I laid out my trouble before him, the Rebbe asked me: "Do you, after all the expert doctors have despaired, believe that I can help you?"
I answered: "Yes, I believe that through your prayer, Hashem will send her a complete recovery." And I added: "Also the priest advised me to come to you, since we believe in G-d and in your salvation."
Rabbi Shlomo walked around his room back and forth. Afterward, he took a piece of silk and gave it to me and said: "Three times a day wash all her body with this, and at the time of washing say: 'The Admor of Sasov commanded me thus.' I hope to Hashem that within a week she will heal completely. However," added Rabbi Shlomo, "for an additional week she shall sit in the house and not go out. And it shall be when she goes out, she will return to her illness, and I will not be able to help her, for we do not rely on a miracle."
And indeed, within a week she healed completely. And we also kept watch over her—I and my wife—that she should not go out the door of the house. But on the last day, when I was busy with my work and my wife was busy in the kitchen, we did not sense that she went out to the yard to play with the children. And it was, as soon as she went out—she fainted. In my distress, I turned running to Rabbi Shlomo, and I fell before him to beg for my daughter. After a time of silence, Rabbi Shlomo asked of me that I bring him the piece of silk.
I brought the silk to Rabbi Shlomo, and the Rebbe said to me: "Three times a day wash her and say, 'Thus commanded the Rebbe of Sasov upon me.' But know, that from now on a sign of illness will remain in her all the days of her life." And indeed, she healed in all her body, except for one leg.
Source: "Zichron Elazar" (Bnei Brak 5760), Introduction p. 8

My grandfather (the Holy Rabbi R' Meshulam Yisachar Ashkenazi of Stanislav-London) *zt"l* told that once his sister was in Tlumatch at her uncle's, the Holy Rabbi R' Yisrael, brother of his father the Holy Rabbi R' Tzvi *zt"l*, and hot water spilled on her leg and she was burned. When they stripped off her stockings, shreds of flesh and sinews were caught and dragged with them, and she became lame in her leg. The doctors could not heal her or cure her.
My father *zt"l* traveled with her to the Holy Rabbi of Sasov to effect a salvation. And behold, he did not touch children (girls), but since she was his relative, he placed a handkerchief on her leg and gave his holy hand upon it and blessed her. Afterward, he commanded her to walk. She began to walk like any person and was healed completely.
Source: "Tiferet Meshulam" (Brooklyn 5761), p. 773

My father and teacher [the Holy Rabbi R' Chanoch Henich of Kerecki] *zt"l* used to tell that at the time of his wedding, while they were sitting reclining at the head of the table, the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov zy"a sat on his right and his father-in-law the "Kedushat Yom Tov" on his left, and he sat between them. In the middle of the meal, a telegram arrived from the district of "Nir" to the in-law, the author of "Kedushat Yom Tov", asking him to pray for a woman having difficulty giving birth. The Kedushat Yom Tov handed the telegram to the Holy Rabbi of Sasov, meaning that he should pray as well. The Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov leaned himself toward my father and teacher and said to him: "The child is already born."
They did not sense that anyone heard what he whispered in his ear. One young man from the students of the Baal "Kedushat Yom Tov" heard the whisper well, and noted in his notebook the exact time, and decided to clarify tomorrow if the matter was true and correct. The young man did not be lazy; the next day he traveled to the district of "Nir", the place from where the telegram arrived, and it was clarified before his eyes that at that exact hour, the child was born, Mazel Tov.
After many years, when I visited my father *zt"l* in his sanctuary, I met sitting there the Chassid Rabbi Zelig Rosenberg from the city of Dobrovka. My father said to me: "Here, Rabbi Zelig is the Jew who tested our grandfather the Holy Rabbi of Sasov *zt"l*." And then my father told the story in the presence of Rabbi Zelig, the subject of the story.
Source: "Ir Chanoch" (Jerusalem 5738), Part 1, p. 53

There was a woman giving birth from New York who became ill. The doctors did an operation here and opened her abdomen and found no injury in it. She traveled to the city of Vienna, and there too the professors did not find a cure for her. She knew nothing of the matter of a Rebbe at all, only she traveled to my father-in-law R' David Leib from the village of Tzerneve near Dukla, and she went out to travel to my father-in-law [the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov zy"a].
When my father-in-law began to read her *Kvitel* (note), she fell to the ground with a great noise and rolled on the ground like a millstone. When my father-in-law stopped praying, she stood on her feet and spoke with intelligence and knowledge, not knowing what had happened to her. On the second day, she fell again as mentioned above, and the *Dybbuk* began to speak in a loud voice, and so it was every time.
Once I was in my father-in-law's house when he prayed for her, and the *Dybbuk* screamed then with great weeping until the heart of every listener melted, and begged my father-in-law to have mercy on him to save him from his great sufferings, for the destroyers (angels of destruction) were torturing him. He screamed in this language: "There are currently in the world wicked people even worse than he was in his lifetime, and through their sins, destructive plagues of the children of men are created, and they torture him additionally to his own destroyers." He stormed asking why he should suffer from the sins of others.
After my father-in-law stopped from his blessing as was his custom, he stood in thought facing the ground and consulted with my father-in-law about a deal as if this [the Dybbuk incident] had not happened. Once the aforementioned *Dybbuk* said that through this he had permission to enter her, because she caused him to be wicked so much, for he was her groom and she left the match without the agreement of the Beis Din, and through this he married a Gentile woman. The aforementioned woman traveled to her home in complete health and sent afterwards redemption money from New York.
Source: "Zichron Elazar" (Tel Aviv 5760), p. 6

The Chassid R' Hershel Miller told me that at the time of the First World War, his father the Chassid R' Shimon a"h needed to stand for the army draft. Therefore, he inflicted a blemish in his eyes—some blemish that could be healed—only he made a blemish on one eye. He lay in the army hospital. When my mother a"h went to visit him, he cried greatly, and told my mother that the doctors said it is impossible to heal the eye, and that the other eye was also affected by the aforementioned illness.
At the time he lived in Oshpitzin, the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov *zt"l* was there. My mother a"h went to the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo, and my mother told the Holy Rabbi everything that happened to her husband. The Holy Rabbi asked about my grandfather (her father-in-law): "Is he a G-d fearing man?" My grandfather answered: "Yes." The Holy Rabbi asked for a *Kippah* (Kappel) from her husband. My mother gave him a *Kippah*. The Holy Rabbi whispered over the *Kippah* and returned it to my mother, and said that he would return in peace to his home.
Afterward, my father left the hospital. In one eye he did not see at all, and in the other eye only thirty-five percent remained. Indeed, he saw so well with this eye that he circumcised four thousand children, and was a *Baal Koreh* (Torah reader), and also at Mincha on Friday night, when it was already a little dark, he saw well in the Torah scroll.
Source: "Siach Zkenim" (Brooklyn 5760), Part 3, p. 345

Once I was in the summer with my father-in-law [the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov zy"a] for Shabbos Kodesh in the holy community of Yartshov, near Lemberg. He told at the meal that his grandfather the Holy Rabbi R' Sar Shalom of Belz asked: Why is it written "We will go" (Nelech) after "and with our elders"? Surely it concludes at the end "We will go" [in Parshat Bo: **ויאמר משה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך בבנינו ובבנותנו נלך** - "And Moshe said, with our youth and with our elders we will go, with our sons and with our daughters we will go" (Exodus 10:9)].
He said that it is in order to interrupt the matter, to include the children with our flock and our cattle, to hint that just as we pray for our children and our daughters, so too we need to pray for the animals, for it is the livelihood of the Children of Israel.
Source: "Zichron Elazar" (Tel Aviv 5760), p. 118

In village A., near Krala, lived a respected family who had a son who did not follow in the ways of his fathers, Heaven forbid, and a spirit of folly entered him and he wanted to marry a certain maidservant. His mother cried before him not to do such a thing, but to no avail. After many efforts, she succeeded in influencing him to travel with her to Sasov.
When they stepped on the threshold of the holy house of the Holy Rabbi and she gave him a *Kvitel* (note), the Holy Rabbi answered and said: "It is not fitting for a Jewish man to do such a thing. Rather, his mother will give him a nice sum for a dowry and make a decent and proper match with him." But the son was brazen faced and said it is impossible for him to change his decision. He asked him and pleaded with him once and twice to return from his evil thought, but the boy did not want to lend a listening ear to the words coming from a holy mouth of Israel.
Then the Rebbe took his handkerchief and passed it over the boy's face. Suddenly he became mute to me! He became like a mute person who will not open his mouth. The mother and her son traveled back to their home. The aforementioned maidservant, upon seeing that he had become mute, did not want to hear from him anymore. The boy understood that his hand—the great hand of the Rebbe—had done all this. He asked his mother to travel with him a second time to Sasov, and she did so.
When they came into the inner sanctum, the Holy Rabbi asked him: "Will you fulfill the words of my mouth?" He answered him with his head [nodding yes]. Then he commanded him to speak, and the power of his speech returned to him, and he became a complete Baal Teshuvah.
Source: "Tiferet Meshulam" (Brooklyn 5761), p. 773

My father-in-law [the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov zy"a] told me that if one prays for a sick person and is not answered, then one should include the prayer for this sick person at the time one prays for *another* sick person. For it is possible that for the other sick person it is a time of favor (Et Ratzon), so there will not be a screen blocking his prayer for him, and within this, his prayer will also be accepted for the previous sick person.
Source: "Zichron Elazar" (Tel Aviv 5760), p. 53

I will bring one thing that I heard from the mouth of my mother, my teacher the righteous Mrs. Esther a"h, who told that once an important woman came from the country of Hungary to Sasov to my father-in-law, the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov zy"a, to ask for a cure for a special illness which visited her, Heaven forbid. It was known that generally one could wait many days until one could enter the inner sanctum. Therefore, she came to my mother a"h that she should enable her to enter through a back door which was open for the descendants of the Tzaddik, and she would enter with her, for the matter was urgent and it was hard for her to wait until she obtained permission to enter.
My mother a"h knew that for this matter, it was the way of the Tzaddik to ask for oil and bless the oil. Therefore, while she was with her, [she noticed] a flask of oil that had already been blessed once and emptied. She sent with the flask to buy more oil, but there was still a little oil stuck to the walls of the regular vessel.
When my mother entered together with the woman into the inner sanctum and presented the oil on the table to bless it, and he began to bless, he said with his holy mouth: "Behold the oil has already been blessed once!" My mother a"h replied: "It is true that there was a little oil in the flask, but the majority is new oil." From this they saw and understood the magnitude of his holy feeling and his holy spirit.
Source: "Ir Chanoch" (Jerusalem 5741), Part 1, p. 79

Regarding the order of his passing [of the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov zy"a], it is told: On the fifth day before his passing, his strength had already left him and he lay without life. The next day in the evening, at the time of the entrance of Shabbos, he sat himself up on his bed and said: "Now behold the Holy Shabbos arrives, please give me Challah of Shabbos and fish." He came down from his bed, washed his hands, blessed Hamotzi, and ate an olive's bulk (Kazayit). He went back up on his bed and said these words: "Seeker of good for his people and speaking peace to all his seed." And at that hour his soul departed in holiness and purity.
Source: "Ir Chanoch" (Jerusalem 5741), Part 1, p. 66

**On Graves of Tzaddikim**
I heard from my father-in-law (the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo of Sasov zy"a) the reason why he says words of Torah from his name on the marker (Tziyun) of his father, and so too on the marker of another Tzaddik. Because it is difficult for the Tzaddik to come to this world to participate with us in prayer, due to the fear that he might become materialized (Gashmi) from this lowly world. But when they say words of Torah from him on the marker of the Tzaddik, he is clothed in this garment of his, and in this it is easy for him to clothe himself and come here and participate with us in our prayer.
Source: "Zichron Elazar" (Tel Aviv 5760), p. 84

**His History**
He was born in the year 5610 (1850) to his father the Holy Rabbi R' Meir of Dzikov zy"a, author of "Imrei Noam". When he reached his maturity, he married the daughter of our Rebbe [the Holy Gaon author of "Divrei Chaim" of Sanz zy"a]. In the year 5636 approximately, Rabbi Aharon was accepted as Rav in the town of Bietch.
He was gifted with a pleasant voice to the point of wonder, and the service of his heart was with an outpouring of the emotional soul, which aroused many to repentance. Those who came from Bietch tell about him that by his merit and from his power, a whole generation was educated to pure Judaism in the place. His influence on the residents of the town was great during the twenty-five years of his tenure there.
In the year 5674 (1914), he escaped from the terror of the war to Kashau in Hungary. The Gaon Rabbi Shaul Brach, Rav of the city, worried to support him in an honorable way, and he was accustomed to go at times on Friday nights with the students of his Yeshiva to the table (Tish) of Rabbi Aharon. In Kashau, the managers of the local factory for the production of coffee from produce, known as "Frank Coffee", pleaded with him that he should accept upon himself the supervision of the factory.
However, he rejected the offer despite the tight state of his livelihood, because of the opposition of his brother-in-law, the Rebbe of Shinova, to the Kashrus of the coffee of Kashau. It is told in the book "Shaul Bechir Hashem" page 50, that when they returned and pleaded with him again on the matter, he went to hear the opinion of the Rav of the place (D'mata). Upon entering to him, Rabbi Shaul ran to greet him and said: "The Rebbe of Bietch! I am certain that his brother-in-law the Rav of Shinova will receive him nicely in the World of Truth, for today I did a thing for his honor, and I revealed my opinion against the Hechsher (certification) that even he opposed." Upon hearing this, Rabbi Aharon reacted with excitement: "Indeed, I have already received a clear answer to my question!"
It is further reported there what Rabbi Shaul said about him, that his face shines, and from his form it is recognizable that he lives a life of holiness and purity. He further added that he merited the radiance of the light of the face because he is a guardian of the Covenant (Noter HaBrit), for while still in his youth he married a woman, the daughter of a Tzaddik like our Rebbe.
He passed away in Kashau on the day of 12th Adar I 5687 (1927), and there his resting place is in honor in a special Ohel.
Source: "Rabbeinu HaKadosh MiSanz" (Jerusalem 5757), Part 2, p. 454

**A Plague Which is Not Written in the Torah**
In the Midrash [brought in "Yaarot Devash" Part 1, Sermon 4, p. 87 in the new edition, see there and in the glosses of HaGr"y Pick] "Also every sickness and every plague which is not written in the book of this Torah, Hashem will bring upon you" (Deuteronomy 28:61)—this refers to the death of Tzaddikim. And it is puzzling.
The Holy Gaon Mohar"a of Bietch zy"a (son-in-law of the Holy Gaon author of "Divrei Chaim" of Sanz zy"a) explained: Behold, the verse says (Isaiah 63:9) **בכל צרתם לא צר** - "In all their troubles He was troubled" (literally: "He was not an adversary/trouble", written with Aleph **לא**, read with Vav **לו** - "to Him"). See Sotah 31a. This teaches that He gave the sorrow below as if it is sorrow above, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, participates in the sorrow of Israel (see Ibn Ezra and Radak on Isaiah there, and see Taanit 16a and Yalkut Shimoni Shmuel I Remez 192).
However, at the passing of a Tzaddik, the sorrow is only below. Since "He rides the skies to your help" rejoices and is happy at the coming to Him of a clean and righteous soul (Moed Katan 25b). And if so, at the death of a Tzaddik, there is no sorrow towards Above, as it were. And this is what the Sages expounded: "A plague which is not written in the Torah"—that we expound the written text **לא** ("not" written), and that there is no sorrow towards Above, as it were—this is only at the death of Tzaddikim.
Source: "Tzanz", Adar 5757, p. 9

**A Holy Letter with Words of Torah for Purim**
To the honor of that great man, the Rav, the Gaon, famous in Torah and Fear in truth and innocence, known in the gates, humble of knee, honor of his name, our teacher R' Shaul Brach *shlita*, Av Beit Din of the holy community of Kashau, may G-d protect it.
Behold I have come to fulfill the Mitzvah of sending portions (Mishloach Manot) a man to his friend. Therefore, I am sending to his honor, his greatness, that he should live, sweets and live fish and beautiful things and cigarettes and kindness called [Noit] and a drink of two flasks of good liquor and other things from me, his friend who loves him, who seeks his welfare with a longing soul and blesses him with the joy of Purim in gladness and exultation and joy of heart.
The small Aharon Horowitz, son of the Holy Gaon HaTzaddik of Dzikov *zt"l*, author of the book "Imrei Noam". And son-in-law of the Holy Gaon HaTzaddik, Rabbi of all the children of the Diaspora, of Sanz, may his memory be for a blessing in the life of the World to Come, author of the book "Divrei Chaim".
And by the way, I will write to his honor, his greatness *shlita*, some word of Torah which I innovated on the days of Purim. Behold it is known from holy books that the days of Purim are a time and season for the wiping out of sins like Yom Kippur. And on the contrary, it is higher, for Yom *Kippurim* is like Purim in the potential of imagination (similarity). And also in the *Yotzer* prayer of Parshat Zachor we say: "And if all the festivals are cancelled, the days of Purim will not be cancelled."
However, there is a distinction. For Purim is a rectification of the *Veshet* (esophagus) to increase in eating and drinking, and Yom Kippur is a rectification on the *Kaneh* (windpipe), to afflict oneself and to cry out to the King of Kings, the Holy One, Blessed be He, in prayers. And furthermore there is a difference: For on the eve of Yom Kippur it is a Mitzvah to increase in eating and drinking, and on the eve of Purim it is a Mitzvah to afflict oneself, for it is the Fast of Esther.
And for this, **קנ"ה וווש"ט** (Kaneh and Veshet - Windpipe and Esophagus) in Gematria is **ע"ת** (Et - Time/Season - 470). That then it is a "Time" of favor for the wiping out of sins like Yom Kippur. And behold Haman the Wicked, may his name be obliterated, wanted to arouse the sin of the Tree of Knowledge, as he said "Let them make a tree fifty cubits high." But the Assembly of Israel acted so that his counsel would be annulled through the fifty letters of the Shema, which we say twice every day, as the Holy Zohar brought. And Haman the Wicked, who was from the seed of Amalek, may his name be obliterated, who made from the Dalet of Echad (**אחד**) a Reish, that he is Acher (**אחר** - Other), because he said that there are two powers (dualism), Heaven forbid, as the Arizal says: **א"ל אח"ר** in Gematria is **עמל"ק** (Amalek), and he deceived with the number 196 (Kuf-Tzadi-Vav), for from Dalet to Reish is a difference of 196. And for this, Haman in his full spelling like this: Heh-Heh Mem-Mem Nun-Nun is Gematria 196.
And for this, at the time he cursed Hashem the Earth, he said: **קו"ץ ודרד"ר תצמיח לך** - "Thorn and thistle shall it sprout for you" (Genesis 3:18), meaning the number of **קו"ץ** (Kotz - Thorn - 196), which is Haman who made a **דרד"ר** (Dardar - Thistle/Descent), from Dalet to Reish.
And therefore we read on Purim **ויבא עמלק** - "And Amalek came," and we conclude **מלחמה לה' בעמלק מד"ר ד"ר** - "A war for Hashem against Amalek from generation to generation" (Exodus 17:16). And this is the war that we will do to return the Dalet of **אחד** (Echad). And Israel, His holy people, believes He is that Hashem is **אח"ד** (One), unique in the world, doing the return from Reish to Dalet. And therefore we read in Parshat Zachor and conclude **תמחה את זכר עמלק** - "You shall wipe out the memory of Amalek," from under the heavens it shall not be forgotten. Therefore, if **זכ"ר** (Zecher - Memory) of Amalek, may his name be obliterated, is wiped out, there remains the number **אח"ד** (Echad - One).
And with this we can say the simple meaning in the Gemara: "A thorn (Kotz) sat in his esophagus (Veshet)," meaning in the days of Purim, that then the rectification of the **ושט** (Veshet) will do Teshuvah and Hashem will forgive him all the sins, Amen. And I will ask him to inform me of a reply if this was good in his eyes.
The aforementioned.
A holy letter written by the Holy Gaon Rabbi Aharon of Bietch zy"a.
Source: "Shaul Bechir Hashem" (Netanya 5736), p. 51

**His History**
The Holy Rabbi R' Yehoshua of Rivotitch. He was born to his father the Holy Rabbi R' Tzvi Elimelech—the "Tzvi LaTzaddik" of Bluzhov in the year 5623 (1863). He filled the place of his father in Risha. He married the righteous Rebbetzin Mrs. Miriam a"h, daughter of his uncle the Gaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Menachem Mendel Marilos, Av Beit Din of Dubetzk, son-in-law of the Holy Rabbi R' David of Dinov. And in a second marriage, he married the righteous Rebbetzin Mrs. Tziporah, daughter of the Holy Rabbi R' Yaakov Shapira (Dakhner) of Delatyn, grandson of the Holy Rabbi R' Pinchas of Koritz, the Maggid of Zlatshov, Chernobyl, Sasov, and more. He passed away on the day of 12th Adar II, year 5692 (1932). He authored the book "Keren Yeshuah" on the months of the year and festivals.
Source: "Yud Gimmel Orot" (Brooklyn 5771), Part 3, p. 338

Regarding the intensity of the admiration of the "Tzvi LaTzaddik" [of Bluzhov] for his son—our Rebbe [the Holy Rabbi R' Yehoshua of Rivotitch zy"a, author of "Keren Yeshuah"]—what he once expressed about him will testify, saying: "The greats of the Tzaddikim of the generation do not comprehend what my son intends at the time he brings the spoon of soup close to himself on the night of Shabbos to eat!"
Source: "Lechem Oni" (Jerusalem 5766), p. 440

His custom in holiness, of the Holy Rabbi the "Keren Yeshuah" of Rivotitch *zt"l* zy"a, was that several times he said during the meal the Mishna at the end of Chapter 4 of Tractate Zevachim: "For the sake of six things is the sacrifice sacrificed," and several times he would say the Mishna at the beginning of Chapter 3 of Avot: "Akavya ben Mahalalel says etc."
Source: "Lechem Oni" (Jerusalem 5766), p. 312

**לוה רשע ולא ישלם וצדיק חונן ונותן** - "The wicked borrows and does not pay, and the righteous is gracious and gives" (Psalms 37:21). One can say by way of jest, for it is known that there were holy Tzaddikim like my master grandfather the Gaon HaKadosh the "Divrei Chaim" zy"a or my master grandfather K"K Maran HaGaon HaKadosh Maharash zy"a, who left this world with large debts that they owed to others. And Heaven forbid to say that they were in the category of "The wicked borrows and does not pay," rather certainly they paid in full to every lender, if not in money simply then in other salvations. And this is "The wicked borrows and does not pay"—but the Tzaddik, even when you see a Tzaddik who does not pay, "is gracious and gives," know that he pays well in some way and repays his debt he pays.
Source: "Tehillim Beit Tzaddikim" (Brooklyn 5765), p. 120

HaGaon R' Chaim Baruch Fink *shlita* told me that he heard from the K"K Admor of Bluzhov *zt"l*, that his father the Holy Rabbi R' Yehoshua of Rivotitch *zt"l* felt pain in his heart, and the doctor commanded him to rest a little from his work, and also that he needs to taste something in the morning.
His father, the Holy Rabbi of Bluzhov *zt"l*, appointed his grandson the Admor *zt"l* to supervise his father.
And he told, when my grandfather asked me afterward if my father is fulfilling all that the doctor commanded him, and I answered that he is not fulfilling it, my grandfather sent to call my father. When he arrived at his father's house, he approached him (leaning a little, out of fear of honor). My grandfather sat at the head of the table and my father approached the edge of the second side of the table. My grandfather said to him: "What do you want from me? Why do you not fulfill the doctor's order? [Vas vilstu fun mir hubn, farvus folgstu nisht dem doctor?] Is it not written **ונשמרתם מאד לנפשתיכם** - 'And you shall guard your souls very much' (Deut 4:15)?"
My father, the Rebbe of Rivotitch, asked his father the Rebbe of Bluzhov if he gives him permission to say a thing, and he agreed. My father asked: "Is it written **ונשמרתם מאד לגופיכם** - 'And you shall guard your bodies very much'? Is it not written 'to your *souls*'?" But my grandfather said to him again: "What do you want from me, etc.," and asked my father again if he gives him permission to say a thing, and he said: "In the army, when a soldier serves well he becomes later an officer, I surely will need to take a *Kvitel* (note) to Jewish children [=it is customary in the army, if a soldier serves well they raise him in rank and he becomes a commander, I surely will need to take a Kvitel to Jews], and he concluded the Admor: When my grandfather heard the words of my father, he did not speak of this anymore.
Source: "Siach Zkenim" (Brooklyn 5767), Part 6, p. 177

There was an incident where once several Chassidim of Rivotitch, distinguished and elevated men, established for themselves to learn together a class in public in the holy book "Etz Chaim", to the Holy Rabbi R' Chaim Vital *zt"l* zy"a, on Shabbos before the prayer. When the Holy Rabbi the "Keren Yeshuah" zy"a saw them, he said to them that it would be better if they established at this hour the study of the class in public in the Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim, Laws of Shabbos, for the study of the Torah of the Hidden (Kabbalah) is preferable when it is in private.
Source: "Lechem Oni" (Jerusalem 5766), p. 312

His close associate, the Chassid Rabbi Shlomo Yehuda Intrator *zt"l*, told a story regarding him ("B'didei Hava Uvda").
When his father Rabbi Yitzchak Eliezer *zt"l*, one of the veteran Chassidim of Dinov-Bluzhov, passed away, the "Keren Yeshuah" instructed him that during the eleven months of mourning, when he prays Shacharit before the Ark (Amud), he should try every day when he finishes the "Baraita of Rabbi Yishmael"—before they begin "Hodu"—to look and search, perhaps there is in the Beis Midrash another Jew who is an "Obligated One" (Chiyuv - a mourner) like him, and he should hand over to him the privilege of being the Baal Tefillah (Leader of Prayer)... that he should concede and do kindness with his fellow in a generous spirit... This too is a benefit for the elevation of the father's soul...
[His son, the "Shufra D'Yisrael" (of Bluzhov) zy"a, used to say in the name of his grandfather our Rebbe the "Tzemach David" (of Dinov) zy"a, that regarding the deceased, it is possible to do Torah and Avodah (prayer), but how is it possible for the deceased to engage in Gemilut Chassadim (Acts of Kindness)? And for this he said, that when there are two obligated people in the Beis Midrash and the son of one of the deceased concedes the Amud for the honor of the other, this is the Act of Kindness that is considered for the deceased himself.]
Source: "Toldot Yehoshua" (Jerusalem 5770), p. 13

The Holy Rabbi the "Keren Yeshuah" zy"a was particular to say 'Tachanun' every day, except on a day of the Hillula of Tzaddikim with whom he had a connection and bond, and he was not pleased when they did not say Tachanun on the day of a Hillula of one of the Tzaddikim with whom the congregation had no connection.
There was an incident where the Chazzan (Baal Tefillah) did not say Tachanun in the Minyan of the "Keren Yeshuah", and excused himself that there is on that day a Hillula of one of the Tzaddikim from previous generations. The "Keren Yeshuah" scolded him: "Did you know him at all?"
Once the "Keren Yeshuah" arrived in a certain city on Thursday, on the condition to stay there until after Shabbos, and the innkeeper did not say Tachanun in the prayer. The "Keren Yeshuah" asked him why he did not say Tachanun, and the innkeeper answered that this is because of the joy that a Tzaddik came to the city. The "Keren Yeshuah" was particular with him in his humility, and said to him: "And who am I, that for my sake they should cancel the saying of Tachanun?"
Source: "Lechem Oni" (Jerusalem 5766), p. 332

Upon standing on the threshold of old age, in 5692 (1932), sufferings of love visited the "Keren Yeshuah". His health condition was shaken greatly, and he went and weakened day by day...
For many days the Tzaddik lay in his house in Risha on a sickbed, and the young men who learned in the Beis Midrash attached to his house rotated in shifts, to serve him and nurse him in his illness. More than them, his son our Rebbe the "Shufra D'Yisrael" of Bluzhov zy"a exerted himself. He served then in the holiness as Av Beit Din of the holy community of Prochnik, and who lived at times together with him in that building, to serve him and to fulfill himself all the needs of his holy father. An attempt was made to transfer the sick Rebbe to a large hospital in the city of Vienna, the capital of Austria, where the best experts tried to bring him relief, but since their hand was short and they despaired of healing him, they returned him to Risha.
The "Keren Yeshuah" ceased then to speak almost completely, but despite all this, his close ones heard from his mouth in a whisper various hints, obscure words, which testified that the Rebbe was preparing to pass to a world that is all good. And furthermore, he foresaw in advance that he would pass away from the world on a cloudy day that would fall on Erev Shabbos Kodesh—a vision that was fulfilled. His son our Rebbe the "Shufra D'Yisrael" told in later days the whole sequence of events as follows:
"About a month before the passing, I was called to Father to his room, and he said to me then that he does not feel well, and showed me with great worry that his legs were swollen. I tried to calm his spirit with the hope that this would pass and he would heal with the help of G-d, but my father and teacher held to his own, that one must remember and take into account that every man sometime arrives at his day to ascend to the Heights and give judgment and accounting, and just as against your will you live, so too the opposite. However, he added, I have distress of the soul from the fact that this will happen on the sixth day, Erev Shabbos Kodesh, and they will be forced to hurry and arrange the burial in haste, and great trouble will be caused to everyone because of the preparations for Shabbos Kodesh. 'Granted,' he continued, 'if it were at least a clear and nice day, but in such heavy snow!'"
"After a few weeks, at the light of the fourth day, his health condition worsened greatly, the doctor [Doppler] who was summoned to his bed estimated and expressed his opinion that the end was approaching and coming, and the public increased in prayers and weeping, and also those who were around his bed and I among them participated with them and said verses of 'Yichud' etc. Afterward, the situation improved and they calmed down. When an additional day passed, on Thursday, Father asked that they dress him and put Tefillin on him. On that day he asked me, why were they so excited two days ago, 'Granted others who do not know, but you surely knew that this cannot happen on Tuesday!' I went out, therefore, to tell all the people of our circle what he said to me before such and such days, and that specifically now is the time to ask for mercy and to tear the heavens in prayers, and so they did, but due to our many sins the angels (Erelim) defeated the mortals (Metzukim)."
On the last night of his life, the light to 12th Adar I 5692, the Rebbe read the Reading of Shema at great length, which lasted almost the whole night, and when he reached the verse "And to serve Him with all your heart and with all your soul," his enthusiasm increased and he repeated the words time after time with sublime adhesion and complete unification. The morning lit up, on Friday Erev Shabbos Kodesh early in the morning, the curtain of his life of the "Keren Yeshuah" zy"a reached its end. In one bond he was bound to the Life of the Worlds and expired and was gathered to his holy fathers.
As he prophesied and foresaw in advance, snow fell then in Risha and its surroundings, heavy snow, with great difficulty the masses trudged who walked after his bier and waded with their feet on the way to the ancient cemetery of the community, wherein a place for his rest was dug next to the holy marker of his father the "Tzvi LaTzaddik" zy"a, and there is the section of the hidden lawgiver (Mechokek Safun). In later days, a shared Ohel was established over the two markers, which became a place of prayer for multitudes of proper Jews, who come until this very day to pour out there the speech of their heart and soul, and to plead to be visited with salvation and mercy by the merit of the Tzaddikim by the command of Yeshua (Salvation).
Source: "Toldot Yehoshua" (Jerusalem 5770), p. 25

On the last night of the days of the life of our Rebbe [the Holy Rabbi R' Yehoshua of Rivotitch zy"a], which fell on Thursday night, I served him a lot, and our Rebbe prepared himself to arrive at the World of Truth, and said the blessing of "Asher Yatzar" for a full hour. At that time it happened that his garment became a little dirty, and he asked that they change his clothes for him, for as is known he was very careful about the cleanliness of his clothes. Afterward, he read the Reading of Shema, for a duration of three full hours, and increased in motions of his hands upon the place of the Tefillin and passed his hands over his eyes during the Reading of Shema, and several more preparations. Afterward, he extended his holy hands to me as a sign of parting from this world. And from all the public that was there, and even his descendants, he gave only me his hand as a sign of gratitude for the good, for that which I served him day and night for several months with wonderful devotion.
Source: "Lechem Oni" (Jerusalem 5766), p. 445

**What is a Chassid?**
Our Rebbe [the Holy Rabbi R' Yehoshua of Rivotitch zy"a] would converse at times with some of his close ones regarding Chassidim and their virtues, and would say with the sharpness of his tongue that a true Chassid is one who sits and engages in Torah, and not one who knows how to smoke...
Source: "Lechem Oni" (Jerusalem 5766), p. 442

I am astonished at how they call me "His Honor the Torah" to say that I permitted a severe prohibition like this, to treat holy names and Torah verses and texts of blessings with disrespect. It is known to all that I cry out like a crane also against the calendars that institutions send to many people so that they will send them donations for this, and printed there are several blessings and the text of Kaddish. There was one institution that listened to my voice and hid them and did not send them, even though they had already printed them. One must strive that no institution does this. And I myself was careful that even on the invitations for the weddings of my sons and daughters, I did not write any verse, not even "The voice of joy" (*Kol Sasson*). And so it is fitting for every person to conduct himself.
Source: Igros Moshe Yoreh Deah Vol 2

**His History**
He was born to his father Maran Rabbeinu the Holy Rabbi R' Baruch, author of "Imrei Baruch" zy"a. From his childhood, he excelled in Torah and service with diligence and tremendous toil.
When he reached the chapter of "a man sanctifies" (marriage), he married the Rebbetzin Mrs. Sheina Rachel a"h, daughter of his uncle the Holy Rabbi R' Shmuel zy"a of Sokal, son-in-law of Maran the author of "Tzemach Tzaddik" zy"a. The joy of the wedding took place with great splendor and majesty on the 6th of Adar 5647 (1887).
After his marriage, the Holy Rabbi R' Pinchas zy"a sat "Kest" (supported study) with his father-in-law the Holy Rabbi R' Yehoshua zy"a of Belz. With the passing of his father Maran the "Imrei Baruch" zy"a in the year 5653 (1893), he moved to live in the city of Bursha and there established his great court. Many walked by his light and accepted his authority upon themselves, and the masses flowed to hear his prayers which were emotional, and they benefited from him with advice and wisdom. He was known and famous in all ends of the world as a worker of salvations, one of the great primordial fiery angels of above.
His scholarship and knowledge in all the treasures of the Revealed and Hidden Torah were from the famous things, and so too the righteousness of his distribution to every needy person and the fact that his house was open wide to anyone in need. Everything was according to the ways of his fathers and holy ancestors.
During the First World War, he moved to live in Vishava, and after a time in the year 5687 (1927) he moved to live in the city of Sighet, wherein he sat until his last day.
The flood of troubles that poured upon the People of Israel in the beginning of the days of the Second World War undermined his fragile health condition, and on the third day of the portion "When you take the census of the Children of Israel," 12th of Adar 5701 (1941), he was bound in the bond of life of the world.
His righteous sons whom he left behind him all perished in the Holocaust, may G-d avenge their blood.
His coffin was brought up to the Holy Land on the 26th of Tishrei 5726 (1965) and was buried in the Ohel of the Admorim of Vizhnitz in the "Shomrei Shabbos" cemetery in Bnei Brak.
Source: "Maaseh Avot" (Haifa 5768), Part 1, p. 167

The Holy Rabbi of Bursha and his wife the Rebbetzin of Bursha a"h were known and famous to a great degree for their acts of kindness. Their distribution to charity was endless. From the day of the Rebbe's arrival in Bursha, all the poor of the area knew that in the rooms of the ground floor of the house, a hot meal was prepared for them by day and a bed made at night.
One of the emissaries of the Holy Rabbi for the distribution of support to the poor was HaRahach R' Yisrael Avraham Katz *zt"l*. Often he was called to the special warehouse that was in the Rebbe's house, and by the order of the Holy Rabbi or the Rebbetzin, he filled sacks of flour or other products and took them to their destination. Sometimes it happened that the Rebbe or the Rebbetzin sent him to the warehouse and it was already almost empty, for the Rebbe zy"a sent the things to their destination without the knowledge of the Rebbetzin, or vice versa. Thus R' Yisrael Avraham returned to the Rebbe and said that in the flour bin there is not enough to send, for nothing remains but for the needs of the Rebbe's house itself... But the Rebbe smiled and said:
"Don't worry for me! If they hear that I have no Challahs for Shabbos, they will send me Challahs... They will not leave me without Challahs for Shabbos... But who will worry for that poor Jew? Take, therefore, the remainder of the flour and the rest of the things and transport them quickly to the dwelling of the needy one..."
Source: "Noam Megadim" (Vizhnitz), Pekudei 5763, p. 3

I remember as a child of five or six years that we traveled to my uncle's house in Bursha. In his house, poverty reigned in a manner that was not seen at that time like it. Everything he had, he distributed and gave to others, and for himself he left nothing.
Source: "Maaseh Avot" (Haifa 5768), Part 1, p. 169

The Holy Rabbi of Bursha was famous as a worker of salvations, and among his Chassidim many stories were known about the Ruach HaKodesh (Holy Spirit) that appeared in his Beis Midrash, whether in the healing of the sick whose doctors despaired of their lives, whether in the remembering of barren women, whether in the release of young men from the yoke of the Romanian army, whether in the granting of blessings that were fulfilled for longevity and abundance of livelihood.
While still in the youth of the Holy Rabbi, upon his arrival in Bursha, a healthy and strong young man came before him to ask his advice whether to present himself before the army authorities or to flee and hide. To the great wonder, the Holy Rabbi said to him: "Go and present yourself." Those present, who were still doubtful of his greatness, were astonished even more when the young man indeed returned with the news in his mouth that he was released. Among them were elderly Chassidim who turned to the Holy Rabbi in wonder: "How does a young *Avreich* show open miracles so much?" However, the Holy Rabbi of Bursha answered them: "We have a tradition from our grandfather the 'Toras Chaim' zy"a, that the word that goes out of our mouth first is the salvation. And for the future, I ask you not to interfere in my business..." (Notes of HaRahag R' Mordechai Gnut *shlita*).
Source: "Noam Megadim" (Vizhnitz), Pekudei 5763, p. 3

The Tzaddik Rabbi Pinchas of Bursha *zt"l* spoke, that the Satan brings before the Heavenly Court a bad Jew and asks to punish him. Then the Good Advocate (Melitz Tov) comes and brings another Jew, who is even worse than him, and compared to him, the first one is a Tzaddik. When they want to punish the second one, he brings a third and saves the second, and so the Good Advocate does until finally he no longer finds a worse Jew, and then he brings before the Heavenly Court a Gentile, and compared to the Gentile—the Jew is a Tzaddik. And this is what the High Priest prayed on Yom Kippur: "That Israel should not need this one to that one and not to another people..."
Source: "Olamo Shel Abba" (Jerusalem 5744), p. 407

One of the residents of Boro Park who is not counted among the Bobov community told: One day after Shacharit prayer, HaRahatz R' Naftali (K"K Maran Admor Maharantz of Bobov *zt"l*) contacted me and informed me that he wishes to stop by my house to raise me for a specific charitable cause. I agreed to this, but I refused that he should come to my house; on the contrary, I will trouble myself to stop by him. But he insisted on his own, and I on mine. Finally he said that anyway he cannot stop by his house now because of a number of creditors waiting for him there and he has nothing in his hand to reply to them now.
After he finished his words about the needy person for whom he was working, and I gave my part, I asked him in astonishment: "Do I not understand from your words that his honor is a great debtor, and if so, what do you have to do with engaging in charitable causes for others while you yourself need huge sums to pay your debts?"
He answered and said: We find in Chazal (Berachot 10a) **אפילו חרב חדה מונחת על צוארו של אדם אל ימנע עצמו מן הרחמים** - "Even if a sharp sword rests upon a person's neck, he should not prevent himself from mercy." And I interpreted this saying thus: Even if a sharp sword etc., meaning that even if the person is immersed in his own troubles up to his head, he is not permitted to prevent himself from having mercy on his fellow and to assist him to be extricated from his troubles and difficulties.
Source: "Binyan Shlomo" (Bobov), Adar 5766, p. 12

A special closeness and tight bond existed between the holy brothers, our Rebbe the author of "Ahavat Yisrael" and his brother the Holy Rabbi of Bursha zy"a.
It is known that after the passing of Maran the "Imrei Baruch" zy"a, Maran the Holy Grandfather the "Ahavat Yisrael" did not want at first to take upon himself the yoke of leadership of the Edah (community), except that the pressure of the heads of the Chassidim increased, especially after the Holy Rabbi of Bursha told them the matter of his dream. And this is the story: The Holy Rabbi of Bursha did not know at first where to settle, and was worried because of this. And behold he saw in his dream his father Maran the "Imrei Baruch" zy"a, who said to him: "Why are you so worried? Go and ask the Rebbe!" To the question of the Holy Rabbi of Bursha "Who is the Rebbe?", the father replied: "Rebbe (**רבי**), the acronym is **R**osh **B**nei **Y**israel (Head of the Children of Israel)."
Then our Rebbe agreed to accept upon himself the high position ("Kadosh Yisrael" Part 1).
From then on, the Holy Rabbi of Bursha would consult much with his brother Maran zy"a. Once when the Holy Grandfather advised a certain Jew who asked for a blessing for Zera Shel Kayama (children) to travel to the healing springs and he would be saved, and the man told the advice of Maran zy"a to the Holy Rabbi of Bursha, the Holy Rabbi of Bursha decided on the spot to send also his daughter there, for she too had been married already twenty years and still had not been visited with children. And indeed, both of them were visited then.
On special Shabbos days when Maran the Holy Grandfather stayed in the cities of Marmorosh, the Holy Rabbi of Bursha came to bask in his shadow, such as on the famous Shabbos in Slatfina (2nd of Elul 5690), and so too on other Shabbos days. And face to face Maran the Holy Grandfather honored him and valued him very much. When the Holy Rabbi of Bursha came to his holy court of Maran the Holy Grandfather in Vizhnitz and afterward in Grosswardein, the Holy Grandfather would worry himself for all the needs of his brother, that they should be in abundance and with honor as fitting.
Once when the holy brothers walked together, Maran the Holy Grandfather spoke to the Holy Rabbi of Bursha, by way of jest: "I saw that you are very famous in the country of Hungary, for on the stores where they sell wine and liquor, a sign was hung outside 'Bar-Shevar' (in Hungarian: Bar - Wine, Shevar - Liquor), and this means 'Barshever' (The Bursha Rebbe)..." (Noam Siach, p. 117)
Source: "Noam Megadim" (Vizhnitz), Pekudei 5763, p. 3

**L'Chaim**
It is fluent in the mouth of every Jew to say "The Minhag (custom) breaks the Din (law)." And the Rabbi of Bursha *zt"l* said to interpret that "Minhag" (**מנהג**) in Gematria is "L'Chaim" (**לחיים** - 98), and this means that by Jews drinking wine and wishing "L'Chaim", they break the "Dinim" (Judgments) decreed upon the person. [And according to this, HaGaon R' Yitzchak Meir HaKohen, Dayan in Dregmirest *zt"l*, explained the Gemara "They sent from there: Be careful with the custom of your fathers in your hands, sometimes the Kingdom decrees a decree and it comes to ruin" (Beitzah 4b), meaning, be careful not to cancel the "L'Chaim" which is Gematria "Minhag", and why? For this he says: Sometimes the Kingdom of Heaven decrees a decree, Heaven forbid, on Israel, and it comes to ruin; through this, meaning to cancel all the Dinim and bad illnesses.]
Source: "Olamo Shel Abba" (Jerusalem 5744), p. 407

**His History**
The Gaon Rabbi Yosef Adler *zt"l*, Av Beit Din of Turda, was born in the city of Nitra on the 18th of Kislev 5644 (1883). He learned under Rabbi David Friedman, Av Beit Din of Tzehlim, Rabbi Moshe Katz, Av Beit Din of Nitra, author of "Shevet Sofer" from Pressburg, and Rabbi Shlomo Zalman Breuer, Av Beit Din of Frankfurt. From the year 5669 (1909), he assisted his great father-in-law, Rabbi Ben Tzion Wesel (one of the greats of Vizhnitz Chassidim) in managing the Rabbinate in the city of Turda. Afterward, he was appointed as Av Beit Din of Sebes in Romania. After the passing of his father-in-law, he filled his place in the Rabbinate of Turda and also served as President of the Bureau of Rabbis in Transylvania. In the years of the war and after it, he engaged greatly in permitting Agunot and worked for the benefit of Judaism. He was one of the heads of the Council of Torah Sages in Romania, and afterward in the Land of Israel. He passed away at the age of 93 on the day of 12th Adar 5737 (1977) [and is buried on Har HaMenuchot].
Source: "Mishnat HaTorah" (Jerusalem 5767), p. 15

**His History**
The Holy Rabbi R' Naftali Tzvi Halberstam ztll"h was born in Bobov on the day of 25th Iyar 5691 (1931) to his father the Holy Rabbi R' Shlomo ztll"h and to his mother the Rebbetzin, daughter of the Holy Rabbi R' Yaakov Teitelbaum *zt"l* of Limanuv. He spent the years of his childhood in the presence of his grandfather, the "Kedushat Tzion" ztll"h of Bobov, where with his open eyes he absorbed much of his holy conduct, ways and customs which were engraved in his tender mind forever. His grandfather ztll"h saw well that he is the continuator of the dynasty, and would root in him faith of Omen in the Torah of Hashem, joining him to his journeys as a companion, so that he would merit to be in the presence of the greats of the Tzaddikim of the generation, the holy ones of the Most High from the previous generation.
But he was only a boy of eight years when the skies of Europe darkened, with the rise of the Destroyer upon its Jews. Also in this difficult time he did not move from the presence of his grandfather. He is the one who stayed in his presence at the last time, before he was taken to the valley of killing at the beginning of the month of Av 5701 (1941), when his last words of the great grandfather to his grandson were: "Naftali, gey noch dein Tatin" [=Naftali, go follow your father]. In later days, when Rabbi Naftali Tzvi inherited his father's place ztll"h in the leadership of the Edah, many mentioned these trembling words, full of meaning, of the Holy One to his grandson.
In the summer of 5702 (1942), when the persecutions from the accursed ones increased, the members of his family smuggled him by means of forged documents across the Hungarian border to Neumarkt, but specifically there Rabbi Shlomo and his son Naftali Tzvi were captured by the oppressors, who tortured them with unbearable harsh tortures so that they would hand over their partners in the smuggling. With the passing of days, Rabbi Naftali Tzvi would tell that on that day they were captured, it was Shabbos, and when they saw that they were standing to be taken out to be killed, Rabbi Shlomo turned to him, hugged him with a brave hug and said to him: "Naftali my delight, know that the body of a Jew is clay, dust from the ground, and the body is possible to torture and even to kill. In contrast to this, the soul of the Jew is entirely spirit and holiness, and the hand of the Gentiles is not capable of touching and harming it. Until then, until the wicked come to harm our bodies, I am your father and you are my son, and you can still fulfill the Mitzvah of Honoring Father. I ask therefore of you with the Mitzvah of Honoring Father, that you listen to these my words and obey them. And so, tomorrow we are destined to fulfill the Mitzvah of 'And I shall be sanctified in the midst of the Children of Israel'. When the cursed wicked ones kill us, remember well that 'For Your sake we are killed all the day'. I know that the murderers will torture me with harsh tortures before my soul departs. I will scream 'Shema Yisrael' until the departure of the soul, and you also scream 'Shema Yisrael'; and my last request to you is that you do not cry, Naftali, at the time they torture me, for with your crying you are liable to confuse me at the time of my intention on Kiddush Hashem." — By the mercies of Heaven, mere moments before they were led to the gallows, they were saved in a wondrous way from the valley of killing.
Towards the end of the war, at the beginning of the year 5705 (1944), the Nazis (may their names be obliterated) agreed to allow three ships loaded with Jews, mostly children, to leave the boundaries of occupied Romania. Among the children was Rabbi Naftali Tzvi, who set his steps to the Holy Land. Here he basked in the shadow of the greats of Israel, especially with the Holy Rabbi R' Aharon of Belz, the Holy Gaon Rabbi Yoel Teitelbaum of Satmar, the author of the "Chazon Ish", the Rav of Brisk, and the Gaon of Tchebin, may the memory of Tzaddikim be for a blessing. Beginning from the year 5714 (1954) of his life, the time he learned in the Yeshiva of Slonim, he became very close with the Holy Rabbi R' Mordechai Chaim of Slonim zy"a.
The incident with the Holy Rabbi Mohar"a zy"a of Belz will testify to the relationship of these Tzaddikim to him. When he was in the Bochnia Ghetto in proximity to the place of Rabbi Shlomo and his son Rabbi Naftali Tzvi. Rabbi Shlomo desired greatly to fulfill the Mitzvah of the day [reading the Torah], and sent to ask the Holy Rabbi of Belz how it is possible to fulfill the Mitzvah of the day [without a Sefer Torah]. The Holy Rabbi of Belz lifted his holy eyes and pointed with his hands at the child Rabbi Naftali Tzvi, and added: "Da hat ir a Sefer Torah, das iz a lebediger Sefer Torah, er vet noch amol baleichten di velt" [=Here you have a Sefer Torah, this is a living Sefer Torah, he will yet light up the world].
In the year 5708 (1948), while he was still a lad of seventeen years, Rabbi Naftali Tzvi sailed to the USA, where his father ztll"h re-established the Kingdom of the House of Bobov, to stand at his right hand and to be a help to him in the holy work. He could not see how the precious time of his holy father was consumed in establishing the institutions, instead of engaging in the leadership of the Edah, in the betterment of the souls of the Children of Israel. As his holy heart desired, Rabbi Naftali Tzvi gathered strength and took upon himself the debts, the maintenance, the development and the re-establishment of the House of Bobov, so that his holy father could sit over the Torah and the Service without disturbance.
Even so, at this time, with his being busy day and night with the heavy yoke which he took upon himself, he spread Torah by saying classes in order in the Mesivta which his holy father established with great sweat, amidst worry and devotion to each and every one, with a shining countenance and grace of humility which so characterized him all the time.
With the passing of his holy father to the High Heavens, on Rosh Chodesh Av 5760 (2000), Rabbi Naftali Tzvi was crowned to lead the Edah filling his place. Despite his great weakness and his many pains which accompanied him all his days and overcame him especially at that time, he led his congregation with devotion of the soul, with strength and power. He passed away to his eternal home on the night of 12th Adar II 5765 (2005).
Source: "Nezer HaTorah", Nissan 5767, p. 32

...After Pesach [5703/1943], when our father [HaRahach Rabbi Moshe Tuvia Gruenzweig *zt"l*] returned from Galanta to Levice, he met in the proximity of the Rav Meislish *zt"l*, a tender lad—a son of wise men and noble in a special way, younger than him by almost a year. This was the K"K Admor HaGaon HaTzaddik Rabbi Naftali Tzvi Halberstam *zt"l* of Bobov, who was sent by his father the Admor HaGaon HaKadosh Rabbi Shlomo *zt"l* to Levice, where it was relatively calm, to take shelter in the shadow of his relative the Rav *zt"l*, that he should spread his wings over the tender lad.
The Rav *zt"l* connected between them, and took our father *zt"l*, who was older than him by almost a year, that he should learn with him. Our father *zt"l* would tell with longing about that half year—from after Pesach until before Rosh Hashanah 5703—that they sat over the Torah and over the Service with great diligence, and in this period they managed to learn the chapter "Kol HaBasar" in Tractate Chullin, out of tremendous toil, as if there is no war raging in the streets...
Source: "Ish Chassid" (Bnei Brak 5767), p. 155

Jews who were in the Bochnia Ghetto at that time when K"K Maran Admor Maharash of Bobov *zt"l* was there with his son Maran Maharantz *zt"l* told: At that time K"K Mahar"a of Belz zy"a also stayed in the Bochnia Ghetto. The situation in the Ghetto was very bad, any fulfillment of Mitzvot they wanted to fulfill was difficult and involved great exertion. On one of the occasions when the Jews there searched for a Sefer Torah, they entered to Mahar"a of Belz and asked him how it is possible to fulfill the Mitzvah of the day when a Sefer Torah is missing. The Holy Rabbi Mahar"a raised his holy eyes and pointed with his hands at the Maharantz who was then a Bar Mitzvah age boy, and said in his holy language:
"Ot da hat ir a Sefer Torah, das iz a lebediger Sefer Torah, er vet noch amol baleichten di velt" [=Here you have a Sefer Torah, this is a living Sefer Torah, he will yet light up the world].
And then K"K Mahar"a stood up and grabbed the Maharantz by his hands and danced with him together in enthusiasm and burning holy fire, and this was a sight of majesty for the broken and crushed Jews who merited to see how the Holy Tzaddik of the Most High dances with the "Living Sefer Torah". On an occasion when the Maharantz of Bobov *zt"l* spoke once about the aforementioned story, he said: "Er hat mich angechapt un getantzt mit mir, beim Taten iz das oich geven a chiddush" [=He grabbed me and danced with me, for Father this was also a novelty].
Source: "Yemei HaBachrut" (Brooklyn 5764), p. 109

It seems that perhaps there has not been in history such a generation, which fulfilled the Mitzvot in such difficult and bitter conditions. I saw this in the Bochnia Ghetto, but I have no doubt that the same thing happened in other camps and ghettos. One cannot estimate the mutual aid, the self-sacrifice to support and assist and bestow kindnesses a man to his fellow, to a neighbor, and to a friend, in the wondrous behavior of the wretched ones in the days of wrath—it was to arouse astonishment.
The Rabbi of Ropshitz zy"a says in his book "Zera Kodesh" (Parshat Pinchas) on the verse in Eichah **כל רדפיה השיגוה בין המצרים** - "All her pursuers overtook her between the straits": When Mashiach comes and the Redemption will be complete, all the nations who persecuted us will comprehend the magnitude of our virtue from the way we behaved between the straits, how we cleaved to Hashem also in times of trouble, and they will all admit that it is fitting to do good to us. Or-then they will comprehend and understand, that as much as they tortured us and oppressed us, they did not distract our minds from Hashem Yitbarach.
In Parshat Vayeilech it is written **והיה כי תמצאן אתו רעות רבות וצרות וענתה השירה הזאת לפניו לעד** - "And it shall be when many evils and troubles find him, then this song shall answer before him as a witness"—this "Song" is our Holy Torah, the Torah itself will testify about us, that even in times of "many evils and troubles," of sword and killing and destruction, there was fulfilled in us "for it shall not be forgotten from the mouth of his seed." In the most terrible conditions, Jews risked their lives to learn the Torah and to fulfill Mitzvot, endangered their lives even for a custom from the customs of Israel.
Still today there are, to our sorrow, those who ask: Why did the holy ones go like sheep to the slaughter, and did not rise up against their murderers the cursed Germans yimach shemam? Why did they not organize and rebel? True, the Germans were stronger and were capable of suppressing any rebellion, but what was there here to lose?
Such a question, in truth, only one who has no inkling of what happened "there," in the valley of weeping, in the valley of killing, is capable of asking. On the one hand, the statement as if they went "like sheep to the slaughter" is refuted from its foundation. Does a beast think when they lead it to slaughter how it is possible to snatch another Mitzvah in the meantime? Is it possible to say such a thing about Jews, who with the remainder of their strength exerted themselves to take with them the Tefillin, so that they could put them on in their last way? Jews who remembered to read the Reading of Shema in its time, when they knew that in a little moment they would no longer be here, is it told of them "like sheep to the slaughter"?!
I remember clearly, two Jews were led on one of the days by the oppressors to the killing. The holy R' David Berger Hy"d and his good friend who remained alive. And at that moment—what did R' David think about then, that his friend who was not yet put to death? Two Jews from the Ghetto police in Bochnia stood in proximity to the place. He turned, therefore, to them that they should testify witnesses that they heard from his mouth that R' David Berger was taken out to be killed on this day at this hour in this place. When they return to the Ghetto, he asked, would they please hand over the details to Rabbis so that the wife of R' David would not remain, Heaven forbid, an Agunah.
Is it possible to define such holy behavior with the nickname "like sheep to the slaughter"? Holy and pure Jews whose all thoughts were solely to Hashem, self-sacrifice pure, how do they dare to compare them to sheep?!
On the contrary and on the contrary, this was a kindness from Above that He gave us a siege for our spirit, and not to rebel. True, we remained few, like the gleaning of an olive tree, one from a city and two from a family. However, in the case that we would have resisted, not even one Jewish soul would have survived alive, and the cursed murderers would have achieved a total victory, they would have achieved their satanic goal in full. Thus Hashem helped us and a remnant remained, and all that we have today, is this not a result and offspring of that handful of survivors. Justly it can be said, that the refraining from profaning rebellion and resistance against the Nazis yimach shemam was also from the kindnesses of the Holy One, Blessed be He, a revealed kindness whose fruits we all enjoy and so too the coming generations.
K"K Maran Admor Maharantz of Bobov *zt"l*
(Translated from Yiddish by Rabbi Aharon Sorsky *shlita*)
Source: "Tosefet HaModia", 10th of Adar 5766, p. 35

...The magnitude of his self-sacrifice and his powers (of K"K Admor Maharantz of Bobov *zt"l*), his intercession and his vigorous activism without any calculations of physical exertion or his precious time, for the sake of the House of Skver—came to amazing expression in the difficult period that passed, to our sorrow, over the community of Skver as is known, at the end of the years of 5750s.
The paper will end and the stories cannot be finished, how the Admor the Maharantz entered into the thick of the beam to do and to assist with all that is possible, and by himself initiated and led moves and meetings to seek counsel and to activate connections with the heads of the government...
The contact man between him and Skver in that period was his close one and his faithful friend from days of old, the great Askan (activist) Mohar"r Avraham Moshe Zilberman Hy"u, one of the heads of our community.
From the testimony of the aforementioned R' A.M.: One day a report was received in the house of our Rebbe about a certain politician who might be able to help in our matter, and the community of Bobov has connections with him. Our Rebbe (K"K Maran Admor of Skver *shlita*) sent me to ask the mouth of the Admor the Maharantz two things: Does Bobov indeed have influence on the aforementioned man, and does the community of Bobov wish now to utilize these connections for their own benefit. And thus the Admor answered: Correct that this man treats "a word of Abba" with seriousness, and regarding the second question: Behold we still do not know if the connections with him will be utilized for Bobov and this is in the realm of doubt, but Skver surely wants to use the connections of this man, and we are speaking of *Pidyon Shvuyim* (Redemption of Captives)—and it is simple that "No doubt removes the hands of Certainty!" He asked me if he should arrange a time for a meeting with this public figure, and I told him that I still have to report to the house of our Rebbe and receive approval. An hour passed and the Admor Rabbi Naftali 'Tshe' contacts me and announces festively: I have already set a meeting with him for next Sunday at three o'clock in a certain office in Manhattan...
On the day of the meeting I arrived by car to take the Admor and together we traveled to the place set to meet. We arrived at three o'clock to a small one-story building where the said office resides, but the building was closed and shut and the lights off because of the weekend vacation. We waited some time and the man did not appear on the horizon, and behold the Admor turns to me and says to me: "Here next to this low building is a tall and impressive building of ten stories, maybe there is a way to pass from that building to this one?" The adjacent building was completely separate, and the whole question seemed strange and puzzling in my eyes, and I asked him: "Does his honor see any connection between these two buildings?..." The Rebbe looked at me and did not answer anything, only said: Let us go and check. We went to the large building and entered the elevator, and the Admor the Maharantz presses the button for the first floor.
The door opens on the first floor and the Rebbe asks the security man standing there: Excuse me, is there any way of passage to arrive from here to the adjacent second building? The man shrugged his shoulders to hear the strange question, and did not find reason to relate to this at all... The Admor continues and goes up to the second floor and again asks and clarifies maybe there is some way to arrive from here to the low building, he was answered in the negative and continues to the third floor and to the fourth and all of them of course return his face empty... And then we went down and returned to the first building, and behold the man we wanted to meet stands already and waits there for us full of apology for the delay due to circumstances beyond his control.
On the way of his travel back after the meeting, the Admor turns to me and says to me: "When I suggested to you to try to find a passage from the second building, you asked me if I see a connection between the two buildings... Do not think R' Avraham Moshe, that I am not settled in my mind, I also did not see an exact connection between the two buildings—but when the matter touches *Pidyon Shvuyim*—'Zenen nishta kein cheshbonos!!!' [=There are no calculations]." This was the starting point of the Rebbe of Bobov in everything connected to his activism and his intercession with all heart and soul in this episode!
(During the visit of K"K Maran Admor of Skver *shlita* in London (Tevet 5760), a delegation of distinguished Bobov Chassidim entered to him, and then our Rebbe said to them: I will tell you a story from the son of your Rebbe... and then he told the aforementioned story as written and in its language).
Source: "Chatzer HaKodesh" (Skver), Pesach 5765, p. 12

On the first night of Pesach 5758 (1998), after the Seder, we were all surprised to hear explicitly coming out of the mouth of K"K Maran Admor [Maharash of Bobov] *zt"l*, who told about a simple and upright man R' Avraham Briner a"h who pushed a *Kvitel* (note) into the bosom of K"K Maran Admor (*shlita*) [Maharantz of Bobov *zt"l*] on the eighth day of his birth [of K"K Admor Maharantz *zt"l*] after his entrance into the Covenant of Avraham Avinu, saying, "I want to be the first to give him a *Kvitel*." The words of our Rebbe *zt"l* spread over the face of the world, with no one understanding what the hint was. And behold, a few months passed, and the health condition of our Rebbe *zt"l* weakened, until in the coming years he no longer had the strength to conduct a Seder in public, and he departed for our sins until his pure soul ascended Heavenward on Rosh Chodesh Av 5760. And it emerged from this that the aforementioned Pesach was the last Pesach in which he conducted Seders in public. And we were present to see that the words of our father our shepherd the aforementioned [Maharash of Bobov] were like a coronation and a crown for the head of the Tzaddik our Rebbe *shlita* [Maharantz of Bobov *zt"l*] to fill his place in the leadership of the Edah and in the taking of *Kvitlach*.
And in his holy spirit he foresaw and saw that this was the last Pesach that he would lead with his holy congregation, and if he does not crown him now, when...
Source: "Hagash"p Beit Tzaddikim" (Brooklyn 5763), p. 198

...And it was when the soul of our Rebbe Maharash [of Bobov] zy"a ascended in a storm Heavenward, on Rosh Chodesh Av of the year 5760, the golden chain was not severed. His son the Admor Rabbi Naftali Tzvi Halberstam zy"a was crowned as filler of the place of his great father.
Because of heart surgery that I underwent in that month, I was prevented from being at the funeral of the Rebbe, and also I was not present at the coronation of the new Admor. I comforted the Rebbe and his brother the "Rav HaTzair" via telephone, I added a few words on my connection and acceptance of his authority, and the Rebbe said to me: "R' Yehoshua'le, du machst dich oich narish? Ich bin a Rebbe?!" [=R' Yehoshua, are you making yourself foolish too? Am I a Rebbe?!]
In the brokenness of his heart and the lowliness of his spirit known from then and always, it did not arise at all in his mind that he is the one designated to sit on the chair of his great father, and to lead the glorious Chassidut of Bobov and thousands of Chassidim.
Great admiration I acquired for his lofty personality over tens of years that he stood at the right of his great father with devotion of body and soul, out of wondrous self-nullification, and took upon his shoulder the heavy yoke of maintaining the court and institutions of Bobov in all stages of their establishment, and did not hold credit for himself.
He was a wise man of the Jews, a reflection of the image in the style of Ropshitz which the name of his grandfather is called upon him, his speech sharp and pungent, measured and weighed in the scale of truth, and despite this mixed with people, humble and low of knee, entirely devoted to the benefit of the community and the individual and an address for every needy and broken hearted person, and did everything for his sake until he stood him on a horn of light. Likewise he tied connections in the "High Windows" and helped our brethren the Children of Israel in many matters.
In his visits to the Holy Land he would stay regularly in my home and likewise in my travels to [his father] K"K Admor *zt"l* I was invited to dine at his table which was seasoned with words of Torah and brilliant insights in his way, stories of Tzaddikim and histories of the generations full of words of Mussar and guidance.
I hoped to see the Chassidut of Bobov continue to blossom under his rod, but alas for the sorrow of the heart his days of leadership were not long. The Rebbe suffered for some years from Parkinson's disease, but he functioned wonderfully in all matters, sounded words of Torah and Chassidut regularly like an overflowing spring, and was a sought-after speaker at many important events. Every year he participated in the "Dinners" of "Chibat Yerushalayim" and was there among the heads of the speakers. However, immediately after he received into his hands the scepter of leadership, a severe deterioration occurred in his health condition, which went and worsened gradually, and the matter disturbed and weighed heavily on his physical functioning and also on his speech...
In his first appearance in our Holy Land after receiving the leadership on 15th Shevat 5761, a reception was held in his honor in the Great Beis Midrash in "Kiryat Bobov". I welcomed him with a blessing in the name of the congregation of Anash as I merited in the past to be the emcee at the reception celebrations we arranged every time his father zy"a visited the land...
In the continuation of the visit, the Admor went up to Jerusalem the Holy City, where he laid the cornerstone for the new building of the Bobov institutions, and prayed a prayer of many at the Western Wall with all Anash, this visit left a great impression on all the Chassidim and admirers of the House of Bobov in the Holy Land...
The second visit of the Admor in the land took place towards Shabbos Parshat Shekalim 5764, they recognized on him that his health condition had worsened greatly. From America a respected crowd of eight hundred Chassidim arrived with him.
At the reception we arranged in his honor in "Kiryat Bobov" in Bat Yam, after seeing his condition, I said: "This is a journey of self-sacrifice." The close family members said that the Rebbe yearned greatly to travel. Otherwise we didn't understand how they took upon themselves the responsibility to go out on an exhausting journey in such a condition...
The Shabbos in Bnei Brak was a Shabbos of Kiddush Hashem. Thousands of Bobov Chassidim and guests participated in the prayers and the Tishes which took place in a giant tent erected in the lot of "Fire Fighters" on Aharonovich St. The meals were held opposite in the new halls "Keter HaRimonim" which opened at that period...
In the coming days the Rebbe zy"a received the congregation of Bobov Chassidim. Admorim and Rabbis visited him, among them HaGra"l Steinman *shlita*, and my teacher HaGaon R' Michel Yehuda Lefkowitz (*shlita*) [*zt"l*]. This was the last visit of our Rebbe *zt"l* in our Holy Land, the land he loved so much, and he asked to part from it before the transition to the World that is All Good.
After his return to the USA his health condition worsened even more. He was still present for the last time at the "Tish", at the meal of Purim night, before he was rushed to the hospital. For a full year severe sufferings passed over him, which he accepted upon himself for the atonement of Israel, in the aspect of "He bore our sicknesses and carried our pains" (Isaiah 53:4). On the day of 12th Adar II, year 5765, his pure soul ascended in a storm Heavenward. Four and a half years of leadership and presidency of the Admor Rabbi Naftali Tzvi zy"a ended and were completed.
Source: "Avo Bigvurot" (Bnei Brak 5769), p. 371

On one occasion, one of Anash heard a chapter of instruction from K"K Admor Maharantz *zt"l* regarding this matter, that also in a time of trouble and grief, Heaven forbid, one calls in the name of Hashem who knows the distress of his soul, and puts all his focus to search and seek to discover the point of faith hidden within him like silver and hidden treasures. And K"K Admor *zt"l* said as follows: "We believe that everything Hashem does is for the good. Sometimes the person merits to see the kindness immediately at the time of the deed, sometimes the kindness is not clarified except after time, and sometimes it is not given to a person to merit to see the kindness at all. But we are believers sons of believers that all that the Merciful One does, He does for the good. We live with the power of sight, we live with the power of faith!"
Source: "Pri HaKerem" (Bobov), Sukkot 5766, p. 3

In the holy writings to one of the young men, our Rebbe (K"K Maran Admor Maharantz of Bobov) *zt"l* wrote as follows:
"And if you specifically want to afflict yourself (Sigufim), let your restriction be in this: that when you desire to close the Gemara or the Tehillim, you dedicate another five minutes to add in learning or saying Tehillim even though the matter is hard for you."
Source: "Binyan Shlomo" (Bobov), Shevat 5766, p. 5

**ותאזרני שמחה** - "And You girded me with joy" (Psalms 30:12). Girding means a belt. And behold Chazal said (Shabbos 10a) that one must gird a belt before praying in order to make with this a preparation for prayer, as it is written **הכון לקראת אלקיך** - "Prepare toward your G-d" (Amos 4:12). And according to this, the intention in the verse "And You girded me with joy" is to say that a good preparation (girding) for prayer is Joy, meaning that through learning Torah before prayer, upon which it is said **פקודי ד' ישרים משמחי לב** - "The orders of Hashem are upright, gladdening the heart" (Psalms 19:9).
Source: "Tehillim Beit Tzaddikim" (Brooklyn 5765), p. 158

**לך דמיה תהלה אלקים** - "To You silence is praise, O G-d" (Psalms 65:2). By way of jest, it is possible to say that when it arises for a person to bring out a forbidden word from his mouth, like evil speech (Lashon Hara) or a matter of dispute, and he curbs his mouth so as not to say it, behold this in itself is praise to Hashem, since it causes a sanctification of G-d's Name through this.
Source: "Binyan Shlomo" (Bobov), Adar 5765, p. 3

...We find in the words of Chazal (Sukkah 56b) that the Sages penalized the whole priestly watch of Bilgah because of one girl from the members of their family who nicknamed the Altar with a derogatory term. And the Shas asks: Because of her daughter do we penalize him (the father)? And Abaye answers: Yes, as people say, "The talk of the child in the market is either of his father or of his mother." And behold it is impossible that this girl heard in her father's house words of actual mockery against the Altar, rather presumably she felt with her father, that he was not completely serious, she did not see him in a state of enthusiasm at the time he spoke of the holiness of the Altar. And from this rolled afterward that she added to speak words of contempt against the Altar. We see from this how far matters reach regarding the responsibility of parents in the education of their children.
Source: "Binyan Shlomo" (Bobov), Adar 5765, p. 3

It is brought in Tractate Eruvin (54b) that a person is obligated to teach his student four times. And this is hinted in the printing of the Shas with Rashi: The Rashi above the Gemara is almost in every place four lines. And so too in Tosafot. And so too in Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim "Magen Avraham", Turei Zahav, four lines. And so too in Shulchan Aruch Yoreh Deah "Shach", Turei Zahav, four lines. And so too in Shulchan Aruch Even HaEzer "Chelkat Mechokek", and Beit Shmuel four lines. And so too in Shulchan Aruch Choshen Mishpat "Shach" and "Sma" four lines. [From the mouth of K"K Maran Admor Maharantz of Bobov (*shlita*) zt"l].
Source: "Yalkut Magen Avot" (Brooklyn 5765), p. 248

**מי האיש החפץ חיים אהב ימים לראות טוב וגו'** - "Who is the man who desires life, who loves days to see good etc." (Psalms 34:13).
