One can interpret, for one who is accustomed to speak Lashon Hara (evil speech) and finds in this satisfaction for his soul, Heaven forbid, then his nature becomes such that when he sees a person or some thing, he finds there deficiencies and blemishes, and afterward he delights himself by handing over to others the deficiency he saw in so-and-so. But one who guards his mouth and his tongue from speaking evil, then his heart does not pull him to see evil in others, for he has no benefit in this, and he sees only good. And this is what the verse says: "Who is the man who desires life, who loves days to see good," meaning that he wants to see only the good that is in each and every one and in every thing, the advice is "Guard your tongue from evil," accustom yourself not to speak evil, and then your heart will not pull you to see the evil in others.
Source: "Tehillim Beit Tzaddikim" (Brooklyn 5765), p. 110

In the Selichot of Erev Yom Kippur we say: **ותדרש בשפך דם לדעת מה זה ועל מה זה** - "And seek the spilled blood to know what is this and for what is this." What is the intention of the Paytan (poet)? My grandfather Hy"d, the "Kedushat Tzion", said in his time: Formerly in all times we knew that "Kiddush Hashem" meant when the Gentiles demand of us to convert, to change our religion, to admit to their faith Heaven forbid, and we refuse and abandon ourselves to be killed for the Sanctification of His Name, may He be blessed, as commanded upon us in the Holy Torah "And I shall be sanctified in the midst of the Children of Israel." So did our fathers in Spain, in the Crusades in Ashkenaz, and in the decrees of Tach and Tat (1648-1649) in Poland.
However, in the days of Hitler yimach shemo they did not leave us any choice. Even conversion of religion did not help. On the contrary, they searched for apostates and sent them to the gas chambers, because some grandmother or great-grandfather was listed with them as a "Yodea" (Jew). The reason for this was simple. They themselves did not believe in the "religion" and "faith" that they had and the religious interest did not interest them. All the wrath and hatred were poured upon the Jews because we are the children of the Omnipresent, His chosen people, they stood up against G-d and sought to wipe out from the face of the earth His people—His treasure.
This is the saying of the Paytan "And seek the spilled blood": Master of the World, seek from our murderers the reason, the background and the cause for the spilling of the blood of Your children, Your innocent ones from crime, what did we do to them, why did they bring upon us such cruel blows? For what is this and upon what is this? Is it not only because we are Your children that they did evil to us. And so we say in the Hoshanot: **הושענא סובלת סבלך** - "Hoshana who bears Your burden." We suffer sufferings and troubles, persecutions and murders only and solely for the sake of the Sanctification of Your Name. Our burden is Your burden, only because we are the bearers of the flag of Your Faith, may His Name be blessed, in the world.
Source: "Binyan Shlomo" (Bobov), Adar 5765, p. 3

Our Rebbe [Maharantz of Bobov *zt"l*] (*shlita*) preached on Chol HaMoed Sukkot 5750 that the Tzaddik is like a doctor, and just as a sick person who comes to a doctor so he can bring healing to his blow, aside from what the doctor gives him, medicine and cure to remove the illness, he also adds for him several instructions and behaviors, to refrain from this food and on the other hand to eat that food, so that the illness does not return as before. And to my mind, a person would think in his soul not to behave according to the instructions and behaviors he received, but rather take the medicine alone and no more—for surely but a few days will pass, and there will be no effect and memory of the medicine, and his illness will return to him as before. And regarding this matter, it is exactly so with the journey to the Tzaddik, that aside from what the stay in the shadow of the Tzaddik is effective to raise a cure for the sicknesses of his soul and for purification with a wondrous effect, he must also receive upon himself all the instructions and guidances he heard from him or from the mouth of his writing, and if he does not accept these instructions and behaviors with strength and intensity day by day without any compromises, the journey will not avail him at all, and all his trouble and toil will be in vain and for nothing.
Source: "Chemdat HaKerem" (Bobov), Mishpatim 5764, p. 2

**His History**
Rabbeinu Yehuda HaChassid, from whose springs of wisdom the Sages of Israel have drawn for more than eight hundred years, was born in the year 4950 (1190) approximately, to his father Rabbeinu Shmuel HaChassid (see about him in the book "Chassidim HaRishonim" by HaGri"a Kamelhar *zt"l*, Waitzen 5677), son of Rabbeinu Kalonymus the Elder of Mainz, son of Rabbeinu Yitzchak, son of Rabbeinu Eliezer the Great (author of the book "Orchot Chaim" and "Tzava'at Rabbi Eliezer HaGadol"), son of Rabbeinu Yitzchak the Great, son of Rabbeinu Yehoshua the Great, son of Rabbeinu Abun the Great (and see in "Responsa Maharshal" Siman 29 the order of this lineage).
Our Rebbe merited to spread Torah to many and established worthy students, greats of the world, among them: Rabbeinu Yitzchak of Vienna author of "Or Zarua", Rabbeinu Elazar of Worms author of the "Rokeach", Rabbeinu Moshe of Coucy author of the "Smag", Rabbeinu Baruch of Mainz, Rabbeinu Yehuda son of R' Kalonymus author of Yichusei Tannaim VeAmoraim, and more. Also from afar the greats of the generation turned to him and sought the word of G-d from him—this is Halacha, to instruct them the way they should walk in it by the light of Hashem (see "Sefer Chassidim" Siman 764, "Shivlei HaLeket" Siman 190, "Tashbetz" Siman 219, and more).
In the year 4977 (1217), our Rebbe fell into a bed from which he did not rise. It is told, that when the elders of the city came to visit him, our Rebbe commanded to sweep the room before his bed and asked those sitting before him if they see anything, and they answered and said that they see in the dust that before his bed is written "Chassid". Furthermore it is told that in Regensburg they were forced to transport every dead person by leading them to his burial place through the gate of the city and the Gentiles hung a bell on the gate, and when they transported the dead, the bell rang according to the custom of the Gentiles. And when our Rebbe fell ill, he said, if I am a son of the World to Come, this gate will fall after my death. On Shabbos Kodesh Parshat Tetzaveh on the thirteenth day of the month of Adar his illness became heavier upon him, and the students who surrounded his bed conversed with him in words of Torah and asked him several Halachot from the matter of the reading of "Parshat Zachor" which they read on that Shabbos, and despite his great weakness our Rebbe exerted himself to reply to them on the first first and on the last last until his holy soul departed in holiness and purity. And when they led his bed through the aforementioned gate, the gatekeeper hurried to hang the bell at the top of the gate as was his habit, and the gate fell with the bell on the head of the gatekeeper and he was killed by it on the spot. This story was publicized even among the Gentiles and caused a Sanctification of His Name, may He be blessed, among the nations, and they said, Blessed is He who chose the words of the wise, that the righteous in their death are greater than in their lives.
Source: "Biton Vizhnitz", Adar 5765, p. 67

His Torah our Rebbe Yehuda HaChassid received from the mouth of his father, Rabbeinu Shmuel, and also from the mouth of R' Yitzchak the Elder of the Baalei Tosafot. He himself was also counted among the Baalei Tosafot (see Bava Metzia 5b, Tosafot d.h. Dechashid).
It is told, that in the days of his youth he did not stand out at all above the rest of his peers of his age, and even exceeded them in an act of mischief. This behavior of his was his daily practice, until once at the time that his father was teaching in his Yeshiva, in Speyer, with his students, he did some prank that angered the students greatly. These, for whom the honor of their Rabbi was dear in their eyes, turned to their Rabbi immediately upon the conclusion of the lesson, and expressed before him their wonder; how does he not supervise his son and educate him in the way of his fathers, the holy ones, and the chain of gold will not be broken - - - Or then his father called him and asked him: Do you wish to learn, my son? When he answered in the affirmative, the father asked to test him if indeed his way would succeed or not, and brought him up to the attic of the Beis Midrash, where he sat him next to his second son—Rabbeinu Avraham of Speyer zy"a. Immediately Rabbi Shmuel mentioned a Holy Name and the Beis Midrash was filled entirely with light. From the magnitude of the radiance of the light, Rabbi Avraham lowered his eyes to the ground, whereas our Rebbe did not move or stir. When he mentioned an additional Name, Rabbi Avraham was no longer capable of bearing the wondrous light, and was forced to cover his eyes with his father's garment, whereas our Rebbe gave his eyes then to the ground.
At the sight of this, Rabbi Shmuel turned to his son Rabbi Avraham and said to him: Know that you will be a Rosh Yeshiva all your days, however, your brother Yehuda will grow greater than you and will know what is above and what is below, and nothing will be hidden from him, and he will become famous as a Master of Deeds (miracles). (Toldot Rih"ch by HaGr"r Reuven Margolies *zt"l*).
From that day onward, our Rebbe drew close to his father who even handed over to him holy manuscripts, the inheritance of his fathers from generation to generation. And indeed our Rebbe rose in Torah and Fear until he ascended in degrees of holy and pure ones, and was accustomed to practices of abstinence and purity by way of fasts and mortifications, as mentioned in Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim (Siman 288:3) regarding the law of "A person who fasts every day, and eating on Shabbos is sorrow for him because of the change of habit (Veset), there are those who say that some Chassidim and Men of Deed were seen who fasted on Shabbos, and so they said that R' Yehuda HaChassid used to do thus."
Also on Yom Kippur he fasted for two days, as per the testimony of his distinct student the author of "Or Zarua" who writes about "those people who are accustomed to do two days of Yom Kippur, if not that I saw my teacher R' Yehuda Chassid and my teacher R' Avi HaEzri who used to do two days of Yom Kippur, I would say they are not doing good, that there is no doing so because of danger" (Laws of Yom Kippur end of Siman 261).
The way of his wondrous and sublime conduct was for a name and a thing, until the sages of his generation expressed about him, "That if he were in the days of the Amoraim he would be an Amora, in the days of the Tannaim he would be a Tanna, and in the days of the Prophets he would be a Prophet" (Sefer Chassidim HaRishonim Part 2, 87).
Source: "Alim LiTerufah", Terumah 5757, p. 3

To the sages of his generation and the sages of his city, R' Yehuda HaChassid was not considered in their eyes only as a great Rav in Torah, but also as a man of wonders and worker of miracles, great in his generation he was and doing wonders as is told about him many wondrous stories and miracles which he did there in Regensburg. The legend tells: A story of two roofers who worked for a certain Jew in Regensburg, who saw that he had in the attic room much money. They stole the money together at night, and the one killed the second in order that he could take for himself all the theft. In the morning they found the murdered man in the street of the Jews, the Christians wanted to attack the Jews but R' Yehuda HaChassid went immediately to the members of the city council and asked of them, since they certainly do not intend to do a harsh judgment in anger and not in justice, therefore let them allow him to find the murderer. Immediately all the gates of the city were closed, and R' Yehuda revived the murdered man by means of a "Kamea" (amulet), and immediately, he found inside the large crowd the murderer who was sentenced to death, and the living murdered man fell dead to the ground when R' Yehuda took the Kamea from him.
Source: "Chassidim HaRishonim" (Waitzen 5677), p. 41

The Holy Rabbi R' Pinchas of Koritz used to interpret regarding our Rebbe Yehuda HaChassid this verse (Genesis 49:8): **יהודה אתה יודוך אחיך** - "Judah, you, your brothers shall acknowledge you"—Children of Israel, your hand which wrote the "Sefer Chassidim" **ידך בעורף אויביך** - "Your hand is on the neck of your enemies"—this is the Yetzer Hara (Evil Inclination), so that the Good Inclination will rule over the Evil Inclination. **ישתחוו לך בני אביך** - "Your father's children shall bow to you"—through your book the forces of matter called "your father's children" will submit and bow opposite the spiritual forces which are in the soul. (Dor Deah [Kamelhar] Part 1).
Source: "Imrei Pinchas" (Bnei Brak 5763), Part 2, p. 59

A story involving a certain Bishop from Salzburg. Upon hearing his greatness and the abundance of his honor even among the Gentiles, he said that he cannot bear to see that a Jewish man should grow so great, and he said to take his life. He traveled to Regensburg with his helpers and came to the house of Rih"ch (Rabbi Yehuda HaChassid) with a knife hidden in his shoe and plotted to stab him with it. But upon his coming to the house of Rih"ch, his strength turned away from him and he changed his taste (attitude) and asked him to show him his wonders. Rih"ch answered him "Yes I will do," and brought him to the room and said to him "Come put your head in the window and look outside and you will see wonders." The Bishop did so and could not take his head out from there and feared for his life lest he be strangled, and begged Marih"ch (our Master R' Yehuda HaChassid) to save him from death, and swore to him that if he does so then he will return all the Jews whom he expelled from his city. Rih"ch acceded to him and released him in peace, and upon his return to his home he fulfilled his words and after days he became a Jew (converted) and they called him a Tzaddik.
Source: "Chassidim HaRishonim" (Waitzen 5677), p. 42

Our Rabbi (Shlita) [K"K Maran Admor of Vizhnitz ZT"L] explains (Tosafot Bava Kamma 27b): "An ox has its eyes downward." An ox hints to Yosef, as it is written (Deuteronomy 33:17) **בכור שורו** - "His firstborn ox." If one wants to merit the holiness of Yosef - one needs to be "His eyes downward," to lower the eyes, and for themselves [to keep them] from seeing evil, Heaven forbid.
Source: HaIgud

Our Rebbe left behind him a blessing, his Torah legacy for generations. These are his compositions known in all professions of the Torah, which were quoted extensively in the books of our Rabbis the Rishonim and the Baalei Tosafot.
From his books in Halacha are known to us the book "Gan HaBosem" (brought in "Chiddushei Anshei Shem" on the "Mordechai" in Tractate Berachot Chapter 2), "Sefer HaChochmah" on laws of prayer, writing a Sefer Torah and customs, "Hilchot Shechitah" (remained in manuscript. See biography of our Rebbe by R' Y. Freimann at the beginning of "Sefer Chassidim" edition of "Mekitzei Nirdamim"). Likewise our Rebbe composed a commentary on the Torah (echoes of this see in "Baalei HaTosafot" on the Torah, in "Paneach Raza", in "Tzioni" and more) and a commentary on the Book of Job (see "Sefer Chassidim" Siman 549). Likewise our Rebbe composed several compositions in the Torah of the Hidden (Kabbalah), among them, a commentary on Sefer Yetzirah, a commentary on Shir HaYichud, Sod HaYichud and an essay on the Name of 72, Sod HaTefillah and Sodot Aleinu LeShabeach, Taamei HaMitzvot, "Sefer HaOrah" and "Sefer HaKavod" which is mentioned many times in "Sefer Chassidim" and in the books of the early ones (see "Rokeach" Siman 315, "Orchot Chaim" to the Ra"a of Lunel Part 2, Laws of Mourning Siman 31, "Rabbeinu Yerucham" Nativ 28. And more). From the remnants of Sefer HaKavod it appears that its content was secrets of the Living G-d, Kabbalah and Segulah matters.
Aside from these books of our Rebbe of which only remnants remained to us in manuscript and in what was brought from them in the books of the early ones, there remained for us as a remnant his book the "Mili D'Chassiduta" which is called by the name "Sefer Chassidim" in which he deepened his investigation into the Mussar of Judaism, the explanation of the hidden light that is in the Torah, and collected sparks of lights in obscure Halachot to awaken man to commandments that have no one to seek them out.
So too there remained for us as a remnant his holy Will known to us as "Tzava'at Rabbi Yehuda HaChassid". In this Will our Rebbe mentions a variety of subjects and matters in which there is an element of danger.
Source: "Biton Vizhnitz", Adar 5765, p. 67

**The Will of Rih"ch**
...Famous is the responsum of the Noda B'Yehuda (Edition Even HaEzer Siman 79) regarding a bride and her mother-in-law whose names are identical, and this is his language: "It is not my way to reply in such matters that have no root in the Talmud and Poskim etc., know my students and let these words be engraved on the tablet of your heart, the great rule is that we have no authority to say a thing against the Talmud, and one who says a thing to contradict the point of a Yod of the words of the Talmud will not be considered among the Sages of Israel. And indeed when we find one of the Sages of Israel who is strong in Torah and Fear without doubt who wrote in a book a thing contradicting the words of the Talmud, we are obligated to pawn our souls to resolve his words so that he did not speak only for the hour or for a private family, and the words of the Talmud are for the general public. And similarly in this we find regarding our Rebbe Yehuda HaChassid in his Will things that are almost forbidden for us to hear them etc., but the truth shows his way that the Chassid foresaw regarding his seed after him, he commanded for generations because he saw with Ruach HaKodesh that his seed would not succeed in such matches, and in this he does not contradict the words of the Talmud which are for the general public, and the words of the Chassid are for the individual etc., and I wonder at the majority of the world that giving their daughter to an Am Haaretz (ignoramus) is simple for them and no one is concerned to refrain, and it is against the words of Chazal who said it is as if he binds her and places her before a lion, and to marry a young scholar whose name is like his name they ask, and let there not be a complete Torah of ours like a mere Will, until here his language. And that which he wrote that only for his seed did the Rih"ch command, others have already preceded him in this in the Responsa Shav Yaakov Even HaEzer Siman 23 (and see there that he brought from the greats of Rabbis who were not particular about the Will of Rih"ch even *ab initio*), and so wrote the Responsa Ramatz Yoreh Deah Siman 87. And we found that also Maran the Chatam Sofer wrote that the Will of Rih"ch was said only for his seed, and it is in Igrot Sofrim Part 2 Siman 25. And in a responsum (Yoreh Deah Siman 138) he wrote that it is better not to be concerned for the Will of Rih"ch, things that were not mentioned in the Shas and Poskim and R' Yehuda HaChassid is not signed on it. However, the opinion of the Chatam Sofer on this subject is not clear...
Source: "Shu"t Noda B'Yehuda" [Implied context from text]

One should note the great story brought in Responsa Shem Aryeh Yoreh Deah Siman 27 (and brought in the glosses of Maharsham on the Will of Rih"ch Letter 61) that in the time of the Maharsha there was a gathering of the greats of the generation and they spoke about the Will of Rih"ch, and the Maharsha stood on his feet and said: "I am from the children of the children of Rih"ch and in his Will it is written that a man from his seed should not call his son not Yehuda and not Shmuel, and I am named Shmuel and my father's name is Yehuda (and in the name of Aryeh he raised that perhaps his intention was that Rih"ch did not command only his actual seed and not for the generations coming after them. And similar to this raised also in Responsa Beit Shearim Yoreh Deah Siman 196).
And behold what they doubted whether the Will was written by Rih"ch, seemingly it is explained from the words of his great students that indeed this Will was written by our Rebbe - see what Rabbeinu Yerucham wrote in Toldot Adam VeChava Nativ 28, and the Rokeach in Siman 317. And so see in Tashbetz Siman 555, Orchot Chaim to R"A of Lunel Part 2 Laws of Mourning Siman 31, Responsa Maharil Siman 111, and in Beit Yosef Yoreh Deah Siman 179 (who brings the words of the Maharil in the name of 'I found written'). And from all the aforementioned places it is explained that they attributed the words of the Will to Rih"ch. And in Mili D'Chassiduta (Tzava'ah Letter 30) he wrote that it is received in the hand of the servants of G-d that it is entirely holy from Rih"ch without mixtures from others. And see further what is written on this in the book Shivim Temarim in the pamphlet Shiva Einayim, Ayin 1...
...And what the Noda B'Yehuda wrote that the Will was said only for his seed alone, also on this the Acharonim lengthened. And I will copy here from the famous responsum in Responsa Divrei Chaim (Part 1 Even HaEzer Siman 8): To debate in this (regarding the marriage of his sister's daughter) is but superfluous for how can we debate in a matter where we have no knowledge and it is from the hidden matters and with forgiveness of the honor of the Torah of the Geonim the Batrai (later ones) who began to debate on the intention of Rih"ch *zt"l* and will we understand a matter that has no entry to our intellect to comprehend, however also to frustrate the opinion of our Rebbe the Master of Chassidim also is Heaven forbid for Rih"ch was known to be the Rebbe of the Smag and the Or Zarua who all our Torah and our customs in the land of Ashkenaz and France are drawn after them and therefore certainly their conversation is beautiful from the Torah of the later sons, and may his Master forgive the Noda B'Yehuda who expanded in his tongue against Rih"ch the Rabbi of the Diaspora of Ariel the land of Ashkenaz and France etc., and certainly it is not for the sages of the Acharonim to reject the words of the early ones if it is not found in the generations of the early ones who disagree with him for we are as nothing against their wisdom and their Torah and their Chassidut and their fear and upon us to accept their words with love even though it is against the Talmud, but because this matter is doubtful whether he intended for his seed or not, we will say in such a case if a Halacha is loose in your hand go out and see how the world conducts itself, and behold in our countries they are not particular only regarding that her name is like the name of her mother-in-law, and this matter is explained to be strict also in the Mishnat Chassidim and in the rest of the matters they are not particular, and also apparently his intention was not in this only for his seed etc...
Source: "Shmirat HaGuf VeHaNefesh" (Jerusalem 5763), Part 1, p. 78-85

**Biography**
The Gaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein, author of *Igros Moshe* zt"l, was born on the 7th of Adar, 5655 (1895), in the town of Uzda, Minsk province, to his father Rabbi Dovid, one of the distinguished students of the Netziv, who was the Rav of Uzda and later the Rav of Starobin. He was named in Israel after Moshe Rabbeinu. In his youth, he received Torah from his father, who was a *Posek* and a great scholar. Afterward, he traveled to Slutsk and studied Torah from Rabbi Isser Zalman Meltzer. From there, he traveled to Shklov to study under Rabbi Pesach Pruskin, whom he considered his primary teacher.
At the age of twenty, he was accepted as the *Av Beis Din* of Uzda, his father's former position. Five years later, in 5680 (1920), he was crowned with the rabbinate of the city of Luban, a city full of sages and scribes. Those days were times of madness and chaos in Russia. A civil war between the Bolsheviks and the loyalists of the Russian Czar wreaked havoc in the land. Rabbi Moshe had not yet served a year in his new position when he was forced to flee from a terrible pogrom perpetrated by the gentiles. Eventually, the town calmed down, and Rabbi Moshe returned.
The difficulty of the oppression reached the town in 5690 (1930). In that year, the hand of the Bolsheviks grew strong, and as is known, a fundamental principle of their system was the persecution of religion. A special branch for the persecution of the Jewish religion was called the "Yevsektsiya," almost all of whose members were heretical Jews who knew their Master and intended to rebel against Him. They persecuted religion to the point of destruction, and hundreds of Rabbis and those who sat in judgment were murdered by them or exiled to Siberia. Under these conditions of destruction, Rabbi Moshe ascended to lofty levels, and even while in this land of decree, he merited to innovate a multitude of Torah insights and reply to many responsa for questioners from all parts of Russia.
When the situation worsened until it was truly impossible to maintain his standing, he immigrated to the United States in 5697 (1937). Immediately upon his arrival, he began delivering his lectures at Mesivtha Tifereth Jerusalem. His Beis Medrash was on the East Side, which he maintained until the day of his passing. For close to fifty years of his activity in America, he left his imprint on all areas of life. The thousands of his responses to questioners printed in the books *Igros Moshe* contain answers in all parts of the Torah and in all matters of life. He merited to raise many disciples, many of whom went out to teach as Rabbis of cities across the United States, and as disseminators of Torah in Israel.
A special chapter is the character traits of Rabbi Moshe. The title "Be humble, be pious, of the disciples of Aharon the Kohen" is fitting for him. With all his extraordinary genius in all parts of the Torah—it was said of him that he finished the four parts of *Shulchan Aruch* with their commentaries four hundred times in his life—he held no airs of superiority, and his humility was to the extreme. He nullified himself before every person, always forgave those who distressed him, was of those who are insulted but do not insult, and received every person with a cheerful countenance. All his days, he engaged in kindness with his body and his money and sanctified the Name of Heaven in all his ways.
He passed away old and satisfied with days on the 13th of Adar II, 5746 (1986). At his funeral in New York and Jerusalem (where he was buried on Har HaMenuchos), about a quarter of a million people participated. He left behind sons and grandsons who are disseminators of Torah in Israel. His works: Responsa *Igros Moshe* (7 volumes), *Dibros Moshe* on Shas, and *Drash Moshe* on the Torah.
Source: Bema'alos Kedoshim U'Tehorim

בְּגִיל עֶשְׂרִים הִתְקַבֵּל כְּאַבַ"ד אוּזְדָא, מְקוֹם רַבָּנוּתוֹ הַקּוֹדֶמֶת שֶׁל אָבִיו. כַּעֲבוֹר חָמֵשׁ שָׁנִים, בִּשְׁנַת תר"פ, נִתְעַטֵּר בְּכֶתֶר הָרַבָּנוּת שֶׁל הָעִיר לוּבָּאן, עִיר מְלֵאָה חֲכָמִים וְסוֹפְרִים. הַיָּמִים הָיוּ יְמֵי טֵרוּף וְאַנְדַּרְלָמוּסְיָה בְּרוּסְיָה. מִלְחֶמֶת אַחִים בֵּין הַבּוֹלְשְׁבִיקִים וְנֶאֱמָנֵי הַצָּאר הָרוּסִי עָשׂוּ שַׁמּוֹת בַּמְּדִינָה. רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה עוֹד לֹא הִסְפִּיק לְכַהֵן בְּמִשְׂרָתוֹ הַחֲדָשָׁה שָׁנָה, וְהִנֵּה נֶאֱלַץ הָיָה לִבְרֹחַ מֵהַפּוֹגְרוֹם הַנּוֹרָא שֶׁחוֹלְלוּ הַגּוֹיִם. סוֹף סוֹף נִרְגְּעָה הָעֲיָרָה וְרַבִּי מֹשֶׁה חָזַר.
קֹשִׁי הַשִּׁעְבּוּד הִגִּיעַ לָעֲיָרָה בְּתר"צ. בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁנָה גָּבְרָה יָדָם שֶׁל הַבּוֹלְשְׁבִיקִים, וְכַיָּדוּעַ יְסוֹד עִקָּרִי שֶׁבְּשִׁיטָתָם הָיָה רְדִיפָה נֶגֶד הַדָּת. אֲגַף מְיֻחָד לִרְדִיפַת הַדָּת הַיְּהוּדִית הָיְתָה נִקְרֵאת "יֶבְסֶקְצִיָּה" שֶׁכִּמְעַט כָּל חֲבֵרֶיהָ הָיוּ יְהוּדִים כּוֹפְרִים הַיּוֹדְעִים אֶת רִבּוֹנָם וּמְכַוְּנִים לִמְרֹד בּוֹ. הֵם רָדְפוּ אֶת הַדָּת עַד חָרְמָה, וּמֵאוֹת רַבָּנִים וְיוֹשְׁבִים עַל מָדִין נִרְצְחוּ עַל יָדָם אוֹ הֻגְלוּ לְסִיבִּיר. בִּתְנַאי שְׁמָד אֵלּוּ נִתְעַלָּה רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה לְמַדְרֵגוֹת נַעֲלוֹת, וְאַף בִּהְיוֹתוֹ בְּאֶרֶץ גְּזֵרָה זוֹ זָכָה לְחַדֵּשׁ הָמוֹן חִדּוּשֵׁי תּוֹרָה וְהֵשִׁיב תְּשׁוּבוֹת רַבּוֹת לְשׁוֹאֲלִים מִכָּל חֶלְקֵי רוּסְיָה.
כְּשֶׁהַמַּצָּב הֶחְמִיר עַד שֶׁהָיָה מַמָּשׁ אִי אֶפְשָׁר לְהַחְזִיק מַעֲמָד, הִגֵּר לְאַרְצוֹת הַבְּרִית בִּשְׁנַת תרצ"ז. תֵּיכֶף עִם בּוֹאוֹ הֵחֵל לְהַגִּיד אֶת שִׁעוּרָיו בִּמְתִיבְתָּא תִּפְאֶרֶת יְרוּשָׁלַיִם. בֵּית מִדְרָשׁוֹ בְּאִיסְט סַיְד שֶׁהֶחְזִיק בָּהּ עַד יוֹם פְּטִירָתוֹ. בְּקָרוֹב לַחֲמִשִּׁים שְׁנוֹת פְּעֻלָּתוֹ בְּאָמֵרִיקָה טָבַע אֶת חוֹתָמוֹ עַל כָּל חֶלְקֵי הַחַיִּים. אַלְפֵי תְּשׁוּבוֹתָיו לְשׁוֹאֲלִים שֶׁנִּדְפְּסוּ בְּסִפְרֵי "אִגְּרוֹת מֹשֶׁה" מְכִילִים תְּשׁוּבוֹת בְּכָל חֶלְקֵי הַתּוֹרָה וּבְכָל עִנְיְנֵי הַחַיִּים. הוּא זָכָה לְהַעֲמִיד תַּלְמִידִים רַבִּים שֶׁהַרְבֵּה מֵהֶם יָצְאוּ לְהוֹרָאָה כְּרַבָּנֵי עָרֵי הַשָּׂדֶה בְּאַרְהַ"ב, וּכְמַרְבִּיצֵי תּוֹרָה בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל.
פָּרָשָׁה מְיֻחֶדֶת הִיא מִדּוֹתָיו שֶׁל רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה. עָלָיו רָאוּי הַכִּנּוּי "הֱוֵי עָנָיו הֱוֵי חָסִיד מִתַּלְמִידָיו שֶׁל אַהֲרֹן הַכֹּהֵן". עִם כָּל גְּאוֹנוּתוֹ הַמֻּפְלֶגֶת בְּכָל חֶלְקֵי הַתּוֹרָה - אָמְרוּ עָלָיו שֶׁסִּיֵּם אֶת ד' חֶלְקֵי שֻׁלְחָן עָרוּךְ עִם נוֹשְׂאֵי כֵּלִים אַרְבַּע מֵאוֹת פְּעָמִים בְּחַיָּיו - לֹא הֶחְזִיק טִיבוּתָא לְעַצְמוֹ וַעֲנַוְתָנוּתוֹ הָיְתָה עַד קָצֶה הָאַחֲרוֹן. הוּא הִתְבַּטֵּל בִּפְנֵי כָּל אָדָם, מָחַל תָּמִיד לִמְצֵרָיו, הָיָה מִן הַנֶּעֱלָבִין וְאֵינָן עוֹלְבִין, וְאֶת כָּל אֶחָד קִבֵּל בְּסֵבֶר פָּנִים יָפוֹת, כָּל יָמָיו עָסַק בְּחֶסֶד בְּגוּפוֹ וּבִמְאוֹדוֹ וְקִדֵּשׁ שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם בְּכָל תַּהֲלוּכוֹתָיו.
נִפְטַר זָקֵן וּשְׂבַע יָמִים י"ג אֲדָר ב' תשמ"ו. בְּהַלְוָיָתוֹ בִּנְיוּ יוֹרְק וּבִירוּשָׁלַיִם [בָּהּ נִטְמַן בְּהַר הַמְּנוּחוֹת] הִשְׁתַּתְּפוּ כְּרֶבַע מִילְיוֹן אֲנָשִׁים. הִנִּיחַ בָּנִים וּבְנֵי בָּנִים מַרְבִּיצֵי תּוֹרָה בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל. חִבּוּרָיו: שׁוּ"ת 'אִגְּרוֹת מֹשֶׁה' (ז' חֲלָקִים), 'דִּבְרוֹת מֹשֶׁה' עַל הַשַּׁ"ס וּ'דְרָשׁ מֹשֶׁה' עַל הַתּוֹרָה.הרב דוד זילבער ז"ל"במעלות קדושים וטהורים" (ברוקלין תש"ס) ע' קכ"ו
body_en:
Regarding a fact of the wondrous diligence of Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l from his youth, the Tzaddik Rabbi Yehuda Leib Maizlik zt"l told a story to which he was an eyewitness during his service in the Russian army. He related the following:
During the training period, our battalion camped near the town of Starobin in the Minsk province. My friend—who had also studied in Yeshiva before being taken to the army—and I utilized the leave given to us and entered the synagogue in the town. There, we studied with diligence, which reminded us of the good days in the Yeshiva.
In that same synagogue, a charming young man of about thirteen sat in a corner next to the Holy Ark, meditating on the Torah without wasting a moment. Because he spared the precious minutes it would take to walk to his home for lunch, his older sister would bring his meal to him. He would go out quickly to the women's section, eat to his heart's content, and immediately return to his studies. And so, day by day, throughout the period we stayed in the area, we saw with our own eyes his tremendous diligence.
The boy was known in the town as "Moshe'le dem Rav's," meaning "The Rabbi's Moshe," as his father, Rabbi Dovid Feinstein zt"l, was the Rav of Starobin.
Source: Hi Sichasi

בִּתְקוּפַת הָאִמּוּנִים חָנָה הַגְּדוּד שֶׁלָּנוּ לְיַד הָעֲיָרָה סְטָארוֹבִּין שֶׁבְּפֶלֶךְ מִינְסְק. אֲנִי וַחֲבֵרִי שֶׁגַּם הוּא לָמַד בִּישִׁיבָה לִפְנֵי שֶׁנִּלְקַח לַצָּבָא, נִצַּלְנוּ אֶת הַחֻפְשׁוֹת שֶׁנִּתְּנוּ לָנוּ, וְנִכְנַסְנוּ לְבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת בָּעֲיָרָה, שָׁם לָמַדְנוּ בִּשְׁקִידָה, שֶׁהִזְכִּירָה לָנוּ אֶת הַיָּמִים הַטּוֹבִים בַּיְשִׁיבָה.
בְּאוֹתוֹ בֵּית כְּנֶסֶת, יָשַׁב בְּפִנָּה שֶׁמִּצַּד אֲרוֹן הַקֹּדֶשׁ, עֶלֶם חֲמוּדוֹת כְּבֵן שְׁלוֹשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה, וְהָגָה בַּתּוֹרָה מִבְּלִי לְבַטֵּל רֶגַע. וּמִפְּנֵי שֶׁחָס עַל הַדַּקּוֹת הַיְקָרוֹת שֶׁתִּתְבַּזְבֵּזְנָה בְּלֶכְתּוֹ לְבֵיתוֹ בַּצָּהֳרַיִם, הָיְתָה אֲחוֹתוֹ הַגְּדוֹלָה מְבִיאָה אֵלָיו אֶת אֲרוּחָתוֹ. וְהוּא בִּזְרִיזוּת יָצָא לְעֶזְרַת הַנָּשִׁים, סָעַד אֶת לִבּוֹ, וּמִיָּד חָזַר לְלִמּוּדוֹ. וְכָךְ מִדֵּי יוֹם בְּיוֹמוֹ בְּמֶשֶׁךְ כָּל תְּקוּפַת שְׁהוּתֵנוּ בָּאֵזוֹר, רָאִינוּ בְּמוֹ עֵינֵינוּ אֶת שְׁקִידָתוֹ הָעֲצוּמָה.
הַיֶּלֶד נוֹדַע בָּעֲיָרָה בְּשֵׁם "מֹשֶׁהְ'לֶה דֶּעם רַבְּ'ס" כְּלוֹמַר, "מֹשֶׁה בֶּן הָרַב", אָבִיו, רַבִּי דָּוִד פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין זצ"ל, הָיָה רַבָּהּ שֶׁל סְטָארוֹבִּין. (סֵפֶר קוֹל בִּדְמָמָה נִשְׁמָע עַמּוּד 16)"הִיא שִׂיחָתִי" (ירושלים תשס"א) ח"א, ע' קכ"ה
body_en:
...Upon this I relied to instruct and also to reply with what appears correct in my humble opinion, after I clarified the Halacha with much toil for those who wish to know my opinion. Especially since I wrote the reasons and everything that clarifies that in this manner, I am only like one teaching the Halacha, so that the questioner should look into it himself, check, and examine, for I am not at all like a *Posek* (decisor) and teacher... And these are my reasons and arguments for my instructions, and I replied to everyone who asked me, if only Hashem helped me to clarify the Halacha. Also, there is satisfaction in this for my father, my teacher, the Gaon zt"l, who said about me that he hopes—and is almost certain—that questioners will multiply for me regarding the word of Hashem, which is Halacha, orally and in writing, and with the help of Hashem, blessed be He, I will reply according to Halacha... Therefore, I found it correct to print them, since I am in this matter only like one clarifying the Halacha, so that every Torah scholar and teacher of instruction may look into the words and examine for himself if one should rule so. And when he sees that I did not rely like a blind man in a chimney upon the works of our masters, but rather I checked with all my strength to understand that they are correct, and so too I request of every examiner of my book that he check after my words, and then he will see for practical application. Therefore, there is great benefit in this, to know how to clarify the Halacha to its clarity...
Source: Introduction to "Igros Moshe" Orach Chaim Vol 1

...I have already arrived, by the kindness of Hashem, blessed be He, and His abundant mercies, to the days of old age and gray hair and strength, and He has not removed His kindness from me, giving me the strength to clarify Halacha to its clarity just as in previous years.
***
The Gaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l told me a story that happened to him personally ("*didi havei uvda*") from the period of his stay in Communist Russia. A Jew came to him whom the NKVD [the secret police of the murderers of Russia, who killed the brother of the Gaon Rabbi Moshe, the Gaon R' Mordechai zt"l, who was destined for greatness] was searching for. The Gaon Rabbi Moshe zt"l hid him in his house for about six months.
At the end of the six months, the Gaon Rabbi Moshe said to this Jew that on his part, he was willing to hide him longer and enter into danger for his sake. However, since this matter endangered the Rebbetzin and the children, it was no longer possible for him to hide him and endanger others for his sake. But, he had advice for him on how to escape from Russia, and so it was.
Source: Migdal Givos Olam

סִפֵּר לִי הַגְר"מ פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין זצ"ל מַה דִּבְדִידֵיהּ הֲוֵי עוּבְדָּא מִתְּקוּפַת שְׁהִיָּתוֹ בְּרוּסְיָה הַקּוֹמוּנִיסְטִית שֶׁבָּא אֶצְלוֹ יְהוּדִי אֶחָד שֶׁחִפְּשׂוּ אוֹתוֹ הַנְּ.קָ.ווּ.ד. [אַנְשֵׁי מִשְׁטֶרֶת הָרוֹצְחִים שֶׁל רוּסְיָה אֲשֶׁר הָרְגוּ אֶת אָחִיו שֶׁל הַגְר"מ זצ"ל הַגָּאוֹן ר' מָרְדְּכַי זצ"ל שֶׁחָזוּ לוֹ גְּדוֹלוֹת וּנְצוּרוֹת] וְהַגְר"מ זצ"ל הִטְמִינוֹ בְּבֵיתוֹ כְּשִׁשָּׁה חֳדָשִׁים.
כִּכְלוֹת הַשִּׁשָּׁה חֳדָשִׁים אָמַר הַגְר"מ לַיְּהוּדִי זֶה שֶׁמִּצִּדּוֹ שֶׁל הַגְר"מ הוּא מוּכָן לְהַטְמִינוֹ יוֹתֵר וּלְהִכָּנֵס בְּסַכָּנָה בִּשְׁבִילוֹ, אַךְ מִכֵּיוָן שֶׁעֵסֶק זֶה מְסַכֵּן אֶת הָרַבָּנִית וְהַיְלָדִים, שׁוּב אִי אֶפְשָׁר לוֹ לְהַטְמִינוֹ וּלְסַכֵּן אֲחֵרִים בִּשְׁבִילוֹ, אַךְ יֵשׁ לוֹ עֵצָה אֵיךְ לִבְרֹחַ מֵרוּסְיָה וְכֵן הָיָה.
וּכְמוֹ דְּאִיתָא שֶׁ"נֶּהֱנִים מִמֶּנּוּ עֵצָה וְתוּשִׁיָּה", עֵצָה - הִיא הָעֵצָה עַצְמָהּ, וְתוּשִׁיָּה - הַיְנוּ שֶׁהָעֵצָה מַצְלִיחָה. - וְהַיְּהוּדִי אָכֵן נִמְלַט מֵרוּסְיָה, וְכַעֲבוֹר חָדְשַׁיִם הִגִּיעַ מִכְתָּב לְהַגְר"מ זצ"ל מִיְּהוּדִי זֶה, וְהַמִּכְתָּב מָלֵא הַפְלָגוֹת וּתְאָרִים גְּדוֹלִים, עַל כָּל הַחֶסֶד אֲשֶׁר עָשָׂה עִמָּדוֹ.
וְלְיָמִים כְּשֶׁשָּׂח לִי הַגְר"מ מַעֲשֶׂה זֶה אָמַר: אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ, לָמָּה מַגִּיעִים לִי תְּאָרִים כָּאֵלּוּ הֲלֹא לֹא עָשִׂיתִי אֶלָּא רַק מַה שֶּׁכָּל יְהוּדִי הָיָה עוֹשֶׂה.הרה"ג ר' מיכל זלמן שורקין שליט"א"מגד גבעות עולם" (ירושלים תשנ"ט) ח"א, ע' ע"א

At a gathering of Rosh Yeshivas on behalf of the presidency of Mifal HaShas held at the home of the Rav of the place (HaGaon Rabbi Yitzchak Zilberstein Shlita), HaGaon Rabbi B.D. Povarsky told a wondrous story that demonstrates the great obligation to listen to the voice of the wise.
This happened during the period when the Gaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l served as a Rav in Russia. In that town, there was an informer who cast his terror upon the Jews, and his closeness to the authorities allowed him to hand over his fellows who feared him with a mortal fear.
This man caused terrible troubles during his life to the community, which suffered from him right and left. His name became infamous in the eyes of all, and his Jewish brothers ostracized him and distanced themselves from him as far as a bowshot. So it was until his last day.
A Jew is a Jew nonetheless, and his soul, the soul of G-d from above, demands its own. And behold, on the last day of the informer, when he felt his hour approaching to ascend before his Creator and give an accounting for his terrible deeds committed during his lifetime, the informer asked to call the men of the Chevra Kadisha (Burial Society) to him and informed them that he had a special message for them.
When the men of the Chevra Kadisha arrived at his bed, the informer told them that since he knows the sins he committed during his lifetime were very severe, he asks to atone even slightly for his crooked path. "Please, bury me with the burial of a donkey, meaning not lying down in the way all Jewish dead are buried, but standing up," he pleaded.
The people standing around his bed were impressed that the informer's words were spoken with great sincerity, and they promised him they would do as he requested, and even signed his will in which the request was written.
HaGaon Rabbi B.D. Povarsky continued to tell that after the passing, the matters reached the hands of the Rav of the place, Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l. When the Gaon heard the promise the Chevra Kadisha had given the informer, he objected with all force and said that since the Shulchan Aruch forbids burying a Jew with the burial of a donkey, as this is a disgraceful burial, he forbids with all force fulfilling the promise given to the informer, and he must be buried like all his Jewish brothers.
The informer was buried, of course, as the Rav commanded.
The next morning, immediately after the burial, men of the secret police, the "NKVD," knocked on the door of the Chevra Kadisha and demanded forcefully to open the grave of the Jewish informer.
All the arguments of the Chevra Kadisha that it is forbidden to open a grave after burial did not help. The police threatened that if the grave was not opened, they would do what they would do to them... The men of the Chevra Kadisha understood they were in danger, and with no choice, they opened the grave. The policemen checked the situation, looked at each other, and went on their way.
Only then did the members of the Jewish community understand what a miracle had happened to them by obeying the words of their teacher and Rav. The reason for the police demand to open the grave was, of course, to check *how* the informer was buried, and this was to verify whether the community had punished him after his death and buried him with the burial of a donkey or not.
If the man had been buried as written in his will, the entire community would have been in mortal danger (a version circulated in the community that the whole matter was the fruit of the informer's initiative, who asked to be buried this way and then told the police that the Jews would likely want to take revenge on him and bury him with a donkey's burial).
Only the Daas Torah of Maran HaGaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l, that it is forbidden to move even a hair's breadth from what is written in the Shulchan Aruch, saved all the Jews. There is in this an additional testimony to the greatness of the author of *Igros Moshe*, who was one of the pillars of the Jewish people in the years following the Holocaust, and testimony to the eternity of the Torah, that only he who fulfills all its commandments will see good in his life and will merit to see the Holy One, Blessed be He, at every step.
Source: Tuvecha Yabiu

הָיָה זֶה בַּתְּקוּפָה שֶׁבָּהּ כִּהֵן הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין זצ"ל כְּרַב בְּרוּסְיָה. בְּאוֹתָהּ עֲיָרָה הָיָה מַלְשִׁין שֶׁהֵטִיל אֶת חִתָּתוֹ עַל הַיְּהוּדִים, וְקִרְבָתוֹ לַשִּׁלְטוֹנוֹת אִפְשְׁרָה לוֹ לִמְסֹר אֶת רֵעָיו שֶׁפָּחֲדוּ מִמֶּנּוּ פַּחַד מָוֶת.
צָרוֹת צְרוּרוֹת הֵסֵב הָאִישׁ בְּחַיָּיו לַקְּהִלָּה שֶׁסָּבְלָה מִמֶּנּוּ עַל יָמִין וְעַל שְׂמֹאל. שְׁמוֹ יָצָא לְשִׁמְצָה בְּעֵינֵי כֹּל, וְאֶחָיו הַיְּהוּדִים נִדּוּ אוֹתוֹ וְהִתְרַחֲקוּ מִמֶּנּוּ כִּמְטַחֲוֵי קֶשֶׁת. כָּךְ עַד יוֹמוֹ הָאַחֲרוֹן.
יְהוּדִי הוּא בְּכָל זֹאת יְהוּדִי, וְנִשְׁמָתוֹ, נִשְׁמַת אֱלוֹק מִמַּעַל, דּוֹרֶשֶׁת אֶת שֶׁלָּהּ. וְהִנֵּה, בְּיוֹמוֹ הָאַחֲרוֹן שֶׁל הַמּוֹסֵר, כְּשֶׁהִרְגִּישׁ שֶׁשְּׁעָתוֹ קָרְבָה לַעֲלוֹת לִפְנֵי בּוֹרְאוֹ וְלִמְסֹר לוֹ דִּין וְחֶשְׁבּוֹן עַל מַעֲשָׂיו הַנּוֹרָאִים שֶׁפָּעַל בִּימֵי חַיָּיו, בִּקֵּשׁ הַמּוֹסֵר לִקְרֹא אֵלָיו אֶת אַנְשֵׁי הַחֶבְרָה קַדִּישָׁא וְהוֹדִיעַ לָהֶם שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ מֶסֶר מְיֻחָד אֲלֵיהֶם.
כְּשֶׁהִגִּיעוּ אַנְשֵׁי חֶבְרָה קַדִּישָׁא אֶל מִטָּתוֹ, אָמַר לָהֶם הַמּוֹסֵר שֶׁכֵּיוָן שֶׁהוּא יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁהַחֲטָאִים שֶׁעָשָׂה בִּימֵי חַיָּיו הָיוּ חֲמוּרִים מְאוֹד, הוּא מְבַקֵּשׁ לְכַפֵּר וְלוּ בִּמְעַט עַל דַּרְכּוֹ הַנְּלוֹזָה. "אָנָּא, קִבְרוּנִי בִּקְבוּרַת חֲמוֹר, דְּהַיְנוּ לֹא בִּשְׁכִיבָה כְּדֶרֶךְ שֶׁקּוֹבְרִים אֶת כָּל מֵתֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל, אֶלָּא בַּעֲמִידָה", הִתְחַנֵּן.
הָאֲנָשִׁים שֶׁעָמְדוּ סְבִיב מִטָּתוֹ הִתְרַשְּׁמוּ שֶׁדְּבָרָיו שֶׁל הַמּוֹסֵר נֶאֶמְרוּ בְּכֵנוּת רַבָּה, וְהִבְטִיחוּ לוֹ שֶׁיַּעֲשׂוּ כְּבַקָּשָׁתוֹ, וְאַף חָתְמוּ עַל צַוָּאָתוֹ שֶׁבָּהּ נִכְתְּבָה הַבַּקָּשָׁה.
הַגְרַבַּ"ד פּוֹבַרְסְקִי הִמְשִׁיךְ לְסַפֵּר שֶׁלְּאַחַר הַפְּטִירָה הִגִּיעוּ הַדְּבָרִים לִידֵי הַמָּרָא דְּאַתְרָא, רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין זצ"ל, וּכְשֶׁשָּׁמַע הַגָּאוֹן אֶת הַהַבְטָחָה שֶׁנָּתְנוּ הַחֶבְרָה קַדִּישָׁא לַמּוֹסֵר, הִתְנַגֵּד לְכָךְ בְּכָל תֹּקֶף וְאָמַר שֶׁכֵּיוָן שֶׁבְּשׁוּ"עַ נֶאֱסַר לִקְבֹּר יְהוּדִי בִּקְבוּרַת חֲמוֹר, כֵּיוָן שֶׁזּוֹ הִיא קְבוּרָה בְּזוּיָה, הוּא אוֹסֵר בְּכָל תֹּקֶף לְקַיֵּם אֶת הַהַבְטָחָה שֶׁנִּתְּנָה לַמּוֹסֵר וְהוּא יִקָּבֵר כְּכָל אֶחָיו הַיְּהוּדִים.
הַמּוֹסֵר נִקְבַּר, כַּמּוּבָן, כְּפִי שֶׁצִּוָּה הָרַב.
לְמָחֳרַת בַּבֹּקֶר, מִיָּד לְאַחַר הַקְּבוּרָה, מִתְדַּפְּקִים אַנְשֵׁי הַמִּשְׁטָרָה הַחֲשָׁאִית, הַ"נְ.קָ.ווּ.ד.", עַל דֶּלֶת הַחֶבְרָה קַדִּישָׁא וּמְבַקְּשִׁים בְּתֹקֶף לִפְתֹּחַ אֶת קִבְרוֹ שֶׁל הַמּוֹסֵר הַיְּהוּדִי.
לֹא עָזְרוּ לַחֶבְרָה קַדִּישָׁא כָּל הַטִּעוּנִים שֶׁאָסוּר לִפְתֹּחַ קֶבֶר לְאַחַר הַפְּטִירָה. אַנְשֵׁי הַמִּשְׁטָרָה אִיְּמוּ שֶׁבְּאִם לֹא יִפָּתַח הַקֶּבֶר, הֵם יַעֲשׂוּ אֶת הַמֻּטָּל עֲלֵיהֶם... אַנְשֵׁי הַחֶבְרָא קַדִּישָׁא הֵבִינוּ שֶׁהֵם בְּסַכָּנָה וּבְלֵית בְּרֵירָה פָּתְחוּ אֶת הַקֶּבֶר. הַשּׁוֹטְרִים בָּדְקוּ אֶת הַמַּצָּב, הִבִּיטוּ זֶה עַל זֶה, וְהָלְכוּ לְדַרְכָּם.
רַק אָז הֵבִינוּ חַבְרֵי הַקְּהִלָּה הַיְּהוּדִית אֵיזֶה נֵס אֵירַע לָהֶם בְּכָךְ שֶׁצִּיְּתוּ לְדִבְרָיו שֶׁל מוֹרָם וְרַבָּם. הַסִּבָּה לִדְרִישַׁת הַמִּשְׁטָרָה לִפְתֹּחַ אֶת הַקֶּבֶר הָיְתָה, כַּמּוּבָן, כְּדֵי לִבְדֹּק אֵיךְ נִקְבַּר הַמּוֹסֵר, וְזֹאת כְּדֵי לְהִוּוֹכַח הַאִם הַקְּהִלָּה הֶעֱנִישָׁה אוֹתוֹ לְאַחַר מוֹתוֹ וְקָבְרָה אוֹתוֹ בִּקְבוּרַת חֲמוֹר אוֹ לֹא.
אִם הָיָה הָאִישׁ נִקְבָּר כְּפִי שֶׁכָּתוּב בְּצַוָּאָתוֹ, הָיְתָה כָּל הַקְּהִלָּה בְּסַכָּנַת מָוֶת (בַּקְּהִלָּה הִסְתּוֹבְבָה גִּרְסָה שֶׁהָעִנְיָן כֻּלּוֹ הָיָה פְּרִי יָזְמָתוֹ שֶׁל הַמּוֹסֵר, שֶׁבִּקֵּשׁ שֶׁיִּקְבְּרוּהוּ כָּךְ וְאַחַר כָּךְ סִפֵּר לַמִּשְׁטָרָה שֶׁהַיְּהוּדִים יִרְצוּ מִן הַסְּתָם לִנְקֹם בּוֹ וְיִקְבְּרוּהוּ בִּקְבוּרַת חֲמוֹר).
רַק דַּעַת הַתּוֹרָה שֶׁל מָרָן הַגְר"מ פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין זצ"ל שֶׁאָסוּר לָזוּז כִּמְלוֹא הַנִּימָה מִמַּה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בְּשֻׁלְחָן עָרוּךְ הִצִּילָה אֶת כָּל הַיְּהוּדִים. יֵשׁ בְּכָךְ עֵדוּת נוֹסֶפֶת לִגְדֻלָּתוֹ שֶׁל הַ'אִגְּרוֹת מֹשֶׁה' שֶׁהָיָה מִמַּעֲמִידֵי הָעָם הַיְּהוּדִי בַּשָּׁנִים שֶׁלְּאַחַר הַשּׁוֹאָה, וְעֵדוּת עַל נִצְחִיּוּת הַתּוֹרָה שֶׁרַק מִי שֶׁמְּקַיֵּם אֶת כָּל מִצְווֹתֶיהָ יִרְאֶה טוֹב בְּחַיָּיו וְיִזְכֶּה לִרְאוֹת אֶת הַקָּבָּ"ה עַל כָּל צַעַד וָשַׁעַל.הרב משה מיכאל צורן הי"ו"טובך יביעו" (ב"ב תשס"א) ח"ב, ע' שט"ו

I, thank G-d, have my entire outlook solely from the knowledge of the Torah, without any mixture of external knowledge, whose judgments are truth, whether to be stringent or to be lenient, and the reasons are not from the outlook of external things and fabricated logic from the heart at all, even if to be stringent.
Source: "Igros Moshe" Orach Chaim Vol 4

**Biography**
The Gaon R' Yechiel Michel Feinstein zt"l was born on the 4th of Tammuz, 5666 (1906), to his father HaRav HaGaon R' Avraham Yitzchak zt"l in Uzda, Lithuania. While he was a child of about seven, Yechiel Michel the younger was orphaned of his father...
After our master was orphaned, he moved to live in the house of his grandfather, the Gaon Rabbi Dovid Feinstein zt"l, who had meanwhile become the Rav of the city of Starobin, which at that time was annexed to White Russia...
In his grandfather's house, HaGaon Rabbi Dovid Feinstein, young Yechiel Michel studied with his grandfather the Gaon Rabbi Dovid, and with his uncles: The Gaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l (*Igros Moshe*) and his brother the Gaon Rabbi Mordechai Hy"d. They drew and watered from the tradition of their great fathers and quenched their thirst from the springs of eternity which flowed with strength in the house soaked in Torah and pure fear of Heaven.
Regarding the Torah atmosphere that prevailed in the Feinstein home in White Russia, we can learn from a casual conversation uttered by the Gaon Rabbi Chaim Ozer zt"l on a certain occasion.
It was between the years 5685-5690 (1925-1930), when HaGaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein wrote a responsum on a certain matter, in which he expressed his opinion—which was opposed to the ruling of the Gaon Rabbi Yechezkel Abramsky zt"l, who had also written a responsum on the same matter. The two responsa were brought before R' Chaim Ozer in Vilna. He sided with the opinion of Rabbi Moshe, remarking: "I heard about the two brothers (Rabbi Moshe and his brother R' Mordechai), who are found in the very heart of the continent of Russia, and they study Torah there as it was studied a hundred years ago!!"...
Source: Eulogy by Rav Yechiel Michel Feinstein

לְאַחַר שֶׁנִּתְיַתֵּם רַבֵּנוּ - עָבַר הוּא לְהִתְגּוֹרֵר בְּבֵית סָבוֹ - הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי דָּוִד פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין זצ"ל, שֶׁנִּהְיָה בֵּינְתַיִם לְרַבָּהּ שֶׁל הָעִיר סְטְרָאבִּין שֶׁבְּאוֹתָהּ עֵת הָיְתָה מְסֻפַּחַת לְרוּסְיָה הַלְּבָנָה...
בְּבֵית סָבוֹ - הַגְר"ד פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין - לָמַד יְחִיאֵל מִיכְל הַצָּעִיר עִם סָבוֹ הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי דָּוִד, וְעִם דּוֹדָיו: הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין זצ"ל ("אִגְּרוֹת מֹשֶׁה") וְאָחִיו הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי מָרְדְּכַי הי"ד, אֲשֶׁר דָּלוּ וְהִשְׁקוּ מִתּוֹרַת אֲבִיהֶם הַגָּדוֹל - וְהִרְווּ אֶת צִמְאוֹנָם מִמַּעְיְנוֹת הַנֶּצַח אֲשֶׁר פִּכּוּ בְּעֹז בַּבַּיִת הַסָּפוּג בְּתוֹרָה וּבְיִרְאַת שָׁמַיִם טְהוֹרָה.
עַל הָאֲוִירָה הַתּוֹרָנִית אֲשֶׁר שָׁרְרָה בְּבֵית פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין אֲשֶׁר בְּרוּסְיָה הַלְּבָנָה - יְכוֹלִים אָנוּ לִלְמֹד מִשִּׂיחַת חֻלִּין שֶׁל תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים, מִתּוֹךְ מִשְׁפָּט אוֹתוֹ הִפְטִיר הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי חַיִּים עוֹזֵר זצ"ל בְּהִזְדַּמְּנוּת מְסֻיֶּמֶת.
הָיָה זֶה בֵּין הַשָּׁנִים תרפ"ה-תר"צ, כַּאֲשֶׁר הַגְר"מ פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין כָּתַב תְּשׁוּבָה בְּעִנְיָן מְסֻיָּם, וּבָהּ הִבִּיעַ אֶת דַּעְתּוֹ - אֲשֶׁר הָיְתָה מְנֻגֶּדֶת לִפְסָקוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי יְחֶזְקֵאל אַבְּרַמְסְקִי זצ"ל - אֲשֶׁר כָּתַב אַף הוּא תְּשׁוּבָה בְּאוֹתוֹ הָעִנְיָן. שְׁתֵּי הַתְּשׁוּבוֹת הוּבְאוּ לִפְנֵי ר' חַיִּים עוֹזֵר בְּוִילְנָא - וְהוּא צִדֵּד בְּדַעְתּוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה, תּוֹךְ שֶׁהוּא מֵעִיר: "שָׁמַעְתִּי עַל שְׁנֵי הָאַחִים (רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה וְאָחִיו ר' מָרְדְּכַי), הַנִּמְצָאִים בְּלֵב לִבָּהּ שֶׁל יַבֶּשֶׁת רוּסְיָא - וְלוֹמְדִים בָּהּ תּוֹרָה כְּפִי שֶׁהָיְתָה נִלְמֶדֶת לִפְנֵי מֵאָה שָׁנָה!!"...
body_en:
Our master (the Gaon Rabbi Michel Feinstein zt"l) explained the definition of Rabbi Chaim Ozer regarding their method of study, later in his eulogy for his uncle, the Gaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l. These were his words:
"Behold, his greatness in Torah and the genius of my uncle zt"l was not at all according to his generation. And although we do not, Heaven forbid, make comparisons, nevertheless, in a certain respect, his entire method of study, the scope, and the breadth were of the type of the previous generations, the generation of the Vilna Gaon and the Chasam Sofer zt"l. This greatness is reflected like dawn from within the 18 volumes of his great works *Dibros Moshe*. You find among Torah scholars, heads of Yeshivas, that their entire focus is on *Chiddushim* (novelties) and to overturn valleys in clarifying Sugyas from several tractates and no more. You find great Poskim answering Halacha for practical application in Shulchan Aruch and judging between a man and his neighbor. There are those who have this and not that, and vice versa.
"The one was my uncle Rabbi Moshe zt"l, who had it all within him. He learned the entire Torah completely and knew everything. He was not what is called a 'Yeshiva of Seven Tractates' man; he was not limited to specific Sugyas or specific orders and subjects within Shas and Shulchan Aruch. Rather, the entire Torah completely entered the circle of his study. He was expert in Scripture, Tanach, and was fluent in the six orders of Mishnah. He studied and reviewed Shas and Poskim all his days, without the Yerushalmi, Tosefta, etc.
"The scope of his study was of a different type, completely different from what is accustomed in our generation. There is no exaggeration at all in what we said, that in a way, his study fit more the generation of the Vilna Gaon and the Chasam Sofer. In that generation, they studied with a different scope; they studied the entire Torah completely and knew everything. And so, the study of my uncle, the Gaon Rabbi Moshe zt"l, belonged to this type."
Source: Eulogy by Rav Yechiel Michel Feinstein

body_he: הָאֶחָד הָיָה דּוֹדִי רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה זצ"ל דְּכֻלָּא בֵּיהּ, הוּא לָמַד אֶת כָּל הַתּוֹרָה כֻּלָּהּ וְיָדַע הַכֹּל, הוּא לֹא לָמַד רַק מַה שֶּׁקּוֹרְאִים "יְשִׁיבָה'שֶׁע מַסֶּכְתּוֹת", הוּא לֹא הִצְטַמְצֵם בְּסוּגְיוֹת מְסֻיָּמוֹת אוֹ בִּסְדָרִים מְסֻיָּמִים וּמִקְצוֹעוֹת אֲחָדִים בְּתוֹךְ הַשַּׁ"ס וְהַשֻּׁלְחָן עָרוּךְ, אֶלָּא כָּל הַתּוֹרָה כֻּלָּהּ נִכְנְסָה בְּחוּג עִיּוּנוֹ, הָיָה בָּקִי בְּמִקְרָא, תַּנַ"ךְ, וְהָיָה גּוֹרֵס בְּשׁוֹפִי שִׁשָּׁה סִדְרֵי מִשְׁנָה, הָיָה לוֹמֵד וְשׁוֹנֶה כָּל יָמָיו שַׁ"ס וּפוֹסְקִים, בַּבְלִי וִירוּשַׁלְמִי תּוֹסֶפְתָּא וְכוּ', הַהֶקֵּף שֶׁל לִמּוּדוֹ הָיָה מִסּוּג אַחֵר, שׁוֹנֶה לַחֲלוּטִין מִמַּה שֶׁרְגִילִים בּוֹ בְּדוֹרֵנוּ, וְאֵין כְּלָל גּוּזְמָא בַּמֶּה שֶׁאָמַרְנוּ כִּי בְּאֹפֶן לִמּוּדוֹ הִתְאִים יוֹתֵר לְדוֹרָם שֶׁל הַגּרע"א וְהַחֲתַם סוֹפֵר, בַּדּוֹר הַהוּא לָמְדוּ בְּהֶקֵּף אַחֵר, לָמְדוּ אֶת כָּל הַתּוֹרָה כֻּלָּהּ וְיָדְעוּ הַכֹּל. וְכֵן לִמּוּדוֹ שֶׁל דּוֹדִי הַגְר"מ זצ"ל הִשְׁתַּיְּכָה לְסוּג הַזֶּה.
body_en:
Indeed, the diligence of the brothers during this period—under the rule of the Communists—was wondrous. Years later, R' Moshe told that there was a period where he studied at night by the light of the moon!! When our master would tell of the wondrous diligence of his uncles during that difficult period, he would add and emphasize that specifically in this period, R' Moshe merited the main part of his ascent in Torah, as per their statement of blessed memory: "**Af Chochmasi Amda Li** - This is the Torah that I learned in anger/duress (*B'af*)."
An interesting fact related to that period served in the mouth of the Gaon R' Moshe Feinstein zt"l as an explanation for his custom to utilize every scrap of paper—a custom that made reading his responsa difficult, as they were spread over the entire page, utilizing absolutely every empty space.
When asked about this by his students, R' Moshe replied that in his youth—while in Russia under Communist rule—there was a severe shortage of paper, a fact that forced him to utilize every smooth corner on the paper to write Torah insights... This impression—so R' Moshe told—remained with him for the rest of his life, and for him, blank paper was worth gold...
Source: Sar HaTorah

Once, when I accompanied HaGaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l to his home, he told me along the way that he received a letter from Chinuch Atzmai. Since a difference of opinion had arisen regarding a certain detail between the heads of Chinuch Atzmai at the time, the Gaon R' Yechezkel Abramsky zt"l and the Gaon R' Zalman Sorotzkin zt"l, they were therefore requesting his decision on the matter.
HaGaon Rabbi Moshe zt"l told me regarding this that he has no intention of interfering in the affairs of the Land of Israel, nor to decide for the greats of the Land of Israel and rule on the question. For it is not the way of *Derech Eretz* (proper conduct) that a Rav from one city should rule on the affairs of a Rav from another city. His maxim was: "The Rav from Minsk does not interfere in the questions of the Rav of Pinsk."
*   And it is known that HaGaon Rabbi Moshe zt"l was a master of the tractates of Order Zeraim, and he left a manuscript commentary on the Yerushalmi of Order Zeraim. Even so, he never intervened or ruled on questions of Mitzvos dependent on the Land (Mitzvos Hatluyos Ba'aretz) that are discussed in the Land of Israel, for the aforementioned reason.
Source: Migdal Givos Olam

K"K our Rabbi (Shlita) [the "Yeshuos Moshe" ZT"L] warns much about the subject of debts. Not once did he dedicate the words of Torah at the time of *Ra'ava D'Ra'avin* (Third Meal) to awaken about this subject. He mentions the words of the Responsa of the *Rosh* (see Gilyonei HaShas Shabbos 11) that the words of Chazal who said that "Repaying a creditor is a Mitzvah" - refers to *its time*! How can it be possible to be **לוה רשע ולא ישלם** - "The wicked borrows and does not repay" (Psalms 37:21)? The Rebbe cried out from the pain of his heart, and lamented his pain over those borrowers without knowing from where they would repay.
When I accompanied K"K Admor (Shlita) [ZT"L] on his walk in the mountains of Switzerland in the summer of 5732 (1972), HaRav Ephraim Fishel Stein spoke and told me: The Rebbe told me: "When I arrived in our Holy Land, I was literally in lack of everything. When Erev Shabbos arrived and I needed to prepare the candles for Shabbos, but what should I do and we have no candlestick (*leichter*)? I went down to the courtyard of the house and took with me a stone, upon which I stuck the candles. So it was for a long period, until R' Asher Bertler granted us a candlestick. Although I could borrow, both because I was 'The Vizhnitzer Rebbe's child', Anash trusted me and lent to me willingly. But, if one does not know in advance from where they will repay - there is no borrowing!
This and more," the Rebbe continued to tell, "when it was upon me to build my house in the neighborhood [Shikun Vizhnitz], I received indeed the land from my father the holy one, but the cost of the building was upon me to pay myself. I borrowed therefore from my mother the Rebbetzin 2,000 Lira, and I obligated myself to bring her ten Lira every day and Erev Shabbos Kodesh. There was not one Friday that I did not bring the sum! Sometimes my mother would ask me: 'What are you panicked about? After all, anyway today is Friday, Erev Shabbos Kodesh, and I can bring the money also on Motzaei Shabbos or on Sunday.' But such a thing is impossible. Even when speaking of my mother, not a stranger, if one borrows, one must pay at the exact time!"
Source: Ayin Shnos Chinuch

עֻבְדָּה מְעַנְיֶנֶת הַקְּשׁוּרָה לְאוֹתָהּ תְּקוּפָה, שִׁמְּשָׁה בְּפִי הַגָּאוֹן ר' מֹשֶׁה פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין זצ"ל כְּהֶסְבֵּר לְמִנְהָגוֹ לְנַצֵּל כָּל פִּסַּת נְיָר פְּנוּיָה - מִנְהָג אֲשֶׁר הִקְשָׁה עַל קְרִיאַת תְּשׁוּבוֹתָיו אֲשֶׁר הָיוּ מִתְפָּרְסוֹת עַל פְּנֵי הַדַּף כֻּלּוֹ, תּוֹךְ נִצּוּל מֻחְלָט שֶׁל כָּל מִרְוָח פָּנוּי.
מִשֶּׁנִּשְׁאַל אוֹדוֹת כָּךְ עַל יְדֵי תַּלְמִידָיו, הֵשִׁיב ר' מֹשֶׁה כִּי בִּצְעִירוּתוֹ - בִּהְיוֹתוֹ בְּרוּסְיָה תַּחַת שִׁלְטוֹן הַקּוֹמוּנִיסְטִים - הָיָה מַחְסוֹר חָמוּר בִּנְיָר, עֻבְדָּה אֲשֶׁר אִלְּצָה אוֹתוֹ לְנַצֵּל כָּל פִּנָּה חֲלָקָה עַל פְּנֵי הַנְּיָר בִּכְדֵי לִכְתֹּב עָלֶיהָ חִדּוּשֵׁי תּוֹרָה... רֹשֶׁם זֶה - כָּךְ סִפֵּר ר' מֹשֶׁה - נוֹתַר בּוֹ לְמֶשֶׁךְ כָּל יְמֵי חַיָּיו, וַעֲבוּרוֹ נְיָר חָלָק - שָׁוֶה הָיָה זָהָב..."שַׂר הַתּוֹרָה" (ירושלים תשס"ד) ע' י"א
body_en:
I give thanks and bless Hashem, blessed be He, for all His kindnesses that He has done with me until this day, that He brought me and my household out from the places of persecution. And that even while I was there, in the days of my poverty and wanderings, He helped me so that I did not cease much from Torah study and from delving into it. And also, He brought me here to a place of Torah and helped me to teach Torah to the many in the Yeshiva.
And certainly, it was not my merit that caused this, but the merit of my holy ancestors, my master, my father zt"l, who was a great Gaon, a Tzaddik, a Chassid, and humble, and almost without parallel in his traits for the sake of Heaven and in his love for Torah and those who study it and for all of Israel. He learned with us, with me and my holy brother zt"l, more than two orders of Gemara and a large part of Choshen Mishpat. Also, I was close to his city, and every difficult matter in ruling I asked him all his days, and his answer was like from Sinai. He ascended to Heaven on the 27th of Tishrei, 5688.
And the merit of my mother, my teacher zt"l, the righteous woman, who had no parallel in her fear and love for Torah, and her entire goal was that we should grow in Torah, and she strove that not even one hour of our study should be wasted. She ascended to Heaven on the 20th of Adar I, 5681. Only their merit stood for me in the kindnesses of Hashem, blessed be He.
Source: Introduction to "Dibros Moshe" on Bava Kamma

My father-in-law, HaRav R' Eliezer Lipa Gartenberg z"l, was the owner of the Pioneer Country Club, which was a Chareidi hotel in America. My *Aufruf* was supposed to take place there in the hotel, as well as the wedding the next day on Sunday. In honor of the simcha, about two hundred and fifty people gathered at the hotel for Shabbos Kodesh, among them my teacher HaGaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l and HaGaon Rabbi Silber zt"l, and other Rabbis and important figures.
Suddenly, in the middle of Shabbos Kodesh, my father z"l passed away. The question in our mouths was whether we could conduct the wedding on Sunday when the groom is an *Onen* (mourner before burial), or if we need to postpone it, and until when. My father-in-law z"l argued that seemingly there is no allowance here of financial loss regarding the food prepared for the wedding, since they could return it to the freezer. Also, regarding the rental of the hall, there is no loss since he is the owner of the entire hotel.
When we presented the question to HaGaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l, he told us to conduct the wedding on Sunday and postpone the funeral to Monday. His reasoning was with him: the allowance of financial loss that permits conducting a wedding for a groom even during his mourning days is not limited specifically to the loss of expenses involved in the wedding preparations. Rather, even losses that would occur to the groom and bride because postponing the wedding until after the seven days of mourning would result in fewer people participating, and thus fewer gifts—such losses are also included in the allowance to conduct the wedding on time. He added that the Grace after Meals of the wedding should be before sunset, and the funeral should be postponed until the next day, Monday.
Not only that, but HaGaon Rabbi Moshe zt"l announced in the synagogue in the hotel and forbade anyone from revealing to anyone that the groom's father had passed away. For if people knew that the groom's father had died in the hotel, they would not come to participate in the wedding, as they would not want to come to a wedding where there is a dead body. Then, the joy of the groom and bride would be diminished even more. And who is like Your people Israel, that they controlled themselves from revealing such a juicy story, that the groom's father passed away at the *Aufruf* and the funeral is delayed until after the wedding.
To the extent that I remember that after the Chuppah, people asked me: "Where is your father?"
Source: Kol HaTorah

בְּאֹפֶן פִּתְאוֹמִי בְּאֶמְצַע שַׁבָּת קֹדֶשׁ נִפְטַר אָבִי ז"ל, וְהַשְּׁאֵלָה בְּפִינוּ הַאִם יְכוֹלִים לַעֲרֹךְ הַחֲתֻנָּה בְּיוֹם א' כְּשֶׁהֶחָתָן הוּא אוֹנֵן, אוֹ צָרִיךְ לִדְחוֹתָהּ וְעַד מָתַי יֵשׁ לִדְחוֹתָהּ. חָמִי ז"ל טָעַן דְּלִכְאוֹרָה אֵין כָּאן הֶתֵּר שֶׁל הֶפְסֵד מָמוֹן מִצַּד הַמַּאֲכָלִים שֶׁהֵכִינוּ לַחֲתֻנָּה שֶׁהֲרֵי יְכוֹלִים לְהַחְזִירָם לַמַּקְפִּיא עַד שֶׁתִּתְקַיֵּם הַחֲתֻנָּה, וְכֵן מִצַּד שְׂכִירוּת הָאוּלָם אֵין הֶפְסֵד אִם לֹא יֵעָרְכוּ הַחֲתֻנָּה עַכְשָׁיו שֶׁהֲרֵי הוּא הַבְּעָלִים שֶׁל בֵּית הַמָּלוֹן כֻּלָּהּ.
וּכְשֶׁהִצַּעְנוּ אֶת הַשְּׁאֵלָה לְהַגּר"מ פַיְינְשְׁטֵיין זצ"ל, אָמַר לָנוּ לַעֲרֹךְ אֶת הַחֲתֻנָּה בְּיוֹם א' וְלִדְחוֹת אֶת הַלְוָיָה לְיוֹם ב', וְטַעְמוֹ וְנִמּוּקוֹ עִמּוֹ שֶׁהַהֶתֵּר שֶׁל הֶפְסֵד מָמוֹן שֶׁיֵּשׁ לַעֲרֹךְ חֲתֻנָּה לְחָתָן אַף בִּימֵי אֶבְלוֹ אֵינוֹ מֻגְבָּל דַּוְקָא לְהֶפְסֵד שֶׁל הוֹצָאוֹת הַכְּרוּכוֹת עִם הַהֲכָנוֹת שֶׁל הַחֲתֻנָּה, אֶלָּא אַף הֶפְסֵדִים שֶׁיִּהְיוּ לֶחָתָן וְהַכַּלָּה עַל יְדֵי שֶׁיִּדְחוּ אֶת הַחֲתֻנָּה עַד לְאַחַר שִׁבְעַת יְמֵי הָאֲבֵלוּת, שֶׁהֲרֵי כְּשֶׁיַּעֲשׂוּ אֶת הַחֲתֻנָּה בְּמוֹעֵד אַחֵר לֹא יִשְׁתַּתְּפוּ כָּל כָּךְ הַרְבֵּה אֲנָשִׁים וְעַל יְדֵי זֶה תִּתְמַעֵט שִׂמְחָתָם וְכֵן הַמַּתָּנוֹת, גַּם הֶפְסֵדִים כָּאֵלּוּ נִכְלָלִים בַּהֶתֵּר לַעֲרֹךְ הַחֲתֻנָּה בִּזְמַנָּהּ. וְהוֹסִיף שֶׁרָאוּי שֶׁבִּרְכַּת הַמָּזוֹן שֶׁל הַחֲתֻנָּה תִּהְיֶה לִפְנֵי הַשְּׁקִיעָה, וְלִדְחוֹת אֶת הַלְוָיָה עַד לְמָחֳרַת בְּיוֹם ב'.
וְלֹא עוֹד אֶלָּא הַגּר"מ זצ"ל הִכְרִיז בְּבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת שֶׁבְּבֵית הַמָּלוֹן וְאָסַר עַל כָּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד מִלְּגַלּוֹת לְאַף אֶחָד שֶׁנִּפְטַר לְעוֹלָמוֹ אָבִיו שֶׁל הֶחָתָן, שֶׁהֲרֵי אִם אֲנָשִׁים מִבַּחוּץ יֵדְעוּ שֶׁנִּפְטַר אָבִיו שֶׁל הֶחָתָן בְּבֵית הַמָּלוֹן, לֹא יָבוֹאוּ לְהִשְׁתַּתֵּף בַּחֲתֻנָּה, שֶׁהֲרֵי לֹא יִרְצוּ לָבוֹא לַחֲתֻנָּה שֶׁיֵּשׁ שָׁם מֵת, וְאָז הֲרֵי תִּתְמַעֵט שִׂמְחַת חָתָן וְכַלָּה עוֹד יוֹתֵר. וּמִי כְּעַמְּךָ יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁשָּׁלְטוּ בְּעַצְמָם מִלְּגַלּוֹת סִפּוּר מְעַנְיֵן כָּזֶה, שֶׁנִּפְטַר אָבִיו שֶׁל הֶחָתָן בָּאוֹיפְרוּף וְדוֹחִים הַלְוָיָה עַד לְאַחַר הַחֲתֻנָּה.
עַד כְּדֵי כָּךְ שֶׁזִּכְרוֹנִי שֶׁלְּאַחַר הַחֻפָּה שָׁאֲלוּ אוֹתִי כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה אֲנָשִׁים אֵיפֹה אָבִיךָ?הרב יעקב הפטלער ז"ל"קול התורה", ניסן תשס"ג, ע' ס"ח

There was an incident with a big businessman who went bankrupt and lost hundreds of thousands of dollars. Among them was the entire fortune and savings of important Kollel students (Avreichim). There was great distress over this. When the matters came to HaGaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l, he was very angry and said: "Behold, one who transgresses a Rabbinic prohibition is a sinner. But one who does not listen to the advice of our holy Sages, his deeds are more severe."
For the Sages said in Kesubos (67a): **לעולם ישלש אדם מעותיו שליש בקרקע ושליש בפרקמטיא** - "A person should always divide his money: one third in land, one third in merchandise..." This implies that one should not invest all his money in one place. It turns out that these Avreichim transgressed this saying of Chazal. And whoever considers himself smarter than Chazal, Heaven forbid, needs an examination of his opinions.
Source: Migdal Givos Olam

It is told about HaRav HaGaon R' Moshe Feinstein zt"l that he once judged a Torah case between two litigants. He ruled in favor of one of the two. The second party wanted to debate with him and prove with arguments and answers that justice was with him.
The Gaon R' Moshe zt"l answered and said to that man: "Know that I am certain that my opinion is the opinion of the Torah, because I never looked at anything except the Torah. Therefore, all my outlook and opinion is solely from the Torah."
Source: B'Pikudecha Asicha

I heard a story. There is a Halacha that it is forbidden to pass in front of someone praying. Forty years ago, telephones were expensive. The Gaon R' Moshe Feinstein zt"l was at a meeting in a hotel in New York. In the middle of the Chazan's repetition, they came to call him to the phone from the Land of Israel. Apparently, it was something very important. There was someone standing behind him in the middle of the Shemoneh Esrei, and R' Moshe did not move.
"Rebbe, there is a phone call from Eretz Yisrael!" He did not move. Only when that person finished Shemoneh Esrei did R' Moshe go out. Someone asked: "Why didn't the Rav go out?" HaGaon Rabbi Moshe said: "Is there not a wall? A barrier? I cannot walk through a wall! Halacha in Shulchan Aruch is a wall. And blessed is Hashem that we know that when Shabbos arrives, it doesn't matter at what hour—we stop working because Shabbos is a wall that separates from work. We must have this recognition..."
Source: Kol HaTorah

Every year, Mesivtha Tifereth Jerusalem holds a dinner for the benefit of the Yeshiva. And every time our teacher HaGaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l spoke there, he only asked the householders to support Torah. He never asked for support for *his* Yeshiva specifically, only support for those who study Torah. He could not bring himself to say that his Yeshiva was more important than another Yeshiva. The main thing is that they support Torah and those who study it.
Source: Kol HaTorah

[The Holy Rabbi R' Yudli Horowitz zy"a related:] The Holy Gaon of Barnov zy"a would make a great noise during the reading of the Megillah at the verse (4:2): "**For none may enter the King's gate in sackcloth.**" This is according to what is known, that an unspecified "King" in the Megillah hints to the King of the World, Blessed be He.
Source: Zichron Yehuda

body_he: וְיָדוּעַ שֶׁהַגְר"מ זצ"ל הָיָה מָרָא דִּשְׁמַעְתְּתָא דְּסֵדֶר זְרָעִים, וְהִנִּיחַ כְּתַב יָד פֵּרוּשׁ עַל הַיְרוּשַׁלְמִי דְּסֵדֶר זְרָעִים, וְאַעַפּ"כּ מֵעוֹלָם לֹא הִתְעָרֵב וּפָסַק בִּשְׁאֵלוֹת שֶׁל מִצְווֹת הַתְּלוּיוֹת בָּאָרֶץ הַנִּדּוֹנִים בְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל, מֵהַטַּעַם הָאָמוּר.הרה"ג ר' מיכל זלמן שורקין שליט"א"מגד גבעות עולם" (ירושלים תשס"ה) ח"ב, ע' ל"א
body_en:
When they informed me that his Honor and Holiness, the Gaon (the Lubavitcher Rebbe zt"l) is interested in the matter of fulfilling the Mitzvah of Tefillin according to Rabbeinu Tam regarding myself, I found it necessary to write my thanks and also my reasons and arguments.
Behold, when I was in Luban, I had perfect Rabbeinu Tam Tefillin which I was accustomed to wear after the prayer, but I made a condition "without a vow" (*Bli Neder*). And so too when I came here (to America), by the mercies of Heaven, I wore them for many years when I found good ones according to my opinion. The issue is that there is a great difference between Rashi Tefillin, which are obligatory—even though one needs to beautify them to be most excellent, nevertheless, when there are none, simply valid Tefillin and even only under duress are a Mitzvah to wear—therefore, over the course of time, many tribulations passed over us due to our sins, and scribes diminished. Afterward, for many years, there were no scribes at all, nor kosher parchment, and we were forced to fulfill the Mitzvah of Tefillin only with those that already existed from many years ago. Although regarding the most excellent ones, they became spoiled and there were questions about them, we fulfilled the Mitzvah with those that existed.
But regarding Rabbeinu Tam Tefillin, since there is no obligation even of doubt, for the Halacha is ruled like Rashi... and since it is that there is no obligation of doubt and no stringency of law, I did not practice it unless the Tefillin were excellent in their kashrus and beauty. But when doubts arose about them that it was not clear I was fulfilling the Mitzvah with them, I did not practice wearing Rabbeinu Tam Tefillin. Therefore, since doubts had already arisen about them, I did not trouble myself to bring them from my place in Luban, which was very difficult. I was forced to leave many books that they did not let me take with me, and also my own writings I could not take out from there with me.
And when I came here (to America), I did not obtain Rabbeinu Tam Tefillin from those excellent ones that would be according to my opinion, except for one time I happened to get old but good Rabbeinu Tam Tefillin which I wore for many years until I had to hide them (Genizah). And obligatory Rashi Tefillin I obtained twice through someone in Eretz Yisrael as I said they should make, but I did not trouble myself so much for Rabbeinu Tam Tefillin since there is no actual obligation, and also no obligation of custom, even though my father, my teacher zt"l, put them on all his days, but he did not conduct himself in a way that his sons would be obligated by the law of custom. Also, because of the great expense when writing them specifically, which many times was not an easy thing. And since it is not an obligation in essence, and also I made a condition "without a vow," I did not press myself on this...
And now, when they informed me in the name of his Honor, the Gaon (Shlita) [zt"l], that there is an expert scribe with him who is correct to send to me and command him to write Rabbeinu Tam Tefillin portions for me as I wish, it is a very great thing. Aside from the fact that I will be able to also fulfill the Mitzvah of Rabbeinu Tam Tefillin as I was accustomed, regarding the matter of money, blessed is Hashem who has helped me and will help me to pay the scribe as he requests. And the scribe will obtain good housings (*Batim*), and certainly, the scribe will also write in the script of the Beis Yosef... We are accustomed that everything should be in the script of the Beis Yosef, whether Mezuzos, Tefillin, or the Sefer Torah in the synagogue where I am accustomed to pray, that its script should be beautiful.
Source: Igros Moshe Orach Chaim Vol 4

Our master (HaGaon Rabbi Yaakov Kamenetsky zt"l) once met his friend Rabbi Moshe Feinstein in a very uplifted mood. R' Moshe told him that on that day, an incident occurred to him which was nothing but a test sent from Heaven, and he merited to withstand the test. And the story was as follows:
"Some months ago," R' Moshe related, "I served as a judge in a Din Torah. After I ruled in favor of one of the parties, I received a phone call from one of the hands (associates/relatives) of the loser. This man accused me rudely that I erred in a matter of Mishnah, etc., and therefore the verdict has no validity."
"Some time later," R' Moshe continued to tell, "I was amazed to see in my house the man who had hurt me in such a shameful way. It turned out to me that he came to me to ask for a 'Kabbalah' (certification) to be a Shochet. The first thought that awakened in me was to throw him out of the house... But in the end, I decided that since on Yom Kippur I forgave everyone who hurt me, I am forbidden to hold a grudge against anyone. I brought him into my room and tested him on his knowledge of the laws of Shechita.
"After the man succeeded in the exam, I granted him the 'Kabbalah' (permission) to serve as a Shochet. As he stood to leave, I rebuked him for his behavior and told him that he transgressed the severe sin of disgracing the honor of the Torah. However, the young man claimed that he did not understand what was being discussed, especially since he had never called me. His words were recognizable as truth, and I sent him on his way.
"The conclusion is inescapable, it seems, that another person hid under a false name and spoke to me as if in his name."
R' Moshe described to our master the great joy he felt after he withstood the difficult test, when he ignored his personal insult even though he thought the person standing before him was the man who had hurt him.
Source: Bemechitzatam
