"לִפְנֵי כַּמָּה חֳדָשִׁים", סִפֵּר ר' מֹשֶׁה, "שִׁמַּשְׁתִּי כְּדַיָּן בְּדִין תּוֹרָה. לְאַחַר שֶׁפָּסַקְתִּי לְזְכוּתוֹ שֶׁל אֶחָד הַצְּדָדִים, קִבַּלְתִּי שִׂיחַת טֶלֶפוֹן מֵאֶחָד מִידִידָיו שֶׁל הַמַּפְסִיד. אָדָם זֶה הֶאֱשִׁים אוֹתִי בְּגַסּוּת כִּי טָעִיתִי בִּדְבַר מִשְׁנָה וְכוּ', וּלְפִיכָךְ אֵין תֹּקֶף לִפְסַק הַדִּין".
"זְמַן מָה לְאַחַר מִכֵּן", הוֹסִיף ר' מֹשֶׁה לְסַפֵּר, "נִדְהַמְתִּי לִרְאוֹת בְּבֵיתִי אֶת הָאָדָם שֶׁפָּגַע בִּי בְּאֹפֶן כֹּה מֵבִישׁ. הִתְבָּרֵר לִי, שֶׁהִגִּיעַ אֵלַי כְּדֵי לְבַקֵּשׁ 'קַבָּלָה' לִהְיוֹת שׁוֹחֵט. הַמַּחֲשָׁבָה הָרִאשׁוֹנָה שֶׁהִתְעוֹרְרָה בִּי הָיְתָה לְסַלְּקוֹ מֵהַבַּיִת... אַךְ לְבַסּוֹף הֶחְלַטְתִּי, שֶׁהֱיוֹת שֶׁבְּיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים מָחַלְתִּי לְכָל מִי שֶׁפָּגַע בִּי, אָסוּר לִי לִשְׁמֹר טִינָה נֶגֶד מִישֶׁהוּ. הִכְנַסְתִּי אוֹתוֹ לְחַדְרִי וְעָרַכְתִּי לוֹ מִבְחָן עַל יְדִיעוֹתָיו בְּהִלְכוֹת שְׁחִיטָה.
"לְאַחַר שֶׁהַלָּה הִצְלִיחַ בַּבְּחִינָה, הֶעֱנַקְתִּי לוֹ אֶת הַ'קַבָּלָה' (- אִשּׁוּר) לְשַׁמֵּשׁ כְּשׁוֹחֵט. כְּשֶׁעָמַד לָצֵאת, הוֹכַחְתִּי אוֹתוֹ עַל הִתְנַהֲגוּתוֹ וְאָמַרְתִּי לוֹ שֶׁעָבַר עַל הָעֲבֵרָה הַחֲמוּרָה שֶׁל בִּזְיוֹן כְּבוֹד הַתּוֹרָה. אוּלָם הַצָּעִיר טָעַן כִּי אֵינוֹ מֵבִין בַּמֶּה מְדֻבָּר, מַה גַּם שֶׁמֵּעוֹלָם לֹא הִתְקַשֵּׁר אֵלַי. נִכָּרִים הָיוּ דִּבְרֵי אֱמֶת, וְשִׁלַּחְתִּי אוֹתוֹ לְדַרְכּוֹ.
"הַמַּסְקָנָה הַמִּתְבַּקֶּשֶׁת הִיא, כְּפִי הַנִּרְאֶה, שֶׁאָדָם אַחֵר הִסְתַּתֵּר תַּחַת שֵׁם מְזֻיָּף וְדִבֵּר אִתִּי כְּאִילּוּ בִּשְׁמוֹ".
ר' מֹשֶׁה תֵּאֵר לְרַבֵּנוּ אֶת הַשִּׂמְחָה הַגְּדוֹלָה שֶׁחָשׁ לְאַחַר שֶׁעָמַד בַּמִּבְחָן הַקָּשֶׁה, כַּאֲשֶׁר הִתְעַלֵּם מֵעֶלְבּוֹנוֹ הָאִישִׁי אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁחָשַׁב שֶׁהָעוֹמֵד לְפָנָיו הוּא הָאָדָם שֶׁפָּגַע בּוֹ.הרב שלמה לורנץ ז"ל"במחיצתם" (ירושלים תשס"ח) ח"ב, ע' 584
body_en:
...As for what his Honor apologizes for, that he holds not according to my words, I do not know why he needs an apology. Behold, certainly everyone needs to clarify the truth according to his opinion, whether for leniency or for stringency, even when he is a student against the reasoning of his teacher, and all the more so to others who are not his students... And if his intention is to apologize because perhaps in his language he spoke harsh words against me, behold it is known to all who know me that, thank G-d, I am far from holding a grudge, Heaven forbid, against any person, and all the more so against a Torah scholar.
Source: Igros Moshe Yoreh Deah Vol 2

...And regarding the Jews who were hijacked to Uganda and saved from there by the soldiers who came there, it stands to reason that this should be considered an open miracle. For by the way of nature, such a thing could not have been possible. And everything that is done in the world is only the hand of Hashem, blessed be He, whether good or, Heaven forbid, the opposite. He is the One who strikes and He is the Healer. He caused them to be captured, and He performed the rescue in that He gave courage and will to go to save them, and He made their way successful so they saved them. These are the ways of Hashem, blessed be He, who performed the miracle through wicked people, hidden from Him. And it is forbidden for any man to be clever with questions against the Holy One, Blessed be He, but rather he should be whole with Hashem...
Source: Igros Moshe Yoreh Deah Vol 4

It seems to me that everything I wrote (both those printed and those not printed) with the help of Hashem, blessed be He, are correct words without contradictions from Shas and Poskim and the commentaries. And if it seems there is a contradiction, one needs to delve deeper... And certainly, it is not relevant to say that justice is with me forever, but all of them were said and written with toil and effort to understand the truth, so I hope that Hashem, blessed be He, who grants man knowledge, has helped me.
Source: Igros Moshe Even HaEzer Vol 4

They say in the name of the Gaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zy"a that he explained the reason why those Jews who came to America eighty and ninety years ago, and had a test regarding Shabbos observance, and withstood this test with lack of bread and wondrous self-sacrifice—why did their children not remain faithful to Hashem and His Torah, may Hashem protect us?
He said: Because on Friday, when they came from work and said they lost their jobs because of Shabbos observance, they said this with sadness and with a "Krechtz" (groan). They did not say it out of joy that they merited, thank G-d, to withstand the test and serve Hashem. And this sadness that was recognizable on their faces gave their children the feeling that they are unable to do this hardest thing, only their father is capable of withstanding such a difficult thing.
But if they had done this with joy, and their children had seen the great vitality their father had in this—that they merited to keep Shabbos and everything is as nothing compared to Shabbos—then automatically they would have had the desire and will to continue and to also have this vitality.
And he explained with this the verse (Devarim 30:19): **ובחרת בחיים למען תחיה אתה וזרעך** - "Therefore choose life, that both you and your seed may live." That by means of you serving with vitality, your seed after you will also serve Hashem, blessed be He.
Source: Halekach Vehalevuv

It bothered him (the Gaon Rabbi Moshe Feinstein zt"l) the fact that only rarely was he asked Halachic questions regarding the distribution of Tzedakah or the education of children. He remarked more than once that the individuals who consult with him regarding the giving of Tzedakah are Kollel students who, in many cases, are not obligated Halachically to give Tzedakah. Do people not understand that the "Shulchan Aruch" discusses laws of Tzedakah and Chinuch with the same measure that it discusses laws of Kashrus, Shabbos, and interest?
Source: Rabbi Moshe Feinstein

Behold, the nations of the world in their vain beliefs believe that there are special people, that their priests have different garments, and are forbidden to marry a woman, and so on—this is like this and that is like that. Aside from it being a lie, it is very damaging. For since they are "holier" than others, the masses can say that therefore *they* need to keep commandments, but the simple people are worldly people who are permitted to do what their heart desires. And so, if one priest acts wickedly, they will learn all the more so that a simple man can act wickedly. And so, all their Torah depends on the will of the priest or the saint among them, and therefore the priests change their laws according to their will and desires.
[But this is not so regarding matters with us.] In the Holy Torah it is written: **משפט אחד יהיה לכם** - "You shall have one manner of law" (Vayikra 24:22) — one law for every person. Because there is no person at all who is holy in essence more than his fellow, only from the aspect of his greatness in Torah. But everyone, even Moshe Rabbeinu, peace be upon him, is born of a woman like every person and needs all the needs of a person like every person. There are no other laws than for every person. A Gaon and a simple man are exactly equal.
And if so, every person can learn from the great one, and everyone understands that he too can be great in Torah and righteous like the great person he knows, since he is a simple person like him and reached perfection.
And for this reason, it is satisfactory that the Torah chose to write the language of "lift" (*Tissa*) regarding the census, and not another language. Because many times a person becomes wicked because he thinks he cannot attain the Holy Torah, and therefore he does not study and does not engage in Mitzvos, and finds himself sinning through the trait of humility. Therefore, the Torah said regarding the census that one sees with one's senses that he is equal to the greatest of the great—that Moshe Rabbeinu, peace be upon him, was counted only as one, and the simple man was counted as one. And just as one needs ten that are equal for a Minyan, therefore the person is uplifted by this. And this is the meaning of "Tissa"—an uplifting in his spirit and soul. And he will learn from the great one and envy him with the envy of scribes, for he too can be so.
Also, there is a benefit that even if, Heaven forbid, a great person turns from the path of Torah, they will not learn from him. Because the Torah is the main thing, and all his greatness is from the side of the Torah. And when he leaves the path of Torah, he is no longer considered great even to the simple people; on the contrary, they will despise him.
Source: Drash Moshe

[אֲבָל לֹא כֵן הֵם פְּנֵי הַדְּבָרִים אֶצְלֵנוּ] בַּתּוֹרָה הַקְּדוֹשָׁה כָּתוּב: "מִשְׁפַּט אֶחָד יִהְיֶה לָכֶם" (וַיִּקְרָא כ"ד, כ"ב) - מִשְׁפָּט אֶחָד לְכָל אָדָם, מִשּׁוּם שֶׁאֵין כְּלָל אָדָם אֶחָד קָדוֹשׁ בְּעֶצֶם מֵחֲבֵרוֹ, אֶלָּא מִצַּד גְּדֻלָּתוֹ בַּתּוֹרָה. אֲבָל כָּל הָעוֹלָם אַף מֹשֶׁה רַבֵּנוּ עָלָיו הַשָּׁלוֹם הוּא יְלוּד אִשָּׁה כְּכָל אָדָם וְצָרִיךְ לְכָל צָרְכֵי הָאָדָם כְּכָל אָדָם, וְאֵין לוֹ שׁוּם דִּינִים אֲחֵרִים מִכָּל אָדָם, וְגָאוֹן וְאִישׁ פָּשׁוּט מַמָּשׁ שָׁוִים הֵם. וְאִם כֵּן יָכוֹל כָּל אָדָם לִלְמֹד מֵהַגָּדוֹל, וְכָל אֶחָד יָבִין שֶׁגַּם הוּא יָכוֹל לִהְיוֹת גָּדוֹל בַּתּוֹרָה וְצַדִּיק כְּהָאָדָם הַגָּדוֹל שֶׁמַּכִּיר, כֵּיוָן שֶׁהוּא אָדָם פָּשׁוּט כָּמוֹהוּ וְהִגִּיעַ לִשְׁלֵמוּת. וּמִטַּעַם זֶה נִיחָא שֶׁבָּחֲרָה הַתּוֹרָה לִכְתֹּב לְשׁוֹן תִּשָּׂא עַל הַמִּנְיָן, וְלֹא לָשׁוֹן אַחֵר, מִשּׁוּם דְּהַרְבֵּה פְּעָמִים נַעֲשֶׂה אָדָם רָשָׁע מִשּׁוּם שֶׁחוֹשֵׁב שֶׁלֹּא יוּכַל לְהַשִּׂיג תּוֹרָה הַקְּדוֹשָׁה, וְלָכֵן אֵינוֹ לוֹמֵד, וְאֵינוֹ עוֹסֵק בְּמִצְווֹת, וְנִמְצָא שֶׁחוֹטֵא בְּמִדַּת הָעֲנָוָה. וְלָכֵן אָמְרָה תּוֹרָה שֶׁבְּעִנְיַן הַמִּנְיָן רוֹאֶה בְּחוּשׁ שֶׁהוּא שָׁוֶה עִם גְּדוֹל הַגְּדוֹלִים - שֶׁמֹּשֶׁה רַבֵּנוּ עָלָיו הַשָּׁלוֹם נִמְנָה רַק לְאֶחָד, וְהָאִישׁ הַפָּשׁוּט נִמְנָה לְאֶחָד. וּכְמוֹ כֵן רוֹאִין בְּכָל דָּבָר שֶׁצָּרִיךְ עֲשָׂרָה שֶׁהֵן שָׁוִין. לָכֵן מִתְרוֹמֵם הָאָדָם בָּזֶה, וְהָוֵי פֵּרוּשׁ תִּשָּׂא הִתְרוֹמְמוּת בְּרוּחוֹ וְנַפְשׁוֹ, וְיִלְמַד מֵהַגָּדוֹל וִיקַנְּאֵהוּ קִנְאַת סוֹפְרִים, שֶׁהֲרֵי גַּם הוּא יָכוֹל לִהְיוֹת כֵּן.
גַּם יֵשׁ תּוֹעֶלֶת שֶׁאַף שֶׁיֵּרַע חַס וְשָׁלוֹם שֶׁאָדָם גָּדוֹל יָסוּר מִדֶּרֶךְ הַתּוֹרָה לֹא יִלְמְדוּ מִמֶּנּוּ, מִשּׁוּם שֶׁהַתּוֹרָה הִיא הָעִקָּר, וְכָל גְּדֻלָּתוֹ הוּא מִצַּד הַתּוֹרָה, וּשֶׁעָזַב דֶּרֶךְ הַתּוֹרָה שׁוּב אֵינוֹ נֶחְשָׁב גָּדוֹל אַף לְהַפְּשׁוּטִים, וְאַדְּרַבָּה יְבַזּוּהוּ.הגאון רבי משה פיינשטיין זצ"ל"דרש משה" (ברוקלין תשל"ט) בהקדמה, ע' י"א

**Biography**
For over ninety years, the life of the Admor HaGaon HaKadosh Rabbi Yochanan Sofer zt"l of Erlau, author of *Imrei Sofer*, was a single unit of Torah and Chassidus. As the successor of the Sofer family after the Holocaust, he rebuilt the Pressburg Yeshiva and the Erlau community from scratch.
The Gaon HaKadosh zt"l was born in the city of Erlau, Hungary, on the 13th of Teves, 5684 (1923), as the fifth generation to our master the Chasam Sofer zy"a. His father was HaGaon Rabbi Moshe Sofer, author of *Yad Sofer*, and his mother was the Rebbetzin Hy"d, who perished in the Holocaust together with four daughters. Rabbi Moshe Hy"d was the son of the Gaon HaKadosh Rabbi Shimon Sofer zt"l, author of Responsa *Hisorerus Teshuva*, the Rav of Erlau, son of the Gaon HaKadosh the *Ksav Sofer* zt"l of Pressburg, who filled the place of his father, the *Chasam Sofer* zy"a.
In his youth, he studied at the Yeshiva of Verpelet in Hungary, which was headed by the famous Gaon Rabbi Yosef Asher HaLevi Pollack zt"l, and at the Yeshiva of Yarmut of the Gaon Rabbi Aharon Dovid Deutsch zt"l, where he acquired his Torah. The Rebbe of Erlau survived the labor camps and arrived in Budapest, where he met and reunited with his older brother, Rabbi Avraham Shmuel Binyamin Sofer, who stayed during the war in the city of Piatra in Romania. He married the Rebbetzin Miriam a"h, daughter of the Gaon Rabbi Yaakov Pahl, grandson of the sister of the *Chasam Sofer*. Together, the brothers re-established the "Chasam Sofer" Yeshiva to fulfill the will of the Chasam Sofer to his descendants: "And make gatherings and groups of workers for Torah in public."
The Rav of Erlau served as a compassionate father to his orphaned students, brands plucked from the fire, worrying about their physical needs and marrying them off. He also established, with self-sacrifice, an underground smuggling network to bring masses of refugees out of the country which had turned Communist. In Kislev 5708 (1947), he arrived together with all the students of his Yeshiva to spend Shabbos in the presence of his holiness, the Rebbe (of Skver) zy"a, who was staying those days in Pest.
At the beginning of Elul 5710 (1950), the Rebbe immigrated to Israel together with a group of students who studied with him. For a short period, his Yeshiva merged with the Pressburg Yeshiva in Jerusalem, which was headed by the author of *Daas Sofer* zt"l, where he served as a Maggid Shiur. In 5713 (1953), he re-established the Ohel Shimon Erlau Yeshiva in the Katamon neighborhood in Jerusalem, in the building of the Syrian Consulate on Yotam Street. At that time, he established an institute for publishing the books of the Chasam Sofer and his students. The Rebbe became close in those years to the Rebbe of Belz zy"a and was one of his closest disciples, bound to him with immense devotion...
Erlau Chassidus developed at a dizzying pace over the years. The Admor founded synagogues and Kollels in Chareidi centers in Israel and abroad named after his father Hy"d, "Sofer," and Torah schools named "Ksav Sofer." The buildings of the Erlau institutions on Givat Moshe in Jerusalem are named after the Chasam Sofer. His sons and grandsons serve as Rabbis of the communities and heads of the Kollels of the Chassidus.
The Admor zt"l did not serve only as a Rebbe and Av Beis Din but was an active Rosh Yeshiva throughout his life. His books on Shas were published under the name *Imrei Sofer* by the institute. Also books *Yomin D'Chanukah* and *Apiryon Chasanim*. The Admor's daily schedule was a continuous sequence of Torah and fear of Heaven. On weekdays, he would deliver a Halacha shiur to the students immediately after Shacharis, as well as a daily shiur to the older students, and in the evening a Daf Yomi shiur for householders. The 'General Shiur' was on Fridays. The Admor zt"l was also known for his rulings in Halacha and wrote thousands upon thousands of letters of response. The Admor zt"l was a father to all his Chassidim and students scattered throughout the land and was a full partner in every decision of a Chassid in his life.
In the month of Av 5770 (2010), while staying in Switzerland for rest, he suffered a severe stroke and had been weak since then. Yet, despite everything, he continued his schedule of receiving the public and his daily holy work with even greater strength. On Shabbos Parshas Terumah, the Rebbe was hospitalized due to pneumonia, and his condition deteriorated due to a bacteria in his body. While all of Chareidi Jewry followed with concern, tearing the heavens with prayers and supplications to keep our sage among us, towards the morning of Monday, Parshas Ki Tisa, 13th of Adar, the lights dimmed with the passing of that wondrous Gaon and Tzaddik zt"l to the hidden treasuries on high, old and satisfied with days, at the age of ninety-three.
Masses of the House of Israel, led by the greats and luminaries of the generation who eulogized him bitterly, participated in his great funeral and the funeral procession that left his Beis Medrash in Katamon towards the Erlau institutions building on Ezras Torah Street in Jerusalem, under pouring rain from the heavens that shed tears like a river, and the plot of the lawgiver hidden in Har HaMenuchos.
The Admor zt"l left behind a branched family: His eldest son, HaRav HaTzaddik Rabbi Moshe, the Rav of the Erlau Chassidim, who was crowned to fill his father's place. Also, the sons: HaRav HaTzaddik Rabbi Yaakov, Rav of the "Ksav Sofer" community in Beitar Illit; HaGaon Rabbi Avraham Shmuel Binyamin, Rosh Yeshiva of Ohel Shimon Erlau; HaRav HaTzaddik Rabbi Shimon, Rav of the 'Toras Moshe' Beis Medrash in Tzfas; HaRav HaTzaddik Rabbi Akiva Menachem, Rav of the Erlau community in Bnei Brak; HaRav HaTzaddik Rabbi Zalman, Rav of the Erlau community in Boro Park; and HaRav HaTzaddik Rabbi Aharon, Rav of the Erlau community in Elad; and grandchildren and great-grandchildren, Torah scholars and G-d-fearing Jews, for name and glory. With his passing, the world of Chassidus lost a sublime figure of a Gaon and Tzaddik of Truth, from the remnants of the Great Assembly, who served his Creator day and night with self-sacrifice solely for Hashem alone.
Source: Bechatzer Hakodesh

בְּבַחֲרוּתוֹ לָמַד בִּישִׁיבַת וֶוערְפֶּעלֶעט שֶׁבְּהוּנְגַרְיָה שֶׁעָמְדָה בְּרָאשׁוּתוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן הַנּוֹדָע רַבִּי יוֹסֵף אֲשֶׁר הַלֵּוִי פָאלָאק זצ"ל, וּבִישִׁיבַת יַארְמוּט שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי אַהֲרֹן דָּוִד דּוֹיְטְשׁ זצ"ל שָׁם קָנָה אֶת תּוֹרָתוֹ. הָרַבִּי מֵעֶרְלוֹי שָׂרַד אֶת מַחֲנוֹת הָעֲבוֹדָה וְהִגִּיעַ לְבּוּדַפֶּשְׁט, שָׁם נִפְגַּשׁ וְהִתְאַחֵד עִם אָחִיו הַגָּדוֹל רַבִּי אַבְרָהָם שְׁמוּאֵל בִּנְיָמִין סוֹפֵר שֶׁשָּׁהָה בִּזְמַן הַמִּלְחָמָה בְּעִיר פִּיאַטְרָא שֶׁבְּרוֹמַנְיָה. הוּא נָשָׂא לְאִשָּׁה אֶת הָרַבָּנִית מִרְיָם ע"ה בִּתּוֹ שֶׁל הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב פַּאל נֶכֶד אֲחוֹת הַ"חֲתַם סוֹפֵר", וְיַחְדָּיו הֵקִימוּ הָאַחִים מֵחָדָשׁ אֶת יְשִׁיבַת 'חֲתַם סוֹפֵר' לְקַיֵּם צַוָּאַת הַחֲתַ"ס לְצֶאֱצָאָיו "וַעֲשׂוּ קִבּוּץ וְרִבּוּץ וּפְעָלִים לַתּוֹרָה בָּרַבִּים". הָרַב מֵעֶרְלוֹי שִׁמֵּשׁ עֲבוּר תַּלְמִידָיו הַיְתוֹמִים מֻצָּלֵי הָאֵשׁ כְּאַבָּא רַחִימָאִי כְּשֶׁהוּא דּוֹאֵג גַּם לַצְּרָכִים הַגַּשְׁמִיִּים וּלְחַתְּנָם לְמַזָּ"ט, וְכֵן יָסַד בְּמַסּוֹת-נֶפֶשׁ מַחְתֶּרֶת הַבְרָחָה לְהוֹצִיא הֲמוֹנֵי פְּלִיטֵי חֶרֶב אֶל מִחוּץ לַמְּדִינָה שֶׁהָפְכָה לְקוֹמוּנִיסְטִית. בְּכִסְלֵו תש"ח הִגִּיעַ יַחַד עִם כָּל בְּנֵי יְשִׁיבָתוֹ לַעֲשׂוֹת שַׁבָּת בִּמְחִצַּת קָדְשׁוֹ שֶׁל כּ"ק מָרָן (מִסְּקְוִוירָא) זי"ע שֶׁשָּׁהָה אוֹתָם יָמִים בְּפֶעסְט.
בִּתְחִלַּת אֱלוּל תש"י עָלָה הָרַבִּי לְאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל יַחַד עִם קְבוּצַת בַּחוּרִים שֶׁלָּמְדוּ עִמּוֹ. לִתְקוּפָה קְצָרָה הִתְמַזְּגָה יְשִׁיבָתוֹ עִם יְשִׁיבַת פְּרֶעשְׁבּוּרְג בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם שֶׁהָיְתָה בְּרָאשׁוּת בַּעַל דַּעַת סוֹפֵר זצ"ל שָׁם שִׁמֵּשׁ כְּמַגִּיד שִׁעוּר. בִּשְׁנַת תשי"ג הֵקִים מֵחָדָשׁ אֶת יְשִׁיבַת אֹהֶל שִׁמְעוֹן עֶרְלוֹי בִּשְׁכוּנַת קָטָמוֹן בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם, בְּבִנְיָן שֶׁל הַקּוֹנְסוּלְיָה הַסּוּרִית בִּרְחוֹב יוֹתָם. בְּאוֹתָהּ עֵת הֵקִים מָכוֹן לְהוֹצָאַת סִפְרֵי הַחֲתַם סוֹפֵר וְתַלְמִידָיו. הרה"ק הִתְקָרֵב בְּאוֹתָן שָׁנִים לְהרה"ק מִבֶּעלְזָא זי"ע וְהָיָה לְאֶחָד מִתַּלְמִידָיו הַקְּרוֹבִים כְּשֶׁהוּא כָּרוּךְ אַחֲרָיו בִּדְבֵקוּת עֲצוּמָה...
חֲסִידוּת עֶרְלוֹי הִתְפַּתְּחָה בִּרְבוֹת הַשָּׁנִים בְּקֶצֶב מְסַחְרֵר, הָאַדְמוֹ"ר יָסַד בָּתֵּי כְּנֶסֶת וְכוֹלְלִים בְּרִכּוּזִים חֲרֵדִיִּים בְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל וּבְחוּ"ל הַקְּרוּיִים עַל שֵׁם אָבִיו הי"ד "סוֹפֵר". וְתַלְמוּדֵי תּוֹרָה עַל שֵׁם הַ"כְּתָב סוֹפֵר". בִּנְיְנֵי הַמּוֹסָדוֹת שֶׁל עֶרְלוֹי בְּגִבְעַת מֹשֶׁה שֶׁבִּירוּשָׁלַיִם קְרוּיִים ע"ש הַחֲתַ"ס, וּבָנָיו וּנְכָדָיו מְשַׁמְּשִׁים כְּרַבָּנֵי הַקְּהִלּוֹת וְרֹאשׁ הַכּוֹלְלִים שֶׁל הַחֲסִידוּת.
הָאַדְמוֹ"ר זצ"ל לֹא שִׁמֵּשׁ רַק רַבִּי וְגַאֲבָ"ד אֶלָּא הָיָה רֹאשׁ יְשִׁיבָה פָּעִיל בְּמֶשֶׁךְ כָּל חַיָּיו. סְפָרָיו עַל הַשַּׁ"ס יָצְאוּ לָאוֹר בְּשֵׁם "אִמְרֵי סוֹפֵר" עַל יְדֵי הַמָּכוֹן. וְכֵן סִפְרֵי "יוֹמִין דַּחֲנֻכָּה" וּ"אַפִּרְיוֹן חֲתָנִים". סֵדֶר יוֹמוֹ שֶׁל הָאַדְמוֹ"ר זצ"ל הָיָה רֶצֶף אֶחָד שֶׁל תּוֹרָה וְיִרְאַת שָׁמַיִם. בִּימוֹת הַחֹל הָיָה מוֹסֵר לַבַּחוּרִים שִׁעוּר בַּהֲלָכָה מִיָּד אַחַר תְּפִלַּת שַׁחֲרִית, וְכֵן שִׁעוּר יוֹמִי לַבַּחוּרִים הַמְּבֻגָּרִים, וּבָעֶרֶב שִׁעוּר בַּדַּף הַיּוֹמִי לְבַעֲלֵי בָּתִּים. הַשִּׁעוּר הַמֶּרְכָּזִי הָיָה הַ'שִׁעוּר כְּלָלִי' בִּימֵי שִׁשִּׁי. הָאַדְמוֹ"ר זצ"ל אַף נוֹדַע בִּפְסִיקוֹתָיו בַּהֲלָכָה וְכָתַב אַלְפֵי אַלְפֵי מִכְתְּבֵי תְּשׁוּבוֹת. הָאַדְמוֹ"ר זצ"ל הָיָה אַבָּא לִכְלַל חֲסִידָיו וְתַלְמִידָיו הָרַבִּים הַפְּזוּרִים בְּרַחֲבֵי הָאָרֶץ, וְהָיָה שֻׁתָּף מָלֵא בְּכָל הַחְלָטָה שֶׁל חָסִיד בְּחַיָּיו.
בְּחֹדֶשׁ אָב תש"ע בְּעֵת שְׁהוּתוֹ לִמְנוּחָה בְּשְׁוַויְץ לְצֹרֶךְ מְנוּחָה, עָבַר אֵרוּעַ מֹחִי קָשֶׁה וּמֵאָז נֶחֱלַשׁ, אַךְ בְּכָל זֹאת הִמְשִׁיךְ בְּסֵדֶר יוֹמוֹ בְּקַבָּלַת קָהָל וּבַעֲבוֹדַת הַקֹּדֶשׁ הַיּוֹמְיוֹמִית בְּיֶתֶר שְׂאֵת וּבְיֶתֶר עֹז. בְּשַׁבָּ"ק תְּרוּמָה הֶעָבָר אֻשְׁפַּז הרה"ק בְּבֵיה"ח עֵקֶב דַּלֶּקֶת רֵאוֹת ל"ע וְשָׁם הִתְדַּרְדֵּר מַצָּבוֹ עֵקֶב חַיְדַּק בְּגוּפוֹ ר"ל כַּאֲשֶׁר כָּל הַיַּהֲדוּת הַחֲרֵדִית עוֹקֶבֶת בִּדְאָגָה וְקוֹרַעַת שַׁעֲרֵי שָׁמַיִם בִּתְפִלּוֹת וְתַחֲנוּנִים לְקַיֵּם בָּנוּ חַכְמֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל, אַךְ לִפְנוֹת בֹּקֶר יוֹם ב' לְסֵדֶר כִּי תִּשָּׂא אֶת רֹאשׁ בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל י"ג אֲדָר חָשְׁכוּ הַמְּאוֹרוֹת בְּהִסְתַּלְּקוּתוֹ שֶׁל אוֹתוֹ גָּאוֹן וְצַדִּיק מֻפְלָא זצ"ל לְגִנְזֵי מְרוֹמִים זָקֵן וּשְׂבַע יָמִים בֶּן תִּשְׁעִים וְשָׁלוֹשׁ שָׁנָה. הֲמוֹנֵי עַמְּךָ בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּרָאשׁוּת גְּדוֹלֵי וּמְאוֹרֵי הַדּוֹר שֶׁסְּפָדוּהוּ תַּמְרוּרִים הִשְׁתַּתְּפוּ בַּהַלְוָיָתוֹ הַגְּדוֹלָה וּבְאַשְׁכַּבְתֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי שֶׁיָּצְאָה מִבֵּית מִדְרָשׁוֹ בְּקָטָמוֹן לְעֵבֶר בִּנְיַן מוֹסְדוֹת עֶרְלוֹי בִּרְחוֹב עֶזְרַת תּוֹרָה בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם תַּחַת גֶּשֶׁם שׁוֹטֵף מִשָּׁמַיִם שֶׁהוֹרִידוּ כְּנַחַל דִּמְעָה, וְחֶלְקַת מְחוֹקֵק סָפוּן בְּהַר הַמְּנוּחוֹת.
הָאַדְמוֹ"ר זצ"ל הוֹתִיר אַחֲרָיו מִשְׁפָּחָה עֲנֵפָה: בְּנוֹ בְּכוֹרוֹ הרה"צ רַבִּי מֹשֶׁה רַבָּם שֶׁל חֲסִידֵי עֶרְלוֹי שֶׁהֻכְתַּר לְמַמְלֵא מְקוֹם אָבִיו. וְכֵן הַבָּנִים הרה"צ רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב רַב קְהִלַּת "כְּתָב סוֹפֵר" בְּבֵיתָר עִילִית, הַגָּאוֹן רַבִּי אַבְרָהָם שְׁמוּאֵל בִּנְיָמִין רֹאשׁ יְשִׁיבַת אֹהֶל שִׁמְעוֹן עֶרְלוֹי, הרה"צ רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן רַב בֵּית הַמִּדְרָשׁ 'תּוֹרַת מֹשֶׁה' בְּעִיר צְפַת, הרה"צ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא מְנַחֵם רַב קְהִלַּת עֶרְלוֹי בִּבְנֵי בְּרַק, הרה"צ רַבִּי זַלְמָן רַב קְהִלַּת עֶרְלוֹי בְּבוֹרוֹ פַּארְק וְהרה"צ רַבִּי אַהֲרֹן רַב קְהִלַּת עֶרְלוֹי בְּאֶלְעָד, וּנְכָדִים וְנִינִים תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים וְיִרְאֵי שָׁמַיִם מַרְבִּים לְשֵׁם וּלְתִפְאֶרֶת. עִם פְּטִירָתוֹ אִבֵּד עוֹלָם הַחֲסִידוּת דְּמוּת נִשְׂגָּבָה שֶׁל גָּאוֹן וְצַדִּיק אֱמֶת מִשְּׁיָרֵי כְּנֶסֶת הַגְּדוֹלָה שֶׁעָבַד אֶת קוֹנוֹ יוֹמָם וָלַיְלָה בִּמְסִירַת נֶפֶשׁ בִּלְתִּי לַה' לְבַדּוֹ."בחצר הקודש", כי-תשא תשע"ו, עמ' ו'

...A brand plucked from the fire [was the C.K. Maran Admor of Erlau zt"l], who was in the valley of killing during the war that stormed with fury upon all its neighborhoods, and did not skip over the small town of Erlau under the presidency of the first Rebbe of Erlau, Rabbi Shimon Sofer zt"l, author of *Hisorerus Teshuva*, who was the son of the Ksav Sofer and grandson of our master, the Chasam Sofer.
In this house, he suckled the path of Maran the Chasam Sofer and followed his grandfather, observing every utterance of his mouth; every custom he practiced, he acquired and adopted for his daily conduct.
Years later, he told of the miracle of his wondrous rescue from the valley of the shadow of death and attributed it to the merit of the blessing of his grandfather, Rabbi Shimon Sofer zt"l. Upon his parting, he blessed him with an exceptionally long blessing with copious tears, that no evil should befall him at the hands of the oppressors, the Germans, may their names be blotted out. But when our master left his room, he called him back a second time and said to him: "Our grandfather the Chasam Sofer and Rabbi Akiva Eiger will accompany you at every step." And our master related that in every place or border he crossed, no policeman or soldier asked him for identification, and it was in the aspect of "seeing but not seen." Everything was in the merit of that old man's blessing.
Source: Marbeh LeTzama

body_he: לְיָמִים סִפֵּר אֶת נֵס הַצָּלָתוֹ הַמֻּפְלָאָה מִגֵּיא צַלְמָוֶת וְתָלָה בִּזְכוּת בִּרְכָתוֹ שֶׁל זְקָנוֹ רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן סוֹפֵר זצוק"ל, בִּפְרִידָתוֹ בֵּרְכוֹ בִּבְרָכָה אֲרֻכָּה בְּיוֹתֵר בְּדִמְעוֹת שָׁלִישׁ שֶׁלֹּא יְאֻנֶּה לוֹ כָּל רַע מִידֵי הַצּוֹרְרִים הַגֶּרְמָנִים ימ"ש, אַךְ יָצָא רַבֵּנוּ מֵחַדְרוֹ קְרָאוֹ לוֹ בַּשֵּׁנִית וְאָמַר לוֹ זְקֵנֵנוּ הַחֲתַ"ס וְרַעֲקַ"א יְלַוּוּ אוֹתְךָ בְּכָל צַעַד וְשַׁעַל, וְסִפֵּר רַבֵּנוּ שֶׁבְּכָל מָקוֹם אוֹ גְּבוּל שֶׁעָבַר אַף שׁוֹטֵר אוֹ חַיָּל לֹא בִּקְּשׁוֹ מִמֶּנּוּ לְהִזְדַּהוֹת וְהָיָה בִּבְחִינַת "רוֹאֶה וְאֵינוֹ נִרְאֶה" הַכֹּל בִּזְכוּת בִּרְכָתוֹ שֶׁל אוֹתוֹ זָקֵן.הרה"ג ר' מנחם מנדל סופר שליט"אראש כולל ערלוי-אלעד"אכסוף", כי-תשא תשע"ו, עמ' ב'
body_en:
HaRav HaChassid R' Beril Daskal Shlita, who was the attendant of my father zt"l after the war, tells that once he walked with him in Pest. While my father was busy with some matter, a woman approached him and asked who this young Rabbi walking with him was.
When he told her that he was the Rav of Erlau, she replied that she was impressed by him immediately after the war. She saw him standing in a place where representatives of the "Joint" organization stood and distributed food to refugees. There were masses of people standing in line asking to take food to revive their souls, but my father zt"l stood aside and looked into a book. Only when he saw that everyone had already taken did he approach and take his portion. And this was due to his extraordinary guarding of his eyes, which he was careful about all his days. Therefore, the woman wanted very much to know who this wondrous young man was.
Source: Olamot

Known and famous is the letter regarding the plagues in Egypt written by the Rebbe of Ostrovtza according to what our master the holy Arizal revealed to him. At the end of the letter, he notes terrible things, and this is his holy language: "After this, he informed me of this secret. Anyone who delves into this wondrous and awesome secret regarding its proper place even once a year, and especially on Erev Pesach, is guaranteed that he will be saved all year from any obstacle and unnatural death and any accident, and his enemies will not rule over him, and all his haters will fall beneath him, and in everything he turns to, he will succeed and prosper, Amen Selah..."
And so testified the Admor of Erlau (Shlita) [zt"l] that in the terrible days when Jewish blood was spilled like water, anyone who said this awesome letter was saved from the claws of the wicked and remained alive. He testified about himself that once he was in great danger in the middle of the month of Elul, and he remembered that in that year on Erev Pesach he did not have time to say the letter. Immediately and instantly, he said it, and indeed he was saved by miracles of miracles.
He also told about his holy grandfather, the author of *Hisorerus Teshuva* zy"a Hy"d, who lived to the age of 94. Every year, on Erev Pesach, he would study this awesome letter of the Rebbe of Ostrovtza zy"a. Aside from his last year, in which he did not read this letter, and indeed in that year, he ascended and was taken to the hidden treasuries on high.
Source: Be'er HaParasha

body_he:
וְכָךְ הֵעִיד כ"ק הָאַדְמוֹ"ר מֵעֶרְלוֹי (שליט"א) [זצוק"ל] שֶׁבִּימֵי הָאֵימִים עֵת נִשְׁפַּךְ דַּם יִשְׂרָאֵל כַּמַּיִם, כָּל מִי שֶׁאָמַר אֶת הַמִּכְתָּב הַנּוֹרָא הַלָּזֶה נִצּוֹל מִצִּפָּרְנֵי הָרְשָׁעִים וְנִשְׁאַר בַּחַיִּים, וְהֵעִיד עַל עַצְמוֹ שֶׁפַּעַם אַחַת הָיָה בְּסַכָּנָה גְּדוֹלָה בְּאֶמְצַע חֹדֶשׁ אֱלוּל, וְנִזְכַּר שֶׁבְּשָׁנָה זוֹ בְּעַרְבֵי פְסָחִים לֹא הָיָה סִפֵּק בְּיָדוֹ לוֹמַר אֶת הַמִּכְתָּב וְתֵיכֶף וּמִיָּד אֲמָרוֹ, וְאָכֵן נִצַּל בְּנִסֵּי נִסִּים.
עוֹד סִפֵּר עַל זְקִינוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בַּעַל הַ"הִתְעוֹרְרוּת תְּשׁוּבָה" זי"ע הי"ד שֶׁהִפְלִיג בְּזִקְנוּתוֹ עַד צ"ד שָׁנִים, וּבְכָל שָׁנָה וְשָׁנָה הָיָה לוֹמֵד בְּעֶרֶב פֶּסַח אֶת מִכְתָּבוֹ הַנּוֹרָא שֶׁל הרה"ק מֵאוֹסְטְרָאפָּאלִיעַ זי"ע לְבַד מִבִּשְׁנָתוֹ הָאַחֲרוֹנָה בָּהּ לֹא קָרָא זֶה הַמִּכְתָּב וְאָכֵן בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁנָה עָלָה וְנִתְעַלָּה לְגִנְזֵי מְרוֹמִים.הגה"צ רבי אלימלך בידרמן שליט"א"באר הפרשה", דברים תשע"ד, עמ' ז'
body_en:
...To what extent my father, master and teacher [the Admor of Erlau] zt"l was bound to the Torah of the Chasam Sofer can be learned from a fact told to me by a Jew. Our master gave him as a gift manuscripts of the *Chasam Sofer* which were printed by him, to a person who gave him in exchange manuscripts of others which had not yet been printed. The main thing was that he should be able to print more of the Torah of the Chasam Sofer.
Simultaneously, spreading Torah was important in his eyes. After the war, our master established the holy Yeshiva in Budapest, and later in Erlau, his hometown. The students were one from a city and two from a family, and the expenses to maintain the Yeshiva were many. In our master's bag remained, miraculously, a Siddur of the Chasam Sofer. But he had a different order of priorities: He sold this Siddur for one hundred dollars (which was a large sum then), reasoning that the Torah study of the young men was more important!...
Source: Marbeh LeTzama

body_he: בְּד בְּבַד, חֲשׁוּבָה הָיְתָה בְּעֵינָיו הַרְבָּצַת תּוֹרָה. לְאַחַר הַמִּלְחָמָה הֵקִים רַבֵּנוּ אֶת הַיְשִׁיבָה הַקְּדוֹשָׁה בְּבּוּדַפֶּשְׁט, וּלְאַחַר מִכֵּן בְּעֶרְלוֹי עִיר מוֹלַדְתּוֹ. הַתַּלְמִידִים הָיוּ אֶחָד מֵעִיר וּשְׁנַיִם מִמִּשְׁפָּחָה, וְהַהוֹצָאוֹת לְהַחְזָקַת הַיְשִׁיבָה הָיוּ רַבּוֹת. בְּאַמְתַּחְתּוֹ שֶׁל רַבֵּנוּ נוֹתַר בְּאֹרַח פֶּלֶא סִדּוּר שֶׁל הַחֲתַ"ס, אַךְ הָיָה לוֹ סֵדֶר עֲדִיפוּיוֹת שׁוֹנֶה: הוּא מָכַר אֶת הַסִּדּוּר הַזֶּה תְּמוּרַת מֵאָה דּוֹלָר (שֶׁהָיָה אָז סְכוּם גָּדוֹל), בְּנַמְּקוֹ, שֶׁלִּמּוּד הַתּוֹרָה שֶׁל הַבַּחוּרִים חָשׁוּב יוֹתֵר!...הגה"צ רבי אברהם שמואל בנימין סופר שליט"אראש ישיבת ערלוי(מרשימות הרב ישראל גרין שליט"א)"מרוה לצמא", פקודי תשע"ו, ע' 9
body_en:
When my father [the Admor of Erlau] zt"l met a certain young man whom the difficult events he experienced during the war [the Holocaust] had affected for the worse, and he had deteriorated and despaired greatly, his intention was to wander to developed countries and engage in business matters. My father zt"l, who understood that this matter was liable to cause his complete deterioration, tried to speak to his heart to come to him to his Yeshiva which he opened in the city of Erlau.
The young man tried to cancel the matter in his despair, saying that anyway he has no desire to study and he wants to start a new life, to enter a new world. But my father zt"l said to him: "Behold, I did not ask you to come study with us. My intention is only for the meantime, before you go out on the road, that you should have a place to sleep and something to eat. For you have no father and mother, and who will worry for your needs? Why shouldn't you come to the Yeshiva and stay with us, and afterwards travel wherever you wish?"
And so he succeeded in dragging the young man to the Yeshiva, and slowly drew him to the Beis Medrash with soft words, until the young man cleaved to my father zt"l with all his heart and soul. He began to study and serve Hashem within the walls of the Yeshiva in Erlau, until he merited to establish a faithful house in Israel in the USA, and remained G-d-fearing and whole until his last day.
Source: Olamot

When the Gaon Rabbi Yochanan Sofer, the Admor of Erlau zt"l, arrived in the Holy Land from Hungary, he established his Yeshiva in the Pag'i neighborhood in Jerusalem. In that period, I studied at the "Etz Chaim" Yeshiva, but from time to time I entered the Erlau Yeshiva and heard lessons from his mouth in Gemara and Shulchan Aruch. A close bond was formed between us, and even years later, he was happy to meet me and converse with me.
In his lessons on Shulchan Aruch, the Gaon Rabbi Yochanan zt"l was accustomed to change the order of the letters of the Siman number to avoid negative expressions, as is the known custom of Israel (famous examples are pronouncing "Rachatz" and "Shad'm"). When he taught Siman 244 (Resh-Mem-Dalet) in the laws of Shabbos, he used to reverse the order of the letters and say "Siman Resh-Dalet-Mem." This was because of a will from the *Chasam Sofer* in which it was said "In the books of RMD do not stretch out a hand"—the intention being the 'Maskil' Moshe Mendelssohn of Dessau (named after his origin, from the town of Dessau). Opinions are divided on what the letter Resh hints to—whether to "Rasha" (Wicked) Moshe Mendelssohn or to "Reb" Moshe Mendelssohn... but in any case, the intention was him.
Source: Leket VePeret

body_he: בְּשִׁעוּרָיו בַּשֻּׁלְחָן עָרוּךְ נָהַג הַגּר"י זצ"ל לְשַׁנּוֹת אֶת סֵדֶר הָאוֹתִיּוֹת שֶׁל מִסְפַּר-הַסִּימָן, כְּדֵי לְהִמָּנַע מִבִּטּוּיִים שְׁלִילִיִּים, כְּפִי מִנְהַג יִשְׂרָאֵל הַיָּדוּעַ (הַדֻּגְמָאוֹת הַמְפֻרְסָמוֹת הֵן לְבַטֵּא "רח"צ" וּ"שד"מ"). כְּשֶׁלִּמֵּד אֶת סִימָן רמ"ד בְּהִלְכוֹת שַׁבָּת, נָהַג לַהֲפֹךְ אֶת סֵדֶר הָאוֹתִיּוֹת וְלוֹמַר "סִימָן רד"מ". זֹאת, בְּשֶׁל צַוָּאָה מֵאֵת הַ"חֲתַם סוֹפֵר" בָּהּ נֶאֱמַר "בְּסִפְרֵי רמ"ד אַל תִּשְׁלְחוּ יָד" - כְּשֶׁהַכַּוָּנָה הָיְתָה לְ'מַשְׂכִּיל' מֹשֶׁה מַנְדֶּלְסוֹן דֶּעסוֹיר (עַל שֵׁם מוֹצָאוֹ, מֵהָעֲיָרָה דֶּסָאו). הַדֵּעוֹת חֲלוּקוֹת לְמָה מְרַמֶּזֶת הָאוֹת ר' - הַאִם לְ"רָשָׁע" מֹשֶׁה מַנְדֶּלְסוֹן אוֹ לְ"ר'" מֹשֶׁה מַנְדֶּלְסוֹן... אַךְ עַל כָּל פָּנִים, הַכַּוָּנָה הָיְתָה אֵלָיו.הרה"ח ר' טוביה בלוי שליט"א"לקט ופרט" (ירושלים תשע"ז) ח"ב, ע' פ"ח
body_en:
In one of the difficult years of the Yeshiva, when the money ran out completely and they did not know from where to pay salaries and feed the young men with bread and milk, the Rebbe [the Admor of Erlau zt"l] took the wanderer's staff and traveled as far as America. During the week, the Rebbe went around, and a student who lived in America and whose redemption (income) was very poor met him. On the threshold of despair, the student met an older bachelor around the age of forty. The student knew this bachelor and suggested to him that he donate to the Yeshiva and the Rebbe would bless him.
The bachelor answered him: "I am satiated with blessings. I only want a promise. If the Rebbe promises me a match, I will support the Yeshiva not for a month but for two months, including everything." The student jumped at the bargain and promised in the Rebbe's name.
When he returned to the inn, he told the story to the Rebbe. The Rebbe refused to agree to receive the bachelor, saying: "To bless—yes, happily. To pray—certainly. To promise—no!" The student said that they hadn't even paid the travel fare yet, and the Rebbe on his part cannot promise. The student pleaded for his soul and told him that he had already promised and it would be unpleasant for him, and he would be a laughingstock in his eyes if the promise wasn't kept.
When the Rebbe heard that the honor and good name of the student were at stake, and as a sign of gratitude, he told him: "Okay, I agree, but this is the last time you promise things like this. And furthermore, do not make deals." Needless to note that within a month, the bachelor became engaged.
Source: Olamot

The Erlau Rav (Shlita) [zt"l], who is a grandson of the Chasam Sofer, arrived at the Tish of Mahara of Belz zy"a. They seated him in the sixth row. Before Mahara entered, he inquired who was sitting at the table and where he was sitting. When he found out that they had seated him so far away, he immediately commanded to bring him closer, saying that one does not seat the grandson of the Chasam Sofer until he is brought close.
Source: Ma'ayan HaBracha

...The mouth of my father [the Admor of Erlau] zt"l was pure and clean. His language was gold and eloquent. He was very particular about cleanliness of speech and was incapable of uttering derogatory words. Thus, in the Zemiros for Motzaei Shabbos, where we say "Purify the filth of my deeds," he would skip and say only "Purify my deeds."
Our master, the definitive man of Halacha, when he read the weekly portion twice in Hebrew and once in Targum (Shnayim Mikra V'Echad Targum), did not utter from his mouth the word for the animal "Davar Acher" (pig), mentioned in Parshas Shemini, but would think it... Also, the word "Choleh" (sick) he would not utter from his mouth, but would say "Lo Bari" (not healthy). This was built into his very essence: purity, cleanliness, and refinement.
Source: Marbeh LeTzama

The magnitude of the feeling and love of the Admor of Erlau zt"l for Eretz Yisrael was expressed in many of his behaviors. For example, it was a common sight to see the Rebbe changing the route of his walk according to the position of the sun's rise, careful to walk in the shade. This was in order not to come to a suspicion of complaining about the dwelling of Eretz Yisrael (i.e., complaining about the heat).
And once, while conversing with one of his close associates about a certain sea abroad, and the person wanted to know its size, the Rebbe told him that it is, "Lehavdil" (to distinguish), like the Sea of Galilee (Kinneret)... For him, it was clear that what is abroad is "Lehavdil" from what is in the Holy Land.
Source: Halichos Malchei Bakodesh

My righteous aunt, Rebbetzin Devorah a"h, wife of the Gaon and Tzaddik Rabbi Shimon Menashe Chaikin Zt"l - Rabbi of the City of the Patriarchs, Hebron - related:
Once, she entered the home of the Holy Rabbi R' Elazar Mendel of Lelov Zy"a to ask for a blessing and success in a certain matter. Amidst the conversation, Rabbi Elazar Mendel inquired about the customs and ways of her husband, Rabbi Shimon Menashe. He explained the meaning of his inquiry, saying thus:
"It is the way of the world that when a craftsman meets another craftsman, he is interested and wants to learn from the other craftsman more ideas and inventions in the work of his craft."
Source: Lev Yisrael

...When we merited to witness the service of Hashem on Shabbos and Holidays with the Admor of Erlau zt"l, especially in the month of Eitanim (Tishrei), there was a fire of holiness. On the Yom Tov of Sukkos, he would remain awake all night to fulfill the positive commandment from the Torah of taking the Lulav immediately in the morning. At the time when they could already take the Lulav, he would take the Four Species with immense joy like one finding great spoil.
He was particular to be in the Sukkah the entire time without interruption at all. All the classes were delivered in the Sukkah, and he studied with study partners in the Sukkah. Also, the three prayers, whether on Yom Tov or Chol Hamoed, were only in the Sukkah. And he merited that even in his last year, all the Sukkos days were inside the Sukkah.
It was fluent in his mouth to say that just as it is forbidden to leave empty vessels that were eaten from in the Sukkah because it is disrespectful to the Sukkah, so too it is forbidden for people to be "empty" (idle) while in the Sukkah. He had already begun to awaken about this before the Yom Tov to study the laws of Sukkah so that we would not be empty on Yom Tov.
Source: Olamot

One year, my father zt"l fell ill with kidney stones and was hospitalized. The doctors spoke of surgery. On Shabbos Chol Hamoed, it is customary to say Koheles, and with us, they read it publicly. The Rebbe [the Admor of Erlau zt"l] commanded the reader to read three times the words "**A time to cast away stones and a time to gather stones**" (Koheles 3:5). After the reading, the Rebbe said to me: "You surely understand my intention."
In the X-ray that was conducted in preparation for the surgery, the doctors were amazed to discover that the stones had disappeared.
Source: Marbeh LeTzama

I heard from one of the distinguished sons of the Gaon HaTzaddik the Admor of Erlau zt"l about an incident he saw in his holy father's house, which was deeply engraved in his memory. It was decades ago. While he was still in his youth, one day he saw his father walking around the house with immense excitement, completely filled with great joy, his heart singing in thanksgiving to the Living G-d!
When the young man asked innocently before his father, "What is different about this day? And what is this joy doing?" the Rav answered him that for some time he had been walking around perplexed by a difficulty that troubled him greatly in the study of a Sugya! He sat extensively on this mortar (problem) and did not succeed in raising a clear matter in his hand. And behold, this day, on its Sabbath rest regarding his study, he struggled again and again in clarifying the depth of the Halacha. It was renewed in his mind, by the gift of the Gracious Giver of Knowledge who gives the Torah, blessed be He—a tremendous and wondrous Chiddush (novelty) that straightens all the difficulties and pours a wondrous light on the entire Sugya, which is now illuminating and clear!
Immediately, the great father sat down with his son at the study table and began to present before him his beautiful Chiddush, dismantling difficulties and breaking rocks, until everything came to its place in peace, and the words were joyous as when they were given from Sinai!
When they finished their study, the Rebbe remarked to his son, the Chassan, that he would not sell this Chiddush to the world, not even for the price of seventy million dollars!!! [$70,000,000].
The son was astonished and wondered: Are Chiddushim lacking for Father? After all, every single day Chiddushim 'pour out' like an overflowing spring in Torah, and the many books will testify and tell! Is it impossible with one less Chiddush... for seventy million dollars! For the need of maintaining the holy Yeshiva for many long years, so that the father would not need to crush his holy feet traveling around the world for weeks and months for the building and maintenance of the holy institutions?
"Far shteist nisht! [You don't understand!]" said the Rebbe. "After all, even if a tycoon, one of the supporters of the Yeshiva and maintainers of the institutions, had arrived here yesterday with an offer of a donation of seventy million good and heavy dollars! And they would ask me: What do you want more? These seventy million, or one such Chiddush that settles the entire learned Sugya? Is it not obvious that I would jump to choose this beautiful Chiddush? Its value rises many, many times over thousands of gold and silver!!!"
Source: Tiv HaKehila

כְּשֶׁשָּׁאַל הַבָּחוּר לְתֻמּוֹ לִפְנֵי אָבִיו, מַה יוֹם מִיּוֹמַיִם? וּלְשִׂמְחָה מַה זּוֹ עוֹשָׂה? - עָנָה לוֹ הָרַב, שֶׁזֶּה עִדָּן שֶׁהוּא מִתְהַלֵּךְ נָבוֹךְ בְּקֻשְׁיָא אַחַת שֶׁהֵצִיקָה לוֹ מְאוֹד בְּלִמּוּד הַסּוּגְיָא! רַבּוֹת יָשַׁב עַל מְדוֹכָה זוֹ, וְלֹא הִצְלִיחַ לְהַעֲלוֹת דָּבָר בָּרוּר בְּיָדוֹ. וְהִנֵּה זֶה הַיּוֹם בְּשִׁבְתּוֹ רָכוּן עַל תַּלְמוּדוֹ, מִתְחַבֵּט שׁוּב וָשׁוּב בְּבֵרוּר עֻמְקָהּ שֶׁל הֲלָכָה, נִתְחַדֵּשׁ בְּשִׂכְלוֹ, בְּמַתְּנַת חוֹנֵן הַדַּעַת נוֹתֵן הַתּוֹרָה בָּ"ה, חִדּוּשׁ עָצוּם וְנִפְלָא, הַמְיַשֵּׁר אֶת כָּל הַהֲדוּרִים, וְשׁוֹפֵךְ אוֹר מֻפְלָא בְּכָל הַסּוּגְיָא, שֶׁמֵּעַתָּה הֲרֵי הִיא מְאִירָה וּבְהִירָה!
תֵּיכֶף הִתְיַשֵּׁב הָאָב הַגָּדוֹל עִם בְּנוֹ לְשֻׁלְחַן הַלִּמּוּד, וְהֵחֵל לְהַרְצוֹת בְּפָנָיו אֶת חִדּוּשׁוֹ הַנָּאֶה, מְפָרֵק הֲוָיוֹת וּמְשַׁבֵּר סְלָעִים, עַד שֶׁהַכֹּל בָּא עַל מְקוֹמוֹ בְּשָׁלוֹם, וְהָיוּ הַדְּבָרִים שְׂמֵחִים כִּנְתִינָתָן מִסִּינַי!
מִשֶּׁסִּיְּמוּ אֶת לִמּוּדָם, הִפְטִיר הָרַבִּי לִבְנוֹ הַח', שֶׁאֶת הַחִדּוּשׁ הַזֶּה אֵינוֹ מוֹכֵר לְעוֹלָם, אַף לֹא בִּמְחִיר שֶׁל שִׁבְעִים מִילְיוֹן דּוֹלָר!!! [$70,000,000].
הִתְפַּלֵּא הַבֵּן וְתָמַהּ, וְכִי חֲסֵרִים לְאַבָּא חִדּוּשִׁים? הֲרֵי מִדֵּי יוֹם בְּיוֹמוֹ 'נִשְׁפָּכִים' כָּאן חִדּוּשִׁים כְּמַעְיָן הַמִּתְגַּבֵּר בַּתּוֹרָה, וְהַסְּפָרִים הָרַבִּים יָעִידוּן יַגִּידוּן! וְכִי אִי אֶפְשָׁר בְּחִדּוּשׁ אֶחָד פָּחוֹת... בִּשְׁבִיל שִׁבְעִים מִילְיוֹן דּוֹלָר! לְצֹרֶךְ הַחְזָקַת הַיְשִׁיבָה הַקְּדוֹשָׁה לְשָׁנִים רַבּוֹת וַאֲרֻכּוֹת, כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יִצְטָרֵךְ הָאַבָּא לְכַתֵּת אֶת רַגְלָיו קָדְשׁוֹ בְּרַחֲבֵי תֵּבֵל שָׁבוּעוֹת וָחֳדָשִׁים בִּשְׁבִיל בִּנְיַן וְהַחְזָקַת הַמּוֹסָדוֹת הַקְּדוֹשִׁים?
פָאר שְׁטֵייסְט נִישְׁט! [אֵינְךָ מֵבִין!] - אָמַר הָרַבִּי, הֲרֵי גַּם אִם הָיָה מַגִּיעַ כָּאן אֶתְמוֹל לְהֵיכַל הַיְשִׁיבָה הַק' אֶחָד מִן הַנְּגִידִים תּוֹמְכֵי הַיְשִׁיבָה וּמַחְזִיקֵי הַמּוֹסָדוֹת, בְּהַצָּעַת תְּרוּמָה הֲגוּנָה שֶׁל שִׁבְעִים מִילְיוֹן דּוֹלָר טָבִין וּתְקִילִין! וְהָיוּ שׁוֹאֲלִין מִמֶּנִּי, בְּמַאי בָּעִית טְפֵי? בְּאֵלּוּ שִׁבְעִים הַמִּילְיוֹן, אוֹ בְּחִדּוּשׁ אֶחָד כָּזֶה אֲשֶׁר מְיַשֵּׁב אֶת כָּל הַסּוּגְיָא הַנִּלְמֶדֶת. - הֲלֹא פְּשִׁיטָא שֶׁהָיִיתִי קוֹפֵץ לִבְחֹר בְּחִדּוּשׁ נָאֶה זֶה. הָעוֹלֶה בְּעֶרְכּוֹ פִּי כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה מֵאַלְפֵי זָהָב וָכֶסֶף!!!הרה"צ רבי גמליאל הכהן רבינוביץ שליט"א"טיב הקהילה", במדבר תשע"ז, עמ' ז'

A man of his trust, our teacher Rabbi Yaakov Shalom Fisher, told a story he witnessed: During the stay of our master [the Admor of Erlau zt"l] in the hospital in Switzerland. Emotional prayers were held in the halls of Torah and in all centers of Chareidi Jewry due to his severe head injury. His condition was then defined as very critical. In a consultation of the expert doctors who visited the hospital, they decided to sedate him. The sons of our master, the Gaonim Rabbis, requested with a decisive request that no nurse should approach him, as he stood guard over holiness so that the request would not be violated.
One day, one of the nurses entered his room and approached him to check one of the devices to which he was connected. At that second, his entire body shook, and he raised his voice in a loud cry calling his son's name. A scene contrary to nature: an extremely old man suffering from a severe head injury and additionally in a deep coma, wakes up like a lion and cries out in the face of the slight doubt regarding what touches the bird of his soul (his essence). It left a tremendous impression on all who saw and heard him and quickly turned into the talk of the day in the hospital, causing a sanctification of Heaven's Name among all the peoples of the land.
Source: Tiv HaKehila

body_he: בְּאֶחָד הַיָּמִים נִכְנְסָה אַחַת הָאֲחָיוֹת לְחַדְרוֹ וְאָז קָרְבָה אֵלָיו כְּדֵי לִבְדֹּק אֶת אֶחָד הַמַּכְשִׁירִים אֲלֵיהֶם הָיָה מְחֻבָּר. בְּאוֹתָהּ שְׁנִיָּה הִזְדַּעְזַע כָּל גּוּפוֹ וְהוּא נָשָׂא קוֹלוֹ בִּזְעָקָה רָמָה כְּשֶׁהוּא נוֹקֵב שֵׁם בְּנוֹ. מַחֲזֶה עַל טִבְעִי זֶה בּוֹ יָשִׁישׁ מֻפְלָג הַסּוֹבֵל מִפְּגִיעַת רֹאשׁ קָשָׁה וּבְנוֹסָף לְכָךְ שָׁרוּי בְּתַרְדֶּמֶת עֲמֻקָּה מִתְעוֹרֵר כַּאֲרִי וּמִזְדַּעֵק נֹכַח הַסָּפֵק הַקַּל בְּיוֹתֵר בִּדְבַר הַנּוֹגֵעַ לְצִפּוֹר נַפְשׁוֹ - הוֹתִיר רֹשֶׁם כַּבִּיר עַל כָּל רוֹאָיו וְשׁוֹמְעָיו וְהָפַךְ עַד מְהֵרָה לְשִׁיחַת הַיּוֹם בְּבֵית הָרְפוּאָה תּוֹךְ שֶׁהוּא גּוֹרֵם לְקִדּוּשׁ שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם בְּקֶרֶב כָּל עַמֵּי הָאָרֶץ.הרב שמואל צבי גנץ שליט"א"המודיע-תוספת" אדר-ב' תשע"ו, ע' ל"א
body_en:
With the Admor [of Erlau] zt"l, there was constantly a feeling in the air of "You do not fear the Sanctuary, but Him who warned about the Sanctuary" (Yevamos 6b). This feeling was expressed in his extreme caution regarding the laws of Brachos (blessings).
Wherever there was any opinion not to bless, he would ask someone else to exempt us with their blessing. So too regarding eating less than the required amount, and so too regarding the blessing on half-Hallel. For the Seven Blessings, he would not recite the blessing because it was not a "House of Groom" (Beis Chasanus), and so on. This conduct was influenced by his stay with the Rebbe of Belz zy"a, who, as is known, had many stringencies regarding blessings. However, the Rebbe never said he learned from the Belzer Rebbe to be stringent with blessings, but his style was always: "By the Belzer Rebbe, we learned how to fear uttering the Name of Heaven."
Once, the Rebbe suffered severe back pains, and every movement from his chair caused him agony. At that time, prayers were held in his home. At Seudah Shlishit, during the Grace after Meals, he exerted himself with self-sacrifice to stand during the saying of "Let us bless our G-d." One of the Rabbis sitting next to him remarked in wonder: "But his grandfather the Chasam Sofer writes that one does not need to stand?" The Rebbe replied to him trembling: "But we are speaking here of the honor of the Honorable Name, and how can I sit?!"
Source: Halichos Malchei Bakodesh

body_he: פַּעַם אַחַת סָבַל הָרַבִּי מִכְּאֵבִים עַזִּים בְּגַבּוֹ, וְכָל תְּנוּדָה מִכִּסְאוֹ הֵסֵבָּה לוֹ יִסּוּרִים. בְּאוֹתוֹ זְמַן נֶעֶרְכוּ הַתְּפִלּוֹת בְּבֵיתוֹ, וּבִסְעוּדָה שְׁלִישִׁית בְּעֵת בִּרְכַּת הַזִּמּוּן הִתְאַמֵּץ בִּמְסִירַת נֶפֶשׁ לַעֲמֹד בְּעֵת אֲמִירַת 'נְבָרֵךְ לֵאלֹקֵינוּ'. אֶחָד מֵהָרַבָּנִים שֶׁיָּשַׁב לְצִדּוֹ הֵעִיר בִּתְמִיהָה: הֲרֵי זְקִינוֹ הַחֲתַם סוֹפֵר כּוֹתֵב שֶׁאֵין צָרִיךְ לַעֲמֹד?. הֱשִׁיבוֹ הָרַבִּי בִּרְעָדָה: "אֲבָל מְדֻבָּר כָּאן מִכְּבוֹד הַשֵּׁם הַנִּכְבָּד, וְאֵיךְ אֵשֵׁב"?!הרה"ג ר' יצחק יהודה דויטש שליט"א"הליכות מלכי בקודש" (ניסן תשע"ו) ע' כ"ז
body_en:
Once, when [the Admor of Erlau zt"l] was busy with a certain public matter and his name was involved in an unwanted way, his son asked him if it wouldn't be better to engage in Torah all day and not get involved in any matter, and thus be accepted by all circles, to sit in the "height of the world," accepted by everyone without worries.
Our master answered him: "After 120 years, when they ask me why I didn't answer so-and-so? Why didn't I reveal your opinion on this matter? What will I answer? That I wanted to sit in the 'height of the world' without worries and be accepted by everyone? How will I not be ashamed at that moment?"
Indeed, our master did not fear and waived his honor in many matters to speak his opinion, especially regarding the sanctity of Shabbos and the sanctity of Jerusalem; he sacrificed his soul for them without any fear or dread of man.
Source: Halichos Malchei Bakodesh

**And He Shall Live by Them**
A discourse from the Chasam Sofer zt"l on the verse (Vayikra 18:5): **ושמרתם את חקתי ואת משפטי אשר יעשה אתם האדם וחי בהם אני ה'** - "You shall keep My statutes and My judgments, which if a man does, he shall live by them: I am Hashem." The Chasam Sofer explains that the way of service that the Holy One, Blessed be He, demands from the Children of Israel is to fulfill the commandments of Hashem, His statutes and judgments, in such a way that it adds vitality and strength to the Heavenly host. When a Jew fulfills a commandment with joy and cleaving, then "And he shall live by them, I am Hashem"—as if to say, this causes vitality to the Heavenly host.
We added a nuance based on another discourse of the Chasam Sofer zy"a, that the Holy One, Blessed be He, warned the priests (Vayikra 10:9): **יין ושכר אל תשת אתה ובניך אתך בבאכם אל אהל מועד** - "Do not drink wine or strong drink, you, nor your sons with you, when you go into the Tent of Meeting." The matter of the warning not to perform the service while intoxicated with wine is because it is known that a Jew who drinks wine for the sake of Heaven increases joy within himself, as it is written (Tehillim 104:15): **ויין ישמח לבב אנוש** - "And wine that makes glad the heart of man." But the holy priests should not have an external thing causing them joy in the service of Hashem. Only the very privilege of performing the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, should bring immense joy into them. Therefore, do not drink wine and strong drink during the holy service.
And with this, one can interpret the aforementioned verse: "You shall keep My statutes and My judgments, which if a man does, he shall live by them"—this will be his vitality, that he has the privilege to fulfill the will of Hashem and to keep His statutes and commandments of the King, the King of Kings, the Holy One, Blessed be He.
Source: Bechatzer Hakodesh

וְהוֹסַפְנוּ נוֹפֶךְ עַל דִּבְרֵי הַחֲתַ"ס עַל פִּי מַאֲמָר אַחֵר שֶׁל הַחֲתַם סוֹפֵר זי"ע, שֶׁהַקָּבָּ"ה הִזְהִיר לַכֹּהֲנִים (שָׁם י', ט') "יַיִן וְשֵׁכָר אַל תֵּשְׁתְּ אַתָּה וּבָנֶיךָ אִתָּךְ בְּבֹאֲכֶם אֶל אֹהֶל מוֹעֵד" וְגוֹ', עִנְיַן הָאַזְהָרָה שֶׁלֹּא לַעֲשׂוֹת הָעֲבוֹדָה שְׁתוּיֵי יַיִן הוּא כִּי יָדוּעַ שֶׁיְּהוּדִי הַשּׁוֹתֶה יַיִן לְשֵׁם שָׁמַיִם מִתְרַבֶּה אֶצְלוֹ הַשִּׂמְחָה כְּמַ"שׁ (תְּהִלִּים ק"ד, ט"ו) "וְיַיִן יְשַׂמַּח לְבַב אֱנוֹשׁ", וְהַכֹּהֲנִים הַקְּדוֹשִׁים אַל לָהֶם לִהְיוֹת שֶׁדָּבָר חִיצוֹנִי יִגְרֹם לָהֶם שִׂמְחָה בַּעֲבוֹדַת ה', רַק זֶה לְבַד שֶׁיֵּשׁ לָהֶם הַזְּכִיָּה לַעֲשׂוֹת צִוּוּי הַקָּבָּ"ה צָרִיךְ לְהַכְנִיס בָּהֶם שִׂמְחָה עֲצוּמָה, וְלָכֵן יַיִן וְשֵׁכָר אַל תֵּשְׁתְּ עֲבוֹדַת הַקֹּדֶשׁ.
וּבָזֶה אֶפְשָׁר לְפָרֵשׁ הַפָּסוּק הַנַּ"ל, וּשְׁמַרְתֶּם אֶת חֻקֹּתַי וְאֶת מִשְׁפָּטַי אֲשֶׁר יַעֲשֶׂה אוֹתָם הָאָדָם וָחַי בָּהֶם, זֹאת תִּהְיֶה הַחִיּוּת שֶׁלּוֹ שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ זְכִיָּה לְקַיֵּם רְצוֹן ה' וְלִשְׁמֹר חֻקּוֹתָיו וּמִצְווֹתָיו שֶׁל מֶלֶךְ מַלְכֵי הַמְּלָכִים הַקָּבָּ"ה.כ"ק מרן אדמו"ר מערלוי זצוק"לבשיחת קדשו - י"א אייר תשס"ו"בחצר הקודש", כי-תשא תשע"ו, ע' ל"א

**Biography**
The Holy Rabbi Shalom Yosef of Bohush-Shpikov zt"l was born in the year 5638 (1878) to his father, the Admor HaRav HaTzaddik R' Dovid zt"l, son of the Holy Rabbi Yitzchak of Bohush zt"l. In the year 5657 (1897), he married the Rebbetzin Feiga, daughter of the Holy Rabbi Mordechai of Shpikov zt"l. After his marriage, he began to lead his holy flock in the city of Shpikov, and many of the Ruzhin Chassidim in Russia sought refuge in his shadow. He passed away on the 14th of Adar, 5680 (1920), and his resting place is in Shpikov near his holy father-in-law.
Source: Baalotz Tzadikim

When my grandfather, the C.K. Maran Admor [of Bohush] zy"a, traveled twenty years ago to the town of Shpikov to the resting place of his holy father, our master of Shpikov zy"a, while standing at the holy gravesite, he said with immense emotion: "From my holy father I cannot speak; pour out your heart like water, from my father I cannot speak..."
Afterward, my grandfather, Maran Admor zy"a, mentioned what he was accustomed to tell almost every year: the unfolding of the matter of how his father became a groom in Shpikov. The story was as follows: The Sadigura Chassidim who lived in Skver opened a *Kloiz* (synagogue) for themselves, and this matter caused some bitterness between the two courts. Between the two Tzaddikim—who were brothers-in-law even before this—great love prevailed, and they were not pleased with this situation. Immediately and instantly, they straightened out the difficulties between them.
In those days, the custom was that when they wanted to strengthen peace between two courts, they would make a match between them. Since at that time there was no candidate for marriage in Sadigura, the Admor of Sadigura zy"a sent a messenger—or a letter—to C.K. Maran Admor the First, Rabbi Yitzchak [of Bohush] zy"a, to ask if he had anyone who could make a match with the holy court of Skver. Maran Admor the First zy"a answered and said: "Yes, I have a grandson who has turned three years old, and it is already possible to match him."
And so, the Rebbe of Shpikov zy"a became a groom to the Holy Rabbi Mordechai of Shpikov zy"a, who was the grandson of the Holy Rabbi R' Yitzchak of Skver zy"a.
In those years, matches were made only through messengers or letters, and they did not know and did not recognize the groom or the bride at all, especially since they were small children. After a few years, they sent from Shpikov one of the important Chassidim and great men of opinion to Bohush to wonder at the character of the designated groom.
The messenger stayed for the entire month of Tishrei in the holy court in Bohush. On one of the days of Chol Hamoed Sukkos, the messenger entered the Sukkah of Maran Admor the First zy"a together with the groom, the Rebbe of Shpikov zy"a, and they conversed together. During the conversation, Maran Admor the First zy"a asked the groom to leave, and conversed privately with the messenger.
When the messenger left, the Rebbe of Shpikov zy"a asked him what the Rebbe had said to him. The messenger replied: "The Rebbe told me, 'I am sending a *Chacham* (wise man) to Russia.'" When the Rebbe of Shpikov zy"a heard these words, he burst into terrible weeping until he fainted.
Because the custom of Maran Admor the First zy"a was that he would give his sons to stay for 'Kest' (board/support) at their father-in-law's for only six weeks, and afterwards they returned immediately to the holy court in Bohush. Except for Maran Admor the *Birchas Moshe* of Pashkan zy"a, who became a groom to his uncle the Holy Rabbi Nachum Ber'enyu zy"a, in whose honor his brother, Maran Admor the First zy"a, allowed him to stay there for two years. From the fact that Maran Admor the First zy"a said he was sending him to Russia, the Rebbe of Shpikov zy"a understood that at his wedding he would no longer be the First Admor in this world, and therefore he fainted from the magnitude of the sorrow.
In any case, the definition of Maran Admor the First, Rabbi Yitzchak [of Bohush] zy"a regarding him was that he is sending a *Chacham* to Russia.
My grandfather, Maran Admor zy"a, also told of the magnitude of his father the Rebbe of Shpikov zy"a's connection to his grandfather, Maran Admor the First [of Bohush] zy"a, who was actually his grower (raised him), that not a day passed that he did not converse about his holy grandfather.
My grandfather, Maran Admor zy"a, told that at the time of his holy father's funeral, which was on Purim, the people accompanying him cried out "**Doresh Tov L'Amo**" (Esther 10:3). Seemingly, the intention of the Rebbe zy"a in telling this was to say: Leave Israel alone; if they are not prophets, they are the sons of prophets. Apparently, this was the aspect of the owner of the celebration, the Rebbe of Shpikov zy"a.
Source: Amrei Kodesh

אַחַר כָּךְ הִזְכִּיר זְקִינִי מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר זי"ע אֶת מַה שֶּׁהָיָה רָגִיל לְסַפֵּר כִּמְעַט בְּכָל הַשָּׁנִים, הִשְׁתַּלְשְׁלוּת הָעִנְיָן הָאֵיךְ נַעֲשָׂה אָבִיו חָתָן בִּשְׁפִּיקוֹב. וּמַעֲשֶׂה שֶׁהָיָה כָּךְ הָיָה. חֲסִידֵי סַאדִיגוּרָא שֶׁהִתְגּוֹרְרוּ בְּסְקְוִוירָא, פָּתְחוּ לְעַצְמָם קְלוֹיְז, וְהַדָּבָר גָּרַם לְהִתְמַרְמְרוּת מָה בֵּין שְׁנֵי הַחֲצֵרוֹת. בֵּין שְׁנֵי הַצַּדִּיקִים - שֶׁאַף הָיוּ גִּיסִים קֹדֶם לְכָךְ - שָׁרְרָה אַהֲבָה גְּדוֹלָה וְלֹא הָיָה נִיחָא לְהוּ בְּמַצָּב זֶה, וְתֵיכֶף וּמִיָּד יִשְּׁרוּ בֵּינֵיהֶם אֶת הַהֲדוּרִים.
בְּאוֹתָם הַיָּמִים הָיָה הַמִּנְהָג, כְּשֶׁרָצוּ לְחַזֵּק אֶת הַשָּׁלוֹם בֵּין שְׁנֵי חֲצֵרוֹת הָיוּ נוֹהֲגִים לְהִשְׁתַּדֵּךְ בֵּינֵיהֶם, וְהֱיוֹת שֶׁבְּאוֹתוֹ הַזְּמַן לֹא הָיָה בְּסַדִיגוּרָא אֵיזֶהוּ מוּעֲמָד לְשִׁדּוּכִין שִׁיגֵר כ"ק אַדְמוֹה"ז מִסַּאדִיגוּרָא זי"ע שָׁלִיחַ - אוֹ מִכְתָּב - אֶל כ"ק מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִאשׁוֹן רַבִּי יִצְחָק [מִבָּאהוּשׁ] זי"ע לְשָׁאֲלוֹ אִם יֵשׁ אֶצְלוֹ מִישֶׁהוּ שֶׁיּוּכַל לְהִשְׁתַּדֵּךְ עִם חֲצַה"ק סְקְוִוירָא. נַעֲנָה מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִאשׁוֹן זי"ע וְאָמַר, הֵן, יֵשׁ לִי נֶכֶד שֶׁמָּלְאוּ לוֹ ג' שָׁנִים וּכְבָר אֶפְשָׁר לְשַׁדְּכוֹ. וְכָךְ נַעֲשָׂה הָרַבִּי מִשְּׁפִּיקוֹב זי"ע חָתָן אֵצֶל הרה"ק רַבִּי מָרְדְּכַי מִשְּׁפִּיקוֹב זי"ע שֶׁהָיָה נֶכְדּוֹ שֶׁל הרה"ק ר' יִצְחָק מִסְּקְוִוירָא זי"ע.
בְּאוֹתָם שָׁנִים נַעֲשׂוּ הַשִּׁדּוּכִים רַק עַל יְדֵי שְׁלִיחִים אוֹ מִכְתָּבִים, וְלֹא יָדְעוּ וְלֹא הִכִּירוּ כְּלָל לֹא אֶת הֶחָתָן וְלֹא אֶת הַכַּלָּה, וּמַה גַּם שֶׁיְּלָדִים קְטַנִּים הָיוּ. כַּעֲבוֹר כַּמָּה שָׁנִים שָׁלְחוּ מִשְּׁפִּיקוֹב אֶת אַחַד הַחֲסִידִים הַחֲשׁוּבִים וּמִגְּדוֹלֵי בַּעֲלֵי הַדֵּעָה לְבָאהוּשׁ שֶׁיִּתְהֶה עַל קַנְקַנּוֹ שֶׁל הֶחָתָן הַמְּיֹעָד.
הַשָּׁלִיחַ שָׁהָה בְּמֶשֶׁךְ כָּל חֹדֶשׁ תִּשְׁרֵי בַּחֲצַר הַקֹּדֶשׁ בְּבָאהוּשׁ אֵצֶל כ"ק מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִאשׁוֹן זי"ע. בְּאֶחָד מִימֵי חוֹל הַמּוֹעֵד סֻכּוֹת נִכְנַס הַשָּׁלִיחַ אֶל סֻכָּתוֹ שֶׁל מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִאשׁוֹן זי"ע יַחַד עִם הֶחָתָן הָרַבִּי מִשְּׁפִּיקוֹב זי"ע וְשׂוֹחֲחוּ יַחַד. בְּתוֹךְ הַדְּבָרִים בִּקֵּשׁ מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִאשׁוֹן זי"ע מֵהֶחָתָן שֶׁיֵּצֵא, וְשׂוֹחַח בִּיחִידוּת עִם הַשָּׁלִיחַ. כְּשֶׁהַשָּׁלִיחַ יָצָא שְׁאָלוֹ הָרַבִּי מִשְּׁפִּיקוֹב זי"ע, מַה אָמַר לְךָ הָרַבִּי. הֱשִׁיבוֹ הַשָּׁלִיחַ, הָרַבִּי אָמַר לִי "אֲנִי שׁוֹלֵחַ חָכָם לְרוּסְלַאנְד". כִּשְׁמוֹעַ הָרַבִּי מִשְּׁפִּיקוֹב זי"ע דִּבּוּרִים אֵלּוּ, פָּרַץ בְּבֶכִי נוֹרָא עַד שֶׁנִּתְעַלֵּף. מִשּׁוּם שֶׁמִּנְהָגוֹ שֶׁל מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִאשׁוֹן זי"ע הָיָה, שֶׁהָיָה נוֹתֵן לְבָנָיו לָשֶׁבֶת 'קֶעסְט' אֵצֶל חוֹתְנָם רַק שִׁשָּׁה שָׁבוּעוֹת, וְאַחַר כָּךְ חָזְרוּ מִיָּד לַחֲצַר הַקֹּדֶשׁ בְּבָאהוּשׁ. לְבַד מִמָּרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר הַבִּרְכַּת מֹשֶׁה מִפָּאשְׁקָאן זי"ע שֶׁנַּעֲשָׂה חָתָן אֵצֶל דּוֹדוֹ הרה"ק ר' נָחוּם בֶּערְ'נְיוּ זי"ע, שֶׁלִּכְבוֹדוֹ שֶׁל אָחִיו נָתְנוּ אַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִאשׁוֹן זי"ע לָשֶׁבֶת שָׁם שְׁנָתַיִם יָמִים. וּמִכָּךְ שֶׁאַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִאשׁוֹן זי"ע אָמַר שֶׁשּׁוֹלְחוֹ לְרוּסְלַאנְד, הֵבִין הָרַבִּי מִשְּׁפִּיקוֹב זי"ע שֶׁבַּחֲתֻנָּתוֹ כְּבָר לֹא יִהְיֶה אַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִאשׁוֹן בְּהַאי עָלְמָא, וְלָכֵן נִתְעַלֵּף מִגֹּדֶל הַצַּעַר.
עַל כָּל פָּנִים הַגְדָּרָתוֹ שֶׁל מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִאשׁוֹן רַבִּי יִצְחָק [מִבָּאהוּשׁ] זי"ע עָלָיו הָיְתָה, שֶׁהוּא שׁוֹלֵחַ חָכָם לְרוּסְלַאנְד.
עוֹד סִפֵּר מָרָן זְקִינִי אַדְמוֹ"ר זי"ע, מִגֹּדֶל הִתְקַשְּׁרוּתוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו הָרַבִּי מִשְּׁפִּיקוֹב זי"ע אֶל זְקָנוֹ מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר הָרִאשׁוֹן [מִבָּאהוּשׁ] זי"ע שֶׁלְּמַעֲשֶׂה הוּא גִּדְּלוֹ, שֶׁלֹּא עָבַר יוֹם אֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא שׂוֹחַח מִזְּקָנוֹ הַקּ'.
זְקִינִי מָרָן אַדְמוֹ"ר זי"ע סִפֵּר שֶׁבְּעֵת הַלְוָיָתוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו הַקּ' אֲשֶׁר הָיְתָה בְּפוּרִים, צָעֲקוּ הָאֲנָשִׁים הַמְּלַוִּים "דּוֹרֵשׁ טוֹב לְעַמּוֹ" (אֶסְתֵּר י', ג'). וְלִכְאוֹרָה כַּוָּנַת הָרַבִּי זי"ע בְּסַפְּרוֹ זֹאת לוֹמַר דְּהַנַּח לָהֶם לְיִשְׂרָאֵל אִם לֹא נְבִיאִים הֵם בְּנֵי נְבִיאִים הֵם (ילקו"ש בְּהַעֲלֹתְךָ רֶמֶז תשיט), וְכַנִּרְאֶה שֶׁזּוֹ הָיְתָה בְּחִינָתוֹ שֶׁל בַּעַל הַהִילּוּלָא הָרַבִּי מִשְּׁפִּיקוֹב זי"ע.כ"ק מרן אדמו"ר מבוהוש שליט"אפורים קטן - י"ד אדר-א' תשע"א"אמרי קודש", אדר תשע"א, עמ' א'

Maran my grandfather, the Admor zy"a, told that one of the elder Tzaddikim of his generation was the Holy Rabbi R' Dovid'l of Skver zy"a, who was one of the famous Tzaddikim of the House of Chernobyl in Russia. When people would come to him with difficult *Kvitelach* (petitions), he would say that he no longer has the strength for this, and if they wish to merit good advice, "Go to Shpikov [and he would mention the holy name of our master] (the Holy Rabbi Shalom Yosef zy"a); there you will find good advice."
Source: Amrei Kodesh

**Biography**
The Admor Rabbi Moshe Mordechai (Morgenstern) of Pilov was born in the year 5619 (1859) in Kotzk, to his father Rabbi Chaim Yisrael, the Admor of Pilov—the fourth generation to the Holy Grandfather, Rabbi Menachem Mendel of Kotzk.
Rabbi Moshe Mordechai was a unique and sublimely wondrous personality. He was gifted with all the virtues of holiness, and all those who came to Kotzk, and later to Pilov, related to him with great admiration, seeing in him the symbol of sublime fear, greatness, and loftiness.
Already from his youth, Rabbi Moshe Mordechai knew nothing but the four cubits of Halacha. Day and night, he sat over the Torah and the service in his room in his father's courtyard, and his hand did not move from his father's hand zt"l. Even after his marriage to the daughter of the Rav of Melbertov, the righteous Rebbetzin Chava z"l, he returned quickly to his father's courtyard and continued to be diligent in Torah.
By nature, he was silent. He spoke little even with the Chassidim who flocked by the thousands for Shabbos and Holidays to his father, the Admor of Pilov. He was careful even regarding idle chatter of Torah scholars, so as not to waste his time dedicated entirely to Torah study.
Chassidim tell: When Rabbi Moshe'le sat in his room to study Torah, he would forget the whole world and everything in it. He would not move from his room for a whole summer day without feeling at all that the day had passed over him. To such an extent did his diligence in Torah study reach.
His knowledge and expertise in Torah were endless. Thanks to his wondrous memory, he acquired tremendous expertise in all the chambers of the Torah, both revealed and hidden. It is told that the author of the *Avnei Nezer* zt"l said of him that he is in the category of a "Holy Ark of Books."
His method of study was the Kotzk style—depth and sharp profundity. Mainly clarifying the Halacha for practical application, alongside constant striving to reach the truth of the logic...
He never tried to stand out with his greatness in Torah. On the contrary, he always strove to hide himself more and more, lest his greatness be revealed. He served as an example to other men of stature who walked in the ways of fear, behind which there is nothing but toil in Torah, love of the Creator, and love of truth.
With the passing of his father, Rabbi Yisrael of Pilov, he was crowned as Admor together with his two brothers—Rabbi Tzvi, whose place of residence was in Lukov near Kotzk, and Rabbi Yitzchak Zelig, who served then in the rabbinate in the city of Sokolov.
Rabbi Moshe Mordechai remained in his father's courtyard zt"l and continued the leadership in Pilov. He attracted many young students, as well as householders who were Torah scholars, whose faith in him was boundless.
His third brother, Rabbi Yossele, who became famous for his scholarship, his good nature, and his love of Israel, did not agree under any circumstances to accept leadership, although many Chassidim pressed him to be their Admor. He accepted upon himself the authority of his brother Rabbi Moshe Mordechai and took shelter in his shadow.
Rabbi Moshe Mordechai's influence on his Chassidim was immense, and every utterance that came out of his mouth would send a tremor of excitement through their bodies. Every output of his mouth was holy to them.
He was firm in his opinion and showed favoritism to no man. He was interested in everything happening and occurring with his Chassidim. Sometimes, when there was a need to remark or rebuke one of the Chassidim, he would invite him to him and speak with him softly, and at times harshly. Mainly, he insisted that an atmosphere of Torah and fear of Heaven should prevail in the home, and that the children be given a Chareidi and Chassidic education.
His words of ethics and rebuke were accepted with love and bore fruit. Everyone felt in them the fatherly love, the sincerity rooted in true Kotzk, and the aspiration for elevation, integrity, and justice.
In all his days, he did not agree to accept upon himself a rabbinical position. He saw in this position such a great and sublime responsibility that he refused to accept it upon himself. Aside from this, by nature, he was inclined more to private life than to public activity. He always preferred to remain in the shadows rather than appear in public. His main purpose in this was not to disturb his diligence and toil in Torah.
During the days of the First World War, in the year 5675 (1915), the Jews were forced to flee from Pilov due to the troops of the Russian Czar. Rabbi Moshe Mordechai moved to live in Warsaw. His uncle R' Raphael Tuchman z"l, son-in-law of the middle Admor Rabbi Dovid of Kotzk, allocated him an apartment in his large house on Nalewki Street. In that same house was also the large Shtiebel of the Admor of Pilov.
Although he was already weak in body, he would go down morning and evening from his apartment to the Shtiebel to pray with the congregation, and he was particular that his Chassidim should also come to the Shtiebel to pray with the congregation and to say ten chapters of Psalms between Mincha and Maariv...
In those days, there were many Chassidim who had lost their assets due to the war, coming to him and pouring out their hearts before him. With an aching heart, he would encourage them and promise them that salvation would surely come soon. However, he did not suffice with this, but acted and activated those with influence and ability to help them to the best of their ability. And with all his diligence and engagement day and night in Torah and service of the Creator, he stood guard and urged his people to fulfill the mission and transfer aid to the needy in a hidden manner, with dignity.
At the end of the First World War, he did not return to Pilov, for all his property there had gone up in flames. He established his residence in Warsaw, on Muranowska Street, in a larger and more suitable apartment.
A significant number of young men and Avreichim from his Chassidim and others concentrated in his special Beis Medrash in his apartment, and the voice of Torah would burst forth from his house until a late hour at night. Several times a day, the Admor would leave his room and enter his Beis Medrash. He knew exactly what the young men were studying and how they were studying. He would ask a question, say a Chiddush, and demand from the students that they think about it and tell him their opinion the next day. Thus, he left them room for thought, delving, and deepening, and the more they knew afterwards to answer with logic and aim for the truth, the more his joy grew.
If he saw one of the young men who needed help and support in a financial sense, he did not rest or stay quiet until the required help was given. Mainly, he insisted that the young men be dressed with dignity, for this is also the honor of the Torah.
His conversations in Torah at his table on Shabbos and Holidays were flames of fire hewn and penetrating the hearts of the listeners. Everyone felt that the Shechinah was speaking from his throat. The masses of Chassidim who flocked to him on Shabbos and Holidays were mostly Torah scholars, and they stood trembling and drinking his words with thirst.
His words of Torah were interwoven with words of the early and later sages, without Yerushalmi, and everything to conclude the Halacha. And in the style of the Grandfather, the Holy One of Kotzk, his sayings also aroused delving and engagement with independent opinion and spiritual elevation.
It was customary among the Chassidim that after the Tisch ended, the students would gather by his brother Rabbi Yossele, and he would explain and clarify the difficult matters in the Torah of Rabbi Moshe Mordechai. Everyone felt as if the Admor intended his Torah for him and that it was upon him to correct himself.
Rabbi Moshe Mordechai was not active in a political framework, but he followed with alertness everything happening and occurring in Jewish life and would react to every event with measured words, through which the Chassidim knew to stand on his opinion and intention.
His attitude towards immigration to Eretz Yisrael was positive. He would speak with admiration about the immigrants, the Chassidim to Eretz Yisrael, and those settling there.
In his last years, his various illnesses weighed heavily upon him, and at times frequently, he was confined to his bed. Nevertheless, he exerted himself on his bed and would receive from time to time the Chassidim who came to see him and ask his advice. They would wait for days upon days and would not return to their homes until they were received by the Admor. It should be noted that all of them, as one, did not take any important step in their private lives without receiving the Admor's consent in advance.
In the year 5689 (1929), his illness intensified, and he suffered severe pains, but his spirit was not broken, and he continued to follow everything and react to every event. Even then, he invited the young men studying in his Beis Medrash to him and conducted conversations with them, and upon their leaving the Admor, they felt within themselves a sort of "additional soul," a renewal of spirituality.
The illness reached its peak in the month of Adar 5689. Since the Chassidim heard about the difficult situation, each one left his daily affairs, and everyone followed with deep anxiety the condition of the Admor. I was shocked to the depths of my soul when I saw Kotzker Chassidim weeping with copious tears.
On the night of Purim, the night of the 14th of Adar, the situation worsened greatly. The house was full of Chassidim from wall to wall. The Admor commanded to read the Megillah. After the reading of the Megillah, he commanded the Chassidic singer, the famous R' Elazar Yitzchak Verman (now in Israel), to sing "Shoshanas Yaakov" with a new tune. And when he finished the singing, he commanded him to repeat it a second time. And a few moments later, his soul ascended to Heaven.
At his funeral, masses of Chassidim participated who came from near and far, as well as all circles of Chareidi Jewry in Warsaw, headed by Rabbis and Admors. He was brought to burial in the cemetery in Warsaw. It should be noted that the Ohel erected over his grave survived the Holocaust and still stands today.
As his successor, his younger brother Rabbi Yossele was crowned, the Rav of Kotzk, who conducted the leadership in the city of his ancestors, Kotzk, for nine years, since Rabbi Moshe Mordechai left no sons behind him.
Although it was not customary in Kotzk to print books of the Torah of the Admors, nevertheless, the writings of Rabbi Moshe Mordechai on the Torah appeared in print. After his passing, all his manuscripts were collected and printed together in the book *Midrash Moshe*, through the efforts and publication of the Chassidim—R' Moshe Shlinitzky (now in Israel) and the Chassid R' Shmuel Yaakov Zilberstein from Warsaw, and R' Dovid Reizman from Lodz. [And in the year 5767, the *Midrash Moshe* was published in a magnificent edition in 3 volumes].
Source: Heichal Kotzk
